title: Sex Guide Is Recalled For Correction of Text
description: Because of what it termed ''a serious error,'' Warner Books is recalling its first printing of 115,000 copies of ''First Love: A Young People's Guide to Sexual Information,'' a paperback book by Dr. Ruth Westheimer and Dr. Nathan Kravetz.

title: A WOODEN VESSEL FOR PROOFING BREAD
description: NOTHING is as soul-warming this time of year as the aroma of baking bread. The once-intimidating task of preparing yeast bread has been made less risky with improved strains of yeasts and the advent of food processors and mixers with dough hooks, which eliminate hand-kneading in some recipes. If there is still a pitfall in making yeast breads, however, it is in the method of proofing.

title: RICKY NELSON AND SIX OTHERS DIE AS THEIR PLANE CRASHES IN TEXAS
description: Ricky Nelson, who gained childhood fame on his parents' radio and television programs and went on to became one of rock-and-roll's earliest teen-age idols, was killed today along with his fiancee and five other people when his DC-3 plane crashed in flames near De Kalb, Tex.

title: Yacht Mishap Injures 1
description: In choppy seas and high winds off the coast of Australia this week, the American racing yacht Courageous suffered a broken mast but no serious injuries to the crew other than to the winchman, Robert Anderson. He suffered a gashed forehead that needed stitches.

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,670,397 for the quarter and year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $50,222. d-After net from discontinued operations of $337,641. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of $322,883.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CHIEF SIFTS BUYOUT BIDS AT RIVAL MANUFACTURING
description: I. H. (Hack) Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Rival Manufacturing Company, has been in the housewares business a long, long time.

title: MICHIGAN HAS A GOAL
description: Bo Schembechler says he is faced with a no-win situation in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl Wednesday when his Michigan Wolverines play Nebraska.

title: AT INAUGURAL, A TASTE OF OLD NEW YORK
description: THIS morning, while most New Yorkers are still in bed after a night of celebrating the future, Richard Ferrugio and 50 employees will busily re-create the past.

title: Blunder by Velasquez
description: Jorge Velasquez misjudged the finish of the Display Handicap yesterday, pulling up Southern Sultan, the second choice, after crossing the line as the leader with a mile to be run in the two-and-a-quarter-mile race. His mount went on to finish a badly beaten sixth in the field of nine.

title: SIGNAL METHANOL
description: Signal Methanol Inc. has signed a financing agreement with a group of international lenders to build a $300 million plant to produce methanol from natural gas in Chile, the company said. Signal previously entered into a 20-year agreement with Empressa National del Petroleo, the national oil company of Chile, to buy natural gas as feedstock for the plant. Signal Methanol is now a unit of Allied Signal Inc., but it will become part of the Henley Group Inc. when that company is spun off in 1986.

title: JAZZ: PUENTE AND SANTAMARIA
description: Two Latin percussionist-bandleaders took their jazz ensembles to the Village Gate last weekend - groups that move beyond the simple harmonies of salsa vamps, but that keep sizzling Latin syncopations close to the surface. The musicians seem happy to break away from dance music; for listeners, however, the most fiery performances are often the up-tempo dance tunes.

title: N. Carolina Sets 100-Point Record
description: Brad Daugherty, a senior guard, scored 19 points and North Carolina posted a record fourth straight 100-point game to beat Florida State, 109-64, in college basketball tonight.

title: REID-ASHMAN INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
ACORN FUND reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: CANDIED PEEL: LITTLE EFFORT, BIG REWARD
description: CANDIED peel is a confection with a split personality, delicious when nibbled straight yet best known and most used as the ingredient that says ''holiday time'' in a panoply of classic baked goods from fruitcake and plum pudding to stollen, panettone and Twelfth Night cake. Unfortunately, modern processing has turned candied peel into a tough, tasteless, useless embellishment. A few discerning food-lovers have concluded it is a Victorian relic that blights rather than enhances the seasonal goodies that would nevertheless be inconceivable without it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Home Group, which is a property and casualty underwriter company, appointed William J. McMorrow executive vice president and chief executive of its Home Group Financial Services subsidiary.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. TRADE DEFICIT FOR 11 MONTHS TOPS RECORD FOR YEAR SET IN 1984
description: The nation's trade deficit surged to $13.68 billion in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HNG/INTERNORTH WITHDRAWS NOTES
description: A proposed $200 million offering of 9 3/4 percent notes due 1992 has been withdrawn by HNG/Internorth Inc., following the nationalization last Friday of its Belco Petroleum unit by the Peruvian Government.

title: SUPPORTERS FEAR UNDERMINING OF BUDGET LAW
description: A successful constitutional challenge to the automatic spending cuts in the new law aimed at balancing the Federal budget would undermine the effect of the landmark legislation, supporters generally agree. Others go even further, saying a successful challenge would render the law pointless.

title: BELCO'S FOUNDERS FAMILIAR WITH PERU
description: The threat had existed for months, but Peru's announcement last Friday that it intended to nationalize operations owned by the Belco Petroleum Corporation, a unit of HNG/Internorth Inc., still came as a shock to many in the investment community.

title: CONDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $2.8 million on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Resources Corp., said it had completed its previously announced plans to buy 90.9 percent of High Plains Oil Corp. for oil and gas properties and a gas processing plant valued at $100 million.

title: EX-CHAIRMAN OF N.H.L. BOARD
description: Bruce A. Norris, former president and owner of the Detroit Red Wings and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died today at age 61, a league spokesman said.

title: ULSTER MARCHERS PROTEST ACCORD
description: The leaders of the largest Protestant paramilitary organization in Northern Ireland, who until now have distanced themselves from unionist politicians, joined them today at the start of a march across Northern Ireland to protest the agreement last month that gave the Irish Republic a say in their affairs.

title: POLICE ILLEGELLY SPIED ON DISSIDENTS IN CHICAGO, FEDERAL JUDGE RULES
description: A Police Department squad that monitored dissident groups and individuals in the 1960's and 1970's illegally spied on two groups and an activist, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: A TROUBLED PROFESSION
description: THE economists who gathered in New York for the annual meetings of the American Economic Association between Christmas and New Year were in a troubled mood about the state of their discipline, about their fall in public esteem and loss of influence in business and government. But, while acknowledging that some of the fault was their own, many found the charges against their profession overdrawn and unbalanced.

title: AGGIES ARE CAPABLE OF STOPPING JACKSON
description: When Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn, met Johnny Holland, the 6-foot-3-inch all-America linebacker from Texas A&M, in New York earlier this month, he asked him if the reports he had heard about the Aggies' defense were true. Did they really play dirty? ''He said it jokingly, so we just kinda blew it off,'' Holland said. ''We haven't talked much about it since.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A HISTORICAL DOCUMENT A number of traditions persevere on the first day of January. One is the resolutions business. Another is open houses and friendly visits - social calling, as the expression goes. And the Old Merchants House (777-1089) is one where the open-house custom prevails. This landmark house-museum offers visitors mulled wine and other refreshments from 1 to 6 P.M. today.

title: New Powers to Detect The Disco Beat
description: At a year-end bill signing, normally a drab City Hall ritual, one new bill was toasted with New York State sparkling wine.

title: LATE SNAG HITS ICAHN'S T.W.A. BID
description: Carl C. Icahn has run into last-minute difficulties with the machinists' union, which makes it uncertain that he can take over Trans World Airlines by today, when union concessions are supposed to take effect.

title: President of Haiti Shakes Up Cabinet
description: President Jean-Claude Duvalier reorganized his Government today, bringing home his Ambassador to Washington to join the Cabinet and sending four powerful ministers abroad as envoys.

title: Chevron Head Has Retired
description: John R. Grey, the president of the Chevron Corporation, has taken early retirement for health reasons, effective today, the company said today. The company did not elaborate, but Mr. Grey, who is 63 years old, is said to be seriously ill.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:36 A.M. today and set at 9:24 P.M. tonight.

title: ASSAD-HUSSEIN TALKS END WITHOUT A FINAL STATEMENT
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and King Hussein of Jordan ended a two-day meeting here today, their first encounter in six years, but issued no statements on the results.

title: BEARS CONCENRATE ON GROUND GAME
description: With Chicago as cold as usual for this time of year, the Bears set up camp here today at the Atlanta Falcons' training complex to begin preparations for their National Conference playoff game Sunday against the Giants.

title: CARBIDE'S OFFER INSPIRES HEAVY WALL ST. SELLING
description: Wall Street professionals were big sellers as stockholders of the Union Carbide Corporation tendered shares last night to the big chemical company for an $85 package of cash and securities.

title: One Way 'Star Wars' Can Make Things Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: FREDERICK C. FISCHER, EX-LABOR CONSULTANT
description: Frederick C. Fischer, a former labor-relations consultant with the United States Department of Labor, died of cancer last Friday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport. He was 80 years old and lived in Peconic, L.I.

title: REPUTED MILWAUKEE CRIME FIGURE PLEADS GUILTY IN KANSAS CITY TRIAL
description: Frank P. Balistrieri, the reputed leader of organized crime in Milwaukee, pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and racketeering and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.

title: GIANTS TAKE PLACE IN PLAYOFFS IN STRIDE
description: In years past, the Giants might have felt fortunate to make the playoffs and win a wild-card game, as they have done this year. The Giants who will play the Bears Sunday in Chicago appear to feel neither fortunate nor honored nor out of place.

title: TV: 'HAPPY NEW YEAR, CHARLIE BROWN!,' ON CBS
description: There is absolutely no reason to watch ''Happy New Year, Charlie Brown!'' except that it's graceful, pleasant and unassuming, and everything the animated cartoons that clank, screech, bellow and turn into ugly toys at Christmas are not. It will be seen on CBS at 8:30 tonight.

title: The Once and Future Candidate
description: Meg Greenfield of The Washington Post once described her generation as having spent its adulthood through 1972 deciding whether to vote for or against Richard Nixon. A slightly later generation can say something similar about Edward Kennedy. He has not run for President in every campaign since 1968 but he has invariably cast a shadow as a potential candidate. His withdrawal from contention in 1988 ratifies the current direction of American politics.

title: SEARCHER CHARGED WITH KIDNAPPING
description: A textile worker was arrested today and charged with kidnapping two 12-year-old girls who turned up Monday after being missing for about a week.

title: PILOT HIRING SURGES AT AIRLINES
description: Embarked on one of their biggest expansions ever, the nation's 14 major airlines are hiring pilots at a furious pace, a record 8,000 in 1985 alone. The dramatic increase in demand, spurred in large part by union concessions on starting salaries, has led to radical changes at airlines of all sizes in the way pilots are hired and trained.

title: SCREEN: INDIANS OF BRAZIL
description: ''Raoni,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a sobering, sympathetic, technically expert documentary on the complex issues surrounding the survival of the indigenous Indian tribes of north central Brazil. It's a story that is still being written. After this film was completed in 1979, angry Indians massacred workers commissioned to clear jungle lands considered by the Indians to be their own.

title: 1985 Player of the Year Title Narrowly Taken by Solodar
description: The race for 1985 New York Player-of-the-Year honors came down to the wire at the Winter Regionals of the Greater New York Bridge Association 10 days ago, and the title went to John Solodar.

title: 2 Packer Aides Quit
description: One day after Bob Schnelker was dismissed as offensive co-ordinator, the Green Bay Packers lost two members of their defensive coaching staff, Herb Paterra and Ken Riley, who are taking other coaching jobs. Paterra, who had been coaching the Green Bay linebackers, left to become defensive co-ordinator of the Buffalo Bills.

title: Soviet Woman's Lover Held in Malibu Death
description: A Soviet defector was arrested today as a suspect in the killing of his lover, a Soviet defector who testified briefly in the spying trial of a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: SEVERAL FACTORS CITED AS PETROLEUM WEAKENS
description: Milder weather, lower Mexican oil prices and concerns about supplies caused petroleum futures prices to slip yesterday on the Mercantile Exchange in New York. Trading was light in a session chopped to a half-day because of New Year's Eve.

title: Jane E. Clark Marries Robert Lee Banse Jr.
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church on Hilton Head Island, S.C., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jane Edmonds Clark, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Holland Ball Clark of Hilton Head Island, to Robert Lee Banse Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Banse of Lawrenceville, N.J. The bride's father, the rector of St. Luke's, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz.

title: SOVIET TEAM TROUNCES CANADIENS
description: Sergei Makarov scored three goals to lead the Central Red Army Team, the Soviet Union's league champion, to a 6-1 victory tonight over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Robert La Fosse Leaves Ballet Theater
description: Robert La Fosse, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, has requested and has been granted a release from his contract for the 1985-86 season, Ballet Theater has announced.

title: Rezoning Will Increase East Side Congestion
description: To the Editor:

title: TOM WAITS HEADS LIST OF YEAR'S TOP ALBUMS
description: In 1985 pop musicians of almost every style and stripe banded together in all-star recording sessions and marathon concerts and asked audiences numbered collectively in the billions to help feed the world's starving, shelter the homeless and fight racial discrimination. These were unparalleled events in the history of popular music, and journalists rightly gave them comprehensive coverage. But it is the business of the music critic to listen to music, to feel it emotionally and appreciate it intellectually and, finally, to impart some opinion as to its musical worth.

title: JAZZ: THE JONAH JONES QUINTET
description: It was more than 30 years ago that Jonah Jones hit on the combination of muted trumpet, catchy shuffle rhythm and familiar melodies that made his quintet one of the great successes of the 1950's. The combination has continued to work successfully for Mr. Jones, but after three decades even a successful formula can stand a little variation.

title: 5 Hurt in Rome Raid Fly Home to the U.S.
description: An elderly California woman and four Illinois children who were wounded in the terrorist raid on Rome Airport flew to the United States today. Four other Americans are still hospitalized.

title: Veeck in Hospital
description: Bill Veeck, the former baseball owner, was reported to be in good condition in Illinois Masonic Medical Center in Chicago, where he was admitted Monday after doctors decided to administer respiratory therapy when Veeck had shortness of breath for several days.

title: Title Fight for Johnson
description: Marvin Johnson is scheduled to fight undefeated Leslie Steward of Trinidad for the vacant World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title Feb. 9 at Market Square Arena in Indianapolis, according to the director of boxing for the arena, Marty Waigand. He said that contracts were expected to be completed this week.

title: PRIMO INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CABARET: 'BLACK MAX'
description: Desperate oddball characters inhabit the 12 cabaret songs by the composer William Bolcom and the poet and playwright Arnold Weinstein that have been collected under the title ''Black Max.''

title: FARMERS' PRICES UP LAST MONTH
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third consecutive increase for the monthly index, but still ended 1985 with a 5.2 percent decline from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Colombia Will Make Buried Town a Park
description: The Colombian town of Armero, devastated by a volcanic eruption last month, has been declared a national monument and will be converted into a national park, the Government said today.

title: EX-AIDE TELLS OF ORDERS TO BE SILENT
description: A recently dismissed city personnel official said yesterday that two Koch administration officials had told her not to testify before a state hearing on entrance standards for the Police Department.

title: NEW TERRORISTS: 'KIDS WHO ARE TRAINED TO GO OUT AND KILL'
description: The attacks mounted by Palestinian terrorists on the Rome and Vienna airports bear a new brand of terrorism that European security officials say poses severe new challenges.

title: Playing Time
description: It's gotten so that Bill Wennington can't find a game anywhere. Wennington, the 7-foot center who helped take St. John's to the Final Four last season, returned to Alumni Hall the other day for his first visit since being drafted by the Dallas Mavericks last spring.

title: Mayor Says Some Homeless Get to Raise New Year Toasts
description: An off-the-cuff remark by Mayor Koch became a reality yesterday when the Mayor announced that some homeless people living in shelters would be treated to a glass of wine to celebrate the New Year. He said Vintage magazine had donated 18 cases of wine.

title: Arts May Find a Home In Custom House
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE-MAN DYNASTY
description: Long before Red Auerbach lit up his first championship cigar, Harry Hopman was winning Davis Cups for Australia. Long before Vince Lombardi goaded his players to run to daylight, Harry Hopman had his players out running in the hot Australian sun.

title: A CHRISTIAN LEADER SURVIVES AMBUSH IN LEBANON
description: A senior Christian leader who had helped negotiate a cease-fire among Lebanon's warring militias narrowly escaped an assassination attempt today.

title: KAISER, OTHERS PLAN '85 CHARGES
description: Reflecting the problems of the nation's heavy industries, four corporations announced separately yesterday that they would take sizable charges against earnings before closing the books on 1985. The four corporations are Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical, Ideal Basic Industries, Halliburton and Lone Star Steel.

title: JAPAN NEW YEAR'S: GREAT DAY FOR BIG MAILBOX
description: On New Year's Day in Japan, the postman only rings once. That is more than enough, many people feel.

title: Seiberling Says He Plans To Retire From House
description: Representative John F. Seiberling of Ohio, an environmental crusader in eight terms in the House, said today that he did not plan to seek re-election in 1986 but would consider running if the Democratic Party could not find a strong replacement.

title: U.S. STEEL SELLS 2 ASSETS TO KAISER
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it had sold the Somerset Coal Mine near Paonia, Colo., and a coal preparation plant in Wellington, Utah, to the Kaiser Steel Corporation.

title: Perfectibility
description: Once a year, in the season when spirits and the sun are at their lowest, nature presents us with a clean slate. So what if the previous 12 months were studded with sins, nonfeasance and miscalculations. On Jan. 1 we get to start all over again, and this time to do it right.

title: HOSTAGE-HOLDERS MAKE NEW THREAT
description: An underground Moslem fundamentalist group claiming to hold four Americans hostage threatened today to take further action against Americans and Israelis.

title: AMERICAN ADVENTURE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in July 1985.

title: CITY'S PARKING RULES FOR HOLIDAYS IN 1986
description: The City Transportation Department has issued its list of parking-rule changes for 1986. Alternate-side parking will be suspended on the following days:

title: LIBYA SAID TO INSTALL MISSILES
description: The Egyptian Government-owned newspaper Al Ahram said today that Libya had completed construction of seven bases for Soviet-supplied antiaircraft missiles.

title: ALL OVER CITY, TRANSIT FARE TRANSITIONS MADE of
description: At 25 bus depots throughout New York City, Transit Authority employees yesterday pasted the last of 7,500 decals on fare boxes in the city's fleet of 4,000 buses. ''Exact Fare. No Dollar Bills. Local Bus $1.00,'' they read.

title: TEXT OF STATE DEPT. REPORT ON ABU NIDAL GROUP
description: Following is the text of a report on the Abu Nidal group issued today by the State Department: Introduction The Abu Nidal group is among the most dangerous of the Middle Eastern terrorist organizations. It is probably the best organized and most effective of the radical Palestinian terrorist groups, carefully planning its operations and keeping its information tightly compartmented.

title: THE KEY TO RESOLUTIONS IS A WILLINGNESS TO CHANGE
description: About 70 percent of Americans who make New Year's resolutions ''are not really ready to change'' and will break their pledges by the end of January, according to a university researcher. John Norcross, a professor of psychology at the University of Scranton who has studied self-change for 10 years, said making no resolution at all may be better than making one you do not seriously intend to keep.

title: WILLIAMS PREPARING FOR FREEDOM
description: Every weekday morning since Nov. 4, former United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. has left a brownstone and red-brick building in a rejuvenated area around Lincoln Park here and gone to his job as a legislative analyst for the New Jersey Building and Construction Trades Council.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DOW DIPS AT END OF A STELLAR YEAR
description: Wall Street concluded the second-best year in its history and its finest performance in a decade yesterday with a not-so-stunning session that saw blue-chip stocks decline slightly but secondary issues rise.

title: CUOMO GRANTS CLEMENCY TO MAN SERVING LIFE FOR DEPUTY'S SLAYING
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday granted clemency to a Bronx man serving a prison sentence of 25 years to life for the 1968 murder of a deputy sheriff.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: The Constitution Calls for Gold and Silver
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of the Times; Fears and Phobias
description: ANXIETY. By Donald W. Goodwin, M. D. 234 pages. Oxford University Press. $17.95. ''No Grand Inquisitor has in readiness such terrible tortures as has anxiety,'' wrote Soren Kierkegaard in ''The Concept of Dread,'' ''and no spy knows how to attack more artfully the man he suspects, choosing the instant when he is weakest, nor knows how to lay traps where he will be caught and ensnared, as anxiety knows how, and no sharpwitted judge knows how to interrogate, to examine the accused, as anxiety does, which never lets him escape, neither by diversion nor by noise, neither at work nor at play, neither by day nor by night.''

title: Ticket to Success
description: The losing coach in the Georgia Southern-Furman matchup was Dick Sheridan, who has now moved up to I-A. Hired away by North Carolina State only two days ago, Sheridan already has a clear understanding of his new employer's priorities. ''I don't have the keys to my office yet,'' he says, ''but I've already got my season basketball tickets.''

title: Daily Doses of American History
description: More than a million Americans will be able to track the days of the new year with a copy of the ''We the People'' calendar. And they have Fred Schwengel, for one, to thank for it.

title: NOVEMBER NEW HOME SALES UP 7.7%
description: Sales of new homes, after falling for three consecutive months, climbed by 7.7 percent in November, the biggest advance in more than a year, the Government reported today.

title: BEATRICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After nets from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $22 million for the 9 months and after-tax losses of $3 million and $4 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for business realignment. c-Includes after-tax gains of $39 million, or 43 cents a share, for the quarter and $43 million for the 9 months from the divestiture of businesses. d-After net from discontinued operations of $8 million; includes a non-taxable gain of $19 million for a debt swap and a $17 million reduction for the reversal of deferred taxes on DISC earnings. On Oct. 1, Beatrice announced its intention to sell its Avis, Jensen, Danskin & Pennaco businesses, which are being accounted for as discontinued operations.

title: MEMORIAL GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Many people this holiday season are contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the name or memory of loved ones.

title: Salvador Guerrillas Tell Of Killing a Mayor
description: El Salvador's leftist guerrillas said today that they had killed a mayor and several municipal officials for crimes against the people and vowed to begin a campaign to put common criminals to death.

title: A DAZZLING EIFFEL TOWER GREETS '86
description: As 1985 came to a cold and misty end here on Tuesday night, four thin streams of blue-green laser light could be seen racing across the skies to converge at the top of the Eiffel Tower, like ropes tethering the neck of some fantastic giraffe.

title: NO. 1 PENN STATE DEFENDING ITS POSITION
description: Despite the clamor in some quarters for a freedom of choice in the polling process that selects a national college football champion, the teams from Penn State and Oklahoma would prefer to think they have become contestants in a closed election.

title: RICHARDSON HAS RELAPSE
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the talented Nets playmaker with a troubled drug past, has had a relapse.

title: CROWNAMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STATE DEPT. STUDY ON TERROR GROUP CITES LIBYAN LINK
description: The State Department issued a report today asserting that the Abu Nidal group, which is suspected of organizing the attacks last week at airports in Vienna and Rome, was ''among the most dangerous of the Middle Eastern terrorist organizations.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE place, during the holiday shopping rush, was the tie counter in the men's department of Lord & Taylor. There, on the counter, was a fiberglass head form displaying three bow ties. There, too, Jean Meyers witnessed the following between a customer and the two salesclerks who waited on her.

title: KOCH LOOKS TO '86 AND SEES A PROBLEM
description: It is on a serious note that Mayor Koch begins his third term today, with one eye on history and the other on Washington's planned budget cuts.

title: New Parents' Needs and Rights
description: The laws governing time off for pregnant mothers and new parents are woefully uneven throughout the United States. The search for new and fairer standards has now gained impetus from a bill under consideration in the House.

title: Letter: On Care of the Homeless; Looking Beyond Hotels and Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast Starters From Georgia
description: When Georgia Southern rallied from a 28-6 third-quarter deficit 11 days ago and beat Furman for college football's Division I-AA championship, 5,306 fans were witnesses at the Tacoma (Wash.) Dome. None of them were more astonished than the winning coach, Erk Russell, and not just because of the way the game had turned. After all, it was only four years ago that the school re-established a football program, and it was only two years ago that the Eagles were still playing on the club level.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not the enemy.'' - Vance C. Clark, head of the Farmers Home Administration, on resumption of foreclosures. [ 1:6. ]

title: Eagle to Cut 23 Employees
description: Eagle Computer Inc., which is struggling to raise capital to keep its operations afloat and bring its newest product, the Concorde, to market, said today that it would lay off 23 of its 83 employees as of Wednesday.

title: Classroom Monitoring, Covert and Overt
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BRIGHTENING THE MORNING AFTER: COUNT THE WAYS
description: FOR most people, the annual orgy of eating and drinking that began with Thanksgiving and sailed merrily through Christmas, rose to a crescendo of intensity sometime in the wee hours this morning. Though there are some dauntless souls who will stagger through yet another day of what they, at least, can still call fun, for the rest of us, the party is over. The national digestive tract is sour and the collective head aches. A restorative, clearly, is in order. ''Pure oxygen is the best cure for a hangover,'' says David Outerbridge, editor of the Belfast, Me., ''Republican Journal'' and author of ''The Hangover Handbook'' (Harmony Books, 1982). ''Kingsley Amis suggests vigorous sex, and the ancient Romans were partial to screech owl eggs.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1986
description: The Economy

title: DECONTROL AIDED EMPIRE AIR
description: In its first year in the air, Empire Airlines carried 381 passengers in its two single-engine planes. Last month, just 10 years later, the Department of Transportation gave tentative approval for the commuter airline to be acquired for $41.6 million by Piedmont Airlines.

title: CHEVRON ARRANGES BIG CREDIT FACILITY
description: The Chevron Corporation has arranged a $2.975 billion, three-year revolving credit facility, through a group led by BankAmerica Capital Markets, banking sources said.

title: Tax Plan's '10 Percent Rule' Hampers Municipalities
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Ways to Transform '86 Into a Golden Age
description: Never having been much good at keeping resolutions, I'm wary of promises and sermons. I'd rather make lists of unlikely recommendations, which, with any luck, might persuade practical people to figure a way around the habits of the old year and into speculations on the new.

title: Toledo Abortion Clinic Damaged in Arson Fire
description: An arson fire damaged an abortion clinic early today, a day after two clinics in Cincinnati were set afire and 12 hours after a bomb threat emptied another clinic here, the authorities said.

title: WINNIE MANDELA FREED ON BAIL AFTER SECOND ARRERST IN SOWETO
description: Winnie Mandela, one of South Africa's most prominent black anti-apartheid campaigners, was freed on bail today after being arrested for defying a Government order forbidding her to visit Soweto.

title: Author, Author
description: One of the trappings of a serious political campaign these days is a book by the candidate, timed for publication about three months before the election. In the old days, this was often a laudatory biography of the candidate, but currently a lively volume on a contemporary problem is regarded as more productive politically and less obvious.

title: ARTHUR HARTOG
description: Arthur Hartog, a former vice chairman of Unilever N.V., the Dutch and British conglomerate, died last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The United States Football League commissioner, Harry Usher, was released from St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., Monday, and his heart surgery was postponed for two weeks so that he could spend the rest of the holiday season at home in suburban Tarzana, a hospital spokesman said. Usher was admitted to the hospital Dec. 21 after complaining of chest pains. . . . The Portland Trail Blazers' general manager, Stu Inman, will be leaving the team, according to a report in The Oregonian. The newspaper said the Blazers were planning to announce tomorrow that Inman was stepping down ''to pursue other opportunities in the National Basketball Association.''

title: HOW TO STOP SMOKING, FIGHT WITHDRAWAL AND STILL END UP TRIMMER THAN YOU STARTED OUT
description: IS your conscience saying that quitting smoking should be one of your New Year's resolutions? At the same time, are you afraid to let go of cigarettes - the things that pick you up and calm you down perhaps 20 or more times a day? And are you afraid that, without cigarettes to relax you and keep your mouth and hands busy, you will eat until you blossom into a human version of the Goodyear blimp?

title: AGRICULTURE DEPT. TO ORDER FARMERS TO PAY LATE DEBT
description: The Farmers Home Administration today began preparing to notify thousands of farmers, who owe the Government nearly $6 billion, that they must bring their loan payments up to date or face foreclosure.

title: OCCIDENTAL SAID TO BID FOR MIDCON
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has made an offer to buy the Midcon Corporation, the natural gas pipeline company that is trying to evade a hostile takeover offer, a source close to Occidental said yesterday.

title: Photo of women sorting cucumbers at Domar; Photo of Bonifacio Sanchez-Crespo Villaverde in greenhouse with Jose Correa (NYT/Edward Schumacher) SPAIN'S FRONTIER FARMS MAKE ARID LAND BLOOM
description: When the Barcelona factory where he worked went bankrupt three years ago, Bonifacio Sanchez-Crespo Villaverde packed wife and kids in the car and headed for this corner in southern Spain billed as the California of Europe.

title: CULINARY AMERICA: FOOD FASCINATION SWEEPS THE NATION
description: IN major metropolitan areas throughout the United States, some of the most intriguing walks are through the well-decked halls of recently installed food emporiums. It is as though the past decade had given rise to extraordinary museums with edible works of art.

title: ISLANDERS SPOIL PARK'S DEBUT
description: The Islanders, trailing by two goals midway through the third period, rallied for a 5-4 victory in overtime over the Red Wings tonight in a game that marked Brad Park's debut as the Detroit coach.

title: Plato's Is Ordered To Close Again
description: The city yesterday obtained a temporary court order to close Plato's Retreat, a sex club for heterosexuals.

title: CLOTHES MANUFACTURER
description: David Schwartz, the founder of Jonathan Logan Inc., one of the country's largest producers of women's apparel, died on Saturday after a long illness at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and had another residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: FACING A DECLINE IN ITS GRAIN FIELDS, CHINA RETREATS ON POLICY
description: Faced with one of the sharpest drops in the size of the grain harvest in 36 years of Communist rule, China's reform-minded leaders have decided to adopt a more cautious policy next year that will defer further relaxation of the controls on peasant producers and seek to put grain yields back on a rising path.

title: ABU NIDAL: LIFE OF A P.L.O. RENEGADE
description: Abu Nidal, the renegade Palestinian leader suspected of having organized the Rome and Vienna airport massacres, is distinguished by two attributes, according to experts who have studied his life.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUT INTERBANK RATE TOPS 9%
description: A severe but largely technical credit squeeze enveloped the money market yesterday, causing interbank overnight funds to trade between 9 percent and 10.5 percent all day. Elsewhere, dealers reported minimal price changes on the last trading day of 1985.

title: Elizabeth P. McGowan Weds Guy Hedreen 2d
description: Elizabeth Perce McGowan, a doctoral candidate at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, and Guy Michael Hedreen 2d, a doctoral candidate in classical studies at Bryn Mawr College, both of whom are attending the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, were married yesterday. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: TOYOTA WILL RAISE U.S. PRICES BY 3%
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it would raise the suggested retail price of Toyota cars and trucks by an average of 3 percent because of the strength of the yen against the dollar.

title: ARMY'S AIR ATTACK STUNS ILLINI
description: Army, a team that seldom puts the football in the air, scored two unlikely touchdowns today on passes from its halfbacks, Bill Lampley and Clarence Jones, one in each half. Those scores were the key ones as the Cadets defeated Illinois, 31-29, in a Peach Bowl game played mostly in rain before a crowd of 29,857 at the 60,000-seat Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.

title: What Poets Do That Politicians Don't
description: Statesmen, ordinary officeholders and political pundits rarely consult poets or their work, except for an occasional misquotation or out-of-context citation intended as a rhetorical flourish. Churchill and Roosevelt quoted Longfellow across the seas in World War II; Yeats, for some reason, is the usual victim nowadays.

title: Iraq Says It's Increasing Raids on Iranians
description: Iraq said today that it had stepped up air attacks on Iran's oil operations and troop positions, with ''hundreds of raids'' against opposing forces in retaliation for what it said were Iranian raids on civilian areas.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN people ask whether it is proper to combine meats or poultry in the same dish without conflicts in flavor, I am amused. Such combinations occur in kitchens throughout the world. The classic example in French cuisine is chicken or veal Marengo. In the original recipe chicken is combined with tomatoes, olive oil, garlic and crayfish, among other things (like a fried egg on top). The Chinese are famous for combining meat or poultry with seafood; the Portuguese justifiably dote on cataplana, made with pork and clams, and in Spain, paella is almost a national dish, blending chicken, pork, clams and mussels.

title: Austrian Is First
description: Peter Wirnsberger of Austria, spurred on by a home crowd, captured his second straight men's downhill today and moved within a point of taking over the overall World Cup lead.

title: SARAH CONLAND
description: Sarah C. Conland, president and owner of The Catskill Daily Mail and The Greene County News since 1979, died Sunday at her home here.

title: AFGHAN INFORMALLY PRESENTS PLAN FOR WITHDRAWAL OF SOVIET TROOPS
description: The Afghan Government has informally presented a timetable for the withdrawal of all Soviet troops from Afghanistan within a one-year period as part of an overall accord, a senior State Department official said today.

title: AIR FORCE RUNNING TOPS TEXAS, 24-16
description: Pat Evans, showing no effects from an early-season knee injury, set up one touchdown with a 48-yard run and scored on a 19-yard run today to lead the Air Force to a 24-16 victory over Texas in the 27th Bluebonnet Bowl.

title: Aux ('To the') Barricades! ('Barricades!')
description: The war of the languages has begun, just where one would expect it to begin - in Paris. Americans now face a difficult decision: Should we prolong the conflict by fighting back?

title: Leafs Sign Defector
description: One of the best wings in Czechoslovak hockey, Miroslav Ihnacak, has defected and signed a multiyear contract to play for the Toronto Maple Leafs. But the Leafs said that the 23-year-old player was still in Vienna yesterday awaiting a permit from the Canadian Immigration Department.

title: INFINITE GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: HIGH CHINESE DEFECTOR IS LINKED TO SPY CHARGES AGAINST ANALYST
description: The espionage case against a retired Central Intelligence Agency analyst began in 1983 with a tip from a Chinese defector, Government sources said today.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLESSEY ACTION AGAINST G.E.C.
description: The Plessey Company said it had started legal proceedings in the United States against the General Electric Company of Britain to protect the interests of its American shareholders. G.E.C., which is not related to the American company of the same name, has made a $1.75 billion hostile bid for Plessey.

title: Magic Numbers
description: Who is Rod Carew's heir as first baseman with the California Angels? Maybe Wally Joyner. The 23-year-old Joyner, a prospect in California's minor league system, is leading the Puerto Rican Winter League with a batting average of .356.

title: LEBANESE ASSERT TOWN WAS RAIDED
description: Israeli troops and their Lebanese Christian allies were reported today to have stormed a Shiite Moslem village in southern Lebanon and forced its entire population of about 2,000 to leave.

title: HUTTON PUTS CLAIMS AT UP TO $4 MILLION
description: E. F. Hutton & Company expects to repay banks it defrauded through a check overdrafting scheme less than half of the $8 million reserve it set aside for repayment, according to senior company officials.

title: TV: 'INTIMATE STRANGERS,' 10 YEARS AFTER VIETNAM
description: Straining to say something significant about Vietnam and moral values, ''Intimate Strangers'' ends up close to incoherent babble. The television movie on CBS at 9 tonight stars Stacy Keach and Teri Garr as one of the more hapless couples likely to be encountered in this new year.

title: IOWA IS HOPING TO END CYCLE
description: Iowa, with a high national ranking and Chuck Long at quarterback, is a strong favorite to beat U.C.L.A. in the 72d Rose Bowl game Wednesday. The Big Ten champion has often been favored going into the Rose Bowl, but Pacific-10 teams have refused to be intimidated.

title: ELMER KELTON'S UNLIKELY HEROES PUSH WESTERN NOVEL INTO NEW TERRITORY
description: Gritty cattle and sheep ranchers all over Texas know Elmer Kelton. He looks and talks like one of them, in his felt cowboy hat and boots, checking on the price of feeder steers and choice lambs at the livestock auctions.

title: SAM SPIEGEL, PRODUCER, IS DEAD AT 84
description: Sam Spiegel, the Academy Award-winning producer of such motion pictures as ''The African Queen,'' ''On the Waterfront,'' ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' and ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' died yesterday while vacationing on the Caribbean island of St. Martin. He was 84 years old and had homes on Park Avenue, in London and on the Riviera.

title: A SURPRISE COALITION THROWS COUNCIL SELECTIONS INTO DOUBT
description: The expected selection of a Queens Councilman as the new City Council majority leader was thrown into doubt yesterday when Councilmen from Brooklyn and Manhattan announced that they had formed a coalition with enough votes to control the Council.

title: AFTER SLAYING, HOSPITALS SAY SECURITY IS A GROWING WORRY
description: Many New York hospitals lack the kinds of security forces that might have prevented the fatal shooting of a doctor at Kings County Hospital Center Monday, according to interviews with hospital personnel.

title: OPERA: A JAZZ 'SOLOMON'
description: ''Solomon Sheba,'' a jazz chamber opera about romance and power, was performed Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall by the Harlem Opera Society. Written by Ed Taylor and composed by Sam Rivers in 1973, and directed by Mr. Taylor, it used a jazz quartet and a cast of opera and blues-style singers to retell the biblical encounter of Solomon and Makeda, the Queen of Sheba.

title: BIFLYX CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $101,000 on the sale of stock and a gain of $3,000 on the retirement of fixed asset. c-After a loss of $28,000 from discontinued fuel distribution business and an estimated loss of $40,000 on the disposal of fuel distribution business.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: College Football Cotton Bowl, at Dallas, Texas A&M vs. Auburn, 2:30 P.M. Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy winner, makes his final appearance for Auburn.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Don't Sigh - Electrify
description: An impulse generated by General Electric addresses the employees of NBC News:

title: FRANCE SAYS 3 PLANNED TO BOMB SYNAGOGUE
description: Three men were charged tonight with preparing a bombing attack against a Paris synagogue.

title: News Conference Canceled Because of Lack of Heat
description: Mayor Koch and the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, Anthony B. Gliedman, were to hold a news conference yesterday in one of the special apartments the city is making available to families without heat.

title: Ewing Back at Practice
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' heralded rookie center, returned to practice yesterday for the first time since jamming his right knee in the closing minutes of the overtime victory against the Boston Celtics on Christmas Day. While the Knicks worked out for tomorrow night's game against the Washington Bullets at Madison Square Garden, Ewing ran, shot and participated in some drills.

title: LIBYANS DENY A CONNECTION TO TERRORISM AT 2 AIRPORTS
description: Libya today denied involvement in the Vienna and Rome airport attacks and said remarks by the United States and Israeli officials were evidence of intended ''joint aggression against Libya by the American military machine and by Israel.''

title: Keep the Doors Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Hatch for Supreme Court?
description: The name at the top of many lists of prospects for the next vacancy on the Supreme Court has been Judge Robert H. Bork of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, who is a former Solicitor General and a certifiable judicial conservative.

title: ANGIOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY BALLET: ROLE DEBUTS IN 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: The New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker'' is, of course, a holiday staple. But this classic, choreographed by George Balanchine to the Tchaikovsky score, also serves as a litmus test of skill, artistry and even nerve for the company's younger dancers. Two of the most promising of those dancers made impressive role debuts Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Talking About Drinking Parents and young people who are concerned about reasonable and responsible alcohol consumption will find helpful suggestions in a little booklet called ''Let's Talk About Drinking,'' published by the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America. The association contends that while alcohol-education programs sponsored by schools, churches and community organizations are all well and good, they must be complemented by family dialogue. To that end, the booklet offers suggestions on how to approach a topic that is often fraught with emotional issues, especially struggles for control between parents and their maturing offspring.

title: Ups and Downs
description: The holiday season brought a mixed measure of recognition to the Gradison family of Washington and Cincinnati.

title: GROUP SCRAPS SHALE PROJECT
description: A consortium of three oil companies that spent more than $180 million and nearly 12 years trying to establish a prototype oil-shale production plant in eastern Utah has returned its Federal leases and scrapped the project without producing a single barrel of oil.

title: RESIDUE OF GEL SAID TO BE CAUSE OF TRAIN CRASH
description: A slippery gel, only partially washed from the tracks after routine testing, caused an N. J. Transit train to slam into a concrete bumper at the terminal in Hoboken Monday morning, injuring 54 riders, railroad officials said today.

title: EATING PATTERNS AFFECT PACKERS STRIKE
description: A Christmas tree, its branches limp after several days in the rain, stood outside a vegetable packing plant here today.

title: Reports on Valvano
description: Jim Valvano may step aside as head basketball coach at North Carolina State after the 1987 season if such a move would lead to his becoming athletic director at the school, The Raleigh News and Observer reported.

title: HERITAGE-GILL DEAL
description: Heritage Communications Inc. said it had bought 50 percent of Gill Industries, which operates the cable television system in San Jose, Calif.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a.-Not available due to New Year's Day holiday* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
200 OBJECTS PICKED FOR DISPUTED ISRAEL SHOW AT MET
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has now made a final selection of some 200 objects for an archeological show from the Israel Museum that has generated considerable dispute over the last three years. The show, entitled ''Treasures of the Holy Land: Ancient Art from the Israel Museum,'' is scheduled to open in September, two years later than originally planned, because of controversy over the ownership of items included from a museum in disputed territory.

title: CITGO AND SUN JOIN IN OIL PRICE CUTS
description: The Citgo Petroleum Company and the Sun Oil Company joined a move to cut oil prices yesterday, reducing the prices for the top grade of American crude, West Texas Intermediate.

title: FROM A TO EAR -- AND NOTES AND BAGS
Tuning In
description: In Washington access can be everything. For nearly a year, Jose Luis Rodriguez, president of the Hispanic Information and Telecommunications Network, had been trying unsuccessfully to get an appointment with James C. McKinney, chief of the Mass Media Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission, to make a case for assigning another television channel to his network.

title: AIRLINE GROUNDS MAN WHO FLEW TOO MUCH
description: Howard Landau is a frequent flier. He is a very frequent flier. He may be a too frequent flier. In the last four and a half years, the 42-year-old truck-tire salesman from New Jersey, who sometimes flies for fun to California for the weekend, has accumulated about 400,000 bonus miles in United Airlines' frequent-flier program, one of the highly popular promotions that most airlines now use to woo customers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1986
description: International

title: A Jazz Legend Enlightens Youngsters in Brooklyn
description: Last night, Lionel Hampton and his band played at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The tab was $235 a person.

title: Peruvian Gunmen Fire Shots At Home of an Ex-President
description: Gunmen in a speeding car fired three shots at the home of former President Jose Luis Bustamente y Rivero on Monday night.

title: RESORT FASHIONS ACT AS TREND SETTERS
description: RESORT fashions have been appearing in the stores for several weeks now, and demand has been sufficiently brisk for buyers to have a good sense of what styles are going to be successful. The designs women are buying offer a good clue to the kind of clothes that will be popular from now through the summer.

title: BEATRICE NET DOWN BY 30.7%
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that third-quarter earnings dropped 30.7 percent, to $88 million, or 79 cents a share, from $127 million, or $1.34 a share, a year earlier. Revenues dropped 14.3 percent, to $3 billion, from $3.5 billion.

title: 'THE PASS' STILL HAUNTS MIAMI
description: It is referred to simply as ''The Pass,'' and is the stuff of legends. Grantland Rice would have enjoyed writing about little Doug Flutie and the day late last season when the Boston College quarterback evaded the rush of the burly defensive lineman Jerome Brown and tossed a desperation 64-yard touchdown pass on the final play of the game to give the Eagles a 47-45 victory over Miami in the gathering dusk at the Orange Bowl stadium.

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR wine enthusiasts, 1985 was a mixed blessing. For the wine makers of the world, it was an unexpectedly bountiful year. For wine drinkers, it was a time of great buys for anyone with the sense to take advantage of them. Alas, for the third or fourth year in a row, many people did not. Consequently, for the wine merchants, 1985 was pretty much what they had expected: a tough sell.

title: TECHNICAL INNOVATIONS IN VIENNA TV CONCERT
description: Because of the scope of its distribution, the annual New Year's celebration of the Vienna Philharmonic has traditionally served as a proving ground for technical innovations in long-distance transmission. This year, American viewers will enjoy a new advantage. At least 26 PBS stations in major cities are now equipped to transmit stereo sound and can take advantage of the stereo signal being supplied from Europe.

title: DRIVERS IN CONNECTICUT MUST START BUCKLING THEIR SEAT BELTS TODAY
description: Starting Wednesday, Connecticut will require automobile drivers and their front-seat passengers to wear safety belts.

title: CAROLINA DEMOCRATS SEE '86 BOON IN REAGAN VETO
description: Over the last two weeks Democrats in North Carolina have broadcast an insistent message to the state's hard-pressed textile workers: President Reagan and his supporters are sending your jobs overseas.

title: EVENTS: CARPETS AS ART
description: Three Lectures on Turkoman Carpets, lecture room of St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, sponsored by the Institute for Asian Studies. Call 212-535-7496.

title: Percy on Georgetown
description: Former Senator Charles H. Percy, who headed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for years and is now an international affairs consultant, is also focusing some of his attention these days on his own neighborhood. Mr. Percy lives on 34th Street in Georgetown, two blocks from Wisconsin Avenue, a main thoroughfare that has been getting messy. Last year, Malcolm Baldrige, the Commerce Secretary, said he was moving away because Georgetown was getting dirtier and noisier. Mr. Percy, in a letter in the January issue of the Citizens Association of George-town newsletter, said: ''I would like to express the same concern expressed by Malcolm Baldrige with respect to street filth and the seeming lack of attention that our Wisconsin Avenue stores give towards cleanliness and appearance.

title: APARTMENT OF THE MOMENT: THE LATEST IN TRENDS
description: THE clients, who had just bought an apartment in Trump Tower, asked their designer, Allen Minars, to do something that was, perhaps, a little different; maybe something with some color. In retrospect, looking around their elegant but startling living room, they admit they hadn't really known exactly what the result would be.

title: INVESTORS OPEN '86 CONFIDENTLY
description: The stock market Tuesday closed out the most profitable year ever for investors, sending them into the new year with a renewed sense of confidence that bodes well for economic expansion in the months ahead.

title: MIAMI SURPRISED BY TENNESSEE, 35-7
description: Ken Donahue is at his best in a darkened room where the only sound is the hum of a film projector. He had spent most of his coaching career plotting defensive strategy for a college football coaching legend and now he does the same for Johnny Majors, who has something of a reputation himself at Tennessee. Donohue's design for the Volunteers' defense tonight against Miami will make Majors even more popular tomorrow.

title: ACQUISITIONS HELPED SOME AMEX LEADERS
description: Buoyed by sharp gains in the stocks of retailers and consumer goods manufacturers, the American Stock Exchange in 1985 posted record trading figures and a marked performance increase over 1984 levels.

title: RANGERS' OFFENSE DESERTS THEM AGAIN
description: When they were bumped, they bumped back. When they were shoved, they shoved back. When they felt called upon, they even swung their sticks. But this time, whatever bravado the Rangers showed could not sustain them.

title: SCOUTING Punter Declared Out of Bounds
description: Apparently unable to make ends meet on his three-year, $500,000 contract with the Giants, Sean Landeta last week took on a second job: scalping tickets to fans.

title: Required Reading; Of Smoke and Work
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General, in introducing his report on smoking and workplace causes of cancer, Dec. 19:

title: JUDGE SETS A TIMETABLE TO CLEAN BOSTON HARBOR
description: A Federal district judge has issued an 11-page schedule of the steps Massachusetts must take over the next four years to begin cleaning up Boston Harbor.

title: FAMILY LIFE PROGRAM REFOCUSES PUBLIC DISCUSSION
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S MESSAGE TO THE SOVIET PEOPLE FOR 'YEAR OF PEACE'
description: Following is a transcript, issued by the White House, of President Reagan's New Year's message today to the Soviet people:

title: Bruce A. Norris, 61, Is Dead; Ex-Owner of Hockey Team
description: Bruce A. Norris, the former owner of the Detroit Red Wings and a member of the National Hockey League Hall of Fame, died Tuesday of liver failure at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 61 years old.

title: A NEW ELEMENT OF VOLATILITY
description: Last Aug. 6, an otherwise desultory summer day, something unusual happened at the New York Stock Exchange. It was as though Jaws, the giant white shark, had suddenly seized hold of the market, At the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen nearly 22 points, with no news developments to account for the sudden decline.

title: 2 Arabs in Belgium Accused Of Planning an Airport Attack
description: The Belgian police are holding two Arab guerrilla suspects who arrived here a day after the attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports and whom the police followed to a cache of arms.

title: I.R.A. AMBUSH KILLS 2 ULSTER POLICEMEN
description: Just one minute into the new year, Irish Republican Army guerrillas killed two policemen and wounded a third in an ambush that the I.R.A. said opened a renewed campaign against British security forces.

title: Harold Osborne, Chief Of A.T.&T. Engineers
description: Harold S. Osborne, a retired chief engineer of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company and a former president of the Regional Plan Association, died Sunday at his home in Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 98 years old and had broken his hip in a fall Nov. 29.

title: Cards Drop Braun
description: Steve Braun, who ranks sixth on the major league career list with 113 pinch hits, will not be offered a 1986 contract by the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Bucks Lose Hodges
description: Craig Hodges, starting point guard of the Milwaukee Bucks, was placed on the injured list and will be out at least five weeks because of a severe dislocation of the index finger on his shooting hand. Hodges was injured Monday night while trying for a steal in Milwaukee's 121-110 victory over Detroit. He leads the National Basketball Association with 37 3-point goals.

title: COMMON MARKET ADMITS 2 NATIONS
description: After eight years of arduous, often frustrating, negotiations, Spain and Portugal became members of the European Economic Community today.

title: JOOP ADMIRAAL IN 'YOU ARE MY MOTHER'
description: IN ''You Are My Mother,'' on WNET/Channel 13 at 11 this evening, a 45-year-old Dutchman spends a Sunday visiting his 80-year-old mother in a home for the aged. He is an actor with Amsterdam's Het Werktater. She is an invalid shrouded in senility, drifting between past and present. What makes this delicate autobiographical exploration of family relationships extraordinary, if not downright unsettling, is that both roles are played by Joop Admiraal.

title: TRYING TO PRESERVE A VILLAGE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE EAST RIVER
description: When people on Roosevelt Island define their community, they don't exactly make it sound like the quintessential New York neighborhood.

title: DOOR PUSH PLATES, PLAIN AND FANCIFUL
description: PUSH PLATES, often seen on swinging doors, are available in a variety of materials - brass, porcelain, plastic, chrome and wrought iron - and in designs from plain to fancy.

title: Space for Women
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Market Place; Assessing the Newsletters
description: MORE than half a million people subscribe to investment newsletters in the hope of making money in stocks, bonds, options or commodities.

title: KOCH PLEDGES AID FOR THE HOMELESS, SCHOOLS AND POOR
description: Edward Irving Koch took the oath of office yesterday for his third term as Mayor of New York City, then pledged that despite a ''Federal assault'' on the city's budget he would work to resolve the problems that still elude solution.

title: Aquino Abandons Her Plans For Rally in Marcos Territory
description: Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition candidate, was forced today to cancel a campaign rally in the home province of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: MONTANA TOWN SEEKS SUCCESS WITH BRAVE (BUT FALSE) FRONT
description: There wasn't a formal vote or anything, but it has been pretty much decided that this isolated county seat is going to change its appearance drastically in a bid to change its economic fortunes drastically.

title: CELEBRATING STATE'S ARCHITECTURAL PAST
description: Architectural heritage year has been proclaimed by Governor Cuomo, and the Preservation League of New York State is coordinating a yearlong series of events in the hope that many residents will soon look at their homes and neighborhoods a bit differently.

title: Why Can't Detroit Improve Seat Belts?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank Aid Delayed
description: The Reagan Administration is withholding a $75 million contribution to the World Bank's special fund for Africa to see if it will be cut under the new deficit-reduction law, a Treasury official said Tuesday.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WINDOWS and doors without weatherstripping or with worn-out weatherstripping are year-round energy wasters. During winter they allow heat to escape and cold drafts to enter, so people tend to set their thermostats higher. And in hot weather missing or inefficient weatherstripping contributes to air-conditioning costs.

title: Ex-Coach Sues Cosmos
description: Ray Klivecka, former head coach of the Cosmos, has sued the soccer team and former team executives for more than $100,000 that he says the organization owes him. The suit, filed in Superior Court in New Jersey, names as defendants the Cosmos; Warner Communications Inc.; George Chinaglia, Joseph Berardo and G. Peppe Pinton.

title: U.C.L.A. WALLOPS IOWA
description: Eric Ball, a second-string freshman tailback, scored four touchdowns and ran for 227 yards today as U.C.L.A. continued its Rose Bowl domination of Big Ten teams by upsetting favored Iowa, 45-28.

title: WOOD AND COAL FOR CITY FIREPLACES
description: FOR those in the Manhattan area with working fireplaces, this is the season to use them.

title: Help AIDS Victims While Cutting Cost
description: Someday there will be a cure or a vaccine for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. Right now, however, all that medicine, family and friends can do for AIDS victims is to make the last months of their lives as comfortable as possible.

title: ARRESTS AND DEBRIS DECLINE
description: The morning after was much the same as the night before: one of the most quiet and restrained New Year's holiday celebrations in recent years.

title: Dallas Police Wound Sniper Who Killed Man
description: A man with a rifle barricaded himself inside his apartment today, firing shots from his front window that killed one man and injured two others before the police wounded him in a hail of gunfire, the authorities said.

title: Advertising; Another Publication For New Homeowners
description: The Castelwood Corporation, Jenkintown, Pa., through its New Homeowner Publications, will bring out in January its second in a series of publications aimed at recent purchasers of single-family homes that cost a minimum of $80,000.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ORIGINALLY from Pakistan, Shyam Ahuja, above, settled in India and developed an unusual range of dhurries. Now he has applied his sense of color and pattern to bed linens and pillows made in Bombay and sold in the home-furnishings department on the seventh floor at Bergdorf Goodman. Included are 100-inch-square quilts, $350 in cotton, $825 in silk; 16-inch-square pillows, $45 in cotton, $65 in silk; 20-inch-square pillows, $65 in cotton, $85 in silk, and chain-stitched wool rugs, $275 to $875 each.

title: I.R.S.-State Data Audited
description: The Internal Revenue Service should follow up on more of the information that states pass along about taxpayers they have audited, the General Accounting Office says.

title: OCCIDENTAL SETS A DEAL FOR MIDCON
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday agreed to acquire the Midcon Corporation, the owner of one of the largest natural gas pipelines in the United States, for more than $3 billion.

title: POP: SUSSMAN-LAWRENCE
description: THE Sussman-Lawrence band showed off an old-fashioned, rock-and-roll party spirit Monday night at the Ritz. When an electronic keyboard broke down partway through the set, the Minneapolis-based group was undaunted; it improvised a stomping blues-rock song about bad keyboards.

title: How to Counter Tobacco Ads
description: The American Medical Association's proposal to prohibit advertising of all tobacco products ''in all media,'' in order to curb the health dangers of smoking and tobacco use and counter the industry's seduction of the young into smoking, is not likely to work, faces formidable political obstacles and, in any case, is not the best solution to the problem.

title: 8 U.S. TOURISTS KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES ON AN ISLAND IN ANTARCTIC
description: They were eight Americans, all men, united in a trip that would take them on the adventure of a lifetime - spending New Year's Day at a Chilean Air Force base in the fog-shrouded wastes of Antarctica.

title: Letter of the Law
description: It's become a well-publicized commonplace for big-city mayors to make small wagers with their counterparts in rival towns on the outcome of major sports events. But when the policemen of East Rutherford, N.J., tried to get in on the act by offering to stake 28 baseball caps and T-shirts against the Chicago Police Department on the Giants-Bears game this Sunday, Fred Rice, the Chicago police superintendent, had two words for them: No dice. Explained Janice Redmond, a Rice spokesman: ''We enforce gambling laws.''

title: 2 Sorts of Debute
description: Giving birth to a play and giving birth to babies do not have much in common, according to Israel Horovitz, who missed the opening preview of his new play, ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen,'' because his wife was having twins.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: BIG SCORERS, SMALL DIFFERENCE
description: The scoring race Adrian Dantley and Alex English are waging brings recollections of the close scoring battle in 1977-78, when David Thompson of the Denver Nuggets thought he had won the title on the final day of the season with his 73-point performance against the Detroit Pistons in an afternoon game. Seven hours later, George Gervin took the honor from him by scoring 63 points against the New Orleans Jazz.

title: A Place for Fast Food in a Balanced Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES BUSH-BROWN
description: James Bush-Brown, a landscape architect and author, died last Saturday at Foulkeways, a retirement community in Gwynedd, Pa.

title: ALBERT ALEY
description: Albert Aley, a television writer and producer whose career began as a child actor with ''Let's Pretend,'' a children's radio series, died yesterday at Seattle Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived on Mercer Island, Wash.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO SUPPORT MEXICO'S QUEST FOR $4 BILLION
description: President Reagan is expected to assure President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico this week that the United States will help Mexico borrow $4 billion in 1986. The two leaders are to hold talks Friday in Mexicali, Mexico, on the United States border.

title: The Markets in '85: Winners and Losers
description: Strong earnings, lower interest rates and takeover bids fueled the stock market's top performers last year.

title: Ex-Guatemala Aide Slain
description: Gunmen have assassinated a former head of Guatemala's secret police, Carlos Ignacio Gonzalez Palacios, the authorities said today. Mr. Palacios, a retired army colonel, was attacked on Tuesday on a street corner in Amatitlan, 15 miles south of the capital. He headed the secret police in the 1960's.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rick Green, a defenseman with the Montreal Canadiens, will be out for six to eight weeks with a fractured left thumb. Green was injured when he was hit by a stick during the first period of a 6-1 exhibition loss to the Soviet Central Army team Tuesday night. . . . Brian Forster, a junior tight end of the University of Rhode Island, has been suspended for the 1986 season because of academic problems.

title: WEST VIRGINIA INMATES TAKE 14 HOSTAGES IN RIOT
description: Knife-wielding inmates seized control of the West Virginia Penitentiary Wednesday, taking 14 hostages and demanding to meet the Governor, the authorities said. One inmate was reported to be dead.

title: Revelers' Pistol Volleys Leave Los Angeles Boy Brain Dead
description: Thousands of New Year's revelers fired off pistols at midnight and a stray bullet struck a 13-year-old boy in the head, leaving him brain dead, the police said today.

title: Texaco-Pennzoil Talks
description: After two weeks of negotiations, Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company remain far apart in their efforts to reach a settlement of their multibillion-dollar legal struggle, a source close to their talks said yesterday.

title: DISAPPOINTING MAYORAL THIRD TERMS
description: On the eve of his third term, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia denounced his critics as ''swivel chair scribes'' and ''two by four editors'' and declared that he would carry out his duties ''as long as I hold out.''

title: IMPROVING TAXI SERVICE THROUGHOUT THE CITY: AN AGENDA FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: The meter is running on plans for the city's taxi-riding public in 1986 - plans that could bring 1,200 more licensed cabs to the city's streets, better service outside Manhattan, higher fares and tighter regulation of thousands of gypsy cabs.

title: CITY BALLET: 'NUTCRACKER' ROLE DEBUTS
description: THE New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker'' is, of course, a holiday staple. But this classic, choreographed by George Balanchine to the Tchaikovsky score, also serves as a litmus test of skill, artistry and even nerve for the company's younger dancers. Two of the most promising of those dancers made impressive role debuts Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: 2 Jazz Pianists to Open Whitney Music Series
description: A jazz concert with the pianists Valerie Capers and Billy Taylor at 6 P.M. on Jan. 28 will open a series of free music performances at the Whitney Museum of American Art branch at Philip Morris, Park Avenue and 42d Street. The series, called ''An American Sampler,'' will run on alternate Tuesday evenings through April 1.

title: Suicide Causes Blast Injuring 6 in Oregon
description: A ''very depressed man'' ignited natural gas in his basement today, killing himself and touching off an explosion that demolished three homes, wrecked dozens of others and injured six people.

title: Romeo Rated by Youths
description: What's in a name? When it's Shakespeare, antipathy, self-consciousness and unease - with the language, his poetry and their accents.

title: The Money Tapes
description: For the political movers and shakers who think they know all there is to know, and for humbler operators, the Federal Election Commission is selling tapes of records that tell who spent how much on election campaigns in 1983 and 1984.

title: GRAVELY ILL MAKE A CHOICE OF DEATH
description: People gravely ill with kidney failure often choose to die by stopping dialysis treatment, and these little-publicized deaths are likely to become even more common, a study has found.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LAUNCHING PADS Al Pacino's introduction to the New York theater was in a play called ''The Indian Wants the Bronx.'' Marsha Mason and Jill Clayburgh were introduced to New York audiences in ''It's Called the Sugar Plum.'' And at one point Richard Dreyfuss starred in ''Line.'' All of these plays were written by Israel Horovitz, whose latest work, ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen,'' will have its world premiere at the American Jewish Theater of the 92d Street Y (427-6000).

title: Strike Cancels Roosevelt Card
description: Last night's 10-race harness-racing card at Roosevelt Raceway was canceled because of a strike by mutuel ticket sellers.

title: Aruba Self-Rule Begins; Cabinet Sworn In
description: Aruba's first home-rule Government took office today after the Caribbean island split from the Netherlands Antilles federation at midnight.

title: Advertising; A New Format For Old-House
description: After 13 years as a newsletter without advertising, The Old-House Journal is converting to an advertising medium with a magazine format.

title: REAGAN EXCHANGES GREETINGS ON TV WITH GORBACHEV
description: In an unusual television exchange, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev extended New Year's greetings today to the Soviet and American peoples. They expressed the hope that the two nations could narrow their differences in 1986.

title: TO MAJORITY RULE
description: Hard-liners in the intelligence ''community'' were somewhat spooked last week when they received their daily intelligence briefing from the State Department.

title: All the Giants Work Out
description: All of the Giants took part in practice today, although both left cornerbacks were below full strength. Elvis Patterson, the starter, had a sprained left ankle and moved gingerly in practice. Ted Watts, the backup, was limited by a bruised left knee.

title: Traveling Wives
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: T.W.A. UNION PACT WITH ICAHN
description: The Trans World Airlines' machinists union yesterday signed an agreement for a new contract with Carl C. Icahn clearing the way for the New York investor to gain control of the carrier.

title: DINKINS TAKES POST AS LEADER OF MANHATTAN
description: David N. Dinkins was inaugurated yesterday as the 24th Manhattan Borough President and promised to be a voice for ''those neighborhoods that have been neglected - Harlem, El Barrio and the Lower East Side.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Marshall Barrett joins B.B.D.O. Direct as a senior vice president.

title: Gramm, Rudman Won On Balanced-Budget Bill
description: Republican Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire teamed up to produce one of 1985's most controversial pieces of legislation. But the principal authors of the bill that requires the Government to balance its budget in five years could hardly be more different representatives of their party.

title: Teacher, Striker, Educator
description: Albert Shanker's retirement this week as president of New York City's United Federation of Teachers marks the departure of a figure influential in city politics for two decades. The union has grown since 1960 from 2,000 to 85,000 members and is now the largest local in the world. It is also a monument to Mr. Shanker's strengths and weaknesses.

title: NEW YEAR IS GREETED WITH RESTRAINT AND NEW TRANSIT FARE WITH DISTRESS;
description: Token clerks praised the convenience and riders complained about the cost yesterday as New Yorkers started the new year paying $1 for bus and subway rides.

title: Columbus!
description: The ancestors of the Belizeans, who descended from a Mayan culture, had their first contact with Europeans in 1502, when Columbus sailed along the coast, a trip that goes unsung in the Washington Opera's production of ''Christopher Columbus'' opening Saturday at the Kennedy Center. The opera was among the bicentenntial gifts Britain gave the United States in 1976.

title: GORBACHEV'S NEW YEAR'S MESSAGE TO THE U.S.
description: Following is the text of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's New Year's message to the American people, as provided in translation by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency:

title: Reagan Approves Raises
description: President Reagan has signed an executive order that gives a retroactive raise to some Federal judges and a 3 percent raise to members of the armed forces, the White House announced Tuesday. The order puts into effect provisions of a catchall appropriation enacted earlier.

title: Victory in First Start
description: For Todd Rampley, the Georgia Tech quarterback, his first collegiate start was one to remember. Rampley led Tech to a 17-14 uphill victory over Michigan State Tuesday night in the All American Bowl in Birmingham, Ala.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BRIEF RESPITE OF THE JANUARY THAW
description: JANUARY used to be called the month of the hunger moon by some American Indian tribes in the Northeast. Food was not easy to come by in the winter woods, and even today, January marks a sort of low ebb in the tide of forest life.

title: 10 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA IN NEW OUTBREAK BETWEEN TRIBES
description: At least 10 black South Africans were reported killed today in tribal fighting near Pretoria set off by an official effort to redesignate an area as part of a so-called homeland.

title: BUTLER AIMING FOR CONSISTENCY
description: Anyone who watched the Giants beat the 49ers the other day knows a thing or two about the importance of the place- kicker in a big game. The Giants' Eric Schubert kicked his first field-goal attempt true. But then he missed three straight, which could have been a problem had the Giant defense not played its best game of the season.

title: Stenlund Wins
