description: Ulf Stenlund of Sweden, playing a steady game from the base line, routed Shigeru Ohata of Japan, 6-2, 6-1, today to win the Boys' 18 title in the Rolex International Junior championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. The victory by Stenlund, who will turn 19 years old on Jan. 21, gave Sweden three of the four Boys' championships.

title: FISHING FOR COD OFF LONG ISLAND
description: The omnivorous, bottom-dwelling Atlantic cod has never inspired the literature devoted to other marine fishes such as the striped bass or bluefish, but there are those who go after it all winter long on party boats from Long Island.

title: MICHIGAN RALLIES TO WIN
description: Michigan turned two third-quarter Nebraska fumbles into 1-yard touchdown runs by Gerald White and Jim Harbaugh and rallied to beat the Cornhuskers, 27-23, in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl game today.

title: Judge Backs San Jose On Desegregation Plan
description: Public schools in San Jose will not have to bus students but will have to speed up desegregation efforts, a Federal district judge ruled Tuesday after 14 years of legal wrangling.

title: Fomon Felt The Heat On Hutton
description: For a man who normally shuns publicity, Robert Fomon attracted the harsh glare of scrutiny in 1985 from Federal investigators, Wall Street analysts and Congress.

title: BEIRUT TERRORISTS KILL A SECOND JEWISH CAPTIVE
description: A Moslem fundamentalist group said today that it had killed the second of four Jews it kidnapped here nine months ago, and the police said later that they had found the body of a man believed to be the victim.

title: BUSINESS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 2, 1986
description: Companies Occidental Petroleum agreed to acquire Midcon, a natural gas pipeline company, for $3 billion in cash and stock. Occidental hopes to make better use of its natural gas reserves. The deal appears to save Midcon from a bid led by Wagner & Brown. [ Page D1. ] GAF is expected to increase its takeover bid for Union Carbide to $78 a share, from $74, sources said. It appeared GAF had learned that Carbide planned to make what other sources characterized as a significant announcement after a board meeting today. [ D1. ] T.W.A.'s machinists agreed on a contract with Carl C. Icahn, clearing the way for him to gain control of the carrier. [ D1. ] The Texaco-Pennzoil talks have made little progress toward resolving their dispute, according to sources. [ D5. ] Markets The stock market closed out the most profitable year ever for investors, sending them into the new year with a renewed sense of confidence that bodes well for continued economic expansion. [ D1. ] Wall Street raised more capital for companies in 1985 than in any previous year, including the record initial public stock offering of $824 million for the Fireman's Fund. [ D1. ] The Economy The Government predicted a better year for industry, saying it expected 80 percent of manufacturing companies to enjoy higher growth and predicting bigger profits for service companies. [ D3. ] At savings and loan institutions, the value of home mortgages is greater than their book value for the first time in six years, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said.

title: Drexel Chief's Success in Junk Bonds
description: When corporate raiders have needed financing for hostile takeovers, they have often relied on the high-risk, high-yield debt securities called ''junk bonds.'' And to sell them they have often turned to the acknowledged leader in the market, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose new chief executive helped to develop and refine the use of the popular instruments.

title: Panda Watch Ends
description: National Zoo officials have given up their round-the-clock watch on the giant panda Ling-Ling, believing she is not about to give birth.A zoo spokesman, Mike Morgan, said the panda watch, which began on Oct. 31, ended at 7 A.M. Tuesday.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:30 A.M. today and set at 9:17 P.M. tonight.

title: Let's Take Another Look at Allocating New York's Police Forces
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TO AID ROCKWELL MUSEUM
description: President Reagan has agreed to serve as honorary chairman of a $5 million drive to build a new museum for Norman Rockwell's works.

title: Early Hits?
description: There's a possibility, however slim, that one of the National Football League's conference championship games the weekend after next will have to begin as early as 9:30 in the morning.

title: Advertising; A Year Of Very Big Deals
description: THERE'S been a lot written about the goings-on in the worlds of advertising and the media during 1985. But eliminate a couple of attempted or completed TV network acquisitions, the creation of three billion-dollar advertisers and the biggest ad agency merger in history and, basically, you've got just another ho-hum year.

title: 'STAR WARS' TESTS TRW ENGINEERS
description: From the moment he arrives at his office every morning at a classified TRW Corporation installation in San Bernadino, Edgar Y. Wong, a youthful-looking 56-year-old engineer, is preoccupied with ''leakers.''

title: QADDAFI 'WELCOMES' A REPRISAL
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, warned today that Israeli or American retaliation for airport attacks by Arab terrorists would set off a ''tit for tat'' cycle of violence, with Libyans harassing ''American citizens in their own streets.''

title: Dodd, Mead to Return To Private Ownership
description: Dodd, Mead & Company, the 146-year-old book publishing concern, is about to be returned to private ownership.

title: MEMBER OF RICKY NELSON'S BAND WAS SET TO QUIT BECAUSE OF PLANE
description: The DC-3 aircraft that crashed and killed Ricky Nelson and six other people had engine trouble before its last flight, and one member of the singer's band had talked of quitting because he did not trust the plane, friends and relatives said today.

title: 12 Thai Inmates Slain As Prison Break Fails
description: Policemen and soldiers killed 12 prison inmates today after they tried to break out of a provincial prison with six hostages, ending a 24-hour drama, official reports said. The six hostages, including the warden, were wounded.

title: Article 531486 -- No Title
description: The GAF Corporation is expected to announce today that it is increasing its takeover bid for the Union Carbide Corporation to $78 a share, or about $5.5 billion in cash, sources close to the situation said last night.

title: Child and 2 Adults Die in Jersey Fire
description: Fire swept through a three-story frame house in Rutherford, N.J., last night, killing two elderly women and an 18-month-old infant.

title: NEW PROGRAMS ARE WIDENING SCOPE OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION
description: THE influx of Asian and Hispanic children into the public school systems of metropolitan areas in the last decade and the increased availability of funds under Title VII of the Federal Bilingual Education Act have broadened the focus of bilingual education programs. Now these programs include seminars for teachers on the cultural and behavioral differences of their students.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: Thursday, January 2, 1986
description: International

title: Spain to Establish Relations With Israel 'Early This Year'
description: Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said today that Spain would establish diplomatic relations with Israel early this year.

title: ARGENTINA'S NEW CAUDILLO: HE'S BUSINESS-MINDED
description: The talk started when the Governor of this northern agricultural province of Entre Rios resurrected a 1934 land redistribution bill.

title: SPORTS THURSDAY
description: College Basketball St. John's vs. Providence, at Providence, R.I., 8 P.M. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.); Brown vs. American University, Iona vs.

title: Chamber Music Group Scheduled at Vineyard
description: Original chamber music by Gary William Friedman will be presented by a seven-member ensemble Jan. 11 and 18 at the Vineyard, 309 East 26th Street.

title: INCOMING LAW SCHOOL DEAN WITH 2 CAREERS
description: When Charles L. Black Jr. was teaching his class in equity at Columbia Law School in the 50's, he once called on a first-year student named Barbara Aronstein. She was stumped, and pleaded the Socratic method's equivalent of the Fifth Amendment.

title: U.S. PREDICTS INDUSTRY UPTURN
description: American industry will have a better year in 1986, with 80 percent of manufacturing companies expected to enjoy higher growth and the nation's service industries expected to increase their profits, the Government predicted.

title: SCHUBERT EASILY FORGETS MISSES
description: After his erratic performance last Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers, when he made only one of four field-goal attempts, Eric Schubert of the Giants has every reason to be upset. Instead, he is upbeat, as he has been every week since he became the Giants' kicker 10 weeks ago.

title: EXPLORING 1986: SIX DESIGNERS DISCUSS THEIR NEW IDEAS
description: At the turn of the year, six avant-garde Manhattan architects and designers were asked about the areas in their work that they planned to explore in 1986 and the trends that they thought would emerge. Here are their answers. Michael McDonough, architect:

title: JOHN PAUL PRAISES WORK OF U.N. AND DEDICATES NEW YEAR TO PEACE
description: Pope John Paul II, citing the words of Mohandas K. Gandhi, praised the peace efforts of the United Nations today and pledged the first day of the New Year ''to the cause of peace and to the prayer for peace in our world so severely menaced.''

title: Baker Marshalled Tax, Dollar Plans
description: When James A. Baker 3d crossed the street from the White House to the Treasury nearly a year ago, the President's former chief of staff walked into what for him would be another important but much more visible role in the Administration.

title: Berndt Gets Rice Post
description: He led the University of Pennsylvania to Ivy League football titles the last four seasons, and now Jerry Berndt is moving on to Rice, where he has been named head coach and athletic director. Berndt, 47 years old, resigned at Penn on Tuesday and has signed a five-year contract with Rice, a Southwest Conference school in Houston.

title: COLUMBIA PICKS WOMAN AS LAW SCHOOL DEAN
description: Barbara Aronstein Black, a legal historian and authority on law in Colonial America, has been chosen as the new dean of Columbia Law School.

title: OKLAHOMA UPENDS PENN STATE, STAKES CLAIM TO No. 1
description: With their powerful wishbone offense stopped for much of the evening, the Oklahoma Sooners took advantage of five turnovers in a 25-10 victory over Penn State in the 52d Orange Bowl tonight that seemed certain to guarantee the Sooners the top ranking in the final national college football polls.

title: HERS
description: UP until the day before yesterday, you were labeled a fanatic if you suggested that the next target of the ''prolife'' movement would be contraception - today the abortion clinic, tomorrow the drugstore. Never mind that the Roman Catholic Church has never made any secret of its ban on any form of contraception except abstinence. What is the rhythm method but planned abstinence - even when pregnancy means death. Never mind, too, that the Protestant fundamentalists take an only slightly less drastic position. In America, we like to think that truth lies in the middle - like the ''Happy Birthday'' on a cake. Thus, people who saw a threat to family planning had to be extremists, to balance the people who conducted funeral services over aborted fetuses.

title: Season Ends for Seaway
description: The Cartiercliff Hall, a Canadian vessel, left the St. Lawrence Seaway at 6:41 P.M. Monday, ending the 1985 shipping season two weeks later than expected, Dennis Deuschl, a seaway spokesman, said Tuesday. Officials now plan to spend $4 million for maintenance of locks on the United States side, he said, one of the largest efforts to date.

title: THE MEANING OF RESPONSIBILITY
description: Once again, Micheal Ray Richardson is being rehabilitated for drug abuse - for the fourth time in less than three years and at a fourth site. In the understandable sympathy for the basketball player's relapse, Lewis Schaffel, the Nets' executive vice president, spoke about how ''there will always be a place'' on the team for this 30-year-old playmaker, so talented and yet so troubled.''

title: WASHINGTON STATE SETTLES DISPUTE OVER PAY EQUITY
description: A settlement between the state of Washington and its largest employee union has ended a 12-year dispute over whether equal pay should be given for different jobs deemed to be of comparable worth, giving 35,000 state workers hopes for fatter paychecks in the new year.

title: BENCHLEY ON THEATER: AN INNOCENT AT LARGE
description: IN the 1920's and 30's, there were drama critics of all stripes, serious arbiters of taste as well as the stage-struck with a penchant for self-promotion. There was room for the personal touch, as exemplified by Robert Benchley. In contrast to his friend and colleague Dorothy Parker, who specialized in the mean mot, Mr. Benchley was the wide-eyed Peter Pan of drama criticism, a self-described innocent who never missed an opportunity to devalue the importance of his reviews. Warning readers against his ''deathless little bijoux,'' he said they represented ''the most unreliable, inconsistent and temperamental page of personal reactions in the country.''

title: GAINS IN O-T-C MARKET OUTRAN THE EXCHANGES
description: Although much of the financial community's attention focused on the hefty gains in the Dow Jones industrial average in 1985, it was the over-the-counter market that proved to be the big winner last year.

title: NICARAGUA ASSEMBLY TO FORM CHARTER
description: When Nicaragua's elected National Assembly ended its first year of work recently, its President, Carlos Nunez Tellez, said in his closing speech that the Assembly's principal role was to be ''the maximum expression of national unity.''

title: Overdue Book Back After Century Passes
description: A rare, 328-year-old book, apparently missing from the state library since the last century, was found returned in a library book drop bin, library officials said Tuesday.

title: Slain U.S. Naturalist Buried In Gorilla Cemetery She Built
description: Dian Fossey, the slain American naturalist, has been buried in a cemetery she had built for gorillas killed by poachers.

title: BIG BOARD'S FINAL SURGE RESHAPES WINNERS LIST
description: Just as in a horse race, the New York Stock Exchange's list of winners and losers for 1985 shifted dramatically when the stock market broke into a gallop down the homestretch. The market's spectacular surge in the final quarter was so strong and so broad that the Big Board was no longer dominated by the companies in a few industries that had shown sparks of life until then.

title: Charter Files Plan in Court
description: The Charter Company has filed a joint plan of reorganization and a disclosure statement with the United States Bankruptcy Court administering its Chapter 11 reorganization, covering itself and its 43 affiliates throughout the country, the company said.

title: CONCERT: BARRY MANILOW
description: BARRY MANILOW appeared on the stage of the Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening sporting a Rod Stewart-styled shag haircut, and later he changed into a black leather jacket and sunglasses for a musical segment whose rhythmic punch and keening electric guitar had a hard-rock edge. Throughout the concert -the first of two New Year's Eve shows at the Music Hall - the singer and pianist also relied heavily on electronics for orchestral coloration.

title: JAZZ: JASON HWANG'S GLASS SHADOWS
description: JASON HWANG'S Glass Shadows, which performed Sunday afternoon at the Blue Note, is geared for Mr. Hwang's rhapsodic, atmospheric pieces. Mr. Hwang's writing fuses jazz improvisation with the timbres of Eastern music; he writes long, multisectioned pieces that float in and out of conventional tonalities and rhythms.

title: U.S. Team Intends to Search Another Laos Air Crash Site
description: A United States military team prepared today to fly to Laos on Thursday for a preliminary survey of an air crash site that will be excavated for the remains of American servicemen.

title: Missing Item at Firehouses
description: Firefighters hope to complete the task of handing out free smoke detectors to the poor this week, but the city's own firehouses still have none. Fire Chief William Baylor said an alarm system would be in place in two stations and battery-powered smoke detectors would be installed in the sleeping quarters of seven other firehouses this week. Officials began distributing free smoke detectors after a fire Dec. 18.

title: ON THE WILD SIDE: WOMEN IN GANGS
description: THE 24-year-old woman wore a black leather jacket, tight jeans, black leather boots and a motorcycle chain around her thick waist as she walked through Central Park, talking about how and why she mugs people.

title: MUSCOVITES VOICE POSITIVE REACTION
description: President Reagan's New Year's greeting to the Soviet people was broadcast at the beginning of the evening television news today, and the initial reaction among Soviet citizens seemed positive.

title: Technology; Sunglasses Go Beyond Basics
description: WITH winter here, it might not seem like the time to talk about sunglasses. But it is skiers, not sunbathers, who put sunglasses to their stiffest test. The sun, reflected off the snow, buffets a skier from both above and below, and at high altitudes there is less atmosphere to screen out harmful radiation.

title: SCHOLAR TO QUIT POST AT HARVARD OVER C.I.A. TIE
description: The director of Harvard University's Center for Middle Eastern Studies will resign after an internal investigation into his acceptance of research funds from the Central Intelligence Agency, the school disclosed today.

title: THEATER AS THERAPY: ACTORS HELPING TO HEAL
description: They are plays that will never be reviewed, except by people in select audiences, who may pore over them for days or even weeks, looking for personal messages.

title: O'ROURKE SWORN IN FOR FULL TERM IN WESTCHESTER
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, sworn in today as Westchester County Executive, said the county was in ''great shape'' and that he intended to keep it that way.

title: Global Seeks Offer
description: Global Marine Inc. said it was soliciting cash offers for its oil and gas subsidiary, Challenger Minerals Inc. The company said the offers are being sought in connection with its continuing discussions with creditors regarding an overall debt restructuring. Any sale would be completed only as part of such a restructuring.

title: TEXT OF ADDRESS DELIVERED BY MAYOR KOCH AT HIS THIRD INAUGURATION
description: Following is a transcript of Mayor Koch's inaugural address as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Bridge: A New Essex Bridge Center Opening in Livingston, N.J.
description: After a successful quarter-century in West Orange, N.J., the Essex Bridge Center, one of America's biggest duplicate clubs, has a a new home. It is reopening today in the V.F.W. Building, 95 West Mount Pleasant Avenue in Livingston, N.J.

title: PROVIDENCE MAKES PROGRESS
description: Louis Lamoriello, the athletic director at Providence, had no sooner narrowed his search for a new basketball coach last winter when his leading candidate, Rick Pitino, began having second-thoughts. The problems began after Pitino, an assistant with the Knicks at the time, had seen Providence play - and lose - by 19 points.

title: Sri Lanka Restores Bandaranaike's Rights
description: President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka announced today that he was restoring the political rights of his chief rival, who was barred from political activity more than five years ago.

title: TRANSMISSIONS IN SOME G.M. CARS ARE DEFECTIVE, SAFETY GROUP SAYS
description: An automobile safety group said today that automatic four-speed transmissions in many General Motors cars and trucks were defective.

title: HOUSE PANEL ASSAILS AGENCY ON HANDLING OF RIGHTS CASES
description: A House committee today criticized the Reagan Administration's handling of civil rights complaints against schools and colleges.

title: ISRAELIS ASKING WHY ONLY THEY MUST RETALIATE
description: Israeli officials expressed satisfaction today with America's apparent support for retaliation over the Rome and Vienna airport attacks, but raised questions about why Israel alone should bear the burden for responding to international terrorism.

title: Destination Belize
description: President Reagan has chosen an experienced diplomat, James L. Malone, as the next Ambassador to Belize, a small nation of potentially strategic importance in Central America.

title: TEXAS A&M STOPS JACKSON AND AUBURN
description: For most teams, a bowl game represents an end, the culmination of a season's worth of efforts and achievements. But for Texas A&M, today's bowl game may have been a beginning.

title: A 15th-Century Copy Of Plutarch Is Stolen
description: A leather-bound copy of ''Plutarch's Lives,'' printed on cream parchment in Venice in 1478, was stolen from a library near this English Midlands city, the police said today.

title: Run to Draddy
description: Vince Draddy of Eugene, Ore., won by 210 yards over Tom Birch of Stamford, Conn., in the New York Road Runners Club midnight race in Central Park. Draddy's time for the five-mile event was 23 minutes 45 seconds.

title: Israel Holds Five Arabs After West Bank Raid
description: Israeli troops raided homes in the West Bank Tuesday night and detained five Palestinians under administrative orders signed by the military governor.

title: Smart Kids Worry More About Nuclear War
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A map Dec. 28 with a dispatch from Spain about the village of Palomares, where three unarmed hydrogen bombs accidentally fell Jan. 17, 1966, incorrectly located the town. It is on the Mediterranean coast 100 miles east of Granada, not near Seville.

title: MUSIC: PEACE CONCERT AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE
description: THE 1985 New Year's Eve Concert for Peace at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine offered a mixture of inspired music-making, muddy acoustics and an earnest solemnity.

title: 'Star Wars' - a Way of Going It Alone
description: Of all the issues that we as a nation will face in the coming year, no single decision is likely to be as significant as what we do about ''Star Wars.''

title: The Art of Public-Interest Lobbying
description: For eight years the Children's Defense Fund had been urging Congress, with little success, to broaden the scope of the Medicaid program to include married mothers and their children. When the issue finally came to a critical point in a House-Senate conference last year, the defense fund turned to a new group, the Advocacy Institute, for help.

title: China Stresses Economy In New Year's Editorial
description: A New Year's editorial in People's Daily said today that China would concentrate on consolidating and adjusting its economic changes this year, and prepare to take them another step forward in 1987.

title: Arranging to Lose
description: One of the most difficult challenges for U.S. foreign policy in this age is to understand and adjust when the ground of power begins to shift in a third-world country. One example, Iran, is enough to show how seriously American interests may be hurt if we get it wrong.

title: Joseph E. McLean, 70, Dies; Former New Jersey Official
description: Joseph E. McLean, a professor of politics and public affairs and a former New Jersey official, died Monday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville after a series of strokes. He was 70 years old and lived in Charlottesville.

title: NEW YORK TRIBUNE RESUMES PUBLISHING AFTER 4-MONTH GAP
description: The New York City Tribune, a daily newspaper owned by associates of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, resumed publication after a four-month hiatus yesterday with a 12-page issue featuring new typefaces, smaller headlines and revamped design.

title: Post Foundation Sells Its Mansion to Trump
description: The developer Donald Trump has acquired Mar-a-Lago, the mansion once owned by Majorie Meriweather Post, from the Post Foundation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review yesterday of the New York City Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' contained some transposed paragraphs. A corrected version is on page C16.

title: THRIFT UNIT HOME MORTGAGES EXCEED BOOK VALUE
description: For the first time in six years, the value of residential mortgages held by the nation's thrift institutions is greater than their book value, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Steel Imports Dropped in '85
description: Steel importers said that foreign shipments declined 7.8 percent over the first 11 months of 1985 and 23 percent in November from the equivalent periods in 1984, but American producers said the levels were still too high.

title: Nuns Sue Union Over Land Sale
description: A group of nuns has sued the pension fund trustees of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, contending that land it bought from the trustees for a children's camp and school contains toxic chemicals. The suit seeks the removal of the substances as a ''severe and present danger'' to the ground water.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Watch in Afghanistan
description: Of Mikhail Gorbachev's inheritances, the sorriest is the war in Afghanistan, begun by Leonid Brezhnev six years ago and implacably pressed by two aging successors. The Kremlin insists that ''foreign intervention'' perpetuates the conflict. But that fiction finds no takers outside the Soviet bloc, as shown by repeated votes at the United Nations. The one scant hope is that the new Soviet leader will reach for the available settlement before the war is unmistakably Gorbachev's quagmire.

title: Amy Newmark Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Louise Newmark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Newmark of Chappaqua, N.Y., and London, was married yesterday to Philip J. Damiano, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Damiano of New Fairfield, Conn. Justice Richard W. Wallach of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Ella Newmark, in New York.

title: Traveling Wives
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: A MUSICAL COLLABORATION IN HOMAGE TO AMERICA
description: To celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, one of the nation's most distinguished composers has joined with one of its most noted poets to create ''On Freedom's Ground: An American Cantata.''

title: Griesa Gets Times Sq. Case
description: If there were two major factors in the demise of Westway, they might be the court decisions handed down against the project in 1982 and last year by Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Aftershocks for Warner
description: The failure of Cincinnati-based Home State Savings Bank last March touched off a crisis that sent tremors through world financial markets -the dollar dipped and gold soared -and led to the temporary closing of 70 other Ohio thrift institutions in the most extensive bank holiday since the Depression. Those shock waves have subsided, but for Marvin L. Warner, the Cincinnati financier who owned controlling interest in Home State, the repercussions are still being felt.

title: VIETNAMESE REVIVING A CHICAGO SLUM
description: Four years ago Argyle Street in the heart of this city's rundown Uptown area resembled a ghost town after dark. Its commercial life was dominated by pimps, prostitutes and drug pushers who assembled on unlit, crumbling sidewalks to ply their trades.

title: To a Third Term, Modestly
description: New York and its triumphant third-term Mayor have reasons for pride this morning, but also modesty. Mayor Koch's inaugural address takes appropriate satisfaction in recovery from the fiscal crisis of a decade ago; the city's spirit and much of its deteriorating plant are, as promised, on the mend. Yet what remains undone, and often imprecisely defined, poses a still greater challenge, even as the Mayor's sway over state and Federal officials seems to be weakening.

title: A SURGE OF VOLUME FOR UNDERWRITERS
description: Wall Street raised more capital for corporate America in 1985 than in any previous year.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Air Raid And Exchange Accusations
description: Iraq and Iran mounted bombing raids today and accused each other of attacking civilian targets in renewed aerial activity in their five-year-old war.

title: MANY TRY TO MAKE DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CASES A TRADITION
description: The beginning of a new year and concern for the needy may have started a new tradition for many families, that of contributing annually to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: IN BRITISH COUNTRY HOUSES, THE ILLUSION OF PERFECTION
description: NO one who has been to see ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington will ever again think of Britain in quite the same way. What we see in the National Gallery is Britain tidied up, polished, perfected, nursed along and dressed up in silks, satins and cashmeres. We can spend all day in the show and not see a dull or an ugly thing, give or take a specimen here and there of high Victoriana.

title: The Bureaucracy The Science (Ha!) Of Quality Statistics
description: If the industry of this capital city is government, its chief product may well be statistics.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: REINHOLD NIEBUHR. A Biography. By Richard Wightman Fox. 340 pages.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I believe that one of the main results of my meeting with President Reagan is that, as leaders and as human beings, we were able to take the first steps toward overcoming mistrust and to activate the factor of confidence. The gap dividing us is still wide, to bridge it will not be easy, but we saw in Geneva that it can be done.''

title: Family Life Program Refocuses Public Discussion
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Hostage Case Leads to Second Body
description: The police today found the body of a youth a heroin addict said he had killed before the addict was slain by a police sharpshooter in a hostage situation.

title: Soviet Squad Tops Blues, 4-2
description: Sergei Babinov scored on a deflection to snap a 1-1 tie late in the second period, and Nikolai Drozdetski scored 80 seconds later, leading the Soviet Red Army hockey team to a 4-2 victory tonight over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AN addition to the late-night scene on the Upper East Side is Caffe Biffi, a rakish Italian bar and restaurant at 251 East 84th Street. It is worth knowing about if you are looking for a lively spot for an after-dinner drink or liqueur-spiked espresso.

title: New Jersey Symphony
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will play music by Prokofiev, Bartok, Rimsky-Korsakov and Bartok tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 at Symphony Hall in Newark.

title: Is 1986 Necessary?
description: For anyone who survived 1984, 1985 etc., it's not hard to predict what will happen in 1986:

title: U.S. SEEKS TO REVAMP RADIATION EXPOSURE LIMITS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed the first major revision in its radiation exposure limits in nearly 30 years. The agency cited improved knowledge of radiation's health effects as the reason for seeking the changes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 3, 1986
description: International

title: STAGE: 'SHOP ON MAIN STREET,' AT JEWISH REPERTORY
description: TO say an unkind word about ''The Shop on Main Street,'' which is playing at the Jewish Repertory Theater, is like being rude to somebody's grandmother. But, then, not everybody's grandmother has to be on the stage.

title: BILL VEECK, BASEBALL INNOVATOR, DIES
description: Bill Veeck, the baseball impresario who once sent a midget to bat as a pinch-hitter for the St. Louis Browns, died yesterday in Chicago at the age of 71 after a 45-year career as one of the most creative and provocative promoters in sports.

title: AT KENNEDY, TON OF MAIL IS UP IN SMOKE
description: More than a ton of mail packed in an air-cargo container was damaged or destroyed Tuesday night at Kennedy International Airport, and Postal Service inspectors said yesterday that it was apparently a strange case of friction-induced spontaneous combustion.

title: Advertising; Oklahoma Agency Gets Food & Wine Account
description: Food & Wine From France, based in New York, has moved the advertising responsibilities of its wine and spirits operation to Ackerman & McQueen Advertising in Oklahoma City from TBWA Advertising in New York.

title: AQUINO SAYS SHE WOULD PERMIT COMMUNISTS IN HER GOVERNMENT
description: Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition candidate, campaigned today in a political stronghold of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and said she would allow Communists into a coalition government if they agreed to renounce violence.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 3, 1986
description: Companies

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Loss for Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it lost $34.8 million in the second quarter ended Dec. 15, in contrast to earnings of $8.5 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales slumped 17.5 percent, to $359.4 million, from $435.4 million. The company attributed the loss to ''reduced demand and pricing pressures.''

title: Articles and Morals
description: Moral Majority, which has chosen not to use ''the'' as a prefix, is changing its name to something that sounds a little less self-annointed.

title: The Jazz Messengers
description: The drummer Art Blakey is leading his quintet, the Jazz Messengers, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Grove Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Uganda Curbs Reports On Its Security Forces
description: Uganda imposed censorship today on news about its security forces amid new rebel accusations that Government troops were continuing to kill civilians.

title: Gramm-Rudman Meets Justice-Justice
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese has a twist on Voltaire, who disapproved of what you said but would defend to the death your right to say it. Mr. Meese agrees with 12 members of Congress that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law is unconstitutional. But he denies their right to say so in court.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a.-Not available due to New Year's Day holiday * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dart Throwers on L.I.
description: More than 1,000 dart throwers will take aim this weekend during the Bud Light Long Island Dart Open at the Marriot Hotel, 101 James Doolittle Boulevard, Uniondale, L.I. Men and women will compete for $10,000 in prizes in a variety of matches, beginning with doubles contests tonight at 8:30.

title: Utility Leaseback
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it had completed a $325 million sale and leaseback of its majority interest in Unit One of the Palo Verde nuclear generation station.

title: FOR SOUTH ASIAN IMMIGRANTS, NEWSSTANDS FULFILL A DREAM
description: It was six years ago, Bawnesh Kapoor recalled recently, that a compatriot from India met him at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas and confided that he was about to give up his career as an accountant.

title: U.N. REPORT LINKS TRAFFIC IN NARCOTICS TO LATIN TERRORISM
description: Drug abuse remains a serious problem around the world, and in Latin America the narcotics trade finances gun running, terrorism and other crimes, said a United Nations report issued today.

title: Temple Hires Theokas
description: Charles Theokas resigned as commissioner of the Atlantic 10 Conference to become director of athletics at Temple University, school officials announced. Theokas, 47 years old, succeeds Gavin White Jr., who resigned to return to teaching at Temple.

title: Walter Van der Waag, Ex-President of Bank
description: Walter E. Van der Waag, former president and chief executive officer of the National Bank of North America, now the National Westminster Bank USA, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 75 years old and lived in Altadena, Calif.

title: Article 787386 -- No Title
description: A $99 one-way cross-country air fare - marked down to $65 for those 65 years of age and older - was announced yesterday by Continental Airlines, which called the ''senior citizen'' fare the lowest transcontinental fare ever offered. The fares are subject to various restrictions. Continental said the fares would apply to about half the 5 million seats the airline has available on all its routes during the two-month period of the promotion, from next Tuesday through March 5. Confusion and Busy Signals

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including net gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $88,000 for the quarter and $170,000 for the year. c-Including a net gain of $352,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Dining Out Guide: Fish and Seafood
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE BARKING FISH CAFE, #705 Eighth Avenue, near 45th Street (757-0186) -

title: Problem Fixed, Shuttle Is to Take Off Monday
description: The steering problem that canceled an orbital flight by the space shuttle Columbia 15 seconds before a scheduled launching last month has been traced to a tiny electrical component that led ground computers astray, officials of the National Aeroanautics and Space Administration said today.

title: CARBIDE TO SELL UNIT AS DEFENSE
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, acting after the GAF Corporation offered to raise its bid for the chemical company to $5.5 billion, announced plans yesterday to sell its consumer businesses for an estimated $2 billion and to distribute the proceeds to stockholders.

title: THE STOP-AND-GO RENEWAL OF THE ARCHIVES BUILDING
description: Eight years ago the Rockrose Development Corporation was chosen from among several contenders to be the developer of the Federal Archives, a landmark building in the West Village.

title: The Challenge for, and to, General Zia
description: Pakistan's President Zia has a problem. He wants respect but he also wants to rule indefinitely. So a year ago, in a bid to legitimize his regime, he ran for a five-year term, without opposition.

title: NATIONAL CRITICS VOTE 'RAN' BEST FILM
description: Akira Kurosawa's ''Ran,'' an epic Japanese interpretation of ''King Lear,'' was voted the best film of 1985 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 43-member group representing critics from New York, Los Angeles, Boston, Chicago and other cities. The group voted Vanessa Redgrave best actress for her performance in ''Wetherby'' and Jack Nicholson best actor for ''Prizzi's Honor.''

title: PITT REAPS REWARDS OF BUILDING YEARS
description: Four seasons after joining the Big East Conference, Pitt, once called the conference's team of the future, believes that its future is now.

title: Demise of a Bakery
description: A mother struggled through the door with a two-seat pram yesterday, its occupants peacefully asleep. She read the sign posted above the mocha mousse cakes.

title: REAGAN ACCUSES SOVIET OF AIDING LATIN TERRORISTS
description: President Reagan accused the Soviet Union and Cuba today of aiding terrorist movements in the Western Hemisphere, saying the link is ''becoming increasingly clear.''

title: ST. JOHN'S TOPS PROVIDENCE IN OVERTIME
description: St. John's had seen the films all week, and they had been warned by Coach Lou Carnesecca that this was not the same Providence team that they had routed three times last year. So they worked on beating Providence's relentless full-court pressure and practiced aga of the Friars' trapping defense.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Monday about foreign investment in the United States incorrectly described the founding of The Washington Times. The newspaper was started not by the Unification Church itself but by New World Communications, a holding company owned by church members and officials.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: DANNY GLOVER recently got a letter from a school friend, describing audience response to ''The Color Purple.'' The friend informed him that there was a point at which it seemed that every woman in the audience wanted to kill Mr. Glover. For the actor, that was a compliment of sorts, because it is a measure of how well he plays the wife-beating villain known as ''Mr.'' in Alice Walker's novel. Mr. Glover's performance is convincing enough to have induced his wife's aunt to tell him she felt like slapping him.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 15
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $2.1 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $1.1 million for the quarter and $5 million for the 6 months.

title: ICAHN IS CLOSING IN ON T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn is about to achieve his long-sought goal, control of Trans World Airlines, but the prize has lost much of its luster because of the carrier's deepening losses.

title: Ski Fall Injures Official Of Software Publishing
description: Fred Gibbons, a founding partner and chief executive of the Software Publishing Corporation, is recovering from a skiing accident on Dec. 22 that paralyzed his left side, the company said yesterday.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF INVITATION TO JOIN 'PIZZA CONNECTION'
description: A key witness testified yesterday that a Sicilian Mafia member had invited him to invest in heroin trafficking that used ''pizza parlors here in America.''

title: RUSSIAN TO CONDUCT THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that Yuri Temirkanov, artistic director and chief conductor of the Kirov Opera in Leningrad, will replace the ailing Klaus Tennstedt for the orchestra's concerts on Jan. 9, 10, 11 and 14 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Topics; Fruesday's Child Market Triumph
description: Every day the U.S. Treasury tracks tax collections, the national debt and assorted Federal trust accounts with two bewildering pages of numbers. Among them appears one statistic of critical importance to certain connoisseurs: the Government's daily cash balance.

title: Turks Kill 4 Iranians
description: Turkish border patrol troops shot four Iranians to death as suspected smugglers as they were trying to cross into Turkey illegally, the independent news agency Hurriyet Haber Ajansi reported today.

title: AUCTION
description: SEIJIRO MATSUOKA, a Japanese real-estate entrepreneur, flew in from Tokyo last month to bid at Sotheby's and Christie's for Chinese porcelains, paintings and ancient bronzes, which he has been collecting for 66 years.

title: Permit for Ihnacak
description: Miroslav Ihnacak, one of the top forwards in Czechoslovak hockey, has been granted a special immigration permit by Canada and should soon be joining his older brother, Peter Ihnacak, on the Toronto Maple Leafs. Ihnacak, who was drafted by the Maple Leafs in 1982 and defected last weekend, became concerned for his safety while waiting with his fiancee in Vienna for permission to enter Canada.

title: An Arms Briefing
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and a team of his top arms control advisers were given a daylong secret briefing at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California last Friday. The group received technical background information in support of President Reagan's proposal for a space-based missile defense system and in opposition to the Soviet proposal for a moratorium on underground nuclear weapons testing.

title: Bill Hardman Quartet
description: The trumpeter Bill Hardman is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, above 22d Street (242-9066). The first set begins at 10 P.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: LOSING BIDDER IN SALE OF NEWS AGENCY SUES WINNER FOR $975 MILLION
description: A would-be buyer of United Press International filed suit today against the successful bidder for the news service, its present management, its major union and its unsecured creditors.

title: VISIONTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: The latest year results include nonrecurring charges of about $2.9 million, of which about $1.3 million was taken in the third quarter for writeoff of a Canadian marketing operation, writeoff of prepaid royalties, closing of a California manufacturing facilities and a reserve for severance payments and closing costs.

title: Dept. of Surplus Military Goodies
description: Sometimes it may seem that the main business of the Pentagon is buying things. But it sells a few things, too.

title: Perilous Waters
description: Chuck Grillo, a 5-foot-10-inch, 250-pound scout for the New York Rangers, expounds on a summertime dislike: ''I don't go near the water. I'm afraid I'll get harpooned.''

title: U.S. SENDING AIDES TO HANOI BUT STILL RESISTS TIES
description: Although the United States is sending a high-level delegation to Hanoi next week, there has been no visible movement toward formal diplomatic relations.

title: New Yorker Slain in San Juan
description: A New York City man was shot to death early today in a robbery at the San Juan Hotel and his wife was wounded, the police said. The New Yorker, Max Chaiken, and his wife, Paula, were stopped at 1:30 A.M. by an armed man on the stairs of the hotel and taken to the laundry room, according to the police, who said Mr. Chaiken was shot five times and robbed of $3,000. Mrs. Chaiken was hospitalized.

title: Working Profile: Representative Mike Synar; From the Annals of Chutzpah and Jurisprudence
description: Representative Mike Synar is the author of a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a new law that would require a balanced Federal budget by 1991. Only nine years ago he was a student at the University of Oklahoma and making a grade of B minus in a constitutional law course.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S now definite. Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy will return to Broadway in April in Brian Clark's new play, ''The Petition.'' The drama, by the author of ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' concerns a retired British general who discovers that his wife has publicly endorsed an antinuclear petition that he strongly opposes. The confrontation and various goings-on will be directed by Sir Peter Hall and take place at an as yet unannounced Shubert theater. Robert Whitehead and the Shubert Organization are producing, and the official opening date is April 24.

title: U.S. PUTS PRESSURE ON ALLIES TO JOIN LIBYAN SANCTIONS
description: The United States again urged Western European nations today to follow the American lead and impose economic and political sanctions against Libya for its purported support of terrorist groups.

title: DOLLAR OFF SHARPLY IN NEW YORK
description: The dollar began the new year on a decidedly bearish note, falling sharply in New York yesterday in a resumption of a steep, weeklong slide.

title: Suspect Held in Seizure Of Arms in New Zealand
description: A cook suspected of hiding an arms cache aboard a French freighter headed for New Caledonia was arrested today and charged with possession of explosives, the police said.

title: China Oil Output Up
description: China's 1985 crude oil production totaled 124.8 million tons - about 911 million barrels - 5.3 percent more than the 1984 output, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BLACK CINEMA: TURNING POINT ''The L.A. Rebellion'' was born in the 1970's of a protest over the way Hollywood portrayed blacks. It was led by a group of young black film makers, centered at the University of California at Los Angeles, who believed they could make movies with language, imagery and settings that offered a more honest vision of black life. The best of their work, both short and feature-length films, has been collected for a series titled ''The L.A. Rebellion: A Turning Point in Black Cinema'' that opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street. ''Child of Resistance,'' a 1972 film by the Ethiopian-born Haile Gerima that is based on a dream about the imprisonment of Angela Davis, the black activist, will be shown today and Saturday at noon, and Sunday at 1. It is to be followed by ''I and I: An African Allegory,'' a 1977 work by Ben Caldwell that examines the effects of modern, urban life in America on black spirituality and political thinking. Larry Clark's 1977 film ''Passing Through,'' about jazz, will be screened today and Saturday at 2:30, and Sunday at 3:30. More films will be shown beginning next Thursday, with screenings daily except Mondays through Jan. 19. Admission is covered by a regular ticket for the museum - $3 for adults, $1.50 for the elderly and free for college students with I.D. cards. Information: 570-0537.

title: NICARAGUA MAY BE ON AGENDA
description: When President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico meet Friday for a half day of talks in the Mexican border city of Mexicali, their discussions are expected to include the situation in Central America - particularly the United States stand toward Nicaragua, and Mexico's role in the region.

title: Paul Haskins Marries Judith Isabelle Hyman
description: Judith Isabelle Hyman, an English teacher at the West Side High School in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Paul J. Haskins, an editor on the national news desk of The New York Times. Judge Elizabeth Zumwalt of the San Diego County Superior Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's sister, Dr. Sally Laura Hyman, in La Jolla, Calif.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DEBORAH YOUNG, in a white puffed-sleeve gown, was the last debutante in the Hotel Plaza receiving line, but it didn't bother her at all. ''I'm last because I'm Young,'' she said. ''Young, Y, not young, although I'm young too.''

title: Unkind Hosts
description: In three weeks, the Detroit Red Wings have a game against the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum. Who do you like? Detroit, no doubt, if you believe in the long-overdue underdog.

title: The High Cost of Doctors as Expert Witnesses
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGAL HELP TAILORED TO VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: On one recent afternoon, 11 Manila file folders were lined up neatly on a glass table in Mark Senak's office at the Gay Men's Health Crisis. Each one had a man's name written on the outside. On the inside, each one contained a newly drafted will, drawn up for someone with AIDS.

title: Chile Recovers Bodies Of 8 American Tourists
description: Chilean Air Force personnel today recovered the bodies of eight American tourists who died on New Year's Eve when the chartered plane in which they were traveling crashed on an Antarctic glacier, officials said.

title: In the Name of Sanity, Don't Tax Imported Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSSY GETS 500TH, RALLIES ISLANDERS
description: When the game was over - and it didn't end until Mike Bossy made history by scoring his 500th goal in the final minute - the New York Islanders had beaten the Boston Bruins, 7-5, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: COURT TEST SEEN FOR MIDCON DEAL
description: A partnership headed by the privately held Wagner & Brown may challenge in court the lock-up agreements granted to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation by the Midcon Corporation as part of their merger accord, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: ERRING TEST MISSILE TAKEN MOSTLY IN STRIDE IN FLORIDA AREA TIED TO MILITARY
description: When the Pentagon disclosed plans for a series of test flights of unarmed Tomahawk cruise missiles over the Florida Panhandle and southern Alabama, it said the odds against a malfunctioning missile's raining death and destruction on the populace below were a quadrillion to one.

title: G.M. Car Import
description: The General Motors Corporation said that the subcompact economy car it will begin importing next year from South Korea will be called the Pontiac Le Mans. The tiny car is scheduled to be imported in 1987 as a 1988 model. G.M.'s Pontiac division has not given dates or said how many cars would be imported, although industry sources said the number might exceed 100,000 annually. It was designed by G.M.'s West German subsidiary, Adam Opel A.G. Daewoo Group Ltd., which is 50 percent owned by G.M., will build the car.

title: A.M.C. Head In Renault Post
description: The president of the American Motors Corporation, Jose Dedeurwaerder, was given additional duties today as a top officer of the French auto maker Renault, which owns 46.1 percent of A.M.C.'s stock.

title: Ramirez at West End
description: Ram Ramirez, the pianist who composed the Billie Holiday song ''Lover Man,'' is leading a quintet through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: CHILDBIRTH DEATHS FOR OLDER WOMEN DECLINE 50%
description: The death rate from pregnancy-related causes among women 35 years and older has dropped nearly 50 percent in recent years, a study shows, but women that age are still three times as likely to die from such causes.

title: Economic Scene; Lost Standing Of Economists
description: IN his presidential address to the American Economic Association this week, Charles F. Kindleberger, Ford International Professor of Economics emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the United States had lost the appetite for providing the world with what he called ''international economic public goods.''

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LAST month's opening of the Ritz Cafe on Park Avenue, sister of a glittery establishment in Los Angeles, is one of the best-kept secrets around. Nearly two months old, this handsome Art Deco Cajun-Creole restaurant, on the site of the ill-fated La Coupole, is a lonely spot at night. This is curious indeed, for the Ritz Cafe has more going for it than many lesser places that were standing-room-only the first week - including some intriguing food.

title: Guarneri String Quartet
description: The Guarneri String Quartet will continue its survey of the complete Beethoven quartets at the Metropolitan Museum tomorrow night at 8. The program will include the Quartet in C minor (Op. 18, No. 4), the Quartet in F (Op. 18, No. 1) and the Quartet in C-sharp minor (Op. 131). Admission is $14; information: 570-3949.

title: Skier Out of Coma
description: Christine Putz, the 19-year-old skier who was hospitalized in a coma three weeks ago after falling during a World Cup downhill race, has regained consciousness and is making satisfactory progress, her mother said yesterday in Innsbruck, Austria. Elisabeth Putz said in a telephone interview that her daughter awoke from the coma Wednesday.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: GEORGETOWN UPSET
description: Villanova shook off a poor first-half performance and defeated Seton Hall, 62-56, in the teams' Big East conference opener tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Tuesday misstated Richard L. Gelb's title and rendered his company's name incorrectly. Mr. Gelb is chairman and chief executive officer of the Bristol-Myers Company.

title: Women's Work
description: To the Editor:

title: SAMPLING FINE WINES, A VINTAGE TOUR
description: AS recently as 18 months ago, wine enthusiasts who wanted to make comparative tastings - say, three or more California chardonnays from the 1981 vintage - had to go out and buy three bottles at a liquor store and try them at home. A handful of bars in town offered a range of wines by the glass, but they were mostly low-key neighborhood places. And the typical house wines s and bars were limited to an inoffensive and inconsequential white paired with an overchilled, underwhelming red.

title: SEQUENTIAL INFORMATION SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
He Didn't Mind
description: Steve Nelson, as macho as a linebacker should be, explains why he didn't miss a down of New England's playoff victory over the Jets despite separating his shoulder midway through the game: ''It didn't really pop out. It just moved around a little.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Celtics, at Boston Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Nets defeated the Celtics in the teams' season opener, but when Boston visited the Meadowlands Dec. 4, the visitors won by 130-111 and Darryl Dawkins was ejected.

title: In the Name of Sanity, Don't Tax Imported Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Taking On Bigger Job At D.D.B.
description: LAST month, on Friday the 13th -''the luckiest day of my business life'' - Peter Falcone became president of Doyle Dane Bernbach/ New York, the flagship operation of the worldwide, publicly held company. He said yesterday during an interview that his change of status from vice chairman of the domestic company would not affect his activities as a new-business seeker. It is a pursuit that has been particularly rewarding for the agency in the last 15 months.

title: PATTERN PROCESSING TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 22, 1985, in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend distributed to shareholders.

title: Topics; Fruesday's Child Honeymoon Over
description: The in-flight movie began as a freebie. Then the airlines started charging for the headphones. Now air travelers also have to sit through a string of commercials before the show.

title: GOOD DAY CARE - A NATIONAL NEED
description: The other day, I had a long conversation with Susan Weissman, the director of the day-care center that my 4-year-old daughter has attended since she was 6 months old. For the past several years, Susan has run three private not-for-profit day-care centers in Manhattan. Each year, she has lost money, and each year she has made up the difference herself. She is a woman who is deeply committed to day care, energetic and usually buoyant. But when we spoke recently, Susan could not hide her despair about the future of day-care.

title: IRISH DAUGHTERS NOW JOIN IN THE MUSIC
description: IRISH traditional music runs in families. Children are welcome at the community dances called ceilidhs and at the informal jam sessions called seisuns, where musicians get together to strike up traditional jigs and hornpipes and reels, trading and reclaiming the thousands of tunes in the traditional repertory. At the homes of musicians, traditional melodies are in the air, ready to be picked up by attentive youngsters; tunes are passed by ear, in a continuity that is centuries old.

title: U.S. ACTS TO BLOCK MASSACHUSETTS CURB ON SUBPOENAS TO LAWYERS
description: The United States Attorney for Massachusetts is suing in Federal District Court here to try to block a new Massachusetts state court rule that would discipline prosecutors for subpoenaing defense lawyers without prior judicial approval.

title: U.S. Pilot Crashes in Iceland
description: A United States Air Force F-15C plane crashed today in icy waters in a routine training flight off Iceland and the pilot was presumed dead, a military spokesman said.

title: THE HANDKERCHIEF: A POCKETFUL OF FASHION
description: ''Is that a new style, or what?'' the young man recently asked, pointing to the white linen handkerchief sticking out from the breast pocket of the middle-aged man's pin-striped navy blue suit.

title: LIBYA AND EUROPE: OUTRAGE BUT NO SANCTIONS
description: The political influence of Libya in Western Europe has begun to weaken as a result of its purported sponsorship of terrorists and the collapse of oil prices, diplomatic and political sources in various capitals say.

title: 'The Big Boys'
description: Ralph Nader, whose theory that consumers have a right to safe and effective products won him both admirers and detractors, has a new book due out this spring. Published by Pantheon, the book, ''The Big Boys,'' contains full-length profiles of nine corporate chief executive officers.

title: Nets Denied New Guard
description: The National Basketball Association yesterday turned down the Nets' request to add a guard to their roster to replace Micheal Ray Richardson, who is undergoing treatment at the Pasadena Community Hospital drug center in California.

title: DISCREPANCIES ARE SEEN IN BHOPAL COURT PAPERS
description: Court documents recently made public show a series of discrepancies in statements by the Union Carbide Corporation about whether the ill-fated Bhopal pesticide plant was controlled by corporate headquarters in the United States or by its Indian subsidiary in Bombay.

title: BRONX CLAMS MOVED TO L.I. TO REVIVE BAYMEN'S TRADE
description: Every Tuesday and Thursday from now until spring, this tranquil harbor is likely to be crowded with baymen in small skiffs harvesting some very special clams.

title: THE SCREEN: 'UFORIA,' A COMEDY, FINALLY ARRIVES
description: WHEN first seen, Sheldon (Fred Ward), an unshaven, cheerfully disreputable con-artist, is cruising down a lonely desert highway in a convertible that definitely looks to have been preowned. He drives with one hand, swigs from a can of beer held in the other, his right foot resting comfortably on the dashboard - the dreary landscape alive with the ear-splitting sounds of a country-and-western tune.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $954 million for the quarter and year and tax credits of $349 million for the quarter and $145 million for the year. c-Net income The pre-tax charge is related to realignment of CSX's transportation and natural resources businesses into four strategic areas, a writedown of Sales 3,622,526 2,177,708 Net loss 956,297 1,828,981 Yr sales 16,770,609 16,150,929 Net loss 1,993,586 3,202,456 The year-ago loss is after a gain of $1,261,356 primarily from the disposition of assets.

title: GAULT IS HOPING TO CHANNEL HIS SPEED
description: Speed kills. Ask any cornerback. Better yet, watch how far back he lines up against one of those track stars-turned-wide-receivers, like Ron Brown of the Rams, Phillip Epps of the Packers or Willie Gault of the Bears. Fairly deep, usually. But speed can sometimes hurt the offense. Gault knows all about that. A former Olympic sprinter and world-class hurdler, he can remember plays this season when he outran the pass, simply because his feet got him downfield faster than the quarterback could deliver the ball.

title: Market Place; Occidental's Sudden Move
description: THE Occidental Petroleum Corporation's seemingly sudden move into the natural gas pipeline industry through its agreement to buy the Midcon Corporation for $3 billion has produced sharply differing views of the deal on Wall Street.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTING FOUNDER
description: Hartford N. Gunn Jr., a pioneer in educational television and the founding president of the Public Broadcasting Service, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 59 years old.

title: SWITZER OVERSEES FROM THE SIDELINE
description: He does not climb a tower. In a world in which some stadiums that house college football teams hardly seem big enough to hold the egos of their coaches, Barry Switzer has no pretentions about being a master of the X and the O. A bullhorn is not part of his communication technique at practice, and he does not sprint from unit to unit to correct a mistake or pat a backside. Patting backsides, or treating them otherwise, is for his assistants. At the University of Oklahoma, Barry Switzer oversees.

title: Setting the Moratorium Record Straight
description: For all the hope and expectation it brings in other realms, the turn of the year has been sadly marred by the Reagan Administration's failure to pursue a comprehensive nuclear test ban.

title: Market Begins '86 on the Down Side
description: The stock market started 1986 on a down note yesterday as investors continued to cash in on the record gains garnered in 1985.

title: DELICATE COMIC BALANCE IN COWARD'S 'HAY FEVER'
description: All of us have experienced at some time or other the social agony of trying to make small talk with a stranger. One of the brightest comic moments on Broadway this season is a scene in the revival of Noel Coward's ''Hay Fever,'' in which a stuffy English ''diplomatist'' and an insecure young ''flapper'' arrive simultaneously at an English country house where no one greets them and they must socially fend for themselves. The Blisses, the hosts of what becomes a weekend of social chaos, are just too busy with their own screwball psychodramas to pay proper attention to guests.

title: STAGE: 'FOUNTAIN PEN'
description: ISRAEL HOROVITZ'S ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen'' is small in scope but wide in its appreciation of family values and the yearnings of youth. Drawn from stories by Morley Torgov about a childhood spent in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, the play enlists the audience in its extended circle of friends. Together, we leaf through an album of reminiscences. Directed by Stephen Zuckerman, the play opened last night at the American Jewish Theater.

title: WEEKEND WALKER AND CITY STROLLER TACKLE NEW YORKIANA
description: ARDENT students of New Yorkiana may find it incomprehensible that their beloved city should be framed in any context that includes the word ''trivia,'' but the trivia passion is upon us and the other day the Weekend Walker was carrying a book that alarmed his constant companion, the City Stroller. The name of the paperback was ''Manhattan Trivia, the Ultimate Challenge.''

title: Hubbard at Blue Note
description: The trumpeter Freddie Hubbard is leading a quintet, and the singer Betty Carter will be accompanied by a trio, in double bills through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). There is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $10 charge at the bar.

title: 'THE DEFIANT ONES' IN A TV VERSION
description: You remember ''The Defiant Ones,'' the 1958 movie about a couple of chained-together convicts, one black, one white, who learn during an arduous escape attempt to respect, admire, like and, yes, understand each other.

title: 3M-Harris Venture Fills Top Position
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and the Harris Corporation yesterday announced the formation of a joint venture company for the worldwide marketing, sales and service of copiers and facsimile machines.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday as traders were discouraged by unusually high overnight interest rates and a lack of strong investor demand after the holiday season.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
Artificial Heart Patient Comes Out of Her Coma
description: Mary Lund, the first woman to receive an artificial heart, emerged from her coma today, sitting up and responding to her husband's voice 15 days after the implant, doctors said.

title: Douglas Air's Big Contract
description: The Air Force awarded a $3.4 billion full-scale development contract to the Douglas Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation based in Long Beach, Calif., to continue the development of the C-17A airlifter.

title: New Shekel For Israel
description: Israel has started the new year with a new currency called the New Israeli Shekel, which it hopes will simplify business transactions in an economy plagued by an inflation of 180 percent in the last year. The new shekel, worth 1,000 old shekels, will be exchanged at the rate of 1.5 to the dollar. The Government has said that the change of currency

title: GIANTS HAVE FAITH IN OFFENSIVE LINE
description: The Chicago Bears rank first in the National Football League in total defense and first in rushing defense. Their so-called 46 defense, which puts eight defenders within a step or two of the line of scrimmage, has confused many opponents and led to sacks, turnovers and a 15-1 record.

title: IU's Ryder Unit Sold to Maxitron
description: The IU International Corporation has sold its unprofitable trucking subsidiary, Ryder/PIE Nationwide, to Maxitron Corporation, a Chicago investment firm.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Why do I work here? In the hopes of making it, the same way as everybody else.'' - Mayur Patel, a new immigrant who manages a magazine and tobacco store at Eighth Avenue and 53d Street. [ B2:1. ]

title: Bad News for Cavaliers
description: Phil Hubbard, the 6-foot-8-inch power forward of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has missed five games because of an injury to his right wrist, but now doctors are saying he will be out at least six weeks and maybe for the rest of the season. The wrist, which at first was thought to be sprained, was examined again yesterday at the Cleveland Clinic.

title: A Design Proposal That Would Make Passenger Planes Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: OKLAHOMA GAINS CONSENSUS NO. 1
description: Oklahoma was the consensus selection yesterday as the No. 1 major-college team for 1985, a day after its 25-10 defeat of previously undefeated and top-ranked Penn State in the Orange Bowl.

title: More British Troops In Northern Ireland
description: More British troops arrived in Northern Ireland today amid guerrilla attacks against the police and rising Protestant anger over the British-Irish agreement giving Dublin a say in the future of the province.

title: POLICE IN SEVERAL EUROPEAN CITIES SAID TO HAVE FOILED TERROR PLOTS
description: The police in several European cities appear to have disrupted a number of Arab-backed terrorist plots for assassinations and bombing attacks during the Christmas and New Year holiday period.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $37,826,000 for the quarter and $37,276,000 for the year. c-After non-operating income of $2,316,000.

title: Boyd to Resign At Miss. State
description: Bob Boyd announced his resignation as basketball coach at Mississippi State University just before the Bulldogs' Southeastern Conference opener with Alabama tonight.

title: KOCH SEES NO GAIN FOR CITY SERVICES IN 1986-87 BUDGET
description: New York City's preliminary budget for the coming fiscal year will provide for no improvements in city services, because of expected reductions in Federal aid, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Officer Slays Suspect In Holdup of Taxicab
description: A police officer shot and killed a 25-year-old man who had just wounded a livery-cab driver on the Upper West Side, authorities said yesterday.

title: Walter Bishop Trio
description: The pianist Walter Bishop Jr. will lead a trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, at 29th Street (502-4300), with the guest singer Kathy Farmer. Tomorrow, the pianist Chris Anderson will lead a trio, joined by the singer Lodi Carr. Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; admission is $8.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP IS DEEPLY DIVIDED OVER PROPOSED MOVE
description: A decision by the board of Friends of the Earth to move its headquarters here from San Francisco has caused a deep rift within the environmental group that some of its officials fear threatens its future.

title: WIDE SUBPOENAS ISSUED IN MILITARY BIDDING CASE
description: The lawyers defending three men charged with illegally obtaining Pentagon planning documents for a military contractor to gain a bidding advantage have subpoenaed nearly 100 Defense Department employees to try to prove that circulation of such information was common practice in the arms industry.

title: Baldwin Pact With Creditors
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a group of creditors to settle more than $500 million in loans made in 1982 to Balunit Inc., a Baldwin-United subsidiary, in connection with the acquisition of the MGIC Investment Corporation. The company said the agreement, which was approved by a Federal bankruptcy court, would probably clear any obstacles to Baldwin-United's reorganization.

title: U.S. SAYS SPY SUSPECT HAD ACCESS TO HIGHLY CLASSIFIED DATA
description: A retired Central Intelligence Agency analyst charged with espionage had access to highly classified information gathered by covert American intelligence agents, the Justice Department said today.

title: Back to Mir i Druzhba
description: It is pathetic to have to celebrate the five-minute appearances of Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev on Soviet and American television screens. That their polite New Year's exchange should be a noteworthy diplomatic event is testament only to how low the relationship has sunk. Toasts to mir i druzhba, peace and friendship, sounded corny a generation ago. The exchange of uncensored television time between heads of government seemed banal a decade ago. Here we go again - yet it sure beats the alternative.

title: Curatorial Adviser, 89, Gets Smithsonian Medal
description: Adelyn Dohme Breeskin, the 89-year-old senior curatorial adviser at the National Museum of American Art, a bureau of the Smithsonian Institution, has been awarded the Secretary's Gold Medal for Exceptional Service.

title: 12 ARRESTED AS DRIVE IS BEGUN TO CURB USE OF SLUGS IN SUBWAYS
description: Twelve commuters were arrested yesterday as the transit police, aware that a rise in fares usually meant more people would try to avoid paying, began a crackdown against the use of slugs on the city's subways.

title: CENTRUST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of investments of $13,472,000 for the quarter and $37,039,000 for the year and gains on the sale of loans and loan servicing of $6,072,000 for the quarter and $90,823,000 for the year. c-Including gains on the sale of investments of $2,746,000 for the quarter and $24,169,000 for the year and gains on the sale of loans and loan servicing of $5,303,000 for the quarter and $117,499,000 for the year. Results for the latest periods reflect loan loss provisions of $397,000 for the quarter and $1,197,000 for the year. Year-ago results reflect loan loss provisions of $232,000 for the quarter and $279,000 for the year. Revenue figures represent interest income.

title: IF IT AIN'T BROKE...
description: Wednesday night's victory by Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl did more than settle the national college football ratings for the 1985 season. It was also a triumph for tradition, a reaffirmation of the charming, anarchic and avaricious system of bowl games.

title: JUDGES END CASES FASTER USING TRIAL ALTERNATIVES
description: Judges around the country are working to end cases faster by calling regular meetings on the status of cases, setting strict trial dates and holding modified trials that may be accepted as final if the parties wish.

title: Malawi Dissolves Cabinet
description: President Kamuzu Banda has dissolved his 13-member Cabinet and personally taken charge of the Government, the semiofficial Malawi press agency reported today.

title: Honoring Unisex Tradition
description: It seems hard to believe now, eight years later. But in 1978, when Carol Bellamy became the first female City Council President, she created a stir with her decision to turn the previously male-only bathroom in her suite of offices at City Hall into a unisex facility.

title: NEW ROOM FOR THE ARTS: KITCHEN GOES 'UPTOWN'
description: ''IT'S otherworldly,'' Caroline Stone said happily of the new Kitchen. This innovative center for new video, music, dance, performance and film has gone ''uptown,'' relocating from SoHo to a building a few steps east of the Hudson River on 19th Street. A dance center burgeoning with trendy nightspots, the area may well be the next SoHo. The building itself is otherworldly, a far cry from the Kitchen's cramped old headquarters. And this weekend the Kitchen will inaugurate its new facilities with ''New Ice Nights,'' two evenings of performances and continuous video screenings.

title: UPSTATE TOWN RESISTING ROLE AS PCB BURIAL SITE
description: A state plan to dredge PCB's from the bottom of the Hudson River has met another snag -the objections of the upstate town selected as the tentative site for burial of the toxic chemicals.

title: Nonmedical Care for Homebound Elderly in Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE NEWSPAPER DIES, BUT RESCUE ATTEMPTS ARE CONTINUING FOR TWO OTHERS
description: By midafternoon on New Year's Eve the newsroom of The Columbus Citizen-Journal in Columbus, Ohio, was silent after publication that morning of the newspaper's last issue.

title: Ratings Restored At Three Utilities
description: Debt ratings on three of four operating companies of Middle South Utilities have been restored, Fitch Investors Service said.

title: No Kickoff For Oklahoma
description: Top-ranked Oklahoma today refused to open its 1986 season at the Meadowlands in the fourth Kickoff Classic. That left a possible matchup between Ohio State and either Alabama or Tennessee, according to a source involved in the selection.

title: 'ON THE RAZZLE' ON 13, A STOPPARD COMEDY
description: THE English-speaking stage has got some extraordinary mileage out of a 19th-century Viennese playwright named Johann Nestroy. His ''Einen Jux Will Er Sich Machen'' (''He's Out for a Fling'') was twice adapted by Thornton Wilder, in 1938 as ''The Merchant of Yonkers'' and in 1954 as ''The Matchmaker,'' which was later used as the basis for the musical ''Hello, Dolly!'' The character of Dolly Levi, it must be said, was entirely Mr. Wilder's invention and Ruth Gordon's triumph.

title: In the Name of Sanity, Don't Tax Imported Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boole & Babbage Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., which sells computer software, has named Bruce T. Coleman president and chief executive officer.

title: CATHOLIC RADIO SHUT FOR INDEFINITE PERIOD BY SANDINISTA ORDER
description: The Government closed the official radio station of the Roman Catholic Church today after the station failed to broadcast most of a year-end message from President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DICKENS AND THE SOCIAL ORDER.

title: ART: 'KERNELS OF ENERGY,' HOW CHINESE SEE ROCKS
description: THE Chinese do not see stone the way Westerners do. Rocks for them are concentrations of energy and life, objects of contemplation and worship, models for human character, microcosms of heaven and earth. In his foreword to the catalogue of ''Kernels of Energy, Bones of Earth: The Rock in Chinese Art,'' at the China House Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, through Jan. 26, Wan-go H. C. Weng, the gallery president, writes that ''if, according to William Blake, a world could be seen in a grain of sand, then the Chinese universe can also be comprehended in a piece of rock.''
