title: A Gillespie Quintet
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie will lead a quintet tonight through Monday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin tonight and tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight, Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. and Monday at 9 and 11 P.M.; there is a $15 cover and a $10 minimum.

title: Durable Flake
description: Those who look forward to the change of seasons may become increasingly confused at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. The sponsors of the giant illuminated snowflake that hangs above the intersection, designed as a seasonal bauble, say they will keep it lighted indefinitely.

title: S.E.C. CENSURES BACHE FOR SUPERVISORY LAPSES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. today for what it described as the firm's failure to supervise employees of the Jacksonville, Fla., and Atlanta branch offices.

title: UNBEATEN MICHIGAN TOPS INDIANA FOR 13TH VICTORY
description: Gary Grant scored 21 points as undefeated Michigan defeated Indiana, 74-69, tonight in the opening Big Ten Conference game. Roy Tarpley, capitalizing on a height advantage inside, scored 20 points for Michigan (13-0).

title: POLYMERIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Plane Landed Intact In Nelson Crash Deaths
description: A smoke-filled plane carrying Ricky Nelson, his fiancee and five band members made a good landing in an East Texas pasture, then burned, officials said tonight.

title: Hart's Announcement
description: About midday tomorrow, Denver time, Senator Gary Hart will tell a news conference in the El Rancho restaurant west of the Colorado capital that he does not intend to seek re-election to a third term next November. Instead, insiders uniformly predict, he plans to devote his political efforts to exploring another attempt at the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988. As evidence of the seriousness of Mr. Hart's ambitions, the Senator's advisers are already debating whether his campaign headquarters should be situated in Denver, emphasizing the candidate's Western roots and independence of Washington, or in Washington, as is more or less customary.

title: BROWNS TO STRESS RUNNING
description: The Cleveland Browns have relied on their running game all season, and they have even more incentive to run the ball in the American Conference semifinal playoff game Saturday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: GORBACHEV ADAMANT ON 'STAR WARS'
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a letter to a British politician made public today, reiterated that progress in arms control ''is possible only if space-strike armaments are completely prohibited.''

title: NEWFOUNDLAND NURTURES ITS OUTLANDISH OLD NOUNS
description: Only a sleveen, shimmick, tissy mawk or grum nunny-fudger could be rafted and harrished by Newfoundland English.

title: TRAFFIC DEATHS TIED TO ALCOHOL DROP IN JERSEY
description: The number of alcohol-related highway deaths in New Jersey decreased by 43 percent from 1981 to 1984, the State Commission on Drunk Driving reported today.

title: TENNESSEE ACCLAIMS DEFENSIVE COACH
description: In his euphoria, Daryl Dickey, the usually low-key Tennessee quarterback, walked around the playing field in the Superdome, holding a football aloft like a trophy for all the Volunteer fans to see. He was joined by Tony Robinson, the preseason all-America candidate, who injured a knee against Alabama in the fifth game and watched Dickey, his understudy, lead Tennessee to the Southeastern Conference championship and a stunning 35-7 victory against Miami in the Sugar Bowl game on New Year's Night.

title: REMEMBRANCES OF VEECK
description: Bill Veeck, the flamboyant former owner of the Chicago White Sox and two other major league teams, was remembered by the baseball world yesterday as a showman whose keen knowledge of and deep devotion to the game was often overshadowed by his own publicity stunts, and as a dedicated executive who cared about winning and profits but who always put the fans first.

title: Study of British Finds 9 of 10 Are Content
description: The average Briton is happy, healthy and prosperous, living in a centrally heated home with a television set, 1.77 children and half of a dog or cat.

title: All Punching, No Skating
description: Ever hear the line, ''I went to a fight last night and a hockey game broke out''? Well, fighting is no laughing matter to Andy Boemer. It's his hobby, as well as a business of sorts.

title: ROCKET AT BORDER HITS ISRAELI TOWN
description: An artillery rocket launched from southern Lebanon struck an Israeli border town overnight, damaging four cars and sending residents fleeing to bomb shelters.

title: ILLNESS INSPIRES DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: The illness of a family member or friend that brings with it an increased awareness of the hardships of the poor who are ill and infirm is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $537,427 and a $700,000 reserve for loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income including a tax credit of $350,000.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Devils sent the defensemen Uli Hiemer and Bruce Driver to the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League today and called up the goalie Sam St. Laurent and the defensemen Ken Danyeko and Randy Velischek. . . . The Milwaukee Bucks named Stu Inman, who had been vice president and general manager of the Portland Trail Blazers, as director of player personnel. The Trail Blazers named Morris (Bucky) Buckwalter to replace Inman as general manager. . . . Four of the world's top high jumpers, including the one-two finishers in the 1985 World Cup - Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden and Jimmy Howard of the United States - have entered the Vitalis-United States Olympic Invitational Track and Field meet scheduled for Feb. 8 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Revisionism
description: At the Atlantic Avenue BMT station in Brooklyn a faded graffito on one of the pillars reads: ''90c for this?''

title: Building Spending Rises 0.5%
description: Construction spending rose five-tenths of 1 percent in November, lifted by strong advances in construction of office buildings and shopping centers, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ADMINISTRATION AWAITS SIGN FROM CONGRESS ON REBEL AID
description: The Reagan Administration will not ask Congress to resume military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels unless it is confident the request will be approved, according to the Administration's top Central American strategist.

title: Clarence Q. Berger, 74, Dies; Ex-Dean and Aide at Brandeis
description: Clarence Quinn Berger, a former dean and executive vice president of Brandeis University, died of pnuemonia Dec. 20 at the Martyrs Hospital in Dublin. He was 74 years old.

title: Volunteers Aplenty
description: Jeanette LePourhiet and Madeleine Ribes have decided to make it an annual event. A year ago, on New Year's Day 1985, when the restaurant they run at 363 West 46th Street would normally be closed, they served free meals to 80 homeless people from the neighborhood.

title: ROBERT SCULL, PROMINENT COLLECTOR OF POP ART
description: Robert C. Scull, the taxi tycoon who assembled a world-famous collection of Pop and Minimal art in the 1960's, died Wednesday night at his home in Warren, Conn., of complications from diabetes. He was 70 years old.

title: INFODATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $273,414.

title: WAYNE LONERGAN, 67, KILLER OF HEIRESS WIFE
description: Wayne Thomas Lonergan, convicted, in one of the most sensational trials of the 1940's, of the slaying of his wife, Patricia, heiress to a New York beer fortune, died yesterday in his native Toronto at the age of 67.

title: Arafat Terms Reagan A 'Robot' and 'Parrot'
description: Yasir Arafat was quoted today as having said that President Reagan is ''a robot and a parrot who has no logic or principles.''

title: ARTERY FAVORED FOR BYPASSES
description: An artery works far better than a vein for replenishing the heart's blood supply in coronary bypass operations, according to a study that compared the long-term results of the two methods.

title: Raiders Relax Blackout Rule
description: The deadline for lifting the local television blackout for the National Football League playoff game Sunday between the New England Patriots and the Los Angeles Raiders was extended until Friday, the Raiders said today.

title: Time Organize
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel has said ''the time has come to organize an international effort'' against terrorism. Certainly it has.

title: Fulton Prebon Deal Expected
description: Officials at Fulton Prebon (U.S.A.) are expected to announce today plans to purchase a large part of the MKI Securities Corporation.

title: CALIFORNIAN AND SOVIET WIFE EXULT IN REUNION
description: Tony Bartholomew and his Soviet-born wife, Tatyana, have had little sleep or time alone since they were reunited Monday, but they feel as if they are on a honeymoon after three years of separation.

title: FRENCHMAN IN FLORIDA CREATES 'BIG BOARD' FOR STAMP TRADING
description: A 35-year-old French-born millionaire wants to rejuvenate the hobby of stamp-collecting and make money in the process.

title: C.D. Yields Down for 3d Week
description: Average yields for six-month certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were down for the week ended Tuesday, the third such decline in as many weeks. Rates on money market mutual funds during the same period showed only a very slight increase.

title: 2 Accused of Abusing A Retarded Neighbor
description: A Brooklyn couple terrorized a retarded man for at least six years by beating him, threatening to kill him and stealing his Social Security checks, the police said yesterday.

title: Mortgage Insurers Face Big Underwriting Loss
description: The private mortgage insurance industry continues to face record underwriting losses, despite rapid growth in premium income from insurance policies covering home mortgages, according to a study by Moody's Investors Service.

title: JERSEY FIRE VICTIMS MISIDENTIFIED
description: The authorities said yesterday that a woman who survived a New Jersey house fire on Monday had been incorrectly identified as one of two people who died in the blaze.

title: Topics; Fruesday's Child The Two-Day Week
description: The last fortnight has left our biorhythms in tatters. We're programmed to work five days, from a slow start on Monday to a high pitch Thursday and Friday, and then to revel or rest on the weekend.

title: ART: 'IMIRA!,' EXHIBITION AT EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO
description: THE exhibition ''IMira!'' is one of those anthologies designed to make the majority aware of the minority - in this case, Spanish-speaking artists living in the United States. The exhibition, the second touring show of this title to be sponsored by Hiram Walker, the liquor company, is making its first stop at El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, between 104th and 105th Streets. After departing on Jan. 27, it will proceed to Chicago and on to Miami, Los Angeles, Houston, Denver and San Francisco.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $335.5 million, to $208.05 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds fell significantly, dropping $739.4 million, to $93.26 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds and 80 institutional investment funds, however, rose $248.6 million, to $60.59 billion, and $157.3 milion, to $54.21 billion, respectively.

title: INMATES AGREE TO YIELD AFTER RIOT
description: Inmates who took over the West Virginia Penitentiary agreed today to release all hostages by Friday and to return control of the prison to the authorities.

title: CAPITOL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF DENER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $4,619,000 for the quarter and $1,053,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: FOREIGN EQUITIES GAIN FAVOR
description: Like many Americans, investment fund managers spend their evenings enjoying a houseful of imported consumer goods ranging from Japanese televisions to European sportswear. These days they are also increasingly likely to spend their working hours investing in the companies that produced those goods.

title: Texas Women Winner by 92-66
description: Fran Harris scored 24 points and Andrea Lloyd added 15 points and 8 rebounds to lead the top-ranked Texas women's basketball team to a 92-66 Southwest Conference victory over Houston tonight.

title: 3 HOSPITAL FINED ON CARE OF PATIENTS
description: Three major medical centers in New York City have been fined up to $50,000 each -among the stiffest penalties ever imposed by the state - for violations of state regulations for treating patients, including two cases in which the patients died, State Health Department officials announced yesterday.

title: YUKICA'S DISMISSAL SUPPORTED
description: The Dartmouth College Athletic Council has approved the dismissal of Joe Yukica as head football coach, the council announced yesterday. But the effect of the council's decision remained uncertain pending further legal action by Yukica and the result of a hearing scheduled for today.

title: Pentagon; The Shot Heard 'Round Officialdom
description: In the Pentagon it is known as ''the Wade White Paper,'' and its criticisms and recommendations have been rumbling through the corridors like an Andean earthquake.

title: Brooklyn Man, 19, Is Charged In Sex Attacks on 7 Children
description: A 19 year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with rape and sodomy of seven boys and girls in a series of sexual assaults in the Bushwick section in the last month.

title: Factory Orders Up 1%
description: Orders to factories rose a modest 1 percent in November, although demand for durable goods was down for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:25 A.M. today and set at 9:10 P.M. tonight.

title: KNICKS ARE BEATEN AS EWING RETURNS
description: The Knicks and their fans expected that Patrick Ewing's return last night would change the team's fortunes. The heralded 7-foot rookie center returned after missing three games because of a jammed right knee, and the Knicks had been beaten badly in two of those games. But Gus Williams, the Washington Bullets' captain, also came back after missing three games with the flu.

title: Talks Set in Fish Strike At New Bedford
description: Striking fishermen blocked one of the nation's most productive fish auction houses today, but a Federal mediator said workers and boat owners had agreed to return to the bargaining table Saturday.

title: Two Fine New Paperbacks By Scotland's Hugh Kelsey
description: Among bridge authors around the world, nobody works harder or produces books of higher quality than Hugh Kelsey of Scotland.

title: BLACKS HONOR WHITE FOE OF APARTHEID
description: To the strains of black nationalist chants and Christian hymns, one of South Africa's most prominent white activists was cremated today after a funeral ceremony that became an emotional tribute by thousands of the poor and voteless blacks whose cause she had espoused.

title: HOW THE (1980'S) WEST WAS WON BY THE BLACK-FOOTED FERRET
description: Finding a federally protected endangered animal on one's property is an honor that most Western ranchers would just as soon pass up.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Oldest schoolhouse: Voorlezer on Staten Island.

title: Sea-Land Fight
description: Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, disclosed that he intended to wage a proxy fight at the Sea-Land Corporation's annual meeting to have himself and two associates - Charles I. Hiltzheimer and Adm.

title: New Jersey's Team
description: It seems unlikely that professional sports leagues will ever return to forcing teams to name themselves for the cities they play in. That would produce the Arlington Cowboys, the Anaheim Angels, the Bloomington Vikings and, in the eastern corridor, the Foxboro Patriots and the East Rutherford Jets and Giants.

title: WORSE THAN GLUTTONY
description: I am very weak on food. This creates constant humiliations, as, for example, on the occasion some years ago when I went to a flossy California restaurant in a party that included Craig Claiborne, a man who is strong on food, very strong.

title: Political Voice
description: The voice will be a new one but a familiar one when Miami Dolphins fans listen to the radio broadcast of today's playoff game with he Cleveland Browns. Gov. Bob Graham will provide details from the sidelines and interviews after the game from the Dolphin locker room. The Governor will work with Henry Barrow, a veteran broadcaster with Miami radio station WIOD.

title: HUGH O'NEILL McTAGUE
description: Hugh O'Neill McTague, a retired Air Force colonel and a former assistant to the dean of graduate studies at Brooklyn College, died Dec. 27 at Veterans Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Massapequa, L.I.

title: Sports Complex in Queens Offers Mixed-Use Opportunities
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR TWO YOUNG DESIGNERS, A CHANGE OF DIRECTION
description: In the first half of this decade, Marc Jacobs and Robert Molnar were two of New York's most-acclaimed young pop fashion designers. By the end of 1985, both were out of business.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the new president and chief operating officer of Entre North America, a unit of Entre Computer Centers Inc. He is Bert I. Helfinstein.

title: PLEAS ON BHOPAL TRIAL HEARD
description: A trial on the Bhopal gas leak disaster would pose major problems in insuring fairness for victims, whether it is held in India or in the United States, according to arguments in Federal court here yesterday.

title: Belgium Said to Demote Officers Over Soccer Riot
description: The three police officers in charge of security at the European Cup Championship here last year have been reassigned, and there are reports that they have been demoted because of security lapses at the match, at which 38 people were killed in rioting.

title: Ex-Rep. J. E. Chenoweth, 88; Won Army Base for Colorado
description: Former Representative J. Edgar Chenoweth, who represented southern Colorado for 11 terms, died Thursday at Mount San Rafael Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: SANDINISTA BAN ON CHURCH RADIO SEEMS TO BE STEP IN DRIVE ON PRESS
description: A decision by the Government this week to close the Roman Catholic radio station here appears to be the latest step in a three-month campaign against non-Sandinista press and broadcasting outlets.

title: A Reason to Pass
description: The Cleveland Browns aren't yet called the Cleveland Ground, but they can still be expected to run, run and then run some more in their playoff game at Miami this afternoon, just as they have all season. On the other hand, they won't forget about Ozzie Newsome entirely.

title: REAGAN, IN MEXICO, SAYS U.S. WILL HELP IN SECURING LOANS
description: President Reagan conferred for four hours here today with President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico and pledged that the United States would continue to help the Mexican Government combat its financial problems.

title: HICKOK ELECTRICAL INSTRUENT CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $14,700. c-Net loss after a net loss of $182,166 from the settlement of litigation.

title: FATALITIES IN PRISON RIOTS: OHIO'S TOLL IN '30 HIGHEST
description: November 1927 - Folsom Prison, Calif. Nine prisoners and three hostage guards were killed after pitched battles between prisoners and the National Guard.

title:
PATENTS;
Toxic Agents Used Against Cancer Cells
description: Compositions for treating cancer were patented this week by Sisir K. Sengupta, a faculty member at the Boston University School of Medicine.

title: THE PIED PIPER
description: Some will remember how Bill Veeck threw a post-leg-amputation party for himself - he was not about to wallow in self-pity - and danced the night away on his new wooden limb. That was in 1946, more than a year after he was injured. He had been a marine on Guadalcanal during World War II when an antiaircraft gun recoiled into his leg, and the leg became infected.

title: JOHN J. WILSON
description: John J. Wilson, an industrialist, yachtsman and patron of the arts in the Boston area, died Tuesday at his home in Marblehead, Mass. He was 78 years old and also had a residence in Barbados.

title: Gaspoz Triumphs In Giant Slalom
description: Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland, continuing a spectacular comeback, won a men's World Cup giant slalom ski race today and solidified his lead in the giant slalom points standing.

title: Appeal by Dartmouth
description: Dartmouth College lawyers asked a New Hampshire judge to lift an order barring the school from dismissing Coach Joe Yukica. Judge Walter Murphy took the request under review and continued the order against Dartmouth indefinitely, said John Safford, Hillsborough County Superior Court clerk.

title: Mayor Ends Emergency In Area of Philadelphia
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode today lifted the state of emergency he imposed on a racially troubled neighborhood in November and presented a plan to avert further racial problems.

title: Lord David Cecil, 83, Historian and Writer
description: Lord David Cecil, a prominent British literary historian and biographer, died Wednesday at the age of 83.

title: Don't Blame the Indians for Those Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Changes
description: Brian Lunde, executive director of the Democratic National Committee since last February, plans to leave that job and enter private business, committee sources say.

title: DOLE URGES AIR FORCE TO CANCEL T-46 TRAINERS
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, has urged the Air Force to cancel production of its new T-46 trainer planes, contending they cannot be built on schedule or within their $3.5 billion budget.

title: MEN WHO KILLED 3 IN VIRGINIA DIE AFTER CAR CHASE
description: Two men today killed a state trooper who had stopped a car they had stolen, then broke into a couple's home, murdered the husband, kidnapped his wife and drove off in their van, only to kill the woman and themselves as the police closed in.

title: BROWNS' DEFENSE TO TEST MARINO
description: Pass defense is anything but secondary to the Cleveland Browns. It will be primary in their American Conference semifinal game here Saturday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: STANG HYDRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LUSTROUS REMEMBRANCE
description: NINE WOMEN. By Shirley Ann Grau. 204 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. In such earlier books as ''The Black Prince and Other Stories,'' ''The Keepers of the House'' and ''The Wind Shifting West,'' Shirley Ann Grau not only established herself as a highly acclaimed writer, gifted with a highly tuned, authoritative style, but also as one of Faulkner's heirs - a Southerner whose stories remained firmly grounded in the places, as well as the gothicism and oral traditions of her native land.

title: THE ULTIMATE IN CALORIE COUNTERS
description: In Beltsville, Md., a rather bucolic Washington suburb where cows still graze and fields have not yet been turned into tract housing, there stands an unexceptional, slightly old-fashioned red brick building.

title: Ruling on Car 'Gray Market'
description: The right of European luxury auto makers to thwart ''gray market'' sales has been upheld by a court in Philadelphia.

title: ICAHN GETS CONTROL OF T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn became chairman of Trans World Airlines yesterday, having gained control of a majority of the board of directors, the carrier said.

title: Hands Off Keeps Rail Deregulation On Track
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DEFENDANT SAID TO BE EX-MAFIA BOSS
description: A key witness identified the main defendant in the ''pizza connection'' trial yesterday as the former top boss of the Mafia in Sicily.

title: HANDS OFF KEEPS RAIL DEREGULATION ON TRACK
description: To the Editor:

title: HAWAII DEMOCRATS SHOW RENEWED STRENGTH
description: Hawaii's Democratic political organization flexed its muscles in a special election and the result casts doubt on Republican assertions of growing strength in this year's race for Governor.

title: TWIN CALIFORNIA PORTS THRIVE
description: When Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo discovered San Pedro Bay in 1542, he was so unimpressed by the shallow, muddy inlet that he promptly left. It was centuries before the bay came into its own as one of the world's great ports.

title: LIBYA REPORTS DEMONSTRATIONS AGAINST U.S.
description: Anti-American demonstrators held protests in several Libyan cities today over United States and Israeli accusations that Libya was linked to the Palestinian terrorist attacks last week at two European airports, the Libyan radio said.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Football Cleveland Browns vs. Dolphins, at Miami, 12:30 P.M. The Browns (8-8) will try to topple the Dolphins (12-4) and earn the right to advance to the American Conference title game next week. They will attempt it with a rookie quarterback, Bernie Kosar, who starred at the University of Miami before joining Cleveland. (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 12:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Rams vs. Dallas Cowboys, at Anaheim, Calif., 4 P.M. After 11 years in Canadian football, Dieter Brock makes his National Football League playoff debut for the Rams (11-5) against Dallas (10-6). The winner goes to the National Conference championship game. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 4 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Nassau Coliseum, 7 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 6:55 P.M.) Devils vs. Washington Capitals, at the Capital Centre, Landover, Md., 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M.) Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:45 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) College Basketball: Tulsa at West Texas State, 1 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.) Kansas at Memphis State, 1 P.M. (Television - MSG, 1 P.M.) North Carolina State at North Carolina, 1:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 1:30 P.M.) Mississippi State at L.S.U., 4 P.M. (Television - MSG, 4 P.M.) Kentucky at Vanderbilt, 7 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Pitt at St. John's, Alumni Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.) Connecticut at Boston College, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 20, 7:30 P.M.) Seton Hall at Syracuse, 8 P.M. (Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:35 P.M.) Duke at Maryland, 9 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Columbia at Manhattan, 8 P.M. Providence at Georgetown, 2 P.M. Medgar Evers at Hunter, 8 P.M. St. Peter's vs.

title: An Event Tomorrow to Put A Premium on Adaptability
description: Adaptability, in terms of partnership, is usually a more significant quality in rubber bridge than in tournament play. But it will be at a premium tomorrow in a new event scheduled by the Greater New York Bridge Association.

title: For Them, Fear of Drilling Is No Laughing Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pretoria Perspective
description: The South African Ambassador to Washington, Herbert Beukes, has started issuing a monthly newsletter ''to share my views on developments and trends in my country.'' Many embassies publish bulletins and reports, but few issue them over the name of the ambassador.

title: STATEMENTS HELD ADMISSIBLE IN SPY CASE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation acted legally in obtaining statements from a retired intelligence analyst on the night of his arrest for espionage, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: MAYORS TO GATHER AT GRACIE MANSION IN A DRIVE TO SAVE REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -

title: Body of Recluse, 72, Found 11 Days After Blast at Home
description: Neighbors of Katherine Carnahan, a 72-year-old recluse, heard an explosion at her home and saw her rolling in the snow, but no one investigated until her burned and frozen body was found 11 days later, the authorities say.

title:
PATENTS;
Work Station
description: Robert L. Brown, an engineer in Buena Park, Calif., was granted a patent this week for a computerized executive work station. It is a desk in which a computer display screen and keyboard have been installed. Patent 4,562,482 says the work station is designed primarily for conferences and paperwork, and the computer acts as an unobtrusive information source easily operated during conferences. Mr. Brown would like to arrange for manufacture.

title: McDonnell Wins Military Contract
description: The Defense Department said yesterday that it had awarded a $331.6 million contract to the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company for a ballistic missile that could intercept incoming nuclear warheads.

title: PROSECUTOR TRYING TO RAISE OUTCRY ON CLEMENCY BY CUOMO IN MURDER CASE
description: The Ulster County District Attorney said yesterday that he would travel around the state to rouse protest against Governor Cuomo's granting of clemency to a man convicted in the murder of a deputy sheriff.

title: Facing Reality In Louisville
description: The thought of fielding a group of freshmen who together averaged 182.1 points a game as schoolboys is enough to excite any college campus. The thought of accommodating high school scoring averages to the demands of a big-time schedule, however, is enough to make the coach keep a firm grip on reality. Which is just what has happened at the University of Louisville this season.

title: FRENCH HOSTAGES IN LEBANON SAID TO BE IN SYRIANS' HANDS
description: Four Frenchmen abducted in Lebanon last year are now under Syrian control, not in the hands of their original kidnappers and may be released soon, a French negotiator said today.

title: INLAND VACUUM INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Gotbaum and Retirement
description: Victor Gotbaum, the labor leader who represents many of the city's workers, is casting about these days for new work.

title: Reagan and Brevity
description: President Reagan may deliver an unusually short State of the Union Message this year, perhaps 15 minutes or so, according to senior White House officials.

title: COMMON SENSE ON FAMILY PLANNING
description: One good way to help men and women make sound decisions about family planning is to make sure they obtain the necessary information. This season Congress is to be congratulated for its rare appreciation of that wisdom in balking at the efforts of those who deny it.

title: Tour Beginner Tied After a 68
description: Davis Love 3d, making his first start as a touring pro, one-putted the final two holes to salvage a 68 and a share of the second-round lead with Bob Tway and Bob Lohr today in the $300,000 Bahamas Classic.

title: Soviet Writers Criticize River Diversion Project
description: A group of leading Soviet writers published a statement today protesting a Government project to divert water from north-flowing rivers to the south, saying it would cause irreversible damage to the nation's cultural heritage.

title: Depleted Team
description: There is little doubt that at Geneva College in Beaver Falls, Pa., books and behavior come before basketball. Coach Marc Evans, who earlier this season dropped three players from his team for disciplinary reasons, now faces the prospect of playing the second half of the season without four freshmen who have been ruled academically ineligible, according to school officials.

title: Indians Assail Union Carbide
description: More than 1,000 protesters shouted slogans today near Parliament, demanding seizure of the Union Carbide Corporation's property in India and additional help for victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MORTGAGE RATES HIT 6-YEAR LOW
description: Home mortgage rates fell sharply last month, hitting their lowest levels in six years, the Government reported today.

title: F.A.A. SEEKS SPENDING CURB
description: The Federal Aviation Administration imposed ''severe constraints'' on spending, including agency-wide hiring freezes in some job categories, in orders distributed Thursday to employees nationwide.

title: WHO CARES ABOUT HALLEY'S COMET ANYWAY?
description: I've been waiting for Halley's Comet for some time now, anticipating the effect that it is said to have on people as it passes by our planet every 75 years or so. I'd heard so much about ''comet fever'' - that special excitment that Halley is said to generate. What a surprise it's been, then, now that it's here. As it turns out, I couldn't care less.

title: Reunion in Toronto
description: The newest member of the Maple Leafs finally reached Toronto yesterday. After defecting from Czechoslovakia, Miroslav Ihnacak was rewarded with a five-year contract, the sweater worn by a former team captain, Darryl Sittler, and a reunion after almost four years with his brother Peter, who defected in 1982 and is now a Toronto center.

title: 13-Year-Old Charged With Murder in Crash
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy was charged with second-degree murder yesterday after he fled from the police in a stolen car, lost control and struck a pole, causing the death of one of three young passengers and serious injuries to the others, the police reported.

title: SLAIN L.I. MAN WAS SHOT 5 TIMES
description: A retired Long Island butcher who was killed when a ''well-dressed'' gunman robbed him and his wife of casino winnings and jewelry was shot five times in the back, authorities said today.

title: LIBYA-U.S. TRADE LINKS HAVE BEEN CUT SHARPLY
description: A sharp decline in the economic ties between the United States and Libya has all but eliminated their economic leverage over each other. The decline has come since the imposition of trade restrictions by the Reagan Administration in 1981.

title: Errant Sculpture
description: People often forget, and leave their umbrellas or briefcases behind in taxicabs. But a piece of sculpture?

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
STIRLING: N.B.A. INSIDE MAN
description: During his more than 30 years of involvement in sports, Gordon (Scotty) Stirling, now the Knicks' vice president and general manager, has always worked behind the scenes. He learned to be a ''little devious'' from Al Davis, the owner of the Los Angeles Raiders of the National Football League. He learned about coaching from the former professional coach Alex Hannum, and how to ''pinch pennies'' from Franklin Mieuli, the owner of the Golden State Warriors.

title: SOCIET PANS 'ROCKY' AND 'RAMBO' FILMS
description: A group of Soviet cultural officials and artists today denounced the movies ''Rocky IV'' and ''Rambo: First Blood Part II,'' saying they were part of a deliberate propaganda campaign to portray Russians as cruel and treacherous enemies.

title: FALWELL FORMING GROUP TO LOOK AT BROAD ISSUES
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, founder of Moral Majority, announced today that he was forming a new political organization with the hope of mobilizing millions of conservatives who support his views on domestic and foreign issues.

title: CPU COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Javits Center Shuttle
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS DISMISS DEBUSSCHERE AND APPOINT STIRLING
description: Throughout what has already become an abysmal season, the Knicks have been widely criticized for their inability to make even one personnel transaction that might have improved their fortunes. Yesterday, they finally made a critical move. But it did not involve a player. Instead, in an action that was as shocking and unexpected as any they have taken in recent history, the Knicks dismissed their executive vice president, Dave DeBusschere, who was in his fourth season as the team's ultimate decision-maker concerning basketball operations. He was replaced immediately by Gordon (Scotty) Stirling, a National Basketball Association vice president. Stirling was named the Knicks' vice president and general manager.

title: 2 JURORS IN THE STEWART CASE EXPLAIN THEIR VOTE
description: We were on the jury that issued not-guilty verdicts last November to six New York City transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart. Mr. Stewart, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man, was arrested by the officers in 1983 for allegedly scrawling graffiti on subway walls. While in police custody, he lapsed into a coma, and he died 13 days later at Bellevue Hospital Center. In the outcry that followed our verdicts, many misunderstandings and errors of fact were reported concerning how and why the jury reached its decision. We would like to clarify our position.

title: TREASURY ISSUES EASE IN PRICE
description: Prices of Government securities eased further yesterday in light trading. Dealers again cited concern over the credit market's lack of liquidity, which has been reflected in the strong demand for the Federal funds that financial institutions lend each other for brief periods.

title: MAN ARRESTED IN SLAYING OF SURGEON AT HOSPITAL
description: The man wanted in connection with the killing of a surgeon at Kings County Hospital earlier this week was arrested last night in a Brooklyn fast-food restaurant, the police said.

title: Banks Altering Deposit Rules
description: AS of Jan. 1, banks no longer have to require a $1,000 minimum deposit for customers who want to open money market deposit accounts, Super NOW accounts and 7-to-31-day certificates of deposit.

title: An 18-Year Sentence Is Given In Diamond District Slayings
description: A Manhattan man who pleaded guilty to murdering two people during a robbery in the diamond district was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of 18 years in prison.

title: DEVILS' SECOND-PERIOD SURGE DALLS SHORT
description: A season that had promised perhaps a playoff spot for the Devils is losing its sparkle. They lost to the Washington Capitals tonight, 3-2, their sixth consecutive loss and ninth in 10 games.

title:
PATENTS;
A New Method For Skywriting
description: A Portland, Ore., pilot who does freelance aerial advertising was granted a patent this week on the method and apparatus for his skywriting.

title: HERBERT MAGIDSON
description: Herbert Magidson, a lyricist who shared the first Academy Award for best song, died Thursday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Bought the contract of Kevin Hagen, pitcher, from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: BIOLOGISTS ROUNDING UP LAST 6 WILD CONDORS
description: Biologists equipped with nets and tracking gear captured an ailing female California condor today, beginning a roundup of the last six condors, the largest North American birds, known to be in the wild.

title: Plugger
description: License plate spotted on a plumber's truck parked recently in midtown: ''NO DRIPS.''

title: List of Victims of Killer In Northwest Rises to 34
description: Two women whose skeletons were found this week in a ravine were today declared victims of a mass killer, bringing the death toll in the nation's worst unsolved mass killings to 34.

title: FARM GROUP PETITIONS REAGAN
description: A State Senator from Idaho has delivered a petition to the White House asking President Reagan ''to prevent an economic disaster of epic proportions'' in rural America.

title: Frances W. Newman Weds
description: At the Village Temple in Manhattan yesterday, Frances Wolf Newman, the daughter of Mrs. Tobian A. Wolf of Fort Worth, Tex., and the late Mr. Wolf, was married to Dr. Frederick Friedman, a clinical assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center.

title: CELTICS WITHSTAND LATE RALLY BY NETS
description: When the game reached its decisive moments tonight, the Boston Celtics did the kinds of things that have almost become routine for them. They made the important defensive plays, converted the unlikely shots and pulled away when their lead was in jeopardy. The Nets, who had come from far behind, seemed to watch in wonder.

title: Von Karajan Is Flown To U.S. for Treatment
description: Herbert von Karajan, the director of the Berlin Philharmonic orchestra, has been flown to the United States for medical treatment, the orchestra's general manager said today.

title: JOHN CONYERS Sr.
description: John Conyers Sr., a retired union official who was the father of Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, died Wednesday at his Detroit home. He was 80 years old. Mr. Conyers had been an international representative for the United Automobile Workers.

title: Aid for Church Schools Still Unconstitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Philadelphia Police Capture Murderer Who Fled Hospital
description: A convicted murderer who escaped from a hospital by using a fake gun fashioned from a bar of soap was captured today about 10 hours after he fled from guards, the police said.

title: MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR FOE OF APARTHEID IS BANNED
description: The police in this coastal town have banned a memorial service for Molly Blackburn, a white anti-apartheid campaigner who was cremated here Thursday after she died in an automobile accident last Saturday.

title: Atari Marketing
description: The Atari Corporation plans to sell its recently introduced 520ST computers through mass merchandise stores, company officials said. The abrupt shift to mass distribution only six months after the machine was introduced could anger the computer dealers who now carry the machine.

title: INNER CITY, ELITE CAMPUS: HOW 2 WORLDS JAR
description: At Princeton University, Frankie with private bath, carpet and large windows overlooking an expansive lawn. Nearby is a golf course.

title: NEW EVALUATION DENIED EX-AIDE AFTER DISMISSAL
description: The city's Personnel Director, Juan U. Ortiz, has rejected a Department of Investigation recommendation that his office conduct a new job evaluation of Dr. Judith Piesco, the deputy director he dismissed last week.

title: GIVE THE NEW HOSPITAL PAYMENTS SYSTEM A TRY
description: This week, New York State joins 48 others in the nation that have adopted the Medicare Prospective Payment System, a development that the Greater New York Hospital Association endorses, but cautiously.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Because of the nature of that regime, because of its erratic behavior, there is always a risk to Americans who choose to go to a country like that.'' - Charles E. Redman, State Department spokesman, referring to Libya. [ 4:4. ]

title: SCREEN: 'HEAD OFFICE,' A CORPORATE SATIRE
description: ''Head Office,'' which opened yesterday at the UA Twin and other theaters, has a droll tone that sets it well above comedy's lowest common denominator. But it also has a bloodlessness that keeps it from being funny very often. Ken Finkleman, the film's writer and director, has assembled an interesting cast and struck a note that might have been timely; though corporate satire has been out of vogue for a while, it's ready for a revival. But while ''Head Office'' has its moments, it winds up much too understated to have a cutting edge.

title: Salvadoran Rebels End Holiday Truce
description: Leftist rebels have ended a holiday truce with attacks on more than 20 electric power stations.

title: Swing Tunes and Dance
description: The Harlem Blues and Jazz Band will play swing tunes and Mama Lu Parks and her Savoy Lindyhoppers will dance tonight at 9 and 11 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets ( 475-5120). Tickets are $12; there is room for audience dancing.

title: THE WILL TO BE EUROPE
description: The excitement that launched the European Common Market a generation ago is no more. Its founders envisioned a Western Europe that would one day be unified in all affairs, starting with economic integration. Thirty years later, even the economic unit is still incomplete. Yet the European Community, as it is called now, continues to expand, and that says more than all the members' tedious squabbling over three decades. There is an evident will to be ''Europe,'' even if the way has yet to be found.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An Argentine soccer star, Diego Armando Maradona, says that the aching knee that has troubled him in recent years does not need surgery, according to doctors in Buenos Aires, and that he expects to be in the Argentine national lineup in the World Cup in Mexico next June. . . . Walter Davis, who has been undergoing treatment at a drug and alcohol clinic in Pasadena, Calif., will be released in 8 to 10 days, according to General Manager Jerry Colangelo of the Phoenix Suns. . . . Tony Yelovich, offensive line coach at Stanford the last two years and at Tulane and Arizona before that, has been hired by Lou Holtz, the new head coach at Notre Dame. . . . The running back Stump Mitchell, who rushed for 1,006 yards for the St. Louis Cardinals this season, said he was considering an offer from the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League. Mitchell's contract with the Cardinals expired at the end of the season.

title: School Attendance Down In Boston Drivers' Strike
description: Striking bus drivers and the city's new school superintendent remained deadlocked today as a walkout kept one of every five students from classes.

title: SUBPOENAS OF CONTRACTORS QUASHED
description: A Federal distirct judge today halted an attempt to force some of the nation's largest military contractors to search their files for evidence that classified Pentagon planning documents were routinely circulated within the industry.

title: QUIET MILESTONE FOR BOSSY
description: He is best known for his quick wrists, and Mike Bossy, who figures his personality quirks are his own business, would just as soon leave it at that. ''I want people to have a good opinion of me,'' he said casually, ''but if they don't, I don't really care. I am the way I am, and on the ice, I play the way I play.''

title: CITY SAYS FIREFIGHTER WAS TOO OLD WHEN HIRED AND MUST BE LET GO
description: More than three and a half years after he applied for a job with the New York City Fire Department, and a year and a half after the department hired him, a Long Island man has been told he was too old to be hired under city policy and he is to be dismissed.

title: U.S. SENDS LIBYA MIXED SIGNALS ON POSSIBILITY OF MILITARY ACTION
description: There was a mood of uncertainty today over whether the Reagan Administration would take military action in response to the airport terrorist attacks last week in Rome and Vienna.

title: Freighter Crew Stricken After Eating Barracuda
description: All 26 crewmembers of a Liberian freighter were stricken with food poisoning today after they ate a barracuda caught near the Bahamas. Six of the most critically ill were taken off the 3,700-ton Brazilian Sky and flown by Coast Guard helicopter to Princess Margaret Hospital in Nassau, the Coast Guard said.

title: Jeffrey S. Darman Marries Ellen K. Wessel in Virginia
description: Ellen Kalfayan Wessel, the daughter of Yvette Bluhm of Mars Hill, N.C., and the late Lewis Wessel, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Stephan Darman, the son of Frank Darman of Providence, R.I., and Frances Darman of East Providence, R.I. Judge Richard Jamborsky of the Fairfax County Circuit Court officiated at the couple's home in Arlington, Va.

title: Newsstand on the Spot
description: A battle on the Upper East Side is being waged over a newsstand on the southwestern corner of Third Avenue and 72d Street.

title: FEATHER FANCIER
description: When the Iowa Hawkeyes paid a post-Rose Bowl visit to the Playboy Mansion in Los Angeles, most of them passed the afternoon nibbling sandwiches and sipping soft drinks with the bunnies.

title: VIABILITY IS SEEN FOR A SLIM CARBIDE
description: The Union Carbide Corporation will pay a high price for its tough antitakeover defense against the GAF Corporation, analysts said yesterday.

title: INMATES IN WEST VIRGINIA RELEASE LAST 7 HOSTAGES, ENDING UPRISING
description: Inmates who took over the West Virginia Penitentiary released their seven remaining hostages today and returned control of the prison to the state.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. Sabry al-Banna, the renegade Palestinian leader who uses the name Abu Nidal, is suspected of organizing the groups that staged the Rome and Vienna airport massacres. 2. The agency said it was ending a moratorium on farm foreclosures but did not intend to begin a wave of such actions. 3. The headquarters of Corazon C. Acquino, who is opposing President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines in the Feb. 7 election. 4. A new set of high-density lamps mounted in the interior of the Eiffel Tower has replaced the exterior illumination that lighted the monument for 97 years. 5. Houston. 6. Leaders of Lebanon's rival militia forces signed a pact designed to end a decade of sectarian warfare. President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and King Hussein of Jordan embraced at the end of their first encounter in six years. 7. The newsstand business. 8. Chicago. 9. Housing. 10. Nengajo, New Year's cards, which are delivered on New Year's Day. 11. Barbara Aronstein Black, the incoming dean, was alluding to the other capacities in which she has performed along with her career - listed on her resume as ''wife'' and ''mother.'' 12. The mystery of the origin of the statue's copper skin was solved through an analysis, which proved that the copper of the tweezers, known to have come from a defunct mine on a Norwegian island in the North Sea, was identical with that of the statute. 13. False. 14.

title: IN NEW YEAR, CONTRIBUTIONS KEEP ARRIVING FOR NEEDIEST
description: Holiday festivities are all but over, but contributions from people wanting to share their joy and good fortune in the new year are still pouring into the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PENTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $11,611. c-Net loss. Year-ago results are for the period from April 8, 1984, the date of inception, through Sept. 30, 1984.

title: MONICA GOLLUB
description: Monica Gollub, a former commissioner of the New York State Workers' Compensation Board, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. Family members said Mrs. Gollub, who had been ill in recent years, had committed suicide.

title: Return to Coaching
description: Frank Cignetti, the former West Virginia University coach who recovered from a form of cancer, will replace George Chaump as Indiana (Pa.) University's football coach.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT POLYGRAPHS
description: Polygraph, or lie-detector, tests are supposed to help investigators determine the truth. But the truth about the Government's use of the polygraph can be elusive.

title: 'JUNK BOND' ROLL CALLED SMALL IN 1984 MERGERS
description: The role of high-yield, low-grade bonds in hostile takeovers and other merger activity in 1984 was relatively small, the Congressional Research Service reported today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 4, 1986
description: Companies

title: TV: CHRISTIE'S MISS MARPLE IS BACK, IN 'BODY IN LIBRARY'
description: Agatha Christie was never very enthusiastic about the formidable Margaret Rutherford portraying Miss Marple in the movies. Jane Marple, patterned after the author's great aunt and grandmother, is supposed to be a far less physically imposing woman. She is an elderly, very pompous spinster with a genius for detection work. Miss Christie would no doubt approve of Joan Hickson, the veteran British character actress who plays Miss Marple in ''The Body in the Library.'' The three-part dramatization begins tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13 as part of the weekly ''Mystery!'' series.

title: POLAND REPLACES HARD-LINE ENVOY TO SOVIET
description: The Government replaced its Ambassador to Moscow today in a move that Western diplomats interpreted as part of a drive by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski to reshape the Communist Party along more politically moderate lines.

title: Antique Doll Show
description: Thousands of dolls from the 19th and 20th centuries will be on display tomorrow at the Antique Doll Show at the Aspen Hotel, Route 46, Parsippany, N.J. Among the rare varieties for sale will be Jumeau dolls, which were made in Paris from the middle to the late 1800's by the Jumeau family. Hours are 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $3.50; information: (201) 887-3092.

title: An Indictment in Thrift Case
description: The owner of a savings and loan association that figured prominently in Maryland's thrift institution crisis last spring was indicted today on a charge of stealing millions of dollars from it and another savings and loan.

title: 'Doubles' Closes Tonight
description: ''Doubles,'' a comedy by David Wiltse about male friendships and midlife crises, will close after this evening's performance at the Ritz Theater. Directed by Morton DaCosta and starring Keir Dullea, Cliff Gorman, Robert Reed and Charles Repole, the play will have run for 277 regular performances and nine previews.

title: William G. Gaylord, 40, Dead; Author of Syndicated Column
description: William G. Gaylord, an interior designer with a syndicated column that appeared in 177 newspapers, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 40 years old.

title: Russian Violinist
description: The Russian violinist Valery Schevchenko will make his American debut as part of the New York City Housing Authority Chamber Orchestra's concert tomorrow afternoon at 2 at Carnegie Recital Hall. The concert will include works by Vivaldi, Bach and Stravinsky. Tickets are $10 and $15; information: 247-7800.

title: C. PALMER BATEMAN Jr.
description: C. Palmer Bateman Jr., the president of Somerset Press Inc., which publishes six weekly newspapers in New Jersey, died suddenly Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Branchburg, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: UNION GROUP FACES STRIKE OF ITS OWN
description: As a dozen striking workers took their turn on the picket line, Sandra Polaski, their captain, cautioned them not to make any comments that would ''embarrass'' their employer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOHO SIGHTS The Manhattan area known as SoHo - the section running south from Houston Street to Canal Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas - emerged in the 1960's as an artists' residential district. It soon was transformed into a display case for the artists' works, and is now the site of countless boutiques and restaurants in addition to galleries.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 15.8% DURING MID-DECEMBER
description: Sales of new cars dropped 15.8 percent in mid-December, American manufacturers reported today, as weak incentive programs, since revised, failed to stimulate the market.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring pre-tax charge of $602,000 for discontinued products at the Robot division.

title: TEXACO AND PENNZOIL SET RESUMPTION OF TALKS
description: Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company are scheduled to begin a new round of talks on Monday that could make or break their attempt to negotiate a settlement, sources close to both companies said yesterday.

title: HOME FUEL COSTS: NO PRICE DROP IN SIGHT
description: Bills for home heating oil are not declining significantly, if at all, despite recent sharp drops in the price of crude oil, according to price surveys. Some analysts are now saying that consumers will not benefit from any reductions this season.

title: TASTE, AND MERIT, ON THE CITY COUNCIL
description: All the candidates for New York's City Council last fall pledged to make it a strong, constructive -and independent - body. Fat chance. Just look at the bargaining over who will be the Vice Chairman and majority leader, the most powerful job on the Council.

title: CENTER STAGE FOR SYRIA
description: Developments in recent weeks, including the recent meeting between King Hussein of Jordan and Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, have again shown the ability of Mr. Assad to move his country to the forefront of Middle East politics. Diplomats here and in

title: EXPERT URGES CAUTION ON REPORTS OF CHILD ABUSE
description: The American public, overreacting to news accounts of beaten, starved or sexually abused children, is reporting suspicions of child abuse where at times none exists, according to an authority on the subject.

title: Disney Change
description: Walt Disney Productions said it was proposing to change its name to the Walt Disney Company in an effort to reflect the company's diversity. Michael D. Eisner, chairman and chief executive, and Frank G. Wells, president, explained to shareholders in a letter that a two-year study showed that the old name was associated with film entertainment.

title: A MUTED DEDICATION FOR 'HOLOCAUST'
description: A realistic life-size sculpture depicting 11 victims of Nazi death camps yesterday became New York City's first major memorial to the Holocaust.

title: HELLO, BIG DEAL
description: With the recent announcement of its plan to sell the Federal Housing Administration, the Reagan Administration has at last revealed its true political game plan.

title: Oklahoma Routs Austin Peay by 32
description: Daryl Kennedy scored 27 points to pace Oklahoma to a 100-68 victory over Austin Peay tonight in the Sooner Invitational tournament.

title: ESTES ILL, TO MISS CONCERT
description: Because of an illness, Simon Estes, the American-born baritone now living in Zurich, will not perform in a concert with Luciano Pavarotti at 8 P.M. on Monday at Avery Fisher Hall. The bass James Morris and the baritone Alan Titus are scheduled to take Mr. Estes's place in ''Pavarotti Plus!,'' which will be telecast on Channel 13 as part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series.

title: WOMAN FOUND SLAIN WITH ROPE AT JERSEY HOME
description: A 39-year-old woman was found strangled Thursday in the basement of her ransacked home in this affluent Morris County community, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: TREATING WINTER'S ITCHY SKIN
description: NEARLY everyone that Dr. Jay Heldman sees these days has dry, irritated skin.

title: FOR BURGLARY VICTIMS, A SENSE OF LOSS LINGERS
description: The police call it a ''closeout.'' It is standard procedure in the burglary game.

title: Al Grey Leads Quintet
description: The trombonist Al Grey, formerly of the Count Basie band, is leading a quintet - with the saxophonist Al Cohn, the pianist Roland Hanna, the bassist Major Holley and the drummer Butch Miles tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: NATIONAL GOLD DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 4, 1985
description: International West Germany ruled out sanctions against Libya. Other Western European countries reacted cooly to calls by the United States for collective action against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government, which is accused of supporting terrorist groups. At the same time, there were signs of growing concern, particularly among countries on the Mediterranean, over a possible flare-up of violence. The concern came amid reports of United States naval operations in the area and plans for eventual military reprisals for the apparently coordinated terrorist attacks on airports in Rome and Vienna. [ Page 1, Column 6. ]

title: Former Congressman Indicted in Louisiana
description: Former Congressman Richard Tonry was indicted today on charges of bribing the chairman of the Chitamacha Indians to get a contract to run bingo games on their reservation.

title: IN AN EMERGENCY, MENNONITES LEND THEIR HANDS
description: They had cleaned away the debris, laid new floors, installed new sheetrock, plumbing and appliances, but there was one more thing to do.

title: CARBIDE BID MAY BE AT CROSSROADS
description: The GAF Corporation still has a chance to take over the Union Carbide Corporation, major Carbide shareholders said yesterday.

title: BABY HOME WITH NEW HEART
description: The world's youngest and longest-lived recipient of a newborn-to-newborn heart transplant went home Thursday, his surgeon, Dr. Leonard Bailey, said. The surgery, done Nov. 20, when the baby was 4 days old, ''reminds us of the scarcity of donor hearts for newborns,'' Dr. Bailey said in a statement. Dr. Bailey has said he implanted a baboon's heart in an infant girl in October 1984 because human donors were scarce.

title: VELASQUEZ FINED $1,000
description: Jorge Velasquez was fined $1,000 by the Aqueduct stewards yesterday for misjudging the finish of the $90,150 Display Handicap, the eighth and feature race at Aqueduct on Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Paris dispatch on Wednesday about the new lighting of the Eiffel Tower referred incorrectly to the symbolic character of Marianne, represented by a likeness of the actress Catherine Deneuve. Marianne is the traditional symbol of the French Republic, not of Liberty.

title: Dollar-Yen Statement
description: The yen-dollar exchange rate should stabilize at the current rate, about 200 yen to the dollar, Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, said in an interview published today.

title: FOR MASRSHALL, SOLID LEVEL OF SUCCESS
description: Years ago, Leonard Marshall Sr. never liked the idea of his son, Leonard Jr., playing football. He thought it was a stupid game, and he thought his son could do more constructive things.

title: Midcon Bid Halted By Wagner Group
description: A partnership headed by Wagner & Brown yesterday ended its tender offer to buy the Midcon Corporation, a pipeline company that earlier in the week signed a $3 billion acquisition agreement with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Soprano in Benefit
description: The soprano Mara Worth-Merriman, in conjunction with the pianist Barry Farber and the guitarist Gene Raskin, will present a benefit program for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at Merkin Concert Hall tonight at 8.

title: Higher Oil Tax Would Pinch the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Inventions Rose in '85
description: ABOUT 3,000 more patents were granted in 1985 than in 1984, with a number of inventors filing from abroad. They included many Japanese and even a few Soviet citizens.

title: CITY FUND RETAINS ITS AFRICA STOCKS
description: Almost 18 months after top city officials voted to divest the city's largest employee pension fund of holdings in companies doing business in South Africa, not one share has been sold.

title: 24 Jersey Hospital Workers Are Dismissed After Checks
description: Twenty-four workers at state-run psychiatric hospitals were discharged today because of their criminal backgrounds, the state's acting commissioner of human services announced.

title: A Cambodia Rebel Chief Says He Banished Foes
description: The Cambodian rebel leader Son Sann said today that he had banished a powerful dissident faction from his group amid an ''open rebellion.''

title: BONN RULES OUT TRADE SANCTIONS AGAINST LIBYANS
description: West Germany ruled out economic sanctions against Libya today as other Western European countries reacted coolly to American calls for collective action against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government over charges that it supports terrorist groups.

title: Chris-Craft Extends Credit
description: Chris-Craft Industries said yesterday that it had extended the $250 million credit line that its subsidiary, BHC Inc., has been using to buy stock in Warner Communications Inc. That credit line had been scheduled to drop by $50 million on Dec. 31.

title: 4 Texas Aides Dropped
description: Fred Akers, the University of Texas football coach, has cleaned house after an 8-4 season, dismissing four assistant coaches, hiring an offensive co-ordinator and leaving five vacancies on his nine-man staff. One of those dropped was Ronnie Thompson, coach of running backs, who said he had asked Akers if he was ''doing this because it was the only way he could stay.

title: Clarence F. Gaines, 88; Introduced a Dog Meal
description: Clarence Francis Gaines, founder of the Gaines Dog Food Company who was also a horseman and Florida developer, died at his home Tuesday. He was 88 years old.

title: LAKERS CATCH JAZZ
description: Kareem Adbul-Jabbar scored 25 points and sparked a 16-0 spree in the fourth quarter tonight that lifted the Los Angeles Lakers to a 110-101 victory over the Utah Jazz.

title: JETS BELIEVE GIANTS CAN HANDLE BEARS
description: The Chicago Bears have an unimpressive offense and a defense that may not be any better than that of the Giants, some people who should know said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Operating Appliances By Voice or Breath
description: A disabled person can control as many as 10 electrical appliances by voice or breath with a switchboard patented this week by Steve Sremac of Santa Clara, Calif.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC'S ALL-WAGNER PROGRAM
description: Richard Wagner arranged excerpts from his operas as concert pieces in large measure to allow his music to be heard at a time when opera companies were resisting the complete scores. Yet Wagner programs by symphony orchestras persist, and it is indeed rewarding to hear this music occasionally with the full power and panache of a modern symphony orchestra, sitting up there on stage and projecting directly out to the audience.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
DOW INCREASES BY 11.47 IN A LACKLUSTER SESSION
description: Stock prices rose a sizable amount in an otherwise dull session yesterday as speculators turned for excitement to potential buyout targets. Other investors sought out secondary stocks.

title: TV: A SOVIET-DONAHUE 'SUMMIT'
description: ''A Citizens' Summit'' won't start a war; it wouldn't stop one, either. Phil Donahue and a Soviet Communist Party handyman match wits, while American and Soviet studio audiences alternate between exchanging pleasantries and getting in a few good licks. The one-hour program can be seen on WNBC-TV at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: ARTISTS OF BALI RESIST THE DOOMSAYERS
description: On this Hindu island of Bali, where stone gods watch over the roads that wind through steep emerald hills with rice-terrace necklaces, no visitor is ever far from the ringing tones of a gamelan orchestra or the hypnotic chanting of the kecak dance. These are the sounds of Balinese culture.

title: Carbide's Brands Draw Recognition and Profits
description: In seeking to sell its consumer businesses, the Union Carbide Corporation is putting on the auction block some of the brand names that are among the most recognized on the market: Prestone antifreeze, Eveready and Energizer batteries, Simoniz and STP automotive products and Glad disposal bags and plastic wrap.

title: WHY SHERLOCK HOLMES FASCINATES AMERICANS
description: How can one explain the American fascination, to the point of exuberant idolatry, with Sherlock Holmes? The fascination finds its latest expression in ''Young Sherlock Holmes,'' the sumptuous period film produced by Steven Spielberg, an engaging trifle in which the great detective makes his imagined first bow as a schoolboy. The idolatry touches its seasonal peak on Friday, when the Baker Street Irregulars converge for their annual dinner at the Regency Hotel.

title: YACHTSMAN REPORTED LOST
description: Jean Castenet, who moved to Newport, R.I., from France after his participation in three America's Cup campaigns, was reported lost at sea Friday during a storm off the coast of Spain.

title: ROCK: JOE JACKSON IN A PRE-ALBUM CONCERT
description: FOR an audience of what he called ''guinea pigs,'' the British songwriter Joe Jackson played 11 new songs and a few older selections Thursday night at Sounds of Brazil. Mr. Jackson will be recording a live album later this month at the Joyce Theater, and he's polishing the material with not-so-secret shows at local clubs. Thursday's concert came to a rushed end when the fire department threatened to close the room because of overcrowding.

title: A VITAL HEDGE AGAINST CORPORATE FRAUD
description: THE idea of equality before the law has deep roots. The barons at Runnymede in 1215 secured a pledge from King John in the Magna Carta that ''one measure of wine [ would exist ] throughout [ the ] realm.'' Special pleading, too, is a recurring theme in the law.

title: LIBRARY EYES SITE OF HISTORIC HOUSE
description: WHEN a developer offered recently to donate to the trustees of the Rogers Memorial Library a parcel in the Village of Southampton, it appeared an ideal location for a new library building.

title: ISSUE OF ARKANSAS OPENS THE NEW YEAR
description: The Old State House in Little Rock, Ark. is the central theme on the first United States commemorative of 1986. The 22-cent first class stamp, which had its first day of issue in that city on Friday, celebrates Arkansas' 150th anniversary of statehood.

title: COUSINS OF AFRICAN VIOLETS PROVIDE UNUSUAL BLOOMS
description: African violets belong to a fine family of indoor plants called the Gesneriads.

title: CAVALIERS ROUTED BY NETS, 125-106
description: When he ran the offense, Micheal Ray Richardson was considered the artistic centerpiece of the Nets. He is gone now, but the team is still finding a way to survive.

title: FOR PEACE AND AN INDEPENDENT PALESTINIAN STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FLOW HAS SLOWED FROM THE OLD COUNTRY
description: The Russians are not coming to the United States much anymore. The last wave from the Soviet Union peaked in 1979, when nearly 29,000 immigrants, most of them Jewish, arrived. But the wave has become a trickle, with fewer than 600 Russians entering last year.

title: AN ECONOMIC GAME PLAN SHORT CIRCUITS IN OREGON
description: Once a thriving logging town, Valsetz is today a bare patch in Oregon's coastal range. Closed 18 months ago by the Boise Cascade Corporation, which ran the logging operations and literally owned the town, Valsetz is a sad monument to Oregon's Age of Timber.

title: TRAIL OF MIDEAST TERROR: SEEKING A LINK TO LIBYA
description: The Administration's concerns over Libya, long focused on that country's attempts to undermine neighboring pro-Western governments, have heightened in the last week with charges that Libya supported Palestinian terrorists who attacked the Rome and Vienna airports.

title: FITTING GRADUATE PROGRAMS TO WORKING-ADULT PROBLEMS
description: USING everything from two-way video systems and computers to altered course schedules, an increasing number of universities and colleges are patterning graduate programs to the needs of working adults. Engineers in classrooms at the Caterpillar Tractor Company in Peoria, Ill., are earning master's degrees from University of Illinois without ever leaving the factory. Jetting into New York once a month, a woman in Saudi Arabia earned a doctorate in education from Teachers College, at Columbia University.

title: GROUP SEEKS TO SAFEGUARD VOTE IN PHILIPPINES
description: In an effort to insure a fair election in the Philippines on Feb. 7, a Filipino opposition group based in New York has started an international program in which people are being asked to ''adopt'' a polling precinct.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS ARE VITAL LINKS IN CHAIN OF LIFE
description: THIS post-holiday period may be a good time to take stock of the role of plants in our lives and to evaluate the effectiveness of our stewardship of these valuable resource.

title: Redevelopment In New London
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., which earned a living from the sea from colonial times onward, is returning to its heritage to revive its downtown. The city has hired a development coordinator and has begun a campaign to redevelop land along the Thames River waterfront for marinas, shops, restaurants and condominiums.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Nest-Egg Effect The year may be over, but taxpayers have until April 15 to lower their 1985 tax bill by making contributions to their Individual Retirement Accounts. An estimated $230 billion will be invested in I.R.A.'s by that date, says Robert A. Schwartz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Financial Economists.

title: IN THE FIELD WITH PUBLIC HEALTH NURSES
description: GAIL McLEOD, a public health nurse, paused for a moment to catch her breath as she climbed three flights of stairs in an old apartment house in downtown Yonkers. Her first patient one recent morning was Frances Cintron, a pregnant woman with high blood pressure.

title: BAIT FOR WILY SEA LION: POISONED FISH
description: This is a fish tale, but one that pits the interests of a multimillion-dollar California industry against those of one of America's most popular ocean animals.

title: A VIRGINIAN IN FRANCE, A FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS
description: Jefferson's Steps Retraced Inspired by the ancient Roman temple known as the Maison Caree at Nimes in France and drawing upon published depictions of other Roman buildings, Thomas Jefferson, in collaboration with the French architect Charles Louis Clerisseau, designed the capitol of Virginia in the late 18th century, while Jefferson was minister plenipotentiary to the court of Louis XVI.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE NAZI'S WIFE. By Peter Watson. (Doubleday, $16.95.) These days novelists like their Nazis in one of two ways - either goose-stepping their way across the pages of paranoid, what-if World War II fiction or craftily plotting a contemporary resurgence of the movement.

title: Sweet Smell Of Baltimore
description: AT LEAST one enterprise in Baltimore's inner harbor has enjoyed the sweet smell of success since 1921, but this year the aromas of cinnamon and other spices that often envelop the city's financial and governmental districts will disappear.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE road to Mark S. Hurvitz's career as a rabbi to the Jewish deaf began with the sounds of music.

title: Abby E. Lipsey To Wed Feb. 23
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. Lipsey of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abby Ellen Lipsey, to Jon Winkelried, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Winkelried of Roseland, N.J. The wedding is planned for Feb. 23.

title: COST ACCOUNTING IN THE PRIMAL PANTRY
description: GOOD TO EAT Riddles of Food and Culture. By Marvin Harris. 289 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: WELCOMING 1986
description: Watchman, what of the night? Years come and go. Prayers are offered and forgotten, resolutions made and repudiated. Will there now be an end to violence? Will fear be vanquished and hate disarmed? Will death yield to humanity and hope?

title: KEEPING THE SEASON
description: Ever since the coaches got the authorized college baseball schedule up to 80 games a year (20 in the fall, 60 in the spring), the professors have been trying to get it back down, suggesting that maybe the players were missing too many classes. Thinking like that, say the coaches, is not only off base but could cost a school its entire baseball program.

title: Jennifer Sullivan To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Jennifer Leslie Sullivan to Allen Arthur Weaver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Weaver of Orange, Calif., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Howard E. Sullivan Jr. of Rosemont, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: ROAD IS FLOODED IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A water main break in Central Park Friday night released a wall of water that rushed along the 97th Street transverse road, briefly trapped two motorists on the roofs of their submerged cars and spilled north on Fifth Avenue for more than 10 blocks.

title: A BHOPAL ON THE BAYOU?
description: ANOTHER Bhopal? That's what trade unionists are saying about the BASF Wyandotte Corporation's big chemical plant in Geismar, La.

title: A PARIS REVIEW
description: To the Editor: Although we appreciate the attention given some of the Anglophone small press publishers, writers and booksellers working in Paris (''Paris Has Plenty to Read -in English,'' Travel, Nov. 24), a regrettable omission was made in listing the current literary and art reviews being published here in English.

title: POSTINGSConversion in Newark; New Condos for the Old News
description: The buildings that housed the old Newark News, structures that have remained unoccupied since the newspaper folded in 1972, are being renovated into condominium apartments.

title: No Headline
description: In a review Dec. 29 of ''Gerald's Party'' by Robert Coover, the year of publication of an earlier novel by Mr. Coover was incorrect. ''The Origin of the Brunists'' was published in 1966.

title: OPERA: 'DAUGHTER OF THE REGIMENT,' IN WASHINGTON
description: Gaetano Donizetti spent his 51 years industriously crafting operas, with the same fecundity that D. W. Griffith showed in grinding out Biograph one-reelers and John O'Hara in writing short stories. ''La Fille du Regiment,'' currently playing in the Terrace Theater of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, was the composer's 56th opera, yet retains a surprising degree of freshness, as was proven by tonight's performance.

title: 2 DIE AS LIGHT PLANE CRASHES
description: Two Rhode Island residents died in the crash of a single-engine Cessna 182 in an isolated, heavily wooded area in southern Glastonbury, the authorities said today. Officials withheld identification of the victims pending notification of next of kin.

title: IS NEO-EXPRESSIONISM AN IDEA WHOSE TIME HAS PASSED?
description: An artistic moment has passed. It is not that the phenomenon known as Neo-Expressionism is dead, or that the artists identified with it are no longer the subject of intense interest and debate. But the fire that was lighted by those European and American artists whose large-scale, usually painted work burst into prominence around 1980 with a flair and sweep that seemed to make everything possible, is now down to a glow. Together, it is unlikely that they will receive the same kind of attention again.

title: WHEN LONG MARRIAGES FALL APART
description: THE PAINTING was titled ''Frank's Ex.'' A woman, neither young nor old, sits in a nightgown and open plaid bathrobe, a coffeepot and mug resting on a small table at her side.

title: ROBERTSON DAVIES AND SPRINGSTEEN
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMB KILLS 4 AT KHYBER PASS
description: Four people were killed and 14 wounded by a bomb blast Friday in the Khyber Pass area on the Afghan border, official sources said today. They said the bomb, in the Landi Kotal bazaar, could have been planted by the Afghan secret police.
