Pakistan, which supports Afghanistan's anti-Government guerrillas, started a crackdown last month against dissident Pakistanis who have purportedly received arms from the Afghan Government.

title: THE URGE TO GET AHEAD OF THE PENTAGON
description: Pentagon officials like to talk about their ''partnership'' with the weapons industry, but lately it has been a relationship under strain. Contractors have been debarred for fraud, dunned for shoddy work and denounced for inefficiency. Now some of them are under fire for mishandling secrets.

title: Janice L. Barefoot Becomes a Bride
description: Janice Lynn Barefoot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kirk Barefoot of Riverside, Conn., and Greenwood, Me., was married yesterday to Richard Burton Sachs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton A. Sachs of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, Conn., assisted by Rabbi Charles Lipmann.

title: 42 FOOD OUTLETS GET CITATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 42 food establishments cited for violating the health code. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Asmara African Restaurant, 951 Amsterdam Ave. (106th St.). La Croissanterie, 224 E. 86th St. Domino's Pizza, 1369 Broadway (36th St.).

title: ASIAN-AMERICANS TURN TO PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: THE children in Wendy Huang's sixth-grade class at Public School 56 in the Bronx tease her and call her ''Brainy Janie'' because the lowest score she has ever received on a test was an 86. She reads at the ninth-grade level and scored in the 98th percentile on a citywide math test.

title: Glut Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NO SKATING IT was not quite as lavish as the ice skating rink at Rockefeller Center, Mayor Louis N. Kash of Port Jefferson said, but the community's ice skating program on a pond at the village-owned Harbor Hills Country Club did offer some special services.

title: FOR STAGE NOVICE, 'ACTING IS IT'
description: HE LIGHTS the filter tip of a cigarette and, in frustration, drops it into a cup.

title: DIFFERENT ENDING FOR KOSAR
description: Had he ever heard noise like this in the Orange Bowl before? Bernie Kosar did not bite at the chance to turn a phrase. ''Yeah,'' he said softly. He knew, and so did the cluster of interviewers around him, that he had heard a huge noise like this the night he and his Miami University teammates won the 1984 Orange Bowl, 31-30, to clinch the top rating for 1983.

title: BACK TO A BASIC CONTRACEPTIVE
description: ANNE, an attractive New York widow in her mid-40's, decided it was time to begin dating again. Before re-entering the social wars, she visited her gynecologist. Anne had long used a diaphragm to prevent pregnancy but feared this would provide little protection against AIDS, the acquired immune deficiency syndrome for which there is no cure.

title: STATE URGING WIDER COLLECTIONS OF HOME TOXINS
description: THE State Department of Environmental Protection is now encouraging a regional approach for the collection of hazardous household chemicals.

title: WHEN A COMPUTER JOINS CHILD'S BUILDING BLOCKS
description: THREE young children faced a computer at the Fox Learning Center, a preschool in Hainesport, N.J., recently, pressing keys in response to instructions from a muffled voice on the screen. They helped one another choose the right key, pressed finger to forehead in contemplation and responded to the teacher. Nearby, other children at the Fox Center cut out pictures of toys, fruits and similar objects and pasted them onto the appropriate paper railroad cars. Thus in one classroom, two forms of instruction were being conducted simultaneously - one involving physical objects, the other embracing a new and controversial technology.

title: FOR ISLAND NEWS, TRY WLIW-TV
description: We applaud the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting in its efforts to increase news coverage of Long Island [ ''TV News Outlook Raising Concerns,'' Dec. 15 ] .

title: The Electric Train Set
description: Having grown up a disciple of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, near Sayre, Pa., I spent many a youthful hour on, under and beside the tracks that served as the vasculature on which America grew up (''Electric Trains,'' by John P. Allegrante, About Men, Dec. 1).

title: On Language; Of Yobbos and Gits
description: BRITAIN'S PARLIA-ment, like the American Congress, has a list of proscribed words that members must not call one another. Decorum must be maintained, which suppresses most of the colorful slang terms that political people use in private debate.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A SENSE OF HISTORY: The Best Writing From the Pages of American Heritage. (American Heritage/ Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) Pewter candlesticks and patriotism once sprang to mind when American Heritage magazine was mentioned. But the 30-year-old magazine has a tradition of publishing graceful, informative essays, more than 50 of which, spanning the time of the first European settlements to the end of the Nixon Presidency, have been collected in ''A Sense of History.'' The subjects range from why Washington and Lincoln were our greatest Presidents, to the legend of Johnny Appleseed, to explanations for Lyndon Johnson's failure in Vietnam.

title: PATTER PERFORMERS IN STAMFORD
description: JOHN REED, recognized as one of the best ''patter'' men performing in Gilbert and Sullivan operas, has been singing such quintessentially comedic roles as the Lord Chancellor in ''Iolanthe'' and Ko-Ko in ''The Mikado'' for more than 30 years. On Saturday, he and the other members of the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will perform ''Iolanthe,'' a satire set in a fairyland, at the Palace Theater in Stamford.

title: THE NEW HAND AT THE BUDGET OFFICE IS EVEN MORE TIGHTFISTED
description: Over the last four years, Administration officials and many perhaps-somewhat-more-objective political scientists have asserted that President Reagan and his lieutenants were not dismantling the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal, but only trying to prune the excesses of Lyndon Johnson's Great Society.

title: CAR COUNTERS WEREN'T TOLD OF CHRISTMAS VACATION
description: Detroit takes a weeklong holiday at the end of every year. The automobile factories close down. The auto companies' executive suites empty out. And for once the freeways are quiet.

title: A PROMISED LAND WHERE OTHERS FEARED TO BUILD
description: By all accounts, there is nothing particularly unusual about the latest Manhattan-style tower that Citicorp hopes to build for some of its corporate offices. It would rise 45 stories, contain about a million square feet of usable space and no doubt possess the cool elegance that marks much of the work of its architects, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.

title: REVISITING A MODERNIST PIONEER AND A POET OF URBAN LIFE
description: At the time of her death in 1976, Imogen Cunningham was a celebrated figure in photography.

title: Martha McNally Intends to Marry James Kerney 2d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Martha McNally to James Kerney 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Kerney of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Pittsford, Vt. The wedding is planned for May 31.

title: U.S. MEDICS GIVEN ANTI-TERROR ROLE
description: The senior United States military medical officer in Europe says 12 special medical teams have been formed and trained to handle casualties arising from terrorist attacks.

title: NORDIC SKIING IS AVAILABLE CLOSE TO HOME
description: CROSS-COUNTRY skiers and those who are thinking about cross-country skiing need not head for the Poconos or Catskills to enjoy the sport. New Jersey abounds in good cross-country areas, including many that have such creature comforts as warming huts.

title: VEHICLE AGENCY FACING SHIFT
description: THE recent recommendation by the State Commission of Investigation that motor-vehicle agencies be state-operated would, if adopted, end the 80-year-old system under which agency directors have been appointed.

title: Q&A
description: A Seller's Right to All Bids Question: Is a real-estate agent required to submit the bid of a prospective purchaser of a house to the seller even if the bid is a low bid? . . . G.G.G., Brooklyn Answer: There is nothing in state law that requires a broker to submit every bid, according to Richard McCarthy, a spokesman for the New York State Department of State, which licenses real estate brokers and salespersons. There are, however, brokerage trade associations that require every bid be submitted as part of their code of ethics and some sales firms include such a requirement in their brokerage agreements. Cold Shoulder on Radiator Question: May a landlord simply remove a radiator from the entrance hall of a tenement apartment building? . . . E.S., Manhattan Answer: There is no city requirement for heat in hallways of multiple dwellings, but there are regulations on how the radiator must be Redinger removed, including requirements for capping the steam riser, according to Emanuel Gentile, assistant in the division of code enforcement in the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The Department of Buildings also requires a plumbing repair slip. Improper removal could result in a violation. In rent-regulated buildings, a landlord who removes a radiator and does not provide a comparable service may be adjudged to have reduced a buildingwide service, says Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. If this has occured, file a complaint with a district rent office.

title: 'THE GRAND GALLERY ON VIEW IN NEWARK
description: JUST when there seems to be nothing left of the 19th century to rediscover, the Newark Museum comes up with ''The Grand Gallery.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. Bears, at Chicago, 12:30 P.M. The Bears, 15-1 and first in the league in rushing defense and total defense, will try to contain the Giants (10-6), led by Phil Simms. The winner moves to the National Conference championship game next weekend. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 12:30 P.M.) Raiders vs. New England Patriots, at the Los Angeles Coliseum, 4 P.M. Jim Plunkett will not be activated for the game, although the quarterback is recovered from a shoulder dislocation suffered in the season's third game. New England will be without the wide receiver Derwin Williams. The winner advances to next weekend's American Conference title game. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Quebec Nordiques, Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. This is the first meeting of the season between the teams. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Minnesota North Stars at Detroit Red Wings, 8:30 p.m. (Television - ESPN.) College Basketball Michigan State at Indiana, 4 P.M. (Television - MSG, 4 P.M.) National Catholic Basketball Tournament, at Dubuque, Iowa. Women's and men's finals of an event that featured 16 N.A.I.A. schools, including St. Thomas Aquinas of Sparkill, N.Y. (Television - SPN , 5 and 7 P.M. Track Metropolitan Athletics Congress Boys, Youth and Masters All-Comers Meet, at Fordham University's Lombardi Center, the Bronx, 9 A.M. Metropolitan Athletics Congress New Years' Festival. Men's and women's high school, invitational and open competition at Army Field House, West Point, N.Y., 9:30 A.M., 1:30 and 4 P.M. Eamonn Coghlan will compete in the invitational mile.

title: Elinor Streator Is Married
description: Elinor Craig Streator, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Streator Jr. of Washington and Paris, was married in Washington yesterday to Jorge Garcia Garcia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Garcia San Miguel of Gijon, Spain, and San Juan, Puerto Rico. The Rev. Charles J. Beirne, a Roman Catholic priest and assistant dean of the Georgetown University School of Business Administration, and the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the National Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: RELIGION PLAYS GROWING ROLE ON CAMPUSES
description: Every Thursday night about 25 Columbia University students who are members of a new group, Chi Alpha, gather to sing, worship and speak in tongues in Earl Hall.

title: OAK: A MATTER OF TASTE
description: ANYONE WHO HAS BEEN to a wine tasting or had the dubious privilege of spending time in the company of ''serious wine buffs'' has been exposed to some of the most impenetrable argot this side of a convention of chemists. At a recent tasting of California chardonnays, the air was thick with such foggy words as supple, chewy, fleshy, opulent, oaky, overoaked, lightly oaked, stemmy, withered and resinous.

title: Loyd Hypes Becomes Bride
description: Loyd Anne Hypes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Parmalee Hypes of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Brian Zisk, a son of Audrey Friedman and Sanford Robert Zisk, both of Dallas. The Rev. William Pietsch, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Americas Society in New York. Mrs. Zisk until recently was an account supervisor with Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Inc. in New York. Mr. Zisk is president and chief executive officer of the American Wholesale Club, a wholesale and retail concern in Dallas.

title: CHOPS ARE AT HOME IN SAUCES, TOO
description: CHOPS cut from the rib or loin section, whether veal, pork or lamb, are most frequently cooked by broiling or grilling. The meat is naturally tender so that it does not require long, slow braising or stewing to make it deliciously succulent.

title: Bogota Ties Nicaragua To Rebel Arms in Siege
description: The Government said today that rifles used by guerrillas in the assault on the Palace of Justice in November belonged to the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua.

title: Divorces in U.S. Decline For Second Straight Year
description: After two decades of increasing numbers of divorces in the United States, the Government is reporting a second consecutive year when fewer marriages were dissolved.

title: THE ELECTRONIC COLLEGE IS STILL A DIM PROSPECT
description: AT THE HEIGHT of the personal-computer boom two years ago, the nation's smallest colleges and largest universities looked at the future and said it was electronic. Now, more than a few of them aren't so sure.

title: SOMEONE HAD BLUNDERED, BUT WHO?
description: PEARL HARBOR The Verdict of History. By Gordon W. Prange with Donald M. Goldstein and Katherine V. Dillon. Illustrated. 699 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $19.95.

title: NEW TALKS SET ON VIETNAM MIA'S
description: The United States and Vietnam do not agree about much, but Hanoi has evidently accepted Washington's insistence that it must cooperate in accounting for the 1,797 Americans listed as missing in the war that ended in 1975. This week, the most senior United States officials to visit Hanoi in eight years are to meet with Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thac to lay the groundwork for closing the books.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TOBACCO CULTURE: The Mentality of the Great Tidewater Planters on the Eve of Revolution. By T. H. Breen. (Princeton University, $19.95.) Tobacco was the ''grand staple'' of colonial Virginia.

title: OPPOSITES MAY YET PROVE TO HAVE MUCH IN COMMON
description: This is a column about similarities and dissimilarities, about how things that once seemed violently opposed can come to appear almost identical, and about how time's process of reconciliation can affect present-day polemics.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THOSE childhood fears really do linger. Take the case of Tom Stern, Pleasantville native. Mr. Stern is 20 years old. But he still gets a shiver every time he remembers the man who worked at the Plaza Discount Center store where he hung out as a kid.

title: HAGGIS: HISTORY AND HUMOR
description: Tell an Englishman that you plan to visit Scotland and eat haggis and he will immediately offer sympathy and advice. ''When you get the haggis,'' he will confide, ''your hosts will give you a glass of whisky. Don't bother to drink it - just throw it on the haggis. That's the only way to get it down.'' Made of suet, spices, onions, oatmeal and a sheep's pluck - heart, liver and lights -boiled in a sheep's stomach, haggis is a form of sausage that seems to generate violent passions and arouses both reverence and mirth among the Scots, who have been eating it for at least 400 years.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS ARE VITAL LINKS IN CHAIN OF LIFE
description: THIS post-holiday period may be a good time to take stock of the role of plants in our lives and to evaluate the effectiveness of our stewardship of these valuable resource.

title: AN AMERICAN TEACHER'S ADVENTURES IN CHINA
description: THERE is nothing so heartwarming to a teacher as when he walks into a classroom and his students accord him a standing ovation. Unfortunately, this display of affection does not happen to me all that often, but it did when I taught English last summer in the People's Republic of China.

title: FANS RECALL BILL VEECK FONDLY AT SERVICE
description: The service began with a trumpeter playing Aaron Copland's ''Fanfare for the Common Man,'' and throughout the Church of St. Thomas the Apostle today there was as much a celebration of the fan in the stands as a mass for Bill Veeck.

title: ECHOES OF CHEKHOV HAUNT FRAYN'S 'BENEFACTORS'
description: In the introduction to his translation of ''The Three Sisters,'' Michael Frayn quotes from a pertinent section of Chekhov's notebooks: ''We struggle to change life so that those who come after us might be happy, but those who come after us will say as usual: it was better before, life now is worse than it used to be.'' That statement could stand as an epigraph to Frayn's ''Benefactors,'' a play that deals provocatively with the personal and societal effects of munificence and asks whether or not good will can be an end in itself. The play is a stimulating and socially relevant consideration of the wages of altruism.

title: COLOMBIA ACCUSED OF RIGHTS ABUSES
description: A human rights organization based in the United States has accused Colombia's armed forces of being responsible for summary executions, torture and ''disappearances'' in its campaign against leftist guerrillas.

title: The Isolated Scientist
description: I ALWAYS SECRETLY HOPE THAT people won't ask me what I do. When I tell them I'm a physicist, conversation stops. My life as a scientist, in fact, is a life of isolation. Nonscientists seem to have no interest in learning much more about me or my work. Other scientists, the ones who best understand what I do, are not much help. Often, they are my closest competitors.

title: HAWKS DEFEAT BULLS, 111-100
description: Dominique Wilkins scored a game-high 27 points and Kevin Willis added 20 tonight to pace the Atlanta Hawks to a 111-100 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: HOW NOT TO GET TRAPPED IN A CHOREOGRAPHIC RUT
description: One of the most likable things about Mark Morris as a choreographer is the way he romps through styles and forms like a frisky puppy.

title: OPERA: 2 CHANGES IN 'FIGARO'
description: EACH new encounter with Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' reaffirms our culture's highest musical standards, provides a moral parable of Johnsonian breadth and wit and, if the performance is a decent one, makes for an exquisite evening of theater. Thursday night's Metropolitan Opera performance, much more than merely decent, featured two additions to the cast.

title: COMPARING COSTS IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: The following is a sampling of packages and charter programs available to the islands in the Caribbean and the Bahamas that have direct (same-plane, but not necessarily nonstop) service from New York or Miami. Both package and charter programs usually combine air travel and accommodations with other features, such as airport transfers. Although the listing includes a choice of hotel accommodations in various price ranges, it is not comprehensive; for more information, contact a travel agent, the tourist office of the island or a participating airline.

title: Blair R. Silliman Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Beach Silliman of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Blair Richmond Silliman to Robert James MacLeod, the son of Marlene MacLeod of Westport, Conn., and James MacLeod of Dallas. A June wedding is planned.

title: Pop/In the Clubs
description: Four years ago, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, stirred up some musical excitement when it unveiled one of the few existing reproducing pianos, a sophisticated cousin of the much better known player piano. The subtleties of expression possible on the reproducing piano induced such great pianists as Paderewski, Rachmaninoff, Gieseking and Horowitz as well as popular songwriters - George Gershwin, Victor Herbert, Richard Rodgers, Vincent Youmans - to cut rolls for the piano between 1910 and 1930.

title: Ballet Theater Dancer To Join Cast of Musical
description: Victor Barbee, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will join the cast of ''Song & Dance'' on Jan. 13. Mr. Barbee, on a leave of absence from the ballet company, replaces Christopher d'Amboise in the Broadway musical. Mr. d'Amboise has returned to his New York City Ballet position as a principal dancer.

title: BLACK HAWKS FINALLY WIN AT COLISEUM
description: It did not take the bullying tactics Al Secord and Behn Wilson occasionally use, nor did it require shimmying theatrics from Denis Savard, the league's seventh-best scorer in the league. What the Islanders did tonight was show a collective effort in mediocrity that cost them a 4-1 defeat to the Chicago Black Hawks, a team that had not won here since Feb. 16, 1974.

title: UNDER BRITAIN'S FABLED CIVILITY, REAL CIVILITY
description: As almost everybody who has visited there will tell you, England is a country full of extraordinarily polite people. Only the English themselves attempt to deny it or explain away the phenomenon, citing the humbling effects of World War II or the beastly English weather (''Any kind of sun makes us grateful'') as possible reasons for the surface politesse observed. But an Englishman attempting to deny his own country's courtesy only serves to reinforce the impression, and last May, when a group of us traveled to England for a walking tour through Wiltshire, Oxfordshire and Berkshire Counties, any number of English men and women had a chance to turn their reputation for civility on its ear. None did.

title: Melissa Jackson Weds W. J. Morgan
description: Melissa Carow Jackson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Eldred Jackson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to W. James Morgan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Morgan of Washington and Merrifield, Va. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VIENNA CHOIR BOYS The Vienna Choir Boys - a group that has made more than 3,000 appearances in the United States since 1932 - will appear Friday in Montclair, the only New Jersey stop on its current tour.

title: ALBURQUERQUE
description: Until recently Albuquerque was more a place to rattle through than stop and see, but an architectural explosion has changed that, providing new (and refurbished) hotels and motels, unusual and restored theaters, a nature park with six miles of trails, shops and boutiques, art galleries . . . and now the largest natural history museum to be opened in the United States in the 20th century.

title: The Life Of a C.E.O.
description: N. R. Kleinfield's article ''What It Takes: The Life of a C.E.O.'' (Dec. 1), provides a broad picture of Hicks Waldron's life style and values as well as the interesting details of his daily life. The article depicts Mr. Waldron as a new breed of C.E.O., but provides little explanation for the development of his style or why it is appropriate today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN IN WAR. By Shelley Saywell. (Viking, $17.95.) Though rarely acknowledged, the role women have played in modern combat is extensive.

title: SCIASCIA IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
NEWARK: SPANISH-CUM-PORTUGESE
description: TO FIT into the belt-tightening regime that traditionally follows the extravagances of December, a visit to one of the informal Spanish-cum-Portuguese restaurants in Newark's Ironbound section is a good bet. Bountiful seafood platters and hefty portions here are the drawing card at refreshingly reasonable prices.

title: YIDDISH PLAY COMES TO AUDIENCES
description: WHILE you don't have to be Jewish to enjoy a Yiddish musical - in these days of simultaneous translations, you don't even have to know the language - it couldn't hurt.

title: INSURANCE PROBLEMS A THREAT TO BIRTHING CENTERS
description: THE Family Childbirth Center in New Haven, the only non-hospital institution for delivering babies in Connecticut, opened last March with a distinct mission: to offer women an alternative to the standardized care of hospitals and the often impersonal manner of their medical staffs.

title: BROOKLYN'S POLYTECH, A STORYBOOK SUCCESS
description: IN A converted razor factory in downtown Brooklyn, across the street from a pizza parlor and a hardware store, resides a school whose contributions to science stand in wild contrast to its surroundings. Over the years it has been a key center of research in the development of microwave physics, radar, polymers and the space program. More recently it has played a key role in the promotion of Metrotech, a 16-acre academic-industrial research park in Brooklyn. And just this year the school - Polytechnic University, the newest of several names it has taken over its 131-year history - was awarded a research grant to develop technology for the ''Star Wars'' project, the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: NOTING A NATIONAL INSTITUTION
description: IN the best of all possible worlds it would be enough to announce that the Museum of Cartoon Art is celebrating the 35th anniversary of ''Peanuts'' and leave it at that. After all, Charles Schulz's comic strip is a national institution, like the work of Andrew Wyeth, and as such needs no critical exegesis to stay alive.

title: FOR U.S. HOCKEY, A START TOWARD '88
description: Preparations for the 1988 United States Olympic Hockey Team got under way in earnest during the holidays. Besides sending a team of youngsters to the 10-day World Junior Tournament in Hamilton, Ontario, the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States assembled two ''select'' teams of college all-stars to face international opposition.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Speaker-elect of the State Assembly, Charles L. Hardwick, says that certain legislative practices violate the public trust and that he intends to do something about them when the Assembly returns for its first session of the new year.

title: RIOT AT PRISON ENDS IN RELIEF AND A DISPUTE
description: With all hostages safe and all inmates accounted for, officials said today they considered it fortunate that an uprising by inmates at West Virginia Penitentiary had resulted in only three deaths.

title: THE LURE OF COMPUTERS FOR THE PHONE INDUSTRY
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: CAPTURING ANIMALS IN THE LENS
description: THOSE who make light of photographing animals are missing a great challenge. This genre provides a test of a photographer's patience, technical skills and understanding of creatures.

title: GOLDEN FLEECE SEES A GLOWING FUTURE
description: ''We want to carry on the best tradition of Off Off Broadway,''

title: THE 'GRAVE MISTAKE' OF GIVE-BACKS
description: LABOR leaders tend to be skeptics. Whenever an employer talks of labor-management cooperation, an old saying goes, hold onto your wallet.

title: CREMINS MOVES UP IN A HURRY
description: BOBBY CREMINS, the former street kid from the South Bronx, will coach his first game in Madison Square Garden Thursday night, and no one can say Georgia Tech's 38-year-old coach hasn't come a long way in a short time.

title: BABY BOOMLET SPURS HUNT FOR SPACE AND TEACHERS
description: AFTER 13 years of steadily declining enrollment in the nation's public schools, babies are booming again and school boards across the nation are scrambling to find new - and sometimes old - classroom space and more teachers. The student increases follow on the heels of plummeting student enrollment that in the 1970's and the early 80's forced schools nationwide to board up buildings and lay off thousands of teachers. Many school districts, often in Sun Belt states but also in the industrialized states of the North, find themselves suddenly shifting gears, thinking now in terms of growth rather than decline.

title: WOMAN TO HEAD COLUMBIA LAW
description: The next dean of Columbia Law School will be a mother of three who says she got where she is because of, not in spite of, her experience as a woman.

title: STUDENT DEATH BRINGS FIGHT FOR SAFER FISHING BOATS
description: Robert and Peggy Barry knew little about commercial fishing or its dangers when their 20-year-old son, Peter, a student at Yale, got a summer job on a salmon boat off Alaska's coast.

title: LAST WEEK I HATED THE 49ERS, TODAY I HATE THE BEARS
description: I hate the Chicago Bears. I have always hated the Chicago Bears.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of transmission errors, an article last Sunday on Bridgeton's tricentennial incorrectly stated the city's radical makeup. It is 60 percent white, 30 percent black And 10 percent mix of Spanish-speaking, Oriental and other nationalities. Also Bridgeton has served as the seat of Cumberland county since 1749.

title: THE COOLING OF CONDO FEVER
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: FOR LIBERAL-ARTS GRADS, AN IMPROVING FORECAST
description: PATRICIA HOWREY, Joseph Schwendler and Joseph Anthony feel lucky. Immediately upon graduating from Alma College in Michigan last May they found jobs. Miss Howrey is with the Arthur Andersen & Company accounting firm in Grand Rapids. Mr. Schwendler is a marketing representative at Bendix in Elyria, Ohio. Mr. Anthony found work in a chemistry department at Hughes Aircraft in El Segundo, Calif.

title: Winifred Stoltzfus, Teacher, Is Wed To Christian Host, Computer Analyst
description: Winifred Lorna Stoltzfus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Stoltzfus Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christian Thorkil Host, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stig Host of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Orford, N.H. The Rev. Dr. Wallace M. Alston performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: bOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: LOOK-ALIKES. Written and illustrated by Henrik Drescher. Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13. (Ages 4 to 8) Rudy and his monkey, Buster, bolt from the breakfast table to their playhouse, where their toy look-alikes spend the day in bizarre adventures captured in tense, wiry illustrations.

title: WHEN A PHONOGRAPH ENCHANTED A SMALL BOY 60 YEARS AGO
description: Stepping from one year into the next often prompts rumination about the past. The filters of memory usually smooth the path of these backward journeys, which is what makes nostalgia so comfortable. But I had quite a jolt on New Year's Day, when I realized that 1986 marks the 60th year of my involvement with electrical sound equipment.

title: PRISON RIOT GETS RESULTS
description: Prisoners at the West Virginia Penitentiary in Moundsville revolted late New Year's Day, taking control of an entire wing and holding 15 guards and one other worker hostage. By the time the episode ended two days later, three prisoners had been killed, correction officials had signed an agreement with the prisoners on live television and Gov. Arch A. Moore had met with the inmates after they released the hostages and returned to their cells.

title: DEBATE SET ON RAISES FOR HIGH STATE AIDES
description: THE Legislature will begin debating this week a bill designed to increase the salaries of the Governor, cabinet officers, judges, county Prosecutors and the lawmakers themselves.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: THINK SNOW You don't necessarily need snow to brush up on your skiing, but it certainly makes things a bit more interesting. So even though the Long Island State Park Commission is conducting Cross Country Skiing Clinics ''rain or shine and with or without snow'' at seven parks, a little of that white stuff could go a long way. Covering basic skills and the selection and care of equipment, the clinics begin today at 10 A.M. at Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale and continue Sundays through Feb. 16, when the final clinic is held at Sunken Meadow State Park in Kings Park. The sessions are free, and, except for those at Caumsett State Park in Lloyd Neck on Jan. 19 (423-1770) and Caleb Smith State Park in Smithtown on Feb. 2 (265-1054), don't require advance registration. Students must bring their own skis. For a complete schedule, call 669-1000, extension 247.SPANISH CHRISTMAS

title: Miss Preston Has Wedding
description: The Convent of the Sacred Heart Chapel was the setting in Manhattan yesterday for the marriage of Vivian Marie Preston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Preston of New York and Orford, N.H., to Clifton Park Gerald, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Park S. Gerald of Wellesley Hills, Mass. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title:
ART;
DOLLS THAT CERTAINLY AREN'T TOYS
description: AT this time of year more than any other, dolls are very much in evidence. The post-Christmas clutter of many homes undoubtedly includes Cabbage Patch Kids, He-Man figures and Teddy Ruxpins, but few of the Island's children will have found under the tree anything like the dolls on display at the Hillwood Art Gallery, on the C. W. Post Center campus in Brookville.

title: THE TANGLED POLITICS OF SALT I AND II
description: The Reagan Administration's recent report to Congress on alleged Soviet arms control violations seemed to follow a predictable pattern. Allegations of substantial concern were lumped together with relatively minor charges of no apparent military significance.

title: IN WEST BANK, ISRAELI POLICIES TO IMPROVE THE 'QUALITY OF LIFE' GET MIXED REVIEWS
description: Since Prime Minister Shimon Peres's national unity Government came into office 16 months ago, it has viewed an improvement in the ''quality of life'' of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip as one of its achievements.

title: HOW OIL SQUEEZES THE TEXAS ECONOMY
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: Y.A. TITTLE: '85 IS A REPLAY OF '63
description: OVER the years, the memories fade. After all, the last time I put on a Giants uniform was more than 20 years ago. Since then, I have always pulled for the Giants, but I have pretty much become a 49ers fan, because I played for them for so long and now live and work in the San Francisco area.

title: STAGING TWAIN AND FRIENDS
description: THE best thing about the Victory Repertory Theater is the way it can tell a story.

title: Diary Of a Cancer Patient
description: Because cancer will strike one out of every four people, Nathan Perlmutter's ''Diary of a Cancer Patient'' (Nov. 24) will surely touch many people, as it touched me.

title: POSTINGSHistory for Sale; Teaneck, Circa 1839
description: The old frame building known as the Leland Ferry House, which was built on the Hackensack River in 1839 in what is now Teaneck, is up for sale. The historic, 11-room house, which sits on a three-acre parcel and has a lawn that sweeps down to the river, is a remnant of one of the last large farms that once dominated Teaneck when it was a farming community. The town evolved into a suburb of New York City at the turn of the century, had a spurt of growth after World War II and now has few large open tracts like the Leland Ferry property.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: CLEAN Water Action Project, a national environmental organization begun with Ralph Nader's help 15 years ago, is recasting its New Jersey chapter to enhance cooperation among local groups.

title: CALENDAR
description: Wednesday - Tidelands Resource Council meets in Room 702, Labor and Industry Building, Trenton, 10 A.M. - Solid Waste Advisory Council meets at the Ocean County Office Building, Hooper Avenue, Toms River, 10 A.M.

title: The Presidential Debates
description: Undaunted by the major parties' decision to sponsor debates between their 1988 Presidential candidates, the League of Women Voters is proceeding to organize its own more inclusive debate program. The league has run the only national debates in the past three Presidential elections and once, in 1980, included an independent candidate as well as the Republican and Democratic standard-bearers.

title: MIXED VIEWS ON THE ECONOMY
description: Maintaining a tradition that began long before Ronald Reagan moved to the Oval Office, the Administration's economic seers last week were decidedly upbeat about the new year.

title: LAND MINE KILLS 2 SOUTH AFRICAN WHITES
description: Two whites were killed and two others wounded today when their pickup truck hit a land mine in the north of the country, close to the Botswana border, the South African military said.

title: CHOPS ARE AT HOME IN SAUCES, TOO
description: CHOPS cut from the rib or loin section, whether veal, pork or lamb, are most frequently cooked by broiling or grilling. The meat is naturally tender so that it does not require long, slow braising or stewing to make it deliciously succulent.

title: WEIGHING THE ROLE OF THE SCHOOL BOARD
description: Is it ''Time to Abolish Boards of Education?'' The letter to the Long Island editor from Walter Skretch [ Dec. 1. ] published under that headline says yes. As a member of a Long Island board of education (Hewlett-Woodmere), I say no.

title: Data Bank; January 5, 1986
Camille A. Pane Is Married To Dr. Stephen P. Hunger
description: Camille A. Pane, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John T. Pane of Tenafly, N.J., was married at Le Chateau there yesterday to Dr. Stephen P. Hunger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Hunger of South Windsor, Conn.

title: PANCAKES
description: To the Editor: The article on ''Pancakes With a Flourish'' (Travel, Nov. 17) brought back memories of 25 years ago when my family and I were living in Holland. We discovered the Pannekoekenhuysje & Rotisserie at 51 Steenstraat in Oudt Leyden.

title: THE THIRD WORLD CHALLENGES DETROIT
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: THE QUALITY OF CARE FROM H.M.O.'S
description: A letter to the Long Island Weekly editor on Dec. 15 asked whether health maintenance organizations would ''indeed improve the quality of health care on Long Island, particularly to those people at greatest risk.''

title: COMPOSING FOR HIS SUPPER
description: SCHUBERT AND HIS VIENNA By Charles Osborne. Illustrated. 209 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: A CASE FOR PEACE PROFITEERING THEORIST OF GUNS AND BUTTER
description: When he set out to write a book about the relationship between economic power and military conquest, Richard Rosecrance spent two years finishing his first draft - then he threw it out. ''I realized I hadn't found the right focus,'' Mr. Rosecrance said in a recent telephone interview from his office at Cornell University. ''I wanted to attempt something new - to combine the role of economics and the role of strategy and defense in a general work of international relations. No one had tried to bring these two things together in that way. So I started over.'' The result was ''The Rise of the Trading State,'' a book the author hopes will lend historical perspective to the trade-offs between economic and military power, and stimulate new debate on the alternatives now facing American policy makers. ''Nations have really always had a choice as they make their way in the world,'' he said. ''They can expand and conquer territory, or they can decide to stay just within their own borders and develop their own economic strength through development at home and trade abroad.'' For the United States, the problem of balancing economic and military strategies is becoming increasingly acute. ''It can't be all or nothing,''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A DEPARTMENT of Defense Procurement Center, established in October at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, will begin helping small businesses this month.

title: ALBANY ADJUSTS TO LACK OF LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
description: The ornate office where Mario M. Cuomo spent four frustrating years as New York State's second in command is empty; the door leading to the State Senate chamber is locked.

title: KAPP TO CONDUCT SYMPHONY CONCERT
description: RICHARD KAPP has become increasingly well-known in the county through his intriguing programs with the Philharmonia Virtuosi, and now he is ready for another, quite different sort of musical challenge: On Jan. 18 he makes his debut as guest-conductor of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester. Although it has not been officially announced, Martin Rich, who is celebrating his 15th anniversary as the orchestra's music director, plans to resign at the end of this season, and it was his suggestion that a visiting maestro be invited to take over one of the subscription concerts.

title: ACADEMICS LOOK AT THE ASSEMBLY LINE
description: When the American Historical Association convened its centennial meeting in New York last weekend, the traditional historians were there, those whose specialties include such subjects as Colonial economics and politics before the Civil War.

title: SHARING BY 5 COLLEGES, A 20-YEAR SUCCESS STORY
description: HAMPSHIRE COLLEGE was short one chemistry instructor in the fall semester, so students who needed the introductory chemistry course he taught took it at Smith College instead. Smith needed help from a neighbor too; it wanted to offer accounting courses in both semesters this year but did not have the faculty, so it ''borrowed'' two full professors and two associate professors from the University of Massachusetts, by paying their overtime.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DOING BUSINESS ABROAD. By Gavin Kennedy. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Gavin Kennedy views international business negotiators as heroic knights of capitalism suffering from jet lag.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: TEACHING MONKEYS TO AID HANDICAPPED
description: AT home Christi is invariably identified as the chief suspect in such mischief as unraveled cassette tapes, spilled cologne and the scattered remains of dismembered Hydrox cookies.

title: Sydney Mesh Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gene I. Mesh of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sydney Mesh, to Michael Harris, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Harris of Neponsit, Queens.

title: Michael Reagor Harbert Marries Martha A. Baird
description: Martha Adrienne Baird, administrative manager of the Hampton Medical Center in Southampton, L.I., was married Dec. 24 to Michael Reagor Harbert, president of Executive Productions and Communications Inc. in New York.

title: ODE TO GREED
description: O Greed! You have never had a decent press. For centuries -yea, millennia - you have been blacklisted as one of the seven sins, usually under the names of Avarice or Covetousness, that lead to the death of the spirit.

title: SKIRMISHES ON THE ECONOMIC FRONTIER
description: Japan seems resigned to the prospect of a continuing deterioration in its trade relations with the United States, possibly at a faster pace this year. Politicians and business leaders assume that the two countries will stop well short of an all-out trade war, but some wonder how long the tension can persist before it starts to undercut the foundation of an otherwise friendly relationship.

title: BUDGET OVERTURE: MAYORAL BLUES
description: Tuning up for negotiations over the 1986-87 New York City budget, Mayor Koch tried last week to whistle up some help from Albany. Without funds from the Legislature to compensate for expected Federal cutbacks, he said, the city will have to forgo increasing the size of the police force and providing more money for education, transportation and other services as planned in the fiscal year that starts July 1.

title: FARMER GROUPS SEEN AFFECTING 1986 ELECTIONS
description: The economic crisis gripping rural America has given rise to dozens of politically active farm groups that could influence the results of this year's Congressional elections.

title: AN EARTHWORK LOOKS TO THE SKY
description: One of the undecided problems of our time is the final status of the earthwork as artwork - the huge construction that is set up in remote places, often at great expense, and is necessarily available to only a very few people. Is it a moral breakthrough, a parable of purity that could be acted out in no other way, and a lasting enrichment of human awareness? Or is it the very rich man's last ridiculous toy, and the natural descendant of the 18th-century folly that looked like a castle, a bridge or a tower and served no practical purpose at all?

title: MCMAHON KEYED UP FOR PLAYOFF CLASH
description: IN a quiet moment the other day, after practice, Jim McMahon was talking about big games. Oddly, for a quarterback with such a colorful past and successful present, he hasn't played in as many big games as you might imagine - a few in his college career at Brigham Young, a few more in four seasons with the Chicago Bears. But not that many.

title: UNA MERKEL DIES AT AGE OF 82; FROM SILENT FILMS TO A TONY
description: Una Merkel, a Hollywood veteran and a Tony Award winner, died Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 82 years old.

title: A SHOW OF UNITY ALONG THE BORDER
description: THE most important result to emerge from the meeting Friday between President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado of Mexico is probably the fact that nothing dramatic occurred, there were no sharp disagreements or clashes.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALBERT SCHWEITZER'S MISSION: Healing and Peace. By Norman Cousins. (Norton, $16.95.) The first half of this book, an adaptation of an earlier reminiscence by Norman Cousins of his 1957 visit to Albert Schweitzer's clinic in West Africa, has all the grace of a snapshot prominently featuring the photographer's thumb. Mr. Cousins, formerly the editor of The Saturday Review and author of ''Anatomy of an Illness,'' appears in every scene.

title: A Little-Known Allergy
description: I read with great interest Amy Singer's article concerning the number of people who develop allergies to the nickel contained in inexpensive costume jewelry (''A Little-Known Allergy,'' Dec. 15).

title: UNSOLVED EQUATION: HOW TO STOP THE TEACHER DRAIN
description: TEACHERS, especially those in the math and science fields, have created an equation that nobody quite knows how to solve: Essentially, at the same time that more of them are needed in public schools, more of them are leaving the profession. Many leave long before retirement age, citing low income and poor working conditions, and even the negative image of the profession in general.

title: ITALIAN AIDES MEET ON LIBYA SITUATION
description: Italian Government officials met today to review the evidence of a possible Libyan connection to recent terrorist attacks here and in Vienna, amid growing anxiety about the possibility of military reprisals against Libya by the United States or Israel.

title: WHEN WRITERS TALK AMONG THEMSELVES
description: FAME, prestige and sheer seniority make the writer a public figure, in some countries a very public figure. And this is when writers not only tend to get more service-minded but are expected to be more collegial. With age, and with a certain volume of accomplishment - whose vol-ume depends precisely on the writer's having been able to sit in a room every day, year after year, alone - comes a stack of invitations to board planes, cross borders and sometimes oceans, check into large hotels, in order to palaver . . . with each other.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 5, 1986 Fiction

title: OPERA: 'IOLANTHE,' BY GILBERT AND SULLIVAN
description: THE New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players have been giving ''Iolanthe'' at Symphony Space (Broadway at 95th Street). It was most enjoyable Friday night, and a visit to the final performance - today at 3 P.M. - is recommended. (There will be one more, in Stamford, Conn., on January 11.) ''Iolanthe'' - about fairies, the law, the House of Lords, a fellow who is part fairy (waist up), a chancery ward desired by the chancellor, and complications arising therefrom - is one of the best Savoy operas; the N.Y.G.S.P. production has enough good voices, enough panache, enough attention to detail and enough strength in the supporting elements to bring it off well.

title: NEW YORK RESERVOIR LEVELS CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The water in New York City's reservoirs has risen to near-normal levels despite below-normal rainfall in December, city officials say, and consumption remains lower than before last year's drought.

title: DEBATING SALTWATER LICENSES
description: THERE is probably no issue that elicits more impassioned debate among anglers than the proposals for salt water fishing licenses that surface with increasing frequency in the various coastal states that do not yet require them.

title: 'Magical' Ferry
description: FOR a year, April Kinser, an artist, importuned the New York City Bureau of Ferry and General Aviation Operations to add a big splash of magenta to its ferryboats as a ''sort of magical'' touch, ''suggestive of sunset.'' In mid-1984, the bureau caved in.

title: 'KING AND I' RETURNS TO ITS OTHER VALUES
description: IN what could be called a back-to-basics production, An Evening Dinner Theater's staging of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' restores the musical to its rightful focus - though it is hardly fulfilled.

title: COLLEGE SPORTS CAN BE BETTER
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PUBLIC-SCHOOL NURSES GET IN-SERVICE TRAINING
description: CAROL A. BROSMITH, the school nurse at the Edward W. Morley Elementary School in West Hartford, concedes that when she attended grammar school, students were often afraid of their school nurse.

title: Brenda O'Brien Plans April Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert O'Brien of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Brenda O'Brien to William Steele Brazier Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Brazier of Fairfield, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
WORKS BY WOMEN ON VIEW IN STAMFORD
description: WHAT amounts to a visual anthem in praise of female artists fills the newly refurbished and sun-filled galleries of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center through Feb. 23.

title: Cable TV
description: Film buffs can sample cable premieres of two 1984 hits this week on Saturday. ''Micki & Maude,'' a slyly delicious caper with Dudley Moore, Amy Irving and Ann Reinking bows in at 8 P.M. on HBO. Then at 9 P.M. on WHT comes ''Starman,'' a crisp, inventive sci-fi fable with Jeff Bridges and Karen Allen. But to keep the new year rolling, nostalgia buffs may prefer the flavor of a Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers musical. The cable week offers three. Count 'em: ''Top Hat,'' ''Follow the Fleet'' and ''Swing Time.'' ''Top Hat'' (1935) takes off - and seldom subsides - Sunday at 4:30 P.M. on Cinemax and Thursday at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. on WHT, with the peerless dancers in top form and that wonderful Irving Berlin score. His melodic batch for ''Follow the Fleet'' (1936) - Monday at 10 A.M. and 6 P.M. on Cinemax - doesn't match it, with a single, haunting exception: ''Let's Face the Music and Dance.'' It's one of the team's great terpsichore turns and not a bad theme song for a new year. The dance is a stately pantomime pairing two luckless strangers. At the end, they stroll away then suddenly dip forward, backs arched, for a high kick toward the future. It makes a thrilling coda.

title: KNICKS SURPRISED BY THE DISMISSAL
description: The news traveled quickly. Minutes before he was going to leave his hotel room here Friday morning and walk across the street to practice, Hubie Brown's telephone rang. The voice on the line told him to represent management in telling his coaching staff and team of the latest development.

title: GRAND VEFOUR
description: To The Editor: Apropos of the Grand Vefour (Travel, Aug. 11), one of the great restaurants in Paris, Raymond Oliver, the owner-chef must not be forgotten. He made Americans conscious of the grande cuisine of France.

title: FINDING AND MARKETING THAT SOMETHING SPECIAL
description: SAINT VINCENT COLLEGE in Latrobe, Pa., does not have the academic reputation of a Harvard University, the big-time football team of an Ohio State University or the beautiful setting of a Dartmouth College. What it does have is an airport across the street, and in an age when small colleges are attempting to capitalize on any advantage they might have, that was enough to spawn an entire marketing program.

title: 'A FLOOD OUTSIDE OUR DOOR'
description: THE IMMIGRATION TIME BOMB The Fragmenting of America. By Richard D. Lamm and Gary Imhoff. 271 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: PUTTING THE FUN BACK INTO I.R.A.'S
description: Investors are often reluctant to buy stocks when starting their Individual Retirement Accounts because the $2,000 initial investment often cannot be efficiently put to work. Not many good issues sell for $20 or less, and commissions on odd-lot stock purchases of less than 100 shares can cut into returns.

title: 'PERSONAL TOUCH' AT THE THORPE
description: ''W HEN I collect this scrap, I pile it up as high as I can go . . . and then I Whizzo along the street to the scrap yard. Yeah, like, it's a flying sculpture. Every day, I'm making a new one.'' Those colorful words are mounted on the wall beside a photograph of a man on a New York sidewalk with a shopping cart full of junk. His ''art by accumulation'' is among the more-eccentric environments documented in an off-beat show at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery here.

title: VICENZA
description: To the Editor: In his excellent description of Palladio's Vicenza (''Where Palladio Thrived,'' Travel, Dec. 1), Olivier Bernier leaves out of his description of the Teatro Olimpico the principal reason for the three-tiered stage set. The levels of buildings start high in the back and end low in front.

title: COMING BACK FROM TRANQUILITY OF LIVING IN THE HILLS
description: DICKENS had his ''Tale of Two Cities,'' but for me it is the tale of two states.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN POMONA
description: WITH its setting at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains, the Rockland County village of Pomona could easily be mistaken for a rustic New England hamlet.

title: AT HOME IN OLD PLANTATIONS
description: Imagine the Caribbean as it was 20 or 30 years ago, before most of that 2,800 mile-long necklace of islands from the Bahamas to Aruba became as popular as it is today. Picture empty beaches, remnants of the old British colonial ''plantocracy'' in the form of inns at restored great houses and a leisurely rhythm of life. Dream of days under shady fig trees enveloped in the scent of frangipani, with nothing much to do except swim, sunbathe, windsurf, snorkel and play a lazy game of tennis (or even croquet).

title: A WINNING RECIPE FOR CHAMER CONCERTS
description: About a week before Christmas, Charles Wadsworth sat in the living room of his East 79th Street apartment surveying a paper mountain that covered the floor and spilled onto most of the furniture surfaces. Among its components were musical scores, arranged in a system only he could decipher; letters from musicians, audience members and partisans of various composers, each offering suggestions; memoranda detailing the availability of a few dozen performers; and pillars of LP's, cassettes and open-reel tapes.

title: TESTING ENERGY EFFICIENCY
description: AN EXPERIMENTAL energy-efficient house, built with rigid polystyrene panels and partly financed by the state, is scheduled to undergo performance tests this winter.

title: Julia Brown Is Betrothed To Clifford B. Thompson
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Barton Brown of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julia Farrington Brown to Clifford Brian Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Henry Thompson of Chelsea, Mass.

title: POSTINGSOffice Rentals; Queens Rx
description: A 60-year old former furniture warehouse in Forest Hills, Queens, is being transformed into professional offices by Benjamin Frankenstein and Joseph S. Goldfarb, developers of Corona, Queens. The six-story structure at 101-20 Queens Boulevard, on the corner of 67th Drive, has been vacant for a decade.

title: STUDENTS APPLY POLITICAL SCIENCE IN YEAR'S FELLOWSHIP AT NEW YORK CITY HALL
description: When James Lowe graduated from Yale University last May, he had what he called ''the classic New York citizen's jaded view that government can't do anything.''

title: Organizing to Build More Housing
description: IN a curious stroke of timing, Mayor Koch has formally sought the advice of major developers in the city on how to pick up the pace of housing construction at the very time that a formidably qualified committee of developers, former housing officials, nonprofit producers and others has given him advice that may take him aback.

title: COLLECTING TRAINS ON A GRAND SCALE
description: JAMES BRADLEY is a railroad buff on a magnificent scale - ''12 inches to the foot,'' as he describes it.

title: The Electric Train Set
description: Who says trains are for boys? Rites of passage, hah! My parents gave me a passenger Lionel, with red cars and a gold observation platform, the Christmas I turned 5. For several years I practiced the ''omnipotence our culture teaches boys to expect,'' then packed it away when I turned to writing stories and making lists of boys I liked.

title: Philadelphia Inquiry's Cost
description: An investigation into the May 13 bombing by the police of a house occupied by the radical group Move has cost Philadelphia more than $700,000 so far, and the city Controller, Joseph Vignola, says it could exceed $1 million. The 11-member commission conducting the inquiry was originally given a budget of $259,000. A bomb dropped from a helicopter started a fire that killed 11 people inside the Move building and burned down 61 homes.

title: THE YEAR OF THE SPY (IN A MANNER OF SPEAKING)
description: The year just past will, perhaps fortunately, have no great claim on history. Partly in consequence it will be remembered, at least slightly, as the year of the spy, more especially as the year of the recidivist spy.

title: C. L. MacNELLY
description: C. L. MacNelly, publisher of The Saturday Evening Post from 1961-64, died Thursday at the age of 65.

title: SAINT-GAUDENS
description: To the Editor: Readers interested in Augustus Saint-Gaudens, the sculptor whose memorial to Marian Hooper Adams was so movingly described by Joseph Gallagher (Travel, Dec. 1), may wish to visit the Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site, near Cornish, N.H., on the Connecticut River about 20 miles south of Hanover.

title: HOW DONALD REGAN RUNS THE WHITE HOUSE
description: IT IS 7:15 A.M., AND THE CHAUFFEUR-driven blue limousine moves through the rain into the west basement of the White House. Donald T. Regan opens the door and walks up a narrow flight of steps into his office where aides, in shirt sleeves, await him. His mood is bleak. En route from his sprawling riverfront home in Mt. Vernon, Va., the White House chief of staff has read the morning newspapers. His eyes had widened over an article containing leaked information about proposed cuts in domestic spending that the White House had planned to announce in February.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AFTER THE FLOOD. By P. C. Jersild. Translated by Lone Thygesen Blecher and George Blecher. (Morrow, $15.95.) About the only optimism inherent in this doomsday novel by a former physician who is one of Sweden's most popular and prolific writers comes in the title.

title: REFUND PLAN FOR TRANS-ATLANTIC PASSENGERS
description: A refund of sorts may await you if you flew to Britain or back between March 1, 1982, and March 31, 1984. If approved by Federal District Court in Washington - a hearing has been set for March 17 - the refund will be in the form of a coupon entitling you to $20 to $50 off your next one-way flight on the same route.

title: JEAN STAPLETON: 'STARDOM ISN'T A GOAL'
description: It has been five years since Edith Bunker was last told by her husband, Archie, to ''stifle'' herself on the landmark television series ''All in the Family.'' In 1980, the actress Jean Stapleton, whose portrayal of the dimwitted but lovable and understanding wife left an indelible mark on the American consciousness, decided to bow out of the long-running series (later renamed ''Archie Bunker's Place''). Accordingly, Edith ceremoniously passed on to television heaven.

title: AN OLD IDEA GETS A NEW LOOK
description: Federal officials went public last week with a plan to make some of New York's mass transit private. The Urban Mass Transportation Administration released a letter in which it urged city and state officials to require competitive bidding for some transit services.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CONVICT. By James Lee Burke. (Louisiana State University, Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $9.95.) These old-fashioned tales of the Louisiana swamps and postwar Texas are more whittled than hewn.

title: Ann Woodbury Plans To Be Married in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Ann Woodbury and Daniel Yalowitz, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Woodbury of Worcester, Mass., have announced. Mr. Yalowitz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nat Yalowitz of New York.

title: BODY DOUBLES
description: Barry McGuigan, the Irish World Boxing Association featherweight champion, doesn't want any surprises when he faces Fernando Sosa of Argentina in a title fight Feb. 15. According to McGuigan's agent, Barney Eastwood, McGuigan is recruiting two sparring partners from Mexico built along Sosa's lines. ''We are looking for stocky, aggressive boys, similar to Sosa,'' Eastwood said.

title: POSTINGSNassau Coliseum Show; Florida Properties
description: New Yorkers who feel themselves drawn to the Sunbelt and want to learn more about properties there without the necessity of a trip South will be able to see what developers have to offer next weekend at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings * 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds * 8.33 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds * 7.48 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts * 6.82 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 12.43 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York * 16.75 Continental Illinois, Chicago * 17.00 Bank of America, San Francisco * 19.50

title: NEW YORKERS ARE WARY OF FEDERAL PLAN
description: Officials in the New York metropolitan area say they are concerned about a Reagan Administration proposal to combine mass transit assistance and highway funds into a single reduced Federal grant.

title: REQUIRED READING ON 'RIGHT TO DIE'
description: In her article, ''Facing Death With Strength,'' [ Opinion page, Dec. 8 ] Jan Henson Dow draws a false comparison when she says her experience was ''similar to that of Betty Rollin.''

title: THE FIRST WORD IN PARENTING: LISTED
description: ALL the people who read this article have at least one thing in common. They are parents or they might be parents or they had parents.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Ubiquitous Exhortation Some of us see advertising as a vice peculiar to our country and age. Not so, says Mark Girouard in ''Cities and People'' (Yale University).

title: NEW VIEW OF UNIVERSE SHOWS SEA OF BUBBLES TO WHICH STARS CLING
description: A new three-dimensional map of part of the universe shows that it is composed of gigantic ''bubbles,'' with the stars and galaxies, probably including our Milky Way, gathered on the surfaces.

title: SMALL COLLEGES RIDE OUT THE STORM
description: LITTLE did the trustees of Wilson College realize when they voted in 1979 to close the tiny liberal-arts institution in southern Pennsylvania how difficult it would be to put out of business. Its enrollment had fallen to less than 125, and a modest endowment to cover its escalating costs had been depleted. But Wilson, in Chambersburg, Pa., is still alive. In response to a suit by alumnae, a judge has barred trustees from shutting it down, and its full-time enrollment has risen to 190. In addition, there are 143 adult students in a new part-time program.

title: Talking Litigation; A Spurt In Suing Boards
description: IN a growing number of cooperatives and condominiums, the relationships between resident-owners and their elected boards of directors have been breaking down to the point where owners are initiating litigation to settle grievances.

title: A CHILL IN THE AIR FOR GIANTS FANS IN CHICAGO
description: Steve Ruvitoso of Howard Beach, Queens, couldn't help noticing that he and his friends were the only ones in the Chicago restaurant and no one was waiting on them. Then he removed his New York Giants cap, and a squadron of smiling waiters and waitresses swarmed to serve them.

title: AN OPENING AT THE TOP FOR COLORADO DEMOCRATS
description: Senator Gary Hart's decision to forgo another campaign for the Senate leaves Colorado Democrats without a national figure at the head of the ticket in November's election. But it clears the way for new Democratic faces to join a field already crowded with a well-organized and well-financed Republicans.

title: ARAFAT ACCUSES SYRIA AND LIBYA IN RAIDS
description: Syria and Libya are behind the recent rash of terrorist attacks in the Mediterranean and Europe and are trying to discredit the Palestine Liberation Organization and hinder negotiations with Israel, Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said in an interview published in today's issue of the Washington Post.

title: REDMEN BEAT PITT IN OVERTIME
description: Playing an opponent it used to beat with ease, St. John's needed an overtime period to escape with a 78-75 victory over Pitt last night at Alumni Hall.

title: Q&A
description: Question: Are there any facilities close to the Great Barrier Reef off Australia that would enable a visitor to go snorkeling along the reef on a daily basis? - H. L., Burlington, Vt.

title: VIETNAM SAYS CHINA HAS STEPPED UP ITS ATTACKS
description: China has stepped up its border attacks on Vietnam in the last week in an effort to deter Hanoi from beginning dry-seaon operations against guerrilla armies in Cambodia, a Vietnamese general said today.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
STUDY OF HUMANITIES IS INDISPENSABLE
description: WHY study the humanities? Why concern ourselves with literature, philosophy, history, religious studies, languages and the arts? In a college like mine, where all the students in whatever major spend a lot of their time studying compulsory humanities courses and where most majors are chosen outside the humanities, the question arises quite often.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Cut Designer Wear, Free Alterations Theo and Theos, a discount men's clothing store, opened in September in New Rochelle with Italian- and French-designed casual-to-business styles and designer clothing made in the Orient, a full line of shoes for men (sizes 5 1/2 to 13), and women's shoes and boots (sizes 5 to 11). The store is patterned on the management's first venture, opened in Astoria, Queens, eight years ago, and all alterations are free and completed at the shop.

title: CHANGING THE SUBJECT
description: 'All conversations in New York center on real estate. It is a constant, boring, hysterical subject, and I just felt that I could not spend the rest of my life listening to people talk about real estate.' Ann Beattie the writer, describing why she moved a year ago from New York to Charlottesville, Va.

title: A NEW BOOK DISPUTES TRUMAN ON A-BOMB
description: A new study of the events that led to the dropping of the first atomic bomb on Hiroshima says that Harry S. Truman knew the bomb was being built while he was still Vice President and that President Franklin D. Roosevelt told Mr. Truman about it.

title: Dr. Susan Cohn Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Cohn of New York and Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of his daughter Dr. Susan Ellen Cohn to Dr. Jonathan David Klein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Klein of Ridgewood, N.J. The wedding is planned for March.

title: WEIGHING THE ROLE OF SCHOOL BOARDS
description: As one who served two terms (six years) as trustee on the Board of Education of Carle Place, I cannot agree with the idea that we ''hand over the vital job of managing education to professionally trained educators.''

title: BROOKLYN PROGRAM TAKES JOB APPLICANTS TO SUBURBS
description: Jose Gracia found himself working in a bagel shop in Pennsylvania after leaving the Army last spring. But the 20-year-old Brooklyn resident really wanted to sell men's clothing.

title: A GROWING DEBATE ON IMPACT STATEMENTS
description: A STATE requirement that developers must file environmental impact statements is increasingly being used as a tool by community groups to delay commercial and industrial projects on Long Island.

title: Marriage Is Planned By Miss van Bemmelin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henri M. van Bemmelin 3d of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann van Bemmelin, to Kenneth A. Lang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Lang of Garden City, L.I. The wedding is planned for April.

title: THE LIGHT TOUCH
description: THE CLOTHES FOR MEN HEADING for a warm-weather resort are usually harbingers of what is to come for spring and summer. This year, there are two distinct trends, both revolving around the theme of dressing for comfort and ease while at the same time appearing elegant. One style centers on slouchy, but not sloppy, garments made up of lightweight fabrics; the other has a feeling of deja vu.

title: CASINOS URGED TO HELP CITY'S HOMELESS
description: CITIES across the country, including this one, are reporting increases this winter in the number of people seeking shelter, and Atlantic City is urging that its gambling-casino industry be required to help alleviate the problem here.

title: STATE CURBING IRANIAN CHARITY
description: THE state's Attorney General, Irwin I. Kimmelman, is considering criminal prosecution of an Iranian fund-raising group that has been registered as a charity in New Jersey for a year, but whose contributions may have been used for other purposes.

title: Martha Munson Pollard Weds James Lind Easton
description: The marriage of Martha Munson Pollard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Pollard Jr. of Richmond, to James Lind Easton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Easton of West Newton, Mass., took place in Richmond yesterday at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Fred G. Pollard. The Rev. Don Raby Edwards, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg, performed the ceremony.

title: 37 Arrested and 10 Hurt At Chicago Labor Rally
description: The police arrested 37 protesters and 10 people were injured today in a rally by at least 10,000 people to bring attention to a six-month labor strike by pressmen and mailers at The Chicago Tribune.

title: TOPIC
description: THE catalogues are coming . . . the catalogues are coming. January brings the threat of snow, the first bouts with the flu, tinsel-clad trees strewn along the streets and mailboxes stuffed with continuing-education catalogues.

title: WORKING WITH THE AGED
description: QUEENIE THOMAS, 24 years old, a gerontology major at York College in Queens, chose the field because she was raised by a grandmother and always had a special love for older people and an interest in ''getting into their lives.''

title: POLITICAL RIFTS APPEARING AS '86 BOARD CONVENES
description: ON the surface it will be business as usual tomorrow afternoon when the county's Board of Legislators starts its 1986 session. All 17 members of the Board - 11 Republicans and 6 Democrats - were re-elected last November, leaving the balance of power, on paper at least, unchanged.

title: LIGHT FARE IN A CONVIVIAL SETTING
description: WHAT'S in a name? When it comes to restaurants, not always what you think.

title: Drew McGhee, a Painter, Is the Bride Of Peter Warner Davidson in Chicago
description: Katherine Drew McGhee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. McGhee of Chicago, was married there yesterday to Peter Warner Davidson, a son of Joan K. Davidson of New York and C. Girard Davidson of Portland, Ore. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike, a family friend and rector of Calvary-St.

title: KATHLEEN TURNER: INSIDE AN 80'S WOMAN THERE SMOLDERS A 30'S STAR
description: You have read all the stories about the chameleon style of Kathleen Turner, how she can look plain or pretty, sleek or voluptuous, shy or sizzling. You've heard about the critics who fail to recognize her until halfway through a film, about the producers who don't register until she starts to talk with that unmistakable tawny voice, about the New Yorkers who never look twice as she roams her Greenwich Village neighborhood.

title: BRIDGE AND TUNNEL CHIEFS FIND A CHALLENGE IN TRAFFIC
description: TOGETHER, they are responsible for the safe movement of more than 300,000 cars, buses and trucks each business day via two of the most heavily used traffic facilities in the world.

title: FAMOUS, UNKNOWN DJUNA BARNES
description: To the Editor:

title:
FASHION;
TRYING TO MAKE IT PARIS
description: IN PARIS, THE NUMBERS ARE DIFFERENT, but money is still part of the game. Patrick Kelly and Peter Kea, Americans who once toiled for others on Seventh Avenue and who are now making names for themselves on foreign soil, can attest to it.

title: CHINA OPENS UP TO AMERICANS
description: WHEN China reopened its doors after three decades to American students in the 1979-80 academic year, fewer than 50 went to pursue studies there. But only four years later, as many as 1,800 Americans were estimated to be studying in China on a full-and part-time basis.

title: COMPUTER-LITERACY RACE: A GLOBAL PRINTOUT
description: IN announcing the French Government's plans to install microcomputer workshops and give special training to teachers in all of the nation's 50,000 schools last fall, Prime Minister Laurent Fabius said that its goal was ''to turn the present generation into the best-trained in our history.''

title: SOME TEXAS STYLE CARDPLAY THAT TURNS DISASTER INTO TRIUMPH
description: It is well known that everything about Texas is on a large scale, and that is certainly true of its two most famous bridge players. Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff of Dallas are big in person and big in reputation. Although Hamman is expected to be slightly less big, in a physical way, by the start of the 1986 world championships in Miami Beach. In Sao Paulo he entered a novel ''if you lose you win'' contest, in which those who fail to lose 10 percent of their body-weight within the 12-month period will each forfeit $100 to the advantage of those who do.

title: TO ACT IS TO TAKE RISKS
description: When you decide to become an actor in England and Ireland, you are committed to becoming a member of a profession. It is like deciding to be a surgeon or a carpenter, a plumber or a dentist. You've got to accept the fact that you will have to serve so many years to prepare yourself. This approach is completely acceptable to European actors, but not quite so acceptable in America.

title: ENSEMBLE THEATER REVISES PRODUCTION
description: A NEW family-oriented ensemble theater in the county - the Three Brothers Theater - is putting on a revised version of a play that reflects in part the organization's name. Entitled ''Unspoken Devotion,'' the work is a collaboration by the theater's founders, Wendell Batts, Michael F. Monastrial and Keith Cobb, that involves three brothers who reunite after the death of their mother.

title: U.S. SAYS SYRIANS HAVE PULLED BACK LEBANON MISSILES
description: Administration officials said today that Syria had withdrawn from Lebanon, at least temporarily, the antiaircraft missiles that had raised the possibility of a clash with Israel.

title: 'OLIVER TWIST' MINI-SERIES STRIVES TO BE FAITHFUL TO DICKENS
description: ''You can do something that is enormously familiar as if it were the first time,'' said the producer Terrance Dicks. This is, to be sure, a sovereign goal for anyone working with a classic, and one that has led to ever more extravagant techniques of renovation over the past few years. But for the new version of Charles Dickens's ''Oliver Twist'' that begins its run of six weekly hourlong chapters on Arts & Entertainment Tuesday evening at 8, Mr. Dicks has made what he feels is a radical departure in adapting this often-retold tale: ''We put the book on the screen as faithfully as possible,'' he said. ''It's a good trick if it works.''

title: DRAMATIC LENGHTS IN FURS
description: REMEMBER the mink coat, the winter wonder that usually adhered to a quiet, pristine shape and let the opulence of the fur itself do the talking?

title: NOT EASILY DISMISSED
description: SHARON An Israeli Caesar. By Uzi Benziman. Translated by Louis Rousso. 276 pp. New York: Adama Books. $17.95.

title: THE 15-SECOND COMMERCIAL
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: 300 RECALL DOCTOR SLAIN AT HOSPITAL
description: More than 300 friends and colleagues of Dr. Thomas W. Pollock filled Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church to overflowing here today and heard him eulogized as a gifted surgeon and a warm man whose concern for his patients was exceeded only by his love for his family.

title: BALLET: PROGRAM OF SOLOS BY GAMSON AND TROUPE
description: ANNABELLE GAMSON is a stunningly powerful solo performer and an extremely sensitive interpreter of the dances of Isadora Duncan and Mary Wigman. But a program by Annabelle Gamson/Dance Solos, on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, suggested that she is her new company's own worst enemy.
