title: Christine Kirwan a Bride
description: Christine Margaret Kirwan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Kirwan of New Springville, S.I., was married yesterday to Michael L. Rogers, the son of Mrs. Charles F. Rogers and the late Mr. Rogers of Rumford, R.I. The Rev. Thomas Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Adalbert's Roman Catholic Church in Elm Park, S.I. Mrs. Rogers is an underwriter for the Ennia Reinsurance Company of America in New York.

title: HARD TO REACH, HARD TO LEAVE
description: I first went to St. Vincent and the Grenadines in 1973. I had never before been south of North Carolina; these were my archetypal Caribbean islands, the ones I imprinted on, and so they became the standard against which I have measured all subsequent experiences of tropical islands. I have not yet found any more wonderful.

title: NEW STATISTIC IS FLAWED
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TRYING TO MAKE IT NEW YORK
description: IT TAKES AT LEAST $1 MILLION. AFTER that come creativity, hard work, perserverance - and luck. Young designers are discovering that talent and ambition are no longer enough to make it. Gone are the days when a young and hungry Calvin Klein could begin the climb to fame with a $10,000 loan. Many observers cite the recent case of Stephen Sprouse. This young talent rose to prominence in 1984 with well-made, neon-colored clothes. Just as suddenly, he disappeared as his financial backing apparently evaporated.

title: Maureen Footer To Wed May 24
description: Maureen Wilson Footer, an assistant manager at the Citicorp Investment Bank, and Thong Minh Nguyen, a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation, both in New York, plan to be married in June, her mother, Mrs. Arthur Wilson Footer of Piedmont, Calif., has announced.

title: Dianne O'Sullivan Plans To Wed Charles W. Ahto
description: The engagement of Dianne Marie O'Sullivan and Charles William Ahto has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Owen Michael O'Sullivan of Morristown, N.J., parents of the future bride.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: COOL CHEFS IN THE EAST A lot of chefs will be out in the cold in a couple of weeks. Six or seven of them and their assistants are expected to carve dragons, pagodas and other images in ice Jan. 18 in the gardens of the museum of archaeology and anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CONFESSIONS OF A PRODIGAL DAUGHTER. By Mary Rose Callaghan. (Marion Boyars, $14.95.) Wintry Dublin of the 1960's forms the oppressive backdrop for a stormy mother-daughter relationship.

title: A GANG IS PREYING ON CHINESE RESTAURANTS ON L.I.
description: The police said a gang that robbed a restaurant here last week preyed on Chinese restaurants on Long Island because the owners did not always report thefts.

title: WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: Amid growing public concern about football injuries, rules changes were made in 1977 to outlaw ''spearing'' and other head-first tackling techniques. In the years since, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association, disabling spinal injuries have been reduced 85 percent and deaths from head injuries are down 22 percent in nonprofessional football.

title: Protestant Rioters Attack Ulster Police
description: Protestant rioters pelted the police with bottles and stones today, injuring 23 officers and burning two police cars, the police said.

title: DRUNKEN-DRIVING DEATHS FALL
description: RISING public outrage against drunken drivers and a strong antidrinking drive mounted by New York State have caused alcohol-related automobile deaths in the state to drop sharply, according to the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: EVEN TO THIS DAY, THERE ARE MEN TO HATE WOMEN
description: SEVERAL years ago, I met a man at a tennis club who belligerently claimed the court for which my sister and I had signed. His attitude was so hostile that I have never forgotten him.

title: STATE ADOPTS PLAN TO CUT HOSPITAL STAYS BY ELDERLY
description: New York State has joined a new Federal system of paying medical bills for the elderly that is intended to reduce health-care costs by shortening hospital stays.

title: TOM JONES REDIVIVUS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AGENCY CRACKING DOWN ON FARM LOANS
description: Hard times for thousands of American farmers may soon get even harder. Officials disclosed last week that the Farmers Home Administration had begun preparing for farmers behind on their loans notices saying that they must bring their payments up to date or face foreclosure.

title: A SKIMPINESS UNDERMINES 'AMAZING STORIES'
description: Calling it television's ''Heaven's Gate'' would be something of an exaggeration, but there is no disguising the fact that the very expensive -$800,000 to $1 million per half-hour episode -''Amazing Stories'' has not lived up to the expectations of either NBC or a good many viewers. Promising a series of ''wonderment, fantasy, irony and comedy,'' Steven Spielberg, the executive producer, has delivered a spotty skein of cliches, sentimentality and ordinary hokum.

title: FAVOR CENSORSHIP? NEVER, READER SAYS
description: ''Censorship: What Next?'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 8) provided a flattering surprise: David Soyka, the (then) boy across the street, remembered ''Mr. Heinholdt.'' But pleasure turned to shock when we discovered that, again, the generation gap had clouded communication.

title: In Delaware, It's Hummers
description: FOR POLISH and organization it can't compete with the Philadelphia Mummers Parade, but that's part of the fun of the annual New Year's Day event in Middletown, Del., the Hummers Parade.

title: VOCATIONAL TRAINING IS ON THE RISE
description: ''WITHOUT my new skills I know I would not have gotten the job,'' said 21-year-old Gail Heath, who recently accepted a good-paying secretarial position with the Metro-North commuter railroad. Miss Heath, a recent graduate of an American Business Institute program in New York City, said she enrolled in the vocational school in order to upgrade her skills and advance her career.

title: FREE M.T.A. RIDES DENOUNCED
description: A Westchester Legislator is urging the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to stop issuing free lifetime passes on its subways, buses and commuter trains to M.T.A. board members.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ELEVATORS, airplanes. Closed spaces, open spaces. Crowds. Driving over bridges, or more than a few miles from home. Dogs, cats, insects. Blood.

title: GUN MAKER FIGHTS FEDERAL 'DINOSAUR'
description: WHEN Dominick Spadea began manufacturing submachine guns at his tool-and-die shop in this Camden County community in 1982, he had no idea that he soon would be, as he put it, ''stepping on the tail of a dinosaur'' - the State Department.

title: FARMLAND SAVED BY SALE TO NURSERY
description: WHEN the Consolidated Cigar Company decided last year to pull out of Connecticut, agricultural officials worried that its tobacco fields would begin sprouting houses and office buildings.

title: STORY SERVICE GROWS
description: ''WELL, hello, little friend. This is your Uncle Jimmy on Storyfone, and you know this is my favorite time of the day, when I sit down to tell you your story,'' says the recorded voice.

title: Susan S. Stix Plans to Wed C. A. Fisher
description: Prof. and Mrs. Thomas Howard Stix of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Sherwin Stix, to Charles Avery Fisher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Avery Fisher of New York and Washington, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 15.

title: THERAPY IN BATTERED-WOMEN'S SHELTERS A POINT OF CONTENTION
description: THIS past summer, Betsy J. called the hot-line number for Shelter Our Sisters Inc., which runs an emergency shelter here for female victims of domestic violence and their children.

title: A WAY BACK FROM DEEP DEBT
description: IT'S A FRIDAY NIGHT IN November. Some 50 people are sitting in molded plastic chairs in a one-room brick building that is part of a church complex in Greenwich Village. It's a comfortable, sparsely furnished room, used by various community groups. Two ceiling fans turn slowly. The group is listening to a woman talk about her life, and about her money.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN CUISINE IN ELMSFORD
description: ALTHOUGH the county abounds with restaurants offering Italian cuisine, increasingly fewer places turn out quality dishes of the caliber found in the most modest restaurants of Italy. With our range of prepared canned sauces, tomato paste, processed cheese, preminced garlic and all manner of frozen foods in all stages of preparation within easy reach, the Americanization - or bastardization - of Italian cuisine was inevitable. It takes time and hard work and principle, more than most places are willing to give, to stem that current.

title: PUTTING MORE GLOW INTO A SEASON OF LIGHT
description: FOR Leo (Sandy) Sanderson, as for Santa Claus, this has been a busy time of year.

title: 23 TEACHERS TO GET GRANTS FOR CLASSROOM CREATIVITY
description: TWENTY-three public school teachers in the Westchester and Rockland County public schools will be honored for their innovative classroom programs at ceremonies next week at Philipsburg Manor in Tarrytown.

title: IT'S NOT CHILD'S PLAY FOR RESTORER OF OLD TOY TRUCKS
description: TOY TRUCKS from the 1920's - the kind that a child might sit on, dump sand with or use to fight an imaginary fire - are highly valued by collectors, with rarities selling for as much as $1,700.

title: Temple University Planning To Reduce Dental School Size
description: Temple University has decided to keep its dental school but will reduce class size beginning in the fall and establish a dental practice run by faculty members to raise revenue, officials said.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FRENCH BALLET, GERMAN REALISM, BRITISH ROCK
description: Black Tights Choreography by Roland Petit, with Cyd Charisse, Moira Shearer, Zizi Jeanmaire and Mr. Petit; introduced by Maurice Chevalier Video Arts International 126 min. $49.95 Four ballets by the French choreographer Roland Petit were included or abridged in this film, which had little success upon its release in 1962 but which is now a highly enjoyable record of Mr. Petit's contribution to ballet.

title: Annette Nazareth To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. George R. Nazareth of Cumberland, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Annette LaPorte Nazareth to Roger W. Ferguson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferguson of Washington. The wedding is planned for May.

title: CHICAGO MACHINE FACES A WRENCH
description: The thumby prints of Gerrymander dinosaurus were erased from a section of Chicago's political map late last year with an agreement on boundary changes that recognized black majorities in three wards and Hispanic majorities in four. Last week, a Federal judge took a further step toward the beast's extinction by ordering special City Council elections in all seven wards.

title: LAUGHLIN BARKER, 37, A PERRY ELLIS EXECUTIVE
description: Laughlin McClatchy Barker, president of Perry Ellis International since 1981, died of lung cancer Thursday night in his home in Manhattan. He was 37 years old.

title: EGGPLANT SHAPES UP
description: THERE IS NO DENYING THAT those of us who write about food have our individual enthusiasms. One of ours is, without apology, eggplant - in any of its manifest forms. It is a subject about which we could write volumes.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT MANAGER URGES TIGHTER SECURITY
description: The general manager of Kennedy International Airport has recommended that airlines operating there tighten their security procedures, including allowing access to terminals only to passengers with tickets.

title: BURT'S DRIVE STIRS DEFENSE
description: JIM BURT of the Giants is the pit bull dog of nose tackles, or defensive tackles, as the position was known in a less complex age.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Before the First World War, Britain's colonies were governed largely by characters who could have been created by Evelyn Waugh. In OUT IN THE NOONDAY SUN: Edwardians in the Tropics (Random House, $19.95), Valerie Pakenham, a former journalist, tells ripping tales about the administrators, planters, missionaries, entrepreneurs and hunters who built the Empire.

title: A NEW CASH CROP FOR NORTH FORK
description: Although the year just ended was bittersweet, grape growers and wine makers have begun to transform the North Fork of eastern Long Island. Hurricane Gloria destroyed almost a quarter of their crop in late September, right in the middle of the harvest. The yield, however, was still their largest ever: 900 tons, which will ultimately produce about 675,000 bottles of wine.

title: THE MANY THINGS THAT MAKE 'SMALL' ATTRACTIVE
description: ASK students why they like Hartwick College, a small four-year liberal-arts school that happens to be in the Susquehanna Valley but in many ways reflects several hundred colleges of its kind in the nation, and the answers are generally a variation on the theme of ''small.'' Brad Smith, an 18-year-old freshman from a rural community near Utica, discovered in his first two months that he had easy access to his professors. ''You can always go and talk to them about anything,'' he said, adding that ''it doesn't have to be academic. I went to talk to my psychology professor the other day about a paper on behavior, and we talked about how I was doing at Hartwick. I learned a little about myself.''

title: LIBERTY, EQUALITY, AND A FLAT 25% TAX
description: RIGHT REASON By William F. Buckley Jr. A Collection Selected by Richard Brookhiser. 454 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95. THIS has been a season for honoring William F. Buckley Jr. He just turned 60. His magazine, National Review, is 30, and his television program, ''Firing Line,'' is 20. He is a man who richly deserves praise. He is generous, erudite, witty and courageous, and he has performed a service to the whole nation, even to those who disagree with him. When the tide of intellectual and political history seemed headed inexorably leftward and the conservative movement was caricatured (not entirely unfairly) as a collection of segregationists, Babbitts and crackpot generals, Mr. Buckley had the temerity to uphold the cause of Toryism. He and his magazine nurtured the movement, helped it recover from the 1964 Goldwater debacle and gave it a rallying point and sounding board as it gradually gained the strength and respectability to win the Presidency. Conservatism is far from the dominant intellectual force in the country today, but neither is liberalism. There is now a balance between the movements, a permanent contest, and Mr. Buckley deserves credit for helping make it so.

title: TARRYTOWN LAND SALE SET ASIDE
description: A CONTROVERSIAL sale of 4.6 acres of land in 1983 by the village of Tarrytown to Laurance S. Rockefeller has been set aside by a State Supreme Court judge, who called it illegal under state law.

title: CAMBODIANS AT ODDS
description: The loose coalition of Cambodian guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnamese-supported Government in Pnom Penh was wracked last week by what Son Sann, one of its leaders, called ''open rebellion.''

title: FREDERICK BOTHWELL Jr.
description: Frederick Charles Bothwell Jr., former chief executive officer of the New York State Liquor Authority, died of heart failure on Dec. 12 at his home in San Diego. He was 71 years old and had lived in San Diego since 1960.

title: DOLPHINS WIN, 24-21; DICKERSON GAINS 248 YARDS
description: If you ever wondered why they pay talented running backs all that money, you only needed to watch Eric Dickerson today in the Los Angeles Rams' 20-0 playoff victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: SUBURBAN COWBOY AND OTHERS
description: THE MAN WHO LOVED LEVITTOWN By W. D. Wetherell. 145 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. $12.95.

title: D'OYLY CARTE'S G & S SHINES ON
description: Even when the fortunes of Victorian art were at their nadir, when anything Victorian was dismissed with scorn, the comic operas of Gilbert and Sullivan -eminent Victorians as ever there were -retained their place in the public heart. Theirs was a partnership made in heaven, though neither would have admitted it to the other.

title: STRONG PERFORMANCE IS FIRST
description: Strong Performance, the only gray colt and the only New York-based entrant in a field of 12, looped his rivals from far off the pace and went on to a score a three-quarter-length victory today in the $239,600 Tropical Park Derby at Calder Race Course.

title: 5 CHILDREN DIE IN FIRE AT 2-FAMILY HOME IN BRONX
description: Four children sleeping in a basement were burned to death and an 11-month-old infant girl suffered a fatal heart attack yesterday when a fire of undetermined origin roared through a two-family home in the Bronx, fire and police officials reported.

title: SAMUEL BECKETT IS HIS CO-PILOT
description: DATING YOUR MOM By Ian Frazier. 123 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: NEW JERSEY'S SAFER HIGHWAYS
description: Source: New Jersey Commission on Drunk Driving TRAFFIC deaths related to the use of alcohol and the total of all traffic deaths both dropped in New Jersey to their lowest points since the state began keeping records two decades ago, the State Commission on Drunk Driving reported last week. Alcohol-related highway deaths decreased 43 percent, and the total number of highway fatalities dropped 20 percent during that period. The commission attributed the decline to, among other things, tough new drunken-driving laws, a higher legal drinking age, increased use of seat belts and improved emergency medical services.

title: HARVARD AND THE C.I.A.
description: After an investigation into his acceptance of research money from the Central Intelligence Agency, Nadav Safran will resign as head of Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern Studies, the school said last week. In a report, a Harvard dean blamed the university itself for failing to act when Mr. Safran first informed it of a $107,430 C.I.A. contract to help finance a book on Saudi Arabia.

title: ONE STEP TOWARD A CLEANER HUDSON
description: For lack of a better alternative, New York City has been pumping as much as 150 million gallons of raw sewage into the Hudson River daily. Environmentalists eager to end the practice have had to await the completion of a mammoth, $1.1 billion treatment plant under construction on the Hudson between 137th and 145th Streets.

title: CECIL B. DICKSON, EX-OFFICIAL OF HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
description: Cecil B. Dickson, coordinator of information for the House of Representatives from 1949 to 1951, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

title: LET THEMRIDE BACKWARD ON SCHOOL BUSES
description: To the Editor:

title: COLOMBIANS EVACUATED
description: The Government ordered a ''preventive evacuation'' today of about 30,000 residents in the Armero Valley, where 25,000 people were killed in November in a volcanic eruption that unleashed torrents of mud.

title: L.I.'S ECONCOMY: DOES SUCCESS NOW BODE ILL FOR FUTURE?
description: THE Long Island economy, which has been growing strongly since 1981, is expected to continue to do well next year. But that very economic strength is breeding some problems for the future, experts say.

title: Nina Yonkman Weds David August Zander
description: Nina Ver Meulen Yonkman, a daughter of Fredrick Albers Yonkman of New York and Mrs. Raymond B. Rudy of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to David August Zander, the son of Arthur James Zander of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Zander. The Rev. John Olofson, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: WHAT PHARAOH SAID
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Will Provide Data on Caesarean Sections
description: Pregnant women who register for care at Massachusetts hospitals will get detailed information about such birth practices as how frequently they perform Caesarean sections, under a law signed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: A MIDEAST CONSUMED BY THE POLITICS OF REVENGE
description: IF there is one ironclad rule of Middle Eastern politics, it is that when things are not moving forward they usually move backward. The mood of quiet hope and expectation that was in the air a few months ago - as Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians groped for a way to open negotiations - has soured, thanks to the Achille Lauro hijacking, the Syrian-Israel missile crisis and the airport massacres in Rome and Vienna. There is still a sense of expectation, but what is being anticipated is a new spiral of violence, possibly even a war.

title: ANOTHER HINT FROM MOSCOW ON AFGHANISTAN
description: Moscow has dropped another hint that it may be ready to at least consider negotiating its way out of Afghanistan, a United States official said last week. Foreign Minister Shah Mohammed Dost, representing the Soviet-installed Afghan Government of Babrak Karmal, has produced a proposed timetable for withdrawal of the 120,000 Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan, the American official said.

title: THE DAY THE WORLD STAYED HOME
description: THE weatherman is talking about snow. And as always, at this time of year, I'm wondering how much snow there will be. You see, snow can be a special problem for me. And for the last two years, whenever snow is predicted, my thoughts go back to a particular Saturday in the winter of 1983. The day before, on Friday, we had had the heaviest snow in years, and on Saturday, the radio warned people to stay home. But I was determined, no matter how, to make it into New York City from Scarsdale.

title: TOWNS AND TRASH CARTERS STILL AT ODDS
description: WHILE Long Island's garbage carters are relying increasingly on litigation to change towns' policies, some town officials see negotiations as a better way to effect change.

title: LASHING BACK AT LILCO'S CRITICS
description: It was with pleasure that I read ''Catacosinos Lashes Lilco Critics'' [ Dec. 1 ] .

title: ART SLOWS CARNEGIE'S REBUILDING
description: The job was clear enough. Workers had to get 52 glass-and-steel skylights to the roof of Carnegie Hall as the next step in the landmark building's multimillion-dollar restoration.

title: WHY PLAY CHICKEN IN NICARAGUA WITH THE RUSSIANS?
description: The Reagan Administration maintains that the only alternatives to our current policy in Nicaragua - our continued support for the anti-Sandinista guerrillas -would be using military force or walking away. This is a misleading and dangerous view.

title: PROJECTS LET PUPILS TRACE AREA HISTORY
description: ON a rural road in Burlington, the old, weather-beaten Schwarzmann Mill stands silhouetted forlornly against the gray, wintery sky while, seven miles away, a group of fifth graders map out a campaign to restore it.

title: SALVADOR'S REBELS HAVE LEARNED TO DODGE THE BULLETS
description: EL SALVADOR'S Marxist-led guerrillas now concede that their chance to seize power quickly has been lost, perhaps forever. Their hopes for broad domestic and international support have also plummeted. But if the guerrillas appear to be winded and wounded, a recent week-long visit to rebel-held territory in the northeastern Chalatenango Province leaves the impression that they are not close to defeat.

title: NEW BEDFORD'S ALLIANCE OF FISHERMEN AND BOAT OWNERS IS SPLIT BY A STRIKE
description: In New Bedford, fishermen and boat owners have struggled together for centuries against wind, the sea and fickle Nature. Now the fishermen and boat owners here are struggling against each other in a strike by unionized crewmen.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THEATER AT YALE Of the four new American plays to be presented in Yale Repertory's Winterfest series, three were given their first public performances as staged readings last summer at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford. They will run in rotation at the Repertory and University Theaters on the Yale campus from Thursday through Feb. 8.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF FUNERAL
description: For many white South Africans watching from their homes in Port Elizabeth last week, the well-attended funeral of Molly Blackburn may have been a revelation. More than 10,000 disciplined blacks showed up at the church, some of them wearing the colors of the outlawed African National Congress and singing songs such as one that goes ''There is no freedom in South Africa without bloodshed.'' Similar scenes have become familiar at the funerals of hundreds of blacks killed in anti-apartheid violence in the last 16 months, but they usually take place far from white areas and are kept off Government television.

title: DALE BERRA IS WORKING HARD TO FORGET SHATTERED SEASON
description: A YEAR ago it was the best of times for Dale Berra. He had been traded to the Yankees and he would be playing for his father for the first time in his life. As the months eventually plodded by, though, it became the worst of times for son of Yogi. His father was dismissed only 16 games into the season, he became heavily implicated in the Pittsburgh cocaine investigation and he lost his job as a platooned third baseman. Billy Martin, Yogi's successor, remarked unkindly that maybe the Yankees got rid of the wrong Berra.

title: EISENHOWER WAS SEEKING TO MAINTAIN A BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz
description: Everything about Carmen McRae, from her clipped hair to her amused clear-eyed gaze, bespeaks a no-nonsense sensibility with an incisive intelligence. The 63-year-old jazz singer and pianist, who went solo in 1954 after working with Benny Carter, Count Basie, and Mercer Ellington, among others, is one of the most discriminating and durable jazz singers.

title: EX-JUDGE BEGINS JAIL TERM
description: Richard F. LeFevour, the highest-ranking official convicted in a Federal investigation of corruption in Chicago's court system, began serving a 12-year prison sentence Thursday. Mr. LeFevour, a former chief judge of Cook County Traffic Court, was convicted last July of selling favors for $400,000 in cash bribes and eight free cars. He is appealing his conviction.

title: Afghan Radio Reports Rebel Losses in Clashes
description: The Afghan Government radio reported today that Government forces had killed many anti-Communist rebels in recent clashes and captured large amounts of weaponry.

title: Lynn LoCastro Wed To Robert J. DeVita
description: Lynn LoCastro, a daugther of Mr. and Mrs. Richard LoCastro of North Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert J. DeVita, a son of Dr. Marie N. DeVita of Paramus, N.J., and Dr. Michael R. DeVita of Westwood, N.J. The Rev. Louis Padovano performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Kirkpatrick Chapel at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.

title:
INVESTING;
STARTING THE YEAR IN SECONDARY STOCKS
description: IT'S probably not in the same league with the theory of relativity or the discovery of electricity, but the stock market's ''January Effect'' has spurred dozens of studies. According to the research, the stocks of companies with lower-than-average market capitalizations should outperform the stocks of larger companies this month.

title: BLOCKING SHOREHAM BLOCK L.I. GROWTH
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature and Governor Cuomo are maneuvering Long Island into an electric power shortage.

title: NEW LOOK IN WORKING YOUR WAY THROUGH COLLEGE
description: THIS YEAR, as student loans vault over $10 billion annually, higher-education officials and policy makers are looking harder at an old student custom - working one's way through college. A growing number of colleges nationwide are beginning to reassess student-employment programs, not only to provide financial aid and meaningful work experience to students, but also to stem the burgeoning student indebtedness.

title: HARTFORD UNIVERSITY GETS COLLECTION OF 1,000 YIDDISH BOOKS
description: 9420>TO augment its 1,500-volume Judaica collection, the University of Hartford has purchased 1,000 Yiddish books from the National Yiddish Book Center of Amherst, Mass.

title: Headliners; HART BOWS OUT - OF SENATE
description: ''Keep fighting and look to '88'' was what Gov. Richard D. Lamm supposedly told his friend and fellow Coloradan, Gary Hart, before the Democratic National Convention in 1984. Mr. Hart has apparently decided to keep on fighting, but not for his Senate seat. At a news conference in Evergreen, Colo., yesterday, he said he would not seek a third term this year. Mr. Hart, who could not derail Walter F. Mondale in 1984, declined to talk about the possibility that he might again pursue his party's Presidential nomination. But since Edward M. Kennedy's announcement last month that he was content to remain in the Senate, many handicappers have put Mr. Hart at or near the front of the Democratic pack.

title: MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE DEAD
description: ACCORDING TO MARK By Penelope Lively. 218 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $14.95.

title: HER LIFE, HER BOOKS, HER SUFFERING
description: ELENA By Thomas H. Cook. 435 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: WHEN Sonny Sloan named one of her daughters Gillis some 20-odd years ago - before the name became fashionable - she provoked an unexpected reaction.

title: DEVILS OUTSKATED BY THE CAPITALS, 9-3
description: Mike Gartner scored three times tonight as the Washington Capitals routed the Devils, 9-3.

title: KANSAS LOSES IN OVERTIME
description: William Bedford scored 22 points and Andre Turner 20 as Memphis State battled from behind to beat Kansas, 83-80, in overtime today.

title: A Republican in Dallas
description: Nancy Harvey Steorts, a Republican who disagreed with the Reagan Administration from time to time and failed to win reappointment as chairman of the Consumer Products Safety Commission, has taken a new job. Effective Jan. 1, she became president of the Dallas Citizens Council, an organization of business and corporate leaders similar to a chamber of commerce or board of trade in other cities.

title:
ANTIQUES;
REMINDERS OF THE STATE'S 'OTHER CAPITAL'
description: THIS last year, as the state began to celebrate the 350th anniversary of its founding, half of its early history has had no attention paid to it - and probaby will not have as the celebration continues in 1986.

title: A TYPICAL SMALL COLLEGE AND ITS BATTLE TO PREVAIL
description: THE cover illustration for a new course catalogue of the College of St. Elizabeth shows two long-stemmed white roses sticking out of leather-bound Jane Austen novels. The composition evokes a world of intellect and art in which women of sense and sensibility conquer romantic or economic adversity.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS ARE VITAL LINKS IN CHAIN OF LIFE
description: THIS post-holiday period may be a good time to take stock of the role of plants in our lives and to evaluate the effectiveness of our stewardship of these valuable resource.

title: SHOPKEEPERS PAYING EXTRA TAXES FOR BETTER SERVICES
description: WILLIAM SHAPIRO, owner of the Triangle Sporting Goods store at 182 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, will be billed for $2,500 in real-estate taxes this month and then, later in the month, about $675 more. ''I volunteered to pay an extra tax,'' Mr. Shapiro said, ''but I really have mixed feelings about all this.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ALLIGATOR REPORT. By W. P. Kinsella. (Coffee House Press, Minneapolis, Paper, $9.95.) ''The humorous story,'' Mark Twain said, ''depends for its effect upon the manner of the telling; the comic story . . . upon the matter.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SWEETLY SINGS THE DONKEY By Vera Cleaver. 150 pp. New York: J. B. Lippincott. $12.50. (Ages 10 to 14) BEFORE I met Vera and Bill Cleaver, I could not imagine how two people could collaborate on something as individual and personal as a book. After I met them in the early 1970's, at a conference on the literature of Appalachia at which they were the featured speakers, I felt I understood. Bill Cleaver generated the ideas and did the research; Vera Cleaver wrote their books. In addition to this successful merger of separate talents, there was complete unity of taste and opinion in the 16 books they published between 1967 and 1981. A Cleaver book was typically set in rural, poor America; the heroines were teen-agers with spunk and determination; the adults were generally ineffective; and the writing was rich, warm and intelligent.

title: IN 'DROOD,' THE CAST GIVES CLUES AND THE AUDIENCES GIVE CUES
description: Some nights The Murderer turns out to be the demure young lady, sweet, blushing Rosa Bud with her china-doll face and golden ringlets; when she is found to be the strangler who stalked her prey in the night, the delicate Rosa turns into a shrieking harpy, raving like a madwoman.

title: HOUSE TAX BILL IS DAMAGING TO THE REGION AND TO THE COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES BALDWIN AND ATLANTA
description: To the Editor:

title: HEGEL'S FEISTY TUBINGEN
description: Every seasoned traveler inevitably becomes his own cartographer, creating a mental map of the world limned by the places he loves. My own map is studded with place names like Oxford and Cambridge in England, Berkeley and Chapel Hill in the United States, Poland's Cracow and Italy's Bologna - each a university town where the sight of bookstore and pub, library and lecture hall never fails to excite the student inside me. In the last quarter century, I have ventured onto more than 200 campuses, from sequestered Notre Dame in pastoral Indiana to the politically tense University of the Americas in Managua, Nicaragua, and that most venerable of urban academic enclaves, the University of Paris. But none is more beguiling than Tubingen in southern Germany, a meld of medieval town and world-class university that remains - as it was at the Reformation - a delightful disturber of the cultural peace.

title: THE SUBURBAN IDEAL: WESTCHESTER'S LEADING ROLE
description: WESTCHESTER readers of ''Crabgrass Frontier,'' a new book by Kenneth T. Jackson of Chappaqua, will experience a glow of recognition and possibly surprise at the role played in suburban history by their home county.

title: FROM A PALETTE OF CLICHES COMES 'THE COLOR PURPLE
description: ''The Color Purple'' is lavender. That's according to Steven Spielberg, the director of the screen adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. The letters that spell out the film's opening credits are lavender -the shade that dying violets take on just before they turn crumbly and gray. The flowers that bloom throughout the film also are lavender, not purple. It may be that lavender& The movie is faithful to the events of the novel, but it sees those events through lavender-colored glasses that transform them into fiction of an entirely different order. It's also a kind of fiction that, I suspect, would have been enthusiastically endorsed by an old-time Hollywood mogul like Louis B. Mayer, who didn't believe it was Hollywood's job to depress its customers by reflecting life's bleaker truths.

title: DURANT IS RECALLED AS A STATE 'TREASURE'
description: It was especially appropriate for the New Jersey Weekly to honor the memory of one of New Jersey's greatest treasures - Will Durant [ a Dec. 8 news article reported the naming of the first Will and Ariel Durant Professor of Humanities by St. Peter's College of Jersey City; the holder of the chair was the author of an Opinion Page article that day ] .

title: Diary of a Cancer Patient
description: My wife and I discussed the merits of publishing Nathan Perlmutter's poignant, almost whimsical, piece.

title: Art
description: One of the stories that has still to be told is how modernism changed the nature of line. Previously line was very much a servant of classicism, a force for artistic order and control. After the Surrealists turned line into the electrical system of the unconscious, however, everything changed. In the ''drip'' paintings of Pollock, the scribbles of Giacometti and the sculptural projects of Picasso, line could also be a life force through which basic energies and rhythms are revealed.

title: Yaddo Director Retiring
description: Curtis Harnack, chief administrator since 1971 of Yaddo, the artists' retreat in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has announced that he will retire at the end of 1986. Mr. Harnack, an author of fiction and nonfiction works, is married to the writer Hortense Calisher.

title: For Connecticut, a Hot Market in Housing
description: LAST year was a banner year for sellers of home properties all over Connecticut.

title: Sri Lanka Denies Report Of Tainted Tea Exports
description: A Tamil separatist group has asserted that it is poisoning Sri Lanka's vital tea exports. The Government, although insisting the assertions are false, says it is ''not taking any chances.''

title: ITALY'S BIKES COMPETE WITH THE BEST
description: In northern Italy on a pleasant day, the roads are filled with bicyclists: many in racing gear; whole squadrons of teen-agers on training runs; pairs of fathers and sons; lone middle-aged or white-haired veterans. For others, cycling is a more practical matter, a way to get around. Housewives hang shopping bags from their handlebars; old men carry melons to market, and children pedal to and from school. Bicycles are very much a part of the Italian scene, especially in the less mountainous parts of the central and northern regions.

title: TREMOR FELT IN WESTCHESTER
description: A minor earthquake rumbled across southern Westchester last night, prompting a spate of inquiries at police departments but causing no apparent damage.

title: LOOKING FOR A RECOVERY IN ELECTRONICS
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: REVISIONISTS AND STORYTELLERS -- IS IT PASSE TO BE ENAGE?
description: DIVERSITY and the rejection of easy categories have replaced morbid ideology here in both fiction and nonfiction, and the talk is of wiping slates clean. In a country once dominated by the New Novel - and where an armchair commitment to Marxism has died a slower death than elsewhere in the West - there is a sense that schools of thought and doctrinal tendencies have disappeared.

title: Law on News Sources Upheld in Philadelphia
description: A Federal appeals court has affirmed the constitutionality of Pennsylvania's law allowing reporters to keep the names of their sources confidential.

title: Miss Spector Engaged To David A. Garfinkel
description: The engagement of Shelley Robin Spector to David Abbot Garfinkel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Spector of Yonkers, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Barry H. Garfinkel of New York and the late Patricia A. Garfinkel.

title: DICKERSON 'RUNS IT' RIGHT PAST DALLAS
description: Eric Dickerson not only set records in leading the Rams to victory over the Cowboys today but he also prevented one of the dullest National Football League playoff games in recent years from dying of ennui. And he began doing it on the first play from scrimmage in the second half.

title: AN ABILITY COMES OUT IN THE WASH
description: LIKE most incompetent homowners, I am not in the habit of making my own repairs, especially on electrical appliances. After one year of high school chemistry, two of physics and seven years of changing my own bulbs, I still do not know the difference between an ohm, a watt and an amp. I understand steam and internal combustion, but generally leave alternating current ot my electrician. He at least gets paid to make himself glow. I would have felt right at thome in the first half o the 19th century, sometime before the Industrial Revolution began playing under lights.

title: REAGAN SEEKS CUT OF 40% IN FUNDS FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: Transportation officials say President Reagan, as part of his budget for the fiscal year 1987, will propose combining Federal aid to highways and mass transit in a single grant with reduced funds.

title: SENTIMENTAL THEME LACKING IN IMPACT
description: SOME plays are apt to induce guilt in theatergoers. Such plays often deal with ailments or death, or confront issues such as apartheid or war.

title: Higher Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGE IS URGED IN RHODES AWARDS
description: The British trustees who administer the Rhodes Scholarships plan to ask the British Government for permission to change a provision in the founder's will restricting two of the scholarships awarded yearly in South Africa to schools that admit only whites.

title: COLLEGE CONSULTANTS GAIN IN POPULARITY
description: JOHN WERGELES, a junior at Weston High School in Connecticut, is about to begin considering colleges.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the music page of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the Lincoln Center hall where ''Pavarotti Plus!'' will be held tomorrow night. The concert will take place in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WHEN THE BOSS BECOMES YOUR DOCTOR
description: LORRAINE ANDREE'S rude initiation into the new world of health care began one Thursday early last October. Her gynecologist had found a lump on her breast and a surgeon concluded that a biopsy was needed. Surgery was scheduled for the following Monday at 7 A.M.

title: MISERY LOVES CREATIVITY
description: THE BODY IN PAIN The Making and Unmaking of the World. By Elaine Scarry. 385 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: NOT SO COMFORTABLE OFF THE COURT
description: THE BANNER with the No. 22 on it will still be hanging from the rafters of Madison Square Garden the next time the Knicks are home, Tuesday night, but Dave DeBusschere will almost certainly not be in the stands beneath his old number.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW MEDAL MARKS KENNEDY'S INAUGURAL
description: This month marks the 25th anniversary of John F. Kennedy's inaugural address.

title: THE UPPER MIDDLE CLASSES ARE RESTLESS
description: EROTIC TALES By Alberto Moravia. Translated from the Italian by Tim Parks. 184 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: THE REAL COST OF LEAD POISONING
description: Since Dr. Norman Schell of the Nassau County Department of Health considers low-level lead poisoning to be a ''cost-benefit'' issue [ ''New Peril for Children: Lead Poisoning,'' Dec. 15 ] , I would advise him to consider the increased cost to Nassau County of educating children with ill-defined learning and behavior disorders. That may be the result of inadequate lead surveillance and treatment. DARYL R. ALTMAN, M.D. East Rockaway

title: STATE HOUSE PIGEONS RUFFLE FEATHERS
description: LEGISLATORS have been known to drop in unexpectedly on the State House. But, then, so have pigeons.

title: 10 IN THE ORDER ARE CONVICTED
description: Robert Jay Mathews, the founder of The Order, a Nazi-like white-supremacist group, died two years ago in a shootout with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Last week, after weighing a startling mass of evidence, a jury in Seattle concluded that 10 of Mr. Mathews's followers were guilty of plotting bloody revolution.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF AN ANNIVERSARY L>By PHYLLIS BRAFF
description: THE B.J. Spoke Gallery in Port Washington is a cooperative that believes in having a membership of widely divergent interests. A current group show, presented as a celebration of the organization's 10th anniversary, offers pure abstraction, realism, collage, photographs, monotypes and sculpture. Emotional temperatures range from very warm to very cool.

title: Letting Loose at Libya
description: Plenty can be done about Libya's Colonel Qaddafi beyond raging in frustration at his hospitality toward terrorism. There are clear, specific acts that victimized countries can take in retaliation. Even while weighing the more complex questions of economic warfare, they can deny landing rights to Libyan aircraft; boycott the Tripoli airport; close Libya's embassies, and monitor all bearers of Libyan passports. But none of these steps will be imposed without American leadership.

title: WEIGHING THE ROLE OF THE SCHOOL BOARD
description: As I am both a former teacher and a member of a board of education, I take exception to Walter Skretch's remarks about boards of education.

title:
ANTIQUES;
LOVE FOR RESEARCH IS KEY TO BOOKSHOP
description: WHAT separates an accumulator from a collector, the dilettante from the connoisseur, may have as much to do with a fine library as it does with matters of finance.

title: From a Palette of Clichs Comes 'The Color Purple'
description: ''The Color Purple'' is lavender. That's according to Steven Spielberg, the director of the screen adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. The letters that spell out the film's opening credits are lavender -the shade that dying violets take on just before they turn crumbly and gray. The flowers that bloom throughout the film also are lavender, not purple. It may be that lavender& The movie is faithful to the events of the novel, but it sees those events through lavender-colored glasses that transform them into fiction of an entirely different order. It's also a kind of fiction that, I suspect, would have been enthusiastically endorsed by an old-time Hollywood mogul like Louis B. Mayer, who didn't believe it was Hollywood's job to depress its customers by reflecting life's bleaker truths.

title: MEMORIES IN A BAG OF CLOTHES
description: OTHER mothers deal with the consignment shop more easily than I do.

title: Investing Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS ARE TROUNCED BY BUCKS, 119-86
description: The Knicks played their first game tonight under the watchful eye of their new boss, General Manager Scotty Stirling. And what they showed him was that his job will clearly not be easy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As I forge some role to help move our party and our country into the future, I won't be coy about my plans.

title: 2 N.Y.U. ALUMNI GROUPS COMPETING FOR MEMBERS
description: Alumni of New York University these days are finding their loyalty to alma mater being not only tested but also divided. Two groups are competing for the fealty of the old grads.

title: FORD PUTTING CHIPS ONSET OF TWINS
description: smooth (smooth) adj. fitting together, even. a) having an even or level surface; having no roughness or projections that can be seen or felt b)free from interruptions, obstacles, difficulties, etc. [ Slang ] very pleasant, attractive, or enjoyable. INDEED. Look up ''smooth'' in the dictionary, and you just might find a picture of one of Ford Motor Company's twins, the Ford Taurus or the Mercury Sable.

title: HART WILL LEAVE SENATE TO THINK ABOUT '88 RACE
description: Senator Gary Hart said today that he would not run for re-election this year and all but announced plans to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: BAN WAR, BAN POVERTY BUT DON'T BAN BOXING
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO'S NEW ON LABOR'S 'DISHONOR ROLL'
description: LAST October, for the third year in a row, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Industrial Union Department vented its spleen in public. It published a ''dishonor roll'' of American corporations that, the labor leaders charge, show ''a continuing pattern of deliberate actions designed to deny workers and unions their rights under the law.''

title: IN THE PULPIT AND ON THE BARRICADES
description: REINHOLD NIEBUHR A Biography. By Richard Wightman Fox. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95:

title: Miss Tanner Wed To Nigel Russell
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Alexandra Tanner, a daughter of Mrs. Harold R. Holmyard and Frederick C. Tanner, both of Greenwich, was married to Nigel Broughton Russell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Russell of Keston, Kent, England. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, minister of the First Congregational Church in Greenwich, performed the ceremony.

title: Railroad Drug Testing Delayed in Court Ruling
description: A Federal court has called off Monday's start of nationwide drug testing for 250,000 railroad workers until it can rule on union contentions that the program amounts to unreasonable search.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: VOLUNTEERS GET A WORKING EDUCATION AT THE SECOND STAGE, OFF BROADWAY
description: ''YOUNG, attractive Upper West Side theater seeks adventuresome New Yorkers looking for an intimate relationship. We offer great looks and terrific quality. No cheap thrills, but plenty of thrilling theater cheap. Good sense of humor and quick mind a must. No experience necessary.''

title: Catherine Weinstock Wed
description: Catherine Anne Weinstock, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Weinstock of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Mariano Enderle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Silvio Enderle of Trento, Italy. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at the Harmonie Club.

title: Medical Marvel
description: THE Secretary of Health and Human Services described it as one of the newest ''medical miracles'' - a $1.7 million machine called the lithotripter. The occasion was a news conference in Washington in December 1984 at which the Food and Drug Administration announced it had approved the use of the machine to remove kidney stones.

title: HOPPING TO AN ISLAND HIDEAWAY
description: Vacationers who prefer the solitude and privacy of the smaller Caribbean islands generally pay a price for reaching their objective. They have to change planes, perhaps twice, or make an overnight stop for lack of a connection until the following day, and they may have to cope with a boat trip as well. Their journey costs more, takes longer, probably involves flying in a small aircraft -with perhaps as few as six seats - and is more likely to be delayed than the trip taken by the traveler who flies nonstop to, say, Montego Bay in Jamaica or San Juan, P.R.

title: Recent Sales
description: Branford, Conn. $73,000 48 Peddlers Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old town-house condominium; *2*deck, pool, tennis, monthly charges $139; *2*taxes $1,095. Clinton, Conn. $56,000 38 Founders Road *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1-year-old town-house condominium; *2*near shopping and beaches, monthly charges $41; taxes $916. Norwalk, Conn. $385,000 89 Comstock Hill *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 56-year-old French country-style; *2*sunken living room with cathedral ceiling, 2.3 acres; taxes $3,990. Elmsford, N.Y. $142,500 66 Hillside Avenue South *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old frame Cape Cod; *2*eat-in kitchen, aluminum siding; taxes $1,719. Lincolndale, N.Y. $192,000 Dogwood Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, lake and pool rights, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,630. White Plains, N.Y. $215,000 50 Beverly Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old frame/ stone ranch, *2*paneled family room, wood-burning stove; taxes $3,053. OTHER AREAS Ridgewood, N.J. $141,500 462 Sheffield Road *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*paneled rec room, attic fan; taxes $2,433. Mineola, L.I. $161,000 335 Horton Highway *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*semi-finished basement, deck; taxes $1,800. Patchogue, L.I. $93,000 217 Sugar Wood Lane *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 24-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, 1-car garage, pool; taxes $2,000.

title: A SLIGHTLY BETTER WEEK FOR CARBIDE
description: Union Carbide Corporation gained ground last week in its drawn-out defense against a takeover attempt by GAF Corporation. And it continued to fight the Government of India and American personal-injury lawyers in the even-more-drawn-out battle against claims arising from the disaster at the company's pesticide plant in Bhopal, India.

title: MYSTERY IN ANCIENT POTTERY
description: The boldly graphic pottery crafted a thousand years ago by the Mimbres people of what is now New Mexico exceeds in expressiveness most other painterly ceramics of the ancient world. The geometric and figural images dramatize the bowls, jugs and jars on view in ''Mimbres Pottery: Ancient Art of the American Southwest,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, through Feb. 2.

title: REBEL WITHIN A CAUSE
description: ROMANTIC IMPRISONMENT Women and Other Glorified Outcasts. By Nina Auerbach. 315 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.

title: HARTSDALE PET CEMETERY, THE FINAL RESTING PLACE OF 50,000
description: EDWARD CATERSON MARTIN JR. never wanted to go into the family trade - making cemetery monuments. The craft, practiced by three generations of Catersons and Martins for more than 100 years, was started by Mr. Martin's great-grandfather, Joseph Caterson, who began designing and selling monuments at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx during the Civil War. Years later when Kensico Cemetery was built in Valhalla, the family moved home and business to Westchester, where they have lived ever since. Mr. Martin Sr. designed and made monuments and stones for area cemeteries for more than 40 years until his retirement recently.

title: WOOING FRESHMEN WITH GRAD SCHOOL
description: AT A TIME when the college-age population is declining throughout the nation, the University of Michigan has embarked on an innovative program designed to lure more first-rate freshmen by offering to guarantee them simultaneous admission into graduate school. The novel program, which will extend beyond similar programs on a number of other major campuses when it begins next fall, also aims to change the narrow focus of most programs of professional training for undergraduates.

title: HAMPSTEAD HARBOR: HOPE AND WORRY
description: AS HEMPSTEAD Harbor's old skyline of smokestacks gives way to condominiums and marinas, optimism for the harbor's future is mixed with worry over increasing development.

title: HOW MUCH LIFE IS LEFT IN THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT
description: AS Congress considers an extension of the Endangered Species Act, which technically lapsed on New Year's Day, it has become clear that the law has run afoul of some state and local groups, particularly in the West.

title: ACT OF CLEMENCY LEAVES CUOMO CAUGHT IN THE MIDDLE
description: Five years ago, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appealed unsuccessfully to Gov. Hugh L. Carey to consider clemency in the case of Gary McGivern, convicted in the 1968 murder of a Westchester County deputy sheriff.

title: MIDCON'S PIPELINES TIE INTO OCCIDENTAL
description: Occidental would add pipelines to its huge energy operations with its purchase of Midcon for more than $3 billion. Occidental had acquired natural gas reserves when it bought Cities Service in 1982, and Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, said that made inevitable the purchase of a means of delivering the gas. The deal also rescues Midcon from an unwanted merger with a partnership of Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran, which had offered $2.71 billion and was reported to have been ready to raise its bid. WB Partners said it would drop its bid.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MINUTE BY MINUTE . . . By Don Hewitt. (Random House, $19.95.) The author is the creator and executive producer of ''60 Minutes''; the book is TV between hard covers, with its large type, script bits and color portraits lifted from videotape.

title: PENSION FUND PREDICAMENT
description: The horns of a dilemma cast their shadow on the city's largest employee pension fund last week as top officials confirmed that 18 months after they had voted to sever links with South Africa, divestment had not begun.

title: FOR WOMEN'S COLLEGES, A SURGE OF OPTIMISM
description: LAST SPRING, some 100 women joined the growing ranks of alumnae of the Simmons College Graduate School of Management, the first and only M.B.A. program exclusively for women. On the other side of Boston, at the Wellesley College Center for Research on Women, more than 60 people are engaged in social science and public-policy studies. And at Alverno College, a Roman Catholic women's school in Milwaukee, nearly half the students are older women returning to college for a rigorous, ''ability-based'' liberal-arts education in which academic aptitudes are evaluated in terms of such criteria as problem-solving, decision-making and social interaction.

title: THE ROHATYNS QUESTION THE GLITTER IN CHARITY FUND-RAISING
description: Between them, Felix G. Rohatyn and his wife, Elizabeth, serve on the boards of a dozen charitable and cultural organizations, but they say they are increasingly experiencing a sense of disquiet about the way philanthropic dollars are raised.

title: FORCED LANDING
description: The airlines are usually delighted when their promotional campaigns whip up business. But United Air Lines decided that it could do without the loyalty of Howard Landau, a truck-tire salesman from Hawthorne, N.J., who, with his family, had run up 1.54 million bonus miles - the equivalent of three round trips to the moon - in the airline's frequent-flier program.

title: CHARTING A SURVIVAL STRATEGY FOR AIRLINES
description: EVERY school child learns about the mammoths. The largest land animals of their time, they died away, the theory goes, because of a change in the climate that had nourished them. The climate changed but the organisms could not.

title: THE CRIME OF THE CRIMINAL COURT
description: Rarely has any public institution been held in such open contempt by those who work in it and those who pass through it. Judges call it a sham and a fraud. Lawyers say that justice is unpredictable at best and that the tawdry surroundings and atmosphere of deal making deprive the court of even a feeling of justice.

title: Melinda Hillarie Boaz Weds Martin A. Kopp
description: At Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford, Conn., last evening Melinda Hillarie Boaz, a daughter of Iris Cohan Boaz of New York and Richard S. Boaz of the Bronx, was married to Martin Andrew Kopp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kopp of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbis Joseph Ehrenkranz, Howard Bald and Alvin Wainhaus, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: WHERE ENTREPRENEURS' IDEAS MEET INVESTORS' DOLLARS
description: GINGER HINES of Greenlawn and Bill Douglas of Bohemia have invented a toy car for boys that they think could be the ''next Cabbage Patch'' phenomenon. But for Santa to deliver it next Christmas they will need $1.5 million.

title: The Life Of a C.E.O.
description: In 1983, after having been with Avon for over 35 years and contributing to its success and growth, from a company with annual sales of $17 million to one with yearly revenues of more than $3 billion, I was ready to retire.

title: WHEN THE DOORBELL DOESN'T WORK, HERE'S HOW TO FIX IT
description: SINCE the wiring in a doorbell or chime system carries only low voltage, usually 12 to 24 volts, a homeowner or apartment dweller can tackle repairs to such systems safely.

title: Robert W. Paton Is Married on L.I. To Miss D'Amato
description: Lorraine D'Amato, a daughter of Senator and Mrs. Alfonse M. D'Amato of Island Park, L.I., was married there yesterday to Robert Webster Paton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Paton of Gaithersburg, Md. The Rev. James DeVita performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ANGELS ALL OVER TOWN. By Luanne Rice. (Atheneum, $15.95.) Luanne Rice's first novel begins in a promisingly eccentric fashion: we meet her heroine, a lonely soap opera star named Una Cavan, just as she's shambling into the bathroom to discover her father's ghost hunkered down with The Daily News.

title: INTENSITY AT PEAK IN RIVALRY
description: The Giants and the Chicago Bears do not sound like the best of friends.

title: BLACK-JEWISH TIES STRESSED BY DINKINS IN SYNAGOGUE TALK
description: In his first speech since his inauguration as Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins told members of the Central Synagogue in Manhattan Friday that ''we cannot allow the anti-Semitism of a few to overshadow the long history of cooperation and mutual understanding between blacks and Jews.''

title: A SPECIAL WEAVE FOR CORPORATE CLIENTS
description: A CONTEMPORARY tapestry created by Helena Hernmarck of Ridgefield already enhances one of the four-story atriums at the new headquarters of Pitney Bowes in Stamford. Another is to be hung in the second atrium of the $100 million building, designed by I. M. Pei and Partners.

title: COMMODITIES IN TRANSITION
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: MOST BLACKS BACK REAGAN, POLL FINDS
description: With more women and blacks than ever before supporting President Reagan, 68 percent of the American people now approve of how he is handling his job, the latest New York Times Poll shows. Twenty-four percent of the respondents disapproved and the rest had no opinion.

title: SELECTING THE RIGHT SOFTWARE LAN
description: ALTHOUGH technologically different, the office copier and local area network, or LAN, share one important characteristic - the way they are perceived by people in the office. Just as no one likes to admit to knowing how to add toner to the copier, unjam the machine or replenish the paper supply, nobody wants to be known as the person who understands the office LAN. In fact, most people simply do not know how to get new software up and running on a LAN or how to hook another computer up to the network.

title: TUDOR CITY RESIDENTS NEAR VICTORY IN BATTLE FOR PARKS
description: ALTHOUGH complex legal issues must still be negotiated, Tudor City residents appear to have won their 14-year court fight to preserve the two private parks within their tranquil community.

title: THE ALCOHOLIC'S MUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM CHICKEN CHIPS TO INSTANT BEER
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: OSPREYS MAKING COMEBACK ON L.I.
description: LONG ISLANDERS who occasionally glance upward may notice increasing numbers of large brown and white hawks in the sky.

title: VICTORY ENDS ERA AT NORTH CAROLINA
description: Nearly a year after its scheduled closing, 21-year-old Carmichael Auditorium was retired in style today by the University of North Carolina, which rallied to defeat North Carolina State, 90-79. It was the Tar Heels' 169th victory against 20 defeats in the arena.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. TV GUEST STARS IN HOLIDAY SPECIALS
description: It might have been called ''Face Each Other's Nation.'' For the first time last week, a President and a General Secretary traded videotaped guest spots on Soviet and American airwaves. If not particularly enlightening, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev were at least encouraging, with Mr. Reagan proposing that the two nations ''work together to make it a year of peace'' and Mr. Gorbachev hailing ''a change for the better in our relations.''

title: HANDYMAN SPECIAL A COSTLY ENDEAVOR
description: THE original price quote was $350. I just tossed out the business card from the paving company, with the figure $350 scrawled in pencil on the back. But it is too late to save money and get those driveway craters and gulleys filled in professionally. We took the Handy-Andy, do-it-yourself aproach. It was a costly bargain.

title: WHEN A PIANO REALLY NEEDS A FRIEND
description: AS an artist, as a technician, indeed as a Renaissance man in his field(s), Kong Ju Lee is a man of parts: the 1,500-odd moving and fixed parts of a piano, the 10 fingers of his hands, and his 2 ears. That's 1,512 parts.

title: CHILD AND 2 AUNTS DIE IN FIRE
description: A 7-year-old girl and her visiting twin 20-year-old aunts were killed early today in a fire that trapped them in upstairs bedrooms of the girl's two-story home, authorities said.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: BETWEEN boos and battered bones, Phil Simms has struggled for seven seasons to get where he will be today - at center stage for the Giants against the Bears in a Super Bowl XX divisional playoff game. Win or lose, he is the Giants' quarterback now. And at age 29, he will be their quarterback for several seasons to come. That's exactly what the Giants had in mind when he was selected with their first choice in the 1979 draft, the first choice of George Young's regime as general manager.

title: WORKER IS KILLED IN NUCLEAR LEAK
description: A worker at a nuclear facility here died today after inhaling acid formed when a 14-ton cylinder ruptured, releasing a cloud of radioactive gas.

title: Smart Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIANS ARE CONFRONTING THE SPOILS OF THEIR LABORS
description: The evening news broadcast recently a story about the pollution problems caused by a chemical plant in Yasnaya Polyana, the birthplace of Leo Tolstoy. Vegetation and wildlife were being killed, the correspondent reported, and the picturesque town near Moscow was being choked by truck traffic.

title: SAUCE FOR THE GOOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Diary of a Cancer Patient
description: Nathan Perlmutter's diary had a special meaning for me. Last summer, my father was diagnosed as having lung cancer.

title: NEXT BEST THING
description: William H. Sullivan, the owner of the New England Patriots, would love to win the Super Bowl, but he'll get almost as much pleasure if the Patriots can beat the Raiders today in Los Angeles. ''Winning this one would mean more to me than anything, except a Super Bowl win,'' said Sullivan, who sees the game as a grudge match against the Raiders' owner, Al Davis, an old courtroom nemesis.

title: THE FALCON AND THE TIGERSHARK
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: On Flunking Kindergarteng
description: BELIEVING that kindergartners should major in more than sandbox, the School Superintendent in Minneapolis ordered a competency test for the youngsters before they could be promoted to first grade.

title: The Life Of a C.E.O.
description: N. R. Kleinfield has written a fascinating account of the life of a C.E.O. in the mid-1980's. I find myself thinking about ''The Life of a C.E.O.'' and wondering why there was no glimmer of statesmanship; no sense of the world beyond the narrow sphere of one company with less than acceptable performance; no interests that fueled the spirit, the mind.

title: HONORING GRUMMAN AND ITS HELLCAT
description: TUCKED in a corner away from the modern streamlined jets and spacecraft that dominate the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, the restored F6F-3 Hellcat, a World War II fighter plane, appears small, ancient and far from intimidating.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TIME OF DIVERSION After the season to be jolly comes the season for such pleasurable diversions as skiing, amateur theatricals, brushing up on French and making preparations for spring trout fishing. Help in honing all of these skills is readily available around the area.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SIGN IN MENDEL'S WINDOW By Mildred Phillips. Illustrated by Margot Zemach. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) WATCH THE STARS COME OUT By Riki Levinson. Illustrated by Diane Goode. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) ADULTS may sometimes feel they have had their fill of nostalgic books about European shtetl life and the immigrant experience in turn-of-the-century America. But as the generation that lived those lives passes on, children lose direct access to the anecdotes, tales and remembrances of that generation. For them, each new book on these subjects strengthens their connection to the world of their grandparents and great-grandparents. These two books treat different aspects of the experiences of another generation, one in the old country and the other on the way to the new one.

title: RICO'S ASSAULT ON LEGITIMATE BUSINESS
description: RICO, the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, is a well-intentioned statute gone awry.

title: Social Events; New Year for Benefits
description: Spirit of '76 Jan. 10 - Seven young women descended from Revolutionary War patriots - an Albert, a Tibbs, the Trommers sisters, a van den Berg, a Van Voorhis and a Watson - will be presented at the 51st annual Colonial Debutante Ball at the Pierre. Sponsored by the New York chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution, the black-tie evening, with fife and drum corps, starts with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. and is followed by dinner and dancing. The evening benefits the education and scholarship fund of the S.A.R. Tickets $100, from 212-206-1776, Monday through Wednesday, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. A Cruise With Extras Jan. 13 - For 50 years, the Academy of Vocal Arts in Philadelphia has provided tuition-free graduate studies for young singers seeking an operatic career. For its anniversary the academy is holding a 12-day benefit. It is a cruise aboard the ship World Renaissance that heads south into the Caribbean, then to the mouth of the Amazon and up the river. Patrice Munsel will provide operatic insights and demonstrations; an astrophysicist will give lectures on Halley's Comet, which the passenger are expected to see clearly, and a naturalist will explain the flora of the Amazon region. Departure 6 P.M. from Philadelphia. Tickets $2,445 per person, double occupancy, from 215-735-1685. Evening at Sotheby's Jan. 14 - The evening starts with cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and entertainment at 6 P.M. followed by an auction of some 500 items of silver, porcelain and antique furniture and winds up with dinner and dancing.

title: URBAN RESIDENTS FIGHTING LOSS OF SUPERMARKETS
description: FIRST the A & P moved out.

title: COST-CUTTING RAILROADS
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: The Russians Are Going
description: ONE DAY THE RUS-sians started going away. They had a new machine that did the trick. The C.I.A. knew they had a machine that made things go away, but it couldn't find out where they went to.

title: OLDER WORKERS MAY NOW KEEP THEIR JOBS
description: Workers in private businesses in New York State who want to keep their jobs after age 70 may no longer be forced into retirement under a law that took full effect last week. Government employees in the state gained that protection a year ago.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FRENCH BALLET, GERMAN REALISM, BRITISH ROCK
description: The Cosmic Eye Produced, directed and designed by Faith Hubley, 1985; with the voices of Maureen Stapleton and Dizzy Gillespie; music by Benny Carter, Mr. Gillespie and Elizabeth Swados Walt Disney Home Video 71 minutes. $49.95 The Academy Award-winning animator Faith Hubley has attempted nothing less here than a synthesis of mankind's mythic understanding of the creation of the world and the ultimate destiny of the human species.

title: GIFTS COME IN DIFFERENT SIZES TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Contributions both large and small continue to pour into the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help the homeless, ill and infirm in the metropolitan area.

title: Burkina Faso's Leader Pledges to Free P.O.W.'s
description: Burkina Faso will soon release all Malians taken prisoner in a five-day border war, this country's leader said Friday night.

title: CUTTING LABOR COSTS WITH A BATTLE-AX
description: WHEN Darwin Stout, the president of the Trojan Luggage Company, joined the Memphis-based manufacturer a year ago, he boasted to a local reporter that he hoped to be known some day as ''the Lee Iacocca of the Luggage World.'' The 40-year-old company, Mr. Stout said, faced many of the same problems that Chrysler faced four years ago: foreign competition, rising labor costs, and aging plants.

title: SWEDE WINS SKATING
description: Anette Carlen of Sweden beat Bonny Blair of the United States today in the 1,500-meter race of a World Cup speed-skating event in the Bavarian town of Inzell.

title: ENGINEERING A NEW FLEET AT AIRBUS
description: ''IN nine months I feel that I've aged two years,'' said Jean Pierson, who last spring assumed the post of chief executive at Airbus Industrie, Europe's four-nation aircraft-building consortium. ''This year, I expect to age another two years. After that, I expect I'll find the work routine.''

title: Diary of a Cancer Patient
description: Nathan Perlmutter's diary shows how important it is to be totally honest with ourselves. In this way, acceptance of a frightening diagnosis and accompanying treatment can be made easier.

title: Senator Bob Kasten Marries Eva J. Nimmons of New York By United Press International
description: Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, was married yesterday to Eva Jean Nimmons, a New York City advertising executive.

title: WRITERS FIND BOOK IS START, NOT AN END
description: THE story of how ''Lovers of the Spirit,'' William J. Arneth Jr.'s first book of poems, came to be published sounds misleadingly happy, the author admits.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LIVES OF THE POETS, by E. L. Doctorow. (Avon, $3.95.) The six stories that begin the book seem unconnected, our reviewer, Benjamin DeMott, wrote in 1984. Yet the novella that follows, about a successful but estranged middle-aged writer, ''strikingly fuses them,'' and ''feelings that earlier were enigmatic are re-experienced as pointedly intense. And as preoccupations of the stories converge, like rays, in the novella's lens, they confirm the existence of levels of passion and idealism in the writer that were initially screened off by the witty surface of his monologue.'' The book's distinction ''lies in the gradual, patiently deliberated, austerely self-effacing unfolding of a moral core.'' THE QUALITY OF MERCY: Cambodia, Holocaust and Modern Conscience, by William Shawcross. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) The British journalist William Shawcross turns his attention to the world's response to the catastrophic hunger and disease that engulfed Cambodia's people in 1979 after years of Khmer Rouge terror and an invasion by the Vietnamese. Aryeh Neier, writing in The Book Review two years ago, said ''The Quality of Mercy'' ''may well be the best account we have of the politics of international charity.'' This edition also includes a report on the Ethiopian famine. THE STREET, by Ann Petry. (Beacon, $8.95.) Ann Petry's novel of life in Harlem, first published in 1946, describes a young woman's valiant struggle to make a good life for herself and her young son despite the hunger, disease and violence around them. It is a story of ''memorable simplicity and power,'' Alfred Butterfield wrote in these pages, and he also called it ''a gripping tale peopled with utterly believable United States citizens, and overflowing with the classic pity and terror of good imaginative writing.''

title: Miss Greene Wed To U.P.I. Writer
description: Robin Greene, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard G. Greene of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Michael Hagey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William McCall Hagey of Bristol, Tenn. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz co-officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE BUDGET CUTS AIMED AT DEFENSE
description: Six months ago the mood among economic forecasters was widely downbeat. The economy, they feared, would slip into recession again in 1986, finally tiring after more than three years of solid growth.

title: FROM CONTINENTAL TO PURE ITALIAN
description: LA VIOLA in Cedarhurst, which opened in 1977, was a Continental restaurant until a few months ago, when the owner, Lino Viola, decided to say adieu to the French part of the menu. Now his restaurant is thoroughly Italian haute cuisine (or alta cucina).

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 5, 1986
description: International

title: LONG JOURNEY ENDS WITH A SMALL SMILE
description: AFTER more than four years of suffering the pain and frustration of trying but failing to become pregnant or adopt a child, I have, at long last, become a mother.

title: Idaho National Guard Works to Build Up Levee
description: National Guardsmen worked around the clock today to build up a levee in southwestern Idaho and prevent millions of tons of sewage from spilling into the Snake River and contaminating water supplies.

title: SCOUTING OUT BARGAINS IN CREDIT CARDS
description: WHEN the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company cut the interest rate on Visa and Mastercard accounts to 17.8 percent from 19.8 percent last November, new applications flooded into the bank. Charles R. Walsh, senior vice president of the bank's retail services division, received one letter from a grateful Midwesterner beginning, ''God bless you . . .''

title: DOLPHINS WIN, 24-21; OVERCOME 18-POINT DEFICIT
description: Confronted with the shocking possibility of an elimination from the American Football Conference playoffs by a team with a .500 record, and confounded for much of the game by disguised pass coverages, the Miami Dolphins overcame an 18-point second-half deficit in a 24-21 victory over the Cleveland Browns today at the Orange Bowl.

title: Hail the Impressionists
description: The National Gallery will try later this month to recreate the atmosphere of shock and dismay and delight that Impressionist painting caused in the Paris art world of the late 19th century. On Jan. 17 the gallery will open an exhibition called ''The New Painting: Impressionism 1874-1886'' made up of 150 French Impressionist masterpieces.

title: EVEN BEHIND THE THRONE, ZIA RETAINS HIS POWER
description: A year ago, politicians were saying that time was running out for Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq. At that time, General Zia sponsored a vaguely worded referendum on his policies, then declared its approval a mandate to serve a five-year term as the ''elected'' President of Pakistan. The action outraged his opponents and brought renewed talk of their taking their protests to the streets.

title: WORST-CASE SCENARIOS
description: MOTHERS ON TRIAL The Battle for Children and Custody. By Phyllis Chesler. 651 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $22.95.

title: DEMOCRACY ISN'T CURING ALL THAT AILS URUGUAY
description: It was only last March that flag-waving crowds were celebrating the end of 12 years of rightist military rule, yet already the optimism that accompanied the return of democracy to Uruguay has begun to fade.

title: WEIGHING THE ROLE OF SCHOOL BOARDS
description: Walter Skretch's frustration with school boards as policymakers is understandable, but his simplistic suggestion that communities ''hand over the vital job of managing education to professionally trained educators'' raises more questions than it answers.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 5, 1986 Fiction

title: NEW CASSETTES: FRENCH BALLET GERMAN REALISM, BRITISH ROCK
