description: Kate Bush Live at Hammersmith Odeon Thorn EMI/HBO Video 52 minutes. $49.95 As the success of the English singer and songwriter Kate Bush demonstrates, once in a while there is room at the top of the pop charts for a genuine oddball.

title: NO CANDY
description: ''Put that back!'' says the parent at the supermarket checkout counter as Junior starts tearing open a candy bar from the adjacent rack. It's a familiar scene and Giant Foods, the largest supermarket chain in the Washington area, is helping parents avoid it.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK FORGES AHEAD WHILE LOOKING BACK
description: When an art form searches for its roots, it finds signs of the present in the past.

title: Making Great White Way Great Again
description: CITY PLANNERS and private developers are moving along converging tracks to restore the glitter of the Great White Way.

title: CONVERGENT THINKING ARRIVES AT A CONCLUSION
description: Although they may cogitate at different ends of the earth, there are times when players independently develop the same early-middle-game strategy.

title: Joanne Zeides to Marry Michael M. Kornbluth
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Solomon Zeides of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Zeides, to Michael M. Kornbluth, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Mendel M. Kornbluth of Monsey, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: THE INSIDER AND THE OUTSIDER
description: OLD CLEMENS AND W.D.H. The Story of a Remarkable Friendship. By Kenneth E. Eble. Illustrated. 242 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $20.

title: RAIDER LINE DEFIES SKEPTICS
description: Without taxing his memory too severely, Howie Long can tick off the names on his fingers. When he joined the Los Angeles Raiders as a rookie in 1981, he says, the team had nine defensive linemen. He's the only one who remains on the squad.

title: ACADEMIC CAPITALISM HELPS MAKE ENDS MEET
description: ABOUT four years ago Lawrence University, in Appleton, Wis., faced a problem many small investors face daily: how to get a better return on its money. The 14 percent the university had been earning on its endowment amounted to less than 10 percent after inflation -not enough, officials of the small liberal-arts school said at the time, to keep up with the school's rising operating costs.

title: A TEACHER TRAINS FOR OUTER SPACE
description: IT'S SUCH A QUANTUM leap from what my life has been like,'' Christa McAuliffe was saying. A frown shadowed her brow. It was the frown of recurring disbelief, not of worry. So much had happened since July, when she was chosen from 11,000 schoolteacher applicants to be the first ''private citizen'' to fly in space. There was the White House ceremony, the onslaught of reporters and television cameras, the hometown parade. Then came the exchange of her high-school classroom for the high-tech simulators at Houston's Johnson Space Center, and the moment she stood on the launching pad at Cape Canaveral and got a close look at the space shuttle Challenger, which is to carry her, a 37-year-old teacher from Concord, N.H., into orbit next month. ''It just didn't hit home that the rockets are going to go off and I'm going to be 200 miles up in space,'' the mother of two recalled. ''It still doesn't seem possible.''

title: Farm Researchers Reap Turmoil With Success
description: In 1910, when the Department of Agriculture established its first research facility here on a 475-acre stretch of pasture and woodland about 15 miles north of the Capitol, a farmer was fortunate to have a cow that could produce two buckets of milk a week.

title: Castrating Is Offered For Block Island Deer
description: The state Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has offered to castrate deer on Block Island as an alternative to allowing limited killing.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FRENCH BALLET, GERMAN REALISM, BRITISH ROCK
description: M Starring Peter Lorre, Gustav Grundgens; directed by Fritz Lang, 1931 Embassy Home Video 99 minutes. $29.95 Some of the spectacular effects of the original, high-contrast black-and-white photography are muted in this newly issued video cassette, but Fritz Lang's German-made ''M'' retains all of its bone-cold fascination, particularly for the performance that made an international star of Peter Lorre.

title: WORKER SHORTAGE LEADS TO 'JOB GLUT'
description: A SHORTAGE of entry-level workers is affecting Long Island's otherwise vigorous economy, and experts say it is only the beginning of a problem that will last for years.

title: EVEN SILENCE IS SUSPECTED
description: Nicaragua's leaders have made it clear that they don't appreciate voices of dissent. Last week they indicated that they will not put up with silence, either.

title: FOR ROBOT FAMILY, TENDER LOVING PROGRAMMING
description: When Dee and Sam Wright decided two years ago to have children, they designed their own. First they made Rebecca and dressed her in a layered, shimmering silver lame dress accented by magenta bows and bulging shoulder pads.

title: DISKS TRACE RUSSIAN MUSIC
description: Three pieces of chamber music that have just entered or re-entered the catalogue illustrate in a necessarily incomplete way the course of Russian music. On one disk is Mikhail Ivanovich Glinka's Grand Sextet in E flat and Nicolai Rimsky-Korsakov's Quintet in B flat (Hyperion A66163). On another is Sergei Taneiev's Trio in D, in this case paired with the Trio in D minor (Op. 141b) of the German Max Reger, also new to the catalogue (Laurel LR-136).

title: THE STAGE: KEITH BAXTER AS TWINS IN 'CORPSE!'
description: CONTRARY to romantic American belief, the English theater is not all ''Nicholas Nickleby'' and ''Benefactors.'' In any given season, the West End produces many more forgettable boulevard entertainments than Broadway does, some of which run forever (''The Mousetrap,'' ''No Sex Please - We're British'') and few of which are ever exported to New York. Connoisseurs of such fare may feel a certain pang of nostalgia while watching ''Corpse!,'' the rather wistfully billed ''comedy thriller'' that has bravely defied convention and ventured from London to the Helen Hayes. This trifle, which eked out a six-month run on Shaftesbury Avenue two seasons ago, may be a feeble mystery yarn, but, as a typical slice of Thursday-matinee West End theatergoing, it's more authentically the real thing than ''The Real Thing.''

title: Leaky Roof Halts Game
description: The game between the Phoenix Suns and the SuperSonics at the Seattle Coliseum was halted tonight in the second period because of a leaky roof.

title: MISSISSIPPI AWAITS DAM AS FLOOD RISK LINGERS
description: When the winter rains began last month, H. G. Sims went straight to work: he piled dirt into a six-foot levee alongside his furniture store, a line of defense against the Pearl River a half-mile away.

title: 'SHATTERED SPIRITS,' ON ALCOHOLISM
description: ALCOHOLISM is the subject of ''Shattered Spirits,'' the television movie on ABC at 9 this evening. It is, of course, a terribly important subject, and it is approached with earnest seriousness in this Robert Greenwald Productions film. Unfortunately, the movie remains naggingly inert.

title: TRIAL OF SURGEON CLOUDS IMAGE OF NAVY HOSPITAL
description: The malpractice trial of a Navy surgeon, which is about to enter its major phase, is expected to challenge the reputation of the Navy's most prestigious hospital and perhaps all of military medicine.

title: PREMENSTRUAL SYNDROME KEEPS DOCTORS GUESSING
description: An increasing number of doctors are studying women with premenstrual syndrome and trying to help them. But in the absence of an accepted standard treatment, some said, they are forced to use an educated version of hit or miss.

title: Don't Let These Jobs Disappear
description: In its rush to adjourn, Congress failed to extend the targeted jobs tax credit, allowing it to expire on New Year's Eve. The lawmakers will have to move quickly in the session starting Jan. 22 to avoid the cruel sacrifice of jobs for 623,000 disadvantaged Americans.

title: A RECOVERY FOR EQUITY FUNDS
description: Amid booming sales and a roaring bull market, equity mutual funds last year scored their best performance since 1980 and one of their best years ever.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Madison Companies, holding company for the financial services subsidiaries of the American Can Company, based in Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Paul A. Finkel senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: COGHLAN CAPTURES MILE
description: Eamonn Coghlan won his first mile race of the season today in a respectable 4 minutes 4.44 seconds. But it was a 15-year-old Philadephia high school sophomore who received most of the spotlight today at the Manufacturers Hanover-Metropolitan Athletics Congress New Year Festival track and field meet in the Army fieldhouse.

title: History and Nature Of Anorexia Nervosa
description: To the Editor:

title: Grace Names New Chief For Its Resources Unit
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the multibillion-dollar conglomerate, has announced that Donald E. Grimm has been named to head its natural resources group, a collection of companies that include oilfield service operations, oil and gas production and exploration properties and a coal business.

title: HART SIZES UP THE ISSUES, PERSONALITIES AND STRATEGIES OF '88
description: Senator Gary Hart has found splendid isolation in Troublesome Gulch, in a turn-of-the-century log and stone cabin on a dirt road that he says was once a stagecoach line between Evergreen and Denver.

title: IN PAKISTAN, A TURN AWAY FROM ZIA
description: In the week since President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq ended martial law, leaders of Pakistan's nine-month-old civilian Government have begun asserting a measure of independence and disassociating themselves from a few of General Zia's policies.

title: More Curbs Sought On Steel Imports
description: Steel imports have run well above the goal set by President Reagan under a five-year restraint program - leading to demands by the industry and its friends in Congress for more comprehensive protection.

title: Dorothy Dunbar Bromley, 89, A Writer on Women's Issues
description: Dorothy Dunbar Bromley, a journalist and early writer on women's issues, died of pneumonia Friday in a retirement settlement in Pennsylvania. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan most of her professional life.

title: BEARS POUND GIANTS, 21-0, IN WIND AND COLD
description: The Giants' season ended today in wind and cold and embarrassment and a 21-0 loss to the Bears. The difference between the teams was a freakish Giants' punt or nonpunt that became a Bears' touchdown, a few good plays by the Bears' offense and a mighty defense that shut down the Giants' running and passing.

title: Advertising; Fallon McElligott Rice Named Allnet Agency
description: Fallon McElligott Rice of Minneapolis, which has been the agency for the Lexitel Corporation, a long-distance telephone company, has now been named agency for Allnet Communications Services, into which Lexitel was merged last month.

title: A BITTER WINTER FOR LEGISLATORS SEEN IN ALBANY
description: The New York State Legislature will open an election-year session in Albany this week with a full menu of divisive issues and a spirit of contention left over from the special meeting last month.

title: Too Many Fingers on the Defense-Spending Trigger
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS SEE HOPES SAIL AWAY
description: It was an Ill. wind that helped blow away the Giants today.

title: TWICE-DELAYED MISSION IS SET FOR LIFTOFF TODAY
description: The countdown went smoothly today for another attempt to launch the space shuttle Columbia on a five-day mission devoted mainly to science. The launching was delayed twice last month.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: BERRY VERIFIES HE'S 'THE TRUTH'
description: WHEN it became clear two summers ago that Walter Berry would attend St. John's, someone asked Shelton Jones to gauge the impact that Berry, a legendary New York City high school star, might have on the Big East.

title: BRAZIL RECOVERS, DESPITE ITS DEBT
description: Without resolving the foreign debt crisis that first tripped its economy, Brazil has suddenly emerged from its worst recession in recent memory, recording 7.4 percent growth last year, its best performance since 1976.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 6, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Market Place; Funds' Goal: Buying Cheap
description: ''I DIDN'T plan to be better than everybody else,'' Max L. Heine once told a reporter.

title: Marilyn Machlowitz Married to Edward C. Katz
description: Marilyn M. Machlowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Machlowitz of Glenside, Pa., and Edward C. Katz, the son of Anita Lieberman Katz of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Nathan R. Katz, were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Marjorie S. Yudkin performed the ceremony.

title: URAGUAY'S NEW FREEDOMS INCLUDE THE RIGHT TO STRAY
description: For more than a decade the rightist military Government kept imported pornographic magazines and movies out of the country as assiduously as it censored what it called subversion from the local press.

title: Austrian Wins World Cup Slalom
description: Roswitha Steiner of Austria came up with a sparkling run when it counted most today to hold off Erika Hess of Switzerland and win a women's World Cup slalom.

title: MEANER STREETS FOR YELLOW FLEET
description: THE subway thunders past Ronald Stoppelmann's office every few minutes, overriding conversation and filling his window with a flash of graffiti. ''It goes all day,'' he said, ''and I see less and less people on it.''

title: LATE RANGER RALLY FALLS A GOAL SHORT
description: Barreling into the goalie and chopping away at the opposition with their sticks, the Rangers came up with four goals in the third period at Madison Square Garden last night. It was not pretty, and it was not enough. They lost to the Quebec Nordiques, 5-4.

title: A Merger
description: Just a mention of the name Tufo & Zuccotti can cause a stir in the hearing rooms and courtrooms where battles are fought over development, zoning, planning and landmarks. The 15-year-old partnership is widely seen as one of the most influential law firms in New York City real estate.

title: Too Many Fingers on the Defense-Spending Trigger
description: To the Editor:

title: SPAIN NOW SET ON DENATIONALIZATION
description: When the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez nationalized the vast holdings of the Rumasa Group only 90 days after taking office, the Spanish business community feared it was just the beginning.

title: WARNS U.S. NOT TO ATTACK
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi asserted today that there are no Palestinian training camps in Libya and that his country was not directly responsible for the attacks by Palestinian terrorists at the Rome and Vienna airports last month.

title: TEXACO AND PENNZOIL IN KEY TALKS
description: Representatives of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company held a secret meeting in Nashville yesterday, as indications mounted that the oil companies would decide soon whether they will be able to reach an out-of-court settlement of their bitter legal dispute, sources close to the talks said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: An Athens-to-New York Flight Is Delayed by a Bomb Threat
description: An Olympic Airways flight bound from Athens to Kennedy International Airport was delayed about seven hours yesterday at a military air base in Canada after the airline received a telephone call in Athens saying a bomb had been placed aboard the plane, the airline said.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Keep It Simple Software to Kaufman & Maraffi Advertising.

title: PIERCING THE FED'S UNITY OF VIEW
description: Dissent on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve is rare by almost any standard. And, of course, any dissent is always quiet and respectful.

title: CONCERT: IRISH FAMILIES AND TRADITIONAL MUSIC
description: IN ''Fathers and Daughters'' Saturday night at the Julia Richman High School auditorium, nine Irish family groups involved in traditional music were presented - duos and trios of fathers and daughters, a father-son pair and two dancing siblings, Donny and Eileen Golden.

title: NICARAGUA DENIES ROLE IN RAID BY COLOMBIAN REBELS
description: Nicaragua has declared that it played no role in the guerrilla assault on Colombia's Palace of Justice in November despite the purported discovery there of weapons that had passed through Nicaragua.

title: KNICKS' PRESIDENT HINTS AT PROBLEMS
description: When Jack Krumpe, the Knicks' team president, stepped to the podium Friday afternoon at Madison Square Garden's Hall of Fame Club, what he was about to say was no longer a secret. He was dismissing Executive Vice President Dave DeBusschere, the legendary former player, and replacing him with a relatively unknown league executive named Scotty Stirling.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; R. Stevie Moore Sings at Speakeasy
description: R. Stevie Moore, a pop cult figure and cottage industry, emerged for live performances Saturday night at Speakeasy, on Macdougal Street). Mr. Moore writes and records songs but bypasses the record business; he releases most of his songs on cassettes - of which there are now dozens - and sells them by mail order. In recent years, he has also made some independent-label albums.

title: THE SMALL CHANGE ADDS UP FOR NATHAN
description: He has already caught the second highest number of passes in the brief but remarkable history of the Miami Dolphins. By this time next year, he may well have the second greatest career rushing yardage on the club. Tony Nathan has already earned a place among the Dolphin elite. But Nathan's description of his role would never lead one to that conclusion.

title: Washington Watch; 'Baker Loan' Possibility
description: President Reagan will receive Ecuador's staunchly free-enterprise President, Leon Febres Cordero, on Jan. 14, and Administration officials said he may well be the first to sign a ''Baker loan.''

title: Hyman M. Cleon Dies at 88; Ex-Civil Engineer in Brooklyn
description: Hyman M. Cleon, former senior civil engineer in the office of the Brooklyn borough president, died Dec. 27 at his home in Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: Co-op City Couple Arrested in Thefts
description: A husband and wife were arrested in Co-op City in the Bronx early yesterday and accused of breaking into 40 storage lockers in three buildings at the complex and stealing clothing, refrigerators and bed frames, the police said.

title: NEW YORK COURTS BEGIN ONE-CASE, ONE-JUDGE SYSTEM TODAY
description: A sweeping new method of organizing and assigning cases in New York State's court system will take effect today, with a number of compromises that have reduced the scope of the initiative.

title: Bad Hijack Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH TO SEEK RISE TO 12.5% IN TAX ON REALTY SALES
description: New York City's preliminary budget for the coming fiscal year will include a proposed tax increase on large real-estate transactions in the city, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: 'IACOCCA' AND 'WOBEGON' TOP-SELLING BOOKS OF '85
description: For the second consecutive year, the autobiography of Lee Iacocca was far and away the best-selling hard-cover nonfiction book in the United States in 1985, according to a New York Times survey. Garrison Keillor's recollections of a small town, ''Lake Wobegon Days,'' was the No. 1 work of hard-cover fiction last year.

title: GAF Warrant Plan Details
description: The GAF Corporation has disclosed details of its plan to offer stock warrants to investors who agree to help finance its attempted takeover of the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: UNTESTED PROCESS WAS IN USE AT TIME OF FATAL GAS LEAK
description: Workers at a uranium-processing plant were using an untested process to expel gas from a tank when it ruptured here Saturday, killing one man and injuring at least 32 people, a top executive of the plant said today.

title: Bond Sales to Dip 28.5% in New York
description: Public authorities in New York State plan to sell 28.5 percent fewer bonds in the first quarter of this year, compared with sales last year, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today.

title: Red Wings' Park Wins First as Coach
description: Petr Klima scored the winning goal at 13 minutes 59 seconds of the third period and added three assists tonight as Detroit beat Toronto, 6-5. It was the first victory for Brad Park as head coach of the Red Wings.

title: DICKERSON'S RUNS KEEP RAMS ALIVE
description: Eric Dickerson not only brought his team a victory Saturday he also enlivened a dull game, scoring on two long touchdown runs and rushing for 248 yards in the Rams' 20-0 victory over the Cowboys that advanced Los Angeles to the National Conference championship game.

title: RAIDERS FALL TO PATRIOTS
description: The New England Patriots turned four turnovers into 20 points today and stunned the Los Angeles Raiders with a 27-20 victory that put them in the American Conference championship game next Sunday in Miami against the Dolphins.

title: A.M.C. Pares Plant Site List
description: The American Motors Corporation has narrowed its search for a new automobile assembly plant to sites in five states and it hopes to announce a decision by spring, the head of the company said Friday. A.M.C. also introduced a new

title: STUDENTS TO MEET BARD ON BROADWAY
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival is forming a multiracial acting company to present Shakespeare on Broadway for school audiences. But year-round operation largely depends on New York City's Board of Estimate approving a $1 million contribution.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: A WEB OF DOGMA AND TRIBALISM
description: In the scrub that surrounds this city, a visitor may see small, crude buildings to which young men of the Xhosa tribe retreat for secret rites that lead to circumcision and manhood.

title: Chrysler Pact With Maserati
description: The Chrysler Corporation said Friday that its new two-seater luxury car to be built by Officine Acfieri Maserati S.p.A. will be priced between $25,000 and $30,000 and will be available in the spring of 1987. Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said the company is planning an initial volume of about 5,000 cars, running up to 10,000 annually.

title: THE DENT IN BACKFIELD
description: THE setting was ripe for boldness. Richard Dent had just turned in one of the mammoth games a defensive end can have: three and a half sacks, six and a half tackles, creating a national advertisement of his contract status.

title: THE NOVELTY GONE, JAI ALAI'S APPEAL SLIPS
description: When jai alai made its debut here nearly 10 years ago, huge crowds flocked to see and bet on the sport promoters billed as ''the world's fastest ballgame.''

title: Fasting Veteran Seen As Threat to Reagan
description: A Vietnam veteran who ended a 51-day fast on behalf of American servicemen missing in Vietnam after President Reagan promised to talk with him is a security risk, the Secret Service says in arguing against any meeting.

title: THE WOMEN BEHIND 'THE TRIP TO BOUNTIFUL'
description: Carrie Watts can bear no more the Houston apartment that she shares with her son, Ludie, and his wife, Jessie Mae. She aches for a last look at Bountiful, the Texas town of her youth, and though old and ailing, she is determined to make the trip.

title: 3 EXECUTIVES BID FOR REPUBLIC HEALTH
description: Three executives of the Republic Health Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest publicly held health services company, offered yesterday to acquire the corporation for $17 a share, or $331.5 million.

title: Suicide, Euthanasia, Living Wills and Patient-Physician Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER MAKERS SEEKING STANDARDS
description: The nation's leading computer companies are about to start a major new effort to develop standards that will allow machines made by different manufacturers to communicate with one another and share information.

title: New Victim Is Found In Serial Killer Case
description: Bones from a third person have been discovered at a site where the remains of two other people were found earlier in the week, officials said. All three were the victims of a serial killer officials say has killed at least 34 young women.

title: Complaint Pays Off
description: It's not easy representing Cleveland in Congress these days, but once in a while a militant defense of that abused city's pride pays off. Recently New York Air began a new service to Cleveland, and began running jocular broadcast and print ads, poking fun at Cleveland's rundown reputation.

title: CONCERN ABOUT THE HOMELESS PROMPTS GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: January's wintry cold and the hardships it creates for the homeless and needy are cited by many donors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: OUTDOORS: PLANS FOR A NEW YEAR
description: MY New Year's Eve roistering - two cups of black coffee; a chunk of cheddar cheese; three miniature hot dogs speared with a toothpick from a nondescript sauce bubbling in a miniature cauldron; half-heard, fixed-smile conversation with too many strangers, and to bed at 10 - left me hungering for accomplishment the following warm and brilliant dawn.

title: U.S. STUDY WEIGHS ROLE WEAPONS PLAY IN VIOLENT OFFENSES
description: Almost 37 percent of the violent crimes in recent years were committed by people with weapons, and more than a third of those offenders were armed with guns, according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Barbara Lea's Stay At Wallman's to End
description: Barbara Lea, who has been singing at Jan Wallman's, a cozy little restaurant at 28 Cornelia Street, one night a week for the past two years, will wind up her stay there at the end of the month when the room closes. The end of this long engagement with the excellent piano accompaniment of Wes McAfee, comes at a time when Miss Lea is putting a fine polish on an observant and probing singing career that has been developing, sometimes hesitantly, for 30 years. She has become one of the most knowledgeable interpreters and collectors of popular songs and her voice has grown to accommodate the increasingly demanding directions in which she has moved. Last Friday evening, which is her performing night through Jan. 24, her program included Lea interpretations of familiar songs, a little known Rodgers and Hart song (''Baby's Awake Now''), contemporary songs (''Twilight World,'' a moody, misty joint effort by Marion McPartland and Johnny Mercer), a song from Kurt Weill's unfinished musical version of ''Huckleberry Finn,'' as well as observations on the idiosyncrasies of singers, such as adding ''yuh'' to a line, as in ''I Loves You, Porgy -Yuh!'' Miss Lea resists stereotypes - she builds a sunny and surprisingly suitable sense of calm in the usually senuous ''Begin the Beguine'' and manages to create a real song out of the seemingly phony fluff of ''Limehouse Blues.'' Her voice, which has worn and husky overtones, opens up cleanly and fully when the occasion calls for it; in controlled, shaded fashion on ''I Never Has Seen Snow'' or rising to whooping exuberance in ''Applejack,'' a song of seduction by Weill and Maxwell Anderson.

title: Two Men Are Killed In Copter Crash in Gulf
description: A helicopter ferrying offshore oil workers to a derrick barge off Grand Isle, La. flipped over in high winds yesterday, killing two people and knocking a third into the Gulf of Mexico. Searchers looked for the missing man until nightfall and planned to continue the search Monday, officials said.

title: Advertising; Burzon Joins Lipstein In Executive Position
description: Jay Burzon, 51 years old and a well-known magazine publishing executive, has joined Owen J. Lipstein, who is managing partner of American Health Magazine and majority owner of the Mother Earth News, and will serve in an executive vice president capacity over not only those two properties but also over a joint venture of the two called Sponsorship Marketing.

title: PRIME OSBORN, WHO HEADED CSX, THE RAILROAD COMPANY
description: Prime F. Osborn 3d, a railroad industry executive who served as chairman of the CSX Corporation and played a key role in the merger of Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line Railroads in 1967, died Saturday at his home in Jacksonville, Fla., after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

title: The Old Scare Tactic
description: Elliott Abrams has given Congress a graphic preview of the choices on Nicaragua with which the Reagan Administration plans to confront it next session:

title: PERES SAYS ISRAEL DOESN'T PLAN TO HIT LIBYA BY ITSELF
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel had no intention of attacking Libya on its own in retaliation for the Rome and Vienna airport killings, and he called for ''collective measures'' against nations that harbor terrorists.

title: Washington Watch; China Trade Still Growing
description: HIGHER import tariffs imposed by the Chinese last year to curb imports and conserve foreign exchange have failed to slow the dramatic growth in United States-China trade, according to an organization representing nearly 500 American companies that buy and sell there.

title: REPUBLICANS SEE A TAX BOOMERANG
description: If the members of the House of Representatives have their way, taxpayers will be allowed, beginning next year, to donate money to candidates for Congress and get every penny back when they file their income tax returns.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Martin L. Orlowsky was named executive vice president, sales and marketing; Richard A. Kampe was named senior vice president-marketing, and Gerald W. McKenna was named vice president-marketing planning, at R. J. Reynolds Tobacco.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 6, 1986
description: International

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 6, 1986
description: Companies

title: LAWYERS STUDY NEW TAX BILL
description: Municipal bond attorneys, whose job is to judge whether new bond issues of state and local governments are legal and exempt from Federal income tax, are just beginning to cope with a myriad of changes stemming from the tax bill approved by the House of Representatives in December but not yet approved by the Senate.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Chester String Quartet At Merkin Concert Hall
description: The Chester String Quartet, an ensemble formed at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester and now resident at Indiana University in South Bend, returned to New York for a concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: 7 Killed at Kite Fest in India
description: At least seven people were killed and 29 injured when street battles erupted today during a kite-flying festival in Ahmedabad, the police said. The city was hit last year by unrest over the establishment of quotas in colleges and jobs for lower castes. It was not clear whether today's violence was touched off by that issue, but the clashes came after rival groups fighting over the policy called on supporters to daub kites with slogans during the kite-flying festival.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've got bands that are in a higher state of readiness than some of our special operations assets.

title: MANHATTAN DEALER AMONG 3 HELD
description: Three men, including a Manhattan antiques dealer, broke into a customs warehouse in Queens yesterday and took Middle Eastern antiquities valued at more than $18 million, the police said.

title: Record Borrowings In Tax-Exempts
description: State and local governments went on an unprecedented borrowing binge in 1985, issuing a record $189.6 billion of long-term tax-exempt bonds, compared with 1984's volume of $99 billion. So insatiable was investors' demand for tax-exempts that they bought half of the year's total offerings in the fourth quarter, when bond yields were sinking to their lowest levels of 1985.

title: Jordan Tax Revenue Up
description: Jordan's income tax revenue is expected to reach a record 61 million dinars this year, or about $168 million dollars, up 6.5 percent over 1985 tax revenues and 13 percent higher than in 1984, according to the country's income tax director, General Salman al-Tarawneh. At a press conference he said that 57 percent of the 1985 tax revenues came from companies in Jordan, the same percentage as in 1984.

title: BRITISH TORIES SPLIT BY BATTLE OVER AILING COPTER COMPANY
description: An open battle for a stake in Britain's only manufacturer of helicopters has merged into a thinly veiled battle over the policies of the Conservative Party and even its leadership when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher eventually steps down.

title: LETHAL ACID IS PRODUCT OF CHEMICAL THAT LEAKED
description: The chemical that leaked at a uranium-processing plant in Oklahoma on Saturday, resulting in the death of one worker and injury to at least 32 others, breaks down on contact with moisture into a substance that is extremely dangerous even in small amounts, according to Federal officials.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: All the fuss this season over the offensive exploits of William (The Refrigerator) Perry has me wondering: Did the former Bear defensive star Dick Butkus ever score any points for Chicago?

title: U.S. Study Finds Jersey Bases Safe
description: There is no immediate public health threat posed by hazardous waste sites at military installations in New Jersey, but further studies are needed to monitor the movement of contaminants in groundwater, a Federal study indicates.

title: AGENCIES BRACING FOR BUDGET CUTS
description: Budget officials predict some pain, confusion and resentment as Government departments and agencies, big and small, learn next week about the spending cuts required by the new balanced budget law.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; New Songs by the Fugs At the Bottom Line
description: The Fugs, New York City's original Bohemian intellectual folk-rock band, are busily reactivating. The group, which was born 20 years ago on the Lower East Side, appeared at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday nights with a slew of incisively sardonic new songs and excerpts from ''Star Peace, '' a politically satirical ''opera'' with music by the guitarist Steve Taylor.

title: CHRISTOPHER ISHERWOOD IS DEAD AT 81
description: Christopher Isherwood, who was best known for the stories he wrote in the 1930's that served as the basis for the play and movie ''I Am a Camera'' and the musical ''Cabaret,'' died of cancer Saturday morning at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: Advertising; Medicus Intercon Hires A Consumer Director
description: Medicus Intercon, a major agency in the health care area, has hired Joseph Davis from Ogilvy & Mather to be vice president, director of consumer services.

title: Bishop Tutu Speaks At Hartford Church
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, beginning a two-week visit to the United States, said at a church service here today that God had a special place in His heart for weak and voiceless people, such as those living under apartheid.

title: Kosar Unhappy
description: Bernie Kosar criticized Cleveland's conservative, run-oriented offense after the Browns lost, 24-21, to the Miami Dolphins in the American Conference playoffs Saturday.

title: 14 YEARS AFTER SAN QUENTIN DEATHS, LAWYER FACES HIS ACCUSERS
description: More than 14 years after six people died in a bloody shootout at San Quentin Prison, a 43-year-old lawyer will go on trial for murder here Monday in connection with the incident.

title: Irwin Shoots a 67 In 6-Shot Victory
description: Hale Irwin shot a 5-under-par 67 and scored a runaway six-stroke victory in the new Bahamas Classic tournament today.

title: Bridge: First Tournament of Year, Tri-State Regional, to Open
description: The first tournament of the calendar year, the Tri-State Regional, is always very popular and frequently sets attendance records. The tournament will be the focus of attention this week for players in the New York metropolitan area.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Penguins, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. In the Patrick Division, the Penguins (16-19) lead only the Devils, who have lost 10 of their last 11 and are suffering a seven-game streak without a victory.

title: Now Repair the 'Speedy Trial' Law
description: It sounded, in 1983, like a typical horror story of criminal justice in New York: a prosecutor's bungling allowing a man to escape trial for rape. But a new ruling from the Court of Appeals now vindicates Brooklyn's District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, and reinstates charges against the accused. It also underscores the weakness of a law intended to speed up justice.

title: COOK'S CAREER IS ON THE RISE
description: The subject still turns Darwin Cook cold, as if the bitter and uneasy memories of last season are still vivid. So when he is asked, Cook merely sidesteps the discussion. His response is a polite but firm refusal.

title: Treasures to Take Out
description: The 300,000 visitors who have flocked through the Treasure Houses of Britain exhibition at the National Gallery in the last two months can now buy reproductions of five of the objects on display. To call them souvenirs would probably not be appropriate, since they range in price from $135 for a pair of bone china plates with pictures of Venice to $1,750 for a sterling silver toilet box copied from a 1717 original.

title: Sarah L. Roberts Wed To Lawrence I. Koplik
description: At the Beck Chapel at Indiana University in Bloomington, Ind., yesterday Sarah Longden Roberts, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Warren E. Roberts of Bloomington, was married to Lawrence Irwin Koplik, a general partner of Princeton/Newport Option Partners in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Byron Bangert, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Faedra Weiss performed the ceremony.

title: A LETDOWN FOLLOWS HOLIDAYS
description: THE frenzy of the holiday season has ground to a halt; the parties are over, and so are the shopping, the cooking, the gift-wrapping, the giant family dinners. In their place: the January blahs. As one Manhattan man, weary from his social rounds and anticipating the month ahead, put it: ''What is there to look forward to? Now there are no more parties, and I put off minor surgery so it wouldn't interfere with the holidays, so I must go into the hospital. And then there are the bills: I spent far more money than I had intended. I'm depressed.''

title: PANEL TO ASSESS SECURITY EFFORTS IN AIRPORT PLAN
description: In the wake of terrorist attacks last month that left 19 people dead at two European airports, a panel has been asked to assess the security provisions of nearly completed plans to upgrade Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports, the Port Authority's executive director said yesterday.

title: Former Arden Marketer In a Top Post at Klinger
description: Byron D. Donics has chosen to become a bigger fish in a smaller pond.

title: Go Ahead and Sell Airport Slots
description: Isn't the right to land at Chicago's O'Hare Airport at 5 P.M. on a Friday a valuable property that should be salable like any other? The Federal Government long resisted the idea, believing it should be the final judge of who flies where and when. The result has been a perpetual conflict among airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration, with oft-delayed passengers the victims.

title: Polish Delay on Debt Seen
description: Poland will probably ask its bank creditors to renegotiate principal debt repayments because of a severe shortage of hard currency and pressures from Western creditor governments, banking sources in London said Friday.

title: Debra Lookstein Wed to a Pediatrician
description: Debra Lookstein, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Haskel Lookstein of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Shelly David Senders, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Myer Senders of Cleveland. The ceremony was performed at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, where the bride's grandfather, the late Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, and her great-great-grandfather, Rabbi Moses Z. Margolies, served as rabbis.

title: OPEC Panel Plans Session
description: The five-member OPEC committee formed last month to recommend a new marketing strategy for the group will hold its first meeting here on Feb. 3, the news agency for the oil producers said Friday.

title: Acquisition by Anchor
description: In another step toward interstate branching in the thrift industry, the $6.8 billion Anchor Savings Bank of Northport, L.I., has acquired the troubled Sun Savings and Loan Association of Tallahassee, Fla., the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. The acquisition of the $365.3 million Florida institution, which was effective last Tuesday, represented a continuing policy of making interstate branching available to healthy thrift institutions that are willing to buy troubled savings and loans.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET: The Fall of the House of Lehman. By Ken Auletta. 253 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $19.95. HOW did Lehman Brothers

title: Tremors Still Coming From Colombia Volcano
description: The Nevado del Ruiz volcano trembled again today and blocks of ice drifted down rivers in the Armero Valley, prompting the Government to keep a state of ''maximum alert'' for fear of another disaster.

title: Anne M. Snyder Becomes The Bride of Barry Specht
description: The marriage of Anne Melanie Snyder, a lawyer with Ashley & Zarnowski in Carle Place, L.I., to Barry Howard Specht, director of purchasing for the Harbor Footwear Group in Port Washington, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Irving J. Rockoff officiated.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
A Flying Finish
description: Southeastern Ohio is hilly agricultural country, and the terrain there has produced a sport that was once peculiar to the region and is still just plain peculiar. It originated from the local recreational custom whereby farmboys would take their favorite chickens to the top of a hill and induce them to fly off, and it has led to the International Chicken Flying Meet, held outside the town of Gallipolis for the last 14 springs.

title: PURCHASERS CITE SLOWER GROWTH
description: Although the nation's overall economy continued to grow in December, it was at a slower pace than in the preceding three months, corporate purchasing managers said in a report yesterday.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Lance Mulcahy Sets Shakespeare to Music
description: Lance Mulcahy, the Australian composer of ''Sweet Will,'' has taken on the formidable task of setting some of the greatest verses ever written to contemporary pop melodies. ''Sweet Will,'' a musical revue whose text is based entirely on Shakespeare, is the composer's follow-up to his 1981 show, ''Shakespeare's Cabaret,'' which won a Tony nomination for best musical score. Though the new show further reveals Mr. Mulcahy to be a versatile, melodically inventive composer, his marriage of Elizabethan poetry and contemporary pop, is an awkward mismatch. ''Sweet Will,'' which opened Sunday at the New Silver Lining Theater (349 West 46th Street), sets lyrics from 11 Shakespearean plays, including four songs from ''The Tempest,'' three from ''Twelfth Night'' and two each from ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and ''As You Like It.'' The 80-minute, two-act show also includes an adaptation of Shakespeare's early narrative poem, ''Venus and Adonis'' and musical settings of seven sonnets. Mr. Mulcahy's stylistic range encompasses delicate folk-pop (''Where the Bee Sucks''), Fats Waller-influenced pop-jazz (''All That Glisters''), Chopinesque ballads (''Take, Oh Take Those Lips Away''), country music (''O Mistress Mine'') and reggae (''Hey, Ho, the Wind and the Rain''). A cast of four actor-singers, including the pop-soul vocalists Keith Amos and Rosalyn Burrough, the tenor Stephen Lehew and the soprano Stephanie Cotsirilos, have strong enough voices to be able to sing without microphones, and Michael Ward's ingenious arrangements weave electric and acoustic keyboards, guitar and percussion into settings that scale contemporary pop sounds down in volume to Elizabethan proportions.

title: SOVIET WIFE PLEADS WITH GORBACHEV TO LET DAUGHTER GO TOO
description: Irina McClellan, whose request to join her American husband in Virginia was recently approved by Soviet authorities, has appealed to Mikhail S. Gorbachev to let her daughter leave as well.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WIND Mitch Miller, a former television personality and a musician who played the oboe, once called the instrument ''an ill wind that no one blows good.''

title: Tracking the Best
description: To help raise money for its sports programs, Cornell University recently commissioned a book on the school's 121 years of athletics and asked Dick Schaap, the broadcaster and writer, to contribute to the project an article entitled, ''Who Is the Greatest Cornell Athlete? ''

title: The Editorial Notebook; Up in the Dumps
description: ''Where does the Lone Ranger take his trash?'' one of my kids would shout as I announced where I was going. ''To the dump, to the dump, to the dump dump dump,'' another would answer as they collapsed laughing. Despite such derision, I never had trouble persuading them to go along on trips to deposit the products of heavy housecleaning at the Fountain Avenue Landfill.

title: THE OPERA: 'COLUMBUS' AT THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: If brevity is indeed the soul of wit, then Washington Opera's current production of ''Christopher Columbus,'' a pastiche created around the music of Jacques Offenbach, can be counted as one joke that goes on far too long. With its frantic, leering attempts at jollity, Saturday night's performance at the Kennedy Center Terrace Theater, the first of 14 scheduled between now and Feb. 2, called to mind a wild soiree at which one neither knows nor cares about any of the guests but must, out of politeness, smile, converse and feign interest in the latest round of the party games.

title: Prone to Losing
description: Before Paul Hornung of Notre Dame was awarded the Heisman Trophy in 1956, the recipient of college football's most prestigious individual honor had almost invariably gone out in style. Of the 21 previous designees, 18 had ended their Heisman seasons with a victory, and one with a tie.

title: Advertising; RCA Global Account Goes to David Deutsch
description: David Deutsch Associates of New York has received the RCA Global Communications account and Silberman Whitebrow Dolan of Philaldelphia has won the Healthwin Company.

title: Tree Hormones
description: Hurricane Gloria brought widespread devastation to eastern Long Island when it swept ashore Sept. 27, sending trees crashing down on power lines.

title: American Delegation Is en Route to Vietnam
description: A high-level American delegation arrived in Thailand today on its way to Hanoi for talks on Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.

title: Too Many Fingers on the Defense-Spending Trigger
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWSPAPERS BACK AUDIT UNIT
description: Reacting to the recent resignation of five newspapers from the Audit Bureau of Circulations, 51 publishers or chairmen of major United States newspapers and newspaper chains have signed a letter supporting the bureau.

title: OF RIGHTS AND RULES IN GRADE 8
description: Brandi Bettencourt's behavior stopped being a Federal case once she was told she only had to stand when George Nishimura, her metals shop teacher, entered the classroom.

title: CONFLICT IN PENTAGON IS SEEN HURTING ELITE UNITS' BUILDUP
description: The Reagan Administration's five-year effort to build up special commando units for unconventional warfare and counterterrorist operations has been hampered by the indifference, and sometimes active opposition, of regular Army and Air Force officers, according to a senior Pentagon official and members of Congress.

title: BUT THEY CAN'T KICK
description: THE quarterbacks wore gloves. That's how cold it was - 14 degrees at the kickoff, with a wind-chill factor of 13 degrees below zero. In the woods, bears hibernate in such weather but yesterday the Chicago Bears didn't know any better. In a 15 mile-an-hour wind that flattened the flags atop Soldier Field here on the edge of Lake Michigan, the Bears clawed the New York Giants, 21-0, in the Super Bowl XX playoffs. But the Giants can't kick.

title: Advertising; Arrow Man Is Painted By Neiman
description: LeROY NEIMAN, the artist, frequently includes men in shirts and ties in his paintings of the contemporary scene. So doing paintings of men so garbed for a new Arrow shirt advertising campaign was no particular strain for him.

title: A Marriage
description: In September 1927, a dressmaker named Rose Mitchmson wed a fur cutter named Irving Ross (or Rose -the records are unclear) in the main sanctuary of the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side.

title: DENIAL CALLED INCREDIBLE
description: The vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today that he found it ''incredible'' that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would deny that Palestinian guerrillas were operating training camps in Libya.

title: Paraguay Assails U.S. Envoy For Talking With Opposition
description: Interior Minister Sabino Montanaro of Paraguay charged the American Ambassador today with interfering in the country's domestic affairs by having talks with opponents of the Government.

title: ISLANDER MALAISE HAS ARBOUR ANGRY
description: These are dark days for the Islanders. Their latest loss, a 4-1 defeat by the visiting Chicago Black Hawks Saturday night, had overtones of a morality play.

title: T.W.A. DEAL: LOSSES SHAPED TACTICS
description: Just a few months ago, Carl C. Icahn, the Trans World Airlines board of directors and two of the airline's major unions seemed to have forged an agreement for the New York investor to take over the carrier that satisfied all sides.

title: Justice Tries to Work in Reasonable Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Variety of Issues Set for U.S. Auction
description: The Treasury will auction a variety of short- and long-term issues this week, starting with today's offering of three- and six-month bills totaling $14.8 billion.

title: Guinness Peat Offer Fails
description: The Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. said Friday that its $410.3 million final offer for Britannia Arrow Holdings P.L.C. had lapsed after failing to attract more than 11.5 percent of stock held by other Britannia shareholders.

title: Catching Up
description: Bobby DelVecchio, the Bronx-born rodeo star, is living in Fort Worth these days with his new, Texas-born wife, Sissy, and is recovering from a groin injury he suffered in the rodeo finals at Las Vegas, Nev., last month. And, yes, he's still determined to become the first Bronx-born world champion bull rider.

title: 'COSBY' CAPTIONING SPARKS DISPUTE
description: ''The Cosby Show,'' the highest-rated show on television, brings NBC an estimated $1.5 million every week in advertising revenues and holds the promise of record earnings for the show's producers when it is sold into syndication.

title: Deadline Set for Suits Over Dalkon Shield
description: The A. H. Robins Company is beginning a 91-nation advertising campaign to inform 4.5 million women that they have until April 30 to file claims for compensation for health problems caused by the Dalkon Shield, an intrauterine contraceptive device.

title: The Uncertain Right
description: American conservatives, who have come so far on the basis of firm and agreed ideological positions, are divided and unsure on one pressing issue today. That is South Africa.

title: NEW YORK URBAN LEAGUE CHAPTER HONORS 5 FOR PUBLIC SERVICE
description: ''You can really look over all of New York from here,'' Dr. Beny J. Primm said as he glanced down from the top of the World Trade Center yesterday afternoon. ''It gives me inspiration to go back down there and do all I can.''

title: Roosevelt Closing Because of Strike
description: The management of Roosevelt Raceway said today there would be no harness races on Monday, the last day of the current meet, because of a strike by parimutuel clerks.

title: Man Gets 12 Medals 40 Years After War
description: The ceremony was 40 years late, but Houston Lowe has finally received 12 medals that he earned in the Army Air Corps, including the Bronze Star and Purple Heart.

title: Suicide, Euthanasia, Living Wills and Patient-Physician Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Aide of S.E.C. Set for Bache Study
description: When he was growing up in a small town near Reading, Pa., Mahlon M. Frankhauser and a friend both had visions of careers as writers. In a way, those dreams were realized.

title: FUEL PRODUCERS CUT EXPLORATION IN U.S.
description: Domestic oil and gas companies are substantially paring their 1986 exploration plans, particularly within the United States, industry executives and analysts say.

title: Sri Lanka Leader Spurns Talks With Guerrillas
description: President J. R. Jayewardene today ruled out negotiations with Tamils fighting for a separate state in the north and east of Sri Lanka as long as they ''came with guns.''

title: Wise-Wise, It's Obscure
description: The United States Merit Systems Protection Board is a small agency, and yet there are those who love it.

title: HELLO, IS THIS CHAOS?
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz may have bested the White House on polygraph testing, but he is apparently no match for the phone company.

title: McCall Is Backed For Cuomo Ticket
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel urged Governor Cuomo yesterday to support a black or Hispanic candidate for lieutenant governor next fall and said H. Carl McCall, a former State Senator from Harlem, would be a good choice.

title: JAZZ: WARREN VAUGHN SINGS AND PLAYS
description: WHEN Warren Vaughn was last in New York for an extended stay, singing and playing piano at the Bon Soir in the 60's, Bobby Short had not yet settled into the Cafe Carlyle, where he established his reputation. Now that Mr. Vaughn is back in town in the lounge of Sandro, a restaurant at 420 East 59th Street, one notices the similarities between the two.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; 'Lohengrin' Performed At the Met Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera gave a discouraging ''Lohengrin'' on Saturday night, in which two debutants whose singing would not meet high standards joined a cast of like description. Roland Bracht gave a dignified, sympathetic interpretation of King Henry, but he ''covers'' his voice to a debilitating degree.

title: Nun Is Killed In Convent Fire
description: An elderly nun was killed and four other nuns suffered minor injuries in a fire Saturday night at the Mount St. Joseph Convent, fire officials said.

title: MANY IN WORK FORCE CARE FOR ELDERLY KIN
description: New research on the family responsibilities of workers shows that an unexpectedly high percentage of full-time office employees spend significant amounts of time caring for elderly relatives and friends.

title: CHEERS, BEERS AND DEJECTION
description: Like most other Giants fans, Barbara Fliegelman has a perfectly good television set at home, and so for that matter do Steve Menna, Brendan Hegeman and Owen Cosgrove.

title: Arab League Attacks Threats Against Libya
description: The Arab League, after a special council session, issued a communique today that ''vigorously condemned'' what it said were threats of American military action against Libya in response to terrorist attacks at two airports in Europe.

title: Washington Watch; Tapping Home Equity
description: Americans hold an estimated $2 trillion equity in their single-family homes. Yet only a small fraction of the equity has been used as collateral for second mortgages.

title: Bush Goes A-wooing
description: As part of his pursuit of the 1988 Republican nomination, Vice President Bush is campaigning ardently to woo hard-line Republican conservatives, accepting invitations to their dinners and conferences and attempting to persuade them in speeches that his dedication to their key positions is strong and steadfast.

title: 3 Mile Island Nuclear Reactor Generates 91% Power in Test
description: Three months of testing the undamaged nuclear reactor at the Three Mile Island plant was completed Saturday with the unit reaching 91 percent of potential power, said the plant's operator, the G.P.U. Nuclear Corporation.

title: INDIANA FALLS TO MICHIGAN ST.
description: Larry Polec hit four free throws in the last 23 seconds as Michigan State held off a rally by Indiana today to beat the Hoosiers, 77-74.

title: Ronald Amey, Creator Of Bold Fashions, Dies
description: Ronald L. Amey Jr., a fashion designer who specialized in creating dramatic evening wear in the 1960's, was found dead last Wednesday in his apartment in Manhattan. He was 52 years old.

title: BEARS USE PASSING ATTACK AND PRESSURE
description: The goals for the Bears and the Giants in today's playoff game were the same. On offense, both wanted to establish their running games, with Walter Payton and Joe Morris as the spearheads. Defensively, both aimed to stop the run.

title: KERR-MCGEE IS CUTTING TROUBLED NUCLEAR ROLE
description: While the Kerr-McGee Corporation's primary business is oil and natural gas, the company has come into the public eye most often for its involvement in nuclear energy. That pattern continued with the fatal accident Saturday at its Gore, Okla., reactor fuel plant.

title: Washington Watch; Environmental Law
description: Barely noticed in the catchall spending bill passed by Congress Dec. 19 was a requirement that the American representatives to international development banks must now urge these institutions to impose stricter environmental guidelines in distributing money to the third world.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:09 A.M. today and set at 8:49 P.M. tonight.

title: Why Has Reagan Yielded to Europe?
description: The Europeans may have won. The Reagan Administration and its European allies disagreed from the beginning about the best way to deal with the Soviet Union. For a long time, the Administration seemed to have the upper hand, but in the last few months it has apparently given up on its efforts to bring the Europeans to adopt a tough anti-Soviet line. Instead, it has adopted the European policies of detente, summitry, subsidies and arms control.

title: History and Nature Of Anorexia Nervosa
description: To the Editor:

title: DON'T HURT VOTING
description: Congress this month may take up a bill that, to end the problem of election night projections and their potential impact on voter turnout and election results, would close all polls in the continental United States at the same hour. The legislation, applying only to Presidential elections, may do more injury to voter turnout than do networks' projections, even though the legislation is the product of good intentions and a willingness to compromise.

title: U.S. POSTAL SERVICE REPLACES TOP MAN AFTER YEAR IN JOB
description: The Postmaster General was replaced today after only a year in the job.

title: Pacific Exchange Shift
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange will move to a new $5 million trading floor Jan. 13. It will leave a 54-year-old facility on South Spring Street downtown for the new facility on the fringes of the city's business core. Brokers say the old building is too small to handle the exchange's growing business.

title: MINE PRODUCES A BIG PART OF U.S. PLATINUM SUPPLY
description: South Africa's Impala mine, from which 20,000 striking miners were dismissed yesterday, is among the world's largest producers of platinum and a major supplier of the precious metal to the United States, according to precious metals analysts.

title: U.S. Delegation in Seoul
description: A six-member United States Senate delegation arrived here today for a five-day visit in South Korea to discuss trade issues between the two countries, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: RESTORING THE MAGIC AT REVLON
description: Ronald O. Perelman is a betting man.

title: UNICOA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $95.6 million on the sale of investments and a gain of $228 million on Litton Industries distribution. c-Including a gain of $52.7 million on the sale of investments.

title: Common Market Study
description: Only a major change in its agricultural policy will enable the European Economic Community to reduce its large agricultural surpluses, according to the annual report of the European Economic Community Commission.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for 13 wks to Nov 30
description: b-Includes the contribution of Food- A-Rama group, which was acquired Dec. 31, 1984.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: Alcan Write-Down
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said that it planned to take a $215 million after-tax charge against earnings in the fourth quarter. Alcan, based in Montreal, said about two-thirds of the charge related to lowered earning power of bauxite and alumina operations owned by its Aluminum Company of Canada subsidiary. The rest of the charge, Alcan said, related to the sale and restructuring of a number of small overseas businesses and to the write-down of raw material inventories.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. JEWISH GROUP CAUTIONS ON ARMS
description: An group working on behalf of Soviet Jews said today that it planned an information campaign to show that Moscow could not be trusted on arms accords if it did not allow freer emigration.

title: Chess: Kasparov Delivers Timman First Defeat in Dutch Series
description: Gary Kasparov, the 22-year-old world champion, has defeated Jan Timman, 34, the top Dutch grandmaster, by 4-2 in the KRO Chessmatch in Hilversum, the Netherlands.

title: Reagan's Dish
description: When in Los Angeles, people who want to eat like a Tastemaker in Chief may go to the Century Plaza Hotel, where Ronald Reagan often stays on his Western swings, and order the menu item listed as ''Supreme of Chicken with Kiwi and Dixie Dressing as served to President Reagan.'' $9.75, ketchup included on request.

title: Appeal in Cigarette Suit
description: An appeal has been filed in an attempt to overturn a jury's decision that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company was not liable in the death of a man who smoked for five decades, the lawyer Melvin Belli said today. Speaking by telephone from his San Francisco office, he said he filed the challenge last week with the state Court of Appeals. A jury in Santa Barbara on Dec. 23 ruled in the company's favor in a $1 million damage suit brought by the heirs of John Mark Galbraith.

title: 10-YEAR-OLD DEATH OF GIRL INVESTIGATED
description: One night 10 years ago Carolyn Majane, then 15 years old, left two girlfriends on Main Street here to walk to a party nearby. It was the last time her friends and family were to see her alive.

title: Key Changes At Dennison
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company, a stationery and computer supplies maker in Framingham, Mass., said yesterday that three top executives would assume new responsibilities.

title: Leo Drachsler, a Prosecutor At War Trials in Nuremberg
description: Leo M. Drachsler, a Manhattan lawyer who was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials in 1945-46, died of a heart attack Friday at Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: KEY IMAGE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLAWED TEXTBOOKS DISTORT U.S.-SOVIET RELATIONS
description: MARINA I. JURAVLEVA, the Soviet Deputy Minister of Education, recently complained to visiting Americans that schoolchildren in the United States know very little about the Soviet Union. Their textbooks, she thought, give them a distorted view.

title: Yanks' Phil Niekro In Contract Accord
description: Phil Niekro, as expected, has reached agreement on a new contract with the Yankees, but the negotiations between the Yankees and Butch Wynegar apparently are unexpectedly sticky as tomorrow's midnight signing deadline draws nearer.

title: SOME LOW-LEVEL RADIATION IS FOUND BEYOND PLANT SITE
description: A Kerr-McGee official said today that all significant radiation from Saturday's accident at the company's uranium-processing plant was probably contained on company property, but that some ''low-level'' radiation had been found along an adjacent public highway.

title: GUN IS CALLED ILLEGAL
description: A 55-year-old Transit Authority token clerk drew a pistol and shot one of three men who was trying to rob him in a Brooklyn subway station last night foiling the robbery, the police said. The token clerk was arrested and charged with illegal possession of a pistol.

title: U.S. Holds Up Sri Lanka Tea After Rebels Warn of Cyanide
description: Black tea arriving in the United States from Sri Lanka is being held up and tested because of threats by terrorists in that country to contaminate exports with cyanide, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Pilot Insurance
description: The General Accident, Fire and Life Assurance Corporation said it had agreed to buy the Pilot Insurance Company subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings for $143.6 million. Pilot is a property and casualty insurance company, based in Toronto, that operates exclusively in Ontario.

title: Business and the Law; Nonunion Labor's Rights
description: EVEN though the National Labor Relations Act is usually invoked to protect unionized workers or workers trying to form unions, the National Labor Relations Board is expected to decide soon a key case about how far the labor act goes to protect nonunion workers.

title: First Oklahoma Names Head of Parent and Unit
description: The First Oklahoma Bancorporation, which over the last three years has experienced financial problems and management shake-ups, announced yesterday that J. G. Cairns Jr., president of the Peoples Bancorporation of Seattle, had been named to the top posts at the holding company and its principal subsidiary, the First National Bank and Trust Company.

title: JUDGE AQUITS TWO IN KANSAS CITY TRIAL ON CASINO CHARGES
description: Two sons of a man suspected of being a leader of organized crime in Milwaukee were acquitted today of conspiracy and racketeering charges in connection with Las Vegas casino operations.

title: A FRENCH PUBLISHER DEFIES SOCIALISTS' EFFORT TO RESTRICT HIM
description: A conservative publisher has challenged the country's Socialist Government by buying a newspaper in violation of a law curbing the size of his press holdings.

title: Kodak Asks Court To Reverse Ruling
description: The Eastman Kodak Company asked a Federal appeals court to reverse a lower court ruling that bars it from competing with the Polaroid Corporation in the instant photography market after Thursday. Kodak appealed an injunction handed down in October by Federal District Judge Rya Zobel in Boston.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Devils Lose Again
description: Terry Ruskowski scored with 1 minute 37 seconds left in the third period to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 4-3 victory over New Jersey tonight, extending the Devils' National Hockey League losing streak to eight games.

title: Careers; Scarce Corporate Directors
description: CORPORATE directors are getting harder to find, but not as hard to find as the proverbial needle in the haystack because of the job's ego and monetary rewards.

title: FOR THIRD YEAR IN ROW, GIFTS REACH $2 MILLION FOR NEEDIEST
description: For the third consecutive year, contributions to the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have passed the $2 million mark.

title: LOSS POINTS OUT RAIDER NEED
description: In the spring of 1983, days before the National Football League college draft, the Los Angeles Raiders were so concerned about their quarterbacks that they offered several players, including the defensive lineman Howie Long, to the Chicago Bears for the Bears' first-round pick in the draft. The Raiders had intended to trade that No. 1 pick and their own to the Baltimore Colts, who had the first pick in the draft.

title: SOVIET SAYS U.S. SEEKS LIBYAN CONFRONTATION
description: A Soviet Government spokesman said today that the United States was making ''direct threats'' against Libya and was not interested in a peaceful resolution of their differences.

title: Nissan Unit Fills Top Post
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation in U.S.A. said yesterday that Kazutoshi Hagiwara had been named president of the company, the second-largest Japanese auto importer and distributor in this country behind Toyota.

title: AUBURN TOPS KENTUCKY, 60-56
description: Chuck Person scored 24 points and Gerald White hit four crucial free throws in the final minute after Auburn had wasted most of a 16-point second-half lead as the Tigers beat Kentucky, 60-56, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: NEXT SUMMER: SIMPLER
description: When the first designs for 1986 were introduced in New York, Paris, Milan and London early last fall, they were instantly dubbed ''understated,'' ''pared-down'' and ''spare.'' Fashion was entering a phase of sobriety.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LIZ CLAIBORNE showed a collection last Friday that was billed as Fall I, 86. To most designers that would mean early fall clothes to be delivered to stores in the summer. But to Liz Claiborne, it means warm-weather clothes to be delivered to stores in May and June, when the weather in many parts of the country is starting to get warm. Since it's become well-nigh impossible to buy summer clothes in the summer, this should give shoppers something to cheer about. It may even start a trend. (Just don't ask why the collection is called Fall I.) The clothes include a bit of everything, from rayon gabardine suits for the office to shorts and T-shirts for the beach. There are stripes, plaids, solids and florals in bright primary colors as well as the palest of pastels.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid May 8.

title: Tightening Nuclear Liability
description: The fatal accident last week at a uranium-processing plant in Gore, Okla., should impress upon Congress the importance of reversing a dangerous law that may set the standard for corporate liability. Last Saturday, a slightly radioactive cloud of hydrofluoric acid leaked from a plant owned by the Sequoyah Fuels Corporation, a subsidiary of the Kerr-McGee Corporation, killing one man and injuring 32 people. It's now clear that nuclear facilities pose the threat of chemical as well as radiation leaks.

title: 4 Killed, 15 Wounded In Attacks in Punjab
description: Four people were killed and 15 wounded today in attacks in the Sikh stronghold of Punjab State.

title: GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenues for the latest year include a nonrecurring gain of $18.9 million on the sale of contract servicing by the company.

title: Remnant of Oxygen
description: Astronomers have discovered what they say is a rare sample of material as it existed within a massive star before it exploded some 10,000 years ago. The remnants of almost pure oxygen may provide new clues to how supernova explosions enrich the universe and supply raw material for the formation of solar systems.

title: PUBLISHING: AUCTION DELAYED FOR 'WHIRLWIND'
description: The auction for James Clavell's new novel, ''Whirlwind,'' which had been scheduled for today, has been postponed. Publishing officials say the auction will take place Thursday, but Michella Clavell, who heads Foreign Rights Inc., which is handling negotiations for the book, would say only that ''negotiations and final terms will be completed on or before Jan. 16.''

title: On the Meaning of It All
description: The Smithsonian Institution is probably as qualified as any to try to explain what it all means. With its countless artifiacts and facts, the institution has a lot of evidence susceptible to grand deduction.

title: Trying to Pay Off
description: ''It was part of a bet,'' Kenneth H. Comer said as he waited at noon yesterday at Manny's in Moonachie, N.J., for strips of steak to be stuffed into two rolls. ''And Mayor Koch pays his bets.''

title: Childhood Bellyaches
description: Some 10 to 15 percent of school-age children suffer from repeated bouts of abdominal pain, and physicians, parents and teachers have long attributed these bellyaches to anxiety, fear and anticipation of stressful situations, such as going to school, meeting new children or taking exams.

title: MUSIC: OPERATIC GALA, 'PAVAROTTI PLUS'
description: EARLY on in ''Pavarotti Plus,'' the gala operatic concert at Avery Fisher Hall last night, Luciano Pavarotti did a fair amount to disingratiate himself with the musically discriminating portion of the audience. One prepared to concentrate on the ''plus'' - nine colleagues, some of them winners of the Pavarotti Vocal Competition in Philadelphia, who were on hand to sing ensembles - but the famous tenor had better in him, and by the end he had given a representative account of himself, prized virtues and frustrating flaws alike.

title: Liberia Installs Leader; Dissidents Are Released
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe freed 18 politicians and journalists from jail today as he was sworn in as Liberia's elected President, less than two months after stopping an attempted coup.

title: Texaco Case: Officers Meet
description: One day after holding what was described by sources as a key negotiating session in efforts to resolve their high-stakes legal battle, the Pennzoil Company and Texaco Inc. held separate meetings of their top executives yesterday to determine their next moves in the tangled case.

title: 'COUNCIL WARS' AT AN END, SAYS CHICAGO MAYOR
description: Several weeks ago, Mayor Harold Washington gleefully told reporters: '' 'Council Wars' are over. Peace has broken out. Come out of the cellar, Chicago. The bombing has stopped.''

title: AIR CONTROLLERS TO FLY WITH PILOTS
description: Top officials of the Federal Aviation Administration and two industry groups announced a voluntary program today that is aimed at giving air traffic controllers practical knowledge about private and corporate aircraft.

title: A FIREFIGHTER HERO, IN LIFE AND DEATH
description: On New Year's Eve, when Rich Reddick heard that his younger brother Marcus had been taken to the hospital with a firefighting injury, he did not believe it could be serious. Marcus Reddick was 26 years old, so young, so nimble - he used to slide down the fire station pole upside down.

title: Getting Multinationals to Pay a Fair Share
description: To the Editor:

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT TERRORISM;
Press For Peace
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's anti-terrorism doctrine, which he calls ''active prevention'' and announced in 1984 after nine employees were killed in a truck bomb attack on the American Embassy in Beirut, is a failure. The reason is that neither threatened nor actual retaliation foil terrorists.

title: RADICAL WHO SURVIVED BOMBING GOES ON TRIAL IN PHILADELPHIA
description: In an ornate courtroom, the only known adult survivor from the barricaded house of the radical group Move began defending herself today against charges stemming from the group's confrontation with the police May 13.

title: Harvester's New Name
description: Hitching its wagons to a star, of sorts, the International Harvester Company is about to become Navistar International.

title: Heart Patient Is Recovering
description: Mary Lund, the first woman to receive an artificial heart, is now able to sit in a chair for short periods and is continuing to breathe well without a respirator, doctors said today.

title: Treasury Rates Are Mixed
description: Interest rates on Treasury issues were mixed with only small net changes yesterday, as securities dealers prepared for a heavy supply of notes and bonds later this week.

title: TENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $331,512 for the quarter and $531,947 for the 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $159,334. The figures for the year-ago quarter were restated. The company changed its fiscal year end to Sept. 30 from Dec. 31. Tensor said the 1985 results include revenue from its artificial flower and plant business, acquired in July.

title: SUDBURY HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $1,425,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,310,000, or 28 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $556,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $948,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: FORMER CONGRESSMAN WAS 87
description: James E. Van Zandt, a former Congressman from Pennsylvania and a Navy war hero who was a three-time chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, died today in a hospice in Arlington, Va. He was 87 years old.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a charge of $553,000 related to the cost of closing a manufacturing facility.

title: Fidata to Sell Unit
description: The Fidata Corporation, formerly the Bradford National Corporation, said that it had agreed to sell a subsidiary, the Fidata Trust Company Massachusetts, to the Mellon National Corporation.

title: The Cabbie Who Guarded 25 Rolls of Film 4 Months
description: >Last August, Kim Garnick, a freelance photographer, returned from a trip West with 25 rolls of film she had shot.

title: Cuomo Admits Error In Seat-Belt Remark
description: Governor Cuomo said today that his comment last year involving the National Rifle Association - for which he has been threatened with a libel suit - was ''the blunder of the universe.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The links between international terrorism and Libya are clear. Any effort by the Qaddafi regime to portray itself as somehow backing away from its earlier positions is disingenuous at best.

title: SYRACUSE TROUNCES VILLANOVA BY 80-57
description: Syracuse has gotten off to a fast start, at least at home in the Carrier Dome. The Orangemen began their Big East schedule last Thursday by pounding Boston College, then routed Seton Hall, and going into tonight's game had won their first 10 games - all on their homecourt.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TETHERS IN SPACE: THE FUTURE MOVES NEARER
description: Even as the space shuttle program struggles to overcome nagging troubles, scientists are laying plans for a bold new era of space transportation meant to go far beyond the shuttle's achievements, and even beyond problem-laden rocketry itself. The goal, a vision of the 21st century, is to slash the cost of moving people and freight into space. The machines for this endeavor have such futuristic names as Sky Hook, Launch Loop and Star Bridge.

title: GIANTS' PATTERSON QUICK TO RECOVER
