description: Elvis Patterson had to smile yesterday when he heard that the Bears' Dennis McKinnon had made fun of him. That smile is a tribute to Patterson's recuperative powers - and his confidence.

title: GIRL GIVEN HIS HEART AS HIS FINAL WISH
description: A 15-year-old boy who learned that his girlfriend needed a heart transplant told his mother three weeks ago that he was going to die and that the young woman should have his heart.

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor 2 News Chains
description: TWO particularly attractive investment opportunities may emerge in 1986 from an already brightening newspaper stock group, some media analysts say.

title: TERRORISTS TRAIN AT 15 LIBYAN SITES, U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The White House has received intelligence information that as many as 15 camps have been set up in Libya to train Palestinian guerrillas and other terrorists, an Administration official said today.

title: World Airways Fare Cut
description: World Airways said it was lowering its coast to coast transcontinental fares to $90. The $90 fare is based on round trip purchase, must be purchased seven days in advance, and is available for every seat, every day. Tickets must be purchased before Feb. 15 and travel completed before March 15.

title: Postermotions' Map Of City's Restaurants
description: A thriving advertising medium in the suburbs these days is a cartoon map of the downtown area of individual communities that local retailers pay to be included in.

title: A Retreat for Tax Writers
description: With the Senate about to begin writing tax-revision legislation, Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, hopes to hold a private retreat outside Washington the last weekend of this month for members of his committee and a few top Administration officials.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT TERRORISM;
Fight Back
description: The recent atrocities at the Rome and Vienna airports have given new urgency to the debate over the proper response to terrorism. Beyond the specific question of retaliation against Abu Nidal's Palestinian gunmen and their Libyan accomplices lies a more profound issue: Can and should the United States and other Western countries defend themselves without exacerbating the situation and feeding a ''spiral of violence''?

title: '85 CAR SALES APPEAR TO SET RECORD
description: With light trucks and imported cars leading the way, vehicle sales in the United States apparently rose to record levels in 1985, according to the manufacturers, who said about 15.6 million vehicles were sold during the year.

title: SALES HELD STABLE ON COMPUTERS
description: After a humbling year, the nation's leading makers of home computers said yesterday that they posted solid sales during the Christmas season. But the top sellers, early reports indicate, were older, established models, rather than flashy new computers rushed to market in an effort to pump up the troubled industry.

title: A LOOK AT 'RAJIV'S INDIA' ON PBS DOCUMENTARY
description: ''RAJIV'S INDIA'' is hopeful about India; a nation of 760 million people is preparing for the 21st century, while trying to join the best of the old and the new. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, meanwhile, is an enlightened leader. The one-hour program, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is clear as to its perspective.

title: PLAN FOR NARROW TOWER FOUGHT IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS
description: Some residents of Brooklyn Heights are locked in a heated fight with a developer over a proposed 26-story condominium project that they say would ruin the character of their community of brownstones, churches and other low buildings.

title: Required Reading; On Federalism
description: Excerpt from ''To Form a More Perfect Union,'' a new report from the Committee on Federalism and National Purpose, a group formed by the National Conference on Social Welfare, of Washington:

title: LONDON FINANCIAL DISTRICT GOING TO THE ISLE OF DOGS
description: The Isle of Dogs, a thumb-shaped peninsula that jabs into the Thames River just east of the Tower of London, was once a landscape of ships' funnels, cranes and pubs, the home of the West India Docks and gateway to the British Empire. Then came the decline of the empire, the death of the docks and, since 1945, an exodus of 200,000 people.

title: NAVY SAYS IN A NONNUCLEAR WAR IT MIGHT ATTACK SOVIET A-ARMS
description: The Navy has officially acknowledged that if a major nonnuclear conflict broke out between the United States and the Soviet Union, it might seek to attack Soviet submarines that carry long-range nuclear missiles.

title: LAWMAKERS SAY BUDGET LAW PUTS 3 BUREAUCRATS IN POWER
description: Twelve members of Congress charged today that a new budget-balancing law was unconstitutional because it would delegate to three unelected officials the ''quintessential legislative responsibility'' of deciding how much money shall be spent by the Federal Government.

title: Falcons Add Coaches
description: The Atlanta Falcons have added Chuck Clausen and Tommy Brasher, two former Philadelphia Eagle assistants, to their coaching staff.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Dec. 12 about the funeral of former Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart incorrectly described the involvement of Justice Thurgood Marshall. He attended the funeral service but not the burial.

title: DAMSON OIL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax loss of $5.2 million resulting from obligations to buy back limited partnership interests in certain partnerships, and a nonrecurring writeoff of $3.9 million of all of the company's capitalized costs related to its oil and gas operations in Africa. c-Net income.

title: Felker Quits Adweek Post
description: Clay Felker, one of the most visible figures on the New York publishing scene, said yesterday that he had resigned as editor in chief of Adweek, the advertising trade publication.

title: Fancy Figures
description: After Eric Dickerson's rampage against Dallas the other day, the top five postseason rushing performances in pro football history are as follows: 248 - Eric Dickerson, L.A. Rams, vs.

title: SCM DEAL REJECTED BY U.S. COURT
description: Ending a judicial split over an important takeover defense, a Federal court in New York ruled yesterday that directors of the SCM Corporation breached their duty to shareholders when, to fend off one acquirer, they agreed to sell the company's most prized assets at bargain prices to another.

title: PERSONAL DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $140,000 relating to the termination of the company's cooperative agreement with Stauffer Chemical Co. for the development of self-care products. c-After an extraordinary charge of $275,000 for a payment to a former underwriter for waiving certain rights of first refusal relating to the company's public offerings of common stock. Year-ago results include operations of Lydo Precision Products Inc. from the date of acquisition, Feb. 10, 1984.

title: Governor of Louisiana Urges a State Lottery
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today that he would call the Legislature into special session to consider a lottery for the state, and casino gambling for New Orleans as a way to ease chronic budget problems.

title: Jobs Tax Credit Stigmatizes Disadvantaged Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Grant Thorton
description: Alexander Grant & Company, one of the nation's largest accounting and management consulting firms, and its British affiliate Thorton Baker said that they had changed their names to Grant Thorton. Robert Kleckner, executive partner of the Chicago-based company, said the change would reinforce the firm's image as having international capabilities for the middle market.

title: ISRAEL TO STUDY EGYPTIAN OFFER
description: An Israeli Foreign Ministry official said today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir had agreed to submit an Egyptian proposal for improved relations to key Israeli Cabinet ministers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 7, 1986
description: Companies

title: The Editorial Notebook; Presidential Timberness
description: Though the next national election remains almost three years away, the campaigns are starting to bubble. Ted Kennedy drops out of the Democratic Presidential race to focus on re-election to the Senate. Gary Hart gives up re-election to the Senate to focus on the Presidency. On the Republican side, the underbrush rings with sniper shots between supporters of Vice President Bush, Representative Jack Kemp and others.

title: 7 RECEIVE MAYOR'S AWARDS FOR ARTS
description: Seven artists were given the Mayor's annual Award of Honor for Arts and Culture yesterday for their contributions to New York City's cultural life. At a ceremony in the Susan Wagner Room at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Koch praised the award winners as ''outstanding artists'' whose talents had enriched New York.

title: Ex-F.D.I.C. Chairman Said to Form New Firm
description: After handling banking crises for the Government as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, William M. Isaac, will now be working on them for the industry.

title: Castellano Slaying Prompts Bid for Mistrial in Theft Case
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would rule on motions for a mistrial in a car-theft and murder-conspiracy case after questioning jurors again on the effects of publicity prompted by the slaying of one defendant, Paul Castellano, reputed chief of the Gambino crime family.

title: The Story Behind the Release of Testimony in the Roy Cohn Case
description: To the Editor:

title: PATH IN JUNGLE OF SOFTWARE FOR WRITING
description: THERE are dozens of word processing programs from which to choose, and they are often as different as the writers who will use them. Some are complex and powerful, while others are dull and slow. Unfortunately, most efforts to survey and rate these varied programs lump them all together and match them against one another on the broadest possible scale, usually giving top honors to two or three high-powered performers with the most features.

title: Davis to Return
description: Walter Davis, the high-scoring Phoenix Suns guard, is scheduled to be released from the Pasadena Community Hospital drug abuse program in California on Friday. It is the same facility in which Micheal Ray Richardson of the Nets is undergoing treatment. Davis, who is 31 years old, entered the clinic Dec. 12 after asking club offcials for help with what he called personal problems.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bear Image
description: Coach Mike Ditka expounds on the image of the Chicago Bears: ''We are met with disfavor in some quarters.

title: PARCELLS'S SUPER OBSESSION
description: Another coach might have been satisfied. His team had an 11-7 record over all. It had advanced to the Super Bowl divisional playoffs for the second consecutive season. And it had lost to the team with the National Football League's best record for the second consecutive season. Quite an accomplishment, especially for a franchise with a recent history of not even challenging to qualify for the playoffs. But when Bill Parcells was asked yesterday if he felt some sense of satisfaction at what the Giants had done, he stared hard at his questioner. ''No,'' he said quickly. ''Why not? '' he was asked.

title: AULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 7, 1986
description: International

title: A CLOSER-TO-DICKENS 'OLIVER TWIST'
description: THE haunting production of Charles Dickens's ''Bleak House'' on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' was made by the BBC in association with cable TV's Arts & Entertainment Network. The same two entities have co-produced ''Oliver Twist,'' which begins a six-part run tonight at 8 o'clock on, appropriately enough, the A&E Network.

title: Soviet-China Disparities
description: The extraordinary development of China under Deng Xiaoping's modernization has led to some misconceptions in the West. People wonder whether something similar is likely in the Soviet Union, and they imagine that China is ''going capitalist.''

title: People
description: Jerome W. Stein has joined Griffin: Thomas Marketing Communications Inc. of West Haven, Conn., as partner and executive vice president.

title: POPE NAMES SEVEN NEW BISHOPS
description: Pope John Paul II named seven bishops today on the Roman Catholic Feast of the Epiphany.

title: PROJECT PROVIDES VISION AND VALUES
description: A YOUNG person growing up in an affluent family takes for granted the presence of adults to whom he can turn for help and advice for such tasks as getting a summer job or choosing a college. But educators say that a minority student at an urban high school often has no family member to provide this kind of knowledge, nor has he a network of adults to help him plan for his life after high school.

title: Three in Ulster Prison End a Hunger Strike
description: Three Irish Republican prisoners today ended a hunger strike begun last month to press for appeals against their murder convictions, officials said.

title: U.S.-Italian Offer For Westland Rises
description: The United Technologies Corporation and Fiat S.p.A. improved the terms of their rescue plan today for Britain's financially troubled helicopter maker, Westland P.L.C.

title: WORLD FORECAST IS SLUGGISH
description: After an uncommonly weak revival from the harsh worldwide recession of the early 1980's, most countries are facing a second discouraging year of slow growth and intractably high unemployment, international economists say. The year will also be marked, they add, by more debt-payment difficulties in Latin America and a renewed drive toward protectionism in international trade.

title: Edalini Winner
description: Ivano Edalini of Italy scored an upset victory today in the men's parallel ski slalom series, outracing Markus Wasmeier, who is the world champion.

title: Show of Courage By the Coach
description: Stories involving feats of great strength have long been one of the hallmarks of sport. But then there is the occasional account of courage so transcendent that most such stories are made to seem quite ordinary. There is, for instance, the case of Charlie Wedemeyer.

title: Counterfeit Computers
description: Hundreds of computers manufactured in violation of international patents were crushed by steamrollers today in a new Taiwan campaign against counterfeit goods. A Government spokesman said more than 3,000 computers had been seized during raids in the last month.

title: THOUSANDS IN U.S. RECEIVE TREATMENT IN EXPERIMENTS
description: American doctors have been treating hundreds of thousands of patients a year with experimental therapies in a wide range of clinical studies of cancer and other grave illnesses, according to estimates by Federal officials and academic experts.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sale of Block Of Schering
description: E. F. Hutton & Company sold much of its holdings yesterday in the Schering-Plough Corporation, according to Wall Street sources. The sale comes a month after Hutton was sued by the pharmaceutical company, which contended that the brokerage had accumulated its stock illegally.

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $169,189. c-Net income.

title: IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL, WITNESS RECALLS ATTEMPT ON LIFE
description: An admitted Mafia member testified in Manhattan yesterday about a dramatic attempt on his life during a gangland war in Sicily.

title: BUFFALO MAYOR WEIGHS RACE
description: Mayor James D. Griffin of Buffalo, who won re-election to a third term last November, said yesterday that he might run for governor this year.

title: Adrift in Space
description: Voyager 2, the spacecraft traveling more than eight years out from Earth, will swing by Uranus later this month, sending back the first close-up pictures of the veiled planet and its five moons. Voyager represents space exploration at its most intelligent and productive. Meanwhile, the American space spectacle planned for this week shows NASA at its least magnificent.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Felker Is Eyed
description: Rockey Felker, the quarterback of 1974 Mississippi State University football team which defeated North Carolina in the Sun Bowl, was expected to return to his alma mater as its new coach yesterday. The 32-year-old Felker, an all Southeastern Conference quarterback, replaces Emory Bellard, who was dismissed after a 5-6 season.

title: CITY STUDIES UPGRADING YANKEE STADIUM ACCESS
description: State and city officials said yesterday that they were studying a request by the principal owner of the New York Yankees for a commuter rail station and more than 1,000 additional parking spaces at Yankee Stadium.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of investments of $274,300,000 and a gain of $83,900,000 from the effect of the Litton Industries distribution. c-Including a gain on the sale of investments of $260,300,000 and special tax credits of $105,000,000.

title: C.B.O.E. Election
description: Gary P. Lahey, a market maker and a director of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, was elected chairman of the executive committee and vice chairman of the board, the top elected position of the nation's largest options exchange. Mr. Lahey's election is seen as a clear victory for the C.B.O.E.'s market makers, or professional floor traders, who have been associated with the open outcry system, or options conducted through voice and hand signals, over the large-member brokerage firms, which yield more orders and favor increased automation. Mr. Lahey, who is 40 years old, joined the C.B.O.E. in 1973.

title: MIDDLE EAST ART THEFTS TIED TO INFLATED MARKET
description: Law-enforcement officials and art experts said yesterday that the foiled theft of $18 million worth of Middle Eastern antiquities on Sunday was probably linked to an inflated art market in which record prices, including those for Middle Eastern art, are repeatedly set.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AFFAIR. The Case of Alfred Dreyfus. By Jean-Denis Bredin. Translated from the French by Jeffrey Mehlman. 628 pages. Illustrated. George Braziller. $24.95. SOMETIME around 1930 a

title: SHUTTLE LAUNCHING DELAYED YET AGAIN BY MECHANICAL FAILURE
description: The shuttle Columbia's return to space after a two-year layoff was delayed again today, this time because of troubles with a valve in the oxygen lines leading to the shuttle's main engines.

title: Parker Pen Charge
description: The Parker Pen Company said it expected to take a one-time charge of about $50 million for the quarter ended Nov. 30 related to the sale of its writing instruments division.

title: A Newspaper Is Elegized
description: SHORTLY before John McNulty and The Columbus (Ohio) Citizen parted company, he dispatched a message to the editor: ''Send me $50 and my middle name. I want to join the Elks.'' But it's the leaving (in his case to write for The New Yorker) that matters here. The Citizen's reporters were always leaving.

title: Steinway Calendar
description: New calendars are going up these days - ones with farm scenes, abstract art, cuddly kittens and even pretty girls and boys.

title: AQUINO SAYS COMMUNISTS WOULDN'T JOIN THE CABINET
description: Corazon C. Aquino, offering a new response to accusations from President Ferdinand E. Marcos that she is pro-Communist, declared today that she would not allow any Communists in her cabinet if she defeats Mr. Marcos in presidential elections scheduled for Feb. 7.

title: MERGER WAVE: HOW STOCK AND BONDS FARE
description: The barrage of corporate takeovers in 1985 enriched stockholders of the acquired companies and helped the stock market climb to a record. But there is growing evidence that shareholders of the surviving companies are no better off and that bondholders on both sides are often big losers.

title: RAIDER NOT SORRY HE HIT PATRIOT OFFICIAL
description: Matt Millen of the Los Angeles Raiders says he did not realize at the time that it was Pat Sullivan, the New England Patriots' general manager, that he hit on the back of the head with his helmet Sunday - but he says he's not sorry he did it.

title: HONG KONG HAS SEEN THE FUTURE AND HAS DOUBTS
description: The young Chinese business official removed his spectacles, polished them with his handkerchief and leaned forward across his desk.

title: Notes Offered By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million of floating-rate notes due on July 10, 1986, at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: Lendl Opens With Smid
description: Ivan Lendl, ranked the No. 1 tennis player in the world in 1985, has drawn Thomas Smid, a fellow Czechoslovak, as an opponent in the opening round of the Nabisco Masters, which begins Jan. 14. Lendl is the top-seeded player in the event, which will be held at Madison Square Garden.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: E.P.A. URGES BAN ON A PESTICIDE TO PROTECT WILDLIFE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today to halt the use of the pesticide diazinon on golf courses and turf farms because it has been killing waterfowl and other wildlife.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEES LITTLE THREAT TO MILITARY IN BALANCED-BUDGET BILL
description: The Administration said today that assertions that President Reagan's military buildup was threatened by a balanced-budget law were based on a ''worst case scenario'' that Congress could avoid by cutting other programs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Friday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misstated Dr. Edward Teller's position at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. He is a consultant.

title: Falwell Assists Church Upset by Sex Scandal
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the leader of Moral Majority, has agreed to serve as interim pastor of the Bangor Baptist Church until it recovers from the scandal generated by its founder's admission in October that he had had an affair with a parishioner.

title: Prisons to Release Victims of AIDS
description: The State Correction Commissioner, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, said today that he would release more prisoners with AIDS into the care of Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize recipient.

title: AMONG HOSPITAL'S TOOLS: ASTHMA SHOTS AND ALKA-SELTZER
description: Doctors at Sequoyah Memorial Hospital here said they had prepared for a disaster Saturday, but in southeastern Oklahoma that usually means a tornado.

title: Toski Withdraws
description: Bob Toski, the 59-year-old member of the Senior PGA Tour who is also a noted golf instructor, has voluntarily withdrawn from the senior tour for an indefinite period after admitting he may have violated the rules of golf by improperly marking his ball on putting greens during recent tournaments. In a statement issued through the PGA Tour office in Ponte Vedra, Fla., Toski said: ''In the late fall of 1985 one of my fellow players brought to my attention that I may have been violating the rules of golf by mismarking my ball.

title: FISCAL SPECIALIST; ALBERT VINCENT CASEY
description: Albert Vincent Casey, an avuncular Bostonian with a reputation as a tough man with a gin rummy hand who has a sharp eye on the bottom line, is no stranger to fiscal crisis.

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: Debating a Police Test for Drug Use
description: Like many other major cities, the nation's capital has a major drug problem. Heroin-related deaths are among the highest in the country. Pushers blatantly make street sales.

title: ST. JOHN'S FACES TOUGHEST FOE
description: On paper, it would seem as if St. John's has been sufficiently primed with close, tension-filled games for its coming Big East schedule.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:03 A.M. today and set at 8:43 P.M. tonight.

title: VIKINGS' GRANT RESIGNS 2D TIME
description: Bud Grant resigned as head coach of the Minnesota Vikings for the second time and has been replaced by the assistant coach Jerry Burns, General Manager Mike Lynn announced today.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOCTOR TESTIFIES WOMAN'S DEATH WAS DUE TO CANCER, NOT MURDER
description: A pathologist testifying for a Houston nursing home charged with murder said today that a patient at the home died of cancer, not neglect or abuse as the prosecution contend.

title: Quake Rocks Nepal
description: A moderate tremor and 15 minor aftershocks rocked the capital of this Himalayan kingdom today, the Department of Mines and Geology said. There was no immediate report of casualties or damage from the quake, which measured 4 on the Richter scale, according to the department's seismological station.

title: Networks Will Carry Reagan News Parley
description: President Reagan's news conference will be televised live at 8 P.M. on ABC, CBS, NBC and the Cable News Network.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Apricot Computer Group P.L.C., London, said it had agreed to restructure its AT Computerworld joint venture with Tandy Corp. because of the slowdown in the microcomputer market. The 13 company-owned stores will be transferred to Tandy and the 16 franchised stores will be put under Apricot's control.

title: HEAVYWEIGHT SERIES PLANNED
description: Home Box Office, the pay-cable TV service, has proposed a deal that could cost it $26 million and lead to a unified heavyweight champion.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation recently announced a $500 million program for 1986 whereby thrift institutions will exchange home mortgages for the corporation's mortgage pass-through participation certificates, which are then exchanged for collateralized mortgage obligations.

title: Revenue Sharing / Sharing No Revenue
description: There's nothing surprising about Mayor Koch's request, in his new five-year financial plan, for hundreds of millions in new aid from the State of New York. The city always asks the state for more. What's new is that the request is conditioned on the Federal Government's plan to eliminate sharing revenue with the nation's cities. If Washington's Republican budget-cutters ignore him, Mayor Koch wants Albany's Democratic budget-builders to wants Albany's Democratic budget-builders to make up half the loss. It's no coincidence that he issued this plea the day before Governor Cuomo's 1986 State of the State address today.

title: Successor Chosen At Bell & Howell
description: The Bell & Howell Company said yesterday that Gerald E. Schultz, executive vice president and chief financial officer, had been named president and chief operating officer and would succeed Donald N. Frey as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Frey retires in 1988.

title: GAF STOCK SLUMPS ON CARBIDE DOUBTS
description: Shares of the GAF Corporation plunged $4, to $51.25, in heavy trading yesterday as Wall Street professionals grew increasingly uncertain that the roofing and chemicals producer would pursue its hostile $5 billion takeover battle for the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: New York State And City Bonds
description: New York State, its major authorities and New York City expect to sell about $1.63 billion of bonds in the first three months of the year. Interest on these bonds, as well as those issued by other local governments in New York State and Puerto Rico are exempt from state, city and Federal income tax for New York State residents.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS LEAST IMMIGRATION SINCE '48 AMID WORRY FOR FUTURE
description: Immigration to Israel last year fell to its lowest point since the country was founded in 1948, according to Government statistics issued today.

title: DR. LOUIS PYENSON
description: Dr. Louis Pyenson, an entomologist and plant pathologist, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Los Angeles Clippers have signed Wallace Bryant, waived earlier in the season by the Dallas Mavericks, to a 10-day contract. The 7-foot, 245-pound center, will replace Derrek Smith, a high-scoring guard, who underwent arthroscopic surgery in his left knee earlier in the season.

title: U.P.S.-Pratt Deal
description: United Parcel Service Inc. has agreed to pay $400 million for 90 Pratt & Whitney PW2000 jet engines to power up to 35 cargo planes that U.P.S. plans to buy, the engine maker said. The engines, the first new series developed by Pratt & Whitney in more than a decade, will be used to power 20 Boeing 757's that U.P.S. has ordered and 15 additional aircraft on which the carrier has options. The engines - installed and spares - will be delivered over a six-year period beginning in 1987, according to Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Hormel Strikers Protest Plan to Reopen Plant
description: Striking meatpackers demonstrated outside the plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Co. today after company officials said they would reopen next Monday despite a five-month strike.

title: REDUCTION OF PESTICIDES NETS INCREASE IN BIRD POPULATIONS
description: FIVE of North America's rarest birds of prey have made dramatic recoveries over the last 14 years, mainly because of the reduction of DDT and other persistent pesticides in the environment, according to ornithologists at Cornell University. Their analysis of data from the Audubon Society's annual Christmas bird surveys found that populations of the bald eagle, prairie falcon, northern goshawk, merlin and gyrfalcon have all soared.

title: Yugoslav Panel Proposes Croat as Prime Minister
description: Branko Mikulic, a hard-liner known for his opposition to Western ideas and criticism of internal dissidents, has been officially proposed as the next Yugoslav Prime Minister, the official press agency said today.

title: Dow Drops 1.61 in Slower Trading
description: The stock market stumbled through another dull session of slightly lower prices yesterday as all those investors who were supposed to return after a long New Year's break apparently did not show up.

title: AMERICAN CYTOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TOXIC-ACCIDENT PARALLELS
description: The fatal chemical accident at a uranium-processing plant in Oklahoma this weekend shared at least eight factors with the accidents at Bhopal, India, and Institute, W.Va. The potential problems that could result from those conditions have been widely known, and experts consider most of the solutions relatively cheap and easy.

title: U.S. AND HANOI EXPRESS SATISFACTION AFTER TALKS
description: Two days of high-level talks between the United States and Vietnam on the issue of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War ended today with both sides expressing satisfaction with negotiations but calling for quicker progress on unresolved cases.

title: Edwin Snyder, Ex-Chairman Of Jersey's Largest Utility, 84
description: Edwin H. Synder, retired chairman of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, died Sunday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: JUDGE SETS DONOVAN TRIAL FOR FEB. 18
description: A Bronx judge yesterday set Feb. 18 for jury selection and the start of the trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, State Senator Joseph L. Galiber and eight other men on state charges of larceny and fraud.

title: EASTERN'S LABOR TALKS FACE GROWING PRESSURE
description: Eastern Airlines will have to reach agreements with its three major unions by the end of February on large permanent cuts in wages and changes in work rules in order to meet requirements set by lenders to keep the carrier out of default.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENT BY KOCH TO CITY BOARD, COUNCIL AND STATE PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from the statement by Mayor Koch to the Board of Estimate, the City Council and the Financial Control Board that accompanied his plan for the next four fiscal years:

title: EASY-TO-USE MACRO PROGRAM ELIMINATES KEYBOARD TEDIUM
description: ONE of the best enemies of tedium in computing, yet one that a lot of users seem slow in adopting, is called the macro. Perhaps it is the name. Macros sound like something from the arcane science of economics. But actually, using them is as simple as opening a can.

title: Malta Opens Hearing In Airliner Hijacking
description: Magistrates started hearing evidence today in the hijacking and storming of an Egyptair jetliner in November, the first step in bringing to trial the man accused of being the only surviving hijacker.

title: Bridge: Berkowitzes and Lilies Win Betty Kaplan Teams Event
description: A new event in the calendar of the Greater New York Bridge Association was played Sunday at the Loeb Student Center at New York University. Called the Betty Kaplan Teams, in memory of a leading bridge player who died recently, the event was pronounced a success by all concerned.

title: 2 Law Firms In a Merger
description: Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the Cleveland-based law firm, said yesterday that it had merged with Surrey & Morse, a smaller firm based in New York. The law firm said the combination would make Jones, Day the nation's second-largest law firm, with a staff of about 570 lawyers, behind only Baker & McKenzie of Chicago.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Henry Field, Anthropologist Who Aided Presidents, Dies
description: Henry Field, the anthropologist who served as a Presidential adviser to Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman and was credited with finding the oldest existing wheel, died Saturday at Coral Gables Hospital after suffering sudden respiratory arrest. He was 83 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A FIRST Feet are the stars of the first Joyce Theater Dance Festival, opening tonight. Eight dance companies will perform over 12 days, presenting various aspects of the art form: modern and jazz, dramatic narrative theater and cool abstraction. Tonight at 7:30 the Hannah Kahn company will offer three new works -''Array,'' ''Accompany'' and ''Punctuation.'' The other companies, in order of appearance, are the Kenneth Rinker Dance Company, the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company, Sounds in Motion, the Bill Cratty Dance Theater, the Clive Thompson Dance Company, Ohad Naharin and Dancers, and the Peggy Lyman Dance Company.

title: Roll 'em, Forsooth
description: Among the things that Jack Benny, Laurence Olivier, Basil Rathbone, Boris Karloff and Mickey Rooney had in common is that they all appeared in movies based on or alluding to Shakespeare plays. To show just how films have dealt with Shakespeare over the years, the Library of Congress is putting on ''Acting It Many Ways: Shakespeare on Film and Television,'' free of charge in its Mary Pickford Theater from tomorrow through March 31. There will be a Hamlet Week, a Macbeth Week, A Lancastrian Tetralogy Week and, on the final night, a chance to watch ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' in which Mr. Rooney, then a small boy, plays Puck and gets to say, ''Lords, what fools these mortals be!''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Arvin Industries , Columbus, Ind., has named Joe T. Atkins president of its North American Automotive division, and David N. Lewis president of its Aftermarket Products division.

title: STATE TAKEOVER OF LILCO URGED BY REPUBLICANS
description: A takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company by New York State was urged today by the Republicans who control the State Senate.

title: Hebrew Bible of 1400's To Be Put on Display
description: A 15th-century Hebrew Bible, the oldest recorded Hebrew manuscript written and dated in Prague, will go on display Sunday for the first time in this country as part of a Yeshiva University Museum exhibition, ''Ashkenaz, World of German Jewry.''

title: Advertising; Marketer Looking at Magazines
description: THE Marketing Corporation of America, which has its fingers in a multitude of pies, is now going to thumb through magazines with an eye toward a buy.

title: BLAZE IN JERSEY KILLS 3 CHILDREN AND TEEN-AGER
description: Three young children and a 15-year-old boy were killed early this morning when a fire roared through their home, the police said.

title: Couple Is Found Murdered In Southampton Apartment
description: A young couple were found stabbed to death this morning in the bathtub of their apartment over a popular tavern here.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a producer's change of plans, a music listing in The Guide on Sunday gave an incorrect date and title for two concerts of works by Gary William Friedman. Under the title ''The Him Nobody Knows,'' the first program will take place Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Micronesia Compact Extends U.S. Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp Plans to Offer Floating Rate Regularly
description: Citicorp announced yesterday the start of a new borrowing program where it will continuously offer floating-rate, medium-term notes in the domestic market with maturities ranging from nine months to 15 years.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
TUTU, IN NEW YORK, CALLS FOR ECONOMIC SANCTIONS
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu yesterday thanked Americans who have protested against apartheid, but chastised those who have not supported the imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: EVERYONE'S A HERO
description: Religious institutions have not yet taken note, but there's no denying that there was a miracle over the weekend. It stretched from coast to coast and was witnessed by multitudes.

title: GIANTS ARE SAD, BUT NOT SORRY
description: In a way, this was the saddest day of the pro football season for the Giants. This was the day they cleaned out their lockers for another year, the day they went home and reflected on what might have been.

title: CITY'S DIRECTOR OF PERSONNEL RESIGNS
description: The director of the City Personnel Department, Juan U. Ortiz, resigned yesterday in a three-sentence letter to Mayor Koch.

title: Time Bomb Found at Boston Garden
description: Bomb squad officers found a time bomb in a trash barrel at Boston Garden today, hours before a scheduled exhibition game between the Boston Bruins and a Soviet hockey team, the police said.

title: FOR ADOLFO'S COLLECTION, A GATHERING OF THE CLAN
description: Long pleated crepe culottes, multicolored tiered chiffon capelets and big taffeta skirts are some of the fashion delicacies Adolfo has cooked up for spring and summer evenings. His audience yesterday greeted each of these styles with appreciative applause, indicating that they certainly will be important sweetening agents at dinners and parties ahead.

title: RESEARCHERS ADVANCE IN EFFORTS TO BREED COLD-RESISTANT PLANTS
description: SCIENTISTS are edging closer to the gardener's dream of June in January and tomatoes in the snow.

title: Three on Oil Rig Feared Dead
description: Two men were killed Sunday when a helicopter dropping them at an oil derrick flipped over in high winds, the authorities said. A third crew member was missing 30 miles offshore in the Gulf of Mexico and presumed dead. Five other people were injured.

title: Politics; The Name Is Kennedy, the Talk Is of Congress
description: One hour into a discussion of voluntarism, government and the nobility of a life in public service, many passionate young Democrats would have summoned the memory of the Kennedys, Robert and John, to add resonance to their words and historical sweep to their aspirations.

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect 50 percent stock dividends paid in June and December 1985.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Sales for the latest and year-ago 9 months periods exclude sales of discontinued operations of Cirus World Toy Stores and Heaven Variety Stores.

title: Not Pretty Sight
description: Coach Tom Watt assesses the Vancouver Canucks' 4-0 loss to Winnipeg: ''We ran around like pregnant foxes in a forest fire.''

title: No Competititon
description: The managers of the Dade County Bridal Show seemingly knew what they were doing when they scheduled their exposition of wedding attire for Jan. 19, on the weekend between the conference championship games and the Super Bowl. ''Brides,'' exclaimed an adverisement in The Miami Herald, ''bring the guys! The only Sunday with no televised football!''

title: Bonner Will Undergo Heart Bypass Surgery
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident, will undergo a heart bypass operation in the near future because medication has failed to improve her heart ailment, her family and doctors said today Her son-in-law, Efrem Yankelevich, said the operation would probably take place sometime after this week.

title: COYOTE STAGING A COMEBACK ON RANCHES OF TEXAS
description: Long after ranchers thought they had driven off the coyote, the predator is staging a comeback.

title: NAVY MOVES FOR COMPETITION ON TRIDENT CONTRACTS
description: The Navy has taken what officials call a first step toward ending General Dynamics's position as the only manufacturer of the Trident nuclear missile submarine. It has offered a competing shipyard a contract to inspect and repair a Trident.

title: 20,000 STRIKING SOUTH AFRICAN MINERS ARE DISMISSED
description: A leading South African mining company announced today that it had dismissed 20,000 workers at a platinum mine after they refused to call off a strike.

title: 2 BILLS TO SPEED WASTE CLEANUP PASSED IN JERSEY
description: The State Assembly gave final passage today to two bills designed to help engineers and contractors working on toxic-waste cleanup projects obtain liability insurance.

title: COLUMBUS CIRCLE AREA GETTING NEW LIFE
description: Values are rising sharply in the business district at the edge of Columbus Circle, an area that some real estate professionals believe was long undervalued. The cause for the change is an unprecedented wave of commercial and residential development.

title: KOCH'S FISCAL PLAN PROPOSES INCREASE IN SOME CITY TAXES
description: Mayor Koch formally began his campaign to get more money for New York City yesterday with the release of an austere preliminary spending plan for the coming fiscal year that provides for no improvements in city services, no new programs and some tax increases.

title: KASPAROV REFUSES TO ACT ON REMATCH
description: The new world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, is causing a furor once again, this time over his rejection of a rematch with Anatoly Karpov that is to start Feb. 10.

title: DR. S. EUGENE SCALIA
description: Dr. S. Eugene Scalia, a retired prolyn College, died Saturday at the Mercer Medical Center in Trenton.

title: SMITHSONIAN AGREES TO PURCHASE 'LEGENDARY' COLLECTION OF PERSIAN ART
description: The Smithsonian Institution has agreed to purchase for $7 million what has been described as one of the finest collections of Persian art ever assembled - a collection whose very existence was a mystery for decades but that actually sat undisturbed in packing crates in New York for 40 years.

title: Intergroup Shares
description: National Intergroup Inc. said it had repurchased 6.9 percent of its common stock, including 75 percent of the shares held by the Leucadia National Corporation, which last summer had made a bid for Intergroup.

title: STUDIES BOLSTER LINK OF FOOD AND MIGRAINES
description: NEW research is lending credence to a long debated idea that food allergies may cause migraines in a majority rather than a minority of people who have the headaches.

title: Bicycle Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: ADMINISTRATION AIDES SEE TAX RISES
description: Senior Administration officials predict that President Reagan will be forced to accept tax increases later this year to meet the requirements of the new balanced-budget law.

title: MANY TOURISTS REVAMPING PLANS IN FEAR OF TERRORISM, EXPERTS SAY
description: In little more than six months, terrorist attacks on travelers have shaken the volatile travel industry and altered patterns of international tourism, according to industry and government representatives.

title: Larouche Must Wait
description: Craig Patrick, the general manager of the Rangers, said yesterday he was no more inclined than he was before to recall Pierre Larouche from the minor leagues even after Larouche asked to be traded from the organization earlier this week. Larouche was the Rangers' leading scorer the season before last, and the Rangers, one of the lowest-scoring teams in the National Hockey League, desperately need a scorer. ''Pierre feels frustrated he's in the minor leagues,'' Patrick said yesterday. ''But he hasn't gone down and blown the American League out of the water. He has 34 points, but the leading scorer has 63. We sent Mike Allison down and he scored 7 points in 5 games. We need Pierre at a 50-goal pace because he does have other liabilities.'' Larouche, playing for Hershey, has 20 goals in 27 games, which would translate into a pace of 60 goals for an 80-game season. The center, who scored 48 goals for the Rangers in the 1983-84 season but dropped off to 24 last season, was demoted just before the start of the season. Last Sunday, his agent, Rob Ingraham, formally passed on Larouche's request for a trade. Patrick granted permission for Ingraham to ask other teams whether there was any interest in Larouche. . . Tony Feltrin, the Rangers' minor league defenseman who suffered a serious injury to his left eye while playing on New Year's Eve for New Haven of the American Hockey League, will undergo his second operation in Halifax, Nova Scotia, today.

title: Ex-Hartford Legislator Says He Will Run Against O'Neill
description: Former State Senator Romeo G. Petroni declared his candidacy for governor today, and said that Gov. William A. O'Neill had shown a ''lack of leadership.''

title: STOCKS HIT HIGHS AS RATES DIP
description: Aided again by declining interest rates, the stock market yesterday scored its best single-day gain in nearly a month as indicators on all the major exchanges surged to record levels.

title: Storer Chief Set to Retire
description: Peter Storer, chairman and chief executive of Storer Communications Inc., the Miami-based broadcasting company, announced his retirement yesterday. Mr. Storer, who is 56 years old, will be succeeded by Terry Lee, the president and chief operating officer.

title: Now That Contadora Is Dead
description: Having won Congress's grudging consent for ''humanitarian'' aid to the proxy army fighting against Nicaragua, the Reagan Administration now wants to rescind the ban on sending weapons. The case for that is revealingly urged by Elliot Abrams, the State Department's chief for hemisphere affairs. If Congress doesn't authorize greater support, he asserts, there are ''only'' two other courses: ''You can use American military force, which is the last thing we wish to do, or you can surrender, which is, I would think, unacceptable.''

title: Scream
description: A local group is organizing a petition drive to give District of Columbia voters an opportunity to declare their city a ''draft registration free zone,'' in which young men who refuse to register could live without fear of Federal prosecution, although it is highly unlikely the Government would honor such a declaration. The protest group, Scream, hopes to get such a proposition on the local ballot in November, which would require about 14,000 signatures, its leaders say.

title: Name That Majority
description: According to a popular bumper sticker, ''The Moral Majority Is Neither.'' Neither, anymore, is it merely the Moral Majority. The Rev. Jerry Falwell, its founder and guiding light, announced last week that it had created a new political umbrella group, the Liberty Federation.

title: COUNCIL IS SPLIT OVER CHOOSING MAJORITY CHIEF
description: Two warring factions on the New York City Council both proclaimed victory yesterday as they prepared to select a new Council majority leader today - the first new majority leader in 16 years.

title: Topics; Listening In; Notes on the Run
description: The off-blond girl played drums. An aging black man in a blue beret was dwarfed by his trombone. A fellow in steel-rimmed glasses who might be a rabbinical student slapped a bass.

title: Schering-Hutton
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said it had withdrawn a lawsuit that charged E. F. Hutton & Company with using insider information in buying up to 2.5 million Schering shares while working for Schering in an investment banking capacity. Termination of the suit, filed Dec. 6, came a day after Wall Street sources said Hutton had sold a block of 950,700 Schering shares on the open market.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SOUTHERN COOKS LOOK BACK TO ROOTS AND ADAPT CUISINE
description: As the scent of biscuits, country ham, fresh greens and candied yams rose over the region during this holiday season, the South's strongest biracial tradition, cooking, grew older and newer by a year.

title: Sri Lanka Landslides Kill 21
description: Landslides caused by heavy rains have killed at least 21 people in Sri Lanka's tea-growing central highlands, officials said today. The slides followed three days of torrential rain. The worst landslide occurred in a small village in the Nuwara Eliya district where 14 bodies were dug out by rescuers, officials said.

title: The Unknowing Host
description: An invitation arrived for dinner next Tuesday at the Executive Mansion in Albany to discuss Governor Cuomo's budget before he submits it to the Legislature the next day.

title: END OF GAF CARBIDE BID SEEN
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday appeared to be on the verge of dropping its increasingly expensive battle to take over the Union Carbide Corporation, Wall Street professionals said.

title: Unionist Sees Danger In F.A.A. Budget Cuts
description: The president of a union of electronics technicians said Monday that $135 million in exoected budget cuts for the Federal Aviation Administration could lead to ''deaths of passengers and aircraft crews.''

title: BUILDING SIZE AFFECTS WATER METER COST
description: The cost of installing water meters varies according to both the size of the building and the number of water lines involved.

title: CUSTODY BATTLE ENDS IN DEATH FOR PARENTS IN IDAHO
description: A four-year custody battle for 6-year-old Jeffery Hayden has ended in the shooting death of both his adoptive parents.

title: Tradition Is Broken For Veteran Reporter
description: President Reagan, breaking tradition, invited a 75-year-old reporter just out of the hospital to ask the first question at his news conference tonight.

title: Musical by U.S. Troupe Sells Out in Moscow
description: Residents of Moscow are enchanted by the first visitor in the new United States-Soviet cultural exchange program -a singing-and-dancing personification of Raggedy Ann, the rag doll beloved by generations of American children.

title: KOCH BUDGET: A FIRST ROUND
description: The situation is nothing if not confusing.

title: Slowing Down
description: Mary Decker Slaney, expecting her first child in early June, plans to continue training ''up to the end,'' all the better, she believes, to have her running again in middle-distance competition as early as August.

title: 3 EDITORS PROMOTED AT TIMES
description: Promotions of three editors at The New York Times were announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor.

title: DEFENSE TO CONTINUE IN PRESCHOOL ABUSE CASE
description: The judge hearing charges of extensive child abuse at a preschool facility here changed her mind today and reopened the defense's case.

title: Bridge: Of Yearning for the Sea Life And a Bridge-Playing
description: Boys who nourish an ambition to run away to the sea nearly always adopt a different profession, and some of them become bridge players.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene, a Second Avenue bus in the upper 30's, heading downtown. Among the passengers, Merv Goldstein and two men - in their mid-20's, stylishly dressed, each carrying a book - whose conversation he overhears. First man: What's that you're reading? Second man: ''Don't Fall Off the Mountain.'' You know, the Shirley MacLaine book where she tells about her experiences in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan. Sounds like a fantastic place. I'd love to go there. What are you reading? First man: It's a biography of Peter the Great. Second man: Boy, if I had the time, would I love to go to Leningrad.

title: HAIM BERNSTEIN
description: Haim Bernstein, chairman of the board of the Regis Brokerage Company, died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan Saturday. He was 61 years old.

title: Cracow Philharmonic Plans New York Debut
description: The Cracow Philharmonic, under the direction of the composer-conductor Krzysztof Penderecki, will make its New York debut with concerts on Jan. 18 and 25 at Carnegie Hall. Yo-Yo Ma will be the soloist the first night, playing Mr. Penderecki's Cello Concerto No. 2.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has elected to its board Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Co. and JWT Group Inc.

title: Ann Sten Is Wed To John Heimann
description: Ann Marie Sten, a fashion representative in New York, was married Dec. 31 to John G. Heimann, vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption on Jan. 1 about a year-end celebration at the New York Stock Exchange misstated the market's 1985 performance.

title: New Kodak Items
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it will introduce new cameras, a new color film and new photofinishing products at a press conference on Jan. 21. Kodak said the new products represent ''the heart and soul of our business'' and should ''maintain and enhance Kodak's position'' in photography.'' The company noted that it had previously said it would market about 50 new products in 1986.

title: Indebted Mexico Staggers On
description: Ronald Reagan's meeting last week with Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico could have been a significant turning point in United States-Mexican relations. It wasn't, largely because neither President was willing to squarely face the key issue: Mexico's $96 billion foreign debt and its increasing inability to meet interest payments on it.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Dec. 26 about Frank Lloyd Wright memorabilia incompletely described a Wright associate to whom a house by the architect was shipped after being dismantled. He was David T. Henken, a mechanical engineer, designer and builder who died last April. Mr. Henken founded Usonia, a cooperative residential community in Westchester County for which Wright designed the site and several houses.

title: Cheese Steaks (Cont.)
description: Those errant cheese-steak sandwiches, the payoff Mayor Koch sent Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago as a result of their bet on the Bears-Giant game last Sunday, are still untasted.

title: Gambino Judge Fears Funeral Denial Impact
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he was concerned about the possible impact on jurors hearing an organized-crime case by the decision of John Cardinal O'Connor to deny a public funeral mass for Paul Castellano, reputed head of the Gambino crime family.

title: Buyout Raised For Gypsum
description: The National Gypsum Company said today that its independent directors had approved a revised plan for a management-led investor group to take the company private through a leveraged buyout valued in excess of $1 billion.

title: Ha-Ha With Hart
description: Now that Senator Gary Hart plans to retire from the Senate at the end of this year, many Colorado Democrats expect Representative Timothy E. Wirth to give up his House seat and seek the party's Senate nomination. If that comes to pass, the departing Senator predicted the other day, ''the Senate will be Hart-less and the House will be Wirth-less.''

title: PRESIDENT BREAKS ALL ECONOMIC TIES WITH THE LIBYANS
description: President Reagan, saying Libya constitutes ''a threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States,'' announced plans tonight to sever virtually all American economic ties to Libya.

title: DeBusschere: The Last Shot
description: When her husband was playing for the Knicks, Gerri DeBusschere said, ''Dave always said he'd take the last shot. He figured he could take the heat.''

title: LIBYA TRADE WAS LOW BEFORE BAN
description: New restrictions on business with Libya announced last night by President Reagan are expected to have little economic impact on either country.

title: FOR PENNZOIL, A SURGING STOCK BUT NO DEAL
description: In a bizarre twist to one of the most complex battles in corporate history, Pennzoil shares soared yesterday when a rumor swept Wall Street that the company had received an attractive takeover bid from Texaco. The reported offer was a tactic by Texaco to avoid paying a multibillion-dollar damage award to Pennzoil.

title: BOLD PLAY (A LA GORBACHEV) MAKES AUDIENCE GASP
description: The big hit at the Moscow Art Theater this season is a play called ''The Silver Anniversary,'' and it deals with corruption, morality and renewal in the ruling elite. Staged by the theater's director, Oleg N. Yefremov, and studded with his top stars, the play is about the return of a high official to the provincial town where he started his political career. There he learns that two local proteges of his were responsible for the prosecution and imprisonment of a journalist who had dug too deeply into their doings.

title: Twice Bitten by the Parking Bureau's Bytes
description: To the Editor:

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:58 A.M. today and set at 8:36 P.M. tonight.

title: TV Reception a Mess? Blame the Russians
description: Ever since the Soviet Union began using its new embassy compound on Mount Alto, just about the highest point in Washington, there has been no end of complaint from American intelligence agencies. But to some residents of Glover Park, the neighborhood just across the street, the latest development makes the longstanding national security concerns seem trivial.

title: Giants Can Use Help, but It's Not Critical
description: Now that one Giant season is over, another is beginning. After a few days of rest and recreation, the coaches and personnel people will start turning their attention to what the team needs to improve next year.

title: AMERICANS BARRED FROM SEEING MANDELA
description: The South African authorities refused permission today for a visiting United States Congressional delegation to visit Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned black nationalist who is viewed by many blacks as their leader.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT has always struck me as odd that in this country, many foods that are eaten raw are seldom thought of as something to toss into a saucepan or skillet. These foods would include cucumbers and various kinds of salad greens, including those crisp, snow-white, tinged-with-yellow leaves of Belgian endive. On rare occasions, you will find braised endive served golden brown and piping hot with a braised veal chop, for example, but that seems to be the limit for the American palate.

title: THINGS OF LUXURY TO HAVE AND WEAR
IN THE TRENCHES OF A WAR AGAINST DRUGS
description: The yellow cab is no longer effective as an undercover vehicle, which is one of the ways that Lieut. John Sullivan measures the success of Operation Pressure Point, the Police Department campaign to sweep drug dealers and their customers from the streets of the Lower East Side.

title: Free Our Presidents From Re-election Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Ken Schrom and Bryan Oelkers, pitchers, to Cleveland for Roy Smith and Ramon Romero, pitchers.

title: Sears Speeds Debut Of Discover Card
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would begin marketing its Discover card nationwide on Jan. 23 and that the start-up costs of distributing the card would result in an after-tax loss of $115 million this year.

title: Lay the 'Tribal Unrest' At Pretoria's Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Plane Crash at Mall Claims a Sixth Life
description: A sixth person died today of injuries suffered when a plane crashed into a mall filled with Christmas shoppers, and commercial jet service to the area was postponed pending a review of safety issues.

title: ATHLETIC FAVORITISM AN ISSUE IN TRIAL
description: Arguments began in Federal court here today in a lawsuit that accuses University of Georgia officials of showing favored treatment to athletes enrolled in a remedial academic program.

title: GIBSON SET TO REJECT TIGERS
description: Kirk Gibson is prepared to ''walk away'' from $3.9 million and the Detroit Tigers, his agent said yesterday, by not signing with them by the deadline at midnight tonight. Butch Wynegar and Joe Niekro are among seven other free agents who face similar decisions with their previous clubs. The status of Wynegar's sputtering negotiations with the Yankees did not change yesterday, and Niekro's agent said he was less optimistic about the pitcher's chances of re-signing with the Yankees.

title: LESSONS FROM THE SCHOOL OF UNFAMILIAR FISH
description: WHILE halibut, haddock and sole continue to be all-time favorites with American fish eaters, and shrimp - at around two pounds per person per year - is the most popular seafood of all, many unusual and unfamiliar species are appearing on our markets that can add variety and interest to fish dishes.

title: NETS RELY ON RESERVES IN STOPPING BULLS
description: The words sounded immodest, but Mickey Johnson spoke them with sincerity. And every word had some truth to it.

title: VIDEO-CASSETTE CONCERN TO MAKE FEATURE FILMS
description: Vestron Inc., a producer and distributor of prerecorded video cassettes in the United States, announced yesterday that it would expand its home-video operations to include production of feature films for theatrical release.

title: REAGAN INSISTS BUDGET CUTS ARE WAY TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan insisted tonight that the Federal budget deficit could be reduced through spending cuts and continued economic growth, but he was careful not to rule out the possibility of a tax increase eventually.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. When the Bucks visited the Meadowlands in early November, they lost by 126-123 to the Nets, who committed 22 turnovers in the second half. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:15 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) College Basketball Televised Games: Georgetown vs. Connecticut, at the Capital Centre, Landover, Md., 8 P.M. (Television -USA, 8 P.M.) Wake Forest at Georgia Tech, 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Texas at Arkansas, 10 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M.) Other Games: Fairfield vs. Syracuse, at New Haven Coliseum, 8 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:05 P.M.) Gannon at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M. C. W. Post at New York Tech, 7:30 P.M. Rochester at Merchant Marine, 7:45 P.M. Rider at Kansas, 7:30 P.M. St. Peter's at Xavier (Ohio), 8:05 P.M. Rutgers at West Virginia, 8 P.M. Women: Fairfield vs. New Hampshire, at New Haven Coliseum, 5:30 P.M. New York Tech at Adelphi, 5:30 P.M. Hockey Devils vs. Black Hawks, at Chicago, 8:35 P.M. The Devils have lost 11 of their last 12 games, 8 in a row. (Television - MSG, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Dwight Muhammad Qawi vs. Ric Enis, at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, Atlantic City, 10 rounds, junior heavyweights. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Qawi, formerly known as Dwight Braxton, once held the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title. This nontitle bout will be Qawi's first since capturing the World Boxing Association junior-heavyweight crown.

title: Spend a Buck Wins Award
description: Spend a Buck, D. Wayne Lukas and the Breeders' Cup were the biggest winners today with the announcement of the Eclipse Awards for achievement in thoroughbred racing last year.

title: Perfect Pitchers Wait
description: Don Larsen, Jim Bunning and Catfish Hunter, all of whom pitched perfect games, are among 41 hopefuls on the ballot for election to baseball's Hall of Fame today. Bunning, the only pitcher to win 100 games in both the American and National leagues, pitched a perfect game for Philadelphia against the Mets on Father's Day in 1964.

title: Lilco Reaches Accord On Refinancing Debt
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement with 42 banks to refinance $1 billion of its debt.

title: War-nography
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the poet, and other Russians decry a wave of recent American movies as crude Soviet-bashing propaganda, even ''war-nography.'' They have in mind movies like ''Rocky IV,'' in which Sylvester Stallone, the prizefight champion, travels to the Soviet Union to battle a huge, merciless boxing machine named Ivan Drago.

title: Forbes Deal For Heritage
description: Forbes Inc., which publishes Forbes, the biweekly business magazine, has agreed to buy American Heritage magazine from a group of investors headed by Samuel P. Reed.

title: Dana Storrs Lamb, 86, Broker and Sportsman
description: Dana Storrs Lamb, an investment broker and sports fisherman who wrote extensively on nature and fishing, died after a long illness Monday at Beverly Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 86 years old and lived in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Duffer's Dream Finally Over
description: It was back in 1977 that a company named Polara Enterprises came up with an aerodynamically new golf ball that seemed to be the duffer's dream. Because of the asymmetrical arrangment of dimples on the Polara, slices and hooks tended to straighten out in flight and make it back to the fairway.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE REAL LIFE OF ALEJANDRO MAYTA. By Mario Vargas Llosa.

title: Charles Lee Morris, 42, Dies; Ex-Publisher Victim of AIDS
description: Charles Lee Morris, believed to be one of the longest-living victims of AIDS, died Monday at his home here. He was 42 years old.

title: NEW CITY PERSONNEL CHIEF IS NAMED
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named Judith A. Levitt, a top lawyer for the city, to replace Juan U. Ortiz as director of the City Personnel Department.

title: New Man in Cairo
description: President Reagan is preparing to nominate Frank G. Wisner, a career Foreign Service officer, to succeed Nicholas Veliotes as Ambassador to Egypt. Mr. Veliotes, who clashed with Egyptian officials over the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship last October, has resigned from the State Department after 31 years for a position in private industry, State Department officials said yesterday.

title: Manila Military Officers Seek an Honest Election
description: A group of military officers opened a campaign today for honest elections, saying they feared civil strife if the voting on Feb. 7 was dishonest. They also said they would support Corazon C. Aquino if she defeated President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DREXEL'S DRIVE TO WIDEN BASE
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., investment banker to the nation's most feared corporate raiders, is being squeezed.

title: SAFETY VIOLATIONS AT NUCLEAR PLANT WERE CITED BY U.S. IN '85 REPORT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said last September that compliance with safety regulations was ''marginal'' at a Sequoyah Fuels Corporation plant in Oklahoma and expressed concern over the potential for the type of accident that occurred there Saturday, killing one worker and sending dozens to the hospital.

title: On the Trail of Halley's Comet
description: The United States Naval Observatory normally goes unnoticed while tending to its job of keeping ships from getting lost and helping Americans know what time it is.

title: Braille Banking Machine
description: Some of the most mundane conveniences - street signs, banking machines, building directories, elevators and menus - have become standard fixtures of modern life. But not for the blind, who, for the most part, are not served by them.

title: WHITE HOUSE GETS WEINBERGER STUDY ON ARMS RESPONSE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has recommended a number of actions that would conflict with the unratified strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979, Government officials said today.

title: EGYPTIAN WHO SHOT 7 IS DEAD
description: An Egyptian border policeman convicted of killing seven Israelis near a beach resort in Sinai was found hanged today in a military prison hospital, apparently a suicide.

title: Such a Marvy Idea
description: Darlings, the privatizing going on in Washington is just too much. You haven't heard of privatizing? That's this fantastically with-it idea the Reagan circle has for getting the Government out of government. Isn't that too marvy?

title: The Heritage Hoist
description: The Heritage Foundation, despite its fierce dedication to free enterprise, does not ordinarily include free plugs for commercial products in its newsletter. In its 1985 year-end edition, however, ''Heritage Today'' describes how young people gather at the foundation every two weeks ''to talk, debate, exchange phone numbers and enjoy a chilled Coors beer and some cheese and crackers.'' Which should not surprise those who remember that the Heritage Foundation was founded in 1973 with a $260,000 grant from Joseph Coors, the Colorado brewer.

title: SEATTLE JARRED BY VIOLENCE TO A FAMILY
description: As a prominent lawyer and his son lie unconscious in a hospital, people throughout Seattle are confused and angry over a brutal Christmas Eve attack that also killed the lawyer's wife and their other son.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REAGAN HAILS BLOCK TENURE
description: John R. Block, the nation's chief farm policy administrator through five of the most turbulent years in the history of American agriculture, announced today that he was resigning as Secretary of Agriculture.

title: HANSON CLAIMS 66% OF SCM
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C. claimed victory yesterday in its fight to gain control of the SCM Corporation. One day after a Federal court struck down a ''lockup'' agreement that SCM was using to defend itself, Hanson said it had acquired two-thirds of SCM's shares and would soon call a stockholders' meeting to take control of SCM's board.

title: Doctor Sentenced to Death
description: Dr. John Dale Cavaness has been sentenced to death in the gas chamber for murdering his son to collect $148,000 in insurance.

title: USTINOV IN 'DEAD MAN'S FOLLY' ON CBS
description: PETER USTINOV, who would seem to have enough to keep him busy as a director, playwright, screenwriter and novelist, not to mention actor, has embarked upon still another presumably lucrative occupation, playing Hercule Poirot. Mr. Ustinov was first seen as Agatha Christie's Belgian detective in the films ''Death on the Nile'' and ''Evil Under the Sun.'' Then he brought the portrayal to television, earlier this season in ''Thirteen at Dinner'' and now, tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS, in ''Dead Man's Folly.'' Coming up soon will be ''Murder in Three Acts.'' The results so far have been spotty, and no more so than in this evening's labored romp.

title: Sea-Land Letter
description: The board of the Sea-Land Corporation said in a letter to Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor seeking to take control of the company for $25 a share, that it had ended agreements requiring certain lenders to accelerate debt repayments if anyone acquired more than 35 percent of Sea-Land's stock. Sea-Land noted that on Dec. 10 it had adopted a shareowners' rights plan for protection from a hostile takeover and at the same time reconsidered the provisions in its long-term debt agreements. Mr. Simmons now owns 34.8 percent of the company's stock.

title: EXECUTIVE ORDER FOR SANCTIONS AGAINST LIBYA
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Executive Order issued today prohibiting trade with Libya:

title: OPERA: PAVAROTTI IN A GALA
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI sang familiar music in his familiar fashion Monday at Avery Fisher Hall, with nine American colleagues on hand to lend variety in a series of operatic ensembles. The show was called ''Pavarotti Plus,'' though some of the guests are too accomplished to be treated as mere ''pluses'' on a Pavarotti show -and though the choice of selections left some of them subtracting more than they added. But the program was designed to focus on the famous tenor, who gave a fully representative account of himself, prized virtues and frustrating flaws alike.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL REVUE, 'COTTON CLUB-GALA'
description: ''COTTON CLUB-GALA'' is Ellen Stewart's congenial homage to the Harlem nightclub that for decades celebrated such talented performers as Lena Horne and Duke Ellington. For the occasion, La Mama Annex has been transformed from its customary setting as a home for the theatrical avant-garde. Tuxedoed waiters lead guests to tables from which they watch the evening's festivities, featuring singers, dancers and a chorus line of spangled ladies called Les Soubrettes.

title: YANKS AND METS FAVORED
description: The Yankees and the Mets, along with the World Series champion Kansas City Royals and the National League champion St. Louis Cardinals, were among seven teams listed Monday as 4-1 selections to win pennants and 7-1 to win the World Series this year.

title: Fixit Shop
description: Gary Danielson, quarterback for the Cleveland Browns, expresses optimism over his chances of a comeback from shoulder surgery: ''I don't have that far to come back. I can only throw 30 or 40 yards anyway. It's not like they're repairing a Porsche -more like a Volkswagen.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLETHORA OF PIANOS There are museums in New York devoted solely to firefighting, military material, ethnic groups and different schools of art, and it makes sense that we also have one that specializes in the piano, that workhorse of concert hall, theater and supper club. The Museum of the American Piano is a modest affair at 211 West 58th Street (246-4646), but it is a place where anyone whose forte is pianos will want to browse.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Market Place; Viacom-JMB Uncertainty
description: THIS is the week that Viacom International's biggest shareholder could become even bigger. And Wall Street, hungry for another potentially lucrative takeover play in the entertainment industry, seems to be cheering on a Chicago realty syndicator that, to the surprise of almost everyone, has taken a major stake in Viacom.

title: PENTAGON OFFICIALS URGE END TO SERVICES' CHEAP CIGARETTES
description: The senior Pentagon officials in charge of manpower and health affairs have urged Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to end the sale of cut-rate cigarettes in military commissaries and exchanges as a health measure, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Advertising; Contest Stiffens for Merrill Job
description: THE recently formed Bozell Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, a subsidiary of Lorimar, has resigned the Prudential-Bache business in order to compete for the far larger account of Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Free Our Presidents From Re-election Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-SOVIET COUPLES: THE EMOTIONAL COST CONTINUES TO SURPRISE
description: SINCE the recent Geneva summit meeting of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, each week brings another chapter in the stories of about 30 American-born citizens who have been separated for years from their Soviet-born spouses. The eight Russians who were told on the eve of the summit meeting that they would receive permission to join their American husbands and wives are arriving in this country even now. The others wait, hoping to be reunited.

title: DANCE: HANNAH KAHN AT THE JOYCE
description: THE Joyce Sampler, a festival featuring eight dance groups, got underway last night with a performance by the Hannah Kahn Dance Company at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue. Hannah Kahn's choreography celebrated the pleasures of coming and going. Meetings were joyous occasions, and if partings occasionally were sorrows, they were sure to be sweet sorrows.

title: Economic Scene; Automation's Labor Impact
description: THE new automation technology, using computers, robots and artificial intelligence, has reawakened fears that machines will replace human beings and create mass unemployment. Do those fears make any more sense today than they did at the dawn of the Industrial Revolution when the Luddites, textile workers, smashed the machinery they thought would put them out of work?

title: Free Our Presidents From Re-election Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBBERS' VICTIM FACES A GUN CHARGE
description: A Brooklyn subway token clerk who shot a man who was trying to rob him, according to the police, was charged yesterday with carrying an unlicensed gun.

title: HIGH-TECH WAY TO WINE BY THE GLASS
description: The popularity of wines sold by the glass has spawned more than just a bevy of wine bars and boutiques. It has made Cruvinets and other wine-preserving systems the darlings of the wine dispensing industry. Big, bold and glossy, the machines are increasingly becoming the impressive - and expensive - centerpieces of wine bars and watering holes, ringing up handsome profits for both the people who make them and the people who buy them.

title: O'Connor Planning A Visit to Lebanon
description: John Cardinal O'Connor plans to visit Lebanon later this month at the invitation of Christian leaders there, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said last night.

title: Dr. Benjamin Beck, 73, Dies; Ex-Nassau Medical Examiner
description: Dr. Benjamin Beck, a former deputy and senior medical examiner of Nassau County, died Sunday at his home in Westbury, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: NEW SURVEILLANCE ON LIBYANS IN U.S.
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said today that they had tightened their surveillance of Libyan nationals in the United States after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi threatened to place ''suicide'' teams on American streets.

title: Eastern Strike Date Delayed
description: The union representing 7,200 Eastern Airlines flight attendants has revised its mid-January strike deadline to coincide with a Feb. 28 default deadline set by the airline's creditors, a spokesman said today.

title: ST. JOHN'S LOSES IN OVERTIME
