description: St. John's, whose freewheeling style of play has made it one of the Big East's most exciting teams this season, met its match in Boston College tonight. The Eagles, unleashing relentless fullcourt pressure on defense and a rib-rocking inside game on offense, forced the Redmen into their third overtime in as many games.

title: WHY REAGAN SHUNS ATTACK
description: For the third time since taking office five years ago, President Reagan has examined the possibility of a military strike against Libya and again chosen to limit actions to diplomatic and economic measures.

title: FOREIGN ROLE IN U.S. POLITICS QUESTIONED
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today that he would conduct hearings on the political influence wielded by foreign investors in the United States and seek to close legal ''loopholes'' that he said allowed such influence to grow.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE only thing more satisfying than being right is knowing that the experts are wrong. Truman taking Dewey, Boris Becker taking Wimbledon, that sort of thing. Wine drinkers are having a chuckle or two these days over the outcome of the 1985 vintage. Six months ago, the proper facial expression for any savants worth their tasting cups was a frown. Across Europe, killer frosts had decimated the vineyards during the winter and spring.

title: Occidental to Tap Existing Credit
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that it would use existing credit agreements to finance its proposed $1.6 billion merger with the Midcon Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Occidental disclosed that it has $1 billion available from a December 1984 agreement with a group of 78 domestic and foreign lending institutions, $300 million available from a January 1985 credit agreement with a group of 21 foreign and domestic banks, and $450 million available from a December 1985 agreement with a group of 23 foreign lending institutions.

title: DISTANT BAD WEATHER DELAYS SPACE SHUTTLE LIFTOFF
description: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia was postponed again today, this time because of bad weather at emergency landing sites in Europe and Africa. Frustrated space officials said they would try again Thursday.

title: Controls Needed on Chemical-Plant Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; Listening In; Fuzz Buster
description: Tom Alexander's career as an Oregon marijuana farmer ended in arrest six years ago. Rather than let his accumulated expertise go to waste, he decided to get into the legal business of helping other growers nurture their illicit crops.

title: PLAN TO CLOSE NUCLEAR PANEL'S SESSIONS IS ASSAILED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has decided to close more of its meetings to the public, and the policy came under renewed attack today by Representative Edward J. Markey, the agency's leading critic in Congress.

title: PROPOSAL FOR A PUBLIC TAKEOVER OF LILCO RAISING MANY COMPLICATED ISSUES
description: The Republican majority in the New York State Senate joined this week with the Democrats who control the Assembly to support a state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Hunting Season
description: Nineteen eighty-five is history, and Jerry Koosman says good riddance: 84 days on the disabled list in Philadelphia last summer, and an earned- run average of 4.62. On top of that, there was the first Jerry Koosman World Series Elk Hunt, organized for the recreation of major league players, which was staged near Gunnison, Colo., several weeks ago.

title: Biotech Concern Names Marketer to a Top Post
description: In the last five years Biotechnical International Inc. has developed microorganisms that render toxic wastes harmless and improve the yield of soybean and alfalfa crops. Most recently, the company invented substances that help identify gum disease.

title: BOSTON RESTAURANT INSPIRES DEVOTION DESPITE ITS SETTING
description: It would be hard to conceive of a less propitious setting for an elegant restaurant. The exterior of the building is drab gray brick, suggesting an old factory. Around the corner is the Combat Zone, an infamous strip of adult bookstores and bars. The restaurant's location, on the edge of the finanicial district in a maze of old twisting streets, makes it almost impossible for drivers to find.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1986
description: International Virtually all U.S.-Libya ties would be severed under plans announced by President Reagan, who said the Libyan Government constituted ''a threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States.'' Mr. Reagan ordered the remaining 1,000 to 1,500 Americans in Libya to leave at once or face ''appropriate penalties'' upon their return home. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: FIGHT OVER JUDGE ENTERS NEW ARENA
description: As the General Assembly's 1986 session began this evening, legislative leaders predicted long hearings on a resolution to impeach the Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court.

title: Bid Improved For Westland
description: A European consortium of aerospace companies today improved the terms of its rescue package for Britain's financially troubled helicopter maker, Westland P.L.C.

title: White Supremacist Gets Life for Killing Trooper
description: A member of the white supremacist group the Order has been sentenced to life in prison for killing a state trooper.

title: Free Our Presidents From Re-election Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Alvin Hampel Gives Seminars
description: Alvin Hampel, the last chairman of D'Arcy McManus Masius/New York before the agency's merger with Benton & Bowles, has established Hampel Creative expressly to teach marketing geniuses about the facts of advertising.

title: Advertising; Martin Landey Buys Chalk, Nissan, Hanft
description: Martin Landey, 56-year-old founder and for many years chairman of Martin Landey, Arlow Advertising, is back in the business, having purchased Chalk, Nissan, Hanft.

title: STATE-PRIVATE EFFORT SET IN HOUSING FOR HOMELESS
description: The Cuomo administration plans to build emergency housing for homeless families under a cooperative effort between government and the private sector, government officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law -Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ART FOUNDATION TO GET $80 MILLION FROM ESTATE
description: The Lannan Foundation announced yesterday that it would receive between $80 million and $90 million from the estate of its founder, J. Patrick Lannan, a businessman and art collector, and would spend about $4 million a year on contemporary art acquisitions and exhibitions.

title: REAGAN AIDE, CITING PROBLEMS FROM ACID RAIN, URGES U.S. ACTION
description: President Reagan's special representative on acid rain, Drew Lewis, will report to the White House Wednesday that acid rain is causing serious economic and social problems in the United States and must be addressed immediately, Canadian and American officials said today.

title: 4 WHITES CHARGED IN A RACIAL FIRE
description: Four young white men surrendered to the authorities today, accused of setting a fire last month at a house in a predominantly white area that was vacated by a black family after protests by neighbors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1986
description: Companies

title: Calling All Couples
description: Honeymooners are being offered a special rate of $76 a night for Friday and Saturday nights by the Capital Hilton Hotel this year, according to a New Year's announcement. It turns out that couples who are not recently married can have the same weekend rate, but their package is slightly different. Honeymooners get a room plus a basket of fresh fruit and a bottle of champagne; all others get the fruit but still wine instead of champagne and a pair of passes for sparetime sightseeing.

title: John Mandanici Dies; Ex-Mayor of Bridgeport
description: John C. Mandanici, Mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., from 1975 to 1981, died of a circulatory disorder yesterday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport. He was 68 years old and lived in Bridgeport.

title: HINTS OF 5TH FORCE IN UNIVERSE CHALLENGE GALILEO'S FINDINGS
description: A new analysis of early 20th-century experiments has produced results challenging both the findings of Galileo that all falling bodies accelerate at the same rate and a fundamental element of Einstein's general theory of relativity.

title: IRANIAN DEALER OWNS ART TAKEN IN QUEENS THEFT
description: An Iranian antiquities dealer in London said yesterday that he was the owner of 105 works of Middle Eastern art, valued at $18 million, that were taken Sunday from a customs warehouse in Queens.

title: Kasparov Can Decide On Match Up to Jan. 27
description: Because of a ''misunderstanding'' of the rules, Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, has another three weeks to decide whether he will play a rematch with Anatoly Karpov, an International Chess Federation official said today.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN ON 3D-PERIOD GOAL
description: The Islanders claim they know what they need to do to escape their midseason malaise. What they need, for the confidence especially of the younger players without the benefit of four championship seasons, is to win a few games in a row. The trouble is, the Islanders no longer seem to know how to win.

title: THE STAGE: 'BE HAPPY FOR ME,' A NEW COMEDY
description: THE biggest surprise in ''Doubles,'' the recently departed Jewish male menopause comedy, occurred when the actor Austin Pendleton appeared without his pants. Mr. Pendleton is just not an actor one ever expected to find nude on stage. In ''Be Happy for Me,'' the new Jewish male menopause comedy at the Douglas Fairbanks, an equally unlikely candidate for self-exposure rears his undraped backside - Philip Bosco. Wasn't it only yesterday that we were watching this distinguished actor in ''Heartbreak House''?

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Elway, the Denver Broncos' starting quarterback, underwent minor arthroscopic surgery on his left knee to ''clean out the knee'' of any floating particles. He had similar surgery on the same knee last year after suffering a sprain. . . . Paul Mokeski, the backup center for the Milwaukee Bucks, will be out for at least five weeks because of torn cartilage in his right knee.

title: STANDARDS ARE DEBATED FOR CEMETERIES FOR PETS
description: When a pet is laid to rest in a shady plot in a pet cemetery, his owners should not return a few years later and find a tangle of weeds or a fast-food restaurant. That is what the International Pet Cemetery Association is trying to prevent, now that more and more Americans are choosing to bury pets in cemeteries.

title: SWEDISH TEAPOT, DANISH SHAKERS
description: TEA connoisseurs would never think of brewing their favorite beverage from chopped-up leaves enclosed in a gauze bag. The proper way with tea, of course, is to infuse the leaves in boiling water until it reaches the desired strength. One problem with brewing tea in a conventional ceramic teapot - at least for the infrequent tea drinker - is knowing precisely when to remove the leaves.

title: Fighter in Comeback
description: A former World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, Matthew Saad Muhammad, announced he was ending his three-year retirement and would attempt a comeback at age 30.

title: Some Culinary History
description: The reception following Mayor Koch's inauguration last week, as reported, included a cake and a beverage from the menus for the inaugural celebrations of two earlier New York City or State officials, Mayor Jacobus Van Cortlandt in 1710 and Gov. DeWitt Clinton in 1803.

title: WATER METER USE IN ALL DWELLINGS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Owners of all the city's residential buildings - from single-family homes to large apartment buildings - would have to install water meters in the next 10 years under a conservation program proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: A BONANZA IN PENNZOIL: STOCK AND OPTIONS SOAR
description: The feasting yesterday by Wall Street pros on the trading in Pennzoil stock will be long remembered - but perhaps not so long as the beating they could take today.

title: 50 YEARS OF BEING AT HOME ON THE RADIO
description: Among other issues of the day, ice-palace construction, Albert Einstein's cat, T. S. Eliot plays and -most importantly - the whereabouts of Mrs. Woo were discussed yesterday on Pegeen Fitzgerald's daily radio program.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Civilized nations cannot continue to tolerate, in the name of material gain and self-interest, the murder of innocents.

title: FED SEEN AS RECEPTIVE TO 'JUNK BOND' STUDY
description: The Federal Reserve, preparing to take final action that would restrict the use of so-called junk bonds in financing corporate takeovers, showed signs today that it was open to a counterproposal from Wall Street that would set up a high-level commission to study the excessive use of borrowed funds in such takeovers.

title: When Public Hospitals Aiding the Indigent Don't Have to Report
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS END THEIR SLUMP
description: When the subject is classic matchups in pro basketball, the heated Celtics-76ers games come immediately to mind. So do the playoff meetings between the Celtics and Lakers. Now, there's also the Knicks and the Pacers. But for very different reasons.

title: Golf's '85 Winners Open 1986 Season
description: The PGA Tour will have a more appropriate start than in past years when the 34th annual MONY Tournament of Champions begins Wednesday at La Costa Country Club with a field of 31, the winners of 1985 tour events and the four major championships.

title: Lessons of the Alger Hiss Case
description: What are the lessons of the Hiss case?

title: Mine Cave-in Kills One
description: A man spending his first day on the job as a coal miner was killed today in a cave-in, a state police spokesman said. The victim was identified as Clayton Knorr, 21 years old, of Gordon.

title: Harvester's New Name
description: The International Harvester Company, the nation's leading producer of heavy-duty trucks, officially confirmed today that it would change its name to the Navistar International Corporation.

title: 2 Die After 2 U.S. Jets Collide in Germany
description: Two United States Air Force F-15 fighters collided in midair today and crashed near the French border, killing a pilot and a civilian and injuring at least five other people, the police said.

title: CUTS ARE EXPECTED
description: President Reagan has decided to ask Congress for a $311 billion military budget for the next fiscal year, including a 4 percent pay increase for the troops, Administration officials said today.

title: Internal Revenue Service; The Don't-Do-It-Yourself Tax Guide
description: While President Reagan seeks tax simplification, the Internal Revenue Service is apparently convinced that taxes are just too complicated for the average citizen.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: YOUR back has been bothering you for days, but tonight it hurts much more than ever before. You've already had aspirin, a hot bath and a shot of brandy, but after three pain-filled hours in bed, you're still awake and the pain, if anything, seems worse. Should you: A. Get yourself to the nearest hospital emergency room?

title: COMPANY BANNED PROCEDURE IN LEAK
description: Kerr-McGee Corporation rules forbid a procedure that employees were using to remove a uranium compound from an overfilled container when it ruptured Saturday, killing one worker and injuring several others, a company spokesman said today.

title: NEW POSTAL SERVICE CHIEF SEEN AS SERVING FOR INTERIM PERIOD
description: The new Postmaster General, Albert V. Casey, will serve only for an interim period, the chairman of the Postal Board of Governors suggested today. He said there would be ''a continuing executive search'' for a permanent successor to Paul N. Carlin, who was replaced Monday.

title: TREASURY BOND PRICES GAIN
description: The Treasury bond market yesterday shrugged off the lethargy of the past week as signs of good investor demand led to price gains of nearly 1 1/2 points for long-term issues.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: REAGAN GIVES 9-STEP PLAN TO END ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Proclaiming that the United States has lived with the problem of organized crime ''far too long,'' President Reagan has called for a national effort to eradicate its ''extensive influence in American society.''

title: PEPPER SHORTAGE WORSE
description: Production of pepper is not keeping up with demand, creating a ''potentially explosive situation'' that could raise its price on world markets, a commodity brokerage reported today.

title: WORLD OF POP-FANTASY BECKONS TO GRACE JONES
description: IN pop music, major stardom is increasingly a matter of creating and sustaining an exotic cartoonlike character. Madonna, Michael Jackson, Prince, Cyndi Lauper, Boy George and Tina Turner are pop icons whose comic-book self-presentation may have as much to do with their popularity as their musical talent. In 1986, Grace Jones, the Jamaican-born fashion model-turned-pop singer, seems likely to join them in the pop-fantasy firmament. She has cultivated a public persona that has titillated movie audiences in ''Conan the Destroyer'' and ''A View to a Kill,'' while developing a vocal personality that is ominously compelling.

title: K.G.B. FIGURE CALLED A SPY FOR FRANCE
description: A K.G.B. officer working in Moscow told French intelligence officials of purported Soviet plans to steal Western technological secrets, according to a book to be published this month.

title: Faces From the Subways Of Four Cities
description: You come out of your train at the IND station at the Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street, walk up the steps and, bang, you are facing subway riders again.

title: Eaton Is Promoting President to Chief
description: The Eaton Corporation, a large manufacturer of advanced-technology products, announced yesterday that after its annual meeting on April 23 James R. Stover would be elected to succeed E. M. de Windt, the company's longtime chairman and chief executive.

title: DIRECTOR OF BROIDA MUSEUM RESIGNS
description: Joan Simon, director of the still-unopened Broida Museum for contemporary art, has resigned. Her move follows the decision of the SoHo museum's founder, Edward R. Broida, to cancel a two-year exhibition program that she had developed.

title: Mercy Slaying Brings Probation in California
description: A man who pleaded guilty to giving his terminally ill uncle a fatal drug overdose has been sentenced to probation and fined $100 in a case the judge described as ''a true mercy killing.''

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND HELPING IMMIGRANTS SHARE GOOD FORTUNE
description: Many immigrants to the United States who wish to share the happiness and good fortune they found in their new homeland are among the contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: CHRYSLER OFFERS NEW INCENTIVES
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced a new sales incentive program today that lowers the financing rate offered on selected models and has an expiration date that coincides with the end of other companies' incentive programs.

title: GERHARD WEISS
description: Gerhard Weiss, a leading member of the East German Government, died today after a serious illness, the press agency ADN reported.

title: FOR MANY, MUSIC CAREERS ASK TOO MUCH
description: RHONDA BENNETT began taking piano lessons when she was 5 years old and felt destined for the concert stage soon thereafter. ''I became a pianist because Rhonda was going to be a pianist,'' she said. ''I would be concertizing; it was just a given.''

title: Xerox Products
description: The Xerox Corporation plans to announce several office automation products Wednesday, including a communications network for personal computers based on American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Starlan technology, industry consultants said. The announcements are the first in a series of office-product introductions Xerox is expected to make over the next few months.

title: 4 Afghans Reported Held For Warning Rebels
description: Western diplomats said today that the Afghan authorities had arrested at least four army generals for warning Moslem rebels about the movement of Soviet troops and that Soviet commanders were tightening control on information.

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yearly results have been restated for the merger with Security Bank and Trust Co., which was consummated on June 1, 1985, and accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: Money With Brunch
description: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, is a man who enjoys going to a party but finds there are risks in being sociable.

title: Minority of One Picks Leader, Unanimously
description: The Republican minority of the City Council unanimously picked a new leader yesterday by a vote of 1 to 0.

title: OLD-HOME-WEEK ATMOSPHERE OPENS NEW SEASON IN ALBANY
description: Lobbyists, legislators, legislative interns and aides blanketed this snow-packed city this week, huddling in restaurants or pumping palms at cocktail parties, talking of little else but today's State of the State Address and the new political season it opened.

title: MCCOVEY ELECTED TO HALL OF FAME
description: Willie McCovey was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame last night in his first appearance on the ballot, but he was the only one of the 41 candidates who made it. And in yet another dramatic close call one year after Nelson Fox missed by 2 votes, Billy Williams missed by 4.

title: JERSET ACTS TO CURB TOXIC ACCIDENTS
description: Governor Kean today signed into law a bill - the first in the nation - requiring chemical plants to have plans for preventing the accidental release of toxic chemicals.

title: SKIING MARATHONS GAIN IN POPULARITY
description: Cross-country ski marathons have long been popular in Europe, often attracting as many as 15,000 entrants. In the past few years, such marathons have been growing in size and number at cross-country centers in eastern North America.

title: CONCERT: 'BLUEBEARD'S CASTLE'
description: BELA BARTOK'S ''Bluebeard's Castle'' (1911) is one of the great 20th-century operas, a brooding, metaphorically evocative study of man's subconscious mind and the love-hate relationship between the sexes that summoned forth some of the composer's most gorgeous inspirations. For all its static nature, it's a work that cries out to be staged. Pina Bausch created one of her most powerful pieces, ''Bluebeard,'' around a fragmented recording of this opera. And one looks forward with real eagerness to the Metropolitan Opera's triple bill three years hence, with Peter Sellars as stage director, which will consist of this opera and another masterly modernist psychological drama, Schoenberg's ''Erwartung,'' and a work yet to be chosen.

title: 'A Human Duty'
description: ''The huge sufferings of the peoples in Europe in this century have proved that it is a human duty not to accept repression. So as long as it lies within my power, I will contest this act of political persecution.''

title: COMMUTER AIRCRAFT DIVES WILDLY AS PASSENGER ATTACKS PILOT TWICE
description: A twin-engine commuter aircraft went into a steep dive twice yesterday morning when a passenger attacked the pilot, who had directed him to put out a cigarette shortly after takeoff from Atlantic City, officials said.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a DISC tax credit of $64,000.

title: F.D.A. SETS RULES ON ARTIFICAL HEART IMPLANTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that experiments to implant permanent artificial hearts could continue in up to three more patients, but only with case-by-case Government approval.

title: U.S.-China Trade Up
description: Trade between the United States and China in 1985 rose to at least $7.5 billion from 1984's $6.1 billion, according to American economists. Forecasters at the United States Embassy here projected a total of $7.5 billion, while the National Council of U.S.-China Trade in New York estimated $7.7 billion.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $115,000.

title: INTEREST RATES IN A SHARP ADVANCE
description: Treasury bond yields rose sharply yesterday, after the December employment data showed that the economy is entering the new year on a firm footing, and does not need any extra stimulus from an easier Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: Frank Miller, 73, Dies; A Leading U.S. Cellist
description: Frank Miller, a leading cellist with American orchestras and a conductor, composer and teacher, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Skokie, Ill. He was 73 years old.

title: WILLIAM A. HUNT
description: William A. Hunt, professor emeritus of psychology at Loyola University, died Friday at his home in Evanston, Ill.

title: Bridge: Team Had Little Incentive From Tournament Prizes
description: The strength of one's desire to win a particular prize varies widely, from a probable maximum in a state lottery to a near-minimum in a bridge event.

title: CANADIAN DEFENDS ACID RAIN REPORT
description: Canada's special envoy on acid rain, William Davis, defended a report on airborne pollutants, released today, that was drawn up with his American counterpart, saying it was the best that he could achieve for now with the Reagan Administration.

title: CONFIDENT VOICE FROM QUEENS; Peter Fortunate Vallone
description: Peter F. Vallone, the new majority leader of the City Council, promises an independent future for the city's long-complacent legislature.

title: BASES TAKE STEPS AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Military bases around the United States have been seeking ways to prevent terrorist attacks since the bombing in Beirut that killed 241 American servicemen in October 1983.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,289,000, or 24 cents a share. Figures have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid May 21, 1985.

title: Advertising; L.I. Cheese Marketer To Waring & LaRosa
description: Waring & LaRosa, a BBDO International subsidiary, has picked up the account of N. Dorman & Company, Syosset, L.I., marketer of cheese -domestic and imported, processed and natural, bulk and retail, sliced and chunk.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Burlington Northern Railroad Co., Fort Worth, said John H. Hertog and Donald E. Engle would retire as senior vice presidents on Feb. 1.

title: Whither Chavez?
description: Linda Chavez, the highest-ranking woman in the White House, not counting Nancy Reagan, is to decide by the end of next month whether she will enter the contest for the Senate seat from Maryland to be vacated by Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a Republican.

title: KOHLBERG SEEKS TO PAY LESS CASH FOR BEATRICE
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which has agreed to buy the Beatrice Companies for $6.2 billion, has proposed modifying the terms of the acquisition so that it would pay less cash, Beatrice announced today.

title: RUSSIAN SET FOR PHILHARMONIC DEBUT
description: When Yuri Temirkanov steps onto the podium of Avery Fisher Hall tonight, he will be making his debut conducting the New York Philharmonic. But he will also be picking up where he left off - as a noted conductor with an international career that includes the United States.

title: CALENDAR: A FAMILY'S HISTORY
description: The Doughty Archive, Queens Historical Society, 143-35 37th Avenue, Flushing, 718-939-0647.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Beneficial Corp. is offering $125 million of 8 1/2 percent notes due Jan. 15, 1989, at a price of 99.55 to yield 8.674 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The notes, rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P., were priced to yield 46-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

title: Ads Have First Amendment Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Direct Names Top Executives
description: Jerome W. Pickholz, 53, president and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, has moved up to chairman, making room for William Morrissey, the 41-year-old general manager, to become president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. MAY SEEK CURB ON MIRANDA RULE
description: The Justice Department is actively investigating ways to blunt the effects of the Supreme Court's 1966 Miranda decision requiring the police to inform criminal suspects of their constitutional rights before questioning, or to overturn it, department officials say.

title: PATENT CASE PLEA LOST BY KODAK
description: The Eastman Kodak Company lost its battle yesterday to remain in the instant photography business.

title: A GUILTY PLEA IN $9 MILLION TAX FRAUD
description: A Manhattan man pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of income tax fraud in a scheme to create bogus tax shelters through master recordings by some major popular musicians.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bacharach Inc.'s vice president and general manager, Paul M. Zito, said he had signed a letter of intent to buy the company from United Technologies Automotive, a subsidiary of United Technologies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Groovy Wins in Florida
description: Groovy, who set the pace and tired badly in four of the biggest races for 2-year-olds last year, benefited from a sloppy track, a shorter distance and some weak opposition today to win the $46,320 Spectacular Bid Stakes at Gulfstream Park. It was opening day at the track.

title: Books of The Times
description: In what amounts to the prologue of Iris Murdoch's new novel, ''The Good Apprentice,'' young Edward Baltram, a college student living in a London bed-sitter, tricks his friend, Mark Wilsden, into taking a psychedelic drug, something Mark would never knowingly do. The resulting ''trip'' is a good one; Mark, in ecstasy, envisions the world as ''one . . . big . . . fish,'' sees God descending ''like a lift,'' and falls happily asleep. So Edward feels free to heed the sexual summons of a young woman he has recently met. But when he returns to Mark, he finds the room empty, the window open, and Mark's smashed body lying on the pavement below. <TD WIDTH=2

title: COMPUTERS EXPAND WEAVERS' ABILITIES
description: THE computer, which might seem alien to textile designers, is, in fact, becoming a useful tool to them. Quilters, weavers and tapestry makers are finding it valuable because it handles some repetitive processes, freeing them for conception and execution.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Dec. 18 about a kitchen fire at the Cafe des Artistes misidentified the painter of the restaurant's murals. He was Howard Chandler Christy.

title: C.D. Yields Decline
description: Average yields for six-month certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Arbitragers Cited in Decline
description: The stock market did not fall off of a cliff yesterday, it was pushed.

title: Not Accuracy, But Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Mud Pies
description: ''Dining Out?'' reads the top line of a sign that covers most of the side of a four-story building on a busy street in downtown Brooklyn.

title: JOINT U.S.-CANADA REPORT ON ACID RAIN IS DELIVERED
description: President Reagan's special representative on acid rain, Drew Lewis, today transmitted to the White House a report that he said stessed ''we don't need to research it to death'' before acting to reduce acid rain.

title: Hancock Confirmed For Court of Appeals
description: Justice Stewart F. Hancock Jr. of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court was confirmed today by the State Senate as an associate judge on the New York Court of Appeals.

title: LOAN SALES TO INVESTORS EXPECTED IN BUDGET
description: President Reagan's 1987 budget is likely to propose that private investors be sold a slice of the $245 billion portfolio of Government loans, according to Administration officials.

title: Moderated Stance
description: North Korean officials have repeated their demand that North Korea join South Korea as co-host of the 1988 Summer Olympic Games, but this time the officials seem to be moderating their stance. Olympic officials who met with delegations from North and South Korea in Lausanne, Switzerland, said that Kim Yu Sun, the president of the North Korean Olympic Committee, had not repeated previous threats of a Soviet-bloc boycott if North Korea's demands were not met.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: Mattel Toys to Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising, Los Angeles, for two new product lines to be introduced next year.

title: VALVE PROBLEM PUTS OFF SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING ONE MORE TIME
description: The shuttle Columbia and its crew were delayed again today when problems with a rocket fuel control valve forced the space agency to cancel the launching set for Thursday morning. It was the fifth postponement of this flight.

title: SMALL TRADES FUELED RISE IN PENNZOIL
description: A trade-by-trade analysis of Tuesday's activity in the stock of the Pennzoil Company shows that a large number of modest-sized individual trades fueled the stock's explosive rise of more than 30 percent.

title: MURPHY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $248,533.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split distributed Aug. 30, 1985.

title: 600 AT FUNERAL OF TOXIC GAS VICTIM
description: More than 600 people gathered with bowed heads today at the Vian High School auditorium to mourn their neighbor, James N. Harrison, the only man to die in an industrial accident Saturday that released a cloud of toxic gas from the Kerr-McGee Corporation's nearby uranium processing plant.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Burma Reports Rebels Killed 46 on Ferry
description: Gunmen from an indigenous ethnic group known as Karens attacked a Government-owned passenger ferry in southern Burma last Thursday, killing 46 passengers and wounding 136 others, the official Burmese press agency reported today.

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,580,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $704,000 for the quarter and $2,517,000 for the year. d-After a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $7,125,000, which includes a gain of $6,551,000 on the sale of Lamination Technology Inc.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Drug Use Is Different From Drug Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Leafs 11, Oilers 9
description: Miroslav Frycer scored four goals and Russ Courtnall and Steve Thomas each had two tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs outscored the Edmonton Oilers, 11-9.

title: DEFENSE PRESSES MOB-TRIAL WITNESS
description: Defense lawyers yesterday attacked the character and the credibility of a key witness who admitted watching a murder shortly before he became a Mafia member in Sicily.

title: TEXT OF THE STATE DEPARTMENT REPORT IN LIBYA UNDER QADDAFI
description: Following is the text of a State Department report on Libya issued today:

title: WHEN THE DESIGN SOLUTION IS A COMPACT ALL-IN-ONE UNIT
description: IS it bigger than a breadbox?

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $20 million for the quarter and 9 months related to an asset redeployment plan.

title: VOYAGER SPACECRAFT DISCOVERS SIXTH MOON ORBITING URANUS
description: The Voyager 2 spacecraft, speeding toward Uranus, has discovered another moon orbiting the giant planet, the sixth to be identified, space agency scientists announced yesterday.

title: Man in Israel Spy Case Is Chosen for New Post
description: The Israeli Ministry of Industry and Trade announced today that it was nominating Raphael Eitan for the position of chairman of the board of Israel Chemicals.

title: Human Rights Appointee
description: Catherine Abate, the Greenwich Village Democratic leader, has been appointed executive deputy commissioner of the State Division of Human Rights.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling-of-interests merger with Maine National Corp.

title: General Dynamics Delays on Cessna
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, citing its suspension last month from the award of future Government contracts, said it had indefinitely postponed a merger plan with the Cessna Aircraft Company.

title: Fetuses Grow Up
description: To the Editor:

title: HAITIAN DEMONSTRATORS CHALLENGE DUVALIER AGAIN
description: Anti-Government protests, a rare event in this Caribbean dictatorship, erupted here for two days this week, and today the authorities declared that security forces had been instructed to ''rigorously put down all illegal action.''

title: Market Place; Analysts View Railway Group
description: SEVERAL major railroad stocks, after lagging behind a surging equity market in the final quarter of 1985, have been selling recently at or near record prices.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOOD APPRENTICE. By Iris Murdoch. 522 pages. Viking. $18.95. IN what amounts to the prologue of Iris Murdoch's new novel, ''The Good Apprentice,'' young Edward Baltram, a college student living in a London bed-sitter, tricks his friend, Mark Wilsden, into taking a psychedelic drug, something Mark would never knowingly do. The resulting ''trip'' is a good one; Mark, in ecstasy, envisions the world as ''one . . . big . . . fish,'' sees God descending ''like a lift,'' and falls happily asleep. So Edward feels free to heed the sexual summons of a young woman he has recently met. But when he returns to Mark, he finds the room empty, the window open, and Mark's smashed body lying on the pavement below.

title: REAGAN DISPUTED BY REP. BROOKS ON POLYGRAPH DIRECTIVE'S MEANING
description: The chairman of the House Government Operations Committee today sharply disputed President Reagan's description of a national security directive he signed authorizing the increased use of polygraph, or lie-detector, tests for Federal employees.

title: Michigan Wins at Buzzer
description: A reserve forward, Robert Henderson, made a 16-foot jump shot at the buzzer to thwart a furious comeback as No. 2-ranked Michigan edged Illinois, 61-59, in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 9, 1986
description: International

title: Top Energy Regulator Resigns Federal Post
description: Raymond J. O'Connor, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the natural gas, electric utility and oil pipeline industries, said yesterday that he intended to resign at the end of the month, citing personal and family reasons.

title: GAMBINO JUDGE DENIES MISTRIAL DEFENSE SOUGHT
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied defense motions for a mistrial in the car-theft and murder-conspiracy trial of nine co-defendants of Paul Castellano, the reputed chief of the Gambino crime family who was slain last month.

title: WOMEN'S LEAGUE HIRES MAN
description: The League of Women Voters has hired a man to be executive director for the first time since it was founded in 1920.

title: Real Estate Trust Set to Offer Stock
description: Paine Webber Residential Realty Inc., a real estate investment trust, announced plans for an initial public offering of 5 million shares, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: MIAMI POLICE SCANDAL RAISING QUESTIONS ON MINORITY RECRUITS
description: A stream of witnesses took the stand in Circuit Court here today and attested to the honor and character of the six young men who sat silently at a courtroom table before them.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUSTICE DEPT. ASKS FOR RULING IN A NEW SUIT ON BUDGET LAW
description: The Reagan Administration sought today to clear the way for a Federal District Court to rule on the constitutionality of a new budget-balancing law.

title: BISHOP TUTU HAILS DEMONSTRATORS NEAR SOUTH AFRICAN EMBASSY
description: Half a block from the South African Embassy, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu today addressed a crowd of cheering, chanting demonstrators opposing that country's policy of strict racial separation, telling them that their support was a ''wonderful boost'' to the ''victims of apartheid.''

title: Terror Is the Most Effective Weapon of Nicaragua's 'Contras'
description: To the Editor:

title: ICAHN'S LARGE TASK AT T.W.A.
description: Times are grim at Trans World Airlines.

title: AFTER '72 MISHAP, U.S. TOLD PLANT TO SET EMERGENCY PLAN
description: For more than a decade, since a 1972 accident that injured one employee, Federal officials have been asking the Sequoyah Fuels Corporation to devise an evacuation plan for chemical and nuclear accidents, according to Government and company documents, officials and residents here.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $7,225. c-After a tax credit of $306,650.

title: SENATORS TO WEIGH LIMIT ON CLAIMS TO STOLEN ART
description: A Senate subcommittee is to consider a bill today that would limit, in some cases to as little as two years, the period in which foreign countries could sue museums and private art collectors in the United States for the return of stolen art.

title: BARRAGAN'S ELOQUENT ARCHITECTURE
description: The Mexicans are a people who live behind walls. Whether it is the home of a wealthy family worried about kidnappings or the humble home of a street vendor, the Mexican house is turned inward, focused on the family and its life there. The wall - high, windowless and foreboding - hides and protects.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 'CAGE,' BY ROBBINS
description: ONCE seen, ''The Cage'' tends not to be forgotten. Jerome Robbins's depiction of life in a covey of female insects is gruesome. These are females who consider males of the species their prey, and two males are killed with brutal dispatch during the ballet, with Stravinsky's String Concerto in D somberly accompanying the murders.

title: Juan Rulfo, a Novelist and Short Story Writer
description: Juan Rulfo, a Mexican novelist who was one of the creators of the ''magic realism'' school of Latin American writing that influenced Gabriel Garcia Marquez and other authors, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: LEGISLATIVE 'GOLD'
description: Time and again in his State of the State Message today, Governor Cuomo used phrases like ''I shall again propose,'' ''I will once more ask,'' ''I will again pursue.''

title: Officials Say Sawhill Will Lead Lilco Panel
description: John C. Sawhill, a former Federal Deputy Secretary of Energy, is Governor Cuomo's choice to head a citizens' commission studying a possible state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, administration officials said today.

title: Chief of St. Joe Minerals Named Fluor President
description: The Fluor Corporation, the huge but troubled engineering and construction company, announced yesterday that John A. Wright, an executive vice president and the chairman of the St. Joe Minerals subsidiary, has been named president and chief operating officer of the corporation.

title: Filling In the Gaps in Shakespeare's Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Workers Stay on Job As Contract Talks Go On
description: About 46,500 members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union continued working today under an extension of contracts with the nation's oil and gas industry.

title: On the Science Front
description: John P. McTague, deputy director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, has been promoted to acting director of the office and acting White House science adviser. He replaces George A. Keyworth 2d, who left the two posts Dec. 31 to start a consulting concern in the capital.

title: ERVING AT GUARD HELPS 76ERS
description: On Dec. 1, the Philadelphia 76ers, who had enjoyed a .720 winning percentage over all for the previous five seasons, the second best in the National Basketball Association, had a 6-8 record and were off to their worst start since the 1974-75 season.

title: MEETING THE CHALLENGE OF REPAIRING BAMBOO
description: Once the peculiarities are understood, anyone able to cope with straightforward furniture repairs should be capable of fixing broken or rickety bamboo. In fact, it often takes more time and patience trying to locate outside help than to tackle the job yourself. That's probably why bamboo furniture has been known to creak, groan and wobble its way through generations of owners. Many pieces have stood up extraordinarily well even when overburdened.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RATES FOR NEW YORK ARE STEADY
description: Unemployment rates for New York remained stable in December, ending a year of substantial job growth in the the state and the city, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Burial Held for Boy Who Left His Heart to Ailing Girlfriend
description: Relatives sobbed and linked arms today around the open coffin of a 15-year-old boy whose gift of his heart to his ailing girlfriend was hailed by a minister as proof that ''all of us have the power to give.''

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FROM GANDHI TO PARTY AT 100: A TONGUE-LASHING
description: Those searching for a symbol of the problems facing Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's governing Congress Party did not have to look far here the other day. Just as a speaker at the party's 100th anniversary celebration urged a ''quantum leap into the 21st century'' the microphone went dead.

title: TEEN-AGERS, DRUGS AND DRINK ON NBC'S 'WASTED!'
description: JUST when you thought video was fun to watch, but had no redeeming social value, along comes ''Wasted!'' to change your mind. The half-hour program, on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight, combines music, words and images -video - to talk about teen-agers, drugs and alcohol. It's a terrific piece of work, giving family viewing a new meaning.

title: Advertising; Magazine's Appeal Is to Walkers
description: NORMAN RABEN, whose Raben Publishing Company in Boston acquired two magazines in two years, is now generating its own title for the first time. In the same genre as the company's Ultrasport and Bicycle Guide, the new magazine will be a quarterly special-interest publication called The Walking Magazine and is due in May.

title: HIGH TECHNOLOGY CAPITAL reports earnings for As of Nov 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Technology; The Portable Computer's Ills
description: JOURNALISTS and traveling sales representatives are always the first - and usually the last - to sing the praises of lightweight, briefcase-sized computers. The better models pack nearly all the functions of a desktop personal computer into an eight-pound plastic case, powered by a handful of AA batteries. They are perfect for people who like to write while standing up in a telephone booth.

title: The Presidency; The Reagan News Conference: A Comparison
description: President Kennedy did it with his quick wits, President Johnson did it with sheer force of personality, and President Nixon did it with a tenacious grip on his material, at least until he became bogged down in the sour futility of the Watergate period.

title: British Aerospace
description: Four American airlines have ordered 24 aircraft worth $135 million from British Aerospace Inc., the British company said. The company's executive vice president, Dewi Rowlands, said that Pacific Southwest Airlines had exercised a $65 million option to buy four 146-200 jetliners. Pacific Southwest currently operates 20 of the British aircraft.

title: Sea Lions Pass Up Trout After a Day of Fireworks
description: A group of sea lions passed up their morning feeding foray into the Ballard Locks today, apparently unwilling to undergo a second day of noise from underwater firecrackers.

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 22
description: b-Net income

title: KENNER PARKER TOYS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Net income after losses of $3,859,000 for the quarter and $3,470,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations and extraordinary credit.

title: DOW PLUNGES 39.10 AS STOCKS RETREAT IN HEAVY TRADING
description: A sudden shift in Wall Street's thinking about interest rates sent a shock wave through the stock market yesterday that lowered the the Dow Jones industrial average by 39 points, its biggest fall ever.

title: I.B.M. System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was introducing a point-of-sale system for department stores and mass merchandisers based on a version of the I.B.M. PC AT. The machine that will function as the system's controller will sell for $9,120 to $9,320, depending on the model, while a terminal in the normal configurations will be $2,928 or $4,399. I.B.M. also announced software for the system. The company said the system was the first it has introduced to handle all of a store's transactions on a personal computer.

title: EMPLOYEES' STOCK ROLE AT EASTERN
description: Charles E. Bryan, head of the largest union at Eastern Airlines, urged all 40,000 of the carrier's employees yesterday to buy enough stock to give them a majority stake in the airline so they could replace its management.

title:
GARDENING;
REST FOR PLANTS, NOT PEOPLE
description: TAKING a cue from their plants, many gardeners choose this season for a rest.

title: ALLIES ARE COOL TO REAGAN'S SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan's appeal to isolate Libya received a tepid response from Western European Governments and Japan today. All expressed doubts about the merits of economic sanctions.

title: SCM Will Merge With Hanson Unit
description: The SCM Corporation and Hanson Trust P.L.C. announced that SCM would be merged into a subsidiary of Hanson, ending a bitter fight lost by SCM and Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: OF IRONY AND 'THE TREASURE HOUSES'
description: THERE is a splendid irony to the installation of ''The Treasure Houses of Britain,'' the much-heralded exhibition of art and decorative objects from great English country houses that is on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington through March 16. The installation is perhaps the most elaborate in modern museum history. So as to provide the hundreds of objects taken from English houses with the kind of setting to which they are accustomed, the exhibition's organizers have gone to painstaking effort to create a series of what might be called platonic rooms, idealized versions of the types of interior spaces found in the great country houses of each period.

title: Ex-Belgian Premier Goes on Trial
description: A former Prime Minister of Belgium went on trial today on charges of committing business fraud while in office.

title: PRESIDENT FREEZES ALL LIBYAN ASSETS HELD IN THE U.S.
description: President Reagan today ordered Libyan assets in the United States frozen, and the State Department issued a report giving details of its charges that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government supported terrorism around the world.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss after a writedown of $16.7 million from the company's Oil Country Tubular operation. c-After extraordinary charge of $1 million, a gain of $2.7 million from pension settlements and an excess assets return and tax credit of $5.8 million.

title: THE AMERICANS LIVING IN LIBYA ARE RESENTFUL BUT RESIGNED
description: Some of the hundreds of Americans living in Libya reacted with a mixture of anger and resignation today to President Reagan's order that they leave the country by Feb. 1.

title: WYNEGAR STAYS
description: Following a furious day of negotiations, the Yankees beat the midnight signing deadline for some free agents last night by reaching agreement with Butch Wynegar and Joe Niekro. Perhaps the most stunning development yesterday, however, was the last-minute decision of Kirk Gibson to accept the Detroit Tigers' offer of $4 million for three years.

title: Two Big Tax Exempts Are Quickly Sold Out
description: The first two sizable tax-exempt offerings of the year were well received this week, as a light supply of new issues compensated for the lack of buying by commercial bank investment portfolios.

title: DIPLOMAT ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses of an affiliate of $250,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income including tax credits of $182,000 for the quarter and $321,000 for the 6 months.

title: FORDHAM COACH THINKS POSITIVELY
description: There is about as much suspense surrounding the outcome as when the Harlem Globetrotters are scheduled to play. North Carolina, the nation's No. 1 team, will face Fordham's sacrificial Rams in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight, and about all anyone can remember is the last time the Tar Heels played a team from New York City, which was during a Christmas tournament in Miami less than two weeks ago.

title: 9 7/8% Debentures
description: The Aluminum Company of Canada Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9 7/8 percent debentures due Jan. 15, 1998, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The debentures, which are callable after eight years, were offered at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 9.965 percent. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: Moslems Force Israelis Off the Temple Mount
description: Hundreds of angry Moslems confronted a group of Israeli legislators today on the Temple Mount, one of the most sacred sites for both Jews and Moslems, and forced them to leave the area, the police said.

title: PANEL ALLOWS LILCO RATE RISE
description: The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday agreed to grant a $68.7 million rate increase to the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Cold Comfort
description: Temperatures as high as the low 40's are expected in Chicago this Sunday for the National Football Conference championship game, but if the forecast is faulty, William Perry won't care. Cold, he says, ''is all in your mind - and I don't plan to think about it.''

title: CUOMO, IN STATE OF STATE MESSAGE, OFFERS ENVIRONMENT AND JOB PLANS
description: Governor Cuomo laid out a legislative program today that included proposals to clean up the environment, provide jobs for welfare applicants, spur economic development and build housing for the homeless.

title: Pakistani Critics Need U.S. Attention
description: Unless the Reagan Administration, which has supported Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan, starts paying respectful attention to the opposition in that country, it will become difficult, if not impossible, for America to continue its policy of support for the Afghan resistance. The political importance of that opposition, whose cooperation the United States needs, will grow now that General Zia has lifted martial law after eight and a half years.

title: Sharp Shooter
description: Peter Brancazio, a 46-year-old physics professor at Brooklyn College, has played basketball ever since he was was a teen-ager in Astoria, Queens, but it was not until many years afterward that he picked up the knack of shooting with consistent accuracy.

title: Dvorak's 'Requiem'
description: Dvorak's ''Requiem'' will be performed by the Canterbury Choral Society on Feb. 9 at 4 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. The group, conducted by Charles Dodsley Walker, features Nadia Pelle, soprano; Shirley Love, alto; Rodney Nolan, tenor, and Thomas Beveride, bass. A donation of $5 is suggested.

title: LIVING WITHOUT A KITCHEN (OR ALMOST)
description: LAST summer, a restaurateur whose lawyer has advised him to keep his name to himself started eyeing his rental apartment's kitchen - its four-burner stove, sink, full-size refrigerator, cabinets and countertops - and thinking about closets.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THOUGH primarily for elderly people who live alone, it could help anyone unable to get to a telephone easily in an emergency.

title: Sea-Land Investor
description: Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, said he had bought an additional one million Sea-Land Corporation common shares, raising his stake in the shipping concern to 39.5 percent of its shares outstanding. Mr. Simmons, who is seeking control of the company, disclosed the purchases, made for $24.75 a share Tuesday in two private deals, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 'METROLINE' LOOKS AT 'FEAR OF CRIME'
description: EVEN the lucky New Yorkers who have been spared a mugging or a snatched purse or a picked pocket know somebody less lucky, so tonight's ''Metroline'' offering, ''Fear of Crime,'' touches a sizable audience. The series, shown at 10 o'clock on Channel 13, is designed to provide useful information to area residents, and under the guidance of Michael Kramer, an editor of New York magazine who serves as moderator, tonight's program fulfills that mission in a sensibly low-keyed way.

title: MOSLEM NATIONS SUPPORTING QADDAFI IN THE U.S. DISPUTE
description: Moslem Governments, ranging from radical Iran to pro-Western Kuwait, have issued strong statements of support for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in his confrontation with the United States.

title: WILL MISS PLAYOFF
description: Irving Fryar, the New England Patriot wide receiver, will miss the American Ffootball Conference championship game against the Dolphins Sunday after accidentally severing a tendon in the pinkie of his right hand this morning.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday about an exhibition on Jewish celebrations of the Sabbath misidentified a girl looking at a display. She was Sara Strobel, not Dini Waxman.

title: Lance Quits Bank Post
description: Bert Lance, the former Federal budget director, has announced that he is resigning as chairman of Calhoun First National Bank. Mr. Lance had been re-elected as chairman of the bank last week despite a legal battle with Federal regulators. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency last summer filed a civil suit in Washington accusing Mr. Lance and the bank of violating securities laws.

title: INCONSISTENT NETS OVERCOME BUCKS
description: When he stopped to consider the performance, Dave Wohl merely offered a smile. He had seen games of far less appeal in his coaching tenure, but this one seemed to stand alone.

title: Ex-Oiler Charged
description: Sidney Blanks, a former Houston Oilers running back, was charged yesterday in Conroe, Tex., with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl, officials said.

title: Supreme Court Has Ruled for Leafleting in Malls
description: To the Editor:

title: INGENIOUS CABINETS, STCKED APPLIANCES FOR SMALL KITCHENS
description: MAKING the most out of the small-apartment kitchen poses the same challenge as an intricate puzzle, only the kitchen is three-dimensional, life-size and plumbed, and the potential parts include hundreds of available appliances and cabinets. Because European and American appliance and cabinet manufacturers are now making many smaller units, including 18-inch-wide refrigerators and dishwashers, 24-inch washers and dryers, 6-inch cabinets, small convection ovens and smaller microwave ovens, it is possible to pack more kitchen facilities into less space.

title: What's a President to Do?
description: You are Ronald Reagan, furious and frustrated about the bloody antics of Libya's flaky Colonel Qaddafi. You owe your Presidency in part to public exasperation with Jimmy Carter's seeming paralysis during the Iranian hostage crisis. On your right flank, your supporters thirst for that famous surgical strike against terrorists that your senior advisers keep promising. So where do you come out? You call for more economic sanctions. Just like Jimmy Carter.

title: Sun-Times to Drop Editions
description: The Chicago Sun-Times announced today that it will drop its afternoon editions at the end of this month because of low circulation. The Chicago Tribune, which had published afternoon editions with late and final market quotations for street sales, did the same thing last summer. The city's last full-time afternoon newspaper, The Chicago Daily News, folded in 1978.

title: FED ADOPTS 'JUNK BOND' CURBS
description: The Federal Reserve Board, rejecting the emphatically stated viewpoint of the Reagan Administration, gave final approval today to a proposal to restrict the use of a financing device that has become a popular means of conducting corporate takeovers.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including extroadinary credits of $12,700 for the quarter and $75,700 for the year and a net gain of $1,257,356, or 76 cents a share, for the quarter and year attributable to life insurance proceeds received, net of deferred death benefits accrued, for the company's former chairman and chief executive officer. c-Net losses after plant closing expenses of $1,155,000.

title: Bomb Scare at Justice Dept.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and others on the fifth floor of the Justice Department were evacuated from their offices for an hour today while officers of the Federal Protective Service, using dogs, searched for a bomb after receiving a telephoned threat. No bomb was found.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline and a table in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about 1985 automobile sales incorrectly characterized the vehicles involved.

title: Advertising; People
description: Joseph P. Flanagan has been promoted to president of Impact, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: Without Dropping a Stitch
description: There is so much going on backstage at the Gershwin Theater, where ''Singin' in the Rain'' is playing, that it is hard to avoid a traffic jam.

title: Killing Young Killers
description: Until last fall's execution of Charles Rambaugh, who was 17 when he committed murder in Texas, the United States had gone 22 years without executing a criminal who was under 18 at the time of the crime. Tomorrow morning South Carolina plans to execute Terry Roach, who was 17 when he joined two others in murdering a teen-age couple. Capital punishment of any sort has no place in an enlightened society. Applying it to children compounds the barbarity.

title: Advertising; Two New Accounts For Homer & Durham
description: Homer & Durham has been named agency for Frances Denney Inc. and Albert Nipon Inc., both in fragrances and cosmetics and both owned and operated by Tedd Munchak.

title: Switching From Time To Newsweek
description: Jaws dropped in the corridors of Time Inc. late yesterday afternoon when it was announced that Stephen Smith, acting assistant managing editor at Time magazine and a likely candidate eventually for the magazine's top job, was leaving to become the third-ranked editor of Newsweek.

title: The State of the Governor
description: Governor Cuomo of New York, as deadly a debater as ever was sent to a neutral corner while his opponent lay inert, demonstrated again in his State of the State Message yesterday that he's more effective against a live opponent than an abstract punching bag.

title: TEST DRUG TO CURB COMMON COLD IS FOUND PROMISING IN 2 STUDIES
description: Research teams in the United States and Australia have reported what appears to be the first practical use of any drug in halting the spread of the common cold.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law -Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 9, 1986
description: Markets

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Amerada Chairman Takes Added Title
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that Leon Hess, its founder and chairman, was reassuming the post of chief executive officer.

title: Newport Folk Festival To Return in August
description: The organizers of last year's peaceful revival of the Newport Folk Festival have said they are planning another concert this summer, on Aug. 23 and 24 at Fort Adams State Park.

title: Cuba's Attorney General Reported Replaced
description: Attorney General Idalberto Ladron de Guevara, who headed the state prosecution office, has been replaced.

title: UNION AND U.S. STEEL AGREE: FURNACE NOT WORTH SAVING
description: The United Steelworkers of American agreed with the United States Steel Corporation today that a blast furnace that won a company award in December 1983 could not be operated profitably and should be demolished.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.3 million, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months on the replacement of a pension plan. c-Including a gain of $500,000, or 5 cents a share, on the sale of nonoperating assets.

title: SCHOOL SEX EDUCATION ENTERS A NEW PHASE
description: TO combat the increasing problem of teen-age pregnancy, a growing number of school districts are revising their sex-education courses. Interviews with officials in 10 public-school districts across United States show that they are adopting what they consider a more realistic and practical approach to sex education, starting as early as kindergarten.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Angus & Robertson To Buy 2 Publishers
description: Salem House and Merrimack Publisher's Circle, publishers and distributors of foreign books, announced yesterday that they had agreed to be acquired by Angus & Robertson, an Australian publishing house owned by Rupert Murdoch.

title: FRANCE PLANS LARGEST MANEUVERS IN WEST GERMANY SINCE THE WAR
description: The Government announced today that it planned to conduct its largest military maneuvers since World War II in West Germany next year.

title: Drug Testing In Winter Ball
description: In September, Peter Ueberroth struck an agreement with the Caribbean Confederation, an umbrella group of winter baseball leagues, that called for random mandatory drug testing of players in Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Mexico, with the commissioner's office providing guidance and supervision. Spurred in part by this accord, a fourth member of the confederation, Venezuela, began two months ago to conduct urinalyses on its own, under the supervision of the nation's Ministry of Sport.

title: Sliver Ruling Backs Developer of a Tower
description: A city panel has ruled that a law banning the building of slivers - tall, narrow towers - does not apply to a parcel in Brooklyn Heights where a developer wants to construct a condominium.

title: Ward Doubts Officer's Story On Comment by Goetz Victim
description: A police officer's statement last month that one of the youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in 1984 had said at the time that he and his companions intended to rob Mr. Goetz was discounted yesterday by the city's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward.

title: TAR HEEL GUARDS BLEND TALENTS
description: North Carolina had built a comfortable lead against North Carolina State and was playing out the seconds Saturday in the last game to be played in 21-year-old Carmichael Arena.

title: TREND IN ART GLASS: OTHER MATERIALS
description: The striking diversity of art-glass styles, from paperweights to neon installations, can be seen in Glass America '86, now at the Heller Gallery. For this annual survey, 73 artists were invited to make selections from their latest work.

title: GEORGETOWN VICTORY MARRED BY BRAWL
description: Reggie Williams and Michael Jackson each scored 16 points tonight to lead Georgetown to a 70-66 Big East Conference victory over Connecticut in a game that was marred by a bench-clearing brawl. The fighting broke out after Connecticut cut an 11-point halftime deficit to 40-37.

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Net loss. c-Including tax credits of $3,857,000 for the quarter and $3,350,000 for the 6 months. d-Including a tax credit of $192,000.

title: ABC CHIEF IS EXPECTED TO QUIT
description: Frederick S. Pierce, chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies, is expected to resign as early as today, according to sources close to ABC. The resignation would came just six days after the merger between Capital Cities Communications and ABC had become final.

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Ken Schrom and Bryan Oelkers, pitchers, to Cleveland for Roy Smith and Ramon Romero, pitchers. COLLEGES

title: MEDICARE EXTENDS PATIENTS RIGHTS
description: The Federal Government will soon require hospitals to tell Medicare patients that they have a legal right to challenge their discharge from a hospital if they think they are being sent home prematurely, health officials said today.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was just unbelievable.'' - John Havens, of Kidder Peabody & Company, describing the stock market. [ D10:4. ]

title: The Cost of Chemical Carelessness
description: James Harrison, a 25-year-old chemical worker in Gore, Okla., died a rare and horrible death last weekend. Because of an accident at the Sequoyah Fuels plant, he inhaled hydrogen fluoride, an intensely corrosive gas that destroys the lungs. His death should spur efforts to improve the handling of hazardous chemicals and protect others from an extremely widespread risk.

title: Control Data Change Seen
description: William C. Norris is expected to announce soon his retirement as chairman and chief executive of the Control Data Company, analysts and others close to the company said yesterday. Control Data spokesmen would not comment on reports that a retirement announcement was imminent, but they said a news conference would be held Friday, after a board meeting in Minneapolis.

title: TOOLS FOR PLACES HIGH OR OUT OF REACH
description: A VARIETY of tools are made for reaching places usually difficult to get at. Brookstone stores carry the High-Altitude Ostrich Feather Duster ($21.50), with a steel handle that extends 4 1/2 feet to 7 feet.

title: SIN License Plea Rejected
description: An administrative law judge at the Federal Communications Commission refused yesterday to renew the licenses of seven stations affiliated with the SIN Television Network, the country's largest Spanish-language television network.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Re-signed Tony Bernazard, second baseman, and Jaime Easterly, pitcher, to two-year contracts.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:53 A.M. today and set at 8:29 P.M. tonight.

title: Time May Quit USA Network
description: Time Inc. is exploring the sale of its one-third interest in USA Network, the advertiser-supported cable programming service that it owns jointly with Gulf and Western Industries and MCA Inc., according to sources familiar with the talks. Time declined to comment.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $109,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for work-in-progress inventory on net income for prior years.

title: Retail Operations Of Altman Are Sold
description: B. Altman & Company announced yesterday that its retail operations had been acquired by an international investment group headed by two former partners of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the accounting firm. The price was not disclosed.

title: CITY AGREES TO INCREASE PAYMENTS TO HOTELS WITH WELFARE FAMILIES
description: City officials, bowing to pressure from several hotels that house large numbers of homeless families, have decided to increase payments to 14 such hotels at a total cost of about $2.5 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A WAY OF LIFE The exhibition that opens today at the quiet and tastefully appointed Center for African Art, 54 East 68th Street (861-1200) is a colorful, eye-opening vision of the culture expressed by a special people who live in West Africa.

title: U.S. LEGISLATORS MEET PRETORIA LEADER
description: An American Congressional delegation met today with South Africa's President, P. W. Botha, and members indicated later that they had come away with the impression that the prospects for racial change in this divided land were limited.

title: Hagler a Trustee
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, cited for his long-time support for Massasoit Community College in Brockton, Mass., has been sworn in as a trustee of the school. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appointed the middleweight boxing champion during a ceremony Tuesday to a five-year term as one of the 10 trustees. ''For more than a decade, Marvelous Marvin has demonstrated that commitment,'' the Governor saids. ''His mother, Ida Mae, and his brother Robbie Sims have attended classes there and through his Marvin Hagler Scholarship Trust Fund, he has reflected our commitment to provide the opportunity to a good sound education to everyone who seeks it.''

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reserve for loss on the sale of operations of $15,600,000. c-Includes a $21.8 million estimated loss from the sale of assets and a $5.2 million gain from the sale of land.

title: 2 Resignations At Ideal Basic
description: Ideal Basic Industries, the nation's third-largest cement company, said yesterday that its two top executives had resigned, and that Thomas E. Bronson, the chief executive of Moore McCormack Cement Company in Tampa, Fla., would become chairman, chief executive and president.

title: Proper Interpretation Of the Constitution
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese's call last summer for a return to a ''jurisprudence of original intention'' has produced a sharp debate over how we should interpret the Constitution. This debate will not end soon. We have seen the problem of judicial activism before in our history, but never with such reach into so many areas previously left to the political process.

title: RISING ENROLLMENT IN PRESCHOOL CLASSES IS REPORTED
description: Enrollment is rising in the nation's kindergartens and nursery schools as the children of the generation born in the ''baby boom'' after World War II begin reaching school age, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
GAIN PUT AT $81 MILLION
description: The battle for the Union Carbide Corporation is over, and so too, it appears, is the war.

title: HERS
description: NOW that I'm not stalking handsome strangers across crowded rooms, what I like best about parties is seeing the shape the lives of my friends are taking, like the pattern of interweaving characters in a novel. This New Year's Eve, glass of wine in one hand, stuffed grape leaf in the other, I looked around the crowded, festive room and thought, well, here we all are, with interesting jobs, lovers, spouses and (some of us) babies, and we all have roofs over our heads and parties to go to and delicious things to eat. So why is it that out of the 20 women in this room 15, including myself, are in some sort of psychotherapy?

title: PENNZOIL CALLS TALKS A FAILURE
description: The high-stakes feud between the Pennzoil Company and Texaco Inc. erupted into public acrimony again yesterday, with the chances of the oil companies reaching an amicable settlement appearing to be virtually extinguished.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net income.

title: ABC DELAYS 'AMERIKA,' DISCLOSES SOVIET WARNING
description: ABC has postponed production of a $40 million mini-series depicting life in the United States after a Soviet takeover, network officials said yesterday. The program, called ''Amerika,'' has had serious financial problems, but a network executive added yesterday that another consideration on whether to proceed with the project was a Soviet warning that ABC's news operations in Moscow could be jeopardized if the mini-series were broadcast.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TEXT OF CUOMO'S 4TH STATE OF STATE ADDRESS TO THE LEGISLATURE
description: Following is a transcript of Governor Cuomo's State of the State Address to the Legislature yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Channel 13:

title: THE BOSTON WRONGBOY
description: Not since John L., the Boston Strongboy who could lick any man in the house, has a Sullivan created such headlines. Although outweighed by about 100 pounds, Patrick J. (for Jerome), the 33-year-old general manager of the New England Patriots, scuffled with Howie Long and Matt Millen of the Los Angeles Raiders after the 27-20 upset that put the Patriots into the American Conference championship game Sunday in Miami.

title: JOBLESSNESS, IN THEORY NO ISSUE FOR SOVIET, IS SUDDENLY DEBATED
description: The Soviet Union has introduced a form of unemployment benefits and begun an unusual public discussion about joblessness as a result of the economic policies instituted by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $106,000.

title: City to Review Care Provided To Mother Whose Child Died
description: New York City Human Resources Administration officials said yesterday that they would investigate whether adequate services were provided to a mother whose 2-month-old son died at a welfare hotel.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the ''Pavarotti Plus'' concert at Avery Fisher Hall misidentified the woman shown with Mr. Pavarotti. She was Mary Jane Johnson, not Susan Dunn.

title: Q&A:M. Wendell Belew Jr.; Trepidations on the Budget Process
description: M. Wendell Belew Jr. was chief counsel for the House Budget Committee from 1977 until Congress adjourned in late December, and as such was a key behind-the-scenes staff member in the establishment of the Congressional budget process in the 1970's and the writing late last year of a budget-balancing law sponsored in the Senate by Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire.

title: CONFIDENT VOICE FROM QUEENS
