description: Peter F. Vallone, a 51-year-old Councilman from Queens, was elected majority leader of the City Council yesterday, by one vote, after a last-minute switch by a Manhattan Councilman.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tucker Ashford, the former infielder who played with both the Yankees and the Mets in his eight-year, five-team career, has been named manager of the Mets' Class A farm club in Columbia, S.C. Ashford, 31, who finished his career with the Royals in 1984, managed the Mets' rookie league club in Kingsport, Tenn., last seaosn. . . . Delray Brooks, a sophomore guard at Indiana and a winner of that state's Mr. Basketball high school award in 1984, quit the team. Bob Knight, the coach, said Brooks left because he was dissatisfied with the amount of playing time.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEVILS END EIGHT-GAME LOSING STREAK
description: John MacLean of the Devils broke a 6-6 tie midway through the third period tonight and Doug Sulliman scored 75 seconds later as the Devils beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 8-7.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in July. The company said the latest second quarter and 6-month figures include the operations of Cable Television Systems acquired from Tele-Communications Inc. in August 1984 and April 1985 and the operations of a cable television system serving the Hartford, Conn., area acquired in September 1985.

title: F.A.A. to Require Pilots To Take Blood Tests
description: The Government said today that it would require pilots, flight engineers and cabin attendants to take tests of blood alcohol when requested by the authorities or face the loss of their certificates.

title: JOBLESS RATE AT ITS LOWEST SINCE 1980
description: The national unemployment rate dropped by one-tenth of a percentage point in December, to 6.8 percent, the lowest level in nearly five years, the Labor Department reported today. This is the lowest rate since the start of the Reagan Administration.

title: Books: A Lost World
description: THE RIDDLE OF THE DINOSAUR. By John Noble Wilford. Illustrated. 304 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95. THE last dinosaur died 65 million years ago. For 160 million years they flourished, living on every major land mass with the possible exception of Antarctica. Some dinosaurs were grazing herbivores. Others were carnivores, fierce predators that hunted in packs. Some were small, no bigger than rabbits or crows. The bigger ones - diplodocus, brontosaurus, brachiosaurus - were the largest land animals that ever lived. They were the dominant animals in the time known as the Age of Reptiles. They saw the first flowers bloom 100 million years ago. None survived.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HARDWARE and furniture made of lustrous stainless steel, polished brass or shiny chromium will eventually oxidize and become dull if not properly maintained - especially when exposed to air and moisture, even the moisture that is always present in the air.

title: COMPANY LINKED TO NAZI SLAVE LABOR PAYS $2 MILLION
description: A subsidiary of the giant Flick industrial empire paid an indemnity of over $2 million today to a New York-based organization representing the interests of Jews who were used as slave laborers by the Nazis.

title: 2 INQUIRIES IN PENNZOIL TRADING
description: Disturbed by what it suspected could be a stock manipulation, the Securities and Exchange Commission began a preliminary inquiry today into the rumors that fueled a $19.75 jump Tuesday in the price of shares in the Pennzoil Company.

title: The Fire Next Time
description: America's allies have responded to President Reagan's plea to join a quarantine of Libya with a loud horselaugh.

title: PEETE AND MCCUMBER SHARE 1-SHOT LEAD
description: Calvin Peete, who has the most PGA Tour victories in the last four years with nine, got off to a good start on this year's tour today when he gained a share of the lead in the 34th annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone President Is Appointed Chairman
description: Norman W. Brown, president and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has also picked up the chairman's title left behind by John E. O'Toole when he retired at the end of the year.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Federal Traffic Official Dead
description: An official of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration who was charged with drunken driving has been found dead of what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said Tuesday. The body of the regional administrator for the agency, Donald Williamson, 53 years old, was found Monday at 11:30 P.M. in his bedroom shortly after his court appearance in a hit-and-run accident. No one was injured.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: College Basketball North Carolina vs. Fordham and Georgia Tech vs. Rutgers, at Madison Square Garden, 7 and 9 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 6:40 P.M.) Other Local Games: Pratt at City College, 8 P.M. Hofstra at Manhattan, 8 P.M. Trinity at Yale, 7:30 P.M. Televised Games: Virginia Commonwealth at University of Alabama-Birmingham, 7 P.M. (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M.).

title: Wallace in Better Condition
description: Doctors treating Gov. George C. Wallace at a hospital here upgraded his condition today from fair to satisfactory. The Governor has been receiving antibiotics intravenously to combat a urinary tract infection, but doctors said today that they might switch to oral antibiotics Thursday. He entered the hospital Saturday.

title: Egypt Cuts Oil Prices
description: Egypt has decided to reduce the price of its light crude oils by $1 a barrel, and its heavier crude oils by up to $1.35 a barrel. The Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation, the state-owned oil company, said yesterday that the price cuts are retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Quarterback Arrested
description: Tony Robinson, the Tennessee quarterback who missed the second half of the season after a knee injury, was arrested at his off-campus Knoxville apartment yesterday and charged with selling cocaine to an undercover narcotics agent. The arrest came a week after Robinson, waving his crutches from the sideline, had cheered his teammates on to a 35-7 upset of Miami in the Sugar Bowl.

title: CELLIST TYPIFIED FRENCH STYLE
description: Pierre Fournier, a cellist whose elegance and reserve represented French musical style at its best, died yesterday in Geneva. He was 79 years old and had lived in Switzerland since 1970. According to his son, Jean Fonda, a pianist who had performed with his father, Mr. Fournier had had a stroke in November.

title: Penn Promotes Aide
description: Ed Zubrow, defensive line coach for the last five seasons, was named Penn's coach yesterday. The 34-year-old Zubrow, from Cherry Hill, N.J., succeeds Jerry Berndt, who resigned Dec. 31 to become athletic director and coach at Rice.

title: Advertising; A Rest in Client Chase For Fallon McElligott
description: You biggies at the big agencies can breath easy for a bit.

title: Bye, Bye
description: For 20 years, just after noontime, the Bluebird has fluttered down on desks all over the Pentagon, the Air Force's blue-covered, midday compilation of news clippings. But last week was the old bird's last; it was killed because of accelerated reading habits at the Pentagon.

title: FORMER POLICE SERGEANT GOES ON TRIAL IN A HIT-AND-RUN DEATH
description: A former police sergeant went on trial yesterday in the hit-and-run death of an elderly Manhattan psychologist on Park Avenue last March.

title: PAUL NEWMAN DONATES $100,000 TO NEEDIEST
description: For the second straight year, Paul Newman has contributed $100,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: THEATER: 'CRYSTAL CLEAR,' AT THE LONG WHARF
description: A young art dealer, suffering from diabetes, suddenly loses his sight. His girlfriend, blind since birth, gradually realizes that he, too, is unable to see. The scene, an evocative study in double disorientation, is at the center of ''Crystal Clear,'' a play ''devised'' and directed by Phil Young, and presented at the Long Wharf Theater's Stage II.

title: Farm Agency Aide Kills Himself and His Family
description: An official of a Government farm agency, apparently troubled over his job, killed his wife and two children and then committed suicide, the police said today.

title: Advertising; A Host Of Account Changes
description: FRIDAY is generally the day that advertisers decide to rush out with announcements of account moves. And yesterday they acted just like it was Friday.

title: JETS DISMISS COACH OF OFFENSIVE LINE
description: Bill Austin, the Jets' offensive line coach, was dismissed yesterday after a season in which the team's quarterback was sacked a league-record 62 times.

title: JAPAN IS SAID TO END SOME BARRIERS
description: As yearlong trade talks draw to their scheduled close, United States negotiators said today that Japan had agreed to changes removing the last legal barriers to telecommunications trade.

title: ART: WILLIAM WEGMAN, PHOTOGRAPHER AS PAINTER
description: IT'S not surprising that William Wegman should have majored in painting or that he began his career in the mid-1960's producing shaped canvases a la Frank Stella. There have been plenty of photographers who started out as plain old artists (Laszlo Moholy-Nagy is one stirring example) and even more videoists. What is remarkable is that Wegman, having made his reputation with cameras, should, after some 25 years, suddenly return to painting - not abstractions, but small figurative works and at the rate of about two a day.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:48 A.M. today and set at 8:23 P.M. tonight.

title: LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The shares outstanding reflect a stock offering completed in November 1984 and all share earnings and data were adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split of June 28, 1985.

title: DRYFOOS ASSERTS CHANGE OF VOTE WAS ON MERITS
description: It was a rare happening in the normally well-controlled world of city politics: the decision of one local lawmaker to bolt from a political arrangement at the last minute and cast the determining vote in this week's election of a new City Council majority leader.

title: A WEEKEND FULL OF DANCES WITH STORIES TO TELL
description: STORYTELLING is back in dance, the pundits say.

title: Market Place; After the Fall: Bulls vs. Bears
description: THE stock market, just a few days after celebrating one of its best years ever, suddenly finds itself nursing a huge hangover. Worried investors are asking: Is the bull market finished? Or is this simply an intermission? In the last two days, the spoiler for the equity market has been the unexpectedly big spill in bond prices. Ever since the bull market began in August 1982, it has been nurtured repeatedly by rising bond prices and falling yields. In the constant tug-of-war for investor money, lower rates enhance the attractiveness of stocks by reducing the return in fixed-income securities.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST CITE THE HARSH WINTER WEATHER
description: Below-freezing temperatures and bone-chilling winds have created an increased concern for the homeless among many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Walesa Urges Poland To Overhaul Prisons
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, urged the Government today to improve the nation's penal system and free its remaining political prisoners.

title: ART: VISION OF AUSTRALIA IN PETER BOOTH'S WORKS
description: PETER BOOTH is a name New York gallery-goers may know. A Booth fire-and-blood landscape with a man on a deserted road staring out at us was one of the most striking images in the ''International Survey of Recent Painting and Sculpture'' that reopened the Museum of Modern Art in May 1984. Booth's compacted, macabre crowd scenes were included in ''Australian Visions,'' the 1984 Exxon International Exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday on polygraph, or lie-detector, tests twice misstated a word in President Reagan's order of Nov. 1 authorizing increased use of such tests for Federal employees. The word is ''aperiodic,'' meaning the tests will be given randomly, and not ''periodic.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; GO-GO-OOPS IN WALL STREET
description: Oops! Stock Market Plummets . . . Plunge Chills Wall Street. Wednesday's leaden drop after weeks of euphoric increases probably sold some extra newspapers. As fodder for dinner party conversation, the go-go market sure beats college tuition bills or Lady Di's wardrobe. But the market's main and mundane function is not entertainment but capital formation. And on that front, its increased volatility suggests that institutionalized speculation may have become disruptive.

title: Don't Tie the Economy To a Deal With OPEC
description: To the Editor:

title: LOCAL N.H.L. TEAMS FALL SHORT OF GOAL
description: The Rangers, long glorified as underachievers, are not talented enough to be much more than a middle-of-the-pack team. The Islanders are no longer among the elite. And the Devils are still not ready to make the leap to a playoff spot, even with all their promise. Through a frustrating first half of the season, these are the realizations that have set in. What follows is a midseason review of each team. RANGERS

title: 100 Sikh Activists Arrested in Punjab
description: Punjabi authorities put a 48,000-member security force on alert today and arrested more than 100 Sikh activists on the eve of a traffic blockade called by radical Sikhs in the northern state.

title: Muzak Up for Sale
description: Muzak, the company that sends placid music into offices and elevators, is for sale, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said.

title: TRAINING LAPSE SUGGESTED IN OKLAHOMA LEAK
description: The head of the Federal team investigating the fatal accident at a Kerr-McGee plant here last weekend said today that workers were unaware of the critical safety significance of their improper overfilling and heating of a chemical storage tank that burst.

title: OF HUMAN RIGHTS AND HUMAN WRONGS
description: To the Editor:

title: PEETE RALLIES TO TIE 2 FOR LEAD
description: Calvin Peete birdied the last three holes today and regained a share of the lead after two rounds of the 34th annual MONY Tournament of Champions on the La Costa Country Club course. He was tied at 9-under-par 135 with Tom Kite, last year's Tournament of Champions winner, and Mark O'Meara, whose 65 today was the lowest round of the tournament.

title: Hormel to Reopen Plant Despite Settlement Plan
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Company said today that it would reopen its meatpacking plant with new employees despite efforts by Gov. Rudy Perpich to resolve a five-month strike by union workers with an independent fact-finder.

title: ELECTRONICS FADS COOLING OFF
description: Cordless phones are on the ropes. So are ordinary color televisions, as consumers prepare for the day when stereo TV broadcasting is commonplace. Compact disk players are hot, as are a new generation of small, 8-millimeter video cassette recorders and cameras.

title: CLAUDE FRANK PLANS AFTERNOON OF BEETHOVEN
description: Before playing the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas in a series of performances, Claude Frank would cut up little pieces of cardboard, one for each sonata, and push them here and there on his bed, trying to decide which to include on which program.

title: Euromarket Sale Of Currency Units
description: Salomon Brothers International is offering in the Euromarket ''put'' and ''call'' warrants for European Currency Units, a basket of 10 European currencies.

title: CUOMO ORDERS SUING OF P.S.C. FOR LILCO'S RISE
description: Governor Cuomo today denounced the New York State Public Service Commission's approval of a $68.7 million rate increase for the Long Island Lighting Company and ordered a lawsuit against the utility regulators to overturn their decision.

title: Marching to His Own Beat
description: Later this month Lester Trimble, the composer, will be able to march to his own music at St. John's University in Queens.

title: Bond Yields Move Up Sharply
description: Yields on Treasury bonds rose sharply for the second consecutive day, as fading hopes for an easier monetary policy led to heavy selling by investors and speculators.

title: Advertising; C & W Group Change
description: Carl W. Nichols, 62 years old and 40 years with Cunningham & Walsh, will relinquish the chairmanship of the C&W Group on Jan. 31 and content himself with chairman emeritus. Adding the chairman's title to his existing collection will be Anthony C. Chevinso, 64, who has been president of the group as well as chairman and chief executive of Cunningham & Walsh, which is one of the Mickelberry companies.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the manslaughter trial of Frederick G. Sherman, a New York City police sergeant, misstated his status in the department. He has been suspended, not dismissed.

title: A.B. Fermenta
description: A major chunk of Sweden's biotechnology industry is being consolidated under the umbrella of A. B. Fermenta, a rapidly growing pharmaceutical company. Fermenta is acquiring a 40 percent stake in A. B. Pharmacia and other biotechnology interests from A. B. Volvo, Scandinavia's largest industrial company. Volvo will end up with a 20 percent stake in Fermenta, which will double its annual revenues to $900 million.

title: S.E.C. BARS PROPOSALS FOR RULES ON TAKEOVERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, back to full strength after nine months, today rejected a broad range of proposals to regulate takeovers and takeover defenses. However, it did ask for public comment on a handful of takeover issues.

title: ARMY IS CONSIDERING MASS BURIAL
description: Military pathologists and dentists have so far been unable to identify the remains of 135 of the 248 soldiers who were killed in an airplane crash in Newfoundland Dec. 12, an Army spokesman said today.

title: Jersey Plans to Raise Jackpots for Pick-6
description: The New Jersey Lottery will add three numbers to its Pick-6 game to increase the jackpots and make the game competitive with those in New York and Pennsylvania, officials announced today.

title: CAROLINA AND TECH ROMP AT GARDEN
description: It was like one of those soft drink commercials where people are asked to pick their favorite cola in a taste test. In this instance, however, the North Carolina and Georgia Tech uniforms were not concealed to insure objectivity. Instead, the crowd of 9,959 at Madison Square Garden last night was able to compare Carolina's disciplined, slick passing offense and pressing defense with Tech's more expressive style that captures the frenetic personality of Bobby Cremins, the silver-haired New Yorker who has made the Yellow Jackets a national power.

title: A. S. Esfandiary Dies at 91; A Longtime Iranian Diplomat
description: Abdol-Hossein Sadigh Esfandiary, who served in Iran's diplomatic service for 40 years, died at Greater Baltimore Medical Center Wednesday after a long respiratory illness. He was 91.

title: Of Human Rights and Human Wrongs
description: To the Editor:

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Housing Administration's Mortgage Insurance Could Go Private
description: To the Editor:

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IT has been two years since George Segal created ''The Holocaust,'' a bronze work memorializing Nazi death-camp victims that became one of this country's first major Holocaust memorials when it was installed in San Francisco's Lincoln Park in 1984.

title: Vuckovich, Pianist
description: Larry Vuckovich is playing solo piano tonight and tomorrow at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M. There is a $7.50 minimum.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $3,514,000 on the sale of real estate and a charge of $3,446,000 from early retirement of subordinated debentures, for the quarter and year.

title: In and Out of the Shop
description: On the sidewalk outside the showroom of a car dealer, a lone man was picketing yesterday. He was wearing a sign saying, ''Porsche-Audi Manhattan Does Not Honor Its Repair Warranties.''

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a special gain of $5,023,000.

title: NAKASONE, IN EFFORT TO QUELL FUROR, SKIPS WAR SHRINE AGAIN
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone made an annual New Year's visit to a Shinto shrine today, but, stung by criticism at home and abroad, he avoided a place of worship dedicated to Japan's war dead.

title: G.M. Job Cuts
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 4,100 workers temporarily in Wilmington, Del., and 30 jobs would be eliminated at a Detroit toolmaking shop. The Wilmington assembly plant, which had been making large Chevrolet and Oldsmobile cars, will be retooled for $300 million for a smaller front-wheel drive Chevrolet line currently code-named the L-car. G.M.'s Linden, N.J., plant was closed in August for retooling to produce the car.

title: U.S. AIDE TESTIFIED SOVIET KEPT MOST ARMS PACTS
description: The Soviet Union has complied with the vast majority of important arms control provisions, according to private Congressional testimony by a ranking State Department official.

title: DOLHINS DISCOUNT INJURY TO FRYAR
description: The New England Patriots' loss of Irving Fryar will have a negligible effect on the way the Miami Dolphins' defense will play in Sunday's American Conference championship game, according to Chuck Studley, the Dolphins' defensive coordinator.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: ''AULD acquaintance,'' which was celebrated in song at many of last week's New Year's Eve revels, will be the basis of three musical events this weekend.

title: REAGAN'S MESSAGE TO TAKE NEW TACK
description: President Reagan will take a ''fresh approach'' to the State of the Union Message by delivering a substantially shorter thematic speech, rather than the usual long catalogue of national issues, White House officials said today.

title: BROADWAY
description: HAPPY news from England - the hit musical ''Les Miserables'' is coming this way, not for a while, it's true, but better in 14 months than never.

title: Precious Metals Rise In Vigorous Trading
description: Prices of precious metals futures advanced strongly yesterday, responding to the decline in the stock and bond markets and the political tension between Libya and the United States.

title: Clara Fortunoff Dead; A Co-founder of Chain
description: Clara Fortunoff, co-founder with her husband of the Fortunoff store chain, died Wednesday night at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. She was 83 years old and lived in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: NEW TEACHER LEADER: SANDRA FELDMAN
description: Sandra Feldman, executive director of the United Federation of Teachers for the last five years, spent Tuesday and Wednesday in public schools in Brooklyn and Queens, hearing the complaints of teachers short of supplies and consoling a teacher who had been stabbed in her classroom by an intruder.

title: IN DEATH, ZHOU ENLAI IS STILL BELOVED (BUT A PUZZLE)
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale was the host at a dinner recently at one of Peking's new Western-style hotels. He was to visit Deng Xiaoping the next morning, and he was eager to share what a Chinese guest at the table thought of the outspoken man who has set China on an ambitious course of modernization.

title: Trilogy Officer Leaves
description: Henry C. Montgomery has resigned as vice chairman, director and chief financial officer of Trilogy Ltd., the computer company announced today. He will continue to serve as a consultant.

title: Bush Going to Honduras
description: Vice President Bush will lead the United States delegation to the inauguration of Jose Azcona del Hoyo as the new President of Honduras on Jan. 27, it was announced today. ''The United States is pleased to mark this event as evidence of the strengthening of the democratic process in Central America,'' the Presidential spokesman, Larry Speakes, said.

title: Court Clears Execution Of South Carolina Man
description: The Supreme Court late today cleared the way for the execution Friday morning in South Carolina of James Terry Roach, who pleaded guilty to murdering two teen-agers when he was 17.

title: IN DEBUT ON BOARD, DINKINS STRESSES MINORITY JOBS
description: David N. Dinkins yesterday attended his first Board of Estimate meeting as Manhattan Borough President and promptly warned that he would demand commitments to hire city residents, particularly black and Hispanic workers, from developers bringing projects before the board.

title: 'Rockabye' Tells of Mother Tracking Son's Abductors
description: Tugging at the heartstrings while taxing credibility, ''Rockabye,'' scheduled for broadcast by Channel 2 on Sunday from 9 to 11 P.M., tells the story of a young mother from California who tracks down the kidnappers who seized her 2-year-old son on the streets of midtown New York.

title: 'Lohengrin' Seminar
description: An all-day seminar on ''Lohengrin'' will be presented by the Wagner Society of New York tomorrow from 10 A.M to 4:30 P.M. at Christ Church United Methodist, Park Avenue at 60th Street. The seminar will feature lectures by scholars and musicians, examining various aspects of the opera's history. Admission is $20; information: 749-4561.

title: Doc Watson, Guitarist
description: The guitarist Doc Watson returns to the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (228-7880), tomorrow for shows at 9 P.M. and midnight. Tickets are $8.50.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Los Angeles Clippers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The teams are meeting for the first time this season.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1986
description: International

title: Carmen McRae to Sing
description: The singer Carmen McRae is performing through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M.; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum, or a $10 charge at the bar.

title: Nixon Price Is $1 Million
description: Norm Nixon, the Los Angeles Clippers' all-star playmaker, is willing to come to the Knicks - but only for a hefty price.

title: U.S. AGENCIES OPPOSE BILL TO LIMIT ART-THEFT CLAIMS
description: The Justice Department said today that a Senate bill that would place a time limit on foreign countries' efforts to recover art and archeological works would turn the United States into a ''pirate's cove'' for art thieves.

title: Safety Questions Keep T.V.A. Reactors Closed
description: The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority said today that they were not ready to affirm under oath that Federal safety requirements had been met at the T.V.A.'s nuclear reactors.

title: SECONDARY ISSUES JOIN STOCK SLIDE
description: Wall Street's record-breaking slide continued yesterday, as investors, alarmed by the stock market's sudden change in direction, continued to unload equities.

title: HERMAN'S SPORTING GOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures are pro forma and have been adjusted to reflect the operations of the company as if its initial public offering had been completed on Jan. 2, 1984.

title: Tax Amnesty Elicits $2.5 Million Check
description: A New York City man mailed in a check for $2.5 million to cover unpaid income taxes for 1984, under the New York State tax amnesty program, officials said today.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ''THE AGE OF CARAVAGGIO'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last year spurred dozens of collectors to get in touch with Sotheby's about paintings they owned that they thought were by the late-16th-century Italian artist or one of his followers.

title: Jockey Fights Vision Ruling
description: When he was 8 years old, Charles Fletcher caught a dart in his right eye and permanently lost vision in it. But he's long since grown used to that handicap, which wasn't an issue when Fletcher, now 19, set out last summer to become an apprentice jockey. Having been granted a license by the State of Ohio, he rode in some 25 races at River Downs in Cincinnati.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend declared Sept. 9, 1985, and paid Oct. 16, 1985.

title: U.S. TOP FREE 33 AFGHANS WHO ENTERED ILLEGALLY
description: Thirty-three Afghan refugees detained here for up to 18 months for entering the country illegally are to be released today under an agreement reached by Federal immigration officials, legislators and lawyers representing the detainees.

title: A Father's Statement and His Son's Response
description: Following are the texts of statements from Barry Bingham Sr. and his son, Barry Bingham Jr.: Barry Bingham Sr. It is my unwelcome duty to announce that the three companies long controlled by the Bingham family are being placed on the market for sale. They are the Courier-Journal and Louisville Times Company, WHAS Inc. and the Standard Gravure Corporation, along with their subsidiaries. These companies have been fully owned by my family through three generations. My father acquired the newspapers in 1918, and the other companies in the early 20's. They have been an intimate part of our lives over the years.

title: GTE Shares Move Higher
description: Shares of the GTE Corporation rose for the second consecutive day yesterday despite a declining stock market on rumors that GTE is about to spin off its Sprint long-distance telephone company.

title: WINTER FUN IN THE CITY, AN EARMUFF GUIDE
description: TO many New Yorkers, the outdoors in winter is a frigid nuisance between the warm place they've been and the warm place they're going to - an unpleasant fact of life to be endured until spring again transforms the city's open spaces into desired places to go.

title: Other Voices
description: Members of Congress returning in 10 days for the 1986 session are going to need all the resources they can lay their hands on to cope with the mountain of economic and political problems facing them. So some may decide to respond to a letter they all got late last year from Nancy Gibbons Baroni, who identifies herself as a ''psychic consultant'' and cites as credentials her membership in the International Guild of Parapsychologists and the Spiritual Frontiers Fellowship.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,277,000. c-After net from discontinued operations. d-After income from discontinued operations of $8,733,000, or 44 cents a share . e-After income from discontinued operations of $12,260,000, or 56 cents a share. Results do not include those of Crucible Materials Corp. and Crusteel Ltd. sold in December. Latest year figures include December sales and earnings of Walbar Inc., acquired in December. The 1984 results have been restated to exclude results of discontinued operations.

title: Woody Shaw Quintet
description: The trumpeter Woody Shaw will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Bridge: Some Odd Bids Accompany An Oddly Constructed Hand
description: The reaction of any reader who snorts ''ridiculous'' on inspecting the diagramed deal and the accompanying bidding is quite understandable.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE idea was to encourage young writers and directors to make independent films, and the subject was surely one that appeals to the young: first love.

title: 2 Shipyards Win Navy Contracts
description: The Navy, continuing to emphasize competition, has divided contracts worth more than $629 million for three new guided-missile cruisers between two shipyards.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it would offer 7.5 percent financing on loans up to 36 months, and 7.9 percent on loans of 37 to 48 months for the purchase of Jeep Commanche two-wheel-drive pickup trucks. Customers could choose a cash rebate of up to $700 on Renault Alliance and Encore models.

title: Income Falls At Chemical
description: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that increases in loan-loss provisions, operating expenses and income taxes caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1985 to fall 7.5 percent.

title: Against a One-Term, 6-Year President
description: The proposal of a single six-year Presidential term has been around for a long time. High-minded men have urged it from the beginning of the Republic. The Constitutional Convention turned it down in 1787, and recurrent efforts to put it in the Constitution have regularly failed in the two centuries since. Quite right: It is a terrible idea for a number of reasons, among them that it is at war with the philosophy of democracy.

title: COURT ORDERS LAWYERS TO TELL OF FEES FROM CRIME FIGURE
description: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that a lawyer must tell a grand jury about fees that he received from a reputed Mafia member.

title: STAKES IN THE STRUGGLE FOR BRITAIN'S WESTLAND
description: Westland P.L.C., Britain's faltering helicopter maker, hardly seems to be worth fighting over. The company lost $:95.3 million, or $137 million, last year, and is short of orders to keep its plants running.

title: DARTMOUTH'S PRESIDENT UNDER ATTACK
description: Inadequate leadership on the part of the president of Dartmouth ''places the college in real jeopardy,'' a faculty study has found.

title: The Mayors Go National
description: New York City is only the biggest beneficiary of the no-strings Federal aid called General Revenue Sharing. Some 39,000 other cities, counties, towns and villages also get a piece, which is one reason President Reagan will have a hard time ending it, as he tried to do last year. People from all over the country met in New York yesterday at Mayor Koch's invitation to form a coalition to fight for the program. Their campaign has muscle; it also has merit.

title: THE STAGE: 'GERTRUDE STEIN AND A COMPANION'
description: IT was from Ernest Hemingway that the late Win Wells took the title of his play, ''Gertrude Stein and a Companion.'' Though Hemingway had variable feelings about Gertrude Stein, he was quite clear in his attitude toward Alice B. Toklas. He found this ''small, very dark,'' hook-nosed woman ''frightening,'' and in ''A Moveable Feast,'' he disdainfully referred to her only as Miss Stein's ''companion.''

title: Pinchas Zukerman To Resign St. Paul Post
description: Pinchas Zukerman has announced he will resign as music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra when his contract expires in June 1987 in order to concentrate on playing the violin.

title: Moscow's View on Nuclear Testing
description: I still want to believe that the Reagan Administration's ''no'' to the Soviet proposal on ending nuclear tests is not its final word.

title: KOHL EXPLAINS REFUSAL TO MOVE AGAINST LIBYA
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl invoked West Germany's national interests and the lives of German expatriates today as he explained his Government's refusal to follow the United States in imposing economic sanctions on Libya.

title: FREE AGENTS RETURN TO FOLD
description: Depending on the day, or perhaps the time of day, the Yankees are or are not interested in acquiring Carlton Fisk. George Steinbrenner said Wednesday the Yankees had terminated their interest in Fisk, then yesterday the owner said they had ''some interest'' in the veteran catcher.

title: Dining Out Guide: With Music
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. GREENE STREET, #101-103 Greene Street (925-2415) -

title: BUDGET LAW AND CONSTITUTIONAL POWERS
description: The major question about the constitutionality of the budget-balancing law now heading for the Supreme Court arises from the mechanism that is supposed to make it work. That is the provision designed to insulate deficit reduction from elective politics by forcing huge spending cuts without requiring Congress to vote on them or the President to set them.

title: TEXACO'S HOME TURF BATTLE
description: The furious battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company returned to a Federal District Court here on Texaco's home turf today, and Judge Charles L. Brieant said he would probably rule Friday on a key aspect of their high-stakes legal dispute.

title: Executive Resigns Post At Realtors Association
description: No one has ever accused Jack Carlson of being wishy-washy.

title: IT'S VERY CLEAR, THE GERSHWINS ARE HERE TO STAY
description: ''THE Rockies may crumble, Gilbraltar may tumble, they're only made of clay,'' goes the lyric of George and Ira Gershwin's final collaboration, ''Our Love Is Here to Stay.'' And in New York these days, the music of the Gershwins looks to be as durable as the love that outlasts geologic wonders.

title: AIDS PATIENTS POSE DIFFICULT NEW TEST FOR CLERICS
description: Sister Patrice Murphy of St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village has long prayed with and comforted the dying, but working with 90 AIDS patients in recent years has tested her in profoundly new ways.

title: 2 Who Disappeared in Guatemala. Forever?
description: It is early April 1985. An Army helicopter roars down to the landing strip at Nebaj, a remote Indian town in northwestern Guatemala. Soldiers are observed hustling two men who look like ''North Americans,'' one tall and blond, the other tall and dark, out of the craft and into a nearby army base. They are never seen again.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Hi-Shear Corp., Torrance, Calif., a subsidiary of Hi-Shear Industries that makes structural fastening systems for aircraft, has appointed H. L. Williamson president.

title: QADDAFI SAYS THE SANCTIONS COULD TURN LIBYA TO SOVIET
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi warned tonight that continued American hostility toward this country would lead to ''more cooperation'' between Libya and the Soviet Union.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'DRINKING IN AMERICA' Intoxication in America is explored in a one-man show that begins performances tonight at 8 at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street. Written and performed by Eric Bogosian, with the dramatic monologues directed by Wynn Handman, ''Drinking in America'' delves into one of the nation's pastimes with slice-of-life vignettes ranging from the comic to the tragic. ''Drinking in America'' will be presented Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 P.M., with matinees Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and Sundays at 3. All tickets are $15. For reservations and information: 246-0393.

title: Gramm-Rudman Lottery
description: The new deficit-reducing law, sponsored by Senators Phil Gramm and Warren B. Rudman, is beginning to make itself felt in social as well as governmental circles in the capital. The Planned Parenthood Federation of America is planning a reception on Capitol Hill next week, and invitations say guests will have an opportunity to ''buy a chance on the new Gramm-Rudman Lottery (tickets are $1, the prize is 50 cents, payable in 1991.)''

title: DUCK GROWERS ON L.I. DWINDLING UNDER PRESSURES OF COSTS AND SUBURBIA
description: The Long Island duck industry, whose world-renowned birds dominated the national market just 20 years ago, has fallen off severely in recent years.

title: JMB Realty Lifts Viacom Holdings
description: JMB Realty increased its stake in Viacom International to 11.78 percent by exercising options for another 615,000 shares of the company's stock. The Chicago-based real estate syndicator had said it owned 1.7 million Viacom shares, which at the time represented about 10 percent of the holdings.

title: Druse Militiamen Clash With Lebanese Army
description: Druse militiamen and Lebanese Army soldiers loyal to President Amin Gemayel, a Christian, fought with artillery and tanks today in the mountains overlooking Beirut.

title: Schools Ask the Wrong Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival Buyout Bid
description: The Rival Manufacturing Company said it had agreed to be acquired in a leveraged buyout transaction by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, an investment banking firm for $17.50 a share in cash.

title: Films by Women
description: ''The Arch,'' a film by the Chinese director Shu Shuen, will open a two-part series devoted to female directors tonight at 8 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. Four films are featured in the first part, which runs Friday nights through January.

title: No Victory For Women
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1986
description: Markets

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $3.4 billion, to $211.39 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: UNION SQUARE AREA GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: The Union Square area, when designed in 1831, served as a gathering place for New York's aristocracy. The Roosevelts lived in the neighborhood, and much of society's cream flocked to the Academy of Music, which stood nearby as the center of the city's theatrical district.

title: PAUL ZUCKERMAN
description: Paul Zuckerman, a Detroit business executive who raised several fortunes for charities and for Israel, died of cancer Wednesday in Harper Hospital in Detroit. He was 73 years old and lived in Franklin, Mich.

title: MUSIC: TWO PHILHARMONIC DEBUTS
description: AS a political symbol, last night's New York Philharmonic concert in Avery Fisher Hall had its immediate importance and possibly an even more significant long-range impact. The reason was that the conductor, Yuri Temirkanov, and the piano soloist, Nikolai Petrov, both making their Philharmonic debuts, are the first Soviet musicians to appear in the United States under the terms of the new U.S.-Soviet cultural exchange agreement signed last November.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate investments of $660,000, or 13 cents a share, for the latest year and $5,262,000, or $1.26 a share, for the previous year.

title: STREISAND ON MAKING HER ALBUM
description: AN old show-business proverb:

title: Just One Problem
description: Woody Hayes, still recovering from a heart attack he suffered a couple of months ago, flew anyway earlier this week to New Orleans, where he accepted the Amos Alonzo Stagg Award from the American Football Coaches Association. Hayes, appearing very frail, nonetheless took the time in his acceptance speech to thank a lengthy list of people, both at Ohio State and elsewhere, for all manner of assistance. Among them was his heart specialist, of whom the longtime Buckeye coach added, ''The only problem is, he's a Michigan man.''

title: ABZUG, IN WESTCHESTER, STUDIES BID FOR CONGRESS
description: Bella S. Abzug, who served parts of Manhattan for three terms in the House of Representatives, is considering running for Congress again - this time from the 20th District of Westchester County.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A GLEAMING new restaurant and carryout off Park Avenue South is doing its share to keep a lid on the 1986 Consumer Price Index. Les Poulets, 27 East 21st Street, offers a tasty grilled half-chicken with a variety of sauces, cottage fries and homemade coleslaw for $4.50 to $4.95, depending on the sauce.

title: CITY POSTPONES SERGEANTS TEST TO PRECLUDE A LEGAL CHALLENGE
description: The Koch administration has indefinitely postponed giving the next Police Department's sergeants examination, scheduled for this month, pending further review of the test by city officials and outside consultants.

title: Whither Shultz?
description: In the early days of the Republic, men who accepted appointment as Secretary of State were often able to make the giant step up to the Presidency later on. Six of them, beginning with Thomas Jefferson, succeeded in that considerable advance, but it has not happened since James Buchanan served as Secretary for James K. Polk in 1845-49 and made it to the White House in 1856.

title: Third Seattle Attack Victim Dies as Result of His Injuries
description: Charles Goldmark, a 41-year-old lawyer whose family was viciously attacked on Christmas Eve, died today at Harborview Medical Center.

title: Director's Chest Pains Delay 'Social Security'
description: Andrew Bergman's play ''Social Security,'' which was to have opened on Broadway on March 27, has been postponed at least one week because its director, Mike Nichols, has experienced chest pains, according to a spokesman for the show.

title: Capital Cities Picks President for ABC
description: The Capital Cities/American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that John B. Sias would become president of its ABC division.

title: Jordan Still Out
description: Any hopes the Chicago Bulls may have had of getting Michael Jordan back in the lineup soon suffered a setback yesterday when doctors said he would have to continue to wear a cast on his broken left foot.

title: Women and Health In Bronx History
description: It must have something to do with sex.

title: Consort of Viols
description: The New York Consort of Viols will play English music of the 16th and 17th centuries at Corpus Christi Church Sunday afternoon at 3.

title: Jet's Landing Gear Collapses
description: A Delta Air Lines Boeing 727 crash-landed today when its landing gear collapsed at Memphis International Airport, but the 35 passengers and crew members were evacuated without injury, an airline spokesman said. The jet, bound for New York, had taken off from the airport at 8:50 A.M., but turned back when a warning light indicated trouble with the landing gear, the spokesman said. The jetliner had almost come to a halt when the left landing gear partially collapsed.

title: Arrests at Temple Mount
description: The police arrested three right-wing Jewish nationalists today when they tried to hoist an Israeli flag at the Temple Mount, a site holy to the Moslem world as well as to Judaism.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A CRIMINAL COMEDY. By Julian Symons. 220 pages. Viking. $14.95. THE FACE BEHIND THE MASK. By

title: 2 KOREAS IN ACCORD
description: North and South Korea have made the first steps toward easing differences that had raised fears of a Soviet-bloc boycott of the Summer Games scheduled in 1988 for Seoul, South Korea, officials at an International Olympic Committee negotiating session said today.

title: More for Your Buck
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT'S a surprise birthday party for Joey Adams, see, and nobody knows how old he is. Kaye Ballard says: ''I saw him in vaudeville when I was a little girl.'' Harvey Fierstein says, ''I heard him on radio when I was a little girl.''

title: HOW SMITHSONIAN BOUGHT LONG-LOST PERSIAN ART
description: At a dinner party in Paris last winter, Laure Lowry of Williamstown, Mass., mentioned to another guest that her son was the curator of Middle Eastern art at the Smithsonian Institution. The other diner replied that he owned some Islamic art he was sure Mrs. Lowry's son would find interesting. He said he had inherited the collection from a man named Henri Vever.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Bruce Silverman has joined Asher/ Gould Advertising, Los Angeles, as a partner, executive vice president and creative director.

title: Upper West Side Show
description: An artist's view of Manhattan's Upper West Side is offered in an exhibition called ''The Best of the West'' at the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street.

title: Shavian Excerpts
description: Excerpts from George Bernard Shaw's ''Man and Superman'' will be performed by students of the Juilliard Theater Center tonight at 8 at the American Irish Historical Society, 991 Fifth Avenue, at 80th Street.

title: BROTHER OF HONORS STUDENT FROM HARLEM GOES ON TRIAL
description: A defense lawyer charged in court yesterday that the plainclothes police officer who fatally shot Edmund Perry, a 17-year-old Harlem honors student, last June was drunk at the time.

title: ROCKETS NOW 19-0 AT HOME
description: John Lucas sparked a second-half comeback that erased a 17-point halftime deficit and rallied the Houston Rockets to a 120-110 victory tonight over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: REGENTS PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY ABOUT GROSS
description: A Board of Regents panel heard more than three hours of legal arguments yesterday in Manhattan on whether the New York State Health Department had jurisdiction to charge Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, and one of his deputies with professional misconduct.

title: GEORGETOWN FINDS LIFE AFTER EWING
description: With Georgetown holding a cozy 11-point lead over Connecticut, Francis Rienzo leaned back in his seat at the Capital Centre Wednesday night and reflected on life without Patrick Ewing.

title: TIMKEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Barry Harris Trio
description: The pianist Barry Harris and his trio will play be-bop tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, at 29th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tickets are $8.

title: LOWER CANCER RISK IS FOUND IN WOMEN WHO ARE ATHLETIC
description: Women who begin athletic training in their youth establish a style of living that significantly lowers their risk of developing cancer of the breast and reproductive organs, a Harvard University study has concluded.

title: Shift at Republic
description: The Republic Gypsum Company, a Dallas-based paperboard and wallboard maker, said yesterday that O. Max Montgomery had resigned as president and chief executive and would be replaced by Phil Simpson, who will retain his title as chairman. Republic was founded by Mr. Simpson's family in 1961. Under Mr. Montgomery, who joined Republic in 1964, the company acquired two large paper mills in 1983 that helped double production at its wallboard plant in Duke, Okla.

title: RESTAURANTS' WORST PATRONS ARE THE NO-SHOWS
description: The large number of restaurant patrons who failed to honor reservations over the busy holiday season, particularly on New Year's Eve, has prompted several New York restaurateurs to reconsider whether they will be open next Dec. 31, and if they are, whether they will require deposits.

title: National Archives; 'Uncle Sam Speaks'
description: Never mind the Government's long campaign by way of Presidential warnings, Administration seminars and fact-finding missions to stir the public about a Communist threat in Central America. What about the Federal campaign by way of simple paper broadside to stir the public to consume more carp?

title: Europe Shies From Pesticide
description: America's friends are making a lot of excuses not to go along with sanctions against Libya for supporting terrorism. Most of the Europeans express their ''sympathy,'' as well they might because most of the attacks have been on their territory and their citizens have been victims.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With regard to the American threat, there will be more cooperation between Libya and the Soviet Union.'' - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. [ A6:2. ]

title: McCOVEY'S TOUGHEST OPPONENT
description: He recalled that first 4-for-4 day against Robin Roberts and he recalled a few of the 521 home runs and he recalled the line drive straight at Bobby Richardson's glove.

title: CRASH INVESTIGATORS, LACKING ANSWERS, HEAD BACK TO GANDER
description: Four weeks after a chartered DC-8 crashed at Gander, Newfoundland, killing 248 U.S. servicemen and eight crew members, investigators are still looking for a cause and are returning to the crash site to search for clues in the scattered wreckage.

title: GUATEMALAN CALLS A REGIONAL MEETING
description: Guatemala's President-elect said today that he would convene a meeting of Central American Presidents here next week.

title: Amen
description: Most authors' acknowledgments of indebtedness in their new books are a soggy combination of overstated gratitude and false humility.

title: Postal Service Rescinds Some Rate Increases
description: Postage rate increases for certain newspapers and nonprofit organizations, scheduled to go into effect Jan. 18, were rescinded today by the United States Postal Service.

title: 7 ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL IN CHILD SEX ABUSE CASE
description: A municipal court judge ruled today that seven teachers and administrators of the McMartin Preschool must stand trial on charges of sexually abusing 14 children who attended the school.

title: FARM LOAN AIDE WHO SHOT HIMSELF 'JUST CRACKED,' FRIEND SAYS
description: A supervisor for the Farmers Home Administration who killed his family and himself Wednesday was frustrated because his efforts to go by the rules had failed to help farmers in financial trouble, friends and clients say.

title: LOUISVILLE BEATEN BY MEMPHIS
description: The junior center William Bedford scored 20 points tonight to lead the Memphis State Tigers to a 73-71 Metro Conference victory over the Louisville Cardinals.

title: SUNSHINE DESERTS GULFSTREAM
description: If this keeps up much longer, the biggest city in the so-called Sunshine State will have to be renamed Miami-by-the-Amazon.

title: Commodore Move
description: Commodore International Ltd. said that it would close its semiconductor manufacturing facility in Costa Mesa, Calif., and consolidate its operations in its Norristown, Pa. semiconductor plant in an effort to reduce costs.

title: U.S. BACKS AWAY FROM ASKING WEST FOR CURBS ON LIBYA
description: Faced with a virtually universal refusal by other countries to join in sanctions against Libya, the Administration backed away today from pressing its allies to take immediate steps against the Tripoli Government, which it accuses of supporting terrorism.

title: BINGHAM FAMILY TO SELL LOUISVILLE MEDIA HOLDINGS
description: Barry Bingham Sr., chairman and patriarch of a Kentucky media empire that includes The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times newspapers, announced yesterday that the family's communications holdings were for sale.

title: Thrift Crisis Report Made
description: The crisis in the Maryland savings and loan industry was caused primarily by a failure of the regulatory system and by the owners of thrift institutions who used depositors' money for their own purposes, a special state counsel said today.

title: I.R.S. TO WITHHOLD TAX REFUNDS OWED LOAN DEFAULTERS
description: The Internal Revenue Service will withhold any 1985 income tax refunds due to 750,000 people who have defaulted on Government loans, the Office of Management and Budget announced today.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
All This and Baseball
description: Syd Thrift, the general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, may not be able to guarantee the city a pennant in his first season, but he seems determined to make sure that the 1986 Pirates are the best educated, most articulate and, well, the thriftiest, players in the major leagues. According to Thrift, spring training will include courses in such subjects as public speaking, drug abuse, personal finance and the intricacies of the nation's tax laws.

title: Callers Besiege Kodak on Trade-Ins
description: The Eastman Kodak Company was flooded yesterday with calls from owners of its suddenly obsolete instant camera seeking information about a company exchange offer.

title: INDIA'S HOMESPUN GETS THE DESIGNER LOOK
description: In the heart of India's bustling commercial capital, two young designers are working with older, dedicated followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi to give new life and shape to khadi, the rough homespun cotton fabric Ghandi called ''the livery of freedom'' but which has fallen into a deep decline.

title: Quarter-Century for Bridge
description: The Throgs Neck Bridge will turn 25 years old tomorrow, and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is celebrating, in its fashion.

title: 2 Financings From Triangle
description: Triangle Industries is offering convertible debentures and convertible preferred stock through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.

title: PEN INVITATION TO SHULTZ CRITICIZED
description: Several members of the PEN board of directors and one of its former presidents have criticized the decision to invite Secretary of State George P. Shultz to be a welcoming speaker at the International PEN Congress that opens at the New York Public Library on Sunday.

title: HEAR THOSE RUBBER STAMPS ROAR
description: As Albert V. Casey, the new Postmaster General, stepped to the microphone this week at his first news conference, he was asked what he expected to do. He never got a chance to reply.

title: SCREEN: 'ALEXINA,' BY FERET
description: AT the far ends of the spectrum of human behavior, film makers like Francois Truffaut (''The Wild Child,'' ''The Story of Adele H.'') and Werner Herzog (''The Mystery of Kaspar Hauser'') have located extremes that cast light on what we consider to be normal. Rene Feret has attempted something similar in ''The Mystery of Alexina,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street 1, but his is a more pedestrian view. In ''The Mystery of Alexina,'' a case as bizarre as anything Truffaut or Mr. Herzog ever dealt with is explored solemnly and decorously. Yet it is made to seem strangely unremarkable, and entirely devoid of real mystery.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES 4 IN PURITAN TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the former chief financial officer of the Puritan Fashions Corporation, one of its public relations officials, and two stockbrokers with insider trading.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY might feel ill at ease if he were to wander into the New York clone of his beloved Harry's Bar in Venice and find (a) a stratospherically chic restaurant with an undersized marble-topped bar serving $8 champagne cocktails, (b) a rakish clientele of impeccably preened women paired with more men in pinstripes than at a Yankees doubleheader and (c) not a canal in sight. No, this is not the Harry's Bar of literary fame.

title: Miranda Needs No Improvement
description: ''Infamous'' is Attorney General Meese's word for the Supreme Court's Miranda v. Arizona decision requiring the police to tell suspects their legal rights before questioning them. Mr. Meese has assumed the heavy duty of overturning the decision or finding an alternative. He's wasting his time.

title: The Heart That Fizzled
description: ''The most glamorous piece of technology in the history of cardiac care.'' That was the kind of plaudit drawn by the artificial heart when it was first implanted in a patient three years ago. Because of the endurance of four recipients - Barney Clark, William Schroeder, Murray Haydon and Jack Burcham, a different verdict can now be drawn.

title: PRETORIA POLICY AT ISSUE
description: Union officials joined leaders of the movement against South Africa's policy of racial separation today to call for a consumer boycott of Shell Oil Company products.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Hunter of the Edmonton Oilers has been given a six-game suspension for swinging his stick at a Los Angeles Kings' player Dec. 20. Unless the ruling is appealed, the suspension will begin Thursday . . . Bob Goodman, a former matchmaker for Don King Productions, has been named director of boxing and matchmaking for Madison Square Garden. . . . Al Davis, managing general partner of the Raiders, is the only nonplayer among 15 candidates nominated for the Pro Football Hall of Fame. 3

title: ORION PICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,935,000 for the quarter and $2,685,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: JAMES M. TUNNELL Jr.
description: James M. Tunnell Jr., a former Justice of the Delaware Supreme Court, died Monday at Wilmington Hospital in Wilmington, Del.

title: Skier Injured
description: Debbie Armstrong, the 1984 Winter Olympic women's giant slalom gold medalist, will return to the United States to undergo treatment for the knee injury she suffered yesterday in Badgastein, Austria, where she crashed head-on into a safety net after making a tactical error during the final day of training for World Cup women's downhill races. Miss Armstrong suffered a tear of the inside ligament of her left knee. . . . Citing a desire to spend more time with his family, Mike Gallagher has resigned as coach of the United States men's cross-country team, effective after this season, saying, ''I want to see my boys grow up and you can't be a part-time husband and father just like you can't be a part-time coach.'' Gallagher, a three-time Olympian, has been on the coaching staff since 1980.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $420,000 from prior years' loss carryforwards of foreign subsidiaries for the quarter and year. c-Includes gains of $755,000 for the latest year and $8.1 million for the year-earlier period from the termination of pension plans.

title: SCREEN: 'AMIGOS,' BY ACOSTA
description: ''AMIGOS'' is a good-natured film that seems almost as naive as its hero, a Cuban refugee who arrives in Miami after nearly two decades in prison. After Ramon (Ruben Rabasa) is finally allowed to leave Cuba in the boat exodus from Mariel, he is welcomed to Florida by an old friend who has fared exceedingly well there. Pablo (Reynaldo Medina), Ramon's boyhood friend, is now a suave, properous car salesman with a comfortable life and a beautiful fiancee (Lucy Pereda). He takes the bumbling Ramon under his wing and attempts to give him a quick, enjoyable introduction to the American dream.

title: Economic Scene; Stock Market Gets the Jitters
description: THIS has been a week of nominal records for the stock market. On Tuesday, at his news conference, President Reagan declared: ''The stock market today set a new high again, an all-time high; it's now 1,565, it went up 18 and something.'' But on Wednesday the Dow industrials plunged 39.10, the biggest one-day plunge in history. The decline continued yesterday.

title: FILM: 'BLACK MOON RISING'
description: AT the start of ''Black Moon Rising,' a new, semi-caper movie, the Federal Bureau of Investigation hires a freelance thief named Quint to break into the accounting department of a private company to obtain records needed in a grand jury investigation.

title: Merrill's Stock Bucks the Tide
description: The stock of Merrill Lynch & Company jumped $2.75 a share yesterday, to $38, in heavy trading, amid rumors that any one of a number of major corporations was interested in taking it over. On Monday, the big Wall Street broker topped the list of most-active stocks, climbing $1.50, to $36.25, on a volume of 2.3 million shares.

title: Back on the Field
description: Kenneth Davis, the Texas Christian running back who was suspended from the team with six teammates after they admitted taking illicit payments from a college official, has been invited to play in the Senior Bowl in Mobile, Ala., on Jan. 18, according to bowl officials, who said that National Football League officials had pressed for Davis's appearance in the game, which serves as a showcase for pro scouts.

title: OFFICER TAKES STAND IN HIT-AND-RUN TRIAL OF A POLICE SERGEANT
description: A police officer testified yesterday that he saw a police car ''out of control'' on Park Avenue in Manhattan a few minutes before coming upon two victims of a hit-and-run accident.

title: Aquino Says She'll Fight Violent Communists
description: Corazon C. Aquino, who has expressed willingness to let Communists who renounce violence enter the Government if she becomes president, vowed today to use ''every available resource of the republic'' against any who continue the rebellion.

title: LUCIA CHASE OF BALLET THEATER IS DEAD
description: Lucia Chase, a founder of American Ballet Theater who helped make it one of the world's great dance troupes in her 35 years as the company's co-director, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: JOHN L. WELLER
description: John L. Weller, former vice president of Trans World Airlines Inc., died Saturday after suffering a lung blood clot at the Carriage Hill Nursing Home in Bethesda, Md. He was 75 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL CALLS FOR STEPPED-UP ATTACKS
description: The leader of the outlawed and exiled African National Congress called today for a ''rapid, extensive escalation'' of his organization's war against white rule and said civilians would die in the process.

title: Space Shuttle Repaired; Launching Set for Today
description: Engineers removed a pencil-size sensor to free a stuck valve today and the space agency said it would try for a seventh time Friday to launch the remodeled space shuttle Columbia on its first flight in more than two years.

title: Distance Champs
description: The Indiana Pacers may be last in the National Basketball Association, but they are undeniably first when it comes to putting the ball through the hoop from very long range.

title: RESISTANT GONORRHEA ON INCREASE
description: Cases of a gonorrhea resistant to penicillin are increasing rapidly, Federal health officials said today. For the first time physicans in all 50 states have reported this strain of the diease.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Wait Till Next Year

title: Four Guilty of Killing Three in a Rampage
description: Four men were convicted yesterday of going on a rampage last Feb. 27 in the home of a reputed drug dealer in Brooklyn, killing three people and wounding and torturing seven others, including two children.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
School Bus Seat Belts Voted
description: The Board of Education here has voted to require that seat belts be installed in its school buses. The belts were recommended by the district's school bus safety committee.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $788,000.

title: Workers at Nuclear Plant Disciplined Over Testing
description: The company that owns the Three Mile Island nuclear plant said today that it had disciplined 17 workers for manipulating records of critical tests before the 1979 accident at the reactor.

title: Edmund Fitzgerald, Insurance Executive
description: Edmund Fitzgerald, an insurance executive for whom an ill-fated Great Lakes freighter was named, died here today. He was 90 years old. Mr. Fitzgerald was the former chairman of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: HUBCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SALVADOR REBELS WIDEN THEIR WAR
description: Fulfilling their pledge to extend the war to all parts of the country, leftist guerrillas carried out a surprise sabotage attack early today on this prosperous coffee town, 45 miles west of the capital and far from the rebels' accustomed theater of operations.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,116,772.

title: ISLANDERS REVIVE AGAINST PENGUINS
description: The Islanders, midway through a season that has proved disappointing, produced a surprising renaissance effort tonight at Nassau Coliseum. A 9-0 rout of their closest division rivals, the Pittsburgh Penguins, might have been the last thing expected from a team that had scored only three goals in its last two home games, but tonight the Islanders eliminated a lot of trouble spots.

title: ITALY PLANS TO BAN LIBYA ARMS SALES BUT IS WARY ON FURTHER MOVES
description: The Italian Government, moving two days after a call by President Reagan for worldwide economic sanctions against Libya, announced today that it had decided to ban weapons sales to the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Article 428186 -- No Title
description: The economic toll of the country's first 10,000 AIDS cases will total $6.3 billion, according to the first published estimate of the national economic impact of the disease. The costs include $1.4 billion in hospital expenses and nearly $5 billion in earnings lost because of disability and premature death.

title: BIG PENNZOIL HOLDERS REAP PROFITS
description: A number of institutional owners of the Pennzoil Company took advantage of the stock's wild price swings of this week to snap up profits, fund managers said yesterday.

title: Reagan And Qaddafi
description: Once again President Reagan has shown admirable restraint in response to a terrorist attack that took blameless American lives -and once again he has done it despite his past rhetoric and the pressures of armchair generals.

title: In Honor of Dr. King
description: A concert of jazz, dance and poetry in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will take place tomorrow at 8 P.M. at BACA (Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association) Downtown, 111 Willoughby Street, in Brooklyn (718-596-2222).

title: MOVE ASSAILED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is about to propose rules that would bar most toxic wastes from landfills unless the wastes are first treated to make them harmless, agency officials said today.

title: San Antonio Providing Tax Analysis of Bonds
description: The tax bill approved by the House in mid-December is causing local governments to make extra efforts to assure investors that the bonds are tax exempt, even though the proposed changes have not been approved by the Senate and are not law.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS MILITARY BUDGET CUTS WOULD IMPERIL ARMS TALKS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that without continued increases in United States military spending the Soviet Union would lose interest in an arms control agreement.

title: Animals Die by the Hundreds In Storms in Northwest China
description: One million yaks, horses, sheep and cattle have died and two million other animals are starving in fierce winter weather in China's desolate northwest, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Syrian Is Publicly Hanged
description: A 25-year-old Syrian convicted of spying for Israel was hanged in a public square here today, one day after his elder brother was executed on the same charge, witnesses said.

title: MAJOR AMERICAN BANKS FREEZE LIBYAN DEPOSITS
description: America's biggest banks froze hundreds of millions of dollars in Libyan Government deposits yesterday, carrying out President Reagan's executive order. Although the President's directive left questions, bankers said they were able to put through the basic elements of a deposit freeze because of their experience in 1979 sequestering the assets of Iran.

title: BRITISH MINISTER QUITS IN DISPUTE WITH THATCHER
description: Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, long considered a likely contender for leadership of the Conservative Party, resigned today in a confrontation with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and stalked out of her official residence at 10 Downing Street.

title: FACING SEX SUIT, PRINCETON CLUB ADMITS WOMEN
description: The University Cottage Club, one of Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs, has voted to admit women.

title: NBSC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Epidemic Traced to Feces Of Beavers Is Easing
description: Health officials say an epidemic of intestinal disease attributed to beaver droppings in a backup city reservoir may be nearly under control after striking up to 7,000 people since Thanksgiving.

title: ACAPULCO RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After extraordinary tax charge of $249,000 for the quarter and extraordinary tax credit of $3,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including extraordinary tax credits of $230,000 for the quarter and $508,000 for the year.

title: PENNZOIL IS QUICK TO APPEAL RULING
description: The Pennzoil Company said late today that it had already appealed Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant's decision to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA EXECUTES KILLER: AGE STIRS PROTEST
description: James Terry Roach died in the state's electric chair shortly before dawn today, despite international protests that juvenile offenders should not be executed.

title: How They Brought Down the Granite for Liberty's Pedestal
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTODIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Announced that Jack Lind would manage Denver of the American Association; Gene Dusan would manage Cedar Rapids of the Midwest League, and Jay Ward would manage Vermont of the Eastern League. Rehired Marc Bombard, manager of Tampa of the Florida State League; Jim Lett, manager of Billings of the Northwest League; Sam Mejias, manager of Sarasota of the Gulf Coast League; Jim Hoff, minor-league field coordinator; Ted Kluszewski and Danny Litwhiler, hitting instructors; Harry Dorish and Larry Rothschild, pitching instructors.

title: Hungary's Lessons for Gorbachev
description: In his effort to put new life into the Soviet economy, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is paying close attention to what is happening in Hungary.

title: RE-CREATING REUBEN'S LEGENDARY APPLE PANCAKE
description: When they closed the doors of Reuben's Restaurant in 1966 the only thing left to commemorate the 60-year-old institution was its justly famous cheesecake. It can still be purchased by mail.

title: Koch Should Help Poor New Yorkers
description: Ten years after its fiscal crisis, New York City faces a major challenge - to devise policies that enable a broader segment of the population to share the benefits of a richer local economy. Mayor Koch, re-elected for a third term by an overwhelming margin, should use some of the city's newly acquired wealth to help those on the bottom of the economic ladder.

title: Lendl, Connors Advance to Final
description: Ivan Lendl beat John McEnroe 7-6, 6-3 tonight to advance to the final of the $500,000 A.T.&T. Challenge tennis tournament against Jimmy Connors Saturday.

title: MERITOR FINANCIAL SEEKS THRIFT UNIT
description: The Meritor Financial Group of Philadelphia said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire eight branches and ''other assets'' of the Community Savings and Loan Association from the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund, the thrift institution's court-appointed conservator.

title: LIBYA'S U.S. ASSETS COVER WIDE RANGE
description: Beyond deposits in American banks, the freeze on Libyan Government property that President Reagan ordered this week touches a variety of Libyan interests in the United States, ranging from an enterprise in Houston known as the Waha Oil Company to two sizable banks in New York to choice real estate properties in New York and Washington.

title: Chevron Denies Report Of Libyan Operations
description: A spokesman for the Chevron Corporation has disputed a State Department assertion that Chevron was among the American oil companies that have maintained a presence in Libya.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPANISH IMAGERY The landscape and history of Spain, each reflecting glory, agony and beauty, have inspired generations of Spanish artists, from sculptors and painters to the photographer. This weekend, a new exhibition of the work of Spanish photographers between the world wars opened at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 93d Street (860-1777).

title: WOMEN'S TEAM IS PENALIZED
description: The women's basketball program at Northeast Louisiana University has been placed on probation for one year by the National Collegiate Athletic Association and ruled ineligible for this season's championship for illegally recruiting Chana Perry.

title:
PATENTS;
Laser-Aimed Sighting For a Ballistic Weapon
description: A laser-aimed sighting system for a ballistic weapon, patented this week for the United Technologies Corporation, Hartford, is described as operating with an exceptionally high degree of accuracy.

title: McCoy Tyner Trio
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tomorrow. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Raise for Newsome
description: As a tight end, Ozzie Newsome of the Cleveland Browns sees himself right up there with such highly paid stars as Kellen Winslow of the San Diego Chargers and Todd Christiansen of the Los Angeles Raiders. Now Newsome has the salary to prove it.

title: Tribute to a Grandfather
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato told a Middle Village, Queens, audience last week how he came to be named Alfonse. He noted that he had not dared to ask his father until he was a teen-ager.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Information Aide Is to Confer in Moscow
description: Charles Z. Wick, Director of the United States Information Agency, will leave Sunday for a two-week trip to the Soviet Union to discuss implementation of cultural accords, the U.S.I.A. announced today.

title: U.S. Denies It Has Plan To Shorten Workweek
description: The Reagan Administration has no plans for shortening workers' hours throughout the Government as a way to help bring spending and the deficit within targets set in the new budget-balancing law, although some agencies may choose that course instead of layoffs, the Office of Management and Budget said today.

title: DECISION UNUSUAL, LEGAL SCHOLARS SAY
description: Lawyers and legal scholars were fascinated with yesterday's decision by Judge Charles L. Brieant in the United States District Court in White Plains barring Pennzoil from executing its $11.12 billion judgment against Texaco.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE LIFT OFF DELAYED FOR 7TH TIME, SETTING RECORD
description: A record for space shuttle postponements was set today when the launching of the space shuttle Columbia was delayed a seventh time, on this occasion by driving wind and rain. Disappointed space officials scheduled another attempt for early Sunday.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend in 1985.
