title: OLD ROADHOUSE IS A WAY OF LIFE JUST EAST OF IDAHO
description: When giving directions to his place, Ellis Schanck likes to tell people he lives just 150 feet east of Idaho.

title: A Reputation For Toughness
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight from Catskill, N.Y., is fast gaining a reputation as a hard day's wage among prospective foes.

title: DANBURY HURT BY CARBIDE WOES, BUT GROWTH CONTINUES ANYWAY
description: This western Connecticut city has done well by Union Carbide. In the five years since the company moved from Manhattan to a vast new headquarters here, Carbide has become the city's largest private employer, its biggest taxpayer, and a major source of income for restaurants, stores, realtors, accounting firms and other small businesses.

title: P. D. EASTMAN
description: P. D. Eastman, an author of children's books that sold more than three million copies and that were translated into 10 languages, died of pneumonia Tuesday in a nursing home in Cresskill, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Kaiser Investment
description: The investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., said today that it had acquired an additional 586,800 common shares of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, bringing its total holdings to 6.9 million shares, or 15.7 percent. The shares were bought at prices from $16.46 to $17.50.

title: COMPACT DISKS: AUDIO INDUSTRY'S NEW HOPE
description: When the compact disk player first appeared in the United States three years ago at prices of $1,000 and up, it was viewed by many, including the American electronics industry, as a toy for rich audiophiles.

title: 1 POTATO 2 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: b-Includes losses of $2,241,540 for the quarter and $2,431,592 for the 9 months from restaurant units sold or to be closed by the end of the company's fiscal year ending Jan. 29.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: President Reagan will fly to Grenada next month to confer with Caribbean leaders and honor the 19 American servicemen killed when United States forces stormed the island and ousted its Marxist Government, it was announced today.

title: Skating Away
description: Midway through the campaign, the Edmonton Oilers are on a pace that would give them a regular-season division championship by a margin of about 50 points, threatening the National Hockey League record.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACCORD IN CABINET REPORTED ON PLAN ON MINORITY JOBS
description: Cabinet officials have ironed out most of the sharpest differences within the Administration over a Presidential order for voluntary goals, instead of strict quotas, for Federal contractors in hiring women and minority workers, Administration officials said today.

title: Drug Tie to Title Bout
description: When Stanley Ross, a once-suspended boxer with a lackluster 10-9-1 record, captured the International Boxing Federation cruiserweight title from previously unbeaten Boone Pultz in Washington last Dec. 7, the victory in a 12-round split decision was considered a stunning upset. Now, according to Washington boxing authorities, Ross may be stripped of his title because traces of drugs, reportedly marijuana, were found in his urine.

title: Grandfather Kills Man Over Beating of Child
description: A man walked into the hospital where his 2-year-old grandson, beaten and burned with cigarettes, lay in a coma and killed the man he believed responsible, the police said today.

title: Sir Henry Tucker Dies at 82; Was First Leader of Bermuda
description: Sir Henry Tucker, the first leader of Bermuda's Government, died Thursday night, his family said today. He was 82 years old.

title: Allis-Chalmers
description: CA Ltd., a partnership controlled by Samuel Zell, an investor, said today that it had entered into an option agreement to acquire the equivalent of about 31 percent of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation. The partnerhip said that it had bought the shares to ''undertake a thorough review of the company.''

title: REAGAN SET TO ASK CONGRESS FOR BINDING SPENDING LIMIT
description: President Reagan will ask for a stronger Presidential hand in shaping the Federal budget when he delivers his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, the White House said today.

title: WHEN CHAMPAGNE FLOWED AT THE LATIN QUARTER
description: The regular monthly meeting of The Latin Quarter Showgirls, Inc., will now come to order.

title: PRODUCER PRICES ADVANCE 0.4%
description: Producer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in December, less than half the level of the two preceding months, the Labor Department said today.

title: Soviet to Let Daughter Emigrate With Mother
description: The Soviet authorities today told Irina McClellan, the Soviet wife of an American professor, that her daughter could move with her to the United States.

title: Reputed Terrorist Chief Wins Shorter Sentence in Mexico
description: William Morales, a reputed leader of a terrorist group that wants independence from the United States for Puerto Rico, has won a reduction of his sentence in the death of a Mexican federal judicial police officer.

title: S.E.C. GETS CHURCH TO REFUND MONEY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a Baptist denomination of selling members a retirement plan that could not pay them the benefits the church promised.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Harlem Globetrotters, at Kemper Arena, Kansas City, Mo. Lynette Woodard, the first female Globetrotter, makes her television debut near the University of Kansas, where she was the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's career point leader. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M., live.) College: Virginia Tech at South Carolina, noon (Television - MSG, noon); City College vs. New York University, at Madison Square Garden, 11:30 A.M.; Georgetown vs. St. John's, at Madison Square Garden, 2 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M. Radio -WCBS, 880; 2 P.M.); Notre Dame at DePaul, 4 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.); Southern Methodist at Kansas, 2 P.M. (Television - MSG, 2 P.M.); Pitt at Syracuse, 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); Columbia at Cornell (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 6:30 P.M.); Fordham at St. Peter's, 8:05 P.M. (Television - CTN, 8 P.M. Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); Long Island University at Loyola-Baltimore (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 2 P.M.); Rutgers at Temple (Radio - WCTC, 1450, and WRSU-FM, 88.7; 1 P.M.); Iona at Manhattan, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFAS-FM, 103.9; 8 P.M.); Harvard at Princeton, 7 P.M.; Villanova at Providence, 8 P.M. Exposition National Boat Show, at New York Coliseum, opening day, 10 A.M. The show is making its last appearance at 59th Street and Columbus Circle. Next year, it will move to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: RECORD $5 MILLION PAID FOR CLAVELL NOVEL
description: James Clavell's novel ''Whirlwind,'' the subject of widespread speculation over the last several weeks, has been purchased for $5 million by William Morrow & Company and Avon Books. The purchase price, which includes North American hardcover and paperback rights, far exceeds that paid for similar rights to any other book.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 14
O'NEILL TO SEEK A 2D FULL TERM IN CONNECTICUT
description: William A. O'Neill, saying ''there's much, much more to do,'' formally announced his candidacy today for re-election as Governor of Connecticut.

title: Ford's EXP Car
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had introduced a restyled version of its EXP car. Ford said the car is a two-door hatchback intended to appeal to people under 30 years old, who account for 25 percent of American car buyers. The car has new aerodynamic features, a larger engine and more standard equipment than its former version.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 11, 1986
description: Companies

title: DRAMA AT 10 DOWNING STREET: THATCHER UNDER FIRE
description: The theatrical exit of the Defense Secretary from the Cabinet room at 10 Downing Street, coupled with his detailed indictment of Margaret Thatcher's manner of running her Government, may not have enhanced his own chances of becoming the next leader of the Conservative Party. But there was little doubt among politicians today that the resignation Thursday of the defense chief, Michael Heseltine, cut short a seeming revival in the Prime Minister's political fortunes.

title: Canada Jobless Rate
description: The Canadian job market continued to improve in December as the number of unemployed declined by 8,000, to 1,238,000, and the seasonally adjusted jobless rate dipped to 10 percent, from 10.2 percent in November, the Government's Statistics Canada agency said today. That rate is the lowest since April 1982 when it was 9.8 percent, the last time it was under 10 percent. The yearlong growth in the labor market left the average unemployment rate for 1985 at 10.5 percent, down from 11.3 percent last year and at its lowest level since 1981, when it was 7.5 percent.

title: U.S. HINTS AT SANCTIONS FOR SYRIA BUT SAYS NONE ARE PLANNED NOW
description: Administration officials said today that there was a possibility that economic sanctions similar to those imposed on Libya might be levied against Syria, but that there were no active plans to do so.

title: JOSEPH KRAFT, CAPTIAL COLUMNIST WHOSE WORK RAN IN 200 PAPERS
description: Joseph Kraft, the widely syndicated Washington columnist and author of books and articles on national and foreign affairs, died last night at the Washington Hospital Center, apparently of heart failure. He was 61 years old and lived in the capital.

title: Edward G. Janeway, 84, Dies; Former Senator in Vermont
description: Edward G. Janeway, a former State Senator in Vermont, died yesterday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center at Hanover, N.H., after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived in South Londonderry, Vt.

title: St. Luke's Benefit
description: A special dinner and music event to benefit a church restoration project is planned for Monday from 7 to 10 P.M. at Sazerac House, a restaurant at Charles and Hudson Streets.

title: Dow Falls By 4.70, To 1,513.53
description: Ending a tumultuous week, the stock market yesterday suffered its third consecutive loss, though a minor one. Trading in blue-chip issues at times became frenzied.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Patrick Lindsay, 58; Christie's Auctioneer
description: Patrick Lindsay, head of the Old Masters department of Christie's in London, died of cancer Thursday at his London home. He was 58 years old.

title: I.M.F. Loan to Mexico
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that, as expected, it is making a special $315 million loan to Mexico to help that country deal with last September's earthquakes. The money is repayable in five years, at 7.87 percent interest. The fund said that because of the earthquakes, Mexico may have had additional foreign obligations of as much as $700 million in 1985 alone.

title: COURT HEARTS IMPASSIONED DEBATE OVER LEGALITY OF NEW BUDGET LAW
description: A panel of three Federal judges heard nearly three hours of impassioned debate today on the constitutionality of a new budget-balancing law signed 29 days ago by President Reagan.

title: CASTRO: STILL ALIVE
description: Is Fidel Castro really dead? That question shattered the calm of the State Department's Latin American bureau Tuesday as Spanish- and English-language radio stations and newspapers in Miami phoned in seeking confirmation of a rumor that the Cuban leader had died.

title: Say 'No' to Haiti
description: Every year about this time, President Jean-Claude (Baby Doc) Duvalier looks to protect Haiti's share of American aid by giving the State Department grounds to perceive ''progress'' in his record on human rights. The search for such progress in that hereditary tyranny becomes ever more difficult. This year's offering comes in response to specific U.S. demands: the release from jail of Hubert de Ronceray, a prominent opposition leader accused of harboring ''subversive'' literature, and the return of Radio Soleil, a church-run station banned for criticizing the Government.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an unusual investment gain of $4,344,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 11, 1986
description: International

title: Fielding to Say Farewell
description: Fred F. Fielding, counsel to the President, plans to leave the White House by the time the cherry trees bloom and has been discussing a new job with several law firms and businesses in Washington and elsewhere.

title: Comdisco Stock
description: Comdisco Inc.'s stock dropped sharply today after the company said Thursday that it was contesting a $200 million Internal Revenue Service adjustment to three years of taxable income, analysts said. The stock closed at $20.375, down $6.50. Comdisco's net income was $7.1 million, $15.6 million and $29.4 million, respectively, in 1980, 1981 and 1982, the three years contested by the Federal tax agency.

title: ON THE LITERARY CONGRESS AND WRITERS' PROBLEMSnomics and; Americans Exclude The Globe
description: The American branch of PEN, the writers' organization, is a yeomanly group that holds contests for first novelists and protests the incarceration of writers who are prisoners of conscience abroad. Next week, for the first time since 1966, it hosts the annual congress of its parent body -a rare occasion when American writers in any numbers take notice of a world beyond our own borders.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION/ INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net loss.

title: FRYAR WOUND TIED TO QUARREL
description: Two months ago, Irving Fryar of the New England Patriots scored on a 77-yard punt return, stopped in the end zone and gave a sweeping bow to his wife, who was sitting in the stands.

title: CAGBARET: MICHAEL FEINSTEIN AT THE ALGONQUIN
description: Michael Feinstein, the 29-year-old singer and pianist who has spent years cataloguing the work of Ira Gershwin, Harry Warren and Oscar Levant, is an avid student of American show music. But the Los Angeles-based musician, who opened an extended engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday, is also a natural entertainer whose curatorial experience supplies his act with a wealth of humorous show-business lore that he skillfully incorporates as running patter.

title: OFFICER TESTIFIES ABOUT FATAL HIT-AND-RUN SITE
description: A New York City police officer testified yesterday that there were no tire marks at the scene of a hit-and-run accident on Park Avenue last March in which one pedestrian was killed and another injured.

title: Canada Bank's New Chairman
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that Allan R. Taylor, its president and chief operating officer, will become chairman and chief executive on June 1.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $843,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,066,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GOING UP: THE PRICE OF COFFEE
description: THE price of coffee beans began rising quietly in September, took several small leaps in October and November and then, in the beginning of December, began rising almost too quickly for the wholesale and retail markets, and for coffee roasters, to keep pace.

title:
PATENTS;
Audible Sound Identifies $1 to $20 Bills for Blind
description: An audible security validator for use by the blind was patented this week. It identifies bills from $1 to $20 and reports the amount by recorded sound.

title: The Fine Print In Health Plans
description: THE increasing complexity of corporate health plans has put an added burden on employees who benefit from them. Not only are there likely to be major or minor variations among plans from company to company, but there could also be alternatives within each plan that affect treatment and reimbursement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Syrians are intelligent, they'll do what the Iraqis did and get rid of Abu Nidal.'' - Robert B. Oakley, head of the State Department's counterterrorism office. [ 5:1. ]

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results include after-tax merger expenses of $1.8 million for the latest quarter and $2.2 million for the latest year related to its proposed merger with Fleet Financial Group Inc.

title: House of Convicted Spy In Norfolk Is Defaced
description: The house of John A. Walker Jr., vacant since June when he was charged with running a spy ring for the Soviet Union, has been defaced by vandals, the police say.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kirk Gibson and Tom Brookens, who signed new contracts with the Detroit Tigers this week, agreed to provisions requiring the players to submit to drug tests, according to the Tigers' president, Jim Campbell. The Major League Players Association, however, has filed a grievance, contending that the provisions violate the union's master contract with team owners. . . . Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, underwent successful coronary bypass surgery at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., according to hospital officials. . . . The University of Tennessee is considering revoking the scholarships of two former football players who were arrested this week on felony drug charges.

title:
ON THE LITERARY CONGRESS AND WREITERS' PROBLEMS;
Why Invite Shultz?
description: When 1,000 writers convene tomorrow for the 48th international conference of PEN, the writers' and poets' organization, dedicated to the free expression of ideas and the enlightenment that comes of an uncensored world literature, they will be joined by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He is to deliver an address at the opening ceremonies.

title: RIVER FOREST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $105,091 on the sale of a loan portfolio.

title: Caterpillar Shift
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it had changed its mind and would make D6 tractors at both its Davenport, Iowa, and Glasgow, Scotland, plants. Last year, Caterpillar said it would make these machines only in Glasgow because of substantially lower costs. Since then, it said the Davenport plant had initiated major cost reduction programs.

title: EUROPEANS WILL DISCUSS CALL FOR LIBYA SANCTIONS
description: Foreign ministers from the 12 European Economic Community nations plan to meet in The Hague this month to discuss President Reagan's call for economic sanctions against Libya, the Dutch Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Spanish Police Free Kidnapped Industrialist
description: The Spanish police today freed a kidnapped Basque industrialist, arrested 20 people and seized arms in raids that dealt a serious blow to Basque separatist guerrillas, officials said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Hypercharge, which is thought to push up against falling objects, against the force of gravity, is a believed to be a function of the mass and the atomic composition of a given object, so the small ball would fall slightly faster than the large one. 2. Less sweeping. 3. The medical and dental records of the passengers were on the plane, contrary to Army regulations, and were destroyed in the crash. 4. Yuri Temirkanov, chief conductor of the Kirov Opera in Leningrad, was able to resume his career as a guest conductor in the United States. His American appearances were canceled in 1980 as a result of a cultural freeze between the United States and the Soviet Union. 5. A new postulated three-dimensional map of part of the universe shows it to be composed of gigantic ''bubbles,'' with the stars and galaxies, probably including our Milky Way, gathered on the surfaces. 6. Unemployment. 7. The Cleveland Indians, the St. Louis Browns and the Chicago White Sox. 8. After announcing that he would not run for re-election this year, Senator Gary Hart denied that he was declaring his candidacy for the 1988 Presidential campaign and affirmed that he still had an interest in being President. 9. In terms of points, it was slightly more than the 38.33-point decline in 1929. In percentage terms, this week's decline of nearly 2.5 percent was much less than the 12.8 percent decline in 1929. 10.

title: Four Survive Knockout 8Play Tri-state Regional Event
description: Four major events were in progress simultaneously Thursday at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Mississippi Families Start Moving Out of Shacks
description: Families living along a drainage ditch dubbed ''Sugar Ditch'' began moving from dilapidated shacks into mobile homes Thursday after state officials freed funds to allow utility hookups.

title: QUEBEC DOWNS OILERS
description: Paul Gillis scored a disputed game-winning goal with 3 minutes 12 seconds remaining in the final period tonight and Peter Stastny scored twice to rally the Quebec Nordiques to a 5-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: BISHOP TUTU CALLS DR. KING INSPIRATION TO BLACKS
description: In a speech today commemorating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luthur King Jr., Bishop Desmond M. Tutu praised the slain civil rights leader as being ''part of a great tradition of American blacks who have served to inspire us black South Africans in our struggle for justice.''

title:
PATENTS;
Reactor Aids Power Efficiency
description: A DESIGN for a nuclear fission reactor that will use high-temperature liquid fuels was patented this week for the Department of Energy. The inventor is Vladimir Minkov, a staff member at the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois, which is operated by the University of Chicago.

title: Hank Mobley Quartet
description: The saxophonist Hank Mobley will lead a quartet, with Lodi Carr as guest singer, tonight at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, below 23d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $7 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-PROSECUTOR GETS 3 YEARS IN DRUG THEFTS
description: A former Federal prosecutor was sentenced to a three-year prison term yesterday for stealing drugs and cash from the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE POWER SNACK
description: In a town where there is much talk about power lunches and two-martini expense account meals, there are alternatives for the executive who wants to eat simply, and silently.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RUTH KEMPER
description: Ruth Kemper, a violinist, teacher, conductor and the executive director of the Turtle Bay Music School from 1956 to 1969, died Dec. 31 at her home in New York City. She was 83 years old.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TV VIGILANTE THEMES COME WITH A QUALIFER
description: Vigilantism, a theme of many popular feature films from ''Death Wish'' to ''Rambo,'' has in recent months emerged as a major preoccupation of television as well. But because of the scrutiny practiced by the networks' broadcast standards departments, the point of view expressed in these television movies is different from that of their wide-screen counterparts.

title: New Offer for Blues
description: Less than three years after Harry Ornest stepped in to buy the Blues to keep the National Hockey League team from being sold, a new group of Canadian investors has offered to buy the team, this time with plans to move it to Hamilton, Ontario. The new effort is led by Michael Gobuty, a former president of the Winnipeg Jets.

title: COMMONWEALTH BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chevron U.S.A.
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. said it would close its Bakersfield, Calif., refinery within a few months because the 26,000-barrel-a-day refinery was no longer economical to operate. Chevron U.S.A., the chief domestic subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, continues to operate 11 other refineries in the United States with a total capacity of 2.1 million barrels a day.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes additional interest income of $2,053,000, or 31 cents a share, from the payoff of four participating loans.

title: MARK JACKSON DEVELOPING HIS POTENTIAL
description: Mark Jackson paused for a second, then replied: Yes, he would try to make an appearance. But the tone of his voice Thursday suggested that he would likely pass on going to Madison Square Garden to see North Carolina play Fordham in a game that turned out to be a rout.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After loan writeoffs of $615,000 for the quarter and $1.1 million for the 9 months.

title: GRACE C. ENGLISH
description: Grace C. English, a retired New York City school principal, died Tuesday after a brief illness at Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood, N.J. She was 79 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: What Ohio Is Doing to Encourage Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Cities Fills Post
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that Michael P. Mallardi had been named a senior vice president of the corporation and president of the ABC broadcasting division. Mr. Mallardi, 51 years old, has served as executive vice president and chief financial officer of the American Broadcasting Companies since 1975. In his new post, he will be responsible for all of Capital Cities/ABC's television stations, radio and broadcast operations and engineering as well as ABC Video Enterprises. The move, which industry experts had foreseen, follows by a day the appointment of John B. Sias to succeed Frederick S. Pierce as president of ABC.

title: Botnick to Head Hospital Agency
description: A political confidant of Mayor Koch, Victor E. Botnick, was named chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday. Mr. Botnick, who has worked as an assistant to Mr. Koch since he was a Representative, will continue as a mayoral adviser.

title:
PATENTS;
Razor Blade With Gel
description: An all-in-one shaver, patented this week by John Cataudella of Rosemont, Ill., is a razor blade with a supply of shave gel.

title: Transco Stock Rise Linked to Wagner
description: The Transco Energy Company's stock rose sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after reports circulated that Wagner & Brown, a closely held energy concern, was accumulating the company's shares.

title: For The Love Of Error
description: Dr. Virginia Miles of Englewood, N.J., wants to know how that goose maneuvered itself into Charles Dickens's ''A Christmas Carol.'' For years she has put up with presentations of the story that have Scrooge buying the goose for Tiny Tim and family, an error ''now set in concrete,'' she says.

title: WARD TO NAME SERGEANTS BEFORE TEST
description: Police Commissoner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that because he has so many sergeant's positions to fill, he cannot wait for the city, its consultants and the United States Attorney's office to prepare a new sergeant's test.

title: INVESTOR AIDS EUROPEAN WESTLAND OFFER
description: A bid by the United Technologies Corporation and Fiat S.p.A. to rescue Britain's financially troubled helicopter maker, Westland P.L.C., has been set back by large purchases of the company's stock by an investor advocating a rival European offer.

title: I.R.S. to Investigate Status of Iranian Fund
description: The Internal Revenue Service says it will investigate the tax-exempt status of the Iran Relief Fund, a group that Federal officials have linked with an Iranian terrorist organization.

title: OPERA: 'ROMEO' AT THE MET
description: Let's start with the celebrated ''five w's.'' The who, what, when and where in this case are easy - Charles Gounod's ''Romeo et Juliette'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Thursday night - but this listener is still trying to figure out why.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Per share net asset value in the latest period was after a capital gain distribution of $2.34 paid in February 1985. Assets figures represent net assets.

title: Reagan to Honor Wilkins
description: President Reagan is to make a posthumous award Thursday to Roy Wilkins, the head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who died in 1981 at the age of 80. The award, a special medal, will be given to his widow, Aminda, at the White House.

title: BANCO DE PONCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,488,459. The year-earlier figures were restated.

title: CANADA SUPPORTS U.S. ON SANCTIONS
description: Canada announced a series of steps tonight in support of the Reagan Administration's sanctions against Libya.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Classical Record Center Relocated to E. 86th St.
description: For some, Bremen House is better known for wurst than for Mozart. But classical record buffs have long appreciated the food store, at 220 East 86th Street, for its fine selection of exclusive imports of such European labels as German E.M.I., British E.M.I. and Harmonia Mundi.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Attention Seeker
description: Coach Bill Fitch, upset that his Rockets had let Golden State back into a game that Houston, after a struggle, finally won: ''This model doesn't come with a cruise control. I tried to tell them that several times, but I kept feeling like a snake charmer with a deaf cobra.''

title: Much More Must Be Done About Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXACO VICTORIOUS IN U.S. COURT TEST OF PENNZOIL CASE
description: Texaco Inc. won a major victory yesterday in its legal battle with the Pennzoil Company when a Federal judge ruled that Texaco would not have to post a $12 billion bond to appeal the tangled court case in Texas.

title: PEN CONGRESS TO OPEN WITHOUT SOVIET WRITERS
description: Almost 700 authors from more than 40 nations are descending on New York this weekend for the biggest international assembly of writers ever held in the United States. But, to the disappointment of the sponsors, the Russians are not coming.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUFFIELD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $109,880 for the quarter and year. c-The company did not report per share figure because it converted to a stock form in June 1984. The per share figures reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in December 1985.

title: Growing Old at Home
description: To reduce the costs of home health care services under Medicare, the Office of Management and Budget proposes charging about $5 for each home visit. Such a fee, it figures, will discourage physicians from ordering more home nursing care than is necessary, and patients from asking for it.

title: Jersey to Study Radon Hazards
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today establishing a $3.2 million study of radon contamination in seven central and northern New Jersey counties.

title: CABARET: LARRY ADLER AND REPRODUCING PIANO
description: Two of the most unusual performers to have graced the ''Great Stage'' at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) in the last four years - the reproducing piano and the mouth-organ virtuoso Larry Adler - have been brought back to perform as a team for the next three weeks.

title: SUPREMA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit gain of $177,500 and a gain of $759,000 from a debt settlement. c-Net loss. Year-ago results are for the 6 months ended July 31, 1984. They are not comparable because results from American Suprema, acquired in February 1984, are only included in that period.

title: Scalp Treatment
description: Michigan's basketball coach, Bill Frieder, whose second-ranked Wolverines are 15-0, was assessing the Big Ten race the other day when the subject turned to Michigan State. The Spartans, coached by Frieder's baldish 58-year-old friend, Jud Heathcoate, are a surprising 10-3 after winning at Indiana last week.

title: DEPT. FO SEXISM, BUREAU OF SO-WHAT
description: Grant P. Thompson became an instant celebrity this week.

title: Closed Hearing On Parole Fought
description: The Ulster County District Attorney asked a judge today to allow him to appear at a parole hearing for a convicted killer who was granted clemency by Governor Cuomo.

title: Don't Make a Target Of Retired People
description: To the Editor:

title: A RARE GLIMPSE OF COLONEL QADDAFI
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Reagan Administration's symbol of international terrorism, says he was born in the Islamic month of Muharram, the month of peace.

title: CREDIT UNIONS BOOM ON CAMPUS
description: Students around the nation have turned to campus credit unions as an alternative source of tuition loans at a time when Federal funds for education have been cut back.

title: Islamic Meeting Postpones Decision on Anti-U.S. Action
description: Arab foreign ministers attending the Islamic Conference Organization meeting here said today that they had postponed a decision on whether to impose sanctions on the United States in retaliation for its economic boycott of Libya.

title: 3 ARE KILLED AND 500 ARRESTED IN SIKH PROTESTS IN THE PUNJAB
description: At least 3 people were killed and 500 Sikhs were reported arrested today in clashes between the police and Sikh extremists staging an anti-Government protest throughout the northern state of Punjab.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of inventory of about $1.1 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Letter: On Refugee Rights; Towns as Instruments of Sanctuary
description: To the Editor:
