Proposal for 'Ruckus'
description: When Red Grooms's monumental 10,000-square-foot sculpture ''Ruckus Manhattan'' first appeared in 1975, critics were dazzled by ''the delightfully looney three-dimensonal re-creation of lower Manhattan,'' as one put it.

title: JAROSLAV SEIFERT, CZECH POET, IS DEAD
description: Jaroslav Seifert, the Czechoslovak poet who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1984, died of a heart ailment yesterday in a Prague hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Old Environmental Crew
description: Business suits mixed with blue jeans and hiking boots Thursday evening, as the Sierra Club gave a party to celebrate its new New York City headquarters in a loft at 625 Broadway, near Houston Street.

title:
PATENTS;
Proof on Plastic Hinge
description: For his employer, the Petro Plastics Company, a small concern in Garwood, N.J., Rommel J. Woodland invented a plastic hinge.

title: COLLECTIVE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months results includes an extraordinary gain of $307,000.

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: Zondervan Stake
description: A group of investors said it holds 247,541 common shares of the Zondervan Corporation, or 6.13 percent of the Bible publisher's shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said that it does ''not intend to be a passive investor'' in Zondervan.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $16,556,018, or 82 cents a share.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect an approximate charge of $1.7 million relating to the company's certified home health agency business and a charge of $300,000 from an equipment inventory writeoff.

title: Another Defector
description: For the third time in less than a year, a Czechoslovak hockey player has defected to the West with the assistance of a National Hockey League team, but if the new defector, Karel Svoboda, has visions of a lucrative N.H.L. contract, he has another vision coming according to his sponsors. ''Apparently he's just an average hockey player,'' said Serge Savard, the general manager of the Montreal Canadiens, who said the team had assisted the 25-year-old forward's defection to West Germany last month only as a favor to his 19-year-old brother, Petr Svoboda, who has been with the Canadiens since 1984.

title: FOR ISRAEL, POLITICS ON SUNDAY, N.F.L. ON MONDAY
description: Only in Israel could you find Jews watching ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' on a pirate evangelical Christian television station broadcasting from predominantly Shiite Moslem southern Lebanon.

title: JOHN MCENROE GIVES $10,000 TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: John McEnroe, the tennis star, has donated $10,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for the third year in a row.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a writedown of $1,292,000 relating to property, plant and equipment, primarily in the company's oilfield services and products businesses. c-Net income.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AN ERA ENDS AT CONTROL DATA
description: William C. Norris, a giant figure in the history of the computer industry, retired today as chairman and chief executive of the Control Data Corporation, a company he founded and headed for 29 years but which is now in a fight for its life.

title: Austrian Wins Downhill Race
description: Katrin Gutensohn of Austria mastered the tricky Graukogel course today to edge two Canadians and win the third women's World Cup downhill ski race of the season.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Following are excerpts of the findings and conclusions of United States District Court Judge Charles L. Brieant in Texaco Inc. v. Pennzoil Company: Jurisdiction Venue is proper in this district. The plaintiff has its principal office at White Plains, N.Y., and defendant does business in the Southern District of New York. The claims arose in this district. Personal jurisdiction over the defendant is satisfied by its presence in this district. Irreparable Harm

title: THE HAWK LIVES
description: Weather in Chicago is generally an idiosyncratic factor. And both the Los Angeles Rams and the Chicago Bears have naturally addressed it in relation to their National Football Conference championship game at Soldier Field tomorrow morning. (Morning is correct, since the game, for the benefit of television markets, will begin at 11:30 A.M., Chicago time.) The Rams left the warm and gentle breezes of California and landed in Chicago Thursday night. ''My own personal experience is, the first time you walk out to extreme weather, you think you're going to die within six minutes,'' said their coach, John Robinson. ''There is a mental adjustment that takes place.''

title: AFGHAN EMIGRES JOYOUS AT BEING FREED BY U.S.
description: The first thing the Singh family did when they got home to Queens was to go to the Sikh temple and offer thanks that Mohan had been freed at last.

title: A Lunch Bunch
description: One of the newest exclusive groups in town has no official name, but it might well be called the Latin American Caucus. It is made up of as many as 45 Washington-based ambassadors from Latin America who now gather for lunch once a month to get better acquainted with this country by listening to, and questioning, top American officials.

title: Prisoner and Wife Held In Plot to Kidnap Official
description: A convict serving time in a murder-for-hire plot and his wife have been arrested on charges that they planned to kidnap Gov. Bob Graham in a bid for the convict's freedom, the authorities said.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company did not report year- ago per share figures because it went public in November 1984.

title: PEETE LEADS BY THREE SHOTS
description: The Calvin Peete green-and-fairway-striking machine (patent pending) was fine-tuned today as the 42-year-old Floridian gained a commanding lead in the third round of the 34th annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $500,000 for the quarter and the year and a pre- tax gain of $1,250,000 for the year related to the settlement of a patent lawsuit. c-Net loss after a provision of $2.5 million as a reserve for potential loss on receivables related to the 1981 divestiture of Glas-Craft.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT MONTREAL
description: With the eyes of Rangers past watching from several different points, the Rangers rose up last night.

title: THATCHER ASSERTS STRIKES ON LIBYA COULD SOW CHAOS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, arguing that terrorism has to be fought by legal means, warned today that retaliatory strikes against targets in Libya might produce ''much greater chaos.''

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gain of $251,000 from Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred dividend.

title: Article 624886 -- No Title
description: The sale of the Louisville Courier-Journal and Louisville Times Company is likely to be the largest newspaper sale ever. Analysts say that the Kentucky newspapers alone, only one component of the Bingham family empire, could fetch anywhere from $250 million to $300 million.

title: Pceptions of Marvels
description: IN THE PENNY ARCADE. By Steven Millhauser. 164 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. The words ''wonder,'' ''magic,'' ''mystery'' and ''secret'' percolate through these stories by Steven Millhauser, surfacing here and there, everywhere, like talismans to an enchanted world. Indeed Mr. Millhauser and his characters, however varied, all seem blessed with a child's easy access to the world of imagination and dreams - they're open to the transformations worked on nature by time and art, and they're transfixed by the beauty in, say, the tiny gears of an antique clock, in the changing silhouette of the moon, in the unexpected appearance of a silver blimp in the sky. The sound of feet running on wet sand; the curve of sunlight on an ocean wave; the shape of a snow angel on a field; the sound of sand sifting through an hourglass - all hold, for them, the possibility of wonder.

title: MANES IS FOUND BLEEDING IN CAR HALTED BY POLICE
description: Donald R. Manes, the Borough President of Queens, was found by the police in his car near Shea Stadium early yesterday morning, bleeding heavily from a slashed wrist and an injured leg.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RATES JUMP AS BONDS FALL AGAIN
description: Treasury bond prices plunged late yesterday, with the longer maturities bearing the brunt of the selling.

title: UNION AND A.T.& T. SEPARATE PACT FROM TALKS OF 7 UNITS
description: The Communications Workers of America and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company have agreed to allow their contract to expire on May 31, 10 weeks earlier than scheduled, union officials said today.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN CITE TRADE TALK GAIN
description: The United States and Japan said today that they had achieved ''positive changes'' during trade talks to open four specific sectors of the Japanese economy to American goods. They agreed to continue the talks and to add new sectors.

title: Jazzmania All-Stars
description: The clarinetist Mike Morgenstern will lead the Jazzmania All-Stars, with the alto saxophonist Sonny Fortune as special guest, tonight at A Discovery of Soho, 451 Broome Street, at Mercer Street (334-1222). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Article 469386 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,517,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $68,000 for the quarter and $644,000 for the year.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL ELEMENTS OFFERS 5 MODERN COMPOSERS
description: ''A Celebration of Living Composers'' was the title of the Musical Elements concert in the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Wednesday night, and the five composers selected for the event were Paul Nash, Roger Briggs, David Wooldridge, Robert Dick and Ned Rorem. The resultant program, though uneven, offered some music that was well worth hearing.

title: AGENCY OVERLOOKS CHEMICAL THREATS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has largely ignored potential chemical hazards to workers and the public at the plants it inspects, officials acknowledged today.

title: CONTROLLER ERRED IN A JERSEY CRASH
description: The air-traffic controller who guided the two private planes that collided near Teterboro Airport last Nov. 10 told the corporate jet's crew twice that the other plane was going west when it was going east, according to transcripts made public yesterday.

title: SHUTDOWN AT MALEAN TRUCKING
description: The McLean Trucking Company, the nation's fifth-largest trucking concern, shut its operations yesterday and said it had been forced to seek reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankrupcty Code because of continuing losses.

title: NETS' DEFENSE INEFFECTIVE
description: By the third period, it was clear the Nets were in trouble. They had been warned by their coach that this was no easy game, and they struggled continually, losing their defensive proficiency and finally losing the game, 125-120, to the Los Angeles Clippers tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Bringing the Council Back to Life
description: The New York City Council's process for selecting its majority leader is usually as cut and dried as a Roy Rogers western, but the choice this week of Peter Vallone of Queens had the wow finish of ''Casablanca.'' Mr. Vallone won by a single vote when a Manhattan Councilman, Robert Dryfoos, decided at the last moment to support him. Whatever the reason for the switch, it gave the job to the best candidate.

title: FRANK POWOLNY
description: Frank Powolny, the photographer who snapped the famous World War II swimsuit picture of Betty Grable, died of a heart attack Sunday while visiting his daughter here. He was 84 years old and lived in Newbury Park, Calif.

title: F.A.A. INSPECTS EASTERN AIRLINES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has begun an intensive inspection of maintenance at Eastern Airlines amid concern about reports of deferred repairs on too many aircraft, officials said today.

title: JAZZ: BUSH ROCK IN DEBUT
description: The idea behind Bush Rock, a band that made its American debut Wednesday at Sounds of Brazil (204 Varick Street), seems to be to build a jazz-funk fusion on African rhythms. In its current state, the group is more skillful than original.

title: Being Victims Together
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTRE COMPUTERS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CELTICS END STREAK BY HAWKS, 115-108
description: Larry Bird scored 29 points, and Dennis Johnson and Kevin McHale had 24 each tonight as the Boston Celtics snapped Atlanta's five-game winning streak with a 115-108 victory over the Hawks.

title: South Africa Criticizes 6 Touring Congressmen
description: Six United States members of Congress, on the last day of a tour of South Africa, ran into harsh criticism today when they were attacked by the state-run radio and snubbed by a black group.

title: JOBS GROWTH TO OUTPACE LABOR FORCE, GROUP SAYS
description: CONNECTICUT will add more jobs to its economy than it will people to fill them over the next 10 years, a privately financed study has concluded.

title: Art
description: The best pottery, archaeologists know, is usually made for the dead. And so it is with the clay vessels produced by the Mimbres Indians, a vanished tribe that existed a thousand years ago in a peaceable valley of what's now New Mexico.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on health care misstated the deductible in I.B.M.'s health insurance plan. Employees earning more than $50,000 a year have a deductible of three-tenths of 1 percent of their salary.

title: JAZZ: JOSHUA BREAKSTONE
description: JOSHUA BREAKSTONE, a young guitarist from New Jersey, is at the West End Cafe through today, playing with a serene, swinging assurance and a melodic warmth that suggests a musician of longer experience than he has had.

title: Checking A House Before Sale
description: A PERSISTENT fear that plagues buyers of existing homes - particularly older country or suburban houses - is that the houses may have hidden defects that could cost the newcomer thousands of dollars to correct.

title: AH, WILDERNESS: ADAPTING ON L.I.
description: THE way it was:

title: DEVILS TROUNCED BY THE FLYERS, 8-4
description: The Devils had earned bragging rights over the Philadelphia Flyers earlier this season, but they lost them today.

title: CHANCE STEPS IN
description: Common sense, hard work and well-applied intelligence usually pay off. But not always: In bridge, as in life, the fates may kick the deserving in the teeth. Unlike chess, it is not a game of justice. Chance has a role to play, even in duplicate competition in which the luck of the deal is theoretically eliminated.

title: OUT OF DESPERATION, A NOVICE VENTURES TO BAKE A CAKE
description: ON a recent Saturday, I was trapped in the house. One car was in for repairs, the other was out with my wife at a shopping mall. I felt a bit desolate. When I am without an auto, when that familiar little house on wheels does not grace my driveway, I feel abandoned and rootless.

title: 'Capriccio' Set to Open Strauss Opera Series
description: A mini-festival of three Richard Strauss operas will begin at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, Jan. 28, with a concert performance of ''Capriccio'' for which Jeffrey Tate will conduct the Orchestra of St. Luke's.

title: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC AND FRIENDS AT RUTGERS'S ZIMMERLI MUSEUM
description: AS WITH the Mona Lisa's smile, one has been surfeited with the work of Toulouse-Lautrec. Also, the man has become a popular cliche: the artist stunted in growth who drew the women of the nightclubs and brothels in the bohemian Montmartre section of Paris.

title: EXPERTS FIND NEW ENGLAND THRIVING
description: Thanks to lucrative military contracts, innovative high-technology companies and the information segment that one analyst calls the ''thought-ware'' industry, New England's healthy economy is expected to continue to prosper in 1986 but with less gusto than in recent years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ADRIFT: Seventy-Six Days Lost at Sea. By Steven Callahan. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) What does one do to stay alive for 76 days at sea on a five-foot inflatable raft? And how does one feel and what does one think while doing so? In ''Adrift,'' Steven Callahan, a 33-year-old naval architect from Maine and an intrepid adventurer, adroitly tells us in minute detail.

title: 'LIVING' HISTORY IS AIM OF COURSE
description: KATHY McGUINESS, a high school senior, was reading a news item in the local newspaper recently: Charlie Platt was engaged at P. T. Barnum's new museum, where he daily ''introduces the living curiosities and tells the wonderful story of each. The smallest dwarf is carried in arms most of the time and treated like a baby. The fat lady sits alone and conducts herself with a quiet dignity.''

title: LEGAL THREAT SEEN IN TEXACO RULING
description: A lawyer for the Pennzoil Company said today that the intervention of a Federal judge on the side of Texaco Inc. in the tangled legal fight between the two companies was an affront to the sovereignty of state courts and was not likely to be upheld by Federal appeals judges.

title: 46 FOOD OUTLETS GET CITATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 46 food establishments cited for violating the health code. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Almis, 1732 Amsterdam Ave. (95th St.). Bobby's, 1031 3d Ave. (61st St.). Crystal Deli, 56 E. 58th St. Dorian's, 1616 2d Ave. (84th St.). 42d St. Restaurant, 330 W. 42d St. Good Location, 958 Lexington Ave. (69th St.). Gourshin Deli, 930 8th Ave. (55th St.). Harlem Chicken, 300 W. 145th St. Harry'n Me Cafe, 416 E. 71st St. Hickory Pit, 1260 2d Ave. (66th St.). Iris Coffee Shop, 3750 Broadway (153d St.). Jimmy's, 1400 Broadway (38th St.). J. R. Restaurant, 264 W. 46th St. La Groceria, 333 Ave. of the Americas (3d St.). Manna Coffee Shop, 270 W. 38th St. Mexico Lindo, 459 2d Ave. (25th St.). Night Shift, 835 8th Ave. (50th St.). Uris Deli, 216 W. 50th St. Whole Grain Restaurant, 7 W. 19th St. The Works, 428 Columbus Ave. (80th St.). BRONX El Molino Rojo, 268 E. 167th St. (Morris Ave.).

title: Joanne Horwood Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Ned Horwood of Reston, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Lisa Horwood, to Alan David Garely, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Garely of South Orange, N.J.

title: TOPICS
description: THE members have flown south like the geese, leaving their fairways and putting greens vacant; another season at the club has ended. Winter at a country club is a time for the employees: we who have served so well in the summer now have time to enjoy the charms of the club that the members rarely see.

title: POTENTIAL DONORS URGED TO MAKE PLANS
description: OBTAINING transplant organs - kidneys, livers and pancreases, as well as hearts - would be easier, experts say, if people who want to donate at the time of their death would discuss it with their families now.

title: ADOBO: SPICY STEW OF THE PHILIPPINES
description: If the Philippines had an official national dish, it would probably be a sort of stew known as adobo. Adobo is actually a process by which anything - fish, fowl, vegetables or meat - is marinated for five hours or more in vinegar, soy sauce and spices, then cooked in hot oil, garnished with an egg and served with boiled rice. Most Filipinos know it as a durable and distinctive meal of either chicken or pork or a combination of the two.

title: JURY SEEN AS GETTING CASINO CASE OF 5 CRIME FIGURES BY MIDWEEK
description: The Federal trial of five reputed crime figures accused of failing to report $2 million in revenue from four Las Vegas casinos could go to the jury by the middle of next week, the judge says.

title:
ART;
A NATION'S HISTORY REVEALED IN MASKS
description: MORE than 50 years ago, Anita Brenner's book, ''Idols Behind Altars,'' told the story of modern Mexican culture in terms of its dichotomies.

title: ALBANY ANGENCY SAYS ENVIRONMENT FUND IS LOW
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation said today that it had spent or committed to specific projects most of the $1.15 billion authorized by the Environmental Quality Bond Act of 1972.

title: Dana Maiman Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Dana Robin Maiman and Don Alan Meyers, graduates of Brandeis University, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Abbott Maiman of Rosedale, Queens. Mr. Meyers is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Meyers of Tamarac, Fla. The future bride graduated also from the St. John's University Law School.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ECHOES. By Maeve Binchy. (Viking, $17.95.) The sweetly moist Irish climate produces many a dawn veiled by a damp mist that another nation might perceive as rain.

title: Audit Faults Upstate Agency For Administrative Practices
description: A report issued by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan criticizes the management and purchasing practices at the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, an agency that is the subject of a Federal grand-jury investigation into corruption.

title: THE DUEL OF THE DINOSAURS
description: USUALLY the quarterbacks are on the marquee. But in the billing for today's National Conference championship game that will produce a Super Bowl XX team, both quarterbacks have been turned into supporting actors by their running backs -Walter Payton of the Bears, yard for yard the best in history, and Eric Dickerson of the Rams, yard for yard the best right now.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET RETURNS TO REGULAR REPERTORY
description: ONE could tell that the New York City Ballet had only recently put away ''The Nutcracker'' and returned to its regular repertory. Nothing went seriously awry when the company offered three works by George Balanchine on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, yet there were moments when some of the dancers looked tentative.

title: Wrong Address
description: To the Editor:

title: 'PRESENT LAUGHTER' REVIVED
description: SIR Noel Coward, the English playwright, director, composer, librettist and actor, died in 1973, but his work is being constantly revived with much audience-pleasing success.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Airlines: The Fuel Factor Jet fuel prices are in a free fall - and for now, the airlines will profit. Since 1981, the fuel's price has dropped from $1.04 a gallon to 81 cents a gallon. This year, fuel could account for only 16 percent of airlines' operating costs - down from 31 percent in 1981 - if the price drops to 55 cents a gallon, as some of the most optimistic analysts predict. A penny drop in the price per gallon of jet fuel, says Mike Derchin, airline analyst for the First Boston Corporation, translates into about $110 million annually in operating profits.

title: Elizabeth Irene Miller Plans to Marry Randolph Guggenheimer 3d in August
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Irene Miller to Randolph Guggenheimer 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guggenheimer Jr. of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: POP: GOLDEN PALOMINOS
description: FOUR lead singers gave the Golden Palominos four distinct identities Thursday night at the Ritz. Led by the drummer Anton Fier, the Golden Palominos are an in-group supergroup -an occasional assembly of cult figures from jazz, rock and pop. It is something between a band and a hootenanny; the group's sound, lineup and repertory depend on who's in town.

title: THIS NETWORK IS BROUGHT TO YOU BY TRENTON
description: For years the New Jersey public television network has attempted to run a conventional and professional news operation while politicians control its purse strings. The arrangement has not always worked smoothly, and this week its latest casualty, Hendrix F. C. Niemann, will step down as the executive director of the state's Public Broadcasting Authority.

title: FILING A CLAIM CAN BE TRYING
description: WHEN Frances C., a musician, teacher and critic, was between jobs, she filed an unemployment-insurance compensation claim.

title: Indiana Inmate Dies In Prison Takeover
description: Inmates armed with knives took over a cellblock and a gymnasium at a maximum-security prison for two and a half hours today, leaving one inmate dead and at least 18 people injured, the authorities said.

title: SQUEEZING A LIVING OUT OF AN INCREASINGLY STINGY SEA
description: There has been discontent on the docks here at least since Herman Melville's time, when crews of whalers whose officers had failed to find fertile hunting grounds were known to publish broadsides warning boat owners against hiring them. So it was not remarkable that picketing dragged on last week.

title: Contractors
description: To the Editor:

title: Applying Fractals To the Real World
description: Had the science historian I. Bernard Cohen scoured the annals of science a bit more thoroughly, he would have added Freud to his list of self-proclaimed scientific revolutionaries.

title: ROCKEFELLER PRESERVE READY TO WELCOME VISITORS
description: ''IT'S not the Grand Tetons or Yosemite. It's the Rockefellers' backyard,'' explained James F. Moogan, manager of the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, the state's 750-acre parkland in Pocantico Hills. ''We've been trying to keep a low profile, because we didn't have parking facilities and couldn't handle crowds.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTIONANCESTORS OF THE T-SHIRT
description: The story of American art since World War II is not easy to tell, but one way is to trace the history of printmaking during the period. In AMERICAN IMPRESSIONS: Prints Since Pollock (Knopf, $40), Riva Castleman, director of the department of prints and illustrated books at the Museum of Modern Art, brings her experience to bear on the subject.

title: ANGOLA'S FEELINGS DON'T GET IN THE WAY PROFITS
description: On one hand, American banks and oil companies provide the cash essential to the survival of this country's Marxist Government. On the other, the White House, backed by a growing number of American conservatives, is reportedly planning to give $15 million to the South African-backed guerrillas fighting to overthrow the same regime.

title: MODERN BLACKSMITH USES OLD METHODS
description: BENT over his forge, a leather apron tied over his bulky middle, his broad, whiskered face beaded with sweat, Walter Scadden fits the image of the village blacksmith so perfectly that customers sometimes are taken aback when he offers to embellish a wrought-iron gate with a band of graceful flowers or a leafy fern.

title: FIRMER BRONX MARKET LEADS TO A CONCERN OVER PRICES
description: JOHN H. FAULKNER bought his first apartment house in the Bronx in 1980, when he was still working in the real estate department of Pan American Airways. It was a 70-unit building on Kingsbridge Avenue.

title: A Tower to Make the Hearts of New Yorkers Soar Outrageously
description: To the Editor:

title: DIANE KETCHAN
description: ALTHOUGH the Christmas season is over for most Long Islanders, it's still very much on the mind of Eugene R. Roos of Liberty Street in Patchogue.

title: CORRECTION
description: The drawings with an article on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s ''dishonor roll'' appeared without a credit line. The artist was John S. Dykes.

title: FALLING LIKE THE RAIN FROM HEAVEN?
description: ORIGINS A Skeptic's Guide to the Creation of Life on Earth. By Robert Shapiro. 332 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: A Force That Defies Gravity?
description: In the early 17th century, Galileo defied Aristotle's law and logic when he said all objects fall at the same rate, regardless of weight. Today, a new theory is challenging Galileo's principle, one of the underpinnings of modern physics.

title: LENDL WINS SINGLES FINAL
description: A powerful serve carried Ivan Lendl to a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Jimmy Connors today in the singles final of the $500,000 A.T.&T. Challenge tennis tournament.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE state's new Public Advocate hates public appearances and speechmaking, and isn't much keener about officeholding in general.

title: CITY'S 7-A ADMINISTRATORS HELP NEGLECTED BUILDINGS
description: A FEW years ago, a suspicious fire broke out on the second floor of a five-story walkup at 715 Ninth Avenue, leaving the building without electricity, heat or plumbing. Only 4 of the 16 renters in the building, between 48th and 49th Streets, stayed, and the landlord was forced to relinquish his control to a court-appointed administrator.

title: O'ROURKE INTERVIEW
description: IN a political career that spans 20 years, Andrew P. O'Rourke has been asked just about every question in the book. But even a seasoned politician and man about town such as Andy O'Rourke found himself blushing last week when questionned by a group of fourth graders at the George M. Davis Elementary School in New Rochelle.

title: From the Bronx, With Love
description: Geography rather than ideology divided the New York City Council last week. An alliance of Manhattan and Brooklyn lawmakers vied against a Bronx-Queens-Staten Island axis as the Democratic-dominated Council prepared to elect its first new majority leader in 16 years.

title: NOTES OF A FOLKLORIST
description: TOM BENTON AND HIS DRAWINGS A Biographical Essay and a Collection of His Sketches, Studies, and Mural Cartoons. By Karal Ann Marling. Illustrated. 224 pp. Columbia: University of Missouri Press. $48. A dubious dividend of the current revival of Realism is the comeback of the Regionalist school, a group of painters who in the 1930's and 40's created on canvas their own cozy folklore of American life. Thomas Hart Benton (1889-1975), who had once been a promising Modernist but vociferously renounced that credo, was one of the school's principals. His resuscitation is evident in the 1982 reissue of his autobiography, ''An Artist in America,'' by the University of Missouri Press, the big exhibition of his work organized last year by Bard College and the installation of his busy 10-panel mural, ''America Today,'' as the sole lobby adornment of the new Equitable Life Assurance tower on Seventh Avenue and 51st Street. And now we have ''Tom Benton and His Drawings,'' an expansive (and expensive) book whose folksy text by Karal Ann Marling, professor of art history and American studies at the University of Minnesota, accompanies some 200 of his working drawings.

title: Barbara L. Ernst Wed To Jeffrey Drew Prey
description: Barbara Elizabeth Ernst, the daughter of Mrs. Herbert Ernst of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Dr. Herbert Ernst, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Drew Prey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Prey of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Pilsch performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Manhasset.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GIVE A BOY A GUN: A True Story of Law and Disorder in the American West. By Jack Olsen. (Delacorte, $16.95.)

title:
COINS;
UNITED STATES GOLD BULLION COINS
description: Nearly a dozen years after regaining the right to own gold bullion, Americans will finally get a chance to own United States bullion coins. Barring unforeseen developments, the United States Treasury will begin issuing four bullion coins late this year.

title: Getting Together
description: It's a small school, but there are those willing to go to court over her, as has been proved once again in Dartmouth College's efforts to dismiss its football coach, Joe Yukica, and keep him dismissed. Now, however, it appears that Dartmouth won't be needing to resurrect Daniel Webster to take the case to the Supreme Court.

title: 3 SOPRANOS AND PIANIST IN RECITALS; Bruce Griffin
description: Bruce Griffin Bruce Griffin is a young pianist from Vermont with only a modest career behind him, but he played at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night in a way that was serious and imaginative.

title: The Unidentified
description: Heavy snows in Newfoundland and a mistake by the military were blamed last week for a delay in identifying the remains of most of the 248 American soldiers and eight crew members killed when their chartered DC-8 crashed after refueling at Gander last month. Pentagon investigators said that, contrary to Army regulations, medical and dental records of many of the men were on the same plane and thus lost when its fuel tanks exploded. An Army spokesman said a mass burial of unidentified remains may be necessary.

title: Tough Driving In Philadelphia
description: LIKE a recurring nightmare, the rebuilding of the Schuylkill Expressway, I-76, will again taunt drivers as the second and most disruptive phase of the $175 million project begins this week. And things will get worse before they get better.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 12, 1986
description: International

title: A GENTLEMANLY STROLL ON JERMYN STREET
description: London's Jermyn Street is all things to all gentlemen. The Lucullan indulgence of A l'Ecu de France, the nostalgic whimsy of the Cavendish Hotel, the cheese-perfumed ambiance at Paxton's and the helpful hauteur at Fortnum's blend easily in a street where a man can pay $1,000 for a pair of shoes, $140 for a hat and with his last $17 face the decision of a shaving brush from Floris or a cigar from Alfred Dunhill.

title: FOR COMET WATCHERS IN NORTH, THE BIG SHOW IS NEAR ITS FINALE
description: Each night over the past week, in backyards and on hillsides, at college observatories and at gatherings of astronomy buffs, people looked to the southwest for what may have been their sole or last glimpse of Halley's comet.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Recent Sales
description: New Canaan, Conn. $895,000 784 West Road *2*5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; *2*paneled solarium, overlooking park, 4 acres; *2*taxes $6,483. New Haven, Conn. $72,000 79 Long Hill Terrace *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*cherry kitchen cabinets, rec room with bar; taxes $2,118. Woodbridge, Conn. $120,000 296 Amity Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old split level; *2*sunken living room with brick fireplace, bay windows, *2*new carpeting, 1.5 acres; taxes $1,470. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $130,000 17 Van Wyck Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old farmhouse; *2*eat-in kitchen, porch, den; taxes $2,140. Katonah, N.Y. $165,000 49 The Parkway *2*4-bedroom, 4-bath, 89-year-old Victorian; *2*mud room, pantry, library, turret, balcony; *2*taxes $3,945. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $159,500 22 Anderson Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 56-year-old stucco colonial; *2*sun porch, modern kitchen; *2*taxes $1,801. OTHER AREAS Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $94,000 129 Maplecrest Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, carport; taxes $1,400. Rutherford, N.J. 168,000 233 Orient Way *2*6 bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 16-year-old Cape Cod; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, patio, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,958. South Orange, N.J. $152,000 257 Kingsland Terrace *2*5 bedroom, 2 bathroom, 50-year-old colonial; *2*finished basement, burglar alarm, patio; taxes $3,672.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
BILL VEECK'S GREATEST GAME
description: AFTER we had gone over the manuscript of ''Veeck as in Wreck'' for the final time, Bill Veeck and I had the only real argument we were ever going to have. That late in the game, Veeck had decided that he had given Rogers Hornsby a worse pummeling than an old guy, long out of baseball, was worth. I accused Bill - if you can believe this - of running scared, and he informed me that it didn't matter what I thought. ''It's my book, and those two pages are out.''

title: ELIZABETH'S MAYOR SHIFTS LAWSUIT PLAN
description: THE City Attorney here says that Mayor Thomas G. Dunn's refusal last year to approve an anti-apartheid ordinance was a ''silent protest'' against the local law and that the Mayor still plans to file a suit challenging the state's Pension Fund Divestment Law.

title: Readers of the Purple Page
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: The New York Medical College received two grants totaling $570,000 last month from the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, which had raised the money by selling Christmas cards by mail.

title: Massachusetts Wage Rises
description: Saying there is little chance of a raise in the Federal minimum wage in the near future, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has signed a law raising Massachusetts' minimum wage rate 20 cents an hour starting July 1 and 20 cents more by 1988. The action Tuesday separates the state minimum wage from the $3.35-an-hour Federal rate, which has not been increased since 1981. The state law calls for the $3.35 minimum to increase to $3.55 on July 1, to $3.65 on July 1, 1987 and $3.75 on July 1, 1988.

title: Children And the Bomb
description: Even if Dr. Coles is correct when he states that ''the children who have taken this issue to heart are from well-off families whose parents are themselves involved in the nuclear-freeze movement,'' then surely that still means a significant number of young Americans must be very worried about the threat of nuclear war.

title: RENEW THE 1/ TAX PURCELL REQUESTS
description: NASSAU County Executive Francis T. Purcell said last week that the county will lose $52 million in revenue next year if the State Legislature does not renew Nassau's three-year-old one-cent sales-tax increase.

title: LET PEOPLE KNOW WHAT THEY'RE EATING
description: IMAGINE a $50 billion-a-year campaign to sabotage Americans' health. Though it would never admit it, that is essentially what the fast-food industry is doing with its slick merchandising of products dunked in fat and laced with salt. While it may be unrealistic to expect fast-food restaurants to adopt a completely healthful menu, is it too much to ask that they label product ingredients so that consumers can at least make informed choices about what they eat?

title: Mayor Koch Says Meters in Homes Will Save Water
description: Mayor Koch has decided to invoke the oldest law of consumption in the hope that it will encourage New Yorkers to conserve water: make them pay for it directly. The Mayor said last week that he would seek legislative approval to require the owners of all residences in the city to install water meters within 10 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review last Sunday of the British rock songwriter Joe Jackson incorrectly identified the theater where he will record a live album later this month. It is the Roundabout Theater, 100 East 17th Street.

title: SALVADOR REPORTS LOSSES ARE DOWN
description: Leftist guerrillas killed 426 Salvadoran soldiers and wounded 1,683 in 1985, according to the Salvadoran Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Adolfo Blandon.

title: MATT SUHEY: A HARD-NOSED, ROLE PLAYER
description: MATT Suhey is the Chicago Bears' starting fullback, and a relatively little known fullback at that. He is so little known, in fact, that few even realize that his most celebrated act on the football field is leaving it.

title: Cable TV
description: Bravo, with its policy of showing uncut film classics, has some real bargains this cable week, one being ''The Leopard'' (1963). Adapted from Giovanni di Lampedusa's novel of a proud aristocrat in war-torn 1860's Sicily, Luchino Visconti's rich dramatic tapestry stars Burt Lancaster, Alain Delon and Claudia Cardinale. The complete 3 1/2-hour movie was finally released here in 1983 to critical reappraisals and acclaim. There's also a striking, bittersweet score composed by Mario Nascimbene. ''The Leopard'' is scheduled for Sunday at 8 P.M. and 2 A.M.

title: Project Diana
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
BARING A 'SECRET' IN MORRISTOWN
description: ''N EW JERSEY's best-kept secret'' is the phrase inscribed on the cover of the menu in a Morristown restaurant called The Recovery Room. But if our visits were anything to go by, then the restaurant is no longer a secret; it was filled to capacity each time we were there.

title: Competition for The Trident Sub?
description: The Navy, increasingly alert to the possibilities for competition among its weapons producers, has taken a step that threatens the General Dynamics Corporation's exclusive domain over the Trident nuclear missile submarine.

title: U.S. WILL SELL 40 FIGHTER JETS TO THE GREEKS
description: The United States and Greece have signed an agreement for protecting military technology that opens the way for the sale of 40 F-16 fighter planes to Greece, a State Department official said today.

title: OVER THE HILL? I HAVEN'T EVEN STARTED
description: WE had a lovely young waitress the other night who not-so-laughingly referred to herself as ''over the hill'' because at 33 she had not ''made it.'' She was not financially successful and perhaps, to her, was not a success in any other way, either.

title: AT LAST, PARIS GETS A MODERN MUSEUM EQUAL TO ITS PAST
description: As of a week or two ago, Paris has at last a national museum of modern art in which quality is high and quantity abundant. Order, reason and lucidity prevail. Spaces are generous. Rooms are rooms and not a series of ephemeral bays. Everything looks its best. A great period in the history of art is set out as it deserves, and there is enough in the way of documentation and memorabilia to remind us how often Paris played an active, protective and supportive part in living art and was the place of all places in which artists most wanted to be.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/THE BARGAIN HUNTERS
description: BLEAK January is upon us, but the bargain hunters at Filene's Basement have found a way to banish the postholiday blues.

title: Haircut, Shave And Health Care
description: TO the traditional barber's haircut, shampoo and shave, three shops in Baltimore added a service last June - a check of blood pressure.

title: FROM DOUBTS TO DIPLOMA IN THE OCEAN'S DEPTHS
description: Suspended in the ocean 10 fathoms deep, I gazed below at a school of bright blue fish rushing along the coral reef. Rolling over on my back, I could see the sunlit surface 60 feet above. All around were noises and the thunder of my own breathing. As I glided through the water, I spotted a two-foot-long grouper, his mouth agape. A red goatfish and a zebra-striped sergeant major swam around purple tube sponges and green and orange coral. Then, our air supply nearly depleted, we swam slowly upward toward the ladder hanging from our boat.

title: JETER'S COMEBACK IS A SUCCESS
description: THE NAME Gary Jeter ring a bell? It should. For six years, he was a defensive lineman for the Giants, their first-round draft choice in 1977 but a player who never quite distinguished himself in the manner he or the Giants expected. Finally, in April 1983 they traded him to the Los Angeles Rams for a third and a sixth-round choice in the 1983 draft, who turned out to be Jamie Williams, a tight end from Nebraska, and Kevin Belcher, an offensive guard from Texas-El Paso.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WERE WE OUR BROTHERS' KEEPERS? The Public Response of American Jews to the Holocaust, 1938-1944. By Haskel Lookstein. (Hartmore House, 1363 Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. 06605, $18.95.)

title: 'DIOXIN CONTAINMENT ON SITE SUGGESTED
description: THE dioxin once scattered over parts of the Ironbound section of Newark should be contained on the site where it originated, according to the company responsible for the site.

title: MORE DONOR HEARTS AWAITED
description: WITH new hearts beating vigorously in their chests, the first two patients to undergo heart transplants in New Jersey were peddaling stationary bicycles, eating solid foods and complaining of boredom last week.

title: A DATA BASE FOR THE FORGETFUL
description: Of all the business software available for personal computers today, probably none are more intimidating to the average user than data base managers. Writers write, after all, so they at least comprehend what a word-processing program is supposed to do. Accountants and other number crunchers gladly allowed computerized spreadsheets to replace their pencils, not to mention erasers. But does anyone actually think of himself as a data base manager?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It is difficult not to view this action as a betrayal of the traditions and principles which I have sought to perpetuate. It fails to meet any standard of fairness that I can comprehend.''

title: Mailbox; Boston Baseball In the 1930's
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SUFFOLK'POWER ELITE' IS ASSAILED BY BLASS
description: THE new Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, Gregory J. Blass, said last week that he was elected despite the effort of a ''power elite'' to keep him out of the post, one of the most powerful in county government.

title: THINKING IT, MAKING IT USING IT
description: DAY OF THE BOMB Countdown to Hiroshima. By Dan Kurzman. Illustrated. 546 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $19.95.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Everything Discounted From Catalogue Prices Lillian Vernon is known as a mail-order business nationwide and locally also for The Store in New Rochelle, opened this year with selections from the company's merchandise and with everything discounted from the listed catalogue prices.

title: NEW GROUP SEEKS STRATEGIES FOR CURBING TEEN PRE
description: DOCTORS, politicians and social service providers from throughout Connecticut are trying to tell people that thousands of teen-agers are having babies, in all kinds of communities -and that Connecticut can do something about the problem.

title: BONES AND CONTENTIONS
description: THE RIDDLE OF THE DINOSAUR By John Noble Wilford. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Tyson Wins Again, Gets 16th Knockout
description: The heavyweight Mike Tyson tied Rocky Marciano's record of 16 consecutive knockouts to begin a career with a first-round knockout of Dave Jaco tonight at the Empire State Plaza Convention Center.

title: MENTORS SOUGHT FOR DISABLED
description: A NEW program, the Mentor Connection, is seeking successful working women with disabilities throughout the county who can serve as role models for disabled teen-age girls in the county.

title: JERSEY REPORTER ALLOWED RETRIAL
description: A newspaper reporter who has been tried twice on a charge of impersonating a government official is entitled to a new trial based on an order entered in Superior Court here today.

title: QUILTERS' WORKS ACHEIVE QUALITY THAT PUTS THEM ON THE WALL
description: THE Gallery in Hastings-on-Hudson's Municipal Building on Maple Street is aglow with the work of 28 quilters. A show numbering 36 items, it runs from actual quilts - one of them an antique - to clothes and includes objects that have no purpose other than to be themselves.

title: Renoir Show Sets Record
description: An exclusive United States exhibition of paintings by the French Impressionist Pierre Auguste Renoir broke attendance records and increased revenue for the Museum of Fine Arts, the museum announced this week.

title: Calling The Dog
description: I have always been told that a dog should have a one-syllable name so he would respond to a command, probably saving his life, if he started across First Avenue against the traffic lights.

title: New Protests Worry Haiti
description: Anti-Government protests are rare in Haiti, which has been the Duvalier family's poverty-stricken fief for nearly 30 years. Last week, however, security forces killed one person as anti-Government demonstrators marched and blocked roads in at least three towns and burned Government buildings in Petit Goave, southwest of Port au Prince, the capital.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: OLD BOOKS, NEW PRICES A copy of Eudora Welty's first book, ''A Curtain of Green,'' will be priced at $500 during the Rye Antiquarian Book Fair to be held this weekend at the Academy of the Resurrection High School. ''The dust jacket is in perfect condition,'' said Gil Rodriguez, proprietor of Gillan Books in Darien, Conn., one of the exhibitors. ''Dust jackets are important. They bring the price way up.''

title: A SEARING 'GLENGARRY' AT GEORGE STREET
description: DAVID MAMET is a maddening playwright. When he is operating on all cylinders scathingly, as in ''Edmond,'' a short play about the pits of urban squalor, he exposes the nerve endings of a sick society, including language that gets to the point and to the pulse.

title: REPORTER WTH A CAUSE
description: REBEL PEN The Writings of Mary Heaton Vorse. Edited by Dee Garrison. 345 pp. New York: Monthly Review Press. Cloth, $26.50. Paper, $11. THE writing career of Mary Heaton Vorse spanned the first half of the 20th century. Her early articles and short stories were published during the years of Theodore Roosevelt's Presidency. Her last published effort appeared in 1953 during the first month of the Eisenhower Administration, when she was in her late 70's. She was an extremely well-received, commercially successful writer of popular fiction and reportage. Later in her long career, Vorse -who devoted herself to radical and feminist causes -became a politically committed journalist who hewed closely to the Communist Party line in much of her writing.

title: Applying Fractals To the Real World
description: Benoit Mandelbrot's fractals may some day invade more than economics, weather and other assorted forms of chaos (''The Man Who Reshaped Geometry,'' by James Gleick, Dec. 8). The concept of imbedded similarity is already involved in the workings of holograms and is probably a part of the mechanism of human memory storage.

title: U.S. SAYS IT WANTS MORE TIME TO DECIDE ON E.P.A. INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department plans to tell Congress this week that it needs more time to decide whether it should investigate allegations that department lawyers improperly withheld Environmental Protection Agency files from Congress in 1983, department officials said today.

title: NAIROBI, THE NGONG HILLS AND BEYOND
description: The best time to view game in East Africa is generally from November through February; the period from August through October is also popular. November and December can be rainy. Visas are required for American citizens by both Kenya and Tanzania.
THE state expects to add up to $6 million to its fuel assistance for the poor this winter, according to state officials.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING CHANGES IS A WINTER PROJECT
description: ONE of the main criticisms of the average American garden might well be that gardeners have exercised too little imagination in designing and planting them. All too frequently, the gardens along a particular street are carbon copies of one another, especially if the houses are similar in architecture.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CRONE: Woman of Age, Wisdom, and Power. By Barbara G. Walker. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) There can be little doubt that in most modern societies, old women are still considered the least valuable members.

title: DOES DANCE REFLECT CURRENT CONCERNS?
description: How does dance relate to Zeitgeist or the spirit of the time? This is the question that the West German dance magazine, Ballett International, asks in its current issue of 11 dance writers from Western Europe, the Soviet Union and the United States. Predictably, the article-long responses reflect cultural differences more than any all-encompassing global Geist. But the telling point is that the authors' differences reflect the dance situation in each country and not necessarily the political or social climate surrounding that dance situation.

title: IS THE I.C.C. AT THE END FO THE ROAD?
description: Some say it would be a mercy killing, the death of a 98-year-old invalid with little reason to live. Others call it betrayal of a trust, the brutal slaying of a defenseless victim. There are so far only the vaguest plans for disposing of the few mortal remains.

title: Housing for All
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOKING BACK AT A MAN AHEAD OF HIS TIME
description: AFTER easily winning re-election in October, Andrew Young was inaugurated last week to a second term as Mayor of Atlanta. Mr. Young later talked about the political progress blacks have made in the South in recent years, as well as the enduring legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his longtime friend and mentor. Dr. King's memory will be celebrated Jan. 20 with the first national observance of the holiday marking his birthday. Here are excerpts of the Mayor's conversation with William E. Schmidt, chief of The New York Times Atlanta Bureau. Question. Blacks serve as mayor in Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Birmingham, Ala., and New Orleans. In Virginia, a black has been elected Lieutenant Governor. Are blacks now full political partners in the South?

title: LIFE AFTER PATRICK
description: ST. JOHN'S and Georgetown met yesterday for the first time since Patrick Ewing and Chris Mullin went to the happy hunting ground last spring. The rivalry remained as intense as ever, with three Big East Conference officials working to avoid three-minute rounds and mandatory eight-counts for the young scholar-athletes.

title: CAPITAL COLUMNS WIDELY PRINTED
description: Joseph Kraft, the widely syndicated Washington columnist and author of books and articles on national and foreign affairs, died Friday night at the Washington Hospital Center, apparently of heart failure. He was 61 years old and lived in the capital.

title: Kuwait Says Libyans Downed Plane
description: Kuwait's official press agency, KUNA, quoted a diplomat today as saying a Libyan anti-aircraft missile shot down an American jet fighter over the Mediterranean earlier in the week.

title:
INVESTING;
LIVING WITH WALL STREET'S ROUT
description: THE record-setting free fall in stock prices last Wednesday rudely reminded individual and institutional investors of the violent volatility inherent in stock index futures programs. ''It's like being caught in the Bermuda Triangle,'' said Harvey P. Eisen, president of New York's Integrated Asset Management. And while program trading may be an unwelcome intruder in the stock market, experts grudgingly acknowledge that the strategy has become a fact of market life. It may even have helped to push stocks higher last autumn.

title: HOMELESS FAMILIES TO DOUBLE THIS YEAR, A REPORT PREDICTS
description: The number of homeless families seeking shelter from New York City will double this year, while the number of single, homeless adults will grow at a slower rate, about 22 percent, according to a coalition of churches and synagogues.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BRASS BED. By Alexandra Marshall. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Triangulation is the theme of this third novel, set in Boston. The story starts when Duncan Jones, turning 40 and moping because he's lost not only his wife but his journalistic touch, spies a woman who reminds him of the Princess of Wales.

title: BEST SELLERS Jan. 12, 1986
description: *4*Fiction 1 1 8 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world in a sequel to ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' and ''The Valley of Horses.'' 2 3 14 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 3 2 20 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a small town. 4 4 14 CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The commotion that follows the reception of a signal from intelligent life beyond Earth. 5 5 12 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The true story, illustrated by Peter Barrett, of how a Yorkshire sheepdog found his long-lost brother. 10 8 4 ''YOU CAN FOOL ALL OF THE PEOPLE ALL THE TIME,'' by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $16.95.) The autobiography of the organizer of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. 12 9 7 SHOOT LOW, BOYS - THEY'RE RIDIN' SHETLAND PONIES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Peachtree Publishers, $13.95.) A humorist looks for unsung Americans with ''true grit.'' 13 9 FERRARO: My Story, by Geraldine A. Ferraro with Linda Bird Francke. (Bantam, $17.95.) (New York Graphic Society/Little, Brown, $50.) The profusely illustrated memoirs of the eminent photographer. 15 12 149 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 1 10 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert Schuller. (Word , $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 3 3 39 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) Recipes for dishes prepared at moderate cost. 4 12 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 4 6 JANE BRODY'S GOOD FOOD BOOK, by Jane E. Brody. (Norton, $19.95.) How to put ''health-promoting carbohydrates'' into your diet, by the personal health columnist of The New York Times. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) REINHOLD NIEBUHR: A Biography, by Richard Wightman Fox. (Pantheon, $19.95.) This scrupulous but warmhearted life of America's most influential modern theologian does not scant Niebuhr's contradictions or inconsistencies, but carefully renders the essentially religious core of his thinking and conduct. DATING YOUR MOM, by Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $11.95.) Twenty-five deft, original and funny pieces adorn this New Yorker staff writer's first collection of comic essays. THE RISE OF THE TRADING STATE: Commerce and Conquest in the Modern World, by Richard Rosecrance. (Basic Books, $19.95.) A brilliant and monitory study of the advantages enjoyed by states that choose - and are able - to turn their energies to commerce and commercial investment rather than armaments. GERALD'S PARTY, by Robert Coover. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) One of our acutest novelists may have gone too far this time, giving us a calculated, technically fascinating, morally exasperating study in interruption and inconsequence - in the form of an upside-down murder mystery. THE GOLDEN DONORS: A New Anatomy of the Great

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Mozart, Smetana, Dvorak, Janacek Performed by the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Vaclav Neuman Sony Video 48 minutes.

title: STATE CHALLENGING BANKRUPTCY RULING
description: STATE officials have appealed to both the Supreme Court of the United States and Congress to remedy what they call ''revolving door justice'' in some bankruptcy cases.

title: GROWTH, PROSPERITY AND CONTROVERSY
description: LIGHT SNOW AND HAIL FELL AS MORE than 6,000 mourners crowded into a cavernous, gilded church in Salt Lake City on a chilly Saturday in early November. Outside, thousands of others stood in the cold, trying to share a moment of history with those inside.

title: A + B - GOODNESS
description: THE WORLD AS A TOTAL SYSTEM By Kenneth E. Boulding. 183 pp. Beverly Hills, Calif.: Sage Publications. $25. HUMAN BETTERMENT By Kenneth E. Boulding. 224 pp. Beverly Hills, Calif.: Sage Publications. $25.

title: Cynthia Hooper to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Hooper of Newtown Square, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Lee Hooper, to Steven Bell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy T. Bell of Upper Darby, Pa. Miss Hooper, an alumna of the Agnes Irwin School and Gettysburg College, is a tennis coach at Bryn Mawr College.

title: INVESTMENT BANKING'S ONE-MAN SHOPS
description: WHEN Eastman Kodak made its first public acquisition ever - the purchase last spring of a small electronics company - that venerable corporation hired as its investment banker not First Boston or Salomon Brothers or Merrill Lynch, but Stephen de Brul.

title: SYRACUSE HOLDS OFF RALLY BY PITTSBURGH
description: Wendell Alexis scored 21 points, and Rafael Addison came through with 9 in the second half as Syracuse survived a rally by Pittsburgh to win, 78-68, today in a Big East Conference game.

title: Carol Joseph Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan L. Joseph Jr. of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter Carol Klee Joseph to John Howland Drake Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Drake of Atlanta.

title: SMALL BUSINESS PLAY A LARGE ROLE
description: DESPITE the sobering statistics - 50 percent of all small businesses fail during their first five years -new business formations in the state rose 27 percent in 1985, a testament to the American entrepreneurial spirit.

title: Albany Flirts With A Lilco Takeover
description: Little illumination accompanied the news last week that there appeared to be powerful support for a state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Q&A
description: Question:We have seen information on hiking the Milford trail in New Zealand with commerical ventures and also heard of the Freedom Walk. Which is better for accomplished hikers? - H. D., Knoxville, Tenn. Answer:A New Zealand tourist official explains that the Milford Track Walk and the Freedom Track Walk are along the same trail. The names distinguish the different hikers' huts - and different prices - that apply. Both walks are organized by the Tourist Hotel Corporation of New Zealand in cooperation with the Fiordland National Park, the site of the trail, in South Island. (The 3,761-square-mile park, which contains many sounds, mountains rivers and lakes, is the largest in New Zealand.) Hikers who go on the escorted Milford Track Walk, a five-day package, need only carry personal belongings. Meals are provided and linens are supplied during their three nights in huts along the 33-mile route, which runs from Te Anau Lake to Milford Sound. The fourth night is spent at a hotel in Milford Sound. The cost is about $275, and $188 for children under 15. The Freedom Track Walk is for hikers prepared to carry their sleeping bags, food and cooking utensils. They stay at three huts other than those used on the Milford package, and the huts are not equipped with linens. No guide is provided. The cost is about $30 a person. Whichever plan hikers choose, they must register at the T.H.C. Te Anau Hotel before setting out.

title: Youth Is Shot in Brawl At School After Game
description: A brawl broke out in a high school parking lot after a basketball game between rival schools, and a teen-ager was shot and critically wounded, the authorities said today.

title: BLACK HISTORY STRUGGLES TO KEEP UP WITH THE DEMAND
description: In the days of legal segregation, black history in public schools consisted of little more than brief lessons on George Washington Carver and Booker T. Washington. As some of today's black history professors remember it, a teacher with more to say had to deliver her lessons surreptitiously. Today that teacher would probably have help from dozens of amateur historians intent on popularizing the story of black Americans as they recreate - and often rewrite - the record of their communities.

title: Victoria Falconer to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Alexandra W. Falconer of Rowayton, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter Victoria Falconer to William Stephen Crane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Crane of Darien, Conn. The future bride is a daughter also of the late David Bruce Falconer.

title: EUROPE HAS ITS REASONS FOR TURNING THE OTHER CHEEK
description: UNITED States frustration in attempting to neutralize the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was compounded last week by what some American commentators portrayed as the craven reaction of the Western European allies. Although Canada supported Washington and Italy announced that it would restrict weapons sales to Libya, the Europeans, with the unanimity of a Greek chorus, expressed their unwillingness to follow President Reagan's lead in attempting to isolate Libya by imposing economic sanctions.

title: FICTION THAT LIES ABOUT ITS DREAMS
description: AFTER retiring from 27 years of psychoanalytic practice, a friend of mine became an avid reader of contemporary novels. ''I've always wanted to read novels,'' he said. ''Thirty years ago when I was in training, I studied the great novelists as well as Freud because they helped me to understand, in a different vocabulary, the vagaries of passion.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE WORLDS OF A MAASAI WARRIOR: An Autobiography. By Tepilit Ole Saitoti. (Random House, $16.95.) In the plains of the Great Rift Valley now shared between Kenya and Tanzania, virtually all Masai boys grow to manhood tending the family cattle herds. Tepilit Ole Saitoti, a Masai in his late 30's, emerges as an unusual warrior in this short autobiography. Mr. Saitoti was marked by his father's decision to send him to a missionary school. The consequences of this act form the basis for a tale of remarkable separations and accommodations among several cultures. His African teachers pressure him to reject ''traditional'' points of view and he is even baptized against his father's wishes. Failing secondary school examinations, he returns to tribal life an uninitiated male, and the path to his becoming a warrior is hammered out within the emotional complexity of life in a family compound. Able to speak Swahili and English, he is in continuing contact with the edges of the world his father and elders refuse to comprehend. Even after he attains the rank of warrior by single-handedly killing a lioness, desire for knowledge of that world compels him to run off to the Serengeti National Park in Kenya where he becomes a ranger and guide and is eventually the subject of a National Geographic Society film. All of this occurs by the time he is 20 years old and is a prelude to a journey that takes him to Europe and the United States.

title: EX-CONVICT SAID TO TAKE CONTROL OF GAMBINO CRIME ORGANIZATION
description: John Gotti, who has served a prison term for manslaughter and is facing trials on racketeering and assault charges, is the new head of the Gambino organized-crime group, according to Federal and local law-enforcement officials.

title: Verbatim; A Slap from the Top
description: 'We obey no discipline, no rule, follow no principle of public morality, display no sense of social awareness, show no concern for the public weal. Corruption is not only tolerated but even regarded as the hallmark of our leadership.' Rajiv Gandhi the Prime Minister of India, admonishing members of his Congress Party.

title: IT'S NO SECRET WHAT'S IN FAST FOOD
description: PATRONS of fast-food restaurants - especially those people with allergies or on restricted diets - have the right to know the ingredients of the food they eat. The question is, What method does a restaurant operator use to convey this information to those customers who want it?

title: LEGISLATORS ACT TO BLOCK SHOREHAM DRILL
description: WHILE state officials moved forward last week with discussions about a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, members of the Suffolk County Legislature were advancing a bill aimed at blocking a Federally sponsored emergency drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant set for Feb. 13.

title: The Bright Side of 50
description: NOTHING WORKED OUT THE WAY I thought it would; as if anything ever does. I figured that when I got to be 50, if I ever did, I'd be firmly ensconced in some insignificant niche with a wife and kids and maybe a few grandchildren. The idea came to me, as such ideas often do, while I was a student at a good prep school, and it hung on doggedly through a hitch in the Marine Corps and a year at Columbia, but then things started to go haywire.

title: ON THE NEED TO BE NEEDED BY OTHERS
description: WHEN I was a young bride, I was very comforted by my husband's dependence on me. In fact, when he told me that he couldn't live without me, I was infused with a sense of godliness. The fact that he was a typical male chauvinist, completely escaped my consciousness.

title: ZONING, HOMES AND HUMAN NEED
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Janet Hansen, executive director of Suffolk Housing Services, a Smithtown-based agency, at a recent symposium conducted by Citizen Action for Affordable Housing in Southold Town in the Peconic Citizens Center in Southold. IWORK for Suffolk Housing Services, a voluntary not-for-profit social-services agency. We help people find housing.

title: DECLARING WAR ON ORGANIZED CRIME
description: WATERFRONT EXTORTION IN NEW YORK, MOB WARS in Philadelphia, threats against a Federal prosecutor in Cleveland and the families of F.B.I. agents, attempted bribery of State officials in Louisiana, protection rackets for bookmakers and pornographers in Los Angeles. And in places too numerous to mention all across America: piracy of union pension and welfare funds; toxic wastes spewed out along our highways, according to state investigators, and into our wildernesses; legitimate businesses fronting as fencing networks for thieves and hijackers; corruption of college athletes through sports-rigging schemes; an invisible tax on food purchases and construction costs imposed by illegal syndicates and paid for by American citizens.

title: OVERPUMPING OF WELLS SEEN
description: OVERPUMPING of well water by Nassau County is reaching a critical point, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation, and the department plans to meet with county officials to find ways to cut back on using wells.

title: The Elephant Under Lilco's Blanket
description: Would Long Island benefit from a public takeover of Lilco, the Island's electric utility? State leaders in Albany, Democratic and Republican, seem ready to embrace the concept. And last week Governor Cuomo formed a committee of experts to study its practicality.

title: HONORING THE NOVELIST Over a Century Ago The first United States geneal issue consists of two stamps, a 5-cent most commonly found in a red brown color and a 10-cent black. Authorized by act of Congress on March 3, 1847, the non-mandatory use of stamps to evidence prepayment of postage took effect July 1, 1847. As might be expected, these first United States stamps are avidly sought by collectors.   At the time the first stamps went into use, the 5-cent issue met the rate for single letters sent less than 300 miles. The 10-cent rate applied to longer distances. Single letters were those that weighed a half-ounce or less with every additional half-ounce being assessed an additional single rate of postage. If not prepaid, the postage fee was charged to the recipient of the letter.   Because the government did not have stamp printing facilities of its own, the work on the first stamps was contracted out to Rawdon, Wright, Hatch and Edson, a New York City company engaged in Bank Note engraving. Production delays ensued and the first stamps were available only in the New York post office on their effective date. Because of this first day scarcity, no covers are known to exist with a July 1, 1847 cancel. Earliest known use of the 10-cent is July 2. The 5-cent has been found with a July 7 earliest known usage.   The 5-cent issue features a portrait of Benjamin Franklin, the first Postmaster General of the United States. The stamp was issued without perforations on a thin, bluish wove paper. ''The Unted State Postage Stamps of the 19th Century'' by Lester G.Brookman attributes to the late Dr. Carroll Chase the study which ''dates'' the first issue by color. The 1847 printings are orange brown, bright orange brown, dark brown and black brown, while the late (1851) printings are deep brownish orange and dark brownish orange. An expert can date the printing of a given example by its color and the sharpness of the printing impression The Brookman book provides an example of the growth in value of this issue. A rare piece described as a rejoined block of six of the 5-cent 1847 in used condition is noted as having sold in 1966 for $1,159. The same piece, which was rejoined around 1918 when the late Stanley Ashbrook discovered a mate for his vertical strip of three in the collection of Judge Robert Emerson, was last offered at auction in 1982. It realized $32,000 in the Daniel F. Kelleher United States Rare Samp Collection auction.   The 10-cent issue bears George Washington's portrait. The stamp is extremely rare in unused condition, carrying a Scott catalogue value of $18,500. Important usages include the 10-cent bisect on cover, used to meet the 5-cent rate, which catalogues for $15,000 or more. The 10-cent and 5-cent used on the same cover are assigned a catalogue value of $18,500.   There are no known dangerous fakes of the 5-cent 1847 issue. Counterfeits of the 10-cent produced by the famous forger Jean de Sperati can be identified by a diagonal line towards the bottom of the left frame line. Fake bisect covers have also been manufactured and are best left to independent experts for detection.   Other potential problems exist in the mis-identification of unused 1875 official government reprints as the more valuable 1847 originals and the passing off of used stamps as unused issues after attempts have been made to wash off the cancellation. The reprints are easily identified when compared with known originals. Verification of unused 1847's should be left to experts although close examination of the front and back of a 5-cent may reveal the cancel, usually a pen-manuscripted ''X'' or diagonal line in the center of the stamp. Because of the black color of the 10-cent stamp, detecting cleaned cancels of this issue is more difficult.   With the reduction in postage rates that took effect July 1, 1851, the 1847 issue was demonitized as of that date. In the four years of use, approximately 3,700,000 5-cent stamps and 865,000 10-cent stamps were sold to the public. This compares with the 120,000,000 copies of each commemorative that are sold.   As with all early issues in limited supply, condition varies greatly with this issue. Value follows directly. A used 5-cent in top condition with wide margins can sell for $1,000 or more, while a damaged, but collectible copy can be had for as little as $50. The 10-cent used can range from $200 to $2,000 or more.   For the budget-minded, attractive reproductions can be found on the 1947 Centenary International Philatelic Exhibition (Cipex) souvenir sheet that has a value of $1.50. The colors are different, but the designs are much the same as the originals.
description: The Postal Service issued yesterday a 25-cent stamp honoring Jack London. The stamp was issued in Glen Ellen, Cal., the author's home in his later life and now the site of the Jack London State Historic Park. Mr. London's biographer, Russ Kingman, and Nancy L. George, executive assistant to the Postmaster General, were the principal speakers at the first day ceremony.

title: Pasadena
description: To the Editor: Thank you for including a picture of the Green Hotel in the articles on Pasadena, Calif. (Travel, Dec. 15).

title: ISRAELIS MEET TODAY ON DISPUTE WITH EGYPT
description: Key Labor and Likud Cabinet ministers will meet Sunday to decide whether Israel should submit a longstanding border dispute with Egypt to international arbitration.

title: ENGINEERING ANOTHER GREEN REVOLUTION
description: In about a month, if all goes according to plan, a historic experiment will take place in a strawberry patch in the Salinas Valley, about 90 miles south of here. Researchers with tanks on their backs will spray strawberry plants with genetically altered bacteria in a test aimed at protecting the plants from frost damage.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
GREATER SCAUP
description: Aythya marila Size: 15 to 21 inches; averaging about two pounds.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Finance column appeared with the wrong byline. It was written by Carole Gould.

title: RE-EMPLOYMENT PROJECT SET
description: WITH a $5.2 million grant awarded last October by the Federal Department of Labor, New Jersey hopes to begin this month a three-year experiment to see how quickly it can get people off unemployment-compensation rolls.

title: Q & A
description: Transfers to Vacancies Question:In May, I sent a registered letter to the managing agent of my rent-stabilized building requesting a transfer to a larger apartment. Three days ago, I learned that such a unit had been vacated. I called the agent and was told the owner isn't transferring tenants to vacant apartments. Can he refuse such a request? . . . D. G., Manhattan Answer: Yes, he can. There is nothing in the state rent regulations that requires a landlord to allow tenants to move to larger units, according to Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner in the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Seepage in a Co-op Question: Water has seeped through the outside walls of my co-op apartment. The managing agent has agreed to replaster the affected areas, but has refused to repaint. He keeps quoting the words ''proprietary lease.'' Who should pay for painting? . . . J. A. S., Riverdale, the Bronx Answer: Most proprietary leases say a tenant is responsible for painting and decoration of his apartment and the co-op board is responsible for repairs to the building's structure. In cases of water damage caused by seepage, most co-op boards would pay to plaster and repaint the damaged area to the ''standard and usual condition,'' but not an entire room and not elaborate painting and wallpapering, according to Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.

title: Civil War Is Likely
description: Two American diplomats traveled here from Manila recently to assess the political climate. Priests and journalists with whom they talked said their most frequent question was whether the militant opposition, the New People's Army, would give up and come down from the mountains if Ferdinand E. Marcos lost the presidency.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: MY LITTLE ISLAND. Written and illustrated by Frane Lessac. Lippincott. $11.50. (Ages 4 to 8) A visit to a Caribbean island told in the first-person by a boy who was born there.

title: ASSEMBLY SETS HEARING ON AUTO INSURANCE
description: THE first skirmish of the new legislative session will get under way this week when the new Republican-controlled Assembly holds the first of two public hearings on amending automobile-insurance laws to limit the rights of injured motorists to sue.

title: 200,000 Turn Out For Aquino in Philippines
description: Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition presidential candidate, drew the biggest crowds of the month-old campaign today and repeated her warning that President Ferdinand E. Marcos could impose martial law to halt the election if he fears he might lose.
