title: A STATE COMMISSIONER PITCHES IN
description: WHEN William Yourconis went to the Willimantic office of the State Department of Motor Vehicles last week, he got much quicker action than he expected.

title: An Old Debt
description: When West Germany's Deutsche Bank bought most of the Flick holding company last month, it acquired a potentially embarrassing liability - a $2-million claim on behalf of Jews forced into slave labor during World War II.

title: Elizabeth B. McMath To Wed J.H. Cumming
description: A June wedding is planned by Elizabeth Barrie McMath and James Hamilton Cumming, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barrie G. McMath of Far Hills, N.J., have announced. Mr. Cumming is the son of John Battin Cumming of New York and Marianne Loftus Cumming of Bethesda, Md.

title: Stan Rapp and Liz Forrest, Executives, Are Wed
description: Liz Forrest, president of Innovation Labs Inc., a market research firm in Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Stan Rapp, chairman and chief executive officer of the Rapp & Collins Group, a direct marketing concern based in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York.

title: FOR FISSCHER-DIESKAU AT 60, THE TRIBUTES ARE IN SONG
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau was born in Berlin in 1925, and his art, which has changed the face of singing and our understanding of song, was forged in a frightful crucible. The baritone's adolescence was divided between an impassioned immersion in the beauties of German song - the artistic embodiment of what is most noble in the German soul - and the encroachment of unbelievable horror in the living Germany around him.

title: Courts Will Be Villain On Gramm-Rudman
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MOZART FOR WINDS The Virtuoso Winds of the Mozart Orchestra will blow up a storm tonight in the second of three concerts in the orchestra's 1985-86 season. (The orchestra - in full, not just the winds - is in residence at the Camden campus of Rutgers University, where its conductor, Dr. Davis Jerome, is head of the music department. On its roster are members of the Philadelphia Orchestra and other professionals from the area.) The program, under Dr. Jerome, begins at 7 P.M. at the Church of St. Luke and the Epiphany, just across the bridge at 330 South 13th Street, Philadelphia, with Beethoven's seldom-heard Rondino for Eight Winds (Op. Post).

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Martin Luther King Classic, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. Four of the top boys' high school basketball teams from New York City will play four of the top teams on Long Island in this benefit for the United Negro College Fund. The scheduled games: North Babylon vs. Springfield Gardens, 11:30 A.M.; Wyandanch vs. Andrew Jackson, 1:15 P.M.; Hempstead vs. Boys and Girls, 3:15, and Uniondale vs. Hillcrest, 5:15 P.M. Expositions National Boat Show, at the New York Coliseum, 59th Street and Columbus Circle. Second day of the exposition, which runs through next Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Football Bears vs Los Angeles Rams, at Chicago, 12:30 P.M. National Football Confernce championship game. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 12:30 P.M.) Dolphins vs. New England Patriots, at Miami, American Football Conference championship game. Coach Don Shula of Miami is 5-0 in A.F.C. championship games. Coach Raymond Berry of the Patriots used to play under Shula at Baltimore. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. St. Louis Blues, at Madision Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Blues are the only team in the league that has not played the Rangers this season. Since St. Louis came into the league in the 1967-68 expansion, the Rangers have a 35-3-3 record against the team, and they have won the last six games against the Blues at the Garden.

title: 'NOTHING IS LOUDER THAN PEOPLE NOT LAUGHING'
description: THE COMIC STRIP, an intimate Manhattan club for aspiring stand-up comics, was buzzing. Word wound through the anxious line of ticket-buyers that, without fanfare, Eddie Murphy was going to drop by his old haunt to test some new material.

title: LIFE AFTER PINOCHET MAY NOT BEGIN FOR A WHILE
description: Politicians here often talk enthusiastically about life after President Augusto Pinochet. It is much more pleasant, after all, than contemplating their inability to nudge him closer to the negotiating table, much less unseat him.

title: TATTOO PARLOR OPPOSED IN BAYPORT
description: THE proposed opening of a combined tattoo parlor and T-shirt shop on Montauk Highway in Bayport has run into local opposition.

title: WINE, WOMEN AND FAMILY HARDBALL
description: THE LEBARON SECRET By Stephen Birmingham. 403 pp. Boston: Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: Straightening Out A Double Life
description: ROBERT L. GIPSON, prominent club member, expert locksmith and a ''citizen of the year'' in Port Richey, Fla., came clean last summer.

title: A CENTURY HENCE, OUR MUSIC WON'T SOUND THE SAME
description: Inevitably, inexorably, time will change how we look at the music of the 20th century. In the early 19th century, Beethoven and Spohr were equal titans, just as Salieri and Mozart had seemed a generation before. Now, except for the exhumations of Peter Shaffer, we have forgotten Salieri, and Spohr as well.

title: ENVIRONMENT
description: MOST land-disposal facilities for hazardous waste, both in New Jersey and nationally, have not complied with the latest Federal standards, but the effect on the state is still unclear.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ROADSIDE GEOLOGY OF NEW YORK. By Bradford B. Van Diver. (Mountain Press, P.O. Box 2399, Missoula, Mont. 59806, Paper, $12.95.) Like dissection of a once-living organism, the incisions made in the landscape during construction of the interstate highway system and other roads has dramatically exposed the working innards of the earth.

title: Funny Economists
description: To the Editor:

title: A DEEP FAITH IN OLD-FASHIONED EVIL
description: THE ENDLESS GAME By Bryan Forbes. 309 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: A TURNABOUT IN BOSTON: COUNCIL'S CHIEF IS BLACK
description: Last fall Bruce C. Bolling, a member of the City Council, signed a letter requesting a referendum on whether Roxbury, a predominantly black neighborhood, should secede from the city of Boston. The letter reflected a deep-seated sense among the city's blacks that they had been left out of the recent economic resurgence here.

title: A COZY NEIGHBORHOOD SPOT
description: IT'S easy to spot this little restaurant encased in the shell of a diner, but the resemblance stops there. The inside is warm and haimish , and what it may lack in style and imagination it makes up for in eagerness to please. Casa de Nikola is one of those cozy and unpretentious eating places every neighborhood should have. Nikola Grbic, the owner, presides at the stove, and his family takes obvious pride in staffing the dining room. The formula must be working; Casa de Nikola celebrates its eighth anniversary in Mamaroneck this year.

title: NEW YORKERS ETC.
description: THERE are all sorts of poor souls around who think that garbage is garbage is garbage. They are completely unaware that even the refuse of the world has its Rolls-Royces, Guccis and Saint Laurents.

title: POLES DISCOVER IT'S NOT 1948 ANYMORE
description: The idea was simple: an international convention of artists and scientists who would come to Poland this week to talk about world peace, and in so doing echo a conference of intellectuals held 37 years ago in Wroclaw. At the Wroclaw gathering Pablo Picasso presented his dove of peace and Albert Einstein sent a letter of greetings.

title: Dana B. Katzman To Wed
description: The engagement of Dana Beth Katzman to Randi Glenn Wiston has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David H. Katzman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Katzman graduated from the University of Rochester, as did her fiance, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Wiston of Valley Stream, L.I. She is a candidate for a master's degree in health advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College. He is a third-year student at the Boston University School of Dentistry.

title: KOCH WAGER PUTS MOONACHIE ON MAP
description: CRIES of ''Let's hunt bear!'' were quickly replaced by whispers of ''Two cheese steaks to go'' last Sunday as die-hard Giants fans at Manny's Restaurant here watched their football team lose in Chicago.

title: R.A. Chipman Fiance Of Stacy E. Futterman
description: Jack Futterman of New York and Eileen Tepper of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacy Ellen Futterman to Richard Alan Chipman, the son of Elaine A. Chipman of Hollywood, Fla., and Donald J. Chipman of New York. A summer wedding is planned.

title: VIOLINIST IN BACH RECITIALS
description: GEOFFREY MICHAELS, a Cherry Hill resident who teaches violin at Princeton University, will perform Bach's complete works for unaccompanied violin in recitals here the next two Friday evenings.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Love at First Sight Some novels have simply irresistible beginnings, like Rose Macaulay's ''Crewe Train'' (Carroll & Graf).

title: DISCOVERING L.I.: A PHOTO OFYSSEY
description: ''I FOUND Long Island tantalizing because of what I knew of it,'' said Steve Dunwell, a Boston-based photographer with a landscapist's eye, ''and challenging because of what I didn't know.''

title: DARING AND DRAMATIC SUITS
description: Amid winter's snowy glare, swimsuits for the 1986 season are making their bright debut, all shimmering and shiny for this new year.

title: The 1987 Budget Just May Have a Familiar Ring
description: President Reagan gave a preview in his radio address yesterday of how he would shape the Federal balance sheet for the 1987 fiscal year so as to meet the $144 billion deficit ceiling mandated by the new budget-balancing law. Listeners familiar with the Administration's previous performances were hardly surprised.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SUBURBIA IN THE LENS Jeff Gates, a California photographer, makes some strong statements about suburbia in his exhibition opening today at Gallery Jazz in New Haven. Thirty pictures are divided into two series, one depicting a neighborhood in progressive stages of abandonment as a thruway is paved over it; the other explores the discrepancies between advertising rhetoric in praise of the American dream, and the reality of living in one of hundreds of identical tract houses.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DANSVILLE. By Robin McCorquodale. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Robin McCorquodale's first novel, set in rural Texas in the late 1940's, concerns a beautiful war widow who falls in love with a younger man, the 19-year-old son of a wealthy rancher.

title: Mailbox; Remembering Harry Hopman
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lieut. McLean To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Lieut. Emmi Alexandra McLean, U.S.N., and Lieut. William Hooker E. Cheney, U.S.N., has been announced by Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Ellis A. McLean of Great Falls, Mont., parents of the future bride.

title: AMERICAN ECONOMICS: 100 YEARS IN A RUT
description: WHAT would the founders of the American Economic Association, which celebrated its 100th birthday late last month, think of the association's and the profession's accomplishments in a century's time? Not much, I fear, after reviewing an account of the group's founding by its prime mover, Richard T. Ely, in his 1938 autobiography, ''Ground Under Our Feet.'' The same shortcomings that led Ely and others to establish the A.E.A. - especially the profession's enslavement to an unscientific and ideological ''economic theory'' in defiance of abundant, contradictory evidence from the real world - still provide the discipline's underpinnings.

title: CHEERLEADERS TO PRESS CASE
description: IS cheerleading a sport?

title: BOWIE'S LEG NOT BROKEN
description: The Portland Trail Blazer center Sam Bowie does not have a broken leg, despite earlier reports, a spokesman for the team said today.

title: 10 'Commandments' for Negotiating With the Soviet Union
description: As the United States and Soviet Union prepare to resume the fourth round of the strategic arms talks in Geneva, it is useful to reflect on lessons learned in past negotiations with Moscow. While much of the discussion on arms control of course concerns the merits of substantive positions, it is also important to consider negotiating techniques.

title: THE DANCE: JAZZ STYLES BY DANNY BURACZESKI
description: IS jazz dancing simply a matter of swinging hips and jutting pelvises? A program by the Jazzdance/Danny Buraczeski Dance Company on Thursday at the Joyce Theater suggested that Mr. Buraczeski believes it's more than that. One of the program's three new pieces was a taut-limbed jazz workout, another took a sad look at the life of a great jazz musician, and a third was an unabashed ode to Manhattan.

title: TOPICS
description: WHAT can be more frustrating than trying to feed an independent 10-month-old? Listening to our pediatrician say that vitamins and milk will suffice until our daughter, Rachel, decides to open her mouth. Unfortunately, vitamins are not on the list of her daily consumed foods, and even the Cheerio infatuation is dying out. Rachel will eat paper, lint, rocks - and milk!

title: Miss Silberstein To Marry in July
description: The engagement of Margery Beth Silberstein and Dr. Leonard Stuart Bloom has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. N. Ronald Silberstein of Chestnut Hill and South Dennis, Mass. Dr. Bloom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Bloom of Bethesda and Ocean City, Md. A July wedding is planned.

title: Dept. of Weft Ikat
description: Every institution in Washington has its own insider's way of saying things. At the Textile Museum, this is reflected in some intriguing language in its current newsletter.

title: SENATOR, IN TOKYO, SAYS JAPAN MUST ALTER OUTLOOK ON TRADE
description: Senator John C. Danforth, one of the most outspoken critics of Japan's trade practices, said today that the mind-set of Japan must change for that nation to remedy its trade imbalance with the United States.

title: THE MASCULINIZATION OF MEDICINE
description: SYMPATHY AND SCIENCE Women Physicians in American Medicine. By Regina Markell Morantz-Sanchez. 464 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: REAGNA LISTS TERMS FOR LIFTING LIBYAN SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan, in an interview made public today, said Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would have to end Libya's financial support for terrorist groups and its training camps for them before the economic sanctions imposed by the United States would be lifted.

title: Steve Reich at Fisher Hall
description: Steve Reich and Musicians will perform an all-Reich concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday, Jan. 20, as part of the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series. George Manahan will conduct a 30-piece orchestra and 10 singers for the New York premiere of the chamber version of ''The Desert Music,'' and ''New York Counterpoint,'' for clarinet and pre-recorded tape, will have its world premier. Tickets, at $17.50, $12 and $9, are available at the box office or through CenterCharge, (212) 874-6770.

title: COURT BUILDINGS, LACKING SPACE, TARGETS OF PLAN FOR EXPANSION
description: WHEN Phillip N. Armentano, an assistant public defender, goes to court in Manchester, he often finds himself picking up the case in the middle.

title: REAL-ESTATE PLAN
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators is expected to decide soon - perhaps before the month is out - whether to authorize the county to purchase the 16-mile-long railroad roadbed that once served the old Putnam line of the New York Central Railroad.

title: Confronting Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: SANCTIONS THREAT SHOCKS DAMASCUS
description: Warnings by Reagan Administration officials that there was a possibility of imposing punitive sanctions against Syria, such as were imposed against Libya, have dismayed senior Syrian officials and Western diplomats here.

title: Miss Mayer Is Married
description: The marriage of Melissa Ann Mayer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Mayer of Bethesda, Md., to John Ely Pflieger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pflieger of New York, took place yesterday. Msgr. James Reedy performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Roman Catholic Church in Bethesda.

title: C.E.O.'s PROBE THE FUTURE OF BUSINESS
description: THE world of business, as any corporate bookshelf can attest, is a world of money, products, technologies and systems. But it is also, of course, a world of people, as two recent books go a good distance to describe. One book is mainly instructive and the other mainly entertaining, but both help to reveal the human factor behind the balance sheets.

title: SOCIAL DRAMA SPEAKS WITH NEW FORCE
description: An impressive and rather surprising feature of the ongoing theatrical season is the prominence of works of pith and moment. They come in new and old shapes, grave and funny, domestic and imported. Whether their appearance signals a resurgence of a theater of ideas remains to be seen, but these plays are doing well enough to suggest there is an audience out there that is not averse to being faced with the serious side of life. Shepard, Shawn and Shaw, Fugard and Frayn speak to us of such matters as apartheid, extermination camps, prostitution, urban dislocation and the macho mania of the American male.

title: WHY BALANCHINE SOMETIMES CHOSE EXTRAVAGANT SETS
description: When the curtain goes up on three of the seven Balanchine ballets in repertory this week at New York City Ballet, the stage will not be set simply with its all-purpose blue cyclorama and black side pieces. The three works -''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze,' '' ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet'' and ''Gounod Symphony'' - each with its own elaborate decor, are exceptions to the generally neutral surroundings against which Balanchine's ballets are usually danced. Indeed, it was widely assumed for decades that Balanchine actually objected to costumes and sets for most of his works. Tights and leotards seemed to be his costume of choice. Ironically, Balanchine never even saw two of the three stage designs during his lifetime.

title: Social Events; Manhattan Divertissements
description: Dinner and a Mystery Jan. 16 - Founded in 1893, the Visiting Nurse Service of New York is the nation's largest voluntary home health agency, providing home visits to thousands each year in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens. A benefit for the service will start with a 5:30 P.M. buffet in its Jacobean-style board room in the imposing Lamont mansion at 107 East 70th Street. A ride to the Imperial Theater for the 8 P.M. showing of ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' will follow. Tickets $150, or for performance alone, $100 or $75, from 212-794-9200, extension 720. Bipartisan Effort Jan. 19 - The Lenox Hill Democratic Club and the Ivy Republican Club don't agree on very much, but when they do, an agreeable time may be had by all. The two political parties will hold a party at the Bombay Palace, 30 West 52d Street, on a point they do agree on: the need to help the city's homeless. City, state and national politicians are expected at the benefit, with buffet and a cash bar from 4 P.M. to 7 P.M. Tickets $15, at the door. Bravos for Ballet Jan. 22 - The School of American Ballet's annual winter benefit, the eighth it has held and its most important endowment fund-raiser of the year, will honor the school's faculty. Alexandra Danilova, teacher and former prima ballerina, will be the hostess at a black-tie evening of cocktails, performance and dinner at the New York State Theater.

title: CHILDRENS' BOOKS
description: PRAIRIE SONGS By Pam Conrad. Illustrated by Darryl S. Zudeck. 167 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 10 and up) DAKOTA DUGOUT By Ann Turner. Illustrated by Ronald Himler. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12) GROWING up with a computer and a video cassette recorder, it is hard for children to imagine life before technology transformed this country. In our urban society, few children have the opportunity to test themselves against the rigors of nature. The frontiers they dream of are the fantasy worlds of other planets, and they imagine facing them not with ax and plow but with robots and laser guns.

title: ROCKETS EDGE BULLETS AT BUZZER BY 87-86
description: Akeem Olajuwon tipped in a basket at the final buzzer tonight to rally the Rockets to an 87-86 victory over the Washington Bullets that extended Houston's home unbeaten string to 20.

title: SEVERAL PROGRAMS FACE ELIMINATION IN REAGAN BUDGET
description: President Reagan will propose eliminating several Federal programs in 1987 to achieve more than a third of the $50 billion in savings required under a new budget-balancing law, White House officials said today.

title: 3 SOPRANOS AND PIANIST IN RECITALS; Deborah Williams
description: Deborah Williams The third soprano of the week -Deborah Williams at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night - was distinguished by the taste and originality in most of her program. Schoenberg's six ''Brettl-Lieder'' was barroom music raised to tremendously sophisticated levels.

title: N.C.A.A. TO REVIEW ACADEMIC STANDARD
description: The 284 major athletic colleges and universities will decide this week whether to invoke the controversial N.C.A.A. Proposition 48 that requires a student-athlete to achieve a minimum score on entrance examinations.

title: TRYING TO STEM VIOLENCE IN THE SCHOOLS
description: A YEAR ago, John Boccuzzi Jr., the president of the senior class at Stamford High School, learned firsthand about the issue of violence in the state's public schools.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Hudson River Valley: A History and Guide By Tim Mulligan. 205 pages. Illustrated. Random House $8.95. Paperback.

title: BOLIVIA COCO GROWERS ARE SAID TO EASE SIEGE
description: Most of the 17,000 coca-leaf farmers who had encircled a camp of 245 narcotics officers quit their siege today, officials said, adding that military intervention would not be needed.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING CHANGES IS A WINTER PROJECT
description: ONE of the main criticisms of the average American garden might well be that gardeners have exercised too little imagination in designing and planting them. All too frequently, the gardens along a particular street are carbon copies of one another, especially if the houses are similar in architecture.

title: BATTLE OVER BLACK HISTORY'S PLACE IN A CITY'S HEART
description: Straddling the Schuylkill, stretching from Center City northeast to the suburbs, Fairmount Park has long laid claim to Philadelphia's heart. ''As fair a landscape and as charming a scene as ever gladdened the eye of mortal man since the gates of Eden were closed to human eyes,'' Assemblyman James Miller called it more than a century ago.

title: A WORD FROM TAL
description: What would you think if you heard someone say: ''I feel that there are nowadays already no completely original new combinations, or practically none. But in any tournament you can find a fresh arrangement, an original coloring, or a combination which is already known''?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If Reagan came here, he would change his mind. He would see that I don't live in trenches and wear hand grenades in my belt and a pistol.''

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING CHANGES IS A WINTER PROJECT
description: ONE of the main criticisms of the average American garden might well be that gardeners have exercised too little imagination in designing and planting them. All too frequently, the gardens along a particular street are carbon copies of one another, especially if the houses are similar in architecture.

title: PLANT IN OHIO LEAKS THE GAS THAT KILLED WORKER LAST WEEK
description: A monitoring system installed at three Ohio plants that make nuclear materials showed that 109 pounds of slightly radioactive gas escaped in one week from one of them, the authorities said today.

title: Alison A. Porter Weds William Michael Resk
description: Alison Ann Porter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond James Porter of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Michael Resk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. William Resk of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Frank Pugliese performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle.

title: CD'S SPUR SALES OF CLASSICS
description: In the estimation of Ray Edwards of Tower Records, CD's have been the major factor in the strong sales growth of classical recordings in the past year, accounting for half the sales of classical music. At Tower's store at Fourth Street and Broadway, classical music accounts for 25 to 28 percent of all sales, while at the uptown store, at 66th Street and Broadway, the figure is 33 to 35 percent. While the total floor space allotted to classical at both stores has remained the same, the rapidly growing space for compact disks is coming out of the space for LP's. Cassettes continue to hold a large share of the market.

title: Platinum Mine Fires 20,000 In South Africa
description: When South African platinum miners refused to call off a six-day strike last week, their employer turned to a drastic solution: It dismissed 20,000 workers, all of them nonwhite, then paid them off and sent them home on buses.

title: Julianne and Jeanmarie Skawinski Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Skawinski of Washington Crossing, Pa., have announced the engagements of their daughters Julianne Skawinski and Jeanmarie Skawinski to Specialist 4 Erik F. Andersen of the Army and Christopher A. Callahan, respecively.

title: FROM THE PENTAGON, AN ULTIMATE BATTLE PLAN
description: THE military is rarely very explicit about how the United States would wage war with the Soviet Union. But now Adm. James D. Watkins, the Chief of Naval Operations, has provided an unusually candid glimpse of the tactics being considered in Pentagon war rooms. In an article published by the United States Naval Institute, he acknowledged that in a major nonnuclear conflict the Navy might seek to attack Soviet submarines carrying nuclear missiles. Such a strategy, conceded Admiral Watkins, the first nuclear submarine officer to rise to the Navy's top job, ''is not without risk.'' Some analysts maintain that the risks would in fact be considerable, and that the strategy could lead the Soviet Union to respond with nuclear weapons. Following are excerpts from the admiral's article, ''The Maritime Strategy'': The United States is inevitably a maritime nation, and the United States and its Navy have inescapable global responsibilities. A carefully designed strategy has always been an imperative, but the need for a sound strategy has grown all the more important as the Soviets developed a formidable blue-water Navy able to challenge U.S. interests worldwide. Accordingly, three years ago, we reviewed our extant strategy - a strategy with broad contours reasonably well understood, but one which had not been submitted to the rigor inherent in codification. The result of that effort was the Maritime Strategy.

title: WAR GAMES
description: WRAP IT IN FLAGS By Robert Terrall. 339 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: January 12, 1986
British Ship Crushed In Antarctic Pack Ice
description: The British Antarctic expedition mother ship Southern Quest sank in the Ross Sea Saturday night, trapped and crushed by pack ice while on its way to pick up three men who spent a year walking and skiing to the South Pole.

title: THE GRANDSON OF A SLAVE TAKES OFFICE IN VIRGINIA
description: Shortly after noon today L. Douglas Wilder, the grandson of a slave, was sworn in as Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, becoming the first black to hold a statewide executive office in the South since Reconstruction.

title: IN EX-BANK, ITALIAN WITH INTEREST
description: WITHOUT the name as a clue, you would not suspect that the building now occupied by Bank Restaurant in Astoria, Queens, was indeed once a bank. But now that you know, you see that separating the bar and dining room is a framework that suggests tellers' windows. It must have been a small neighborhood branch without marble pilasters or heavy bronze doors. And the restaurant is now a pleasant neighborhood spot for dining.

title: FOR PHILHARMONIC, NEW HORIZONS
description: ON Friday, when Seymour Lipkin takes the stage of the Fine Arts Center at the State University of New York at Stony Brook to perform Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini'' with the Long Island Philharmonic, it will be a homecoming of sorts.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Theater page of the Arts and Leisure section Dec. 29 about Toni Morrison's play ''Dreaming Emmett'' misidentified the set designer. He is Dale F. Jordan.

title: PRIVATE AID FILLING A SOCIAL-SERVICE NEED
description: IN Mount Vernon, youngsters in trouble are living in a shelter rather than being incarcerated for their misdeeds. In New Rochelle, that city's two colleges are advising municipal leaders on how to improve the urban condition. In Stamford, Conn., families are building houses by the sweat of their brows through a neighborhood program designed to provide them new homes at about two-thirds of the market cost.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE 'INCORRUPTIBLE CASHIER' LIVES
description: ONE OF the nation's high-technology companies has not only passed its centennial year, but significant numbers of its earliest product are also still in active use and in high demand among collectors.

title: 3 SOPRANOS AND PIANIST IN RECITALS; Louisa Jonason
description: Louisa Jonason The recital and the operatic stage are different much as radio drama and its television counterpart are. The first deprives our eyes while massaging our imaginations; the second uses one sense to reinforce the other.

title: TOPICS
description: WHEN I was a teen-ager, I remember wishing that I was Marilyn Monroe so that Joe DiMaggio would love me. This fantasy was not a product of homoerotic tendencies or an unconscious transvestite identification. Rather, it reflected a common Bronx neurosis of the 1940's - the wistful dream of being even a second-string major league infielder rather than Albert Einstein.

title: THIS YEAR, SMALL BOATS ARE THE BIG SELLERS
description: YACHTING'S reputation as a rich man's sport is not holding up well these days. One has only to visit the New York National Boat Show, which opened yesterday and runs through next Sunday, to realize that the industry is reaching out to the masses. Small boats, which once were used largely as yacht tenders, are becoming the bread and butter of the boating industry. Both powerboat and sailboat manufacturers are thriving on small-boat sales. The National Marine Manufacturers Association, which is sponsoring the 76th edition of the show at the New York Coliseum, reports that an outboard runabout is the best-selling boat in the business. Part of the reason is the price. An 18-foot fiberglass boat with a 35-horsepower engine and boat trailer retails for about $6,600, the equivalent of a low-cost compact car. And as with buying a new car, marine loans are readily available this year for installment buying.

title: LOBSTER PSYCHOLOGY
description: IT MAY SEEM A trifle farfetched, but it has long been my conceit that a diner's approach to the enjoyment of a lobster is the gastronomic equivalent of a Rorschach test. If you look on the lobster's carapace as a beastly piece of ugly armor, you are inclined to be notably fastidious. By contrast, if you regard his roguish mantle as a thing of beauty, you are likely to be joyously primitive. I am of the latter persuasion.

title: SUPPLY-SIDE'S INTELLECTUAL GURU
description: DABBING at a huge oil painting in his Morningside Heights apartment last month, Robert A. Mundell was gloating. The House of Representatives had just passed a tax simplification bill that would reduce the maximum income tax rate to 38 percent from 50 percent. And, although the tax cutting did not go as far as Mr. Mundell would have liked, he saw it as a personal victory.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
ON WORKING YOUR WAY THROUGH THE MONTHLY TELEPHONE BILL
description: THERE was a time when getting the telephone bill at our house was a normal, routine, everyday occurrence, one free of tension, mystification or trauma. This is no longer the case. Today, just the sight of the window envelope with my name visible through the clear plastic, the blue bell logo winking at me slyly from the upper left-hand corner and the name ''New Jersey Bell'' situated majestically above it all is enough to bring moisture to my upper lip, chills to my extremities and a sharp pain to my right temple.

title: LILCO'S FATE: A SUDDEN SHIFT TO ALBANY
description: UNTIL last Monday, the movement for a state takeover of the embattled Long Island Lighting Company had been strictly grassroots, pressed by local citizens fearful of the Shoreham nuclear power plant opening and irate over rising electricity rates.

title: OCEAN YATCHS OFFER EFFICIENCY, LUXURY
description: IN spite of the obstacles in transporting an object the size of a 44-foot sportfishing yacht across one of Manhattan's bridges and through the streets to the New York Coliseum, boat builders and transport professionals manage to set up an exhibit for the New York National Boat Show every year. And this year, Ocean Yachts, of Egg Harbor City, N.J., has earned the title of Queen of the Show with a 44-foot Super Sport yacht, The Super Sport is typical of the ocean yachts line of luxury sportfishermen, yachts designed with two goals in mind - to function as fast and efficient fishing machines, and to provide luxury in living accommodations. The Super Sport handles the performance part with a pair of Detroit Diesel 6-71TI engines that give her speeds of more than 30 knots -important for the sportfishing enthusiast who would rather spend his time fishing than just traveling to-and-from the fishing grounds. The luxury part comes with the sumptuous interior, full air-conditioning and reverse-cycle heating, modern galley and an entertainment center with color television, AM/FM receivers and a stereo cassette.

title: A Marcos Charge Irks Mrs. Aquino
description: Corazon C. Aquino tried to make herself perfectly clear last week: She is not a Communist, never has been one and, if she beats Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos in next month's election, will not allow a Communist in her cabinet. The widow of the assassinated opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., also challenged Mr. Marcos to ''put up or shut up'' on his much-repeated charge that the opposition was ''bedding with Communists.''

title: Tornadoes in Bermuda Tear Roofs Off Homes
description: Tornadoes hit Bermuda's south and north shores today, tearing roofs from at least 30 homes, sinking boats and causing other damage, officials said. No casualties were reported.

title: UNWED, BUT JUST ANOTHER MOTHER
description: THE two women had never been close. Lucy was a very casual housekeeper, in love with books and music. Margaret, her sister-in-law, was extremely neat and practical-minded. They both, however, had strong and outspoken opinions about life.

title: GLOOMY RUNES AND LOONY SPOONS
description: THE ROUNDHOUSE VOICES Selected and New Poems. By Dave Smith. 182 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95. SELECTED POEMS #1963-1983. By Charles Simic. 186 pp. New York: George Braziller. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. A SENSE of specific place is essential to Dave Smith, but different times flow together in his work. As he says in ''Tide Pools,'' ''I duck under in time, holding my breath.'' So, when asked about poetic influence, he often tends to cite such medieval poems as ''The Seafarer'' and ''The Wanderer,'' gloomy 10th-century songs of isolation set in seascapes one imagines filmed by the young Ingmar Bergman. They are meditations on wyrd, or fate, spoken as darkness endlessly approaches over the hwaelweg (whale-way) by weary outcasts who are nostalgic for home and brood alliteratively over wintry waves. Such poems resound in Dave Smith's work, not only in his occasional use of the Old English alliterative line, but in the fatalistic conviction of isolation beneath his celebrations of familial love and masculine courage. He is sometimes blunt to a fault: ''The truth is we were alone, and are,'' while - he says in another wyrd-obsessed poem - ''unbearable stars yet wheel / in bright, ubiquitous malice.''

title: JURORS ARE NAMED FOR PULITZERS IN JOUNALISM
description: Columbia University has chosen a jury of 65 newspaper editors and executives to submit nominations for this year's Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title: Rock Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: LANGUAGE UNDER SURVEILLANCE: THE WRITER AND THE STATE
description: WHETHER by sloppiness or cunning, the theme of this year's PEN Congress - the international meeting of writers that begins today in New York - is almost meaningless. ''The Writer's Imagination and the Imagination of the State'' is a vacant phrase. Its grammar limps. As William Blake and George Orwell remind us, bad grammar is a symptom: it tells of a deeper muddle or mendacity in public and private affairs. The phrase could signify ''ways in which writers imagine the nature or forms or history of the state, of the body politic.'' It could also mean, with obscure portent, ''the ways in which the (personified) state imagines things, the manner in which Washington, Moscow and Monrovia think, fantasize about themselves, about writers, about matters sundry.'' Neither reading carries conviction or any incisive provocation.

title: TROTTIER GETS 400TH
description: The Islanders now consider themselves a team clearly on the rebound. Tonight, they humbled the Detroit Red Wings, 8-2, at Nassau Coliseum, their second consecutive victory here. The Islanders have scored 17 goals in their last two games after scoring just three in the previous two losses to Minnesota and Chicago.

title: Time Is the Enemy of Nuclear Stability; Ban Is Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Osher to Wed
description: Nina Lynne Osher and David Laurance Kopp plan to be married in April, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul J. Osher of Wesley Hills, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Kopp, vice president of the Kopp Brothers Corporation, a real-estate development company in Ramsey, N.J., is the son of Judith Kopp of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and the late Marvin Kopp. Miss Osher is a program assistant for the American Diabetes Association in White Plains.

title: Music
description: The Residents, who are at the Ritz on Wednesday, are not merely seldom seen performers. Although they have been making odd, adventurous, and frequently influential recordings of electronic pop and sonic moonscapes for a decade now, they have never allowed themselves to be glimpsed in public, unless in costume or disguise. Their visages have not adorned any of their numerous record covers.

title: Timothy Palmer And Tina Laidlaw To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Ziegler of Bainbridge Island, Wash., of the engagement of Mrs. Ziegler's daughter, Christina Laidlaw, to Timothy Locke Palmer, a son of Glenn Palmer of Binghamton, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Palmer. The future bride, who is known as Tina, is a daughter also of the late David Laidlaw of Old Lyme, Conn.

title: MAIMI NEEDS DAVENPORT'S FULL ATTENTION
description: SOMEHOW, some way, there is always a Ron Davenport on the Miami Dolphins, a 230-pound (or bigger) fullback able to punch over for a first down or a touchdown on a short-yardage play.

title: WRITERS, POLITICS AND REALITY
description: William F. Buckley Jr. meets Norman Mailer and Kurt Vonnegut on ''Firing Line'' today in a very civilized, seldom acerbic, encounter. Mr. Buckley represents a conservative philosophy, of course; Mr. Mailer and Mr. Vonnegut are somewhere left of center. In a way, their putative topic - ''What does PEN have to offer?'' - is a guise. PEN, an acronym for poets, essayists and novelists, opens its 48th international congress tomorrow in New York. On ''Firing Line,'' Mr. Mailer and Mr. Vonnegut say that PEN is not a political organization, although Mr. Buckley is suspicious. The real topic, however, isn't PEN; the subject is something larger: Where have our artists, writers and intellectuals been politically, and where are they going now? ''Firing Line'' will be shown at 1 this afternoon on WNET/Channel 13.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ANDES FOLK MUSIC On the lookout for the new and exciting - who says a library has to be stodgy? - the music advisory committee at the Port Washington Public Library has really struck it exotic with its entry today in its concert series, Tahuantinsuyo. The word is Incan for ''Four Corners of the World,'' and the quartet performs authentic music from the Andes. All recent arrivals from their native lands, Pepe Santana from Ecuador, Guillermo Guererro from Peru and Alcides Lozo and Isaac Lopes from Bolivia, play pre-Columbian music on instruments they make, just to keep the sound genuine. The concert is at 3 P.M. at the library, 245 Main Street, and it is free.

title: IN THE WEST, CONCERN OVER ACID RAIN
description: ACID precipitation threatens many high-altitude lakes in the American West, says Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric physicist in the New York City office of the Environmental Defense Fund.

title: 2 Prosecutors Removed In School Abuse Case
description: Two of the three prosecutors in the child molestation case against a nursery school here have been removed, the District Attorney's office said today.

title: 'A WORD FROM YOU' -- CONFESSIONS OF AN EX-BLURB WRITER
description: My agent dropped a hint in the offhand manner for which she is famous. Soon I would come to know the unfamiliar rites and rituals of a successful publication. Auctions, floor bids, first serial rights, a promotional tour. ''And oh, are you going to get books in the mail,'' she said with a faint smile.

title: Facing Up to Acid Rain
description: President Reagan's special investigator has discovered that acid rain is a twofold problem. It is ruining the environment, reports Drew Lewis, and eroding America's relationship with Canada. ''The seriousness of the problem, especially as it affects diplomatic relations with Canada, dictates that we act,'' he has told the President.

title: ASSESSING THE RECORD-SETTING SPEAKER O'NEILL
description: When the second session of the 99th Congress convenes next week, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will begin his 10th year as Speaker of the House. The Massachusetts Democrat, who plans to retire at the end of the session, will thus have set a record for the longest consecutive tenure as Speaker.

title: Confusion at Aqueduct
description: Even the winning bettors were unhappy after the running of the fifth race at Aqueduct yesterday. With the fillies and mares in the gate for the six-furlong allowance, Miss Otani began thrashing about and kicked Mostly Memories, who was in the adjoining stall.

title: Pope Condemns Terrorism
description: Pope John Paul II called terrorist acts ''crimes against humanity'' today and called on the United Nations not to accept member countries that violate the principles of its charter ''by accepting to compromise with terrorism.'' But the Pope also condemned reprisals against terrorists that take innocent lives.

title: Glut Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: HUMANE SOCIETY CITES WORKERS' STRESS
description: ROD MAGOON took a job at the Connecticut Humane Society in Waterford 11 years ago because he loves animals and enjoys caring for them. As it turns out, one of his duties is to inject ailing and unwanted dogs and cats with a lethal dose of sodium pentobarbital and then put their bodies into an incinerator.

title: WHEN TREES FALL IN THESE FORESTS, THEY ARE HEARD
description: The green serenity of the scenes belies the ferocity of the faraway battles fought over them. The country's vast national forests have become the focus for numerous political and economic struggles that will decide their fate and shape.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Monterey Pop Directed by D. A. Pennebaker, 1967 Sony Video 72 minutes. $59.95 How quaint it seems today - the 1967 world of hippies, love-ins, Day-Glo-painted buses and acid rock.

title: Indonesia's Neighbors Fear Expansionism
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPOSED FEDERAL VOUCHER PLAN BAD FOR PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEMS
description: EDUCATION Secretary William J. Bennett's thinly veiled plan to direct public education funds to the private schools comes as no surprise to the education community. After being thwarted by lack of legislative success with the tuition tax credit approach and being sidetracked by last July's United States Supreme Court decision barring Chapter I services to students on the premises of religiously affiliated schools, it was only a matter of time until the United States Department of Education devised a new method. On Nov. 13, the Secretary announced the latest nostrum - the voucher plan.

title: CONTRIBUTORS HONOR FAMILIES BY GIVING TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund make donations to honor their children or grandchildren. They wish to share some of their families' good fortune and happiness.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING CHANGES IS A WINTER PROJECT
description: ONE of the main criticisms of the average American garden might well be that gardeners have exercised too little imagination in designing and planting them. All too frequently, the gardens along a particular street are carbon copies of one another, especially if the houses are similar in architecture.

title: BATTLE OVER 2 TOWNS CREEKS
description: THERE is nothing new about disputes between officials of Long Island towns and New York State over who controls local waterways, but a wrangle over boating rights in two Shelter Island creeks has produced a novel theory of divided jurisdiction.

title: Another Toxic Chemical Leak
description: The story that emerged from Gore, Okla., last weekend started out as a description of a nuclear accident - a worker's death after a storage- tank rupture at a nuclear-fuel processing plant released a cloud of radioactive gas. But as Federal investigators reviewed what happened, it began to look more like a chemical accident, and its causes sounded distressingly familiar.

title: Some Liberal Thinking
description: SINCE LIBERALS were put on the endangered species list last summer, their population has leveled off at about 40. The last official count, made in November, showed 20 female liberals and 17 males.

title: WHAT STANDARDS FOR CORPORATE CRIME?
description: AT ANY COST Corporate Greed, Women, and the Dalkon Shield. By Morton Mintz. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: ATONING FOR HOLIDAY FEASTS: SPICES ENLIVEN PLAIN DISHES
description: PLAIN cooking, the saying goes, is for plain cooks. But after the holidays, to atone for the overeating that started sometime around Thanksgiving and continued through the New Year, many of us turn to the plainest food we can think of. We go from overindulgence in such fattening things as foie gras, roast duck and chocolate mousse cake to a round of fish broiled without salt or butter, unseasoned steamed vegetables, and chicken from which the delectable skin has been removed. This can be punishing.

title: POP: FOLK AND FUNK, BY LILI ANEL
description: LILI ANEL, the Bronx-born singer, songwriter and guitarist who was presented in a showcase at Folk City Thursday evening, has an impressively rich, dark folk-pop alto that could be channeled in any of several stylistic directions. Hearing her, one is bound to make comparisons with other similarly endowed singers.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS Jan. 12, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Happy Ending
description: To the Editor: At 6 in the morning we arrived by car at the airport in Tenerife. Much to our dismay we discovered that we had left all of our Spanish money in our room at the hotel.

title: Providence Finds A New Slogan
description: THEY looked for something that would encompass the character of Providence, a slogan that could be used to promote Rhode Island's capital for tourism, business and conventions.

title: Photo Science and Art
description: To the Editor:

title: 82D BIRTHDAY NEAR, WILLIAM L. SHIRER KEEPS BUSY ON MEMOIRS AND A PLAY
description: From his writing table, William L. Shirer looked out on snow, birch trees and an empty bird feeder.

title: KENYA SEEN THROUGH WRITERS' EYES
description: Early Friday morning Abde pulled up in front of the Norfolk Hotel in Nairobi. Lean, with light black skin and dark wavy hair, he was impatient, even moderately disdainful, of the tourists who come to visit Kenya's game preserves. Most often he spoke in a hoarse bellow, as if to make up for the gaps in his English.

title: A DOCUMENTARY LOOKS AT THE WORLD OF CHILDHOOD ILLNESS
description: More than 2 million of America's children, a new documentary reports, are ''chronically ill'' - a medical classification that translates into frequent trips to the hospital, sorrow and uncertainty for parents and steady grappling with life's larger questions. In ''The Gift of Life,'' HBO's ''America Undercover'' series looks at two of these children, both born with a congenital heart defect called truncus arteriosis, and how their conditions transform the lives and attitudes of their families. Produced and directed by Bill Couturie - who has previously worked as a producer for the two acclaimed studies of the Debolts, a West Coast couple who adopted 20 handicapped children - the hourlong documentary has its premiere tonight at 10.

title: CRAZY EDDIE TO PUT ITS HOME IN EDISON
description: CRAZY EDDIE INC., the electronics retailer with 23 stores in the tristate area -6 of them in New Jersey -will move its corporate headquarters to Edison in the spring.

title: GAF, A BIT RICHER, GIVES UP ON CARBIDE
description: GAF dropped its bid for Union Carbide, but walked away with an $81 million profit. Its battle to take over the troubled Carbide was extraordinarily complicated, with offers and counteroffers that bid the price up to what analysts said would have been a prohibitive level for GAF. Carbide will complete its buyback of 55 percent of its shares for $85 each, but GAF will retain a 10 percent stake. Some analysts say that indicates that GAF could zero in again on Carbide.

title: Fugard on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE MEN IN MORE MINK
description: ONCE men's fur coats were big, bulky, roughly stitched affairs of raccoon, wolf, unplucked nutria or beaver with the aura of the Great North Woods. But these days the approach is more civilized and the choices far greater.

title: Prelude to Glory
description: It may be a bit early to start practicing his Heisman acceptance speech, but Tony VanZant has to be an early favorite to win the 1989 trophy. After finishing his three-year high school career with 6,138 yards and 91 touchdowns, VanZant has been named by Parade magazine as the high-school player of the year, an award that has been won by five schoolboys who went on to earn Heismans as the college player of the year: Herschel Walker, Marcus Allen, Billy Sims, Earl Campbell and Tony Dorsett.

title: Protect Animals, Not Trappers
description: Your Dec. 8 article, ''Fur Bearers Studied With Trappers' Aid'' reveals the ignorance of the State Department of Environmental Protection in allowing an open season on the public's wildlife while failing to conduct scientific population counts of the animals subjected to unlimited trapping.

title: Virgin Wins Race
description: Craig Virgin, a three-time Olympian, won a 15-kilometer race here today in windy and rainy conditions.

title: Another Official Leaves a City Job
description: In matters involving money and public officials, appearances count. So Mayor Koch, a few days after lamenting as ''dumb, dumb, dumb, dumb'' the City Personnel Director's receipt of a cash gift from subordinates, accepted the official's resignation last week and quickly ushered in a replacement.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: BELOW THE SURFACE, ABOVE THE SALT
description: Submarine Sail For Flora And Fauna For those who neither dive nor snorkel, there is now a new means of seeing the underwater attractions of the reefs and grottoes that lie off Grand Cayman island in the British West Indies - a submarine.

title: OF RUNS, DRIPS AND SAGS: DO'S AND DON'TS OF SPRAY PAINTING
description: SPRAY painting is almost always a lot faster than painting by brush or roller, especially when working on furniture, cabinets and other many-sided objects. It also makes the job of paintifg over textured or carved surfaces a lot easier than it would be otherwise, and enables a reasonably skilled painter to get a much smoother finish than would be possible with a brush.

title: ONCE MORE, 1776 TAXES FILMGOERS
description: The reporter for a large London weekly had called to discuss what he discreetly described as ''the generally unfavorable notices'' for Hugh Hudson's would-be epic about the American War of Independence, ''Revolution,'' which had opened in New York on Christmas Day. ''Is it possible,'' he asked, ''that some people were offended by the fact that this American subject was made by an English director in England?''

title: Topics: Changes, Not All for the Better; Plum for Panama
description: The new law to wipe out the Federal deficit is unlikely to do any such thing, but it sure will give Panama a windfall of at least $16 million.

title: SHAPING A PORTRAIT OF A PLAYWRIGHT
description: Preparing to play Lillian Hellman last summer, Zoe Caldwell buried herself in research. She read memoirs and studied videotapes. She pored over old photographs. She grilled enemies and friends, among the latter Maureen Stapleton, who had acted in the Hellman drama, ''Toys in the Attic.'' At dinner one night, she asked Miss Stapleton what she missed most about Miss Hellman, who died in 1984.

title: LAURELS REWARD HIGH PERFORMANCE AND VALUE
description: A crusty old insurance executive, who also happened to be one of America's great composers, once refused the Pulitzer Prize. ''Prizes are the badge of mediocrity,'' scoffed Charles Ives.

title: Topics: Changes, Not All for the Better; Clean Government
description: A couple who moved from Chicago to Montclair, N.J., was recently surprised to receive in the mail the town's ''1986 Holiday Refuse Collection Schedule.''

title: CUOMO BARS FUNDS TO OFFSET U.S. CUTS
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that his budget for the next fiscal year would not include money to compensate local governments, including New York City, for possible sharp cuts in Federal aid.

title: AN ABBEY'S GRANDEUR RESTORED IN AUSTRIA
description: Spring will be the best time in more than a decade to visit the great yellow Abbey of Melk - one of the splendors of Austrian baroque architecture - that stands on a rocky bluff above the Danube, some 60 miles west of Vienna.

title: U.S. 1 PUBLISHER CLARIFIES BACKGROUND
description: The flattering renew of my Princeton-based newspaper, U.S.1 [ New Jerseyans, Dec. 22 ] , contained one piece of misinformation, no doubt caused by a misunderstanding between me and the reporter: U.S. 1originally was supposed to be exactly what it turned out to be - a business and entertainment journal serving the Greater Princeton Area and the fast-growing Route 1 corridor.

title: ATONING FOR HOLIDAY FEASTS: SPICES LIVEN PLAIN DISHES
description: PLAIN cooking, the saying goes, is for plain cooks. But after the holidays, to atone for the overeating that started sometime around Thanksgiving and continued through the New Year, many of us turn to the plainest food we can think of. We go from overindulgence in such fattening things as foie gras, roast duck and chocolate mousse cake to a round of fish broiled without salt or butter, unseasoned steamed vegetables, and chicken from which the delectable skin has been removed. This can be punishing.

title: A NEW FACE AND FRESH IDEAS IN THE PUBLIC-ART DEBATE
description: Can we de-accession public monuments the way museums do smaller objects?

title: A CHANGING SENSE OF PLACE
description: WALKING west on Bedford Road in Pleasantville, going toward the railroad station, there used to be a point - just before the road dips into the Saw Mill River Valley - where you caught a sudden wide-angle view of tree-covered hills in the distance. In autumn you saw a canvas splashed with ocher, orange, and cerise; in winter a charcoal drawing of stark lines and wispy smudges; all spring and summer a sprightly landscape of vivid greens. I loved that view, not only for the esthetic pleasure it offered but because it conveyed a vivid sense of place. If I forgot momentarily where on this whirling globe I happen to be situated, the panorama reassured me: you live in a place that is nestled among hills.

title: EPISCOPALIANS INSTALL LEADER
description: Calling on his church to join him on a ''spiritual mission of compassion,'' Edmond L. Browning of Hawaii was installed yesterday as the Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in a stately ceremony at the Washington Cathedral.

title: OF RUNS, DRIPS AND SAGS: DO'S AND DONT'S OF SPRAY PAINTING
description: SPRAY painting is almost always a lot faster than painting by brush or roller, especially when working on furniture, cabinets and other many-sided objects. It also makes the job of painting over textured or carved surfaces a lot easier than it would be otherwise, and enables a reasonably skilled painter to get a much smoother finish than would be possible with a brush.

title: DEMOCRATS MOVE ON CHALLENGE TO DIOGUARDI
description: TWO years ago, when Westchester Democratic leaders began the process of selecting a candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated after 16 years by Richard L. Ottinger, they found their party deeply divided over several choices. So they called a convention, in March.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN EVENTS OVERTAKE GUIDEBOOKS
description: The earthquakes that shook Mexico and killed thousands of people in September also had an impact on people who publish guidebooks. The 1986 editions of most of the major annual volumes about Mexico - those that are expected to remain valid at least through this coming summer - were already at press or even on the way to bookstores. It was obvious from reports of earthquake damage that some of the information in the guidebooks, especially on Mexico City, would be out of date.

title: 'ANDROCLES' IN HARTFORD
description: A CHEERY company and a jovial director, who also plays two characters, are having a high time with George Bernard Shaw's ''Androcles and the Lion'' at the Hartford Stage Company.

title: TIPPETT IS RANKED WITH THE VERY BEST
description: ANDRE TIPPETT was the first one to make the comparisons.

title:
WHAT WILL HAPPEN AFTER THE PHILIPPINES ELECTION;
Marcos Reforms Are Likely
description: Everyone ''knows'' that since Ferdinand E. Marcos is a corrupt dictator whose greed has destroyed the Philippine economy, the only way he can win the election in February is to use his troops to intimidate voters and his election commission to steal or mis-count votes. But my own observations suggest that he might be able to win without such tactics - and that, in victory, he could well move toward some important reforms of the Philippine system.

title: Jane Ellen Blumenthal Weds Scott Stechman
description: Jane Ellen Blumenthal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Blumenthal of Brooklyn, and Scott David Stechman, the son of B. Sheila Stechman of Lake Grove, L.I., and Irwin M. Stechman of Centereach, L.I., were married yesterday evening. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich performed the ceremony at the Huntington (L.I.) Town House.

title: SOME PLAYS FARE BETTER THE SECOND TIME AROUND
description: Though it occasionally presents new plays, the Second Stage is committed to an artistic policy of reviving works from the recent past. According to the company's co-directors, Carole Rothman and Robyn Goodman, these are plays they think ''deserve to be seen again - in a new and surprisingly different light.'' Often that ''light'' is not so much a radically altered production as simply a change in venue and in time. These are not necessarily rediscoveries but, rather, plays that might have been overlooked and should be performed again. A decade, or even a few years, can make all the difference in the public perception. At a certain point, a theme can seem overly familiar; a surfeit of family plays, for example, can cause a drama, perhaps even a serious one, to be slighted. A play can be victimized by coincidence. A world event can make a subject seem trivial in comparison, or a certain style of writing can become unfashionable, at least for a time. Attitudes can change toward playwrights. Audiences can be more willing to encounter work on its own terms or in the context of a career.

title: MANES'S CONDITION HINDERS INQUIRY ON INJURY
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, hospitalized for a slashed wrist and other injuries, was suffering from medical complications yesterday and could not be questioned by the authorities, according to his doctor and family.

title: GREAT KILLS
description: THE Village, the point where Amboy Road, Nelson Avenue and Giffords Lane meet, is the quaint nickname for the center of Great Kills, a community on the south shore of Staten Island.

title: Afghan Leader Rejects U.S. Settlement Offer
description: Babrak Karmal, the Afghan leader, has said that he rejects an offer by President Reagan to serve as a guarantor of a settlement of the war in his country.

title: A New Test for Sergeants' Exam
description: The Koch administration has decided to postpone a new sergeants' examination scheduled for this month to make sure it can sustain a legal challenge. Two previous exams for officers seeking promotions to sergeant have been subject to lawsuits on the ground that they had a discriminatory impact on black and Hispanic officers and were not sufficiently job-related.

title: Wendy Stein Marries Bart Friedman W
description: Wendy Alpern Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Stein of Manhasset, L.I., and Copake, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bart Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Friedman of Brooklyn and West Palm Beach, Fla. Associate Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: Iona Sets Back Manhattan, 79-73
description: Richie Simmonds and Bob Coleman each scored 25 points as Iona handed Manhattan its seventh straight defeat last night with a 79-73 victory in a Metro Atlantic Conference game.

title: IN PRAISE OF AMERICA'S INTERNAIONAL GAME: TENNIS
description: FOR YEARS I have heard the fans of soccer, golf, horse racing, auto racing or track and field proclaim that their sport is the most international, the most popular in the world. Here's my suggestion: Tennis. It certainly is the most popular international sport among American sports fans.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Japan Solo: A Practical Guide for Independent Travelers By Eiji Kanno. 252 pages. Nitchi Map-Publishing Company. $12.50.

title: THE DARK SIDE OF FRANCHISING
description: CAROL and Jerry Holt thought they had found the path to financial independence in mid-1983: running a franchise for Fabulous Fakes jewelry. For $18,000, they were told, the franchiser would provide them with store fixtures and an initial inventory of the jewelry, which features a type of artificial diamond called cubic zirconia.

title: CHINA GETS A 30-SECOND MESSAGE
description: ON a Sunday late in February, right after the evening news, some 300 million residents of the People's Republic of China - 40 percent of its total population - are expected to watch the premiere of ''One World'' - a series of 15-minute international documentaries that is the first TV program produced in the West specifically for China.

title: PENDERECKI IS RETROGRESSING NOW -- ON PURPOSE
description: The creator of ''Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima,''

title: PICKING THE RIGHT TAX-RETURN GUIDE
description: Are you itching to get a head start on completing your 1985 tax return but feel the need for a refresher course on the major points of the nation's 3,000-page tax code? If so, you might consider buying one of the paperback tax-return guides making their annual appearance at bookstores around the country.

title:
ANTIQUES;
STRATFORD'S JANUARY SHOW OFFERS EXTRAS
description: THE first 1986 show of Early American furniture and accessories will be at Stratford next weekend. The fifth January Antiques Show, with 50 exhibitors from the Northeast, will be at the National Guard armory on Armory Street, just off the Merritt Parkway.

title: POSTINGSComplementing a Condo; BAYSIDE SHOPPING MALL
description: Nearing completion in Bayside, Queens, is Baybridge Commons, a shopping center with 40 stores that is being developed as an adjunct to Baybridge Condominiums, a 750-unit project at Bell Boulevard, near the Clearview Expressway.

title: INTO THE DARK CHAMBER: THE OVELIST AND SOUTH AFRICA
description: WHEN a colony is founded, wrote Nathaniel Hawthorne in ''The Scarlet Letter,'' ''among [ the ] earliest practical necessities [ is ] to allot a portion of the virgin soil as a cemetery, and another portion as the site of a prison.'' Prisons - Hawthorne called them the black flowers of civilized society - burgeon all over the face of South Africa. They may not be sketched or photographed, under threat of severe penalty. I have no idea whether laws against visual representations of prisons exist in other countries. Very likely they do. But in South Africa such laws have a particular symbolic appropriateness, as though it were decreed that the camera lens must shatter at the moment it is trained on certain sites; as though the passer-by shall have no means of confirming that what he saw - those buildings rising out of the sands in all their sprawl of gray monotony - was not a mirage or a bad dream.

title: WHEN THE HOUSE NO LONGER FITS
description: I HAVE been helping a land hermit crab house-hunt. His old shell no longer fits. I am sitting on a tropical beach pushing West Indian Top shells toward the palm tree root where he is fussily choosing his new pad. He is searching for the smallest, lightest shell that will do. ''Try this, crab,'' I say. He flicks a stalked eye, grasps my gift with his big claw, and pokes a curious leg into the wide opening. The decision to move involves a rite of passage during which he will be highly vulnerable.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: RESTORING HISPANIC THEATER IN BRONX
description: As a boy growing up in the late 1940's and early 50's, James Sanchez regularly attended shows at the Teatro Puerto Rico in the South Bronx, never dreaming that someday he would own it.

title: Sidney Anderson Wed in Arkansas
description: Sidney Walt Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Sidney Anderson of Little Rock, Ark., was married at Trinity Episcopal Cathedral there yesterday to Geoffrey Robert Thornton Kenyon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tristam Kenyon of Los Angeles and Bridgewater, Vt. The Very Rev. Joel Pugh, dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: Time Is the Enemy of Nuclear Stability; Weapons Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Bienstock To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Bienstock of New York, Wilton, Conn., and London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Bienstock, to Dr. Louis R. DePalo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Genaro DePalo of Mount Vernon, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: 3-BLOCK REBUILDING DUE IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: THIS resort's Planning Board may be seeing a lot of the Natco Realty and Development Company in coming months as company officials appear for approvals of plans to renovate 11 noncasino hotels in the city, build three new hotels and spruce up the rundown neighborhood around them.

title: SCIENCE TEACHERS IN COUNTY
description: SINCE November, high school science teachers in the county have been refreshing their scientific knowledge in a program called Science Seminars for Teachers, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences and Westchester Community College's Center of Science, Mathematics and Technology Literacy.

title: TOPICS
description: IHAVE lived in my house for 15 years, the longest I have ever lived anywhere. In a few months my youngest will be graduated from high school and my husband and I will move to Manhattan, fulfilling a longtime dream of mine. There will only be two regrets for me - leaving Toby and Sunken Meadow Beach.

title: POSTINGSGramercy Challenge; Retaining the Past
description: When the Landmarks Preservation Commission awarded special status to the Gramercy Park area 20 years ago the aim was to preserve its ''special historical and esthetic interest and value.'' The architectural firm of Joseph Pell Lombardi had to keep this in mind when it won a commission from the Sarwyn Development Corporation to retain the exteriors of two buildings in the neighborhood, but rebuild their insides into four cooperative residences and a professional office.

title: Patriotism, to Go
description: If you ate less than seven pizzas in 1985, you were a below-average American. Not slices, whole pizzas. That awesome statistic alone clearly justifies the luncheon planned by the National Restaurant Association tomorrow at the National Press Club to kick off National Pizza Week.

title: Taking Off the Gloves
description: In a remarkable departure from the norms of British politics, Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine literally took a walk last week, storming out of a Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street and, ultimately, out of the Cabinet itself. Mr. Heseltine, long considered a candidate for leadership of the Conservative Party, resigned after a confrontation with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Two multinational consortiums have been bidding for a stake in Britain's only helicopter manufacturer, an ailing company called Westland. Mr. Heseltine had championed a European consortium, while Mrs. Thatcher had insisted publicly that the Government remain neutral. In a news conference, Mr. Heseltine implied strongly that Mrs. Thatcher had used her authority to block the European consortium in favor of an American-Italian group.

title: Elizabeth Gilmor And Kelly Conlin To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Anne Gmor to Kelly Peter Conlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Conlin Jr. of Minneapolis, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gilmor Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: VALUE OF PROPERTY HIGHEST IN STAMFORD
description: THE value of all property in Stamford grew by more than $200 million, to $4.9 billion, in 1984, making it greater than the total property value in 65 of Connecticut's smallest towns, a new study has shown.

title: Dance
description: Some of the 11 men performing at P.S. 122 on Monday night are well-known choreographers and dancers. Others have recently arrived on the New York dance scene.

title: QADDAFI IS MAKING THE MOST OF THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Like a lightweight using jujitsu principles to outmaneuver a bigger, stronger adversary, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appeared last week to be making American sanctions and threats of military reprisal work for him. ''The challenge was very useful,'' the Libyan leader said at a news conference.

title: THE CITY HAS MANAGED TO FEND FOR ITSELF
description: MAYOR KOCH sent a message to Washington last week - loud, direct and about as subtle as the anecdotes in his own beloved books. Do not cut our budget any more, the Mayor told the Federal Government as he released his preliminary financial plan for the next fiscal year, doing so 10 days ahead of time to get what he called the ''bad news'' out early.

title: MUSIC: 2 MEDIEVAL DRAMAS BY MANNES CAMERATA
description: IT is indicative of just how far we've come that a group of talented music students can now offer a livelier, more elegant, professional and stylistically authentic evening of early music than could have been expected from the most erudite performers and scholars of a generation ago. Truly ours is a golden age of musical discovery.

title: Ahoy, Sequoia
description: A favorite publicity maneuver of American Presidents over the past 50-odd years has been announcing early in their terms that they were giving up the Presidential yacht to save the taxpayers money. Herbert Hoover did it in 1929, Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1953, Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, Richard M. Nixon in 1970 and Jimmy Carter in 1977.

title: PRISONS ARE ON THE ALERT AGAINST AIDS
description: Despite early concerns that AIDS might become rampant in prisons, officials say there is little evidence that the disease has spread behind bars.

title: Eimicke Holds Firm on M.C.I. Rule
description: THE Commissioner of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal told owners of rent-stabilized buildings last week that he would continue to allow rents to rise to cover major capital improvements by no more than 6 percent a year and that their only recourse was to get the state law changed.

title: PERGOLESI SINFONIAS IN CONCERT AT LAST
description: MARVIN E. PAYMER of Stamford knows a real Pergolesi when he sees one. Or hears one.

title: DARING EXPLOITS AT SEA INCREASE
description: ATTEMPTS to cross the oceans in ways never tried before are not uncommon these days, either by power or sail. But some efforts stand out not only as successful attempts to break records, but also as unusual tales of adventure.

title: New Defense Against Colds
description: Scientists have not yet found a way to cure colds, but researchers in the United States and Australia have developed a new defense. The doctors reduced the incidence of colds in test families as much as 80 percent by using a nasal spray containing the drug interferon.

title: VIETNAM HAS TROUBLE AFFORDING ITS IMAGE
description: ''You Americans have given the world a false impression of Vietnam,'' a European with long experience in Indochina said last week, just before Hanoi welcomed the highest-level United States delegation to visit Vietnam since the war ended. ''These people are not giants.'' The theme is repeated by diplomats, aid officials, scholars and the few business representatives who somehow manage to trade with Vietnam. The country they describe is not the vanquisher of two large Western armies or the conqueror of Pol Pot. It is a very poor, chronically undernourished, badly administered nation riven by ministerial rivalries in the capital and gestures of defiance in the provinces, whose authorities hew to the old Vietnamese adage that ''the power of the emperor stops at the village gate.''

title: Topics: Changes, Not All for the Better; Subway Lifers
description: Deploring ''a taxpayer rip-off,'' a Westchester legislator, Paul Feiner, wants New York's transit authority to stop giving its board members lifetime passes for free rides on subways, buses and commuter trains.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: A DOOR INTO OCEAN by Joan Slonczewski (Arbor House, $17.95) starts so slowly that many readers may not get past the 40 leisurely pages of Part One. This would be a mistake. By the time the conflict she introduces so obliquely in Part One has moved to center stage, you not only know the antagonists intimately, you care passionately about the outcome. Two sister-planets, Valedon and Shora, harbor societies that appear to be mirror images of each other. On Valedon, an Earthlike world, the principal occupations are trade and war; those Valans who compete successfully are rewarded with wealth and power. On Shora, a water world with no dry land and no males, self-awareness and ecological awareness are so linked that the inhabitants refer to themselves as Sharers; whole-hearted participation in the planet-wide web of life is not an ideal or a goal for Sharers but a source of pleasure so intense that they have trouble believing that creatures who cannot ''share'' are human.

title: WHEN 'KIDS AMERICA' IS ON, THE SWITCHBOARD LIGHTS UP
description: Public radio might seem an unlikely medium for attracting an audience of schoolchildren, who would presumably rather play with futuristic robots or watch mindless cartoons on television than subject themselves to anything ''educational.'' Luckily, nobody explained that to the devoted young fans of ''Kids America,'' the Peabody Award-winning program that celebrates its second birthday this month.

title: Luck on the Slopes
description: The European downhill ski slopes have been taking their toll in injuries this season, claiming five victims in less than a month, including Christine Putz of Austria, who spent three weeks in a coma after a fall early last month, and Debbie Armstrong of the United States, who fell in a training run on Thursday and suffered a knee injury that will keep her off skis at least six weeks. Ariane Ehrat of Switzerland broke her wrist in a spectacular tumble on Friday and yesterday Holly Flanders, the leading American downhill competitor, narrowly escaped serious injury during a downhill race in Badgastein, Austria, when she hurtled out of control in a mushy rut midway down the Silberkrug course.

title: SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR REQUESTS 12.7% BUDGET RISE
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones proposed a record $4.8 billion Board of Education operating budget for the 1986-87 school year last week, saying a spending increase of $552 million was ''vital to ensuring a real standard of education for the children of New York City.''

title: A New Year, An Old Agenda
description: Governor Cuomo kicked off the legislative session in Albany last week with his State of the State Address, and, as tradition requires, the Governor was thinking big.

title: TEACHERS VIE FOR NEW GRANTS
description: AT Bridgewater-Raritan High School West, Michael Petrus's 11th- and 12th-grade students study poetry by drawing images that poets have created with words. Then they analyze the pictures to see whether their fellow students have read the poems closely.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two telephone numbers were given incorrrectly in last week's Long Island Weekly section. The correct number for the car and van pool service of Island Rides Inc. is 423-CARS.In the article ''Where Entrepreneurs' Ideas Meet the Investors' Dollars,'' the number mentioned by Bill Douglas of B. & G. D. Inc. should have been 754-3045.

title: IN SEARCH OF KAREN BLIXEN'S KENYA
description: Of the thousands of tourists who travel to Kenya each year, many have been inspired to do so after reading the classic ''Out of Africa'' by Karen Blixen, who wrote under the pen name Isak Dinesen. It has not seemed to matter to them that everything she described has been unceasingly compromised. Her ability to observe with the eye of a painter, to write with the sensibility of a poet, has insured that the fundamental beauty of the book remains untarnished.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SWIMMING TO CAMBODIA. By Spalding Gray. (Theatre Communications Group, Paper, $7.95.)
