Theater critics have compared the actor-storyteller Spalding Gray to figures as diverse as Woody Allen, Mark Twain, Andy Warhol and Mr. Rogers - an indication of how difficult it is to categorize his work.

title: Head of Realty Board Named
description: Jerry I. Speyer, the president of Tishman Speyer Properties Inc., has been elected chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York, officials said yesterday. Mr. Speyer, who is 45 years old, is the youngest person ever to serve as the board's chairman, according to the president, Richard M. Rosan. He succeeds Larry A. Silverstein, who will serve as chairman of the executive committee of the board, an industry trade association with a membership of more than 5,000.

title: Miss Bullock Has Wedding
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Alicia Benedict Bullock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bullock Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., to Christopher Beckman Dow, the son of Anne Rindlaub Dow of Cambridge, Mass., and Frank B. Dow of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. F. Bryan Williams, assisted by the Rev. Susan C. Harriss, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW IRT SUBWAY CARS PASS TRIAL
description: The five new silver subway trains that have been operating on the IRT No. 1 line since mid-November have passed their 30-day test and been deemed ''a qualified success,'' according to the Transit Authority.

title: Peete Winner By Six
description: Calvin Peete, who has won more PGA Tour events and more official tour money in the last four years than any other golfer, picked up his 10th triumph in that period by winning the 34th annual MONY Tournament of Champions in a runaway today with a tournament-record score of 21-under-par 267.

title: KEY TO MOONACHIE IS THRE LAST SYLLABLE
description: PEOPLE who live in this Bergen County community say they are used to visitors' mispronouncing the town's name. But they are a patient lot, says Mayor Frederick J. Dressel.

title: Linda R. Heimerdinger Planning to Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Heimerdinger of Armonk and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Reyman Heimerdinger, to William Stevens Faulkner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Faulkner Jr. of Keene, N.H.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
MOSAICS IN RAVENNA: AN ANCIENT ART LIVES
description: In Ravenna they call mosaics la Pittura Eterna, Eternal Art. The ancient mosaics of Italy have survived earthquakes, volcanoes, bombings and fires and now, centuries later, we can still walk the mosaic floors of Pompeii, and the Empress Theodora still stares sternly down at us from beneath her outsize halo on the ceiling of the Basilica of San Vitale in Ravenna.

title: FACES BEHIND THE FAMOUS BRAND NAMES
description: THE world of business, as any corporate bookshelf can attest, is a world of money, products, technologies and systems. But it is also, of course, a world of people, as two recent books go a good distance to describe. One book is mainly instructive and the other mainly entertaining, but both help to reveal the human factor behind the balance sheets.

title: Davin Mackenzie, Banker, Weds Leslie Hui-Yun Chu
description: Leslie Hui-Yun Chu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Te-Chang Chu of Pingtung, Taiwan, was married yesterday to Davin Alexander Mackenzie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick L. Mackenzie of Princeton, N.J. A civil ceremony was performed at the AsiaWorld Plaza Hotel in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: ROGER SMITH'S TROUBLED SECOND ACT
description: WHEN Roger B. Smith announced the restructuring of the General Motors Corporation in January 1984, he was exultant. The plan called for folding fractious divisions into two super groups which, the G.M. chairman said, would give the giant automaker ''a more effective method for designing, engineering, manufacturing, assembling and selling cars.''

title: A COMEDY OF WORLDLY SALVATION
description: THE GOOD APPRENTICE By Iris Murdoch. 522 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95. AT the end of her first book, an enduring study of Jean-Paul Sartre published in 1953, Iris Murdoch prophetically lamented that Sartre's ''inability to write a great novel is a tragic symptom of a situation which afflicts us all.'' Her own inability has extended now through 22 novels, of which the best seem to me ''Bruno's Dream'' (1969), ''The Black Prince'' (1973), ''A Word Child'' (1975) and her latest, ''The Good Apprentice.'' So fecund and exuberant is Miss Murdoch's talent that many more novels may be expected from her. If ''The Good Apprentice'' marks the start of her strongest phase, and it may, then a great novel could yet come, rather surprisingly in the incongruous form of the 19th-century realistic novel. The age of Samuel Beckett and Thomas Pynchon, post-Joycean and post-Faulknerian, is set aside by Miss Murdoch's novelistic procedures, almost as though she thus chose to assert her own direct continuity with the major 19th-century Russian and British masters of fiction.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL '86;
UNUSUAL HERO FINDS SUCCESS ON AND OFF COURT
description: AT night, when the three brothers in Drewry, N.C., paused to say their prayers before going to sleep, the youngest asked for one thing most of all. Raised on the televised heroics of Atlantic Coast Conference basketball, David Henderson asked to grow tall. On a December night in 1985, more than a decade later, Duke defeated Kansas, 92-86, and that hopeful boy from the small white cabin in the Drewry woods stood alone near midcourt in Madison Square Garden, 6 feet 5 inches tall, the most valuable player in the preseason National Invitation Tournament.

title:
ART;
RETROSPECTIVE OF STEPHEN BUCKLEY PAINTINGS AT YALE CENTER
description: SINCE new, robust, abstract painting has been outside the pale of critical discourse in recent seasons, the retrospective of Stephen Buckley at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven through Feb. 16 seems of special importance.

title: PUTTING LIFE INTO BIOGRAPHY
description: ''HE is a multi-multi-millionaire. And he is not even 30 years old. No wonder he believes in fairy tales. His whole life has been like a fairy tale . . [ But ] he was born, just like the rest of us, into a perfectly ordinary family in Gary, Indiana'' - thus a recent children's biography of Michael Jackson follows the glitzy fantasy formula of immediate and total success. At the other extreme is the pedestrian account of the eminent, ranging from the founding fathers to women scientists. Dull, earnest chronology that reduces its subject to stereotype, that sort of biography relies on inflated cliche rather than authentic detail (Nobel Prize week ''passed like a dream''). What the formula biographies - whether glitz or heavy - have in common is an adulatory tone. They communicate little sense of the drudgery, sacrifice and pain that go with achievement, the uncertainty and weakness that humanize the great.

title: WHAT THE NEW TECHNOLOGY PROMISES
description: The coming of a new year invariably stirs prophecy, and the prevailing mood of seasonal clairvoyance tempts me to forecast the shape of things to come in this first video column of 1986. Luckily, this requires no high-caliber crystal ball because incipient trends and technologies already point the way.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SEVENTH SECRET. By Irving Wallace. (Dutton, $17.95.) ''Another book on Hitler? . . . It has become an industry,'' says a character in this novel about the ''real'' story behind Hitler's and Eva Braun's supposed suicides.

title: RESPONSE TO TERRORISM: HOW PRESIDENT DECIDED
description: On the morning after the terrorist attacks at airports in Rome and Vienna, an interagency group was hastily convened at the White House to draw up a response. At the Pentagon, the Joint Chiefs of Staff started shaping contingency plans and military options for a possible reprisal against the terrorists.

title: STAGE: TWO WORKS BY AUSTRALIAN WRITER
description: FOLLOWING the example of Australia's movie makers, who have found acclaim in this country, Australia's playwrights may be starting to show their stuff. At any rate, that hope is aroused by the first appearance in New York of two short works by Daniel Keene. Mr. Keene, who has had several plays produced back home, is represented at the Women's Interart Center by ''The Hour Before My Brother Dies'' and the briefer ''Echoes of Ruby Dark.''

title: Fire at Farmhouse Kills 6 in Maryland
description: A fire that officials said was apparently started by a wood-burning stove swept through an isolated farmhouse here early today, killing two children and four adults and injuring five others, officials said.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CONGLOMERATE TO TEST EMPLOYEES FOR DRUG USE
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc., a broadcasting and publishing company, plans to impose a stricter antidrug policy and may send undercover investigators and drug-sniffing dogs into its newsrooms and radio and television stations, including those of the recently acquired broadcasting company, officials said yesterday.

title: Daimler
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor Southworth Marries
description: Eleanor Ewart Southworth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Southworth Jr. of New York and Quoque, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Randolph Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Gene Thompson of Lima, Ohio. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Baylor Women Routed
description: The top-ranked University of Texas women's basketball team, led by Fran Harris with 17 points, defeated Baylor, 93-40, today to remain unbeaten.

title: CABARET: ONE HOUR OF GERSHWIN
description: FAMILIAR songs by George and/ or Ira Gershwin are such a standard part of the repertory of almost any cabaret singer, supper-club pianist or even jazz groups that a revue made up entirely of such songs might seem to be laboring the obvious.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: GIGGLING IN PHILADELPHIA Promising ''giggles, not goose bumps,'' park rangers in Philadelphia will talk about the humor of a famous frightener, Edgar Allan Poe, as they lead candlelight tours of a nearly empty house that was once his home.

title: SCHOOLS ANALYZING STATE TEST SCORES
description: EVEN before the scores on the first statewide tests for fourth graders were announced last week, Connecticut educators were acting on the results.

title: Children And the Bomb
description: Robert Coles's article ''Children and the Bomb'' (Dec. 8) implied what I have always believed: that except for a few precocious youngsters of privileged socioeconomic status who are eager to score points with adults, most children have other, more pressing and reality-oriented, concerns on their minds. As far as I am concerned, the issue of juvenile bomb hysteria is a myth!

title: BLAZERS EDGE KNICKS
description: For once, everything seemed right for the Knicks. Playing against the Portland Trail Blazers, one of pro basketball's most talented teams, they had survived serious lapses by playing some of their most confident and smoothest basketball of the season at Madison Square Garden. In fact, Hubie Brown called their third period - in which they made 16 of their first 20 field-goal attempts to transform a 9-point halftime deficit into a 15-point lead - ''the best quarter that we've played all year.''

title: NOW IS THE TIME TO PUT THOSE PRUNING SHEARS TO WORK
description: If ever a deed struck fear in the hearts of property owners, it's pruning. The mere act of putting a pruning saw or pruning shears to the wood of an ornamental tree or shrub sends shudders through many a new gardener. Yet, pruning is the deed most needed to keep plants in scale.

title: Michigan Nuclear Plant Is Cited in 26 Violations
description: The Detroit Edison Company could be fined up to $100,000 for each of 26 operating violations found at the Fermi 2 nuclear power plant last year, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says.

title: 13-YEAR-OLD TO LEAD ADULT CLASS
description: AT 13, an age when most children are not even thinking about college yet, Matthew Green of Killingly will be teaching at one.

title: FULKL SEASON IS SET AT STAMFORD CENTER
description: THE concert calendar is filling up again after the holiday break, and the next fortnight promises an abundance of choices.

title: President Gets The Lowdown On Acid Rain
description: The Reagan Administration has moved a step closer to formally declaring that acid rain has done great damage in the United States and that American industry has contributed to the problem in Canada. But it is not clear what will happen next.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WOMEN AGAINST MEN, by Storm Jameson. (Virago/Penguin, $6.95.) The first of these three novellas by the English writer Storm Jameson is the story of a seductress whose own amours provide material for the sexy novels she writes; the second explores a woman's love for a man who is socially beneath her, and the third is about a poor, lonely and embittered middle-aged woman. Harold Strauss wrote in The Times in 1933, ''So completely is she the master of her art, so instinctively the craftsman, so superlatively the selective artist, that a restrained evaluation of her work is difficult for a student of the novel.'' The same publisher has reissued Miss Jameson's 1934 novel COMPANY PARADE ($6.95), about a young woman who has come to London to find work after the Armistice. Reviewers praised its ''fastidiousness of phrase and tight emotional control.'' OLYMPIO: The Life of Victor Hugo, by Andre Maurois. (Carroll & Graf, $12.95.) This biography of the poet and novelist was hailed as a ''major achievement'' that ''stands high among biographies'' by our reviewer, Francis Steegmuller, when it appeared in Gerard Hopkins's translation in 1956. A general's son who grew up in near-palatial surroundings, Hugo led a turbulent existence. His tempestuous love life, Mr. Steegmuller wrote, ''is a veritable Decameron,'' and the triangle formed by Hugo, his wife, Adele, and the critic Sainte-Beuve was ''one of the most famous in French literary history.'' The text provides quotations from Hugo's verse and commentary on the novels and other works.

title: PRESERVING GEMS OF CANADIAN MUSIC
description: For 25 years, the Canadian Music Centre, with main offices in Toronto and regional headquarters in Montreal, Alberta and Vancouver, has devoted itself to the nurturing, care and preservation of Canadian composers and their work. For the past five years, its quasi-independent, Toronto-based subsidiary, Centrediscs, has been releasing recordings of contemporary Canadian music. Unlike its parent organization, Centrediscs receives no direct financial support from the Canadian government, relying instead on funds raised through corporate sponsorship as well as contributions from other nonprofit cultural institutions to finance its productions. Significant support is also given by some of Canada's most famous performers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WIELDING a paintbrush loaded with determination, a 29-year-old Camden artist's campaign to beautify her city is transforming graffiti-spattered walls into works of art and groups of teen-agers with names like ''The Seven Deadly Sins'' and ''Crime Squad'' into muralists.

title: THE LIBRARY SPEAKS VOLUMES ABOUT CHANGE
description: WHILE my head was buried in the sand of the past, the wave of the future washed over me the other day at the Oceanside Free Library. I spent half a day in the library, making use of its many facilities, and only when I left did I realize I had never opened a book.

title: RETHINKING SOCIALISM
description: TAKING SIDES The Education of a Militant Mind. By Michael Harrington. 278 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: ANOTHER GRAFFITI BATTLE LOST
description: GRAFFITISTS have struck again!

title: BOARD SAILING RIDES IN ON A POPULAR WAVE
description: ALTHOUGH it may never surpass its popularity in the lakes of Europe, board sailing, an American invention that has enjoyed huge success abroad, is beginning to show signs of steady growth and acceptance on its home waters.

title: WEAPONS OF CHOICE: CRIME BY CRIME
description: ALMOST 37 percent of the 65.3 million rapes, robberies and assaults that took place in the United States between 1973 and 1982 involved the use of guns, knives or other weapons, the Justice Department reported last week. About one-third of the weapons were guns.

title: BRIGHT MOMENTS OF DISAPPOINTMENT
description: DARKNESS By Bharati Mukherjee. 199 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: Chill a Factor In Chicago
description: The temperature for today's two National Football League conference championship games may be twice as warm in Miami as in Chicago.

title: Australian Wine
description: To the Editor: I was interested to read Harold C. Schonberg's article on Australian wines (Travel, Nov. 24) and his comments on Tyrrell's as being one of Australia's ''outstanding'' wineries, and in particular his praise of its Cabernet Merlot. These wines, as well as the Hardy range, are available in the tristate area, being imported into this country by the Joseph Victori Company in Brooklyn.KEVIN HAYTER Manalapan, N.J.

title: COMPANY TO ASSIST COMMUNITY GROUPS
description: AFTER its debut last year in several cities in the Middle West, a public-service program sponsored by the American Can Corporation of Greenwich has recently started in Fairfield and Westchester Counties.

title: Botha and Banker Confer on Debt Crisis
description: An international banker who is a mediator in South Africa's foreign debt crisis met today with President P. W. Botha, officials said.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Razor's Edge Starring Tyrone Power, Gene Tierney, Clifton Webb, Anne Baxter, Herbert Marshall, John Payne; directed by Edmund Goulding, 1946 Key Video 146 minutes. $59.98 As a film, this meticulous, silver-plated version of Somerset Maugham's best-selling novel about a charismatic American soul-searcher is an interesting curio now, though still not especially profound.

title: Jessica Miller to Wed Robert Woodbury 2d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller of New York and Shinnecock Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Davi Miller, to Robert Arthur Woodbury 2d, a son of Drs. George Woodbury and Linda Woodbury of Memphis and St. John, V.I. The wedding is planned for July.

title: WOR-TV MOVING TO NEW SECAUCUS STUDIOS
description: WOR-TV, New Jersey's only commercial VHF station, plans to begin its move from Manhattan to Secaucus later this month.

title: Fed Stands Firm; The Dow Plunges
description: The few who doubt that Paul A. Volcker is his own man became fewer last week when the Federal Reserve Board chairman, despite uncommonly strong White House opposition, won a vote among his members to limit the use of ''junk bonds.''

title: FRENCH IMPRESSIONISTS AT THE NATIONAL GALLERY
description: In Paris in the spring of 1874, a group of Impressionist painters, considered renegades by their peers and derided by the artistic and academic establishment, banded together and rented space at 35 Boulevard des Capucines to hold an exhibition of their avant-garde art.

title: For Connecticut, a Hot Market in Housing
description: LAST year was a banner year for sellers of home properties all over Connecticut.

title: A TOUGH GUY GETS TO SING A SONG
description: ''WHAT I want to show people is that there's two sides to Ed Lauter. There's the side a lot of people perceive me as - the heavy, the bad guy, the guy you love to hate, one of the top heavies of the later 70's in the movie business.

title: DEFENSE AND HISTORY TO BE TESTED IN PLAYOFFS
description: History has no place in a football game, according to Julius Adams, and neither does a jinx, added Raymond Clayborn. In fact, there is no jinx.

title: Mailbox; The Jets' Fans Are Hospitable
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FRESH DEVELOPMENT FOR MARINE GEAR
description: THE MARINE industry has seldom found itself at the vanguard of technology. Advances in electronics have largely been spinoffs from the military and space programs. Marine engines have been slow to assimilate developments from Detroit's truck and auto industry. And plastic marine components, such as Marelon sea cocks, Kevlar laminate sails and Delrin bushings, are all second-generation applications.

title: Kate Saltus Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Saltus 2d of Morristown, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Elizabeth Saltus, to Edward Homer Painter, a son of Prof. and Mrs. William H. Painter of Urbana, Ill,, and Sandwich, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Nothing Humane In Shooting Deer
description: In her haunting essay about the hit-and-run death of a fawn on a Connecticut highway [ ''A Killing by the Roadside,'' Dec. 15 ] , Rosemary C. Serfilippi asks serious questions about our responsibility to wild animals that find themselves the luckless victims of human intrusion. Her serious questions deserve serious answers.

title: NEW SCHOLARSHIPS AIM TO IMPROVE U.S. STANDING IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: More than 150 college students from seven Central American countries, including Nicaragua, are to arrive in Miami tomorrow under a new scholarship program through which the United States hopes to improve its relations in the region and counter Soviet influence.

title: Eileen Rodgers and Steven L. Feigenbaum Wed
description: Eileen Susan Rodgers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Rodgers of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Lawrence Feigenbaum, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Feigenbaum of Pembroke Pines, Fla. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church and Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ZURICH
description: An increasing number of Americans are choosing Zurich as their gateway to Europe, largely because of the security and services at Kloten Airport. This winter many will head from Kloten directly to ski runs in the Alps. But Zurich deserves more than a fleeting visit. The city offers a full opera and concert season, renowned hotels, fine restaurants and the Bahnhofstrasse, one of the world's most opulent shopping streets. Getting There Pan American World Airways, Swissair and Trans World Airlines operate daily flights from New York. Kloten, with direct rail connections to Zurich, St. Gallen, Winterthur, St. Moritz, Lugano and many other places in Switzerland, coddles passengers with luggage carts that cling to escalators, quick check-in and baggage delivery and comfortable lobbies. The 10-minute train ride between the airport and Zurich's Hauptbahnhof (main train station) operates about every 20 minutes in both directions and costs $2, $1 for children. Getting Around Sightseeing buses leave from the south side of the station at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. daily. The two-hour tour with an English-speaking guide costs about $8.

title: The Outs and the Ins of Out and In
description: A generation ago, Nancy Mitford and Alan Ross compiled a list of what was ''U'' and ''Non-U''-''U'' standing for ''upper class.'' Pop sociologists have since been issuing lists of what is In and Out among the glitterati.

title: Leigh A. Whittingham To Wed John Ruhl Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Whittingham of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leigh Ann Whittingham to John Russell Erskine Ruhl Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruhl of Asheville, N.C. The wedding is planned for May.

title: ROWING: A GRACEFUL FITNESS ALTERNATIVE
description: SOME of the largest growth in the marine industry can be found in the construction of its smallest boats. Manufacturers of recreational rowing shells are starting to move out of the garages and barns where their operations used to fit so snugly and into factory-sized buildings to accommodate demand. Two-person companies have become 20-person companies. The businesses are growing by as much as 250 percent per year, and, according to some manufacturers, they may continue to do so for quite some time.

title: Readers of the Purple Prose
description: To the Editor:

title: SERENGETI'S LIVING LANDSCAPE
description: A hard day's drive by Land-Rover from Mount Kilimanjaro, that ponderous, snowcapped stone giant that seems to weigh down the eastern horizon, lie the southern edges of the Serengeti National Park, the centerpiece of several magnificent wildlife areas scattered across northern Tanzania. From the startlingly barren plain to the slightly rolling woodlands of the north, the Serengeti has remained virtually unchanged for milleniums. Indeed, the archeologist Mary Leakey maintains that this place looks very much the way it did millions of years ago.

title: Fugard on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: College Says Homosexuals Are Entited to Equal Rights
description: Swarthmore College has adopted an equal educational opportunity statement that includes a prohibition on discrimination in admissions or employment based on sexual preference.

title: AT 90, NEW VIGOR INFUSES REALTY BOARD
description: THE good times are rolling for the real-estate industry and triumphant optimism is likely to be the prevalent mood on Thursday night, when 2,600 members and guests of the Real Estate Board of New York gather at the New York Hilton for the board's 90th annual black-tie banquet.

title: TAIPEI'S TROVE OF CHINESE ART
description: Taipei's National Palace Museum, which prides itself on possessing the world's greatest collection of Chinese art, has increased its exhibition space, doubling the number of objects on display to about 12,000.

title: Children And the Bomb
description: I admire the way Robert Coles has tried to understand the social context out of which come the thoughts and dreams of the children he studies. He has often warned against a factitious detachment from particular social conditions in the practice of psychiatry.

title: POLES WHO SAVED JEWS
description: WHEN LIGHT PIERCED THE DARKNESS Christian Rescue of Jews in Nazi-Occupied Poland. By Nechama Tec. 262 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. WITH the recent release of Claude Lanzmann's film ''Shoah,'' Nechama Tec's book comes out at a time when many people are thinking about the destruction of European Jews during World War II. Her book tells the story of Jewish survivors and their rescuers in Nazi-occupied Poland. Mrs. Tec herself lived through the war in Poland. Her family was assisted by a number of people, including the German manager of a factory the family had owned before the war.

title: CHINESE NEWCOMER IN NORWALK
description: WHEN the Happy Balcony first opened several months ago, in a Norwalk building that formerly housed a pizza establishment, we found the name doubly puzzling: There was no balcony and not a lot to be happy about. The service was erratic and somewhat slapdash. Many dishes, especially the more unusual ones, were disappointing.

title: Reagan Is Urged To Break SALT II
description: The view is far from unanimous in Washington, but the Defense Department says the Soviet Union has a ''policy of treaty violations.'' With that as his text, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has urged President Reagan to set aside some restraints imposed by the unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty known as SALT II.

title: Fighting to Cure The 'Incurable'
description: ACCORDING to conventional medical opinion in the United States, Todd Cantrell was in a losing fight with an incurable disease. In time, doctors told him, he would be blind.

title: On Language; Piggyback Slam-Dunking
description: WHEN POLITICAL operatives of the putative Presidential candidate George Bush asked a poll taker for the Republican National Committee to frame a few questions their way, the metaphorical roof fell in: not only did Senator Bob Dole of Kansas demand to know if the supposedly neutral national committee had suddenly become ''Bush headquarters,'' but a spokesman for former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. stormed that any over-$5,000 expenditure by the Bush committee for polling would be a slam-dunk violation of Federal election laws.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Yeager, the 37-year-old catcher who was traded by the Los Angeles Dodgers to the Seattle Mariners at baseball's winter meetings, has passed his Mariner physical examination, validating the trade that sent Ed VandeBerg, a left-handed pitcher, to Los Angeles. . . William J. Williams, a United States Golf Association vice president and a former general counsel of the group, has been nominated to succeed James Hand as president. . . Ken Brett, the former major league pitcher and a brother of the Kansas City slugger George Brett, has been named a commentator for the Seattle Mariner telecasts over KIRO-TV in Seattle. He replaces another former major league pitcher, Nelson Briles, who was dismissed. . . . The Yankees completed last September's trade for Joe Niekro by sending Dody Rather, a right-handed pitcher, to Houston. Rather had a 10-3 mark in the Yankee system last season.

title: COLLECTORS PURSUE THE AMERICAN DECOY
description: Decoys - ducks, geese and shore birds, so realistically carved and painted that hunters use them to pull birds from the sky - are among the liveliest targets today for Americana collectors. Some of the reasons why these 19th- and early 20th-century birds seem irresistible to so many people are immediately apparent in viewing ''An Art of Deception: American Wildfowl Decoys,'' at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street, through Feb. 16.

title: CANON HAS ENTERED THE HIGH-TECH AGE
description: THE new Canon T90 is a 35-millimeter computer-camera for the photographer who needs everything but autofocus. While it lacks this feature, it has a wealth of others.

title: Free-Agency Test for Owners Must Wait Till Next Year
description: TRY reading a mystery novel, then reach the end of the book and find that someone has ripped out the last page. When Kirk Gibson and some of his fellow free agents - but especially Gibson -signed new contracts with their 1985 clubs last Wednesday ahead of the midnight deadline, they figuratively ripped out the last page of the manual for the owners' free-agent game plan. No one, certainly not on the players' side, knew what would happen with the Gibsons of the free-agent group after the deadline, and now everyone will have to wait until next year to get a chance to find out.

title: POSTINGSConversion Seminar; The 'Red Herring'
description: Apartment dwellers whose buildings face conversion into either cooperatives or condominiums may obtain detailed information about the process, including practical answers to thorny questions, during a three-hour seminar at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, next Wednesday at 6:45 P.M.

title: 2 DIE IN 3 HOSTAGE INCIDENTS
description: Three hostage incidents in three states yesterday resulted in the death of two people and the wounding of eight, the authorities said.

title: MORATORIUM DEBATED FOR ROUTE 110
description: AS Huntington's new Town Board holds its first sessions of the new year, it will be considering a broad building moratorium - an action that an increasing number of towns have adopted as they wrestle with problems of growth.

title: For Preservation
description: The D.C. Preservation League, dedicated to keeping an elegant old face on the capital, is getting some Federal help. The league wants to make a thorough survey of 4,000 apartment buildings constructed between 1880 and 1945.

title: West Wins Hula Bowl, 23-10
description: Doug Gaynor of California State-Long Beach passed for two touchdowns to lead the West to a 23-10 victory over the East in the Hula Bowl today.

title: COSTUME DESIGNER DISCUSSES HER ART
description: PERFORMERS and playwrights are praised or panned. Some directors are extolled to the point of attaining star status. Even some producers were once legendary.

title: Correction
description: A review Dec. 22 of Deborah E. Lipstadt's ''Beyond Belief: The American Press and the Coming of the Holocaust, 1933-1945'' suggested an incorrect date for the Yalta Conference. The conference was held in February 1945.

title: WETLANDS NEED PROTECTION
description: THE New Jersey Conservation Foundation is a 3,500-member nonprofit organization that is involved in natural-resource protection and land-use issues throughout the state.

title: QADDAFI INVITES REAGAN TO VISIT HIM IN LIBYA
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi tonight invited President Reagan to come sit in his tent in Tripoli and see for himself that he is not a terrorist.

title: A Bad Review
description: The production of ''Amerika,'' an ABC mini-series about a drab and deprived United States 10 years after a K.G.B.-engineered takeover and one of several American efforts that Soviet officials have pronounced insulting, has been suspended after a warning Moscow sent to Broadcast Row. Brandon Stoddard, president of the network's entertainment division, said last week that the production had been beset by financial problems. But, he added, ''part of the consideration'' in deciding its ultimate fate would be a warning issued to Walter Rodgers, the Moscow bureau chief, when he was summoned to the Soviet Foreign Ministry on Dec. 15.

title: Priscilla Dunne A Boston Bride
description: Priscilla Nan Dunne, the daughter of Doris Scheff of Cambridge and South Yarmouth, Mass., and Arnold H. Dunne of Boston, was married yesterday to Milton Thomas Herzig, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Herzig of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Kushner performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title: Roman Law et Cetera
description: To the Editor:

title: Bethlehem Mayor Defies Ordinance
description: WHEN Paul Marcincin was a member of the City Council in Bethlehem, Pa., in 1973, he voted for an ordinance limiting the mayor of that city to two terms in office.

title: A Happy Ending
description: Just before the Geneva summit in November, the Soviet Union announced that 10 of its citizens with ties to the United States would be allowed to emigrate.

title: SOPRANO WITH A SHINING FUTURE
description: In opera land, this is decidedly the year of Carol Vaness. It is not often that a young American soprano turns up in key roles in three Metropolitan Opera productions, but Miss Vaness is doing so. She started her Met season in November as the Countess in a new Ponnelle ''Figaro.'' On Friday, quick-change artist, she metamorphoses into the manic Electra of ''Idomeneo,'' and on Feb. 3, she reappears as the Israelite Woman, to sing the hit tune of Handel's ''Samson,'' ''Let the Bright Seraphim.'' ''I have the first aria and the last aria and dinner in between,'' says the soprano. ''And maybe a show.''

title: SWING'S PRECIOUS FEW PLAY ON IN POLISHED STYLE
description: The Swing Era, that decade of popular music from 1935 to 1945, is now little more than nostalgic memories, fed by occasional reissues of records made by the big bands that dominated the music of that time. Only a handful of the leaders of those bands are still alive and active -Woody Herman, Lionel Hampton, Les Brown and, sporadically, Benny Goodman, who recently formed a band that will be heard on PBS on March 15. Artie Shaw organized an orchestra a couple of years ago and, although he appears with it from time to time, he never plays anymore. And there are ''ghost'' bands that carry the names of leaders now dead -Glenn Miller, Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey - and the ''descendant'' bands of Count Basie and Duke Ellington in which musicians who played with Mr. Basie and Mr. Ellington may still be heard.

title: CROWDS GATHER IN CITY'S PARKS FOR A GLIMPSE
description: It was hard to tell the stars from the lighted jets approaching La Guardia Airport, but at least some eager-eyed watchers in Prospect Park in Brooklyn saw Halley's comet last night.

title: Topics: Changes, Not All for the Better; Peephole of Science
description: Science magazine has given itself a typographical facelift with a bizarre blemish. The learned journal now solemnly dots the ''I'' in its all-capital logo, SCIENCE.

title: Block Is Leaving To Mixed Reviews
description: Few members of the Cabinet have have had a longer row to hoe than John R. Block. Though the Federal Government has spent record sums on the nation's farms during his tour as Secretary of Agriculture, much of rural America has bogged down in the hardest times since the 1930's.

title: Oaxaca
description: To the Editor: Having wintered in Oaxaca for the past 10 years, my husband and I read with great interest Olivier Bernier's article ''Valley of the Ancient Gods'' (Travel, Nov. 10). It was a far more insightful piece than most, but I would like to add a bit of information:

title: JOSEPH HELLER: THE ROAD BACK
description: MEL Brooks materialized out of nowhere to pay me the first of his visits. Nothing could have been more unexpected to me than the sight of him in my intensive-care unit at about 9 P.M. on a frigid, black winter evening in late December. I had not even known he was in New York. For reasons no more arcane than a very solid and self-centered intelligence, Mel does not take any more warmly to the idea of dying than I do. His face was pinched and gloomy, he regarded me sorrowfully. I could see he had not come to make me laugh. He had bigger fish to fry.

title: AUCTION OF JAY HOMESTEAD PORTRAITS SPURS DRIVE
description: G. PALMER LeROY of Bedford knows that a picture is worth a thousand words, but right now he is more concerned with how many thousands of dollars six pictures are worth. He will know the answer to that in less than two weeks.

title: 3 SOPRANOS AND PIANIST IN RECITALS
description: Mara Worth-Merriman Ironically, Mara Worth-Merriman's recital the night before at Merkin Concert Hall actually rescued itself by appealing to our eyes. Miss Worth-Merriman was such a marvelous musical comedian and armed with such funny material, in other words, that one quickly forgave her substantial catalogue of vocal problems.

title: PANEL RULED TO LACK AUTHORITY TO LICENSE GYPSY CABS IN CITY
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the Taxi and Limousine Commission lacks the authority to license livery vehicles - more commonly known as gypsy cabs - and to issue summonses against them.

title: MICHIGAN HOLDS OFF PURDUE TO GO TO 16-0
description: Roy Tarpley scored 18 points and Robert Henderson 13 as Michigan struggled to a 75-71 Big Ten victory over Purdue today.

title: POLISH POLICE ARREST SOLIDARITY FIGITIVE
description: The Polish authorities announced the arrest today of the leader of the Solidarity underground in the Gdansk region, who went into hiding when martial law was declared four years ago.

title: Punjab Officials Ask For 6,000 More Troops
description: Punjabi authorities asked New Delhi to send more than 6,000 additional soldiers to the province because they expect another violent confrontation with Sikhs who have vowed to destroy a holy shrine, the police said today.

title: 25 Injured in Ammonia Leak
description: Ammonia gas leaking from a broken refrigeration line spewed into a packing plant, injuring 25 people, eight of them critically, officials said. The critically injured employees of Braunfels Meat Inc. were hospitalized in Houston , suffering respiratory burns and irritation to the eyes and face.

title: Time Is the Enemy of Nuclear Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. SEEKS NEW LOBBYIST
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S top lobbyist here is a liberal Democrat who, Republican critics argue, should be replaced by a Republican who can better promote both the Governor and New Jersey.

title: Diana Lee Plans To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Diana Lincoln Lee to Peter John Hammond has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lee Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Prouts Neck, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neville Hammond of Perth, Australia.

title: Calling The Dog
description: Williams Safire's article on the gentrification of dogs' names reminded me of a Shakespearean scholar I knew at a university where I once taught (''Name That Dog,'' On Language, Dec. 22). He was a cat person, but grudgingly consented to tolerate a mongrel his children dragged home one day.

title: CUOMO SEEKS PATH TO INSTALL A CABLE
description: Governor Cuomo asked the Reagan Administration yesterday to waive an ''antiquated'' Federal rule and allow a state-of-the-art fiber optics communications cable to be laid along the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway from New York City to the western reaches of the state.

title: MARTIN RITT: HUAN RELATIONSHIPS AND MORAL CHOCES FUEL HIS MOVIES
description: Midway through Martin Ritt's new film, ''Murphy's Romance,'' starring Sally Field and James Garner, the latter explains to Miss Field's young son that all the blood and gore in a slasher film they've just seen is phony.

title: Colombo Lawyer Must Testify
description: A prominent New York criminal lawyer was directed last week to tell a grand jury about fees a client had paid him, even though the information could be used against the client.

title: WHY TOLLS STILL VEX THE MOTORIST
description: THE mystery that confounds laymen and politicians alike is why Connecticut drivers continue to slow down at those sections of Interstate 95 where the tolls have been removed.

title: A WELL OF CREATIVITY IN TRENTON
description: CHARLES A. KUMNICK is an artist whose ongoing dialogue with materials cannot be separated from the evolution of his vision.

title: YOUTH GANGS RISE IN SUBURBS IN WEST
description: Officials in California say gang membership is increasing among white, middle-class suburban youths, and the officials say these gangs are engaging in such criminal acts as gang fights and robbery, and that some take part in Satanic rituals.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Dec. 22 about a performance in New Jersey by the Vienna Choir Boys incorrectly described the relationship of some famous musicians to the choir. Mozart was never a member; Bruckner was a teacher, but not a member.

title: REDMEN BEAT HOYAS BY 79-74
description: There had been suggestions throughout the week that the St. John's-Georgetown rivalry had lost some of its luster this season because the main protagonists of the past four seasons - Chris Mullin for St. John's and Georgetown's Patrick Ewing - had moved to higher ground.

title: POSTINGSFive States Nexus; Warehouse Sold
description: The Fedders Corporation warehouse in Edison, N.J., a landmark for over a decade to the millions of drivers who pass it on the New Jersey Turnpike, has been empty and silent for two years. But soon this vast, low complex with almost a million square feet of space will spring to life again under a new ownership.

title: THE DANCE: GINA BUNTZ AND TROUPE
description: GINA BUNTZ'S choreography is most likable when it is bright and merry. And Miss Buntz offered a real charmer at the performance Thursday night by Dancers and Gina Buntz at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street.

title: GENERATION GAP: 60's ACTIVIST, CONSERVATIVE SON
description: Jeremy Pinchot is 16 now and lives in a suburb of New Haven, but when he was young, he lived on a commune in upstate New York and had a ponytail like most of the boys there. On the commune, his family shared a one-room cabin. Jeremy went to school in a barn.

title: FORTUNATE PROSPECT WINNER
description: Fortunate Prospect took the lead at the top of the stretch and then held off It's a Done Deal by a nose to win the $48,080 Hallandale Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEAR SISTER. By Judith Summers. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Relationships between sisters are often close -but are they easy? Those who are sisters know the answer to this question.

title: U.S. COUNTDOWN STARTS FOR DR. KING'S HOLIDAY
description: A weeklong schedule of concerts, church services and school activities commemorating Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. got under way in Atlanta today, as the nation began the countdown to Jan. 20 and the first observance of the national holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader.

title: Sales Up For City's Big Stores
description: New York City's big retailers registered the year's biggest sales gains in December, according to a monthly spot-check, helped considerably by a strong surge in the final weekend before Christmas and an exceptionally busy post-Christmas week.

title: LIVELY NEW BOOKSTORE FOR ACADEMIC PRESSES
description: If you are a history buff, a new New York bookstore has just the right book for you: ''The History and Social Influence of the Potato.''

title: Race-Car Owner Granted Pardon
description: Junior Johnson, the stock car driver and a successful racing-car owner, has been granted a Presidential pardon for a moonshining conviction in 1956.

title: SALVADOR PRELATE ACCUSES AIR FORCE
description: In one of his strongest statements to date, the Archbishop of El Salvador today condemned the indiscriminate bombing of civilians by the Government air force and the destruction of homes and crops in army sweeps of rebel-held areas.

title: URANIUM PLANT WHERE MAN DIED WAS CITED FOR LEAKS OF POLLUTION
description: The uranium-processing plant in Gore, Okla., where a chemical leak killed a worker nine days ago, has been a source of controversy for more than a decade over routine discharges of small amounts of radiation and pollutants to the air, soil and water.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
description: The Economy

title: SYRIA DEFENDS ITS RIGHTS TO PLACE BORDER MISSILES
description: Syrian officials today defended their country's right to install antiaircraft missiles on the border with Lebanon and in Lebanon's Bekaa region, an action that has recently brought the Syrians into sharp conflict with Israel.

title: THEATER: 'OUR SONG,' NEIL SIMON
description: MAYBE you have to be the sort of friend of Marvin Hamlisch and Carole Bayer Sager that Neil Simon is to find their romance interesting enough to provide the book for a musical comedy. That's one observation prompted by the Equity Library Theater's revival, in a manner of speaking, of ''They're Playing Our Song,'' the 1979 musical on which the three collaborated. Another observation is that this show is beyond reviving.

title: Sale of Potash Co. Set
description: Ideal Basic Industries said on Friday that its bank and insurance company lenders had consented to the sale of Ideal's 88 percent interest in Potash Company of America Inc. to Rio Algom Ltd. Approval by Ideal Basic shareholders, expected Jan. 30, is now the only condition to close the sale on Jan. 31. The company also said it had agreed with the lenders to extend through Feb. 14 waivers of financial covenants and interest and principal defaults.

title: HAITIAN IS CAUGHT IN PROTEST BACKLASH
description: Adler Volny, a tall, gray-haired schoolmaster, stood in his ransacked bedroom in a city 90 miles north of here, amid mattresses askew, dresser drawers emptied in heaps, papers and books tossed about.

title: Hail, NBC Peacock - Bird Thou Never Wert
description: My daughters have never seen the NBC Peacock.

title: ASSESSING THE DROP IN CANADA'S DOLLAR
description: By numerous measures, Canada's economy appears robust. The economic growth rate is higher than in the United States, corporate profits are fat and home building is on an uptick.

title: THE STAGE: 'IT'S ONLY A PLAY'
description: ''IT'S ONLY A PLAY'' is both the title and the most persistent refrain of the frequently uproarious Terrence McNally comedy now to be found at the Manhattan Theater Club. ''Whatever happens tonight, it's only a play,'' the revelers at an opening-night party keep reminding themselves as they wait for the reviews of Broadway's newest arrival, ''The Golden Egg.'' But Mr. McNally knows well that his characters protest far too much. For the fictional show people in ''It's Only a Play,'' the play's the thing, the only thing - at least until an offer from Hollywood comes along.

title: A 'GENTLEMAN' IN LINE OF FIRE AT JUSTICE DEPT.
description: To take the full measure of a prosecutor's reputation, talk with defense lawyers who have faced him in court. Attorneys acknowledge that it is sometimes like asking cobras to critique an ill-mannered mongoose.

title: IRAN'S NAVY STOPS U.S. SHIP IN SEARCH NEAR PERSIAN GULF
description: The United States said today that armed Iranian sailors stopped and searched an American merchant ship for more than an hour in international waters near the Persian Gulf.

title: DOLPHINS ERR IN 31-14 ROUT
description: The New England Patriots, continuing to exact revenge in the playoffs against teams that defeated them in the regular season, reached Super Bowl XX today by defeating the Miami Dolphins, of all people.

title: CONCERN FOR VICTIMS OF AIDS SHOWN IN GISTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Concern for the needy and the ill, particularly those suffering from the disease AIDS, is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: LOTTERY OF SHARING A HOME
description: SHE is an older woman with a large home, a professional whose office is in that home. Her husband is ailing and spends much of his time in the drier climate of the southwest. ''I used to go away a lot,'' she said. ''I had discomfort about the lack of activity in my house, its emptiness. So I decided I would take someone in, someone who wants companionship, but privacy as well, and for whom knowing that there is someone behind that wall in another room is a comfort.''

title: A FILM'S 'TYPICAL AMERICAN' ASKS WHY SOME SAY HE ISN'T
description: The United Nations film shows a young Russian pole-vaulter, his face bright against the background of a war memorial, running and finally hurling himself over a crossbar. Later, shown training children, he turns to the camera and says, ''There is no other sport that requires so much.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
description: International Iran intercepted a U.S. freighter in international waters near the Persian Gulf, White House and State Department spokesmen announced, saying that it was a ''matter of serious concern.'' The American freighter, the President Taylor, was stopped by Iranians who boarded from an Iranian Navy ship and searched the American vessel for more than an hour. The freighter then went on to Fujaira, a port in the United Arab Emirates. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: RAMS MISS KEY OPPORTUNITY
description: The Bears were so coldly efficient against the Los Angeles Rams today that they probably would have won their playoff game easily even if the Rams had scored at the end of the first half. But time ran out on the Rams then as they seemed about to score, and even in their locker room after the game they were not sure what had happened or why it happened.

title: One Inmate Killed In Indiana Uprising
description: Officials searched for weapons today while State Police detectives questioned prisoners at the Indiana Reformatory to determine what triggered a short-lived uprising that claimed the life of one inmate.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. SHOULD 'RAISE THE COST' TO TERRORISTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz suggested today that he believed the United States should take military action to punish terrorists or those who help them and not just apply economic sanctions.

title: Joan Gelman Weds Donald E. Aronson
description: Joan Gelman, a television producer and freelance writer, was married yesterday to Donald E. Aronson, director of marketing and a partner at the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company. Rabbi Harvey Goldman performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: CITY'S BIGGEST CONSTRUCTION BOOM: PUBLIC PROJECTS
description: If a single recent event has symbolized the city's construction boom, it is not the opening of Trump Tower or any of the other gaudy office or apartment towers in Manhattan.

title: TREASURY SETS SHORT-TERM ISSUES
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the short-term market, starting with today's sale of three- and six-month bills totaling $14.8 billion and ending Thursday with a $9 billion sale of one-year bills.

title: Vatican Recognition and an Israel That Lives Up to Its Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Seeks Plan Backing
description: AT 8 percent, Brazil's economic growth last year was the highest in the world. Its trade surplus of $12.45 billion was third only to Japan's and West Germany's. But its average inflation rate for last year was 230 percent and it owes more money to foreign creditors - $100 billion - than any other developing country.

title: People
description: Horace M. Malfa, president, has been designated chief operating officer at Cunningham & Walsh.

title: Top Newsletter In Stock Picks
description: LOOKING back on a momentous week in the stock market, Alfred Frank, publisher of an investment newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif., declared on Friday: ''I'm still constructive on prospects for stocks in 1986.''

title: Briefcases
description: Finance ministers from the West's leading industrial powers - the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Japan - will meet in London next weekend. It will be the first gathering of the ministers from the Group of Five since early October, when they met in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Jackson Scores 3 In Japan Bowl
description: Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy winner, scored three touchdowns, including one on a 57-yard run to clinch the victory in the fourth quarter, as the East defeated the West, 31-14, today in the Japan Bowl.

title: LONDON'S TAXI ELITE PROTESTS, WITH STYLE
description: Stanley Roth hardly sounds like a disgruntled worker. ''This trade has given me everything I want in life,'' the 49-year-old Londoner said. ''I'm a free man. There's no boss looking over my shoulder. I earn a comfortable living, and I travel and talk to interesting people.''

title: Nakasone in Canada For a 4-Day Visit
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan arrived in Canada today for a four-day visit that is expected to center on Japan's attempts to enlist Canada's help in opposing protectionist measures in the United States.

title: China Seeking GATT Status
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said Friday that China wants to rejoin the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade after a 36-year absence.

title: KOCH INTENDS TO NAME A LAWYER TO VACANCY ON EDUCATION BOARD
description: In his continuing effort to revamp the Board of Education, Mayor Koch is to name Richard I. Beattie, a corporate lawyer and former Federal official, to be a board member. The appointment is expected today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHANGING TIMES Jan Wallman's Restaurant, a small niche at 28 Cornelia Street, near Bleecker Street (242-9557), has carved itself a place in the hearts of many entertainers who have sung and played there. The compact restaurant-club is scheduled to close Jan. 26, but Miss Wallman is already looking for new premises.

title: AS PLAN IS PURSUED, SO IS LEGAL CHALLENGE
description: Twelve members of Congress are challenging the constitutionality of the new budget-balancing law even as the Reagan Administration prepares to carry it out.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Claude Frank, Pianist, In Beethoven Program
description: Claude Frank's name on the program is a good guarantee of good Beethoven, and he began his Beethoven Society concert at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon with a beautifully paced performance of the Sonata in E minor (Op. 90). The second movement answered the composer's specification exactly: ''very songfully.''

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN SLAIN BEFORE TALK WITH U.S. OFFICIAL
description: A black township activist was stabbed to death, reportedly by pro-Government vigilantes, hours before he was scheduled to meet today with a high-level American official.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Youth on the Sidelines
description: When 26-year-old David Shula emerged as a candidate to be named head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, some news accounts fumbled the ball. Though Shula's selection would undeniably make him the youngest person to hold such a job in the National Football League's postwar era (Harland Svare, the current postwar record-holder, was 32 when hired by the Los Angeles Rams in 1962), the reports that he would be the youngest in all of N.F.L. history were far off the mark.

title: 'AMERICANIZED' LENDL GAINS CONFIDENCE AND DRIVE
description: THE changes have been subtle, like the ones an animator draws to bring an illustration to life on a movie screen. If his career were evaluated frame by frame, it might appear that Ivan Lendl has not changed much at all, when in fact, he now stands alone at the top of men's tennis. In style, the topspin forehand that he cracks like a whip is still his trademark, his invitation to a tournament final. In substance, he remains introspective and relatively guarded, the type of person who will look through a peep-hole before opening the front door.

title: Gramm, Rudman and Who?
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings is a sponsor without honor in his own capital. The South Carolina Democrat is one of the original drafters of the pioneering budget-balancing legislation that President Reagan signed last month, but he rarely gets any of the credit.

title: ISRAEL IN ACCORD ON ARBITRATION IN LAND DISPUTE
description: Israel today agreed conditionally to submit its Taba border dispute with Egypt to international arbitration after a stormy meeting between key Likud and Labor Cabinet ministers lasting nearly 13 hours.

title: U.S. AND HANOI HOPEFUL AFTER TALKS ON THE MISSING
description: While American and Vietnamese officials expressed satisfaction last week with the atmosphere of good will surrounding two days of high-level talks in Hanoi on Americans missing in action since the Vietnam War, both sides agreed that they had reached a time when building confidence and increasing cooperation would be critical.

title: New Yorker Losing Longtime Chairman
description: Peter F. Fleischmann, longtime chairman of The New Yorker Magazine Inc., has announced that he intends to resign at the end of the month.

title: Gas Prices Show Drops
description: Retail gasoline prices fell in the first two weeks of 1986, but the decline of half a cent a gallon failed to keep pace with plummeting wholesale prices, an oil industry analyst said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allegheny Beverage Corp., Washington, has named Edward A. Weisman president, succeeding Morton M. Lapides, who remains chairman and chief executive officer. David Barr was appointed executive vice president and William Avella was named president of the company's food and vending subsidiary, Service America Corp.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Pre-game Packaging
description: The way NBC sees it, the problem with the Super Bowl is football.

title: IN NEWARK, TUTU PRAISES JERSEY'S DIVESTITURE
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa visited New Jersey yesterday and thanked Governor Kean and other officials for their leadership, which, he said in a speech in Newark, ''has led yours to be the first state to pass legislation seeking to bring pressure on the Government of South Africa.''

title: WHERE JAPAN BEGAN, PROGRESS BOWS TO ARCHEOLOGY
description: They were building a new golf course outside of town when someone discovered that a 1,300-year-old burial mound lay where a fairway was supposed to go.

title: ITALIAN CAR MAKERS SEEKING U.S. NICHE
description: Italy's reputation for fine design has stoked an enormous American appetite for all manner of Italian goods, from sweaters to lamps to appliances. But Italian car manufacturers have been unable to capitalize on that appetite.

title: VATICAN RECONGNITION AND AN ISRAEL THAT LIVES UP TO ITS IDEALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Interferon Lifts Schering-Plough Hopes
description: Over the last five years, the Schering-Plough Corporation has poured more than $100 million into research relating to interferon in the hopes that sales of the drug might someday be as strong as its prized Garamycin, the once strong-selling antibiotic whose patent expired in 1980.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:32 A.M. today and set at 8:04 P.M. tonight.

title: Slalom Race Won By Kronbichler
description: Anni Kronbichler easily captured the first heat and then hung back in the second run today to win a women's World Cup slalom ski race.

title: A 'Frail Strand'
description: ''I can't stand bullies, and I don't like people being fobbed off with second-rate justice.'' - Molly Blackburn Last May, at one of the numerous funeral rallies blacks have staged during 15 months of unrest that have claimed more than a thousand lives in South Africa, a white activist named Molly Blackburn led a delegation of white people into a stadium jammed with thousands of blacks.

title: LITTLE MOVE IN 2 OIL STOCKS PREDICTED
description: Analysts expect a moderate rise in the value of the stock of Texaco Inc. and a slight fall in that of the Pennzoil Company today as a result of a Federal judge's ruling Friday. The judge said Texaco would not have to post a $12 billion bond to appeal a Texas jury's verdict against it.

title: Man at the Wheel
description: Careering uptown on the West Side, the taxi driver took on potholes with what seemed to be courageous abandon, as if they were invisible.

title: MORE SIGNS OF VIGOR EXPECTED
description: Following last week's sharp rise in interest rates, the credit markets are prepared for a spate of strong economic statistics this week, including sizable gains in retail sales and industrial production for December.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: U.S. Steel Suit Dropped
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation jointly said on Friday that the lawsuit commenced earlier in the week against both companies had been voluntarily dropped by the plaintiff.

title: 24-0 DEFEAT FOR RAMS
description: At the end, the winds were blowing and snow was falling and the fans were dancing in the aisles, delirious with glee.

title: Bonner Goes to Hospital; To Get Bypass Today
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident, entered a hospital today for open heart surgery, and her family said she was worried because she had not heard from her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, in more than two weeks.

title: 24 POINTS ON FOUR FUMBLES
description: The essence of New England's victory over Miami today was the four fumbles by the Dolphins recovered by the Patriots. These turnovers, one in each of the four periods, were the preface to 24 points for New England that sent the Patriots to the Super Bowl.

title: Playboy's New Twist On a Tease
description: THE teaser campaign is a venerable and recognized advertising ploy, but who has ever heard of a 30-second tease?

title: photo of Jason Connery and Judi Trott; 'ROBIN HOOD' SERIES, ON SHOWTIME
description: WHAT happens when a lucrative television formula is faced with a crucial casting change? American producers have discovered that their audiences will accept just about anything. One prime example invalved the matriarchal role of Miss Ellie on ''Dallas.'' When Barbara Bel Geddes became ill, Donna Reed was brought in as a replacement for a full season. Then Miss Reed was dumped as Miss Bel Geddes recovered sufficiently to return. Most viewers, it seems, didn't bat an eye, which in itself is perhaps a comment on the reality demands of nighttime soaps.

title: Cetus Head Adds Position
description: The Cetus Corporation, a leading biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., has given Robert A. Fildes, its president, the additional title of chief executive. Mr. Fildes, 47 years old, has served as president and chief operating officer since he joined Cetus in December 1982.

title: McHeadband Is 'Different'
description: THE day Jim McMahon arrived at the Bears' complex as their first-round draft choice in 1982, he stepped out of a limousine with a can of beer in his hand.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A WRITER'S TIME. A Guide to the Creative Process, from Vision through Revision. By Kenneth Atchity. 194 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $12.95. FIRST, the good news. Kenneth

title: LIFE AFTER A SON'S SUICIDE: ONE FAMILY'S STRUGGLE
description: ''Somehow I didn't communicate to my son how important his life was to me,'' Susan White-Bowden said the other day as she talked about the death by suicide at age 17 of her son, John O'Donnell White Jr. ''He must have asked himself,'' she continued, '' 'What difference would it make? My mother has her career and her relationship. My sisters are in college and have their friends. Whose life would really change if I were dead?' ''

title: There Were No Indians
description: Has the life of the mind been so politicized in this country that intellectuals who welcome a book's political conclusion will shrug off challenges to its truth? That is the troubling question raised by the controversy over ''From Time Immemorial: The Origins of the Arab-Jewish Conflict Over Palestine,'' by Joan Peters.

title: A DREAMER IN SPACE
description: As a child in San Jose, Costa Rica, Franklin R. Chang-Diaz used to play inside an empty packing crate, pretending that it was a spaceship on its way to a distant star. Yesterday Dr. Chang realized part of his dream, riding into orbit aboard the shuttle Columbia as the first Hispanic American astronaut to fly in space. He came to the United

title: White House Economists
description: President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board at long last will meet with the President. The date is Jan. 23, just five days before the State of the Union address and 11 days before the budget is presented to Congress.

title: FOR SOME APPLICANTS, STUDENT ESSAY UNLOCKS OR SEALS THE DOOR TO COLLEGE
description: The college admission essay, Harry Bauld cautioned seniors at the Horace Mann School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, can be the ''ultimate noose with which a 17-year-old can hang himself.''

title: BEYOND THE HILL: A LOBBYING BATTLE
description: As the lobbying game is played in this town, the battle generally centers on Capitol Hill, between those pushing a cause and those in Congress who see things differently. But from time to time, a lobbyist might find a foe within his own ranks.

title: ASTRONAUTS LAUNCH RCA SATELLITE
description: After weeks of frustration and a record seven postponements, the space shuttle Columbia soared into space this morning to begin a five-day scientific mission.

title: ADOLESCENT SUICIDES: THE GRIM STATISTICS
description: Jody White killed himself in 1977, the year that ranks highest in the rate of adolescent suicides in this country. In that year, 5,565 people ages 15 to 24 took their own lives, bringing the rate per 100,000 people in that age category to 13.3, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: DANCE: DIANNE MCINTYRE AT THE JOYCE
description: DIANNE McINTYRE'S Sounds in Motion lives up to its name. Miss McIntyre has been working with musicians for many years, well before the current vogue of collaboration. An exciting performance by the company on Friday at the Joyce Theater suggested that she has a corner on the market.

title: How Police Caught Solidarity Leader
description: The capture last week of a top Solidarity fugitive occurred when the police raided a clandestine printing plant while the underground leader was inspecting it, opposition sources said today.

title: RUSSIAN COMPOSER IN NEW YORK
description: The cultural breeze emanating from the Reagan-Gorbachev summit in Geneva has wafted Rodion Shchedrin in our direction this week. The 53-year-old Soviet composer - considered by many the natural successor to Dmitri Shostakovich as Soviet spokesman for contemporary Russian music - is in New York to hear the premiere of his suite ''The Seagull'' at the National Orchestra of New York's Carnegie Hall concert tomorrow night.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; 'Jitterbug Jazz' Revue At the Top of the Gate
description: ''Jitterbug Jazz,'' the musical comedy revue now in its third month at the Top of the Gate (160 Bleecker Street), looks back affectionately at Harlem in the 30's and 40's. But it offers nostalgia with a difference: Many of the performers in this celebration of the swing era helped shape the cultural history that the show recreates with a jubilant informality.

title: Seeking Profits Via Bond Index
description: IT was time to take cover in the bond market last week as prices of tax-exempt, or municipal, bonds abruptly headed south and sentiment soured.

title: NATALIA MAKAROVA ANNOUNCES DECISION TO END BALLET CAREER
description: Natalia Makarova has announced that she has decided to end her ballet career after nearly three decades of dancing. The international ballet star, who won a Tony in 1983 for her Broadway performance in ''On Your Toes,'' said she hoped to continue acting. Miss Makarova said she decided to stop dancing mainly because of the unchallenging ballet roles she had recently been offered.

title: Output Lags For Soviet Oil
description: Soviet oil output fell short of its target again last year despite a warning from the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Pravda said Saturday.

title: ITALIAN CHIEF WARNS OF HIGH RISK OF MORE ATTACKS
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi has warned Parliament that instability in the Middle East has created a ''high risk'' that Italy will face new terrorist attacks.

title: BATTLE OF SEXES, WAR OF WORDS
description: Word wars are heating up. After more than a decade of taking a defensive posture against feminist allegations that English usage is biased in favor of the male, men are launching a counterattack.

title: CITY BALLET: 'GLASS PIECES'
description: TWO studies in high energy were danced for the first time this season by the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Japanese Car Shipments
description: Practically all Japanese cars sold in the United States are transported on Japanese-owned ships, which does not sit too well in an increasingly protectionist Congress.

title: GAS PIPLINES SEEN AS MERGER TARGETS
description: Takeover speculation surrounding the sharp rise last week in the stock of the Transco Energy Company occurred against what several energy analysts described as a backdrop of continuing consolidation, falling prices and turmoil in the natural gas pipeline industry.

title: Other Rumanians Feel Human-Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Does the ''O. J.'' in O. J. Anderson stand for the same names as the initials in O. J. Simpson? Regardless of what's in a name, how does the St. Louis Cardinals' O. J. compare with the Hall of Famer as a running back?

title: The U.N. Today: Jan. 13, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL

title: CABARET: JANE HARVEY
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM is not a songwriter whose work readily lends itself to jazz interpretation. His refined European melodies partake sparingly of blues influences, and the chiseled psychological insights of his lyrics resist tampering.

title: SHULTZ FACES CRITICS IN SPEECH OPENING 48TH PEN ASSEMBLY
description: More than 600 writers from around the world opened the 48th International PEN Congress last night amid a continuing dispute over the invitation to Secretary of State George P. Shultz to address the meeting.

title: THE BEARS' HARD HATS
description: THE idea for the Bears' defense was to stop Eric Dickerson. ''We knew,'' said Otis Wilson, a Bear linebacker, that ''we'd have to put hats on him so he'd have trouble.''

title: State Senator Bloom Of Illinois Dies in Fire
description: State Senator Prescott Bloom, who gained recognition last year by posing as a drifter in an investigation of Medicaid fraud, died Saturday trying to save his two children from fire in his home, officials said.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Like Father, Like Son
description: Several weeks ago, the University of Texas-Arlington, citing financial losses and a lack of fan support for its Division I-AA program, announced that it was dropping football.

title: Coffee Prices Stir Criticism
description: African coffee producers have urged an immediate suspension of international quotas for the commodity to bring down soaring prices and curb speculation.

title: CON EDISON TO FREEZE RATES IN '86
description: The Consolidated Edison Company agreed yesterday not to raise its electricity rates before March 1987, at which time it will have gone four years without a rate increase.

title: OIL AMPLE, FOOD SHORT FOR LIBYA
description: A banana boat from Nicaragua steamed into port here last week. Several people were injured in the riots that broke out at fruit and vegetable stores throughout Tripoli, diplomats said, as people pushed and shoved one another for the prized imported fruit.

title: A PBS DOCUMENTARY ON GUATEMALA
description: IT'S not that ''Guatemala: When the Mountains Tremble'' is controversial; it's more that it's so badly done. The original 83-minute documentary, sanitized, so to speak, with the addition of panel discussion and explanation, now runs two hours. Public television ought to have cut its losses and forgotten the whole thing.

title: Farewell to a Friend
description: For what almost seemed like forever, he was there at the door on Riverside Drive - there to exult in someone's triumph, there to share a whispered sorrow and, always, there with an attache case full of cookies for the children.

title: ANTHONY VALENTI
description: Anthony (Rip) Valenti, a long-time boxing promoter in the Boston area, died Friday after a brief illness.

title: GUNTHARDT AND TAROCZY WIN
description: Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland and Balazs Taroczy of Hungary won the $200,000 World Doubles Tennis Championship for a record third time today, beating the Australian Open champions Paul Annacone and Christo Van Rensburg in five sets.

title: Gambling on Third-World Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: MCCOY TYNER'S TRIO PERFORMS
description: TWO years ago, when McCoy Tyner gave up the jazz quintet and quartet formats he had been using for most of the previous decade, his thinking turned in two opposing directions. One was the formation of a trio; the other, of a big band.

title: The Rush to 'Privatize'
description: ''Privatization'' means the opposite of ''nationalization,'' but until just a few years ago, the tendency was all one way. Selling or giving away public property was just a gleam in the eye of a few free-market zealots. Nowadays, the idea of privatization is generating enthusiasm from the Potomac to the Ganges.

title: SCIENTISTS WARN OF EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITY ON ATMOSPHERE
description: Human activity is changing the earth's atmosphere and scientists know too little about the long-term environmental consequences, according to a draft of an international scientific report by 150 scientists from 11 countries.

title: FROM TEXACO JUDGE, PLAIN TALK
description: Charles L. Brieant, the Federal district judge whose ruling last Friday gave Texaco Inc. a reprieve in its battle with the Pennzoil Company, is known in legal circles as a plain-spoken jurist with a flair for distilling complex cases in stylish, sometimes acerbic opinions.

title: M.T.A. OFFICIAL FINDS FIRE EXITS IN SUBWAYS IN DANGEROUS CONDITION
description: Many emergency fire exits in New York City's subway tunnels are in ''potentially life-threatening'' condition, according to a report by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: HOMOSEXUAL-RIGHTS BILL WILL PASS, BACKER SAY
description: Supporters of a homosexual-rights bill said yesterday that they were confident the City Council would approve such legislation this year, despite what they described as stepped-up efforts by John Cardinal O'Connor to defeat it.

title: U.S. Is a Tax Haven For Foreign Cheats
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''America is proud to have you here. Diversity, debate, contrast, argumentativeness are what we as a people thrive on.''

title: Bridge: Final for Knockout Teams Ends in a Dramatic Climax
description: A dramatic climax with some last-board irony ended the final of the Knockout Team Championship in the Tri-State Regionals in Port Chester, N.Y., on Saturday.

title: Don't Go Back On Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Scapegoat the PAC's
description: We, as a people, love reform.

title: GROUP CRITICIZES CITY'S TRACKING OF CONSTRUCTION
description: Mayor Koch and his top City Hall aides have no system for keeping track of the status of city construction projects, for which billions will be spent within the next 10 years, the Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday.

title: HEADACHES FROM RITE OF SPRING
description: Easter comes on the last weekend in March this year, a week earlier than last spring, and for Ron Cochran, the Police Chief of Fort Lauderdale, that spells trouble.

title: NORWALK SEEKS RENEWED GLORY FOR W.P.A. ART
description: The largest known collection of Depression-era murals soon will be cleansed of spitballs, ketchup and, in one case, the penciled signature of ''Michael Angelo.''

title: KNIFE CUTS APPEAR SELF-INFLICTED, INVESTIGATORS IN MANES CASE SAY
description: Wrist and ankle cuts suffered three days ago by Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes were apparently self-inflicted, law-enforcement officials investigating the mysterious incident disclosed yesterday.

title: GLAMOUR IS GONE, BUT WESTHEAD IS COACHING AGAIN
description: ON most mornings these days, a group of men gathers inside the gymnasium here on the sprawling, sun-drenched campus of Loyola Marymount University. They are the Los Angeles Lakers, currently professional basketball's best team and probably the best team of the 80's. This is where they practice during the season.

title: HORFORD'S APPEAL DENIED BY N.C.A.A.
description: Tito Horford is still ineligible to play at Houston because of an illegal recruiting contact in 1984, a National Collegiate Athletic Association appeals committee ruled today.

title: Clear Up This Clemency
description: After gunshots rang out in a car pulling off the New York State Thruway, a deputy sheriff, William Fitzgerald, was found dead in the front seat, and a convict, Robert Bowerman, lay dead in the back. That's all that is known for sure about the incident in September of 1968. Eventually, two other convicts, Gary McGivern and Charles Culhane, were found guilty of participating in the deputy's murder.

title: New Agency Named For La Yogurt Account
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has been named agency for La Yogurt, which is produced by Johanna Farms in Flemington, N.J. The previous agency was Sawden & Bess Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, which won the account in 1981 and moved it, according to Martin M. Mitchell Jr., its president, to 11 percent share of the market, from 3 percent, and from 12th to 2nd place after Dannon in the New York and Washington marketing areas.

title: Get It?
