description: President Reagan puzzled the journalists and academics who flyspeck his public statements last week in his news conference when he ad-libbed the punch line of an old joke few Washingtonians could recall. Answering a question on tax increases, he said Congress had reneged on a past promise to cut spend-ing $3 for every $1 of a tax increase.

title: SALE BY BINGHAMS MARKS END OF ERA IN KENTUCKY JOURNALISM
description: George Yater says that when he heard the Bingham family was selling The Courier-Journal, for decades the state's premier newspaper, he felt the way he did when President Roosevelt died.

title: TEXACO'S LEGAL STRATEGIST
description: On the evening of Dec. 9, Texaco Inc.'s top executives, in a crisis meeting at the oil company's branch office in Houston, made a risky decision: to attempt to bring a portion of their legal battle with the Pennzoil Company before a Federal court.

title: Keeping Pressure on the Sandinistas
description: The debate over what is to be done about the Communist regime in Nicaragua will resume when Congress returns on Jan. 21. This year, however, the argument is not over who the Sandinistas are; it is over what can be done to stop their continuing repression and subversion.

title: ERIXON HURT AS RANGERS TIE
description: The Rangers settled for a 2-2 tie with the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden last night despite scoring their goals in the first two minutes, but perhaps more disheartening for the Rangers was the loss of Jan Erixon, the swift left winger.

title: Hormel Strikers Rally As Plant Nears Opening
description: More than 2,000 people, workers on strike against the Hormel meatpacking plant here and their supporters, staged an enthusiastic rally here today in support of continuing the strike.

title: 4.3% CUTS NEEDED IN DOMESTIC AREA UNDER BUDGET LAW
description: Federal spending for most nonmilitary programs must be cut by 4.3 percent on March 1 under the terms of a new budget-balancing law, the Reagan Administration and the Congressional Budget Office have concluded.

title: Gentleman at the Wheel
description: Another West Sider heading home.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: J. Walter Thompson Wins a Computer Job
description: J. Walter Thompson's Detroit office has been named agency for Inacomp Computer Centers based in Troy, Mich.

title: MOVES ON CAPTIVES IN LEBANON FALTER
description: Last month's terrorist attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports are reported to have caused complications in efforts to gain the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon.

title: World-Class Talk
description: Fordham University was the battleground for an international war of words this weekend, as Irish and Australian debaters contended for the 1986 World University Debating Championship. The Irish won.

title: Landeta Cleared of Charge
description: A state police investigation has cleared Sean Landeta, the Giants' punter, of charges he tried to scalp two tickets for the wild-card playoff game at Giants Stadium, the Bergen County prosecutor said today.

title: American Wins World Cup Sprint
description: Dan Jansen of the United States and Gaetan Boucher of Canada won the 500- and 1,000-meter sprint events of the World Cup speed-skating competition today.

title: Elliott M. Rudwick, 58, Dies; Sociology Professor at Kent
description: Elliott M. Rudwick, a professor of sociology at Kent State University and an expert on the history of black Americans, died Dec. 20 at his home in Kent, Ohio, the university has reported. He was 58 years old.

title: A Warning Revisited
description: Twenty-five years ago next Friday, President Eisenhower warned the American people in his farewell address: ''In the councils of government, we must guard against the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military-industrial complex. The potential for the disastrous rise of misplaced power exists and will persist.''

title: Fake Pass at the N.C.A.A.
description: The rulers of college sports meet in New Orleans today to rearrange the educational fig leaf covering their entertainment industry. The hottest issue at the annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association concerns the use of freshmen in varsity competition. An important question, to be sure, but only one of many that bear on the distorted priorities and corruption now threatening college sports.

title: HONG KONG BANKER PLANS FOR NEW ERA
description: China does not resume sovereignty over this British colony until 1997, but David Li, a prominent banker here, is already getting ready.

title: Tamil Guerrilla Groups Call Off Sri Lanka Truce
description: Tamil guerrillas said today that they were calling off a seven-month-old truce with Sri Lanka security forces, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Talbott Takes Greenwich Squash
description: Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., fought off a sustained challenge by Ned Edwards of New York City today to take the $15,000 Chase Manhattan Greenwich Squash Open at the Field Club of Greenwich. The scores were 15-12, 12-15, 7-15, 15-8, 15-8.

title: F.D.A. FAULTED IN THREAT FROM ANIMAL DRUGS
description: The Food and Drug Administration has inadequately monitored the use of toxic drugs and nutrition supplements in raising livestock, posing a grave threat to the health of consumers, according to a Congressional report.

title: Shawmut Chief Puzzled By Society Move on Bid
description: After a lengthy courtship, John P. LaWare, the 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Shawmut Corporation, the third-largest bank holding company in Massachusetts, still is not sure if the object of his affection, Society for Savings, a Hartford-based savings and loan association, really wants to get married.

title: Missouri Newspapers Reconsider Drug Plan
description: The publisher of The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times, responding to negative reaction by employees, said today that he would reconsider a plan to bring drug-sniffing dogs into the building.

title: Islanders Rebound And Pull Together
description: The mood has gone from funereal to festive in the Islander locker room since the team's victories over Pittsburgh and Detroit in the final two games of its five-game home stand.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Sacramento Kings, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. First meeting of the teams since the Kings moved to the West Coast.

title: Home Ownership
description: If you bought a house last year, chances were you were older than those who bought houses in the last nine years and earned more money than they did.

title: 3d U.S. Bank Failure in '86
description: Bad farm loans forced the closing of the Bank of Dixie in Lake Providence, La., Friday, making it the third bank in the nation to fail this year and the second in agriculture, officials said.

title: China Cracks Down On Film Makers
description: Amid signs of an ideological crackdown on Chinese film makers, a Politburo member has warned that movies must benefit Communism or face a stern ''red light,'' the official press reported today.

title: JAPAN STILL WEIGHING AUTO CURBS
description: Japanese officials denied reports this morning that they were close to a decision on whether to continue the voluntary restraints on auto exports to the United States.

title: WILLIAMS SEEKS FAN SUPPORT
description: ON the ballots, he is listed among the forwards in the Eastern Conference simply as Williams, B. But there is nothing else to distinguish him from the other 95 players who appear as candidates for the National Basketball Association's annual All-Star Game next month at Reunion Arena in Dallas. Other names are clearly more recognizable to the fans who select the two starting teams - Bird, Moncrief, Abdul-Jabbar - but Williams, B. seems to be little more than a gifted, but anonymous, player.

title: 7 Reputed Mobsters Charged In '84 Train Bombing in Italy
description: Italian officials announced today that seven suspected gangsters had been charged with mass murder in a 1984 train bombing that killed 15 people and wounded 180.

title: That's Progress
description: In the 1985 Congressional ratings by Americans for Democratic Action, which are due out this week, Representative Jack F. Kemp will receive 10 on a scale of 100. This, however, is twice the New York Republican's 5 rating of 1984. A.D.A. officials note that if Mr. Kemp continues to become more liberal at this rate, he will reach 80 by 1988 and become eligible for consideration for A.D.A. endorsement in the Presidential election, in which he is currently expressing considerable interest. A.D.A. has never endorsed a Republican for national office, but there's always a first time.

title: FALLING PESO DRAWS NEW CONCERNS
description: Bankers, economists and business executives will be watching the currency exchange markets closely Monday to learn whether the Mexican peso will stabilize or continue its precipitous slide against the dollar that began at the end of last week.

title: VICTORY ERASES BAD MEMORIES
description: Garin Veris, a defensive end for the New England Patriots, is going to the Super Bowl. His fumble recovery on his team's first defensive play helped begin a victory in the American Conference championship game. From his defensive end position, he put a consistent pressure on Dan Marino that created a series of problems for the Miami Dolphin quarterback.

title: OUTDOORS: TRAILS FOR ORIENTEERS
description: ORIENTEERING, like fishing, is a sport in which one may participate at one's chosen level of intensity.

title: Pando Rehired By Doyle Dane
description: Alan O. Pando, still a man of broadening horizons at the age of 54, will return to the employ of the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group with the vast chunks of the agency's Western operation in his pocket.

title: Debt of Republic Health Called No Bar to Buyout
description: When business slows between Thanksgiving and New Year's Day, the Republic Health Corporation conducts a holiday sale for Medicare patients: $200 to $400 off each cataract operation.

title: JERSEY MAN GOING ON TRIAL ON CHARGES HE PAID TO HAVE WIFE SLAIN
description: Jury selection will begin here Tuesday in the murder trial of a prominent Toms River insurance agent and the Louisiana man he is accused of hiring to kill his wife.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split paid Jan. 7, 1986.

title: Philharmonic Brass At Holy Trinity
description: It must be a rewarding experience for an orchestra's brass section to emerge momentarily from the back of the ensemble and take center stage. Thirteen members of the New York Philharmonic brass did just that Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Holy Trinity; the results were grand.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $97,550 for the quarter and $157,750 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $199,500 for the quarter and $585,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid July 8, 1985.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON WINS PATENT RULING
description: A Federal judge has overturned a jury finding and ruled that a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson did not infringe upon a patent held by the Fonar Corporation.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: FRED WHIPPLE: A LIFETIME OF SOLVING COMETARY RIDDLES
description: THE man credited with originating the widely accepted concept of comet heads as ''dirty snowballs'' was not told about Halley's comet when it last crossed his skies in 1910. It was not table talk on his father's Iowa farm.

title: PHILADELPHIANS PROTEST PLANS TO LOAD WASTE
description: A thousand people sang ''God Bless America'' and recited the Pledge of Allegiance today to protest a plan to use the city's port to load toxic wastes on an incinerator ship.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,537,000 for the quarter and $6,194,000 for the year, tax credits of $1,430,000 for quarter and $1,238,000 for the year and a charge of $14 million for the quarter and year reflecting a writedown in the carrying value of certain assets. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $101,000 for the quarter, a loss from discontinued operations of $1,812,000 for the year, tax credits of $247,000 for the quarter and $10,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $2,686,000 for the year.

title: SHULTZ ISSUE DOMINATES PEN CONGRESS SESSIONS
description: Some of the world's best-known writers wrestled briefly yesterday with the assigned topic of ''How Does the State Imagine?,'' but both the morning and afternoon sessions of the International PEN Congress were dominated by a dispute over Norman Mailer's decision to invite Secretary of State George P. Shultz to address Sunday's opening ceremony.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:27 A.M. today and set at 7:57 P.M. tonight.

title: MUSIC: CONSORT OF VIOLS
description: There cannot be many more pleasant ways to spend Sunday afternoon in New York City than listening to ''Music Before 1800'' in the resonant and welcoming sanctuary of Corpus Christi Church (529 West 121st Street). The most recent installment in the series featured the New York Consort of Viols in a lovely program of English viol music by John Jenkins, Thomas and Christopher Simpson, Matthew Locke, Purcell, Lawes, John Adson and William Brade.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 14
Dow Up 7 as Volume Shrinks
description: A rally in the final hour helped stock prices rise moderately yesterday, ending a three-day slide brought on by fears that interest rates have stopped falling.

title: A Seat for the Gypsies
description: Although 500,000 gypsies were killed by the Nazis, many of them at Auschwitz, no gypsies are included among the 65 members of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, which is planning a Holocaust museum in Washington. Not surprisingly, representatives of the 250,000 American gypsies have argued for years that the gypsies' story cannot properly be told in the museum unless at least one of their own is on the council.

title: REAGAN OPENS OBSERVANCES LEADING TO DR, KING'S BIRTHDAY
description: President Reagan, who initially opposed having a national holiday on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, today opened a week of observances leading up to that Jan. 20 holiday by linking himself to Dr. King's vision of ''the great promise'' of the United States.

title: NCR Net Rises by 7.4%
description: The NCR Corporation, benefiting from the strong domestic growth of general purpose computers, reported yesterday that net income for its final quarter of 1985 rose 7.4 percent, to $133.2 million, or $1.34 a share, from $124 million, or $1.23 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 11.9 percent, to $1.41 billion, from $1.26 billion.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N V reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NO DRUG SEARCHES AT TWO NEWS UNITS
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc., a publishing and broadcasting conglomerate, yesterday assured its employees that no drug searches or tests were being conducted on company premises and that none would be conducted without consultation between management and employees.

title: Advertising; Senior Officer Named For Waring & LaRosa
description: Allan Baum is coming aboard at Waring & LaRosa, the BBDO International subsidiary, as senior vice president, management supervisor.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC FROM ISRAEL
description: CONTINUUM brought us a report on new music in Israel Saturday night and depressing news it was. These seven pieces - written in a variety of styles, but on a disturbingly low level of inspiration - occupied a long and trying evening at Alice Tully Hall. One waited eagerly and full of hope for something interesting to happen. There were a few stirrings at the very beginning of this concert and some fresh ideas at the end but a lot of mediocrity in between.

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADER CALLS FOR SOUTHERNER ON PARTY'S '88 SLATE
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee said today that it would ''make sense'' for his party to have a Southerner on its 1988 Presidential ticket.

title: A Chance to Relax Israeli-Syrian Tensions
description: Tensions between Syria and Israel - tensions caused primarily by the Syrian ground-to-air missiles deployed on the Syrian-Lebanese border and, intermittently, in Lebanon - have diminished but not disappeared in the last week or so. Syria did move its mobile missiles out of Lebanon, but only under some duress, and diplomatic and military observers expect that it may move them back again soon.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results include a $30,600,000, or 30 cents a share, non- recurring tax credit resulting from legislation which effectively forgave previously deferred income taxes on qualified earnings on DISC.

title: Suffolk Law Restricts U.S. on Shoreham Drill
description: A local law barring Federal and utility officials from holding a planned emergency drill for the Shoreham nuclear power plant without county permission was signed today by the Suffolk County Executive.

title: The Scientific Gag Rule
description: Now comes Dr. Edward Teller, of all people, to argue that there is far too much secrecy surrounding ''Star Wars'' research and more facts should be revealed to the public.

title: Twin Pregnancies
description: The main hazard of multiple births is the increased risk of premature delivery, and it is common practice for physicians to recommend to women carrying twins that they try to avoid premature labor by spending much of the day in bed during the last two or three months of pregnancy. In fact, sometimes hospital bed rest is prescribed.

title: Fear of Heights
description: In 1984, Valerie Brisco-Hooks won three gold medals in the Los Angeles Olympics. Last year, in 100-meter and 200-meter races on the same day, she beat the world's fastest women, both East Germans.

title: Amerikan Broadcasting
description: Even by the lax standards of prime-time television, the premise of ''Amerika,'' a 16-hour mini-series planned for ABC Entertainment, seemed conspicuously feeble. The tale would depict life in the United States a decade after its bloodless capture by Soviet agents. Having now got cold feet about spending $40 million on such nonsense, the network has put off the project, but in ways that imply a bloodless surrender to Soviet pressure. This is dumbness squared.

title: Unix Continues Its Quest for Wide Acceptance
description: LAST year was supposed to be the year of Unix. So was the year before, and the year before that and the year before that. This operating system's search for acceptance in the world of personal computing has seemingly become as endless as the quest for the unicorn.

title: T.W.A. PLANS MORE FLIGHTS
description: Trans World Airlines, which has agonized for years over what to do about its money-losing domestic division, plans to add flights instead of making drastic cuts as recommended by some studies done in the past.

title: A SALUTE TO BUGS BUNNY AND LOONEY TUNES
description: THE hourlong special on CBS at 8 tonight is called ''Bugs Bunny/Looney Tunes All-Star 50th Anniversary,'' but the celebrating actually got under way at a very formal evening last September at New York's Museum of Modern Art. An exhibition was being opened in tribute to the art of animation as evidenced in Warner Brothers' long-running Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies cartoons. Snippets from that gala are included in this television scrapbook but Lorne Michaels, the producer, taking a break from the beleaguered ''Saturday Night Live,'' has chosen to give Bugs and gang a different spin.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SERTVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the 48th International PEN Congress incorrectly identified the position to which Norman Mailer was elected Sunday. He was chosen president of the PEN Congress.

title: Court Orders Halt To Alaska Oil Auction
description: A Federal district judge today ordered a halt to a Federal auction scheduled for Wednesday of oil and gas drilling rights to 5.6 million acres off Alaska. But the judge allowed the Interior Department to accept bids while fighting the decision.

title: Take the Segregation Out of Head Start
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CAMPAIGNING ON CUE'
description: THE title ''Campaigning on Cue: the Presidential Election of 1984'' is a little bit of a misnomer. We're not sure if anyone did campaign on cue, or if the Presidential race, as seen on television, wasn't something that just happened. Nonetheless, the program, the first in a three-part series, does explore some fascinating aspects of election politics. It can be seen on Channel 13 at 11 tonight.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mats Naslund, the Swedish-born forward of the Canadiens, has signed a three-year contract, plus an option year, with Montreal. The 26-year-old Naslund is second in scoring in the National Hockey League, behind Wayne Gretzky, with 28 goals and 44 assists. . . . The heavyweight Mike Tyson (16-0, all by knockout) will fight the ESPN champion, Jesse Ferguson, (14-1 with 10 knockouts), Feb. 16 at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute fieldhouse in Troy, N.Y., in the first of four nationally televised Tyson fights the network will carry under an $850,000 contract signed recently.

title: FARAH IN TALKS ON GOING PRIVATE
description: The Farah Manufacturing Company, the apparel manufacturer based in El Paso, has announced talks about taking the company private.

title: PHOENIX FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. SAYS HALTING OF VESSEL BY IRAN MAY BE JUSTIFIED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that Iran might have been within its rights in forcing an American merchant ship to submit to a search by armed Iranians in international waters near the Persian Gulf on Sunday.

title: Whither Reynolds?
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the combative Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, has decided to leave the Justice Department this year and has begun to consider future employment.

title: Topics; The Buck The Bang Cash and Conscience
description: ''The opportunity of a lifetime.'' That's how Tax Commissioner Roderick Chu describes New York's tax amnesty program, which has brought in more than $50 million since November.

title: MERRILL BANKSHARES CO (BANGOR, ME) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,016,000 related to the proposed purchase of Merrill by Fleet Financial Group.

title: 30 EXPOSED TO CORROSIVE GAS MONITORED FOR URANIUM PERIL
description: Thirty workers who were exposed to a corrosive radioactive gas here will be closely monitored for several weeks to see if they suffer any permanent health effects, according to a nuclear radiation expert who is following their progress.

title: Nova Laser Creates an Artificial 'Star'
description: The world's most powerful laser has created its first ''star'' in an experiment that scientists said was ''another step forward on the mile-long journey toward harnessing fusion energy,'' officials of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory reported today.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA
description: SUNDAY evening's first New York concert of the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall began a half-hour later than the time printed on the tickets - the televising of a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert ended at 7 P.M. and caused the delay - and then, just as Gustav Leonhardt was poised to give the first downbeat, the stage went totally dark.

title: CATHOLIC RELIEF SERVICES LENDS $100,000 TO CHIEF
description: Officials of Catholic Relief Services said yesterday that the agency had granted a $100,000 interest-free loan to its executive director.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Gooden Twists Ankle
description: The Mets got a bit of a shock last night when they learned that Dwight Gooden had twisted his right ankle while working out 10 days ago at his old high school in Tampa, Fla., and had even walked on crutches for a day or two. But the 21-year-old strikeout pitcher assured them by telephone that he felt fine now.

title: Moscow K.O.'s ABC in the First Round
description: Twice in six years, we have sadly witnessed the spectacle of public broadcasting systems coming under pressure to withdraw or modify politically controversial programs. In 1980, the State Department and the Mobil Corporation, a financial backer of the Public Broadcasting System, tried, successfully, to dissuade it from presenting ''Death of a Princess.'' This fictionalized account of the execution of a member of the Saudi Arabian royal family for adultery was said to offend an ally that is a major oil supplier.

title: NEW FORM OF ICE IS INVENTED TO BATTER HULLS OF MODEL SHIPS
description: NOT content with the ordinary ice that blankets their country in winter, Canadian scientists have created two new kinds - one designed to help make ships safer, and the other replicating a strange, extraterrestrial form of water.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEDSIDE MANNERS. The Troubled History of Doctors and Patients. By Edward Shorter. 316 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. ONCE upon a time doctors were hopeless, and everyone knew it. Then, in the 19th century, they learned to understand the nature of disease, and enjoyed a dramatic rise in prestige. But while the new confidence they inspired was itself a valuable therapeutic asset, until some 40 years ago there was a strong element of myth-making, even bluff, in the image of streamlined progress that they projected. Despite a few limited advances, they were still unable to cure most of the illnesses they diagnosed.

title: TREASURY PRICES DROP AGAIN
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell yesterday for the fourth consecutive day. The declines, however, were the smallest since the bond market turned weaker last Wednesday.

title: EXTRANCE EXAMS VOTED BY N.C.A.A.
description: The major athletic colleges, acting over strong objections from predominantly black institutions, today approved the use of entrance examination scores to determine whether or not a college athlete may participate in varsity sports during his freshman year.

title: Japan Trade Shift Urged
description: Senator John C. Danforth said today that Japan should set a goal of doubling its imports of foreign goods in the next three to five years to calm rising protectionist sentiment in other nations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in Sports World Specials yesterday about NBC's pre-game coverage of the Super Bowl on Jan. 26 misspelled the name of a director who will film a segment of the program. He is Bob Giraldi.

title: LOUISIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIBYAN MILITARY TERMED RESTIVE UNDER QADDAFI
description: Growing discontent within the Libyan armed forces has presented Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi with one of the most politically sensitive challenges in his 16-year rule, according to diplomats and Libyan officials.

title: Careers; Corporate Technical Assessment
description: IN this fast-changing world, much corporate strategy depends on keeping up with technology. As a result, an old function has gained new importance and a new title: director of technology assessment.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Nigeria Chooses Pain and Pride
description: Nigeria's military strongman, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, now shows himself to be a bold economic warrior. Fresh from squelching a coup attempt, he has decreed a tough austerity that could finally begin to repair Nigeria's ailing economy. At the same time he has challenged Nigeria's creditors by breaking off talks with the International Monetary Fund and says he'll cap interest payments at 30 percent of export revenues.

title: BOB KAUFMAN
description: Bob Kaufman, a Beat poet who was one of the founders of Beatitude magazine, died of emphysema Sunday at the Lady of Perpetual Help Residential Care here.

title: Chubb Buys Reinsurance
description: The Chubb Corporation, a major property and casualty insurance company, announced yesterday that it had purchased medical malpractice reinsurance from a British insurer for $173.5 million that would have the effect of reducing its net operating income for the fourth quarter of 1985 by $2.97 a share.

title: State Department; A Flag Day On Afghanistan
description: State Department officials are disinclined to boast about it, and in some quarters are even disavowing any part in it, but last Tuesday an American operative, unimpeded by diplomatic protocol and legal precedent, took decisive action.

title: TRANSPORTATION DEPT. TO BROADEN INSPECTIONS OF AIRLINES AS RESULT OF GANDER CRASH
description: The Department of Transportation said yesterday it would broaden its airline inspection program, giving priority to carriers with contracts to carry military personnel. Department officials said the program would be announced today.

title: GORDIMER ON ART AND APARTHEID
description: ''A writer is 'selected' by his subject,'' Nadine Gordimer wrote once, ''his subject being the consciousness of his own era.'' In her case, the time is the late 20th century, the place South Africa, and in eight novels and nine collections of short stories she has mapped out the social, political and emotional geography of that troubled land with extraordinary passion and precision. Yesterday she was in New York to deliver one of the opening speeches at the 48th International PEN Congress, speaking on the anomalous relationship between the writer and the state.

title: LAP MODEL BY I.B.M. EXPECTED
description: Reports abounded throughout the computer industry yesterday that I.B.M. was preparing to introduce its long-delayed lap-top portable computer, perhaps as soon as next week.

title: Chrysler Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had increased its five-year capital spending program by $1 billion. Gerald Greenwald, chairman of Chrysler Motors, a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, said in remarks to the Detroit Economic Club that the nation's third-largest auto maker would spend $12.5 billion for modernization and new products in the next five years, a company record and double what Chrysler has spent in the last five years.

title: 3 BANKS IN CITY REPORT 4TH-QUARTER INCOME RISE
description: Helped by lower interest rates and a further push into investment banking, three large New York City banks yesterday reported higher fourth-quarter earnings.

title: ECUADOR PRESIDENT SAYS GAINS MERIT FRESH HELP
description: President Leon Febres-Cordero of Ecuador said today that his country's economy was growing again, thanks to a shift to market-oriented policies that could make Ecuador the first to benefit from a new United States strategy for dealing with the global debt crisis.

title: Pasta Diet Wins Refugee A Place in Flight School
description: A 24-year-old Vietnamese refugee who went on a pasta-rich diet and did special exercises has added enough flesh to his buttocks to meet measurement standards for flight training, Navy officials said today.

title: CARRIAGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: Highway Death Rate Has Been Declining Since 1925
description: To the Editor:

title: CBC CALLS FOR END OF MOST U.S. PROGRAMS ON ITS TV BY 1987
description: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation has proposed removing virtually all United States commercial programs from its television network by the 1987 season, to give what it calls ''equal time for Canada.''

title: COLLEAGUES DESCRIBE MANES AS A SKILLED POLITICIAN
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens is a popular politician and a strong leader, yet one who is willing to listen to those he leads, friends and associates said yesterday.

title: Nigerian Sets a Deadline For Relinquishing Power
description: The military leader, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, today set a target of Oct. 1, 1990, for his Government to hand over power and said he would leave it up to the Nigerian public to determine the form of the next government.

title: CONIFER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures include the results of Plymouth-Home National Bank since June 30, 1984.

title: Daffy Dan's Plans Store
description: Daffy Dan's, an apparel retailer based in New Jersey, plans to take over the vacant Harry Rothman store site in Manhattan, becoming the first major discounter of women's clothing to open on lower Fifth Avenue. The new 36,000-square-foot store on 19th Street and Fifth Avenue is expected to open late this summer or early fall.

title: MAN WHO WAS WRONGLY JAILED IN SLAYING IS AWARDED $750,000
description: A court awarded $750,000 in damages yesterday to a 74-year-old man who was wrongfully convicted of killing a man in a Manhattan speak-easy 53 years ago.

title: WHEN CLASSES FOR GIFTED SWELL WITH UNGIFTED
description: Kathy Moravick, a fifth-grade honors math teacher, has gifted pupils still stuck on fourth-grade math. She spends lunch hour doing remedial tutoring for the gifted. Recently a dozen of them were slow in catching on to least common denominators.

title: Two Presidents of Units Of HNG/Internorth Quit
description: Aftershocks from last year's merger of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Internorth Inc. reverberated through the executive suite yesterday, when the presidents of two of HNG/Internorth's largest subsidiaries announced they were stepping down.

title: FEW OF 1,500 STRIKERS ANSWER HORMEL'S CALL TO RETURN TO WORK
description: Only a handful of 1,500 striking workers responded today to a call to return to work at Geo. A. Hormel & Company, but the meatpacker said it would have no trouble hiring replacements.

title: TURNOVERS COST SHULA SLEEP AS WELL AS GAME
description: Don Shula was alone in his office, his renowned jutting chin below lips that were turned down. It wasn't only the obvious distress that his Dolphins had lost the American Conference championship on Sunday to the Patriots. His team had made mistakes. Because they created six turnovers - while forcing only one from New England - in the 31-14 defeat, Shula was seething. He was also thinking about next season.

title: Recognized Now
description: How does a freshman at a small Middle Western bible college without affiliation with the N.C.A.A. or the N.A.I.A. gain a spot on an all-America football team? Without the aid of drum-beating from his college, it takes raw talent.

title: Union Pacific Deal
description: The Union Pacific Corporation and the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad announced that they had terminated a merger agreement for a Union Pacific subsidiary, the Missouri Pacific Railroad, to acquire M.K.T. for about $110 million in cash and securities.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: JANUARY is rather a schizophrenic time in the fashion world.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. This is the third game in New Jersey for the two teams, with Philadelphia having won by 106-102 on Nov. 1 and the Nets winning, 111-100, the day before Thanksgiving. The teams play for the first time in Philadelphia tomorrow night. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) College: Manhattanville at Lehman, 7:30 P.M.; Stevens Tech at York, 7:30 P.M.; Providence at Pittsburgh, 8 P.M.; North Carolina at Maryland (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Canucks, at Vancouver, British Columbia, 10:35 P.M. This is the first meeting this season between the teams and the only meeting scheduled for Vancouver. Last season, the Rangers split the two games played in Vancouver, losing by 4-1 and winning, 6-3, and won the only game played in Madison Square Garden, 6-0. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 10:30 P.M.) Devils vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. The Devils shocked the Flyers, 6-5, in the season opener on Oct. 10 for only their second victory in the franchise history at the Spectrum. They played two games in three days in December, with the Devils winning at home on the 17th and losing in Philadelphia on the 19th. In their most recent meeting, Saturday at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Flyers won easily, 8-4. (Television, MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Tennis Nabisco Masters, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Burlington To Sell Unit
description: Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textile company, will sell its Domestics division to J. P. Stevens & Company for an undisclosed amount.

title: World's Fastest Transistor
description: Researchers at the University of Rochester have reported measuring the world's fastest transistor using a special optical technique that tests electronic responses.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share results reflect a 2-for-1 split in December 1985.

title: BENDING THE RULES FOR STUDENT ATHLETES
description: In testimony in a Federal courtroom here, a group of current and former instructors charged last week that administrators at the University of Georgia had changed grades and bent the rules so student athletes in remedial academic courses could remain eligible to compete.

title: Vietnam to Investigate 95 Reports on P.O.W.'s
description: Vietnam has agreed to investigate 95 United States reports that some Americans are still being held prisoner in Indochina, senior Administration officials said today.

title: VIDEO CASSETTES BRING HISTORY TO LIFE
description: IS history moving so fast that students cannot keep up with the recent past? Are the schools leaving a void in young people's minds about anything that happened before today's headlines or newscasts? Surveys show that young Americans know little about their country's recent past - events of the 20th century that shaped the world in which they live.

title: TECHNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tin Decision Is Delayed
description: The London Metal Exchange has deferred a decision on the future of its tin contracts and will meet again on Jan. 20, the exchange's chief executive, Michael Brown, said today.

title: A Bridge Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Systems, Psychology and Chemical Spills
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American PD Co., which distributes Porsche design products in the United States, has named Samuel J. Tucker chairman, replacing Hans-Peter Porsche, who resigned. James G. Ellis was appointed president.

title: China Studies Investor Plan
description: A draft law intended to encourage foreign investment in China was considered today by the National People's Congress, the official New China News Agency said.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid on Dec. 30, 1985.

title: DECEIT FOUND PERVASIVE IN THE NATURAL WORLD
description: IN the rain forests of Peru, a scientist has caught two species of birds in the avian equivalent of crying wolf. The birds, sentinels whose job is to warn their flocks when a predator is lurking, often sound false alarms to divert their competitors as the sentinels swoop toward a tasty bug.

title: FOUR DESIGNERS PREDICT THE SHAPE OF FALL TO COME
description: For fashion designers on Seventh Avenue, the fall collection has the longest lead time of the year. Spring clothes are introduced in November, after which designers frequently take long holiday vacations to rest and get the creative juices flowing. They arrive back in their studios in January with almost four months to develop the fall styles that will be presented at the end of April and the first of May.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1985 net income reflects the full year's impact of the acquisitions of Nederlandse Credietbank N.V. and Lincoln First Banks N.A., while 1984 included the impact after the mid- year consolidations of the two entities. Accordingly, net income for the first half of 1985 was favorably impacted by about $22 million from those acquisitions.

title: MORGAN, J P & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Cabdriver Is Found Slain In His Taxi in Starrett City
description: A taxi driver was found shot to death in his medallion cab last night at a street corner in Starrett City in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: British Political Furor On Copters Heats Up
description: A furor erupted today in Parliament in the controversy over the future of Westland, Britain's only helicopter manufacturer.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $38,413,000 on the sale of Alliance Mortgage Co.

title: Chess: After Setback, Korchnoi Hit Excellent form at Lucerne
description: Viktor Korchnoi peaked at the wrong moment.

title: HIGHWAY DEATH RATE HAS BEEN DECLINING SINCE 1925
description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY HIRSCH
description: Henry Hirsch, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in restaurant law, died yesterday at New York Hospital.

title: Syracuse Player Leaves
description: Michael Brown, a sophomore guard who started in every game during his freshman year at Syracuse University, has left the team, Brown, who had lost his starting job to Howard Triche, a senior, was averaging 7.7 points a game. He was not immediately available for comment.

title: CHRISTIAN MILITIAS' RIVALRY ERUPTS INTO BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: Heavy fighting raged around the capital today between Christian militiamen loyal to President Amin Gemayel and rival Christian forces.

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Donation for the Homeless
description: On the night before Christmas, a well-meaning gesture ran afoul of holiday schedules, and 200 beds for the homeless went undelivered.

title: Alex. Brown Plan
description: Alex. Brown & Sons, the nation's oldest investment banking firm, is reportedly planning to go public.

title: UNITED ENERGY TECHNOLOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MANY COMPANIES MATCH GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Many employers and their workers, concerned by the evidence of poverty around them, cooperate in efforts to aid the poor by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Why Should School Buses Have Standees?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Limits Expansion Of Bell Telephone Units
description: Accusing the seven regional Bell telephone companies of ''conglomerate ambitions'' and ''lack of interest'' in providing reasonably priced local service, a United States District Court judge today restricted the companies' ability to expand rapidly.

title: Chain Had 1842 Start
description: It was just a country store in Indiana that sold itself into the hearts of shoppers and became a merchandising legend.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share and shares outstanding figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 common stock split.

title: O, Say Can You See Your Bank?
description: Americans love to criticize the Federal bureaucracy for wasteful spending. But there are a few generous souls who think the Government is doing just fine, and they show their appreciation by sending in cash contributions every year to various Federal funds to help things along.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After idle plant costs of $400,000 for the quarter and year. c-After idle plant costs of $150,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net loss.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our towns must not zone out decent affordable housing. On the other hand, let us make it clear that we will not allow the rights of our towns and elected officials to be trampled by a combination of profit-minded builders and an over-active judiciary.''

title: Benson Out of Hospital
description: The president of the Mormon Church, Ezra Taft Benson, was released from a hospital today. A spokesman said his doctors believed that a weekend fainting spell suffered by Mr. Benson, 86 years old, was caused by standing up too quickly to answer the telephone.

title: RETENTION OF LOWER AUTO FUEL LIMIT PREDICTED
description: The Department of Transportation, perhaps this week, will propose retaining lower fuel economy standards for automobiles for two more years, according to sources in the department and the automobile industry.

title: COURT REJECTS AN APPEAL BY MANDELA
description: The South African Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by Winnie Mandela of a Government order forbidding her to live at her home in Soweto, Johannesburg's sprawling black satellite city.

title: SOVIET EXPANDS SURVEILLANCE OFF LIBYA, WEINBERGER SAYS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger asserted today that in the tense period after terrorist attacks in Vienna and Rome, the Soviet Union increased its surveillance of United States Navy movements and is believed to have shared its findings with Libya.

title: Hearing on Packers
description: The United States Supreme Court cleared the way for a public hearing on charges that two Green Bay Packers players sexually assaulted a dancer at a Milwaukee nightclub.

title: CIRCADIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $213,000 for the quarter and $322,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $94,000 for the quarter and $132,000 for the 6 months.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON LAWS FAVORING THE PREGNANT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may require employers to give pregnant employees better disability leave and other benefits than are required for other workers.

title: Airport Landing Rights Aren't Private Property
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.8 million for the quarter and the year from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. distribution. c-Including an extraordinary net gain of $545,000.

title: OFFICER TELLS OF SHOOTING HONORS STUDENT TO DEATH
description: The plainclothes police officer who shot a 17-year-old Harlem honors student to death in Morningside Heights last June testified yesterday that he had fired because he had feared for his life.

title: Tutu Points to Inconsistency In U.S. Policies on Sanctions
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu today criticized the Reagan Administration for being ''coy to taking actions against South Africa'' while imposing sanctions against Libya at the ''drop of a hat because of terrorism.''

title: Advertising; Gray & Co. Adds Tromson
description: Tromson Monroe Advertising/Public Relations, which specializes in the travel field and bills about $17 million, has been acquired by Gray & Company Public Communications International, a publicly held, Washington-based organization.

title: THE ROAD TO BROADWAY NOW BEGINS IN SUN BELT
description: The Broadway tryout, once a tradition in the Northeast, is moving to the Sun Belt. Cities such as Dallas and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., are supplanting New Haven and Boston, and one of the key producers is a company that also promotes tractor pulls and the ''Destruction Derby.''

title: Victory for Yukica
description: Coach Joe Yukica and Dartmouth reached a settlement allowing Yukica to coach the school's football team through the 1986 season and then retire.

title: BONNER HAS HER BYPASS SURGERY
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident, underwent open-heart surgery today, and doctors said later that she was in satisfactory condition.

title: Topics; The Buck The Bang Chemical Warfare
description: The same skills that make sea lions enchanting entertainers in captivity make them expert fishermen in nature. Humans, however, are not always amused, and some are finding odd ways to curb their appetites.

title: COURT TO REVIEW CONNECTICUT'S OPEN-PRIMARY BAN
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Connecticut had violated the Constitution in barring the state Republican Party from opening to all voters its primary elections for Congress and statewide offices.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE KINGS, 115-97
description: After losing five of their last six games, the Knicks saved themselves from dropping farther by trouncing the Sacramento Kings last night at Madison Square Garden by 115-97.

title: MGM/UA BID ALTERED BY TURNER
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said yesterday that it was renegotiating its $1.4 billion deal to buy the MGM/UA Entertainment Company for the second time.

title: MARCEL ARLAND
description: Marcel Arland, a novelist and essayist who was a member of the Academie Francaise, died of a heart attack Sunday at his country home, French radio reported.

title: Gracias
description: A loan four years ago to an endangered Guatemalan politician has paid a dividend for Laurence R. Birns, a well-known figure among followers of Latin-American issues in Washington. Mr. Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, flew to Guatemala yesterday to attend that country's Presidential inauguration today at the personal invitation of the President-elect, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo.

title: TIP OF THE MIKE TO BROADCASTING'S BEST
description: Now that the American and National Football Conferences have selected the Super Bowl teams and the Pro Bowl players, it's time to announce the all-star broadcast team. This dream team has five spots: three for studio and/or pre-game shows and two for game work. Those eligible are the people who appeared on the three networks during the 1985-86 football season.

title: CONFEREES SEE PERIL IN GOALS OF GROUPS ON RELIGIOUS RIGHT
description: The religious new right poses an increasing threat to women's rights and freedom of religion in the United States, speakers at a conference on the effects of religious fundamentalism said yesterday.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Davis Returns
description: The guard Walter Davis returned to the Phoenix Suns yesterday after a 30-day stay in a California rehabilitation clinic. He later scored 11 points in a 121-98 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $81,000 for the quarter and $126,000 for 9 months.

title: FARM BELT SUICIDES REFLECT GREATER HARDSHIP AND DEEPENING DESPONDENCY
description: Mike Hrabe, a Kansas wheat grower, says he understands why others across the Farm Belt have been driven to suicide. The 41-year-old farmer had already written a note telling a neighbor where to find his body when the sight of his son's baseball uniform, laid out for a Little League game, stayed his hand.

title: TRIBECA BUILDING BEGUN WITH HELP FROM THE CITY
description: With the encouragement of liberalized zoning and tax benefits, a full block in Manhattan's TriBeCa section is being developed with a 14-story high-tech office building that will offer big space users floors of up to 46,000 square feet.

title: Talking Business with Dahl of Morgan Stanley; Doubts on Sale Of U.S. Loans
description: As the Reagan Administration casts around for ways to come up with a 1987 budget to achieve the savings required by the new budget-balancing law, it is weighing the sale of portions of the Government's $245 billion loan portfolio.

title: LOSS BY DOLPHINS CHANGES ATTITUDE
description: They made no secret of the fact that they wanted the Miami Dolphins. Why not? The Dolphins had messed up their perfect season, beating them, 38-24, before a Monday night national television audience and nearly 80,000 more in the steamy Orange Bowl.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Patriots Greeted Wildly
description: A mob of frenzied Patriots fans broke through crowd-control ropes at Green Airport early this morning to greet their heroes.

title: More Disclosure Urged For Insurers of Bonds
description: Many companies that insure and guarantee tax-exempt bonds and other securities could be required to make new financial disclosures under an accounting bulletin issued recently by the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: State Chooses Merrill Lynch
description: New York State's spring borrowing - traditionally the largest tax-exempt financing of the year by any state or local government - will be underwritten through securities dealers led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, state officials announced yesterday.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MEDICAL DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
JAPAN AND SOVIET TESTING THE WATERS
description: For the first time in years, Japan sees reason to hope for better relations with the Soviet Union, the country most Japanese say they trust least and fear most.

title: Wisconsin Sheriff Held Liable In Police Terrorist Exercise
description: A county sheriff recklessly violated the constitutional rights of five people who were taken hostage in a police terrorist exercise, a jury has ruled.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE AND ROBBINS
description: THERE was some fine dancing on view Saturday afternoon when the New York City Ballet presented three works from its repertory at the New York State Theater.

title: MUSIC: 'FAUSTUS,' NEW OPERA AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: THE development of new works in English for operatic voices is an end so desirable that efforts directed toward it rightly enjoy a high degree of presumptive support. The Center for Contemporary Opera, which took the unusual step of presenting an ambitious work by an unknown composer in a full semi-staged performance Friday at Symphony Space, is doing something that must be done, and deserves praise for the professionalism and care of its efforts.

title: Service for Audrey Wood
description: A memorial service for Audrey Wood, a theatrical agent who represented many of America's leading playwrights, will be held tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. at the Shubert Theater. She died Dec. 27. Among the many playwrights she represented who are scheduled to speak are Robert Anderson, Arthur Kopit and Murray Schisgal.

title: CHURCHES SUE U.S., ALLEGING ILLEGAL ACTS IN INQUIRY ON ALIENS
description: Two major religious denominations and four Arizona congregations sued the Government today, asserting that it had unjustifiably intruded on their services in its search for illegal aliens and those who help them.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WITNESS DESCRIBES AID TO GAMBINO CAR-THEFT RING BY OFFICERS
description: A prosecution witness yesterday implicated eight of the nine defendants charged with running a car-theft ring operated by the Gambino crime family and described the role of two New York City police officers in aiding the ring.

title: Market Place; Capital Goods Issues Favored
description: CONSUMER stocks have provided the leadership ever since the bull market began in the summer of 1982. But there are signs now that the long-depressed production sector of the economy is about to stage a recovery and, in the process, brighten the outlook for this stock group.

title: Into the Future, on Automatic Pilot
description: America is about to get its first taste of balancing the budget by machine. The immediate cutbacks will be nothing compared to the prospect for future years, starting in October. But the arbitrary trimming about to occur should serve fair public warning. Defense and non-defense programs will be severely damaged unless President Reagan and Congress turn off the automatic pilot and find a plan for deficit control that is run by leaders instead of robots.

title: EX-OFFICER SAYS SERGEANT DRANK, THEN DROVE CAR IN HIT-RUN DEATH
description: A former New York City police officer testified yesterday that the police sergeant accused in the hit-and-run death of a Manhattan man last March had been drinking on duty the night of the accident and that the sergeant was driving the patrol car when the accident occurred.

title: Beech Layoffs
description: About 300 workers of the Beech Aircraft Corporation in Wichita and Salina, Kan., or 9.4 percent, will be laid off during the next three months, a company spokesman said. The action reflects the impact of continuing softness in the general aviation market and the transition from development to production of the Starship I, Beech's new-generation composite turboprop, John Gedraitis, a spokesman, said.

title: CITY BEGINS STEPPED-UP CAMPAIGN TO COLLECT DEBTS OWED BY ITS EMPLOYEES
description: The Koch administration announced a new, more agressive program yesterday to collect millions of dollars in parking fines, income taxes and welfare overpayments owed by city employees.

title: Dollar Edges Upward In Nervous Trading
description: The dollar bounced up and down in nervous trading yesterday before ending the day a bit firmer.

title: TINY TRACES OF SUSPECT CHEMICAL FOUND IN APPLE JUICE AND SAUCE
description: Trace amounts of a widely used farm chemical that some tests have shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals have been detected in apple juice and applesauce sold in supermarkets.

title: WITH 2,490 TABLES IN PLAY, TRI-STATE NEARED A RECORD
description: The Tri-State Regional Championships, which ended Sunday night at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y., was one of the biggest regionals ever staged in the Northeast. In five days, 2,490 tables were in play, just short of the tournament record.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: CAREMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results restated to conform to current presentation.

title: KEAN TO PROPOSE THAT JERSEY ADD NO. 2 STATE POST
description: Governor Kean will call for the creation of the office of lieutenant governor and for other electoral changes when he delivers his State of the State Message Tuesday at the opening of the 202d New Jersey Legislature.

title: MANES SAYS 2 MEN SEIZED HIM IN CAR
description: Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, told investigators yesterday that he was abducted last Thursday by two men he could not identify and forced to drive his car around Queens for an unspecified period of time.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MORE FRUSTRATIONS FOR COLUMBIA'S CREW AS COMET PHOTO SESSION IS MARRED
description: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia, frustrated so often on the ground as they repeatedly tried to begin the current mission, found frustration in orbit today, too, when an instrument for viewing Halley's comet failed to work properly.

title: U.S. and Soviet Resume Chemical Weapons Talks
description: American and Soviet negotiators today held their first meeting in Geneva on a proposed chemical weapons ban since President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, agreed at their summit meeting in November to ''accelerate'' talks on the issue.

title: Teamster Chief Won't Have to Testify
description: Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, will not be compelled to testify at the Federal trial of five men accused of skimming untaxed gambling profits from Nevada casinos, under an agreement reached today.

title: Gemayel and Assad Meet
description: Presidents Gemayel and Assad conferred for seven hours today on the Syrian-brokered peace plan.

title: ALBERT A. TERRIEGO
description: Albert A. Terriego, an international vice president and director of the railroad division of the Transport Workers Union, died Sunday at Bay Shore Community Hospital in Hazlet, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Hazlet.

title: GULF FISHERMAN FEAR FOR THE REDFISH
description: The soaring popularity of blackened redfish, that spicy, Louisiana-born dish that has become the hit of fashionable restaurant menus from New York City to California, has stirred a growing debate around the Gulf of Mexico.

title: OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,877,000, or 12 cents a share, from overfunded pension plans for the quarter and year. c-Includes a gain of $1.5 million, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and year for attorneys fees awarded in connection with an antitrust suit against the company's licensor, Sealy Inc. and a gain for the year from discontinued operations of $2.1 million, or 14 cents a share.

title: Prison Riot Is Termed Racially Motivated
description: An uprising at the Indiana Reformatory last weekend in which one inmate died and two dozen people were injured was triggered by racial unrest, Cloid Shuler, a Department of Correction official, said today.

title: CITY OPERA OFFICIAL QUITS
description: Christopher Keene, music director of the New York City Opera since 1983, will resign as of Jan. 1, 1987, the company said yesterday. Beverly Sills, general director of the company, said she hoped to name a successor by the middle of February.

title: BRITISH OWNER IS PLANNING TO SELL GIMBEL CHAIN AND OTHERS IN U.S.
description: The 36 Gimbel stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee will be sold by B.A.T Industries, the British company that bought them from the Gimbel family in 1973.

title: PENNZOIL, TEXACO STOCKS FALL
description: The Pennzoil Company's shares fell $2 today in the first day of trading after the company's courtroom setback in its battle with Texaco Inc., while Texaco's stock dropped 50 cents in heavy trading.

title: UNITING TO CREATE PRODUCTS
description: American companies, facing stiff competition from abroad and relaxed antitrust regulations at home, are banding together to cooperate in research and development at an unprecedented rate, according to corporate and Government officials.

title: THE DANCE: SPANISH PROGRAM
description: CASTANETS chattered and feet rapped out their beat in ''IEspana!,'' a program presented by the Spanish Dance Theater on Saturday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. But this was an unusual evening of Spanish dancing, filled with dramatic vignettes as well as strong performing.

title: Delay Cited in Leak At Oklahoma Plant
description: Workers at a uranium-processing plant waited four hours before trying to drain excess fluid from a tank that later ruptured, releasing a toxic acid that killed one worker and sent 100 people to hospitals, investigators said today.

title: LONG-SILENT PARAGUAY ASTIR WITH A SCANDAL AND DISSENT
description: For the first time since Gen. Alfredo Stroessner seized power here 32 years ago, Paraguay's traditional political silence has suddenly been disrupted by debate, controversy, scandal and even protests.

title: IVB FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $459,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $167,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
description: International Iran intercepted a U.S. freighter in international waters near the Persian Gulf, White House and State Department spokesmen announced, saying that it was a ''matter of serious concern.'' The American freighter, the President Taylor, was stopped by Iranians who boarded from an Iranian Navy ship and searched the American vessel for more than an hour. The freighter then went on to Fujaira, a port in the United Arab Emirates. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MAYFAIR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect earnings for the company's Class A stock and a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: THEY'LL CARVE OUT A WHITE HOMELAND
description: There will, first of all, be the grain silos, standing over the fields of corn stubble. Then there will be a church, and, by the town for whites, a township for blacks, some way off, marked at dusk by the smudge of smog from fires of cheap coal.

title: Advertising; Image Ad Approach For Boats
description: C. GORDON HOUSER is one of the people in town for the New York National Boat Show that opened last week at the New York Coliseum. People who know him expect him to be there because boating, especially the advertising side of it, is his business and has been for quite a while.

title: Spouse as Sponsor
description: Judge Emily J. Goodman of Civil Court in Manhattan will make an unusual appearance this morning at the United States Court House on Foley Square.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Politics; From Money Magic to Money Misery
description: Ronald Reagan's political success seems to have been something of a financial disaster for Richard A. Viguerie, the direct-mail tactician who raised hundreds of millions of dollars in the 1970's for causes and candidates of the political right and, as a result, became a force in American politics.

title: Advertising; Procter & Gamble Rides Space Shuttle
description: The packages aboard the space shuttle Columbia include one from our old friends at Procter & Gamble.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jerry Sherman has been promoted to president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves's sales promotion and collateral division.

title: RAI RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $7,421 for the quarter and after a loss of $64,638 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,135 and $41,912, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and including a gain of $267,000 for 6 months from a tax reversal of defererd income taxes related to accumulated earnings of the company's DISC subsidiary.

title: Question of Perspective
description: The bulk in the Police Department may soon disappear.

title: BECKER PAYS THE PRICE, GLADLY
description: Boris Becker is learning that sometimes the best place to hide is in a crowded room. That is the paradox of New York City, and the appeal it holds for the West German teen-ager who generates nationwide news coverage at home just about every time he ventures outdoors. ''Becker goes to the movies; film at 11,'' is a news report that will keep many adoring West Germans glued to their television sets.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $121,000 for the quarter and $994,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $1,119,000 from the sale of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net losses include gains from discontinued operations of $499,000 for the quarter and $1,012,000 for the 9 months.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST : TUESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1986
description: Companies

title: A Dispute At Nomura
description: A push to expand its operations in the United States has apparently created strains between the Nomura Securities Company and some of its American employees, according to sources close to the situation.

title: U.N. Halts Broadcasts On Shortwave Band
description: The United Nations radio service has halted its shortwave broadcasts because it cannot afford a 600 percent increase in transmitting fees charged by the Voice of America.

title: GUATEMALA'S NEXT LEADER ALREADY FACES DEMANDS
description: Before he even takes the oath of office on Tuesday, Guatemala's new civilian leader is facing angry demands.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains from the sale of property of $1.9 million, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $24 million, or $1.94 a share, for the year. c-Including a gain of $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share, for the year from the sale of properties.

title: BEARS SHUFFLING TO A SHUTOUT?
description: Three days before Super Bowl III, Joe Namath ''guaranteed'' the Jets would win. But eight weeks before Super Bowl XX, several members of the Chicago Bears virtually predicted they would be in New Orleans a week from Sunday by recording a videotape titled ''The Super Bowl Shuffle.'' And now they will be.

title: LARGER MEMORIES ARE NO LONGER A LUXURY
description: SOFTWARE is getting more complex and powerful, and computer owners are demanding more memory to harness it effectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Advertising; William Esty Sets Campaign for Nissan
description: To the creative team at the William Esty Company that worked on the advertising for the introduction of the new 1986.5 Nissan truck, the vehicle looked as if ''it had just worked out.'' And that is why we are blessed with a ''Hardbodies'' campaign that will burst upon the scene, first tomorrow as full-page spreads in major daily newspapers and then burgeon into a multi- (but unspecific) million-dollar explosion of advertising.

title: Mr. President, Save the Farms
description: Dear President Reagan, I write to ask you to take urgent action to prevent an economic disaster. The rapidly growing number of bankruptcies, foreclosures and sheriff's sales of farms and rural businesses is changing the face of this nation.

title: Works by Friedman At Vineyard Theater
description: Gary William Friedman is a composer whose best-known piece, even if he himself is not well known for it, is the theme song for Spiderman cartoons. He also writes chamber music and vocal/theatrical works of various dimensions, and an engaging program of them was presented Saturday night by the Vineyard Theater (309 East 26th Street), where it will be repeated next Saturday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Dec. 29 about an exhibition at the United Nations on the Auschwitz concentration camp misstated the closing date for the display. It can be seen through Jan. 31.

title: SOUTHERN YEMEN SAYS A COUP ATTEMPT FAILED
description: The President of Marxist-ruled Southern Yemen has survived an attempt to overthrow and assassinate him, and leaders of the uprising have been executed, the state-run Aden radio reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 14, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Horford to Kentucky?
description: Tito Horford, the 7-footer from the Dominican Republic, plans to enroll Thursday at the University of Kentucky, according to a report by a Houston television station. KTRK-TV, quoting Horford's attorney, Pat Ellis, said he would enroll at Kentucky in hopes of regaining his basketball eligibility by next spring.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a special net charge of $1,900,000 related to the phaseout of keyboard design and production activities at the company's Waukegan, Ill. plant. c-Net income.

title: Upper East Side Hubbub
description: More boldly than any Hollywood setting, the backdrop illustrated the problems.

title: An Arab Paper Reports Abu Nidal Visited U.S.
description: A newspaper said today that it had interviewed Abu Nidal, the Palestinian linked to the Rome and Vienna airport attacks, and that he had undergone plastic surgery and has visited into the United States on a false passport.

title: GOTTI IS ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
description: John Gotti - who law-enforcement authorities say is the new boss of the Gambino organized-crime family -and six other men were ordered yesterday to stand trial April 7 on Federal racketeering charges in Brooklyn.

title: HIGH COURT TO GET A CASE ON WHALING
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Government's appeal of a court order that it restrict Japanese fishing rights in American waters because of Japan's whaling activities.

title: Court to Review Rules on Merger Suits
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the legal standards for allowing competitors of merging companies to challenge the mergers in private antitrust suits.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOGETHERNESS Activities in New York, even competing ones, tend to group together. Fifth Avenue museums and similar institutions have organized themselves into a ''Museum Mile.'' Now, six more institutions on the East Side are announcing themselves as a bloc entry, ''The World in Five Blocks,'' an assertion that has more truth than hyperbole for the square bounded by 65th and 70th Streets and Lexington and Fifth Avenues.

title: BERRY'S TEAM AT HOME ON ROAD
description: Finally, the Patriots can do their laundry at home.

title: Bailey Is Best, Wagner Falters
description: Terrance Bailey, a 6-foot-2-inch point guard at Wagner, is scoring more but enjoying it less this season. The junior from Trenton, whose main responsibility under Coach Neil Kennett was supposed to be feeding passes to his teammates, is the leading scorer in N.C.A.A. Division I with a 27.8-point average.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ISRAEL CONDITIONALLY AGREES TO BORDER ARBITRATION
description: Israel agreed conditionally overnight to submit a long-festering border dispute with Egypt to international arbitration, and today rival Labor and Likud ministers each claimed a political victory in the Cabinet's decision.

title: DROP IN COMPUTER STUDY SEEN
description: Fewer college freshmen are planning careers in computers or engineering now than a year ago, and the total who consider it very important to make a lot of money decreased for the first time in 15 years, according to a new study.

title: Disney Declares A Stock Split
description: Walt Disney Productions declared a 4-for-1 split of its common stock, the first major split in 13 years, as well as an increase in its quarterly cash dividend. The split will increase Disney's common shares outstanding to about 129.5 million shares, from about 32.4 million shares outstanding as of today.

title: ROONEY PACE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-After a loss of $1,444,000 for the quarter and 6 months from investment in the Norlin Corp., a tax credit of $371,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $5,469,000 for the 6 months from debt restructuring. c-After a loss of $2,731,000 for the quarter and 6 months from investment in the Norlin Corp. and including a tax credit of $2,677,000 for the quarter. Results for the latest quarter also reflect a loss of $2,165,000 related to liquidation of securities positions compared to a trading profit of $2,324,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Telenova Official Fills 2 Top Posts at Ericsson
description: Ericsson Inc., the American subsidiary of L.M. Ericsson of Sweden, yesterday named a new president and chief executive. He is M. Peter Thomas, president and chief operating officer of Telenova, a small Silicon Valley manufacturer of voice/ data office controllers.

title: THE DANCE: CREACH AND KOESTER
description: TERRY CREACH and Stephen Koester swept like an invigorating breeze through the Field, a new performing space at the Pineapple Dance Center, on Sunday night. The two men presented a program of good dancing and interesting choreography that were devoid of sentimental message-making. Choreographers have recently begun to explore same-sex partnering. The implications - in terms of movement quality and social custom - are considerable. Mr. Creach and Mr. Koester explore those implications, but they do so without a bit of irony or self-indulgence.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 6, ''Tightening Nuclear Liability'' by Kathleen Welch, incorrectly stated the U.S. Public Interest Research group's position on the Price-Anderson Act. It supports repeal of only that part of the law that limits the nuclear industry's liability for damages resulting from accidents.

title: What Due Process Meant to Potter Stewart
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO NAMES PANEL TO STUDY INSURANCE RISES
description: A commission to investigate ''sudden and dramatic increases'' in the cost of liability insurance was appointed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: RAIDING OF THE RATE SWAPPERS
description: There is no plaque on the door denoting it as such, but Citibank has become the leading academy for training bankers in the arcane art of interest rate swaps, one of the most sophisticated and hottest areas in finance today.

title: SOUTH POLE EXPEDITION LOSES SHIP TO PACK ICE
description: A GROUP of amateur British explorers, rescued by United States helicopters after their ship was crushed by pack ice, gathered at McMurdo Station yesterday for evacuation from Antarctica.

title: AIDS IN THE FUTURE: EXPERTS SAY DEATHS WILL CLIMB SHARPLY
description: The AIDS epidemic is not expected to spread rapidly into the general population, Government and academic experts now believe, but the disease will probably kill far more Americans than is generally recognized.

title: E.E.C. Maps Curbs on U.S.
description: The European Economic Community is considering a plan for quotas on United States exports of fertilizer and paper and cardboard products in retaliation for American restrictions on imports of European semifinished steel products, community diplomats said.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Home Loan Banks Set 4 Bond Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks' office of finance said it would announce interest rates today on four new bond issues totaling $2.025 billion.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After tax credits of $128,000 for the quarter and $247,000 for the 6 months.

title: WANTED: A WRITER WITH STYLE TO REPORT FROM SPACE
description: Fewer college freshmen are planning careers in computers or engineering now than a year ago, and the total who consider it very important to make a lot of money decreased for the first time in 15 years, according to a new study.

title: Dr. Charles Blanford, Ex-Head Of U.S. Milk-Marketing Area
description: Dr. Charles Jessie Blanford, a former administrator of the New York-New Jersey Federal milk-marketing area, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: New Inquiry Is Set In Hammer Death
description: The authorities have reopened the investigation of the death of a man whose skull was broken by 32 hammer blows, though the local police have said it was a suicide, officials said today.

title: OILERS BEAT BRUINS
description: Glenn Anderson scored his 29th and 30th goals and set up two others tonight to spark the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-3 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: NOTRE DAME UPSET BY BRIGHAM YOUNG
description: Tom Gneiting scored 7 of his 18 points in overtime to lead Brigham Young to an 80-76 upset of Notre Dame tonight.

title: Cooney Agreement
