description: A disorderly conduct charge filed against Gerry Cooney, the heavyweight boxer, was dropped in Harrisburg, Pa., when the fighter agreed to stage a benefit match there. The agreement calling for off-duty police officers to drop assault charges against Cooney and three associates was accepted by District Justice Michael Stewart at a hearing. In addition to the benefit match, Cooney and the other defendants have agreed to write a letter of apology to the police officers involved.

title: Pavelich Joins Rangers
description: Mark Pavelich, who missed the Rangers' previous five games because of a fractured right index finger, accompanied the team on its trip to the West yesterday and is expected to play against the Canucks tonight in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: IN CONTINUING CASE OF EVOLUTION, MOTH APPEARS TO ALTER COLOR IN CLEAN AIR
description: IT is the classic example of natural selection at work, described in countless biology textbooks: the shift in predominance from white to black forms of the peppered moth in 19th century England. The change occurred as smoke belching from the new factories of the industrial revolution darkened the landscape and killed light-colored lichens on tree trunks, rocks and walls.

title: Thrift Units' Profits Off a Bit
description: Profits at the nation's federally insured thrift institutions fell slightly in the third quarter of 1985 to $1.1 billion, from $1.2 billion in the second quarter, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Lewis Is Resigning Warner Amex Jobs
description: Drew Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., said yesterday that he plans to resign from the television company on April 1.

title: A DRIVING FORCE LEAVES ROLM
description: A little more than a year after the International Business Machines Corporation bought the Rolm Corporation, M. Kenneth Oshman, Rolm's president and the moving force behind its ascendancy in the telecomunications industry, said yesterday that he would resign.

title: Housing the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income after a pretax writedown of $2,500,000 for the quarter and year related to an account receivable.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Panel on Needs of Blacks
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday the creation of a commission on black New Yorkers - to ''examine the economic development, employment and education needs of black residents,'' he said.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Simmons Changes Plan for Sea-Land
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, says he will not try to gain control of the Sea-Land Corporation by stock ownership, but will attempt a takeover through the election of new board members.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings were restated for 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 15, 1986.

title: JONES SPACELINK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $48,000 from reversal of a tax credit.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for 14 wks to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest periods are for 14 weeks and 53 weeks. Year-ago results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks ended Nov. 24, 1984.

title: CUOMO OFFERS SPENDING PLAN OF $41 BILLION
description: Predicting ''a new economic resurgence for New York,'' Governor Cuomo today proposed a $41.4 billion state budget that would increase spending by 7 percent while also putting into effect the second year of a tax-cut plan.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $308,000 for the quarter and $908,000 for the 9 months and a loss of $2,995,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the disposal of the discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $236,000 for the quarter and $424,000 for 9 months.

title: THE SCREEN: 'FOLLWOING THE FUHRER'
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago Erwin Leiser, the German-born Swedish film maker, put together a documentary feature he called ''Mein Kampf,'' a comprehensive history of the Third Reich composed of clips from old newsreels and footage obtained from both Allied and German sources. Though much of the material wasn't especially new, ''Mein Kampf'' was an effective summation of the Nazi era as recorded on film.

title: Indians Pick Pitcher
description: The Cleveland Indians made Jeff Shaw, a sophomore pitcher at Cuyahoga Community College in Ohio, the first player selected in the regular phase of baseball's amateur draft. The 19-year-old Shaw, from Washington Court House, Ohio, throws a fastball that has been timed at 93 miles an hour.

title: Places in the Sun Appeal to Rams
description: For pro football fans who have been following the fortunes of the Rams since they moved from Cleveland to Los Angeles before the 1946 National Football League season, Sunday's 24-0 defeat by the Bears in Chicago hardly came as a surprise.

title: International Law and Terrorist Havens
description: To the Editor:

title: The Producer
description: The Democrats have chosen Joe Rothstein of Washington to produce their televised response to President Reagan's State of the Union Message Jan. 28. In 1985 he produced two major Democratic Party television appearances, Representative Dan Rostenkowski's reply to the President on tax reform and Senator Robert C. Byrd's on the budget. The live broadcast, 15 to 20 minutes long, will be offered to the networks immediately after Mr. Reagan closes.

title: STILL STUCK ON TEFLON, AFTER 25 YEARS
description: THIS month, Teflon, the magical material that created something of a minirevolution in the kitchen, is marking the 25th anniversary of its United States debut in cookware. The product was almost an overnight success on its introduction and since then sales have swelled a hundredfold. Currently, 26 American cookware manufacturers use a nonstick finish.

title: EX-AGRICULTURE DEPUTY SEEMS SET FOR TOP JOB
description: Richard E. Lyng, former Deputy Secretary of Agriculture who is now a private agricultural consultant, is scheduled to meet with personnel officials at the White House Wednesday to discuss succeeding John R. Block as Secretary of Agriculture, according to White House and Congressional sources.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ARGENTINES RIOT AGAINST ROCKEFELLER
description: The worst street violence since the return of democracy two years ago erupted overnight as demonstrators protested a visit here by David Rockefeller, the former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Rocket Streak Stopped at 20
description: Rickey Green hit a basket and two free throws in the final nine seconds, and Karl Malone scored 29 points tonight as the Utah Jazz snapped Houston's season-long home winning streak at 20 games with a 105-102 victory.

title: Eyes on Howard Baker
description: When Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee failed to win the Republican Presidential nomination in 1980, some analysts concluded that he had started his campaign too late and devoted too much of his time to being Republican floor leader. He eliminated one of those problems by retiring from the Senate at the end of his third term in 1984, and he has been practicing law in Washington since.

title: Voices From the Jury Box
description: In celebrated criminal cases, the press and television give extensive coverage to an arrest, indictment and trial. But they rarely get more than a glimpse of the most crucial event: the jury's deliberation. The trial of six Transit Police officers for the death of Michael Stewart in 1983 seemed to be no exception - until two of the jurors, Peter Griffin and Richard Essex, rose to defend the jury's decision to acquit. Their recent article on the Op-Ed page provided a welcome clarification.

title: Sudan Reports Rebels Killed 83 in Massacre
description: The official Sudanese press agency said today that anti-Government rebels had raided a town in southern Sudan and massacred 83 people, including patients in a hospital.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss. The fourth quarter results includes the use of $20,000,000 remaining in an employee profit sharing reserve. There were no share earnings in the latest year because net income was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $312,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income. d-Including a tax credit of $613,000.

title: SUNTRUST BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLAN FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS: $303 MILLION RISE IN AID
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a $303 million increase in aid to public schools, a figure that many educators and lobbyists had rejected even in advance of the budget as too low.

title: Don't Ask Criminal Courts to Decide Social Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTION
description: The caption of a picture by United Press International on Thursday with an article about the trial of police officers in Miami misidentified one person in the courtroom. He was Gregory Denaro, a defense lawyer, not Armando Garcia, a defendant.

title: CARELESS NETS BEATEN BY 76ERS
description: The Nets committed too many turnovers and fouls in the first half tonight. In the third quarter, their offense collapsed. In the last period, so did their defense. The combination of minuses was more than enough for the Philadelphia 76ers, the hottest team in the league, to overwhelm the Nets, 123-105, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THATCHER BACKS AIDE ACCUSED IN PARLIAMENT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, facing what is rapidly developing into her most severe political test since the Falkland War, rallied today to the defense of a key member of her Cabinet, who is accused of misleading the House of Commons.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DONNA REED, OSCAR WINNER AND TV STAR, IS DEAD AT 64
description: Donna Reed, the Academy Award-winning actress who starred in more than 40 movies and portrayed the quintessential mother and wife of middle America on television's ''Donna Reed Show'' in the 1950's and 60's, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 64 years old.

title: PANTRY PRIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-Net income after a loss of $488,000 from discontinued operations and including an extraordinary credit of $819,000. Results do not include operations of Revlon Inc., acquired Nov. 1, 1985.

title: FINDING A CAB IN MOSCOW: ANYTHING THAT MOVES
description: Anyone who has tried to hail a taxi in Manhattan on a wintry night would appreciate the frustration of Muscovites stranded downtown in Arctic conditions this time of year.

title: A PORTRAIT OF THE TRANSLATOR AS A LITERARY GENIUS
description: ''A translator requires an imagination that surpasses that of the original writer,'' Gonie Bang, a Korean delegate, said during a panel on translation at the International PEN Congress here. ''The best translator must be a genius, knowing both languages to the point of recreating not only words and phrases but also the spirit of the work. Since translators are not all geniuses, they must at least be at the level of education and imagination of the writer.''

title: Advertising; Magazine Focuses On Drinkers Only
description: Michael Minick, publisher of Beauty Digest, is particularly interested in target marketing. That is why he was always concerned about the amount of waste involved in liquor advertisers buying space in general consumer magazines and wasting their romantic imagery on a multitude of non-drinkers, about half the population.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 15, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Saints Name Finks
description: Jim Finks, the former general manager of the Chicago Bears and the Minnesota Vikings, has been named president and general manager of the New Orleans Saints and will become a part owner of the club, according to Tom Benson, who bought the team last year. ''We have been working to win, and now we bring you a winner,'' Benson said.

title: Stunning Upset In British Soccer
description: Altrincham defeated Birmingham, 2-1, in a sensational upset today in the third round of English Football Association Cup.

title: Ice-Nine, et al.
description: Ice-nine, the imaginary material in a Kurt Vonnegut novel, was so dangerously infectious that one crystal would have turned the world's waters solid. Now scientists have outrun science fiction.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Mavericks, at Dallas. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Nets vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) College: Army vs. Northeastern, 6:45 P.M., and St. John's vs. Seton Hall, 9 P.M., at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, (Television - MSG, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. and USA, 2 A.M., St. John's-Seton Hall only. Radio - WCBS 880, 8:30 P.M.). Brooklyn at Maryland Eastern Shore, 8 P.M. City College at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M. C. W. Post at Queens, 7:30 P.M. Stockton State at Glassboro State, 7:30 P.M. Drexel at Hofstra, 7:30 P.M. Monmouth at Wagner, 7:30 P.M. Stony Brook at New York Maritime, 7:30 P.M. Southampton at New York Tech, 7:30 P.M. Pace at Mercy, 7:30 P.M., St. Peter's at Fairfield, 8 P.M. Baruch at Staten Island, 8 P.M. Ramapo at William Paterson, 7:30 P.M. Lafayette at Navy, 7:30 P.M. Rutgers-Newark at Kean State, 7:30 P.M. Syracuse at Georgetown (Television - USA, 8 P.M., Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 8 P.M.) Boxing Roger Mayweather vs. Walter Sims, lightweights, 10 rounds, at the Sahara Hotel and Casino, Las Vegas, Nev. Mayweather, from Las Vegas, is a former World Boxing Association junior lightweight champion. He is 23-3 with 14 knockouts and has moved up to heavier competition. Sims, from Los Angeles, is 16-2-2 with 11 knockouts. (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M. live.) Hockey Rangers vs. Los Angeles Kings, at Inglewood, Calif.

title: OKLAHOMA SENATOR'S WOES MIRROR G.O.P. WORRIES
description: The First State Bank of Cache closed its doors this week. It was the 23d bank to go under in Oklahoma in less than four years. The Legislature is wrestling with a way to cut 9 percent out of the state budget to bring it in line with declining revenue. And Senator Don Nickles's family-owned machine shop in Ponca City has had to dismiss half its workers.

title: Valentine to Clippers
description: The Portland Trail Blazers traded the guard Darnell Valentine to the Los Angeles Clippers in return for a first-round draft choice this year, according to a team spokesman, John White.

title: How to Honor Dr. King - and When
description: ''One day,'' Martin Luther King Jr. wrote in his celebrated 1963 letter from the Birmingham City Jail, ''the South will recognize its real heroes. . . . One day the South will know that when these disinherited children of God sat down at lunch counters, they were in reality standing up for the best in the American dream and the most sacred values in our Judeo-Christian heritage.''

title: PEANUT SHACK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
111 IN CITY ARE SEMIFINALISTS IN THE WESTINGHOUSE CONTEST
description: New York City high school students accounted for more than one out of every three national semifinalists named in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

title: Palestinians Expelled By Italy in Crackdown
description: Italy has expelled about a dozen Palestinian students as part of a stepped-up campaign against terrorism, officials here said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: KEAN, IN STATE OF STATE MESSAGE, CALLS FOR FAR-REACHING CHANGES
description: Governor Kean asked the New Jersey Legislature today for far-reaching governmental changes that he said would strengthen the state as it approaches the next century.

title: RCA Merger Opposition
description: Robert R. Frederick, the president and chief executive of RCA Inc. opposed the merger between the General Electric Company and RCA Inc., according to proxy material filed Monday in connection with the $6.28 million deal.

title: Action Seen On Antitrust
description: President Reagan, accepting recommendations from his Economic Policy Council, will ask Congress to ease the nation's antitrust laws in an effort to make American companies more competitive in world markets, Administration sources said today.

title: NOVEMBER BORROWING RISE SMALL
description: Americans took on $4.88 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in November, the smallest monthly increase in more than two years, the Government reported today.

description: b-Including tax credits of $3,938,000 for the quarter and $3,778,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $4,035,000 for the quarter and $26,354,000 for the year.

title: Loss Posted By MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company yesterday reported a $26.9 million net loss for the quarter ending Nov. 30, in contrast to $1 million net income, or 3 cents a share, for the comparable 1984 period.

description: b-After a pretax charge of $35.9 million, relating to costs incurred in connection with a tender offer made for the company by Hanson Trust PLC. c-After a net charge of $19.9 million for costs incurred by the company in connection with the tender offer by Hanson Trust. d-After a pretax charge of $39 million for the quarter and 6 months as a result of a major restructuring of Smith-Corona typewriters and the disposal of operations, and income of $4 million, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and six months, from the reduction of tax reserves related to foreign operations.

title: ANGENCIES' FIGURES SHOW WIDE IMPACT UNDER BUDGET ACT
description: Figures the Government will announce Wednesday indicate the widespread impact of the first automatic spending cuts under the new landmark budget-balancing law.

REAGAN HAILS ECUADOR PRESIDENT AS MODEL LEADER
description: President Reagan met today with the President of Ecuador, Leon Febres Cordero, and hailed him as a model leader in the Western Hemisphere.

title: New Manville Plan
description: The Manville Corporation has told a Federal bankruptcy judge in New York it will submit a new, $2.5 billion reorganization plan and a financial statement by Feb. 14. The plan, which first was outlined by the company in December, must be voted on by each of the company's thousands of creditors. It would set aside about $2.5 billion for asbestos-disease victims and $125 million for property owners with asbestos on their premises.

title: Advertising; Burson-Marsteller Set For 1988 Olympics Job
description: Burson-Marsteller, the world's largest public relations company, announced yesterday that ''in conjunction'' with the Richard V. Allen Company of Washington it had been named public relations consultant to the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the State Legislature:

title: UNESCO DIRECTOR SPEAKS AT PEN, UNEVENTFULLY
description: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, the controversial director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, made a brief and uneventful noontime visit to the International PEN Congress yesterday, in marked contrast to the atmosphere surrounding the appearance on Sunday of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Many writers who protested Mr. Shultz's speech made no objection to Mr. M'Bow's presence.

title: Tentative Contract Reached For City Building Engineers
description: Negotiators for the owners of 700 large office buildings in Manhattan and the 2,500 engineers and maintenance workers who provide heat and other services for the buildings reached tentative agreement on new contract terms last night, a state mediator said.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $575,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

Gannett Deal Cleared
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it approved the transfer of the Evening News Association to the Gannett Company. It said the rules covering cross-ownership of media in the same market would not prevent Gannett, which owns USA Today based in Arlington, Va., from owning WDVM-TV in Washington.

title: A Positive Experience With Jobs Tax Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: After 60 Years, A Fitting Display
description: It glows softly from its wall in the Charles Engelhard Court of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, depicting two large figures surmounted by musical instruments and old music notations.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures were adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1985.

title: Avon to Eliminate About 470 Jobs
description: Avon announced that it was moving much of its manufacturing and administration operation from several New York locations to various sites in the Middle West to improve efficiency and profitability. John Cox, a company spokesman, also said that Avon would take an undisclosed charge in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Alaria Chamber Group In Its New York Debut
description: Since its formation in 1982, the Alaria Chamber Ensemble has performed regularly in local churches, libraries, schools, private homes and at the Mannes College of Music, where it is in residence. Still, it wasn't until Saturday night's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall that the group finally made its formal New York debut.

title: CONVICTION REVERSED ON EXCLUSION OF BLACKS FROM GRAND JURY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the conviction of any defendant indicted by a grand jury from which members of his own race were unconstitutionally excluded must be reversed, even if guilt was clear and the trial was fair.

title: DISCOVERIES
How to Join The Intelligentsia Without Trying
description: The most exciting new game around is called ''Feelings.''

title: CITY FILING SUIT IN ILLEGAL RAZING AT HISTORIC SITE
description: The city began civil action yesterday against a developer who demolished a historic Queens house without a permit, several weeks before it was to be considered for landmark status.

title: BIG BANKS UPGRADE ARGENTINA
description: It was only one year ago that American bankers were girding themselves to write off billions of dollars in Argentine loans. But now, one major bank after another is reporting sharply higher profits, thanks in part to the interest earned from those same loans.

title: Does No One Have Sufficient Legal Standing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Holds Steady In Cautious Trading
description: The dollar held steady in light volume yesterday as currency traders adopted a cautious attitude.

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a special loss reserve of $1,293,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the taxi industry in London misidentified the Asian leader who once worked as a kitchen porter at the former Carlton Hotel. He was Ho Chi Minh, not Mao Zedong.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: Wednesday, January 15, 1986
description: WORLD

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN the Old Testament, Samson's mother is admonished by an angel: ''Thou shalt conceive, and bear a son. Now therefore beware, I pray thee, and drink not wine nor strong drink.'' In ancient Carthage, the law forbade bridal couples to drink on their wedding night. And in 1834, a report to the British House of Commons noted that infants born to alcoholic mothers had ''a starved, shriveled and imperfect look.'' But it was not until 1973 that medical scientists confirmed what people seem to have known for thousands of years: that alcohol consumed by a pregnant woman can damage her unborn child. That year two pediatric researchers from the University of Washington in Seattle rediscovered and named fetal alcohol syndrome.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a gain of 65 cents per share from the sale of a unit.

title: FOUNDATION SEND CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST
description: Trusts and foundations have been among the contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE Residents have been making records for 13 years.

title: NEW INCIDENT ON TEMPLE MOUNT
description: A new confrontation erupted today in Jersualem between Israeli legislators and Moslems on the Temple Mount, which is sacred to Jews and Moslems. It was the second incident in a week.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $144,020.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Bit of London Rona Deme's Country Host, the British bakery and food shop that has been at 1435 Lexington Avenue for 14 years, will close at the end of this month and move slightly uptown to 1457 Lexington (95th Street). Mrs. Deme's kitchen, catering operation and residence have all been in the brownstone at 1457 for the last nine years. She said moving the retail operation to that address would bring all their working efforts under one roof. ''It's very English and very much the way things are done in London,'' she said, ''living over the shop, you know.''

title: Sperry Corp.
description: The Sperry Corporation is offering $200 million of 7 5/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Oil Workers' Panel Accepts Amoco Proposal
description: Negotiators for the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers have accepted a proposal from the Amoco Corporation for a two-year contract that union leaders said would lead to a settlement of a nationwide contract dispute between 46,500 workers and 80 petroleum companies.

title: FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE STAGE: 'DECEMBER SEVENTH'
description: IT is early in December 1941, and we are in the living room of a fraternity in an upstate New York college. At the center of the stage is a large radio-phonograph, and, before the play has finished, there will be a news bulletin that will irrevocably change the lives of the characters. Until that predictable ''Day of Infamy'' announcement, George Rattner, the author of ''December Seventh,'' will marshal a regiment of dramatic cliches.

title: GRASS VS. BELLOW OVER U.S. AT PEN
description: A day of relatively calm literary discussion was shattered yesterday at the International PEN Congress when Gunter Grass forcifully challenged Saul Bellow on his appraisal of the American dream.

title: MANES CUT IN PARK, HE ASSERTS
description: Donald R. Manes, who is recovering from a slashed wrist and cut ankle, told investigators last night that he remembered where he was injured - somewhere in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: THE CHINESE TAKEOUT GAME: THE GOOD, THE BAD, THE BLAND
description: HUNAN COTTAGE, Hunan Tower and Hunan Taste; Empire Szechuan Paradise, Empire Szechuan Garden and Szechuan Broadway; Yang Yang Too, Chan Cheun and Cheung Shing; China West, China King's, Taste of China and the Cosy Chinese: The name of the game is Chinese takeout and, win a few, lose a few, it is played every night of the week on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results reflect a nonrecurring charge of $700,000 for moving expenses.

title: Minding the Hall
description: For most of the world outside City Hall, Edward I. Koch must seem to be the most active person in that venerable building.

HOUSE CALLS OF A CLOCK SELLER
description: AMERICANS shopping for a long-case, or grandfather, clock in England will find an unusual service at Hymore-Hodson Antiques: free home installation anywhere in the United States by the proprietor, Johann Hodson-Klein.

title: Market Place; Rises in Profits Seen for I.B.M.
description: WHEN the International Business Machines Corporation reports its 1985 fourth-quarter earnings - expected on Friday - the overwhelming expectation on Wall Street is that rising profits are back on track for Big Blue. The consensus calls for earnings to show a sizable advance over the $3.55 a share reported in the final quarter of 1984.

title: MICROSIZE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Financing Violations Charged
description: Common Cause, criticizing the use of Congressional campaign contributions, said today that a Republican campaign group might be violating tax rules and that Representative Bill Boner, Democrat of Tennessee, might have used campaign money for personal gain.

title: OUTLOOK MODEST FOR GENEVA TALKS
description: The talks on intermediate-range nuclear weapons represent the most promising area for progress at the next round of the Geneva arms negotiations, which begin on Thursday, according to some Reagan Administration officials.

title: UPHILL FIGHT FOR COONEY
description: On a wintry morning in Lancaster, Pa., Gerry Cooney is running up Lincoln Highway East. Traffic whooshes by, as Cooney - in a dark blue training suit and weighted blue fingerless gloves - strides past Pizza Hut and Hardee's, on by Murray's Men's Wear and the House of Shanghai.

title: CRIME PANEL FINDS U.S. STRATEGY LAGS
description: Law-enforcement officials lack a coherent strategy in attacking organized crime's corruption of certain labor unions and legitimate businesses, a Federal commission said today.

description: Retail sales, spurred by a rebound in auto demand, rose 1.9 percent last month, the biggest gain since September, the Government reported today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: F. MURRAY ABRAHAM, who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the composer Antonio Salieri, the envious adversary of Mozart, writes:

title: Pennzoil Hearing Set for February
description: The legal battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company is scheduled to resume the week of Feb. 10, when a Federal appeals court will hear arguments on Pennzoil's request that a lower-court ruling be overturned, the companies said yesterday.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring pretax charge of about $1.8 million which relates to the possible annulment and related expenses of the sale of Idle Wild's L.B. Darling division.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COLLECTED POEMS: 1948-1984. By Derek Walcott. 516 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25. ''I

title: Advertising; Time Cites Its Appeal To Women
description: BEFORE the advent of People, the magazines of Time Inc. were, in the words of Richard B. Thomas, the new publisher of Time magazine, ''feeding at the same trough.''

title: UNITED AIR STILL LACKS JAPAN DEAL
description: After two days of tough negotiations, the United States and Japan failed to agree on a way for United Airlines to take over the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways.

title: COM TEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
U.S. WEIGHS ASSIGNING WARSHIPS TO ESCORT DUTY IN THE PERSIAN GULF
description: The Administration is considering assigning Navy warships to escort American merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf to prevent another boarding by armed Iranians, State Department officials said today.

title: The Red Red Cross
description: An unusually heavy number of floods and hurricanes in 1985 left the coffers of the American Red Cross depleted. So now, in an effort to recoup, the organization has come up with plans for an ''Undisaster Day'' to kick off a national campaign for funds.

title: Advertising; New-Product Totals
description: As they usually do, the Christmas holidays cut into the volume of new-product introductions in the supermarket field, which dropped to 175 in December from 223 in November, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. However, compared with December 1984, totals were up from 164. The full year 1985 showed 2,206 introductions, up from 1,988 in 1984.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $297,000 for the quarter and $471,000 for the 6 months.

title: METS TO CHECK GOODEN ANKLE
description: Both Dwight Gooden and his agent insisted yesterday that the star pitcher's twisted right ankle was healing and was no threat to his season or his career. But the Mets said they were ''disappointed'' that the injury had not been reported to them for 10 days, and scheduled a medical check for Gooden in New York next Monday.

title: A Hero Of Industry
description: An uncle of mine had an idea for getting rich: a flying bicycle. He called it an ''aerocycle.'' This shows how long ago he had the idea, because the prefix ''aero'' went out with the buggy whip and would now be forgotten if the Air Force 30 years ago hadn't concocted the word ''aerospace'' to justify its dubious claim on the billions soon to be lavished on rocketry.

title: New Postmaster General To Leave in September
description: Albert V. Casey, the new Postmaster General, will leave the post in September to accept a professorship at Southern Methodist University's business school, postal officials said today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch on Jan. 9 from Tripoli, Libya, reported the reaction of some Americans after President Reagan's order to leave that country.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Intel Is Expected To Lay Off 1,000
description: The Intel Corporation is expected to lay off as many as 1,000 employees Wednesday, according to analysts and sources close to the company.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; American Symphony Plays Mahler's Ninth
description: The American Symphony Orchestra's Sunday afternoon performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 9 at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of Benjamin Zander, was longer on passion and ideas than it was on polish.

title: Flight Crew Error Cited In Galaxy Airlines Crash
description: The pilot and co-pilot of a Galaxy Airlines plane that crashed last Jan. 21 in Reno, Nev., killing 70 people, probably caused the accident by failing to concentrate on flying when strong vibrations shook the airplane, a Federal panel said today.

title: CREATIVE COMPUTER APPLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $52,000. c-Net loss.

title: ADMIT IT OR NOT, WORK DRESS CODES ARE A FACT OF LIFE
description: WHEN Jeff Leston was a salesman at International Business Machines, no one told him the company had an unwritten dress code, but, he said, ''You got the message.'' So he dressed in dark suits, conservative ties and white shirts with button-down collars. ''Your collar couldn't be too long or too short,'' Mr. Leston said. Then one day he rebelled. His boss eyed the blue shirt Mr. Leston had chosen to wear and asked, ''Jeff, are you selling to the Air Force this morning?''

title: Three Men Indicted In Foiled Antique Theft
description: Three men were indicted yesterday on a variety of charges stemming from the foiled theft of Middle Eastern antiquities from a Queens warehouse on Jan. 5.

title: SAKHAROV PLEASED ON SURGERY
description: The Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov talked with his relatives here today for the first time in more than two weeks and said he was pleased that his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had successfully undergone a coronary bypass operation in Boston.

title: LIBYAN FIGHTERS BUZZ U.S. PLANE PATROLLING CENTRAL MEDITERRANEAN
description: Two Libyan MIG-25 fighter planes intercepted a United States Navy surveillance plane Monday over the Mediterranean Sea, flying within 200 feet of the American aircraft and returning to Libya before American fighter planes reached the scene, Pentagon officials said today.

title: GANDER CRASH BRINGS RISE IN U.S. AIRLINE CHECKS
description: The Department of Transportation, concerned by the crash of a chartered Arrow Air DC-8 jet in Newfoundland last month that killed 248 soldiers, yesterday announced ''special accelerated inspections'' of airlines with contracts to carry military personnel.

title: FILM: 'SHARMA AND BEYOND,' COMEDY
description: IF a pretty young couple and a pretty house, pretty scenery and pretty music could a movie make, ''Sharma and Beyond'' would be up for all the awards. Unfortunately, it is light on other useful ingredients, in particular a plot.

title: FRANCIS KINGSLEY, EXECUTIVE OF TEXTILE AND STORE CONCERNS
description: Francis G. Kingsley, a business executive, died Friday at a nursing home in West Haven, Conn. He was 90 years old and had homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: BACK TO WORK
description: In the final hours of the old year, a 33-year-old man went to work in the company of his family. It was such a warm moment that its memory lingers two weeks later: the father busy at the trade he knows best, two of his children playing with his tools, his wife and in-laws chatting as they waited for him to finish.

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Excluding $2.7 million for elimination of deferred income taxes no longer required.

title: Cuba Official Arrives in Peru
description: The president of Cuba's National Assembly arrived today on a visit that diplomats said showed the strengthening of ties between Cuba and Peru since President Alan Garcia took office in July.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN'S STATE OF THE STATE ADDRESS TO THE JERSEY LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's State of the State Address that he delivered today to the opening session of the 202d New Jersey Legislature:

title: IRVINE SENSORS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $92,700 from the settlement of trade accounts payable.

title: WINE TALK
description: WITH the dollar sinking steadily, imported wines are not the bargains they were a year ago. Of course, the wine makers and the importers might decide to absorb some of the expected increases. But then again, they might not.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: National Westminster is a wholly owned subsidiary of National Westminster Bank PLC Group, London.

title: IN TRENTON, POMP AND POIGNANCY
description: Politics is full of ritual, some of it open and excessively formal and some of it all but unseen and often poignant. Today, as one party ascended to power here and another tried to regroup after defeat, the state capital echoed with ceremonies large and small.

title: 2 SPY COUNTS IN TRANSCRIPT CASE
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a messenger for a Washington-based company that transcribes official proceedings on two counts of spying for the Soviet Union.

description: At least 370 people have been injured in more than 700 toxic chemical accidents in New York State since early 1983 because of ''serious gaps'' in state and Federal laws to protect the public, according to a study released yesterday by the State Attorney General's office.

title: First Chicago's Profits Rise 7%
description: The First Chicago Corporation today reported net income of $59.4 million in the fourth quarter, up 7 percent from $55.5 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were $1.04 against $1.03 in the quarter a year earlier.

title: CAPT CRAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
Sky Chefs' Sale
description: The AMR Corporation said it was selling its food service unit, which operates under the name Sky Chefs, to the Onex Capital Corporation of Toronto for an undisclosed amount.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Nelly Kokinos, Piano, Plays Chopin's Etudes
description: Playing all 27 Chopin Etudes in a sitting - as Nelly Kokinos did at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon - is as much a feat as a musical event. In them Chopin created a whole new vocabulary of pianistic difficulties - innovative uses of the instrument on which piano composers have drawn ever since.

title: QADDAFI CALLS FOR ECONOMIC WAR AGAINST U.S.
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi urged the Libyan people tonight to ''wage economic warfare'' against the United States and respond in kind to American sanctions against his country.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES FALL 8.3%
description: The nation's major auto makers turned in a disappointing sales performance for the beginning of the year, reporting today that car sales were down 8.3 percent in the Jan. 1-10 period compared with the corresponding period of 1985.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect nonrecurring charges from restructering at the company's American Tourister unit.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $501,000. c-Net income.

title: FLORIDA SITE YIELDING REMAINS OF ICE-AGE PEOPLE AND TOOLS
description: A sinkhole just outside Miami is revealing what archeologists say is important evidence corroborating that humans lived here 10,000 years ago in a cool climate among Ice Age animals.

title: CHRISTMAS FILM SALES SET RECORD
description: The movie industry - which thought during most of 1985 that Christmas would never come - wound up with a splendid present.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would like someone to protect us out here. I would like destroyers or battleships or God knows what.''

title: COURT IN POPE PLOT WON'T EXTEND TRIAL TO HEAR TESTIMONY IN U.S.
description: An Italian court trying seven men accused of plotting to assassinate Pope John Paul II refused today to extend the trial to hear testimony in New York about allegations that the Italian secret services fabricated evidence to implicate Bulgaria in the shooting.

title: A Leader of Solidarity Will Face Charges
description: The Government said today that an underground Solidarity leader would face charges of illegal union activities and trying to set off social unrest.
