description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,825,000 for the quarter and $10,804,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $1,771,000 for the quarter and $9,711,000 for the year and a gain for the year of $5,525,000 on the exchange of debt.

title: FACTIONS BATTLE FOR CAPITAL CITY OF SOUTH YEMEN
description: Street battles raged in the capital of Southern Yemen today after an attempted coup against the Marxist Government there by a more hard-line, pro-Soviet faction, according to reports received here.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VISITORS FROM BRAZIL Even the trained spotter of ethnic neighborhoods might have difficulty finding the Brazilian neighborhood in New York, for few Brazilians live there. It is an enclave scattered among Korean, Japanese, Hispanic and other national bailiwicks along West 46th Street, and to a lesser degree, West 45th Street, in the blocks between Fifth and Seventh Avenues. But one who searches carefully will find a score of Brazilian establishments: restaurants, a barber shop, some general stores and a few community, travel and promotion organizations.

title: NU HORIZONS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EASTERN AIR HAS A LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday reported a $67.4 million loss in the fourth quarter, in line with the expectations of management and analysts. The loss followed five profitable quarters.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,135,000.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $61,000 for the quarter and $1,041,000 for 6 months.

title: APPLE NET UP 23.4% TO RECORD
description: Apple Computer Inc. today reported a 23.4 percent gain in earnings for its first fiscal quarter, despite a 23.5 precent decline in sales. The increase brought the computer company's profits to a record, only two quarters after Apple had the first quarterly loss in its history.

title: TREASURY PRICES END DECLINE
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, following four days of steep declines.

title: JOB APPLICANTS GO BEYOND THE RESUME
description: WHEN Scott Immergut decided to seek full-time work in film production after freelancing for a year, he knew he would face stiff competition. The field is flooded with far more applicants than there are jobs. In an attempt to distinguish himself from the other candidates after interviewing with a Manhattan concern, he began sending ''ransom notes'' to the company's office, with his name and return address on the envelope. Written with letters he cut from newspapers and magazines, they read, ''Hire Scott or you'll regret it.''

title: JURY IS TOLD CRIME FAMILIES CONTROL CONCRETE BUSINESS
description: A concrete contractor testified yesterday that a person accused of being a member of the Colombo Mafia family had told him of a ''club'' of crime leaders who controlled the concrete business in New York City and parceled out large contracts to a group of seven companies.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split distributed in July 1985.

title: New York State Wines
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: W. P. KELLENBERG, EX-ROCKVILLE CENTRE BISHOP
description: Bishop Walter P. Kellenberg, the founder of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, died of a heart attack Saturday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: Required Reading; On Dr. King's Birthday
description: Excerpt from ''A Challenge to Protect the Integrity of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Legacy,'' a speech by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson to the Federal Communications Commission Bar Association of Washington, Jan. 12, three days before Dr. King's birthday:

title: Pennsylvania Begins $250 Million Financing
description: A $250 million issue of Pennsylvania tax anticipation notes was offered yesterday with a yield of 5.20 percent to maturity on June 26, 1986, through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Another Setback
description: Tito Horford, the Dominican-born former high school basketball star who was barred from playing for the University of Houston and later dropped from the Louisiana State team, has been rebuffed in an effort to enroll at the University of Kentucky, according to the Wildcats' coach, Eddie Sutton. In a statement issued yesterday, Sutton said that Pat Ellis, a Houston lawyer representing Horford, had called him Monday night to see if Horford would be welcome at Kentucky.

title: New Ink
description: A new national journal of opinion on public policy, described by its founders as somewhat left of center, is being prepared for publication later this year, possibly out of a Washington headquarters. It is financed by Richard Dennis, a Chicago commodities trader who provided $10 million to create the Roosevelt Center, a liberal-oriented organization in Chicago.

title: DANCE: PERRON AT THE KITCHEN
description: THE Kitchen's new home at 512 West 19th Street is a fine place for cooking up dances.

title: FRYAR MAY WATCH FROM AFAR
description: The controversy surrounding Irving Fryar has drawn so much attention that the New England Patriots are unlikely to bring him to the Super Bowl in New Orleans even if he could play against the Chicago Bears.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hutton Forms 2 Groups From Brokerage Unit
description: The E. F. Hutton Group, whose prestige was shaken badly last May when its brokerage unit pleaded guilty to 2,000 counts of mail and wire fraud, announced yesterday that it was reorganizing the unit's operations and shuffling its top management to improve efficiency in serving customers.

title: Rangers Win on McEwen's 2
description: Mike McEwen scored his first two goals of the season to give the Rangers a 2-1 victory tonight over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Memory Lane
description: A college basketball game played in Omaha on Monday night seemed as though it might have been played in a time warp: There were the staunch defenses and deliberate offenses of 50 years ago. Even with a 45-second shot clock in operation, Illinois State and Creighton could combine for only 69 points as Illinois State won, 35-34.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
COMMODITY PITS FACE TIGHTER RULES
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted yesterday to enact new rules to tighten the procedures for reporting trades on the floors of futures exchanges.

title: N. CAROLINA WINS
description: Warren Martin and Steve Hale scored 4 points apiece during an 8-0 North Carolina streak late in the game, giving the No. 1 ranked Tar Heels a 71-67 victory over Maryland tonight.

title: Aileen Lippincott, 88; Led Work Exchange
description: Aileen Lippincott, director and president of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, died of a heart attack Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
OCILLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the quarter and $196,000 for the 9 months.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FORT MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOMEZ MAKES MOST OF HIS OPPORTUNITY
description: At midday yesterday, when Jimmy Connors was still trying to determine whether to ignore the flu symptoms that had weakened him and fly to New York City for his first-round match in the Nabisco Masters, Andres Gomez of Ecuador was in Washington having lunch with the President of his country and Secretary of State George Shultz. Such is life in the fast lane for a professional tennis player.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: CSX Corp., Richmond, a railroad company, has appointed Mark G. Aron senior vice president, law and public affairs.

title: N.C.A.A. VOTES FOR DRUG TESTING
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today authorized drug testing for any athletes competing in the association's championship events and the 18 major-college postseason football bowl games.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS HUNGER IS COMMON IN RURAL U.S.
description: Food stamps reach less than one-third of the people eligible to receive them in 150 counties around the United States, according to a study reported today by a Harvard University group, and the researchers say this indicates hunger is common in many counties across the South, the Middle West and the West.

title: Leasing Bus Routes Will Give New York a Long-Run Headache
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: THE VERDI REQUIEM
description: FOR 10 years after the death of the great American tenor Richard Tucker, his wife, Sara, oversaw the Richard Tucker Foundation's work in support of young American opera singers. Sunday night the foundation marked its own anniversary and mourned Mrs. Tucker's death last year, with a performance of the Verdi Requiem in Carnegie Hall.

title: Advertising; People
description: John Hayes, Ella Kelley and Abbott Wool have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HORMEL SAYS 1,000 SEEK STRUCK JOBS
description: Hundreds of people applied for work at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant today as the company began accepting applications for workers to take the jobs of striking meatpackers.

title: Advertising; Dai-ichi Raises Stake In Ally & Gargano
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been informed that Dai-ichi Kikaku, a Japanese ad agency, and its United States subsidiary between Sept. 3 and Dec. 23 of last year increased their stockholdings in Ally & Gargano by 158,500 shares, bringing their total ownership to 325,450 shares, or 14.7 percent of the agency.

title: Auction Rates Up at Citicorp
description: At its weekly commercial paper auctions, Citicorp yesterday sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.874 percent, up from 7.673 percent the previous week.

title: Group Reports Decrease In Anti-Semitic Incidents
description: Anti-Semitic incidents against Jews and Jewish property in the United States decreased significantly last year, according to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Don't Ask Criminal Courts to Decide Social Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: SPACE AGENCY TO END SHUTTLE MISSION A DAY EARLY
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia, no strangers to disappointment after its launching was postponed a record seven times, were ordered today to end their mission one day early by landing here Thursday.

title: Home Loan Bank Rates on Issues Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is offering four bond issues totaling $2.03 billion through various securities dealers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in 60-Minute Gourmet Jan. 1 for chicken with mussels, sausage and peppers failed to state that the 3 cups of tomato cubes should be added in Step 3.

title: RICHARD ROTHSCHILD 90, A WRITER
description: Richard C. Rothschild, a writer on philosophy who led the American Jewish Committee's educational campaign against anti-Semitism during World War II, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: MGM-UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: 2D OFFICER TESTIFIES ON DRINKING BY SERGEANT ON NIGHT OF HIT-RUN
description: A police officer testified yesterday that on the night a Manhattan man was killed in a hit-and-run accident, he saw the sergeant now on trial in the death, in an ''intoxicated'' condition near a badly damaged patrol car.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The White House; All the President's Wines
description: When it comes to choosing the wines for state dinners and other festive occasions, the Reagan White House does not dispatch its agents to search out old European wine cellars. Instead, it looks to ''all-American'' labels.

title: Economic Scene; Overvaluation Of the Dollar
description: THE dollar, after moving down almost 25 percent from its peak on March 6, 1985, seems to be stuck on a plateau and, in fact, in recent weeks has been inching upward. Has the effort of the Reagan Administration to move the dollar down - an effort that culminated with the meeting of the Group of Five major industrial countries in New York last Sept. 22 - petered out?

title: CITY REMOVES FILES OF AIDE IN AGENCY UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: City investigators removed files and changed the lock yesterday on the office of a deputy director of the Parking Violations Bureau after Federal officials provided them with information about the possibility of improprieties at the agency.

title: Treasury Department; They Who Dig the Trenches for Economic War
description: Dennis M. O'Connell is a lawyer and civil servant who toils in one of the Government's sorriest quarters, just two blocks along G Street from the colonnaded palace of the Treasury's main building. Plywood covers one of the two entrances to the narrow and grime-covered onetime bank building, and dust clouds the windows.

title: Blockade by Pretoria Said to Strain Lesotho
description: Lesotho, a small country encircled by South Africa, was reported today to be running low on gasoline and other critical supplies because of a blockade by Pretoria that threatened to cripple the mountainous nation.

title: HIGH COURT PONDERING RELIGIOUS ATTIRE IN MILITARY
description: In a case pitting religious practice against the military dress code, members of the Supreme Court today engaged in a lively exchange with lawyers on whether the military may ban its members from wearing skullcaps, turbans, long hair or toupees as badges of faith.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Westfield Coatings Corporation in January 1985.

title: Nigeria Sees U.S. Support
description: Nigeria's Foreign Minister, A. Bolaji Akinyemi, said today that he had won the support of the United States for a new economic program in Nigeria that looks forward to export-led growth and ultimate resumption of full payments to creditors.

title: A HEAVY-DUTY PAN FOR HEARTY MEALS
description: WITH the dark shadow of winter upon us, hearty cooking has great appeal - regal roasts, long-simmering casseroles, homemade breads, cakes and pies. A well-made roasting pan is of paramount importance, be it for preparing a simple roast chicken or a leg of lamb with all the trimmings.

title: PRESIDENT EMERITUS OF DREXEL UNIVERSITY
description: William Walsh Hagerty, president emeritus of Drexel University in Philadelphia, died of cancer yesterday at Savannah Memorial Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 69 years old and lived on Skidaway Island, Ga., where he had moved from Berwin, Pa., on his retirement in August 1984.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year net includes a gain on the disposition of options of $3,146,000, or 19 cents a share.

title: A DARING CLASSICIST UPDATES CUISINE
description: THREE years ago I traveled to Japan to judge an international cooking test for a Tokyo television station. One of the dishes entered by the Swiss team contained something called sprouted lentils. I had never heard of them and after tasting - they were delicious - wondered aloud why we couldn't find something like them in America.

title: Swiss Inflation Is 3.4%
description: Consumer prices in Switzerland rose 3.4 percent in 1985, compared with 2.9 percent in 1984, the Government announced today. It was the first increase in the inflation rate since 1981. Major factors included cold weather early last year, which lifted fuel costs by 4.6 percent, and currency fluctuations.

title: Heritage Communications
description: Heritage Communications Inc., one of the country's 20 largest cable television operators, is offering $125 million of debt securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: First Chicago has adopted Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 87, which governs accounting for pension costs for the full year of 1985 and as a result earnings for the first 9 months of 1985 have been restated to reflect an after-tax increase of $4.8 million, or 10 cents a share.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Brooklyn Mill Basin Club Changing Name and Site
description: The biggest bridge club in Brooklyn undergoes a double change today.

title: NBC'S 'BLACKE'S MAGIC,' MAGICIAN AS DETECTIVE
description: THOUGH it is being applauded as the most innovative of the networks, having come up with winners ranging from ''The Cosby Show'' to ''Miami Vice,'' NBC now appears eager to prove that it can be just as pedestrian as its competitors. The new weekly series ''Blacke's Magic,'' on Wednesdays at 9 P.M., does a slight variation on television's favorite young-man/old-man formula with a middle-aged man/old-man turn.

title: DEVILS LOSE AGAIN TO PHYSICAL FLYERS
description: The memories of the last encounter were fresh for the Flyers and the Devils, who spent more time fighting than playing hockey again tonight at the Spectrum.

title: Reagan Dog Has Surgery
description: President Reagan's spaniel Rex successfully underwent a tonsillectomy today, the White House reported. Rex, the year-old King Charles spaniel that replaced another dog, Lucky, in December, checked into a veterinary hospital at an undisclosed location on Monday.

title: F.C.C. LIMITS RULES OVER TV RECEIVERS
description: The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that state and local government restrictions on antennas that receive satellite signals cannot be used to curtail competition in the distribution of television programs.

title: SETON HALL SEES BETTER DAYS
description: During the Big East's media day last November, many of the conference's coaches agreed that this season would be the one when Seton Hall would finally hoe that tough row.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN the average home cook thinks of coating a food for sauteing or deep frying with something other than flour, bread crumbs come easily and logically to mind. But finely ground nuts - cashews, macadamia nuts and so on - can also be used to coat food, and they give it a meatier flavor.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago per share net reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October.

title: STUDY FINDS UNANNOUNCED U.S. ATOMIC TESTS
description: The United States carried out as many as 19 unannounced underground nuclear tests from 1980 to 1984, according to a report by a private group.

title: THE CUOMO BUDGET: A CALL FOR MORE GREETS NEW SPENDING PLAN;
description: New York City would get $6.7 billion in the state budget that Governor Cuomo proposed today - up $354.9 million, or 5.5 percent, from the current year, according to state budget officials.

title: TOP U.S. EDUCATOR CALLS DR. KING A FINE TEACHER
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, stood in front of Denise Mathis's third-grade class here this morning and asked the students how they planned to celebrate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. La Shante Buffard, who is 8 years old, said her mother and her aunt were going to get a cake and invite people over for a party. Another student said she was going to visit Dr. King's tomb, only a block from the school.

title: P.&G. President Named Chairman
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced yesterday that John G. Smale, president and chief executive since 1981, would succeed Owen B. Butler as chairman when Mr. Butler retires on April 1. Mr. Smale will remain chief executive.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Dec. 26 about the Church of the SubGenius, a mock religious organization based in Texas, misidentified one of four radio stations that broadcast the organization's programs. It is WFMU in East Orange, N.J., not WSMU.

title: EUROPEAN RETAILERS FIND U.S. DIFFICULT
description: This week's decision by the British-based B.A.T Industries to sell its 36 Gimbel stores is just the latest indication of the difficulties foreign companies have had in operating American retailers.

title: GRAY & CO PUBLIC COMMUNICATION INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
IRRADIATION OF PORK IS APPROVED
description: The Government today approved low-dose irradiation of fresh pork to combat parasites that cause trichinosis.

title: GUATEMALA INAUGURATES CIVILIAN LEADER
description: An elected civilian was sworn in today as President of Guatemala after more than 30 years of military-dominated rule.

title: MIKE GARCIA, A TOP PITCHER FOR CLEVELAND IN THE 1950'S
description: Mike Garcia, the former Cleveland pitcher who helped the Indians set the American League record for victories in winning the pennant in 1954, died Monday at his home in the Cleveland suburb of Fairview Park. He was 62 years old and had been suffering from kidney disease for several years.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $51,262,000 for the quarter and $51,327,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a gain for the quarter of $1,299,000 and a loss for the 9 months of $3,299,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $206,027. c-Net income includes an extroardinary tax credit of $60,576.

title: Reagan's Carter Policy on Handling Terrorism
description: Never has President Reagan sounded more like Jimmy Carter than in explaining his decision not to take military reprisals for the Rome and Vienna airport murders. Once again, alas, the President spoke loudly and brandished a very small stick.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
DOW DOWN 1.49
description: Wall Street results were mixed yesterday in a dull session during which investors, shrugging off unexpected economic news, bought secondary stocks while ignoring blue-chip issues.

title: New Sybron Offer
description: The Sybron Corporation, a maker of medical and scientific supplies, said it received a new leveraged buyout offer of $24 for each common share and $38.40 for each preferred share, or a total of about $265 million. The offer is on behalf of a new corporation to be formed by Montgomery Medical Ventures, an affiliate of Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage, and the Morgan Capital Corporation, an affiliate of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: McAdoo Signs Offer by 76ers
description: Seeking to bolster their front court for the second half of the season, the Philadelphia 76ers today signed Bob McAdoo to an offer sheet.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 8:22 A.M. today and set at 7:51 P.M. tonight.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $49,500.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCRAMBLING OF SIGNALS TODAY THWARTS TV DISH ANTENNAS
description: Wednesday is S-Day, for scramble, for millions of Americans with satellite television antennas in the backyard.

title: Acid Criticism
description: Once upon a time, a rotten tomato was the popular choice for expressing strong disapproval in a forceful manner. But in 1986, Knoxville, Tenn., has hit on the orange as the symbol of irritation with the computer used by The New York Times to rate college football teams.

title: Preserve Tax-Free Bonds
description: While tax reform is an idea whose time has come, as governors we hope this effort does not undermine the ability of state and local governments to manage their own fiscal affairs. Provisions in the tax reform package the House passed late last year would do precisely that, by severely restricting their ability to raise money through tax-exempt bonds. These provisions merit careful re-examination by the Senate.

title: COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Including a tax credit of $17,000. c-Net loss.

title: Chip Makers Report Gains
description: Electronic chip manufacturers in the United States, Europe and Japan have reported gains in orders and shipments for December.

title: Long Run and Short in New Jersey
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey was re-elected in November for four years; his huge margin of victory emboldened him to cast his State of the State Message yesterday as an agenda that looks forward to the year 2000. On the crucial issue of toxic waste, however, he retreats to the here and now.

title: EPIGONES ROAST BUCKLEY WITH HOT AIR BALLOONS
description: The occasion clearly called for speechifying, and Jeff Greenfield was happy to oblige.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year figures were restated to reflect the acquisition of American Bancorp Inc. on Dec. 31, 1985.

title: Ex-Convict Is Accused Of Murdering Couple
description: A ex-convict has been charged with murdering a couple in their apartment above a tavern here, officials said today.

title: CUSTOMS CHIEF PROTESTS CUTS AS DEVASTATING TO DRUG WAR
description: The Reagan Administration has proposed deep cuts in portions of the Customs Service's proposed 1987 budget that would devastate the agency's ability to enforce drug laws, the Customs Commissioner's office has said in an unusually strong letter of protest.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,003,000 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $3,532,000 for 6 months.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Hoyt Spelman appointed senior vice president at Decker Decker & Freas.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WISEGUY: LIFE IN A MAFIA FAMILY.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLL FINDS 'NO CREDIBILITY CRISIS' FOR NEWS MEDIA
description: A study of public attitudes toward the press has concluded that there is ''no credibility crisis for the nation's media'' and that Americans find their news more believable than President Reagan.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS DEFENDED BY MEESE ON PRESSER CONTACT
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today defended the Reagan Administration's contacts with Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who had been the subject of a Federal investigation into union corruption.

title: MCA BUYS INTEREST IN THEATER CHAIN
description: MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Pictures, has agreed to invest $75 million for a one-third interest in the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a Canadian theater chain with a major presence in the United States.

title: To Teflon or Not to Teflon
description: Officials at Du Pont say that what bothers them is not so much that commentators sometimes call President Reagan a Teflon President, meaning that no matter what happens, no blame sticks to him. Du Pont simply wants users of Teflon to add a little circle with an R inside to denote that Teflon is a registered trademark. A printed message being sent to reporters all over the capital adds, ''It is not, alas, a verb or an adjective, not even when applied to the President of the United States!''

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split in March 1985.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Ultimately, the great lesson of Martin Luther King, Jr.'s life was this: He was a great man who wrested justice from the heart of a great country - and he succeeded because that great country had a heart to be seized.'' - President Reagan. [ A14:4. ]

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Primarily attributable to an $11,997,000 after-tax gain on the sale of EAB's former administrative building in Roosevelt Field, Long Island. c-Net loss

title: Persico Trial Witness Reports Project Payoffs
description: A concrete contractor testified yesterday that he had illegally paid more than $800,000 to a former union official who told him much of the money was going to the Colombo crime family and the ''club'' of organized-crime bosses who controlled the city's concrete industry.

title: DALLAS GETS KEY FURNITURE COLLECTION
description: The Dallas Museum of Art has agreed to purchase a Houston collection of 18th- and 19th-century American furniture that has been described as one of the most important such holdings in private hands. The collection is valued by experts at more than $5 million.

title: Mother Earth Needs More Children in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $63,250,000, or $1.07 a share, from the tax treatment of DISC.

title: NEW CHARGES ADD TO BRITISH FUROR
description: New disclosures and charges added today to the political furor over the future of an insolvent helicopter company, appearing to undercut the position of the Cabinet minister responsible for carrying out Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policies in the affair.

title: Harm to Capital Subway Seen
description: The budget cuts announced today could drive the Washington area subway system into default, according to the Congressional Budget Office and the White House Office of Management and Budget, but they called that possibility a correctable oversight.

title: RIDLEY SCORES TWO IN RANGER VICTORY
description: Mike Ridley is the rookie in many classic ways: He is shy, not a force in the locker room and still learning some of the nuances of playing in the big time. But he is learning well.

title: NAVY CITES 2 ACCIDENTS WITH NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Navy acknowleged today that it had experienced two accidents with nuclear weapons and 628 incidents with equipment associated with those weapons from 1965 through 1985.

title: U.S. PANEL LINKS A BANKER TO MARCOS
description: A House subcommittee has found evidence that a Philippine banker said to handle the personal finances of President Ferdinand E. Marcos played a key role in the acquisition of hundreds of millions of dollars in property in the United States, according to Congressional and Filipino sources.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There were no year-ago figures because the company recently began operations.

title: BENETTON'S CLUSTER STRATEGY
description: Seven years ago, Benetton, the Italian-based chain of midpriced apparel stores, had yet to enter the United States. Today, it seems to be everywhere.

title: S.E.C. Settles Goodrich Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the B. F. Goodrich Company today with failing to disclose all details of a $41 million ''greenmail'' payment to the investor Carl C. Icahn in November 1984. Goodrich simultaneously entered into a consent agreement, settling the case.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Synthetic Gas Price Ruling
description: A judge has ruled that four energy companies must pay the full price for gas produced at the nation's first commercial-scale synthetic fuels plant, even though it costs two and a half times the spot-market rate.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Less Expensive Plan for a West Side Rail Line
description: To the Editor:

title: West German Soldier Reported Missing
description: A noncommissioned officer with access to classified information has been missing from his West German Army unit in Munich for three weeks, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: ECUADOR'S PRESIDENT BACKS REAGAN POLICIES
description: President Leon Febres-Cordero of Ecuador, seeking American help to obtain $500 million in international loans, expressed strong support today for the Reagan Administration's free market philosophy and foreign policy objectives.

title: Books: Jazz Nobility
description: GOOD MORNING BLUES. By Count Basie, as told to Albert Murray. Illustrated. 399 pages. Random House. $19.95. IN the pantheon of jazz, Count

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Boston Consulting Group Inc. has named its president, John S. Clarkeson, to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: Sudeshna A. Chowdhury Is Wed to Shahiduz Zaman
description: Sudeshna Anwar Chowdhury, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anwarul Karim Chowdhury of New York and Dhaka, Bangladesh, was married in New York yesterday to Shahiduz Zaman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Khorshed Ali of Dhaka.

title: Aid Guatemala Doesn't Need
description: Those who want to see what transition to democracy in Guatemala looks like can begin by looking at the body of Beatriz Eugeni Barrios. Her face bears the marks of torture. Her hands rest on her stomach, her wrists severed. On her chest is carved in ballpoint pen the message, ''More is to come.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District of Maryland is offering $75.7 million of various purpose and storm water drainage bonds, through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank and Citibank.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS TO SCRAP A-ARMS WITHIN 15 YEARS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a broad timetable today for the elimination of all nuclear arms by the end of the century and announced a three-month extension of the Soviet moratorium on nuclear tests.

title: I Have a Dream
description: When Dr. King was alive, some who said they were opposed to segregation nevertheless harshly criticized him. He was mixing religion in politics, they said. He was too provocative. He was too impatient. He should allow time for the South to work out its racial problem.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SHULTZ SUPPORTS ARMED REPRISALS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States ''cannot wait for absolute certainty and clarity'' before using military force to strike at terrorists or countries that support them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 16, 1986
description: International A plan to eliminate all nuclear arms by the end of the century and a three-month extension of a Soviet moratorium on nuclear tests were proposed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. A statement by Mr. Gorbachev also included what diplomats said was a potentially new Soviet stance on medium-range arms in Europe. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Bridge: For Championship Players, No Standard Age to Retire
description: While company employees may retire routinely at 65, there is no standard age for bridge players. At one end of the scale, among New York experts, is Sam Stayman.

title: U.S. REGULATORS WANT BANKS TO COVER RISKY LOANS BETTER
description: The Federal Reserve Board and two other Federal agencies today proposed requiring banks to maintain more financial reserves for risky loans than for safer loans.

title: Ex-Legal Aid Director Named Correction Board Chairman
description: Mayor Koch has named Robert Kasanof, a lawyer and a former director of the Legal Aid Society, as the chairman of the city's Board of Correction. He will replace Peter Tufo, who has resigned after serving in the unsalaried position since 1975.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1984 results were restated to reflect merger of Peoples National Bank of North Jersey, accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: COURT THROWS OUT LIBEL SUIT FILED AGAINST CBS BY COLONEL
description: A $44 million libel suit that a retired Army lieutenant colonel filed about a CBS News broadcast of ''60 Minutes'' was thrown out yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: Where War on the Mob Must Start
description: President Reagan asked for it and now he's got it, from his own Commission on Organized Crime. He boasted only a few days ago about his effective war against the underworld. Now the commission rises to remind him how the Administration's dealings with Jackie Presser of the Teamsters undermine that campaign. Those ''contacts,'' the commission asserts, ''can lead to an erosion of public confidence and dampen the desire to end racketeering.''

title: Looking at Budget Grist
description: The talk of official Washington yesterday was mostly budget talk. Copies of the Federal Register were received with more than usual interest on Capitol Hill, as they contained the Government's first round of automatic cuts under the budget-balancing law sponsored by Senators Phil Gramm and Warren B. Rudman.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FLUORESCENT lighting is much more efficient than incandescent - a 40-watt fluorescent tube will give off five or six times more light and last five or six times longer than a 40-watt incandescent bulb.

title: TOP FARM GROUP TO PICK LEADER IN TOUGH TIMES
description: In its first contested election since 1980, the most influential of the country's farm organizations will choose a new president Thursday to lead it in a time of turmoil for American farmers.

title: 3 DISTRICTS CITED FOR HIGH SCORES ON READING TEST
description: Two school districts in Queens and one in the Bronx had the best overall performance on citywide reading tests administered last spring, according to figures released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Advertising; Top D'Arcy Executive Is Leaving the Agency
description: Hal Bay is leaving D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the country's sixth-largest agency, which he, as chief executive of D'Arcy MacManus Masius, a largely Middle Western agency, helped put together last year. He is 48 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday on Mike Garcia, the former Cleveland Indian pitcher, misstated the major league record for team victories in a season. The Chicago Cubs hold the record, with 116 in 1906.

title: C.D. Yields Inch Up In Week
description: The average yield for a six-month certificate of deposit was up for the week ended yesterday, the first increase since Oct. 30. Bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds moved lower.

title: SHUN 'STAR WARS,' SHEVARDNADZE URGES IN TOKYO
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Tokyo today and promptly urged the Japanese not to take part in the United States space defense program.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. PANEL WARNS OF CANCER RISK FROM CHEWING TOBACCO AND SNUFF
description: A Government panel today issued one of the strongest warnings to date against smokeless tobacco, saying that the use of snuff and chewing tobacco endangered health and increased the risk of mouth and throat cancer.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thanks, George
description: Moments after he had accepted the George S. Halas Trophy, emblematic of the National Conference championship, Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears acknowledged with an unaccustomed gush of sentiment the other day that the former owner of the Bears, who died in 1983, had played a role in the victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Staff Rehired
description: The San Diego Padres have rehired their entire coaching staff, and that includes the third-base coach, Ozzie Virgil, whose dismissal last November led to speculation that Manager Dick Williams would leave the team. Virgil said at the time he believed they let him go in an effort to get his longtime friend Williams to quit. Williams has since agreed to return to the Padres with no assurances that his contract will be extended after 1986.

title: Dance/U.S.A. to Honor Graham and Tudor
description: Martha Graham and Antony Tudor will be honored this weekend for their contributions to dance at a conference in Atlanta sponsored by Dance/ U.S.A., a national service organization based in Washington.

title: Black & Decker Stock Offering
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said yesterday that it was offering about $171 million of common stock in the United States and overseas at $20.125 a share, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bubka Does 19-3 For Indoor Best
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union, the world outdoor record-holder in the pole vault, set the world indoor best today, and Ben Johnson of Canada lowered the world indoor best in the 60-meter dash at the '86 Yomiuri International Indoor Track and Field Meet.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY SCHWARTZ
description: ELLIOTT SCHWARTZ'S music combines so many disparate elements that it moves beyond eclecticism into its own genre - multifaceted yet self-contained. A 50th-birthday concert at Symphony Space on Tuesday night offered an engaging retrospective of the composer's work over the past three decades.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TOWN & COUNTRY JEWELRY MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GILBERT UPSETS MCENROE
description: What worries John McEnroe the most is that he is losing more than just the grip on his tennis racket. A practice session or two can correct a flaw in his game, but it will take something more than hard work for McEnroe to rediscover the enthusiasm and zeal that enabled him to become the No. 1 player in the world and one of the best in history by the time he was 25 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: COLLECTIBLES PRICE GUIDES DOING NICELY
description: A GROWING fascination with American collectibles has stimulated a highly competitive market in price guides, published annually and used for appraisals by individual collectors, dealers and even auction galleries.

title: BERRY SAYS HIS JOB IS 'ALL-CONSUMING'
description: As the New England Patriots have reached heights unknown in the history of the franchise, Raymond Berry has sometimes sounded overwhelmed when discussing the demands of his job as the head coach.

title: THE DANCE: BILL CRATTY
description: THE dance festival at the Joyce Theater continued Tuesday night with a performance by the Bill Cratty Dance Theater that suggested that Mr. Cratty is a promising young choreographer. His works varied in quality. Yet it was interesting to see how he responded to the challenges he set himself.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Really Useful Unit
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's company, the Really Useful Group, has been valued at $50.8 million after a public tender for five million shares in the concern, a spokesman said. The company holds the copyright on several works by the 37-year-old British composer, who wrote such musicals as ''Cats'' and ''Evita.'' Analysts said the issue had received a lukewarm reception.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After pretax provisions for possible losses and writeoffs of $6.9 million for the quarter and $14.3 million for the year and a gain of $1 million for the year on the sale of securities. c-Net income.

title: CONCERT: A YOUTH ORCHESTRA
description: THE National Orchestra of New York, a youth ensemble sponsored by the National Orchestral Association and conducted by Alvaro Cassuto, commissioned the chairman of the Composer's Union of the Russian Federation, Rodion Shchedrin, to provide a new work for its first concert of the new year. The composer responded with a suite extracted from his ballet ''Chaika'' (''The Seagull,'' based on Chekhov), which accordingly had its premiere Tuesday at Carnegie Hall.

title: CLINTON RENEWAL PROPOSAL RAISES FEARS OVER EFFECTS OF 2 HIGH-RISES
description: At its hearing yesterday, the City Planning Commission was officially only reviewing plans for two apartment towers for 10th Avenue in the Clinton section of Manhattan. But the real subject was much deeper. It was the very future of Clinton itself, and the question of to what extent this complex and ramshackle neighborhood on the west side of midtown Manhattan ought to be rebuilt at all.

title: PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Title Stripped
description: The Canadian Professional Boxing Federation has stripped Trevor Berbick of his heavyweight title because of inactivity and has sanctioned a Jan. 30 title bout in Edmonton between the No. 1-ranked contender Ken Lakusta and the No. 2-ranked Conroy Nelson to fill the vacancy.

title: HERS
description: I'M 36. How old is that? Well, this year some of my work was printed in an anthology of ''younger poets,'' so that makes me young, at least compared with some other practitioners of my craft. To my mathematical friend Maria, however, I've been middle-aged for years: take 75 as the average life span, she points out in her logical way, and the middle third begins at 25. And it gets worse: if I decided to have a child, I'd be positively decrepit, what obstetricians disapprovingly call an ''elderly primagravida'' - unless the doctor is very up to date indeed and refers to me tactfully as ''reproductively mature.''

title: PEN TALKS ON FREEDOM OF THE WORD
description: Nations that imprison, censor and abuse writers came under attack yesterday, at the midway point of the weeklong International PEN Congress in New York.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TINKERING LEADS TO REWARDS
description: Tell an accomplished tinker of a new role for a long-existing piece of equipment and he will not rest until he has done you one better.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A MEMPHIS EXHIBIT
description: Memphis/Milano, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6868.

title: Masonite Fills Key Position
description: The Masonite Corporation, a subsidiary of the USG Corporation, announced today that A.J.

title: Moore Lost to Spurs
description: The San Antonio Spurs' veteran point guard, Johnny Moore, is out for the season, receiving treatment for a rare form of meningitis, according to team officials and physicians at a San Antonio hospital.

title: SOUTHERN BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 31.

title: The Minimum Wage: A Sinking Floor
description: The day President Reagan took office, the minimum wage was $3.35 an hour - $134 for a 40-hour week. It still is. But $3.35 does not buy what it did in 1981. After adjusting for inflation, the value of that wage has declined by 25 percent. In fact, for the first time in nearly four decades, it has fallen below 40 percent of the average private hourly wage. The minimum wage should be raised to $4.33 - that is, $173.20 a week - to restore it to its traditional level of 50 percent of the average private hourly wage.

title: MANES MOVED FROM QUEENS TO THE N.Y.U. MEDICAL CENTER
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, who was seriously injured last week during what he said was a kidnapping, was transferred yesterday from a Queens hospital to the New York University Medical Center.

title: Liberal Leaders in Israel Establish a New Party
description: Prominent leaders of the Liberal Party who opposed its partnership with Herut in the Likud bloc announced the establishment today of an independent party to be called the Liberal Center.

title: Man Sought in Israel for Attacks on Arabs Is Seized
description: Federal marshals yesterday arrested a New York law student who is wanted in Israel on charges of planning and carrying out armed attacks on Arabs.

title: DEPUTY CHIEF OF PARKING BUREAU CHARGED WITH EXTORTING $5,000
description: A deputy director of the city's Parking Violations Bureau was charged yesterday with extortion in what Federal officials described as a widening inquiry into thousands of dollars in bribes paid to city officials by private collection agencies.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Fire Damages Cruise Liner
description: A fire broke out aboard the cruise liner Oceanic while it was in port tonight, forcing the evacuation of its crew, the authorities said.

title: Building a Shrine In Cincinnati
description: As halls of fame go, the Communiplex Women's Sports Hall of Fame has not enjoyed an especially sacred beginning.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GEM SESSION When it comes to gems, the mind rarely turns, as it ought to, to the American Museum of Natural History, 81st Street and Central Park West (873-1300). Yet it is here and not among the jewelers of Fifth Avenue that the largest cut gem in the world is housed and, starting today, on view to the public.

title: Union Carbide
description: A Federal district judge in New Haven yesterday denied the Union Carbide Corporation's request that the GAF Corporation be required to notify it before making further purchases of Carbide stock. The decision follows last week's announcement by Samuel J. Heyman, chairman of GAF, that his company would end its efforts to take over the giant chemicals company after Carbide had countered GAF's $74-a-share bid with an $85-a-share stock buyback package.

title: OFFICIALS BRACING FOR FUTURE CUTS
description: Local officials in New York and the metropolitan region were hardly happy with Federal budget cuts that were outlined today, but they were far more concerned with the shape - and size - of cuts to come.

title: BALTIMORE'S STORY OF CITY HOMESTAEDING
description: THE Guinness Book of World Records has not yet established a ''waiting-in-line-to-buy-a-house'' category - (''That's not something that would be of any interest,'' said a Guinness spokesman) - so it is only speculation that Catherine Van Allen is a possible record-breaker.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures were restated to reflect the pooling of interests from the Arltru Bancorp merger in August 1985 and the Seymour Trust Co. merger in October 1985.

title: Municipal Hospital in Bronx Fined on Care of AIDS Victim
description: Bronx Municipal Hospital has been fined $31,000 for not providing adequate care last year to a man suffering from AIDS, State Health Department officials said today.

title: APPLE WOOS BUSINESS MARKET
description: Apple Computer Inc. will announce faster and more powerful models of its Macintosh computer and Laserwriter printer on Thursday, as well as some corporate alliances intended to spur sales of the Macintosh to businesses.

title: Chesire Kitten Wins in Florida
description: Chesire Kitten scored an upset in the first division of the $40,000-added Suwanee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park today.

title: Ruins of Chinese City Found
description: The ruins of an 800-year-old city have been discovered in the northeastern province of Jilin, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: FIGHTING IN SOUTHERN YEMEN CONTINUES FOR 3D DAY
description: Fighting continued for a third day in Southern Yemen today between supporters of the Marxist Government of President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani and Communist hard-liners trying to mount a coup, according to reports reaching here.

title: New Councilman Invited by Harlem Leaders
description: Before his election to the City Council last November, Hilton B. Clark, a 41-year-old Democratic district leader in Harlem, was known to toss the occasional brickbat at the door of the Harlem business establishment.

title: TOOLS FOR LEFT-HANDERS
description: HOUSEHOLD tools for the left-handed are listed in the new Lefthander's Catalog.

title: REPUBLICANS ATTACK BUDGET PROPOSAL
description: Governor Cuomo's $41.4 billion budget proposal drew criticism today from Republican leaders, who charged that he had concealed a $300 million surplus that could be used for the tax cuts they were seeking.

title: FALWELL BUYS A CABLE-TV NETWORK
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the leader of Moral Majority, has purchased a cable-television network, which he will call the Liberty Broadcasting Network.

title: FRIGID DAY: CURSE FOR SOME, A BLESSING FOR OTHERS
description: It was a busy day for auto mechanics and purveyors of winter attire. It was a rough one for sidewalk food vendors and those who appreciate a leisurely evening stroll.

title: RUSH IS TO INTERIOR AS CALIFORNIA GROWTH SHIFTS
description: This is the town the Okies called ''the end of the line.''

title: Liberian President Shuffles Cabinet
description: Liberia's President, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, shuffled his Cabinet today, ousting or transferring six ministers.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $822,000 for the quarter and $1,087,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REAGAN, WELCOMING GORBACHEV PLAN, SAYS HE'LL STUDY IT CAREFULLY
description: President Reagan said today that he welcomed the comprehensive arms-control proposal of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and would study it carefully.

title: Market Place; Traders Watch GTE's Sprint
description: A DIRECTORS meeting of the GTE Corporation that is scheduled for today may shed light on one of Wall Street's hottest recurring rumors. Only last week it sent the company's stock to new highs. According to this conjecture, the telephone and communications equipment company plans to spin off its big money-loser, the Sprint long-distance network.

title: 'LAW AND ORDER,' ABOUT STREET POLICE
description: TRACY ROBINSON, a New York City police officer, is so appealing as she patrols her beat in Laurelton, Queens, patting the heads of children and pressing the flesh of storekeepers, that she looks good enough to be a real fictional cop on ''Cagney & Lacey.''

title: THE 'GOOD BLOKE' (AND U.S. BUDDY) DOWN UNDER
description: On a popular satirical television show that lampoons everyone from the Pope to politicians, a character resembling President Reagan is asked about the Australian Prime Minister.

title: Los Angeles Unit
description: The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power is offering $50 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.05 percent for bonds due in 2026, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Yields on shorter maturities ranged from 6.40 percent for bonds due in 1992 to 7 percent in 1995, 7.60 percent in 2000, 7.85 percent in 2005 and 8 percent in 2009. According to underwriters, the bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: AID TO ANTI-SANDINISTAS WEIGHED
description: Congress would probably approve $30 million to $50 million in military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels if the aid request from the Administration ''is done right,'' a spokesman for the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today.

title: Liberty Artifacts on Loan For Library Exhibition
description: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi is not exactly a household name in France. And he lived only a few years of his life in Colmar, the Alsatian city where he was born.

title: President to Enter Hospital For Cancer Surgery Checkup
description: President Reagan is scheduled to enter the Bethesda Naval Hospital on Friday for a follow-up examination of his colon, from which a cancerous tumor was removed last July, the White House announced today.

title: BAKER EFFORT ON RATES IS SEEN
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, having led the multinational drive to lower the value of the dollar, will discuss with West Germany, Japan, France and Britain this weekend the possibility of forcing down global interest rates, a West German minister said today.

title: BIG CHANGE IN ANTITRUST LAW URGED
description: The White House said today that President Reagan would ask Congress for sweeping antitrust law changes.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOAH GOLDSTEIN
description: Noah Goldstein, a former New York Civil Court judge, died of cancer Saturday at Long Beach (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: OFFICER CHASED BY POLICE IS SHOT
description: A probationary off-duty New York City police officer, who the police said had been driving his car erratically, was shot by another officer after a seven-block automobile chase on Staten Island, police officials said.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUT A BIG TRIM IN 1987 COULD BE DISASTEROUS, SOME OFFICIALS SAY
description: The Administration said today that $11.7 billion in 1986 spending cuts, announced today under the new budget-balancing law, could be achieved with ''a minimum of disruption.''

title: Republic Bank Expands Profit
description: The Republic New York Corporation, which owns the Republic National Bank of New York, reported yesterday that it earned $32 million, or $1.59 a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $25.2 million, or $1.33 a share, a year earlier.

title: NEWORLD BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $612,000 for the quarter and $1,617,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $429,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net loss

title: 159 FILE FOR BASEBALL HEARINGS
description: Don Mattingly, Dwight Gooden, Fernando Valenzuela, Tim Raines and Wade Boggs were among a record-breaking number of baseball players who filed for salary arbitration yesterday. If any of those five stars reach the hearing stage, baseball should also have a record arbitration award.

title: RECITAL: RICHARD LUBY, VIOLIN
description: THE violinist Richard Luby and the pianist Phyllis Rappaport teamed up for a first-rate program at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night.

ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Freebies
description: Culture and diplomacy often overlap in Washington. The latest incident came yesterday morning in the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, where two events were scheduled: a meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d and President Leon Febres Cordero of Ecuador, and a news conference related to the National Gallery's new exhibition on Impressionist paintings, which is to open tomorrow.

title: Fox Posts Earnings
description: The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation today reported net earnings of $2.2 million for the first quarter, ended Nov. 30, compared with a loss of $12.4 million for the comparable period last year.

title: Cheeks to Cheeks
description: ''Some awards are just awards,'' said Senator Bill Bradley, who counts a Rhodes scholarship, an Olympic gold medal and numerous political honors among his prizes. ''But this award - this is one a man can be proud of.''

title: U.S. CITES VICTIM IN CLOSE OF SKIMMING TRIAL
description: A former casino owner who borrowed money from a teamsters' union pension fund was victimized and lost his company to gangsters, a Federal prosecutor said today in closing arguments in the trial of five reputed organized crime figures.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ST. JOHN'S TIES FOR FIRST
description: Lou Carnesecca was a little concerned that his nationally ranked St. John's team would come out flat tonight against the Seton Hall Pirates, who are in last place in the Big East Conference.

title: Youngest University From Old Institution
description: New York's youngest university is one of its oldest.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, said its American Airlines unit had introduced special fares for the elderly, giving them a 10 percent discount on any of the airline's fares.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $886,000 for the quarter and 9 months from equity in loss from discontinued operations of an affiliate and extraordinary gains of $137,000 for the quarter $456,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a loss of $839,000 from equity in loss from discontinued operations of an affiliate.

title: Leader of Worldwide Church Names Aide to Succeed Him
description: Herbert W. Armstrong, 93 years old, the ailing founder of the Worldwide Church of God, has named a successor to replace him as pastor general in the event of his death.

title: Owner of 'Faberge' Egg Is Suing Christie's
description: The owner of a Russian jeweled and enameled egg filed suit against Christie's for $37 million in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, claiming fraud and misrepresentation in the sale of the egg to him in Geneva in April 1977.

title: In 750 Words
description: On undertaking this column 13 years ago, I mentioned to Joseph Kraft, a former Kennedy speechwriter who had turned columnist 10 years before, that I felt comfortable with economics and foreign affairs, but wondered about pontificating on those matters about which I did not know beans.

title: Nisshin Steel, Wheeling Pact
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said it signed agreements today with the Nisshin Steel Company of Japan to build a $65 million plant for coating sheet steel. The venture had been delayed since October 1983 by the American company's financial trouble.

title: Stop Demolition of Sound Housing in New York
description: To the Editor:
