title: REAGAN TELLS PUPILS OF STRUGGLE WON BY DR. KING
description: Continuing his personal involvement in ceremonies honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., President Reagan told black schoolchildren today that the slain civil rights leader ''was a great man who wrested justice from the heart of a great country.''

title: Advertising; Another Ross Roy Acquisition
description: Ross Roy Inc. in Detroit is going to acquire Calet, Hirsch & Spector here on Jan. 31 just four months after it bought the Griswold agency in Cleveland.

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Good Ol' What's-her-name
description: Most members of Congress are back home these days, traveling their districts and trying to convince the home folks they have not ''gone Washington.'' Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma was at a community forum in Okemah recently, and when a voter asked a question about a local problem the Senator suggested he contact his state legislator.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 15
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for 4 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 3.

title: Missile Company Agrees To Clean Up Site in West
description: State and Federal officials reached agreement with a California missile manufacturer today for the company to pay for cleaning up contaminated soil and water in the soil at its facility in Rancho Cordova, east of Sacramento.

title: Bonner Could Leave Hospital Next Week
description: Yelena G. Bonner was walking around her hospital room today and may be back at her family's home in suburban Newton as early as next week, hospital officials said.

title: G.E.'S INCOME UP 1.2% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter edged up 1.2 percent on a 9.4 increase in sales.

title: METS SIGN JOHNSON TO 3-YEAR CONTRACT
description: The Mets signed Davey Johnson to a three-year contract yesterday to remain as their manager, and conceded they had done it chiefly to forestall any chance that he might retire once they had won the World Series.

title: ISLANDERS STUNNDED BY RALLY
description: The Penguins scored four goals in a five-minute span of the third period tonight and went on to beat the Islanders, 6-3.

title: Bacteria Experiment On Berries Faces Fight
description: A state permit went into effect today allowing a company to release genetically engineered bacteria into the environment, but opponents are seeking to halt the experiment.

title: Hold the Pancake, Mr. Bush
description: Will Vice President Bush make a cameo appearance as a squint-eyed Federal drug-buster on the hit television series ''Miami Vice''?

title: Tours for Tickets
description: Anybody trying to get Super Bowl tickets at this late date is on his own, of course, but anybody trying to get rid of them will find help at a New Orleans travel agency that has hit upon a distinctive enticement.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Including a net credit of $1.6 million from an accounting change and a net gain of $1.4 million from the reduction of LIFO inventories. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $311,000 and a net gain of $200,000 from the reduction of LIFO inventories.

title: 'JEWS OF MOSCOW' ON 13
description: WHO are the Soviet Jews?

title: COMEX GOLD AT $349.50; PRICE HIGHEST SINCE '84
description: Gold prices staged their largest one-day spurt in nearly a year yesterday, largely on a sudden flurry of buying that hit the European markets, much of it reportedly on behalf of interests in the Middle East.

title: MIXING POLITICS AND LITERATURE
description: WHEN the Indian writer Salman Rushdie put it to Saul Bellow at the PEN Congress that writers had ''the task'' of explaining how the United States is seen in the world, Mr. Bellow responded: ''We don't have 'tasks.' We have inspirations.''

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Conrail Posts a Profit
description: Despite a general downturn in railroad business, Conrail says it had a good year in 1985, earning $440 million and increasing its cash reserves. The figures prove, according to the Government-owned railroad, that it should be allowed to remain independent instead of merging with another railroad.

title: PENTAGON SAYS SOVIET HAS LAUNCHED FIRST CARRIER
description: The Soviet Union has launched its first full-scale aircraft carrier from a shipyard on the Black Sea and has begun building a second, the Pentagon said today.

title: Options Kept By Big Board
description: After months of considering whether to drop one of the two stock index options contracts it trades, the New York Stock Exchange has decided to retain both. The exchange, however, will bring in new specialists to handle trading in the contracts, according to an exchange official.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Tops in the Nets
description: Not since Billy Smith of the Islanders posted 32 victories in 1981-82 has a goaltender from a New York team led the National Hockey League in that category at the end of a season. But the Rangers' 2-1 success over Vancouver on Tuesday night put John Vanbiesbrouck atop the league. These are most frequently triumphant goalies in the N.H.L., heading into last night's play: John Vanbiesbrouck, Rangers19-11-2 Andy Moog, Edmonton18-4-4 Rejean Lemelin, Calgary16-15-3 Bob Froese, Philadelphia16-7-0 Al Jensen, Washington16-6-2 Tom Barrasso, Buffalo15-12-5 Mike Liut, Hartford14-12-1 Grant Fuhr, Edmonton13-5-0 Patrick Roy, Montreal13-7-0

title: HIGGINS'S FAST GOAL WINS IN OVERTIME
description: Perhaps a tie would have been more fitting for a game between two uninspired teams, but Tim Higgins of the Devils spoiled everything tonight.

title: Advertising; Ted Bates Unit Gets Shoemaker's Business
description: AC&R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been appointed agency for Marx & Newman, a maker of shoes, after a competition with two other agencies.

title: TV'S, VIDEO CAMERAS EGT SMALLER, HANDIER
description: AT the Consumer Electronics Show, stretched across an arena as big as 10 football fields, 1,400 exhibitors peddled the newest and trendiest toys for adults. More than 100,000 salesmen, distributors, store owners and reporters walked through acres of compact disk players, combination video cameras and recorders, television sets small enough to be carried in a pocket, telephones shaped like bananas, and sky-blue microwave ovens. The show was at this city's convention center and, by invitation only, in suites tucked away at many of the major hotels.

title: Topics; Coffin Nails/Cats First Pets
description: Rex, the Presidential dog, has just had a tonsillectomy. It was performed at an ''undisclosed location,'' doubtless to guard his privacy, and the patient is doing well.

title: Politics; Frankly, Democrats Want the South
description: Perhaps not since Rhett Butler's determined and difficult courtship of Scarlett O'Hara in ''Gone With The Wind'' have such advances been made below the Mason-Dixon line.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $6.2 million, or 14 cents a share, from the recovery on disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $78.6 million for the quarter and $25.2 million for the year and a loss of $70.6 million for the year from recovery on disposal of discontinued operations. Year-ago period earnings include a gain of $40 million form changes in DISC tax law.

title: Sutton Shares Lead With a 65
description: Hal Sutton, with a swing change and a new set of clubs, shot a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a share of the first-round lead today in the $600,000 Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: 76ERS STOPPED BY NETS
description: About an hour before game time tonight, the Philadelphia 76ers learned they would be without Charles Barkley, who was averaging 17.7 points and 10.5 rebounds a game and had played a key role in a victory over the Nets 24 hours earlier. The second-year forward sat out the game with lower back pains and the Nets easily defeated the 76ers, 123-89.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM PLANS A MAJOR RESTRUCTURING
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that it would restructure the company by forming a holding company, refinancing bank debt and issuing new preferred stock and subordinated debt securities.

title: Topics; Coffin Nails/Cats Military Casualties
description: At a New York City supermarket, a carton of filter cigarettes might cost $11.67. At a military commissary, the price might be only $5.75. That's because taxpayers subsidize cigarettes sold to the military, one of the fringe benefits of wearing the uniform. Some benefit. In making cigarettes cheap, the military aids and abets an enemy of health - a habit that is very hard to break and is responsible for 9 of 10 lung cancers, a third of all heart-disease deaths and the vast majority of deaths from emphysema and chronic bronchitis.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALTIMORE BROKER SETS PUBLIC OFFER
description: Alex. Brown Inc., the holding company for the nation's oldest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had decided to go public and will sell $40 million in stock.

title: Statement Denies Abu Nidal Spoke With Arab Newspaper
description: A man claiming to be a spokesman for Abu Nidal denied in a statement published today that the Palestinian guerrilla leader was interviewed by an Arab newspaper.

title: Market Closes Higher; Dow Up 8.25
description: A decline in interest rates yesterday sent the stock market broadly higher. Trading picked up somewhat from the relatively depressed levels of earlier in the week.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a pretax provision of $4 million for a patent judgment liability.

title: 'Star Wars' Software Is Beyond Our Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: JIM CROWLEY, FINAL MEMBER OF FOUR HORSEMEN, IS DEAD
description: Jim Crowley, the small, swift halfback who galloped into sports lore as one of the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame and later coached the Seven Blocks of Granite at Fordham, died yesterday at a nursing home in Scranton, Pa., after a long illness.

title: The Manes Nightmare
description: Nightmare may be the only word for the ordeal of Queens Borough President Donald Manes and his family, and he's far from recovered. The physical and emotional torment cry out for sympathy.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 16, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.

title: EXPRESSIONS OF TASTE: FIVE NEW DESIGN STORES
description: IF a lesson is to be learned from the new shops featuring modern furnishings and home accessories around town, it is that the stores themselves are excellent signposts to the latest design trends. The interiors incorporate such up-and-coming ideas as smooth pastel plaster walls, custom-crafted iron windows and rough cement floors. In these special environments, merchandise usually reflects the personal taste of the shop owners and ranges from one-of-a-kind art furniture to clean-lined modern accessories.

title: WINTER COLOR IN NIDOOR PLANTS
description: INDOOR flowering plants are welcome at this time of year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Commissioner Harry Usher of the United States Football League was discharged from St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif., six days after he underwent successful coronary bypass surgery and was reported to be in excellent condition. . . . After seven straight losing seasons, Jim Boyce resigned under pressure as basketball coach at Eastern Michigan and was replaced by his assistant, Ben Braun, for the rest of this season. Boyce's teams had an 84-94 record, including a 4-8 mark this season. . . . The 1984 Olympic gold medalist at 3,000 meters, Maricica Puica of Rumania, will compete in the three major indoor track meets here, the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational Feb. 8 at the Meadowlands and the Wanamaker Millrose Games, Feb. 14, and USA/Mobil Indoor Championships, Feb. 28, both at Madison Square Garden. . . . Jackie Joyner, a U.C.L.A. basketball standout who also broke American records in track and field last season, has been named the nation's top female collegiate athlete and awarded the Broderick Cup.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect the acquisitions of Atlantic Bancorp., Central Florida Bank Corp. and Northwestern Financial Corp., which were completed in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: EDITORI IS NAMED AT DALLAS PAPER
description: Shelby Coffey 3d, editor of U.S. News & World Report, has been named editor of The Dallas Times Herald, the newspaper announced today.

title: Single-Sex Education
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: For Richardson, Another Chance
description: Micheal Ray Richardson says he is a different person now. But he still sounds the same. There is still the high-strung sense of urgency in his voice that at times he simply cannot control -much like his addiction to cocaine.

title: SUPPORTER OF AQUINO IS KILLED
description: Gunmen today shot dead a local politician who had endorsed the opposition candidate for president, Corazon C. Aquino, the police and opposition officials said. It was the first killing believed linked to the presidential election campaign.

title: MAKING HISTORY COME ALIVE ON EDUCATIONAL TV
description: SEPT. 19, 1356. Opening shot in the cloister studio. Anchorman Robert of Fairfield reports the British victory over the French at Poitiers. Cut to correspondent Richard of Essex for an on-the-scene interview with Edward the Black Prince. Back to you, Robert, for an update on the plague. Inset high-tech graphic map of Europe, concentric circles spreading like the disease itself.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $159,000 for the quarter and $1,540,000 for the 9 months.

title: MISSILE DEFENSE SPARED IN MILITARY BUDGET CUTS
description: The Defense Department today disclosed details of $13.8 billion in budget cuts that mark the formal end of six consecutive years of military buildup.

title: CHANGING HABITS IN FLOWER BUYING
description: IN the past flowers were sold primarily by florists and were, for the most part, purchased as gifts for special occasions and holidays. Today, that bouquet is more likely to be a spur-of-the-moment purchase, perhaps bought from a street vendor, greengrocer or supermarket.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $884,000 for the quarter and $1,909,000 for the 9 months. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $936,000 for the quarter and $3,321,000 for the 9 months. Sales for the year-ago periods did not include Pittway net sales but included the company's share of Pittway's earnings on the equity method. The 1984 net was restated to reflect Brand Insulations as a discontinued operation due to the spin-off of Brand to Standard Shares stockholders in the current year.

title: Jacob Wiens, 75, Physicist; Teacher Worked on A-Bomb
description: Jacob H. Wiens, a nuclear physicist who worked on the development of the atomic bomb in World War II and who had a long college teaching career in California, died last Friday of heart failure at his home in Magalia, Calif. He was 75 years old. Dr. Wiens, who taught for 31 years at the College of San Mateo, was chairman of its physics faculty when he retired in 1973.

title: ARMY MOVE SHAKES TINY AFRICAN LAND
description: Hundreds of heavily armed troops surrounded the offices of the Prime Minister of Lesotho today, and firing was heard in the capital, Maseru. But the Government there denied that there had been an attempted coup.

title: OFFICER SAYS EFFORT AT INQUIRY ON SURGEON WAS THWARTED
description: A Navy hospital administrator testified today that his efforts to force an investigation of Comdr. Donal M. Billig, the former top heart surgeon at the Bethesda Naval Hospital, for questions of surgical incompetence and dishonesty were sharply criticized by superiors who accused him of trying to ruin the famed hospital's reputation.

title: Advertising; Polaroid Shuffles 2 of Its Assignments
description: The Polaroid Corporation has shifted a couple of accounts among its three agencies.

title: HOMELESS MAN, 19, SHOT DEAD AT CITY-RUN SHELTER
description: A homeless young man was shot and killed Tuesday afternoon in the recreation room of a city shelter. The slaying renewed complaints that the shelters are dangerous and that security is lax there.

title: THE DANCE: WORKS BY GERALD OTTE
description: GERALD OTTE displayed his versatility in ''Hot Dances for a Winter's Night'' on Sunday evening at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. All but one of the five works were choreographed by Mr. Otte, and all but one had electronic music by him.

title: Technology; Measuring Fat In a Patient
description: EVER since Eli Whitney developed the cotton gin in 1793 and helped get the Industrial Revolution under way, manufacturers, engineers and scientists have eagerly awaited new agricultural developments and the chance to adapt them to broader markets.

title: Cartier, Gump's
description: Cartier of New York said it was considering the purchase of the four Gump's home furnishings and gift stores owned by Macmillan Inc., the publishing company.

title: Prof. Daniel Saks, Economist In Carter Administration, Dies
description: Prof. Daniel H. Saks, senior staff economist for President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, died Tuesday after a long illness.

title: Freedom in the Malls
description: To the Editor:

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,164,000, or 65 cents a share, from the sale of Atlanta radio properties.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNITED CAROLINA BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Tuesday, about a lawsuit filed against the Federal Government by church organizations over sanctuary for illegal aliens, misstated the position of the American Lutheran Church. The church neither endorses nor opposes sanctuary; it permits congregations to take stands and has pledged to support whatever position a congregation takes.

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROTEST HINDERS KENNEDY IN CHILE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, arriving here today on a tour of South America, was forced to leave the airport by police helicopter after dozens of pro-Government demonstrators blocked a highway.

title: LIBERTY UNITED BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Two Michigan Prisoners Seize Four Hostages
description: Two inmates scheduled to be transferred from one maximum-security prison to another bolted from their guards today and took three employees and another inmate hostage at knifepoint, the authorities said.

title: READING SCORES IN CITY'S ELEMENTARY AND JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1985.

title: Advertising; Changes at the Top Of Kallir, Philips, Ross
description: Kallir, Philips, Ross, an ad agency in the health care field, announced major executive changes yesterday starting right at the top.

title: CITY BALLET: SERENE 'MOMENTUM'
description: ''MONUMENTUM PRO GESUALDO'' is George Balanchine at his most serenely elemental. The ballet is set to Stravinsky's muted reworking of music composed in the late 16th and early 17th centuries by Carlo Gesualdo. Like Stravinsky and Balanchine, Gesualdo was interested in developing artistic forms. The ballet both defines and extends the classical canon. And the New York City Ballet's performance of ''Monumentum'' on Tuesday at the New York State Theater revealed the ballet as the small, perfect jewel it is. As danced by Suzanne Farrell and Sean Lavery, this was a jewel that glowed with the pale, searing light of idealized Balanchinian purity.

title: NEW YORK'S PARKING BUREAU AND HOW IT WORKS
description: The Parking Violations Bureau, which is under investigation by Federal and city authorities, is a 16-year-old city agency responsible for collecting parking-ticket fines.

title: QADDAFI TO HELP ARAB 'TERRORISTS'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said tonight that Libya would train, arm and protect Arab guerrillas and other Arab volunteers for ''suicide and terrorist missions,'' and make his country a ''base for the liberation for Palestine.''

title: Trusthouse Forte Picks Executive for 2 Posts
description: Trusthouse Forte Inc., the American holding company of the British hotel chain, announced yesterday that Barry L. Conrad had been named president and chief executive officer of its North American hotels group, which includes the Westbury Hotel and the Plaza Athenee, both in Manhattan.

title: SCM Executives
description: SCM's chairman, Paul Elicker, and president, George Harris, will remain with the company after its acquisition by Hanson Trust, Lord Hanson said today. The decision follows a bitter takeover battle that ended Jan. 9. Hanson Industries, the British conglomerate's United States subsidiary, has started detailed appraisals of SCM, best known for its office equipment products.

title: Meese Weighs Texaco Battle
description: The Justice Department is studying separate requests by Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company for it to enter the legal battle between the companies, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said at a news conference in Washington.

title: SYRACUSE'S 13-VICTORY STREAK IS ENDED
description: Georgetown, which four days ago was outjumped and overpowered inside in a loss to St. John's, rebounded tonight with its most impressive performance of the season.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Bonds Post Sharp Price Gains
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday on speculation that economic officials from five leading industrial countries meeting this weekend will discuss the possibility of reducing interest rates.

title: A Governor's Ultimate Balance
description: Governor Cuomo has produced his second consecutive balanced budget for New York. It has grown to $41 billion (including Federal grants) and offers moderation in all things - plus a modest but welcome $150 million reduction in the longstanding $4.3 billion debt accumulated by many administrations. Protecting even that small redemption will require strong citizen support.

title: 2 Seek to Join Group
description: Italy and Canada have asked to join the Group of Five, monetary officials disclosed today.

title: NEC Tops a List
description: The NEC Corporation of Japan has taken the lead in annual worldwide semiconductor sales, according to preliminary estimates released by Dataquest Inc., a market research company based in Cupertino, Calif. NEC jumped from No. 3 on the Dataquest list to the top spot in 1985 with $1.98 billion in sales. Motorola Inc. remained No. 2 with $1.85 billion in sales and Texas Instruments Inc., which had held the top spot since the 1950's, fell to third, with $1.76 billion.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORPO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARTERIAL DISEASE TRACED TO YOUTH
description: The earliest stages of hardening of the arteries can be seen in teen-agers who have high cholesterol levels in the blood, and efforts to control this should begin in childhood, researchers say.

title: Brazil Debt Talks Set
description: Brazilian officials will meet with bankers in New York today in an attempt to reschedule $19 billion in long-term debt and to beat a deadline tomorrow, when $16 billion in other debt comes due.

title: Triborough Authority Sets $150 Million Issue
description: A $150 million issue of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with maximum yields of 9.42 percent for bonds due in 2016 and 9.31 percent for bonds due in 2006, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: 23.4% RISE IN DIGITAL NET AIDS STOCK
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation surprised Wall Street and sent technology stocks soaring yesterday with a strong quarterly earnings report that many in the industry said could mark the revival of the world's second-largest computer company.

title: Helping the Young
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: G.O.P. OPPOSITION TO MCGIVERN PAROLE
description: All 56 Republican members of the Assembly called on the State Parole Board today not to release a convicted murderer who has been granted clemency by Governor Cuomo.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $307,000.

title: PLIGHT OF HOMELESS KEY CONCERN IN GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: The plight of the homeless in a city of plenty is perhaps the concern expressed most often by contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A FRAME THAT SUITS THE PHOTO
description: SHE comes from Kentucky but for the past year Kathleen D. Karp, a photographer has been combining photographs of either New York City or the Southwest with her hand-made ceramic frames.

title: Quake Jolts Greek Resort
description: A moderate earthquake shook this seaside resort north of Athens today, causing no casualties or damage, officials said. The quake, which measured 4.4 on the Richter scale, was the second in 24 hours to hit Oropos, the Athens Seismological Institute said.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FIRST WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 16, 1986
description: The Economy

title: ASTRONAUTS READY FOR RETURN TODAY
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia, 25 days late going up, one day early coming down and unable to meet all their scientific goals, stowed equipment today to prepare for a landing Thursday.

title: THEATER COMMUNITY HONORS AUDREY WOOD
description: The playwrights she had nurtured, the producers she had challenged but who respected her, and hundreds of other members of the theatrical community paid tribute yesterday to Audrey Wood, the doyenne of agents, who died at age 80 on Dec. 27. She had been in a coma since suffering a stroke almost five years ago.

title: PEKING REJECTS MOSCOW NONAGGRESSION PACT
description: China today rejected a Soviet proposal that the two nations sign a mutual nonaggression treaty, saying Moscow had more concrete ways of improving relations if it chose to exercise them.

title: WILKINS SPARKS THE KNICKS
description: Gerald Wilkins says he has grown used to living in the imposing shadows of other players. For most of his life, he was known simply as the younger brother of Dominique Wilkins. Now, he is another rookie on the same team as Patrick Ewing.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in U. S. dollars. Rogers is a partially owned subsidiary of Rogers Cablesystems Inc. of Toronto which is listed on the over- the-counter.

title: El Salvador Promotes Officers Tied to Killings
description: Salvadoran military officials said today that two army officers, linked by Washington to right-wing death squads and later sent into exile under United States pressure, have received promotions.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chicago ECU Trading
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange opened trading today in the European Currency Unit, a composite of currencies in 10 member countries of the European Monetary System. The contract is 125,000 ECU's, quoted in United States dollars per ECU. The 10 currencies are the West German mark, French franc, British pound, Italian lira, Dutch guilder, Belgian franc, Danish krone, Greek drachma, Irish punt and Luxembourg franc.

title: Let's Put the Museum Back Into the Seaport
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank; Politics Rears Its Unquiet Head
description: Over the 40 years of its existence the Washington-based World Bank, now a lender of more than $15 billion a year to nearly 100 underdeveloped countries, has had only six presidents, all of them American.

title: U.S. SUPREME COURT LISTENS TO ARGUMENTS ON 'BABY DOE' RULES
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Federal Government had the authority to try to force life-prolonging medical treatment for severely handicapped newborn babies over the objections of their parents and doctors.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS BANK F A reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Stockholders voted at the annnual meeting to change the corporate name from Carteret Savings & Loan Association.

title: Provincetown Air
description: The Provincetown-Boston Airline, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last March, said it did not pay its employees as scheduled yesterday. The airline, based in Naples, Fla., said it missed the payroll because it had not negotiated a new debt agreement with its banks. The talks are continuing, the airline said, adding that it was operating all its flights on schedule and planned to issue a partial payroll next week.

title: FRENCH COMEDIAN WITH POLITICAL BITE
description: The most widely known person in France these days is probably not a politician or a writer or even a movie actor; it is arguably a rather round, provocative, often coarse and Rabelaisian 41-year-old comedian known as Coluche, whose stock in trade, as he has put it himself, is to be a ''pain in the neck'' to almost everybody.

title: DECISION FOLLOWS A DECADE OF LEGAL DISPUTES
description: A Federal appeals court's decision to throw out a libel suit brought against CBS by a retired Army lieutenant colonel comes after more than a decade of legal disputes and delays.

title: Julius H. Weitzner, 90, Dies; A Dealer in the Old Masters
description: Julius H. Weitzner, a leading dealer in Old Master paintings in New York and London for the last half century, died Tuesday at his home in London. He was 90 years old. Mr. Weitzner, a native of New York City, began his career as an art dealer in the late 1920's, when he opened the first of a succession of Manhattan galleries.

title: MUSIC: THE CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE Chamber Music Society was on television Sunday afternoon, so it came to Alice Tully Hall flashing its widest smile for the cameras. Thus this ''Live From Lincoln Center'' telecast began with a few jokes and featured a lot of entertainment, but still it wisely held on to its dignity and sophistication.

title: Household Plans A Stock Buyback
description: Household International Inc. said its board had approved the purchase of up to 11.5 million, or 22 percent, of the company's shares outstanding with cash from the sale of its merchandising unit. Household said it would pay $42 to $46 a share, based on the number of shares tendered and the price each shareholder specifies.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $16,035,000, or 84 cents per share, for the quarter and year. The company said per share results for the latest fourth quarter and year reflect lower dividend requirements on preferred stock.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax insurance proceeds of approximately $1.6 million from a fire claim.

title: 2 Fined for Fight
description: Jawann Oldham, the Chicago Bulls' 7-foot-1-inch center, was suspended for one game without pay and fined $1,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for fighting with 7-6 3/4 Manute Bol, the Washington Bullet rookie who was fined $500. The skirmish took place in the fourth quarter of Tuesday night's game in Chicago, which the Bullets won, 117-113.

title: Ulster's Ancient Capital Unites Northern Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC EXPECTED TO SEE VARIOUS SMALL EFFECTS IN FEDERAL PROGRAMS
description: Doctors will receive less for treating elderly Medicare patients. Nonprofit organizations may have to pay higher postage for fund-raising letters. College students will be charged more for Government-guaranteed loans.

title: Inventories Up 0.2% as Sales Jump
description: Business inventories rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in November, while sales were soaring by 1.5 percent, the strongest increase since August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEBANESE CHRISTIANS OUST MILITIA LEADER
description: Christian supporters of a Syrian-sponsored pact for peace in Lebanon were defeated today in fierce clashes that engulfed Christian areas north and northeast of here.

title: DWIGHT GOODEN'S ANKLE
description: The Royals had lost the first two games of the World Series in Kansas City, but now they had won the third game, 6-1, on a six-hitter with eight strikeouts by Bret Saberhagen, who would be voted the Cy Young Award in the American League after a 20-6 season. In the St. Louis Cardinals' clubhouse, Terry Pendleton, their third baseman, was being asked to compare the Royals' 21-year-old right-hander to Dwight Gooden, the Mets' right-hander who had been a 24-game winner at age 20.

title: 13 Engineers at Pictel Meet Phone Deadline
description: Thirteen engineers and entrepreneurs at the Pictel Corporation met a multimillion-dollar deadline last week by developing a picture telephone.

title: DENISON MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $240,739,000 writedown of its investment in the Quintette Coal Ltd. operations. c-Net income

title: BUDGET CUTS TO AFFECT U.S CULTURAL PROGRAMS
description: Federal officials said today that the 4.3 percent reduction in the nonmilitary budget for the current year would be applied across the board for cultural programs, with most recipients having to share part of the cuts but with no programs being canceled outright.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. The company did not report share earnings for the latest fourth quarter.

title: O'Connor Postpones His Visit to Lebanon
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has postponed a trip to Lebanon ''on the advice of high church officials'' in that strife-torn country, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday.

title: PIPER, JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: Batus to Release 3 Top Officials
description: After more than 25 years in the business, no one has to tell Arnold H. Aronson that retailing is a tough game. But events over the last few days may have forced the veteran executive to redefine just how tough.

title: Challenging the Thesis of a Palestine 'Uninhabited' in 1880
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER BOWL FEVER
description: Doctor, Doctor, thank you for seeing me so soon. I've had these symptoms ever since Sunday night, and I just wasn't myself. You know how my system can normally throw off all common ailments, but this one has me worried.

title: MUSIC: LEINSDORF CONDUCTS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: ERICH LEINSDORF is a conductor whose limitations, some of them apparently self-imposed, are clear. In music demanding great rhythmic vitality or dramatic thrust, he regularly falls back on a kind of workmanlike precision that is often admirable enough in itself but beside the musical point. He applies his attention to the cosmetic surface of a score more assiduously than to its meaningful core. And so on, as any follower of this veteran's career might testify.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: One of the largest new residential buildings to rise in the Chelsea district of Manhattan in recent years is in construction on West 19th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and its development history illustrates how zoning shapes such projects.

description: If it's O.K. for Rambo and O.K. for Rocky it is certainly O.K. for George Washington.

title: Moody's Rates C.D.'s
description: Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday that it had begun rating bank certificates of deposit and other bank instruments, such as obligations to deliver foreign exchange, bankers' acceptances and interbank placements.

title: GOLD JUMPS IN HECTIC TRADING
description: The gold market, defying several bearish influences, staged one of its most powerful rallies in years, only to fall back nearly as sharply toward the end of trading yesterday.

title: SCREEN: 'ADVENTURES OF MARK TWAIN'
description: ''THE ADVENTURES OF MARK TWAIN,'' which opens today at the 23d Street West Triplex and other theaters, is virtually unclassifiable. It's a G-rated fantasy designed, I would think, for young children. Yet it's so unusually literate that, I suspect, only adults, and maybe only adults who are Mark Twain scholars, might fully understand what's going on. Then, too, it's shot in Claymation, a patented, stop-motion animation process that one can admire without much liking.

title: 3 STATES CHARGED WITH VIOLATING ASBESTOS RULES
description: The Justice Department today charged three states, Conrail, a New Jersey school district and other defendants with violating Federal standards for the handling of asbestos, a cancer-causing air pollutant.

description: Seven young people pleaded guilty today to charges of using their home computers to break into confidential equipment and telephone files of the Pentagon and A.T.&T. They were each given one year of unsupervised probation.

description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, who returned today from an official visit to Yugoslavia, said in a speech in Belgrade Wednesday night that a distinction must be made between terrorism and actions of liberation movements.

title: TITLE BOUT A CLASH OF CHECKERED CAREERS
description: Tony Tubbs, the undefeated World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, and Tim Witherspoon, his challenger in tonight's title fight in Atlanta, share the dubious knack of having on occasion been their own worst enemies in a business where there is never a dearth of enemies.

title: PATRIOTS EAGER TO HIT THE ROAD
description: Raymond Berry looked a little concerned. After his team finished its first day of work at Sullivan Stadium in preparation for the game against the Chicago Bears, a practice that followed three days off, Berry sensed his first Super problem. His team was home. ''Actually it's disruptive,'' Berry said as a thin smile appeared. ''We're used to being on the road, living in strange places. We'd like to go back on the road. We've got to be leaving pretty soon. Go back to comfortable surroundings.''

title: METS TRADE TO HELP HITTING
description: The Mets ended their off-season quest for a good-hitting infielder yesterday by acquiring Tim Teufel, who was the Minnesota Twins' starting second baseman the past two seasons. For Teufel and a minor league outfielder from Queens, Pat Crosby, the Mets gave the Twins Billy Beane, a good minor league outfielder; Bill Latham, a pitcher who commuted between New York and the Tidewater Tides last season; and Joe Klink, a minor league pitcher.

title: EVANGELIST AND A BROADCASTER
description: Herbert W. Armstrong, the broadcasting evangelist who was founder and pastor general of the Worldwide Church of God, died today at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 93 years old. Church officials said no official cause of death had been established, but they added that Mr. Armstrong's health had been declining about four months because of a heart ailment.

title: A WITNESS IN GAMBINO TRIAL ADMITS LIES ABOUT HIS ROLE
description: A key prosecution witness in the trial of nine reputed members of the Gambino crime family testified yesterday that he ''lied to protect myself'' before telling law-enforcement officials the truth about a stolen-car ring and the murders of suspected informers.

title: CLOSINGS SCHEDULED FOR KING HOLIDAY
description: Federal, state and municipal offices in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed on Monday to commemorate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. - the first time the holiday will be celebrated as a Federal and state holiday.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT is like entering a time warp, circa 1893, an era when women carried parasols and gentlemen wore hats. The expansive, multilevel dining rooms are agleam with burnished rosewood supporting vines of hammered brass, intricate wall moldings, sylvan murals, stained glass galore, oversized sconces, plush banquettes and tables holding pink roses and matching lampshades. While I didn't sport a top hat, I was decked out in black tie, which is de rigueur on weekends at Maxim's, Manhattan's newest old restaurant.

Park Ponies' Farewell
description: From a child's point of view, they were the four-legged landmarks of Central Park, as familiar a part of the terrain as the Friedsam Memorial Carousel or the statue of Alice in Wonderland.

title: Leninism Amok in Yemen
description: Southern Yemen, an impoverished nation of two million, has long been put down as the Soviet Union's puppet in the Arab world. Yet all this week, Moscow has appeared unable to untangle a murderous disorder there. It could not readily condemn a rebellion led by a former President known for his pro-Soviet ardor. Neither could it disinherit loyal incumbents whose saner flexibility may have made them more useful allies. Whatever the course of events, they show again that the Soviet model loses something in stability when transported to the third world.

title: OF PLUMBING, PARTIES AND PEN
description: Simmering resentment among women attending the International PEN Congress boiled over yesterday when a women's caucus criticized ''the underrepresentation of women.''

description: The Tennessee quarterback Tony Robinson is back on athletic scholarship pending the outcome of a case charging him with peddling cocaine to undercover policemen. According to Haywood Harris, the school's sports information director, the university's scholarship committee informed school officials that there were no grounds for revoking the scholarships of Robinson and the former Volunteer fullback Kenneth (B. B.) Cooper because their case was still before the court. A preliminary hearing is set for Feb. 5.

It was the highest profit ever for a fiscal first quarter at Disney. Revenues rose 18.2 percent, to $504.2 million, from $426.5 million.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STEP-BY-STEP: A SHOOTING , A DISMISSAL
description: Following is how the events have unfolded over the 13 months of the Goetz case: Dec. 22, 1984 - Bernhard H. Goetz is approached by four young men -one of whom asks for $5 - on a southbound IRT No. 2 subway train. He opens fire with a .38-caliber handgun. The four, all of whom had arrest records, are wounded, and one, Darrel Cabey, is left paralyzed. Dec. 26, 1984 - An anonymous caller tells the police that Mr. Goetz, who had rented a car and fled to New England, fits the description of the subway gunman. Dec. 31, 1984 - Mr. Goetz surrenders to the Concord, N.H., police. Jan. 3, 1985 - Mr. Goetz is returned to Manhattan and charged with four counts of attempted murder.

Snug Harbor is at 1000 Richsection; to get there from Manhattan, take the ferry and then the No. 1 bus. Tickets are $6; reservations: (718)448-2500.

title: Gleeful Choice
description: Compared with baseball's main free agent draft in June, the January draft for college dropouts and junior college players is a ho-hum affair that produces few major league prospects. According to the Pittsburgh Pirates, this year may be different.

title: French Right Pledges To Roll Socialism Back
description: France's Conservative opposition parties today promised far-reaching measures to liberalize the national economy, including the return to private ownership of all companies and banks nationalized by the Socialists, if they win the March 16 parliamentary election.

Antiquarian Book Sale
description: First editions of Dr. Seuss's ''And to Think I Saw It on Mulberry Street'' and Eudora Welty's ''Curtain of Green'' are among the books that will be on view this weekend at the Rye Antiquarian Book Fair and Sale, at the Academy of the Resurrection High School, 946 Post Road, Rye, N. Y. In addition to books, there will be magazines, prints and personal correspondence dating from the mid-19th century.

title: CAR GOES OUT OF CONTROL, KILLING PEDESTRIAN ON 5TH AVE.
description: A pedestrian was killed and two others were injured when an automobile lurched out of control and onto a Fifth Avenue sidewalk during the morning rush hour yesterday.

Keeping Card Catalogue Up-to-Date by Computer
description: As in most libraries around the country, the card catalogue at the Columbia University Libraries has begun to shrink. CLIO, for Columbia Libraries Information Online, is the new computerized library catalogue.

title: FED DATA HELP RATES DECLINE
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined late yesterday as traders were encouraged by falling oil prices in the futures market and Federal Reserve data showing that bank reserves remain in ample supply.

title: PANEL SEES CHANGE IN U.S. FAMILY BUT NOT IN JOBS
description: The American workplace, shaped by the attitudes of government and industry, has failed to adjust to dramatic changes in the American family, a panel of labor, corporate and academic leaders concluded in a study published today.

title: REPERTORY COMPANIES OFFER CLASSICS AND CAMP
description: ''IT'S something I've always dreamed of,'' says Ken Marshall. ''It's the greatest work you can do as an actor,'' says Tovah Feldshuh. ''It's the proper way to create theater,'' says Marshall Mason. ''It'' is alternating repertory, a species regularly proclaimed to be endangered if not extinct in contemporary New York theater. But a look around the city this weekend reveals a surprising amount of repertory in Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theaters. And despite the familiar complaint that there is no audience in New York for serious theater, let alone the classics, this season's schedules boast such illustrious names as Shakespeare and Ibsen, Gorky and Camus.

title: ADMINISTRATION DEBATES ARMS-PACT ENFORCEMENT
description: Dissension is continuing within the Reagan Administration over how to respond to what some officials have charged are Soviet arms-control violations, according to Administration officials.

title: WOMEN AT PEN CAUCUS DEMAND A GREATER ROLE
description: It started Monday when the plumbing broke in Robert Coover's hotel room. The management, a little embarrassed that a big-time novelist couldn't wash his hands, gave Mr. Coover a suite. So he decided to have a party, and invited some friends -Raymond Carver, Grace Paley, William Gass, Vance Bourjaily.

title: SNAGS SEEN IF GROUP OF 5 TRIES TO LOWER INTEREST
description: Reports that finance ministers and central bankers from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain and France plan to discuss a coordinated effort to push down interest rates at this weekend's meeting in London were confirmed today by Pierre Beregovoy, France's Finance Minister.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday CHOREOGRAPHIC REUNION Rachel Lampert, once dubbed the ''Woody Allen of modern dance,'' is celebrating her first decade of professional activity this weekend with three retrospective evenings. She has chosen nine pieces from the repertory of her company, Rachel Lampert and Dancers, with colorful names such as ''Bloody Mary Sunday,'' ''Me and Beethoven'' and ''Doing the Dance.'' Collectively, the evenings are titled ''The Choreographer's Album'' and represent a sort of guided tour of Miss Lampert's repertory. Several artists who have performed with the troupe will return for these reunion programs, among them Holly Harbinger, Michael Blue Aiken, Kenneth Tosti, Erica Eisenberg and Alyce Brochette. The newest work by Miss Lampert, ''Love It, Leave It, or Let It Be Lonely,'' will also be presented, to round out both the evening and the decade. The performances will take place tonight, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8 o'clock at the Nikolais/ Louis DanceSpace, 33 East 18th Street, seventh floor. Admission is $7, or $2 with a Theater Development Fund voucher. Reservations are suggested, and the number for information is 219-1672. Saturday MULTIMEDIA TRILOGY In the 1970's, the lofts of SoHo were filled with exciting artistic activity. When you went to a concert at a space like the Kitchen or the Franklin Furnace, you never knew what to expect. Some of this experimental spirit lives on below Houston Street and, this weekend, ''The Age of Invention,'' a trilogy of multimedia plays featuring the puppetry and direction of Theodora Skipitares and the music of Virgil Moorefield and Scott Johnson, will be presented at the Performing Garage.

title: 007 and the K.G.B.
description: Has Moscow hired James Bond to supplement its intelligence forces in the United States? Last year the District of Columbia issued a new series of diplomatic license plates, and the designation SX was assigned to the Soviet Union. Parked outside its embassy this week was a dark Oldsmobile sedan carrying SX-007 plates. Or perhaps that number has become generic and is routinely assigned by the embassy to the resident senior K.G.B. officer.

title: Two Cubans Acquitted Of Leading Jail Riot
description: Two Cubans were acquitted today of charges that they led a 1984 riot among hundreds of Cubans awaiting possible deportation at the Federal Penitentiary here.

title: PLAIN TALK FROM ONE CAPITAL TO ANOTHER
description: Gov. John Carlin of Kansas did something remarkable here this week. In his State of the State Message, the Democrat frankly told the Legislature that it had to raise the state sales tax by one cent on the dollar or watch Kansas sink into economic decline.

Comings and Goings
description: Jim Mora, the coach of the Baltimore Stars, whose United States Football League contract expires today, is reportedly weighing an offer to take over as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League. . . . Steve Spurrier, approached in recent weeks by several colleges seeking head coaches or assistants, has signed a contract to remain coach of the Tampa Bay Bandits of the U.S.F.L. His previous contract expired Dec. 31. . . . John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, has fined Coach Jim Schoenfeld of the Buffalo Sabres $5,000 for throwing a water bottle at Referee Terry Gregson in a game against the Quebec Nordiques last Dec. 10. . . . Mike Tyson, the heavyweight from Catskill, N.Y., who has won all 16 of his professional bouts by knockout, got a new opponent, Mike Jameson of San Jose, Calif., for his 10-round fight next Friday night in Atlantic City. Phil Brown, originally scheduled to meet Tyson, withdrew because of an unspecified injury. . . . Kevin Dineen, who has 16 goals and 22 assists for the Hartford Whalers, will be sidelined two to three weeks because of a broken knuckle on his left pinky, suffered in a fight with Behn Wilson of Chicago last Sunday.

title: Insurance Broker Names Top Officer
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's leading insurance brokerage, announced yesterday that Frank J. Tasco, president and chief operating officer, had been named chief executive officer, succeeding John M. The company said that Mr. Tasco, who is 58 years old, will succeed Mr. Regan, 64, as chairman in May.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Ronald Shannon Jackson and the Decoding Society, Jazztrack, 27 Greenwich Street, at Seventh Avenue South (431-3009). When Ronald Shannon Jackson plays drums with a band, he seems to be everywhere at once - knocking out a solid back-beat, trading accents with soloists, urging the bassist forward - and making each independent part swing. He started the Decoding Society after working with the three leading figures in free jazz - Ornette Coleman, Cecil Taylor and the late Albert Ayler. Like Mr. Coleman's Prime Time, the Decoding Society's repertory calls for multiple keys and tempos simultaneously, all supported by Mr. Jackson's polyrhythms; also factored in are hints of world music and Mr. Jackson's native Texas rhythm-and-blues. The current Decoding Society, an electrified sextet, features the firebrand guitarist Vernon Reid. Sets are tomorrow at 9:30 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH TAXIS
description: According to figures kept by Washington taxi companies, this city has more cabs per capita than any other in the United States. But that, many riders say, is not the point.

title: TREMORS AT MACK TRUCK JOLT PENNSYLVANIA TOWN
description: Many dignitaries visiting here receive bronze keys to the city embossed with the snarling bulldog that symbolizes Mack Trucks, a picture of the company's headquarters and the city's motto, ''The Truck Capital of the World.''

title: WEIGHING THE SOVIET PLAN
description: With the latest nuclear arms proposal by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Moscow has seemingly reversed itself and opened the door to permitting research on space-based defenses and to eliminating its SS-20 medium-range missiles and all other nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Providence Wins in Overtime
description: Bill Donovan hit a 10-foot jumper with a second left in overtime to give Providence a 76-75 victory over Boston College tonight in a Big East Conference game. Donovan earlier sank one of two free-throw attempts with four seconds left in regulation play to force the overtime. Donovan had a game-high 22 points.

title: Bar Panel Backs Red-Light Areas
description: A committee of the New York State Bar Association proposed yesterday that prostitutes be legally allowed to walk certain streets at certain hours to solicit customers, in effect creating red-light districts.

title: BRITAIN RULES OUT JOINING SANCTIONS
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, told a high-ranking American official today that Britain will continue to urge the European allies to isolate Libya diplomatically and militarily. But he refused again to join the United States in economic sanctions, which the British regard as counterproductive.

title: PROGRAM TO HOUSE AGED FACING NEW QUESTIONS
description: For almost three decades the Federal Government's housing construction program for the elderly was cited by liberals and conservatives alike as an exemplary effort under which community-based religious and civic groups helped old people with low incomes.

description: President Reagan today issued a proclamation deploring what he called ''the terrible toll'' of abortion and reaffirming his commitment to ''the sanctity of human life.''

title: McFarlane to Tour
description: Robert C. McFarlane, who resigned as President Reagan's national security adviser last month, is putting together what looks like a lucrative future in private industry. Associates report that Mr. McFarlane, an Annapolis graduate and former Marine officer, is going to join the faculty of a university in a role that will give him time for writing on national security affairs and for public speaking around the country and abroad.

title: UCONN SEES SOME GAINS
description: When Lou Carnesecca analyzes Connecticut's game films, the St. John's coach will most likely come away with an uneasy feeling about the team his Redmen will face tomorrow night in Hartford Civic Center.

title: CABARET: VOCAL POINT
description: ALTHOUGH a singing quartet called Vocal Point, which performed as Don't Tell Mama on Tuesday (and will be at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street, on Sundays starting this weekend) can trace its heritage back through Manhattan Transfer and the Fifth Dimension, the group manages to establish an identity of its own.

title: Bayer Trademark
description: Bayer A.G., the West German drug and chemical group, said it had paid Sterling Drug Inc. $25 million to buy back partial rights to its Bayer trademark in the United States, ending a prohibition dating from the end of World War I. Sterling will continue to sell aspirin under Bayer's name and symbol in North America. Bayer bought the right to use the trademark on industrial products such as plastics and organic and inorganic chemicals. Bayer, which invented aspirin at the end of the last century, will still be barred from selling consumer products and pharmaceuticals under its own name in the United States.

title: Advertising; U.A.W. Buys Six Spots For Special on Dr. King
description: The second-largest advertiser after Procter & Gamble on the Martin Luther King special on the NBC-TV Network Monday night will be the United Automobile Workers union. It has bought three of the available 13 commercial minutes for about $750,000 and will run six 30-second spots.

title: As America Diets, Allies Must Eat
description: The apparent stability of the world economy belies the pessimism that was fashionable only yesterday. In America, employment and growth are strong. Japan and Western Europe also are enjoying modest growth. And the poorer nations have picked their way through the minefield of debt and depressed exports without catastrophe.

You try all manner of original pairings, you have your pick of the world's art and there's no one around to demur. As daydreams go, it takes some beating.

The man was identified as John Paul Govert, 36 years old. He surrendered when the police agreed to let him talk to a Broward County sheriff's deputy who arrested him on drug charges several years ago, according to the authorities.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SOME of the most lovingly prepared Italian food in New York can be found at an unprepossessing 50-year-old family-run restaurant in the Bronx called Amerigo's. Easily accessible from Interstate 95, Amerigo's is a well-guarded secret among its cultlike clientele from this safe and solidly Italian neighborhood as well as from nearby Westchester County.

title: CONGRESSIONAL CHIEFS SEEK COALITION IN BUDGET PROCESS

title: Cowboy Ritual Begins
description: It's become something of a postseason ritual in Dallas. A season ends, Cowboy players and coaches start thinking about next year and the backup quarterback, Gary Hogeboom, dissatisfied after spending yet another frustrating season on the bench, tells Coach Tom Landry he wants to be traded.

title: Two Men in St. Louis Buy Globe-Democrat
description: Two businessmen presented the trustees of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat with a $500,000 check today, consummating the purchase of the 134-year-old newspaper that had been in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Format Brings Exciting Finish at Regionals
description: One of the reasons for the great popularity of the Swiss Team format is that it nearly always produces a dramatic finish. When the last seven deals are played, there are nearly always two or more teams in contention with full knowledge that the title is up for grabs. Most of the time the two leading teams meet head to head, knowing exactly their relative standing.

title: Joining the Party
description: Thoughts on the Queens Democratic machine from Governor Cuomo, prompted by a question yesterday on the effects of the incident in which Borough President Donald R. Manes, also the Queens Democratic leader, was seriously injured last week:

title: PEN MEMBERS ARGUE THE DANGERS OF UTOPIA
description: YESTERDAY afternoon the PEN International Congress devoted one of its sessions in the Essex House hotel to the theme of ''Utopia and the Imagination.'' There have been times during the congress, at its more strident or its more jargon-ridden moments, when one's idea of utopia would have been the instant termination of the entire proceedings. This particular session, however, turned out to be exceptionally rewarding; it was conducted at a high level, and distinguished by at least two unusually powerful contributions, from Czeslaw Milosz, who left Poland in the early 1950's, and a more recent exile, the Lithuanian writer Tomas Venclova.

title: CONTINENTAL NET RISES; BANKERS TRUST UP
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation yesterday marked a year of major recovery by reporting improved earnings. MCENROE MAY NEED RESPITE

title: THE STAGE: ZOE CALDWELL AS HELLMAN IN 'LILLIAN'
description: THERE are few, if any, more startling sights in a New York theater right now than the one that opens ''Lillian,'' the new one-woman play at the Barrymore. As the curtain rises, we are confronted by an eerie reincarnation of the writer Lillian Hellman - complete with wavy blondish hair, elegant gray suit, pearl necklace, mountainous nose, lighted cigarette and, most unsettling of all, a fierce smile that seems more an invitation to hostilities than an offering of warmth. Makeup, of course, can do wonders, but so can a fine actress. Zoe Caldwell, one of the more estimable actresses around, has surely captured the seething physical presence of Hellman, a woman whose volatile political and personal battles were inseparable from her careers as playwright, screen writer and memoirist.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FILM: TALE OF RUNAWAY, 'JOURNEY OF NATTY GANN'
description: NATTY GANN loves her father and her dog. She sneaks cigarettes in the bathroom, and she gets into scuffles with the boys who are her friends. She is, as written, an old-fashioned tomboy heroine whose feistiness is rivaled only by her spunk, and she ought to have a lot of appeal, especially for little girls. If ''The Journey of Natty Gann'' were only a speedier, more energetic movie, Natty might have real staying power.

title: ART: THE OUTSIDERS, AT ROSA ESMAN GALLERY
description: WHEN the psychiatrist Karl Prinzhorn collected and wrote about it in the early 1920's, it was simply called the drawings and paintings of the insane; now it's ''Outsider Art.'' This is for once a euphemism that's called for, and it's not because progress in psychiatry has made insanity hard, if not impossible, to define. And it is especially not because patients today go free, though dependent on drugs, who yesterday were adjudged fit to be tied. The work of the sedated lacks the special quality that would make it Outsider Art -and is to the real thing what mission-school sculpture is to genuine tribal work. Rather, Outsider Art is a useful term because being clinically crazy is not necessarily a prerequisite for genius, although to judge from the recent traveling show of art from the Prinzhorn Collection it certainly helps.

title: IN MUSIC, READINGS AND FILM, SALUTES TO DR. KING
description: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was born 57 years ago this week, is only the second American to have a Federal holiday named for him: Americans celebrate George Washington's birthday in February, but a proposal in 1920 to make Abraham Lincoln's birthday a national holiday failed to come to a vote in Congress.

title: Higher Education
description: James Wharton, the chancellor of Louisiana State University, when asked to assess the effect of the N.C.A.A.'s minimum academic standards for athletes: ''We no longer will have students majoring in eligibility.''

title: SCREEN: 'CLAN OF THE CAVE BEAR'
description: ''THE CLAN OF THE CAVE BEAR,'' a big, scenic adaptation of Jean M. Auel's best-selling novel, travels eons backward in time in order to tell the audience things it already knows. It concerns a Cro-Magnon foundling named Ayla, who is raised by Neanderthals and inculcated with their sexist, oppressive ways, only to rise up as history's first free-thinking woman warrior. The film chooses to lean heavily upon these stereotypes, at the expense of the behavioral and anthropological detail that has enlivened the best of the cinematic cavemen, most notably in ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' and ''Quest for Fire.''

title: Idaho Governor Has Surgery
description: Doctors operated Wednesday on Gov. John V. Evans to reconstruct his right ankle, fractured Tuesday night in a jogging accident. Mr. Evans, a 60-year-old Democrat, was on a statewide trip to announce his candidacy for the Senate against the incumbent, Steven D. Symms, a Republican. ''The Governor tolerated the anesthetic well and the surgery went uneventfully,'' said Dr. Mike Coughlin, an orthopedic surgeon.

Stewart Jr., chief financial officer at Kidder, Peabody & Company, had been named controller.

title: Bradley And Bird

title: DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time reversal of $276,000 and 6 cents per share of deferred income taxes previously provided on DISC earnings.

title: Trainer Loses License
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has revoked the trainer's license of Alain de Royer Dupre because one of his horses, Lashkari, tested positive for etorphine after finishing fourth in the Breeders' Cup Turf race at Aqueduct on Nov. 2.

title: FILM: FIELD AND GARNER IN 'MURPHY'S ROMANCE'
description: MANY years ago there used to be a series of short subjects titled - I think - ''Screen Snapshots,'' which allowed the underprivileged in movie theaters to see how responsible Hollywood stars behaved at home, in private moments that were alternately playful and solemn. You didn't have to believe in the truth of the scenes to be beguiled by the sight of a loving Joan Crawford teaching her children how to swim or listening to them recite the Lord's Prayer.

title: BULLS' NIGHT ON THE TOWN
description: A dozen bulls bolted through an open gate after they were sold at auction Wednesday night and went on a rampage through downtown Tulsa, breaking into a state office building and frightening police officers who joined cowboys to round the bulls up.

title: Murdoch Affirms Plan on Papers
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch said he was not seeking a permanent waiver of Federal Communications Commission rules that require him to sell The New York Post and The Chicago Sun-Times. The sales are necessary because Mr. Murdoch agreed last spring to purchase six television stations, including WNEW-TV in New York and WFLD-TV in Chicago, from Metromedia Inc. The F.C.C. generally prohibits a company from owning a broadcast outlet and a newspaper in the same city.

title: Bow Ties and Skullcaps
description: Arguments before the Supreme Court this week on whether Orthodox Jews, with their religious duty to wear skullcaps, should be exempt from the military dress code's ban on hats indoors raised multiple questions. May Sikhs wear turbans? May Rastafarians wear their hair in dreadlocks?

title: K Mart to Pull Out Of Two Operations
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest general merchandise retailer, said yesterday that it would divest itself of two unprofitable operations - its stake in a Mexican retail venture and its insurance subsidiary, K Mart Insurance Services Inc.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE Brazilian Princess, as everyone and her handmaidens know by now, is not a who, it's a what. It is, in fact, the world's largest cut gem, a nine-and-one-half-pound, 21,000-carat topaz, and on Wednesday evening the American Museum of Natural History gave it a cocktail party. The stone went on exhibition behind glass yesterday. For the party, with appropriate background of tapes of soft Brazilian tangos, the dazzler was out in the open, under close scrutiny of a burly guard or two, on a round table covered with beige-colored psuedosuede.

title: A SLICE OF HANOI NIGHT LIFE: HEAR A TALE OF SAIGON
description: In the cold of winter Hanoi is often silent after sundown, with little more than the ring of bicycle bells or the clang of a streetcar to compete with the muffled conversations or coughing of unseen people in dark courtyards.

title: Friends Matched in Bout
description: Emile Griffith, the former middleweight champion who trains James (Bonecrusher) Smith, cherishes his friendship with Joe Frazier. But business is business.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Madison Square Garden, 8:30 P.M. The Knicks split the two games they played against the Spurs last season and won the first meeting of this season, 108-98, Dec. 14. (Television - MSG, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 8:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. The Nets and the Bullets have split the two previous games played this season. (Television - SportsChannel, 11 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Indiana Pacers vs. Boston Celtics, at Indianapolis. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) College: Brown at Columbia, 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 7:30 P.M.); C. W. Post at Virginia Union (Radio -WCWP-FM 88.1, 8 P.M.); Catholic U. at Upsala 7:30 P.M.; Yale at Cornell, 7:30 P.M.; Baruch at Mercy, 8 P.M.; Montclair State at Kean, 8 P.M. Boxing Tony Tubbs, champion vs. vs. Tim Witherspoon, 15 rounds, for World Boxing Association heavyweight championship, at Atlanta. This is the first defense for Tubbs since he won the title from Greg Page in a 15-round decision in Buffalo last April. Witherspoon, the former World Boxing Council champion, who lost his title to Pinklon Thomas in a 12-round decision last August, is 23-2-1, with 15 knockouts. (Television - HBO, 10 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Washington Capitals, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. In their first two games of the season, the Devils split with the Capitals, winning, 4-1, and losing, 6-2, both games at the Meadowlands.

title: 'SHAKESPEARE HOUR' ON CHANNEL 13
description: WITH as much of a flourish as public television can muster nowadays, ''The Shakespeare Hour'' is being unveiled on Channel 13 on Sunday at 10 P.M. Actually, this is just another instance of PBS, constantly strapped for production monies, using the standard technique of repackaging. ''The Shakespeare Hour'' is constructed around the BBC's productions of all 37 plays attributed, more or less, to one William Shakespeare. Those productions have already been seen on public television over several seasons. Now they are being chopped up and supplemented with appropriate commentaries, written by Kenneth Cavander and delivered by Walter Matthau. Thus can a claim be made to ''an entirely new format.''

title: Zondervan Stake
description: An investment group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds a 7.3 percent stake in the Zondervan Corporation and may seek control of the Bible-publishing company. The group is led by two Cleveland investors, Lawrence D. Altschul and James J. Apostolakis. It includes Bartle Bull, a partner in the New York law firm Jones, Hirsch, Connors & Bull and former publisher of The Village Voice.

title: Bernard J. O'Connell, Ex-Judge in City Court
description: Bernard J. O'Connell, a former Criminal Court judge and Commissioner of Licenses for New York City, died Wednesday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Baryton Trio
description: The Esterhazy Baryton Trio will present a concert at the great hall of the Coe Mansion, Planting Fields Arboretum, Oyster Bay, L.I., Sunday at 2:30 P.M. The baryton, an instrument so rare as to be almost obsolete, is distantly related to the viola da gamba and was very popular with Haydn's patron, Prince Esterhazy, who commissioned many works for the instrument. Tickets are $7.50; to reach the arboretum, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 41 North, then Route 106 to Route 25A, and follow the signs. Information: (516) 922-0061.

Assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds increased $608.9 million, to $95.76 billion, while assets of the 192 general purpose funds rose $809.4 million, to $60.89 billion. These gains, however, were all but offset by a $1.11 billion drop in assets of the 80 institutional investor funds, which ended the week at $65.04 billion.

CABARET: IAN TYSON LEADS COUNTRY BAND AT BITTER END
description: IAN TYSON, the Canadian singer and songwriter who made an exceedingly rare appearance at the Bitter End on Wednesday evening, is a godfather of the Canadian folk movement that produced Neil Young, Joni Mitchell, Gordon Lightfoot and others. More recently, the 52-year-old musician, who lives and works mostly in Alberta, has identified himself with western cowboy music, recording little-known songs in the genre as well as contributing strong originals.

title: City Grants Permit For Hudson Ferry
description: A docking permit was granted yesterday for a ferry service between midtown Manhattan and Weehawken, N.J., the first new trans-Hudson ferry since the turn of the century.

title: THE SCREEN: 'TROLL'
description: ''TROLL'' takes its inspiration, if it can be called that, from those late, great, bargain-basement science-fiction films that managed to be funny without trying. Innocence like that is not easily imitated, as ''Troll'' unwittingly demonstrates time and again. Directed by John Buechler, whose background is in creature-related special effects, and written by Ed Naha, ''Troll'' has a knowing tone that's more smart-alecky than clever. And it hovers uncomfortably between comedy and horror, without ever landing decisively in either camp. The film is as funny as it gets in a sequence that has Sonny Bono pretending to be a great ladies' man.

title: SECRECY AT BEARS' WORKOUT
description: Here in the heart of Illini country, the Bears have traveled 120 miles from Chicago to train for the Super Bowl game against the New England Patriots Jan. 26 in New Orleans.

title: A SMORGASBORD OF MUSICAL MORSELS AT THE KITCHEN
description: ''STRANGE MUTATIONS,'' the adventurous three-week music series that opened last night at the Kitchen, offers a feast of musical hybrids designed to re-tune the most jaded New York ears. This weekend, music explorers who have been able to follow transcultural fusions from overseas only through import records can hear first hand some of the cult sensations of the European club circuit. Next week, the series will pay tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., from jazz, blues and Caribbean musical perspectives. In its final week, the smorgasbord will include Japanese synthesizer music, experimental music-video from West Germany and an anti-apartheid rock-funk extravaganza.

title: OPERA: THE MET'S FIRST 'IDOMENEO' THIS SEASON
description: ''Idomeneo,'' the finest work ever composed in the opera seria tradition, is not only about virtuosic singing by any means, but without important voices in half a dozen roles it cannot begin to reveal its greatness to an audience. The season's first performance of the Mozart work, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night for the first time since Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production was new in 1982-83, measured up reasonably well in spots, but on the whole could not sustain the brilliance necessary for opera in the high-Baroque manner.

title: GET THE GOETZ CASE BACK ON TRACK
description: Has Judge Stephen Crane found plausible technical grounds for dropping charges of attempted murder and assault against Bernhard Goetz? Yes. Are they clear or compelling enough to derail a case that has excited such national concern over self-defense? Certainly not.

title: LENDL AND JARRYD GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: Brad Gilbert had two days to savor the biggest victory of his career, to accept the congratulatory telephone calls and ego-boosting pats on the back, praise for his victory over John McEnroe in the Nabisco Masters tournament. During the same two days, Tim Mayotte plotted for a watershed match of his own, against Ivan Lendl.

title: Belly-Landing at Dulles
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner with faulty landing gear touched down on its belly tonight and skidded 1,000 feet to a safe stop at Washington-Dulles International Airport. None of the 142 people aboard the Boeing 727 were injured, officials said.

title: Honda Steel Pact
description: Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. said Armco Inc. and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation would join the Inland Steel Company of Chicago in supplying steel for Honda's auto assembly plant here. The three steel companies will supply about 78,000 tons annually of coiled steel for the major body parts of the four-door and three-door Accord models now being made at the plant as well as the being made at the plant as well as the four-door Civic that begins production in July. About

title: GETTING JAPAN TO BUY ABROAD
description: Noriko Takemoto remembers her Prime Minister going on television last April and asking the nation to buy more foreign goods. But the request had no effect on her shopping.

title: Detroit Import
description: WABC-TV (Channel 7) has hired a new, first-string sports broadcaster to bolster its early-evening and late-night news telecasts. That's the word from Detroit, where it was confirmed yesterday by the broadcaster's agent, Rick Brode; the broadcaster's current station, WDIV-TV, and the broadcaster himself: Eli Zaret, a 35-year-old native of Nutley, N.J., who brings to the job a deep, raspy voice and a prior reputation as an anti-establishment radio commentator at several Detroit rock music stations.

title: Kodak Dismisses 500 Employees
description: The Eastman Kodak Company dismissed 500 employees, effective immediately. It said the layoffs were for financial reasons and had nothing to do with the recent court order that forced the company to close its instant photography business.

title: BITTER STRIKE AT FUEL PLANT OVER SAFETY
description: As a cold dusk enveloped the Appalachian Mountains here in eastern Tennessee Mike Hampton stood on the front porch of the frame house that serves as his union local's headquarters, looking across the road at employee buses loading up under armed guard at the Nuclear Fuel Services plant.

This latest in the endless stream of published revelations about the British royals is significant since it throws new light on the all-purpose nature of the headgear referred to.
