title: REAGAN CITES INCREASED COST IN VETOING HEALTH BENEFIT BILL
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have made changes in health benefits for Federal employees. He said he did so because the measure would have increased the budget deficit by eliminating a 75 percent ceiling on the Government's share of health care premiums.

title: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Schoenfeld Replaced
description: He was one of the most popular Sabres' players, but since taking over as the coach this season, Jim Schoenfeld had lost much of appeal. Yesterday, with the team at the bottom of the Adams Division, Schoenfeld was replaced by Scotty Bowman, the general manager. A team spokesman said the change was not related to the recent incident in which Schoenfeld was fined $5,000 by the league after throwing a water bottle at a referee and saying he wished it had been a brick. Bowman, in his third stint as the coach, has an overall record of 718-302-20, representing a winning percentage of .670, best in the league.

title: Surgery for Marino
description: Dan Marino will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee and will miss the Pro Bowl in Hawaii on Feb. 2. Ken O'Brien will replace the Dolphin quarterback and become the first Jets quarterback to appear in the game since Joe Namath after the 1972 season.

title: ISLANDERS WIN IN LAST SECOND
description: Bryan Trottier reminded the Islanders tonight that split-second victories are still within their grasp. In the final second against the Flyers, Trottier sprinted to the crease to receive a crisp pass from Mike Bossy and knocked the puck past Bob Froese for a stunning 4-3 victory, spoiling their hosts' eight-game home winning streak.

title: Mesa Officials Are Promoted
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company announced yesterday that several key executives had been promoted. David H. Batchelder was named president and chief operating officer, positions formerly held by T. Boone Pickens, who remains Mesa's chairman and chief executive.

title: Fryar Works Out With the Patriots
description: Amid conflicting versions of what caused the knife wound to his right hand, Irving Fryar returned to practice with the New England Patriots this afternoon, apprehensive about the first hard pass that will come his way and upset with reports about his personal life that he contended were untrue.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. The net losses for the latest periods reflect expenses of $4,692,000 for the quarter and $5,314,000 for the 9 months related to the dispute and settlement between Frantz Manufacturing and EAC Industries, arising from an unfriendly takeover attempt mounted by EAC in April.

title: SECURITY BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Conditional Promotion Of Navy Doctor Detailed
description: Comdr. Donal M. Billig's superiors at the Bethesda Naval Hospital decided to promote him to chief of cardiothoracic surgery but agreed among themselves that he was not to do heart operations without supervision, a witness testified today at Dr. Billig's court-martial.

title: Store Consolidation Seen at Federated
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest operator of department stores, is planning to merge its two Middle West department store divisions, Wall Street and retailing sources said yesterday. It will also merge two discount chains, the sources said.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPAIN, AMID SECRECY, FORMALLY RECOGNIZES ISRAEL
description: Spain formally recognized Israel today, 38 years after Israel's founding as a nation.

title: MAKING RECIPES EASY TO READ
description: Struggling to digest half a hundred cookbooks each winter, I realized that without thinking about it I routinely discarded those in which recipes were not clearly written. The only exceptions to that rule were the books that were simply decorative, picture books for the coffee table.

title: Killer Whale Baby Dies
description: The first killer whale born at the Sea World marine park here has died after only 12 days. The park said the 350-pound calf, born Jan. 5, failed to respond to emergency treatment for a flu-like respiratory disease and died Thursday.

title: Folk Art and Pottery
description: American folk art and rare French pottery will be displayed tomorrow at the Tarrytown Antiques Market at the Westchester Marriott Hotel, 670 White Plains Road, Tarrytown, N. Y. More than 100 dealers from the United States and Europe will take part in the show, which runs from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; there is a special preview from 7 to 10 A.M. Tickets are $3 ($35 for the preview). Information: (518) 766-3065.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: From Dr. King's Son To High School Students
description: No place could better perpetuate the legacy of his father than a school, Dexter King told the students of Martin Luther King High School yesterday. Mr. King, 24 years old, urged them to make good use of that legacy and to embrace the teachings of love and nonviolence that his father had so powerfully preached.

title: UNBUCKLED FOR FREEDOM
description: Well, the plan is working, isn't it? Mandatory seat-belt laws for motorists are now in effect in New York and Massachusetts.

title: INTEGRATED BARTER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring writeoff of goodwill of $10,350,000, a writeoff of deferred costs of $450,000, development expenses of a subsidiary of $310,000 and losses on foreign subsidiaries of $791,000. c-After development expenses of a subsidiary of $675,000.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS TERROR POLICY
description: President Reagan is considering issuance of a directive that would establish the State Department as the agency that would take the lead in dealing with international terrorism, Administration officials said today.

title: Orion Bars Warrants' Sale
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation chairman, Arthur Krim, said yesterday that Orion's top management would not sell the 1.8 million warrants it owns to any outside group.

title: ANNE BAXTER SERVICE FRIDAY
description: A memorial service for the actress Anne Baxter will be held on Friday at 4 P.M. at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street.

title: SCIENTISTS VS. TRADITIONALISTS: A BATTLE OF BIDDING GOES ON
description: A 50-year battle, likely to last another 50, has been waged between the scientists who believe in long, descriptive bidding sequences and the traditionalists who rush to a final contract with all convenient speed.

title: DOGS KILL 4-YEAR-OLD BOY
description: A 4-year-old who wandered away from his home while his mother was doing housework was killed by neighborhood dogs, the Tuolumne County Sheriff's office said today. the body of the boy, Jacob Hosek, was found by joggers a half-hour after he left his home on Thursday.

title: PARKING UNIT VENDOR LACKED ASSETS
description: A $20 million contract to supply traffic agents with hand-held computers was awarded to a company that had no assets, no engineering staff and no working prototype, according to public records.

title: UPSTATE SCHOOL TEACHES SNOW FIGHTERS THE INS AND OUTS OF PLOWING A CLEAR PATH
description: All week 12 State Transportation Department workers have gathered in a drafty highway-maintenance garage to attend lectures on the fine art of snow removal.

title: HARVARD STUDENTS PROTESTING ACTION AGAINST THE HOMELESS
description: Harvard students circulated a petition today demanding the removal of iron grilles that had been placed over a dormitory's heat vents to keep away homeless people seeking warmth.

title: INTERFIRST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $70 million from the sale of the company's interest in a building.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 14
description: b-After a pretax charge of $325,118 for the quarter and 6 months related to a store closing.

title: MANUFACTURERS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in October.

title: JACKPOT CARRIES LONG ODDS
description: A dollar bet on the Lotto 48 game offers two chances to play and 6.135 million-to-1 odds of winning the jackpot.

title: YORK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $114,000, or 12 cents a share.

title: Another Body Found At Gander Crash Site
description: Searchers have discovered a human body, body parts and medical records at the Newfoundland site where a chartered jet crashed Dec. 12, killing 248 American soldiers, officials said today.

title: U.S. BACKS LATIN PEACE EFFORT BUT STILL SEEKS TO ARM REBELS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they took a positive view of efforts in recent days to revive the peace process known as Contadora, but that they would continue to seek military aid for the rebels fighting Nicaragua's Government.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VALERIAN A. ZORIN, SOVIET ENVOY, DIES
description: Valerian A. Zorin, a top Foreign Ministry official who served as the Soviet representative to the United Nations in the early 1960's, has died after a long illness, the Comunist Party newspaper Pravda said today. He was 84 years old.

title: Criminal Charge in Medical Error Is Unjust
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Has Roots In the 15th Century
description: The Gucci family has been producing and selling leather goods in Italy since the 15th century.

title: Alaska Law Restricting Hiring Is Struck Down
description: The Alaska Supreme Court today declared invalid the state's law that restricts hiring of nonresidents to work on public construction projects, saying that the United States Constitution protected nonresidents from job discrimination so the nation could function as an economic unit.

title: Bail Denied In Thrift Case
description: A circuit judge today denied bail for the former president of the Old Court Savings and Loan Association and his wife. But an appellate court did not rule on their case, allowing Jeffrey and Karol Levitt to remain free at least through the weekend.

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago revenue figures have been restated to exlude sales of crude oil and refined products resulting from reciprocal purchase-sale agreements. Net income for 1985 reflects a reduction of $35 million due to a deferral of realization of crude oil profits in inventory, effective June 1, 1985.

title: FOREIGNERS EVACUATING SOUTHERN YEMEN
description: Hundreds of Soviet nationals and other foreigners were evacuated by ship from battle-torn Southern Yemen today.

title: Austrian Wins
description: Peter Wirnsberger overcame poor visibility and gusty winds to win the men's World Cup downhill ski race today. The victory moved him to within striking distance of first place in the overall standing.

title: OLSON SETS RECORD IN POL VAULT
description: Billy Olson soared 19 feet 3 1/2 inches tonight to regain the world indoor pole-vault record at the Sunkist Invitational track meet.

title: MOSELEY, HALLGARTEN, ESTAROOK & WEEDEN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $12,024,000 from liquidation of inventories associated with certain terminated U. S. Government securities trading activities. c-Net income.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income after a net charge of $1,890,000 for inventory writedowns.

title: Staying Close to Home
description: With more than 100 recruiters after him and his mother and father pulling him in different directions, Tony VanZant, the running back who was named by Parade magazine as the top high school player of 1985, was beginning to wonder if he would ever get out of school. ''This last month or so my school work was not coming around like it was supposed to,'' he told a Quarterback Club awards banquet in St. Louis Thursday night.

title: A Princely Art Show Is Visiting the Met
description: To the Editor:

title: Burkina Faso and Mali Hold Warm Talks
description: The leaders of Burkina Faso and Mali smiled broadly, shook hands and hugged each other here today as they met for the first time since their countries fought a brief border war last month.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE DOWNTOWN Y
description: In the locker rooms and on the squash courts of what has become one of Washington's most exclusive health clubs, the swimmers are fomenting rebellion. Already the aquatic activists have organized themselves into six committees to work out a plan of action. Petition drives are under way to alert the more complacent weight lifters, joggers and handball players to the gravity of the situation.

title: THE SYSTEM NEVER FAILS
description: With a mere 105 days left until post time, it is time to ask: Who's going to win the 112th Kentucky Derby?

title: IOMEGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,362,000 for the quarter and $7,080,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $1,055,000 for the quarter and $1,280,000 for the year.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THORNY ISSUE IN GOETZ CASE
description: Justice Stephen G. Crane acknowledged on Thursday with unusually forceful language how extraordinary the case of Bernhard H. Goetz had become. He called it ''one of the most difficult of our generation,'' and said that when Mr. Goetz shot four young men on an IRT subway train a year ago, his action ''galvanized the world.''

title: KDI Sale Fought
description: The KDI Corporation said its executive committee would recommend that the full board reject a proposal by First Wilshire Securities Management to purchase all of KDI's outstanding shares. First Wilshire has offered $12.50 a share, or about $106 million total, for the maker of swimming pools and industrial products. First Wilshire and its clients already control 6.7 percent of KDI's shares.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,577,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $61,064. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $18,414. The company did not report sales figures because it is still in the development stage.

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIVOR WINS SUIT
description: A jury awarded $5.2 million today to a survivor of a Nazi concentration camp who asserted he had been emotionally tortured by the taunts of a man who kept telling him the Holocaust was a fiction.

title: IF MR. SHULTZ IS SERIOUS ABOUT VISAS
description: To hear George Shultz tell it, there's now a ''significant change'' in the State Department's oddly fearful policy of denying visitors' visas to controversial writers and public figures. As the Secretary of State explained to the International PEN Congress, the issuing of visas ''now involves the strong presumption against denying access for foreign policy reasons. No denial is ever based on a person's abstract belief.''

title: From Rung to Rung On the Civil Service Ladder
description: Two New York City Civil Service workers, a man and a woman, were gossiping about who had argued with whom, when Smith had replaced Jones, where had Jones gone, what had broken down this week and other significant news.

title: THE S.E.C. MAY PAY INFORMANTS
description: John S. R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency might begin to offer cash rewards for information about people who manipulate stock prices by spreading false rumors or who profit by insider trading.

title: WICKES SETS TALKS IN GRACE UNIT BID
description: The Wickes Companies said today that it planned to discuss the purchase of a chain of retail home-improvement stores from W.R. Grace & Company, the New York-based chemical and natural resources company.

title: REAGAN'S HELP IS NEEDED TO SAVE THE EVERGLADES' ECOSYSTEM
description: Florida's Everglades ecosystem is one of a kind: an intricate mosaic of marshes, lakes, rivers, mangrove forests and the world's greatest concentration of sawgrass prairies. It nurtures an extraordinary variety of wildlife, providing a home for 30 endangered species, including the wood stork, the manatee, the Florida panther, the American crocodile and bald eagle.

title: Bulldogs, Gators Fail to Get Along
description: Georgia and Florida were playing basketball on the Bulldogs' court the other night when a Big East game broke out. Yes, it was another in a series of brawls that seem to be growing in both number and nastiness as the college season progresses. The bench-emptying violence at Athens occurred early in the second half, when, within a span of 30 seconds, players from both teams landed so many punches to the head that Larry Gay, one of Georgia's assistant coaches, said afterward he had feared a repetition of the infamous Minnesota-Ohio State melee of 1972.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cracow Philharmonic
description: Yo-Yo Ma will join Krzysztof Penderecki and the Cracow Philharmonic for the first New York performance of Mr. Penderecki's Cello Concerto tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall. The program will also include Mr. Penderecki's ''Awakening of Jacob'' and Shostakovich's Symphony No. 6 in B minor (Op. 54). Tickets are $13 to $22.50; information: (212) 247-7800.

title: TWO, IT SEEMS, CAN PLAY THE NUMBERS GAME
description: Twenty-one years ago Ruth Legard Sivard started publishing a comparison of world social and military expenditures for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: Ralston Purina
description: The Ralston Purina Company said its board had adopted a new program to repurchase up to five million shares of the company's common stock.

title: South Africa Bars 9 Clerics From Visit
description: South Africa refused today to allow nine clergymen from the United States and Canada to come here for a visit, accusing them of links to black guerrillas.

title: GUARDING AGAINST FALLS
description: A FEW days before Christmas, Stephen Brotter, a 37-year-old Manhattan resident, was walking along Lexington Avenue, finishing his holiday shopping. It had snowed the night before and the sidewalk was slick. He was wearing rubber-soled boots.

title: PEN CONGRESS ENDS WITH A PROTEST
description: Women at the International PEN Congress got an explanation, but no apology, yesterday for what they considered to be inadequate representation at the weeklong gathering. Several walked out in protest.

title: WITHERSPOON CAPTURES CROWN
description: Tim Witherspoon wrested the World Boxing Association heavyweight title from previously unbeaten Tony Tubbs tonight with a pressuring body attack that earned him a majority decision.

title: CULLEN/FROST BANKERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bankruptcy Court Receives 25,000 Dalkon Shield Letters
description: The United States Bankruptcy Court has received nearly 25,000 letters from potential Dalkon Shield claimants in the United States, Europe and Australia, the court's clerk says.

title: Passing at Auburn
description: At Auburn, Pat Sullivan set 20 school passing records and won the 1971 Heisman Trophy, but since then Auburn has been more known for its running backs. Bo Jackson, who won the 1985 Heisman Trophy is the latest of outstanding runners, including William Andrews, James Brooks and Joe Cribbs.

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Ransom of $3 Million Frees Arab Businessman in London
description: The kidnapped brother of the United Arab Emirates Ambassador to Britain was found unharmed today after a $3 million ransom was paid, the police said.

title: NEWCENTURY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: WEST SIDE TRANSIT: OFFICIALS TAKE A LOOK AHEAD
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is taking a long, hard look at the developing West Side corridor - the area from the Battery to the George Washington Bridge on the West Side of Manhattan - to assess the area's future mass transit needs.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK- ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividends to be paid Jan. 31.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Paris on Dec. 14 about a lawsuit brought against the United States by the Pasteur Institute incorrectly characterized the Institute's accomplishments in the study of AIDS. In early 1983, the Institute sustained the suspected AIDS virus in a test tube by repeated infection of fresh white blood cells. In the months that followed, many scientists eventually became convinced that the Institute had indeed identified the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Sutter Suffers Fracture
description: Brian Sutter, the Blues captain who was injured Thursday in the loss to the North Stars, suffered a hairline shoulder fracture and will be out indefinitely. . . . Bob Probert, the Red Wings forward who was involved in a brawl with the Maple Leafs Jan. 13, was given a four-game suspension after Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L. executive vice president, ruled that Probert had ''deliberately used excessive and potentially dangerous methods to gain advantage'' in the fight.

title: Spinks to Fight Holmes
description: Michael Spinks will defend the International Boxing Federation heavyweight title in a rematch with Larry Holmes sometime in April as one of a series of bouts leading to an undisputed heavyweight champion in 1987.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE PARK Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux were perhaps New York's greatest ''parkies.'' They are best known here for the creation of Central Park and Prospect Park, but they left their marks on other New York open spaces, as well. This weekend, in two separate walking tours, the Urban Rangers, will be patrolling such sectors.

title: CONTROVERSY SERVES PARTNERS WELL
description: The natural thought was that the first thing Ken Flach would do would be to cut his hair. Maybe even shave it off completely. He certainly had reason enough, because that wavy, shoulder-length mane had almost cost him and his doubles partner, Robert Seguso, the United States Open doubles championship last September.

title: BAD WEATHER LEAVES SPACECRAFT STUCK ORBIT FOR AN EXTRA DAY
description: The space shuttle Columbia, which set a record for launching delays, distinguished itself today by becoming the first shuttle to have its landing postponed twice.

title: CHALLENGER INTL SERVICES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Society for Savings
description: The Society for Savings said it had remerger proposal from the Shawmut Corporation. The society's board said the price was inadequate and that this was an inappropriate time to consider selling the company. Shawmut said it was disappointed by the board's decision and would now review its options.

title: INDICES OF MODERNITY
description: BAD MANNERS. By Maggie Paley. 198 pages. Clarkson N. Potter. $14.95. There are New Yorkers who have evolved a sort of rarified life that takes place almost entirely on the phone. They conduct business meetings, therapy sessions and romances over the phone; they order groceries, pizza and Chinese food over the phone, and they plan parties, orchestrate affairs, and plot the course of their lives over the phone. To deal with all this, they've also developed their own complicated rules of etiquette and gamesmanship, involving the answering machine, the secretary and the multiple-line telephone. Who calls whom first, who keeps whom waiting, who leaves messages for whom and who puts whom on hold -all are indices of where one stands.

title: Columbia Beaten By Brown, 67-61
description: Brown, with a height advantage, held off a second-half challenge and downed Columbia, 67-61, last night in an Ivy League game at Levien Gymnasium.

title: Lawyer Told to Return Legal Fee of $237,853
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ordered Aaron Broder, a trial lawyer, to return $237,853 in legal fees that he received from clients in a personal injury case.

title:
PATENTS;
Recovering Silver From Zeolites
description: A method to recover silver from silver zeolites has been patented for the Energy Department.

title: BULLETS' BACKCOURT ROUTS NETS
description: For much of the season the Washington Bullets have attempted to find backcourt help to replace the injured Frank Johnson, who missed 28 of the 41 games with injuries to his left foot, which was broken for the third time in his career last Dec. 28. They signed Ennis Whatley and Freeman Williams to 10-day contracts, but neither solved the problem.

title: A MANES BIRTHDAY PARTY WITHOUT MANES
description: The gray-haired politicians danced with the ''cute little blonde'' and the band played on.

title: Steven Jobs Settles Suit Filed by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. and its former chairman, Steven P. Jobs, reached a settlement today in their lawsuit filed when Mr. Jobs formed his own company with other Apple employees.

title: MANY CONTRIBUTE TO NEEDIEST OUT OF CONCERN FOR HOMELESS
description: Contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have surpassed last year's total and approached the record set the year before.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOAL WITH 1:25 LEFT BEATS THE DEVILS
description: Despite committing many forced passes and unnecessary penalties, the Devils had a good chance to win, or at least tie, the Washington Capitals tonight. But a goal with 1 minute 25 seconds left sent the Devils to a 4-3 defeat at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: VLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A Critic's Notebook column on Thursday about the PEN Congress misstated the length of time the Cuban poet Heberto Padilla was imprisoned in Cuba. He was jailed in 1971 for a month, not for years, after breaking with Fidel Castro.

title: SEEQ TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit $183,000.

title: New Parking Chief Named
description: Joseph F. Bruno, the city's First Deputy Fire Commissioner, was named director of the Parking Violations Bureau yesterday, replacing Lester N. Shafran, who resigned this week as a Federal investigation into allegations of bribery in the bureau widened. Mr. Bruno, who is 42 years old, was appointed by Mayor Koch. He will earn an annual salary of $82,110.

title: NASHVILLE CITYBANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earns have been adjusted to reflect a 20 procent stock dividend in January 1985 and a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1985.

title: TANK BATTLE PUTS LEBANESE NEARER TO FULL CIVIL WAR
description: A tank battle raged today between rival Lebanese at the approaches to the hometown of President Amin Gemayel as Lebanon slipped closer toward full-scale civil war.

title: MORGENTHAU TO APPEAL RULING ON GOETZ
description: The Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday that he would appeal a judge's dismissal of charges of attempted murder and assault against Bernhard H. Goetz in the shooting of four youths who sought money from him on a Manhattan subway.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction in this space on Thursday, about a Washington dispatch on a lawsuit against the Federal Government by church organizations, characterized the suit incorrectly. It opposes, on constitutional grounds, Government agents' infiltration of congregations harboring illegal aliens.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Standard Inc. announced that it had accepted a letter of intent from an investor group to purchase its Majestic Fireplace division.

title: TWIN DISC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: YORK FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $685,000 for the quarter and $695,000 for the 6 months.

title: THIS HIRING TIGER NEEDS ITS TEETH
description: Why should the Federal Government loosen affirmative action requirements for Federal contractors that have been in place for 20 years? If Labor Secretary Bill Brock has his way, they'll hold firm. But if Attorney General Edwin Meese prevails, a proud history of progress in opening employment opportunities to minority members and women may come to an end. A long debate within the Reagan Administration seems near conclusion; the outcome will determine whether it has any respect at all for civil rights.

title: Housing Starts Soared in December
description: The level of construction of new housing in December, reflecting declining mortgage rates and the effect of variable rates, soared 17.5 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: TWO KILLED IN OHIO IN CHEMICAL BLAST
description: A tank containing 2,000 pounds of a caustic chemical exploded today, killing two people, injuring at least 18 and sending a green cloud into the air.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 18, 1986
description: Companies

title: There Is No Bangladesh-India Refugee Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: A VOICE FAR FROM HOME
description: ''Where can a contemporary writer find more vertiginous adventure,'' Vassily Aksyonov once wrote, ''than in literary exile.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. In a bold action, an American operative unimpeded by protocol and legal precedent removed this flag from the diplomatic foyer of the State Department. What flag is it and what was at issue? 2. ''We're very grateful for the offer,'' President Reagan said about something Soviet newspapers had termed ''truly a milestone.'' What offer is it and what condition attached to it may pose problems for the Reagan Administration? 3. ''Diversity, debate, contrast, argumentativeness are what we as a people thrive on,'' said an Administration figure, in a speech that caused diversity, debate, contrast and argumentativeness among many of those who heard it. Identify the figure and explain. 4. For millions of American television viewers, S-Day was a dark day. Explain. 5. As Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger continued to disagree on the best response to terrorist acts, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, issued a new public threat. What was it? 6. The Chicago Bears reached the Super Bowl without giving up a point in the playoffs, making them the only team that managed that feat. True or false? 7. B.A.T. Industries, a London-based company, intends to sell a retail chain whose flagship store, now foundering, was until recently one of the more visible retailers in New York City. What store is it? 8. When the second session of the 99th Congress convenes next week, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will have set a record for the longest consecutive tenure as Speaker.

title: PAROLE IS DENIED MURDER CONVICT GIVEN CLEMENCY BY THE GOVERNOR
description: A panel of the State Parole Board voted unanimously today against releasing a convicted murderer granted clemency by Governor Cuomo.

title: LITTLE ACTION EXPECTED AT GROUP OF 5 MEETING
description: Senior officials from the five major industrial nations will gather here Saturday for two days of talks that are expected to reaffirm a commitment to the major initiative the group forged last September, but yield no further sea changes in world economic policy.

title: Why Limit Presidents To Just Two Terms?
description: To the Editor:

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 22
Arbitration Dropouts
description: Nine players who filed for salary arbitration Wednesday have reached agreement with their clubs, including three of the four players from Baltimore who filed - Jackie Gutierrez, Floyd Rayford and John Shelby. Others who removed their names from the arbitration list were Mark Gubicza of Kansas City, Carlos Diaz of Los Angeles, Candy Maldonado of San Francisco, Jose DeLeon of Pittsburgh, Luis Aguayo of Philadelphia and Keith Atherton of Oakland.

title: KOHL SPURNS OVERT ACTION AGAINST LIBYA
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, although urging closer international cooperation in combating terrorism, warned this week that overt action against Libya could generate a wave of solidarity among Arab nations that would be harmful to Western interests.

title: From Brooklyn Heights To Cobble Hill
description: There will be a small party with wine this afternoon to mark the end of the Community Bookstore in Brooklyn Heights. For the last two years, community residents have rallied to keep the bookstore, at 162 Montague Street, open, but the rent just went to high for the owner, John Scioli.

title:
PATENTS;
Improving TV Quality
description: AT&T; Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., received a patent this week promising television with higher definition and better luminance, chrominance and aspect ratio. Patent 4,564,857 was granted to Joseph L. LoCicero, a faculty member at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, and two associates. Ordinary television signals are to be transmitted over one channel and the brightness and color over another.

title: SEACOAST BANKING OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOTTO PLAYERS MAKE $30 MILLION PLANS
description: Casper Baker Gary is a man with a plan.

title: COMPUTERS SEEN AS A KEY HURDLE IN MISSILE SHIELD
description: Previous Pentagon studies have paid too little attention to the fundamental problem of how to design computer programming that could manage a space-based antimissile system, a panel appointed by the Defense Department has concluded.

title: Bonner Calls Sakharov, But Talk Is Interrupted
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident, talked for 10 minutes today with her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, but the call was interrupted by static when she tried to tell him he was being secretly filmed by the K.G.B., according to her son-in-law, Efrem Yankelevich.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE POSITIVE MOVE BY MOSCOW ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The recent arms-control proposal by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, signals some possible movement toward a ban on chemical weapons, according to Administration officials.

title: MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Edged Out
description: Devils' Kirk Muller, left, and Capitals' Dwight Schofield battling for the puck in first period last night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Devils lost, 4-3. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of units acquired from Hoover Universal Inc. in May 1985 and from Ferro Manufacturing Corp. in July 1985.

title: On Paying the Bill for Last Year's Dr. King Day
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JANUARY 18, 1986
description: International A tank battle near Beirut between rival Lebanese at the approaches to the hometown of President Amin Gemayel brought Lebanon closer to full-scale civil war. A Lebanese Army spokesman said troops loyal to Mr. Gemayel, a Christian, used United States-supplied tanks and armored personnel carriers to drive back the Soviet-built tanks of the Syrian-backed Moslem and leftist militias. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Italy is ready to take new steps against Libya, its political leaders told President Reagan's special envoy. The envoy, Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead, on a tour to enlist support for President Reagan's moves against Libya, said the United States had given the Italian leaders new evidence of Libyan ties to the airport attacks in Rome and Vienne last month, and said it was ''incontrovertible.'' [ 3:1. ] Spain formally recognized Israel. Senior foreign ministry officials from the two countries met in what was described as virtual secrecy in The Hague and signed a joint statement establishing diplomatic ties. [ 3:2. ] Southern Yemen was evacuated by Soviet citizens and other foreigners. The evacuation by ship began as a violent four-day-old power struggle in the country's Marxist Government appeared to veer toward tribal warfare. [ 4:1. ] Shareholders rejected a rescue plan of an American-led consortium for Britain's financially ailing Westland helicopter company at a meeting in London. Their refusal to support the bailout offer by the Sikorsky division of United Technologies and Fiat of Italy insured that the commercial and political battle surrounding Westland, would continue.

title: POLICE TAPES ABOUT MANES ARE RELEASED
description: The Police Department yesterday released tape recordings of conversations between police officers the morning that Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes was taken to a hospital, bleeding from wounds he suffered under circumstances yet to be clarified.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST MICHIGAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OFFICIALS DROP CASE AGAINST 5 ON CHILD ABUSE
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney today dropped charges against five of the seven teachers and administrators at the McMartin Preschool in a child molestation case, saying the evidence against them ''was incredibly weak.''

title: College Head Asks Study Of Spanish Be Required
description: The president of Temple University, situated in a black and Hispanic neighborhood in north Philadelphia, wants to make Spanish a requirement for graduation by 1990.

title: Wanted: Library Director
description: The National Archives, which manages Presidential libraries around the country, is looking for a new director for the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston.

title: UNION BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Union Bank is a wholly owned subsidiary of London-based Standard Chartered PLC and, therefore, does not report per share earnings.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The figures include the results of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Kearny from Oct. 1, 1984. The per share figures have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1985.

description: b-Including a gain of $4,284,000, or 17 cents a share, from the disposition of the Shamrock Hilton in Houston. c-Including gains of $18.2 million, or 71 cents a share, for the quarter from the sale of Avco stock and $28,482,000 for the year on the sale of marketable securities.

title: Adjournment In Tin Talks
description: The International Tin Council adjourned emergency talks in London today without reaching a solution to the crisis in the market, delegates said. They said the talks will resume Tuesday.

title: SETTING THE GROUND RULES
description: Ordinarily, Washington newsmakers and the reporters who cover them are able to work out in advance the ground rules for interviews. But not always.

title: Spud's Slams
description: The idea emits a distinct aroma of gimmickry, but you have to like the National Basketball Association's creative thinking. To what else can you attribute a decision to ask a 5-foot-7-inch rookie guard to participate in the league's popular slam-dunk contest?

title: GUCCI ADMITS ERVADING $7 MILLION IN INCOME TAXES
description: Aldo Gucci, the former head of Gucci Shops Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges for failing to pay more than $7 million in Federal income taxes.taxes.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mudd Posts 63 to Tie for Lead
description: Jodie Mudd came onto the PGA Tour in 1982 after winning two consecutive United States Public Links championships in 1980 and 1981, and he then found himself spinning his wheels in the professional game until last year. But even 1985 was frustrating because he finished second three times, including two runner-up spots in playoffs.

title: DANCE: A TRIBUTE TO JEROME ROBBINS
description: Can there be any doubt that Jerome Robbins is America's greatest ballet choreographer? And can anyone doubt that he is also American ballet's most versatile choreographer?

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Strikers Gain Raise of 52% in 4-Year Pact
description: Twelve striking workers at the headquarters of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have returned to work after winning a 52 percent pay increase over four years.

title:
PATENTS;
Procedures to Test A Rheumatic Disorder
description: Procedures to be used for testing a rheumatic disorder, in which the body produces substances that attack its own tissues, have been invented by Ethan A. and Michael R. Lerner, brothers who did the research at Yale University.

title: From the Bronx to 47th St.
description: ''I'm nervous,'' Federico Fraguada said, chewing gum rapidly and holding a glass of champagne in a shaky hand.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: McCall Pattern, incorporated as TLC Pattern Inc., is a member of the TLC Group Inc.

title: Capacity Use Rises To 80.5%
description: The operating rate at United States factories, mines and utilities climbed to 80.5 percent of capacity in December, the best gain in four months, the Government reported today.

title: A PREMIERE DOWN HOME FOR 'THE COLOR PURPLE'
description: The hand-lettered banner stretched across Jefferson Avenue reads, ''Welcome Home, Alice Walker,'' and the marquee of the Pex Theater, the town's last and only picture show, proclaims the big news.

title: No Headline
description: S.E.C. Files Insider Charge

title: SELF-DEFENSE AGAINST THE COMMON COLD
description: It may not be a milestone in medical history, but it's nothing to sneeze at either. After years of futile assaults from home remedies, folk wisdom and the best that science can offer, the common cold has finally yielded ground. A few sniffs of the natural antiviral agent alpha-2 interferon, say two reports in The New England Journal of Medicine, can halve the number of colds passed around a family.

title: BEAUFORT OIL HOPES SPURRED
description: The recent discovery of a potentially huge oilfield in the Beaufort Sea has heightened optimism about future oil production in the Canadian Arctic, according to Canadian oil industry officials.

title: REAGAN'S PROSPECTS: EXPERTS SEE NO CAUSE FOR ALARM
description: The discovery of three new polyps in President Reagan's bowel only six months after his colon cancer was surgically removed was unusual and unexpected but is not necessarily a cause for concern, according to leading cancer experts.

title: THOMAS LIEBMAN, 78, EX-BREWING EXECUTIVE
description: Thomas Liebman, a former brewing executive and president of the 92d Street Y, died Tuesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain from the sale of a subsidiary of $8,700,000, or 63 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: TV: 'MAFIA PRINCESS,' AN NBC OFFERING
description: There are some surprises in ''Mafia Princess,'' the autobiographical film on ''NBC Sunday Night at the Movies'' at 9 P.M. tomorrow. There is minimal violence, only two short, unemphasized scenes. And the show, sentimental and often cliched as it is, evokes in a viewer a concern about the principals, who are so well characterized by the actors who interpret them.

title: ITALY READY FOR NEW LIBYA SANCTIONS
description: Italian political leaders told President Regagan's special envoy today that they were prepared to take new measures against Libya. Libya.

title: EQUITABLE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings have been adjusted for subsequent stock dividends.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Tumble
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled in late trading yesterday on moderate but persistent selling.

title: CORETTA KING STRUGGLES WITH WEIGHTY LEGACY
description: All this week tourists, celebrities and platoons of security officers have been crowding the $15 million Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, as the recorded preachings of the slain civil rights leader play above his tomb.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
KNICKS FALL SHORT IN CLUTCH
description: The Knicks came a long way back tonight, and then they stumbled badly. After spending most of the evening trying to recover from an abominable opening period, they failed at the game's decisive moments, missing seven chances to score in a four-minute span and finally succumbing to the San Antonio Spurs, 113-100.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss form discontinued operations of $12,000.

title: A PAY PHONE CAN BE YOURS AND THE TOLL IS NEGOTIABLE
description: Just because the telephone company says a call from a pay phone costs 25 cents does not mean it has to. A new regulation allows any individual to install a pay phone and charge a dime, a nickel or whatever.

title: SOCIETY FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,411,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,725,000, or $1.21 a share, for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,738,000, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,919,000 for the year. The per share figure for the previous year was not applicable as the bank converted to stock form in February 1984.

title: FIRST UNITED FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aloha Retains Bear
description: Aloha Inc. said its board had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to advise the company with respect to enhancing shareholder values. The company said it had been advised by shareholders representing about 37 percent of its two million shares outstanding that they had decided to consolidate their voting interests.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S.-Japan Textile Talks
description: The United States and Japan remained far apart on an American proposal to curtail Japanese textile exports after the third round of talks on the issue ended Thursday.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on sale of investments of $298,000 for the quarter and $4,597,000 for the year. c-Includes gains of $682,000 for the quarter and $18,130,000 for the year.

title: FRANCHISEIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
West Village Chorale
description: The West Village Chorale, under the direction of Gwen Gould, will present a 15th anniversary benefit concert and homecoming celebration tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the restored Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street, which was destroyed by fire in 1981. The program includes music by David Goldstein, Michael Ward, Bach, Schutz, Josquin and Palestrina. Tickets are $15; information: 924-0562.

title: MONEY FUNDS RETAIN ALLURE
description: When the public discovered money market funds about five years ago, high interest rates were believed to be the big attraction over savings deposits. But even though rates are now nowhere near their former double-digit levels, investors continue to squirrel away more than $200 billion in the money funds.

title: LONDON PLAN FAILS ON AILING COMPANY
description: Shareholders of a financially ailing British helicopter company, whose future has become a major political issue here, refused today to endorse a rescue plan offered by an American-led consortium.

title: KOCH SAYS RISE IN AID BY STATE IS SHORT OF GOAL
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that, with the city counting on a $200 million net increase in state aid to help it maintain essential services in the face of Federal budget cuts, Governor Cuomo's budget proposal was short $94.2 million in aid.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shares outstanding represent sub- shares. Share earning are per sub- share. Total income for the latest periods include rentals, royalties and other income of $1,585,577 for the quarter and $7,268,506 for the year and land sales of $3,398,848 for the quarter and $4,899,770 for the year. Year-ago total income figures include rentals, royalties and other income of $1,609,067 for the quarter and $6,726,204 for the year and land sales of $1,345,073 for the quarter and $6,457,009 for the year.

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $262,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary credit of $272,000.

title: SCREEN: 'IRON EAGLE,' A TALE OF TEEN-AGE MILTARY EESCUE
description: ''Iron Eagle'' is a very shrewd teen-age variation on the ''Rambo''/''Missing in Action'' formula, a military rescue movie with a nice young hero and a fun-loving feeling. It tells what happens to Doug Masters (Jason Gedrick) after his father, Col. Ted Masters (Tim Thomerson) is shot down in an unnamed Arab country for accidentally violating that country's air space. The Arabs are planning to execute the colonel, and the State Department and Air Force are doing little to negotiate his release.

title: COURT HOLDS PRIVACY ACT REQUIRES CLEAR DECISIONS IN SECURITY CASES
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the Privacy Act required the State Department to make a clear-cut decision on a disputed security case.

title: BURGERS AND BERT
description: Bert Lance of Calhoun, Ga., still makes news occasionally, as he did the other day when he announced plans to resign as chairman of the Calhoun First National Bank and to sell, with others, controlling interest in the bank. Peter Jennings, who anchors the ABC News program ''World News Tonight,'' decided to call Mr. Lance about this development. Mr. Jennings rang a Calhoun number and asked for Mr. Lance.

title: LIBYAN FORUM: AMID CHANTS, A WHISPER OF DOUBT
description: Ahmed, a tailor, has a sore arm. The affliction, he says, has political rather than medical origins.

title: La Scala Sees an End To Financial Troubles
description: La Scala, Italy's most prestigious opera house, is expected to end a long streak of multimillion dollar deficits this year thanks to growing commercial sponsorship and television rights.

title: 4 Escape Indiana Prison Through a Storm Sewer
description: Three convicted killers and a convicted burglar broke through six steel barriers blocking a tunnel for steam pipes and storm sewers and escaped from the Indiana State Prison, the authorities said today.

title: RELAX THE IRISH QUOTA
description: Irish officials returned home this week from a visit to Washington jubilant at the prospect of American aid to Northern Ireland's economy. But the aid, though a welcome boost to the recently concluded Anglo-Irish accord giving Dublin a limited voice in Northern Ireland, is not likely to include what many Irish officials privately say would be the best form of assistance Washington could offer Ireland, north and south: permission for more Irish to go to work in America - legally.

title: Your Money; Home-Insurer Discount Plans
description: ROBERT DOWLING, a Braintree, Mass., businessman, found an insert enclosed with his renewal notice for his homeowner insurance policy last year. The announcement said that he would receive a 5 percent discount on his annual premium if his home had three safety features -smoke detectors, a fire extinguisher and dead-bolt locks.

title: Levitt Tells Democrats He Won't Seek Senate
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., Chairman of the American Stock Exchange, told Democratic leaders today that he would not seek the nomination to run against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in New York State.

title: DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $39,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $443,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $373,000 for the quarter and $934,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income.

title: STATEMENT ON TESTS DONE ON REAGAN
description: Following is the White House statement on President Reagan's medical examination today:

title: Photo of advertisements in unusual locations (NYT/Nic Kleinberg; Marty Katz; AP); AD INDUSTRY TURNS UP VOLUME
description: Using such traditional vehicles as television screens and billboards and such unlikely new ones as parking meters and ski lift towers, advertisers are bombarding Americans with an ever-increasing number of messages.

title: Mailbox; List of Shutouts Was Incomplete
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: About Men; A Nightingale Sang
description: IT IS 6 A.M. AND I AM AT THE AIR-port on my way to Philadelphia. I have not slept well. Around midnight last night I turned on the radio.

title: On Language; Sack Pig's Aperiodic Non-Life-Style
description: CAVALRYMEN FROM Parthia, an ancient land southeast of the Caspian Sea, gained fame by shooting over their shoulders while running away; the technique became known as the Parthian shot, and is now often corrupted to parting shot. In this tradition of defiant retreat, President Reagan's recently departed national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, has left his imprint on military bureaucratese.

title: WHAT CITY TEST SCORES ADD UP TO
description: There were smiles of satisfaction at the Board of Education's headquarters in Brooklyn last week as officials released a school-by-school breakdown of the results of reading tests administered in April to more than 430,000 elementary and junior high school students.

title: SOUTHPORT ZIP
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPANSION UNDER WAY AT TEMPLE ISRAEL
description: THE staff of the Temple Israel Center in White Plains has set up its desks in two large trailers in the synogogue's garden, in order to get out of the way while workmen complete a $2.5 million addition and renovation.

title: A VENERABLE MODERNIST BRINGS CHICAGO A BREATH OF FRESH AIR
description: It is nearly a quarter-century since the completion of Marina City, a pair of 65-story, round towers of concrete that stand out boldly amid the sleek, glass-and-steel skyline of downtown Chicago. The scalloped-edge Marina City buildings, which from a distance look not unlike upended corncobs, were among the first major mixed-use projects in the country; they contain apartments and commercial space, and were intended by their architect, Bertrand Goldberg, to be a social statement as much as an esthetic one. Mr. Goldberg, like many architects trained in the modernist idiom, dreamed of great megastructures that would infuse life and activity into the central city, and envisioned the technology of concrete construction as the most economical means to this end.

title: COLLEGE BOXING: RARE BUT RESURGENT
description: TRADITIONALLY, school sports teams wear the school's colors. In the case of Central Connecticut State University in New Britain, that would be royal blue and white.

title: Sally Kornbluth to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. H. George Kornbluth of Fair Lawn, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Sally Ann Kornbluth, to Daniel Julio Lew, the son of Drs.

title: WEST GERMAN FANS SUPPORT BECKER
description: Down near the court, where corporate executives and the wealthiest of the tennis elite fill most of the seats, the atmosphere at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon during the opening semifinal match was traditional. There was little cheering, except for the proper kind, which came only after a particularly well-played point by Boris Becker of West Germany or Anders Jarryd of Sweden.

title: INFORMER'S ACCOUNT ATTACKED AT 'PIZZA' TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers have completed eight days of cross-examining a Mafia informer, repeatedly attacking his key testimony in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial in Manhattan.

title: SHOULD FARMERS GO COLD TURKEY?
description: Perhaps the most important event in the postwar drive to modernize the raising of farm animals, most authorities now agree, was the discovery in 1949 that antibiotic drugs cause chicks to gain weight quickly. The finding forever changed how farmers produce beef, pork, poultry and eggs.

title: Miss Abert Plans A June Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. James G. Abert of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan A. Abert to David Lindsay Noonan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Noonan of Evanston, Ill. The wedding is planned for June.

title: A JOURNALIST FALLS BEFORE MYTHMAKERS
description: A COUPLE of years ago, while teaching a broadcast journalism course at the University of Hartford, I asked my students, ''Who was Edward R. Murrow?'' I was dismayed to learn that not one could identify the late CBS News correspondent.

title: FINDING SAFETY AND YIELD ON BIG BOARD
description: Some investors seek big returns by investing in companies with a high growth potential - and high risk. Others concentrate on dividend yields, and generally shun growth stocks.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: PAINTER'S WORKS IN A SINGULAR SHOW
description: PRACTICALLY all of the 60 or so artists whose works are now at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center for its ''American Art: American Women'' exhibit have major reputations. But reflecting the policy of Dorothy Mayhall, the museum's art director, of giving unknowns a chance, in its Art/Ex Gallery is a solo show by Betty Tompkins, one of the unfamiliar names in the main event.

title: NEW CASSETTES: QUAKERS, CRICKETS, LOW-KEYED JAZZ
description: The Jazz Life: The Chico Hamilton Quintet Featuring John Benthal, Michael Santiago, Paul Ramsey, Kathleen Adaar; produced by Ben Sidran Sony Video 53 minutes. $29.95 Chico Hamilton is - or should be -a provocative visual subject.

title: ORCHESTRAL AND CHAMBER OFFERINGS ROUND OUT THE MONTH
description: HALF a dozen orchestral programs and at least that many chamber recitals are scheduled over the rest of the month.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEMOJO BLUES: De Quest of HighJohn de Conqueror. By A. R. Flowers. (Dutton, $16.95.) The black veterans Tucept HighJohn, Willie D. and Mike return from Vietnam in 1971, dishonorably discharged, and go on to their separate lives and different arenas of the black struggle.

title: FAKE FUR, WARM MILK AND DRY ICE ARE PART OF HIS PALLETTE
description: When a camera descended into the lightning-torn clouds of Venus in a sequence that John Allison created for Carl Sagan's television series ''Cosmos,'' viewers were not supposed to guess that they were actually watching swirls of warm milk in a fish tank of water lighted from below by an array of flashbulbs. When Mr. Allison bought $300 worth of Karo syrup to create a giant mock-up of a neuronal synapse (for the public-television series ''The Brain''), his intention was to convince viewers that they were looking at a magnified image of a real nerve cell.

title: A PROLIFERATION OF SPACE CONFERENCES
description: USED to be, the Canaveral Council of Technical Societies' annual Space Congress in Orlando, Fla., was the only chance that space buffs had to gather together. Not any more. A rash of splashy space conferences and symposiums are now covering subjects ranging from how to raise capital for a space venture to how to go about marketing space-related products.

title: NEW FOCUS ON THE OLD
description: I was glad to see Christopher Hallowell's article ''New Focus on the Old'' (Dec. 15). My father was diagnosed as having Alzheimer's disease in 1977, and I would like to bring to the attention of your readers that the National Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association estimates that the disease, which afflicts approximately 2 million United States citizens, costs $26 billion to $28 billion a year.

title: REAGAN'S POLYPS NOT CANCEROUS LAB TESTS SHOW
description: Laboratory tests showed that the three polyps removed Friday from President Reagan's colon were benign, the White House announced today.

title: Day of Reckoning
description: The New York State Legislature passed last year a special bill allowing William Fisher to collect damages for having served 11 years in prison for a crime he did not commit. Last week, the State Court of Claims decided that Mr. Fisher's time was worth $750,000.

title: ARE MUSIC VIDEOS REALLY OPERATIC?
description: The august Metropolitan Opera is the home of the world's greatest operas and the world's largest, greatest opera singers. Here a couple happily pays $130 in tickets for an evening's entertainment and, they earnestly hope, enlightenment.

title: MAGAZINES CATERING TO CRAFTSMEN PROVING POPULAR
description: PAUL ROMAN, an amateur woodworker, sat down in the basement office of his Newtown home one day 10 years ago, and that was the last his family saw of him for three weeks. When he emerged, he had produced the model copy of a glossy black and white bimonthly magazine called Fine Woodworking, which was mailed to 20,000 pre-subscribed readers a few weeks later.

title: CRAZY BY DEFINITION
description: THE FEMALE MALADY Women, Madness, and English Culture, 1830-1980. By Elaine Showalter. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: THEATER: 'THE DUEL,' BASED ON CONRAD TALES
description: IN ''The Duel,'' being presented at La Mama by Jordcirkus, the international, multilingual theater collective based in Stockholm, two 19th-century men right out of Joseph Conrad - or are there really four, or is all this conflict really inside one man? - are pitted against one another in a battle to the death that is absurd but also natural, even inevitable.

title: Jennifer Maslow, Teacher Is Bride Of F. C. Morgan
description: Jennifer Lynne Maslow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., was married yesterday to Frederick Converse Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Morgan 2d of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Wallace F. Stettler, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Church of Christ Uniting in Kingston, Pa.

title: THE TEST-TUBE LEAGUE
description: THERE will be no lament here for the good old days when ballplayers hunted and fished all winter and general managers sent out contracts in the low five figures and fans talked trades, not collusion or drugs.

title: Rules of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: A Renewal Of Faith
description: Dan Wakefield has discovered the truth understood by Old Testament believers but so foreign to our modern, supposedly more sophisticated, society.

title: TWO CHURCHES VS. THE STATE IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: Should the Government be allowed to infiltrate a church during a criminal investigation? That question is at the heart of a growing debate over the prosecution of members of the sanctuary movement, which transports Central American refugees into the United States and shelters them in churches and homes.

title: NEW RATING SYSTEM FOR RELIEVERS
description: BASEBALL certainly has enough statistics for judging and rating players and doesn't really need any more, but if there's one group of players who could use more statistics, it's relief pitchers. Statistical categories currently in use do not always fairly reflect the contribution they make - or accurately show their failures. Existing statistics acknowledge only victories, losses and saves. The Baltimore Orioles, though, have created a system that adds holds and squanders, assigns weighted point values to each category and comes up with a point total for each reliever.

title: THE HIDDEN STING OF THE TRADE DEFICIT
description: AMERICAN history is marked by periodic surges in economic inequality that have to be contained by government action. The Interstate Commerce Commission and the antitrust laws were designed to stop the surge in inequality created by the robber barons of the mid- and late-19th century. Social Security and unemployment insurance were our answer to the surge in inequality produced by the Great Depression.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hartsdale, N.Y. $161,000 115 Alexander Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 60-year-old stucco colonial; *2*formal dining room, den, eat-in kitchen, 3d-floor sitting *2*room with skylight; taxes $3,301. New Rochelle, N.Y. $342,000 215 Ronbru Drive *2*5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old stone/ frame split level, *2*formal dining room, den with fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $6,902. Scarsdale, N.Y. $407,500 107 Brite Avenue *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 68-year-old colonial; *2*den, porch, darkroom, 2-car garage; taxes $5,816. Greenwich, Conn. $240,000 20 Church Street *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old high-rise condominium; *2*near shopping, $357 monthly charges; taxes $2,684. West Haven, Conn. $65,500 844 Ocean Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, older ranch; *2*opposite waterfront, aluminum siding; taxes $1,418. Norwalk, Conn. $181,000 5 Frances Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; *2*2 fireplaces, attractive lot; taxes $2,269. OTHER AREAS Secaucus, N.J. $149,900 320 Sea Isle Key *2*1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 8-year-old town-house condominium; *2*sunken living room, fireplace, den, $133 monthly charges; taxes $1,920. Head of the Harbor, L.I. $274,500 10 Armand Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; *2*fireplace, loft, den, brick patio, 2 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $4,800. Mineola, L.I. $155,000 26 Hill Street *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,200.

title: THE BEARS BET AGAINST COMMODORE
description: DESPITE the popularity of its inexpensive home computers, Commodore International Ltd. has been badly wounded in the industry's marketing wars - and some professional traders are betting that the wounds may prove fatal if the company's vaunted Amiga does not pan out.

title: ACTRESS FINDS FIRST STAGE EASY, BUT...
description: TRACY SALLOWS is not having a particularly easy time launching her acting career - it just looks that way.

title: FAST FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BENCHLEY AT THE THEATRE: Dramatic Criticism, 1920-1940. By Robert Benchley. (The Ipswich Press, P.O. Box 291, Ipswich, Mass. 01938, $14.95.) The best dramatic criticism recalls theatrical occasions to vivid presence, reveals what is not obvious about their nature and workings and relates them to larger contexts of art and life.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TAX SUCCESS SEEN AS A BOON TO DUKAKIS
description: An innovative program to improve tax collection has increased state revenue by 27 percent over the past two years, Massachusetts officials say, enabling Gov. Michael S. Dukakis to preside over the largest tax cut in Massachusetts history.

title: Debra Stone, Lawyer, Weds David H. Glaser
description: Debra F. Stone, an associate with the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and David H. Glaser, an associate in the corporate finance department of Bear, Stearns & Company, were married yesterday. Rabbi Joel Gorr officiated at Le Ferrandi restaurant in New York.

title: OPERA: 'IDOMENEO,' BY MOZART, AT MET
description: ''IDOMENEO,'' the finest work ever composed in the opera seria tradition, is not only about virtuosic singing by any means, but without important voices in half a dozen roles it cannot begin to reveal its greatness to an audience. The season's first performance of the Mozart work, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday night for the first time since Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production was new in 1982-83, measured up reasonably well in spots, but on the whole could not sustain the brilliance necessary for opera in the high-Baroque manner.

title: Ilissa A. Kimball To Wed in April
description: Judge and Mrs. Sherman P. Kimball of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ilissa Ann Kimball, to Lon Fredric Povich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Povich of Bath, Me.

title: WHERE INGREDIENTS GET RESPECT
description: THE approach to Jonathan's Bridge View in Bayside, Queens, is romantically scenic as the restaurant - in a large, green-shuttered white house trimmed with twinkling lights - comes into view along with the gracefully illuminated sweep of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: Cable TV
description: In frosty weather, a sky-blue little movie like ''Virgin Island'' (1959) should make a balmy antidote this cable week - Friday at 10:05 A.M. on WTBS. This is a pleasant tale of newlyweds on a remote key - John Cassavetes and Virginia Maskell, and a friendly, helpful neighbor, Sidney Poitier. They're appealing people and so is that island background.

title: OPENING YEATS TROVE TO ACADEME
description: TEN years ago, 33 reels of microfilm arrived at the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York. On them were what scholars have termed the most comprehensive collection of manuscripts outside Ireland of William Butler Yeats.

title: LINCOLN MAKES A BOLD DEBUT INTO PROFESSIONAL THEATER
description: ''THE four illustrious Beaugrand sisters meet again in mutual massacre, according to tradition.''

title: Smithsonian to Receive Gift
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has agreed to give $1 million to the Smithsonian Institution for its planned new hall on the information revolution in its National Museum of American History. The gift will account for almost one-quarter of the hall's $4.3 million cost.

title: THE WORLD AS A WORK OF ART
description: NIETZSCHE Life as Literature. By Alexander Nehamas. 261 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: MELANOMA RISE IS SEEN ON ISLAND
description: MELANOMA, a form of skin cancer, is a growing national problem.

title: SPRINT AND TELECOM HEAR WEDDING BELLS
description: GTE is spinning off its Sprint long-distance telephone service into a merger with U.S. Telecom. Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance company after A.T.&T. and MCI, has about 2 million subscribers, mostly in metropolitan areas; U.S. Telecom, No. 4, has specialized data communications facilities. The combination, analysts say, will allow the new U.S. Sprint Communications Company to compete more effectively for business customers with specialized data communications needs. GTE has been rumored to be seeking a way of shedding the money-losing Sprint. GTE will take a $1.3 billion writedown; United Telecommunications, U.S. Telecom's parent, will take a $170 million charge and will pay GTE $230 million.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 19, 1986 Fiction

title: NEW ENGLAND VOICES
description: A WHILE ago I was asked to write the introduction to a book of short stories by contemporary New England writers and to consider the question of regional writing. My first thought was that all serious writing, from anywhere, so far transcends the regional that the question didn't warrant discussion. I hardly ever think whether fiction from New England is different from Middle Western fiction or Southwestern fiction or whatever fiction. Real writers - the writers who write serious rather than formula fiction - use the images at their fingertips, whatever they are, to give us experience and after that, we hope, some truth.

title: Theater
description: ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' Herb Gardner's affectionate portrait of a pair of New York oldtimers - a diehard socialist and an about-to-be-retired building superintendent -breaks no ground in urban or dramatic redevelopment. However, it is the kind of play that makes theatergoers feel good, providing theatrical comfort in a threatening world.

title: B. Kathleen Munguia Engaged to J. I. Mark
description: Mr. and Mrs. Romulo Munguia of San Antonio have announced the engagement of their daughter B. Kathleen Munguia to Jonathan I. Mark, a son of Ruth W. Friendly of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Sandor Mark. A May wedding is planned.

title: KANSAS WATCHES WHILE WASHINGTON SQUIRMS
description: Retired veterans and civil servants expected a cost-of-living increase in their pensions this month, but as a result of the new budget-balancing law enacted last year, those increases were shelved, and Senator Bob Dole's office here has received more than 100 phone calls protesting the delay. The majority leader says he expects to hear from many more of his constituents as the budget knife slices into other programs.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Jade, Carved Ivories And Tiger's Eye Classic Imaginations opened a year ago in the Scarsdale Park Mall on Central Avenue with traditional crafts from China and Taiwan and some wares from Japan, including costume and fine jewelry; handmade collectibles and gifts; decorative antique and modern vases; hand-painted snuff bottles and fans; carved and lacquered screens and rosewood furniture; children's pajamas, dolls and furry animals. Locally mailed coupons offer a 15 percent discount except on sale items and a copy of this column warrants the same markdown through February.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE only Toyota I've ever owned was a well-used little red wagon, a '71 Corolla that was purchased for its economy. As it turned out, the four-cylinder engine never managed to pull more than 14 miles out of a gallon of gas, despite a valve job and all of my best efforts.

title: NEW FOCUS ON THE OLD
description: The Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopedic Institute initiated a geriatric-trauma program last August. This is a program to provide comprehensive care for the geriatric patient who suffers orthopedic injuries.

title: Information on Information
description: The Smithsonian Institution has received the first infusion of private money for its planned new permanent exhibition on information and computers. The institution is trying to raise at least $4.3 million from private sources.

title: McKay Runs 440 Yards In World-Best Clocking
description: Antonio McKay, running unattached, turned in a world-best time tonight in the invitational 440-yard dash at the Eastman Invitational track and field meet at East Tennessee State University. McKay, who finished in 45.45 seconds, bettered the time of 46.60 set by Sumder Nix of Indiana on March 3, 1984.

title: BLASS PLANS LEGISLATIVE CUTS
description: THE new Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, Gregory J. Blass, plans to cut his staff by nearly half and reduce various legislative perquisites because of concern over the Legislature's image and periodic moves to abolish it.

title: PLEASE HOLD THE SALT
description: I especially enjoy your reviews of Nassau restaurants because we frequent them.

title: THE EXPERT WITNESS: ECONOMISTS TURN DATA INTO TESTIMONY
description: WHEN billions of dollars are at stake, where do lawyers find economists to testify as expert witnesses?

title: ELMSFORD WEIGHS OPTIONS FOR LIBRARY SERVICE
description: AN ad hoc committee of nine Elmsford residents has begun studying ways to offer library service to the village of Elmsford. The recommendations of this committee will be presented to the Village Board of Trustees and possibly placed before the voters in a referendum later this year.

title: The Pollack Touch
description: The article on Sydney Pollack was right on target, especially about his concern for ''minutiae.'' As a former director of customer services at Barneys, in New York, I helped Mr. Pollack choose the clothes for his role as Dustin Hoffman's theatrical agent in the movie ''Tootsie.''

title: WRONGFUL ARREST SUIT CITES FLAWS IN COMPUTER DATA
description: Late one evening last summer a Boston graduate student was arrested at gunpoint and held in jail overnight. A week later he was found not guilty of a crime that never occurred.

title: AIR FORCE FAULTED ON SPARE PARTS
description: The Air Force has been buying spare parts for its C-5A cargo plane that appear to be overpriced or unnecessary, a Congressional audit has found.

title: The Navy's Brash Leader
description: It is about time our naval leadership became brash (''The Navy's Brash Leader,'' by Bill Keller, Dec. 15). The Navy, of which Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. took the helm, had sadly been allowed to become complacent, and its forces had fallen to a level that would preclude aggressive response if the call to action was ever sounded.

title: Anne G. McChord Bride of McNeal C. Hutcheson
description: Anne Gayle McChord, a daughter of Catharine McChord Duncan of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Hood Squires McChord, was married yesterday to McNeal Campbell Hutcheson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Houston Hutcheson, also of New Canaan. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: UNIONS HAVE BEEN TAKING THEIR LUMPS
description: ''Organized labor can no longer snap its fingers and expect Democrats to dance,'' Representative Stanley Lundine of upstate New York said recently, explaining why he and 53 other Democrats had voted to kill a bill, backed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., that would have required employers to give 90 days' notice before closing plants or announcing any layoffs.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TWO CELLO PREMIERES The 17-member Garden State Chamber Orchestra will perform in Englewood, Morristown and Union next weekend. The soloist, Joseph Kimura, will play the American premiere of Jacchini's Cello Concerto No. 2 in G minor and the premiere of Frederick Kaufman's Concerto for Cello and String Orchestra (''Kaddish''). Frederick Storfer will conduct. The program also will include Bach's Suite in G minor, Grieg's Holberg Suite and Grainger's ''Handel in the Strand.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON THE BARYTON Although one music dictionary called the baryton ''obsolete,'' the 18th-century instrument is alive and well, and figures in a concert today at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Baryton? But of course; it's a variation of the viola da gamba that produces an almost harpsichord-like sound with its sets of bowed and metal strings. Prince Nicholas Esterhazy played it, and since the Prince was Franz Joseph Haydn's patron, the composer created more than 200 works for the instrument. Some of them will be performed when the Esterhazy Baryton Trio, with its baryton, cello and viola, takes over Coe Hall at 2:30 P.M. For ticket information call Friends of the Arts at 922-0061.CHRISTIE MYSTERY

title: U.S. Court Refuses to Order Rubin Carter Back to Prison
description: A Federal appeals court has denied a request by New Jersey prosecutors that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter be returned to prison while they appeal a dismissal of his 1977 murder conviction.

title: A Testing Time
description: WHEN HITLER AND Stalin flourished, Americans were horrified by stories about good Nazi and good Communist children betraying their parents to the police. ''That can never happen here,'' we said. To make sure it couldn't, we made war upon Hitler and have since devoted much of our national treasure to resistance against Communism.

title: Nancy Burke Is Engaged To Bryan Jason Tunney
