description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burke of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Burke to Bryan Jason Tunney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Tunney of Port Washington, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: CUT DEFICITS, BUT NOT BY SELLING ASSETS
description: MY late father-in-law had a quip - perhaps about himself, after bravely opening a law office in the depths of the Depression - ''Had a good day today,'' he would say. ''Sold my desk.''

title: SPACE SHUTTLE, DETOURED TO CALIFORNIA BY WEATHER, LANDS SAFELY UNDER FOODLIGHTS
description: Guided by powerful floodlights, with the hint of dawn on a desert horizon, the space shuttle Columbia landed safely here today at 5:59 A.M., Pacific standard time.

title: Bright Revival; Chandeliers For Albany
description: The newest stars of Albany are eight glittering chandeliers that were recently hung in the Hampton Plaza development on State Street as part of the rehabilitation of the building. They also are symbols of the economic revival of the downtown area.

title: A PLAN TO FIGHT RETARDATION
description: AN INFLUENTIAL panel appointed by Governor Kean has called for a wide range of state programs to reduce the incidence of mental retardation in New Jersey, including stepped-up efforts to prevent teen-age pregnancies and establishing school-based health clinics in areas with high concentrations of poor children.

title: Who Owns the Poem?
description: In two recent instances The New York Times has treated its readers to all or part of a newly discovered work by and important literary figure: unpublished poetry by William Faulkner, unearthed by Judith Sensibar as part of her doctoral dissertation (March 27, 1984), and now an unpublished poem by Shakespeare. The two events are different, however, in that copyright was attributed to the heirs of the recently deceased Faulkner, while in the case of Shakespeare The Times didn't attempt the backbreaking task of searching out the unknown heirs.

title: Julia A. Bermudez To Become Bride Of George Buxton
description: The engagement of Julia Aurora Bermudez to George Norman Buxton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jorge N. Buxton of New York, Southampton, L.I., and Windham, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Armando Bermudez of Santiago, the Dominican Republic. A March wedding is planned.

title: THE SNOW OF WINTER: WONDERFUL MAGIC...
description: THE first snows of winter are upon us, and my trusty Farmer's Almanac tells me we are in for a few more storms before spring arrives. My neighbors are already grumbling, ''Snow! Who needs it?''

title: ISRAEL REPORTS NO PROOF ETAN PATZ WENT THERE
description: Senior police officers involved in the Israeli hunt for Etan Patz, the missing New York schoolboy, said this week that there was no evidence showing the boy had ever entered Israel.

title: Q&A
description: When an Insider's Out Question: I have lived for nine years in a rent-stabilized apartment. In the spring I plan to move when I am married. My lease expires in September. I believe the building is going to be converted to cooperative ownership. Can I continue to pay the rent even though I don't live there and if so, would I be entitled to a renewal lease? . . . F. H., Sunnyside, Queens Answer: A landlord is not under an obligation to continue renting to or renew a lease for a tenant who is not a primary resident, according to Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner for the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: A LABOR DISPUTE WITH A THIRD SIDE
description: IN rrthis town of 23,000 near the Iowa line, one of the most bitter and intriguing fights in modern labor-management relations is being waged among 1,500 striking meatpackers, their employer, Geo. A. Hormel & Co., and their parent union, the United Food and Commercial Workers.

title: FACTS, NOT OPINIONS, ON TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: In ''Big Brother and Anti-Drinking Laws,'' Arlene DiScala describes the normal interest of teen-agers to try the ''forbidden'' and their use of alcohol in nonrestricted settings. She also discusses the ability of teen-agers to circumvent the law and obtain false identification with which they can purchase alcohol.

title: SEVERAL REPORTED DEAD IN LESOTHO CLASH
description: Several people were reported today to have been killed in a clash between rival forces Friday night near Maseru, the capital of Lesotho, a black-ruled country encircled by South Africa.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: POSTMORTEM: New Evidence in the Case of Sacco and Vanzetti. By William Young and David E. Kaiser. (University of Massachusetts Press, Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.) In 1977 David E. Kaiser, now an associate professor of history at Carnegie-Mellon University, struck up a friendship with William Young, a rare book and art dealer who collected documents bearing on the murder trial of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the two anarchists whose executions in 1927 caused an international furor. Young was preparing a manuscript based on a huge cache of newly released evidence that the Massachusetts State Police had held for nearly 60 years. When Young died of cancer in 1980, Mr. Kaiser went on to complete the work. ''Postmortem'' is a plodding but persuasive study. Its cumulative effect is to affirm the reputations of ''two innocent men'' who ''most probably were framed for a murder they did not commit.'' The revelations of state police files, grand jury proceedings and prosecution notebooks, the authors conclude, ''show that virtually every piece of evidence against the two men ultimately rested upon falsehoods and fabrications.'' The case began in broad daylight on April 15, 1920, when a pair of payroll bandits gunned down two employees of a shoe factory in South Braintree, Mass., and made off with $15,000. Sacco and Vanzetti, Italian immigrants who had been known to dabble in radical politics, were arrested in May. The prosecution did not have a strong case, but the political climate was favorable for a conviction and the district attorney, Frederick Katzmann, was resourceful.

title: OFFICES MOVE BOLDLY BACKWARD OR PLAYFULLY FORWARD
description: TECHNIMETRICS Inc. may only produce what amounts to sophisticated mailing lists, but its offices, which occupy a five-story brick building near Wall Street, are boldly charismatic. The entrance is filled with closely spaced, salmon-colored columns, one of which is broken in the middle; the top half hangs from the ceiling.

title: Mailbox; Penalize Teams For Fans' Noise
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW FOCUS ON THE OLD
description: All of us who have parents lost in senility applaud the new emphasis on geriatrics in medical schools.

title:
ART;
IMAGES DOUBLED IN SCULPTURE SHOW
description: ''DOUBLE IMAGE,'' the title of the current exhibition in the downstairs gallery at the Port Washington Public Library, describes a unifying characteristic that gives coherence to what otherwise would have been simply another group show.

title: NETS STOP NUGGETS, 124-113
description: The Nets got 64 points and 39 rebounds from their starting front line tonight, the best output of the season from their big men, and the payoff was a 124-113 victory over the Denver Nuggets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A Defense of Rhymes
description: To the Editor:

title: A QUESTION OF DEGREE IN SICILY
description: ''Sicily?'' people wondered when my wife and I announced our itinerary last year. ''But why?''

title: MOUNT KISCO CENTER IS FIRST OF TWO PLANNED BY PACE UNIVERSITY
description: PACE UNIVERSITY, which has grown in Westchester from one building and 143 students in 1963 to two campuses and 12,000 students today, will open its third Westchester center on Jan. 27 in eight classrooms of the former St. Francis of Assisi School in Mount Kisco.

title: Georgetown Holds Off Seton Hall, 82-72
description: Seton Hall played evenly with Georgetown for 31 minutes today, and even managed a 5-point lead with seven and a half minutes to go. But since college basketball games remain 40 minutes long, and Georgetown remains Georgetown, the more experienced Hoyas regained command in the final five minutes and won, 82-72, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: IN MINIATURE, U.S. NUCLEAR ARSENAL
description: The 35,000 small clay cones stand in neat rows at the Museum of Science here, like fields of grain waving in the wind.

title: BALLET DE SANTIAGO GROWS UP AND JOURNEYS NORTH
description: ''This is a young company, full of individuality,'' Ivan Nagy says of the

title: HOUSING CRISIS
description: To the Editor; While I agree with every point in ''Facing Up to the Housing Supply Issue'' on Dec. 29 concerning the horrendous implications of our middle-income housing shortage, I feel that the single greatest contributing factor was insufficiently stressed.

title: SHOWS SPUR INTEREST IN ORIENTAL ART
description: Michael Goedhuis, a London dealer who specializes in Islamic, Indian and Japanese art under both his name and Colnaghi Oriental, has been extremely busy on both sides of the Atlantic during the past year. For one thing, he says, he has seen quickened international interest in Oriental art at his London gallery, spurred by several major museum and gallery exhibitions of such material in New York, London and Geneva.

title: NEW CASSETTES: QUAKERS, CRICKETS, LOW-KEYED JAZZ
description: The Beatles Live Sony Video 20 minutes. $19.95 In the heat of Beatlemania, the British pop television series ''Ready Steady Go'' broadcast, in black and white, a live mini-set by the group in 1964 - five full-length songs and a medley of a verse or two from six hits, from ''Love Me Do'' to ''Can't Buy Me Love.''

title: FRENCH BREAD AND CIRCUSES
description: PLEASURES OF THE BELLE EPOQUE Entertainment & Festivity in Turn-of-the-Century France. By Charles Rearick. Illustrated. 240 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: An Easier Way To Grind Pepper
description: EVER try to operate a rotary pepper mill with one hand? Tom David of Nantucket Island, Mass., confronted this problem and came up with what he calls the world's first practical one-handed spice mill.

title: HERO AWARDS GO BEGGING
description: THE Hometown Heroes Program seemed like a nice idea at the time, a way to recognize all those non-celebrities who, without fanfare, have lent a helping hand in their communities.

title: Shall We Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: MINI-SUMMIT HELD IN SOMERSET COUNTY
description: DURING friendly conversations between Soviet visitors and local residents here recently, Yelena Khalevinski, a visitor, commented:

title: VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS ASK FOR PENSIONS
description: VOLUNTEER firefighters in three Connecticut municipalities are seeking pension benefits to help compensate them for services they have traditionally performed for free.

title: MR. CUOMO'S SPENDING PLAN
description: A week after sketching out an agenda for the Legislature in his annual State of the State Message, Governor Cuomo presented the bill last week. In proposing a $41.4 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1, the Governor suggested that New York State increase its spending by more than 7 percent over the level of this fiscal year.

title: STATE FOUND 104 HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES LAST YEAR
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation said this week that it had discovered 104 new hazardous-waste sites in the state last year, including one on Staten Island and 33 others in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Mailbox; Viewers Vote With Radios
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mascot Won't Return
description: Chief Noc-A-Homa, the Braves mascot whose spirited dances after home team home runs have been a part of the ball park scene since the franchise moved to Atlanta in 1966, will not be back for the 1986 season, the club announced. According to the Braves' spokesman, Wayne Minishew, club officials and Levi Walker, the man under the chief's war bonnet, agreed Friday to end their 17-year association, which began when Walker became the third Chief Noc-A-Homa.

title: JIM AND CHONG FIND INNER PEACE
description: THE PROGRESS OF A FIRE By Robert Abel. 509 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Program Trading
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I am trying to find information on purchasing tickets for the World Cup soccer games in Mexico this summer and would like details of any travel agencies offering World Cup packages. - M. W., New York Answer:According to the United States Soccer Federation, the company selected by the Mexican authorities to sell World Cup tickets in this country is Gazebo Travel International (6378 Richmond Avenue, Houston, Tex. 77057; 713-266-1955 or 800-323-2743). Soccer enthusiasts can either deal directly with Gazebo, a travel wholesaler, or have their travel agents do so. The 24 qualifying countries (the United States is not among them) will play off in eight cities from May 31 to June 29.

title: NEW MEDICAL UNIT FOCUSES ON AGING
description: ''IT is important for us to understand that the elderly of today are survivors. The child born at the turn of the century could expect to live about 50 years. The 80-year-olds of today are the ones who didn't succumb to pneumonia when there were no antibiotics, and didn't have a fatal coronary in midlife. Today's 80-year-olds have lived far beyond their 'life expectancy.' '' This comment is by Dr. Steven R. Gambert, professor of medicine at New York Medical College in Valhalla, and director of the newly formed division of gerontology and geriatric medicine.

title: THIS TIME, IRAN CAN CITE CHAPTER AND VERSE
description: WHEN Iranians boarded an American merchant ship last week in search of weapons bound for Iraq, the Reagan Administration conceded that Iran was largely within its legal rights. Although the United States fought the War of 1812 over Britain's gross interference with neutrals during the Napoleonic wars -including commandeering American ships -Washington has long recognized that international law permits belligerents, within reason, to search neutral ships.

title: STAGE: 'FALLEN ANGELS,' NOEL COWARD COMEDY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 - In the space of about one year, Noel Coward - still in his early 20's -wrote four plays, including ''Hay Fever'' and ''Fallen Angels.'' The former is enjoying a revival on Broadway, and the latter can be seen at the Hartman Theater here in a production directed by Nagle Jackson. Anyone who regards ''Hay Fever'' as the height of triviality might well reconsider that judgment after revisiting ''Fallen Angels.'' Even the author deemed it ''extremely slight.'' Nevertheless, in the 60 years since it was written, it has become one of Coward's more popular comedies, principally as a vehicle for the actresses cast in the two leading roles.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE LAW AND THE MALL THE recent New York State court ruling regarding leafletting at the Smith Haven Mall brought national media attention to the Lake Grove shopping center, according to its vice president and general manager, Abe Zitren. ''We had TV out here and everything,'' he said. But, he added, there's been no reaction from the Long Island public, those most affected by the decision.

title: Fast Food
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
TREES WITH A SPECIAL WINTER APPEAL
description: DIVERSITY is the rule in nature. Drive through the countryside and you will see variety in color, texture, form and size of plants. It is this diversity that catch's one's eye and captures one's interest. Too often we ignore this when selecting plants for our gardens.

title: SULLIVAN GUARDS TEAM, MEMORIES
description: EVERYONE in Boston - the fans, the writers, the broadcasters and the players - know how to run their teams. Is there a city in America with so many opinionated observers, or where its celebrities - in politics, sports and the media - mingle with one another so closely?

title: ...OR A MANTLE OF MISERY
description: FOR too many years I have lived a lie that is a little worse than the garden-variety white lie. This particular falsehood is maybe the color of snow smudged by the carbon from auto exhausts.

title: GIBSON DESCRIBES GAINS IN NEWARK
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, who announced this week that he would seek a fifth term as Mayor, says Newark is ''no longer a terminal case'' but there is still much to be done in New Jersey's largest city.

title: A LETTER TO THE 'SWINE WHO STOLE MY WIFE'S PURSE
description: SWINE (or swine-ette, as the case may be):

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HAIR
description: EVER since she can remember, Denise Falzerano has loved working with hair.

title: CLOUDS IN MAGAZINE HEAVEN
description: THE WORLD OF TIME INC. The Intimate History of a Changing Enterprise. Volume Three: 1960-1980. By Curtis Prendergast with Geoffrey Colvin. Edited by Robert Lubar. Illustrated. 590 pp. New York: Atheneum. $25.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Michael Brady of American University and Warren Lipka of South Carolina were named the top soccer players of 1985 in voting by college coaches. . . . Mike Norris, the former Oakland A's pitcher, was ordered to stand trial on a felony drug charge stemming from his arrest on a charge of possession of cocaine in California last February. . . . John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball star who has been accused of taking part in a point-shaving scheme, has asked the Louisiana Supreme Court to dismiss the sports bribery charges against him.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THOMAS TRANTINO, convicted 23 years ago of murdering two police officers in a Lodi tavern, has lost another bid to be released from prison. A Federal judge has ruled that the state's Parole Board acted fairly in denying parole in 1982.

title: A NEW ERA FOR GUATEMALA
description: Guatemala is ''a nation of real heroes'' who will have to keep on acting heroic, the new civilian President said last week. Taking office after 30 years of military control, President Mario Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo called for ''great austerity and sacrifice'' -because the treasury is empty.

title: THE WOUNDING OF DONALD MANES
description: Nine days after Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens was found at the wheel of his car, dazed and bleeding profusely, the central questions in the bizarre episode -how was Mr. Manes injured, by whom and why? - remain unanswered.

title: CITY PARKING AIDE IS ACCUSED OF EXTORTION
description: Federal prosecutors said last week that a top official of the New York City agency responsible for collecting parking-ticket fines had done some illegal collecting of his own. In what the authorities described as a widening investigation, the official, Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, deputy director of the Parking Violations Bureau, was charged with accepting a $5,000 bribe from the president of a private collection company that does business with the city.

title: SURF AND SAND IN CHINA
description: Not since the 1930's have foreigners been able to think of China as a place for a beach holiday, and even then there were more comfortable and less risky places to go. Yet on Hainan Island, at the southernmost point of the old Chinese empire, there is something for seekers of sand and sea to ponder.

title: ARTFUL LESSONS FROM TWO MASTERS OF THE KEYBOARD
description: Public performance has become so central to our musical experience that we forget how many important pieces were written to instruct as well as to entertain.

title: Miss Williams Wed to George Ireland
description: Elisabeth Trefz Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Williams of Pueblo, Colo., was married in Colorado Springs yesterday to George Ring Ireland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Ireland of Cleveland. Edward C. Turner, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Kansas, performed the ceremony at Shove Chapel on the Colorado College campus.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TREASURE HUNT
description: Once upon a time, the gifted and talented students of Lakeland decided to search for Treasure. Treasure is the name of a make-believe stallion, and of a real gold statuette shaped like that stallion. Inside the statuette is a key that unlocks a safe deposit box, and inside the safe deposit box is a certificate redeemable for $500,000.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Detroit Pistons vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Pontiac, Mich., noon. This game has always been a homecoming of sorts for Magic Johnson, since he drew heightened national attention by helping Michigan State win the national collegiate title in 1979. (Television -Channel 2, noon.) College: North Carolina at Marquette. (Television -Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) Golf Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, at Palm Desert, Calif. The final round of this tournament moves to the Bermuda Dune course after playing the first four rounds at four courses. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Buffalo Sabres, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 5:05 P.M. In the 40 games in the rivalry, the Sabres have won or tied all but two games, and the Devils have never beaten Buffalo since they moved to New Jersey. They are without a victory in the last 20 games against Buffalo, 0-17-3. (Television - MSG, 5 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 5 P.M.) Jets vs. Boston Bruins, at Winnipeg, Manitoba. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., live.) Tennis Nabisco Masters finals, at Madison Square Garden, 12:30 P.M., doubles and singles. (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M.) Track and Field Manufacturers Hanover/MAC, boys youth 18 and under and masters 30 and over men and women, at Fordham University's Lombardi Center, 9 A.M. Other Events EXPOSITIONS: National Boat Show, at the New York Coliseum, 59th Street and Columbus Circle, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. This is final day of the show.

title: U.S. Admiral Arrives in Cairo
description: Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived here today on the fourth leg of a tour of the Middle East and Europe.

title: TOXIC WASTE HIGH ON AGENDA
description: IN THE year after the ''Year of the Environment,'' Governor Kean devoted the environmental section of his annual State of the State Message to equal measures of past accomplishments and future objectives.

title: Cast-Iron Rehab; New Role For 90 Fifth
description: First designed as a loft building in 1902 by Robert Maynicke, the 11-story building at 90 Fifth Avenue at the corner of 14th Street, is being rehabilitated into the new national headquarters of the Research Institute of America.

title: Texas Governor Challenged
description: Andrew C. Briscoe 3d entered the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination Friday. Mr. Briscoe, a second cousin of former Gov. Dolph Briscoe Jr., acknowledged he would be outspent in the primary by the incumbent, Gov. Mark White. ''Money isn't everything in a campaign,'' Mr. Briscoe said.

title: Talking Insiders; Selling Rights In Co-ops
description: NEW YORKERS who live as tenants in buildings undergoing co-op or condominium conversion are increasingly likely to be invited by real-estate brokers or friends to sell their ''insider rights.'' Such an offer will be most appealing to a tenant who expects to move out of the city or who cannot afford to buy the apartment.

title: IONA EDGES ARMY
description: John Kijonek and Nestor Payne each converted two free throws in the final 59 seconds as Iona held off Army, 58-54, this afternoon to register its third straight victory in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

title: STORM WARNINGS FROM THE GULF TO GIBRATLAR
description: THE Middle East volcano was rumbling again last week, spreading violence and new problems from the Gulf of Oman to the Mediterranean. The repercussions were felt thoughout the region, in Western Europe and in Washington and Moscow.

title: WHAT THE SHORHAM TEST WON'T TEST FOR
description: Richard Kessel has now issued an estimate that Lilco can save $300 million a year by not opening Shoreham.

title: Soviet Kin Permitted to Join Emigre Film Director Abroad
description: The son and mother-in-law of Andrei Tarkovsky, the emigre film director, have been allowed to join him abroad, Western diplomats said today.

title: HOW TH N.F.L. IS TRYING END RUN ROUND CONGRESS
description: NOTHING shows off the American competitive spirit better than football. On the playing field, as in the marketplace, Americans love to compete for the rewards of success.

title: UPWARDLY MOBILE
description: The United States has no shortage of good reasons to criticize the United Nations so it's dismaying to see American officials strain to assail ''Being Young,'' a half-hour film produced for the United Nations International Youth Year in 1985.

title: NEW CASSETTES: QUAKERS, CRICKETS, LOW-KEYED JAZZ
description: Friendly Persuasion Starring Gary Cooper, Dorothy McGuire, Anthony Perkins; directed by William Wyler, 1956 CBS/Fox Video 138 minutes. $59.98 Warm comedy mingled with serious questions prove a durable combination in this film drawn from a Jessamyn West novel and set among Quakers in Indiana during the Civil War.

title: STATES LAY SNARE FOR TAX CHEATS
description: Tax officials from Maine to the Potomac agreed last week to harness their computers in joint pursuit of state income-tax cheaters.

title: MIXED RESPONSE TO LOUISIANA GAMBLING PLAN
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards's proposal to bring a lottery to Louisiana and casino gambling to New Orleans has stirred conflicting storms of opposition and approval.

title: ACCESSORIES FOR THE ROAD
description: Every traveler has a few items tucked into the corner of a bag that seem indispensable. Marguerite Gamble of Little Rock, Ark., always takes along a tape measure with inches marked on one side and centimeters on the other.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
DINING CAUSE
description: The invitation: ''You are cordially invited to join the owners of our area's finest restaurants in an evening of culinary splendor.'' The occasion: The third annual Dining Out for the March of Dimes, a benefit for the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, Westchester-Rockland-Putnam chapters.

title: PERMANENT HOUSING FOR HOMELESS IS URGED
description: Permanent housing and jobs must become goals of volunteer groups now providing emergency shelter and food for the homeless in churches and synagogues, leaders of a coalition of such groups said yesterday.

title: Health Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: EAVESDROPPING AT A WRITER'S CONFERENCE
description: AT THErr 48th International PEN Congress in Manhattan last week, the organization - whose name is an acronym for poets, essayists and novelists - often seemed more concerned with politics than literature. Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and from the remarks of four writers.

title: A GLOWING TRIBUTE TO DR. KING
description: CLOTHED in a dazzling copper robe, an awesome statue of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. now commands an entrance lobby at Passaic County College here.

title: NIAGARA FALLS, BY BRUSH AND CAMERA AT THE NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: AT his first sighting of Niagara Falls, Father Louis Hennepin, a 17th-century writer and a traveling companion of the explorer LaSalle, found it was ''so prodigious high, that it would make one tremble to look steadily upon the water, rolling along with a rapidity not to be imagin'd.''

title: SIGNPOSTS TO WASHINGTON
description: FDR The New York Years. 1928-1933. By Kenneth S. Davis. 512 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: A SINGER OF THEIR TALES
description: THE MORAL LIFE OF CHILDREN By Robert Coles. Illustrated. 302 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95. THE POLITICAL LIFE OF CHILDREN By Robert Coles. Illustrated. 341 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95. WHEN I was in grade school, Christmas time was a problem. We were always made to sing those mysterious carols, and although ''Jingle Bells'' was a piece of cake, most of the canon was fraught with danger for a Jewish boy. Harold Goldstein and I figured out a way to defend ourselves. We turned the line ''Deck the halls with boughs of holly'' into ''Deck the halls with rows of cholly,'' this last word being our rhymed distortion of ''challah,'' the delicious Jewish bread served on the Sabbath. No one actually heard us do this. We believed Christian ears would not suffer our defiance lightly, and so we silently mouthed the words rather than utter them. When we had done this, Harold and I always exchanged the kind of glance that might have passed between Kim Philby and Guy Burgess in the corridors of Whitehall.

title: ABU NIDAL BACKING IS SAID TO BE WIDE
description: A senior Palestinian guerrilla leader says that Abu Nidal, the Palestinian accused of having organized the Rome and Vienna airport massacres, receives various types of support from conservative Arab countries as well as radical movements and that he spends time in Iran.

title: GOETZ WINS ONE ROUND
description: The scales of justice tipped in favor of Bernhard H. Goetz last week. A State Supreme Court justice dismissed the major charges against the man who became a symbol for many when he shot and seriously wounded four youths on a Manhattan subway train 13 months ago.

title: LACEY TALKS OF YEARS ON BENCH
description: IT IS 9:01 A.M. in Courtroom 9 at the United States District Court here. Clerks and the stenographer are in place and, in the public section, 16 people, mostly lawyers, talk in low tones, waiting for the day to begin. day to begin.

title: ALMOST PERFECT IS A FAILING GRADE
description: BLIND TRUST By John J. Nance. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Boston School Bus Drivers Agree to End 16-Day Strike
description: School bus drivers agreed to settle their 16-day walkout and return to work when classes resume Tuesday, a School Department spokesman said today.

title: Lindo Wins Twice
description: Errington Lindo and Mark Mendes, his coach at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, passed up the Martin Luther King Jr. Relays for Public Schools Athletic League boys teams and opted to run instead today at the fourth annual Yale Games in the University's Cox Cage. Lindo did not disappoint anyone, winning the 400 and 800 meters.

title: Truth Will Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding Planned By Jennifer Press
description: A May wedding is planned by Jennifer Press and John D. Goodkind, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Press of New York, have announced. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Goodkind of Rye, N.Y.

title: GLOBAL EFFORT AGAINST SMOKING
description: A million people die prematurely each year from tobacco-related diseases, according to the World Health Organization. So last week the United Nations agency declared in the strongest possible terms that smoking is dangerous to the planet's health and that something must be done about it.

title: FIGHT ON PRIMARIES TAKES ITS PLACE ON NATIONAL STAGE
description: WHAT began two years ago as a Connecticut political quarrel over whether unaffiliated voters should vote in a party's primary elections, was transformed last week into a constitutional issue to be decided by the United States Supreme Court.

title: CABARET: BLOSSOM DEARIE
description: Blossom Dearie, who is in her third season of early-evening performances - 6:30 P.M. Wednesday through Saturday - at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, is such a consistent performer that she is apt to be taken for granted. But even though one may be familiar with her extensive repertory of both old and witty songs and new, ironic ones, as well as with her astonishing voice that is part little-girl innocence and part dark throatiness, there are always new facets emerging from her performances.

title: MACK TRUCKS TO BUILD OUTSIDE PENNSYLVANIA
description: Mack Trucks Inc. announced today that it would build an $80 million truck assembly plant outside Pennsylvania, refusing a union proposal to keep the nation's No. 2 maker of heavy trucks from taking an estimated 1,800 jobs from this area.

title: MEXICO'S GRAND 'MAQUILADORA' PLAN
description: WITHIN this city of nearly one million people across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Tex., are 180 ''maquiladoras'' - factories owned by foreign companies that use cheap Mexican labor to assemble products that are shipped out of Mexico for marketing elsewhere.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PAPA: An Intimate Biography of Mark Twain. By Susy Clemens. (Doubleday, $15.95.) In 1885, when Susy Clemens was 13 years old and her beloved father, Mark Twain, was 50, she undertook the task of writing his biography. It begins ''We are a very happy family!'' and ends abruptly in midsentence about a year later. Twain, having just published ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' was at the height of his fame and powers, but the reader sees this only obliquely through Susy's fond but limited childhood gaze. Most of what she describes is domestic - Twain forced by his children to invent stories based on the furniture in the library (thus producing a romance about a fender, tongs and a ''shuvel''); Twain suggesting that Biblical names be used for the chess pieces so he could play on Sunday; Twain cursing while shaving; acting in family charades; writing letters in schoolboy German; and providing names for the many household cats. Susy, who died of spinal meningitis when she was 24, writes of all this with the unaffected warmth and charm of a child and with what her father called her ''frequently desperate'' spelling. After her death, her father annotated her work in his own unmistakable voice, here mellowed by loss and great affection. This is the first publication of Susy Clemens's ''Papa,'' which, as the title page says, has ''a Foreward and Copious Comments by Her Father.'' Twain's remarks, which are interspersed with Susy's, are explanatory, correcting and admiring.

title: FOREST OWNERS FIND BENEFITS IN CUTTING
description: DEAN AVERY, a retired newspaper publisher who owns 100 mostly wooded acres in Stonington, said that six months ago he would have been ''aghast if someone came and suggested cutting down an acre.''

title: U.S. AIDE FAULTS LAWS ON SEAT BELTS
description: Many states have recently adopted laws requiring motorists to use seat belts, and more are expected to do so this year. But many of the laws do not meet six Federal standards that must be met if the Government is to drop its requirement that cars sold in the future be equipped with air bags or seat belts that close automatically, according to a top Federal transportation official.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: GALA IN HARTFORD Feeling exuberant at the age of 350, Hartford, Conn., plans a birthday extravaganza from noon to midnight Jan. 31-Feb. 1.

title: AN EYE FOR AGELESS BEAUTY
description: ON A FALL DAY IN 1930, while camping in a Navajo reservation, Laura Gilpin and a friend named Elizabeth Forster ran out of gas in an uninhabited stretch of New Mexico desert. Miss Gilpin hiked more than 10 miles to a trading post, and on her return with the gasoline found Betsy Forster playing gin rummy with a group of Navajos who had come to help. The Indians were so friendly that Miss Forster took a nursing job among them, and Miss Gilpin returned to photograph them as the friend of someone they trusted. She continued to photograph the Navajos for almost half a century.

title: Dialing Middle America
description: Using new-fangled telemarketing techniques to appeal to Middle America for money and political support has long been a goal of Washington's electronically wired lobbies. But at least one organization, the National Right to Work Committee, is finding that methods designed to reach out and touch someone may elicit annoyance as well as money.

title: ARCHITECTURAL HERITAGE
description: Two of the county's leading historic-preservation organizations and one of the nation's leading architects will join next week to kick off Westchester's celebration of New York State's Architectural Heritage Year.

title: Mental Hospital And 'Danger'
description: ABOUT 50 residents applied for gun permits last year in Marlboro Township, N.J., contending that ''dangerous'' patients were fleeing the Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital and turning up in the community.

title: ST. JOHN'S AND NORTH CAROLINA TRIUMPH TAR HEELS HAND DUKE FIRST LOSS
description: The venue was rather unusual, but the outcome was strikingly familiar.

title: William R. Greer Weds Tracy Ball
description: Tracy Jean Ball, the daughter of Margaret Logan of Boston and George M. Ball of Charlotte, N.C., was married in Boston yesterday to William Robson Greer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander P. Greer of Spokane, Wash. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony in the Leslie Lindsey Memorial Chapel at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: MEMORIES OF DR. KING LINGER ON L.I.
description: MILLIONS of Americans will join tomorrow in the first national observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But for a small number of people on Long Island, the remembrance of Dr. King's life as what he called a ''drum major'' for racial equality and nonviolence will always be linked to June 13, 1965, when he delivered a moving commencement address at Hofstra University.

title: CALIFORNIA'S WILD KINGDOM BY THE SEA
description: For those traveling north of San Francisco, the advice is usually brief:

title: Alison Gottlieb Plans To Wed Craig Jampol
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Gottlieb of Scarborough, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Brooke Gottlieb, to Craig Brian Jampol, a son of Shirley Jampol Ansbacher and the late Paul Jampol, both of Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: THE FIRST RAINS. By Peter Bonnici. Illustrated by Lisa Kopper. Carolrhoda. $8.95. (Ages 5 to 8) Waiting for the arrival of the annual rains is a tense and sticky business in India.

title: Housing Sprouts on Once-Spurned Sites
description: ''I ADMIT it's marginal,'' said Ellis Lasberg, looking over a triangular piece of land in Briarcliff Manor with Route 9A on one side, a supermarket and parking lot across the road and a rear view of stores on Pleasantville Road on the third side.

title: Andrea M. Szechenyi To Wed Joseph Leo Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Laszlo Szechenyi of Tokyo and Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Andrea Maria Szechenyi to Joseph Edmond Leo Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo of London and East Hampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 21. Miss Szechenyi, a computer systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, graduated from Mount Holyoke College.

title: THERE'S MORE TO THE MUSIC OF NEW ORLEANS THAN JAZZ
description: The out-of-the-way musical venues of New Orleans -what might be described as Off Bourbon Street and Off Off Bourbon Street - are smaller, simpler, and perceptibly less glamorous than the clubs typically preferred by tourists. But they are also the locales of a kind of musical activity indigenously their own -either more challenging or more intimate, more unabashedly experimental or more mindful of grassroots tradition than their more fashionable neighbors.

title: STATE'S LAWS AMONG TOUGHEST IN NATION
description: ALTHOUGH drunken-driving laws can never be stringent enough for some of the survivors of innocent victims of alcohol-related accidents, New Jersey, officials say, has some of the toughest measures in the nation.

title: SAVORING SPINACH
description: THERE ARE SOME foods reflexively linked to memories of things past, a bit of poetry perhaps ('' 'A loaf of bread,' the Walrus said, 'is what we chiefly need','' Lewis Carroll), literary dialogue (''He was a bold man that first eat an oyster,'' credited to Jonathan Swift) and maxims in general (''Four persons are wanted to make a good salad: a spendthrift for oil, a miser for vinegar, a counselor for salt, and a madman to stir all up.'') Whenever it comes to a discussion of spinach, my mind invariably recalls that celebrated New Yorker cartoon of Carl Rose with the caption: Mother to child, ''It's broccoli, dear.'' Child to mother, ''I say it's spinach, and I say the hell with it.'' It is jarring to learn, after a bit of research, that the cartoon appeared almost 60 years ago, on Dec. 8, 1928.

title: FACTS, NOT OPINIONS, ON TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: I was distressed to read Arlene DiScala's feeling that, because she is the parent of teen-age children, ''Big Brother'' is ''breaching the sanctity'' of her home [ ''Big Brother and Anti-Drinking Laws,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 29 ] . She refers to efforts to counteract the appalling toll of teen-age alcohol abuse through making alcoholic beverages less available to under-age youth.

title: THE INSPIRED GAME
description: It would be unrealistic for even the most brilliant of players to expect to win most of his games by inspired play. Consistent, solid, high-level performance gets the palm for tournament and match successes.

title: Ruth Cheney Streeter Weds
description: All Saints' Episcopal Church in Peterborough, N.H., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ruth Cheney Streeter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Streeter of New York and Darien, Conn., to John Brimelow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Brimelow of Birkenhead, Merseyside, England. The Rev. Louis Stone performed the ceremony at the church, which was built by the late Mary Cheney Schofield, the bride's great-grandmother, in memory of her husband, Charles Cheney.

title: GIGANTISM IN THE MOVIES: THE BAD AND THE BEAUTIFUL
description: At the climax of ''The Jewel of the Nile,'' a supposedly lighthearted adventure-comedy filmed mostly in Morocco (''Why do these Third World cesspools always have to be so hot?'' says one character in the film by way of a joke), a scheming Arab potentate stages a huge sound-and-light show in the middle of the desert to demonstrate his divinity before the gullible masses.

title: SONIC BURST ARE NO PROBLEM FOR THIS NOVEL CIRCUIT
description: The 13th bun in a baker's dozen always tastes especially good. There hovers about it a suggestion of something for nothing. Chances are you can't even tell the 13th bun from the other 12. And yet . . . ! Something similar applies to a recent innovation by Proton, an American audio and video company noted for offbeat engineering. Like a baker slipping in that bonus bun, Proton's new DPD circuit packs an extra jolt of power when the music needs it.

title: FRANZ KLINE- A LEGACY IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: Franz Kline is one of the most familiar American painters. His thick black strokes set into or slashed across white grounds are as deeply etched in the landscape of postwar American art as Pollock's ''drips'' or de Kooning's women. Kline's architectural building blocks are as erect as bridges, as insistent as trains, as inevitable as a cross-country interstate, as inescapable as night.

title: FORMER BANGLADESHI OFFICIAL FORMS AN OPPOSITION PARTY
description: A former Bangladeshi official said today that he had set up a new political party to oppose military rule and help to restore democracy.

title: 2 HOSPITALS AGREE TO SHARE SERVICES
description: AN alliance between two Connecticut hospitals, one of the largest in the state and the other much smaller, is being praised by officials as a way of using the resources of both to maximum efficiency.

title: DeLorean's Trial in April
description: The trial of John Z. DeLorean, accused of defrauding investors in his automobile company of $8.9 million, will begin April 7, Federal District Judge Julian A. Cook Jr. ruled Friday. Mr. DeLorean has pleaded not guilty of racketeering. In a separate order, Judge Cook repeated his ban on out-of-court comments by participants in the trial. The ban will begin on the first day of jury selection, he said.

title: SMALL GROWTHS IN REAGAN'S COLON PROVE BENIGN
description: The White House announced yesterday that three ''very small'' growths doctors removed from President Reagan's colon during an extensive medical examination Friday had proved to be benign.

title: CLOSE CALL FOR PLANE CARRYING MARCOS
description: A small aircraft carrying President Ferdinand E. Marcos to a campaign appearance narrowly avoided a collision today with another small plane landing from the opposite direction on a small grass airstrip, according to officials traveling with Mr. Marcos.

title: A SOPRANO WHO REFUSES TO JOIN THE JET SET
description: ''I turned down a lot of roles when I was beginning my career,'' the young American soprano Aprile Millo said in an interview last week. ''In the world of Italian opera, you don't make a debut in anything but a leading role if that is where you want to be. So I waited for the right moment.''

title: SEABROOK ACCIDENT PLAN BRINGS HEATED PROTESTS
description: A new dispute has arisen over emergency planning for the Seabrook nuclear reactor, this time involving how long it would take radiation to reach dangerous levels outside the plant in an accident.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In terrorism prosecutions the issue is not gathering evidence, like in other criminal cases, but in getting the defendants and doing something about it.'' - E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., the assistant United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. [ 10:4. ]

title: Shelly Sue Goodman and Jeffrey Hollander Marry
description: Shelly Sue Goodman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goodman of Mountainside, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Jeffrey Michael Hollander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo L. Hollander of Watchung, N.J., and Boca Raton, were married yesterday. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J.

title: SUPPORTERS SAVE HISTORIC BUILDING IN PHILADELPHIA
description: After nearly a decade, a $75 million renovation of the ornate structure that once housed the Lit Brothers' department store is under way, representing one more victory for this city's preservationists.

title: OFFICIALS IN LOS ANGELES SEEK MAN IN 15 PROSTITUTES' DEATHS
description: A team of detectives set up to find a man who might have killed as many as 15 prostitutes in the last 28 months has developed hundreds of leads, the police say.

title: Edward E. Biddle Becomes Fiance Of Miss Horsey
description: Announcement has been made by Alexandra Leigh-Hunt of Sag Harbor, L.I., and Justice Henry Ridgely Horsey of Dover, Del., of the engagement of their daughter, Philippa Ridgely Horsey, to Edward Elliot Biddle, a son of Barbara Noyes of Durham, N.H., and William W. Biddle of Seattle. A May wedding is planned.

title: FIRST LOVE AND THE LAST AUTOMATONS
description: IN THE PENNY ARCADE By Steven Millhauser. 164 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.STEVEN MILLHAUSER'S first novel, ''Edwin

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: French Is for Speaking In ''People and Places'' (Oxford University), Richard Cobb evokes the kind of world depicted by Rene Clair, one of the great French film makers.

title: HANOVER
description: When the Rev. Eleazer Wheelock, described as a ''Connecticut missionary with a vision of civilizing the wilderness,'' journeyed north to Hanover, N.H., to found Dartmouth College in 1770, prominent among his stores was an ample winter's supply of rum. The event - the transport of the rum, that is - has been celebrated ever since in college song, and the image has proved durable; to many, Hanover is still a frozen north woods outpost that closes its gates at nightfall and returns to the casks and flagons.

title: SOVIET AND JAPAN SIGN 2 ACCORDS IN TOKYO
description: The Foreign Ministers of the Soviet Union and Japan signed financial and cultural agreements today, and their Governments exchanged invitations for their leaders to visit each other's countries.

title: HEPBURN STYLE
description: KATHARINE HEP-burn is the essence of classic style. Just ask any good American sportswear designer.

title: RICHARDSON SET TO REJOIN NETS
description: The Nets said today that they expect to activate Micheal Ray Richardson on Monday in time for a five-day road trip that opens Wednesday night in Denver.

title: Mailbox; Praising Soccer, Simple Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FED WANTS BANKS TO GAMBLE LESS
description: The Federal Reserve Board proposed last week new restrictions on American bankers with a penchant for high-risk loans.

title: THATCHER SEEMS THE HEAVY IN DOWNING STREET DRAMA
description: ''I have lived through this,'' boasted a Prime Minister not displeased to be known as the ''Iron Lady'' a day after a senior member of her Government stalked out of 10 Downing Street, scattering in his wake accusations of mismanagement and duplicity. ''I know every single document,'' she said, ''every single phrase, every single nuance.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WINTER'S EDGE. By Valerie Miner. (Crossing Press, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.) San Francisco's Tenderloin is gearing up for the election of the district supervisor, and Chrissie MacInnes, a 65-year-old waitress and self-proclaimed ''sprightly senior activist'' is working to elect Marissa Washington - the neighborhood residents' champion and the foe of developers who would build hotels and support pornographers.

title: Frugal Lessons In Government
description: FOR 26 fourth-grade pupils from Hewlett, L.I., it was a trip to remember.

title: CHAMBER RECITAL OFFERS YOUNG ARTISTS
description: IN these days of spiraling concert costs, it remains a wonder and a delight to report that the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society is continuing its policy of presenting fine young artists in public recitals at no charge. In the Mount Pleasant Library today at 3 P.M., the Vox Nova Wind Quintet offers music of Ibert, Rossini, Hindemith and -with the guest pianist Barbara Mort - the whimsical Sextet for Piano and Winds by Francis Poulenc.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS ACTIVIST HONORED
description: A#22-cent United States commemorative stamp will be issued to honor human rights activist Sojourner Truth. The stamp will be released Feb. 4 in New Paltz, N.Y. with first day ceremonies to be held at the State University of New York. Assistant Postmaster General Mary J. Layton will be the principal speaker.

title: 'Love' and 'Dove'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TOTAL GENE SCREEN
description: JOGGING DOWN A NEW JER-sey park trail one morning, Ed Morgan felt wonderfully content. A tall man of 62, lean and fit, he particularly enjoyed running on such a day; his business, selling insulation supplies, was doing better than ever and his children and grandchildren were all thriving.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE WAND The Return to Mesmeria. By Allan W. Eckert. Illustrated by David Wiesner. 214 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THIS sequel to ''The Dark Green Tunnel'' is a satisfying fantasy that can be compared with the Narnia books on one level and the ''Star Wars'' movies on another. It has just about everything a good fantasy ought to have: bright, enterprising, likable children; noble, heroic adults; all manner of exotic, imaginatively named creatures, some lovable, others loathsome; a beneficent sorceress and a wicked sorcerer; gentle humor; a colorful, compelling setting; wonderful illustrations; and a plot of high adventure culminating in eventual triumph for the forces of good.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED...BY TRYING
description: IT MAY not be a success story -yet. What the show is, however, is a story of survival, and one of the most continually publicized in theater memory.

title: CARING FOR ELDERLY KIN TAKES ON-THE-JOB TIME
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHERN IRELAND'S BALLOT-BOX BATTLE
description: ''Ulster Says No,'' reads the huge banner on Belfast City Hall. This week, tens of thousands of Protestants in Northern Ireland are expected to second that verdict on the agreement giving the Irish Government a say in their affairs.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WHEN IN FLORENCE. By Richard Cortez Day. (Doubleday, $15.95.) Here are 15 old-fashioned stories about Italians and Americans living in the City of Flowers, each story linked by coincidence, so that a worshiped professor who receives a letter in one story becomes, in a second, the hospitalized man to whom a pedophile confesses just before he is stabbed by Uccello Uccello, the crazy subject of yet another piece.

title: AT HOME WITH HISTORY IN LONDON
description: One of the pleasures of living in, or visiting, an old country is the plenitude of places with historic and literary associations. Again and again, when I have gone, I find I have something good to feed on in my mind, further knowledge of them and of the people who lived in them to acquire and enjoy.

title: Robbery Victim Kills Robber After Theft on Eighth Avenue
description: A 35-year-old man who stole another man's wallet outside the Port Authority terminal last night was chased by the 58-year-old robbery victim and stabbed to death after a scuffle, the police said.

title: 3 Nicaraguans Seized; Newsletter <u4Is <u4Banned
description: The Interior Ministry announced today that it had barred publication of a mimeographed anti-Government newsletter and arrested its authors.

title: Who Wrote Burgess?
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Events; Varied Settings and Causes
description: West Village Phoenix Jan. 19 - Gutted by fire in 1981 and reopened for worship in November, St. Luke in the Fields Church will hold a celebration and benefit with three new works commissioned and performed by the West Village Chorale. The concert will be at 4 P.M. at the church, 487 Hudson Street, near Christopher Street, and will be followed by a Champagne reception. Tickets, $15 at the door. Information: 212-734-5819 or 212-757-9340. Helping Big Brothers Jan. 21 - Of all the many needs of the young, one of the most important, a trustworthy and caring adult, is too often missing. To fill that void, Big Brothers has been matching boys and girls with adults for weekly visits since 1904. Mayor Koch, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Dr. Gerald M. Edelman, Nobel laureate in medicine, will be honored at the group's awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, beginning with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets for black-tie evening, $250, from 212-288-1551. Historic Setting Jan. 22 - One of New York's lesser known but most historic museums is the Abigail Adams Smith Museum at 421 East 61st Street. Built in 1799 as the stone coach house on the East River estate of William Stephens Smith and Abigail Adams Smith, a daughter of John Adams, the house museum is furnished in the Federal style. At a benefit for and at the museum, six authorities on antiques and the decorative arts will lecture, answer questions and identify and give an opinion about the condition of small items brought by the audience.

title: Shakespeare's Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques Preview; THE NEW ARRIVALS
description: THE SIX NEW EXhibitors at New York's Winter Antiques Show - opening to the public Saturday and running through Feb. 2 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street - will be displaying objects as arcane as a 16th-century cup made of rhinoceros horns and as stately as a George II gilt mirror. Variety, as the old adage goes, is the spice of this 32-year-old show. So is the smattering of controversy that continues to brew, as it has for several years.

title: FOR RETIREES, NEW RETURN TO OLD OFFICES
description: After working for 44 years, Sylvia Corvo looked forward to retirement. But after seven years of travel, bridge games and lunch parties, she recalls, ''I woke up and realized I was bored.''

title: GUNFIGHT AT THE I'M O.K. CORRAL: M. SCOTT PECK DUELS WITH THE DEVIL
description: AS usual, eager souls are pushing into the aisles of bookstores in pursuit of revelation and relief. Positive thinking, a popularized transcendentalism, ways to do your inner housecleaning - these have been the basics of big business for wise publishers who know us as a nation of seekers and sinners; a flock in search of today's shepherd, lovers of rousing sermons and happy endings. Consider Dr. M. Scott Peck, whose book ''The Road Less Traveled'' was published by Simon & Schuster in 1978 and sold 12,000 copies in hardback in its first two years, then gradually, the way an avalanche gathers force, picked up readers and has now sold more than one and a half million copies. It has been on the New York Times paperback best-seller list almost every week for over two years, and was the best-selling nonfiction paperback of 1985. A new, shimmering, cellophane-covered boxed version ($17.95) has just reached local stores. The book's main audience is in the vast Bible Belt, which corsets this country in its own breath-holding way, but from sea to shining sea Scott Peck is known as the Sister Kenny of the psyche, the Dr. Spock of the church.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a letter from Dr. Jack C. Schoenholtz published on Dec. 22, l985, contained a word not used by the writer. In discussing plans to send an insurance company nurse to a patient's bedside, he wrote: ''If not permitted (by the patient), the insured employee may receive severe financial penalties.''

title: A Gucci Down Payment
description: Confessing to what his lawyer called ''foolish and improvident'' accounting practices, the 80-year-old former head of Gucci Shops Inc. admitted last week to having defrauded the Federal Government of taxes on more than $11 million in personal income. The funds had been diverted from the expensive leather-goods shops, Aldo Gucci said, and had not been reported as taxable income.

title: A New 'Shakespeare' Poem
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATURE WATCH;
ATLANTIC TOMCOD
description: Microgadus tomcod Size: Averages 10 to 12 inches.

title: IN OLD ISTANBUL, A NEW HOTEL
description: Just after dawn the mournful cry of the muezzin, calling the faithful to prayer, rouses you from slumber. You stand at the window, gazing out over stone domes and turrets toward the graceful minarets of the Blue Mosque. In the garden below, birds chorus their own salutation to the morning.

title: WHY SELL RCA AT ALL?
description: When I was an RCA vice president only a decade ago, the lawyers wouldn't even let us use the term ''synergy'' in our ads about the company's varied operations. The word was supposed to be catnip to the tigers in the Justice Department's Antitrust Division. The lawyers even shrank from a proposal that the annual report carry a map showing the worldwide scale of RCA's activities - ''Not the octopus map!''

title: PERFORMANCE IS RITUAL FOR ALEXANDER TORADZE
description: In 1872, the first American tour of the great Russian pianist and composer Anton Rubinstein marked the beginning of America's fascination with Russian performers. Rubinstein's demeanor was so shambling and awkward some witnesses compared him to an elephant, but his playing embodied perfectly those qualities the legendary virtuoso Theodor Leschetizky attributed to the Russians: ''prodigious technique . . . passion, dramatic power, elemental force and extraordinary vitality.'' The fascination mushroomed in later years with pianists such as Rachmaninoff, Horowitz, Richter and Gilels, among others. .

title: PROSPECTS
description: Pumping Up Inflation?

title: New York Home Buyers Atypical
description: LAST year, the average home buyers across the country were 36 years old and married. They had a family income of about $42,000 and bought a house that cost approximately $75,000 with a down payment of roughly $14,000.

title: JAZZ: 'SATCHMO' TRIBUTE
description: TWO approaches to the music played by Louis Armstrong were taken Thursday at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert called ''We Remember Satchmo'' at New York University's Loeb Auditorium.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: BOZELL & JACOBS, a Union-based advertising agency that merged with Kenyon & Eckhardt of Omaha, Neb., on Jan. 1 to become what is now Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has won a three-year contract from the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development with total billings worth about $21 million.

title: A LITTLE HELP FOR G.M. AND FORD
description: Ignoring the complaints of consumer groups and the Chrysler Corporation, the Department of Transportation said last week that it would propose retaining for an additional two years the lower fuel-economy standards it granted General Motors and Ford last summer.

title: Robert Peabody and Laura Sass, Both Manhattan Lawyers, Are Wed
description: Laura Sass and Robert L. Peabody, both lawyers in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Puck Building. Justice Betty Ellerin of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court for Manhattan and the Bronx, performed the ceremony.

title: FOR EX-ROCKETTES, CAMARADERIE AND PHILANTHROPY
description: When the Rockettes Alumnae Association gathered in Radio City Music Hall on a recent Sunday, its members had more on their minds than dancing.

title: MEMORIES OF THE SLEEPY HOESEMAN
description: IT was on an early autumn afternoon in 1922 that a Notre Dame halfback named Crowley, who had been nicknamed Sleepy Jim, explained to Coach Knute Rockne that he actually suffered from insomnia. ''I sleep all right at night and in the morning,'' he related with a straight face, ''but in the afternoon I toss and turn something awful.''

title: Try It With Music
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE COMPLETE SHORTER FICTION OF VIRGINIA WOOLF. Edited by Susan Dick. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Despite her experiments with forms of prose throughout her long writing career, Virginia Woolf published only one collection of short stories during her lifetime.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED BY CANADIENS, 3-0
description: The Islanders expected a loftier effort from themselves tonight, especially because they were performing in the venerable Montreal Forum, but as their goalie Kelly Hrudey remarked after they were beaten, 3-0, by the Canadiens, ''This is a feeling I'd like to forget.''

title: IN ORLANDO, DISNEY IS MAKING ITSELF A WORLD APART
description: Since Walt Disney's agents secretly bought up 28,000 acres of land just south of here 20 years ago, everything around Orlando has been measured by superlatives of growth and prosperity.

title: STATE SAID TO LEAD IN CUTTING DEATHS RELATED TO ALCOHOL
description: FEDERAL and state statistics on drunken driving over the last five years have begun showing that New Jersey has been outpacing the nation as a whole in reducing alcohol-related deaths on its roads and that important new trends may be emerging in alcohol consumption and the social habits that surround it.

title: BITS, BYTES AND STAR WARS
description: At the bargaining tables in Geneva and around Capitol Hill, the Administration has assigned a high priority to the development of a space-based antimissile system. But, according to a panel appointed by the Pentagon, efforts to make that dream a reality may be doomed because insufficient attention is being given to the complicated computer programming needed for an array of ''Star Wars'' missile-zappers.

title: GOVERNMENT BY ZOMBIE
description: Of all the absurdities in the new budget law, none is so measurably mindless as treating the Internal Revenue Service as just another agency.

title: Rypien Leads North To Senior Bowl Victory
description: Mark Rypien of Washington State, playing because of injuries to three other quarterbacks, threw three touchdown passes, two in a 49-second span of the fourth quarter, as the North downed the South, 31-17, today in the 37th Senior Bowl football game.

title: STIFFER RULES PROPOSED FOR RETAIL AIDS
description: MERCHANTS who advertise sales on items ranging from refrigerators to grapefruits will have to comply with stiffer regulations if the State Department of Consumer Protection has its way.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MAYONNAISE AND THE ORIGIN OF LIFE: Thoughts of Minds and Molecules. By Harold J. Morowitz. (Scribners, $15.95.) Toward the end of an essay called ''Ice on the Rocks,'' Harold J. Morowitz tells us about the time when, sipping Scotch and soda in the bar of a small cruise vessel on an inlet in Glacier Bay off Alaska, his thoughts returned to the relation between the ice cube in his glass and the enormous wall of the Marjorie Glacier he had seen from the wind-beaten foredeck.

title: 'MURROW' SKETCHES A PORTRAIT OF A LEGENDARY BORADCASTER
description: Although arguably the most famous and certainly the most influential news broadcaster of the century, Edward R. Murrow still remains something of a mystery. He was an idealist in a business obsessed with the ''bottom line.'' He had no professional training as a journalist, yet he laid the foundations for broadcast journalism as it has evolved to the present. He showed immense courage in tackling some of the most troubling issues of his day, most notably McCarthyism, but he also played the TV-entertainment game nimbly with shows like ''Person to Person,'' an early entry in celebrity huckstering. A rather withdrawn and dour man, he became a hero to most of his colleagues, so much so that even today they scurry to position themselves under his heroic mantle. Witness the hullaballoo in some quarters of CBS News last year when a filched early script of the new film ''Murrow'' was deemed to contain distortions, giving too little credit to some co-workers, too much to others.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA'S TIGHTENING GRIP, LESOTHO GASPS
description: Lesotho, a small country surrounded by South Africa, has learned to duck when it offends its big neighbor. Last week, residents of Maseru, Lesotho's capital, were short of gasoline, food and medical supplies that had been delayed by a South African slowdown. And in what Lesotho officials said was an attack of jitters but which may well have reflected profound divisions in the nation's hierarchy, hundreds of heavily armed soldiers temporarily surrounded the offices of the Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan. ''There is a morbid fear of the South African defense forces,'' said Lesotho's Information Minister. He denied that there had been a coup attempt.

title: VACANT BUILDINGS BEING REVIVED AS CONDOMINIUMS
description: IN distance, it is four miles from Sackett Street in the lower Park Slope section of Brooklyn to Dorchester Road in Flatbush. But in housing terms they are not so distant, for vacant older buildings are undergoing rehabilitation into condominiums in each location.

title: Paying Directors
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATIVE HONEYMOON IS SHORT-LIVED
description: GOVERNOR KEAN and Republican and Democratic lawmakers opened the 202d session of the State Legislature last week with appropriate pomp and pledges of mutual cooperation, but behind the optimistic speeches loomed some areas of strong disagreement.

title: Andrea Hawkins, A Banker, Is Wed
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Andrea Marie Hawkins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Donald Hawkins of White Plains, to Steven Bennett Stuart, a son of Frederick E. Stuart Jr. of Baltimore and the late Jane Lloyd Stuart. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: Tara Lynn Holtje to Wed
description: The engagement of Tara Lynn Holtje to Nicholas Simeonidis, a member of the class of '86 at the University of Notre Dame Law School, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Holtje of Great Kills, S.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance, who graduated from Princeton University, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Simeonidis of Athens.

title: PRACTICING THE ART AND ARTIFICE OF PICKING SPORTS WINNERS
description: WANT to know who's going to win Super Bowl XX next Sunday? Ask Royce Kanofsky of Oyster Bay Cove.

title: Kiyoko Hawley
description: The purpose of a debut recital is to showcase a performer. For comparative purposes, this is usually best accomplished when the performer plays standard repertory - pieces that may be overfamiliar but that offer a sure basis for judgment of the performer's skills as a technician and interpreter.

title: Mission Accomplished
description: On the eve of the Geneva summit in November, Soviet authorities agreed to grant a temporary visa so Yelena G. Bonner, the human rights activist, could be treated in the West for a heart ailment. Last week, at a hospital in Boston, Miss Bonner underwent four hours of surgery, during which doctors bypassed six clogged arteries.

title: GULFSTREAM WOE: A LACK OF HORSES
description: There are fewer horses than usual racing at Gulfstream Park this winter, and among the missing is the colt who starred here a year ago and went on to win the richest race in the world.

title: THESE UNDERSTUDIES OFTEN GET THE PART
description: Governor Kean surprised everyone, including his own staff, when he said last week that New Jersey had been tempting fate by not having a lieutenant governor waiting in the wings in case a governor dies, becomes ill or resigns.

title: SHOCK OF THE NEW: GIVE ME THE OLD
description: When it comes to high-tech, I might well be Neanderthal, Reactionary, obtuse, unable to handle it all. New super-advanced technologies Do little to nurture my own inner peace. Somehow I long for a simpler time When person-to-person we could make our lives rhyme. Robots and humanoids are space-age inventions, Were these innovations Mother Nature's intentions? What ever happened to state-of-the-heart? Has it been replaced by state-of-the-art? Astronauts are building towers in space, Since moon-walking has become so commonplace. ''Star Wars'' once meant fantasy film entertainment; Now Reagan is battling against its containment. Lucas feels there's copyright infringement, The Feds say surely there is no such impingement. Copyright laws might be a great pain, But if ''Star Wars'' is deemed in the public domain, And our race for space has only to gain -Will R2-D2 show up for the arraignment? The computers are down, no bank balance in sight; The deposit I'm making can't be entered tonight. Tomorrow? Perhaps, but it's still touch and go, Come back - or call, if you really must know. The ''convenience'' machine just chewed up my card; Suspicious looks stem from the security guard.

title: OPERA: 'DER FREISCHUTZ' BY BRONX COMPANY
description: THE high point of the Bronx Opera's ''Freischutz'' comes where it should, in the Wolf's Glen scene, where Carl Maria von Weber gave operagoers their first full taste of the supernatural preoccupations that would so mark German romantic opera for the first half of the 19th century. James Feng's scenery (seen at the production's third performance Friday night, at the Hunter College Playhouse) is composed of adroitly executed cliche: full moon in cloudy sky; water falling from on high in the distance, forbidding crags and a blasted circle for invoking the devil. The Boschian creatures that rode by or fluttered down were uncommonly eerie and telling (Nancy A. Palmatier, the costumer, is presumably to be credited here); Whitney Quesenbery's lighting design was simple, vivid and apt.

title: BLUES: MASON RUFFNER, WITH GUITAR AND BAND
description: MASON RUFFNER - a lanky, gold-toothed, black-suited, Texas-born guitarist and songwriter - came to the Bottom Line last weekend. Mr. Ruffner has just moved up from New Orleans clubs, where he was discovered, to nationwide attention with a CBS Records debut album. But his early set Friday was closer to the roadhouse than to pop.

title: CROWDING THE AUCTION
description: The Russians are said to have claimed, without convincing the rest of the world, that they were the first in many fields. They have never claimed to have invented bridge, although they could make a good case.

title: Change of Heart
description: When the pianist Vladimir Horowitz left Russia 61 years ago, he swore never to return. Last week he announced that he would play two recitals in the Soviet Union this spring, on April 20 in Moscow and a week later in Leningrad, as part of the cultural exchange arranged at the Geneva summit.

title: U.S. PARKS CHIEF CANCELS A SPEECH
description: The director of the National Park Service abruptly canceled a scheduled speech today to a ''Save the Everglades'' conference because of political considerations, his spokesman said.

title: SERGEANT LINKED TO HIT-AND-RUN
description: The blue wall of silence cracked a bit last week. A former New York City police officer testified that a sergeant accused of manslaughter in a hit-and-run death had been drinking on duty and was driving a patrol car when the accident occurred March 15.

title: Klan March Protests Holiday Honoring King
description: About 100 members of the Ku Klux Klan marched here today to protest the first Federal observance, on Monday, of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and to proclaim itself America's salvation.

title: NEEDED: A MONROE (TOWNSHIP) DOCTRINE
description: ALL Monroe Township is divided into five ZIP codes:

title: FOR WEST GERMAN YOUNG, CONSERVATIVE IS IN
description: Middle-class West Germans in their teens and early 20's are repudiating many of the rebellious, anti-establishment values that gave birth to the leftist Green Party and fed the campaign against the stationing of American missiles here three years ago.

title: NOW EVEN THE SKY IS SCRAMBLED
description: When people in the empty stretches of the American West talk wistfully of the open sky, they do not mean the great outdoors. They are referring to their backyard dish antennas, which can tune in dozens of satellite-borne television channels carrying everything from sermons to the latest movies.

title: REDISCOVERING THE GRANDMOTHER
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS, in one of their more brilliant discoveries of the obvious, have recently pronounced that a certain part of a baby's brain has the special function of recognising the face of its grandmother. Now that I have a grandson, I am determined to provide him with a face that fits this need.

title: Harvard Rescinds Move Against the Homeless
description: Officials of Harvard College yielded to students' protests today and removed metal grilles over heat vents that had prevented homeless people from warming themselves.

title: FACTS, NOT OPINIONS, ON TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: Arlene DiScala has come down squarely on both sides of the issue in her article ''Big Brother and Anti-Drinking Laws.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: LAST week was the last one in office for Assemblyman Stephen Adubato Jr., who last November lost not only the election but also his status as the state's youngest legislator.

title: KNICKS ARE BEATEN BY ROCKETS, 104-95
description: In many ways, it was a replay of the night before. The Knicks enjoyed their moments of promise, but everything crumbled again. They missed a crucial rebound, missed four important shots and ultimately failed to win.

title: BLACKWOOD LOOKS BACK ON FIRST YEAR
description: FOR a decade Ronald A. Blackwood had aspired to the mayoralty of this city, which he has called home for the last 30 years. Last January his perseverance - and his change in political affiliation - paid off and Mr. Blackwood became the first black candidate to be elected mayor in New York State.

title: COUNTY MOVES ON DRUG-TESTING BACKLOG
description: FOLLOWING complaints by city officials in Mount Vernon, the county moved last week to speed up the processing of drugs seized as evidence by various police departments in Westchester. The processing is done at the county's drug chemistry laboratory here, where chemists analyze packages of drugs brought in by police agencies.

title: CHINESE FILM MAKING AND A MATTER OF HU
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKE BACK YOUR MAINSTREAM
description: SHENANDOAH An Anthology. Edited by James Boatwright. 512 pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: The Pushcart Press. $28.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES WITH A SPECIAL WINTER APPEAL
description: DIVERSITY is the rule in nature. Drive through the countryside and you will see variety in color, texture, form and size of plants. It is this diversity that catch's one's eye and captures one's interest. Too often we ignore this when selecting plants for our gardens.

title: AN OFFER FROMM GORBACHEV ENLIVENS THE ARMS DEBATE
description: PRAISING his own sweeping proposal to eliminate all nuclear arms by the end of the century, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said last week that it was ''a peace initiative of historic significance,'' while the Soviet press declared it ''truly a milestone.''

title: THE HARDY CLAMMERS OF WINTER
description: ''A harbor, even if it is a little harbor, is a good thing, since adventures come into it as well as go out, and the life in it grows strong, because it takes something from the world and has something to give in return.'' -Sarah Orne Jewett AS the last dry leaves on the beech tree whispered in the wind, a flock of widgeons ate their somewhat undignified breakfast in the little pond below my window. Beyond them, the pull of the full moon pushed the tide over the marsh and up the fresh-water creek to the dam and spillway from the big pond.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: RECALLING DR. KING Ossie Davis, Don Oliver and Therese Plair will lead area observances of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday this week. Mr. Davis, the noted actor who delivered a eulogy at the slain civil rights leader's funeral in 1968, will take the place that Yolanda King, Dr. King's daughter, filled last year in a program at the Herbert H. Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: PRINCETON: MAKE A STATE, AS WELL AS A STATE OF MIND
description: NEW JERSEY has a very low self image in the minds of many of our residents and, even more so, in the eyes of our neighboring states.

title: DANCE: 'MIRROR'S EDGE,' FROM PEGGY LYMAN
description: THE Peggy Lyman Dance Company appeared Friday night as the final attraction in the Joyce Theater's dance festival. The performance allowed one to ponder Miss Lyman's artistic development.

title: AUTEUR! AUTEUR!
description: THE DAY AFTER CHRISTMAS, AN OLD BRONX BALLROOM HAS BEEN turned into a 1940's dance hall, Mia Farrow transformed into a U.S.O. singer complete with seamed stockings and a huge corsage, and Woody Allen has stepped into his role as director on the set of his film-in-progress. It's an easy workday; the brief scene - the actress singing ''I Don't Want to Walk Without You'' - had been shot days before, and two versions of the song prerecorded. But the lighting had been wrong, the tempo of the music too fast, so Allen has rebuilt the set and brought back 100 extras to reshoot. Mia Farrow lip-syncs a dozen times while Allen stands quietly beside the camera; between certain takes he whispers something to her. Then, he offers his most conspicuous direction of the day; in the middle of her song, he smiles and gives her a tiny wave - her cue to wave back on camera.

title: CORRECTION
description: A profile of the economist Robert Mundell in this section last Sunday misstated his son Bill's title. Bill Mundell is manager of new business at Data Resources Inc.'s Los Angeles office.

title: CRIME
description: This column somehow missed ''Thus Was Adonis Murdered,'' Sarah Caudwell's first novel, a few years ago. But if it was as good as Miss Caudwell's second book, THE SHORTEST WAY TO HADES (Scribners, $12.95), the loss was ours.

title:
ART;
LUCIDITY IN JERSEY CITY AND HIGH SPIRITS IN MONTCLAIR
