description: THE small paintings by James Bowness at the Jersey City Museum have the directness and lucidity of stained-glass windows. But Mr. Bowness does not work on glass; rather, his supports are something quite the opposite.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW TRADING NETWORK USES TOUCH-TONE TELEPHONES
description: Old coins and new technology will be wedded in an interesting and potentially important manner starting Wednesday, when a computerized coin trading network opens for business in New York. The network, known as Teletrade, will be totally electronic and will not require the use of a personal computer. All a subscriber will need is a touch-tone telephone.

title: SYRACUSE IS SOLID IN MIDDLE BUT NEEDS WASHINGTON'S LIFT
description: WHEN the subject of Syracuse basketball arises, an old joke about Los Angeles seems to be a perfect metaphor: A cluster of communities in search of a city.

title: SUFFOLK RAISES ANTE OVER DRILL
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY last week offered the strongest challenge to date to the Federal Government's power to regulate the development and licensing of nuclear plants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 19, 1986
description: International

title: SPACE STATION IS A STEP INTO THE BEYOND
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT ALL OF THE SOUTH IS IN THE SUNBELT
description: Since 1981, Georgia has recorded the nation's second-fastest rate of growth in per capita income, and that prosperity is reflected in Atlanta and its suburbs. Not only has this city's population grown by nearly 15 percent over the last five years, to more than two million, but three-quarters of all the new jobs created in the state are here as well.

title: BACON PLAYS A SUBTLE YET HAUNTING CULINARY ROLE
description: BACON is to meat as onions are to vegetables: a savory workhorse ingredient that lends an underpinning of hauntingly rich and complex flavor to a dish, frequently without celebration or menu credit. Roll some impeccable trout in cornmeal and sizzle it in freshly rendered bacon fat and you have trout to remember.

title: A CHANCE INTRUSION PROVES UNSETTLING
description: THE ad read: ''Estate sale, Sunday at 10 A.M.'' As I drive up to the neat brick house at 9:15 this cold winter morning, there is already a flurry of activity outside. A man in a bulky green parka struggles to fit a large framed picture in the trunk of his car while, at the same time, his wife approaches, carrying a handsome mahogany sewing basket marked five dollars.

title: A PARISH CHANNELS ITS YOUTHS' ENERGIES
description: NINE years ago, when the Rev. Peter Sticco came to Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church here from a post in Baltimore, he found a parish that, like many throughout the country, was slowly dwindling.

title: Thai Boxer Captures Title
description: Samart Payakaroon of Thailand won the World Boxing Council superbantamweight title today with a fifth-round knockout of Lupe Pintor of Mexico.

title: WHY SOME BIG RETAILERS ARE BEYOND ALTERATIONS
description: After years of what one retailing executive calls ''catering to yesterday's market,'' the Gimbel stores, which have been doing business here since 1909, may become just a memory in New York City. B.A.T. Industries, a British conglomerate with interests in tobacco, paper and financial services as well as retailing, said last week that it would sell its 36 Gimbel stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee.

title: WHY IT PAYS TO PRIVATIZE PUBLIC SERVICES
description: FEDERAL budget-making in the era of the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget amendment has catapulted a new word into the nation's vocabulary - ''privatization,'' or the transfer of Federal assets and functions to the private sector. As a commendable first step, the Reagan Administration has proposed the sale of a portion of the $245 billion portfolio of outstanding Government loans, such as those to students and small-business men.

title: Summer-Camp Show
description: The National Children's Camp Show will take place today from 12 to 5 P.M. at the Walden School, 1 West 88th Street.

title: Caryn Buchner Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Buchner of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caryn Wendy Buchner, to Timothy Gordon Coville, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Coville of Syracuse.

title: LOUISVILLE DEALS SYRACUSE 2D LOSS IN ROW, 83-73
description: Milt Wagner scored 24 points as Louisville resisted several comebacks for an 83-73 victory over fourth-ranked Syracuse today. Louisville (11-4) dealt Syracuse (13-2) its second consecutive loss.

title: PORTRAIT OF AN OBOE PLAYER: A DEEPENING COMMITMENT
description: PLAINTIVE and full, the voice of the oboe soars above the orchestra, or mingles in musical dialogue with the other woodwinds. More and more often, the player producing its tones on stages around the metropolitan area, as well as in three Westchester orchestras, is a dark-haired young woman named Jennifer Graham.

title: DEMOCRATS' HOPES UP IN CAROLINA SENATE RACE
description: The Democratic Party's chances of winning a United States Senate seat in North Carolina has taken on a new dimension with former Gov. Terry Sanford formally beccoming a candidate.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NEW THEATER A contemporary Canadian drama is to be the first production of the new professional theater at the University of Hartford's Lincoln Theater. ''The Impromptu of Outremont'' will be performed at 8 P.M. Thursday through Saturday and at 3 P.M. next Jan. 26. Its author, Michel Tremblay, will lecture at 4 P.M. Wednesday in the Gengras Student Union.

title: WHAT STILL PHOTOGRAPHERS BRING TO VIDEO
description: IN the United States there is a tendency to catalogue photographers as either still photographers or motion-picture and video photographers. Underlying this is the idea that a photographer can do one but not the other. In Europe, however, still photographers like Raymond DePardon win more awards for television and motion-picture work than for their outstanding still photography.

title: 8,000 SALVADORANS PROTEST AUSTERITY PLAN
description: About 8,000 people marched through San Salvador today to protest expected Government austerity measures.

title: TAX BASE UP IN NEW YORK BY $4 BILLION
description: The taxable value of property in New York City has been tentatively set at $56.6 billion, an increase of $4 billion, or 7.6 percent, over last year, the City Finance Department announced this week.

title: LEVITT DECLINES TO CHALLENGE D'AMATO
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, says that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato can be beaten by a strong Democrat, but that he will not be the one to try.

title: IMPROBABLE CAUSE
description: The Justice Department is pondering ways to protect police from what it regards as undue interference with their work, notably the Miranda rule that requires suspects to be informed of their rights before questioning. The assumption seems to be a need to, as the bumper sticker puts it, Support Your Local Police.

title: Anne O'Neil Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. O'Neil of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Kennard O'Neil, to Juan Manuel Ocampo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jaime Ocampo of Lake Bluff, Ill. The wedding is planned for May.

title: OLD FASHIONED GERANIUMS ARE UNDERGOING A RENAISSANCE
description: My grandmother's house was always crowded with plants saved over from summer. Most especially, I remember her geraniums, tall and skinny in the wan winter sunlight but still capped by a few bright blossoms. The distinctive fragrance released by rubbing a leaf of the old-time favorites still brings back memories of those happy visits.

title: Airline Strategies
description: To the Editor:

title: A FRIEND OF DRAYTON'S
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW ALISTAIR COOKE EVOKES THE WORLD OF THE 'MASTERPIECES'
description: This month marks the 15th anniversary of ''Masterpiece Theater'' on public television. In the following essay, Alistair Cooke, the program's host, reflects on his long relationship with the series.

title: HOW TERRY GILLIAM FOUND A HAPPY ENDING FOR 'BRAZIL'
description: The movie is a surrealistic, nightmarish comedy about a naive clerk who inadvertently defies a powerful but incompetent bureaucracy and is destroyed by its relentless insistence on passive conformity.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IN LIBYA, THE COLOR GREEN
description: An earnest young man in olive green military fatigues addressed a People's Congress meeting last week.

title: A BIAS TOWARD BAD GOVERNMENT?
description: THEY work mostly in an unimposing one-story brick bulding near the edge of campus and under a banner that seems almost deliberately unrevealing. This is an economic research operation in the shadow of Washington whose thinkers do not study policy options, rarely testify before Congressional committees and seem to mind not at all that their public recognition quotient is virtually zero.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 19, 1986 Fiction

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FIRESIDE TALES OF THE TRAVELLER CHILDREN Twelve Scottish Stories. Told by Duncan Williamson. Illustrated by Alan B. Herriot. 170 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $12.95. (Ages 8 and up) THE children of Scottish travelers, gathered around a campfire listening to tales told by their fathers, contrast sharply with American children transfixed by bright pictures and patter emanating from a television set. What children of all cultures and times share is the thirst for story and entertainment. The differences suggest how traditions, values and the role of the imagination have changed.

title: Interest Reports; I.R.S. Delays Co-op Order
description: The Internal Revenue Service has put off for a year a requirement that cooperative housing corporations file an annual accounting of the payments for mortgage interest they receive from their tenant-shareholders. The requirement, which the I.R.S. had ordered last year, led to an outburst of criticism from co-ops about the enormous and unnecessary amount of red tape the regulation would have entailed, as well as complaints that the I.R.S. had timed the announcement of the regulation so that few co-ops could have complied with the necessary paperwork within the time alloted.

title: LAWMAKERS TO GET VIEW FROM JAIL
description: SOME state legislators plan to go to jail later this month to gain a first-hand glimpse of life behind bars. They will be participating in a two-day project designed to sensitize them to the needs of the criminal justice system.

title: Another Look Back On Rent Scene
description: The Dec. 29 article, ''Stutz Looks Back on Rent Board Tenure,'' is rife with Alan Stutz's intemperate remarks and quotations castigating tenants' spokesmen for being ''terribly bankrupt in marshaling their facts,'' operating from emotion; ''you feel that your intelligence is being insulted by people saying the same things in an insulting way.''

title: News From Ferraro
description: In September, Geraldine A. Ferraro wrote to Democratic supporters all over the country, asking them for contributions to a campaign committee exploring her possible 1986 challenge to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York. Three months later, the former Vice-Presidential candidate decided not to run, and now she has written a letter of explanation to those who sent her money, saying, ''There's far more at stake here than my personal desires or disappointments.''

title: CHEMICAL IN BLAST WAS BEING HEATED
description: A chemical that is explosive at high temperatures was being heated at the time the tank it was in exploded Friday, killing two workers and injuring 14 others in Ohio, a spokesman for the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company, said last night.

title: FAMILY AFFAIR
description: The other day, Yehudi Menuhin - Sir Yehudi in England now - was talking about performing with his son Jeremy, the pianist, which he will be doing at Avery Fisher Hall this afternoon. ''It's one of the great joys of my life,'' the violinist/conductor said. ''He feels the need to establish his independence, which I understand, and we play together only on special occasions.''

title: Robyn Silverman Is Wed
description: Robyn Beth Silverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Silverman of Highland Beach, Fla., and New York, and Albert Harvey Gorman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gorman of Long Beach, L.I., were married last evening at the Pierre Hotel by Rabbi Marshall Meyer. The bride is an associate in the New York law firm of Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman. The bridegroom is a lawyer in private practice in Manhattan.

title: HUGHES INSTITUTE GIVING $45 MILLION TO FOUND COLUMBIA NEUROBIOLOGY CENTER
description: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute will spend $45 million during the next five years to establish a neurobiology research center at Columbia University, officials said.

title: TAX-EXEMPT EFFECT
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACKENED ZUCCHINI
description: Not having tasted blackened redfish, golden caviar, blue cornmeal, jicama, Chinese pear and the liver from a moulard duck isn't simply a matter of not knowing what you're missing. It also means not knowing where it's at.

title: Paterno Wins Award
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State and one of his former players, George Landis, the coach of Bloomsburg State in Pennsylvania, have been named Eastern major-college and small-college coaches of the year, respectively, by the New York Football Writers Association. As a result, Paterno will receive the 18th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award after coaching the Nittany Lions through an undefeated regular season (11-0) before losing to Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl.

title: Lynn Darling, Writer, Wed To Lee A. Lescaze, Editor
description: Lynn Darling, a freelance writer, and Lee Adrien Lescaze, an assistant foreign editor of The Wall Street Journal in New York, were married yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Bollman
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. McWilliam V. Bollman of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Louise Bollman, to Lieut. Anthony P. R. Schmidt, U.S.N., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leo A. Schmidt of McLean, Va.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR BETTER SCHOOLS, TEACH THE TEACHERS
description: SO how can we still dream of better-quality classrooms in Connecticut when half of tomorrow's teacher-candidates flunked a ''basic skills'' exercise recently? A dismal statistic indeed for a land once famed for schoolmasters like Noah Webster. It but thickens our catalogue of educational woes on the eve of Connecticut's ''Year of Education.''

title: ALZHEIMER'S: A GUIDE TO SERVICES
description: IT was 80 years ago in Germany that one type of mental confusion was delineated in a woman in her 50's by Dr. Alois Alzheimer. The condition is now known as Alzheimer's disease. Some other names commonly, but incorrectly, used over the years for memory loss in the elderly were ''hardening of the arteries,'' ''organic brain syndrome'' and ''cerebral arterial sclerosis.''

title: POLAND'S ABSENT JEWS GROW CONSPICUOUS
description: The Polish Government has bought ''Shoah,'' the unflinching and lengthy documentary of the Holocaust, and is showing it in movie theaters. A photographic exhibit about remnants of Jewish life in Poland drew 10,000 visitors, almost twice the number of Jews left in this country. Discussions of Jewish themes and debates about anti-Semitism have been an almost daily feature the last few months in the Polish press. Programs about the Nazi persecution have been televised. Indeed, a Government that in 1968 expelled more than 200,000 Jews has agreed to protect Jewish cemeteries and mark old synagogues and is setting up consular links with Israel.

title: DANCE: OHAD NAHARIN AND TROUPE AT THE JOYCE
description: OHAD NAHARIN is a dancer with an exceptionally lithe, strong body. He is also a performer capable of projecting small shifts of emotion and dynamics. But the program presented by Ohad Naharin and Dancers, on Thursday at the Joyce Theater, suffered greatly from an evenness of tone. Aside from the charged opening of ''Innostress,'' this was an evening of lulling, muted sensibilities.

title: MARTIN LUTHER KING HELD A CONVICTION
description: ONE of the inspirational forces in the life of Martin Luther King Jr. was his enduring conviction that humanity would progress toward the Beloved Community. This conviction was extraordinary when one considers some of the many challenges to his natural optimism; namely, the physical violence he and his nonviolent demonstrators suffered, the numerous death threats against him and his family, the apathy among so many whites and blacks who should have been at the forefront of the struggle, the scope and depth of racial discrimination, and the criticisms he received from some other civil-rights leaders, especially for his opposition to the Vietnam War.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CABOT WRIGHT BEGINS, by James Purdy. (Carroll & Graf, $4.50.) Cabot Wright, a former Wall Street executive convicted of raping more than 300 women, has been freed from prison, and Bernie Gladhart, a used-car salesman, sets out to write the great American novel about him. Susan Sontag wrote in The Book Review in 1964 that James Purdy was ''indisputably one of the half dozen or so living American writers worth taking seriously,'' and that ''Cabot Wright Begins'' represents ''the side of Purdy that can be compared with Nathanael West.'' This satirical novel, she said, ''is one of his best. It is a fluent, immensely readable, personal and strong work.'' THE HUMAN PROVINCE, by Elias Canetti. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95.) Thirty years' worth of excerpts from diaries kept by Elias Canetti, winner of the 1981 Nobel Prize in Literature, including notes made as he worked on ''Crowds and Power'' (1960), his study of mass movements. The work gives his readers ''the best portrait we have of Mr. Canetti,'' our reviewer, Michael Wood, wrote in 1979. ''We get a clear sense of this prickly, ambitious, intelligent and sometimes silly man.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Canetti's EARWITNESS: Fifty Characters ($6.95), also translated from the German by Joachim Neugroschel, which Mr. Wood called ''a set of fantastic character sketches, a human bestiary.'' MEMOIRS OF A TOURIST, by Stendhal. (Northwestern University, $10.95.) Stendhal published recollections of his travels through France, with a few side trips to Italy, Switzerland and Spain, in 1838 and cloaked his identity in that of a commercial traveler for an ironworks.

title: HOPES RISE FOR A NEW YORK RAIL LINK TO CAPE COD
description: Vacationers who want to go to Cape Cod this summer will be able to make the trip by train from New York City if Massachusetts officials can persuade their state Legislature to finance a $5 million operating subsidy by spring.

title: VALERIAN A. ZORIN, SOVIET ENVOY, DIES
description: Valerian A. Zorin, a top Foreign Ministry official who served as the Soviet representative to the United Nations in the early 1960's, has died after a long illness, the Comunist Party newspaper Pravda said today. He was 84 years old.

title: EXHIBIT EXPLORES WOMEN AND WORK
description: A NEW exhibit that traces the history of working women in Connecticut from the turn of the century until the present explores, through photographs and actual quotes from employees, why women worked and what they did.

title: TENNIS LAWNS, VINEYARDS, BATTLE FIELDS
description: Visiting Sites Of Battles Past When the 40th anniversary of the end of the war in Europe was observed last year, the occasion was marked by numerous tours of the old battlefields and other historic sites.

title: THE PLEASURES OF THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: Jewels depend a lot on their setting, architectural gems in particular. Any London visitor who doubts this need only look up Ludgate Hill to see how a grubbily intrusive office building of the early egg-crate school mars the grandeur of the great west front of St. Paul's. Or across the Thames from the South Bank to where the clumsy towers of the Department of the Environment, in an ironic commentary on that agency's own performance, ruin the classic composition of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. If poor Wordsworth were to stand on Westminster Bridge today, the prospect would be more likely to inspire an elegy than an ode.

title: Christmas in China For Hockey Team
description: Harbin, Manchuria, is an unlikely place to spend a Christmas vacation.

title: THE U.S. SHOULD PLAY ITS JORDAN CARD
description: Nearly a year has passed since King Hussein of Jordan and Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasir Arafat reached agreement on a common approach to peace with Israel, with little concrete results to be seen. Indeed, events of the last months indicate that their precarious entente has all but collapsed. And the prospects for another military engagement between Israel and its adversaries have increased sharply as a new political alignment takes hold in the Middle East.

title: INSURERS SHY AWAY FROM SATELLITES
description: JUST goes to show how relative everything is: Insurance insiders are feeling chipper these days, basking in the knowledge that they will not lose as much money on space ventures in 1986 as they did in 1985. Why? They are not going to insure as many satellites.

title: ROSEMARY HARRIS IS PURE PRESENCE
description: When Oscar Wilde called the stage ''the refuge of the too fascinating,'' he might have been talking of Rosemary Harris. The British-born actress has a presence so rare that, over the years, critics have outdone themselves trying to describe it: She flutters like a beautiful butterfly. She rises like an undulating coil of smoke forming into unpredictable billows. She moves like a magical, mesmerizing gauze.

title: Question of Honor In Concord, N.H.
description: While Christa McAuliffe, the social studies teacher who is to become the first ordinary citizen in space, finishes her training, her hometown of Concord, N.H., is divided and confused over how to celebrate her.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST NEAR RECORD
description: Contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have surpassed last year's total and approached the record set the year before.

title: A DEAL IS A DEAL
description: I hailed a cab in Manhattan the other day. It was across the street and the driver nodded and blinked his lights in acknowledgment. Then another cab came along on my side of the street and stopped in front of me. I waved him on, having made my deal with the other cabbie.

title: THE MOB AND THE LAW
description: 'The Government's efforts to remove organized crime's influence over unions and legitimate business have been largely ineffective.

title:
AN AFTER WORD;
BANKING ON A WHITE HOUSE PUT OPTION
description: AFTER the stock market collapsed recently, I asked myself if I shouldn't look for a way to hedge my portfolio, such as it is (or was). In quest of enlightment, I decided to listen to the advice of some of the authority figures in my life.

title:
MUSIC;
FRENCH PIANIST IN RETURN VISIT
description: THE appearance by the French pianist Philippe Bianconi at the John Harms Plaza Theater here Thursday will be a return engagement for the 25-year-old artist. A year after his previous performance, in 1984, he won the silver medal in the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE trainman was very new, at least to the South Shore run, and very young. The commuter was a veteran of just about everything that can happen between Pennsylvania Station and points east, and not so very young. He had been riding the Long Island Rail Road regularly for 40 years. He remembered steam engines.

title: Dance
description: Winter chills need not turn dancegoers gloomy, for three choreographers known for their invigorating movement styles are showing new works. Two premieres will be offered by the Elisa Monte Dance Company, during its engagement at the Joyce Theater, which opens Tuesday night.

title: 'THE HIGHEST PASSION IS TERROUR'
description: HAWKSMOOR By Peter Ackroyd. 217 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: David Burgess
description: Like many guitarists, David Burgess, who appeared Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is prone to transcriptions - in his case, his own. The first half of his program consisted of a sonata cobbled together from two Haydn keyboard sonatas, a version of Bach's first keyboard Partita (shorn of one movement) and a Guitar Quartet adapted from a Haydn string quartet and an anonymous 18th-century transcription of that quartet for lute and three strings.

title: Bruno Seeks Title
description: Tim Witherspoon, who won the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship in a majority decision over Tony Tubbs in Atlanta Friday night, won't have the title long, according to a British promoter.

title: 52 ACTS AWAITING ACTION
description: ALTHOUGH new laws have helped to make New Jersey's highways safer from drunken drivers, the state's Commission on Drunk Driving made many recommendations in its first year that will require additional laws.

title: Loen Kelley Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John H. Kelley of Des Moines of the engagement of their daughter Sandra Loen Kelley to John H. Knowles Jr., a son of Edith LaCroix Dabney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Knowles. The wedding is planned for June 14.

title: SPECULATING ON AN EARTHLY SPACE BOOM
description: THANKS to the space program, land prices in certain parts of the country are defying gravity. Corporations are buying up land - or leasing it at astronomical prices - around NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, as well as in areas adjacent to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: WINDHAM MAY AID TECHNOLOGY PARK
description: THE University of Connecticut Technology Park, if approved by regulators, would be built in Mansfield, but its developers have turned to the neighboring town of Windham for financial aid.

title: Amy B. McIntosh Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Douglas D. Drysdale of Washington and Robert C. McIntosh of Cincinnati of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Bennett McIntosh, to Jeffrey Ross Toobin, the son of Marlene Sanders and the late Jerome Toobin of New York and Sherman, Conn.

title: ST. JOHN'S AND NORTH CAROLINA TRIUMPH REDMEN EDGE UCONN, 61-60
description: For his first two seasons, when he played in the shadows of others at St. John's, Mark Jackson quietly bided his time in the belief that his perseverance as a role player would someday be rewarded.

title: PARKS NEW RECIAL ISSUE IN DEARBORN
description: In the days when Orville L. Hubbard ruled this industrial enclave, he made no secret of his segregationist views. As the town's tough-talking Mayor for 36 years, he was proud that he kept Dearborn lily white.

title: MUDD A SHOT AHEAD IN BOB HOPE GOLF
description: Jodie Mudd, who tied the Bermuda Dunes course record of nine-under-par 63 Friday, shot a four-under-par 68 at LaQuinta today to take a one-shot lead after 72 holes of the 27th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: NASSAU G.O.P. ACTS ON LILCO
description: NASSAU County Republicans have begun the new year by quickly attempting to seize the initiative on the question of a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: NUCLEAR NAKED
description: The proposition is simple yet also cynical: Nuclear weapons are not rationally usable; therefore they're useless; therefore don't just limit them but get rid of all of them, and quickly.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BOROUGH PARK
description: A PROMOTIONAL poster displayed in Borough Park offers this description of the predominantly Jewish Brooklyn neighborhood: ''A thriving community of traditional family values.'' Residents say it is true. In this community of more than 100,000 people packed into 200 blocks, signs of tradition are easy to spot. Storefronts advertise in Hebrew, beckoning to an estimated 80 percent of the community who are observant Jews, the highest concentration anywhere outside Israel, community leaders say.

title: CUOMO ASSERTS HE IS VICTIM OF ETHNIC BIAS BY COLUMNISTS
description: Governor Cu''increasing references to my ethnicity,'' declared today, ''If anything could make me change my mind about running for the Presidency, it's people talking about, 'An Italian can't do it, a Catholic can't do it.' ''

title: Isabelle Kellogg Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bertschmann of New York and Basel, Switzerland, have announced that her daughter, Isabelle Kellogg, and Luc Roland Van Wambeke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Armand Robert Van Wambeke of Ithaca, N.Y., plan to be married in the summer.

title: BACON PLAYS A SUBTLE YET HAUNTING CULINARY ROLE
description: BACON is to meat as onions are to vegetables: a savory workhorse ingredient that lends an underpinning of hauntingly rich and complex flavor to a dish, frequently without celebration or menu credit. Roll some impeccable trout in cornmeal and sizzle it in freshly rendered bacon fat and you have trout to remember.

title: REAGAN QUOTES KING SPEECH IN OPPOSING MINORITY QUOTAS
description: President Reagan quoted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today in support of his contention that there should be no quotas in a truly ''color-blind'' society.

title: SHARING THE LOVE OF HUNTING ON A STILL MORNING
description: For years Master Sgt. John Taylor played tuba in the United States Army Band, but some of his friends believe he blows sweeter music on a goose call.

title: Homeless Families in Cities Found Increasingly Rapidly
description: Homeless parents and their children now substantially outnumber homeless single adults in urban centers around the nation, according to a report by a New York-based coalition of churches and synagogues.

title: 29 FOOD OUTLETS GET CITATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Bradley's, 70 University Pl.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES WITH A SPECIAL WINTER APPEAL
description: DIVERSITY is the rule in nature. Drive through the countryside and you will see variety in color, texture, form and size of plants. It is this diversity that catch's one's eye and captures one's interest. Too often we ignore this when selecting plants for our gardens.

title: POP: THE RESIDENTS GIVE FIRST NEW YORK SHOW
description: ROCK'S best-known nobodies, the Residents, played their first New York show Thursday night at the Ritz. For 13 years, the members of the San Francisco-based group have stayed anonymous, releasing records regularly and touring occasionally, gaining a following among self-described ''weird music'' devotees.

title: Dr. Brad Mitchell Perlstein To Wed Lori M. Krichmar
description: Lori M. Krichmar, an education instructor at the New York University Medical Center, and Dr. Brad Mitchell Perlstein, a dentist in Middletown, N.Y., plan to be married April 20, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sy B. Krichmar of Baldwin, L.I., have announced. Dr. Perlstein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Perlstein of New City, N.Y.

title: Mary E. Hopkins To Marry Feb. 15
description: Mary Elizabeth Hopkins, the executive director of the National Committee for a Single Six-Year Presidential Term, and Dr. George Melville Williams, chief of the department of transplantation and vascular surgery at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, plan to be married Feb. 15.

title: FOR CHILDREN ONLY: NEW BOOKSTORE REFLECTS A TREND
description: WITH the recent opening of ''Once Upon a Time,'' a bookstore exclusively for children, Westchester has joined what the book trade describes as a growing trend: the proliferation of ''for children only'' bookstores. According to recent estimates there are now more than 300 children's bookstores nationwide. Ten years ago there were about 12.

title: PICKING A MUSICAL INSTRUMENT
description: THROUGHOUT my career as a music educator, and subsequently in my dealings in the music industry, I have been troubled about the manner in which students select a musical instrument for study. I am in direct contact with literally thousands of young students each year and yet I seldom hear of someone taking advantage of the myriad musical-aptitude testing procedures that are now available. Instead, the selection of a musical instrument is made on the basis of what appeals to the eye of the student, what mom and dad like, or what instrument is in the attic.

title: POP: AKSAK MABOUL
description: MIXING bistro music, rock, noise, whimsy and a taste of Minimalism, the Belgian band Aksak Maboul opened the Strange Mutations music series Thursday night at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street. Aksak Maboul is an occasional project of the keyboardist Marc Hollander, who runs the Crammed Disc record label, and the guitarist-bassist Vincent Kenis.

title:
DINING OUT;
FOR A CHEF, A DREAM COMES TRUE
description: THE ultimate dream of many an ambitious chef is to have a restaurant of his own.

title: THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF BINGHAM
description: ''IT'S a sad day for all of us,'' said Paul Janensch, executive editor of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, hoarsely addressing several hundred somber co-workers who had jammed the company cafeteria to consider their uncertain future. It was 3 P.M. on Friday, Jan. 10, the day after the abrupt announcement that the Bingham family, the glamorous and tortured clan that had owned the newspapers for almost 70 years, was selling out.

title: A Renewal Of Faith
description: I was deeply moved by Dan Wakefield's account of his rediscovery of God (''Returning to Church,'' Dec. 22). We can only be happy for him in the renewal of his faith.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES WITH A SPECIAL WINTER APPEAL
description: DIVERSITY is the rule in nature. Drive through the countryside and you will see variety in color, texture, form and size of plants. It is this diversity that catch's one's eye and captures one's interest. Too often we ignore this when selecting plants for our gardens.

title: MCCASKEY PUT BEARS ON SOLID FOOTING
description: WHEN George Halas died in October 1983, the line of succession was in order. His Chicago Bears would pass to his only daughter, Virginia Halas McCaskey.

title: PARIS TURNS THE SPOTLIGHT ON HUGO AND GENET
description: The cultural scene in Paris, particularly in the subsidized theaters, reflects a curious longing for the ''old and true,'' the touchstones of dramatic literature. If anything defines the current theater season, with Corneille's ''Cid'' alternating with Aristophanes' ''Birds'' at Barrault's Rond Point, Corneille's ''Illusion Comique'' held over at the Odeon and Racine's ''Bajazet'' at the Carre Silvia Monfort, it is a return to the classics, and a redefinition of what constitutes Classicism.

title: THE GOVERNOR, THE CONVICT, AND THE QUALITY OF MERCY
description: Virtually lost amid the 93 pages of New York State's Constitution is the sentence: ''The Governor shall have the power to grant reprieves, commutations and pardons after conviction for all offenses except treason and cases of impeachment.''

title: The Navy's Brash Leader
description: Though Navy Secretary Lehman's 600-ship fleet has enhanced our nation's security, some of his strategic concepts are open to severe criticism, and not only via ''armchair strategy'': the notion of concealing American aircraft carriers in the fjords of Norway for operations against Russia has a direct and negative precedent. During World War II, powerful German naval units - the battleships Tirpitz and Scharnhorst, plus cruisers and destroyer flotillas - attempted to use these same fjords as bases for attacks on Murmansk-bound convoys in the Norwegian and Barents Seas. Despite air support from fields in Norway and Finland, they accomplished little (submarines did much more damage), and all were eventually winkled out and destroyed by British air and naval forces. DAVID $:UCK Brooklyn

title: CHARITY FOR NONE, AVARICE FOR ALL
description: GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET The Fall of the House of Lehman. By Ken Auletta. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: THE RUSSIANS BROKE 1958-61 TEST MORATORIUM
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN DISHES TO TAKE HOME
description: THE term ''Indian takeout food'' is almost a contradiction. The elaborate preparation involved in Indian cuisine is the antithesis of fast food.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING LOOKS TO BETTER TIMES
description: THE proclamation of ''Connecticut Housing Week,'' which begins today and commemorates the state's 50 years of providing public housing, is prompting an examination of the successes and failures of the program.

title: Margot E. Greenbaum to Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Greenbaum of South Orange, N.J., and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margot Elizabeth Greenbaum, to James Mustich Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mustich of Pleasantville, N.Y. A May wedding is planned. The future bride, who attended Vassar College, and her fiance both graduated magna cum laude from Princeton University.

title: Reunion for Babych
description: Wayne Babych, a 27-year-old forward who played six seasons with the St. Louis Blues, has been reunited with his old coach and his baby brother after being traded from the Quebec Nordiques to the Hartford Whalers for a center, Greg Malone. His brother, Dave Babych, 24, is a Whaler defenseman and his old Blues' coach, Emile Francis, is Hartford's president and general manager.

title: SAINTS AND SINNERS IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: ANATOMY OF A WAR Vietnam, the United States, and the Modern Historical Experience. By Gabriel Kolko. 628 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $25.

title: HOW TO IMPROVE A PC'S MATH SKILLS
description: THE heart of the current generation of I.B.M. PC's and their compatibles is the 8088 chip, which serves as their C.P.U., or central processing unit. This tiny piece of circuitry contains the arithmetic and logic unit, or A.L.U., some memory and the control unit that directs the operation of the computer and its peripherals.

title: BUDGET CITED AS GRUNEWALD QUITS MUSEUM
description: WHEN he took over as president and chief executive officer of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers last July, Dr. Donald Grunewald was seen by some as the ''white knight'' who would rescue the financially troubled institution by applying the fund-raising skills he honed during his 12 years as president of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry.

title: RIDING THE NOUVELLE PREMIERE
description: Hidden away in the Gare de l'Est in Paris, not far from the long-distance tracks, is a waiting room set aside for the passengers of a very special new train. A uniformed doorman takes your bags, a hostess checks your reservations and, if you ask, will book you a hotel room at the other end of your trip, and a barman mixes you a drink. When the train is announced, your luggage is already aboard and you are met at the steps of your car by the young man or woman who will take care of you during the journey, the commissaire de bord.

title: FAST FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: Sue Van De Ryt Engaged
description: Sue Van De Ryt, a flight attendant for American Airlines in New York, and Brian Lachapelle, an American Airlines pilot, plan to be married April 12. Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Van De Ryt of Cincinnati have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lachapelle of Massapequa, L.I. Miss Van De Ryt graduated from the College of Mount St. Joseph in Cincinnati. Her fiance is an alumnus of the Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Sarah O'Neil Weds Thomas P. Lemke
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday Sarah Elizabeth O'Neil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Roderick O'Neil of Hartford and Chappaqua, was married to Thomas P. Lemke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lemke of Colonie, N.Y. The Rev. James T. McGuire performed the ceremony.

title: DIVINE VISIONS, DIABOLICAL OBSESSIONS
description: IMMODEST ACTS The Life of a Lesbian Nun in Renaissance Italy. By Judith C. Brown. 214 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $14.95.

title: Hanley Daws
description: Hanley Daws, the associate concertmaster of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra in Minnesota, offered a better blend of old and new in his debut program Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall; this was the debut, as well, of the Daws-Faricy Duo, which he formed with the excellent pianist Katherine Faricy.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT OILERS TO REACH .500
description: They were tired from traveling. Some were sick with the flu. Some had even suggested beforehand that two victories on the road swing would be enough. Suffice to say, these are not the optimum conditions for confronting Wayne Gretzky and the Oilers.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
ENCHANTED BY REALISM
description: HOPPER'S PLACES (Knopf, Cloth, $18.95, Paper, $10.95) dispays photographs of many of the buildings that appear in paintings by Edward Hopper (1882-1967) side by side with color plates of those paintings. To compare photographs of unmemorable structures with the saturate, intensely lighted paintings (most from private collections) is to see how realism is much more then mere depiction.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SEEKS TO BREAK IMPASSE ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: The Reagan Administration has sent its top Middle East official on an unannounced trip to Europe in an effort to break the impasse on Arab-Israeli peace talks, Administration aides said today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MEN OF COMPANY K:

title: A COUNTRY INN IN MOUNT KISCO
description: WHAT is it with the county's inns? Managements seem to cling to a mistaken notion that charm and age are inseparable, that dining rooms in houses dating to the 18th century need no further credentials, and that somehow stains, poor housekeeping, bleak lighting and mediocre food will be forgotten or forgiven as customers whisper at the sight of wide-plank floors, low raftered ceilings, wood paneling and the flash of copper and brass.

title: LENDL AND BECKER REACH THE FINAL
description: After seven years of hard labor, Ivan Lendl has finally reached the top in men's tennis, only to encounter an overnight sensation with an engaging personality and overpowering style that threatens to make Lendl's reign brief. From the vantage point of Andres Gomez of Ecuador, today's Nabisco Masters final between Lendl and Boris Becker may very well establish the winner as the dominant player in men's tennis, the one everyone else will be trying to beat.

title: WHEN FIRE MEETS ICE: HOW TO HANDLE FROZEN WATER PIPES
description: EVEN in a house that is well insulated and properly heated, an extreme cold snap can freeze water lines.

title: COLONEL LOSES A BATTLE AGAINST CBS
description: The long legal battle between a retired Vietnam War officer and CBS produced a potentially important distinction in libel law last week.

title: Camille Cooley Rosso Marries Scottow King
description: Camille Cooley Rosso, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman V. Cooley of Santa Paula, Calif., was married yesterday to Scottow Atherton King, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kimball King of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Stephen Elkins-Williams performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Chapel of the Cross in Chapel Hill, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Lowry, the bridegroom's grandfather.

title: NEW CASSETTES: QUAKERS, CRICKETS, LOW-KEYED JAZZ
description: A Cricket in Times Square Written and directed by Chuck Jones, 1973 Family Home Entertainment 30 minutes. $19.95 This animated version of George Selden's much-loved children's book was adapted and directed by the inimitable Chuck Jones.

title: WHAT THE SHOREHAM TEST WON'T TEST FOR
description: Some of the details of the Lilco Shoreham evacuation plan not mentioned in ''Shoreham Drill: Planning the Details'' [ Dec. 15 ] deserve consideration and public attention. While these details that follow are not part of the test of the plan, they are part of the plan, having already been approved by the Nuclear Rregulatory Commission.

title: Consumerism In Massachusetts
description: Massachusetts has a new ''lemon law'' that the state and automobile makers call one of the toughest in the country.

title: DOWN-HOME MUSIC THAT EVOKES THE SOUL OF MEXICO
description: Knowledge of Mexican traditional music in North America is generally limited to one or two specific genres. One is the mariachi sound, with its high close-harmony singing, the vigorous strumming of guitars of various sizes, and sometimes blaring trumpets, their chording sounding almost pressed or squeezed together into thirds, like the vocals. Originally a regional folk style, this sound has become popular throughout Mexico. The Norteno music of the Texas-Mexican border and neighboring areas is also a regional style, but since the 1950's it has seeped into the North American consciousness through its impact on rock-and-roll.

title: CARBIDE'S WESTCHESTER LAND MAY YIELD 1,000 HOMES
description: AS many as a thousand condominium units may be developed by foreign investors on the 275-acre tract, straddling the Mount Pleasant-Greenburgh town line, that Union Carbide sold at the turn of the year. The price for the property, $170 million, is believed to be the largest for a real-estate transaction in the history of Westchester County.

title: Marjorie Peerce Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart B. Peerce of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of his daughter Marjorie Joan Peerce to Mark Laurence Fuerst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel M. Fuerst of Warwick, R.I.

title: AMERICA'S YIDDISH THEATER HONORED BY WASHINGTON B'NAI B'RITH MUSEUM
description: Paul Muni (when he was known as Muni Weisenfreund) learned his craft in it. So did Edward G. Robinson. As a child star, Sidney Lumet appeared in it in a 1937 version of Sinclair Lewis's ''It Can't Happen Here.'' It is Yiddish theater, and the B'nai B'rith Klutznick Museum here has mounted a show that takes an exuberant look at its history in America.

title: Suzanne Mitchell to Wed Steven A. Shaver in June
description: The engagement of Suzanne Mitchell and Steven A. Shaver, seniors at Middlebury College, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Mitchell of London, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Alan M. Shaver and the Rev. Ellen M. Shaver of Bronxville, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Barrie E. Todd Plans To Marry Kent Dahl
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Todd Jr. of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter Barrie Ewing Todd to Kent Wilson Dahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. William Dahl Jr. of Norwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: IT'S A JUNGLE OUT THERE
description: MAD MARIA By Marcio Souza. Translated by Thomas Colchie. 390 pp. New York: Bard/Avon. Paper, $4.95.

title: ITALY'S POLENTA: MORE THAN MUSH
description: What you find on your plate in Venice, Cortina d'Ampezzo or Bergamo may look like a wedge of yellow or white Styrofoam. But that wedge of food, polenta by name, has character, and it allies happily with fowl, meat or fish. With butter and fried onions or with tomato sauce, it can be a meal in its own right. It cries out for Merlot, Valpolicella or some other full-bodied red wine, and it sticks to the ribs.

title: SOME THINGS A LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR CAN DO
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDITION UPGRADED TO 'GUARDED'
description: Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, was transferred from a cardiac care unit to a private room at New York University Medical Center yesterday as he continued recuperating from a mild heart attack and wounds suffered 10 days ago.

title: CONRAIL SALE DECISON NEARS
description: THE struggle for control of Conrail, the federally owned all-freight rail system, is expected to reach a critical juncture in the United States Senate this week.

title: A SOFT GLOW FROM KYOTO'S LAMPS
description: The blazing lights of a thousand candles have never been the Japanese ideal for an elegant room. Rather, the muted glow of a single flame, preferably screened by pure white paper, is the most fitting complement to a room defined by the natural tones and delicately rough surfaces of wood, straw and mud. Before they incorporated sliding glass doors, Japanese houses filtered the raw glare of daylight through translucent paper shoji screens, except when weather or the desire to admire the garden required exposing the interior to the elements. Even now, when a homeowner can afford them, wood-framed shoji screens mask glass doors and windows in their harsh and unattractive aluminum frames, lending a soft quality to the light, as if everything had been washed with a thinly diluted white pigment. The most characteristic atmospheric quality of outdoor light is similar, a misty subfusion of form and light that derives from the high humidity that Japan experiences much of the year.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE ASCENDANCY OF THE HUMBLE
description: THANKS to scarcity and demand, always a twin index of value for antiques, even the more humble areas of collecting have been elevated to the kind of sought-after status that encourages dealers to specialize without any certainty of being able to replenish quality to keep up with the market.

title: SOUTH YEMEN HEAD IS SAID TO DEPART
description: The Marxist President of Southern Yemen, beleaguered in nearly a week of fierce fighting by hard-line Communist rebels, reportedly flew to Ethiopia late Saturday night.

title: ARBITRATION FOR A RED SEA STRAND
description: It seems an unlikely trouble spot -700 yards of beach with a five-star hotel - but for several years the Red Sea resort of Taba has come between Israel and Egypt diplomatically as well as geographically. When it evacuated the Sinai in 1982, Israel gave back everything but Taba, asserting that it had unearthed turn-of-the-century British maps placing the town in Palestine, its forerunner.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LIABILITY insurance could become freely available again, thanks to recent action in Trenton, but it would cover far fewer environmental injuries than older policies did.

title: AN AQUATIC IMAGE
description: The first 100 condominiums in the Waterways at Bay Pointe project at Moriches in Suffolk County are under construction and will be available for occupancy late this summer, according to the developers, Bregman Construction Company of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE UNLOVED: From the Diary of Perla S. By Arnost Lustig. (Arbor House, $14.95.) Despite its setting - a Nazi concentration camp - Arnost Lustig's latest novel is strangely affirmative in its vision of innocence and courage. Mr. Lustig traces five months in the life of Perla S., an adolescent prostitute in the Theresienstadt camp.

title: A COMEBACK FOR SINGLE-DIGIT MORTGAGES
description: Several years ago, when mortgage interest rates were pushing into the high teens, many financial experts predicted that conventional, fixed-rate loans were gone forever. Bankers, it was said, could no longer risk their money at fixed rates in the highly volatile, deregulated marketplace - borrowers would have to share the risk by holding adjustable-rate loans. So much for predictions. By the fall of 1982, inflation and interest rates had stabilized and two years later fixed-rate loans were again competitively priced - within a percentage point of adjustable-rate loans. Interest rates continued to decline as inflation came under control and as the secondary mortgage market became more active and efficient.

title: Business Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE SPACE BUSINESS
description: IN THE 28 years since Sputnik captured the world's attention, space exploration -despite occasional well-publicized fiascos - has titillated the public's imagination and stirred its pride. Pictures of astronauts floating gracefully hundreds of miles above a bright blue earth, Neil Armstrong's footprint on the moon, the ''Right Stuff'' swagger of the early astronauts and the professional coolness of the shuttle generation, all have come to symbolize the pinnacle of technological achievement and personal courage.

title: IN COMMACK, DREAMS RISE WITH BIG HOUSING DEVELOPMENT
description: OVER the centuries, a 276-acre parcel in Commack has gone through many changes.

title: Cardiologist Is Convicted In Pacemaker Kickbacks
description: A Rhode Island cardiologist, accused of implanting as many as 55 pacemakers in people who did not need the heartbeat stabilized or the heart muscle stimulated electronically, has been convicted of taking kickbacks from pacemaker manufacturers to use their products.

title: Allison Wilcox Is Wed To Dr. Steven Parker
description: Allison Hadley Wilcox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Wilcox of New York, and Dr. Steven P. Parker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Parker of Duncan, Okla., were married yesterday in Austin, Tex. Deborah Ravel, a justice of the peace, officiated at historic Caswell House.

title: A CALL FOR ACTION FROM THE NEW ASSEMBLY SPEAKER
description: GOVERNOR KEAN has provided inspired leadership to New Jersey for the last four years. We know that leadership will continue. We Republicans sit as the majority party in this house today largely because the people apporove of the direction the Governor has charted for our state.

title: FOR TEEN-AGERS LOLLIPOP SHAPES
description: IT may be midwinter, the wind-chill factor may make it feel like minus 15 degrees, the rest of us may be swaddled in our heaviest and dreariest clothes. But for teen-agers, January is definitely not the month for colorless clothes.

title: AUSTRIA IN HIS DREAMS
description: FREUD'S DISCOVERY OF PSYCHOANALYSIS The Politics of Hysteria. By William J. McGrath. 336 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $25.

title: TWO NOT QUITE NICE THINGS
description: TENDER OFFER By Nora Johnson. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: HARLEM WARILY GREETS PLANS FOR DEVELOPMENT
description: At perhaps no time in the 15 years of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation have so many been so eager to invest in Harlem real estate. And at no time in his 10 years as president of the agency has Donald J. Cogsville been more excited, or more wary.

title: MAN ARRESTED IN KIDNAPPING OF BROTHER OF ARAB DIPLOMAT
description: Federal authorities last night arrested a Manhattan man believed to be involved in the kidnapping of an Arab diplomat's brother in London on Jan. 6.

title: Sarah Peirce to Wed Edgar Mead 3d
description: An April wedding is planned by Sarah Griffith Peirce and Edgar Thorn Mead 3d. Mrs. R. Thomas B. Peirce Jr. of Beach Haven and Marlton, N.J., has announced her daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Etna, N.H.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MOSES OF ROVNO. By Douglas K. Huneke. (Dodd, Mead, $17.95.) The story of a heroic German structural engineer, Herman (Fritz) Graebe, survives Douglas K. Huneke's melodramatic rendering. Mr. Graebe, who now lives in San Francisco, joined the National Socialist Party in 1931, later renounced his membership and risked his life to save Jews in the Ukraine.

title: ECHOES OF LENNY BRUCE, VIA BOGOSIAN AND REDDIN
description: When auditions began for ''Rum and Coke,''

title: SOVIET JAZZ HAS DEBUT IN STATE
description: JAZZ fans in the Hartford area got a preview last week of five new records from the Soviet Union that are to be released nationally as part of a venture born of both commercial and diplomatic goals.

title: CONSUMER RATES
LEBANESE MOSLEMS CALL FOR THE OUSTER OF GEMAYAL
description: Leaders of Moslem militias in Lebanon called today for the ouster of President Amin Gemayel, a Christian, as the only way to break a political deadlock over carrying out a Syrian-sponsored peace plan.

title: SENATOR RETURNS WITH 2 VIETNAMESE CHILDREN
description: Senator Frank H. Murkowski went to Vietnam to find out about Americans missing in action in the Indochina war, but left today with two Vietnamese children who were separated from their mother seven years ago.

title: NAVY BLOCKED IN AIDS CASE
description: A Federal district judge on today temporarily barred the Navy from discharging 11 recruits whose blood tests indicate exposure to the AIDS virus, pending a review of the case by the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: Nudity at Issue On Virginia Island
description: January may seem an unlikely time to think about nude sunbathing along the coast of Virginia, but a group of nudists who would rather pursue a suit than wear one are taking their fight to the courts.

title: MOSCOW AMPLIFIES LATEST ARMS PLAN
description: Soviet officials confirmed today that the package of arms proposals offered by Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week included a new approach to the elimination of medium-range missiles in Europe.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOW OF COUNTRY COLLECTIBLES
description: THE collector who has a special liking for what has come to be called country antiques may enjoy shopping next weekend at the annual show in the Carl Allgrove School on Route 20 in East Granby. The Country Antiques Show is held each winter to raise funds for the local historical society.

title: KR. KING'S DREAM LIVES ON IN EAST ORANGE
description: The Rogers twins, Kendall and Kenneth, are only in first grade, but they know the whole story on Martin Luther King.

title: AGREEMENT IS REPORTED FOR CHANNEL RAIL LINK
description: Britain and France have decided to build a fixed transport link involving a twin rail tunnel but no immediate roadway under the Channel, according to reports in Britain's Sunday newspapers.

title: FAST FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 548386 -- No Title
description: The six winning numbers for the $30 million Lotto 48 - 12-14-22-32-34-43 -were picked at 10:20 P.M. last night.

title: REAGAN AT 75
description: As he enters the sixth year of his Presidency and the 76th year of his life, Ronald Reagan is undoubtedly the happiest politician in Washington. And no wonder.

title: Faculty Sex Bias Suit Settled
description: The state has ended an eight-year legal battle with women on the faculty of the University of Rhode Island by agreeing to settle a discrimination suit for $1.24 million.

title: Music
description: Given the myriad musical events that come and go in New York every season, it is easy to lose sight of interesting concerts that are neither heavily publicized nor devised with the box-office in mind.

title: MAGAZINES ON CRAFTS FIND NICHE
description: PAUL ROMAN, an amateur woodworker, sat down in the basement office of his home one day 10 years ago, and that was the last his family saw of him for three weeks. When he emerged, he had produced the model copy of a glossy black and white bimonthly magazine called Fine Woodworking, which was mailed to 20,000 pre-subscribed readers a few weeks later.

title: ARIANNA STASSINOPOULOS TO BE MARRIED
description: Arianna Stassinopoulos and R. Michael Huffington plan to be married in April, her parents, Constantine Stassinopoulos of Athens and Elli Stassinopoulos of London, have announced.

title: FOUR ISLAND MUSEUMS EXPANDING
description: HAMMERS, saws and construction workers are becoming as much a part of the scene at Long Island's museums as paintings, sculptures and curators.

title: The Pollack Touch
description: Janet Maslin's article ''The Pollack Touch'' (Dec. 15) offered a sense of optimism about the future of Hollywood. Too often today, movies are made based largely on tried and proven formulas and audience demographics rather than on the strength of the conviction of those who conceived them.

title: COMING INTO MONEY - AND NOT TROUBLE
description: LAST spring, David Paul Pappas, vice president of Donghia Showrooms Inc., a prominent New York design firm, was in his office planning a show scheduled that month for Minneapolis. He took a telephone call from the executor handling the estate of Angelo Donghia, the company founder; Mr. Donghia, who had died following a long illness, had left Mr. Pappas 25 percent of the company stock. ''I had prepared myself for his death, but the gift was totally unexpected,'' he recalled.

title: A SEAT BELT LAW FACES REPEAL VOTE
description: Opponents of Massachusetts' three-week-old law requiring use of seat belts have submitted enough signatures to put a repeal question on the November ballot.

title: LUCIA CHASE HELPED CREATE THE BALLET WORLD WE KNOW
description: American Ballet Theater would not be here today if it had not been for Lucia Chase. Nor can one separate the international reputation of the company from Miss Chase's association with Ballet Theater. She was its founding patron in 1939 and, later, its longtime artistic director. She herself probably cherished her days as a dancer most of all.

title: INSURANCE COSTS SQUEEZE SCHOOLS
description: WE'RE in budget season again, the time when school boards begin to formulate the budgets they will submit to the voters in the spring. It is always a difficult task to balance the needs of the children for educational programs with the ability and willingness of property owners to pay taxes.

title: The Maid's Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: QUAKERS, CRICKETS, LOW-KEYED JAZZ
description: Saint-Saens's 'Samson et Dalila' A Royal Opera, Covent Garden, production, featuring Jon Vickers and Shirley Verrett; conducted by Colin Davis, directed by John Vernon Thorn EMI/HBO Video 135 minutes. $39.95 Camille Saint-Saens originally conceived his opera ''Samson et Dalila'' as an oratorio and probably should have left well enough alone.

title: THE SUMMER GAME IN THE SPRINGTIME
description: I don't remember just how old I was, but I won't ever forget the impression her casual comment made on me. My mother, who until then seemed rather unremarkable, mentioned one day that on a trip to Florida with her family one spring she had met Babe Ruth. Just walked up to him in the lobby of a St. Petersburg hotel, she related, and shaken his hand. Even now, more than 30 years later, I'm probably still more impressed than if she'd told me she had danced with the Prince of Wales.

title: Princeton Raises Tuition
description: Princeton University's board of trustees today approved a 7 percent increase in student tuition and fees for the 1986-87 academic year. The trustees set the cost of attending Princeton next year at $15,980, up from $14,940 this year. The university's president, William G. Bowen, said Princeton would continue its policy of admitting students without regard to their financial need.

title: LIBYAN ISSUE LEAVES MANY QUESTIONING ROLE OD ALLIES
description: President Reagan's attempt to impose an economic quarantine on Libya, and the lukewarm response of the Western European allies, has once again raised the question - asked by many Americans - of whether America's allies are letting Washington down.

title: 'WHITE RAJAHS' LINGER IN A MALAYSIAN TOWN
description: This is the town the White Rajahs built, and it revels in the distinction of having been the heart of one of the most eccentric ventures in the history of European colonialism.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEMINGWAY'S NOTEBOOK. By Bill Granger. (Crown, $15.95.) St. Michel is one of those Caribbean islands nobody seems to care about but everybody wants to control, where lots of people deal in drugs or espionage.

title: Data Bank; January 19, 1986
NOTES ON SOME NEW BOOKS
description: MANY years ago, a thick-wristed North Carolina waterman who, as many such men do, set aside part of each winter for guiding duck and goose hunters on the vast reaches of his state's Pamlico Sound, described to me his technique for training retrievers.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: CAN it be possible in social situations these days that the extra person, female, is as acceptable as the extra person, male? No, it's not possible, that is to say, it's not true -yet. But it's happening more and more, and it's getting awfully close to being the kind of given that no longer deserves or requires discussion.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO WEIGH ABDUCTING TERRORISTS ABROAD FOR TRIALS HERE
description: The Reagan Administration has been debating several proposals to abduct suspects in terrorist attacks on Americans abroad and bring them before American courts, according to Administration officials. So far, senior officials have declined to approve the plans, but the Administration is continuing to consider the idea, the officials said. For example, they said, the Central Intelligence Agency and the United Stats Marshals Service are preparing a contingency plan for seizing several people in the Middle East who have been implicated in two recent terrorist actions.

title: Dance Performances At Ballet School Benefit
description: Alexandra Danilova will serve as the hostess of the School of American Ballet's eighth annual benefit gala, which takes place on Wednesday at the New York State Theater. The benefit program will include a revival of George Balanchine's ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue,'' from the original production of ''On Your Toes.''

title: Edwards Suffers Upset In Squash Tournament
description: Michael Desaulniers of New York City upset second-seeded Ned Edwards, also of New York City, today to moved into the semifinals of 44th annual Apawamis Invitational squash racquets tournament. The scores were 15-4, 7-15, 15-10, 15-11.

title:
ART;
IMAGINATION SPURS THE IMAGE AT PHOTO EXHIBITIONS
description: PHOTOGRAPHY'S recognition as a substantive, immensely diverse creative pursuit warranting carefull historical and stylistic definitions has certainly been one of the important developments in the visual arts.

title: NAMING THE GAME
description: IN a word, it was accidental.

title: Navratilova Wins
description: Pam Shriver was routed by topseeded Martina Navratilova, 6-1, 6-1, tonight in semifinals singles play of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of New England tournament.

title: SIBERIAN AIRLIFT MELDS 2 TECHNOLOGIES
description: Two of the largest products of modern engineering came together just before the New Year in the Siberian port of Vladivostok in a melding of Soviet and American technology.

title: Punts Go a Long Way
description: It's a familiar enough story, one of those cautionary tales about a couple of kids who start out having a little fun and end up with nothing less than a consuming obsession.

title: Why Sergeants' Test Will Fail Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Unkindest Cut of All
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Feet Tough to Fit
description: Jack Jensen of Nashville has been selling special shoes for 28 years, and until recently he never met a foot he couldn't fit. Then in walked Will Perdue, a 6-foot-11-inch center on the Vanderbilt University basketball team.

title: Washington Watch; World Bank Post for Brock?
description: Should Labor Secretary Bill Brock lose in his battle over affirmative action, some Administration aides suggest he might accept the presidency of the World Bank, if the White House will give it to him.

title: POLICE IN SEATTLE 'OPTIMISTIC' ON ARREST IN GREEN RIVER KILLINGS
description: Investigators say they think he is a white man of above average intelligence, a heavy smoker and drinker who likes to drive, loves publicity and is an outdoorsman. But all they know for sure is that they are looking for the killer of 34 women.

title: TUTU WARNS PARLEY AT ATLANTA CHURCH: TIME TO ACT IS NEAR
description: In a speech that ended with the plea ''help,'' Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa said today that if his country made no significant changes in its policies of strict racial separation by the end of March, ''We start a campaign in our country of civil disobedience.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Ralph W. Rydholm will join Ted Bates Advertising/New York as executive vice president and executive creative director.

title: Peril From Above
description: The cry of the umbrella vendor promises protection for $3.

title: WEAK BOTTLER TIES HURT 7-UP IN FIGHT FOR SHARES
description: For decades, when it came to marketing, Philip Morris Inc., was considered one of the best.

title: 3 Hurt as Sikhs Clash At Shrine in Amritsar
description: Three people were reported wounded today as 70 Sikhs fought with rifles and shotguns in the Golden Temple over who would rebuild its throne room, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 20, 1986
description: International

title: Advertising; Needham's Consultant
description: Stanley Marcus, 80 and chairman emeritus of Neiman-Marcus, has joined Needham Harper Worldwide as a consultant and will be available to all the agency's accounts offering his expertise, especially in the area of retailing and customer service.

title: NEW MUSEUM IN ATHENS SHOWS EARLY GREEK ART
description: A new museum, designed as a showcase for an exceptional private collection of the earliest Greek art, will open here Monday.

title: Ex-Dean of Stanford and Wife Killed in Automobile Wreck
description: Ernest C. Arbuckle, a business leader and former dean of the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University, and his wife, Katherine, died Friday night in an automobile accident.

title: CONNECTICUT SEEKING TO CUT MEDICARE COSTS
description: Under a new program designed to reduce costs, physicians in Connecticut are required to obtain approval from a central office before admitting many elderly patients to hospitals under the Federal Medicare program.

title: C.I.A. SAYS IT HAS RESTORED LINK TO CAMPUSES TO GET MORE ADVICE
description: Twenty years after the Central Intelligence Agency was all but banished from American campuses, the C.I.A. says it has re-established its ties and is receiving research and advice from a growing number of university professors.

title: DITKA: 'BASIC GUY' MOLDS UNCOMMON TEAM
description: IT was September, early in the 1983 football season, and the people around Mike Ditka, then in his second year as coach of the Chicago Bears, were aware of, what, a certain dissatisfaction?

title: Bogus Contest Lures 55 Aliens Into Custody
description: Immigration officers turned 55 illegal aliens from happy winners into startled losers Saturday after they showed up to collect promised contest prizes and were promptly arrested.

title: CASINO INCOME GROWTH SLOWS
description: Growth in casino revenues here slowed again last year, and analysts predicted that increases in operating expenses would cause profits for the year to plummet.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 1 P.M. Although this is the teams' third meeting of the season, it is the first one in the Spectrum. Moses Malone has dominated the previous two games in Madison Square Garden, teaching Patrick Ewing about playing without picking up fouls in the first game and scoring 30 points in the second. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M.) Bulls vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Chicago. (Television - WTBS, 3:30 P.M.) Colleges: Syracuse at Louisville (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 3:35 P.M.), Villanova at Georgetown (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.); Brooklyn at Campbell, 7:30 P.M.; Medgar Evers at C.C.N.Y., 8 P.M.; Bloomsburg at C. W. Post, 7:30 P.M.; Holy Cross at Fordham, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); Hofstra at Notre Dame, 7:30 P.M.; York at Hunter, 8 P.M.; Marist at Long Island, 7:30 P.M.; (Television -Cablevision, Channel 25, 9 P.M., tape); New Jersey Tech at William Paterson, 7:30 P.M.; Gannon at Queens, 7:30 P.M.; Stevens Tech at New York Polytechnic Institute (Brooklyn), 7:30 P.M.; Trenton State at Rutgers-Newark, 7:30 P.M.; Dominican at Wagner, 7:30 P.M.; Baruch at Dowling, 7:30 P.M. Women: Old Dominion at Texas. (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Hartford Whalers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Whalers have not been beaten by the Rangers in two seasons. They were 1-0-2 against the Rangers last season and routed the Rangers, 8-2, in their only meeting this season at Hartford.

title: PASSENGERS IN WEST SUFFER MINOR INJURIES IN TRAIN DERAILMENT
description: An Amtrak train with 190 Seattle-bound passengers derailed south of Tacoma today when a roadbed weakened by heavy rains gave way.

title: JACKSON FACES LIFE AFTER 40
description: THE idea of Reggie Jackson - showdowns with fastball pitchers, home runs hit far into the night, bat dropping to the dirt because he knows it's gone - still conjures one of the most powerful images American sports has to offer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's done. It does my heart good to see the complete word of God in Navajo hands at last.''

title: A Continent Aroused Against Drugs
description: In Bolivia, cocaine growers put a U.S.-trained police force under siege. In Peru, a new reformist president urgently asks for weapons to fight against narcotics peddlers. In Mexico, 17 narcotics officers are murdered in the line of duty. In Colombia, the mayor of Bogota is forced to resign when linked to a suitcase full of drug money.

title: LABORER IS APPARENT WINNER OF $30 MILLION LOTTERY PRIZE
description: A 59-year-old Staten Island construction worker was identified as the apparent winner of a $30 million New York State Lotto jackpot, lottery officials said last night.

title: 'AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE' OFFERS 'DANIEL ROCKET'
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S ''American Playhouse'' returns for a fifth season tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET/ Channel 13, with precisely the kind of offering that has made this showcase so striking and indispensable. ''The Rise and Rise of Daniel Rocket,'' written by Peter Parnell, was first produced as a stage play Off Broadway in 1982, at Playwrights Horizons. Although it officially opened and closed on the same night, after several weeks of previews, the production was seen by Lindsay Law, executive producer of ''American Playhouse,'' who was impressed enough to get in touch with the playwright about a possible television version. The collaboration proves rewarding for all concerned.

title: APPROVAL OF CHANNEL PLAN LIKELY
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain appear set to give immediate approval to plans for linking Britain and France by a tunnel under the English Channel when they meet Monday in the northern French city of Lille, officials said today.

title: KILLINGS PROMPT TEXAS PRISONS TO HALT INMATES' MAIL
description: In one week last November, inmates in Texas prisons received 9,000 pieces of mail from other inmates in the huge prison system, and not all those letters were friendly greetings from old pals. Some contained coded assassination orders from leaders of inmate gangs, prison officials say.

title: GIANT DAM IN CHINA SEEN AS A DREAM OR NIGHTMARE
description: After decades of debate, China is nearing a decision on whether to block one of the world's mightiest rivers, the Yangtze, with a great wall of concrete.

title: Blast at Plant Hurts Worker
description: An explosion at a turkey-processing plant released a cloud of a toxic, highly irritating gas today that burned one worker and prompted the temporary evacuation of more than 500 people, said the Mayor, Dale Helmerich.

title: TOUGH DECISIONS AWAIT 99TH CONGRESS ON RETURN
description: The second session of the 99th Congress begins Tuesday, and lawmakers expect the year to be dominated by one overwhelming issue, the struggle to control a budget deficit that has now soared beyond $200 billion a year.

title: OPERA: 'CHINCHILLA,' BY MYRON FINK
description: The two most powerful ruptures between opera and its historic public, both suffered early in this century, were the encroachment of dissonance beyond the point of recognizable tonality, and the schism in musical language between the world of art and the world of popular entertainment. So in a sense there is a powerful logic behind the idea of writing an opera as though neither of those things had happened. That is what Myron Fink has done in ''Chinchilla,'' which was given its premiere here Saturday by the Tri-Cities Opera. The music is all fox trots, beguines, tangos, soft-shoes and spiffy two-steps.

title: DEADLINE FOR PACT MISSED EASTERN
description: The midnight Sunday deadline for negotiations between Eastern Air Lines and its flight attendants union passed with no settlement, but a Federal mediator said he has been assured the union will not strike until March.

title: How to Get Ready for the Superchip Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Appoints a Dean
description: Princeton University has appointed a new dean of its School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. The dean, Dr. Hisashi Kobayashi, is the founding director of the Japan Science Institute, a research arm of the International Business Machines Corporation in Tokyo. Dr. Kobayashi will succeed Robert G. Jahn, who is retiring this summer after 15 years as dean. Dr. Kobayashi received his Ph.D. in computer science from Princeton in 1967.

title: Dollar Rises Sharply in Asia
description: The dollar rose sharply in Asia today, as key industrial nations agreed to continue to hold down the currency's value but failed to announce steps to lower interest rates.

title: Catching Up
description: * It's been a little tiring, but Buddy Biancalana is grateful for it. Biancalana, the unheralded shortstop whose performance both at bat and in the field was a factor in Kansas City's World Series victory over St. Louis last October, says his life has been changed ''tremendously'' by the resulting attention, which has brought him numerous television appearances and speaking engagements.

title: LOAN SALES MARKET SWELLING
description: Last October, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company lent $180 million to a major oil company. But rather than holding the loan to maturity, as banks have always done, Manufacturers Hanover within weeks turned around and sold half of it to other financial institutions around the world.

title: CATHOLICS OPEN STATE DRIVE AGAINST MEDICAID ABORTION
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of all eight dioceses in New York State asked their congregations yesterday to take and sign postcards urging Governor Cuomo to end Medicaid financing of abortions.

title: PISTONS TOP LAKERS
description: Kelly Tripucka sank a 3-point field goal with two seconds left to give the Detroit Pistons a 118-115 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers today.

title: 'The Two Oregons'
description: Not long before Election Day next November, a new light rail line will begin operation at street level through this beautiful city's busy downtown section - one of the liveliest in a nation strung out on suburban shopping centers.

title: Alabama Plane Crash Kills 4
description: A twin-engine plane plunged into a wooded, mountainous section of northern Alabama Saturday, killing all four people aboard. ''It appears the plane struck a tree and went straight down,'' said Charlie Forman, the St. Clair County Coroner.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WITH THE CONTRAS: A Reporter in the Wilds of Nicaragua. By Christopher Dickey. 327 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. THE actual narrative of Christopher Dickey's ''With the Contras,'' a vivid if horrifying report on recent events in Central America, begins in San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua, on July 19, 1979.
