The civil war is over, the government of dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle has collapsed, Somoza has left, the officers of his Guardia Nacional, or National Guard, have fled. But the rank and file remain, and the townspeople of San Juan del Sur, trapped between the Pacific Ocean and the guardsmen fleeing from the victorious rebel army, are bracing themselves.

title: GTE and Telecom Pick Leaders for New Sprint
description: Last Friday, the day after their companies, United Telecommunications Inc. and the GTE Corporation, announced that they had agreed to the largest merger yet in the long-distance telephone industry, Charles M. Skibo, Donald G. Prigmore and J. David Hann were all on the move.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Exploration Cruise Lines, owned by the Busch Entertainment Corporation, to Needham Harper Worldwide, Chicago.

title: NBC'S GAME PLAN IS MOST EXTENSIVE
description: BOB COSTAS calls it ''a game, not a religious event.''

title: Market Place; Bank Officer's Stock Choices
description: WHILE most Wall Street professionals envisage loftier prices for stocks in 1986, they tend to be divided about market timing. Some see equities hitting their highs in the first half; others see prices moving to record levels toward the latter part of the year.

title: HAND GRENADE EXPLODES NEAR AQUINO RALLY AREA
description: A hand grenade and what was believed to be a large firecracker disrupted a rally today by the opposition presidential candidate, Corazon C. Aquino. The police reported there were no serious injuries.

title: HIS NAME IS JIM MCMAHON, HE'S THE LEADER OF THE BAND
description: JIM McMAHON has been observed walking on grass. Jim McMahon has been observed walking on carpets.

title: A Waitress Saves the Day For a Frazzled Architect
description: Riding the F train recently, a young Manhattan architect traveled from a subway nightmare to Burger Heaven.

title: DANCE: LES BALLETS JAZZ DE MONTREAL IN BROOKLYN
description: LES Ballets Jazz de Montreal specializes in a choreographic hybrid. Its dancers are balletically trained. Yet the company's choreographers put classical technique to various contemporary uses and use music possessing at least some sort of connection with the jazz tradition.

title:
IN MEMORY OF DR. KING;
What He Meant To Jews
description: The telegram that came to the 1964 convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis in Atlantic City from Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was terse.

title: Advertising; Claim for Acne Product Rejected by Ad Group
description: After considerable study, the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus concluded in December that the research that Sterling Drug's Glenbrook Laboratories used to back its competitive advertising claim for Stri-Dex acne treatment product was insufficient and recommended that the claim be withdrawn.

title: PRIME-TIME TV SERIALS LOSE EDGE
description: To the executives who assembled ABC's current program schedule with the hope that the network's ratings slide could be stemmed, ''The Colbys'' must have seemed irresistible.

title: Washington Watch; Poland and the I.M.F.
description: Poland's five-year-old membership application is slowly moving forward within the International Monetary Fund, following the Reagan Administration's decision a year ago to lift its veto.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 20, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: Washington Watch; Conrail Fight in Senate
description: When the Senate returns to work this week, its first item of business will be the Administration's proposal to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $1.2 billion.

title: Supreme Soviet Turns To Congress on Arms
description: The Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, urged the United States Congress today to accept the new Kremlin disarmament plan as ''the only reasonable and feasible alternative to nuclear weapons'' and renewed a plea that the United States support a halt to nuclear tests.

title: School Destroyed by a Fire on L.I.
description: An elementary school building was destroyed by fire this morning, leaving about 330 pupils without classrooms, fire officials said.

title: 2 'WILD CARDS' PUZZLE TRADERS
description: Credit market participants are now confronted by two developments that make the traditional tools of interest rate forecasters seem puny and insufficient. These developments are the weekend meeting of the finance ministers and central bankers of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan and the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing legislation.

title: LENDL WINS MASTERS IN THREE SETS
description: His shoulders drooped and his strawberry blond hair was damp with perspiration, matted across his forehead as if he had been caught in the rain. Boris Becker's right knee was bleeding and his spirit was apparently broken as he waited dejectedly for the match to run its course. On a day when the rising star of tennis hoped to show Ivan Lendl that his hold on the No. 1 ranking was tenuous at best, he was given a spanking that put him in his proper place, still a considerable distance behind Lendl.

title: HONORING OLD CITIES, GREAT MEN
description: For generations Youngstown, Ohio, was synonymous with steel. Today many of the blast furnaces and finishing mills are closed and 30,000 of the area's residents are unemployed.

title: SAVING A DISSENTER FROM HIS LEGEND
description: A flock of pre-schoolers was brought to one of the many events held here last week to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As they waited, a little hungry and a little squirmy, they were asked by a visitor what they knew about the civil rights leader who died 14 years before most of them were born.

title: GARBAGE-TO-ENERGY PROPOSAL ASSAILED IN ROCKLAND COUNTY
description: A proposal by a New Hampshire company to build a $200 million plant to turn much of Rockland County's garbage into electricity has generated intense opposition from residents in this Hudson River village.

title: A YOUNG MAN MATURES IN 'PRINCE OF BEL AIR'
description: TO us careworn Easterners, Southern Californians seem to lead spur-of-the-moment lotus-eater's lives, tanned existences thriving on whim, on sun and surf. ''Prince of Bel Air,'' the ''ABC Monday Night Movie'' at 9 o'clock, is about this and about the qualms that a young fellow who has been quite happy cleaning pools and chasing women experiences when a beautiful but oh-so-serious artist crosses his path.

title: Jets Win on Crowder's Goal
description: Keith Crowder scored his 19th goal of the season at 1 minute 31 seconds of the third period to give the Boston Bruins a 2-1 victory over the Winnipeg Jets on tonight.

title: 3 on Moscow's Exit List Fly To Frankfurt en Route to U.S.
description: A Massachusetts woman was reunited with her Soviet husband today after three years of separation, while two other Russians prepared to join their American wives in the United States.

title: Fannie Mae Easing Rules
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest investor in residential mortgages, said it would ease some of the underwriting guidelines that it imposed on lenders last summer in an attempt then to reduce rising foreclosures.

title: BANKING CHALLENGE IN CONGRESS
description: When Congress reconvenes Tuesday, it will confront a broad range of banking issues left unresolved last year. Among them are limiting the time it takes to clear checks and revamping the way bank deposits are insured.

title: THREE GREAT QUARTERBACKS CALL THEIR GAMES
description: JOE Namath, Roger Staubach and Terry Bradshaw played on teams that went to 10 Super Bowl games among them, Namath with the New York Jets, Staubach with the Dallas Cowboys and Bradshaw with the Pittsburgh Steelers. Recently, by telephone conference call, they discussed with Dave Anderson of The New York Times's sports staff their experiences in pro football's biggest game. Here are excerpts of their conversation:

title: ...BUT MONTAGNARDS STILL WAIT IN A THAI CAMP
description: Y-Tlur Eban remembers them all. ''Captain Daniel, Major Findlay, Captain Wood, Captain Penney, Lieutenant Parker,'' he muses, looking into the distance as he searches his mind for more names. More than 20 years ago, they were his Green Beret officers and he was one of ''our Yards.''

title: Prison Escapee Named In Another Attack
description: A prison escapee already accused of three kidnappings since fleeing a New Orleans hospital beat an elderly couple today and tried to abduct a woman, the police said.

title: DAVIS HERRON
description: Davis Herron, an artist and teacher, died Friday at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston after a series of strokes.

title: BERRY: SUCCESS COMES QUICKLY, BUT JOYRIDE IS A BIT FAST
description: AS if the New England Patriots did not have enough to keep their bodies occupied during those halcyon days of training camp last summer, the fertile mind of Raymond Berry produced something else. Two players would face each other on opposite sides of a pile of eight dummies. Between the players, underneath the dummies, a football rested on the ground. The players, who had already been schooled in the art of falling down, would fight for the ball.

title: LAKERS AND CELTICS ON MARK TOWARD ANOTHER TITLE SERIES
description: Jeff Ruland made a suggestion the other night. The Washington Bullets' center, who has been waiting for a broken bone in his right foot to mend, said with a smile: ''How about an all-broken-foot team? It could be a pretty good team.''

title: HAMMOND WINS IN SUDDEN DEATH
description: Donnie Hammond, a 28-year-old Floridian in his fourth year on the putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat John Cook and win the 27th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic at Bermuda Dunes.

title: Bridge: In Spite of Logic and Talent, Disappointment Can Intrude
description: If bridge were a game of justice, any player who reached a logical contract and then handled the cards skillfully to succeed could expect to gain points or at worst break even. There is a tendency toward justice but, as in real life, disappointments must be expected occasionally.

title: Non-Communists Join Afghan Government
description: Dozens of people from outside the Afghan Communist Party, including at least one religious leader, have been allowed to join the Afghan Government in an attempt to broaden its popular support, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: H&C SEEN IN BID FOR TEXAS STATION
description: H & C Communications Inc. is negotiating to buy KSAT-TV, an ABC affiliate in San Antonio, for about $150 million, according to sources familiar with the negotiations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cetus Corp., Emeryville, Calif., a biotechnology company, has named Robert A. Fildes chief executive officer, succeeding Ronald E. Cape, who continues as chairman.

title: AVIATION LEADERS EYE FUND AS CUSHION FOR F.A.A. CUTS
description: To provide a cushion against the impending budget squeeze at the Federal Aviation Administration, the airline industry and some members of Congress are pressing a campaign to facilitate the use of a multibillion-dollar surplus in a trust fund for aviation.

title: REBEL FIGHTERS DECLARE VICTORY IN SOUTH YEMEN
description: Forces loyal to the former President of Southern Yemen, a hard-line Marxist, claimed victory today in a six-day battle for control of the impoverished nation, the Soviet Union's strategic toehold in the Middle East.

title: ESSENTIAL, THEY SAY, BUT 'REPUGNANT'
description: Anyone who has ever attended a convention of real estate agents or funeral directors would have detected a familiar undertone, the camaraderie of the misunderstood, at Fort McNair here last week. As Gen. Paul F. Gorman told his assembled colleagues, the business they were gathered to discuss was ''inherently repugnant to most Americans.''

title: Muldowney Loses In Racing Return
description: Bill Mullins edged Larry Minor in the final race to win the Top Fuel division in the Super Bowl of Drag Racing here today at Firebird International Raceway.

title: FOUNDATION IS STARTED TO AID STUDY OF AGING
description: A foundation to promote research and education about aging and to ''change attitudes about older people'' is being established by an Arizona entrepreneur.

title: CORRECTION
description: An arrow in the Business Digest on Saturday misstated the drop in the price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The drop was 58 cents a barrel, to $23.53.

title: Advertising; High Cost Of Making TV Spots
description: ONE of the most frequent complaints agencies get from their clients, according to Jean-Claude Kaufmann of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, concerns the escalating cost of television commercial production.

title: Intruder Leaves Photo In Yoko Ono's Home
description: A man broke into Yoko Ono's home in the Dakota apartment building on the West Side of Manhattan early yesterday morning, and left his photograph, name and address, before fleeing by the fire escape, a police spokesman said.

title: IF HE WERE ALIVE
description: All Americans past a certain age can still hear his voice in the nautilus of their minds.

title: SUPER ALL-STARS
description: AS the Super Bowl moves into its twenties from its teens, the rites of passage demand an all-time Super Bowl team.

title: How to Get Ready for the Superchip Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Cetus Planning Stock Offering
description: The Cetus Corporation, a leading biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said Friday that it intends to file a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offering of 3 million common shares.

title: The Background; A Success at La Scala in 1843
description: Verdi's fourth opera, ''I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata,'' tells of the rivalry of two Lombard brothers, Arvino and Pagano, for the hand of Viclinda at the time of the First Crusade near the end of the 11th century. First produced at La Scala in Milan in 1843, the work scored an opening-night success.

title: GROUP OF 5 HINTS AT EFFORT TO CUT INTEREST CHARGES
description: Top economic officials of five leading industrial countries agreed today that the time looked ripe for their interest rates to fall. They indicated that they might try to push them down a bit.

title: Cummings Wins Race in Houston
description: Paul Cummings of Ogden, Utah, broke away from David Edge of Canada in the final mile today to win the Houston-Tenneco Marathon by eight seconds.

title: IN MANILA PRESS, IT'S 'CORAZON WHO?'
description: Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition presidential candidate, has been mentioned by the main Philippine television channel exactly three times in the last 10 days, according to one of her lawyers.

title: CONCERT: THE Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: CAMILLE SAINT-SAENS'S Symphony No. 2 is a polished example of neo-Classicism, circa 1859: dry, bright, expert and orchestrated with such lucid transparency that it is still used as a model in conservatory classrooms. Every note sounds, and if the results don't add up to anything profound, this symphony - actually Saint-Saens's fourth (two earlier works were not published during the composer's lifetime) - remains a pleasant diversion, as was proven by the Y Chamber Symphony on Saturday night at the 92d Street Y, under the direction of Raymond Leppard.

title: THE REGION;
description: New York has awarded $2.7 million in grants to finance 15 AIDS research projects.

title: Kaiser Suing Frates Group
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had filed suit in a Federal District Court in northern California against an investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla.

title: MORE BANK AMERICA PROBLEMS SEEN
description: Wall Street is bracing for another report of many nonperforming loans from the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: ON THE FIELD, HERE'S HOW THE TWO TEAM MATCH UP
description: THE CHICAGO BEARS Defense Richard Dent/95 Right End, 6-5, 263, 25, 3d year, Tennessee State. Pro Bowl starter. Led league with 17 1/2 sacks in 1984 and 17 in 1985. Outstanding pass rusher, not strong when play is run at him. Wilber Marshall/58

title: NAVAJOS WELCOME A NATIVE AMERICAN BIBLE
description: The books were bound in black and had a familiar biblical heft, but the words embossed on the covers were new.

title: Advertising; Amex to Siegel & Gale
description: The American Stock Exchange has assigned its $2 million advertising account to Siegel & Gale, a Saatchi & Saatchi-owned corporate advertising specialty firm. The former agency was Leber Katz Partners.

title: ATLANTA, MECCA FOR MIDDLE-CLASS BLACKS, ALSO HARBORS POVERTY
description: Last week, as this city and the nation began celebrations in honor of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Charles Johnson, a black lawyer, arrived for lunch at the Atlanta City Club.

title: Leafleting in Malls Is Up To the States
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Swissair Cites Its Wide Scope
description: The local marketers of Swissair and their ad agency, Doyle Graf Mabley, with the help of consumer research, have concluded that the airline's growth is being retarded by the popular belief that it flies only to Switzerland.

title: OPERA: 'I LOMBARDI' BY VERDI, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT is a bitter irony that just at the moment when all of Verdi's operas, early and late, have acquired an audience, the reservoir of Verdi singers has fallen to drought levels. So it is that a young soprano such as Aprile Millo, who sang in a concert version of ''I Lombardi'' last night at Carnegie Hall, commands unusually close attention and hopeful scrutiny. Miss Millo, who was born in New York and reared in California, made the ears of Verdi fanciers perk up at her Metropolitan Opera debut last season in ''Simon Boccanegra.'' It is pleasant to report, based on this ''Lombardi'' performance with Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York, that the promise is being fulfilled.

title: Greece's Aid on Libya Urged
description: The United States Deputy Secretary of State, John C. Whitehead, met Foreign Minister Karolos Papoulias of Greece today to seek support for Washington's economic sanctions against Libya, an authoritative source said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Sports section yesterday with an article about Billy Sullivan, owner of the New England Patriots, misidentified one of Mr. Sullivan's sons. He is William H. Sullivan III.

title: VOEST-ALPINE PLIGHT AFFECTS ALL AUSTRIA
description: Voest-Alpine, Austria's largest state-owned industrial concern, has been shaken by heavy losses, and the tremors are being felt throughout the country's large nationalized industries.

title: CONCERT: PENDERECKI AND CRACOW ENSEMBLE
description: DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH carried more sad news to 20th-century listeners than perhaps any of his contemporaries, so it was strange to find the Sixth Symphony of this most melancholy composer providing the leavening agent at Saturday night's concert by the Cracow Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall.

title: Uganda Rebels Clash With Troops for 3d Day
description: Fighting between guerrillas and Government troops continued in the suburbs of Kampala for the third day.

title: GUATEMALA CRASH TOLL NOW PUT AT 93
description: Authorities recovered the bodies of all 93 people who died in Guatemala's worst air crash and by tonight had flown most of them back to the capital from the isolated jungle site. Eight Americans were among the dead.

title: FOG DISRUPTS OPERATIONS AT AIRPORTS
description: A thick blanket of fog settled on New York yesterday, disrupting flights at La Guardia Airport and making driving difficult throughout the region.

title: TAR HEELS STRONGER WITH ADDED DEPTH
description: Most of North Carolina's players had yet to shower after defeating Duke in Saturday's battle for the top spot in the polls, and already their coach was scurrying to catch a plane. The 95-92 victory that knocked Duke from the ranks of the unbeaten also marked a successful North Carolina debut in its 21,426-seat arena, the Dean E. Smith Student Activities Center. But for 54-year-old Dean Edwards Smith himself, there was little time to relax.

title: Great Expectations
description: The most furious bidding in the history of horse auctions came to an end one evening two and a half years ago when Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al Maktoum beat his archrival, Robert Sangster, for the privilege of paying $10.2 million for a yearling son of Northern Dancer. The colt, subsequently named Snaafi Dancer, was sent from the Keeneland sales paddocks in Lexington, Ky., to England, where he was trained by John Dunlop. The other day Dunlop announced that Snaafi Dancer, now a 4-year-old, had been retired to stud. He had not been to the races even once.

title: 'Hearing No Objection . . .'
description: The phrase ''unanimous consent'' is a familiar and magic password in Congress.

title: Washington Watch; Petrofina's Taxes
description: American Petrofina, a subsidiary of the Belgium-based oil multinational company, Petrofina S.A., has gone to the United States Tax Court to challenge an Internal Revenue Service demand for more than $100 million.

title: Fix the School Budget, and the Board
description: Mayor Koch plans no spending increases for New York City services. Yet Chancellor Nathan Quinones has prepared a budget that would require adding half a billion dollars in spending for the public schools. Where will that kind of money come from? And if it doesn't materialize, what should be cut accordingly?

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 'GROUND SYMPHONY'
description: THE New York City Ballet's revival last year of George Balanchine's ''lost'' ''Gounod Symphony'' seemed one of the greatest gifts of many a season. And the reappearance of the ballet in a performance by the company Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater confirmed that first impression. In this vibrant staging by Vita Brown Olinick, ''Gounod Symphony'' lays claim to being a Balanchine masterwork, in its sweet and deceptively understated way.

title: Washington Watch; Semiconductor Ruling Is Near
description: AN imminent International Trade Commission decision may put more pressure on Japan to resolve differences with the United States on hotly contested trade in semiconductors.

title: Advertising; Good Food Magazine At Checkout Counter
description: Good Food magazine, the latest contribution to the checkout counters of the nation by Triangle Communications, goes on sale in 40,000 supermarkets today right next to TV Guide, its sister publication.

title: Holiday Closings Today
description: Government offices and banks will be closed today in observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, but most businesses will be open. The nation's stock and commodity markets will also be open. The weekly Treasury bill auction will be Tuesday instead of today.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS TRY TO CLOSE RANKS
description: Leaders of Lebanon's Christians, faced with the prospect of another armed confrontation with the Moslems, have been engaged in intensive consultations to close their ranks.

title: Coleman Working To Cut Strikeouts
description: Vince Coleman, the St. Louis Cardinals' left fielder, has recovered from the cracked leg bone he he suffered when he was run over by an automatic tarpaulin roller during the National League championship series last fall.

title: Frommelt Wins World Cup Slalom
description: Paul Frommelt of Liechtenstein won his first World Cup slalom ski race in five years today. Frommelt, in beating Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark, was fastest in the first heat with 52.18 seconds and placed second in the second heat in 49.95 for a total of 1 minute 42.13 seconds.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Now that the Chicago Bears and New England Patriots have made it for the first time in the 20 years of the event, which are the remaining teams, besides the Giants, who have never played in a Super Bowl?

title: No Concern Over Gooden
description: Dwight Gooden did not appear in New York last night to accept the Cy Young Award at the baseball writers' dinner. But the Mets said they were satisfied that his sprained right ankle was healing and that his absence had been prompted only by the death of his grandmother and her funeral on Saturday.

title: U.S. DEAD IN JET CRASH
description: Following is a preliminary list of the Americans killed Saturday in a jet crash in Guatemala, as provided today by the airline and the State Department in Washington: CHINZE, Walter Peter CONSOLVO, Paul, Virginia Beach, Va. GONZALEZ, Ruth PUFFETT, John, Department of Agriculture employee RODRIGUEZ, Teresa SAGE, Jeffrey, Long Island SWEENEY, Patricia, Cincinnati SWEENEY, Robert Todd, Cincinnati

title: Synagogues to Honor Memory of Dr. King
description: At least two New York synagogues will honor the memory and accomplishments of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. during services this week.

title: BATTALION REBUILDS AFTER CRASH LOSS
description: The infantry battalion of the 101st Airborne Division that lost nearly a third of its soldiers in an airplane crash in Newfoundland has begun to rebuild.

title: SLOW SALES PORTEND A SHIFT BY RETAILERS
description: Many of the nation's retailers, facing only modest growth in the first half and a drying up of available suburban sites for long-term expansion, are turning their attention inward. Their goal is to wrest greater results from their existing stores. But to do this some stores are expected to undergo drastic changes.

title: TUTU'S DAUGHTER TAKES ANACTIVIST'S ROLE
description: Going home has always been difficult for Naomi Tutu-Seavers.

title: AT PEN, A FEELING OF COMMUNITY
description: RUNNING through the lately concluded 48th International PEN Congress was a craving for what more than one participant called a ''community of writers.'' It could be discerned in the meeting's theme, ''The Writer's Imagination and the Imagination of the State,'' and in the panels, where writers presented themselves as adversaries of official power. It was there, too, in the protests that attracted so much attention and in the concern for writers in the jails of their homelands. That is not to attribute all that happened to group psychology; every day had its portion of intelligent discussion of interesting ideas. Nonetheless, the aspiration to community was very much in the air.

title: Constitutional Split: Texaco's Expert . . .
description: He has been retained as an adviser to Texaco Inc. because of his expertise in constitutional law, but Charles Alan Wright does not think he will be spending much time on the bitter legal struggle with the Pennzoil Company.

title: GOVERNORS IN THE REGION VOICE COMMON THEMES
description: In the annual rituals of convening their legislatures, the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are sounding common themes this year and proposing strikingly similar solutions to parallel problems.

title: How Reagan Decides
description: In arriving at decisions on the issues that face him daily in the White House, President Reagan uses a dual system: he reads staff memoranda on various options involved in the question before him but also listens to pitched debates between the proponents and opponents directly involved. This insight comes from Roger B. Porter, a Harvard professor who until last fall was deputy assistant to the President and director of the Office of Policy Development in the White House.

title: Truman the Art Critic
description: During and after his Presidency, Harry S. Truman became famous for outspoken and pungent observations on a range of subjects, with his targets ranging from Gen. Douglas MacArthur to music critics. Now some vigorous and unequivocal comments by Truman on the subject of art have come to light at the National Archives, in a collection of State Department documents recently removed from a confidential category by the historians.

title: It's Time to Stop Executing Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN AND SOVIET TO RESUME LONG-DORMANT TREATY TALKS
description: The Soviet Union and Japan agreed today to resume long-suspended negotiations on a peace treaty that because of a lingering territorial dispute has eluded them since the end of World War II.

title: CUTS IN HOUSING AID OPPOSED
description: Several leaders of the nation's home construction and financing industries said this weekend that they would strongly oppose a range of cutbacks in housing-related programs that the Reagan Administration is expected to propose for the 1987 Federal budget.

title: OKLAHOMA TOXIC LEAK: FEW STEPS TO REDUCE RISK
description: Investigators and experts say it is becoming clear that the fatal accident at an Oklahoma uranium-processing plant Jan. 4 could have been avoided had procedures and equipment been used that have been available elsewhere for years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 20, 1986
description: International

title: N. Carolina Wins In Last 3 Seconds
description: Kenny Smith made two free throws with three seconds remaining today to give undefeated North Carolina a 66-64 victory over Marquette, which lost a 9-point lead in the final four minutes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: CONGRESS TEAM SAYS LAOS REJECTS U.S. SEARCH FOR THE MISSING
description: A United States Congressional delegation said today that Laotian officials had rejected an appeal to allow Americans to enter Laos to help investigate possible sightings of American soldiers.

title: FANS' MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: GET your stopwatches out. It's time to see if the American public is equal to the challenge laid down by the National Broadcasting Company for next Sunday: How to get the most out of an inflated minute of free time.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WESTERN FRONT Manhattan's Upper West Side grew up in the early 1900's and has, architecturally, remained for the most part as it was during the 1920's. It is a cosmopolitan sector, a mix of well-to-do and working class, of beautiful and graceful but not flashy apartments and hotels, of brownstones and tenement apartments. And it is the subject of ''The Best of the West,'' an exhibition of the Municipal Art Society in the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street (935-3960).

title: PIONEERING DOCTORS: WOMEN OF THE PAST
description: The sign above the trellised arch reads, ''Send Us a Lady Physician,'' and beyond it photographs and drawings of 20 women, the members of the class of 1879 at the Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania, hang in a gazebo. Overhead, the recorded voice of Dr. Clara Marshall, their professor, addresses them at commencement. She urges them to ''seek and take advantage of opportunities - despise no opening wedge, however small.''

title: 5 Die in Yugoslav Avalanche
description: Five family members were killed and four people were injured today by an avalanche in the southern province of Kosovo, the national news agency Tanyug reported. All the victims lived in a village near the town of Urosevac, about 160 miles south of Belgrade, the report said.

title: BEARS LOOK TRULY SUPER
description: The following scouting reports were compiled by Dick Verneil, the former head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles. He was assisted by Williaim N. Wallace of The New York Times.

title: LEARNING TO TRUST INTUITION
description: YOU are interviewing a prospective employee, and although you know he is the most qualified candidate, your intuition tells you he's the wrong man for the job. What should you do?

title: MILITARY COUP REPORTED IN LESOTHO AFTER CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan of Lesotho, facing a South African blockade, was reported today to have been overthrown by his army commander after a five-day political crisis.

title: . . . vs. Pennzoil's
description: Laurence H. Tribe does not care about the billions of dollars Pennzoil stands to win in its legal battle with Texaco. For Mr. Tribe, it is the principle that counts.

title: Undersea Volcano Erupts
description: Smoke rising to about 13,200 feet was sighted this afternoon off Iwo Jima in the Pacific Ocean, apparently the result of an undersea volcanic eruption, the Japanese Navy reported. The site was believed to be the Futokuokanoba undersea volcano, about 31 miles southwest of Iwo Jima, which is 840 miles south of Tokyo.

title: WHEN ACTION STARTS, A NATION STOPS
description: IT has grown so much in its first two decades that the nation has virtually shut down by the kickoff. Business leaders complain that sales practically stop. Law enforcement officials rejoice because crime does, too. Traffic subsides. Long-distance telephone lines open. In millions of households, from ocean to ocean, border to border, it's party time, as it will be again Sunday in New Orleans, where the Chicago Bears and the New England Patriots will play for the National Football League championship in Super Bowl XX.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MACAO AIM IS DIVERSITY IN INDUSTRY
description: The Hotel Oriental, complete with casino, is the first sight greeting visitors when they step off the boat in Macao. Tourists seldom venture farther than the casinos or the nearby pawnshops that provide a quick infusion of cash for those down on their luck.

title: Get Serious About Truck Safety
description: There continue to be plenty of reasons to welcome the economic deregulation of the trucking industry, approved by Congress in 1980. But as competition intensified, some truckers began to cut corners on safety. Then Congress gave bigger trucks access to all interstates, making better safety regulation an urgent matter.

title: EX-HARLEM RECTOR FINDS RETIREMENT A SPRINGBOARD
description: For Dr. M. Moran Weston, the 75-year-old former rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Harlem, retirements have become commonplace. Yet the more posts Dr. Weston leaves, the more organizations he seems to head and the more projects he plans.

title: DEVILS' PENALTIES HELP SABRES
description: Scoring on the power play had been a weak part of Buffalo's game, until the Sabres came to Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight for the first time this season.

title: OUTDOORS: HUNGTING QUAIL IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: WEARING borrowed trousers, boots and jacket and toting a borrowed gun, I ventured forth for an afternoon of shooting at the Hickory Creek Quail Club.

title: EL SALVADOR IS FERTILE GROUND FOR PROTESTANT SECTS
description: Only a decade ago revivalist preachers were viewed with hostility in deeply Roman Catholic El Salvador, at times even treated as alien sorcerers - stoned, tied up in village squares and run out of town.

title: AMERICANS WED TO LIBYANS FACE AGONIZING CHOICE
description: Rebecca is leaving Libya, probably for good. Nadine is also leaving, but only for a week of shopping in London. Mary, the mother of two young daughters, is staying because she does not want to leave her children, even for a short time.

title: U.S. PLANS TO MAKE DEFECTORS SECURE
description: The Reagan Administration is actively considering plans to provide guaranteed lifetime incomes to high-ranking defectors and may attempt to reduce the waiting time required for conferral of American citizenship, a senior White House official said today.

title: A MEMBER OF THE CLASS OF '83 GROWS UP
description: Early in the second quarter, early enough that the word ''jinx'' was still used to describe the adventures of the New England Patriots in the Orange Bowl in Miami, the Dolphins had taken the lead in the American Conference championship game and it was time for the Patriots to respond.

title: PROGRAM AIMS TO RESCUE EVERGLADES FROM 100 YEARS OF THE HAND OF MAN
description: Work has begun on an ambitious effort to undo what officials call the nearly lethal damage that has been inflicted on the Everglades by a century of development and exploitation.

title: Advertising; Donald Miller Going To a Media Buyer
description: Anyone who has observed Donald B. Miller, usually the tallest man at any American Association of Advertising Agencies annual meeting, in action would certainly make the educated guess that he could not wait for retirement so that he could get out to the links full time.

title: Progress on New York Rent-Regulation Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Rights And Wrongs
description: Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, has been proclaiming the Reagan Administration's ''success in promoting human rights and democracy in Central America.'' His talk is evidently a prelude to a new hard sell in Congress for Administration policy.

title: CONCERN OVER HOMELESS STIRS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: The cold weather of January and the thought of homeless families in need of warm shelter are cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: HOW RESTRUCTURINGS CAN HELP
description: Now that the Union Carbide Corporation has escaped the clutches of Samuel J. Heyman and the GAF Corporation, the tough work begins.

title: Advertising; Media News Group Picks Plapler Russo
description: Plapler Russo Wilvers & Associates has been named agency for the Media News Group of Woodbury, N.J., owner of 15 daily and four weekly newspapers.

title: DANCE EVENTS FACE U.S. CUTS
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts has said its Dance Program's budget would drop immediately because of Federal budget cuts and probably would decrease further next year.

title: New Texaco Talks Possible
description: Representatives of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company might meet this week in an attempt to resume their stalled settlement talks, a source close to the companies said yesterday.

title: PRIME MINISTERS OF ISRAEL AND SPAIN HAIL NEW LINKS
description: The Prime Ministers of Spain and Israel today hailed the establishment of diplomatic relations between their countries as a historic step that could contribute to peace in the Middle East.

title: HOLIDAY DELAYING U.S. BILL AUCTION
description: The Government securities market will be closed today in observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. The regular Monday sale of Treasury bills will be delayed until tomorrow.

title: Talbott Captures Final in Squash
description: Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., took only 25 minutes to defeat Michael Desaulniers of New York today, 15-9, 15-12, 15-10 and win the 44th Apawamis Invitational Squash Tournament.

title: PRINCIPAL TRIES TO BOLSTER IMAGE OF SCHOOL BEARING KING'S NAME
description: On the walls of his office at Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan, Frank N. Mickens has framed poems written about him by students when he arrived as principal at the start of the school year in September, including one set of verses that begins:

title: Officers' Dispute Leads to Shooting
description: An officer of the Passaic County park police remained in the hospital today, a day after he was shot in the leg and arm by another officer in a traffic dispute, the police said.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The White House has nominated a member of the International Trade Commission, David B. Rohr, for a full nine-year term at the agency.

title: ORGANIZATIONS THAT AIDED IMMIGRANT JEWS RECALLED IN EXHIBIT
description: For the Jewish immigrants who came to America in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, America was a land of heartache as well as hope.

title: U.N. GIVES 100,000 VIETNAMESE A SAFE EXIT...
description: Vo Thi Hau was reunited with her husband in Amsterdam recently, shortly after becoming the 100,000th person to safely and legally leave Vietnam under one of the most successful programs ever run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Indonesia Loan Plea
description: Indonesia will need more soft loans from industrial nations because of falling world oil prices, Foreign Minister Mochtar Kusumaatmadja said today.

title: SYRIA CALLS ITS PLAN STILL THE ONLY WAY
description: Syrian officials said today that despite the apparent collapse of the Syrian-brokered peace plan for Lebanon, it remained the only viable solution for ending 11 years of civil war in that country.

title: Man Who Fired At Trooper Sought
description: The New York State police said yesterday that they were searching for a man who fired a shotgun at two troopers when they pulled him over for a traffic violation on the New England Thruway.

title: NIGERIAN RULERS ASK SUPPORT FOR 'MILITARY DEMOCRACY'
description: The military Government announced this week that the country would return to civilian rule by Oct. 1, 1990, after an extended national debate over what its political future should look like.

title: In Lieu of a Lieutenant Governor
description: The obscure office of lieutenant governor has suddenly been plunged into an unaccustomed spotlight. New York has been without a lieutenant governor since Alfred DelBello resigned a year ago. The main effect of the prolonged vacancy, no disrespect to Mr. DelBello personally, has been to save the taxpayers about $650,000 in staff salaries and to invite a question: Why not abolish the job?

title: DISCIPLINARY CASES RISE FOR DOCTORS
description: Federally financed medical review agencies have begun disciplinary proceedings against more than 1,100 doctors and hospitals around the nation in the last few months, charging them with providing unnecessary or poor medical treatment.

title: Arbitron and SAMI Venture
description: Selling Areas Marketing Inc. and the Arbitron Ratings Company announced yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture company to create a marketing information network.

title: Iraqis Raid Dutch Ship; Australian Killed
description: An Australian was killed and two others were badly hurt in an Iraqi rocket attack today on a Dutch oil maintenance ship in the Persian Gulf, the ship's owners said.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CUT ROLE IN INSURING PENSION BENEFITS
description: The Reagan Administration is developing proposals to reduce the role of the Federal Government in insuring private pension benefits paid to millions of Americans.

title: Moynihan Milestone
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan came of age in a special, political way when he appeared on the NBC News broadcast ''Meet the Press'' yesterday. He first appeared on the program in 1965, 21 years ago.

title: BLAZE AT BELMONT PARK KILLS 45 THOROUGHBREDS IN STABLE
description: Forty-five thoroughbred horses were killed early this morning when a fire swept through a wooden barn on the grounds of Belmont Park race track.

title: Advertising; Doyle's Australia Tie
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group announced yesterday that its Australian office, billing $23 million, was being merged with Magnus Nankervis & Curl, which becomes Magnus Nankervis & Curl/DDB, billing $60 million and operating in three cities. The locals will own 51 percent.

title: School Drivers to Vote On Ending Boston Strike
description: School bus drivers and the Boston School Committee were scheduled to vote Monday on a tentative contract to end a two-week strike. The dispute has kept about half the district's 27,000 bus-riding students from class.

title: TRADE OFFICIALS TO PUSH COUNTERFEIT GOODS CODE
description: Trade ministers from the United States, Japan, the European Economic Community and Canada agreed during several days of talks here to press for adoption soon of an international code against counterfeit products.

title: Trust Fund for Housing Is Proposed by Dinkins
description: The Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, yesterday called for the creation of a $1 billion municipal trust fund to be used for rehabilitation of vacant city-owned housing for poor and homeless residents of the city.

title: SUBTLE COACHING OF BECKER TESTS RULES
description: There are several ways to win in tennis. Most of them involve playing the game: delicate drop shots, well-placed lobs, unplayable volleys and searing serves. In the seven months since his surprising victory at Wimbledon, however, Boris Becker has been known to employ another tactic: being coached.

title: JACKSON GIVES ST. JOHN'S CRUCIAL OUTSIDE HELP
description: If someone had told Walter Berry immediately after St. John's 61-60 victory Saturday night over Connecticut that he had played a major role, the 6-foot-8-inch forward might have frowned and pointed digustedly at the box score.

title: Medical Helicopter Crashes
description: An emergency medical helicopter crashed in a city park today, killing two people, after it delivered the victim of an accidental shooting to a downtown hospital. The helicopter had left the University of Maryland Hospital about 4 A.M. to return to its home base in Frederick. It was staffed by two state troopers, but it was not immediately known whether they were the two people killed, said Sgt. Bill Tower of the State Police.

title: Gunman Shuts Off Respirator for 2 Hours
description: An armed teen-ager disconnected his comatose brother's life-support system early today and held off doctors for about two hours before surrendering to the police who were planning to storm the hospital.

title: Reporter for The Times Briefly Jailed by Syria
description: A correspondent for The New York Times was detained yesterday and jailed for a brief period by Syrian authorities in Damascus.

title: Hitch Developing In Outlet Buyout
description: A complication may be developing in the proposed leveraged buyout of the Outlet Company subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group Inc. because of proposed changes in the tax laws, according to Wall Street sources. The sources said that the Rockefeller Group and advisers to the investors who want to buy the radio and television subsidiary were working last night to resolve the problem.

title: Super Bowl Notebook; Curfews to Keep Play on Field
description: This is the City That Care Forgot, and coaches who have come here for Super Bowls have worried about the night life and what it might do to players.

title: Bribe Trial of U.S. Judge Opening in Mississippi
description: Jury selection begins Tuesday for the trial of a Federal judge on criminal charges. It is only the third trial of a Federal judge for crimes in office in the history of the Federal bench.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect the acquisition of Texas American Bank-Southwest which was accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRM ZEROS IN ON CAR TRENDS
description: Like to tinker with cars? If so, you are four times more likely to buy a pickup truck than someone who never looks under the hood.

title: Early Aid to Minorities In Medical Study Urged
description: Waiting until minority students are in college to give them special help to get into medical school ''may be too little, too late,'' according to a new study of black and Hispanic young people seeking careers in medicine.

title: Burroughs Reports Net Rose 22% in 4th Quarter
description: The Burroughs Corporation, recovering from a poor earnings performance in the third quarter, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 22 percent, amid what it called ''encouraging signs for 1986.''

title: RYAN, RUST A SUPER SUBPLOT
description: In a familiar Super Bowl subplot, the two defensive coordinators, Buddy Ryan of the Bears and Rod Rust of the Patriots, are being coveted as National Football League head coaches - Ryan by the Philadelphia Eagles and the New Orleans Saints, and Rust by the St. Louis Cardinals. ''It's about time,'' Buddy Ryan says. Indeed it is. For both. The architect of the Bears' notorious 46 defense, Buddy Ryan is 52 years old. With the Bears' success this season, he deserves the opportunity to be a head coach. So does 57-year-old Rod Rust, whose popularity among the Patriots was responsible for Ron Meyer being abruptly dismissed as head coach during the 1984 season and Raymond Berry being hired.

title: Sunspot Cycle Revealed
description: Scientists drilling deep into siltstone and sandstone that was laid down in an Ice Age lakebed in Australia some 680 million years ago have found evidence of an unbroken period of sunspot cycles that lasted 19,000 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1986
description: International

title: Friendly Terms
description: When the Celtics paid a recent visit to Los Angeles, Cedric Maxwell, who had been traded by Boston to the Clippers, was asked whether revenge would be a motive in his game. ''How can you have a revenge motive,'' Maxwell responded, ''when a team is still paying you?''

title: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUMMIT SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AS VOYAGER NEARS URANUS, FLURRY OF DISCOVERIES IS EXPECTED
description: FAR out in the solar system, eight years and three billion miles after its departure from Earth, the Voyager 2 spacecraft is approaching Uranus with cameras and remote sensors ready for the first close-up examination of the seventh planet.

title: INLAND STEEL SAYS LOSS SET RECORD
description: The Inland Steel Company, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, today announced the severest quarterly and yearly loss in its history. Inland reported a loss of $90.5 million in the fourth quarter, widened from a loss of $28.3 million a year earlier. Sales shrank to $716.4 million from $723.4 million.

title: CAPITAL JUBILANT
description: A military coup today ended two decades of increasingly autocratic rule by this tiny nation's Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan. The coup began with unconfirmed reports that an army commander had taken control of the Government.

title: Options Expansion
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it had decided to expand its successful energy futures business by offering options contracts later this year. The exchange said it would offer an option on its crude oil future contract. If approved by regulators, the option is expected to begin trading by the fall.

title: BIG BANKS IN RACE FOR DISTRICT FOOTHOLD
description: A unanimous vote by the District of Columbia's City Council has touched off a race among the country's biggest banks, eager to stretch the geographic boundaries of their operations, to buy up Washington's local banking institutions.

title: Ashford Set to Race
description: She did not run during her pregnancy, and she has not competed since her daughter was born May 30, so the track world will be curious to see how Evelyn Ashford performs when she returns to racing next month. The 1984 Olympic gold medalist at 100 meters and in the 400-meter relay will return to competition in the Vitalis/ United States Olympic Invitational track meet at the Meadowlands Feb. 8, and expects to compete in the the Millrose Games Feb. 14 at Madison Square Garden. ''I was so anxious to get back into shape I began running two weeks after Raina was born,'' said Miss Ashford, who said she gained 50 pounds while pregnant.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLAST CLUES FOUND IN AIR-INDIA JET
description: A team of five Indian scientists was reported today to have concluded that a ''chemical detonation,'' possibly caused by a bomb, ripped through the front cargo hold of an Air-India jetliner last year.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE Brazilians brought their fashion collections to town last week and showed that they do indeed make some of the most provocative (as in see-through) and daring (as in bared skin) sportswear in the world. But American designers are no slouches in the bare skin area either. They're showing lots of midriffs and small bandeaus for summer -along with shorts, shorts and more shorts.

title: MERCHANTS BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share net reflects 2-for-1 stock split in August.

title: How the Homeless Horde Lives
description: For several months not long ago, Ronald Reagan's closest neighbor was Earl Douglas Edwards Jr. Mr. Reagan slept inside the White House; Mr. Edwards slept on the sidewalk out front.

title: LIBERIA REPORTED READY TO INDICT DETAINED BANKER
description: The Liberian Government plans to seek an indictment against a Citibank vice president on charges of treason based on accusations that she was involved in an unsuccessful coup, State Department and Liberian Government officials said yesterday.

title: Metromedia Ad Business Sale
description: Metromedia Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its outdoor advertising business, the nation's largest, for $710 million.

title: Medals Are Awarded For Children's Books
description: Patricia MacLachlan, author of ''Sarah, Plain and Tall,'' the story of a widower who brings a mail-order bride from Maine to his home in the western Plains, was chosen today by the American Library Association as winner of the John Newbery Medal for the year's most outstanding children's book.

title: Market Place; A Brisk Pace Is Set by Nike
description: AMERICA'S broadening interest in running, aerobics and similar leisure activities has rekindled competition among the nation's leading publicly held producers of footwear.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSECT CENSUS FINDS APARTMENTS INFESTED
description: THE average low-income apartment in the Southeastern United States is infested with about 26,000 cockroaches, according to a recent survey by the Agriculture Department.

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Union Debates Pact at Mack
description: Members of a local of the United Automobile Workers will urge the international union to approve wage and benefit cuts demanded by Mack Trucks Inc., according to Eugene McCafferty, president of the local.

title: Hutton Group Fills Financial Chief Post
description: Robert P. Rittereiser took another step in consolidating his control at the E. F. Hutton Group, of which he is president, with the announcement yesterday that the company had named Edward J. Lill, a prominent accountant, as chief financial officer.

title: Landmark and Telecable Buyback
description: Landmark Communications Inc. and the Telecable Corporation each repurchased 39 percent of its own stock from 56 minority stockholders for an undisclosed price, the companies said.

title: Hanson-Imperial
description: Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson Trust P.L.C., said he would write to the chairman of Imperial Group P.L.C., Geoffrey Kent, suggesting an immediate meeting that he hoped would result in Imperial's recommending acceptance of Hanson's bid of $:1.8 billion - about $2.5 billion.Lord Hanson made his remarks at Hanson Trust's meeting where the bid was approved.

title: Chrysler Makes Payout to Workers
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced that it had distributed more than $550 million in cash and stock last week to its 87,500 United States and Canadian workers under its Employee Stock Ownership Plan. The four-year ESOP program was set up in 1981 as part of a concession agreement by the United Automobile Workers while Chrysler was struggling for its financial survival.

title: Proposal to Lift Coffee Curbs
description: Coffee-producing countries decided today to back the suspension of all remaining limits on exports in an attempt to check the rise in prices.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RICHARDSON'S GOAL: PERSONAL REBOUND
description: Micheal Ray Richardson came back to the Nets today, but his homecoming was an uneasy one. He faced a small news-media gathering at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in the morning, returned to practice for the first time in three weeks later in the day and resumes his playing career Wednesday when the team begins a weeklong road trip - all with the memory of another drug relapse hanging above him.

title: FAMILIES SEND JOINT CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST
description: Families who celebrated together during the holiday season are remembering those festivities by contributing to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary last Thursday of Noah Goldstein, a former New York City Civil Court judge, listed his survivors incompletely. They include his wife, Sylvia.

title: The Chunnel Again
description: They've been talking about it for nearly 200 years, and now they say they're really going to do it. Work on the ''chunnel'' (a tunnel under the English Channel) is supposed to start next year, and sometime in 1993 people should be able to go by land between London and Paris in three and a half hours.

title: Joint Maneuvers in Panama
description: Some 1,500 United States soldiers joined 500 Panamanians today for annual military maneuvers to prepare for the protection of the Panama Canal when the United States pulls out in the year 2000. The exercises are held pursuant to the 1977 treaties that will turn the waterway over to Panama in 14 years.

title: CRUDE OIL FALLS BELOW $20 A BARREL
description: Crude oil breached the $20-a-barrel barrier for the first time in six years yesterday as petroleum prices continued their precipitous slide on world markets.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Professional homecoming for the former St. John's all-American Chris Mullin, who was the No. 1 draft pick of the Warriors.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $994,000.

title: Malaria Antibodies
description: Monoclonal antibodies, already used widely throughout the world in biomedical research, laboratory testing and diagnosis, may also prove valuable in treating malaria, Swedish scientists have reported.

title: WITH SERMONS AND PROTEST, NEW YORK HAILS KING
description: Carl Smith stamped his feet from the cold and waited by a Harlem storefront for a food handout. But at the mention of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., he smiled warmly.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $900,000 for the quarter and $5,600,000 for the year and a credit of $20,100,000 for the year representing cumulative effect of change in accounting. c-Includes tax credits of $2,400,000 for the quarter and $11,400,000 for the year. The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split, effective Jan. 15, 1985.

title: BIZARRE STRUCTURES FOUND IN GALAXY
description: Strange new objects have been found at the center of the Milky Way galaxy, giving rise to wild and wonderful theories that astronomers concoct to explain the unexplained.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in the latest fourth quarter earnings to a non-recurring after-tax charge of $4,222,000 to establish a reserve against the value of uncleared items remaining from the 1984 acquisition of First Bankshares Corp. The company also said prior year earnings included gains of $2,220,000 from the sale of branch offices.

title: Nuclear Plant in California Disciplines 12 Over Drugs
description: A dozen employees of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant have been discharged or disciplined for involvement with illegal drugs, the plant manager announced today.

title: Ex-Mayor's San Diego Job
description: Former Mayor Roger Hedgecock began working as host of a radio talk show today, six weeks after his resignation and sentencing on a 13-count felony conviction involving election violations. Mr. Hedgecock, 39 years old, resigned as Mayor Dec. 10, an hour before he was sentenced to 365 days in county custody, three years probation and fined $1,000. He was accused of accepting more than $350,000 in illegal contributions for his 1983 campaign and lying about it on state-mandated disclosure forms. Mr. Hedgecock may not run for office for the length of his probation.

title: TRANSIT CHIEFS LOOK FOR 'HEADHUNTER'
description: It is axiomatic: good help is hard to find - even high-priced help, as the city's Transit Authority has discovered.

title: IN THE GENE LAB, SCIENTISTS MANIPULATE CODES OF LIFE
description: Magnified 400 times on the television monitor, the hollow needle glides forward to touch a living cell, pierces its surface and slides deep inside.

title: KEY DEMOCRAT DENIES ETHNICITY IS BAR TO TICKET
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee, responding to comments by Governor Cuomo, declared yesterday that the party had not ruled out an Italian-American or a Northeasterner as its 1988 Presidential candidate.

title: THEATER: 'DRINKING IN AMERICA'
description: THERE are few theatrical experiences more exhilarating than watching a talented young artist fulfill his promise. That experience is now to be had at the American Place Theater, where the performer Eric Bogosian, a downtown fixture for almost a decade, has put together an airtight 80-minute show in which his gifts for acting and social satire collide to their most incendiary effect yet. ''Drinking in America'' is the evening's title, and, like such past Bogosian efforts as ''FunHouse'' and ''Men Inside,'' it is a breakneck, hair-raising comic tour of the contemporary American male psyche, with its creator playing all the roles. But if this is the funniest and most shapely of Mr. Bogosian's shows, the edges of his humor have not been smoothed out: ''Drinking in America'' leaves a hangover of outrage that a theatergoer can't easily shake.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PEOPLE WILL TALK. By John Kobal. 728 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $25. IN ''People Will Talk'' the film historian John Kobal has written up 41 of the interviews with vintage Hollywood personalities that he has been taping since the early days of his career - the first of them, featuring such veterans of the silent era as Dorothy Gish and Colleen Moore, dating from 1964, the most recent of them recorded within the past year or two. Their documentary interest is obvious, and even if you can't take the minutiae of the movies quite as seriously as Mr. Kobal himself does, they make enjoyable and sometimes riveting reading.

title: Eager for No. 2 Spot
description: Most people hoping to be named lieutenant governor are content to wait for a telephone call from Governor Cuomo, the man who most politicians expect to make the final decision on his running mate.

title: Baylor Basketball Put on Probation
description: The men's basketball program at Baylor was placed on probation for recruiting violations, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Go out into the hedges and the highways and lift up those who are oppressed, and then Martin will have a gift,'' - The Rev. Joseph L. Roberts Jr., in Martin Luther King holiday address in Atlanta. [ A1:2. ]

title: Boa Held in Zoo Break-In
description: The curator of the St. Louis Zoo says a strange boa found in a corner of the zoo's reptile house will be examined by veterinarians.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
OPERA: 'I LOMBARDI,' BY VERDI, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT is a bitter irony that just at the moment when all of Verdi's operas, early and late, have acquired an audience, the reservoir of Verdi singers has fallen to drought levels. So it is that a young soprano such as Aprile Millo, who sang in a concert version of ''I Lombardi'' Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, commands unusually close attention and hopeful scrutiny. Miss Millo, who was born in New York and reared in California, made the ears of Verdi fanciers perk up at her Metropolitan Opera debut last season in ''Simon Boccanegra.'' It is pleasant to report, based on this ''Lombardi'' performance with Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York, that the promise is being fulfilled.

title: AIDS SAID TO INCREASE BIAS AGAINST HOMOSEXUALS
description: Public fear over the spread of AIDS has led to increased discrimination and violence against homosexuals, even as it has created new obstacles to obtaining legal protections, according both to leaders of homosexual groups and to government officials.

title: OHIO FACTORY LEADS A GAS THAT KILLED 1 IN OKLAHOMA BLAST
description: A metal cylinder cracked at a Federal uranium processing plant and a small, white cloud of radioactive gas leaked inside a building, but no workers were injured, the authorities said today.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
WHALERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 5-0
description: The Rangers came up with a lackadaisical performance near their opponents' goal at Madison Square Garden last night, and they paid the penalty.

title: Waving to the Future From the Electronic Cottage
description: PERSONAL computer communications, its early proponents claimed, would open up a new world of telecommuting and instant information resources for all of us. Soon the nation would be abuzz with people working happily and conveniently in their homes. Rather than wasting hours weaving through traffic traveling back and forth to work, they would simply walk over to their home computers and set about their business, still dressed in pajamas and robe and leisurely enjoying a second cup of coffee.

title: Scout Talk
description: The 21 teams in the National Hockey League hire a total of more than 100 scouts, whose assignment is to look for talent wherever it may be budding. That yearlong job takes them thousands of miles to games in the lowest of minor leagues, to any number of colleges, to all gradations of Canadian junior hockey and even to Midget League games.

title: TRUCKING INDUSTRY ASKS U.S. TO EASE WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS
description: Trucking industry representatives and their supporters in the West are expected to ask the Federal Government Tuesday to allow 17 Western states to set their own weight and length limits for trucks that use the Interstate Highway System.

title: MARCOS STANDS BY HIS MILITARY CHIEF
description: Seven weeks after his reinstatement after a trial on charges of involvement in the murder of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., General Fabian C. Ver continues to receive the tacit support of his cousin and patron, President Ferdinand E. Marcos, despite strong American pressure to remove the general as Chief of Staff of the armed forces.

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTH AFRICA PUTS 22 ON TRAIL
description: Twenty-two black dissidents went on trial today on charges of murder and of seeking to overthrow the Government.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ayerst Laboratories, a pharmaceutical division of the American Home Products Corp., has named David G. Shand senior vice president of medical affairs.

title: COURIER-JOURNAL CHIEF TO STAY IN JOB
description: Barry Bingham Jr. said yesterday that he had agreed to stay on as editor and publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times for a year, until the papers, together with other family companies, are sold.

title: Advertising; Redefining Of Ad Ethics
description: There can be dire consequences from advertisers who are out to destroy competition rather than only seeking an increase in market share, Louis T. Hagopian, chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, is telling an advertising audience today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about corporate reorganization, and a picture caption with it, incorrectly described William C. Douce. He is no longer chief executive officer of the Phillips Petroleum Company, having retired last spring.

title: GENERAL CERAMICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
3 ARRIVE FROM SOVIET TO JOIN U.S. WIVES
description: Three Soviet men, long separated from their American wives, arrived here today to try to begin normal married life.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Group Stock Is Split 3 for 2
description: The Ogilvy Group, parent of Ogilvy & Mather and Scali, McCabe, Sloves, and other companies, announced a 3-for-2 split of its common stock yesterday.

title: Lunch With Mrs. Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan has invited one of the stars of ''Hill Street Blues'' to have lunch with her at the White House today.

title: SOLVED: CONVENTION CENTER CLEANING PUZZLE
description: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was designed as something close to an architectural essay in glass - four long blocks of glass that would turn what could have been a squat, warehouse-like building into a shimmering ornament.

title: CCX NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about New York State Catholics' opposition to Medicaid financing of abortions misstated the Medicaid guidelines. Elective abortions are allowed until the 24th week of pregnancy; thereafter only medically necessary abortions are allowed.

title: The Lessons of the Richard Nixon Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Before the Gala, A Bit of Tennis
description: ''Charity dinner-dances are just plain boring in my estimation,'' Carrie Rozelle said the other day at a dinner-dance to raise money for the charity she heads, the Foundation for Children With Learning Disabilities.

title: MERGER FEVER AFFECTING CORPORATE PHILANTHROPY
description: The surge of company mergers, acquisitions and buyouts is altering the way corporations dispense their charitable contributions. Leaders of nonprofit organizations fear, as one said, that ''one and one will not add up to two,'' especially on the local level. On the other hand, some corporations are urging new subsidiaries to increase giving.

title: President of Matsushita Resigns; Successor Set
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest consumer electronics concern, announced yesterday that Toshihiko Yamashita, its president since 1977, will resign next month to make way for his hand-picked successor, Akio Tannii. The change is effective Feb. 19, after the company's next board meeting.

title: Federated Mergers To Spur Write-Off
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. confirmed that it would combine in two separate mergers four of its store divisions and said the moves would result in a 1985 fourth-quarter after-tax charge of about $25 million.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Century Corp., San Antonio, said its board had approved the previously announced offer by Gerald H. Stool to acquire the 67 percent of the company he does not already own for about $6.30 a share.

title: DR. J. DOUGLAS BROWN, A DEAN AND SOCIAL SECURITY ACHITECT
description: Dr. J. Douglas Brown, an architect of the Social Security system and former dean of the faculty at Princeton University, died Sunday at the Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, N.J. He was 87 years old and had lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Earl Conrad, 79, the Author Of Books on Race Relations
description: Earl Conrad, who wrote many books dealing with race relations in the United States, died last Friday of complications resulting from lymphoma at San Diego Medical Center in La Jolla. He was 79 years old and lived in Coronado, Calif.

title: Orosco Signed After Checkup
description: The Mets, who wondered and even worried about Jesse Orosco's left elbow last year, said yesterday that he had scored 100 percent in a medical check the other day. So they signed him to a two-year, $1.6 million contract with an option for a third year, and avoided an arbitration battle with their No. 1 relief pitcher.

title: BACK IN 1802, NAPOLEON WOULD HAVE LIKED ONE
description: Britain and France have dreamed about digging a tunnel under the English Channel for at least 200 years, but every attempt to do so has been disrupted by age-old antipathies between the two countries or by financial problems.

title: BancTexas Payout
description: BancTexas Group Inc. said that its directors had suspended payment of annual dividends on its preferred stock because of a loss in the fourth quarter. The company also said that its independent auditor had given notification that it was considering issuing a qualified report for the year ended Dec. 31. 1985.

title: MASTERPIECE THEATER IS HONORED
description: The slightly stooped, frosty-haired gentleman stepped to the podium unnoticed, and with five familiar words engaged the audience.

title: GANDER INQUIRY FINDS ONE ENGINE APPEARED WEAK AS JET CRASHED
description: Investigators looking into the crash Dec. 12 in Gander, Newfoundland, of a chartered DC-8 airliner carrying 248 American servicemen said today that they had determined that the right outboard engine was delivering less power than the other three engines at the moment of impact.

title: Make-Believe Trials, Real Work
description: If ever Elaine Marks wanted to know what life would be like for her daughter, the aspiring lawyer, yesterday she found out.

title: U.S. INQUIRY FINDS PATTERN OF FRAUD IN HOUSING LOANS
description: Federal investigators say they have uncovered a pattern of frauds against the Department of Housing and Urban Development involving falsified documents used to obtain tens of millions of dollars in Government-backed mortgages.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
A Profit Again For Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, aided by cost-cutting and the weakened dollar, today reported its first annual profit in four years. In the fourth quarter the company earned $87 million, or 88 cents a share, in contrast to a $251 million loss a year before.

title: Dalfort, Braniff Halt Talks
description: The Dalfort Corporation yesterday announced the termination of talks on Dalfort's possible acquisition of the stock it does not already hold in Braniff Inc., the Dallas-based airline.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Lessons of the Richard Nixon Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Hire Glanville as Coach
description: The number of coaching vacancies in the National Football League decreased by one today, when the Houston Oilers named Jerry Glanville to succeed Hugh Campbell, who was dismissed with two games left in the regular season.

title: FIRMS REASSESS MATCHING GRANTS
description: ROBERT HICKS, an inmate at a Federal prison near El Paso, is a reminder of the potential for abuse in the matching grant programs that generate $80 million a year from business corporations for the nation's colleges and universities.

title: GUARD CALLED IN TO KEEP PEACE AT HORMEL SITE
description: Gov. Rudy Perpich called out National Guardsmen today to help preserve order at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant as applicants and new workers began arriving to replace striking meatpackers.

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $245,000 for the quarter and $445,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $490,000 for the quarter and $371,000 for the 9 months.

title: CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEBANESE PREMIER CALLS FOR A NEW POLITICAL SYSTEM
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami called today for a new political system for Lebanon, including an immediate end to Christian dominance, as a substitute for a foiled Syrian-sponsored peace accord.

title: Ike's Lesson, Unlearned
description: A quarter-century ago, after guiding America through eight years of peace and prosperity, President Eisenhower delivered a famous farewell address. It is best remembered for warning against ''the acquisition of unwarranted influence . . . by the military-industrial complex.'' But Ike's valedictory centered on a more fundamental theme: balancing defense spending with the needs of a healthy economy. None of his successors has ignored that advice more than Ronald Reagan.

title: Corning Glass Profit Up
description: Corning Glass Works today reported a 74 percent rise in its fourth-quarter earnings to $29.4 million, or 68 cents a share, from $16.9 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales were $398.1 million, compared with $404.1 million, but sales were up 13 percent when adjusted to reflect the sale of the company's refractories business and separate reporting of the medical-instrument business.

title: SATORI ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Advertising; Magazine Ad Pages Off
description: In December magazine-members of the Publishers Information Bureau - and that's most of the truly important publications, were down 2.7 percent in advertising pages from the same month in 1984, to 13,697. Although, thanks to rate increases, ad revenues gained 8.7 percent, to $480.3 million. That brought the year's results to 152,565 pages, a 3.3 percent drop from the previous year, and $4.9 billion in revenues, an increase of 4.5 percent.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to include operations of American Medical Systems Inc., acquired in May 1985 in a pooling of interests transaction.

title: REBEL GAINS ARE REPORTED, AND DISPUTED, IN SOUTHERN YEMEN
description: Rebellious Marxist forces appeared to have the upper hand in most of Southern Yemen tonight, according to refugees reaching here and diplomats' assessments. But with communications still cut, the political situation in the Soviet-allied nation remained confused.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $3 million on the sale of the Kenroc division.

title: That Lady
description: France Magazine, published in Washington by the French Embassy, has devoted its entire current issue to the Statue of Liberty, which the French packed in 200 boxes and sent to New York in 1885.

title: Nominees for Award
description: The American swimmer Matt Biondi and the British runner Steve Cram head a list of eight athletes from seven countries who have been nominated for the sixth annual Jesse Owens International Amateur Athlete Award after setting world records or winning world championships during 1985. Biondi set a world mark of 48.95 seconds in the 100-meter freestyle, and Cram set world records of 3:46.31 for the mile; 3:29.67 for 1,500 meters (later broken by Said Aouita of Morocco) and 4:51.39 for 2,000 meters. Others nominated include Aouita, Sergei Bubka, the Soviet pole vaulter; Michael Gross, the West German swimmer; Yuri Korolev, the Soviet gymnast; Felke Petra, the East German javelin thrower, and Yashuhiro Yamashita, the Japanese judo star.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary charge of $5.2 million.

title: CLUES TO BEHAVIOR SOUGHT IN HISTORY OF FAMILIES
description: IN their search for the causes of human behavior, some psychologists find themselves drawn ever deeper into the past, beyond the history of any individual and toward that of the whole family.

title: Article 975286 -- No Title
