description: Never mind that he had won a $30 million jackpot over the weekend. Pasquale (Pat) Consalvo, a 59-year-old construction worker from Staten Island, was planning to go to work yesterday. But his family had other ideas. They reasoned that the recipient of the largest single payoff in the history of the New York State Lottery deserved the day off, and they were determined to make him take it.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: NCNB said the results include those of Pan American Banks Inc. and Southern National Bankshares Inc., acquired at the end of 1985, and accounted for on a pooling-of-interest basis. The 1985 earnings include a 13 cents a share after-tax gain on the sale of a subsidiary bank by Pan American.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Boatmen's said 1985 earnings include the results of Chartercorp., acquired in January 1985.

title: PUBLIC COLLEGE COST UP OVER 7%, STUDY FINDS
description: The cost of attending the nation's four-year public colleges and universities has rise more than 7 percent since last year to an average of $4,587 a year for tuition, room and board, a survey reported today.

title: SLOAN TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WALL ST. RENTERS ASSUME A BUILDING'S ENTIRE COSTS
description: Office tenants in New York City have long accepted the fact that they pay not only a rent based on the number of square feet they let but also charges for part of their landlord's expenses in operating the building. It is through these extras, which are known as pass-throughs and which are part of most standard leases, that building owners make a portion of their profits.

title: A MONTH AFTER PEACE PACT, UGANDA REMAINS TENSE
description: Relations between the military Government of Uganda and a powerful rebel army remain tense a month after the two groups signed a peace agreement, and prospects that the accord will be fully carried out are not good, according to Western diplomats and Ugandan journalists.

title: More Inaction on Acid Rain
description: The spread of aerial sewage in the form of acid rain over the lakes, streams, woods and buildings of eastern North America will continue as usual. This is the real, if hidden, meaning of the ''recommendations'' of Drew Lewis, President Reagan's special representative on acid rain, in a report just issued jointly with a representative of the Canadian Government. Mr. Lewis, former Transportation Secretary, is the prospective chairman and chief executive officer of the coal- and oil-rich Union Pacific Corporation.

title: Drexel Appoints Head Of Global Arbitrage Unit
description: In a move intended to strengthen its international arbitrage operations, Drexel Burnham Lambert has hired Kenneth Morris as senior vice president and director of international trading and sales of foreign securities worldwide.

title: STANDARD PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a non-recurring credit of $1,191,000, or 19 cents a share, related to the termination of Disc regulations and the associated reversal of taxes.

title: ISRAEL HONORS DR. KING
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir dedicated a street in Jerusalem today to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Mr Shamir called Dr. King a ''man of vision and courage.''

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO ACQUIRE SYBRON
description: The Sybron Corporation and Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that they had agreed in principle for Forstmann to acquire Sybron in a cash deal worth about $300 million.

title: G.E.C. Charges Libel by Plessey
description: The General Electric Company of Britain said it had begun libel proceedings against the Plessey Company, which G.E.C. is trying to acquire. G.E.C., which is not related to the United States company with the same name, offered $:1.18 billion - about $1.7 million - for Plessey on Dec. 9.

title: STAGE: MICHAEL LEARNED IN 'TIME OF THE CUCKOO'
description: ADMIRING James Morgan's set of a back garden in Venice, with its umber facades and its vines and vino bottles, the audience waiting for the lights to dim at the York Theater Company's revival of ''The Time of the Cuckoo'' may look forward to a romantic cruise along the canals. But then the action starts, and one cannot help noticing, despite the agreeable distractions of the tour guides, that the vessel leaks.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 9.

title: TO INSPIRE BETTER WORK, ESTONIA TRIES NEW LURES
description: The dividing line between communism and capitalism seems to be blurring at Television Repair Shop 1, a large government-run establishment in this Estonian capital.

title: NATION PAUSES TO REMEMBER KING, LED BY A HUGE TRIBUTE IN ATLANTA
description: Singing the ballads of the civil rights movement, thousands of people marched slowly through Atlanta today as this city and the nation marked the first Federal holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In Atlanta, where Dr. King was born and where he is buried, and in cities across the country, church bells tolled, choirs sang and citizens paused to remember the slain civil rights leader, eulogized in speeches and services as tion's ''drum major for justice and peace.''

title: RHNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MADRID MAYOR AFTER FRANCO
description: Enrique Tierno Galvan, a Spanish intellectual who was Socialist Mayor of Madrid and a leader of the peaceful transition to democracy after the rule of Generalissimo Franco, died yesterday of cancer. He was 67 years old.

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $323,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Nicaraguans Discuss Aid On a Visit in China
description: Nicaragua and China today discussed an interest-free loan of goods to the Central American nation, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: MUPPETS CELEBRATE 30 YEARS
description: MUPPETS are harmless creatures, funny little figures in the guise of animals and humans that have been warming television homes for three decades. If they are not human, they are certainly the antithesis of inhuman and, surely, there can be no television better deserved than ''The Muppets: A Celebration of 30 Years,'' which appears at 8 tonight on CBS.

title: RETIRED U.S. JUDGES SAY THEY MUST PAY TO WORK
description: More than half of the nation's 273 senior Federal judges, most of whom hear cases part time, have stopped working because, under a recent change involving Social Security, their income is higher if they stay home.

title: Next Stop, Miami
description: Tito Horford plans to make the University of Miami the next stop in his short but complicated collegiate travels. Clint Bryant, an assistant coach, said that Horford, the 7-foot-1-inch center who has made appearances at the University of Houston and Louisiana State, had told the Hurricanes' coaching staff he hoped to enroll at Miami when the registrar's office opened today.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTERN AIRLINES SLASHES FLIGHT ATTENDANT WAGES
description: Eastern Airlines unilaterally cut the wages of its flight attendants by 20 percent today and lengthened their work hours in a drive to avoid default on its $2.5 billion of debt.

title: BOGGS TOPS ARBITRATION LIST
description: A record eight players and five clubs submitted salary arbitration figures of $1 million or more yesterday, with Don Mattingly of the Yankees and Dwight Gooden of the Mets each seeking $1.5 million. The Yankees submitted $1.25 million for Mattingly, the Mets $1.1 million for Gooden.

title: INDIA AWAITING VERDICT TOMORROW IN TRIAL OF 3 IN '84 GANDHI SLAYING
description: The trial of three men accused of conspiring to assassinate Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ended last week with the chief defense lawyer saying that the ''real assassin'' had been allowed to escape.

title: Treasury Bond Futures Off
description: Prices of Treasury bond futures fluctuated in a wide range yesterday before closing slightly lower.

George Furey Is Dead at 71; A Former Coach at Columbia
description: George Furey, a former football player and coach for Columbia University, died yesterday at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital after a short illness, the university reported. He was 71 years old.

A Weed Is a Weed
description: Some 10 million Americans, including a large number of teen-agers, dip snuff and chew tobacco. Many, the kids especially, probably think those habits are a risk-free alternative to smoking.

title: JOHN D. CALANDRA, STATE SENATOR
description: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Republican leader of the Bronx since 1970, died last night in Mount Sinai Medical Center after suffering his second heart attack in several days. He was 57 years old.

title: ELECTRICAL CONCERN IN 14% GAIN
description: The Westinghouse Electric Company, aided by strength in its industrial products operations, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1985 rose 14 percent on an 11.4 increase in sales.

title: 'Shoot From the Hip,' Rambo-Style Editorializing

title: Improving U.S.-Soviet Texts
description: IN a recent column (''Flawed Textbooks Distort U.S.-Soviet Relations''), I raised the question of whether bilateral efforts could make American and Soviet textbooks more objective in dealing with the other country's history. Elimination of inflammatory distortions could be helpful now that exchanges of young people and televised people-to-people discussions are being resumed.

title: What Price Delayed Justice?
description: Manhattan prosecutors framed Willie Fisher in 1933 and sent him up for manslaughter. He spent 11 years in prison and 14 more years on parole before New York courts held that the state had used deceptive evidence and suppressed evidence in his favor. Prosecutors had introduced a gun with the false suggestion that it was the murder weapon during a brawl in a Harlem speakeasy. They concealed evidence that Mr. Fisher wasn't even in the bar when the shooting happened.

title: Trainer Looks Beyond Ashes
description: John Campo is a trainer of thoroughbreds. Thirty-eight of those in his care were housed in stalls at Belmont Park's Barn 48. Shortly after 1:20 A.M. Sunday, a fire broke out in the barn, where an automatic sprinkler system was out of order. The fire killed 36 of his horses and nine others.

title: Brazil Debt Deadline Set
description: Brazil and its leading commercial bank creditors have set a deadline of March 15 for completion of negotiaMarch 15 for completion of negotiations on a new program to restructure debt due in 1985 and 1986.

description: More than two months have passed since Chris Mullin left New York for San Francisco to begin his pro basketball career with the Golden State Warriors.

title: U.S. AIDE IN TALKS ON MIDEAST
description: The United States negotiator on Middle East issues, Richard W. Murphy, stepped up discussions in Europe today with Jordanian and Israeli leaders on convening a Middle East peace conference, Administration officials said.

title: Navratilova Wins Again
description: Martina Navratilova had a 2-hour-2-minute struggle tonight before edging Claudia Khode-Kilsch in the finals of the New England Virginia Slims tournament.

title: Adding Memory Boards
description: THE first personal computer, the Altair, came with 256 bytes of memory - barely enough to hold this first paragraph - and owners salivated at the thought of adding 2 whole kilobytes on a memory expansion card.

title: 'HOSTAGE IN IRAN,' ON 'FRONTLINE' SERIES
description: STAY with ''Hostage in Iran,'' which opens the new season for ''Frontline'' tonight, beyond its opening minutes. There is a cumulative effect. There may not seem to be any reason to relive the Iranian hostage crisis -other than to observe the fifth anniversary of its conclusion - but once again we're gripped. It remains a stunning chapter in American history. The 90-minute program can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 P.M.

title: ARTICLE BY REAGAN IN TIMES BRINGS 2 UNSUCCESSFUL CALLS FOR MISTRIALS
description: An article by President Reagan in the Jan. 12 issue of The New York Times Magazine has prompted attorneys in two organized-crime trials in Federal District Court in Manhattan to seek mistrials. Both motions were unsuccessful.

The company said the exact number of shares to be purchased would depend on employee involvement in various stock plans.

description: Chuck Norris, the actor, felt he was getting the runaround from the major movie studios. Some liked his script, ''Missing in Action,'' but he found himself talking to executive after executive with no clear promises of support.

The structure is the former Municipal Asphalt Plant, a barrel-domed, concrete affair behind Gracie Mansion, on the East River at 90th Street. The building has become the Murphy Center, an institution that provides space for community affairs.

description: Continental Airlines of Houston said it would file an amended reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The company said that it expected the latest proposal to be its final plan and that the reorganization should be completed in the first half of 1986.

description: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C. today announced a record $3.2 billion bid for the Distillers Company, the world's leading maker of Scotch whisky, including the Johnnie Walker and Dewar's brands.

description: The Soviet dissident Yelena G. Bonner was released from the hospital today, one week after undergoing coronary bypass surgery, and she returned to suburban home of her family to recuperate.

description: Government offices and banks will be closed today in observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s open. The nation's stock and commodity markets will also be open. The weekly Treasury bill auction will be Tuesday instead of today.

description: Ivan Lendl made a victory tour of Manhattan yesterday, attending three news conferences, among them a promotion for his instructional book, titled ''Hitting Hot,'' which will be published in August to coincide with the start of the United States Open.

description: Activists of the environmental group Greenpeace, who tried last year to snare an unarmed United States cruise missile with a giant fish net, headed toward a northern Canadian military base today to protest a new round of test launches.

description: Trustees of the city's largest public employee pension fund have the authority to begin withdrawing investments from companies doing business with South Africa, according to the city's Law Department.

description: The Louisiana Ball, an annual extravaganza sponsored by the Louisiana State Society, is one of Washington's best parties. But this year's ball at the Washington Hilton Saturday night was unusually alive with political numbers.

Singer said that miscellaneous pre- tax income for the latest year includes a gain of $16.9 million from the 1985 first quarter sale of 51 percent of the equity in its Malaysia subidiary. The miscellaneous pre-tax income for the 1984 year includes a gain of $5.3 million representing the net effect of a gain from the 1984 first quarter sale of 51 percent of the equity in the company's Thailand subsidiary and a loss on the disposition of a consumer operation in Europe. The company also said that the latest quarter earnings include favorable foreign exchange adjustments of $4.6 million, compared with $3.7 million for the year-earlier period and $19.8 million for the latest year against $16.7 million for 1984.

PRESIDENT IS TOLD HOW HE MUST CUT FEDERAL SPENDING
description: For the first time, the Comptroller General of the United States told the President today precisely what cuts he must make in Federal spending.

title: CONCERT: WEILERSTEINS PLAY BLOCH
description: IN the tiny Ann Goodman Recital Hall atop Merkin Concert Hall early Sunday evening, Donald Weilerstein and Vivian Hornik Weilerstein played four pieces by Ernest Bloch for violin and piano. Bloch wrote beautifully for the violin and often with real inspiration.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOW AN ELI TURNED INTO A MONSTER
description: For 10 years, Gary Fencik has been hearing the same question: ''What is a nice Yale boy like you doing playing football for the Chicago Bears?''

title: Congress; Of Life In the Cloakroom
description: When Congress resumes business Tuesday, the action on the floor is what will make the news, but the behind-the-scenes work of a small group of staff members will keep the show running.

title: Travels With Shultz
description: George P. Shultz is making tentative plans to visit Greece and Turkey for the first time since he became Secretary of State in 1982.

title: CONCERT: VOCAL ENSEMBLE
description: THE Center for Inter-American Relations, on Park Avenue at 68th Street, has on display a fascinating collection of colonial paintings from Latin America, and on Sunday afternoon it decided to set the same topic to music. The result was 13 vocal works spanning the 17th and 18th centuries. Many, like the paintings nearby, were anonymous, but all were held in various degrees of tension between their European roots and a wholly new environment. The performers were the eight members of the Manhattan Vocal Ensemble supported from time to time by piano, guitar, even a drum.

title: LIBYAN HIGH SCHOOL'S 3 R'S: READING, WRITING, ROCKETRY
description: Mohammed el-Aref, 15 years old, studies algebra, chemistry and literature at his neighborhood high school in Tripoli. He also has weekly lessons in rocket launching, hand grenade tossing, signals and communication, and machine gun assembly and maintenance.

title: Perez to Return
description: Tony Perez, a major cog of Cincinnati's ''Big Red Machine'' and the career leader among active major leaguers in runs batted in, will return to play for the Reds in 1986. The 43-year-old Perez, who signed a one-year contract, alternated last season at first base with Pete Rose, the Reds' player-manager. In 72 games, Perez batted .328 with 6 home runs and 33 runs batted in.

title: Keep Christmas Lights Shining All Winter Long
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKETS FALL ON GROUP OF 5'S INACTION
description: The financial markets yesterday registered their disappointment that the weekend meeting of the so-called Group of Five in London had yielded no commitment to cut interest rates.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belt
description: John R. Reilly, one of the chief strategists in the 1984 Presidential campaign of Walter F. Mondale, was an unexplained rider yesterday on Air Force Two as it took Vice President Bush to and from Atlanta for ceremonies honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Mr. Reilly chatted with Mr. Bush, but the Vice President's aides would not disclose the subject.

title: Anschluss in Lesotho
description: Lesotho is a tiny mountain kingdom encircled by South Africa whose Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan, has long courted trouble by refusing to genuflect to Pretoria. The trouble took a new turn on Jan. 1 when South Africa imposed a blockade, cutting off essential supplies. Now Lesotho's armed forces, whose officers Pretoria has cultivated, have seized power. To all appearances, it is an annexation carried out by native proxies, recalling that old, ugly German-Austrian word: Anschluss.

title: Mistrial Denied in Death In Texas Nursing Home
description: A judge today denied a motion for a mistrial in a four-month murder-by-neglect trial involving a nursing home and four individual defendants.

title: DESIGNERS' SALUTE LEADS OFF WITH HEPBURN
description: The spirit of fashion past was spliced with fashion present as the Council of Fashion Designers of America gave its fifth annual awards dinner at the New York Public Library Sunday night. The heroine of the black-tie gathering, which included practically every designer you can think of, was clearly Katharine Hepburn, who described herself as ''the original bag lady'' and expressed surprise that she was chosen as a symbol of style.

description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, is expected to approach Britain soon to determine whether non-OPEC oil producing nations would be willing to coordinate output with the Organization of Petroleum Exorting Countries, an authoritative oil journal said today.

title: FED SEEMS AGAINST RISK OF RATE CUT
description: Although the Reagan Administration would like further cuts in interest rates, as reflected in its stance at the meeting of the so-called Group of Five in London over the weekend, the Federal Reserve seems to have decided that the risks of trying to drive rates down from present levels outweigh the benefits.

title: The Background; A Success at La Scala in 1843
description: Verdi's fourth opera, ''I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata,'' tells of the rivalry of two Lombard brothers, Arvino and Pagano, for the hand of Viclinda at the time of the First Crusade near the end of the 11th century. First produced at La Scala in Milan in 1843, the work scored an opening-night success.

title: The Lessons of the Richard Nixon Case
