title: A SCULPTURE AND A CHARGE OF CENSORSHIP
description: A sculpture depicting a border agent searching an illegal alien atop a donkey cart was removed the day it went on display outside the Federal courthouse here, setting off a flurry of censorship charges as well as a lawsuit.

title: MIX AND MATCH SPORTSWEAR
description: ''We want everything to work together,'' said Danny Noble. ''Depending on how the pieces are put together, the clothes can look grown-up or playful, they can be worn to dinner or the beach.''

title: Mercedes-Benz Maker Considers Reparations
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., maker of Mercedes cars and trucks, has commissioned a study to determine the use of forced labor by the company under the Nazis, a company spokesman said today.

title: Advertising; People
description: Dennis Schmidt is joining Campbell-Ewald, New York, as a group senior vice president and associate creative director.

title: Leeches Studied
description: Leeches may be useful in studying and treating Parkinson's disease, a disorder that affects the brain and nervous system, a Utah State University researcher said today.

title: STUDY LINKS SMOKING AND WEIGHT
description: MANY smokers have noticed that they gain weight when they quit the cigarette habit, but the seemingly obvious explanation -that they eat more - has been hard to prove.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Chess: Spassky Uses King's Gambit For Another Piece of Piracy
description: A half-century ago, Siegbert Tarrasch said, ''It is almost madness to play the King's Gambit.'' A quarter-century ago, Bobby Fischer professed to having refuted it. Nowadays, myriads of the less prominent scorn it as belonging to a bygone period of devil-may-care sacrificing, but this swashbuckling opening refuses to die out completely.

title: Stating the Case For Academics
description: Before the recent convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, John Keiser, president of Boise State University, circulated a letter to other college presidents. The letter advanced a proposal, pushed by Boise State and other members of the Big Sky Conference, that athletic eligibility be increased from four years to five, as a means of encouraging athletes to remain in school and earn their degrees.

title: Special Camp Fair Is Set
description: The Second Special Camp Fair, sponsored by Resources for Children with Special Needs, will be held Feb. 2 at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street. About 80 camps offering a variety of programs for youngsters with disabilities will be represented at the fair, which is free and runs from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 677-4650.

title: School Digs
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: KOCH DEMANDS ALBANY REPLACE CUTS IN U.S. AID
description: Mayor Koch said today that the Cuomo administration would have a budget surplus of about $600 million and that it should use some of the money to shield local governments from cuts in Federal aid.

title: NORTHWEST SEEN AS GROWTH AREA IN DRUG SMUGGLING
description: The Coast Guard's seizure of a small Honduran coastal freighter last weekend with 447 pounds of cocaine hidden aboard has helped to confirm some officials' suspicions that Puget Sound is a new, major entry point for drugs.

title: Ethiopian Refugees Are Fleeing to Somalia
description: United Nations and Somali officials say a new wave of Ethiopian refugees is fleeing into this East African nation to avoid Government resettlement programs, worsening one of the world's worst refugee problems.

title: CHEAP OIL IS WELCOMED, BUT WITH A WARNING
description: As crude oil prices continued their downward spiral yesterday, analysts and economists found the news generally good for consumers and the United States economy, but potentially very bad for oil-exporting countries, oil companies and banks with large portfolios of energy loans.

title: OFFENSIVE LINE A KEY ELEMENT FOR BEARS
description: Many kindergarten students know that William (the Refrigerator) Perry, the hero of television commercials, also plays football for the Chicago Bears. Many older people know the Bears have an awesome defense. Most people who know the difference between a football and a tennis ball know Walter Payton is a great running back.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $180 million on the sale of the bank's FinanceAmerica Consumer Finance unit. c-Net income d-Includes pre-tax gains of $490 million on the sale of assets and a charge of $4.75 million for a civil penalty agreed to yesterday with the U.S. Treasury Department for unintentional reporting violations under the Bank Secrecy Act.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available because of the Martin Luther King holiday* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Horford Enrolls at Miami
description: Tito Horford enrolled at the University of Miami today and said he just wanted to be a normal college student and play a little basketball for the Hurricanes.

title: Videos at 7-Eleven
description: The Southland Corporation, which runs 7,000 7-Eleven stores, said it would begin renting video cassette movies and recorders in almost 2,000 of the convenience stores by the end of the year. Southland said the move would make 7-Eleven the nation's top distributor of rental video movies.

title: Beatrice Meeting
description: The board of the Beatrice Companies is expected to meet Jan. 28 to consider the revised $6.2 billion bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, sources close to Beatrice said. Kohlberg, which had agreed to pay $43 in cash and $10 in preferred stock for Beatrice, now proposes to pay $40 in cash and $7 in preferred stock.

title: Offering by Utility In Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering $125 million of 10 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2016 at 99.78 to yield 10.9 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Padres Testing
description: Mandatory drug testing for all front-office employees of the San Diego Padres began today at the order of Ballard Smith, the team president.

title: HEALTH
description: MORE and more Americans who might once have spent months or years in hospitals or nursing homes are today being cared for at home. Usually, they are under the loving supervision of a friend or relative, supported by a fast-growing network of health-care professionals who make house calls.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Jan. 10 described a protest by a Porsche owner, Donald Schupak, who hired a picket to walk outside the two sites of Porsche-Audi Manhattan Inc. with a sign saying, ''Porsche-Audi Manhattan Does Not Honor Its Repair Warranties.''

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
All-Stars Picked
description: Mike Bossy and Bryan Trottier of the Islanders were among 14 players named yesterday by Coach Mike Keenan to fill out the Prince of Wales Conference all-star roster. Keenan, who guided Philadelphia to a berth in the Stanley Cup final series last season, also picked Kirk Muller of the Devils and Reijo Routsalainen of the Rangers for the Wales team, which will play the Clarence Campbell Conference team in the 38th National Hockey League All-Star Game Feb. 4 in Hartford.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A FOUNDATION CHIEF AGREES TO REPAY $1.3 MILLION
description: The president of two foundations, accused by state officials of siphoning off funds for private use, has agreed to repay $1.3 million and distribute the foundations' remaining assets of $8 million to $9 million to public charities.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: She had inadvertently misdialed, so instead of the number she had intended to reach, Clara Greenspan got a recording recited by an unfamiliar youngster's voice. The girl sounded as if she were about 6 or 7 years old, and this was her message:

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Youngs Drug Products business, acquired Sept. 13, 1985.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $1,830,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $31,061,000 for the year. c-After a nonrecurring charge of $42,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $2,525,000 for the year.

title: HOW SIDNEY OF CITISOURCE PRODUCES PARKING TICKETS
description: Sidney - the Citisource Inc. device that has become one of the first casualties of the city's investigation into the Parking Violations Bureau - is essentially a limited-use personal computer that can be carried on a traffic officer's hip. It was intended to solve two problems faced by the Parking Violations Bureau - the rejection of tickets because of illegibility and quick identification of scofflaws and stolen vehicles.

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including nonrecurring gains on real estate transactions of $566,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,488,000, or 15 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year reflect an approximate charge of $35 million taken in the fourth quarter to reflect an antitrust settlement with MCI Communications and reductions of certain access charge revenue.

title: The Chaplin Files: Can It Happen Again?
description: In preparing his latest biography, David Robinson, a British writer, asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation for its records on his subject. He was pleased that the F.B.I. responded so quickly, within about nine weeks, and surprised by the extent of the Federal investigations: 1,900 pages from bureau files on his subject, Charlie Chaplin.

title: Walesa to Go to Trial On a Charge of Slander
description: The Government said today that it would put Lech Walesa on trial on charges of slandering state election officials, but indicated that he probably would not go to prison.

title: Navy Officer Is Guilty In Recruiting Surgeon
description: Comdr. Reginald E. Newman of the Navy, charged with misconduct in recruiting a surgeon later accused in the deaths of five patients, was convicted on five counts today.

title: 3 SIKHS CONVICTED IN GANDHI MURDER
description: Three Sikhs, two of them bodyguards of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, were found guilty today of murder charges in the assassination of the Indian leader.

title: EX-AMSTERDAM NEWS EDITOR
description: James L. Hicks, a former editor of The Amsterdam News and a pioneer black American correspondent, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 6 Americans Honored By French Government
description: The French Government announced yesterday that six Americans have been named Commandeurs in the French Order of Arts and Letters. They will receive medals of the order, which was created in 1957 to recognize ''those persons who have distinguished themselves by creative work in the fields of arts and humanities.''

title: Advertising; Dewe Rogerson in U.S.
description: Dewe Rogerson International, a major British financial public relations firm, has opened an office at 250 Park Avenue with Carol A. Ruth, a former senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton, as president of the Dewe Rogerson Inc. subsidiary. In England, about 30 to 40 percent of the company's revenues are from advertising. The new office in the colonies is still devoid of clients.

title: Cuomo Sets a Standard
description: The Presidential election of 1988 will be the first in 20 years with no President on the ballot, which may help explain why there is now so much speculation here so soon about Ronald Reagan's successor.

title: Literature Lost
description: I like writers more than any other human class. All my best friends are writers. The reason is the way writers, taken three or four at a time, tend not to withhold the free surge of words, however quarrelsome, controversial, skeptical, passionate, ironic, nasty, jokey or dreamy. Writers have an urge - like living grass growing up through concrete - to tell what they see and feel and notice and believe, even when they are, by someone's fiat, not allowed to.

title: REAGAN WILL SEEK $100 MILLION IN AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: President Reagan has decided to seek $90 million to $100 million in military and other aid to the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government, a ranking White House official said today.

title: CZECH GOVERNMENT EULOGIZES MAVERICK POET
description: In separate and distinct ways, the Czech people and the Czechoslovak state today bade farewell to Jaroslav Seifert, the Nobel Prize-winning poet who died 11 days ago at the age of 84.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV NEWSMAN'S TRANSITION TO NOVELS
description: Gerald Seymour once had it made as a British television journalist: he carried a company air-travel card, appeared on camera in a street-scarred overcoat (''I was against the romantic trenchcoat image'') and did his two minutes of stand-up reporting from many of the magic-carpet datelines of the world.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST PLUNGES 11.7% IN MONTH
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest plunged 11.7 percent, or 35.3 million shares, in the month ended Jan. 15, to 266.6 million shares. The previous high of 301.9 million shares was set last month ended Dec. 13. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 207.3 million shares.

title: FOREST SABOTAGE IS URGED BY SOME
description: Frustrated by the failure of conventional tactics to stop logging on Federal lands, some environmentalists are deploying a new weapon: six-inch spikes they drive into trees scheduled to be logged.

title: OIL SLUMP SENDS DOW DOWN 14.68
description: Wall Street stock prices slumped in heavy volume yesterday after the investment community, focusing on the negative implications of lower oil prices, battered shares of energy and banking concerns.

title: Letter: On Electric Power; To Spark a Utility's Competitive Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3.3 million from the sale of the company's industrial businesses.

title: ASSEMBLY TAKES QUICK ACTION
description: In an unusual move, the Democratic-controlled Assembly, at its opening session today, challenged Senate Republicans by passing three controversial bills the Senate had rejected at the special legislative session last month.

title: APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $2,659,000 for the year. The company reported share earnings for the latest quarter only since it converted to a stock form July 3, 1985.

title: Colds, Not Hangovers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: REPUBLIC BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RARE PFORZHEIMER BOOKS BOUGHT FOR U. OF TEXAS
description: In what book dealers said was the largest sale of rare books ever made, a large portion of the New York-based Pforzheimer collection of English books and manuscripts has been purchased for the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Nicaraguan Cardinal Appeals to U.N. Chief
description: Nicaragua's Cardinal issued a letter today accusing his country's Government of harassing Roman Catholics and church institutions with the goal of ''neutralizing religious activity and the preaching of the Gospel'' there.

title: U.S. Reporter Detained Overnight by Nigeria
description: Security forces Saturday held Charles T. Powers, a correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, overnight at Murtala Muhammed International Airport without explanation and refused to let him call the United States Embassy.

title: Could an Italian-American Win?
description: Any self-respecting yuppie can readily tell you the differences between tortellini, fettucine, fusili and penne, and the number of people who swoon with pleasure over sun-dried tomatoes seems to grow daily. Lee Iacocca's book has been on the best-seller list for 64 weeks, and other Italian names appear high on the letterheads of the largest corporations and bluest-chip law firms. Italian-Americans rank among leading movie makers, editors and merchandisers, and 34 of them hold seats in Congress. Ours might, indeed, be called the Italian era in America.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $4.2 million from the sale of non-strategic assets. The company said latest fourth quarter net benefited by $18.5 million as the result of an agreement with Signal Capital Corp. involving the sale of rights to future recoveries of charged- off loans.

title: Snag in United Air Plan
description: United Airlines postponed plans today to start expanded service to the Pacific later this month because Japan has balked at granting landing rights. Japanese and United States negotiators ended two days of meetings Monday without resolving Japan's insistence on concessions for granting the rights to United, which has purchased Pan American World Airways' Pacific unit.

title: DISCIPLINING INCOMPETENT DOCTORS: SLOW AND COMPLEX PROCESS IN THE STATE
description: Incompetent doctors are allowed to keep on practicing in New York State because the procedures for disciplining them are slow and inefficient, witnesses said yesterday at a City Hall hearing.

title: RENAISSANCE IN SPAIN LIGHTENS THE CUISINE
description: WHILE Americans are embracing traditional Spanish foods such as paella and gazpacho, Spaniards are increasingly turning to something else. Many are calling it new Spanish cuisine. There is no one definable taste or method. It is more a process, begun a decade ago and steadily growing, to lighten food while maintaining flavor, sometimes clear and simple, sometimes rich and earthy.

title: CANADA AGREES TO EXTRADITE A KILLER TO U.S. TO FACE DEATH PENALTY
description: Canada's Justice Minister today announced his approval of the extradition of a convicted murderer to Philadelphia, where a jury in November 1983 recommended that he be sentenced to death.

title: YOUNG PROFESSIONALS JOIN THE NEEDY AS S.R.O. TENANTS
description: As one of the city's few remaining single-room-occupancy hotels, the Hotel 17 at 225 East 17th Street has its share of the poor, the elderly and the mentally ill. But those traditional S.R.O. tenants are now living side by side with young working people who have been locked out of the apartment market by high rents.

title: SWEETNESS COMES HOME
description: Jazz moved up the Mississippi from New Orleans to Chicago, but Sweetness reached Chicago by way of the Pearl River.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two dispatches from France - one on Monday from Paris and one yesterday from Lille - about British-French plans to build a tunnel under the English Channel misidentified one member of the construction consortium. The three state-owned French banks include Banque Indosuez, not Paribas.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., said it had agreed to sell its iron ore interests in Western Australia to Peko-Wallsend Ltd. of Australia for $54 million.

title: MOYNIHAN TAKES FLOOR ON GRAMM'S TV ATTACK
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, took the Senate floor today to criticize Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, for remarks he made on a Sunday television program.

title: 2 WHITE SOUTH AFRICAN POLICEMEN SLAIN IN CLASH WITH BLACK CROWD
description: Two white policemen were reported today to have been stabbed and beaten to death by a crowd of blacks near a segregated township southwest of here.

title: Advertising; Yachting Magazine Has a New Publisher
description: Never an ad salesman. Never a circulation type. Never a research maven.

title: Economic Scene; The Struggle Over Rates
description: WHAT did the London meeting of the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Five - the United States, Japan, West Germany, France and Britain - accomplish?

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Jan. 1 of the movie producer Sam Spiegel misattributed the authorship of the screenplay for ''On the Waterfront.'' It was written by Budd Schulberg alone, not with Irwin Shaw.

title: 'PLANET EARTH,' PLATE PECTONICS AND GREEN TURTLES
description: ''PLANET EARTH'' is public television's new entry in the television-with-a-purpose, television-that-is-good-for-you, television-that-looks-spectacular-but-never-panders-to-the -viewer sweepstakes. This puts it under a burden. So what? ''Planet Earth'' is what it sets out to be: It has purpose; it's good for you; it looks spectacular, and goodness knows it doesn't pander. ''The Living Machine,'' the first episode in the seven-part series, can be seen on Channels 13 and 49 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: WEST COAST BANK POSTS LARGE LOSSS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation today reported an unexpectedly large loss of $178 million in the fourth quarter of 1985 and, after a special meeting of its board of directors, eliminated the quarterly dividend on its common stock.

title: AT INAUGURATION, KEAN STRESSES JERSEY ECONOMY
description: Governor Kean began his second term today with a pledge to work for an improved economy, a cleaner environment and better educational opportunity.

title: MARKET MAINTAINS TRADITIONS
description: Selling shoofly pie and apple dumplings at the Lancaster Central Market is a Hess family tradition.

title: 5 REPUTED CRIME FIGURES CONVICTED OF SKIMMING CASINO RECEIPTS
description: Five men, including the reputed leader of organized crime in Chicago, were convicted today of conspiring to divert more than $2 million in untaxed winnings from gambling casinos in Las Vegas.

title: The Nobel Peace Prize Winner Is an Organization, Not a Person
description: To the Editor:

title: Play Ball!
description: Washingtonians eager for the return of major league baseball to the capital must be content, for the moment, with the news that the Old Timers Baseball Classic will be played in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium for the fifth time in five years next June 23. Proceeds go to the Association of Professional Ball Players of America, which as-sists sick and indigent former players and other retired baseball people. The National League old-timers lead the series three games to one, having won the 1985 contest thanks to home runs by Henry Aaron, Joe Torre, Bill Mazeroski and Tommy Davis.

title: MANILA WILL LIMIT VOTE INSPECTIONS
description: Foreign election observers and foreign journalists will be banned from polling places under an election commission ruling reported here today.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BURGER GIVES PLEA ON JUDGES' TAX
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger urged Congress today to make a swift reversal in a recent tax law change that in effect penalizes more than 170 semiretired Federal judges for working.

title: Kansas Stops Sooner Streak
description: Danny Manning ignited an early second-half burst as Kansas ended the unbeaten streak of Oklahoma at 17 games tonight with a 98-92 Big Eight Conference victory.

title: On Line at the Library With Four Terminals
description: ''I think it's great, fantastic,'' said Louis Kruh as the computer terminal told him in a matter of seconds that there were 533 items under the book heading that he was researching. ''In the old days, I would've had to go through card after card.''

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10.3 million.

title: COMMERCE UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'SON OF CONCORDE' PLANNED BY FRENCH
description: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger plane that marked its 10th anniversary today, has proved to be a technological achievement but one that has had trouble getting off the ground financially.

title: Kaat on TV Team
description: Jim Kaat, the former Twins pitcher, will join Phil Rizzuto and Bill White as a member of the Yankee broadcast team for telecasts over WPIX-TV this season. Kaat, who once had an offseason radio show in the Minneapolis area and has since done occasional television commentary, replaces Spencer Ross, who is shifting to WPIX radio.

title: High Time to Tax America's Top Cash Crop
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly Lesson
description: What does it profit a lad if he gain $1,534.25 but jeopardize his eligibility?

title: 'MISSING II: HAVE YOU SEEN THIS PERSON?,' ON NBC
description: AT the top of a one-hour show tonight at 8 on NBC called ''Missing II: Have You Seen This Person?,'' these words are shown on the screen:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fred Marion, free safety of the New England Patriots, and Jim Collins, inside linebacker of the Los Angeles Rams, were added to the rosters of the A.F.C. and N.F.C. Pro Bowl teams. . . . Sergei Bubka, the outdoor record-holder in the pole vault, has entered the Wanamaker Millrose Games Feb. 14 along with six other Soviet athletes, including Tamara Bykova, who holds the women's world indoor best in the high jump. . . . Frank Shorter, the 1972 Olympic marathon champion, is one of 2,760 entered in the first City of Los Angeles Marathon March 9. Organizers announced a $325,000 prize list: the top male and female runners will earn $41,000 each in cash and prizes: a check for $10,000, a $25,000 car and a round-the-world trip for two valued at $6,000.

title: The Hash Bashers
description: Eight men met secretly in Washington.

title: MCMAHON'S INJURY IS CONCERN
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, expressed strong concern today that his play in Super Bowl XX on Sunday could be restricted without some relief to the pain in his left buttock.

title: LAST ARGUMENTS OFFERED IN TRIAL OF JONAH PERRY
description: The opposing sides in the Jonah Perry assault case summed up yesterday, with the prosecution saying it was time for the 19-year-old defendant to stop running from the truth and the defense imploring the jury to condemn an unprovoked ''murder and cover-up'' by the police.

title: CONCERT: STEVE REICH PREMIERE
description: THE concert of recent works by Steve Reich presented Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall was a winning occasion, and one reason - beyond the sheer sound of clever music brilliantly performed - was what it indicated about Mr. Reich's success (mostly) and failure in resolving Minimalism's most basic dilemma.

title: FRAYAR WON'T DWELL ON INJURY
description: Irving Fryar was willing to display his injured right hand today, but the Patriot wide receiver and runback specialist was not willing to discuss the knife injury he suffered two weeks ago.

title: Sybron Accepts 4th Buyout Offer
description: The Sybron Corporation, which approved a buyout offer from Forstmann Little & Company on Monday, had rejected three rival bids, a Sybron executive said. Basil H. Dumbleton, Sybron's vice president of corporate and investor relations, said eight outside directors had rejected bids from Sybron's management; a partnership between Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage firm, and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and a third party that he would not identify.

title: Seven-Up Link Seen to Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc. is set to purchase the Seven-Up Company from Philip Morris Inc., Beverage Digest, a soft drink industry newsletter, reported yesterday.

title: Guerrillas in Peru Wound 11 In Attack on Mining Center
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked Peru's main mining center on Monday night, wounding 11 people as they threw sticks of dynamite at a political party office, a police station and other buildings, the police said today.

title: SANTA FE SOUTHERN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today: Jan. 22, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on situation in the occupied Arab territories at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Ballard Hospitalized
description: Harold Ballard, the 82-year-old owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, Maple Leaf Gardens and the Hamilton Tiger Cats of the Canadian Football League, was in satisfactory condition after being admitted to the intensive care unit of Wellesley Hospital yesterday after reportedly suffering chest pains. A spokesman at the hospital said no further details would be released until today. A diabetic, Ballard has had difficulty walking in recent months because of circulation problems.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENTRANCES. An American Director's Journey. By Alan Schneider. Preface by Edward Albee. Illustrated. 416 pages. Viking. $25. WHEN he died two years ago at the age of 66, Alan Schneider left behind a considerable body of theatrical work. He had worked on Broadway and off, in regional theaters and abroad, and he had earned a reputation as one of the pre-eminent American directors of work by Samuel Beckett, Edward Albee, Harold Pinter, Bertolt Brecht and Michael Weller. Nine days before he was struck and killed by a motorcycle in London, he turned in the manuscript of this book - the first volume of his autobiography, which chronicles his life up through 1966.

title: Kaiser's Board Under Attack
description: The investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., said today that it intended to seek to oust the board of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. The Frates group now holds about 18.6 percent of Kaiser's shares outstanding and has proposed to buy the company for $7 a share in cash and $13 in unspecified securities.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared yesterday and a 3-for-2 stock split paid Sept. 3, 1985.

title: Tax-Reform Provision Is Unfair to Retirees
description: To the Editor:

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $2,700,000 from litigation.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
J. PETER SCHAEFFER
description: J. Peter Schaeffer, a senior vice president of Prudential Bache Securities Inc., died Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Senior Judges Need a Break
description: Dozens of nominally retired but highly active Federal judges have stopped working because of a quirk in the Social Security law. It requires them, when working, to pay Social Security taxes when they could be drawing full salary and doing nothing.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Sept. 24, 1985.

title: Advertising; Fragrance Assignments To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey, an agency for Squibb's Charles of the Ritz Group for about a year, has now gotten a number of important additional assignments from its Yves Saint Laurent Beaute and Parfums.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1984 fourth quarter and year nets include a one-time gain from the sale of a building of $105 million.

title: MANES RETRACTS STORY AND SAYS HE CUT HIMSELF
description: Donald R. Manes admitted yesterday that contrary to his original account, he was not abducted by a pair of kidnappers nearly two weeks ago, but slashed his own left wrist and ankle so seriously that he was near death.

title: INSURANCE IS A BIG GAMBLE
description: The fire that killed 45 horses at Belmont Park Sunday morning pointed out once again that horse owners are among the world's biggest gamblers - when it comes to insurance. According to John Campo, who trained 36 of the horses that perished, only five or six of them were insured.

title: Gorman, Mets Agree
description: Tom Gorman, the Mets' pitcher who filed for salary arbitration, seeking $185,000 after the Mets offered him $150,000, reached agreement on a contract that will bring him $170,000. . . . Mike Marshall, the Los Angeles outfielder who hit .293 with 28 home runs and 95 runs batted in last season, reached agreement with the Dodgers on a one-year contract that will reportedly pay him $650,000. . . . The Atlanta Braves signed the relief pitcher Terry Forster to a one-year contract that includes weight clauses. The team did not reveal the terms, saying only that Forster will have to meet specified weight requirements during the season. Forster, a left-hander, was 2-3 with a 2.28 e.r.a. and one save in 1985. . . . The Boston Red Sox have hired Al Bumbry, a former major leaguer, to coach outfielders and base-running in their minor league system.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Leslie H. Green and Karl Maier have been promoted to senior vice president at Lowe Marschalk.

title: JOHN CALANDRA, STATE SENATOR AND BRONX G.O.P. CHIEF, DIES
description: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Republican leader of the Bronx since 1970, died Monday night in Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after suffering his second heart attack in several days. He was 57 years old.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share figures are fully diluted.

title: IN PLACE OF PRESENTS FOR HOLIDAYS, MANY GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Instead of giving presents during the holiday season, some people have made contributions in the names of friends and relatives to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WEST GERMANS DECLINE U.S. BID TO JOIN IN MOVES AGAINST LIBYA
description: President Reagan's special envoy met with West German political leaders today and proposed a four-step program to retaliate economically against Libya for what the United States has said is its support of terrorism. The West Germans again declined to take part.

title: Bonner, Week After Surgery, Is Still Reported Having Pain
description: Yelena G. Bonner, still in pain a week after coronary bypass surgery, tried to walk a bit today as she continued her recovery at her relatives' home.

title: Enjoying Music
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SALVADOR PARTIES LOOSEN REBEL LINKS
description: After five years of political opposition and forced exile, El Salvador's small Social Democratic parties have loosened their ties with the armed rebel movement, according to senior party officials. A few of their members are quietly returning to test conditions in El Salvador.

title: Effects of a Switch At the City Council
description: The City Council is expected to be reorganized today, in more ways than usual, after the swearing-in of Peter F. Vallone, Democrat of Queens, as majority leader.

title: Leave Soviet Jews Out of Arms Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: African Aid Group Formed
description: Sixty prominent Americans have formed a ''national support group for Africa'' to publicize the continent's economic difficulties and help other organizations develop African assistance programs, the United Nations announced today.

title: RUTH MACK
description: Ruth Mack, a former personnel director of the Pepsi-Cola Company and the wife of Walter S. Mack, former president and chairman of the company, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment in recent years.

title: A Play on Isadora Duncan
description: A benefit performance of ''Isadora, American Legend,'' a one-woman show about the dancer Isadora Duncan, will be given Saturday night at 8 o'clock at the Secret Theater Studio, 43 West 13th Street.

title: Technologies Net Up 10.7%
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 10.7 percent on a 5.8 percent increase in revenues.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures are fully diluted.

title: SOUTH YEMEN LOYALISTS REPORTED HOLDING ON
description: Fierce fighting still raged today between factions of Southern Yemen's ruling Marxist party, according to refugees arriving in the African nation.

title: A JUICE EXTRACTOR FOR FRESH TASTE
description: FRESH fruit and vegetable juices are among the most concentrated sources of vitamins and minerals, and all of us should drink plenty of them at this time of year. One way to assure a tasty supply is to make them at home.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in a letter Jan 17 from Rizwan Hameed, the Punjab of Pakistan was confused with the Punjab of India. The writer wished to stress that Pakistan's Punjab region is the chief recruiting base for the army, a situation that creates tensions in other parts of Pakistan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 22, 1986
description: The Economy

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Homey Touches Backstage For Actors in 'Foreigner'
description: At the Astor Place Theater at 434 Lafayette Street, near Astor Place, where ''The Foreigner'' is in its second year, there is a small door just off the entrance that opens on to flight of rickety wooden steps.

title: Bangladesh Bank Plan
description: Bangladesh hopes to increase its foreign-exchange earnings by allowing offshore banking in its free trade zone near Chittagong, the central bank said today. Offshore banking units would be allowed to accept deposits in 10 currencies.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANK OF AMERICA IS TOLD TO PAY U.S. $4.75 MILLION FINE
description: The Treasury Department announced today that it had imposed a record $4.75 million civil penalty on the Bank of America for failing to report more than 17,000 large cash deposits or transfers from 1980 to 1985.

title: 3 DIE AS COPTER CRASHES
description: A helicopter carrying an ABC News crew to a meatpackers' strike crashed today in thick fog, killing the two ABC News employees and the pilot, the authorities said.

title: THE MAKING OF A WINE PRICE FROM VINEYARD TO TABLE
description: IMAGINE that on July 2, 1986, the actor Burgess Meredith, a regular Sherry-Lehmann customer, pays $33.25 for a bottle of 1983 Chateau Leoville-Las- Cases. Two years earlier, to the day, Michel Delon, Leoville's owner, introduced his first 83's at $9.45 a bottle. That's nearly a 252 percent difference in price.

title: Tighter Rules In Repo Deals
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a regulation requiring disclosure of details of repurchase agreements.

title: 22 KILLED BY A CAR BOMB IN EAST BEIRUT
description: A car-bomb explosion ripped through a busy street in East Beirut today, not far from the headquarters of President Amin Gemayel's Christian Phalangist Party. The police said 22 people were killed and more than a hundred wounded, many seriously.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Defense Asks Dismissal In Aid to Illegal Aliens
description: Defense attorneys for 11 church workers charged with helping illegal aliens moved to dismiss the case today in the wake of evidence that appeared to contradict the testimony of the Government's key witness.

title: Small Bus Riders
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Inhaling of Chloroform Kills Scarsdale Girl, 16
description: A 16-year-old girl in Scarsdale, N.Y., died Saturday night after inhaling chloroform, apparently to become intoxicated, the police said yesterday. A 15-year-old friend of the girl, who had also inhaled the chloroform, was treated at White Plains Hospital and released, according to the police.

title: AIDS FEARS OF THE UNMARRIED
description: Eighteen percent of people who are single, divorced or separated have changed their sexual behavior for fear of AIDS, according to a nationwide NBC News/Wall Street Journal Poll released yesterday, while just 3 percent of married people have changed their practices.

title: Advertising; Alberto-Culver Shifts Some Duties to Grey
description: The Alberto-Culver Company in Melrose Park, Ill., has switched the creative responsibility for most of its hair-care and food brands to Grey Advertising's Chicago office from Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt of Chicago.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses on the retirement of debt of $316,000 for the quarter and $1,714,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss on the retirement of debt of $2,788,000 and a charge of $15.3 million in connection with the abandonment of plans for a casino-hotel in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

title: Supreme Court Takes Religious Holiday Case
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Connecticut school officials must accommodate a teacher's religious beliefs by granting him more paid religious holidays a year than most other employees receive.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Dow Chairman
description: Robert W. Lundeen, chairman of the Dow Chemical Company, will retire in May shortly before he reaches the company's mandatory retirement age of 65, Dow said yesterday. He will be succeeded by Paul F. Oreffice, 58, who will also continue as president and chief executive. The company said Mr. Oreffice will remain in the three positions until November 1987, when he becomes 60 and, by Dow bylaws, must give up the posts of president and chief executive.

title: ARTISTS IN OLD AGE: THE FIRES OF CREATIVITY BURN UNDIMINISHED
description: THIS is a portrait of the artist in old age. Twelve artists sat for the portrait, in places as distant as the manicured lawns of exurban Connecticut and the tawny hills of northern California. All are greatly talented, all famous, all still at work despite physical ravages that have diminished some. The baby among them is 70. The oldest is 91.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net income from businesses sold of $858,000 for the quarter and $19,754,000 for the year, a net gain of $56.5 million for the quarter and year from the sale of businesses and a provision of $50 million for the quarter and year for impairment of investments in certain foreign locations.

title: IN CHICAGO, SCANDAL IS POLITICAL SPORT
description: There are six spectator sports played professionally in this city: baseball, basketball, hockey, soccer, football and politics.

title: LTV Closing Unit
description: As part of its cost-cutting efforts, the LTV Corporation, burdened by huge losses and long-term debt, said it would close indefinitely the blast furnace and basic oxygen process steelmaking operation at its Chicago Works. Russell W. Maier, president of LTV's Steel Flat Rolled and Bar Company, said steel for the unit would be supplied by the complex's three electric furnaces.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: DAUGHTER'S BURDEN AND PRIDE: MANDELA NAME
description: The world knows him as Nelson Mandela, the black South African leader who has remained unbowed through 21 years of imprisonment by white authorities.

title: The 20's and 30's Can Happen Again
description: I am often asked whether the financial panics of the 1920's and the Great Depression of the 1930's could happen again. For 20 years, I have answered that what happened then could not happen now. Today, I would not so answer. The loan portfolios of American banks include more than $500 billion in farm and third-world debt, where default is easily imagined. As oil prices fall, what were good oil loans are rapidly becoming bad ones. Major banks are sinking under the weight of falling real estate values. Mergers and leveraged buyouts lead to firms that can barely meet interest obligations in boom periods and that could not meet them in a recession.

title: KODAK SEEKS SLICE OF 35-MM. MARKET
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced two 35-millimeter automatic cameras, the first such products the company will have sold in the United States in nearly 16 years. Kodak also introduced new color film and photographic paper.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $119.2 million in asset writedowns for the quarter, a loss from discontinued operations of $3.3 million for the year and losses of $1.5 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year on the disposition of discontinued operations. c-Net income . d-After losses from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $5.6 million for the year and a loss of $60.7 million for the year on the disposition of discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change from LIFO to FIFO in the company's method of accounting for about 60 percent of its inventories.

title: Bridge; 3 NEW YORK TEAMS QUALIFY IN EVENTS TO ENTER PLAYOFFS
description: There were three winning teams in the New York metropolitan area over the weekend.

title: Jim Walter Corp.'s $125 Million Issue
description: The Jim Walter Corporation, a producer of building materials, is offering $125 million of 11 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2006 at 99.15 to yield 11.105 percent. The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Advertising; New TV Campaign For Harris
description: HOW would you feel if you spent $5.5 million to buy recognition only to find you are not being recognized?

title: Bowling For Dollars
description: In both greater Chicago and greater Boston, the Super Bowl is generating increased interest, in more ways than one. A total of three banks in the two locales are offering one-year certificates of deposit with interest rates tied to - of all things -the margin of victory by the local heroes.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET ATTACKED AS CONGRESS IS RECONVENED
description: Congress returned to work today on a testy note as lawmakers from both parties sharply attacked President Reagan's budget proposals and said they would be soundly rejected on Capitol Hill.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Nuggets, at Denver 9:30 P.M. This is the first game in a five-game road trip for the Nets, who beat the Nuggets, 124-113, last Saturday at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. (Television -SportsChannel, 9:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 9:30 P.M.) Celtics vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Boston. This is a rematch of last year's championship series. which was won by the Lakers. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: St. Peter's vs. Manhattan, 7 P.M., and St. John's vs. Fordham, 9 P.M. at Madison Square Garden (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. Radio -WFUV-FM 90.7, and WCBS 880, 9 P.M.); Boston College at Pitt (Television - USA 8 P.M.); City College at Baruch, 7:30 P.M.; Southampton at C. W. Post 7:30 P.M.; Pace at Dowling, 7:30 P.M.; St. Francis (Brooklyn) at F.D.U., 8 P.M.; Kean at Glassboro State, 8 P.M.; Long Island University at Wagner, 7:30 P.M.; Stevens Tech at Rutgers-Newark, 7:30 P.M.; Vassar at New York Polytech (Brooklyn), 7:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Maple Leafs, at Toronto, 7:35 P.M. In their only previous meeting of the season, Nov. 20 at Madison Square Garden, Bob Brooke, in his third season, got his first N.H.L. hat trick and Tomas Sandstrom scored twice to help the Rangers romp, 7-3. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M., delayed tape.) Devils vs. Flames, at Calgary, 9:35 P.M. The Flames are unbeaten in their last nine games with the Devils (7-0-2) and are poised for a sweep of the season series by virtue of winning the first meeting, 5-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Nov. 6 and at Calgary, 7-2, Nov. 16.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results reflect a net charge of $18,000,000 to cover costs associated with phasing out five roofing operations.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a pre-tax gain of $6,000,000 from real estate sales, net of provisions for costs associated with the relocation, consolidation and disposition of certain facilities and operations. c-Including an approximate nonrecurring pre-tax gain of $24,000,000 from the sale of the store equipment group, net of provisions for closing certain facilities. A change in accounting for pensions increased net income by $1,400,000, or 5 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $5,400,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year. The changes reflect the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Rule No. 87 which relates to accounting for U.S. pension plans.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ISLANDERS CONTAIN FLYERS FOR 3D TIME
description: As tonight's 7-3 victory against the Philadelphia Flyers at Nassau Coliseum attests, the Islanders are capable of beating the best team in their division, or any division.

title: THE DANCE: BALLET DE SANTIAGO
description: IF we haven't heard much about Chile's Ballet de Santiago, its artistic director since 1982, Ivan Nagy, is certainly a familiar face in New York's dance world.

title: PATRIOTS MAY NEED FRANKLIN'S KICKS
description: The last time they had a Super Bowl here someone asked Tony Franklin's coach about Tony Franklin.

title: ALUMINUM COMPANY OF AMERCA (ALCOA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net charges of $144.6 million for the quarter and $156.9 million for the year, primarily from an asset sale and writedowns related to a slated 25 percent reduction of the company's primary aluminum production capacity. c-After net charges of $33 million for the quarter and $32.5 million for the year primarily from the closing of a Mobile, Ala. bauxite plant. d-Net income.

title: Milwaukee Marketing Notes That Yield 5.60%
description: Milwaukee is offering $53 million of short-term notes due Dec. 31, 1986, to yield 5.60 percent, through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE universal nature of certain food combinations has always fascinated me. Years ago, I created a dish made with chicken, sausage and seafood not knowing that there was a Spanish creation called paella. Before I ever came to the United States, I had topped baked oysters with chopped spinach, having never heard of oysters Rockefeller.

title: I.B.M. OFFERS DESK UNIT FOR FASTER COMPUTING
description: In its first attack on the market for engineering and scientific computers, I.B.M. yesterday introduced a line of personal computers that uses an unusual high-speed processing technology that the industry is just beginning to embrace.

title: Lewis to Retire
description: Guy Lewis, who served as captain of the University of Houston's first basketball team in 1946 and later built the Cougars into a national power in 29 seasons as head coach, will retire this year at the end of his 30th season, the school announced yesterday. For the 64-year-old Lewis, who has not had a losing season in 26 years and whose teams made the N.C.A.A. Final Four in 1982, 1983 and 1984, the announcement comes as the Cougars have been struggling with an 8-7 record, including a 2-3 mark in the Southwest Conference. Lewis, who has spent his entire coaching career at Houston and has a mark of 586-272, has taken his team to 14 N.C.A.A. tournaments and made the Final Four five times.

title: DRUGS MANES TOOK MAY HAVE EMOTIONAL EFFECTS
description: Although there is no way of knowing to what extent prescription drugs and a weight-loss diet may have affected the mental state of Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, doctors have long been concerned about the emotional and physical hazards of both therapies.

title: JOSEPH KALTENBACHER
description: Joseph C. Kaltenbacher, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Seton Company of Newark, died Monday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: The Ministers Ate Well
description: To hear their press agents tell it, the finance ministers of the five major democracies, meeting in London last weekend, found that they agreed on just about everything. Interest rates, they proclaimed, are still too high. Further decline in the exchange value of the dollar would please them all.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: PHILADELPHIA OFFERS WERNICK
description: THE second half of this century has been a perplexing time for composers. It is difficult to think of a comparably long period in Western music's history when the language of composition has endured such a confusion of tongues. Two or three times a decade, it seems, someone invents a new system, demands the abolition of all systems or calls for a return to an old one.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE COLLECTORS Starting a collection can be as perplexing as starting to write a book. The idea may be there, but bringing the concept to reality is a daunting chore. Yet this is an age of collecting, and tonight, beginners will have the opportunity to get some guidelines from experts. The lessons take place at a historic site noted for its own collectibles, the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street.

title: Feud Cools
description: Lee Stern owns the Chicago Sting, and Bart Wolstein owns the Cleveland Force, and together they're front-running candidates for anybody's don't-invite-'em list.

title: 'LYRICS' SERIES AT THE Y
description: MOVING into its 16th season this weekend, the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y is undertaking another in what have become periodic changes of approach. It is going back to its original source of material, the Broadway musical, concentrating on the 1940's, with programs organized by the types of source from which the musicals were drawn.

title: Mother Charged With Killing Baby She Made TV Plea For
description: A woman who made tearful pleas on television for kidnappers to return her baby was charged with murder today after the girl's body was found in a garbage bag in the Shenandoah River, the authorities said.

title: MOSCOW AND ADEN
description: More than a week after civil war broke out in Southern Yemen, one of Moscow's closest allies in the Arab world, indications are strong that the Soviet leadership was caught by surprise and is watching developments anxiously.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IRANIAN, IN ZIMBABWE, AFFRONTS WOMEN
description: The President of Iran, his Islamic fundamentalism clashing with the customs of his Zimbabwean hosts, refused to attend a state banquet in his honor Monday night because women sat at the head table and wine was to be served.

title: HORMEL PLANT SHUT AS TROOPS ARRIVE AND STRIKERS THIN RANKS
description: The National Guard and the city police reduced tension in Austin today by closing the plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Company in exchange for an agreement by strikers to reduce picket lines and stop blocking city streets.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Prime Computer Inc., Natick, Mass., has appointed to its board John E. Sheehan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Johnstown Corp.

title: Woman Who Sought To Starve Sues Hospital
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, a quadriplegic who sought court permission in 1983 to starve to death, filed suit today against a hospital she says is force-feeding her.

title: WINE TALK
description: BY now, most people interested in wine - and quite a few who just like a good story - have heard about the schism in the house of Sebastiani, the California family that owns one of the largest wineries in the United States.

title: Market Place; How Analysts View Earnings
description: THE stock market feeds on earnings estimates, and this year - as usual - security analysts are considerably more optimistic than the market strategists and economists employed by brokerage firms.

title: A TV EPIC STARRING (MOSTLY) MAXIMILIAN SCHELL
description: ''Peter the Great,'' the $30 million production filmed in the Soviet Union last year, is the first television mini-series that Maximilian Schell has starred in. ''It will also be my last,'' he says.

title: WAYS TO PROTECT CHILD VICTIMS IN COURT
description: A child victim of sexual abuse or violence needs special care in the adult world of jurisprudence, where even the size of the witness chair is threatening, according to a new Justice Department guide.

title: STANDOUT BASKETBALL PLAYER TEACHES BY HIS EXAMPLE
description: In the aftermath of another Miami University basketball game here, interviewers are clustered as usual around Ron Harper, the Redskins' diversely talented 6-foot-6-inch senior forward.

title: CRUDE PRICES CONTINUE PLUNGE
description: Crude oil prices continued to weaken on world markets yesterday, pulled down by the combination of abundant supplies and slack demand.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 22, 1986
description: International Nicaraguan rebels need more aid, in the view of President Reagan, according to a White House official. He said Mr. Reagan had decided to ask Congress for $90 million to $100 million in military and other aid for the insurgents. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Belgian Police Arrest A Suspected Terrorist
description: The Belgian police said today that they had arrested a suspected member of a leftist terrorist group that bombed multinational targets and seized a number of important documents and materials.

title: DEBATE ON OIL TAX AFFECTED
description: With oil prices plunging below $20 a barrel, the debate over a tax on imported oil has taken an important new turn, members of Congress and economists said today.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Revenue
description: b-After an extraoridnary charge of $66,313,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: U.S. SAYS A LONG WAR IN SOUTH YEMEN IS POSSIBLE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that unless an early cease-fire could be worked out between the rival factions in Southern Yemen, the fighting could turn into a protracted civil war.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Tribute to Yul Brynner
description: A memorial tribute to Yul Brynner will be held Jan. 30 at 2:30 P.M. at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Mr. Brynner died in October at the age of 65. Among the people expected to speak are John Frankenheimer, Betty Furness, David Hartman, Mayor Koch, Alan Jay Lerner, Sidney Lumet, Liza Minnelli, Inge Morath, Mrs. Richard Rodgers and Mike Wallace. The tribute is open to the public.

title: MAXICARE HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE ULSTER PATROL: I.R.A. BOMBS AND CRITCS' BARBS
description: This seaside resort town is quiet in winter, and when four members of a largely Protestant paramilitary group headed for an overwhelmingly Roman Catholic housing project one recent night, they had the streets to themselves.

title: NANCY WILSON ROSS, NOVELIST AND EXPERT ON EASTERN RELIGION
description: Nancy Wilson Ross, a novelist and an authority on Eastern religions, died of heart disease Jan. 18 at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. She was 84 years old. From the early 1930's until the late 1950's, Miss Ross wrote some 15 works of fiction, including ''Take the Lightning,'' a novel about malaise and despair in a Western university town; ''I, My Ancestor,'' which ranged from Manhattan's Park Avenue to a sparsely inhabited island near Seattle, and ''The Left Hand Is the Dreamer,'' about a couple in upstate New York whose marriage is shattered when the wife has an affair with an Austrian refugee doctor. Reviewing that book in The New York Times in 1947, Orville Prescott described it as ''tense with the fears and pressures of civilization's agony.''

title: SUIT CHARGES E.P.A. FAILS TO ACT ON AIR POLLUTANTS
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council yesterday asked a Federal District Court to order the Environmental Protection Agency to set standards for eight toxic air pollutants that are known or probable agents of cancer in humans.

title: EASTERN'S BATTLE OVER WAGES
description: Wayne A. Yeoman, the senior vice president of finance at Eastern Airlines, earlier this week pointed to a chart of figures that showed the airline's operating expenses in line or close to other carriers, including low-cost ones - except for wages.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Hunts Point Strike A strike has closed the city-owned Terminal Market in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, which supplies most of the city's independent produce merchants. The strike, which began early Friday, involves a dispute over pay and working hours by members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 202, which includes warehousemen, salesmen and foremen. Although the strike is not expected to affect produce supplies at the large chain supermarkets, hospitals and restaurants, which have different distribution networks, smaller supermarkets and independent greengrocers are already feeling its effects.

title: 2 DECTECTIVES SHOT, ONE FATALLY, AT QUEENS DINER
description: Two plainclothes New York City detectives on organized-crime surveillance were shot last night - one of them fatally - in a sudden encounter with their ''targets'' outside a Queens diner, the police said.

title: Prohibit Call-In Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Gains on the sale of investment securities in 1985 were $92.5 million, compared with $3.6 million in the prior year.

title: U.S. Helps Egypt in Drug War
description: The United States today gave Egypt five vans with sophisticated communications systems for use by narcotics agents fighting drug dealers. The gift was presented to Interior Minister Ahmed Rushdi by Jon Thomas, the Assistant Secretary of State for international narcotics matters, a ministry spokesman said. Egypt, concerned at a rise in heroin and cocaine smuggling, has recently toughened penalties for drug-related offenses and stepped up efforts to curb addiction.

title: AT 8, ROMAN FOOD FROM THE GHETTO
description: ''WE are from Rome, and as children we lived near the ghetto,'' said Paolo Lattanzi. ''We used to go there and eat pezzetti, which is fried codfish with vegetables. We didn't know then that we were eating Jewish food. It was Italian, Roman, the food of my city, and it was very good.''

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for 1985 includes other income of approximately $25.3 million, or 63 cents a share, principally from the settlement of claims and litigation and from a gain on the sale a a subsidiary. Net income for 1984 includes other income of $26.7 million, or 60 cents a share, principally from the disposal of the company's investment in Mesa Petroleum Co. and the settlement of claims and litigation.

title: DUKE LOSES, 87-80, TO GEORGIA TECH
description: Bruce Dalrymple scored 21 points, including four free throws in the final 35 seconds, as Georgia Tech survived a late rally to down Duke, 87-80, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Japan Reviews Euroyen Curbs
description: Japan wants to abolish restrictions on the issuance of Euroyen bonds by non-Japanese companies, Finance Ministry sources said today.

title: Working Profile: Dr. Donald Macdonald; Found: A Warm Heart Among the Bureaucrats
description: Dr. Donald Ian Macdonald sees no point in containing his delight when the hot line rings in his office and the caller is a member of the Cabinet.

title: Dupree Seeks Waiver
description: His college classmates are still in school, and that makes him technically ineligible to join the National Football League, but Marcus Dupree, the running back who dropped out of Oklahoma in 1983 to play for the Breakers of the United States Football League, has asked the league for a waiver to enter the April 29 draft, according to his agent, Ken Fairley. N.F.L. officials said they had not received the request but that it would receive due consideration. About half a dozen eligibility waivers are granted by the league each year, but the players are rarely stars and are usually not picked in the draft, according to the N.F.L. spokesman, Joe Browne. Dupree has not fully recovered from a severe knee injury that knocked him out for most of the 1985 U.S.F.L. season.

title: Dole and Academia
description: If Senator Bob Dole of Kansas is seeking the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, as many people believe, he isn't running on his academic record. The other day he was telling a Topeka luncheon audience that he pays close attention to the biographical details when he is being introduced.

title: COURT REINSTATES INTERNMENT SUIT
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today reinstated a lawsuit brought on behalf of the 120,000 Japanese-Americans who were removed from their homes and detained in camps in World War II.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special net charges of $215,000,000 for the quarter and $252,000,000 for the year and tax credits of $8,000,000 for the quarter, and $36,000,000 for the year. c-Net income including tax credits of $8,000,000 for the quarter and $37,000,000 for the year. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Senator Long, the Critic
description: Politicians who take issue with television documentaries rarely get much opportunity to voice their side of the subject. Occasionally, like the opposition party after a Presidential address, they are allocated a measure of broadcast time afterward.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Most Reliable Method To Fix a Traffic Light
description: A taxicab headed north in Central Park the other day came to a halt at a red light near the East 72d Street exit.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
STATEMENT BY BOROUGH PRESIDENT ON INJURIES
description: Following is the statement released yesterday by Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens:

title: LIBYA SAYS MOVIES HELP ITS ARAB TIES
description: Libya's Foreign Minister said today that United States economic sanctions and threats of military action against Libya had prompted an improvement in Libya's relations with neighboring Tunisia and with other Arab nations with whom ties had been strained.

title: PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY LINKING IMELDA MARCOS TO L.I. ESTATE
description: A Congressional subcommittee investigating investments in the United States by President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, heard testimony today from two lawyers who said they were told Mrs. Marcos owned a Long Island estate and that she intimidated another investor in the property.

title: What Meese Means by Miranda
description: To the Editor:

title: Helms and the Jews
description: Advance publicity for a dinner speech that Senator Jesse Helms is to make tonight at the Capitol Hill Club identifies the North Carolina Republican bluntly as ''the man who many American Jews view as the personification of everything they distrust about conservatism.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Jan. 13 about a report on atmospheric changes misidentified the National Center for Atmospheric Research. It is linked to a consortium of universities and is sponsored by the National Science Foundation; it has no affiliation with the National Academy of Sciences.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $12.2 million for the quarter and $8.6 million for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8.5 million for the quarter and $8.1 million for the year. Year-ago results include a pretax gain of $25.7 million from the sale of land and air rights.

title: Wickes Units Sold
description: The Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell Red Owl Stores, a grocery chain; Snyder Drug Stores, and its Western Diversified Services insurance unit.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $4.7 million for an increase in the provision for loan losses and a gain of $5.1 million on the sale of a building for the quarter and year.

title: SCREEN: 'GLORY DAYS,' GROWING UP IN ENGLAND
description: MAKING movies when you don't know what you're doing is a little like playing with a chemistry set without reading the directions. When mixed in the wrong proportions, perfectly innocuous ingredients may produce unfortunate results, anything from an unexpected explosion to a lingering stink or a gooey mess.

title: HOMELESS AND HUNGRY FOUND IN WORSE PLIGHT
description: Demands for emergency food and shelter rose sharply in most of 25 surveyed cities last year, and in many cases hungry and homeless people were turned away because there was not enough to go around, the United States Conference of Mayors reported today.

title: Chairman to Resign After MGM Sale
description: Frank Rothman said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company upon the closing of the sale of MGM to the Turner Broadcasting Company. He said he would return to private law practice.

title: Oil Decline Spurs Rate Drop
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday as credit market participants were encouraged by the continued decline in oil prices.

title: Shifts by New Owners At Moseley, Hallgarten
description: An Arab investment group that gained a controlling 39 percent stake last week in the Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corporation, parent of an ailing New England retail brokerage house, announced a number of changes in top management yesterday.

title: CITICORP'S EARNINGS DROP 6.9%
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, said yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter fell 6.9 percent, to $243 million.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net credits of about $2,300,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $4.8 million, or 6 cents a share, for the year. c-After a net charge of $20,000,000 to cover writeoffs and shutdown costs related to the closing of a lead anti- knock plant.

title: OVERTIME SURGE SPARKS KNICKS
description: In their days as collegians, the moments when the two shared the court were special ones. Chris Mullin was the subtle, but spectacular guard with an uncanny ability to put the ball in the basket or into the hands of someone else who could. Patrick Ewing was the overpowering center, whose defensive presence alone affected the tone of any game.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a loss from discontinued operations of $96.9 million.

title: STATE OFFICIALS HELD FREE FROM LIABILITY FOR NEGLIGENT ACTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that negligent acts by state officials do not violate the Constitution's guarantee of due process of law, even if they cause serious injuries to prisoners or to other people.

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,856,000 for the quarter and year.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated on a pooling of interests basis for the acquisition of Union Trust Bancorp of Maryland, which was merged Dec. 31, 1985.

title: Invitation To a Crisis
description: By early next week a ''crisis'' will have developed in the Caribbean. By midweek two policy teams of 15 people each -a ''blue'' American side and a ''red'' Soviet one - will gather at Georgetown University to try to resolve the crisis and avert a nuclear war.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The truth of what happened to me on the night of Jan. 9 is as the police have said.

title: Tapes Show Second Pilot Tried to Aid Nelson Plane
description: A commuter plane tried to go to the aid of Rick Nelson's burning DC-3 as the singer's pilot repeatedly pleaded for help, according to radio transcripts made public today.

title: CANCELED CONTRACT SHOWS IMPACT OF POLITICAL TIES
description: The story of how a $22.7 million city computer contract was won and lost provides a glimpse of how influential and knowledgeable former officials are sometimes able to use the system for personal gain.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Re-signed Terry Forster, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: Children's Book Award Is Won by Jean Fritz
description: Jean Fritz, the author of novels and history books for children and young adults, has won the 1986 Laura Ingalls Wilder Medal, it was announced yesterday.

title: Keep the Change
description: Martina Navratilova, whose victory over Claudia Kohde-Kilsch at the Virginia Slims of New England brought her $40,000 closer to career earnings of $10 million: ''I didn't know how much I was going to win until they gave me the check. It's nice not to worry about money.''

title: JONAH PERRY ACQUITTED OF MUGGING OFFICER WHO FATALLY SHOT BROTHER
description: Jonah Perry was acquitted yesterday of mugging a plainclothes police officer in an incident that led to the killing of his younger brother, Edmund, a youth from the streets of Harlem who won honors at Phillips Exeter Academy.

title: NEW CATEGORIES: '85 AUCTION STARS
description: WILL English majolica replace Meissen in collectors' affections now that a record price - $3,850 -was paid last October for an 1890's majolica dish in a sale at William Doyle Galleries?

title: U.S. BANKS FACING OIL PRICE SQUEEZE
description: With the plunge in oil prices to under $20 a barrel, American banks stand to suffer, especially those in Texas and New York.

title: Two Bits of Good News For Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam received two pieces of pleasant news yesterday. It will retain the Nynex Corporation corporate account, which was on the block, and its Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline subsidiary has been designated to handle the direct marketing for American Airlines' five-year-old AAdvantage frequent-flier program.

title: ZITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $90,000. c-Including a loss of $75,000 from discontinued operations.

title: JAPAN LOSES CHIP PRICE RULING
description: The United States International Trade Commission ruled unanimously yesterday that Japanese electronics manufacturers are selling 256K memory chips in the United States for less than the cost of production.

Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change aligning the fiscal years of the foreign semiconductor subsidiaries with the company's fiacal year-end.

description: The Sea-Land Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, under which the shipping and container company would nominate Mr. Simmons and two others selected by him to its board.

description: Three Sikh men were convicted today and sentenced to be hanged for conspiracy and murder in the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

description: Washington has long since stopped gossiping about whether Margaret M. Heckler was pushed out of her post as Secretary of Health and Human Services last fall and, if so, why. Now she is on her way to Ireland as Ambassador and honors are in order.

description: In what appeared to be a carefully balanced package of austerity measures, President Jose Napoleon Duarte has devalued the national currency and sharply raised gasoline prices. But he also granted wage increases and froze prices on basic consumer goods.

description: At least 1,500 jobs will be eliminated this year at the General Electric Company's turbine division in Schenectady, the top local G.E. executive, George Cox, said. ABC WILL PROCEED WITH 'AMERIKA'
description: ABC said yesterday that it had decided to go forward with ''Amerika,'' a mini-series depicting life in the United States after a Soviet takeover. The project had been postponed because of budget problems, but it had also become the subject of controversy after a Soviet warning that ABC News operations in Moscow could be jeopardized if it were broadcast.

description: Chana Krinsky, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yehuda Krinsky of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Rabbi Yosef Y. Futerfas, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Sholom D. Futerfas of London. The company also made a $90 million provision against third-quarter results, bringing the 1985 total to $275 million. The provisions will reduce the carrying value of certain assets that the company did not specify.

title: 34 KILLED IN HOTEL FIRE IN INDIA
description: A fire erupted early today in the banquet hall of a luxury hotel and swept through the building, killing at least 34 people and injuring at least 41 others, police and hospital officials said.

title: MOVE TO LICENSE INTERIOR DESIGNERS
description: A NATIONAL campaign to license interior designers has been undertaken by the American Society of Interior Designers. Officials of the society, a professional organization with 20,000 members, say that although licensing has been discussed for almost 20 years, the increasing complexity of the field makes it more urgent now.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
EASTERN CHIEF ASSESSES CRISIS
description: Eastern Airlines is at the most critical stage in its long struggle for survival. Frank Borman, the chief executive for the last nine years, has weathered a history of crises but acknowledges that this one, heightened by the carrier's determination to permanently slash wage costs, could decide whether the airline survives.
