description: A state appellate court has ruled that parole boards can be held liable for crimes committed by prisoners they release, if they release them in violation of laws governing the boards.

title: COAXING PLANTS INTO TOPIARIES
description: MAYBE you were among the fortunate people who received a lollipop-shaped topiary as a gift, and now you're wondering how to keep this house plant going. Or maybe you didn't, and now you'd like to make this whimsical tree yourself. In any case, coping with an indoor topiary is not difficult, although a dollop of patience will prove a virtue.

title: Mild Flu Season Is Predicted
description: New York City health officials said yesterday that seasonal outbreaks of influenza had begun in the city but they would be comparatively mild and short-lived.

title: THE DANCE: SALLY HESS
description: ''SALLY HESS SOLO DANCES,'' a program performed by Miss Hess on Sunday afternoon at the Douglas Dunn Studio in SoHo, was on one level an expressive exercise for a long, slender torso; long, snaking and curving arms and agile fingers, and long, pliant legs with equally agile toes. On another level, the program offered a telling glimpse of a particular body moving in a particular, luminously framing space.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on Dec. 26 with an article about the Gold and Silver Ball misidentified a guest, shown at the center of a group wearing black dresses. She was Alexis Brashich.

title: FAT OR FIT? STUDY MAY CONFIRM SUSPICIONS IT IS IN THE GENES
description: The perennial debate as to whether fat people are ''born or made'' has been further fueled by a major new study strongly suggesting that heredity, not family environment, plays the main and perhaps only role in determining a person's tendency to be fat or thin.

title: Medicare Makes A Wrong Diagnosis

She has a tube in her stomach and a urinary catheter. She is on morphine around the clock. Surgery has been futile. Her seven-year battle with cancer is finally near the end. But now she has also become the victim of Medicare rules - specifically, diagnosis related groups.

description: A Japanese acupuncturist arrived here today to treat Jim McMahon, the Bears' quarterback.

title: Bristol-Myers Net Up 11.2%
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, a leading manufacturer of drugs, health-care products and toiletries, said yesterday that it earned $130.9 million, or 95 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, up 11.2 percent from $117.7 million, or 86 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Sales rose 9.9 percent, to $1.11 billion, from $1.01 billion.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a loss from discontinued operations of $2.1 million. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $32.6 million and a gain of $92.6 million on the sale of Hertz Corp. d-Including net from discontinued operations of $92.9 million and a credit of $51.7 million from an accounting change.

title: Technology; 'Intelligent' Auto Controls
description: TUNING a car radio, particularly today's button-bedecked models, can be an uncomfortable, even dangerous, undertaking on the highway. Drivers have to take their eyes off the road and look toward the middle of the dashboard to change stations or balance the sound.

title: The Cemetery Called Lebanon
description: Not arms or diplomacy, not weariness or revulsion stay Lebanon's quarreling factions from killing each other. Only cemeteries prosper in Beirut, where the first car-bombing of the year has just added 30 bodies to a decade's appalling toll of 100,000. The bomb exploded near offices of President Amin Gemayel's Phalange Party. Who did it? It could be anyone, since even the Christians are at each other's throats in a civil war within a civil war over a Syrian-backed peace proposal.

title: Ameritech Gains 22.3%
description: Ameritech, the regional telephone holding company based in the Middle West, said yesterday that it earned $248.1 million, or $2.55 a share, in the fourth quarter, up 22.3 percent from $202.9 million, or $2.07 a share, a year earlier.

title: The Color Green
description: The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., an old-line Boston Democrat who has never shied away from the wearing of the green, has proposed dressing up the doormen of the House in new Irish-green blazers.

title: Vacating Sound Tenements Swells the Ranks of the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Day Care, Too, Faces An Insurance Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUG TESTS SET FOR ARMY WORKERS
description: Seven months after the military services were authorized to test civilian employees for drug abuse, the Army has become the first to win final approval for a urinalysis program.

title: FINDING MACINES TO GET IN SHAPE WITH
description: FOR New Yorkers with small apartments, finding home exercise equipment that can be handily stored is almost as important as the exercise regimen itself. According to exercise equipment dealers, consumers with limited space often choose rowing machines as a solution. Most of these are small enough to be stowed into a closet or under the bed or hung on the wall.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including pretax gains of $175,000 for the quarter and $8,823,000 for the year from the sale of property and a tax credit of $450,000 for the year.

title: PLEASURE OF GIVING ARE CITED BY DONORS IN HELPING NEEDIEST
description: The joy of giving and sharing one's good fortune with the needy - the homeless, the ill and the despairing -is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Johnson Controls Names Key Officer
description: Johnson Controls Inc., a Milwaukee-based electronic instrument manufacturer that widened its business base last year through a series of acquisitions, announced yesterday that James H. Keyes had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: What to Assume About Donald Manes
description: With his hoarse, halting sickbed statement, Queens Borough President Donald Manes has defanged some of the mystery concerning the near-fatal stab wounds he suffered on the night of Jan. 9. It could not have been easy for a man dependent on the voters' good opinion to have admitted that he cut himself. Yet much mystery remains.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT SLOW 2.4% RATE IN FINAL QUARTER
description: The nation's economy grew at a sluggish rate of 2.4 percent from Oct. 1 to Dec. 31 last year, much more slowly than last month's official estimate for the period, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 'THAT OLD TIME RELIGION' IS EXPLORED ON 'CURRENTS'
description: ''CURRENTS,'' Channel 13's worthwhile documentary series, takes on a highly charged theme - the significance of the fundamental and evangelical church movements in the United States. ''That Old Time Religion,'' shown tonight at 8:30, treats the theme a little too gingerly.

title: STAGE: AT VILLAGE GATE, 'EL GRANDE DE COCA-COLA'
description: ''EL GRANDE DE COCA-COLA'' has returned to New York with a partly new version of the popular 1973 musical revue, a classic of fractured Spanish and splintered tomfoolery. A knowledge of the language -or of any language - is not necessary for one to enjoy the show. It is muy ridiculo y histerico, somewhat in the manner of Monty Python, and a great deal of the fun is physical comedy. The musical revue opened last night at the Village Gate.

title: CENTER SHELTERS INJURED ANIMALS
description: Where nature fails, the TreeHouse Wildlife Center steps in, caring for orphaned and injured wild animals and preparing them to return to the wilderness.

title: URANUS SYSTEM 'UNLIKE ANYTHING WE HAVE SEEN'

HIGH COURT RULES ON INTENT IN DEATH PENALTY CASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today by a 5-to-4 vote that the Constitution does not bar imposition of the death penalty on a murder defendant whom neither the jury nor the trial judge specifically found to have acted with intent to kill.

title: More Than a Parking Scandal
description: ''Sidney'' - the cutely named Summons-Issuing Device for New York - might well bring computer efficiency to the writing of parking tickets and the pursuit of scofflaws. But from what is known so far about the contracting for Sidney, it was pushed past a napping City Hall by politicians more interested in their private interests than the public's.

title: Killer of 3 Sentenced
description: A karate expert convicted of first-degree murder in the killings of three elderly women was sentenced today to death in the electric chair. A jury deliberated 45 minutes before returning the death sentence against the defendant, Roland Steele of Canonsburg, 39 years old.

title: DRYFOOS NAMED TO BE CHAIRMAN OF A COMMITTEE
description: The new leadership of the City Council yesterday gave Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos - the Democrat of Manhattan whose surprise vote put them in power - the chairmanship of the Committee on State Legislation.

FOR SMALL BATHROOMS
description: A BATHROOM need not be large to accommodate such bathroom amenities as the whirlpool bath, spa bath, sauna or steam shower. Many models come in standard sizes. The city athlete with limited apartment space does not have to envy the suburban one.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FIRE IN HEAVEN. By Malcolm Bosse. 654 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. THAILAND. 1948. A girl is watching frozen with fascination as a crocodile emerges from a pond and approaches her erect on its hind feet, gazing with a single ''round and gentle eye.'' She awakens from her nightmare, recalls the equally disturbing sight she once beheld of two women making love, and begins to describe the experience to an imaginary friend. One of the women was her mother, she explains, but you have to understand that she suffered greatly during the Russian Civil War, having had to walk ''thousands of kilometers across Siberia, when she was no older than we are.''

title: BEHIND CUOMO'S ACTIONS: INSTINCT AND CALCULATION
description: Governor Cuomo questioned whether there was a Mafia. He summoned the Legislature into special session, only to see lawmakers reject all but one of his proposals and go home the same day.

title: Texaco-Pennzoil
description: The Justice Department said it had decided not to take a stand in the legal battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company over Texaco's acquisition of the Getty Oil Company in 1984. The department had been asked separately by each side to file a brief in favor of its position in the pending appeal of a Federal District Court's recent ruling in favor of Texaco.

GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECONSTRUCTION They may not have been the Andrews Sisters of their day, which was 400 years ago, but the ''three ladies of Ferrara'' were three professional sopranos, a combination called ''concerto delle donne.'' Tonight at 8 o'clock, a program re-creates the popular trio, with selections written expressly for their talents, at Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7800).

title: Buying Brutality in Liberia
description: American taxpayers need to look closely at Liberia, where they are being made to prop up the bloody dictatorship of Gen. Samuel K. Doe. The list of his victims is long and growing. But his misrule can be understood from the single case of Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, a United States-trained economist and former Liberian Finance Minister.

title: Thorn Is Appointed
description: Rod Thorn, the former general manager of the Chicago Bulls, was named vice president for operations of the National Basketball Association yesterday. He succeeds Scotty Stirling, who left to replace Dave DeBusschere as vice president and general manager of the Knicks.

title: Shuttle to Nowhere
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel has a problem: if he cannot soon find a credible issue over which to call a new election, he will have to keep his word and turn over his office to his coalition partners of the right in September.

title: HERS
description: WELL, the 48th International PEN Congress is over, and all around the world writers are regarding their typewriters with unwonted surges of affection. I know I am. How friendly my Olympia Report Electric seems now, with its expectant little hum, compared to the jostling of world-class literary egos in plenary sessions, panels and parties. How inviting my drab and heatless little study compared to the glittering hotels in which the conference was held. The 48th International PEN congress, I am trying to say, was not about poetry, fiction, plays, essays and editing. Like most gatherings involving the words ''international'' or ''congress,'' it was about money, power, celebrity and politics.

title: Japan Aide Quotes Reagan on United
description: The Japanese Finance Minister, Noboru Takeshita, told President Reagan he would try to resolve a problem holding up United Airlines service to Tokyo. Mr. Takeshita said that at a White House meeting the President had quoted the airline's slogan, ''Fly the Friendly Skies of United,'' and said he wanted the problem resolved in a friendly manner.

title: Arms Negotiators Meet
description: American and Soviet negotiators specializing in strategic nuclear weapons met today for the first time since the arms talks resumed last week. The United States delegation issued a brief statement saying the meeting had lasted two hours and 45 minutes.

title: GIGA-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARMY ONCE BARRED FILES ON MARCOS
description: More than two years ago, the United States Army barred an opponent of Ferdinand E. Marcos from looking at files of the guerrilla unit said to have been headed by Mr. Marcos in World War II, according to Federal officials.

title: INTERNATIONAL TOTALIZATOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $389,000 for the quarter and $609,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special net charge of $1.8 million related to severance and employment contract obligations arising from recent management changes. c-Net loss, after a special net charge of $3.8 million.

title: ST. JOHN'S GRABS EARLY LEAD AND COASTS
description: In a game that Coach Lou Carnesecca called one of the worst - in spots -that his team has played all season, St. John's defeated Fordham, 56-47, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: BARD COLLEGE WILL SLASH FEES TO TOP STUDENTS
description: Bard College, hoping to recruit some of the nation's top public high school seniors, has approved a scholarship program that will cut their costs at Bard to exactly what they would pay at a public college in their home state.

title: Living Up to a Slogan
description: A large sign on the Brooklyn Bridge seen traveling from Manhattan proclaims: ''Brooklyn. A nice place to visit, a great place to live!''

title: Chrysler Mini-Van
description: The Chrysler Corporation will start assembling mini-vans at its St. Louis plant in Fenton, Mo., early next year, company officials said.

title: E.P.A. WON'T BAN USE OF CHEMICAL ON APPLES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would permit the continued but limited use of the chemical daminozide on apples and other foods because it had so far been unable to determine if it posed a significant risk of cancer.

title: 2 Officers Say Sergeant In Hit-Run Was Sober
description: Two New York City police officers testified yesterday that a police sergeant on trial for manslaughter did not appear drunk on the night of a fatal hit-and-run accident last year.

title: MUSIC: TORADZE, PIANO, IN CARNEGIE HALL RECITAL
description: THERE is no easy set of rules for judging a musician's worth, but any evaluation must take into consideration what may be termed the four T's: technique, temperament, tone and taste. A close follower of the concert scene could give you a list of artists who were deficient in one or another of these areas but built famous careers, nonetheless. It is, in fact, a paragon who can rate high everywhere on the T-scale. At the moment, Alexander Toradze is not one of the rare ones.

title: PROFIT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 23, 1986
description: The Economy

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a joint venture of Corning Glass Works and the Dow Chemical Company.

title: RCA Net Fell 8.2% in Quarter, but Gained in Year
description: RCA Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 8.2 percent, to $94.4 million. The result was generally in line with analysts' expectations and an RCA forecast made earlier this month in a proxy statement for its planned purchase by the General Electric Company.

title: A.T.&T. GIVES PUPILS HELP WITH HOMEWORK
description: Sixth graders at Milliones Middle School are getting extra help with their math homework this week. Employees of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are reaching out and tutoring them at home over the telephone.

title: Houston Bank in Loss
description: Texas Commerce Banchares today reported a $28.8 million loss for the fourth quarter, in contrast to earnings of $44.7 million for the 1984 quarter.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROBERT MacFARLAN COLE
description: Robert MacFarlan Cole, a chemist who helped develop Freon and its use as a refrigerant and an aerosol propellant, died Saturday.

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AIR-INDIA BOMB CALLED LIKELY
description: Canadian investigators have found that a bomb explosion was the probable cause of the crash of an Air-India jet in June that killed all 329 people aboard, a Canadian scientist testified today.

title: PNEUMATIC SCALE CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $256,659. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,036,464.

title: Dart & Kraft Gains 2.9%
description: Dart & Kraft Inc., the food and commercial products company, said today that fourth-quarter earnings were $129.1 million, or 89 cents a share, up 2.9 percent from $125.5 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Simple Answer
description: Leonard Campbell, an official of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, explains why the association has no N.C.A.A.-type enforcement personnel on the nationwide level: ''Money is what corrupts, and we don't have enough money.''

title: 11 Convicted in Chicago In Medicaid Fraud Case
description: Eleven doctors and medical workers were found guilty today of defrauding the Medicaid system out of $20 million.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge; An Ugly Duck Saves the Day In Land of the Ugly Duckling
description: The town of Odense in Denmark was once the home of Hans Christian Andersen, creator of the Ugly Duckling and other memorable characters.

title: Sekanovich Is Hired
description: Dan Sekanovich, assistant coach for the Atlanta Falcons for the past three seasons, has been hired as defensive line coach for Miami, replacing Mike Scarry, who retired earlier this month after 16 years with the Dolphins. Sekanovich, 52 years old, was credited with developing the famed ''New York Sack Exchange'' during his six seasons with the Jets, from 1977 to 1982. The Jets led the league in sacks in 1981 with 66.

title: CONCERT: DANIEL McKELWAY
description: DANIEL MCKELWAY is a fluent, elegant and musical oboist, and his Tuesday night concert at the 92d Street Y was, in the main, deeply satisfying. Mr. McKelway does not exult in his virtuosity for its own sake, but rather uses it as the means to an expressive end, adapting it to the contours of whatever musical esthetic is at hand.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $56.5 million from secondary offering of IP Timberlands Ltd. Partnership Class A units and a pretax charge of $11.6 million for facility closures. c-Net loss after a pretax charge of $155 million for adjustments to facilities and investments. d-After a pretax charge of $29 million for the company's early retirement program, plus a $1.6 million restatement for the cumulative effect, to Dec. 31, 1984, of a change in accounting for cost of timber harvested. e-After a pretax charge primarily for anticipated losses from the sale or closing of certain wood products manufacturing facilities and expected losses on West Coast timber leases.

title: COMSERV CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $1 million for the quarter and $700,000 for the year from tax credits and redemption of debentures. c-Net losses. Net loss for the prior year reflects a charge of $12,833,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: EDWARD F. CALLAN
description: Edward F. Callan, a senior partner in the law firm of Putney Twombly Hall & Hirson, died Tuesday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 67 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I..

title: 4 Schoolchildren Killed By Soldiers in Uganda
description: Several people, including four schoolchildren, were shot dead by Government soldiers today after clashes with rebels on the edge of Kampala, residents said.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a non-recurring pre-tax charge in the quarter and the 6 months of $1.6 million to provide for an estimated loss on an anticipated June 1986 sale of the major portion of the company's unoccupied facilities in Watsonville, Calif.; and including tax credits of $2,592,000 for the quarter and $3,758,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses. The year-ago figures are restated to include the results of the company's thin film media subsidiary, Seagate Magnetics, formerly Grenex Inc.

title: Hyundai's $25 Million Campaign
description: THIS week, as Hyundai Motor America prepared for the introduction of its low-cost South Korean automobile and the $25 million ad campaign that will promote it, the people at its agency, Backer & Spielvogel, were pitching to Hyundai's three dealer organizations in hopes of landing an additional $20 million in billings.

title: 12 Hurt in Plane Shakeup
description: A United Airlines jet on its way from Chicago to San Francisco hit severe turbulence over Utah today, injuring at least 12 people, airport officials said. Flight 127, a DC-8 carrying 138 passengers and a crew of six, landed safely in San Francisco, where medical personnel helped carry the injured off, according to an airport spokesman, Ron Wilson.

title: Talks Continue On Outlet Deal
description: The deadline for an investor group to buy the Outlet Company from the Rockefeller Group passed yesterday without a deal, but Wall Street sources said the talks were continuing.

title: NETS LOSE
description: Micheal Ray Richardson sat in a corner of the dressing room tonight and heaved a sigh of relief: his return to the Nets was over. His performance was spotty, and his teammates played unevenly in a 137-124 loss to the Denver Nuggets.

title: Jail Delay In Thrift Case
description: Maryland's highest court has temporarily delayed jail terms for the owner of Old Court Savings and Loan and his wife so it can review their contempt of court convictions.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PANEL DIFFERS WITH TWO ECLIPSE CHOICES
description: The authors of the Experimental Free Handicap, the prestigious annual rating of thoroughbred racing's newly turned 3-year-olds, sharply disagreed today with the results of last week's Eclipse Award balloting for 2-year-olds.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis.

title: COMMERCIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A COMBINATION OF GYM AND BATH, THE LATEST IN HOME AMENITIES
description: MANY decades after labor-saving devices were introduced into the American home, hard physical labor seems to be back, having returned in style in the form of the home gymnasium.

title: Reagan the Volunteer
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, have agreed to serve as honorary chairmen of the United Way Centennial next year. And in a letter accepting the post, the President disclosed that it was, indeed, the United Way that helped him become an advocate of what he now calls ''voluntarism.''

title: U.S. WANTS WORLD BANK TO LEND $2 BILLION MORE
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States expected to see a ''growing stream'' of World Bank loans to the third world this year in support of ''privatization, open markets and increased savings and investment.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Constance Harper, a long-time associate of Don King, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison following her conviction for attempted evasion of taxes on money skimmed from King's boxing promotions. King was acquitted of similar charges by the Federal jury that convicted Miss Harper last November. . . . Keith Byars, the Ohio State tailback who missed much of the season after breaking a bone in his right foot, was in Columbus, Ga., for corrective surgery at the Hughston Sports Medicine Hospital yesterday.

title: Sperry Net Up 10.9% in Period
description: The Sperry Corporation, citing strength in its commercial computer operations, said yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter of 1986 increased 10.9 percent, to $67.9 million, or $1.20 a share, from $61.2 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier.

title: ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
FOR BRITAIN, CALLS TO CURB PRODUCTION
description: With oil prices dropping sharply, Britain is under increasing pressure to change both its energy policy and its economic plans.

title: Ohio Tax-Exempt Issue Has a 6%-8.30% Range
description: New tax-exempt bond issues continue to be well received, despite questions among securities dealers and investors about the future tax status of the bonds.

title: FIRST MIDWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $140,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $182,000 for the quarter and $575,000 for the year.

title: PASSING MUSTER IN BRAZIL: PRESIDENT WOOS ARMY
description: It was a formal yet friendly occasion, with the 143 men in white dress uniforms and decorations enthusiastically applauding their guest of honor's stern warning that ''anarchy and civil disobedience'' would not be tolerated.

title: S.I. GRAND JURY FINDS FAILINGS IN ETHICS RULES
description: A Staten Island grand jury has sharply criticized the City Charter's provisions on conflict of interest by public officials and the policies and procedures of the city's Board of Ethics.

title: Rolls-Royce Unit's Changes
description: Rolls-Royce Motors Inc., the American subsidiary of the British luxury car company, said yesterday that Robert Schwartz, vice president of sales and marketing, had been named president and chief executive.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: MILITARY GETS STUDENT AID LIST
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett agreed today to give the Selective Service System the names of applicants for student aid to help the military track down young men who are not registered for the draft.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its enrolled actuary recommended certain changes in actuarial assumptions used to compute 1985 pension expense for USAir, and these changes had the effect of increasing its fourth quarter and 1985 net earnings by $13.6 million.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS AND SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include pretax gains from the sale of land of $624,000 for the latest 6 months and $175,000 for the year- ago 6 months.

title: REAGAN URGES SENATE TO CLEAR CONRAIL SALE
description: President Reagan, leading an Administration drive to save his proposal to sell the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $1.2 billion, has told the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, in a letter that ''now is the time'' for the Senate to approve the $1.2 billion sale.

title: PENN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHY SOME WOODS CHANGE COLOR
description: After long exposure to air and light, highly pigmented woods that have not been finished tend to fade. Others darken because of oxidation of their pigments. Some period furniture in walnut, mahogany, cherry or maple was given a coat of oil - sometimes with color added - and a coat of clear varnish. This treatment helps the darkening process somewhat. One wood guaranteed to hold its original color with consistency is the whitest wood of all - holly.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges for investment and asset provisions of $115.6 million. c-Net income, after charges for investment and asset provisions of $18 million.

title: Clock's Secret Wins by a Neck
description: Clock's Secret, the favorite of the Aqueduct turnout of 10,188, set a blistering early pace with fractions of 21 2/5 seconds and 44 3/5 yesterday on her way to a front-running victory in the $36,000 Evening Glow Handicap for fillies and mares.

title: 4 Arrested in Canada As U.S. Missile Is Tested
description: An unarmed United States cruise missile was launched from a B-52 bomber over the Beaufort Sea today on a 1,500-mile test flight across northwest Canada.

title: CLAMS AND OYSTERS IN THE EAST HIT HARD BY MYSTERY DISEASES
description: Since the invention of mechanical clam rigs 25 years ago, the fishermen of this isthmus town each year have dug hundreds of bushels of clams off the Castle Haven sand bar in the Choptank River near here.

title: WAR, PEACE AND CARL MYDANS
description: ''When people see the picture of General MacArthur wading to the beach, they wonder how many times did he do that,'' said Carl Mydans, the photographer who snapped the historic picture of MacArthur's return to the Philippines more than 40 years ago. The occasion was Mr. Mydans's exhibition of his photographs from more than three decades entitled ''A Photojournalist's Journey Through War and Peace,'' which begins tomorrow and runs through March 8 at the International Center of Photography's midtown gallery, at 77 West 45th Street. MacArthur 'Did Not Pose'

title: Coleco Results
description: Coleco Industries expects its 1985 sales to be about level with 1984's $775 million, while earnings are expected to achieve ''record levels,'' the company's chairman, Arnold C. Greenberg, said in a letter to shareholders. He said the company -which lost $79.8 million in 1984, mostly because of its discontinued Adam computer - ended 1985 with no short-term bank debt and $110 million in cash and equivalents. Coleco, noted for its successful Cabbage Patch Doll line, also said it would begin shipping its Rambo doll this spring.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mack Picks Site In South Carolina
description: Mack Trucks Inc., the nation's second-largest heavy-truck maker, said it had chosen Winnsboro, S.C., for an $80 million assembly plant, replacing one that has operated here in the Lehigh Valley for 60 years. The company announced the decision after a meeting in New York of the executive finance committee of the company's board, Don Miller, Mack's governmental affairs director, said.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $6,654,000 for the quarter and year from a company- wide review of assets and operations. c-Net income.

title: Men Emerging As Leaders In NOW Ranks
description: THE recent election of Dr. Robert Seidenberg as the first male president of the Greater Syracuse Chapter of the National Organization for Women inspired an editorial-page cartoon in a local newspaper. It showed a bearded man, wearing a dress and high-heeled pumps, being sworn into office by a woman in a man's pin-striped suit.

title: DOW TUMBLES BY 12.16, TO 1,502.29
description: The Dow Jones industrial average sank close to the 1,500 level yesterday as recently strong technology stocks joined the already weak oil and banking sectors in driving the market sharply lower to its fourth consecutive loss.

title: MUSIC: ELINOR AMLEN SINGS
description: THE song recital Elinor Amlen gave at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night was devoted entirely to the works of one composer, Mona Hector, and the program was supported in part by a grant from Meet the Composer, a new-music organization.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Panel Revokes Licenses Of Two Hyatt Engineers
description: A state board today revoked the licenses of two engineers convicted of gross negligence for their part in designing the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City, Mo., where skywalks collapsed and killed 114 people in 1981.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax loss of $868,000 and a credit of $1.6 million for previously paid income taxes. c-Net income.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from operations of distributed properties of $213,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,061,000, or 34 cents a share, for the year. c-Net losses after a loss from operations of distributed properties of $5,000 for the quarter, income from operations of distributed properties of $2,053,000 for the year and a charge of approximately $7 million for the quarter and year for a federal timber contract 'buy out' expense.

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $5,722,000 for the quarter and $8,900,000 for the year.

title: VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $366,000 from the sale of aviation operations. d-Including a tax credit of $1,240,000.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Working Profile:Elliott Abrams; The Man Not to Invite To Your Revolution
description: In a rare, unguarded moment, Elliott Abrams will say that he has been a counterrevolutionary since his undergraduate days at Harvard.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROLLINS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier share earnings was restated for a 2-for-1 stock split issued Sept. 25, 1985.

title: Nurses in Pennsylvania Strike State Facilities
description: More than half of Pennsylvania's nearly 3,500 state-employed nurses and other health care workers went on strike today, setting up picket lines at hospitals and other facilities.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PORTABLE power tools keep getting lighter, more efficient and more versatile as the years go by. Many of the newest models now have built-in rechargeable batteries that supply the power needed - thus freeing the user from dragging around a long extension cord. One of the latest such tools is described below, as well as other new products that will appeal to those who work around the house. Combination Tool

title: 8 ZOO ANIMALS ARE STOLEN
description: Eight animals were stolen late Tuesday from the Central Park Children's Zoo, and officials said yesterday that the animals might have been taken for religious sacrifice.

title: PRICES UP 0.4% IN DECEMBER
description: Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Government reported today. The increase was less than many economists had predicted after the November rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index.

title: VERMONT FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $108,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday, about a crisis simulation exercise at Georgetown University, misstated attendance rules. The program simulation is open to invited guests only.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONTADORA IS DEAD ONLY IF WASHINGTON KILLS IT
description: To the Editor:

title: SAILOR IS ON TRIAL IN SLAYING OF A NAVY OFFICER
description: An eight-member military jury was selected today for the court-martial of a black sailor who fatally stabbed a white officer at sea, a case in which the defense says the Navy is seeking the death penalty.

title: FULLER IS PREPARED TO START FOR BEARS
description: After seven years in the National Football League, Steve Fuller is a happy man and the backup quarterback for the Chicago Bears. And after seven years and three teams, Fuller has no desire to change.

title: FED LOSES 'NON-BANK' BANK CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 0, that the Federal Reserve Board has no authority to regulate or restrict so-called limited-service banks.

title: MID-JANUARY SALES OF NEW CARS JUMPED 18.1%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rebounded in the Jan. 11-20 period with the major manufacturers today reporting an 18.1 percent increase compared with the corresponding period in 1985.

title: TWAIN AND HARTE PAPERS AT THE MORGAN LIBRARY
description: Mark Twain and Bret Harte, two of America's renowned authors, were not exactly pen pals. Their paths crossed as San Francisco journalists and storytellers, and they admired each other - until they collaborated on a play, produced in 1877, called ''Ah Sin.'' Long afterward, when Henry James asked Twain if he was acquainted with Harte, he replied, ''Yes, I know the son of a bitch.''

title: Farmers Act to Block New U.S. Rules on Loans
description: Farmers have asked a Federal district judge to prevent the Farmers Home Administration from acting under new rules that the farmers say could cause a wave of foreclosures.

title: EVIDENCE OF MAGNETIC FIELD IS FOUND
description: The Voyager 2 spacecraft today was detecting radio emissions from Uranus, the first clear evidence of the planet's extensive magnetic field, as it sped toward a historic rendezvous with the planet on Friday.

title: CASEY'S SPEECH ON FIGHTING TERROR
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on terrorism given by William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, last April at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University:

title: U.S. RIGHTS CHIEF QUITS SAN DIEGO JOB
description: The chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights resigned today as head of a San Diego development organization in light of a Federal agency's questions about his business dealings.

title: D'AMATO PICKS EX-PROSECUTOR FOR U.S. POST
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he had recommended Andrew Maloney, a Manhattan lawyer and a former Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, to be the United States Attorney in Brooklyn.

title: Bridge: Poor Discarding by Defense Throws Opportunity Away
description: A major embarrassment for the defenders occurs when bad discarding turns the declarer's sure loser into a winner and gives him his contract. In the post-mortem, too late, the defenders work out where they went wrong.

title: Mary Whitehouse, 90, Leader of Civic Groups
description: Mary Crocker Alexander Whitehouse, one of the first women elected to the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a prominent figure in many civic and charitable activities, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old and also lived in Newport, R.I.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A THOUSAND MEOWS Some 46.3 million cats now live in 27.2 percent of American homes, and 75 percent of New York area pet owners keep a cat in their household. There will be 1,000 more cats in the neighborhood starting today at 2, when the second International Cat Show opens at Madison Square Garden, continuing through Sunday night. The visitors from around the world - both purebreds and household tabbies - will compete in what has been called the world's largest international feline forum. Among this year's novelties are six breeds that New Yorkers will see for the first time. The Garden Cat Club, which is producing this extravaganza, is a not-for-profit organization with the goal of promoting educated pet ownership, supporting local shelters and fostering advances in veterinary medicine. Today's events end at 9; tomorrow and Sunday's events run from 10 to 7. Tickets are $7 today, $8 tomorrow and $10 Sunday; a three-day combination ticket is available for $20, and a two-day weekend ticket is $15. Tickets for children and the elderly are $4 today and tomorrow; $5 Sunday. Information: 564-4400. No dogs allowed.

title: WHY NOT A TEST BAN?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has extended the Soviet moratorium on nuclear testing until the end of March to induce the United States to stop testing. A House resolution calling on the Administration to resume negotiations for a complete nuclear test ban has 207 Congressional co-sponsors, and is sure of passage. A similar resolution was passed by the Senate.

title: EVERETT R. CLINCHY, ONE OF THE FOUNDERS OF ECUMENICAL UNIT
description: Everett R. Clinchy, a founder and former president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, died Wednesday at the Branford Hills Health Center in Guilford, Conn. He was 89 years old and lived in Guilford.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rockefeller Group
description: Negotiations for the Rockefeller Group to sell its Outlet Company broadcast subsidiary to a group of investors have broken off after lingering tax issues could not be resolved, according to sources close to the situation. The investor group, which reportedly was willing to pay between $600 million and $650 million for the subsidiary, consisted of Outlet's management, Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the investors Melvin Simon and Jay A. Pritzker.

title: Conrail Bill Advances
description: Prodded by an appeal from President Reagan, the Senate voted today, 90 to 7, to consider the proposed sale of Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad, to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: SENATOR SEES FUTURE CUTS IN SOCIAL SECURITY RISE
description: Alan K. Simpson, the Senate Republican whip, said today that the deficit reduction required under the new budget-balancing law would eventually force Congress to consider cutting the cost-of-living increase for Social Security benefits.

title: Tribute to Dr. King
description: A concert tribute to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., featuring music by the violinist Malcolm Goldstein and the saxophonist Archie Shepp, will take place tonight at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street (255-5793). The musicians will include the saxophonists David Murray and Henry Threadgill, the percussionist Denardo Coleman and the composers. Doors open at 8 P.M., with music at 9:30; tickets are $7.

title: Young William Yeats
description: ''Cauldron,'' a play about the poet William Butler Yeats in his youth, will be presented this weekend at the Irish Arts Center, 553 West 51st Street.

title: PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a non-recurring credit of $9 million from the reversal of deferred taxes on Disc income and the effect of a non-recurring $1.6 million writedown of Compeda goodwill.

title: 30 YEARS LATER, AN EX-MOUNTIE ADMITS A BETRAYAL
description: Until the former Mountie appeared on a Canadian television show disguised in a wig and false mustache a few years ago, the Government didn't seem to be very interested that he had disclosed the identity of a Canadian double agent to the Soviet Union.

title: CONVERSION QUESTIONED AT TOWERS
description: With large green numbers on a new tan canopy, 185 West End Avenue sets itself apart from the cluster of eight yellow-brick buildings that make up the huge Lincoln Towers development on the Upper West Side. The building at 185 - with new sliding glass doors and a lobby newly decorated in gray and mauve - is the most visible evidence that change is under way at Lincoln Towers.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN BACKS ALIEN BILL
description: The White House today reaffirmed its support for a comprehensive immigration bill, even though President Reagan's economic advisers have warned that certain provisions in the legislation would harm the economy.

title: Dow Jones Net Up
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that it had earned $40.9 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985, up 18.9 percent from $34.4 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Evening of Comedy
description: An evening featuring six young comedians is planned for tomorrow at 7 at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

title: Canadian Concedes His Alert On Terrorist Bomb Was Hoax
description: A Canadian who told the police that a bomb might be planted by a Libyan sympathizer on a United States-bound jet last weekend has admitted that it was a hoax, the police said.

title: Great Western
description: In its latest effort to acquire the Citadel Holdings Corporation, the Great Western Financial Corporation filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission proposing an exchange of stock worth about $145 million. Great Western plans to offer 1.2 shares of its common stock for each share of Citadel's common stock, on the condition that a minimum of 1.8 million shares, or 51 percent, of Citadel's outstanding shares are tendered.

title: Office Expansion to Outer Boroughs Squeezes Manufacturers
description: To the Editor:

title: THATCHER ADMITS THAT HER OFFICE DISCLOSED AN EMBARRASSING LETTER
description: In what was possibly her most difficult afternoon in the House of Commons since she became Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher acknowledged today that the disclosure of a letter that embarrassed a member of her Government had been authorized by her own office.

title: TWO VIEWS OF NEW YORK, ONE THAT ROTATES
description: TWO of the latest places from which to admire New York by looking down on it are Broadway hotels a few blocks apart. There's the brand new Marriott Marquis at 45th Street, with lounges and a restaurant that revolve in stately fashion - apparently the first perambulating premises in town. And there is the year-old, French-owned Novotel at 52d, whose Wine Bistro stands still.

title: MUSIC: AIR FORCE GROUP
description: THE United States Air Force Symphony Orchestra came to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday to present ''An Evening of 20th-Century American Music.'' This turned out to be, essentially, a program of works by Larry Alan Smith prefaced by Copland's ''Fanfare for the Common Man'' and Arthur Foote's ''Four Character Pieces After the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam.''

title: Eastern Wage Action
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it would cut the salaries of 17,000 nonunion workers by 20 percent on Feb. 1 and require the employees to work more hours to help to trim costs and avoid loan defaults.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges in Alien Case
description: A Federal District judge refused today to dismiss smuggling charges against 11 church workers on trial here for offering sanctuary to Central American aliens.

title: A WINTER SHOW OF ANTIQUES TO WARM A COLLECTOR'S HEART
description: Birds and beasts are dramatizing many of this year's displays at the Winter Antiques Show - just waiting for collectors to hunt them down. But there's lots more at this antiques extravaganza, the nation's most important bazaar for secondhand wares. The booths of the 74 participating dealers are chock-full of pedigree French and English furniture, fragile porcelain figurines, Renaissance bronzes, folk art and exquisitely crafted 19th-century toys.

title: AT A CHURCH IN DARIEN, APOLOGIES AND REGRETS FOR A PREJUDICED PAST
description: From within the crowd, an older white woman slowly lifted her hand, cleared her throat and rose to address a tall black man leading the discussion group.

title: ART: DIETER HACKER, PAINTINGS AND SCULPTURE
description: DIETER HACKER is a veteran of the 1982 Berlin roundup, ''Zeitgeist,'' as well as of several one-man exhibitions, most of them in West Germany. But the show now at Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, marks only his second appearance in New York (his third in the United States) and, as such, requires more background than is supplied by Norman Rosenthal's catalogue essay.

title: Market Place; Merrill Action Stumps Street
description: MERRILL LYNCH has 5 million customers, 9,525 brokers and 99 securities analysts.

title: Cohn Back in Court
description: Roy M. Cohn, who has been absent from courtrooms because of illness, argued some pretrial motions yesterday in the Mafia commission case in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: SURVEY FINDS SPLIT ON DRUG PROBLEM
description: Almost half the players polled who had an opinion believe there is a drug problem in the National Football League, according to the results of a Players Association survey announced today.

title: MORE JITTERS IN THE OIL MARKETS
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products dropped again yesterday on the world markets after Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, said that oil prices could fall to $15 a barrel unless non-OPEC producers agreed to cooperate in restraining oil production.

title: Economic Scene; Analysts' View Of G.N.P. Data
description: AT first sight, the new official data on the economy's growth last year look disappointing.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect special nonrecurring costs of $29 million for the quarter and $60 million for the year associated with staff reductions, organizational restructuring, discontinuation of certain product lines and writedown of obsolete inventory and equipment in the semiconductor products sector, Four-Phase Systems Inc. and Tegal Corp.

title: Diner's Journal
description: YOU suspect you may have had one too many shots of sake. Don't fret, the three video monitors above the sushi bar at Cafe 212, showing simultaneous scenes of Japanese surfers, are just part of the show. This polymorphic restaurant - part Japanese, part French - is worth considering for a quick lunch in the midtown area, especially if you are dining alone. The striking modern dining room is done in soft shades of rose and pink with a spacious sushi bar in the front and tables in the back. Another dining area is upstairs. Solitary diners will find the sushi bar particularly accommodating because it is wide enough to hold a newspaper or magazine while eating.

title: GRAY AREAS OF ETHICS
description: The widening Federal investigation into lucrative contracts awarded to private companies by a city agency has raised new and troubling questions about the proper role of elected officials - and political officials - in the city's business dealings.

title: U.S. VOICES FEARS FRAUD COULD MAR PHILIPPINE VOTING
description: Senior Administration officials and members of Congress expressed serious concern today over whether the Philippine presidential elections Feb. 7 would be fraudulent.

title: FILM: JAGLOM'S 'ALWAYS'
description: ''ALWAYS,'' Henry Jaglom's fifth and most amiable film to date, is set in the Los Angeles of today, but its sensibilities are rooted in the 1960's, the decade of the so-called film explosion, when anyone with access to a camera could call himself a film maker. It brings back that era when movies, somewhat prematurely, were being championed as the only true art of the 20th century, and when nothing was thought to be so banal that it couldn't be made significant simply by being recorded on film.

title: SAUDI ARABIA PLAYS HIGH-STAKES GAME
description: Just a few months ago, the so-called oil weapon was deemed irretrievably blunted. But suddenly, and in a new guise, Saudi Arabia seems to have brought it back with a vengeance.

title: Tournament Revisions
description: Before the first Big Apple National Invitation Tournament got to the Big Apple for the final rounds at Madison Square Garden last fall, the early rounds of the preseason college basketball tournament proved to be small potatoes. With regional doubleheaders held in four neutral cities, attendance was disappointing.

title: Torpedo From the White House
description: Two striking facts characterize the national debate over immigration reform. First, how remarkably bipartisan is the support. Second, how remarkably bipartisan is the opposition - opposition that could now be deadly unless President Reagan himself speaks out.

title: STANDARD OIL CO (OHIO)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $1.15 billion. c-Net income. d-After extraordinary charges of $50 million.

title: Big East Leaders
description: At his pace of 17.8 points a game this season, Rafael Addison looks like a good bet to break Dave Bing's career scoring record at Syracuse University - if not during the 11 games remaining in the regular season, then during the tournaments. These are the Big East colleges, the top career scorers in their history and their active scoring leaders: Boston College Bob Carrington1,849 Roger McCready1,181 Connecticut Tony Hanson1,990 Earl Kelley1,464 Georgetown Eric Floyd2,304 David Wingate1,540 Pittsburgh Clyde Vaughan2,033 Charles Smith739 Providence Jimmy Walker2,045 Donnie Brown774 St. John's Chris Mullin2,440 Walter Berry1,063 Seton Hall Nick Werkman2,273 Andre McCloud1,765 Syracuse Dave Bing1,883 Rafael Addison1,682 Villanova Keith Herron2,170 Harold Pressley1,284

title: Messages
description: When President Reagan has something important to say, the White House doesn't take chances that a significant segment of the public might miss it. Tuesday evening Mr. Reagan will be delivering his yearly State of the Union Message to a joint meeting of Congress, and the major television networks will all be covering it live.

title: CAPITAL TRANSCRIBER'S AIDE PLEADS TO LESSER CHARGE IN SPYING CASE
description: A former messenger for a Washington company that transcribes Congressional proceedings pleaded guilty today to a charge of supplying national security documents to a person who was not entitled to receive them.

title: G.O.P. Governor Race Widens in Connecticut
description: The field of Republican candidates for Governor of Connecticut increased to four today with the entry of former State Senator Richard C. Bozzuto of Watertown.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Automatic Toll Systems Inc., Mount Vernon, N.Y., the revenue control systems subsidiary of Basix Corp., has appointed Thomas J. Quinlan Jr. president.

title: Dining Out Guide: East Side, Above 79th Street
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BISTRO BAMBOCHE, #1582 York Avenue, near 83d Street (249-4002) -

title: Celebrating Novelist From Brazil on 46th St.
description: The Brazilian novelist Jorge Amado, still in town after the PEN writer's convention, strayed from the literary scene Wednesday to sign copies of his latest book, ''Tocaia Grande'' (''Big Ambush''). The event was in a 46th Street grocery store.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: AS he does before he begins any sculpture, Donald Lipski started his latest work with a visit to a scrap heap. This time, he stumbled upon the nose cones to what he believes are four outdated United States Army Pershing I nuclear missiles.

title: 'Heartbreak House' On 'Great Performances'
description: In ''Heartbreak House,'' George Bernard Shaw, influenced by ''The Cherry Orchard'' and disturbed by world events, contemplated ''cultured, leisured Europe'' on the eve of World War I. The play is a precursor of all the fall-of-empire plays that dominated the British theater later in the century, with Shaw's distinction being that he was first and that he was prescient.

title: Acquisition of Billboards Fulfills Founder's Plan
description: When Metromedia Inc. said this week that it was selling its outdoor advertising business, the nation's largest, with 45,000 billboards, to the Patrick Media Group Inc. for $710 million, many executives in the billboard industry expressed surprise.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Wednesday of J. Peter Schaeffer, a senior vice president of Prudential Bache Securities Inc., listed his survivors incompletely. They include a sister, Margo C. Schaeffer of New York. A memorial service is scheduled for Monday at 11 A.M. in St. James Episcopal Church, 71st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Student Loan Unit In Australian Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday offered a $100 million Australian issue of 13 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Ratings Reduced At BankAmerica
description: The subordinated note rating of the BankAmerica Corporation was reduced to a speculative grade of BB from BBB-, analysts at McCarthy Crisanti & Maffei said yesterday. Senior notes and debentures of BankAmerica, the holding company of the California-based Bank of America, were reduced to BBB- from BBB+, but remain investment grade, Lower ratings for the approximately $3.5 billion of debt securities were warranted, the rating agency said, by ''expectations of continued low profitability and poor asset quality'' and the bank's vulnerability to additional losses from its domestic and foreign loans.

title: End Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Hawks, at Atlanta. With three victories in the previous four meetings, the Hawks are on the brink of winning the six-game season series. Dominique Wilkins scored 71 points (35 and 36, respectively) in the last two meetings, both Hawk triumphs. (Television -MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660 7:20 P.M.) Cleveland Cavaliers vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Richfield, Ohio, 8 P.M. The 76ers won the only game played between the teams this season, in Philadelphia. (Television - WTBS, 8:O5 P.M.) Colleges: City College at York, 8 P.M.; Juniata at Drew 7:30 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson-Madison at Susquehanna, 7:30 P.M., Baruch at Lehman, 8 P.,M.; Utica Tech at Medgar Evers, 7:30 P.M.; Western Connecticut at New York Maritime, 7:30 P.M.; Old Westbury at Binghampton State, 7:30 P.M.; Upsala at Johnson State, 7:30 P.M. Boxing Mike Tyson vs. vs. Mike Jameson, heavyweights, 10 rounds, at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Tyson, going for his 17th straight knockout at the start of his career, is attempting to break a record held by Rocky Marciano. Jameson, substituting for the injured Phil Brown, is 17-9 with 7 knockouts and from San Jose Calif. (Television -MSG, 10 P.M., live.) John Meekins vs. Juan Ramon Santana, junior welterweights, 10 rounds. at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M. Meekins, 9-0-1, with 8 knockouts, is from New York City.

title: A FIRM FOR THE BLUT-CHIP ELITE
description: More than any other firm, Morgan Stanley & Company epitomizes Wall Street's blue-chip elite.

title: Missing Boy Is Found After He Sees His Photo
description: A 5-year-old Kentucky boy who apparently was kidnapped a year ago was found after he saw his picture on a television show about missing children and notified his baby sitter, the authorities said today.

title: Rebel Gains Reported
description: Rebel Marxist forces were in control of almost all of Aden, according to refugees who arrived here from the Southern Yemen capital today.

title: RCA Lawsuits
description: A tentative settlement has been reached in 16 lawsuits filed in Delaware by shareholders of the RCA Corporation regarding the proposed acquisition of RCA by the General Electric Company. The dispute involved RCA's agreement to give G.E. an option to buy 28.3 million shares at $53.125 a share if G.E.'s $66.50-a-share offer was topped by another bidder or in some way compromised by any major change in RCA's assets. The settlement, if approved by the Delaware court, would raise the price that G.E. would have to pay to $59.75 a share, the closing price of RCA's shares on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 11, the day the bid was announced.

title: NORTHWEST TO BUY REPUBLIC
description: Northwest Airlines, the nation's 10th-largest airline and the biggest carrier to the Pacific, announced yesterday that it would buy Republic Airlines, the nation's seventh-largest airline, for $884 million.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Including a tax credit of $4,300,000 for the quarter and the year. Results for 1984 include a gain equal to 15 cents a share as a result of the discontinued operations.

title: KANSAS SURVIVES
description: Ron Kellogg dropped in two of his 27 points on foul shots with eight seconds remaining tonight, helping Kansas withstand Missouri's late rally and record an 81-77 Big Eight Conference victory.

title: Keeping the Word From the Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including unusual gains of $7.4 million.

title: GRAMM-RUDMAN AS A LEVER
description: In his forthcoming budget message, President Reagan will have to explain how he can meet the spending targets imposed by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction schedule. Many believe that Mr. Reagan, who in the past has announced himself ''set in concrete'' on some issues, only to slip off into an eventual compromise, will do so again, and the compromise will be a tax increase.

title: Uganda Rebels Advance To Kampala's Outskirts
description: Ugandan rebel forces advanced to the outskirts of Kampala today and an army barracks in the capital was reported shelled.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $175,700,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $187,900,000.

title: Wick Has Met the Enemy
description: When he took over as director of the United States Information Agency in 1981, Charles Z. Wick was regarded as possessing one of the most strident anti-Communist voices in Washington.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7.6 million. c-Net income, including net from discontinued operations of $206,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $30,937,000. e-Net income, including net from discontinued operations of $495,000.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Richard Passanant, secretary and treasurer, named vice chairman at McCaffrey & McCall, where Peter A. Manley, Norman Freeman and William J. Vieser were promoted to executive vice president, and Tom Wilson named to the board.

title: Nicaragua Says Cardinal Engages in 'Calumny'
description: The Nicaraguan Government has accused the head of the country's Roman Catholic Church hierarchy of aiding President Reagan's campaign to raise more funds for anti-Sandinista rebels.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including pre-tax charges of $167 million related to the company's restructuring program; $185 million for litigation accruals; $58 million for its share exchange offer, and an after- tax provision of $25 million for future resolution of tax controversies. c-Net income. d-After pre-tax charges of $1.19 billion related to the company's restructuring program, including: a $1.17 billion unusual charge for the write-off and write-down of assets and for personnel reduction costs; a $43 billion charge for adopting shorter estimated useful lives of equipment and machinery; a loss of $23 million for a discount incurred from the early retirement of a long-term note, and an extraordinary gain of $33 million for the reduction of long-term debt and interest income of $9 million related to the reversion of pension funds.

title: Mullin Set to Play
description: Chris Mullin, the former St. John's star, will rejoin the Golden State Warriors in Boston for tonight's game after seeing his brother, John, continue to improve in a Brooklyn hospital following an emergency appendectomy Tuesday. Mullin stayed behind with his family in New York as the Warriors went to Atlanta for a game against the Hawks Wednesday night. Yesterday, doctors at Long Island College Hospital said John Mullin's condition had improved from serious to stable.

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,305,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: DOW RISES 8.95 TO 1,511.24, HALTING SKID
description: After four straight losing sessions, the stock market rose moderately yesterday in continued heavy trading as investors searched for issues that have fallen to attractively low prices.

title: Homosexuals' Rights Need Protection
description: After more than a decade of debate, there may be enough votes in New York's City Council to pass a law forbidding discrimination against homosexuals in jobs, housing and public accommodations. As now refined and focused, the measure deserves the support of all New Yorkers.

title: Involuntary Prayer
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Hydrilla and Light
description: Until a few years ago, scientists thought they had finally conquered pollution in the Potomac River. But just as they were congratulating themselves and just as local swimmers and fishermen were beginning to enjoy the waters again, a monstrous new problem surfaced.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Zellerbach in Pact With James River
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and the James River Corporation said they had agreed to settle a class action suit involving Crown Zellerbach's poison pill provisions. The provisions, which were adopted by Crown Zellerbach during its takeover battle with the British investor Sir James Goldsmith, provided that in the event of a takeover, holders of the rights could buy shares of the surviving company at two for the price of one.

title: Italy Issues a Warrant For Abu Nidal's Arrest
description: Italian prosecutors issued an international arrest warrant today for Abu Nidal, charging him with mass murder as the mastermind of the Dec. 27 killings at the Rome airport.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Earl Jones, a 6-foot-11-inch forward who joined the Milwaukee Bucks Jan. 13 as an emergency replacement after Paul Mokeski underwent knee surgery, has signed a second 10-day contract. . . . Amy Alcott, the fifth-leading money winner in the history of women's professional golf, has donated $50,000 to endow a golf scholarship at U.C.L.A.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SLAIN NATURALIST'S LIFE: CLUES TO THE MYSTERY?
description: Late last month, an American zoologist who had devoted years to the study of the rare mountain gorilla was killed at her research camp in a rain forest near the top of a mountain in central Africa.

title: GORBACHEV-REAGAN ADDRESS TO CONGRESS IS SOUGHT
description: The Senate Democratic leader, Robert F. Byrd, Jr., said today that President Reagan had tentatively agreed to appear jointly before Congress with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.But White House officials said no decision had been made.

title: SEARCHING FOR SUBSTITUTES: INDUSTRY OFFERING CHOICES
description: No material has yet been developed with the numerous properties of asbestos: resisting heat, providing strength and adding durability in more than 3,000 products for very little cost.

title: KNICKS LANGUISH AFTER KEY INJURIES AND INDECISION
description: If the purpose of operating a sports franchise is to progress toward the goal of winning a championship, then the Knicks are on a treadmill - running hard, but going nowhere.

title: Why Marcos Can't Risk a Fair Election
description: To the Editor:

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $10,957,000 for the quarter and $9,557,000 for the year.

title: Champion Injures Hand
description: Terry Marsh, the European light-welterweight champion, suffered an injury to his left hand in his victory over Tek N'kalankete in London Wednesday night and may be forced to postpone his scheduled fight against Alexis Arguello April 3.

title: 2 MORE HELD IN THE MURDER OF DETECTIVE
description: Two more suspects were arrested yesterday in the murder of a police detective and the wounding of his partner in Queens on Tuesday night, the police said.

title: Impact on Vote Predicted
description: Some anti-Marcos Filipinos in New York said they thought the report on Mr. Marcos's wartime record would influence the outcome of the Feb. 7 election.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Uranus misstated the length of a Uranian day. Scientists suspect its length may be 12, 16 or 24 hours, not days.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL REVUE OF JEROME KERN SONGS
description: Just when you fear that you might gag on all the false cheer being propagted by 'Jerome Kern Goes to Hollywood,' the bland English cabaret show at Broadway's Ritz Theater, along comes a performer (one of four) whose authenticity cuts right through the show-biz cheesiness. Her name is Elisabeth Welch, and she's a small woman with apple round cheeks, silverish hair, large mischievous eyebrows and a posture that curls her body into a perptual, lightly amused shrug. Once you hear her light soprano make the most of familiar Kern songs, 'Smoke Gets in Your Eyes,' into something dramatic and new, you're likely to start riffling through the Playbill trying to find out where she's been all these years.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $74.9 million for the quarter and year and a special charge of $159.2 million for the year. c-After net losses from discontinued operations of $68.2 million for the quarter and $71.5 million for the year. d-Net income.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS RISES A SHARP 60.8%
description: The American Express Company reported today that net income in the last quarter of 1985 rose 60.8 percent, to $272.6 million, or $1.19 a share, from $169.5 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier, and was led by the strong performance of its Shearson Lehman Brothers subsidiary. Revenues went up 24.2 percent, to $3.35 billion, from $2.7 billion.

title: DIRECTOR OF VETERANS ADMINISTRATION STEPS DOWN
description: The director of the Veterans Administration, a man widely respected by veterans' organizations, has resigned.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RETURN,' A LOOK AT REINCARNATION
description: THE only thing more depressing than the failure of an ambitious movie maker is a movie maker who aims low and still misses the mark, which is what Andrew Silver seems to have done. Mr. Silver - who has the direction of some well-received fiction films for the Public Broadcasting System attributed to him - makes his theatrical film debut as the writer-director of ''Return,'' a technically competent but completely witless mystery movie about possession and reincarnation.

title: STUDENTS AT DARTMOUTH FACE OFF ACROSS WIDENING POLITICAL DIVIDE
description: Dartmouth has an intermittent tradition of campus protest, but in the last few days there have been vandalism and sit-ins with students aiming at unusual targets: one another.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.18 billion, to $212.94 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Mirth
description: Humor so low-key that it would hardly prod a chuckle from a television audience can seem nearly uproarious in such sober precincts as the Supreme Court or the Federal Reserve Board. Thus, Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, got a Bob Hope response this week when he spoke to the Bretton Woods Committee, a group of bankers and business leaders who lobby for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $52,000,000 from the sale of 59 percent of Fireman's Fund Corp and after a loss on a certain nonrecurring expenses resulting in part from the actions the company took to focus on its core businesses. Year-ago revenues have been restated to conform to the equity method of accounting. Year-ago results include operations of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Holding Company, acquired efffective May 11, 1984.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown for facilities at Midland Nuclear Power plant for use by Dow Chemical. c-Net income.

title: INTERLAKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: After a loss from discontinued operations of $315,000.

title: AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Last year's quarter includes a gain of $42 million from the sale of producing properties.

title: THE DANCE: 'SLAUGHTER'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE gained fame on Broadway in 1936 with his choreography for the Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart musical ''On Your Toes.'' ''Slaughter on 10th Avenue,'' which a ballet company in the play performed as its big premiere, was also the musical's big number.

title: Outbreak at L.S.U.
description: A chicken pox epidemic has hit the Louisiana State University basketball team, the team's captain has been denied an appeal of a failing grade in math, and both incidents have given Coach Dale Brown a headache. His team has a 16-3 record this season, but now Nikita Wilson, the captain, will not be allowed to attend the university this semester, and he cannot even play next fall if he decides to re-enroll.

title: Uniform Poll Closing Will Make Every Vote Count
description: To the Editor:

title: IN NEW ORLEANS, SUPER BOWL SPELLS BONANZA
description: Maureen Reagan was turned down for a room at the Inter-Continental, Antoine's Restaurant had to scramble to find table space for Pete Rozelle and the Windsor Court is geared for impromptu cocktail parties at 3 A.M.

title: Advertising; Reichhold's Fight to Be Recognized
description: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS has happy customers, or at least that is what C. Robert Powell, its chairman, believes.

title: MORGAN MAY SOON GO PUBLIC
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking house that traces its origins to the financial empire of J. P. Morgan, will shortly offer its shares to the public, insiders said yesterday.

title: CITY WEIGHS LIMITING USE OF COLLECTION AGENCIES
description: The Koch administration, amid widening allegations of bribery at the Parking Violations Bureau, is considering reducing its reliance on private contractors to collect tens of millions of dollars in overdue fines each year, city officials said yesterday.

title: ASTRONAUTS ON HARD-LUCK FLIGHT FAILED TO GET A GLIMPSE OF COMET
description: Astronauts on the recent hard-luck flight of the space shuttle Columbia said today that a broken light intensifier kept them from taking pictures or even getting a glimpse of Halley's comet.

title: A Mascot Is No More
description: The San Diego Chicken is rich and famous, and the Phillie Phanatic has a Muppet-like quality all his own. But the Chicken and the Phanatic belong to the world of show business, just like most of the other animals, real and costumed, that parade the sidelines in support of America's teams. Chief Noc-a-Homa, sent packing last week by the Atlanta Braves, was different, at least in some people's eyes.

title: Yugoslav-I.M.F. Talks
description: Yugoslavia and the International Monetary Fund began talks today on this nation's embattled economy. One key topic is a switch in Belgrade's interest rate policy.

title: NORMAN'S GAME SHIFTS TO OVERDRIVE
description: Jack Nicklaus was addressing his putt at the 320-yard fifth hole of the Phoenix Country Club today when a ball trickled over the green just behind him.

title: HOUSE BACKS CHECK BILL
description: The House of Representatives approved a bill today that would substantially reduce the time banks are allowed to hold checks before making the funds available to depositors.

title: Dr. Lowell Kelly, 80, Psychology Professor
description: Dr. E. Lowell Kelly, former professor of psychology at the University of Michigan and a former Peace Corps official, died Sunday, the university said Wednesday.

title: RISE IN FIGHTS IN N.B.A. CAUSES CONCERN
description: Fighting in the National Basketball Association is on the rise, and coaches and general managers are fearful that serious injuries may result if the increased physical contact is not checked.

title: BUSH ACCUSES CUOMO OF FOSTERING DIVISIVENESS WITH BIAS COMPLAINT
description: Vice President Bush accused Governor Cuomo last night of ''pitting one American against another'' by contending that as an Italian-American, he might be discriminated against as a potential Presidential candidate.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provisions for the restructuring of operations which reduced net income by $18.8 million for the quarter and $12.8 million for the year.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. NAVY STARTING FLIGHTS OFF LIBYA
description: The United States Navy has informed Libyan air controllers that planes from two aircraft carriers will be operating off Libya for the next week, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After non-cash net charges totaling $176 million. c-Net income, including a gain of $40,584,000. d-Including non-cash net charges of $176 million and a credit of $63,153,000, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change. e-Including net from discontinued operations of $1,313,000 and a gain of $40,584,000 on disposal of forest products opeations.

title: Ballet School's Goal: Residence Hall for Students
description: Outside, the lighted fountain gushed, the lean days of the drought only a memory. Inside, at the New York State Theater, the scene was just as opulent, with crystal and black ties, as hundreds gathered Wednesday night for the School of American Ballet winter benefit gala.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 24, 1986
description: Companies

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NETS ARE IMPROVED DESPITE RICHARDSON'S ABSENCE
description: His days and nights have been consumed by the game, by its demanding pressures and by his desire to mold a good team into something better. And in a significant way, Dave Wohl has succeeded.

title: AQUINO VOWS PROTEST CAMPAIGN IF CHEATED IN VOTE
