description: Denouncing President Ferdinand E. Marcos as a dying dictator, Corazon C. Aquino said today that if she wins the presidential election next month but is denied office she will tour the country and encourage daily demonstrations of protest.

title: Piedmont Blues
description: Piedmont blues will be heard tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, in concerts presented by the World Music Institute (362-0290). A triple bill will feature the duo of Bowling Green John Cephas on guitar and Phil Wiggins on harmonica, along with solo blues from John Jackson and John Dee Holeman. Tickets are $10.

title: Koch Favors New Criminal Court Judgeships
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS SPARKED BY RICHARDSON
description: Dave Wohl knows it's only a matter of time, that Micheal Ray Richardson is ready to start again for the Nets. It could come within the next two games.

title: VIACOM GROUP BUYING STAKE IN ORION PICTURES
description: An investment group led by Viacom International agreed yesterday to buy a major stake in Orion Pictures, the movie company, for $26.3 million.

title: McDonnell Gets Order From Delta
description: Delta Air Lines, in a move that took many in the industry by surprise, announced yesterday that it had ordered 80 small commercial jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation rather than the Boeing Company.

title: Barbara Rockefeller, Ex-Head Of Craft Council, Dies at 55
description: Barbara Olsen Rockefeller, former chairman of the American Craft Council, died Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 55 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in London.

title: OLD MASTERS: FINE AND UNFAMILIAR
description: IF your idea of bliss is to look at some unfamiliar and very good Old Master paintings in one of the most stylish of New York town houses, your day is made. What you have to do is to go to the National Academy of Design at 1083 Fifth Avenue, near 89th Street. There, you will find paintings by Poussin, Claude, Murillo, Rembrandt, van Dyck, Guercino, Canaletto, Tiepolo and Gainsborough, not to mention others less famous but well worth a visit. (If you want to think grateful thoughts about Ludolf Bakhuizen, Jan Weenix, Sir Peter Lely and George Knapton, this is the time and the National Academy is the place to bring it about). The hours are from noon to 8 P.M. on Tuesdays, and from noon to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays, and the show can be seen through Feb. 15.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOME CONTRIBUTIONS AID NEEDIEST CASES TO HONOR DR. KING
description: Donations honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. - whose birthday was observed as a national holiday for the first time on Monday - are among the contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: U.S. URGES SOVIET TO STAY OUT OF SOUTH YEMEN WAR
description: The United States, concerned that Moscow may have decided to back the more hard-line forces in Southern Yemen, has urged the Soviet Union not to intervene in the civil war there, State Department officials said today.

title: MEESE OBSERVES A DRUG PROGRAM IN A CITY SCHOOL
description: For an hour yesterday afternoon, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d sat in an elementary school classroom in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant, listening attentively as a group of sixth-grade pupils discussed an unpleasant but unavoidable reality of life in the big city: the temptation of drugs.

title: RANGERS SHUT OUT 5TH TIME
description: There must be a limit to how many times the Rangers can berate themselves when the real problem has nothing to do with effort but perhaps with simple natural talent.

title: TEST OF PICTURE WEEK IS SUSPENDED BY TIME
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it would temporarily stop publishing Picture Week, a new magazine that it has been test-marketing in 13 cities, to modify its editorial content.

title: Church Expels Parenthood Aide
description: The Diocese of Providence has excommunicated the head of the state's Planned Parenthood organization for what it called activities causing ''the sinful termination of human life.''

title: BINGHAMTON WATER CRISIS IS EASING
description: As workers restored water pressure, Binghamton today limped through the second day of a state of emergency that has closed schools and industries, forced high-rise residents to sleep in lobbies and virtually emptied downtown.

title: Window Shopper
description: William (The Refrigerator) Perry, when asked whether he had been directed to any famous New Orleans restaurants: ''I don't notice the names. I just browse.''

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax charge of approximately $50 million related to the formation of a joint venture with Harris Corp.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STEISEL, SANITATION CHIEF, RESIGNING AFTER 7 YEARS
description: Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel, one of the longest-serving commissioners in the Koch administration, resigned yesterday after more than seven years on the job.

title: 30 REPORTED SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: At least 30 people were reported slain in renewed tribal fighting between Zulus and Pondos south of Durban today that left hundreds of shanty homes ablaze and sent hundreds of blacks fleeing for safety.

title: Symposium to Mark Furtwangler Centenary
description: The 100th anniversary of the birth of the German conductor Wilhelm Furtwangler will be marked with a symposium sponsored by the Wagner Society tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 82d Street.

title: HOSPITALS ENCOURAGED TO JOIN AN AIDS NET
description: The New York State Health Commissioner said yesterday that the state would increase by nearly a third the payments that hospitals received for treating AIDS patients if the hospitals joined a new network of AIDS centers.

title: Lighthouse Benefit
description: The soprano Linda Skroski and the pianist Valerie Capers, who are both blind, will be the featured artists in a concert Sunday to benefit the Lighthouse Professional Musicians' Fund, an annual event sponsored by the Lighthouse Music School to showcase the work of established blind musicians and to raise funds to support performance opportunities for other professional and aspiring blind musicians.

title: WILLARD VAN DYKE, EX-HEAD OF FILMS AT MODERN MUSEUM
description: Willard Van Dyke, a photographer, film maker and former director of the film department at the Museum of Modern Art, died of a heart attack yesterday in Jackson, Tenn. Mr. Van Dyke had been driving from his home in Santa Fe, N.M. to Cambridge, Mass., where he had recently been named Laureate Artist in Residence at Harvard. He was 79 years old.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $6 million for the quarter and $8.8 million for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $900,000 for the quarter and $5.9 million for the year and tax benefits of $8.8 million for the quarter and $1.7 million for the year.

title: A.T.& T. Will Retire 2 High-Interest Issues
description: With corporate bond yields near their lowest levels since 1979, many corporate treasurers are making plans to retire high-interest bonds that were offered earlier this decade but will be callable at the issuing company's option this year.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SUCH unusual pieces of Americana as a cigar-store Indian Princess, a pair of early-18th-century silver caudle cups found in a London flea market and a Philadelphia Chippendale tea table that may break the American-furniture auction record of $687,000 are among the highlights in New York sales tomorrow and next week. Up for bidding in the largest and most important auctions of Americana this season will be hundreds of pieces of 18th- and 19th-century furniture, paintings, folk art, ceramics, silver and textiles. Sotheby's expects its sales will total $4 million to $6 million; Christie's, $2 million to $3 million.

title: 10,000 Maniacs on Bill
description: The folk-rock group 10,000 Maniacs will perform tonight at 8:30 and 11:30 at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street (228-7880), and tomorrow at 9 P.M. and midnight. Tickets are $8.50.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jitterbug Jazz, Top of the Gate, Bleecker Street at Thompson Street (475-5120). The mythical locus of this nostalgic revue celebrating late-swing-era Harlem is the legendary Savoy Ballroom. The house band, called the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band, consists of seven jazz and big-band veterans who are all over 70 years old but can still kick out the jams. The liveliest soloists are the trombonist Eddie Durham, who composed ''One O'Clock Jump'' and arranged for Glenn Miller, and the tenor saxophonist and former Lionel Hampton cohort Eddie Chamblee. Mama Lu Parks and Her Savoy Lindyhoppers demonstrate some of the more acrobatic styles of jitterbugging. The stand-up comic, tap dancer, singer, actor, impressionist and songwriter Jack Hammer makes an engaging emcee, full of nonstop jivey patter. There are two shows nightly, tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. All tickets are $12; one-drink minimum.

title: SUBMARINER AND SEA SCIENTIST
description: Vice Adm. William W. Behrens Jr., retired, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Bayfront Medical Center, St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 63 years old and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: Topics; Missing Links; The Ice Connection
description: In New York City, ''breaking the ice'' describes the process by which strangers exchange introductory pleasantries. A hundred miles north, breaking the ice is even more serious business.

title: EX-PROFESSOR OF GOVERNMENT
description: Louis Hartz, a longtime professor of government at Harvard University whose work in political theory and comparative history influenced and inspired a generation of scholars, died Monday in Istanbul. He was 66 years old.

title: LAWYER TAKES SPOTLIGHT IN CITY PARKING SCANDAL
description: The phone rang at Representative Thomas J. Manton's home at 3 A.M. yesterday.

title: AHMANSON & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $5.6 million from the withdrawal and expected sale of the company's liability insurance operation, excepting Nebraska operations. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $6,425,000, or 23 cents a share, from dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participating preferred stock.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Movies are not born equal, particularly in their chances for Academy Award nominations.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE recently spruced up Union Square area has become fertile ground for a new crop of restaurants. Union Square Cafe, an inviting, low-key newcomer on the site of the former Brownies, a health food restaurant, is one of the most appealing of the lot.

title: PATRIOT SECONDARY SET FOR MCMAHON
description: First there was Ken O'Brien, then Marc Wilson, and finally, Dan Marino.

title: IMPERIAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an additional writedown of $5 million for the quarter and year of Granduc copper mine and a charge of $45 million for the year from a June 1 crude oil pricing accord.

title: JOHN RYERSON
description: John Ryerson, an amateur golfer and one of last survivors of the sinking of the Titanic, died Tuesday at a nursing home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: MARIO BUATTA: UNRUFFLED AND FLOURISHING
description: ''Mario Buatta? You cannot be Mario Buatta!'' said a woman at a recent dinner party after being introduced to the man on her left. ''I have your chintz in my living room, and you are nothing like your chintz.'' ''No?'' Mr. Buatta said. ''No,'' the woman said. ''I envisioned an older man, shorter, fatter and . . . '' ''Glazed?'' The interior designer, who stands 6-foot-1 in his Ferragamo shoes, was, in fact, 55 pounds fatter until he dieted down to 178 in time for his 50th birthday party last October. He does, in fact, give off a social sheen, not unlike the finish on high-glaze chintz. And, as those who move in the gossipy world of decorating will tell you, the man they call the Prince of Chintz resembles his trademark fabric in still other ways: He wears well and resists stains. Socially Registered Clients

title: U.S. PANEL SEEN AS LIMITING PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS' FUNDS
description: The Federal Election Commission issued a ruling today that could provide grounds for challenging the use of special political action committees to finance the activities of unannounced Presidential contenders.

title: KOCH, IN SHIFT, ASKS FOR STUDY OF CONFLICT LAW
description: Faced with widening allegations of municipal corruption, Mayor Koch reversed himself yesterday and asked the Board of Ethics to consider barring political party leaders from doing business with the city.

title: AT INTERNATIONAL SHOW, FAR-OUT FELINES STAR
description: Here come the cats, the familiar household cats as well as the new, trendy jet-set cats, the designer cats, as it were. The second International Cat Show and competition opens today and runs through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, not with a whimper but a purr. The show is sponsored by the Garden Cat Club, a nonprofit organization. More than 1,000 prize-winning purebreds and humble household pets from all over the world will be competing for cash, cups and applause at this Super Bowl of Pussycats.

title: Appointments
description: President Reagan is expected to make two major appointments soon that ordinarily would be largely based on specialized professional credentials rather than political endorsement: Archivist of the United States and chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. In each instance, Congressional sources say, the field has narrowed to two candidates, one of whom appears to enjoy a political edge over the other at the White House.

title: 4 U.S. PROPERTIES TIED TO MARCOSES
description: A New York lawyer testified before a House panel today that he was told repeatedly by a real estate broker that Imelda Marcos, First Lady of the Philippines, owned four Manhattan properties worth an estimated $350 million.

title: BAUTIER: A RARE BLUES TALENT DISCOVERED
description: THE times when a pop critic stumbles across a major talent who is totally unknown are very rare. But Michele Bautier, the jazz singer who opened a two-week engagement at Freddy's Supper Club on Tuesday, was one of those once-every-five-year discoveries.

title: MOISEYEV TO VISIT U.S. IN EXCHANGE PROGRAM
description: The Moiseyev Folklore Ensemble was added today to the list of Soviet performing arts companies that will appear in the United States under the cultural exchange agreement that came out of last November's summit meeting.

title: Jimmy Scott and Group
description: The singer Little Jimmy Scott and a quintet are appearing tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHOREOGRAPHERS' STORY: PUTTING DANCE TOGETHER
description: Dance is a rigorous discipline for choreographers as well as performers. But there are almost as many ways of making dances as there are choreographers. Dances come out of instinct for Elisa Monte, whose company performs this weekend at the Joyce Theater. Susan Marshall, whose dances will be performed this weekend at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, stores up images, then works with her dancers on ways of expressing them.

title: Literary Criticism
description: A discussion of literary criticism will open a six-part series on ''The Arts of Biography'' tonight at 8 at the Rockland Center for the Arts, 27 South Greenbush Road, West Nyack, N.Y. The discussion will be led by the writer and critic John Leonard and Roger Jellinek, chairman of the literary program.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest periods was reduced by $2.8 million in the quarter and $3.2 million in the year from additional charges for changes in the company's estimates for closed facilities. Net income for the previous year reflects a reduction of $4.9 million from the divestment of certain operating facilities and an increase of $2.5 million, or 22 cents a share, as a result of a tax provision.

title: NEW LESOTHO RULERS TO OUST, NOT TURN OVER, PRETORIA FOES
description: Military officers who seized power in Lesotho this week have decided to fly South African political fugitives out of the country ''as quickly as possible'' but will not hand them over to Pretoria, the state-run Lesotho radio said tonight.

title: Advertising; New Grace Commercial To Attack the Deficit
description: If the TV networks approve of his new commercial, then J. Peter Grace will get his two cents in on the Federal budget deficit right after President Reagan's State of the Union address next Tuesday.

title: Topics; Missing Links; River Traffic
description: Skeptics once dismissed Arthur Imperatore's dream of reviving trans-Hudson ferry service to connect his new office and housing development in Weehawken, N.J., with a Manhattan pier at West 38th Street. But it was only the governmental machinery for dealing with ferries that was rusty.

title: MOTHER AND SON DENY SUBJECTING SCHOOL'S CHILDREN TO SEXUAL ABUSE
description: With more than 30 parents of nursery school children looking on, Peggy McMartin Buckey, former director of the McMartin Preschool center in Manhattan Beach and her son, Raymond, today pleaded not guilty to charges that they sexually abused at least 14 students and conspired to cover up their activities.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Reached agreement with Danny Heep, outfielder, on a one-year contract.

title: REAGAN IS ASSAILED BY BLACK LEADERS FOR VIEW ON HIRING
description: Leaders of the National Urban League denounced the Reagan Administration today for its proposal to roll back a 20-year-old Federal program designed to make jobs that involve Federal contracts available to blacks, members of other minority and women.

title: CARTWRIGHT MAY PLAY FOR KNICKS TONIGHT
description: The long-awaited return of Bill Cartwright may come sooner than expected. The Knicks' 7-foot-1-inch center, who has suffered a broken left foot three times in the last 18 months and has not played since the 1983-84 playoffs, practiced yesterday for the first time since he suffered his latest injury last October.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE literary and business worlds of New York converged on Jason Epstein's pied-a-terre at the Hampshire House, high above Central Park South, to toast Ken Auletta on the publication of his new book ''Greed and Glory on Wall Street: The Fall of the House of Lehman.''

title: COUNTERTENOR SET TO MAKE U.S. DEBUT
description: Despite the unending successes in his singing career, Paul Esswood still finds himself a pioneer in a sometimes reluctant world.

title: 8 Protesters Arrested In Strike at Hormel
description: Pro-union demonstrators today tried to block a highway near a Hormel meat-processing plant to prevent nonstriking employees from getting to work, and eight people were arrested, the authorities said.

title: Sohio Has Loss Of $771 Million
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio), hurt by special charges and unusual items in the fourth quarter totaling $1.15 billion, yesterday reported a loss of $771 million in the period.

title: Orioles Waive Ford
description: The veteran Baltimore Oriole outfielder Dan Ford has been placed on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES PLAN TO CURB ASBESTOS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed a long-range program to protect the public from what it called ''the serious health threat of asbestos.''

title: Three Named to Receive Film Institute Award
description: The first Maya Deren award for independent film makers and video artists, sponsored by the American Film Institute, will be given to three recipients - Stan Brakhage, a film maker; Sally Cruishank, an animator, and Nam June Paik, a video artist.

title: 9A and 5N, Please
description: Here's a way New Yorkers and anyone else writing to a New Yorker can help balance the Federal budget. It won't cost anyone more than the few seconds it takes to write a number on an envelope -an apartment or mailbox number.

title: ROMULO: 'THE PROBLEM IS MARCOS'
description: Last month, shortly after President Marcos announced that he would hold a ''snap election'' in the Philippines on February 7, Carols P. Romulo died at the age of 86. As the Philippines held a state funeral and President and Mrs. Marcos prayed over his open, flag-draped coffin, President Reagan called Romulo ''a giant of this century.''

title: Interest Rates Fall Slightly
description: Interest rates were slightly lower yesterday, in very quiet trading.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $5,000,000 from a provision for restructuring of operations. c-After a charge of $18,500,000 from a provision from restructuring of operations and a gain of $17,742,000 or $1.25 a share as a result of elimination of deferred income taxes.

title: He's Adaptable
description: Edgar Jones, forward for the Cleveland Cavaliers and crown prince of self-promoting hyperbole, says that as a Newark high school student, he was terrific in track, football, baseball and wrestling.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After a net charge of $2.1 million for the quarter and 6 months related to a facility closing, moving of an operation and additions to bad debt reserves.

title: COLLECTION OF PARKING FINES: THE WAY THE SYSTEM WORKS
description: Private collection contracts with the city's Parking Violations Bureau are divided into a two-tiered system, and city officials and industry experts yesterday agreed that the most desirable are the so-called first-placement contracts.

title: Dealing With the Trauma Of Losing a Pet
description: Recognizing that the loss of a pet can be as traumatic as the loss of a close human friend, the animal shelter of the Bide-a-Wee Home Association in Manhattan has appointed its own pet-grief therapist, Muriel Franzblau.

title: REPELLING GAF GIVES CARBIDE LOSS
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the giant chemical company, yesterday reported a $211 million loss for the fourth quarter and a $58.7 million loss for all of 1985. The company said the losses reflected pretax charges of $435 million resulting largely from the restructuring and legal expenses of fending off a hostile takeover bid by the GAF Corporation.

title: 'SMITHSONIAN WORLD' TRACKS SCIENTIFIC SLEUTH
description: ''SMITHSONIAN WORLD'' has always been a good series. ''On the Shoulders of Giants,'' the episode tomorrow night, is one of its best. Indeed, it is everything that a program about natural science is supposed to be. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Jan. 9 from Gore, Okla., about an accident at a nuclear-fuel plant, misstated the time and place of a previous accident involving uranium hexafluoride that prompted Federal calls for emergency planning. The earlier accident occurred in 1966 at the Fernald plant, near Cincinnati. That plant is owned by the Department of Energy and was then operated by the National Lead Company of Ohio.

title: HANOVER BANK'S POSITIVE VIEW
description: In an unusual effort to calm jittery investors, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that some third-world borrowers could benefit from lower oil prices.

title: PHONE GROUP PLANS PACIFIC CABLE LINK
description: In one of the largest fiber-optic cable projects ever undertaken, the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and a host of international telecommunications companies said yesterday that they would build an underwater lightwave communications system across the Pacific Ocean by 1989.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 24, 1986
description: International Fears that the Philippine election Feb. 7 will be fraudulent prompted senior Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress to express serious concern over the prospect. Officials cited the recent slayings of nine campaign workers, reports that ''intimidation in a number of areas is growing'' and the reported printing of extra ballots for stuffing voting boxes. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Northern Ireland Votes; No Violence Reported
description: Citizens of Northern Ireland lined up under heavy guard today to vote in parliamentary elections that are the first popular test of the British-Irish agreement signed in November.

title: Delay on Plan For Seven-Up
description: Pepsico Inc., which had been expected to announce yesterday that it planned to buy the Seven-Up Company, is now likely to announce the purchase today, sources close to the company said yesterday.

title: COLLECTION EXECUTIVE SAID TO LINK MANES TO PARKING BUREAU PAYOFFS
description: A Queens collection agency executive has accused Donald R. Manes of extortion in the awarding of contracts by the city's Parking Violations Bureau, a high Federal law-enforcement official disclosed yesterday.

title: Mexico at the Brink
description: Plunging oil prices mean that Mexico may have to stop paying interest on its $97 billion foreign debt, perhaps right away. Better to do it now, President Miguel de la Madrid is likely to reason, than with a far bigger debt and smaller reserves later on.

title: 5 Reported Killed In Lebanese Clashes
description: President Amin Gemayel's Christian loyalists and Syrian-backed militia forces exchanged heavy artillery and tank cannon fire in Lebanon's central mountains today. The police said five combatants were killed and seven wounded.

title: Surgeries
description: Jim Lehrer of ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' was interviewing Representative Thomas S. Foley, the House Democratic whip, the other evening on the impact of the new budget-balancing law. Mr. Foley was home in Spokane, appearing by satellite, and Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Senate Republican whip, was standing by in the PBS television studio with Mr. Lehrer to offer his reactions.

title: A Mascot Is No More
description: The San Diego Chicken is rich and famous, and the Phillie Phanatic has a Muppet-like quality all his own. But the Chicken and the Phanatic belong to the world of show business, just like most of the other animals, real and costumed, that parade the sidelines in support of America's teams. Chief Noc-a-Homa, sent packing last week by the Atlanta Braves, was different, at least in some people's eyes.

title: Kodak Refunding
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's refund program for owners of soon-to-be-worthless Kodak instant cameras will be delayed about a month because of delays in the printing of special forms and brochures, a company spokesman said. Kodak began its special refund program, in which consumers call a special toll-free number to get a packet of information about the refunds, on Jan. 9, the day a court order went into effect forcing the company from the instant photography business.

title: Death at 100 Ends Sentence
description: Anna Szenan, who twice refused to leave prison, saying it was her home, died Wednesday at the Ohio Reformatory for Women in Marysville. She was 100 years old and had spent 57 years in prison, turning down offers of parole in 1942 and 1959, saying she considered the prison staff her family. She was sentenced to life in prison in 1929 for a murder in Cleveland.

title: Licorice Factory Sextet
description: The clarinetists Perry Robinson, Mark Whitecage and Mike Morgenstern will lead Licorice Factory, a sextet, tonight and tomorrow at A Discovery of SoHo, 451 Broome Street at Mercer Street (334-1222). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: FOR MIKE SINGLETARY, A LONG HARD ROAD
description: For many years, the Rev. Charles Singletary, a Pentecostal minister in Houston, refused to allow his 10 children to take part in sports or undress in gym class. Besides, his youngest child, Mike, was so frail and sickly that organized sports would have been too much for him.

title: MCKESSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $752,000 for the 9 months.

title: Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it expects to report a unspecified loss in the fourth quarter because of about $100 million in nonrecurring charges. It said the charge resulted from lower crude oil prices and to losses from a pending divestiture.

title: THE BOYD HALL REUNION
description: Steve Moore does not normally leave his hotel door ajar, but he knew his old Tennessee State teammate was on his way over the other night, so he left it open, just the way they used to do in Boyd Hall.

title: Congress; Tales From Home: Lost Jobs and Delusion
description: In downstate Illinois, Representative Richard J. Durbin talked to workers who had just been laid off from a construction equipment factory.

title: TRANSWORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a loss from discontinued operations of $1,803,000 and a gain of $102,750,000 from disposal of discontinued operations in the quarter; and net from discontinued operations of $9,994,000 and a gain of $102,750,000 on disposal of discontinued operations in the year. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $2,930,000 in the quarter; and net from discontinued operations of $16,894,000 in the year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There will be no limitation to the downward price spiral which may bring crude prices to less than $15 a barrel, with adverse and dangerous consequences for the whole world economy.'' - Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister. [ D1:3. ]

title: LAWMAKER WARNS ON CUTS AT F.A.A.
description: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Aviation warned yesterday that threatened automatic spending cuts would prevent the Federal Aviation Administration from paying for key safety programs in the 1987 fiscal year beginning in October.

title: Brown Top Rookie
description: Eddie Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' acclaimed receiver from the University of Miami, caught 53 passes for 942 yards and 8 touchdowns in his first professional season.

title: WHAT MCMAHON DOESN'T SAY HURTS HIM
description: The countdown to Super Bowl XX took another bizarre twist today when Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, learned that a local sportscaster had reported that McMahon had made derogatory comments about the people of New Orleans.

title: New Chief Chosen At Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the aerospace contractor, said yesterday that Norman R. Augustine, executive vice president, will become president and chief executive officer, effective April 1.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $93 million on the formation of Gulf Canada Resources partnership with Norcen Energy Resources and after a loss of $80 million on the sale of refining and marketing assets to Petro-Canada.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JONATHAN SWIFT, A HYPOCRITE REVERSED. By David Nokes. Illustrated. 427 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: CONSUMER SPENDING UP SHARPLY
description: Car financing deals and a brisk Christmas shopping season helped propel Americans' spending up by 2 percent in December, the biggest monthly rise in more than a decade and outpacing an accompanying 1.4 percent gain in personal income, the Government said today.

title: MARCOS SAYS REPORT CASTING DOUBT ON WAR EXPLOITS IS 'FOOLISHNESS'
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has dismissed a report that the United States Army repeatedly rejected his claims that he led a World War II guerrilla unit.

title: BROADWAY
description: HER name is Charity Hope Valentine and she burst on the Broadway scene 20 years ago this month, a lady with a reputation not quite as untarnished as her heart of gold. Can it be true that she's coming back? Yes, yes and yes - get ready to welcome ''Sweet Charity,'' a $1.5 million bundle preparing to hit the Great White Way in April.

title: STORM AROUND KOCH
description: Municipal corruption.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $2,180,1888 for the quarter and $3,081,220 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $1,920,000.

title: UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Ahead To the Past
description: In the old days - and the old days nowadays can be just a year or two ago, or even just a small number of days ago, because when there is no sense of history left nobody can tell precisely how long ago the past occurred . . . But that's another subject . . . In the old days everything was new in the United States, and - come to think of it - in the new days, which is where we are now, everything is old. People - the population, I mean: old and getting older. The President is old, the airplanes are old and, worse, the airplane engines are old. The New York subway is old, the ad man's favorite slogan - ''new and improved'' - is old.

title: CONCERT: SARAH GRUNSTEIN PERFORMS ALL-BACH PROGRAM
description: Sarah Grunstein, an Australian and a Bach pianist of experience and accomplishment, took on Book One of the mighty 48, the Well-Tempered Clavier, at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday evening. This great monument of a work, which defines for most musicians the highest achievement of Baroque counterpoint, is more a lofty treatise, an exhaustive compendium, than an evening's musical entertainment. Still, a public exegesis on it can be powerful.

title: VENTURI CHOSEN TO DESIGN EXTENSION OF THE NATIONAL GALLERY IN LONDON
description: Robert Venturi, the Philadelphia-based architect whose writings and buildings are often credited with initiating the shift of architecture away from modernism, yesterday was named architect of the extension of Britain's National Gallery. The selection of Mr. Venturi, who is the senior partner of the firm of Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown, will pair one of the most influential architects in the United States with what is considered the most prestigious new building project in Britain.

title: TV: 'CBS REPORTS' EXAMINES BLACK FAMILIES
description: Television journalism may not exactly come of age tonight, but ''The Vanishing Family - Crisis in Black America'' is as close to maturity as we are likely to get. It should be seen; it demands to be seen. It plunges into an enormously important, culturally unpopular topic, and examines it with intelligence and grace. The two-hour program, a ''CBS Reports,'' can be seen on Channel 2 at 9 P.M.

title: Phone Line Available For Voyager Updates

title: Memorable Punt
description: Of 52 individual one-game Super Bowl records listed by the National Football League, only five date from 1967, when the champions of the N.F.L. and the American Football League clashed for the first time. And four of those five records, though never bettered, have since been tied: the eight straight pass completions by Len Dawson of Kansas City (equaled once); the five extra points kicked by Don Chandler of Green Bay (tied three times); the two touchdowns rushing by the Packers' Elijah Pitts (tied four times), and the two touchdown receptions by the Packers' Max McGee (tied five times).

title: A Remedy for the Displaced-Worker Problem
description: The strong expansion of the economy still blinds us to turbulent shifts in the nation's labor markets and, in particular, to the sad plight of the displaced worker. Of the millions unemployed, those who are changing jobs or waiting to be recalled are only temporarily out of work. But hundreds of thousands are unemployed because their jobs have permanently disappeared - the assembly-line worker who has lost his job to a robot, the office worker shunted aside by automated equipment, the steelworker whose company has been damaged by foreign imports. We should be paying much closer attention to this group.

IN GREEKS' MYTHS, URANUS WAS MIGHTY AMONG GODS
description: Voyager 2's images of Uranus are the first close-up views of any of the planets that were unknown to the ancients. After Uranus was first detected by William Herschel with his telescope in Bath, England, on March 13, 1781, the German astronomer Johann Elert Bode proposed that it be named for Uranus, the Greek god of the heavens.

title: ISLANDERS REGROUP IN TIME TO WIN
description: The Islanders mounted a five-goal comeback in the second period that earned them a 7-5 victory tonight over the Washington Capitals. Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy, perennial linemates who view their success as symbiotic, paired up again tonight as Trottier collected his first hat trick of the season and Bossy provided the key assist, giving him his 1,000th National Hockey League point.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Answering and Understanding Help-Wanted Ads
description: Job hunting probably doesn't top anyone's list of favorite activities, but it can be made easier by learning to read the want-ads correctly. Here is a guide to phrases that are commonly used in the classified job advertisements and what they really mean: 1. ''Include salary history'' (where no salary is mentioned in the ad) -The employer is looking to get you cheap. Don't, under any circumstances, include your salary history. If they're interested, they'll call. 2. ''Send resume with earnings history and compensation requirements'' - Not only do they want you cheap, they expect you to bid for the job. Advice: same as above. 3. ''Include salary history'' (where the salary they are offering is mentioned in the ad) - For what purpose? This indicates the employer may simply want to pry into your past. Again, don't give in. 4. ''Salary history a must!'' - No, it isn't. This indicates that many candidates have followed the advice given above and have refused to provide their salary histories. 5. ''Administrative assistant'' -Typist needed. 6. ''Para-professional'' - Clerk needed. 7. ''Strong organizational skills'' -Clerk-typist needed. 8. ''Records analysis specialist'' -File clerk needed. 9. ''Highly visible professional position'' - Receptionist needed. (If the position is so great, why is it advertised in two-point type under ''administrative assistant''?) 10. ''Attractive appearance'' -Euphemism for ''young.'' Those older than 22 need not apply. 11. ''Excellent communications skills required'' - Candidate should be able to read without moving lips. 12. ''People person'' - You will be expected to handle angry and abusive customers or clients without suffering a nervous breakdown. 13.

title: Mack Reiterates 'Outsourcing' Plan
description: Mack Trucks Inc. is not likely to reconsider its decision to use outside companies to produce some parts now manufactured at its plant here, a company official said. But it is still too soon to say how many jobs will be lost at the Hagerstown plant once ''outsourcing'' begins, said William McCullough, Mack's vice president of corporate affairs. Mack said last Saturday that it would move its outdated Allentown, Pa., manufacturing operation to Winnsboro, S.C., and outsource some parts made at Hagerstown as a means of cutting costs.

title: ASPEN RIBBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unfairness in New York's Tax Amnesty
description: New York State's decision to offer amnesty to delinquent taxpayers has been hailed as a way to flush out chiselers. The state's booklet on the subject trumpets threateningly: ''It would be a crime to miss out on amnesty.'' It also warns that ''amnesty is a onetime opportunity for taxpayers to pay delinquent taxes without penalty or criminal prosecution.''

description: The city's high schools have been told by the Board of Education that they may no longer fail students or withhold course credit solely for excessive absence.

title: DEVILS LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: Wayne Gretzky stole the puck from Craig Wolanin, and beat Craig Billington from close range at 1 minute 29 seconds in overtime tonight to lift the Edmonton Oilers to a 7-6 victory over the Devils.

BUSH SALUTES FALWELL CONSERVATISM
description: Vice President Bush, intensifying his political courtship of Republican conservatives and religious fundamentalists, said today that ''America is in crying need of the moral vision'' he said the Rev. Jerry Falwell and his followers had brought to the political process. ''Let me say, go for it,'' Mr. Bush declared in urging a gathering of state leaders of Mr. Falwell's Liberty Federation to become more politically active. The federation is a political organization formed recently by the founder of Moral Majority to mobilize conservatives who support his views on domestic and foreign issues. Moral Majority has become a subsidiary of the federation.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Who Can Lead Newark?
description: While much of New Jersey experiences brisk growth, Newark stagnates, and the responsibility must fall largely on Mayor Kenneth Gibson, who recently announced for a fifth term. His administration has become closed, unresponsive and ineffectual. It is unclear whether Newark can produce a preferable candidate. What is certain is that the city desperately needs new leadership.

title: Mexican Loan Talks
description: A new date for talks in New York between Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, and representatives of the country's bank advisory committee will probably be set next week, a Finance Ministry spokesman said. Mr. Silva Herzog postponed the talks on new money for 1986, originally set for Thursday, because of the serious implications for Mexico of the latest drop in oil prices, he said.

description: The Farmers Home Administration said today that it was delaying and scaling down a program it announced in December to send foreclosure notices to tens of thousands of farmers who owe the Government a total of $6 billion.

title: Bridge; For Either Side, Deflection Can Confuse the Opponents
description: The delicate art of deflection is not well understood. It can be practiced by both declarer and defender, and aims at making the opponents think that they are on the right track when they are not.

description: DALLAS, Jan. 24 - Texas Instruments Inc., still suffering from Japanese competition in its semiconductor unit, reported today that it lost $41.2 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $64.6 million, or $2.64 a share, a year earlier.

description: If other nations can't catch terrorists or refuse to surrender them, why shouldn't Americans snatch suspects wherever they can and bring them to justice in the United States? That question no longer sounds far-fetched.

title: TEACHER IS FOCUS OF SPACE MISSION
description: The flight of the first private citizen into space, scheduled to begin Sunday, has filled the Kennedy Space Center with crowds of teachers and tourists in what promises to be a public relations bonanza for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: U.S. PLANS ALTERNATIVES TO MANILA BASES
description: Detailed contingency plans have been drawn up to move Navy and Air Force units from the Philippines to Guam, Okinawa and other Pacific locations if the United States is forced to leave its Philippine bases, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: PEPSICO IN PACT FOR SEVEN-UP
description: In the largest consolidation in the soft-drink industry, Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of the Seven-Up Company from Philip Morris Companies Inc. for $380 million.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Fans' Tribute To Papa Bear
description: When the Chicago Bears beat the Los Angeles Rams two weeks ago to earn a spot in Super Bowl XX tomorrow, Coach Mike Ditka and several of his players avowed that the late George Halas, the team's founder, had been watching over them. And if Papa Bear hasn't forgotten his gladiators, it's a certainty that Chicagoans haven't forgotten him.

title: Like Old Times
description: For almost a quarter of a century, the National Hockey League All-Star Game pitted the previous season's Stanley Cup champions against the best of the rest in the N.H.L. That format was abandoned in 1970 in favor of interconference matchups, but it's made a virtual encore with the news that the first-ever fan balloting for the game led to the selection of five players from Edmonton - Wayne Gretzky, Glenn Anderson, Jari Kurri, Paul Coffey and Grant Fuhr -among the six Campbell Conference starters. The only interloper is Doug Wilson of Chicago, who beat Kevin Lowe of the Oilers for the second defenseman's spot by 46,097 votes, about 6 percent of the total cast for Campbell defensemen.

title: Austrian Woman, 26, Is Dead Of Wounds in Airport Attack
description: An Austrian woman died of wounds suffered in the Palestinian terrorist attack on Dec. 27 at the Vienna airport, becoming the fourth fatality from the attack, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: STRIKE HITS ARGENTINA
description: A 24-hour general strike called by labor unions as a ''popular referendum'' against the Government's austerity measures and the International Monetary Fund virtually shut Argentina down today. Many sections of Buenos Aires were deserted as tens of thousands of residents took advantage of the strike to travel to resort areas for a three-day weekend.

title: UNDEFEATED TYSON GETS 17TH KNOCKOUT
description: The undefeated heavyweight Mike Tyson stopped an overweight 3l-year-old Californian named Mike Jameson tonight 46 seconds into the fifth round of a scheduled eight-rounder.

title: QMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
3M Sues Ampad
description: The Ampad Corporation said that the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company had filed suit against it, charging patent infringement by Ampad's Clingers stick-on note product. The company, a leading manufacturer of paper products, said it believes that Clingers does not infringe any patents held by 3M for that company's Post-It product and that the suit was without merit.

title: Russian, 17, Reunited With Mother in Vienna
description: A 17-year-old Soviet youth allowed to immigrate to the United States was reunited with his mother today after more than six years of separation, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: Coffee Prices Climb; Orange Juice Tumbles
description: Coffee prices shot back up today, following a three-week decline, when the International Coffee Organization failed to release extra supplies of coffee onto the market.

description: A Queens man strangled his 14-year-old nephew and took his own life by hanging himself with a bedsheet in the apartment where the two lived, the police said.

ROZELLE CITES TV, CROWD GAINS
description: With one year remaining on the National Football League's contracts with the three major television networks, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today that ratings for games on each network had increased and that attendance was close to what it was in 1981, the league's best at the gate.

title: U.S. NAVY EXERCISE STARTS OFF LIBYA
description: United States Navy carrier jets began operations north of Libya today, and the State Department said the weeklong naval maneuvers were intended to demonstrate ''U.S. resolve to continue to operate in international waters and airspace.''

title: QADDAFI SAYS HE HAS CALLED 'FULL ALERT'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that he had placed Libya's armed forces on ''full alert'' in response to United States air and naval maneuvers off the coast of Libya.

title: Lockheed, Wang Get U.S. Contracts
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company has been awarded a $467.9 million Army contract for work on the Strategic Defense Initiative, the Army said.

title: Fox-Time Venture
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation has joined with Time Inc.'s Home Box Office pay-television unit to show Fox films through HBO, co-finance original productions and distribute theatrical motion pictures produced by HBO. Under the first agreement, HBO will receive the non-exclusive domestic pay-television rights to Fox films through 1988, including such current releases as ''Cocoon'' and ''Jewel of the Nile'' as well as older releases and five Charlie Chaplin classics. Fox and HBO will also finance the production of HBO Premiere Films and other original programs to be produced by HBO, the companies said.

GROGAN'S EASY BUT TOUGH JOB
description: Reality has been double-teamed here this week. But despite the disadvantage of being matched against that overwhelming combination of excess and foolishness, reality has fought off the blocks, gotten to the quarterback, and sacked Steve Grogan for a loss.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Politics and Passion In Argentina
description: In ''Alfonsin's One-Man Show'' (Dec. 15), Lydia Chavez identifies the Argentine temperament as a major explanation for the repeated failures of democracy in Argentina, when she writes that Argentine history ''is propelled by dramatic emotional swings.'' This view lends credence to the widely held -and largely racist - notion that Latin Americans are somehow so charged with emotion and passion that their culture is incompatible with democracy, which demands restraint and compromise.

title: ALBANY FINANCES HOMETOWN PROJECTS
description: The city of Oswego got $5,000 for monitoring mosquitoes, the Town of Goshen $150,000 for a water tower and the 47th Senate District $40,000 for concerts. A center for Tibetan art received $50,000 and scores of Little Leagues got $1,000 each.

title: Topics; Magic and Specters No Problem
description: The new balanced-budget law is routinely, though falsely, advertised as requiring budget cuts ''across the board.'' That suggests universality, implying every Government project and activity will be cut by the same percentage.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
A SHUFFLIN' CREW ON THE BOWERY
description: WE were walking along the Bowery the other day when we came across the Bear superfan. He was at the corner of Houston Street wearing a blue-and-orange Chicago Bears stocking cap. While doing unsolicited windshield cleaning work, he sang: ''We are the Bears' shufflin' crew, shufflin' on down, doin' it for you.''

title: UNDER THE WHEELS OF PROGRESS
description: PANDAEMONIUM #1660-1886. The Coming of the Machine as Seen by Contemporary Observers. By Humphrey Jennings. Edited by Mary-Lou Jennings and Charles Madge. Illustrated. 376 pp. New York: The Free Press. $17.95. ORWELL, in ''The Road to Wigan Pier,'' laments the fact that ''Socialism, as usually presented, is bound up with the idea of mechanical progress . . . as an end in itself, almost as a kind of religion. . . . The Socialist is always in favour of mechanization, rationalization, modernization - or at least thinks that he ought to be.''

title: Carol Landorf to Wed Thomas Frank Lowell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Landorf of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Ann Landorf to Thomas Frank Lowell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lowell of Mount Kisco, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEW LEADER AT SPACE CENTER
description: Jesse W. Moore, the chief of shuttle operations for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has been named director of the Johnson Space Center here, the space agency announced Thursday.

title: Karen Ann Boe Wed in Vermont
description: Karen Anne Boe and John Adams Morgan Jr. were married yesterday at the Chapel of the Snows in Stratton Mountain, Vt., by the Rev. Robert A. Bryan, an Anglican priest.

title: FOR BING DEVINE, SUPER BOWL IS NOT A WORLD SERIES
description: BING DEVINE is not in New Orleans today. He is in St. Louis, at home. He would be in New Orleans, of course, if the Cardinals were playing in the Super Bowl today, but Bing Devine never stayed home from a World Series, even if the Cardinals were not playing in it.

title: LAND AND TAXES: 2 VIEWS OF A SUIT
description: WHETHER a lawsuit scheduled to go to trial tomorrow in Morris County Superior Court involves an attempt by land barons to try to maintain their extraordinary tax benefits, or an attempt by environmentalists and conservationists to try to hold back developers' bulldozers, depends on which side you talk to.

title: Net Lessees Must Pay Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: PULITZER TO STEP DOWN AT PAPER IN ST. LOUIS
description: Joseph Pulitzer Jr. will step down as editor and publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch on March 31, the Pulitzer Publishing Company announced today.

title: EVERYTHING ABOUT THE GAME - EXCEPT THE GAME
description: The problem of what to do for an encore is a frequent one in many pursuits; the problem of what to do for a centerpiece crops up rather less often. But that is precisely the situation faced today by ESPN which is presenting 15 1/2 hours of programming relating to the Super Bowl without being able to present the game itself. The rights to that were acquired long ago by NBC.

title: MISSING PERSONS: POLICE ROLE STESSED
description: A YEAR'S study by the New Jersey Commission on Missing Persons has recommended that the Legislature require police departments to investigate immediately all calls that someone is missing.

title: A SAMPLING OF WARES FROM KODAK'S '86 LINE
description: EASTMAN KODAK has unveiled some of the 50 new products it plans to market this year - 15 items varying from compact 35-millimeter cameras to negative color films said to produce truer colors.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is reviewing a proposal for a development in Brick Township that some clammers say may endanger their livelihood.

title: ENGLAND'S MODERN COMPOSERS SOUND A TIMELESS NOTE
description: The English composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor (1875-1912) was born in London of mixed West African and English parentage. Like so many men of genius, he was an early achiever. In fact, the work that made him famous and by which he is now remembered, the cantata ''Hiawatha's Wedding Feast,'' was completed by the time he was 23.

title: INAUGURAL BENEFITS SPECIAL OLYMPICS
description: GOVERNOR and Mrs. Kean presented a check for $150,000 last week to New Jersey Special Olympics Inc. The money - far more than was expected - was raised at a party arranged by the Governor's wife, Debby, as part of the inaugural festivities honoring Mr. Kean.

title: BALLET TO HELP MARK OPERA ANNIVERSITY
description: WHEN the New Jersey State Opera celebrates its 20th anniversary with Gounod's ''Faust'' at Symphony Hall here next Sunday, the New Jersey Ballet Company will be up there on stage, too.

title: Gander Searchers Find More Identification Clues
description: Searchers combing a hillside where a DC-8 plane crash killed 248 United States soldiers and 8 crew members say they have found wallets, military dogtags and burned bits of medical records that could help identify bodies.

title: VIENNA
description: Vienna is one of the most popular cities in Europe. Based on hotel occupancy last year, the Austrian capital ranked fourth among European destinations - behind London, Paris and Rome and ahead of Venice, Florence and Amsterdam - according to the city's leading newspaper, Die Presse. Out of every 100 visitors to Vienna, 15 were Americans.

title: TAR HEELS TOP GEORGIA TECH
description: The surprise today was not that North Carolina dispatched Georgia Tech, rather it was the ease with which the top-ranked Tar Heels rolled to an 85-77 victory before 21,444 fans at the Dean E. Smith Student Activities Center. It was North Carolina's 20th victory without a loss and the second against a top opponent in eight days.

title: A CORRECTION
description: A chart on Libyan trade in The Week in Review Jan. 12 contained misleading figures in some categories. In 1984, Libya's exports to the Soviet bloc were $746 million and its imports were $444 million.

title: SOVIET NAMES A NEW POLICE CHIEF
description: The Soviet Union today dismissed Vitaly V. Fedorchuk, 67 years old, as Interior Minister and replaced him with a provincial party leader.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the Home Video page of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misidentified the actress with Gary Cooper in the film ''Friendly Persuasion.'' She was Dorothy McGuire.

title: OUR FIRST CENTURY BEHIND THE WHEEL
description: THE argument has been going on for a long time.

title: MORE QUESTIONS ABOUT SHOREHAM
description: According to Herbert Jaffe, a director of the Association of Investors in New York Utilities Inc. [ ''Blocking Shoreham Blocks L.I. Growth,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 5 ] , ''the Governor and the Suffolk County Legislature are strapping Long Island into an electric chair.'' Mr. Jaffe refers to opposition to Lilco's evacuation plan for Shoreham as ''absurd,'' and the substitution of cheap and plentiful Canadian hydroelectric power as a ''myth.''

title: Miss Eisenman Engaged
description: The engagement of Sue Ann Eisenman, an editorial assistant at Woman's Day magazine, to Richard Evan Saslaw, a financial analyst with the Bristol-Myers Company, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ben Eisenman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving M. Saslaw of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Miss Eisenman and Mr. Saslaw graduated from the University of Florida and Lehigh University, respectively.

title: HBO FIGHT SERIES HAS ITS CHALLENGERS
description: As further details of Home Box Office's proposed series of fights to unify the heavyweight championship became known this week, promoters, lawyers and managers not in on the deal were scrambling to counteract the effects of the package.

title: Patton's Pistol Grips
description: To the Editor:

title: ADD THE ENVIRONMENT TO THE '86 WISH LIST
description: I went back over the statements of all 12 of your ''random selection'' of prominent Long Island residents quoted in ''Year Ahead: Prospects and Problems - Long Islanders Look Into Crystal Ball for '86'' [ Dec. 29 ] . I sought in vain for any reference to agriculture (except Nassau County grapes), the farmland preservation program of Suffolk County and East End towns, or the fishing industry.

title: JULIUS ADAMS
description: JULIUS ADAMS was worried the other night. His mother, whom he brought in from Macon, Ga., to see him play in the final game of his career, was back in her hotel room, ill with the flu.

title: DANCE: AILEY REPERTORY
description: THE Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble was formed by Mr. Ailey in 1974 as a workshop group of selected, gifted students. The concept was originally for a company that would serve as a bridge from the classroom to the stage. The ensemble became a company in its own right, with vital performances by well-trained young dancers.

title: A RARE LOOK AT THE ARTS OF JAPAN
description: SCHEHERAZADE WOVE her magic of 1,001 tales to save her life. In a similar ploy, people in premodern Japan often attempted to ward off evil spirits at night by telling stories. Story-telling held such a distinctive place in Japan that by the 10th century, it had become a literary and pictorial art form with few parallels in the world. A century later, what is perhaps the world's earliest full novel - ''Genji Monogatari'' - was written by a Japanese noblewoman, Murasaki Shikibu. In ''The Tale of Genji,'' Lady Murasaki details not only the life and loves of Prince Genji, but also the court mores and morals of her day.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: William J. Williams Jr., a vice president of the United States Golf Association, was elected president of the organization. He replaces James R. Hand. . . . John Goldner, who helped develop Madison Square Garden's basketball program in a 50-year career with the organization, will retire as a Garden consultant on his 75th birthday, Feb. 1. . . . Steve Rogers, who won 156 games and lost 148 in a 12-year career with the Montreal Expos, has scrapped his plans for a comeback attempt and retired.

title: THOUSANDS MOURN DETECTIVE KILLED ON QUEENS STAKE-OUT
description: Thousands of relatives, friends and police officers gathered yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mel in Flushing, Queens, for the funeral of Detective Anthony J. Venditti, who was shot to death Tuesday while on an organized-crime stake-out.

title: BIG BEN GLITTERS ANEW
description: The famous London clocktower that houses Big Ben is again visible in all its restored glory. The clocktower had been shrouded since 1983 as part of a major repair, cleaning and restoration program of the Palace of Westminster.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MORE THAN FRIEND: The Letters of Robert Browning to Katharine de Kay Bronson. Edited by Michael Meredith. (Wedgestone Press, P.O. Box 175, Winfield, Kan. 67156, $25.)

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT TREES ACCENT THE LANDSCAPE
description: WHILE most trees have round or oval forms that provide a certain mass in the winter landscape, it is the less common tree with a vertical, horizontal or weeping form that stands out from the rest.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS A CITY FOR '88
description: The Republican National Committee has begun the process of selecting the city for the Republican National Convention of 1988. Atlanta, Kansas City, Las Vegas, Philadelphia, San Diego, Seattle, St. Louis, Los Angeles, Houston and several Florida cities have applied, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the party's chairman, told his executive committee this week. The committee ratified an agreement between him and Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Democratic national chairman, for the parties to take over Presidential debates, sponsored in the past by the League of Women Voters.

title: KEY 'PIZZA CONNECTION' WITNESS HOLDS TO ACCOUNT OF DRUG MEETING
description: A key witness has ended extensive testimony in the ''pizza connection'' trial by adhering to his accusation that four defendants participated in a Mafia meeting about a large heroin shipment.

title: OLD WAYS OF PORTLAND VS. THE NEW
description: On Friday nights the Porthole Restaurant, a well-worn luncheonette whose windows advertise ''Wonderful Food,'' ''Good Prices'' and ''Coca-Cola,'' serves its neighbors on Custom House Wharf an all-you-can-eat fish fry for $2.50.

title: Getting to the Show At the Coliseum
description: The Greater New York International Automobile Show runs through Feb. 2 at the New York Coliseum, Columbus Circle (59th Street, Broadway and Eighth Avenue), from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. today and next Sunday and from 11 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. weekdays and Saturday. Admission is $6 for adults and $3 for children 12 and under.

title: Orchestras' Well-Being
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM IDEA TO STAGE IN TWO(SIC) WEEKS
description: SOME musicals seem to take a millennium to materialize.

title: ARGUING THE MERITS OF HUGH HUDSON'S 'REVOLUTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: ILLITERATE LETTER COSTS TEACHER
description: A school principal hired to be a teacher at the age of 19 was forced to give up his certificate after he wrote an error-ridden letter pleading to keep his job when officials queried his education.

title: RETURN OF THE COMET MAN
description: I BEEN THERE BEFORE By David Carkeet. 314 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95. IT is a well-known cosmic coincidence that Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, was born during one visit of Halley's Comet to our solar system in 1835 and died during another in 1910. In his biography ''Mr. Clemens and Mark Twain,'' Justin Kaplan reports Clemens's version of what God was no doubt saying about Halley's Comet and Mark Twain: ''Here are these unaccountable freaks. . . . They came in together and they must go out together.'' Mr. Kaplan adds, ''Like his Connecticut Yankee, he was 'getting up his last effect': he was to die at sunset on April 21, one day after the comet reached its perihelion.'' Clemens did not exactly stop his breath and die; he was 75 years old and suffering from heart failure. Still, the coincidence, like Mark Twain himself, has all but passed into American folklore.

title: Parlay Voo
description: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed ''Parlay Voo Anything ?''; now let's be fair and present le cote francais as well.

title: Reagan's Man For Education
description: I feel that Education Secretary William J. Bennett is on target when he sees the emergence of a ''national curriculum'' (''Reagan's Man for Education,'' by Edward B. Fiske, Dec. 22). The United States would benefit from consistency in education.

title: HIGHWAY DEATHS CONTINUE TO DROP
description: FOLLOWING the state's first New Year's holiday with no highway fatalities, and the release of figures showing that such deaths dropped by 4.7 percent in 1985, officials say they are looking forward to a continued decline in injuries and deaths on the state's roads.

title:
ART;
THREE ARTISTS WHO CHALLENGE THE POTENTIAL OF PASTELS
description: PASTEL is a medium of many possibilities, capable of sensuous texture, linear nuance and vibrant color.

title: CALANDRA'S DEATH LEAVES 'SAFE SEAT' FOR G.O.P. IN DOUBT
description: THE death last week of State Senator John D. Calandra, a Republican whose district included the north Bronx and parts of southern Westchester, represented to his constituents the loss of an outspoken and effective legislator and the emergence of a political problem for his party.

title: PRETORIA'S HOT PURSUIT OF THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
description: South Africa's long-running, dogged campaign against the African National Congress and its allies seemed last week to have paid a harsh if ambiguous dividend. After a three-week blockade by Pretoria, the Government of neighboring Lesotho, which had been showing increased hostility to South Africa, fell in a military coup. In one of the new regime's first acts, Lesotho's military rulers demonstrated a more conciliatory policy toward South Africa by ordering followers of the Congress deported to black-ruled countries farther north. Yesterday, South Africa announced that it would lift the blockade of Lesotho, and nearly 60 A.N.C. supporters arrived in Zambia.

title: LIFE, DEATH, LAUGHS IN 'STEAMBATH'
description: BRUCE JAY FRIEDMAN'S ''Steambath'' is a too-rarely-revived black comedy that is receiving a stellar production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: COUNTY ADOPTION UNIT CITES POTENTIAL OF STATE'S NEW COMPUTERIZED REGISTRY
description: WHEN 13-year-old LaJuana was first removed from her home at age 6, she had been so severely neglected as to require hospitalization for malnutrition and anemia. Since then, she has lived with four different foster families and is now in a residential center for children. Though LaJuana is ''legally free'' for adoption and says she wants to find a home, social workers in the county's adoption unit say they have had no luck finding an appropriate placement - despite a yearlong search. LaJuana's story, adoption workers say, is all too typical of ''hard-to-place'' children around the state, 800 of whom today wait for a place to call ''home.''

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT TREES ACCENT THE LANDSCAPE
description: WHILE most trees have round or oval forms that provide a certain mass in the winter landscape, it is the less common tree with a vertical, horizontal or weeping form that stands out from the rest.

title: NEW PLANS SEEK TO EASE CROWDING AT NASSAU JAIL
description: AFTER a decade of overcrowding at the Nassau County jail, local officials, the courts and lawyers representing the prisoners are still seeking ways to solve the problem.

title: VITAL ARTERY GASHED BY NAVAL SURGEON, COURT-MARTIAL TOLD
description: Dr. Donal M. Billig once slashed a patient's main artery and panicked as blood spurted from the three-quarter-inch gash, a witness testified Friday at the Navy surgeon's court-martial.

title: Finding New Ways to Use Old Churches
description: THE spare white clapboard church with its soaring steeple is one of the most enduring architectural symbols of New England. Usually situated on a town green or at a main traffic intersection, the church not only serves as a center for religious life, but it also sets the tone for the community.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: A GUIDE to state government developed and sponsored by the League of Women Voters of New Jersey made its debut earlier this month at a ''spotlight celebration'' at which the league and its publisher were the hosts.

title: Patricia Salas to Wed Dr. Harlan K. Cohen
description: Announcement has been made by Margarita Valencia Salas of Willemstad, Curacao, of the engagement of her daughter Patricia Louise Salas to Dr. Harlan Kurtz Cohen, a son of Acting Justice Charles H. Cohen of New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Cohen of Astoria, Queens. An April wedding is planned.

title: 20 FOOD OUTLETS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 20 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
ABOUT CARS;
DADDY'S LITTLE GIRL AND TODAY'S MERCEDES
description: SHE was 12 years old, and her name was Mercedes Jellinek.

title: TAPES PLAYED AT MOB TRIAL FOCUS ON MONEY AND POWER
description: Tapes of a secretly recorded 1983 conversation involving reputed Colombo and Gambino crime-organization figures appear to support assertions by officials that there is a governing commission of organized-crime leaders.

title: INDICTED LAWMAKER ANGERED BY REPORTS OF SECRET TAPINGS
description: Representative Bobbi Fiedler, indicted on charges of campaign improprieties, voiced outrage today at reports that the Los Angeles District Attorney's office had secretly taped talks between herself and a rival campaign official.

title: TV SPORTS MONEY MACHINE FALTERS
description: AT THE START OF EVERY WEEK-end during the football season, before the flickering images of the games showed up on the nation's television screens, a new pregame ritual took place out of the view of the fans. The scene of the action was the Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan, where the three broadcast networks are headquartered within five blocks of one another. In offices perched high above the avenue, network advertising salesmen engaged in ''Friday afternoon fire sales.'' Glued to their telephones, the salesmen eagerly, often desperately, took whatever they could get at the last minute for commercial spots on top-rated weekend games.

title: OLSON VAULTS 19-4, INDOOR BEST
description: Billy Olson bettered his world-indoor best in the pole-vault by going 19 feet 4 inches on his first attempt at that height during tonight's Albuquerque Jaycee Invitational track and field meet.

title: 15 FROM NEW YORK ARE AMONG FINALISTS FOR SCIENCE AWARDS
description: Fifteen high-school students from New York State, including three each from the Bronx High School of Science and Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Queens, were among the 40 national winners named last week in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL, 'AFRICANIS INSTRUCTUS'
description: ANTICIPATION runs high at ''Africanis Instructus,'' the new Richard Foreman-Stanley Silverman musical at St. Clement's. These creative collaborators (''Dr. Selavy's Magic Theater,'' ''Hotel for Criminals'') have undertaken the challenging subject of colonial expansionism and African exploration.

title: A Pulse-Quickening History of Polygraphs
description: To the Editor:

title: EYELESS WITH BRUEGEL
description: THE PARABLE OF THE BLIND By Gert Hofmann. Translated by Christopher Middleton. 152 pp. New York: Fromm International Publishing. $14.95.

title: Dance
description: The Atlanta Ballet, founded in 1929, is not only America's oldest ballet company, it is also BCBC's dance company-in-residence. It returns for its third engagement at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Friday and Saturday nights and next Sunday afternoon.

title: A NEW COAT SILHOUETTE
description: SUDDENLY, it seems, coats have waistlines. Or at least waistlines have been rediscovered. After years of straight coats and puffy down coats, there is discernible movement in the direction of coats that fit snugly at the waist, then spread out to the fullness of a waltz skirt.

title: CORNELL SPURNS GRANTS GIVEN WITHOUT REVIEW
description: At a time when some universities are getting direct research grants by lobbying in Congress, Cornell University has declared it will accept such money only if it is free of politics and subject to competitive bidding by colleges.

title: Reagan's Man For Education
description: As a religious leader in this nation, I welcome the call for a new ''national conversation and debate on the place of religious belief in our society.''

title: Parlay Voo
description: To the Editor: Ira Berkow's article, ''Parlay Voo Anything ?'' (Travel, Dec. 29), brought back memories and chuckles about some of our linguistic problems in France and England.

title: CAMPAIGN STARTED TO LICENSE DOGS
description: A SEARCH to find unlicensed dogs will get under way throughout the state on Saturday.

title: RANGERS BRINGH UP LAROUCHE
description: They have tried all kinds of experiments, including line changes, other personnel switches and new strategies to perk up their offense. Nothing worked.

title: ISRAEL'S RECIPE FOR DINING
description: Aside from the justly famed fruits and vegetables of its kibbutzim, Israel has been generally excused as too young, too austere and too involved with the basics of state-building to have developed a national cuisine. The subject hardly seems to worry the Israelis: they're too busy enjoying a home-cooked international smorgasbord.

title: THE CLOUD ON THE PHOENIX HORIZON IS MADE UP OF SMOG
description: For much of this century, East Coast physicians had a standard prescription for patients suffering from serious respiratory ailments: Send them to Arizona, where the air is fresh and clean.

description: Danny Glover was sitting at a table by the picture window of an Upper West Side restaurant - all 6 feet 3 1/2 inches of him - in green leather pants and tooled leather cowboy boots, and barely a passer-by seemed to notice.

description: AN INTERESTING mounting of vintage photographs and collectible artifacts broadly relating to the history of rail transportation in Middlesex County is the latest enticement to visit the Cornelius Low House on River Road here.

description: THE NIGHTINGALE: Or The Saga of Yosele Solovey the Cantor. By Sholom Aleichem. Translated by Aliza Shevrin. (Putnam, $16.95.) Aliza Shevrin offers readers of ''The Nightingale'' ''a small prize'' for telling her what chata pokrishke means.

description: Federal officials confirmed last week that they had found a pattern in their continuing investigation of home mortgage fraud. Across the country, they said, real-estate investors have used similar methods in defrauding the Department of Housing and Urban Development of tens of millions of dollars.

description: JOURNALS 1939-1983 By Stephen Spender. Edited by John Goldsmith. Illustrated. 510 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. COLLECTED POEMS 1928-1985 By Stephen Spender. 204 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. IN February 1960 Stephen Spender - Sir Stephen

description: Earth's Bounty, Sky's Beauty A tour bound for New Zealand and Australia in April offers its participants terrestrial as well as celestial attractions.

title: Troops Mobilized In Hormel Strike
description: ''We are under seige in this town,'' a senior vice president of Geo. A. Hormel & Company said last week as Minnesota National Guardsmen were called out to preserve order in Austin, near the Iowa border. Local officials requested the Guardsmen Monday after striking meatpackers blocked two gates at the company's plant so applicants and new workers could not enter and those inside could not leave.

title: John Hildt to Wed Elizabeth Alling
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Alling Jr. of New York and Kennebunk, Me., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Dwight Alling to John Bradley Hildt, a son of John Hildt and the late Patricia Hildt of Gates Mills, Ohio, and Harbour Island, the Bahamas. An August wedding is planned.

title: SYRIA HAS TRIED TO KEEP ITS TIES TO THE RUSSIANS ELASTIC
description: At the recent Syrian air academy graduation in Aleppo, 200 Soviet advisers and their families received almost as much attention as the graduates. On Friday afternoons, when Government offices are closed, Soviet families go on weekend outings with Syrian military escorts. And the state-controlled newspapers in Damascus publish frequent dispatches from Tass, the Soviet press agency, praising Syrian-style socialism.
