title: INTRUDER FOUND IN FERRARO OFFICE
description: A burglar carrying a camera was discovered in the offices of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro yesterday afternoon by an aide to Mrs. Ferraro who apparently surprised the intruder, the police said.

title: BETWEEN C.I.A. AND K.G.B. IN AFGHANISTAN
description: LIE DOWN WITH LIONS By Ken Follett. 333 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Thatcher Loses a Lieutenant
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's critics have made the most of a controversy over her Government's handling of the case of a small bankrupt helicopter manufacturer.

title: JOYS OF ADJUSTING TO THE RURAL LIFE
description: THIS past July, I sold my condominium on Strawberry Hill Avenue, which was 10 minutes' walk from the Stamford Town Center. I wanted a change and bought a Cape Cod on a Sandy Hook hillside that is two miles from the general store at the intersection where the bridge crosses the Pootatuck River. I swapped four rooms and a bath in 880 square feet for seven rooms and one-and-a-half baths in 2,100 square feet. I traded 7 acres of common property filled with 500 cars for a half-acre of greenery. Monetarily speaking, it was an almost even swap. I surrendered a 6-by-10-foot terrace, concrete with iron railing all around, for a 12-by-25-foot deck, natural wood all around. The terrace was suspended over the Stamford skyline, and for eight years I watched new buildings rise. At the beginning, I thought the development was exciting, but soon the glossy buildings jutted higher and higher and blocked my view of the sound on those moonlit nights when water shimmered with light. My new deck also juts, but over a lawn that slopes gently down into my own small and tangled forest. I counted my trees the other day; I own 78, and I will be adding a few blue spruces. I'm in control of the view from my deck.

title: Social Events; Beneficial Parties
description: Review and Preview Jan. 27 - Now in its 70th year, the Drama League serves the theater with programs that include aid for fledgling directors and playwrights. Marvin Hamlisch will be the host at a black-tie dinner benefit at the Pierre that will include a retrospective of five decades of musical theater as well as songs from two coming shows, ''Captain America'' and ''Back on the Town.'' Cocktails at 7:45 P.M. Tickets, $150, from 212-302-2100. Statue of Liberty Party Jan. 28 - A party for the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation will have foods from almost as many countries as supplied immigrants for this country. The setting is the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center, not far from the 100-year-old symbol of liberty. Cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by a black-tie dinner-dance. Tickets, $100, from 212-938-9100, extension 7215. For the Family of Man Jan. 30 - The Council of Churches of the City of New York founded the interfaith and international Society for the Family in 1963 with a simple credo: All people belong to one family under God. At its annual award dinner at the Pierre, Governor and Mrs. Cuomo, Harry Belafonte and others will be honored for their dedication to that principle. Cocktails at 7 P.M. start the black-tie evening that includes singing by Judy Collins. Tickets, $300, from 212-749-1214. Scholarships for Israel Jan. 30 - There are some 12,000 students in Everyman's University, Israel's open university where students mostly pursue their studies at home or while serving in the military.

title: Simple Plan Allows Human Control Over the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: DETROIT PLAYS CATCH-UP
description: THE 1963 Pontiac GTO set the style for muscle cars. It was a plebian hardtop, but fitted with a 335-horsepower engine, big tires, and some special trim, it became a king of the road. The GTO was cheap and popular, and the rest of the industry soon copied it with a succession of Road Runners, Boss 302's, 440 Magnums, and the like. From a stoplight, they'd burn the rubber off the tires and often leave outraged citizens in their smoke.

title: Dropping the Bomb
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT-SO-ORGANIZED CRIME
description: WISE GUY Life in a Mafia Family. By Nicholas Pileggi. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE STORYTELLER. By Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Someday Harold Robbins is going to wash his mouth out with soap and call it quits, but until then, here comes ''The Storyteller,'' his 19th novel. There are 10 things you need to know before you purchase or don't purchase it, according to your custom. (1) It is possibly autobiographical, at least in part, because when the hero, Joe Crown, an aspiring novelist, is asked what he expects from his career, he replies, ''I want money.'' (2) Most of the words in the book have only one or two syllables (and four or five letters), but in the case of adverbs Mr. Robbins will stretch it to seven syllables or even eight (''unenthusiastically''). (3) The book boasts some hilarious lines, such as ''A good pimp has to be born, not taught.'' (4) This is an adult book in the sense that for plenitude and monotony of sex scenes it could be stocked wherever ''Adult Books'' are sold. (5) As Joe Crown travels from the Brooklyn of 1942 to Hollywood to Europe and the top of his profession -buying his way out of the draft, managing a high-class West Side bordello, climbing in and out of beds and bathtubs, writing in spare moments - he meets few women but many ''girls.'' (6) The only honor observed in the tale is among racketeers. (7) Mr. Robbins's women - well, girls - get slapped around plenty; as Joe explains, ''She probably wanted it.'' (8) Facts are treated cavalierly - in 1949, Audrey Hepburn was not an American movie star, nor were Sophia Loren and Carlo Ponti gossip column fodder. (9) Lesbians abound, but there are no male homosexuals. (10) A more appropriate title, since there isn't much in the way of storytelling, might be ''The Draft Dodger,'' ''The Pimp'' or ''The Best-Selling Author.''

title: MERRILL MYSTERY
description: So far, it has been a dismal year in the oil patch. The recent slide in oil prices to the $20-a-barrel level - and predictions that $15-a-barrel crude oil is not out of the question - have cast a pall over the whole sector.

title: REDMEN EDGE PITT BEHIND BERRY'S 34
description: After watching Walter Berry score 35 points against Duke earlier this season, Bob Ferry, the general manager of the Washington Bullets, marveled that ''when there's a big shot to be made, he makes it; if there's a key shot to be blocked, he blocks it; if there's a play to be made on the boards, he gets the offensive rebound. Whenever it's time to come through, he's there. That's greatness.''

title: THE FREE EXERCISE THEREOF
description: THE FIRST LIBERTY Religion and the American Republic. By William Lee Miller. 373 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. RELIGIOUS OUTSIDERS AND THE MAKING OF AMERICANS By R. Laurence Moore. 243 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: REACH OUT AND SCRATCH SOMEONE
description: BAD MANNERS By Maggie Paley. 198 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $14.95. IF forced to choose, many of us would surrender our television before our telephone. Telephone calls feel like palliatives for some kinds of modern isolation.

title: MORE QUESTIONS ABOUT SHOREHAM

Yet such a drill does nothing to answer questions about:

title:
LIFE AND DEATH: THE STRUGGLE TO CLARIFY LEGAL, MEDICAL AND EHICAL ISSUES;
PANEL PROMOTES PUBLIC DISCUSSION
description: MARCIA - I've been on kidney dialysis most of my adult life, and I really don't want to continue with it.

title: Housing Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: COALITION SEEKS DOWNZONING ON EAST SIDE MIDBLOCKS
description: TROUBLED by what they believe is the threat of further high-rise development in their East Side neighborhoods, a coalition of community groups has been formed to press for zoning changes that would scale down allowable heights for new buildings on side streets.

title: IN BELGIUM, FRITES ARE A SALTY TRADITION
description: As a couple of hungry customers wait in line, Jean-Paul Desmiet eases a kilo of sliced potatoes into a sizzling vat of vegetable grease, which bubbles with volcanic fervor. The unmistakable aroma of french fries, known here as frites, pours out of the cramped, open-air stand at a busy intersection in Brussels. While traffic lights change and cars roar by, Mr. Desmiet uses a giant spatula to skillfully nudge the frites around the vat, and then scoops them up in a smooth motion, depositing the new french fries into a steel wok, where they glisten under the somber light of another cloudy day in Belgium. ''This,'' says Mr. Desmiet, shaking some salt onto the fries as he hands them to a customer, ''is a Belgian tradition.''

title: TWAIN ON STAGE: HOW MUCH TO TELL?
description: In reviewing ''A Mark Twain Birthday Celebration'' [ Dec. 29 ] , Leah D. Frank raises an interesting point -how far can a playwright rely on the audience to fill in any gap he may have left in dealing with the life of a renowned literary figure?

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: In painting, a masterpiece is unique. In photography, however, a masterpiece may be shadowed by a whole series of slightly different versions known only to specialists in the field. The aim of the exhibition ''Variants,'' organized by John Szarkowski at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, through March 11, is to teach the rest of us something about the nature of photography by showing a number of well-known photographs by acknowledged masters along with little-known variants by the same masters. If in the process the idea of what constitutes a photographic masterpiece gets slightly smudged, so much the worse for it.

title: 8 Dead as 27 Vehicles Pile Up in Arkansas Fog
description: Eight people were killed and more than a dozen were injured in a 27-vehicle, chain-reaction accident in dense fog today, the police said.

title: PERFORMANCE IS BACK, NO LONGER MUSCLE-BOUND
description: In past years, high-performance cars were as common at local drive-in restaurants as cheeseburgers. They were good old American coupes with big, powerful engines driven by teen-agers in blue jeans. Then, like the drive-in, high-performance cars faded away, their extinction hastened by ruinous insurance rates and accelerated fuel costs.

title: MARCOS REPORTED TO LOSE SUPPORT IN ADMINISTRATION
description: A consensus has developed in the Reagan Administration that the departure of President Ferdinand E. Marcos is critical to a non-Communist future for the Philippines and American interests in that country.

title: COUNSEL FOR PATS FANS
description: IN the pro football season before I met Jim in September 1964, the Boston Patriots had parlayed a 7-6-1 record and a 26-8 divisional playoff victory over the Buffalo Bills into a championship encounter with the San Diego Chargers. That proved to be poor judgment on the part of the Pats; they got creamed, 51-10.

title: SERVING CHICKEN WHOLE ADDS UP TO MORE THAN ITS PARTS
description: CHICKEN is one of the cheapest meats on the market. It has become as common as the hamburger for a fast meal. But not all that long ago it was an expensive dish, usually served for company. On those occasions, it was most often roasted.

title: FRANK G. RAICHLE, 87, A BUFFALO TRIAL LAWYER
description: Frank G. Raichle, who practiced law in Buffalo for 65 years and was one of the best-known trial lawyers in the state, died Friday at Buffalo General Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 26, 1986
description: International

title: COMING UP FOR KEAN: HOW TO PAY FOR CLEANUP
description: GOVERNOR KEAN has delivered two major speeches to the Legislature in the last two weeks, outlining more than 30 initiatives for improving the state's economy, education and environment and asking for support. Now comes the hard part. On Feb. 10, he must appear before the Legislature again and explain how he expects to pay for his programs.

title: DENT WANTS RING AND RAISE
description: It was a little more than 24 hours to the kickoff of Super Bowl XX, and Richard Dent was relaxed.

title: L.I. YOUTH HELD IN WILD DRIVE
description: A Long Island youth was charged with second-degree criminal mischief today after a car he was driving knocked over eight aluminum street-light poles and 19 traffic signs, the Nassau County police said. The youth, Jeffrey Frame, 17 years old, of Levittown, ran over the poles, 15 stop signs, two speed-limit signs, a school stop sign and a no-stopping sign at about 2 A.M. near Ranch and Abbey Lanes, a police spokesman said.

title: PREHISTORY'S UNDERGROUND MUSEUMS
description: The most emotional moment of a visit to the prehistoric cave of Lascaux in southwestern France a few weeks ago was seeing handprints of the humans who created the most beautiful art of the Stone Age. They really were there, 15,000 years ago.

title: IMAGES THAT REPRESENT DEEP BITES OF FORBIDDEN FRUIT
description: Until recently, photographers who aspired to be artists were content to draw their stylistic inspiration from painting - not surprisingly, since art traditionally has taken its cues from other art. But in the last 10 years they have widened their sights, cannibalizing (and sometimes capitalizing on) the styles of fashion photography, photojournalism and Hollywood glamour portraiture. These genres, in most respects diverse, share two features: they are directed at a mass audience, and they are governed more by commercial intentions than by esthetic ones. Neither feature would appear to endear them to the art world.

title: A Shakeout At Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines clipped some wings last week to keep its planes aloft. Under pressure from creditors threatening to call in $2.5 billion in debt unless the airline trims its costs by the end of February, Eastern cut the wages of flight attendants by 20 percent and lengthened their work week.

title: You Are What The Family Was
description: No one irritates overweight people more than thin friends who gorge on pizza and cheesecake, never seeming to gain an ounce.

title: A Reminder of the Government's Bounty
description: A state embodies and magnifies the frailties of man and his capacity for good or ill. Unchecked and unopposed, it can be an engine of oppression, sweeping hordes to concentration camps or Gulags. Held within democratic bounds by free citizens, it is an indispensable instrument of progress.

title: THE KREMLIN WORRIES THAT TOO MANY KNOW TOO MUCH
description: Many foreigners who did business in the Soviet Union in the old days were familiar with the Russian technician known as ''the hammer man.'' Whenever one of their photocopying machines was ready for the scrap heap, the Soviet Government summoned him to break it beyond repair.

title: TOPICS
description: TURNING 30 wasn't half as traumatic as I'd imagined. I had the usual party with my family, and when my father asked his yearly question, ''So, do you feel any older?'' I automatically shook my head and said no.

title: IN QUEENS, VOLUNTEERS MONITOR COURT SYSTEM
description: When Janet Egan works at the Queens Criminal Court Building, she spends her time watching the lawyers, prosecutors, judges and courthouse employees do their jobs.

title: And for the Coffee Table:
description: There is no shortage of printed opinion in Washington, but this does not deter those determined to start new publications. Two of the most recent are Defense News, a weekly newspaper, and The Washington Book Review, a monthly with a tabloid format similar to The New York Review of Books.

title: HELPING INVESTORS AVOID THE DOWNTURNS
description: A growing number of investors are using mutual funds, once considered strictly holdings for the long haul, as shorter-term market trading vehicles. In response, newsletters and advisory services have proliferated to help investors decide when to get in and out of the market.

title: Let's Not Reclassify Greed as a Virtue
description: To the Editor:

title: CARS GETTING SMARTER
description: AUTOMOBILES are undergoing a dramatic metamorphosis from an assemblage of largely mechanical devices to an integrated electronic system.

title: DROPOUTS LEARN ON THE JOB
description: THEY look like other painting crews working on their first inside, winter job. With brushes in hand, four young people prepare the interior of a large house in New Haven that is being made into medical offices. They work in overcoats and gloves, there is no heat, and sometimes they stop for a moment to muster the warmth and energy to continue.

title: SEAT BELT LAWS SAVING LIVES, BUT COMPLIANCE DIPS
description: MORE Americans buckled up last year than ever before as 16 states and the District of Columbia passed mandatory seat belt laws, bringing the total number of states requiring seat-belt use to 17.

title: 2d DANBURY SHELTER OPENED IN CHURCH
description: AFTER hearing that homeless people were being turned away from a nearby shelter because of lack of space, a Danbury church is allowing use of its building as an emergency shelter.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Official Optimism Last week's Government report on fourth-quarter gross national product growth was a disappointment - it revised to 2.4 percent an earlier estimate of 3.2 percent real annual growth for the period.

title: Q & A: THE SOUTH KOREAN SCRIPT FOR SUCCESS
description: NEXT month a new imported car will go on sale in the United States.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PAINE MYSTERIES The odd history of Thomas Paine's monument in New Rochelle will be the subject of a talk by Frederick Voss, research historian of the Smithsonian Institution, at 3 P.M. today in the New Rochelle Public Library Theater, on Lawton Street.

title: THE FALSE PROMISE OF 'OPTING OUT' PLANS
description: PRESIDENT Franklin D. Roosevelt regarded Social Security as one of the most important and far-reaching achievements of his Presidency. Fifty years later, most Americans agree that Social Security has allowed our nation to make great strides in rolling back the frontier of economic fear once experienced by many of our nation's elderly.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My parents are retired and are interested in guided tours in this country at a leisurely pace. Are there tour organizations that cater to retired people? Can the elderly get discounts? - D. G., Ridgewood, N.J. Answer:One tour company that specializes in travel for older people - of 60 and over - is Saga International Holidays (120 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116; 617-451-6808 or, outside the 617 area code, 800-343-0273). Its tours are conducted at a slower pace and, according to a company offical, with more attention to detail than many other programs. A new bus trip it has scheduled to start in April is a 24-day Trans-America Tour that will originate in New York, go south and continue by way of Texas and Arizona to Los Angeles. The cost of $1,809 includes hotels, most breakfasts and dinners, sightseeing, insurance and air fare from Los Angeles back to New York. Saga also offers bus programs in New England, to national parks in the West and along the California coast, and cruises to Alaska.

title: THERE ARE SINGERS-AND THEN THERE ARE DIVAS
description: One week from today, if all goes as planned, Kathleen Battle will sing a recital at Alice Tully Hall at 3 P.M., Jessye Norman will sing a recital at the Metropolitan Opera at 5 and Montserrat Caballe and Marilyn Horne will give a joint concert at Avery Fisher Hall at 7:30. Even for New York, this is a little unusual. There they are, four divas in three acts, neatly slotted in at Lincoln Center so that the opera buff whose purse and appreciative stamina permit can hear them sequentially, cumulatively. Faintly ludicrous similes suggest themselves:

title: IT ISN'T GOING AS MARCOS HAD PLANNED
description: THE politics of personalities rather than philosophies has long been the rule in the Philippines. From the start of the presidential campaign now under way, strategists on both sides agreed that the main issue would be President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Corazon C. Aquino, his opponent, is campaigning as his ''complete opposite.''

title: U.N. ISSUES ON AFRICAN HUNGER
description: The United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of three stamps Friday on the theme ''Africa in Crisis.'' The issue is intended to focus greater international attention on the critical social and economic problems in Africa, where many nations are experiencing food shortages and starvation, domestic policy problems, civil disruption, abandoned development projects and economic and natural disasters.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHEN James H. Gardner speaks before the environmental science class at Millburn High School later in the semester, he figures he will be able to speak with a shade more authority. He recently spent time aboard an oil rig 10 miles off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: THE PROFESSOR VANISHES
description: TIME AFTER TIME By Allen Appel. 372 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $17.95.

title: THE RAPID ASCENT OF JEFFREY TATE
description: Things sometimes move with lightning speed in the conducting world. Six years ago, Jeffrey Tate was a relative newcomer to the podium. He had just completed several years as a coach at Covent Garden, after which he had worked as Pierre Boulez's assistant in the preparation of the 1976 Bayreuth ''Ring'' cycle, as well as the Paris Opera premiere of Berg's complete ''Lulu.'' His name was listed as a continuo player on a few Baroque music disks, and he had been doing some conducting with smaller Swedish and German opera companies. In 1980, he made his Met debut, taking over ''Lulu'' from James Levine; but the young British conductor's career had not advanced enough to rate an entry in the New Grove, published that same year.

title: MEXICO LEARNS THE TRUE VALUE OF A PESO
description: The price of tortillas in Chihuahua is a small but telling example of the clash of Mexican interest groups as the country struggles to turn its deficit-plagued economy around.

title: DANCE IS SUBJECT TO DELUSIONS OF GRANDEUR
description: Often, when dancers present something unusual or controversial, disgruntled spectators with short tempers may accuse them of being ''fakes'' or ''phonies.'' Yet, though absurdities abound in it, the dance world probably contains little actual fakery.

title: LACK OF MONEY MIGHT HALT TOXIC CLEANUP SOON, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency are warning that the Federal toxic cleanup program will come to a virtual halt in two months because it is running out of money.

title: SUBMARINE COMMISSIONED
description: The Trident submarine Alaska was commissioned today at the Naval Underwater Systems Center here as dozens of antinuclear protesters demonstrated outside. About 50 of the demonstrators, who the police said had blocked buses carrying guests to the ceremonies, were arrested. The Alaska is the seventh of the nation's Trident submarines, which carry long-range nuclear missiles.

title: On 'The Color Purple'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SNOW-SCULPTING What more could a dedicated snow-sculptor ask for than 40 cubic feet of snow regardless of the weather, access to running water, an assigned site in front of an imposing public building, and 15 hours to complete the project in a two day period?

title: Susan Gilder to Wed
description: Mrs. Owen C. Moore of Stockton, Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Candace Gilder, a fashion model in New York, to Edward Walter Hayes, a trial lawyer in New York. He is a son of Edward Hayes of Sag Harbor, L.I., and Jean Hayes of Bohemia, L.I. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Capt. Jackson H. Gilder, U.S.A. She studied at the Warren Robertson Theater Workshop and with Lee Strasberg at the Actors Studio. Mr. Hayes graduated from the University of Virginia and Columbia University Law School.

title: Let's Help Moscow -- and Ourselves
description: Whatever the particular merits of the Soviet proposal put forward last week for the elimination of nuclear weapons, it was a welcome effort to maintain the good will and cooperative spirit kindled at the summit meeting in Geneva. President Reagan ought to respond in kind. One particularly effective way to do so, in my view, would be to revive his promise to share the technology being developed for his Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: Bach the Lutheran
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE'S TEST RAISES SOME QUESTION OF VALUE
description: LAST September, 30,000 fourth graders took the state mastery test. Students were tested in math, reading, language arts and writing. The results are in, and many school officials throughout the state are pulling their hair out because so many students flunked the test.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady N. Shevchenko. (Ballantine, $4.95.) In 1978 Arkady N. Shevchenko, the senior Soviet official at the United Nations, became the highest-level Russian ever to defect to the West. Leslie H. Gelb wrote here last year that compared with other defectors' memoirs, Mr. Shevchenko's ''is more nuanced, complicated, defensive and contradictory -touchstones of reality.'' He ''offers some gems of history,'' Mr. Gelb said, and his portraits of Soviet leaders ''are often revealing and important.'' THINGS INVISIBLE TO SEE, by Nancy Willard. (Ban-tam, $3.50.) Nancy Willard's first novel begins with the birth of the twins Ben and Willie Harkissian in a small town in Michigan in the 1920's and concludes with a high-stakes baseball game with Death. Our reviewer, Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, wrote in 1985 that ''Things Invisible to See'' ''is an altogether marvelous book'' and ''a lovely, moving parable of life as a playing field on which the desire to live must continually contend with the forces opposing it.'' AT MOTHER'S REQUEST, by Jonathan Coleman. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) An account of the 1978 killing of Franklin Bradshaw, a Utah auto-parts millionaire, at the hands of his own grandson and at the behest of his daughter. J. Anthony Lukas wrote here last year that Jonathan Coleman's treatment of the case is provocative and intriguing and his ''interesting speculation about the family's pathology'' lends the story an extra dimension. Mr. Coleman suggests, among other things, that the culprits wanted to be caught.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page caption in some copies of the Travel section last Sunday incorrectly identified the seat of the Duke of Northumberland as Osterley Park House near London. It is Syon House, also near London.

title: New Day Is Dawning on the Hudson Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE FROM URANUS: 15TH MOON, 10TH RING AND MAGNETISM ASKEW
description: Scientists reported today that Voyager 2 had discovered another small moon and another faint ring of particles orbiting the planet Uranus and had also observed a strange ''electro-glow'' and a surprising tilt to the Uranian magnetic field.

title: CHILD OF PARENTS WHO WERE 'PINK' RECALLS A YOUTH EDGED WITH FEAR
description: MY parents weren't Communists, but they were close enough to be labeled ''pink.'' And back in the 1950's, those fabulous, terrifying, McCarthy 50's, it wasn't a respectable label to have.

title: TOPICS
description: IHAVE frequent spells of gazing at our dining room - majestic, ready for occupancy, but empty. Do people really eat in their dining rooms anymore, or do those rooms stand there, as ours does, wondering where all the jollity went?

title: STAMFORD STRETCHES ITS LABOR POOL
description: A growing number of female students at Stamford High School now turn up in class dressed for corporate success in high-heeled shoes, a man-tailored suit and a frilly blouse. Each afternoon they report to clerical and secretarial jobs for which regular full-time employees can no longer be found. ''We used to have to beg companies to hire our students,'' said Frances Howes, a career counselor with the Stamford schools. ''Now we're getting inundated with calls from employers who need these kids.''

title: MACHINES THAT TRY TO READ MINDS
description: A recent article in the Harvard Business Review tells of a young investment adviser here who was asked to submit to a lie detector test after $20,000 in securities disappeared from his office. Certain of his innocence, the young man agreed to the test. But the polygraph made him so nervous that the examiner concluded he was being deceptive. The young man was dismissed.

title:
DINING OUT;
POMPTON LAKES: FRONT'S IN BACK
description: THE famed French writer Colette was not the inspiration behind the naming of a restaurant in Pompton Lakes. It was named for the owner's niece, who died five years ago of leukemia. (The owner is Arthur Barretta.) Although it was a little difficult to find the entrance to the restaurant - one is inclined to expect to find it at the front of the building, not at the rear - it's worthwhile persevering. Inside is a bar with a minuscule dance floor, and beyond that a relatively small dining room decorated in shades of pink, with large flower paintings gracing the walls and tiny lights visible in unexpected locations.

title: YUGO: AS BASIC AS THEY GET
description: AUTOMOBILE manufacturers in South Korea, Greece and Spain will soon compete on American soil for the first time with some of the lowest-priced cars to enter the market in several years. But a Yugoslavian company, Zavodi Crvena Zastava, may have already staked the best claim for the bottom-end market.

title: CELEBRATING BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: JAMES FARMER, founder of the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE), former Representative Shirley Chisholm of New York City and Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's delegate to the House of Representatives, are among those scheduled to take part in Black History Month events in New Jersey in February.

title: Gregory Brodsky Is Fiance of Leigh Conyngham
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Conyngham of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leigh Anne Conyngham to Gregory N. Brodsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Brodsky of Closter, N.J. The wedding is planned for April. The future bride is a sales manager in the licensing division of United Media Enterprises, a syndication concern that is a division in New York of Scripps Howard.

title: Caroline Smith Will Marry Mark D. Stevens in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Smith of Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Freeland Smith, to Mark David Stevens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Stevens of Quakertown, Pa.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW BRITISH PROOF SET
description: Collectors are getting a double-barreled bonus in the 1986 British proof set. According to the British Royal Mint, the set contains two coins with new designs. One of them, a two-pound piece, is the first British coin of that denomination to be issued in base metal.

title: A Mayor Is More Than Chairman
description: What everyone has always said about Ed Koch, even when exasperated by his sharp tongue, is that he has run a New York City administration of sterling honesty; no scandal of consequence arose in the eight years of his first two terms. Only eight days into his third term, however, began a chain of events that is now rocking City Hall:

title: IN THE LAND OF CAVES AND CASTLES
description: ''In France, I cannot recall having consciously planned to visit a beauty-spot, a monument or a panorama,'' the writer Colette boasted. ''This one,'' she said, ''just happened to me, that one came my way, the other just opened before my eyes like the valleys we fly over in dreams.''

title: The Gloup
description: To the Editor: Reading Roy Reed's dandy description of the Severn Bore (Travel, Dec. 22) reminded me of another natural phenomenon called The Gloup. I came upon it during a hike in Orkney, the northernmost county of Scotland.

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT TREES ACCENT THE LANDSCAPE
description: WHILE most trees have round or oval forms that provide a certain mass in the winter landscape, it is the less common tree with a vertical, horizontal or weeping form that stands out from the rest.

title: HAITI'S PRESIDENT-FOR-LIFE NOW HAS AN OPPOSITION
description: PROTESTING recently against the Government of the President-for-Life, Jean-Claude Duvalier, demonstrators unfurled an American flag. Haitian officials dismissed the gesture as merely a Communist trick. But United States officials in Washington, often quick to express suspicion of Communist connections, said they saw no reason to doubt the sincerity of these demonstrators.

title: Mary Villani Is Married
description: At St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., yesterday Mary Elizabeth Villani, a systems analyst with J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. in New York, was married to Thomas Edward Morrow, a financial consultant with Shearson Lehman Brothers. The Rev. William Delaney performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Villani of Port Washington and the bridegroom the son of Donna Randall of Renton, Wash., and Robert L. Morrow of Los Angeles.

title: CHILD RESTRAINT: MAJOR PROBLEM IS IMPROPER USE
description: THE number of children killed in car accidents has declined significantly in recent years as all 50 states have adopted legislation requiring automobile safety seats for young children. But additional deaths and serious injuries could be prevented, highway officials said, if more people would use the equipment properly.

title: STEWART JOINS YOMIURI
description: Dave Stewart, the former Texas Rangers' pitcher who was traded to the Philadelphia Phillies in September, has thought it over and decided that all things considered he'd rather be in Japan. He said he'd reached agreement on a two-year, $2 million pact with the Yomiuri Giants and that the Phillies had agreed to sell his contract to the Japanese club, reportedly for $1 million.

title: Labor Unrest on The U.S. Bench
description: Although Federal judges can retire at 65 with full pay if they have served 15 years, few choose to do so. They stay on, usually part time, helping ease the heavy caseload in the Federal courts.

title: Horford Affair Called Ridiculous
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
PAINTINGS SHOW PEOPLE AND SCENES FROM STATE'S PAST
description: HIDDEN treasures from the past - paintings and sculpture that show Connecticut people and places as they looked in the 18th and 19th centuries - are now on display in a special exhibit at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR. . . .: To The Mountaintop. By Wm. Roger Witherspoon. (Doubleday, $24.95 until Jan. 31; $30 thereafter.) Wm. Roger Witherspoon's primer on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: THE FOODS THAT COMFORT AND SOOTHE
description: IT'S been one of those days. Things that couldn't go wrong, did. People who never let you down proved they were human. The thermometer didn't have the sense to know when enough was enough, or the landscape was obscured in rain and gloom, or the streets were awash in snow and slush.

title: Reagan And Gorbachev
description: The main news here now is that President Reagan is taking seriously, maybe for the first time, Mikhail Gorbachev's latest proposals for the control of nuclear weapons.

title: Miss Gembala Fiancee Of Richard E. Parsons
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Gembala Jr. of Philadelphia and Beach Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rosaleen Bridgette Broncha Gembala to Richard Evan Parsons, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Parsons of Bonita, Calif., and Rio Hardy, Mexico. An April wedding is planned.

title: Philip C. Halsey Plans to Be Wed To Miss Millhiser
description: The engagement of Mary McGue Millhiser to Philip Crawford Halsey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ross Randolph Millhiser of Rumson, N.J., and Richmond, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Marita Conroy Halsey of Montclair, N.J., and Bridgehampton, L.I., and the late Donald Post Halsey Jr.

title: MOSTLY PASTA, AND THAT'S ENOUGH
description: PASTAS, a tiny, sparkling white bandbox of a place in Hicksville, yields to a decidedly American point of view. There is no saving room for the chicken gismonda, striped bass livornese, veal piccata or anything else to come next because here the pasta is the main course.

title: CLARITY SOUGHT FOR INSURANCE
description: WHEN Hurricane Gloria sideswiped Hazel Frank Gluck's home in Lakewood last fall, she had to reread her homeowner's policy ''three or four times'' to see if she was covered and ''even then,'' she said, ''I had questions.''

title: SUTTON TAKES FOUR-SHOT LEAD
description: Hal Sutton appears to be headed for an excellent year: He started with a tie for seventh and a fourth-place finish in the first two tournaments on the PGA Tour, and now he has a chance to run away with the Phoenix Open title in the third week.

title: AIR BAGS APPEARS IN '86
description: DESPITE the imminent arrival of several high-technology automobile safety devices, the most closely watched safety issue today concerns a pair of old systems -air bags and automatic seat belts.

title: ARGUING THE MERITS OF HUGH HUDSON'S 'REVOLUTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: JAM: A True Story. By Margaret Mahy. Illustrated by Helen Craig. Atlantic Monthly Press. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) Soon after mother is called away to a job as an atomic scientist, the plum tree yields its harvest, which father puts up and then serves at virtually every meal for what seems like forever.

title: Chaos in Uganda
description: A month after the signing of a peace accord that was to end years of bloodshed in Uganda, Kampala, the capital, was convulsed in fighting last week. According to diplomats in the East African country, rebel troops, probably from the National Resistance Army, descended on the city by the thousands.

title: Rachel Ijams Plans to Wed
description: Mrs. Edward M. Crane Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Fishers Island, L.I., and Porter Ijams of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rachel Lee Ijams to James Peter Schmader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Schmader Jr. of Solon, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title: SOVIET-BACKED YEMENI IS 'ACTING PRESIDENT'
description: The Soviet Union said today that Prime Minister Haider Abu Bakr al-Attas of Southern Yemen, who was in Moscow during 10 days of civil strife, had returned home and had been made ''acting president.''

title: Dorothy Sears And V. C. Brown To Wed in June
description: A June 21 wedding is planned by Dorothy Parker Spears and Vance Carrier Brown, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Spears of Greenwich, Conn., have announced.

title: WILL THE SPARKS FLY WHEN STEPPENWOLF TAKES ON PRINTER?
description: He made his acting debut in New York crushing beer cans against his forehead in Sam Shepard's ''True West.''

title: WHY ITALY IS SURPRISINGLY HOSPITABLE TO FEMINISM
description: Italian men are famous the world over for their aggressive affronts to female dignity and other sins against equality between the sexes.

title:
ART;
'NATURAL DISASTER SHOW' OFFERS SAMPLES OF CREATIVE UPHEAVAL
description: JUST as watching tigers in a zoo can be pleasurable, regarding chaos and upheaval through the eyes of creative artists can be amusing and even exhilarating. That experience is offered by ''The All Natural Disaster Show'' at the Longwood Arts Project in the Bronx.

title: UNION LEADER RECALLS KING'S ROLE IN MEMPHIS
description: There have been lots of articles written about Martin Luther King Jr. praising him for his leadership, but the true measure of the man was in his going to Memphis on behalf of our union to help striking sanitation workers. Because of this, he paid the ultimate price of death on April 4, 1968.

title: FOR GRUMANN TEST PILOT, A LIFE ON THE EDGE
description: ONE morning several years ago, Charles A. Sewell rose at 6:30 at his home in East Setauket, jogged two or three miles, then headed for the office as usual.

title: YEAR OF THE CUSTOMER
description: Bill Hoglund, president of the Saturn Corporation, stood on a platform at the dedication of the company's headquarters building north of Detroit last fall, introducing local officials and company officers. Then he paused and asked for the ''director of customer satisfaction'' to stand and be recognized. As he did, every employee of the new General Motors subsidiary jumped up with a cheer.

title:
INVESTING;
FINDING WINNERS AMONG SMALL STOCKS
description: MUCH of the hoopla about Wall Street has centered on the blue chips and the gains in the Dow Jones industrial average. But small stocks have also been hot.

title: LILCO CONTESTS SUFFOLK LAW
description: WHEN the Suffolk County Legislature meets tomorrow, a prime topic of conversation is expected to be the Long Island Lighting Company's latest effort to get its Shoreham nuclear power plant into operation - a Federal lawsuit.

title: A SHOCK THAT OPEC WON'T OVERCOME
description: IN THE 1970's, economists debated whether the oil market was fundamentally different from other commodities markets. Last week's impressive plunge in oil prices provided an emphatic answer to the questions of the 70's. Oil has become a commodity like any other, and the price changes of recent weeks are part of a pattern of volatility that will characterize the market in the future.

title: Sunday Observer; The Pulse of Life
description: I FEEL GOOD ABOUT me.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WILD BANANAS. By Sandra Thompson. (Atlantic Monthly, $15.95.) The year is 1966. Sally leaves New York City to lose her name and her identity when she marries Barry Feldman, a Jewish law student studying for the Florida bar exam in Birmingham, Ala.

title: No Headline
description: IN the days before radios and movies, in the days before televisions and VCR's, people sometimes enjoyed reading aloud during evenings together. The activity has mostly disappeared now, but outposts remain. One of them is Symphony Space, where, beginning Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. and continuing for nine more Wednesdays through the end of May, the series ''Selected Shorts'' will feature a combination of well-known and promising young actors reading distinguished pieces of short fiction.

title: On Repeating Mistakes Of Past in Guatemala
description: To the Editor:

title: Parlay Voo
description: To the Editor: Ira Berkow's article on the language barrier in France opened up a floodgate of memories. My wife and I were married in Paris in 1949 and the only French word she knew was ''oui,'' which proved to be inappropriate in a wide range of circumstances.

title: READING BALANCE SHEETS INSTEAD OF POETRY
description: In the 1950's, college women overwhelmingly went into teaching because it was expected of them. In the 1960's, social work and related fields became popular with a generation that heeded President Kennedy's call to ''ask what you can do for your country.'' And in the 1970's the rapid advances in high technology attracted students to computer fields.

title: TUBINGEN
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDUCTORS VIE FOR STOKOWSKI AWARD
description: Leonard Bernstein helped prove that America could produce worthy conductors; Michael Tilson Thomas, Gerard Schwarz and Leonard Slatkin, among others, have since carried the torch, distinguishing themselves on podiums at home and abroad. And now the American Symphony Orchestra's Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition, the only event of its kind in the United States, may be helping to forge a new generation of orchestra leaders.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FUNNY FARM: A Sweeping Epic of the Sticks. By Jay Cronley. (Atheneum, $14.95.) To say that ''Funny Farm'' is an uproarious comedy about a couple who move from New York to the Sunbelt might suggest that some fact in the story has a logical consequence, and nothing could be further from the truth.

title: BRELAND AND BIGGS WIN UNANIMOUSLY
description: The Olympic gold medalists Mark Breland and Tyrell Biggs continued their progress in the professional ranks here today with unanimous decisions.

title: A SURGE IN HIGH-PRICED NEW APARTMENTS
description: NEW YORKERS who can afford to buy or rent expensive apartments in newly constructed buildings this year are likely to have one of the widest selections available in this century - 15,000 or more apartments will be marketed, though only two-thirds of them will be ready for occupancy in 1986. Housing analysts have to look back to the 1960's to find comparable production numbers, and even then there were far fewer apartments built for the high end of the market.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HEAR THE WIND BLOW American Folk Songs Retold. By Scott R. Sanders. Illustrated by Ponder Goembel. 202 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) TELLERS of folk tales, no matter how slender the bridge between their stories and the original material, must move in tune with their music.

title: FOLLOW BRITAIN'S LEAD ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: IT IS not yet possible to determine who will be the last recipient of Social Security benefits, but it's fairly safe to say that he or she is alive today. For, unless the pay-as-you-go nature of the system is altered, it will collapse in the first half of the next century.

title: MID-YEAR EXAM TIME, AND THE SLEEPING IS EASY
description: It has been wonderfully sunny here over the past few days. Yet for students at Harvard University, the days and nights have been laborious, tense and tiring: It is the season of mid-year exams. Should it be any surprise, under the circumstances, to see scholars of all ages, all over campus, letting their heads lean forward over folded arms, or letting their heads loll backward - and dozing off?

title: THOSE CORPORATE HELIPADS ARE TAKING OFF IN JERSEY
description: WHEN the developers of a large, mixed corporate- and commercial-use complex in central New Jersey were designing the layout for their 500-acre spread, they decided to incorporate a feature that is becoming increasingly popular in similar developments across the nation - a helipad.

title: IT'S BIGGER THAN REAGAN! EVEN COSBY!
description: OH sure, we call ourselves the United States and indivisible and all that, but other than in moods of collective Khomeini- and Qaddafi-bashing are there many occasions when we Americans are truly united? Important people getting shot at receive our undivided attention for a while, and I suppose we would all drop what we were doing if an earthquake made pebbles out of San Francisco, or if Bruce Springsteen announced plans to become a Soviet citizen. But for happy, multigenerational, cross-class, multiracial, 100 percent national fixation, nothing tops that most mega of megamanias, the Sooooper Bowl! What I'm saying is, it's going to get a higher Nielsen rating than ''Masterpiece Theatre'' on PBS.

title: Orchestras' Well-Being
description: To the Editor:

title: AN 'ELATED' BISHOP TUTU WINDS UP TOUR OF U.S.
description: About 30 corporate chiefs and University of Pennsylvania trustees listened politely as Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa told them recently that they should be ready to use their influence to withdraw American investments from his country if its Government did not act quickly to end strict racial separation.

title: Economic World War II
description: For the second time in this generation, the monarchy of Saudi Arabia has declared economic war on most of the rest of the world.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE HIGH AND THE MIGHTY BEFORE last weekend, the smallest plane that Richard J. DeVivo, an air traffic controller trainee, ever flew in was a 727. Now he's flown in a small four-seater, a Cessna 172, sitting in the cockpit next to a veteran general-aviation pilot, Stanley F. Dalton of Holbrook.

title: HOW MUCH CASH, HOW MUCH PLASTIC
description: Listen to some of those radio and television commercials and you get the impression that it is possible to travel extensively with little or no cash. All you supposedly need is a credit card. If you accept this idea, the question is, which one? Almost weekly for many Americans, the mail brings an invitation to accept a card by agreeing to a few terms.

title: Jeffrey Koeze to Wed Katharine Reid
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Seabury Reid of York Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Hencken Reid, to Jeffrey Scott Koeze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Scott Koeze of Grand Rapids, Mich. A July wedding is planned.

title: TRAINING FOR PEOPLE WHOSE JOB SAVES OTHERS
description: ONE ''patient'' lies apparently unconscious on the floor, undergoing an initial assessment to determine the extent of his injuries. Nearby, another person with apparent back injuries is being carefully secured on a special board for transport to the hospital.

title: JPORT AGENCY TO SHIFT PLANS ON SPENDING
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which has spent billions of dollars on economic development in the last 15 years, is redirecting its emphasis to transportation and trade, particularly redevelopment of the ports, the agency's executive director said in a speech last week in Manhattan.

title: Oil and the Crash of '74, '79, '86
description: American Airlines is ''delighted.'' European bankers describe themselves as ''terribly concerned.'' The subject is oil prices and the reactions are the opposite of those when oil prices were soaring in the 70's. Now it's producers, and the bankers who finance them, who scurry for the Valium.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WRITERS AND READERS
description: Four renowned authors read from their work. They debated such issues as national identity in literature and the status of female writers. And they mingled with people who otherwise might never have met them: ''We're getting readers and writers together,'' E. L. Doctorow said during a reception crowded with fans and seekers of autographs. ''Establishing a community without an intervening agency.''

title: SOME MILESTONES OF THE AUTO AGE
description: Here are some high points in the 100-odd years that got the automobile from there to here: 1884: In France, a patent is issued for an internal-combustion engine to drive the Delamare-Deboutteville steam car. 1886: The world's first practical motorcar is patented in Germany by Carl Benz. 1894: In the United States, bricks are laid on a rural road, paving the Wooster Pike, near Cleveland. 1895: The first major American auto race, from Chicago to Evanston, Ill., is won by Frank Duryea, 50 miles in nine hours. The French brothers, Andre and Edouard Michelin, make the first pneumatic tire for an automobile. 1898: In New York, the first independent auto dealer opens his shop. The next year, the first mechanic opens his garage, also in New York. 1900: The first national automobile show is held at Madison Square Garden. In addition, New York issues the country's first driver's license to Harold J. Birnie. 1901: The curved-dash Oldsmobile becomes the first car to be made in quantity. 1903: Using $28,000 in cash, Henry Ford forms the Ford Motor Company. 1904: The five Studebaker brothers, former makers of Conestoga wagons, produce their first car. In Detroit, the Y.M.C.A. establishes the first school for auto mechanics. 1905: In St. Louis - and for the first time - an automobile is reported stolen. 1907: Vanderbilt Motor Parkway, privately owned and the first major highway in the nation, opens on Long Island. 1908: Ford introduces left-hand steering with its new Model T, which sells for $850.

title: Building Rooms for the Homeless
description: FROM the outside, the building at 530 West 178th Street in Washington Heights is not easily distinguished from its neighbors. They form a string of five-story walk-ups facing the below-grade approach to the George Washington Bridge across the street. The hum from bridge traffic is unceasing.

title: MATCHING CAREERS
description: Career paths often move along parallel lines, but few have been as parallel as D. Kenneth Patton's and Richard M. Rosan's.

title: Northern Ireland 'Says No' to Pact On Joint Rule
description: ''Ulster Says No'' was the re-election rallying cry of the 15 Protestant Members of Parliament who resigned in protest against the Anglo-Irish agreement. And Ulster did say no in last week's Parliamentary by-elections. The question was, did it say so loudly enough?

title: McClain Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: BEN KINGSLEY PUTS 'GANDHI' BEHIND HIM
description: Ben Kingsley the man may go about the globe on a British passport; Ben Kingsley the actor likes to travel with more exotic documentation. As much as any performer now living, he can claim to be a citizen of the world. After all, how is he marking his return to the Royal Shakespeare Company after his international success as the founder of modern India in the film ''Gandhi''? In the big Barbican Theater he's Shakespeare's Othello, and a rather unusual Othello at that, kin both to the sultan who turned poor Scheherazade into a talking book and to the proud chieftains who rode through the desert with T. E. Lawrence. On the evenings he appears in the little Pit auditorium nearby he's an American Indian called John Lame Eagle, protagonist of ''Melons,'' which is the latest play by Bernard Pomerance, best known as the author of ''The Elephant Man.'' When the R.S.C. attempts a saga about Genghis Khan, or a stage version of ''Nanook of the North,'' it will know where to look for a lead.

title: SO LONG, SMOKESTACKS
description: THE Ogden Corporation washes the windows at the World Trade Center, burns municipal garbage and serves food on the Concorde. The former industrial conglomerate also performs a thousand other daily chores in maintaining Yankee Stadium, the United Nations and hundreds of office buildings and industrial plants.

title: Somali President Declares an Amnesty
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre declared a general amnesty today for thousands of Somali who have been living in exile for nearly a decade.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: HISTORIANS RECALL A TEA PARTY THAT WAS NOT QUITE SO FAMOUS
description: THE cavalcade was sizable, 30 irate women on horseback who on one fall morning in 1776 surrounded John Arthur's farm near Bedford and demanded ''the delectable leaf.''

title: Peter Posner Engaged To Patricia Firestone
description: The engagement of Patricia Anne Firestone to Peter Scott Posner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Firestone of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Posner of Cedarhurst, L.I., and New York.

title: Cynthia Bird to Marry William B. Grogan Jr.
description: The engagement of Cynthia Hewitt Bird to William Bernard Grogan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grogan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Waddell Bird of Nashville and Bay Head, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: ANYBODY WHO WAS SOMEBODY KNOCKED AT HIS DOOR
description: Among the major European painters of the 18th century, none has been more subtly or more persistently underrated since his death than Sir Joshua Reynolds, the portrait painter and first president of the Royal Academy of Arts in London who singlehandedly raised art in his native country to the level of a learned profession. The current and majestic exhibition of Reynolds at the Royal Academy in London comes at a time when the artist's reputation is at last taking an upturn. For that and other reasons, it is a considerable event - with well over 100 paintings by Reynolds, together with a mass of related or comparative material - and one that has been planned and carried out with a degree of care that Reynolds himself would have been the first to acknowledge. Nicholas Penny, Keeper of European Paintings at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, coordinated the show and edited the catalogue, and he and his colleagues (among them, Pierre Rosenberg of the Louvre) wrought well.

title: HAPPY 150TH, NATIONAL THEATER
description: In December 1835 a Washington newspaper, The National Intelligencer, announced the opening of a ''new and splendid establishment which for comfort, beauty and magnificence is equal, if not superior, to any theater in the country.''

title: BLACK MUSIC ON BROADWAY, FROM CAB CALLOWAY TO PRINCE
description: It started on a stalled subway train, the No. 1 Broadway local. Maurice Hines, who danced in the Francis Ford Coppola film ''The Cotton Club'' and had co-founded a dance company called Balletap, was thinking about the connections between generations of black singers and dancers. Stuck between stops, he got the idea of packing five decades of black song and dance into an ambitious revue - ''a celebration of black musical theater from the 1930's to the 1980's,'' he said recently. Mr. Hines, who had sung and danced in the Broadway shows ''Eubie'' and ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' would be a director for the first time.

title: Health Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFETY FIRST: HOW TO USE AND MAINTAIN A SNOWTHROWER
description: SNOWTHROWERS are great time-savers, back-savers and even heart-savers in some cases - but they can also be dangerous if not used properly, and they can result in needless annoyance and discomfort if not used wisely. Since weeks, or even months, may go by between uses, most homeowners don't use their snowthrowers often enough to get really expert at handling them.

title: Lisa Greene to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Theodore Greene of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Greene, to Bruce Hoffman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin I. Hoffman of Los Angeles.

title: THE BASIC AMERICAN CREPE
description: WE HAVE BEEN NOTABLY AMUSED - AND IN no way distressed - to note in recent travels around America the recurring appearance of one appetizer on the menus of many restaurants that stress their service of American cuisine. It involves the use of cornmeal in the preparation of ''crepes'' to act as a base for caviar. These might be made with yellow cornmeal or with blue, which is a novelty outside the Southeast. To our taste, cornmeal crepes offer a fine foil for caviar, be it black (sturgeon), red (salmon) or golden (whitefish) - or a small mound of each.

title: EXPLORING BELOW GROUND AND ABOVE
description: The region with the greatest concentration of Paleolithic art caves in France is in the southwest, about a six-hour drive from Paris to Brive-la-Gaillarde. One can then go to Perigueux and on south. Or you can take the express train Le Capitol from Paris to Brive and rent a car there. Cars can be reserved through the French National Railroads or rented at agencies opposite the station.

title: Get a Jump on Christmas
description: Oh, to be in Washington now that the spring Smithsonian Catalogue is here. Leafing through the pages, one gets the impression that almost any object can be rendered in cloisonne, including lamps, ceramic eggs and necklaces.

title: ONLY THE MAD KNOW BROOKLYN
description: THE BUILDING By Thomas Glynn. 371 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. THOMAS GLYNN'S new novel is the get of monsters, an 80's offspring of 70's leviathans such as Thomas Pynchon's ''Gravity's Rainbow,'' Robert Coover's ''Public Burning'' and William Gaddis's ''JR,'' books that swallow a subject and the reader. Like them, Mr. Glynn's novel imitates in its form and style what it's about - a Brooklyn apartment house tenanted by the crazed - and comments on its own monstrosity: ''The Building is huge,'' runs the first sentence, ''a grotesque magnificence.''

title: NO CHEERS FOR THOSE UBIQUITOUS AWARDS
description: Tonight the members of the New York Film Critics Circle, their families, friends and hangers-on will squeeze into Sardi's to fight for food and drink and to honor, among others, Norma Aleandro as the best actress of 1985 for her performance in the Argentine film, ''The Official Story.'' The award was voted to Miss Aleandro at a meeting in New York in the third week of December.

title: PRIMARY TROUBLES SEEN FOR CARNEY
description: ALREADY threatened with a Republican primary, Representative William Carney of Hauppauge is now under fire from Conservative Party leaders who oppose his renomination because he switched from the Conservative to the Republican Party last year, among other reasons.

title: New Bedford Talks On Fishing Hit Snag
description: Negotiations for a new contract to end the strike of fishermen against boat owners have broken off.

title: DISH-ANTENNA RULING EXAMINED
description: THE Federal Communications Commission has sent a signal to Westchester and other communities that are considering adopting zoning ordinances to restrict the growth of satellite antennas: Don't.

title: BLACK GROUPS IN ALABAMA FEUD OVER POLTICS
description: For more than a decade the black political agenda in Alabama has been dominated by the Alabama Democratic Conference and its chairman, Joe Reed.

title: FOR MANY JURORS, LITTLE WAS PROVED IN PERRY CASE
description: When the jury in the Jonah Perry case began deliberating last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, one of the first things jurors did was examine the clothing worn by Officer Lee Van Houten on the night he was said to have been mugged by Jonah and his 17-year-old brother, Edmund.

title: SO MANY NEW MODELS, SO FEW WONDERFUL NAMES
description: For years cars sold in the United States have born evocative names redolent of the sleek, like Mustang, the powerful Corvette, and the elegant, Fleetwood. But cars, and their names, are changing, and today's auto buyers are faced with a deluge of Cordias, Camrys and Cieras, artificial, sometimes computer-generated words that have no meaning of their own.

title:
LIFE AND DEATH: THE STRUGGLE TO CLARIFY LEGAL, MEDICAL AND ETHICAL ISSUES;
3D RIGHT-TO-DIE CASE IS SCHEDULED
description: ALTHOUGH 30-year-old Nancy Ellen Jobes, comatose for nearly five years, may no longer feel pain, her family suffers.

title: BERNADETTE PETERS ANIMATES A LLOYD WEBBER SCORE
description: ''Bernadette Peters in Andrew Lloyd Webber's 'Song & Dance' '' (RCA Red Seal HBC1-7162; cassette HBE1-7162, no CD) is a glowing personal triumph for a singer and actress who is rapidly establishing herself as the first lady of the Broadway musical. Performing material whose music borders on kitsch and whose lyrics and story suggest a verbose soap opera, Miss Peters nevertheless projects an astounding emotional generosity and conviction. Almost singlehandedly she turns the inconsequential erotic misadventures of Emma, an English hat designer pursuing a career in America, into a touching romantic fable about love and its defenses and the loss of innocence.

title: SOME TANGLED TALES OF CORRUPTION
description: IT reads like the start of a detective novel, but it may turn out to be the most far-reaching corruption investigation in New York City in more than a decade.

title: INSURANCE PROBLEMS A THREAT TO ALL
description: CONNECTICUT, insurance center of the nation, faces an insurance emergency. Insurance, or lack of it, is changing how many institutions function. It may change the very quality of life for ourselves and our children.

title: 10,000 Killed In South Yemen
description: The Peoples Democratic Republic of Yemen, the thinly populated strip of desert and mountains at the strategic southern tip of the Arabian peninsula, is noted chiefly for its Moscow-style Government and the presence of 1,000 Soviet advisers. Heavy fighting broke out among Southern Yemen's leaders Jan. 13, evidently surprising the Russians, the more so as the Soviet Embassy came under fire.

title: Glenn Close as Narrator
description: The actress Glenn Close, co-starring on Broadway in the play ''Benefactors,'' will narrate two Little Orchestra Society presentations of Prokofiev's symphonic fairy tale ''Peter and the Wolf'' on Saturday, Feb. 8, at Avery Fisher Hall. Dino Anagnost will conduct the two performances, at 10 A.M. and 12 Noon. Tickets, at $18, $13, $11, and $8, are available at the box office (874-2424) or through CenterCharge (874-6770).

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
PARENTS AND FRIENDS OF LESBIANS AND GAYS
description: RICK, who is 24 years old, has seen his mother once in the last six years. When he was 18, he told her he was a homosexual. She was furious and disbelieving. He packed his bags and left.

title: Janet Hess Weds Steven Schneider
description: Janet Marie Hess, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joe R. Hess of Corpus Christi, Tex., was married yesterday to Steven Alan Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schneider of Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Harold White and the Rev. Jerome Hall, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Loews L'Enfant Plaza Hotel in Washington.

title: ARGUING THE MERITS OF HUGH HUDSON'S 'REVOLUTION'
description: To the Editor: Vincent Canby's conclusion that part of the failure of ''Revolution'' lies in its director and writer's populist approach to the American Revolution should come as a surprise to a number of historians [ ''Once More, 1776 Taxes the Filmgoer,'' Jan. 12 ] . Mr. Canby asserts that the ''most important battles'' were fought by ''home-grown aristocrats'' in the legislatures, Continental Congresses and drawing rooms of the Colonies. The director Hugh Hudson's insistence on portraying the Revolution through the experiences of Tom Dobb, ''an economically desperate, illiterate, apolitical colonist,'' therefore inevitably led to an incoherent, confusing and uninspiring portrait of the War for Independence.

title: LOVE OF CATS IS MUTUAL -- ALMOST
description: I LOVE cats, but not the way Amy does. She has showed me that cats can be funny and lovable, trustworthy and predictable, loyal and responsive. Didn't Bert come bounding out of the woods (like a dog, I thought) when she called, and he had not even seen her for six months? Doesn't Stitches look up and answer when Amy talks to her?

title: Congresswoman Indicted
description: Bobbi Fiedler, a California Republican who parlayed an antibusing campaign into a seat in the United States House of Representatives, announced three weeks ago that she would seek her party's nomination for the Senate. But last week she and an aide were charged with attempting to buy off an opponent.

title: HULL ON FACE MASKS
description: Bobby Hull, the former Chicago Black Hawk star, was in Chicago to take part in an old-timers game last night and he made it clear that he planned to play it the old-fashioned way - without a face guard. Asked if he would wear one, Hull scoffed and called the National Hockey League's decision to allow face guards, ''the worst thing they ever did.''

title: NEW SEATS STAND UP TO ROAD
description: ONCE upon a time, the typical car seat was little more than a couch on wheels. Stretched bench-like from door to door, constructed of foam and springs and encased in waterproof vinyl, the seat was taken for granted, even ignored, as the automobile industry focused its attention on exterior styling and under the hood.

title: HAWORTH
description: IN eastern Bergen County, where many municipalities have been permitting their last tracts of open land to be developed intensively to gain more tax revenues, the Borough of Haworth is holding fast to its traditional pattern of low-density zoning.

title: Karen Blum to Wed in June
description: Karen Amy Blum and William Mark Sheinbaum, members of the class of 1986 at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, plan to be married June 1. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Blum of Lido Beach, L.I., who have announced her engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel Sheinbaum of Roslyn, L.I. Miss Blum graduated from Tufts University. Her fiance is a magna cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Patriotic Pachyderms As a drama critic for the old Life magazine in the 1920's, Robert Benchley reviewed the elephants in the circus. This is one of 84 theater pieces in ''Benchley at the Theatre,'' edited by Charles Getchell (The Ipswich Press).

title: Diana F. Reed, an Account Executive, To Wed Gregory Collins Carey in May
description: The engagement of Diana Frances Reed to Gregory Collins Carey has been announced by Adrian P. Reed of Centreville, Md., and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and New York.

title: CORNWALL GROUPS STUDYING TOWN'S HIGH HOUSING COSTS
description: INCREASING real-estate values in Cornwall have led to the formation of two groups concerned that the character of the town may be lost.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SHAKESPEARE STORIES By Leon Garfield. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 288 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) TELLING the story of a Shakespeare play is an exacting test of understanding and imagination.

title: ANCIENT URNS OFFER POETRY OF FORM
description: Urns are almost as old as man - and more varied in their materials and crafting than most other objects.

title: DOOMED FROM THE START
description: NAPOLEON 1812 By Nigel Nicolson. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: TOO MUCH GOLD IN THE PARACHUTES?
description: ''Essentially, golden parachutes take money out of shareholders' pockets.'' - Samuel J. Heyman, chairman of GAF Corporation. ''The incongruity is that underperforming chief executive officers and managements are getting these huge awards.'' - Louis J. Brindisi Jr., consultant with Booz Allen & Hamilton. ''It's wrong. You're supposed to reward people for success and not for failure.'' - Irwin L. Jacobs, chairman of Minstar Inc. GOLDEN parachutes - those multimillion-dollar bailouts that make corporate America's richest executives even richer when their companies are taken over - are under attack these days. Shareholders call them a flagrant waste of corporate assets, acquiring companies are refusing to honor them, corporate raiders are enraged about them -and the battle over their validity is increasingly being fought in the courts.

title: THEISMANN GETS PACT
description: A broken leg and a scrambling replacement may have cost him his role as starter, but Joe Theismann has not been forgotten by the Washington Redskins. The quarterback has been given a new, two-year contract, according to a club announcement, which also said that the receiver Art Monk had signed a three-year pact.

title: ARGUING THE MERITS OF HUGH HUDSON'S 'REVOLUTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: AT CLUB MED, TWO VARIATIONS ON A THEME
description: My first clue that things had changed subtly but significantly at Club Med came when my companion and I entered our room at Turkoise, on the island of Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos.

title: PACKING THE CLOUT OF AN M.B.A.
description: ''NOTHING is intrinsically valuable,'' wrote John Barth in ''The Floating Opera.'' ''The value of everything is attributed to it, assigned to it from outside the thing itself, by people.''

title: CUSTOM TREATMENT FOR SPECIAL CARS
description: STEVEN HALL and Mark Barton are among an elite group of automotive specialists who are considered to be master craftsmen in their native England. Known as ''panel beaters,'' they now work in Greenwich, using their skills in building the entire body of an automobile, or any individual body part.

title: 2 LONDON PAPERS SHUT BY STRIKE, BUT 2 PUBLISH
description: A strike by printers stopped publication of today's issues of two of Britain's main daily newspapers, The Times and The Sun, both owned by Rupert Murdoch. [ However, early editions of Mr. Murdoch's two Sunday papers, The Sunday Times and The News of the World, were printed and distributed despite the strike, The Associated Press reported from London. ] At issue in the strike by 6,000 printers and other workers against News International, Britain's largest newspaper group, is the introduction of new technology and Mr. Murdoch's refusal to pledge that no jobs will be eliminated as a result. Mr. Murdoch has also called for a no-strike agreement, a demand the unions have rejected.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 26, 1986 Fiction

title: SCHOOLS AWAITING ASBESTOS RULES
description: THE State Education Department will soon begin a program to find and resolve any problems with asbestos insulation in Connecticut schools.

title: Sarah Carter Plans to Wed Schuyler Grey 3d in Spring
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Burr Noland Carter 2d of Richmond of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Ames Carter to Schuyler Everett Grey 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grey Jr. of Denver.

title: AFTER 25 YEARS, AN OPERA GETS ITS CHANCE
description: FRUSTRATED at being an ''unperformed'' composer, Andrew Liotta decided to ''get back to playing,'' he said. So last year, the teacher-composer-musician from Malverne joined the North Shore Community Orchestra as a violinist.

title: PAGEANTRY COLORS A HISTORICAL PORTRAIT
description: Once again, India is the star. ''Lord Mountbatten: The Last Viceroy'' may pretend that other things matter, but even in the opening minutes we know that's not the case. It's the train that does it. There are no trains like Indian trains, of course; they enter stations very slowly, and people cling to their sides. A young British civil servant in a white suit gets off and is met by an older man, who carries a rolled-up umbrella. A moment later, marauders with clubs brutalize other Indians. Then we are at 10 Downing Street for a meeting between Mountbatten - hero of Burma, great-grandson of Queen Victoria, cousin to the king - and Clement Attlee. The new ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation alternates this way through all its six parts: First, India, crowded, seething, tempestuous; then the raj, its symbols, representatives and accouterments. This is lavish, civilized television, and, visually speaking, India usually wins.

title: Treasury Settles Accounts With Bank of America
description: For a certain criminal class, the bank is the safest place to dump unsightly piles of cash. There profits from drug deals and other schemes are hidden from the law and diverted into legitimate channels.

title: Alleged Mafia Chiefs Convicted
description: The Government's investigation of Midwest Mafia operations began nearly five years ago, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation's evidence eventually grew to include more than 4,000 hours of tape recorded conversations. Last week, the spadework paid off; a Federal jury in Kansas City convicted five men, including the reputed leader of organized crime in Chicago, of conspiring to skim more than $2 million in untaxed winnings from gambling casinos in Las Vegas.

title: BOL EXCELS IN BULLETS' VICTORY
description: Cliff Robinson scored 38 points for Washington, Jeff Malone added 29, and the rookie Manute Bol blocked 15 shots tonight, the second-highest single-game total in National Basketball Association history, as the Bullets defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 111-103.

title: NEW YORK MAY GET $200 MILLION
description: More than 75,000 individuals and companies have come forward to pay a total of $130 million under New York State's tax amnesty, Governor Cuomo announced today as the program entered its last week.

title: 28 on a Courtyard
description: Belleville, N. J., a community on the eastern edge of Essex County, is not well known, but it has a claim on history. According to local legend, the Continental Army retreated through the town during the Revolutionary War and Washington spent a night hiding in the cellar of the Dutch Reformed Church there while British forces searched the countryside for him.

title: STUDENTS WIN ART AWARDS
description: Seven New Jersey high school seniors have won awards in the Arts Recognition Talent Search (ARTS) sponsored by the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts. The program is the only national venture recognizing excellence by young Americans in all major art forms.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE FARE WHERE DUCK IS KING
description: DINERS in the Mount Kisco area who crave, in general, some good Chinese cooking and, in particular, some dishes chacteristic of northern China can save themselves a trip to Manhattan's Chinatown and instead head for Omei, where a new chef works from a new menu and turns out such lovely items as homemade pulled noodles and rice-stick noodles and nicely served, lean and crisp Peking duck. Although the chef is from Peking, for centuries China's culinary hub, the menu, exciting as it is with nationally popular dishes, offers only a small number that are special to northern China. A few more wouldn't be amiss.

title: CRIME
description: Andrew Taylor's ''Caroline Minuscule'' (1983) won the John Creasey Award for best first novel by a British writer and was nominated for an American Edgar. Mr. Taylor continues the good work in OUR FATHER'S LIES (Dodd, Mead, $16.95).

title:
GARDENING;
THE RIGHT TREES ACCENT THE LANDSCAPE
description: WHILE most trees have round or oval forms that provide a certain mass in the winter landscape, it is the less common tree with a vertical, horizontal or weeping form that stands out from the rest.

title: DIGGING IN AS OIL PRICES SLIDE
description: WHEN Joe Pevehouse looks out over what he calls ''the charred battlefield'' of the American oil and gas industry, he can smile broadly. At the height of the great oil boom, in the frenzied summer of 1981 when everybody said oil prices could go nowhere but up, the crafty old Texas wildcatter put his finger to the wind and decided it was not going to last much longer. So he ordered the company he founded in 1960, Adobe Oil and Gas, to cut spending, reduce its debt and sell off some of its producing properties.

title: HOUSING PERMITS RISE 35%
description: LAST year was the best for the housing construction industry in Connecticut since 1972, the State Housing Department reported last week. But figures show a shift away from building in Fairfield County and toward less-expensive areas.

title: WHAT WE SAY AND WHAT WE MEAN
description: FORMS OF FEELING The Heart of Psychotherapy. By Robert F. Hobson. 318 pp. New York: Tavistock Publications/Methuen. $19.95. CAN you simply talk to someone and go away healthy? The claim that you can is not universally accepted. Some people believe you recover spontaneously and the psychotherapist takes the credit. Others say you are healed by the power of faith. Still others think the whole thing is a fraud. My respect for doctors persuades me that talking doctors must do something helpful. And whatever they do, it is not beyond human understanding.

title: The Man Who Almost Came to Dinner
description: The art of diplomacy has not been the strong suit of the fundamentalist Iranian Government. The point was underscored last week when Ali Khamenei, the Iranian President, stormed out of a state dinner held in his honor in Zimbabwe. Mr. Khamenei objected to seating arrangements, which placed two women at the head table, and to the inclusion of wine on the menu.

title: CLEANING UP AFTER A BANKRUPTCY
