description: ABOUT five years ago, the Quanta Resources Corporation got hit with the bad news: Tanks at its processing plant in Edgewater, N.J., contained an illegally high level of polychlorinated biphenyls - better known in pollution circles as PCB's. The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection ordered Quanta to clean the site up, at a cost of more than $6 million - at least triple the value of Quanta's total assets.

title: 1 Million Votes For Johnson
description: In a record-breaking total, Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers became the first player to eclipse a million votes as the National Basketball Association announced yesterday the results of the fan voting to determine the starting teams for the league's All-Star Game Feb. 9 in Dallas. Johnson drew 1,060,892 votes.

title: RIGHTIST MOZAMBIQUE REBELS SAID TO ATTACK TOWN IN NORTH
description: Rightist guerrillas in Mozambique inflicted heavy casualties in an attack on a northern town and derailed a train with a land mine, the Noticias de Portugal news agency reported today.

title: CONCERT SCHEDULE QUICKENS
description: IF it has taken most of January for the music schedule to return to its preholiday pace, it will certainly be back to concert business as usual come February, with at least four orchestral programs and a dozen chamber concerts planned that first week alone.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: HUNDREDS of New Jerseyans will be on the telephone next Sunday, asking folks to do their part to help needy Jews at home and abroad.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams Starring Dan Haggerty, Marjorie Harper, Don Shanks, Lisa Jones; directed by Richard Friedenberg, 1974 (G) United Home Video 93 minutes. $24.95 Why are children smitten by big, barrel-chested, bearded, friendly, hearty-voiced Grizzly Adams? Well, for such a great strapping figure of a fellow, Grizzly is endearingly gentle.

title: Reagan's Man For Education
description: I strongly disagree (and I am not a teacher) with the statement that Education Secretary Bennett ''occupies the lowliest of Cabinet positions - one that even he will readily agree is by no means essential to the survival of the Republic.''

title: ABOLISHING WINE CLASS: SOCIETY'S SOUR GRAPES
description: LONG ISLAND'S oldest wine course, an institution in Great Neck for more than 10 years, is being canceled. Like so many lost traditions, the demise of ''The Art of Wine'' is both regrettable and needless.

title: HIGH K.G.B. OFFICER IS SAID TO DEFECT
description: A high-ranking officer of the K.G.B. fled the Soviet Union last year and may be the most valuable defector from the Soviet bloc to the United States in recent years, Congressional sources said today.

title: MIDDLETON SCORES 3 AS BRUINS WIN
description: Rick Middleton scored three goals for the eighth hat trick of his National Hockey League career today, leading the Boston Bruins to a brawl-filled 6-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: A MONTH OF EVENTS ON HISTORY OF BLACKS
description: FEBRUARY will be a time of reflection on black historical accomplishments for schools, community centers and professional groups throughout the state as they observe Black History Month.

title:
MUSIC;
STATE OPERA TO OPEN WIH A GALA 'FAUST'
description: THE New Jersey State Opera will mark the opening of its 20th season next Sunday with a performance of Gounod's ''Faust'' at Symphony Hall here. Curtain time is 6 P.M.

title: ORIOLES SIGN BENiQUEZ
description: Juan Beniquez, the outfielder-first baseman who hit .304 with the California Angels last season, has agreed to a contract with the Baltimore Orioles, making him the 27th of the year's free agents to sign, but the first one to jump clubs.

title: EDITED BOOK JOURNAL
description: Solomon M. Malkin, the former publisher and editor of AB Bookman's Weekly, a journal about rare and out-of-print books, died Friday at his West Side apartment. He was 75 years old and had been in ill health for several years.

title: CASHING IN ON ANTIPOLLUTION SYSTEMS
description: ''CONVENTIONALLY in the printing industry,'' said Gunnar Walmet, program manager for industrial conservation at the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority in Albany, toxic vapors were routine byproducts of the printing process, and ''went up a stack into the air.''

title: Ninth Square
description: The rebirth of New Haven's Ninth Square is being furthered by the renovation of the James English building, a 119-year-old Italianate structure at Court and State Streets, into 50,000 square feet of office space. The building, which formerly housed manufacturers, is on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LIVING CHAMBER MUSIC As far as the six members of L'Amore di Musica are concerned, their chamber music repertory isn't inscribed in stone. Rather than begin in the Baroque period and end with the late 19th-century Romantics, it continues to grow with new works contributed by contemporary composers, says the ensemble's director, Mildred Perlow. To foster young talent and keep the chamber music tradition alive and growing, the Long Island-based group commissions pieces designed to display its players' special talents.

title: CORRECTION
description: Picture captions in the Westchester Weekly last Sunday with an article on the testing of drugs at a county laboratory incorrectly identified two people. Photographed examining cocaine was Jeffrey Sootin, a senior forensic scientist. William V. Graziano was the chemist testing a sample.

title: Gaynor Deegan Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Barbara B. Deegan of Harrison, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Anne Gaynor Deegan, to Keith Wilson Luke, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Luke of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SEA TO SHINING SEA: People, Travels, Places. By Berton Roueche. (Truman Talley/Dutton, $18.95.) You can never be sure what will bubble to the surface next in Berton Roueche's stew-pot collection of 18 essays, most of which have appeared in The New Yorker over the last 40 years.

title: THE MAN WHO UNDERSTOOD BECKETT
description: ENTRANCES An American Director's Journey. By Alan Schneider. Preface by Edward Albee. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Viking. $25. ALAN SCHNEIDER died in London in May 1984. During a break in rehearsals of a play he was directing at the Hampstead Theater Club, he was about to step across a notoriously dangerous intersection to post a letter to Samuel Beckett when a motorcyclist ran into him. He was thrown on his head and received fatal injuries. He was 66 years old. A few days earlier he had delivered the manuscript of ''Entrances,'' the first volume of his autobiography, to his publishers.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WEST BANK IS LINKED TO JORDAN VOTING PLAN
description: The Government has sent Parliament a new electoral law that reasserts Jordan's responsibility for the Israeli-occupied West Bank and provides representation for Palestinian refugees in Jordan.

title: WALTER PAYTON
description: AFTER thinking for many years that it simply might never happen, Walter Payton has made it to the Super Bowl.

title: Elisabeth S. Ross To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Ross of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Sarah Ross, to Ealan Joshua Wingate, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Wingate of Old Westbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for March.

title: TOLL-FREE LINE FOR TAXPAYERS
description: Taxpayers who have questions about the state's tax-amnesty program can call a toll-free telephone number, 1-800-CALL-TAX.

title: TENSION AGAIN ON RISE ON THE PUNJAB
description: A fresh wave of bombings, killings and mass arrests in northern India this week has created new tensions between Sikhs and Hindus and damaged the effort to resolve the crisis in the Punjab.

title: Table Space For Nonsmokers
description: OBSERVING that ''cigarette smoke in the eyes can ruin a meal just as easily as a fly in the soup,'' Mayor Koch asked restaurants in New York to set aside voluntarily at least 25 percent of their seating capacity for nonsmokers.

title: TURNOVERS MAY WRITE THE SUPER BOWL SCRIPT
description: They last played 19 weeks ago, but it might as well have been 19 years ago for all the influence history has in a championship game. More to the point is what the Chicago Bears and the New England Patriots have done since then, in prelude to their meeting at 5:16 P.M. Sunday in Super Bowl XX. Here's what: The Bears have mastered one of the most complex defenses ever designed, captured the fancy of the nation with people like William (Refrigerator) Perry and their iconoclastic quarterback, Jim McMahon, and established themselves as a 10 1/2-point favorite to win their first National Football League championship since 1963.

title: SAY 'MAMA LOVES ME'
description: SECRETS OF MARIE ANTOINETTE By Olivier Bernier. 326 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95. MARIE ANTOINETTE didn't brush her teeth properly, dressed badly, wrote sloppy letters and was generally frivolous, foolish, loose-tongued and dissipated. That is, according to her mother. Maria Theresa, Empress of Austria and an 18th-century Miss Manners, bombarded her teen-age daughter with advice on everything from politics to sex. No subject was too small or personal for the Empress's nagging solicitude, from the consummation of Marie Antoinette's marriage (it took Louis XVI seven years) to her reluctance to wear a corset or read a book. Their 10-year correspondence - selected and impecca-bly translated by Olivier Bernier, a popular writer on the 18th century, under the lurid title ''Secrets of Marie Antoinette'' - is a behind-the-scenes peek at Versailles avant le deluge and an account of a fraught mother-daughter relationship.

title: Jay Rosenthal to Wed Dr. Joyce A. Kornfeld
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Kornfeld of North Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Joyce A. Kornfeld, to Jay Philip Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rosenthal of Port Chester, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: AT SING SING, A POETS' CORNER THRIVES
description: HECTOR ALGARIN, standing at a microphone on the stage of the Sing Sing auditorium, said he would read a poem dedicated to a fellow poet, Charles Culhane, who has been in prison for 19 years. The poem, he said, was titled, ''A Lifer Who Is a Friend of Mine.''

title: New Rights Bill For Homosexuals
description: Mayor Koch introduced a homosexual-rights bill last week, and supporters gave it a fighting chance of passing. Although the City Council has been defeating such proposals annually for 15 years, Koch said this one had been revised to ''resolve all of the concerns that had been raised in the past.''

title: BLACK FILM MAKERS RETRACE THE CIVIL-RIGHTS STRUGGLE
description: On the old film, Rosa Parks doesn't look very threatening, a prim woman with glasses, hair tied neatly back, her Sunday-best gray suit carefully pressed. But there she is in a police station in Montgomery, Ala., being fingerprinted.

title: RACES MAY BE PREVIEW OF CUP
description: To test the waters for next year's America's Cup races, western Australian yachtsmen have organized a 12-Meter World Championship for Feb. 7-20 in Perth. But of the six United States syndicates still challenging for the America's Cup, only two plan to participate.

title: Topics; Magic and Specters Haunted Houses
description: AIDS stands for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. As it spreads, so does another malady called IFAIDS - irrational fear of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: CLIMATE OF AN UNDECLARED WAR
description: WITH THE CONTRAS A Reporter in the Wilds of Nicaragua. By Christopher Dickey. Illustrated. 327 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN POLLUTION CONTROL
description: IN the 15 years or so since the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, Safe Drinking Water Act and other Federal laws were enacted to clean up the environment, significant progress has been made in getting carbon monoxide, lead and other pollutants out of the air we breathe and the water we drink.

title: SIZING UP THE NEW SMALL FORMAT
description: The first independent laboratory tests of some of the new 8-millimeter video devices have now been completed. Among the brands evaluated were Sony, Kodak and Canon, and the results confirm what has been apparent to the eye: The picture quality of the format equals that of its predecessors. The figures are astounding, and one marvels that they were attained with equipment whose size and weight are a mere fraction of previous designs.

title: Tubingen
description: To the Editor: Tubingen is indeed a charming old town and its university is well respected throughout Europe. But during the 1930's and 40's, Tubingen was known as a hotbed of Nazism and many of its professors earned a wide reputation as avid anti-Semites.

title: Living In the Living Room
description: It is a pity that Nora Ephron can't find a use for her living room (''Room With View - And No People,'' Dec. 22). But I think I know why.

title: FOR WOULD BE POETS, A BETTERSWEET AVOCATION
description: Sometimes it seems the unknown poets hold poetry in the highest esteem. Their poetic triumphs are few, and yet they will travel far for poetry. Rosemarie Perry arrived an hour late for an hour-and-a-half seminar at the Nyack library. She had to catch two buses to get there, but she did.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DISNEY'S WORLD: A Biography. By Leonard Mosley. (Stein & Day, $18.95.) In November 1928, a young artist from Kansas City, Kan., sat in the audience of the Colony Theater in New York, tears rolling down his cheeks, as the people around him laughed at the antics of ''Steamboat Willie,'' billed as ''the first animated sound cartoon.''

title: SAVORING LONDON'S LUXURY
description: I had lived in London off and on for more than 15 years. I can tell you its highways, its byways, its galleries, its little-noticed museum treasures, its rare-book shops. I knew the odd, the outre, the way to get to obscure places by bus or tube, including the Colindale library, the Soane Museum, the Isle of Dogs, Kew Gardens, Chiswick, Wormwood Scrubs Prison and Kensal Green Cemetery. But there is one experience I had never had in all my years there until a few weeks ago.

title: WORKERS CAMPAIGN TO SAVE A FACTORY
description: PLANT closings in Bridgeport have come to be greeted with little more than resignation, community leaders agree. Until now.

title: COACH INSPIRES FAIRFIELD
description: Mitch Buonaguro is largely responsible for the return of Stagmania to Fairfield University's basketball program.

title: ONE NIGHT AT THE THEATER
description: As with other social occasions in Washington, international crisis and diplomatic tension can intrude upon a night at the theater.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: WARES A QUARTER OFF, SOMETIMES HALF Almue Stuen in Pleasantville has been a source for traditional Scandinavian tablewares and clothing for eight years, while gradually adding items from domestic manufacturers and craftsmen and from Italy, France, Austria, Ecuador, Great British and the Far East.

title: INFORMER IN PARKING BUREAU INQUIRY SAID TO KNOW MORE THAN HE HAS TOLD
description: The lawyer for a convicted swindler whose undercover work led to a corruption investigation of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau says his client has never been questioned by the Federal authorities about the full extent of his knowledge of bribes at the city agency.

title: QADDAFI SAILS OFF TO 'CONFRONT' U.S. WARSHIPS
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi boarded an armed Libyan patrol boat today and sailed into the choppy waters of the Gulf of Sidra to stage what he called a confrontation with the United States Sixth Fleet.

title: SWEDES AGAIN CITE EVIDENCE OF ALIEN SUBMARINE ACTIVITY
description: The Swedish Military Command said Friday that it had evidence indicating foreign submarines had intruded into Swedish waters 15 times in the last quarter of 1985.

title: REGINE CRESPIN, IN PHILADELPHIA IS COMMUNICATING WITH ESPRIT
description: AT an age when many opera singers start thinking of a farewell tour, Regine Crespin has shifted vocal gears and embarked contentedly in a new direction, using the rich mezzo voice that for several years had seemed to be lurking behind the gossamer soprano one. New roles, a professorship at the Paris Conservatory and master classes fill her schedule.

title: SYNAGOGUE PROGRAMS FOCUS ON INTERMARRIAGE
description: WHEN Christine and George Markley of Fairfield decided to get married 15 years ago, a rabbi told them that if they really loved each other, they would not go through with the wedding. In fact, Mr. Markley recently recalled, the rabbi said that because they were from different religions, their children would have severe emotional and behavioral problems.

title: Katherine Rudd Is Wed
description: Katherine Barr Rudd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Rudd of Portland, Me., was married yesterday to Douglas Dale Thaw, the son of Margaret James Thaw and Douglas Charles Thaw, both of Richmond. The Rev. Kevin Madigan performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The bride is a student at the State University of New York College at Purchase. Mr. Thaw is an actor and photogragher.

title: Qualifying for Capital Gain
description: Question: My client paid for her apartment and is awaiting the transfer of deed from the sponsor to the co-op corporation. What is the earliest she can sell and still qualify for capital gains treatment on her profit - six months from the date we signed the agreement or from when we paid the full balance into escrow, or from the date title passed? . . . H. J. E., West Hempstead, L.I.

title: WHEN TIME IS SHORT, PLAY CAN BE DARING
description: In match play, standard advice after a loss is to recover one's bearings by running off one or more draws. But in short matches, this might only hasten defeat.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Andreae
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eric Andreae of Tenafly, N.J., and Sea Island, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Andreae, to Henry Overstreet Booth 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Booth Jr. of Nashville. An April wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SCOTTISH NEWSLETTER
description: Yesterday was the birthday of the famed Scottish poet Robert Burns - and Harry Neeson, Yorktown resident and native of Renton near Loch Loman in Scotland, has special cause to celebrate. This month, Mr. Neeson, an insurance agent, mailed out the first issue of a newsletter he wrote and designed to spread information about the local Scottish community.

title: Art
description: Joe Stefanelli, whose recent paintings can be seen at the Ingber Gallery, 415 West Broadway, through Saturday only, is a true painter, a lifelong painter and a painter whose work is built to last. This is made clear in his every least move with the loaded brush.

title: America Needs Investment in Small Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne B. Spencer Wed to a Lawyer
description: Anne Bunte Spencer, a daughter of John Hutchings Spencer of Sharon, Conn., and Galveston, Tex., and the late Mrs. Spencer, was married in New York yesterday to William Pierre Holm, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Holm of Sharon. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: GENERALS MERGER OFF
description: The planned merger of the Houston Gamblers and the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League has been terminated, according to one of the Gamblers' owners, Jay Roulier of Denver. The merger, originally agreed upon last Aug. 1, called for Stephen Ross, a Manhattan real estate entrepreneur, to become a 50-50 partner with Donald Trump, the Generals' owner, and the two were then to buy the Houston franchise.

title: CUSTOMER SERVICE: BE NICE (AND QUELL COMPLAINTS)
description: THE Ford Motor Company sends ''mystery shoppers'' to thousands of dealerships, where they pose as customers seeking to have cars repaired. Then they report to the company on the quality of service, whether employees were courteous and whether their cars were returned on time.

title: Living In the Living Room
description: We do not have servants, drinks before dinner, nor do we work, sleep, telephone, watch television or swim in our living room. Yet, we use it all the time.

title: 34% Had No Opinion
description: Anyone who fears that political polling is turning the electoral process into an exact science should read some of the answers obtained recently, at considerable expense, by the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: TEA TABLE GETS RECORD PRICE
description: An 18th century Philadelphia tea table was auctioned yesterday to a New Hampshire industrialist for the highest price ever paid for a piece of American furniture anywhere - $1,045,000.

title: A New Bridge For Long Island
description: BEFORE everybody got smart, ''selling'' a bridge to an unsuspecting stranger was a favorite trick of confidence men. But there really are bridges for sale, and the Long Island Rail Road is buying one in Florida for $475,000.

title: STENMARK IS LEADER IN SLALOM
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden moved back into a familiar spot today - first place in the men's World Cup slalom standings with his first slalom victory in two years.

title: MANHATTANITE FINDS LIFE FORMS DO EXIST OUTSIDE OF NEW YORK
description: WHEN I moved to Westchester from Manhattan recently, I was so nervous about leaving New York City, especially Manhattan, that I was relieved to find an apartment only a few blocks from the Bronx border, more commonly known as City Line. For I regarded Manhattan as the center of the civilized world. And since I'd lived there for a long time, I believed that everything just about everybody in Manhattan said about the sterility of suburban life was true, and that there was nothing whatsoever to do in the suburbs.

title: CLOUDY FORECAST DELAYS TEACHER'S SPACE FLIGHT
description: The launching of the space shuttle Challenger planned Sunday has been postponed because of menacing weather. Space agency officials said it was tentatively rescheduled for 9:37 A.M. Monday, pending further review Sunday afternoon.

title: MUSIC: QUARTET PLAYS MOZART AND HAYDN PIECES
description: HISTORY records that Haydn and Mozart played chamber music together - Haydn taking the second-violin part, Mozart the viola. The Classical Quartet played music by these mutual admirers Thursday night at St. Michael's Church and did so on instruments with which both composers might have felt comfortable.

title: COLUMBIA AND BARNARD WILL ADD DORMITORIES
description: Columbia College and Barnard College, both faced with a shortage of student housing, plan to begin construction of dormitories in Morningside Heights within a year.

title: A Tuition Sale For Top Students
description: Bard College, a small, private liberal arts college in Annandale-on-Hudson, N. Y., 90 miles north of New York City, announced last week that it would attempt to recruit top public high school students with the zeal that many universities reserve for promising nose tackles.

title: Miss Sapinsley to Marry Harold Levy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Sapinsley of Providence, R.I., and Center Conway, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Sapinsley, to Harold Oscar Levy, a son of Alice Levy of Miami and the late Hugh Levy. A May wedding is planned.

title: Costly Correction
description: A year ago, Ariel Sharon won at least partial vindication when a Federal jury in Manhattan found that the former Israeli Defense Minister had been defamed by Time magazine. Time was incorrect, the jury said, in reporting that Mr. Sharon had encouraged Christian Phalangists to massacre residents of two Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut in 1982.

title: THE WRITER IN A TRANCE: ANGUISH, ANXIETY AND MIRCALES
description: AN admirable line of Pablo Neruda's, ''My creatures are born of a long denial,'' seems to me the best definition of writing as a kind of exorcism, casting off invading creatures by projecting them into universal existence, keeping them on the other side of the bridge, where it is no longer the narrator who has blown the bubble out of his clay pipe. It may be exaggerating to say that all completely successful short stories, especially fantastic stories, are products of neurosis, nightmares or hallucinations neutralized through objectification and translated to a medium outside the neurotic terrain. This polarization can be found in any memorable short story, as if the author, wanting to rid himself of his creature as soon and as absolutely as possible, exorcises it the only way he can: by writing it.

title: Tubingen
description: To the Editor: I most heartily endorse Kenneth Woodward's enthusiastic and informative report on Tubingen (Travel, Jan. 5). It is indeed one of Europe's most livable cities.

title: D.W.I. CHIEF RESIGNS
description: THE coordinator of Bergen County's successful Driving While Intoxicated Strike Force has resigned under pressure because, law-enforcement officials say, he overstepped his role on New Year's Eve by telling a television news reporter that no county road checks were scheduled because of a lack of police volunteers.

title: Recent Sales
description: Kent, Conn. $155,000 Route 7 South *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 30-year-old contemporary; *2*good location for an in-house business or an office, 3.6 acres; taxes $1,819. Redding, Conn. $344,000 356 Black RockTurnpike *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-month-old colonial, *2*fine moldings, stone fireplace, large deck, 2.9 acres; taxes, $3,740. Ridgefield, Conn. $329,000 223 Limestone Road *2*5-bedrooms, 3-bath, 35-year-old ranch; *2*heated pool, detached garage, apartment, 5.5 acres; taxes $3,740. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. $298,000 20 Hastings Landing *2*2-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, new town house; *2*river view, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $7,110. White Plains, N.Y. $215,000 7 Pinewood Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old frame split level, *2*eat-in kitchen, cathedral ceiling, den; taxes $3,350. Yonkers, N.Y. $159,000 36 Gibson Place *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, 2 decks; taxes $2,693. OTHER AREAS Patchogue, L.I. $89,000 37 Oakland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; *2*dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Shirley, L.I. $86,900 7 Maple Lane *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, den, basement; taxes $2,000. Iselin, N.J. $123,000 2 McKinley Avenue 3 *2*bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 6-year-old split level; den, *2*eat-in kitchen, central air-conditioning; taxes $1,843.

title: Liquor Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Offices as Condos
description: It happens often to residential tenants, but commercial tenants rarely must chose between buying their space or moving when a rental building is converted into a condominium. But that is what will happen at the Gramatan Building, a three-story, 24,000-square-foot office building in Bronxville, N.Y., whose owners are planning a conversion under an eviction plan.

title: Kotzwinkle in Print
description: To the Editor:

title: AID CENTER REOPENS FOR MINORITY FIRMS
description: OFFICIALS of the United States Department of Commerce hope they have finally found the right company to operate the Connecticut Minority Business Development Center.

title: LAST CHECK-OUT IS NEAR FOR BELLEVUE STRATFORD
description: The Corinthian columns that helped make the storied hotel's lobby a symbol of turn-of-the-century elegance presumably will still stand.

title: A NEW LOOK AT 'NOBLE SUFFERING'
description: ''PRAY, my dear . . . have you not forgot to wind up the clock?'' asks Mrs. Shandy at the crucial moment of Tristram's conception, and three-and-a-half volumes later when, face blackened and nose squashed, Tristram finally makes a precarious entry into the world at the clumsy hands of Dr. Slop, we witness the first descriptive childbirth scene in English fiction.

title: STATE IS PLANNING 'PARADE OF LIFETIME'
description: IT is still more than two months away, but preparations are under way for the state's 350th Anniversary Parade in April, an event officials expect will be the largest parade in the state's history.

title: G.O.P. SPLITS WITH O'NEILL ON KEY ISSUES
description: ALTHOUGH the 1986 session of the General Assembly does not convene until Feb. 5, Governor O'Neill and the Republicans who control the legislature already are sharpening their differences on some key legislative issues.

title: MINNESOTA COACH QUITS AFTER ARRESTS
description: Jim Dutcher, the University of Minnesota basketball coach, resigned today, one day after three of his players were arrested on charges of sexual assault.

title: Red Cross Fund Fraud Laid to 27 in Puerto Rico
description: The police have charged 27 people, including a Red Cross worker, with misusing more than $40,000 given to Puerto Rico by the American Red Cross after flooding last October.

title: Facing a Jury
description: Jury selection began in Hattiesburg last week for the trial of Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr., the chief Federal judge of the Southern District of Mississippi.

title: Marianne Cabot To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Marianne Cabot to James Stirling Welch Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Cabot of Cold Spring, N.Y, and La Malbaie, Charlevoix County, Quebec, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Welch of Louisville, Ky.

title: Kenneth S. Kail And Ivy Hwang To Wed in April
description: Ivy Hwang, an associate with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, and Kenneth Stoner Kail, an associate with Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, both Manhattan law firms, plan to be married in April. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sheuan Ching Wong of Singapore.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PARKS FARE
description: THE best things in life are not always free.

title: TRILOGY GROUP CANCELS TOUR
description: HAVING completed its three performances of ''Vanities'' at Mamaroneck's Emelin Theater earlier this month, the Trilogy Theater Company's board of directors has chosen to cancel the proposed local tour of Jack Heifner's popular play. Seven performances in five locations had been scheduled through Feb. 2.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER ANGOLAN REBELS MORAL BACKING
description: The Reagan Administration will seek a Congressional resolution declaring moral support for the anti-Communist rebels in Angola, Administration and Congressional sources said today. But, they said, the Administration will oppose legislation giving the rebels military or economic aid.

title: Talking; Setting The Bait For Buyers
description: ''URGENT. You have been computer selected to receive a luxury cruise to Freeport in the Bahamas including free round-trip tickets for two,'' the letter began.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Jan. 26, 1986 Fiction

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE DUKES AND THE DETAILS
description: The British have a way, at times, of reminding us that the small things in life make the great things great. BLENHEIM REVISITED: The Spencer-Churchills and Their Palace (Beaufort, $16.95) is an example of such a philosophy.

title: Gregory Wojahn Weds Eileen Hamilton Carothers
description: Eileen Hamilton Carothers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Carothers of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Lee Wojahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl F. Wojahn of Cincinnati. The Rev. John Reutter-Harrah, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Sheena Easton: Live at the Palace, Hollywood Thorn EMI Video 60 minutes. $49.95 This cassette captures Sheena Easton in 1982, when she was pop music's fresh-faced bonnie lassie.

title: WHEN THEATER MAKES FUN OF ITSELF
description: An astute theatergoer should be able to identify ''Mixing It Up,'' ''Love's Whirlwind,'' ''Nothing On,'' ''The House of Cards'' and ''The Golden Egg.'' Each is the title of a play within a play, one that is enacted on stage or referred to at some length and that parallels the main play. The theatrical device is as old as ''The Murder of Gonzago'' and ''Pyramus and Thisbe.'' It has been used by playwrights from Shakespeare to Tom Stoppard, from Molnar to David Mamet, a regiment of writers that includes Chekhov, Sartre, Genet and Moss Hart. One might regard the approach as holding a mirror up to theater.

title: DOW NEW COMPOSITIONS INSPIRE GOOSE PIMPLES?
description: A critic, it has been said, is someone who conducts his education in public. That definition, which critics ought to accept without the least sense of shame, can also apply to prominent composers, whose progress or lack of progress is monitored at every step of their careers both by their peers and, if they are fortunate, by audiences. It takes a hard-shelled character to bear up under such continual and pitiless scrutiny, which is perhaps why so many composers (and critics) choose early on to fasten onto accepted ideas and skulk behind them.

title: NEW DRUG SHOWS GAIN IN FIGHT AGAINST AIDS
description: A new drug treatment for AIDS tested on 15 patients in the United States has proved effective in keeping the virus from multiplying but cannot be considered a cure, a Japanese researcher says.

title: BANK OF AMERICA HAS A BAD WEEK
description: Bank of America's future, and that of its chief executive, Samuel H. Armacost, was clouded by a triple whammy. The nation's No. 2 bank was fined a staggering $4.75 million for failing to report large cash transactions. The same day its parent, BankAmerica, reported a $178 million loss, much more than most analysts had expected. Then, having slashed its dividend last August, the big West Coast bank eliminated it for the latest quarter. The loss came largely from its troubled portfolio of bad loans. While the bank says it has reduced its problems, analysts are skeptical of a turnaround soon.

title: PROPOSAL FOR MALL DEBATED
description: WHEN Brookhaven Town's six-month moratorium on construction of multifamily housing expired Jan. 1, the town designated two large sections as critical environmental areas. But now a developer who is planning to build a huge mall in Yaphank, in one of the critical areas, is under fire from local groups and officials.

title: Irene and Adam W. Rothkrug Planning Weddings
description: Irene Rothkrug plans to marry Mark V. Soresi in May, and her brother, Adam Wise Rothkrug, plans to marry Lisa Ilene Spector in August. The engagements have been announced by the parents of the future brides, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard F. Rothkrug and Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector, all of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Anne Keresey Edmonson, an Editor, To Be Wed to E. Coe Kerr 3d in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mahlon William Edmonson of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Keresey Edmonson to E. Coe Kerr 3d of Mill Neck, L.I., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kerr Jr. of Brookville, L.I., and Manhattan. A March wedding is planned.

title: 28 Said to Die in Blast At Chilean Arms Factory
description: An explosion rocked Chile's largest arms factory today, killing as many as 28 people and injuring 11, the police said.

title: FLORENTINE POTIONS FOR SALE
description: The smell of incense has been replaced by an overwhelming fragrance of herbs. Footsteps on the flagstone floor echo from the frescoed ceilings, people talk in whispers and old-fashioned cabinets housing glass-stoppered decanters are interspersed with the choir stalls. This is the setting of the Farmacia di Santa Maria Novella, which was once a chapel belonging to the Dominican monastery of Santa Maria Novella, and the hallowed atmosphere lingers.

title: BRITISH AND FRENCH MISSILES COMPLICATE LIFE FOR MOSCOW
description: While the United States and the Soviet Union exchange suggestions for deep cuts in nuclear arms, Britain and France are heading the opposite way. Both have started programs to multiply their nuclear arsenals.

title: JUDAICA MEETS MATH AT NEW 'SCHOOL'
description: TWELVE-year-old Rachel Schein became interested in religion through her temple's Sunday School. ''But it was only three and a half hours a week and she felt it was not enough,'' said her father, Aaron, a mathematics professor at Nassau Community College.

title: FROM TOKYO TO SUPER BOWL
description: NEVER in the XX years of the Super Bowl has anyone come so far as Hiroshi Shiriashi to take an active part in America's most-watched sporting event.

title: CONGRESS ENVISIONS A YEAR TO FORGET
description: When Republican leaders had breakfast at the White House last week, they listened quietly as President Reagan sketched out a budget proposal that would slice deficits solely by reducing domestic programs. Lower defense spending and higher taxes were ruled out. No voice was raised in opposition to the President's plan, but later in the day Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi joked that it was a good thing none of the Republican leaders had been asked to take lie detector tests.

title: Foundations and Research
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE OVER ASH FILL INTENSIFIES
description: A STATE agency is expected to recommend to Governor Cuomo this week that a Long Island regional ash fill be set up on a 230-acre tract in Yaphank. But some local officials, spurred by a Brookhaven Town lawsuit against the state over the site, continue to argue that the legislation on which the recommendation is based is flawed, and that a single ash fill site in Yaphank is unworkable, unwise and unfair.

title: Another Capital Lawyer
description: Roderick A. DeArment is resigning this week as chief of staff to the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, to join the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling as a partner. He was an associate in the firm from 1973 to 1979, when he came to Capitol Hill to work for the Senate Finance Committee, and later for the Senator.

title: 3 Sikhs Convicted In Gandhi Slaying
description: Even before the final arguments in the trial of three Sikhs accused of the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, Sikh extremists had been stepping up bombings and killings in the name of independence for the state of Punjab, where they are in the majority. So it was widely feared that last week's verdict - all were found guilty - and death sentences would be fuel for the fire.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS PRESS U.S. ON ISSUE OF CROTON LANDFILL
description: FOR more than 30 years, environmentalists, Croton residents and government officials have called for the closing of a county-owned landfill on Croton Point in Croton-on-Hudson. Closing dates have come and gone, but the landfill continues to operate. In an effort to close the Croton Point Landfill and to restore the surrounding marshlands, the Hudson River Fishermen's Association recently turned over information to the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, asking the Federal Government to sue Westchester County for violation of a 1977 consent agreement.

title: Reagan's Man For Education
description: Like Secretary Bennett, I too had the pleasure of studying philosophy under Laszlo Versenyi.

title: Budd Keeps 1,500 Title With British Record
description: Zola Budd, the British track star, never trailed as she retained her British national indoor 1,500-meter run title today and broke a nine-year-old domestic record in her first race of 1986.

title: SLAYINGS IN THE PHILIPPINE CAMPAIGN CLIMB TO 13
description: Incidents of assassination and intimidation, part of the political tradition in the Philippines, are an increasing factor in the campaign for the presidency, with 13 slayings reported in the Government's latest count issued today.

title: THE DUAL NATURE OF PIANO MUSIC IS RESOLVED BY THE CD
description: Until CD's came along, a recording engineer looked at a concert grand as a long-distance swimmer would look at a shark. No other instrument ever gave him so much trouble.

title: LIFE IMITATES ART: WE SEE WHAT ISN'T REALLY THERE
description: MY FIRST known exposure to the art form known as trompe l'oeil was in New Brunswick a few years back, just about the time that city's renaissance began.

title: Jessica B. Sporn To Wed in April
description: Announcement has been made by Samuel P. Sporn and Dr. Ellen Sporn of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter Jessica Beth Sporn to Nader M. Tavakoli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Akbar Tavakoli of Mystic Islands, N.J. The wedding is planned for April 12.

title: JAPAN AGREES TO UNITED AIRLINES FLIGHTS
description: The United States and Japan agreed today that United Airlines could replace Pan American World Airways on trans-Pacific routes, thus clearing the last major obstacle to United's $750 million purchase of Pan American's routes in that part of the world.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: M*A*S*H: Goodbye, Farewell and Amen Starring Alan Alda, Mike Farrell, Harry Morgan, Jamie Farr, David Ogden Stiers, Loretta Swit; directed by Mr. Alda, 1983 CBS/Fox Video 119 minutes.

title: Nina Harkrader To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton K. Harkrader Jr. of Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Elizabeth Harkrader, to Dr. John David Meyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Meyer of Syracuse. An April wedding is planned.

title: CUOMO WANTS TO GO BEYOND WORKFARE TO WORK ETHIC
description: Memories of Governors Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt were stirred a year ago when Governor Cuomo reminded legislators, gathered in the Assembly for his State of the State Address, of what their predecessors had done. ''The future once happened here,'' he said.

title: THE 'CHUNNEL' IS LAUNCHED
description: FRANCE has been itching to tunnel under the English Channel since the 1750's, but the project repeatedly foundered on British concerns about security and costs and prejudices dear to island dwellers. Last week, mindful of such issues as jobs, European togetherness and their separate slumps in popularity, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher relaunched the ''chunnel'' in a ceremony at Lille, in economically depressed northern France.

title: Battling to Change Scout Tradition
description: THE Boy Scouts of America insists that its scoutmasters be men, arguing that boys need a male role model. In 1974, Catherine Pollard, then a 56-year-old music teacher in Milford, Conn., challenged this rule.

title: Linda Wiley To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Thomas H. Wiley of Lincolnshire, Ill., of the engagement of her daughter Linda Helen Wiley to John Fleming Ball Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ball of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Off the Shores of Tripoli
description: Navy jets from the carriers Saratoga and Coral Sea began operations over Mediterranean waters last week to show, the State Department said, ''U.S. resolve to operate in international waters.''

title: PANEL MAY LIMIT DEDUCTINS OF STATE TAXES, SENATOR SAYS
description: After an overnight meeting with Senate tax writers and top officials of the Treasury Department, Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that he sensed his committee would vote to limit Federal deductions for some state and local taxes.

title: THE NEXT STEP IN ENVIRONMENTAL LAW
description: INDUSTRY has been effectively backed into a corner by pollution measures. But the the environment is certainly not pristine, and chances are good that more anti-pollution laws are in the offing. ''State and Federal agencies have done better at cleaning up sewage'' than they have in cleaning up toxic chemicals, complained Mr. Zwick of the Clean Water Action Project.

title: ASBESTOS SUIT WON BY GREENVILLE, S.C.
description: A jury has ordered a Massachusetts company to pay Greenville $8.4 million in damages for selling it an asbestos-based fireproofing material used in City Hall.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIME SHARING. By Richard Krawiec. (Viking, $14.95.) The landscape in Richard Krawiec's first novel consists of porno theaters, wrestling parlors, dark and violent barrooms, rotting tenements decorated with 3-D pictures of Jesus.

title: THE COURSE OF A CAUSE CELEBRE
description: THE AFFAIR The Case of Alfred Dreyfus. By Jean-Denis Bredin. Translated by Jeffrey Mehlman. Illustrated. 628 pp. New York: George Braziller. $24.95.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LAKE GEORGE SHENANIGANS Why will people race motorcycles, stock cars and even outhouses, among other things, across frozen Lake George? ''Anything to break cabin fever,'' explained a spokesman for Winter Carnival, the occasion for these unlikely events in upstate New York.

title: ALTA: HIGH, MAIGHT AND LOW-KEY
description: The attendant brushed a thin layer of fresh snow off the chairlift seat and with an easy smile said, ''All aboard for paradise.'' It was shortly after 9:30 on a cloudless January morning, the temperature was 8 degrees and there was more than 100 inches of snow on the ground, 3 or 4 of which had fallen the night before.

title: BRINGING THE TERROR OF AIDS DOWN TO A HUMAN LEVEL
description: EVERY Wednesday night in Highland Park, the terror of acquired immune deficiency syndrome is reduced to a human level.

title: NEW PLAYS SHOWN AT YALE WINTERFEST
description: THE Yale Repertory Company's Winterfest, the theater's midwinter respite from its regular series of plays, was created six years ago to explorenew works-in-progress by emerging American playwrights.

title: Mary Harper Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Forrest Dail Harper of Oklahoma City and Pebble Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Harper to Michael John Moran, a son of Robert James Moran of Madison, Conn., and the late Marylin Dowling Moran.

title: TEXANS SHUDDER AS PRICE OF PETROLEUM FALLS
description: The swift and drastic fall in the price of oil on world markets over the last week has sent a deep shudder throughout Texas, stirring fears that this oil-rich region will be thrown into a recession.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THEODORE ROOSEVELT, CULTURE, DIPLOMACY, AND EXPANSION: A New View of American Imperialism. By Richard H. Collin. (Louisiana State University, $25.) To many, Theodore Roosevelt epitomizes the arrogance of American expansionism.

title: A NEW WORD SWEEPING NEW ENGLAND: PATRIOT-ISM
description: Growing up in the nearby industrial city of Brockton, John Boyajian could never bring himself to be a New England Patriots fan. ''They were such a disappointment - a few wins and then they'd die,'' he recalled. Mr. Boyajian did go to one game but got bored and left in the third quarter.

title: OKLAHOMA TRIES TO MAINTAIN ITS SUCCESS WITHOUT TISDALE
description: WHEN the University of Oklahoma's 1975 top-ranked football team returned from the Orange Bowl on Jan. 3, 1976, more than 3,000 fans waited in subfreezing temperatures at the airport to welcome the players home. A crowd estimated at 2,000 attended the Sooners' basketball loss to Oral Roberts on campus the same day.

title: ADVANCES IN THE ART OF WAITING
description: HERE it was in frosty January, and I kept thinking about the ''waiting game'' in Kurt Weill's ''September Song.'' I remembered the tune and the first few words, ''It's a long, long something from May to September,'' with ''waiting game'' bringing up the rear somewhere.

title: 'Scrub Suit' Case In Allentown
description: FASHION-CONSCIOUS thieves who have been pilfering green surgical ''scrub suits'' from 30 hospitals in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York may soon find a detective agency on their trails.

title: NETS ARE DEFEATED BY SONICS, 106-99
description: When he emerged from the dressing room tonight, Dave Wohl had calmed down. But in the aftermath of the Nets' 106-99 loss to the Seattle SuperSonics, Wohl was clearly exasperated. Behind closed doors, the Net coach could be heard scolding his team, which played ineffectively down the stretch and finally lost to a club that had dropped six straight games before tonight.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SUMMER. By Lisa Grunwald. (Knopf, $15.95.) Nineteen-year-old Jennifer Burke is the daughter of a famous sculptor, Milo Burke, and his elegant wife, Katherine, called Lulu, who abandoned her Back Bay family and then her own painting to become a witty earth mother.

title: THE ECONOMY MAY GROW AS THE PRICE OF OIL SHRINKS
description: LIKE the oil-price explosions of a decade ago, it was one of those times when conventional wisdom gives way to another shock, this plunge in the cost of oil. Prices for a barrel of oil dipped below $20 last week, close to half the all-time peak. And even Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said, ''We don't know where this thing is going to settle out.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Jan. 5 about St. Kitts and Nevis in the Caribbean misstated the year in which Alexander Hamilton's family left Nevis, his birthplace. The year was 1762.

title: COUNTY OFFENDERS CONFINED AT HOME
description: Since last October, Judge Nicholas Colabella of Westchester County Court has sentenced 15 Westchester residents to house confinement, a middle ground between probation and prison.

title: Of Spiced Apples And Relaxation
description: THE aroma of spiced apples, researchers at Yale University discovered, has a calming effect on many people that tends to lower blood pressure.

title: LUCINDA CHILDS EXPANDS HER VISIONS OF DANCE
description: In Lucinda Childs's new full-evening dance, ''Portraits in Reflection'' - which is to be given its premiere Tuesday when her company opens a two-week season at the Joyce Theater - the music, set, costumes and choreography start simply. Gradually, however, the work acquires added layers - a decor of slide projections, for instance, and costumes that feature shiny metallic waistbands. By the end, it is positively extravagant, complete with a fire burning upstage. All this from a choreographer who's been called ''minimal.''

title: SUFFOLK SEEKING ACREAGE
description: A PLAN to spend $23.5 million to buy and preserve 1,918 acres of open land was placed before the Suffolk County Legislature last week by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan.

title: SUPER BOWL PLAYERS WILL BE REACHING FOR THE RING
description: The joy of becoming No. 1 is exhilarating. The notoriety is lasting. The $36,000 winners' share pays many bills. But to most professional football players, perhaps the greatest tangible satisfaction from winning the Super Bowl comes from the Super Bowl ring.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILHARMONIC
description: ARNOLD SCHOENBERG'S ''Transfigured Night'' (Opus 4) opened the New York Philharmonic's Friday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: FOREIGN COMPANIES IN BURMA TOLD TO DISMISS LOCAL AGENTS
description: Foreign companies doing business in Burma have been told to dismiss all locally hired representatives, whose jobs will be taken over by workers for the Government-run Inspection and Agency Corporation.

title: MCHEADBAND'S DECISION
description: IT'S been Jim McMahon's week.

title: CHICAGO COUNTS THE WAYS IT DOESN'T LOVE THE BEARS
description: Who cares about the Chicago Bears? Obviously, not Chicago.

title: PARK IS SUSPENDED
description: Three of his Red Wing players have just returned to the team after spending a total of nine games on the suspension list following a brawl Jan. 13, and now it's Brad Park's turn to leave. The rookie Detroit coach was given a six-game suspension for ordering his players off the bench to start the brawl in the third period of a losing effort against the Maple Leafs in Toronto.

title: OFF WITH OLD, ON WITH NEW -- BUT WHY?
description: A FEW weeks into 1986, but there's still time. Off with the old, on with the new!

title: POLICE OFFICERS GIVE LESSONS IN SCHOOL
description: WHEN Officer Felicia Perry of the Hartford Police Department walked into a third-grade classroom at St. Peter's Elementary School in that city recently, the students greeted her enthusiastically.

title: RETURN OF SALMON PROPOSED
description: THE effort to bring the Atlantic salmon back to the Connecticut River and its tributaries would be enhanced by a proposed regulation that would end harvesting of those fish in the marine waters of eastern Long Island, according to Christopher Percy, president of The Sounds Conservancy.

title: SILENCE IS MUSICAL
description: FROM THIS CONDENSERY The Complete Writing of Lorine Niedecker. Edited by Robert J. Bertholf. 336 pp. East Haven, Conn.: The Jargon Society/Inland Book Company. $30. THE GRANITE PAIL The Selected Poems of Lorine Niedecker. Edited and with a preface by Cid Corman. 111 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $11. LORINE NIEDECKER, throughout a literary career of some 50 years, both admired and wrote poems she hoped would stand up against a culture engaged, as she put it, in ''the armed avoidance of quiet.'' She once told the poet Cid Corman, who is the editor of ''The Granite Pail,'' a selection of her poems, ''I want to plant my poems in deep silence.'' Her masters and influences were meditative men and women - Jefferson, Darwin, William Morris, the botanist Asa Gray and more contemporary strategists of poetic silences like Mr. Corman, Basil Bunting and her sometime mentor and correspondent, the Objectivist poet Louis Zukofsky. From them she learned to use contemplation and the absence of noise not as a defense against the world, nor as a form of withdrawal, but as a compositional element, a way of forcing the reader's attention on the precision and subtlety of her verse. Trees, flowers and rivers, in particular those of her native Wisconsin, are among her favorite subjects partly because their growth and development occur without auditory fanfare. In one poem in ''From This Condensery,'' a collection of all her poetry and prose edited by Robert J. Bertholf, the poetic act is likened to the soundlessness of a bird in flight: I was the solitary plover a pencil for a wing-bone From the secret notes I must tilt upon the pressure execute and adjust In us sea-air rhythm.

title: Reconciliation
description: 'Has Germany ever asked us to forgive? To my knowledge, no such plea was ever made. With whom am I to speak about forgiveness? I, who don't believe in collective guilt. Who am I to believe in collective innocence?' Elie Wiesel; chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, during his first vist to Germany since his release almost 40 years ago from the Buchenwald concentration camp.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am sailing out along parallel 32.5 to stress that this is the Libyan border.'' - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. [ 1:4. ]

title: PEQUOTS ADDING NEW VENTURE TO ENTERPRISES
description: BY the Fourth of July, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians of southeastern Connecticut hope to add the next unit to their growing business conglomerate: a $4 million bingo hall.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
VISIT TO A GRANDDAUGHTER'S SICKBED
description: MY granddaughter, Nicole, was ill with a virus. That is the malady patients have when the doctor is perplexed. He certainly isn't going to tell you that he hasn't any idea why you're running a fever of 103 degrees. ''You have a viral infection; there's a lot of this going around,'' the doctor says assuredly. He deftly writes a prescription for a costly antibiotic, and hopes you recover.

title: A TOWN THAT CAN'T GET ENOUGH TRASH
description: WHILE most towns search frantically for ways of disposing their garbage, Windham has just the opposite problem. It doesn't have enough garbage.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Consumers are alive, well, kicking and spending.''

title: THE SPLENDOR OF SIMPLICITY
description: THE CREAKY FLOORS, SLANTING EVER SO slightly with age, have been left bare save for three small area rugs in the living room. Only simple blinds hang in the windows and the furnishings, for the most part a combination of English and American antiques, are few in number.

title: BRING BACK THE GINGERBREAD
description: FLIGHT OF FANCY The Banishment and Return of Ornament. By Brent C. Brolin. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $30. BRENT C. BROLIN writes that ''Flight of

title: FOOT PAIN SIDE LINES CARTWRIGHT IN LOSS
description: Never has a facial expression said so much. It came just before the start of the final period of last night's 104-88 Knick loss to the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden. As the players from both teams walked onto the court, Bill Cartwright, sitting alone at the end the Knicks' bench with a towel in his hands, was in tears.

title: PESTICIDE FEARED AT SCHOOL ANNEX
description: A MIDDLE ISLAND school district reopened an elementary school annex last month that had been closed and cleaned because of contamination by the dangerous pesticide chlordane. However, parents and others fear that the annex and other parts of the school still may not be safe to use.

title: ON NORDIC SKIS IN CANADA'S WILDERNESS
description: Every skier has a favorite place with reliable snow, challenging slopes and superb mountain vistas. For cross-country skiers, particularly those who like their snow untracked and are partial to high alpine meadows, the Tonquin Valley in the Canadian Rockies may well measure up to the ideal.

title: Jonah Perry Wins Acquittal In Mugging Case
description: Until her younger son was killed in an episode of street violence on the night of June 12, Mrs. Veronica Perry's primary goal for Edmund, 17, and Jonah, 19, was a first-class education. They were getting it, and the world lay ahead: Edmund had just graduated with honors from Phillips Exeter Academy and was planning to enter Stanford University.

title: 'HI, MOM, CAN I ASK YOU A QUESTION?'
description: CONTRARY to public opinion, life for parents does not become easier as children grow older.

title: PUBLIC POWER HAS SOME BRIGHT LIGHTS
description: As private utilities struggle to complete over-budget nuclear plants and press for large rate increases, some consumers have again shown an interest in public power.

title: Second Guessing The Parole Board
description: New York State's parole board lost some of its legal immunity last week. A state appellate court ruled that the board, traditionally protected from suits that seek to hold it responsible for crimes committed by convicts it has released, is not beyond judicial review.

title: GIVING OF ONESELF AND ONE'S WALLET
description: When Barbara Gerbasi wrote ''The Best Charity: Give of Yourself and Your Wallet'' [ Opinion Page, Dec. 29 ] , she was referring tp a special kind of person. She was thinking of someone who has been tempered by travail and hardened by the unrelenting side of life itself.

title: A U.S. DEBUT ON THE TOKYO EXCHANGE
description: ON Christmas Day 1984, Merrill Lynch Japan was one disappointed company. Daifuku Securities had just announced that it was awarding its vacant seat on the Tokyo Stock Exchange -the first seat ever open to a foreign securities company - not to Merrill Lynch but to a Japanese firm. Merrill Lynch lost out to a higher bid and, some suspected, to the network of relationships that link Japan's financial world.

title: Parlay Voo
description: To the Editor: I basked merrily in the humorous sunshine of ''Parlay Voo Anything?'', having been in Korea, China and Japan armed only with four non-Asian languages.

title: Topics; Magic and Specters Naming Names
description: Some of the most informative television programs involve ''talking heads'' - one or more seated experts discussing a subject or being interviewed. Often the face is familiar: Secretary Shultz, Dr. Ruth.

title: HERE'S GARDEN FLOWER THAT CAN BE SOWN IN THE SNOW
description: Poppy seeds can be sown in melting spring snow. When I was young, my grandmother used to tell me to sow them for the garden fairies. She said the earlier the seed was sown, the sooner shawls of silky flower petals would warm the tiny shoulders of these visitors.

title: 2 Liberian Politicians Charged With Treason
description: Two prominent Liberian politicians who contested the October general election that kept Gen. Samuel K. Doe in power have been formally charged with treason, officials said Friday.

title: Business Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN AN EXECUTIVE FACES UNEMPLOYMENT
description: OUTPLACEMENT, that awkward word that crept into the business lexicon about 10 years ago, is best described by its practitioners as an outside counseling service that companies offer discharged employees to soften the trauma of being dismissed.

title: HIGH-PRICED CHINESE IN STAMFORD
description: THE Stamford Plaza Hotel has added two restaurants, both of which are branches of establishments elsewhere. One is Mr. Lee, which has a large, somewhat sparse-looking dining room with small reproductions of Chinese paintings along the walls. Two smaller, more intimate rooms branch from the main room.

title: PUBLIC BULLISH ON BEARS, POLL FINDS
description: The Chicago Bears are the overwhelming popular choice in today's Super Bowl, with two-thirds of all Americans who are rooting for anyone rooting for the Bears.

title: NO ILLUSIONS
description: THE DEBATE IS ALWAYS THERE. STOP AND listen for a moment on any Israeli street corner and you will hear it, like a far-off volcano on a low boil or the pounding of a not-too-distant sea. It takes place on the editorial pages and in living rooms on Friday nights, in buses on long trips north and in casual encounters between people who barely know each other. It is the background noise of Israeli society. It is the debate about ''peace'' - what to do about it, how much, if anything, to give for it. It is the one issue on which every Israeli has at least one opinion, if not half a dozen.

title: Data Bank; January 26, 1986
PUT SEAT BELTS ON SCHOOL BUSES
description: THE seat belt law in New York State has saved lives. No one seriously disagrees with that fact, or the fact that it will continue to save lives. But the life that it will not save, the life that it cannot save, is the life of your child, or my child, or anyone's child tragically killed in an accident on a school bus.

title: Leslie H. Wilcott to Wed Hunt Henrie
description: Mrs. Gardiner Wilcott of Concord, Mass., and Harry W. Wilcott of Boston and Ogunquit, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Hudson Wilcott to E. Hunterson Henrie 2d, a son of Barbara Henrie Faricy of Washington and Dr. Edwin J. Henrie of Newport, R.I. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Living In the Living Room
description: From now on, I need not defend myself to people who accuse me of not using my living room. The next person who remarks that my living room looks un-lived-in will be seated there and handed Nora Ephron's article.

title: PRESENCE OF FOYT ENLIVENS DAYTONA
description: His name is magic to auto-racing fans. When his car rolls out onto the race track, whether for qualifying or just a low-speed shakedown run, the crowds in the grandstands invariably applaud. The name, of course, is A. J. Foyt, and even when he starts a race dead last, as he did two years ago at the Michigan 500, the fans still cheer loudest when his name is announced.

title: FOR NEW HONDURAN CHIEF, OLD RULE: ARMY AND U.S.
description: He will not take office until Monday, but already a wide variety of political commentators here are predicting that the next President of Honduras is likely to be even more dependent than his predecessor on the army and the United States Embassy.

title: TRUCKS SHOW UPWARD MOBILITY
description: THE truck favored by Queen Elizabeth II will soon be available in the United States. Called the Range Rover, a descendant of the Land Rover, it sells for the equivalent of $28,000 in Britain, where it is built. It will doubtless cost more here.

title: About Men; A Sense of Injustice
description: IT WASN'T THAT WE WERE ashamed of our display of affection, it was just that we didn't think about it, this man-boy of mine and myself. We unabashedly hugged, kissed, cried and clung to each other in the courtroom hallway. I can remember the tough, hardened marines surrounding us. They turned away, lest they display the same gut emotion as my son, their fellow marine.

title: Students to Patrol Annapolis
description: Law-enforcement students from Anne Arundel Community College will be joining the police this spring on downtown foot patrols in an effort to increase police visibility, Mayor Dennis Callahan said. The students, who will be in uniform but will not carry guns, are expected to be on the streets by the end of April, Mr. Callahan said. They will be empowered to enforce laws on loitering, noise and littering.

title: A CALL FOR HELP FROM MADD
description: The articles and graphics on declining alcohol-related highway fatalities [ Jan. 19 ] were an interesting and dramatic presentation of a statistical report that illustrated the ''New Jersey phenomenon'' in curbing drunken driving. I would like to go a bit further in explaining the ''why'' of our state's success.

title: Kim Midgarden Weds Arthur J. McGinnis Jr.
description: Kim Elizabeth Midgarden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Midgarden of Hoople, N.D., was married yesterday to Arthur J. McGinnis Jr., the son of Mr. McGinnis and the late Roselind Diskon McGinnis of Allenhurst, N.J. The Rev. William L. Reilly, former president of Le Moyne College, performed the ceremony at the St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: MUSIC: MADRIGALS BY POMERIUM MUSICES
description: NEXT Sunday is diva-day for New York voice lovers, when four of our best-known opera singers will be heard here in recital. On a slightly more rarefied level, Thursday evening's Pomerium Musices concert at Carnegie Recital Hall offered a historical equivalent. And indeed, the place was packed, and not just with early-music fanatics; some Metropolitan Opera-style voice lovers were in attendance, too.

title: CITY UNIT CALLED TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators in Brooklyn are looking into the possibility that bribes or kickbacks were paid in connection with contracts awarded to collection agencies by the city's environmental officials, according to investigators and lawyers familiar with the inquiry.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AFTER THE WAR WAS OVER: 168 Masterpieces by Magnum Photographers. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $39.95.) It was spring 1947. Five photographers, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Capa, David Seymour, George Rodger and William Vandivert, seated around a table in the restaurant of the Museum of Modern Art decided to form a photographic agency.

title: CRIME VICTIMS TRY TO EASE PAIN
description: WHEN Charles W. Hoyt of Fairfield meets with other crime victims this afternoon, he knows they will be eager to talk to him about their experiences.

title: Back From Brasilia
description: The United States Ambassador to Brazil, Diego C. Asencio, is retiring at the end of February after 29 years in the Foreign Service, and the leading candidate to succeed him, according to State Department sources, is Harry W. Shlaudeman, who has been a special ambassador to the Contadora group of nations seeking a peace formula in Central America.

title: LESOTHO EXPELS 60 SOUTH AFRICAN INSURGENTS
description: Lesotho's new military rulers deported a group of South African political fugitives today in return for the lifting of a blockade imposed by Pretoria more than three weeks ago.

title: SOLDIER WITH U.N. KILLED IN LEBANON
description: A Nepalese sergeant serving with the United Nations force in Lebanon was killed today when the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army fired five tank-cannon rounds into the center of Kafra, a Shiite village of 900 people 12 miles east of here, according to United Nations officials.

title: REASON FOR CHEERS
description: His team is limping along with an 8-8 record, including a 2-4 mark in the Pacific-10 Conference, and three of his players have been dropped from the team for academic or disciplinary reasons, but Steve Patterson, the interim basketball coach at Arizona State, finally got something to cheer about. In a surprise announcement he was officially appointed to the post of head coach and given a one-year contract. ''It removes the cloud,'' said the 37-year-old Patterson, a former Arizona State assistant who was appointed interim coach after the dismissal of Bob Weinhauer last August.

title: EYE ON TAXES AND ON HISTORY'S LESSONS l>By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER
description: ''NOTHING is going to happen until well into 1986, which makes it chaotic.''

title: THE THEATER: 'BODEGA'
description: THE climax of ''Bodega'' by Federico Fraguada at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater is shocking, and also annoying. Two armed, masked robbers invade a neighborhood store in the South Bronx, tie and gag the store's owner and attempt to rape his wife and daughter. When he breaks free and rushes them, one robber stabs him to death while the other flees. The wife grabs a gun from behind the counter and shoots the murderer. He struggles to his feet bleeding from his stomach and as he simultaneously menaces her and pleads for mercy, she shoots him again.

title: On Language; Secs Appeal
description: DO YOU KNOW WHAT secular humanism is?'' asked Norman Lear a few months ago, subtly knocking the term in a letter to what he called ''a number of well-known educators, artists, and public officials like yourself.'' Myself, I prefer like you, and don't know exactly which direct-mail category applies to me, but I will try to illuminate and aggravate the controversy about the phrase.

title: ISLANDERS IN 3-3 TIE WITH HAWKS
description: The Islanders had a one-goal lead after two periods, lost it in the third, and settled for a 3-3 tie against the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders had been hoping for their first three-game winning streak of the season, but a third-period surge by Chicago spoiled their intentions.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Celtics vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Boston, noon. The Celtics lead the season series by 2-1, after splitting two games in Philadelphia and winning the first one in Boston Garden. (Television - Channel 2, noon.) Colleges: Notre Dame at North Carolina. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) The Tar Heels are still No. 1. St. Joseph's (Me.) at United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I. 4 P.M. Football Chicago Bears vs. New England Patriots, Super Bowl XX, at New Orleans. What else can be said that hasn't already? (Television -Channel 4, 5 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 5 P.M.). Other Events BOXING: Golden Gloves, at Madison Square Garden Felt Forum. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M.) GOLF: Phoenix Open, final round. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.). Ladies P.G.A. Mazda Classic, final round, at Boca Raton, Fla. (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M.). RUNNING: New York Road Runners Club, 20-kilometer race, at Central Park, 9:30 A.M. SKI JUMPING: Bear Mountain Sports Association New York State junior championship, at Bear Mountain State Park, noon. SLED DOG RACING: Eighth annual ALPO International, at Saranac Lake, N.Y. Almost 2,000 dogs and 200 drivers from 15 states and three Canadian provinces will be competing for $50,000 in prize money. SOCCER: Roma vs. Napoli, at Rome, Italian professional league game of the week. (Television - Channel 31, 8:30 A.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACING: The $60,000-added Coaltown, for 4-year-olds and up at six furlongs, is the feature. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.) TRACK AND FIELD: Manufacturers Hanover/MAC men's junior metropolitan championships at the 102d Engineers Armory, 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, high school boys and girls, at 10 A.M.; boys' youth, at 12:30 P.M.; championship open and masters for men only, at 2:30 P.M.; includes one-mile women's walk.

title: Cable TV
description: Saturday's cable cluster of film premieres and other new screen fare should satisfy anybody, starting with ''The Empire Strikes Back'' (1980) on HBO at 7:30 A.M. and 8 P.M. Here, finally on cable, is the dazzling sequel to ''Star Wars,'' with its eye-popping spectacle, lightning pace and an alumni cast headed by Mark Hamil, Carrie Fisher, Harrison Ford and Billy Dee Williams. Showtime is spotlighting earthy American youth. Its noon matinee - repeated at 10 P.M. - is ''The Flamingo Kid'' (1984) with Matt Dillon - an ebullient, unsentimental ''Summer of '42'' about a Brooklyn lad on nouveau-riche Long Island terrain. ''Mischief'' (1985) - at 8 P.M. and 3:05 A.M. - is a glistening, racy frolic about 1950's youngsters, with ''Porky's'' flavoring.

title: SHOWING CONTROLS AFTER A STRONG CLUB
description: More than three decades ago the great Pietro Forquet of Italy, with various partners, reintroduced with success the strong club method which had been recommended in 1929 by Harold Vanderbilt, the founder of the modern game.

title: KOCH URGES MANES TO RESIGN HIS POST OVER U.S. INQUIRY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called on Donald R. Manes to resign as Queens Borough President, saying that allegations that Mr. Manes took bribes to influence city contracts made it ''impossible for him to continue'' as a city official.

title: A POSSIBLE TENANT FOR LEDGE LIGHT
description: FOR the Ledge Lighthouse at New London, the era of being manned by the United State Coast Guard is to end this spring or summer. A local educational group hopes the new era will see it holding the lease to the light.

title: THE FIERCE FIGHT FOR I.R.A. FUNDS
description: IT's that time again - I.R.A. season. The frantic selling of Individual Retirement Accounts has become a familiar ritual during the months preceding April 15, as certain as tax collection itself.

title: OFFICIALS, BACKING AWAY FROM ASH FILL PLAN, EYE ALTERNATIVES
description: AS the debate grows over the recommendation that a Long Island ash fill be situated in Yaphank, there are indications that state and local leaders are beginning to back away from the entire regional ash fill concept.

title: DETROIT FEARS DISCOUNT PLANS ARE HERE TO STAY
description: DETROIT'S auto companies, which ushered in 1986 with bargain-rate financing programs, are worried that consumers are now so hooked on discounts that they will not buy cars without them.

title: REBELS IN UGANDA TAKE CONTROL OF CAPITAL, BUT BATTLES CONTINUE
description: Western diplomats here said today that rebel troops were virtually in control of Kampala, Uganda's capital, and that fighting was continuing in and around the city.

title: RESTORING A CLASSIC AUTO: 'WHY AM I LAUGHING?'
description: THE dream of owning a restored automobile can be realized in three ways. One, as practiced by Tom Monaghan, owner of the Detroit Tigers baseball team, is to find two Duesenbergs that are on the edge of perfection and simply write out a check for $2 million.

title: MICHIGAN ST. UPSETS MICHIGAN
description: The senior guard Scott Skiles scored 40 points tonight to power Michigan State to a 91-79 upset over Michigan in a Big Ten game. Skiles was deadly from the floor in the first half, hitting 9 of 12 shots, and added 6 of 7 in the second half. Most of his baskets were from 20 feet and beyond. He also made 10 of 11 free throws.

title: A PEEK AT WHAT'S DUE TO DRIVE UP THIS YEAR
description: ALTHOUGH American automakers will be previewing a handful of 1987 models at the Greater New York International Automobile Show - the eye-catching Chrysler/Maserati roadster is a prominent example - most of the new cars are being kep carefully under wraps. Some will debut later this spring, others in the usual fall commencement of the new model year.

title: EASON, 'CLOSE TO 100%', EXPECTED TO START
description: Tony Eason, who missed practice Friday suffering with a 101-degree fever and the flu, is expected to start in Super Bowl XX for the Patriots.

title: RASTROLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS
description: THE BEETHOVEN SKETCHBOOKS History, Reconstruction, Inventory. By Douglas Johnson, Alan Tyson and Robert Winter. Edited by Douglas Johnson. Illustrated. 611 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $75. BEETHOVEN was a slow worker. There could be years and even decades between the conception of a work and the finished product. He was constantly changing, restructuring, refining. In his studio and in his pockets were sketchbooks in which he jotted down ideas. He adhered to this practice much of his life and never threw a sketchbook away. Thus posterity has a very good idea of how Beethoven worked and of how, through the alchemy of his genius, he changed lead to gold.

title: Short Cut To Sicilian Sauce
description: Paula Wolfert's description of the hardships of finding the ingredients for pasta con le sarde is enough to deter anyone from experiencing this excellent sauce (''A Dish of Sicilian History,'' Dec. 15).

title: GROUPS OF WORSHIPERS GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Congregations and prayer groups at churches and synagogues are among those sending contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Dollar at Low Against Yen
description: The dollar opened today at a seven-year low of 195.10 yen, extending its sharp loss on Friday in hectic and nervous trading, dealers said.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Split Vote
description: The day before the Super Bowl, the committee that sifts candidates for the Pro Football Hall of Fame met in New Orleans to choose the class of 1986. In previous years, that committee - football writers, mostly - had elected seven players from Vince Lombardi's great Green Bay teams, along with the legendary coach himself. But the Packer player from those years who most endures in memory, Paul Hornung, Heisman Trophy winner and Golden Boy halfback, was on the ballot Saturday for the 15th time, having met 14 rejections.

title: SOME CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST FOLLOW A FAMILY TRADITION
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have done so for decades, some to carry on a family tradition, others to remember friends and loved ones.

title: Rhetoric and Reality
description: Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Unita rebels in Angola and darling of the American right, is coming to Washington this week with ruffles and drums. He will see Secretary of State Shultz, and very likely President Reagan. His admirers will hail him as a valiant fighter for democracy and enemy of Communism.

title: LAFONTAINE OUT WITH INJURY
description: While the Rangers are expected to increase their offensive production with the promotion of Pierre Larouche, the loss of Pat LaFontaine to a shoulder injury Saturday night may hamper the Islanders.

title: Merged Line Losing Republic Air Chief
description: Stephen M. Wolf, the president and chief executive officer of Republic Airlines, seems to be the odd man out as a result of the proposed acquisition of the carrier by Northwest Airlines.

title: FRIEDMAN MIXES INSTINCT, CONTACTS AND ILLUSION, FRIENDS AND FOES SAY
description: Among the many questions being asked in New York political circles is whether this time Stanley M. Friedman - lawyer, Bronx Democratic county leader, former deputy mayor, former city lobbyist, former aide to the City Council majority - may have pushed too hard.

title: 'OFFICER' IN SUBWAY THEFT
