description: A man dressed as a police officer was summoned to help a subway token-booth clerk early yesterday. Instead, the police said, he ended up helping to steal $11,000 in cash and tokens.

title: SCIENTISTS REPORT A MOON OF URANUS IS 'BIZARRE HYBRID'
description: Detailed images streaming back to Earth from the Voyager 2 spacecraft have revealed the startling features of Uranus's major moons, and awestruck scientists studying the photographs today described the findings as bizarre, exotic and extraordinary.

title: INTRUDER SOUGHT IN ODD BREAK-IN AT FERRARO SUITE
description: With an intruder's camera, shopping bag and description as their only clues, police detectives will seek today to unravel the mystery of a weekend burglary at the Queens office suite of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: ARAFAT MEETS WITH HUSSEIN ABOUT KEY U.N. RESOLUTIONS
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, met with King Hussein of Jordan today for the first time in three months and was expected to give the King the P.L.O.'s final position on two key United Nations resolutions.

title: SOUTHERN YEMEN BATTLES SUBSIDE
description: Bulldozers removed charred tanks from the streets of Aden today as the leaders controlling the city organized mass burials for victims of battles between rival Marxist factions.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT 76ERS, 105-103
description: The pre-game mood was different today in the Philadelphia 76er and Boston Celtic dressing rooms. The 76ers were relieved that Kevin McHale, who had scored 88 points in his previous three games against them, was sidelined with a painful Achilles tendon in his left foot. The Celtics were wondering who among them would make up for the loss of the 6-foot-11-inch power forward.

title: INDIA DELAYS KEY PART OF PUNJAB PACT
description: The Indian Government today delayed carrying out a key portion of an accord intended to settle the crisis in the troubled state of Punjab.

title: WOHL ANGERED BY NETS' LOSS
description: The game might have represented the low point in the Nets' season, partly because they languished at the worst of times and partly because their statistical accomplishments were far below their norm.

title: Customs Delay On Textiles
description: THE Customs Service, following protests by retailers and importers, has decided to delay, until March 9, a textile import directive that has caused a storm at the nation's ports.

title: Article 476686 -- No Title
description: Striking workers at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx planned to return to their jobs last night after approving a contract that raises wages $40 a week over three years.

title: Army Found a Pollutant Earlier Than Disclosed
description: The Army has reversed earlier statements and said that it found a poisonous chemical at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal five months before reports disclosed that the chemical had polluted nearby drinking wells.

title: JAZZ: A VARIED TRIBUTE TO DR. KING
description: IN style, personnel, emotional tone and musical quality, ''Free at Last, Free at Last'' -the Kitchen's Friday night concert - was thoroughly mixed. For a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., some of New York's best young jazz musicians joined the tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp - a patriarch of 1960's jazz - and musicians from the sphere of nonjazz ''new music'' improvisation, including the violinist Malcolm Goldstein, who directed the group.

title: Positions Shift At Monsanto
description: The Monsanto Company has announced that Richard J. Mahoney, president and chief executive officer, has been named chairman. Mr. Mahoney, 51 years old, replaces Dr. Louis Fernandez, 62, who is taking early retirement.

title: SPORTS MONDAY
description: Basketball Nets vs. Clippers, at Los Angeles. Since the Clippers won on their only visit to Byrne Meadowlands Arena this season, on Jan. 10, they can sweep the season series with a victory at home tonight. (Television -SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 10:30 P.M.) Mavericks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Dallas (Television -WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: Georgetown at Providence, 7:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Virginia Tech at Memphis State (Television - ESPN, 9:30 P.M.); Army at Fordham, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); Franklin & Marshall at Princeton, 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WHWH, 1350; 7:30 P.M.); Rutgers at Duquesne, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCTC, 1450; and WRSU-FM, 89.1; 8 P.M.). Other games: Hunter at Baruch, 6:30 P.M.; Chicago State at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; Jersey City State at C. W. Post, 7:30 P.M.; John Jay at Ramapo, 7:30 P.M.; St. Peter's at Monmouth, 7:30 P.M.; Molloy at New York Tech, 7:30 P.M.; Southampton at Southern Conn. State, 7:30 P.M.; Stony Brook at Vassar, 7:30 P.M.; East Stroudsburg State at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M., Stevens Tech at Kean, 8 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Nordiques, at Quebec. Maybe the Rangers can get their game together on this six-game road trip. Four Ranger goals in the third period were not enough when these teams played on Jan. 5, at the Garden as the Nordiques held on for a 5-4 victory. When they played again Thursday, the Nordiques won again, this time by 4-0.

title: Ego Boost
description: Need some confidence? Check with Otis Wilson. He has more than enough.

title: No Need to Protect the Dishes
description: Owners of television dish antennas have long enjoyed the equivalent of a free lunch. Home Box Office, Cinemax, ESPN and the whole array of pay- television operations transmit programs by satellite, and anybody with a dish has had the pick of the menu, without having to pay.

title: Small Consolation
description: It was their town and their practice field where the pregame attention was focused, and it was their own Superdome that served as the site of the game itself. For the New Orleans Saints, Super Bowl XX was a galling reminder of Super Embarrassment XIX: Since joining the National Football League in 1967, they've never had a winning season, which means they've never come closer to a Super Bowl than the pair of $75 tickets that each player was allowed to purchase for yesterday's clash between the Chicago Bears and the New England Patriots.

title: Channels Magazine Changing
description: REGULAR readers of Channels of Communications will immediately notice something different about the current issue: The magazine, instead of using an illustration on the January-February cover as it has done for all of its almost six years, features a color photo of Grant A. Tinker, NBC's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: DATING GAME AND THE CHECK: WHO PAYS?
description: Mike Duffy knows we're supposed to be in the midst of a renaissance of romance. But somehow when he thinks of the contemporary dating scene, his thoughts turn to the two impeccably put-together young professionals featured in a credit-card commercial he sees on television.

title: Willing to Wait
description: What distinguished her from scores of other would-be renters was not that she was lugging so many shopping bags, but that they seemed to contain all her worldly possessions.

title: Public-Employee Unions Will Fight Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a long way, but it was worth it. A lot of dreams were fulfilled.

title: CUOMO ASKS STRICTER BAIL RULES
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a variety of changes in the bail system, including a measure that would make it harder for suspects to be released on bail in cases where there is evidence that witnesses have been intimidated.

title: STAGE: FRANCES FOSTER IN 'HOUSE OF SHADOWS'
description: IN Steve Carter's ''House of Shadows,'' two old women, one white, one black, share a haunted house in Chicago. Portentous events take place in the ''now and then,'' to a background of sighs, whispers and threats of violence. The ''now'' is more interesting than the ''then'' in an evening that is ripe with self-parody. The play, a Gothic horror story, a ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane'' with Faulknerian undertones, opened this past weekend at Theater Four as a production of the Negro Ensemble Company.

title: BELLEVUE MAKING HOUSE CALLS TO HELP DYING AIDS PATIENTS
description: Doctors at Bellevue Hospital Center are breaking with tradition and making house calls on sick and dying AIDS patients throughout the city.

title: LIBYA BAN UNCLEAR TO U.S. COMPANIES
description: Less than a week before the deadline for complying with President Reagan's sanctions against Libya, many American companies doing business there are still unsure of what they will do. But most of the companies operating through foreign subsidiaries say they believe they will be able to carry on business as usual.

title: DANCE: SANTIAGO BALLET IN THREE NEW WORKS
description: SEEKING to demonstrate the range of its repertory, the Ballet de Santiago offered the New York premieres of three works on Saturday night at the City Center Theater. Since the ballets differed stylistically and the well-disciplined company conscientiously attempted to perform each in its own special style, this suggests that Ivan Nagy, the artistic director, is taking pains to train and coach his dancers. Unfortunately, though one could applaud the Chileans' aspirations, all three premieres were flawed.

title: CARBIDE-INDIA TALKS ON BHOPAL RESUME
description: Prodded by a Federal judge, attorneys for the Union Carbide Corporation and the Indian Government have resumed active work on a settlement in the multibillion-dollar litigation over the 1984 gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, according to sources close to the case.

title: Cambodia Rebels Report Killing Vietnam Troops
description: Cambodian guerrillas of the Communist Khmer Rouge said today that they killed 30 Vietnamese soldiers and wounded 20 last week in a town near Phnom Penh.

title: A VIDEO PREVIEW OF PLASTIC SURGERY
description: Ever so carefully, Dr. H. George Brennan sliced a bump off his nose and carved some loose skin from his neck.

title: G.O.P. RIVALS ATTACK O'NEILL'S RECORD
description: The four Republicans running for Governor of Connecticut this year have begun their campaigns by stressing a similar issue - the leadership of the state government under the Democratic administration of Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: THE EBB AND FLOW OF FRIENDS
description: IT'S January, stock-taking time, when people assess what they have and determine what they want, invest in the new and divest themselves of the old - friendships, that is.

title: Key U.S. Financing Move Expected
description: Today's regular auction of three- and six-month bills are the only Treasury auctions scheduled this week, though dealers in Government securities expect the Treasury to announce on Wednesday a major quarterly financing of notes and bonds.

title: Warming Trend
description: This is Jan. 27, one day after the Super Bowl. In three weeks, pitchers and catchers begin reporting to spring camps.

title: BLACKS IN HEATED DEBATE OVER 'THE COLOR PURPLE'
description: Some people say ''The Color Purple'' is only a movie. But many black people disagree.

title: RYAN 'THREW THE PLAYBOOK AT THEM'
description: The Chicago Bears ran up a 15-1 record in the National Football League regular season with defense. They shut out the Giants and the Los Angeles Rams in their two previous playoff games with defense. Today, they won Super Bowl XX with defense.

title: REPAIRS TO ENGINES ORDERED BY F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has issued an emergency order requiring prompt repairing of 27 jet engines that it said had been improperly overhauled by a Miami maintenance company. Another 78 engines will have to undergo special inspection soon to see if they need repairs.

title: Will a Woman Lead St. Patrick's Parade?
description: ''My friends are saying to me, 'Well, Dorothy, here it is, St. Patrick's Day again,' '' said Dorothy Hayden Cudahy. But something important has changed.

title: CONSERVATIVE LEADS VOTE IN PORTUGAL
description: A conservative took a commanding lead in Portugal's presidential elections today, but fell short of a first-round victory.

title: Public-Employee Unions Will Fight Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING PUBLIC ON WALL STREET
description: Within the last few months, private investment banks on Wall Street have been falling like dominos.

title: RISE OF LIMITED-SERVICE BANKS SEEN
description: A Supreme Court decision last week limiting the Federal Reserve's regulatory powers over limited-service banks will result in a flood of new applications to establish such operations from both banking and non-banking institutions, according to industry experts.

title: Public-Employee Unions Will Fight Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: Sled Dog Race Won by Logger
description: Paced by Amy and Swaps, his team's mother and son lead dogs, a Wisconsin logger upset a field of top Alaskan mushers today to take the top prize in the eighth annual $50,000 Alpo International Sled Dog Races.

title: SECRET POLL IS SAID TO HAVE FOUND GLOOM IN POLAND ABOUT ECONOMY
description: Nearly three-quarters of the industrial workers and managers interviewed in a secret Government poll rated the Polish economy as unsatisfactory to hopeless, while virtually none of those questioned believe the Government's economic policies are correct.

title: DON'T TOUCH THAT DIAL...
description: And now, live from Capitol Hill, it's George Mitchell and the Democrats! With guest stars Chuck Robb, Harriet Woods, Tom Daschle and Bill Gray! Stay tuned for 20 fun-filled minutes as the out-party gives its response to President Reagan's State of the Union Message!

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Let's Poll All the Lawyers
description: The old political saw that the Supreme Court follows the election returns is probably a good deal less valid than the idea that the Justices' decisions reflect the views of most lawyers.

title: POP: SAM FAN THOMAS AT RITZ
description: SAM FAN THOMAS, one of Cameroon's top band leaders, brought the intoxicating grooves of makassi music to the Ritz late Thursday night. Like other modern African pop, makassi mixes circular, intertwined melodies - from voices, electric guitars, horns and keyboard - with polyrhythmic percussion, creating light but kinetic dance tones that sound like they could easily roll all night long.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Transport Association, a Washington-based airline organization, has named William F. Bolger president and William W. Hoover executive vice president for operations and safety.

title: Contempt for Abortion, and Tolerance
description: Last week marked the 13th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion, and Washington was once more the scene of the ''March for Life'' rally. The crowd was only half what it was last year, but the enthusiasm was the same - and so was the host. ''We will continue to work together with Congress,'' President Ronald Reagan told the crowd, ''to overturn the tragedy of Roe v. Wade.''

title: UNSTOPPABLE BEARS STOP PATRIOTS COLD, 46-10
description: What happened here today in Super Bowl XX was shocking, even in the context of the Chicago Bears' merry dance through the 66th National Football League season.

title: Steel War With Europe
description: The United States and the European Economic Community are at a new face-off in steel, with the Europeans threatening to introduce quotas on their imports of American fertilizers and paper products because of Washington's decision late last year to limit imports of European semifinished steel.

title: New Chairman At Loan Bank
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has appointed Lois L. Evans, president of a Manhattan financial consulting company, to a one-year term as chairman.

title: 67 HAITIANS RESCUED OFF MIAMI
description: The Coast Guard Sunday rescued a group of Haitians from a crowded sailboat foundering in heavy seas 20 miles east of Miami, officials said today.

title: BEARS TROUNCE PATRIOTS, 46-10, IN SUPER BOWL
description: Stripping a page from the New England Patriots' book of destiny and reading from their own copyrighted manual of defense, the Chicago Bears swept to a 46-10 victory over the Patriots in Super Bowl XX at the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans yesterday.

title: Summer Jobs Program Seeks to Place 35,000
description: The New York City Partnership has begun a campaign to find summer jobs for 35,000 youths from low-income families in the city.

title: LAWMAKER ASSAILS NUCLEAR AGENCY
description: Representative Edward J. Markey, the chairman of a House subcommittee overseeing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, demanded today that the commission replace its top investigators for conduct that he said put them ''under a cloud of criminal suspicion.''

title: Oil Nations Set Talks on Prices
description: Meetings will be held this week between members and nonmembers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss plummeting oil prices and how to control them, according to the official United Arab Emirates news agency.

title: Index Options Specialist At Amex Is 20 and Busy
description: When she moved to New York two years ago, working as a clerk at the American Stock Exchange during the day and going to New York University at night, Laura Pedersen said she got pretty good at sleeping on trains.

title: INJURED CARTWRIGHT CONSIDERS SURGERY
description: While the Knicks await the results of new X-rays of Bill Cartwright's re-injured left foot, the 7-foot-1-inch center said he would undergo another operation rather than consider the possibility that his career might be over.

title: ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL SHIFTS SEEN IF OIL PRICE FALL PERSISTS
description: Plummeting oil prices suggest that the world may be crossing a threshold, marking the emergence from a dozen painful years in which expensive petroleum skewed economies, geopolitics and national and individual priorities.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Ilene Weiss In Songs As Done by Others
description: Ilene Weiss, the singer, songwriter and comedian who has won Folk City's ''perform as your favorite performer'' contest for the last four years, has conceived a number of inspiredly funny hybrids of familiar songs interpreted by unlikely caricatures.

title: Afghan Asserts U.S. Should End Rebel Aid
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan asserted today that the United States should stop aiding Moslem guerrillas if it wanted an end to the war between the rebels and his Soviet-backed Government.

title: MATCHING WITS IN JERUSALEM: TALMUD AND ST. PAUL
description: From a distance the scene looks like any medieval yeshiva: young men huddled in small groups, their yarmulkas slightly askew, gesticulating wildly over thick Babylonian Talmuds that lie before them. But a closer look reveals a priest's collar among the yarmulkas. Elbow-to-elbow with the yeshiva boys pounding tables for emphasis is a nun. Nestled amid the Talmuds is the Gospel According to St. John.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: USING SPARE TIME What do performers do in their spare time offstage? In the case of the company of the recent musical ''Poppie Nongena,'' the answer is: they perform. During the show's tour after its Broadway run, the cast spent its leisure hours on the road putting together a revue, ''Halala,'' that starts performances tonight at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street (239-4321).

title: TROOPER ON L.I. KILLS A FRIEND, THEN HIMSELF
description: A New York State trooper killed a friend, a Suffolk County Court officer, with a shot from his service revolver and then shot himself to death at the woman's apartment on Long Island, the state police said last night.

title: Futures/Options; Pricing: Back To Specifics
description: WHICH should you believe, oil or gold?

title: BID MADE FOR CLEVETRUST
description: A group led by a Canadian investor, Robert N. Goodman, said Friday that it had made an offer for all of the outstanding shares of Clevetrust Realty Investors for $20 a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it was also considering soliciting proxies to elect three of its nominees to the board. The group, which holds 8.52 percent of Clevetrust's shares outstanding, told the S.E.C. thaT if its offer was not accepted, it might seek control of the Cleveland-based real estate and mortgage company through negotiated purchases or a tender offer.

title: HOSPITAL AND PRESERVATIONISTS CLASH OVER MOVE TO TALLY OLMSTED DESIGNS
description: An effort to honor Frederick Law Olmsted Sr., revered as the father of American landscape architecture, has stirred a argument on Capitol Hill over the proper way to translate admiration for him into legislation.

title: Abuses Are Reported In Philadelphia Courts
description: The city's court system is seriously flawed by nepotism, political patronage and unethical practices, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today after a two-year investigation.

title: BRIBERY TRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE SHAKES A DEEP SOUTH SOCIETY
description: In the Community Center of this quiet old city, in a sunny auditorium normally given over to the annual Bridal Show, the Sport and Tackle Show and the Saturday worship meetings of the Worldwide Church of God, the trial of Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. is under way.

title: THE BEST TEAM
description: UP on the television screens at the Superdome before the Super Bowl XX kickoff yesterday, President Reagan proclaimed, ''May the best team win.'' It did.

title: U.S. Used Cited Toxic Dump
description: The Pentagon has continued to ship toxic waste to a California dump that was cited for violating environmental regulations, according to a Federal report.

title: Union Votes for Boycott Of Hormel Products
description: Striking meatpackers voted to begin a nationwide boycott of food products sold by Geo. A. Hormel & Company and to resume picketing at other Hormel plants, local union officials said today.

title: Market Place; Stock-Buyback Strategies
description: THE stock market took a drubbing early last week when falling prices of crude oil caused particular weakness in oil issues and shares of money-center banks perceived as having possible energy loan problems. But Richard S. Strong, a money manager in Milwaukee, said the market had misread the implications of lower energy prices and overreacted in its initial behavior.

title: State Says Refuse Plant In Westchester Is Clean
description: Westchester County's year-old garbage-to-energy plant deserves ''a clean bill of health'' because it produces only tiny amounts of toxic chemicals, a state official whose agency is studying plant emissions said last week.

title: HOME PRICES SOARING IN NEW YORK'S SUBURBS
description: At a time when the nationwide boom in real estate is fading, economists say the suburbs of New York City may be emerging as the region with the strongest demand - and most rapidly rising prices - for housing in the country.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: What would happen if they held a Super Bowl and only one team showed up?

title: Nina Weitzen Married To Michael Goldmuntz
description: Nina Lee Weitzen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hyman G. Weitzen, was married in her parents' home in New York yesterday to Michael Richard Goldmuntz, a son of Edgard Goldmuntz of Brussels and Ruth Goldmuntz of New York. Rabbi Thomas Weiner officiated.

title: ROGERS & COWAN BUYS ROGERS & ASSOCIATES
description: Rogers & Cowan, the show biz public relations firm based in Beverly Hills, Calif., has acquired Rogers & Associates of Los Angeles, specializing in corporate public relations, and the Rogers from the latter is moving in as president and chief executive officer of the former.

title: CITY BALLET: 'GOUNOD,' 'TCHAIKOVSKY' AND 'GLASS'
description: THE New York City Ballet continues to cast dancers in new roles with increasing and successful frequency, as was obvious again this weekend at the State Theater. Ib Andersen was the new male lead in ''Gounod Symphony'' while debuts in ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2'' succeeded those of Lourdes Lopez and Adam Luders earlier in ''Glass Pieces.''

title: NEW AMBASSADOR GIVES IMPETUS TO U.S. PUSH FOR CHANGE IN CHILE
description: Since the arrival of a new American Ambassador to Chile, the United States has taken a more aggressive role in supporting moderate opposition leaders seeking a return to democracy, according to diplomats and opposition leaders.

title: The Truth and Ferdinand Marcos
description: Politicians, being mortal, often concoct fictions about their past, but for creative audacity, Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines is nonpareil. Out of military archives comes evidence that he fabricated his World War II heroism, invented a whole guerrilla army and may have collaborated with Japanese occupiers. And in the twilight of a charmed career, President Marcos is gearing for a final whopper - the claim that his people have embraced him in a ''free and fair'' vote on Feb. 7.

title: MORE ACCOUNTABILITY SOUGHT FROM CITY EDUCATION BOARD
description: An educational advocacy group is asking the state and city governments to spend $300 million more on programs in New York City's public schools next year in return for greater efficiency and accountability by the city's Board of Education.

title: CUOMO, ON FLORIDA TRIP, ASSAILS BIAS IN POLITICS
description: Governor Cuomo came to Florida today to test his thesis that prejudice is being used to bar members of some ethnic groups from Presidential politics.

title: TAX PLAN ON MUNICIPAL BONDS SAID TO SNARL MANY PROJECTS
description: Plans for large construction projects by state and local governments around the country are being disrupted by provisions in the Federal tax bill, approved by the House last month, which severely restrict sales of municipal bonds, government officials and securities dealers say.

title: CLASSLESS SOVIET FAR OFF, PAPER SAYS
description: A leading Soviet economist has published an article asserting that economic opportunity in the Soviet Union is still determined to a large extent by a person's social status, connections and geographic location.

title: 'PSYCHOLOGICAL SEPERATION' LED TO ROUT
description: The big margin - 36 points - in yesterday's Super Bowl victory for the Chicago Bears over the New England Patriots was due to a ''psychological separation'' that grew and grew, in the opinion of Dick Vermeil.

title: NEWSWEEK NOW IN JAPANESE
description: The translators must wrestle with all manner of questions. Will a Japanese reader know what a lounge lizard is? Or recognize the expression ''junk bonds''? Or realize right away that Johnny and Merv are popular American talk-show hosts? Or, for that matter, care?

title: MUSIC: MODERN WORKS AT JUILLARD
description: FOR some years, the Juilliard School provided an annual admission-free, all-purpose contemporary-music festival that managed to showcase some new music, some Juilliard composers and some Juilliard performers to no particular overall purpose. Now, for the second year in a row, these activities have been focused under the title ''Focus!'' and placed under the coordinating direction of Joel Sachs, who runs the new-music group Continuum, teaches at Juilliard and probably writes the best program notes in town.

title: CONCERT: JULIAN BYZANTINE
description: THE guitarist Julian Byzantine neatly bisected his Saturday night concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, devoting the first half to the classical repertory (Daniel Bachelar's ''Monsieur Almaine,'' Niccolo Paganini's Grand Sonata and Bach's Suite in E minor for Lute, BWV 996), the second to 20th-century works by Leo Brouwer, William Walton and Manuel Ponce, all with contrasting strains of nationalism and impressionism.

title: World Bank Delay Defended
description: Round and round goes the wheel of speculation over the selection of a president for the World Bank. Critics wonder what is taking the Administration so long to name someone to succeed A. W. Clausen, who is leaving in June.

title: Topics; Heartbreaks Perish the Thought
description: Ischemia is what happens when the arteries to the heart momentarily shut down, starving the heart muscle of oxygen. When it happens during physical exercise, it can produce the chest pain called angina.

title: Bridge: Opening Bid of 2 No-Trump Means Less Than It Used To
description: The passage of time has eroded the strength of a two no-trump opening bid.

title: When Theater Stinks, Show Does Not Go On
description: One has heard of Broadway shows that stink. One rarely hears of Broadway theaters that stink. It happened yesterday, however.

title: SENATE FINANCE COMMITTEE: 20 MEMBERS WHO WILL CONSIDER TAX CHANGE
description: The following sketches of the 20 members of the Senate Finance Committee, 11 Republicans and 9 Democrats, are presented in order of the Senators' seniority: REPUBLICANS BOB PACKWOOD of Oregon . . . 53 . . . committee chairman for the last two years and the most important voice in the Senate on tax matters . . . capacity for leadership still untested . . . up for re-election this year to a fourth term, apparently without important opposition . . . traditional conservative on economic issues but liberal on social policy and has gained the enmity of the Reagan Administration by criticizing the President's policies on abortion and civil rights . . . favors using the tax code to achieve economic and social goals . . . advocates low capital gains rates, tax-free fringe benefits for workers, favorable tax treatment for Oregon's timber industry and tuition tax credits. BOB DOLE of Kansas . . . 62 . . . relinquished committee chairmanship last year to become majority leader . . . facing re-election in November without serious opposition . . . successfully changed public image from hatchetman to statesman . . . dominant Congressional figure on tax legislation in first Reagan term . . . orthodox conservative, willing to stand up to the President and advocates of supply-side economics . . . chief concern is the budget deficit but believes the tax revision bill ''should not be used as a vehicle to raise taxes or reduce the deficit'' . . . often has expressed distaste for special tax breaks and lobbyists. WILLIAM V. ROTH JR. of Delaware . . . 64 . . . Senate author of 1981 tax cuts . . . sponsor of a business transfer tax, similar to a value added tax, with the revenue used to reduce income tax rates . . . advocates low rates, tax-free savings accounts, generous business depreciation rules, deductible mortgages on vacation homes and tuition tax credits . . . chairman of Governmental Affairs Committee.

title: Mora Named Saints' Coach
description: The New Orleans Saints have signed Jim Mora to coach the club next season and will make the announcement official on Tuesday, team sources said today.

title: BALTIMORE STUDY OF TEEN-AGE SEX DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Alice G. Pinderhughes, the city's school superintendent, thought it would be a simple survey of teen-age attitudes on sex and health care, a vehicle to help curb teen-age pregnancies.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 27, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: GEMAYEL CALLS CABINET OVER SYRIAN PLAN
description: President Amin Gemayel, in a move apparently designed to head off an opposition call for his resignation, has summoned the Cabinet to an emergency meeting on Monday to consider referring to Parliament a Syrian-sponsored plan for peace in Lebanon.

title: A LISTLESS FORECAST FOR PROFITS
description: Hampered by sluggish growth in the economy, corporate profits for the last quarter of 1985 are expected to be flat or down slightly, based on earnings already reported and various economic factors, according to many economists and industry analysts.

title: WHO'S GOING TO PICK UP THE TAB?
description: In mandating a balanced budget by 1991, Congress was careful to exempt Social Security benefits from automatic cuts. But it did not protect the agency that distributes the checks.

title: Article 396186 -- No Title
description: Forceful bargaining to raise pay for jobs normally held by women has already put $200 million in workers' pockets, a conference on women's issues in the labor movement was told here Saturday.

title: HEADED SPORTSWEAR CONCERN
description: Tina Leser, a leading sportswear designer in the 1950's and 1960's, died Thursday at her home in Sands Point, L.I., after a brief illness. She was 75 years old.

title: Watch the Fine Print
description: Now that most Federal agencies face budget cuts under a new law aimed at eliminating the deficit, resourceful members of Congress are devising ways to protect their favorite programs. As a result, Thomas S. Foley, the House Democratic whip, warned his deputies at a meeting last week to be on the watch for any bill with a sentence that opens with these words: ''Notwithstanding any other provision of law . . .''

title: Suspects' Rights: An Irony
description: It couldn't be more ironic: Just as the Reagan Administration is about to try to persuade the Supreme Court to find a way of eliminating the Miranda rule requiring that suspects be told about their rights not to answer police interrogation, Margaret Thatcher's Government has just enacted legislation to guarantee the equivalent of the Miranda warning for suspects in Britain. The President ought to take a lesson from his fellow conservative.

title: NBC'S UNLIKELY HIGHLIGHT
description: THE suspense was building all across America. You just knew that people everywhere would stop whatever they were doing to watch. And there it was, as promised, on time. The kickoff to Super Bowl XX? No way. The big moment was NBC's much-ballyhooed minute of silence midway through its two-hour pre-game show. The dancing hot dogs, candy bars, soda containers and popcorn bags, circa 1950's, followed by the seconds ticking down to music - that's what we waited for.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1986
description: The Economy

title: 2 Utah Banks Taken Over
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has announced the takeovers of two failed Utah banks.

title: Decent Child Care Is a National Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: STRAIGHT ADVICE ON NATIONAL SECURITY
description: In the hours before President Reagan's last news conference more than three weeks ago, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter sat with a group of White House aides in the Oval Office briefing Mr. Reagan.

title: MORE POLICE SEEKING ARRESTS IN INSTANCES OF DOMESTIC ASSAULT
description: The number of police departments encouraging their officers to make arrests in cases of minor domestic violence has tripled in a year, according to a survey made public today today by a private research organization.

title: Fed Confirmations
description: The Senate is unlikely to confirm Wayne D. Angell and Manuel H. Johnson as governors of the Federal Reserve Board before the Feb. 11-12 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. That is an important session because it sets the 1986 monetary targets to be presented to Congress a week or so later. The two new members give Reagan appointees a majority on the seven-member board.

title: Let New York Lieutenant Governor Candidates Run on Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Near San Francisco
description: A moderate earthquake shook Northern California this morning, spilling 20,000 gallons of wine at a winery and sending an oak tree crashing into a home, the police said in Hollister, about 100 miles south of San Francisco. No injuries were reported.

title: Mother to Be a Donor; Girl Sends a Thank You
description: A teen-age girl suffering from Hodgkin's disease sent a word of thanks today to her natural mother - whom she has never met - for agreeing to donate bone marrow needed to save her life.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE HANDMAID'S TALE. By Margaret Atwood. 311 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: REBELS IN UGANDA SAY THEY OUSTED MILITARY LEADERS
description: Leaders of a rebel movement announced today that they had overthrown the military Government of Uganda after seizing control of Kampala, Uganda's capital.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Good Neighbor Shelters A Trusty Wheeled Steed
description: One day, John Dobkin got to thinking that his old-fashioned Raleigh bicycle was a beloved and irreplaceable friend, like the faithful horse on whom one can always count to ride over the toughest terrain.

title: TOBY W. BECKENSTEIN
description: Toby Weintraub Beckenstein, a public-relations consultant, died of a heart attack Friday while traveling in a car near her home in Avon, Conn.

title: DELAY IN MEDICARE PAYMENTS SEEN AS RESULT OF FEDERAL BUDGET CUTS
description: Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and beneficiaries will be delayed this year because of budget cuts sought by the Reagan Administration and approved by Congress, according to Federal health officials.

title: MARCOS CRITICIZES 'MEDDLERS' IN VOTE
description: Only days before the arrival of international observers to monitor the Feb. 7 presidential elections, President Ferdinand E. Marcos today criticized what he called the ''meddlers and interventionists'' who will be watching the vote.

title: ALLY & GARGANO EXPANDS PROFIT, ADDS AN ACCOUNT
description: Ally & Gargano, in a Friday announcement, disclosed its latest operating results and some new business.

title: SOUTHWARD GOES RIVER OF FINANCE
description: For generations, San Franciscans could boast that Los Angeles was where the movies were made in California, but San Francisco was where the money was made.

title: Catholic Bishops Lead Anti-Apartheid Service
description: Roman Catholic bishops celebrated a mass today in this black township near Pretoria in what they said was a demonstration of solidarity with victims of apartheid.

title: Canadair Gets Contract
description: Canadair Ltd. has been awarded an $800 million (Canadian) contract to develop a pilotless reconnaissance system for a consortium involving Canada, West Germany and France, Canada's industry minister, Sinclair Stevens, said Friday. In a statement, Mr. Stevens said the three countries had signed a memorandum of understanding to proceed with the preproduction stage of the system. Mr. Stevens said the contract would enhance the value of Canadair for the Government, which has been negotiating in recent months with unidentified suitors to sell the aerospace concern.

title: Cuomo and Bush
description: Republicans have been doing Governor Cuomo of New York the favor of suggesting in all sorts of ways that they believe he will be the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1988. That's given them some early licks at him, but this dubious tactic could backfire, particularly on Vice President Bush, the Republican front-runner.

title: Israeli Prime Minister Arrives For 3-Day West German Visit
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel arrived today on a three-day visit to West Germany, seeking support for a Middle East peace process that excludes the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: NORMAN MAILER OFFERS A PEN POST-MORTEM
description: As Norman Mailer now assesses the recently concluded PEN International Congress, its central theme was ''a great mistake,'' some of his critics were ''catatonic leftists'' and he owes no apologies to women for their lack of representation. The main creator of the congress, as well as the main subject of much of the controversy, reviewed his work the other night at an East Side coffee shop.

title: CHICAGO CELEBRATES END OF TITLE QUEST
description: As Chicagoans romped through the streets tonight in celebration of a Bears' victory in the Super Bowl and an end to this city's championship drought, the main question was: When does the ticker-tape parade start?

title: Outdoors: Hunting in Midwinter
description: WITHIN a few days, most hunting in the northeast will be limited to cottontail rabbits, varying hares and ruffed grouse.

title: Next Week: Moment of Truth
description: The heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds expected for sale in the first week of February will be a moment of truth for the credit markets that will test the acumen of investors and traders.

title: BOROUGH CHIEF REMAINS ISOLATED
description: On the first day that Donald R. Manes spent at home since his release from the hospital, Mayor Koch called him ''a crook'' and intensified his calls for Mr. Manes to resign as Queens Borough President.

title: The Vietnamese Left Stranded Merit Consideration
description: Two weeks ago, senior officials from the State Department and Defense Department visited Hanoi to achieve greater progress on the issue of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War. A Congressional delegation went to Vietnam for that purpose last week. All this is welcome news. As the son of an American seaman still missing in action from World War II, I share the hope of achieving as full an accounting of our M.I.A.'s as possible.

title: SHUTTLE LAUNCHING DELAYED AGAIN OVER WEATHER FEARS
description: A forecast of threatening weather forced space agency officials to postpone this morning's scheduled launching of the shuttle Challenger until 9:37 A.M. Monday.

title: Bulgarian Communist Party Dismisses 2 From Politburo
description: Bulgarian Communist Party leaders have dismissed two Politburo members and issued a call for a new ''climate'' in Bulgarian society, the official press agency BTA reported Saturday night.

title: Schroder Picks Officers And Sets Japanese Sale
description: The J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, the American banking, trust and leasing businesses of Schroders P.L.C., the big British merchant bank, has announced a number of changes in its top management.

title: Qaddafi Turns Back, Far Short of Benghazi
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was shown today on Libyan television returning to Misurata harbor hours after he announced he was sailing to meet the United States Sixth Fleet.

title: Heart-Research Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRIAN WINS SLALOM
description: Roswitha Steiner of Austria overcame a hardened, quick-turning course to win a women's World Cup slalom race today while Monika Hess of Switzerland placed fourth to win a combined event.

title: Differing Antitrust Bills
description: The first shot against President Reagan's effort to relax antitrust laws to reflect global rather than national competition will be fired today by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, who is introducing his alternative Antitrust Improvement Act.

title: NIGERIA'S ECONOMY FACES NEW BURDEN
description: Nigeria's economy, already struggling with a staggering foreign debt, failing industries and a stumbling agricultural sector, faces even harder times with the sudden collapse of oil prices last week, according to economists here.

title: SENATORS EXPECT APPROVAL IN '86 OF TAX CHANGES
description: As they take up tax revision this week, most Senators on the Finance Committee say they expect enactment this year of legislation similar to the tax bill President Reagan proposed last spring and one the House of Representatives passed last month.

title: Swiss Watch Exports
description: The stylish, inexpensive Swatch designs helped Swiss watch exports to reach a record high last year, confirming the industry's recovery from its financial crisis in the early 1980's, the Watchmakers' Federation said Friday. Exports rose 12.2 percent, to $2.1 billion, in 1985.

title: STUDIOS WOO CASSETTE MASS MARKET
description: In a hotel suite overlooking the Las Vegas convention center recently, buyers for Waldenbooks and for Target, a major discount department-store chain, discussed buying quantities of romantic melodramas and animated children's films on video cassettes. With cassette recorders now in 25 million American homes, another 10 million machines expected to be sold in 1986 and revenues that rival movie ticket sales, the battle to cash in on prerecorded video cassettes is intensifying.

title: Is It a Writer's Right To Be Political?
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATOR CITES C.I.A. ON DEFECTOR
description: The vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee declined to comment today on reports that a high-ranking official of the K.G.B. had defected to the United States and was living here under an assumed name.

title: China Eases Venture Curb
description: China's State Council formally approved an extension for the maximum duration of most joint ventures with foreign companies to 50 years from 30 years, effective Feb. 1, the New China News Agency said. Foreign business executives had said the old limit was too short.

title: Grand Old Flags
description: When the Texas State Society booked its annual ''Salute to Congress'' reception at the cavernous caucus room of the Cannon House Office Building, the occasion called for Texas-size, Texas-style decorations. So the 500 or more guests will be surrounded Wednesday evening by a framed and mounted set of five historic Texas flags, part of a series of precise replicas that are tattered and stained just like the originals and retail for $950 apiece.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS DOWN 9.3%
description: The machine tool industry, still waiting for its recovery to happen, ended 1985 with a drop in new orders. Analysts say the outlook for this year is only modestly optimistic.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Paul Esswood Offers Countertenor Works
description: Paul Esswood's recital at the Metropolitan Museum Friday with the harpsichordist John Constable offered some fine singing without quite matching the expectations raised by the countertenor's excellent recordings.

title: Topics; Heartbreaks Block That Mercy
description: Perhaps it's good that kids no longer find so many heroes among athletes. Their random worship might easily select someone like Michael Ray Richardson of the New Jersey Nets.

title: EARLY BIRDS CATCH THE 6:29
description: The sunrise is a full 45 minutes away. The ''Today'' show will not herald the new day for another half-hour. But a few dozen top bankers, lawyers and Wall Street traders have already embarked on their daily ride on the 6:29 A.M. from Greenwich, Conn. - a journey that will deposit them in Manhattan at 7:20 and at their offices by 8 A.M., still a good hour ahead of most New Yorkers.

title: SINGAPORE ARREST JOLTS MALAYASIA
description: When a wealthy Malaysian businessman and political leader was arrested and charged here this week with breaching the Singapore Companies Act, the news was an economic and political blow to Malaysia and jolted the financial world throughout Southeast Asia.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; The Billy Taylor Trio And Joe Morello Five
description: The combination of Billy Taylor's trio and Joe Morello's quintet - which closed at the Blue Note last night - is an unusually strong double bill and is made even stronger by the addition of a guest guitarist with each group.

title: Monet and Conservatives
description: Beside many of the paintings in the new Impressionist exhibition at the National Gallery are hostile quotations from critics of the day, who were resisting the new, freer style. Monet's ''Boulevard des Capucines,'' for example, now considered a classic, was described in 1873 as ''an undecipherable chaos of palette scrapings'' and his painting technique as ''slap-dash, any old way.''

title: MAYOR REFERS TO CORRUPTION IN PREVIOUS ADMINISTRATIONS
description: Mayor Koch, asked yesterday about mounting allegations of corruption in his administration, said that dishonesty in government was nothing new and listed examples in many previous administrations.

title: OIL CUTBACKS IN IRAN, EGYPT
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi of Iran said his country would cut its oil output in half until further notice, the Iranian news agency Irna said today.

title: HOW IT WAS 'IN THAT NUMBER'
description: They played the ''Saints'' at Preservation Hall over and over again, and the Bears threw chairs at a wall in their hotel, and fans arrived by private railroad car, and the Patriots didn't want to embarrass themselves, and people never had enough tickets but usually too much to drink, and they re-examined X-rays, and they tried to conduct business in the center ring as if nothing was happening.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1986
description: International Victory for Ugandan rebels was claimed by the rebels' leaders. They announced that they had overthrown the Government after seizing Kampala, the capital. Maj. Gen. Tito Okello, who became Uganda's head of state after leading a military coup last July, was reported by a Kenyan newspaper to have said that he would fight on. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: EARLY MORNING FIRE IN WASHINGTON KILLS 9 IN ROW HOUSE BASEMENT
description: Nine people were killed and four hospitalized in a fire early today in a row house basement apartment in Northwest Washington frequented by transients.

title: NEW MIDTOWN BRANCH FOR WHITNEY
description: The lobby of a new corporate skyscraper in midtown will soon become the home for a Whitney Museum of American Art branch, making it the latest and largest addition to an extensive collaboration between a major art museum and the corporate world.

title: People
description: Warren Fischer has been promoted to senior vice president at Grey Advertising.

title: NORTH CAROLINA ROLLS TO NO. 21
description: Kenny Smith scored 20 points and Joe Wolf added 16 as unbeaten North Carolina extended its winning streak to 21 games today with a 73-61 victory over Notre Dame.

title: THATCHER SAYS SHE WON'T QUIT BUT WILL RUN AGAIN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose harried Conservative Government has lost two Cabinet ministers in the last two weeks, said today that the resignations and the continuing political crisis would not force her to step down or undermine her Government's effectiveness.

title: New Sears Credit Card
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's new Discover credit card made its nationwide debut last week, and company officials say they hope to have 25 million of the cards in circulation by the end of the year. It is intended to compete with such cards as American Express, Visa and Mastercard.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day on Jan. 9 incorrectly reported a new advertising account of Homer & Durham. The agency was assigned Albert Nipon Fragrance. Arnell/Bickford continues as agency for Albert Nipon Inc.

title: EASTERN AND PILOTS END TALKS
description: Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association broke off talks today, setting off a 30-day cooling-off period that will end just three days before the date on which Eastern's creditors have threatened to put the airline into default, officials said.

title: PAYTON MISSES OUT ON SCORING PARADE
description: He is the leading rusher in the history of pro football and, for that matter, he gained more yards rushing than anybody in the Super Bowl today. But Walter Payton never reached the end zone in the Bears' 46-10 victory, and that disappointed some fans in the stands who chanted ''Walter, Walter, Walter.''

title: FOR EASON, VIEW FROM THE SIDELINE
description: Nothing was working. The New England Patriots needed nearly one full quarter to gain their first yard against the Chicago Bears. Tony Eason, the quarterback who had taken the Patriots to the Super Bowl, had not completed a pass.

title: Rampal to Lead Flute Concert
description: Jean-Pierre Rampal will be the principal artist in ''A Multitude of Flutes'' on Feb. 15 at Carnegie Hall. Julius Baker and Eugenia Zukerman and a choir of 20 other flutists will take part in a program of seven compositions.

title: Members of Kahane's Group Protest at Mormon Offices
description: About 100 people opposed to the construction of a Mormon institute in Jerusalem protested yesterday across the street from the Mormon Visitors Center at 65th Street and Broadway. The protesters, led by members of a Jewish organization headed by Rabbi Meir Kahane, asserted that the Mormons intended to proselytize Jews.

title: BEARS' TRAIN ARRIVES
description: THE train arrived backward, which was obviously not an omen. Even the sign on the last car, as it backed into the New Orleans train station, was in the Chicago Bears' navy blue and orange colors and it said, ''Super Bowl Shuttle.''

title: MINNESOTA OFFICIALS STUDY TEAM'S FATE
description: Officials at the University of Minnesota continued to confer yesterday about whether to cancel the remaining 11 games of the school's basketball schedule in the wake of the arrests of three players on rape charges and the resignation of Coach Jim Dutcher.

title: SUTTON TAKES PHOENIX OPEN
description: Hal Sutton, the leading golfer on the PGA Tour so far this year by the measures of scoring and finishes, said, ''You give me a one-stroke lead with nine holes to go and I'll play anyone in the world.''

title: Japan Record For Vehicles
description: Japan's vehicle output and exports rose to record levels for 1985, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday.

title: Catherine Collins Married To James Albert Stratton
description: Catherine Victoria Collins and James Albert Stratton were married yesterday at the New York home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Drs. Harold L. Davis and Eleanor Morin Davis.

title: 'ROOMMATE,' A PLAY ABOUT 1950'S STUDENTS
description: JOHN UPDIKE'S short story ''The Roommate'' is a literary roommate of ''The Odd Couple.'' A young overachiever from North Dakota named Orson, who lines up his toilet articles like toy soldiers, finds himself sharing a room at Northwestern University with a misfit named Henry, who stands on his head and operates a spinning wheel for spiritual refreshment. It's all-American boy meets beatnik.

title: REFEREE ERRS
description: Art McNallt, the National Football League's supervisor of officials, said that Referee Red Cashion erred when he allowed Kevin Butler to kick a 24-yard field goal at the end of the first half, giving the Chicago Bears a 23-3 lead over New England.

title: Reynolds Transferring Media Buying Function
description: In a move sure to chill the hearts of advertising agency people everywhere, R. J. Reynolds Industries is removing national electronic media buying responsibilities from its agencies and giving it to a newly formed buying unit of which it is part owner.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: Per share figures reflect a 5 PC stock dividend to be paid in March.

title: Careers; Placing Dismissed Employees
description: SOME outplacement experts have recently noticed a growing number of ''shoppers,'' potential clients who shop around seeking the right outplacement firm to help them find new jobs.

title: THE PURSUIT OF DONORS
description: THE Metropolitan Museum cherishes big donors, real or potential, and delights in helping serious collectors collect. Everybody is expected to snare promising strangers, turn them into friends, turn friends into partisans and partisans into donors.

title: ISRAEL'S PREMIER VISITS A NAZI SITE
description: Shimon Peres, making the second visit to West Germany by an Israeli Prime Minister, laid a wreath today at the site of the Bergen-Belsen death camp and later met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Kosher Poultry Plant Burns in Pennsylvania
description: Nearly 1,000 workers, some of them rabbis, were out of work today after a fire destroyed most of the Empire Kosher Poultry Inc. plant, said to be the largest of its kind in the world.

title: Banks Bailout Doubted
description: The European Common Market countries will not rescue commercial banks hurt by defaults on loans to heavily indebted third world nations, the Netherlands finance minister said today. ''There should be no bailout of the commercial banks,'' H. Onno Ruding told a news conference. Mr. Ruding is also chairman of the Interim Committee, or policy-making arm, of the International Monetary Fund.

title: PAUL H. LANGENBERGER
description: Paul H. Langenberger, a retired internal auditor for The New York Times, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: L. RON HUBBARD, 74, FOUNDER OF SCIENTOLOGY CHURCH, DIES
description: L. Ron Hubbard, the science fiction writer who founded the Church of Scientology three decades ago, has died of a stroke, the church said tonight. He was 74 years old.

title: Patriot Bancorp
description: Patriot Bancorp Inc. said it had agreed in principle to merge into the Conifer Group Inc. in an exchange of Conifer stock worth $64.27 for each Patriot share. The company said the transaction was valued at about $135 million, including adjustment for stock options, with the number of Conifer shares to be issued to be determined before the merger date. The transaction must be approved by the boards of both companies, by Patriot shareholders and by banking regulators.

title: WITH WINGS FLAPPING, MODEL PTERODACTYL TAKES TO AIR
description: A half-size model of the giant pterodactyl, a flying reptile that lived 70 million to 140 million years ago, has been successfully flown for the first time under its own power and guidance, the Smithsonian Institution said today.

title: Florida Bank Ban Voided by Justices
description: The Supreme Court today vacated and remanded to a Federal appeals court for reconsideration a ruling that prohibited the United States Trust Company of New York from operating a limited-service bank in Florida.

title: DISORGANIZED NETS BEATEN BY CLIPPERS
description: The Nets never seemed to hit their stride tonight, and their coach, Dave Wohl, said it was probably their own fault. In the end, they were beaten, 103-98, by the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Agriculture Secretary May Be Selected Soon
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan was expected to announce the nomination of Richard E. Lyng as Secretary of Agriculture this week.

title: Navratilova Has Flu
description: Top-ranked Martina Navratilova pulled out of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tennis tournament late Sunday night when she was unable to shake a bout with the flu. Miss Navratilova notified the Women's Tennis Association that she wouldn't be playing this week.

title: SELLING PLASTIC FOR ITS QUALITY
description: Plastic, once equated with flimsy, throwaway products, is winning a reputation for durability, quality and versatility, appearing in everything from hip implants to bodies of jet fighters.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Swan Seeks to Buy Pittsburgh Brewer
description: The Swan Acquisition Company today offered $27 million in cash, or $21.50 per share, for the 1.25 million shares outstanding of the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, the ninth-largest American brewer. A Pittsburgh Brewing spokesman, William Eiler, declined comment but said the company might respond to the offer on Tuesday.

title: WHEN PEKING FIGHTS CRIME, NEWS IS ON THE WALL
description: For Ge Guocai, a 68-year-old retired factory worker, it was a day to celebrate being among the living. A slight breeze had blown away the winter smog that sits on Peking like a shroud, and Mr. Ge was out for a stroll with his 17-year-old grandson.

title: Giants' Davis Signs
description: Chili Davis, the San Francisco Giants' most consistent hitter with a .270 batting average last year, signed a one-year contract with the team.

title: Business and the Law; Forced After-70 Retirements
description: MANDATORY retirement became illegal in New York State on Jan. 1, but for a few workers in their 70's, it was too late. In several cases, workers in their 70's were forced to retire late last year, just before the effective date of the law that would have protected them from mandatory retirement, no matter what their age.

title: 3 Are Reported Killed In Protests in Haiti
description: Three people were killed and 30 were wounded today when the police fired automatic weapons and tear gas to break up an anti-Government demonstration in the port city of Cap-Haitien, a hospital spokesman said.

title: A.H. Robins Posts Profits
description: The A.H. Robins Company said today that it posted a 1985 fourth-quarter profit of $13.5 million, or 55 cents a share, after losing more than $481.8 million in the 1984 period.

title: DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Russian Youth, 17, Reunited With His Brother in Boston
description: Mikhail Stukalin, a 17-year-old Soviet emigre, arrived here today from the Soviet Union to greet a brother he had not seen for seven years.

title: COURT IN TOXIC-WASTE RULING
description: The Supreme Court ruled by 5 to 4 today that trustees for bankrupt companies may not abandon toxic waste dumps in disregard of state regulations ''reasonably designed to protect the public's health or safety.''

title: CRANE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax charge of $25,428,000 for restructuring and closure costs. c-Net income. The results for 1985 include Unidynamics Corporation which was purchased in February 1985.

title: Chief Executive Named At New Federal Agency
description: Roslyn Payne, a vice president in charge of real estate at the Genstar Corporation, yesterday was named president and chief executive of the Federal Asset Disposition Association, an agency created last November by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to assist in managing and liquidating assets acquired from failed savings and loans.

title: 'MAIN STREET,' ON NBC
description: ''THERE are now more people homeless than at any time since the Great Depression,'' says Bryant Gumbel of the ''Today'' show, who also serves as the host of ''Main Street,'' NBC News's nonpatronizing program for young people. The hourlong after-school broadcast, to be shown today at 4 o'clock, is as well produced as several of the prime-time network documentaries, including some of the programs on public television.

title: Bank in Boston Loses a Ruling
description: The Bank of New England, three employees and a customer are scheduled to go on trial Wednesday, after a Federal judge refused to dismiss charges that they failed to report $870,000 in transactions to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,112,000. c-Including an extraordinary charge of $3,114,000. d-Net income.

title: Stocks Post Third Consecutive Gain
description: Technology and interest-sensitive issues were strong yesterday as the stock market scored its third consecutive gain despite what traders said was, on balance, a very unexciting day.

title: Federal Agents Query Haitians Rescued at Sea
description: Immigration agents went aboard a Coast Guard cutter today to question 68 Haitians rescued from an overcrowded sailboat foundering in the Atlantic.

title: Telephone Assignment Is Won by TBWA
description: In December TBWA Advertising was given an advertising assignment by the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven.

title: Chrysler Unit Sets $1.5 Billion Offer
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a shelf registration statement covering $1.5 billion of debt securities and warrants to buy additional debt securities.

title: BOEING POSTS 51.6% RISE
description: Spurred by increased commercial and military sales, the Boeing Company today reported sharp gains in revenues and net earnings for the fourth quarter of 1985 and for the full year.

title: Christian TV Network Begins News Program
description: ''CBN News Tonight,'' a half-hour television news program from a Christian perspective, begins tonight on the Christian Broadcasting Network.

title: Arco to Sell Some Units, Cutting Up to 2,000 Jobs
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it would consolidate its operations and sell some oil and gas properties, requiring a further elimination of up to 2,000 jobs.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a DISC adjustment to federal income taxes of $397,000,000. Share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1985.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hot Dog!
description: New York and Washington have always enjoyed a special relationship, albeit tinged with an edge of rivalry, tending, as they do, to see themselves as the nation's two most important cities (sorry, L.A.). So it is perhaps no surprise that Washington's Omni Shoreham hotel is laying on a two-month ''I love New York'' Festival beginning next Tuesday with exhibits and displays evoking the cultural, historic, recreational and entertainment heritage of the Empire State, with special emphasis on New York City.

title: Pacific Lumber
description: Three grandchildren of Albert S. Murphy, a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company, said they had filed suit here in Federal court to delay a Feb. 25 meeting announced Friday by the company.

title: Calculating Airflow
description: Researchers at Princeton University have developed a new technique for calculating airflow that will enable aerodynamic engineers to determine the theoretical accuracy of their designs for aircraft at the computer terminal before constructing and testing prototypes in wind tunnels.

title: EXXON LOSES PLEA TO AVOID PAYING $2.1 BILLION TO U.S.
description: The Exxon Corporation will have to pay $2.1 billion in refunds and interest to the Government for overcharges to customers in the 1970's because the Supreme Court turned down its final appeal today.

title: MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net gains of $189,000 for the quarter and $42,000 for the year from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After net losses of $29,040,000 for the quarter and $27,970,000 for the year from discontinued operations, net gains of $107,789,000 for the quarter and $112,629,000 for the year on the disposal of discontinued operations and net charges of $71,753,000 for the year relfecting the writedown of assets.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a total writeoff of $102 million in the value of oil and gas properties.

title: MELBA MOORE IN NEW CBS SITCOM
description: MELBA MOORE, who deserves better, stars in ''Melba,'' a new situation comedy on CBS that starts tonight at 8 o'clock. Either it is not very good for her or she is not very good for it, and the chances are that the former is truer than the latter.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a $125 million after-tax charge from a partial writedown of the company's shale oil project. c-Net income.

title: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PACIFIC BANK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Bus for 11th Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: House Leader Hurt in Fall
description: Jim Wright of Texas, the leader of the Democratic majority in the House of Representatives, broke his wrist today in a fall from a makeshift podium in a room near the House chamber. Mr. Wright, who is 63 years old, said he was standing with one foot on each of two chairs in order to see his audience and slipped when he attempted to step down. He is expected to have a cast for four to six weeks.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
3 Large Investors For Counterpoint
description: The Counterpoint Computer Company said that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Kyocera Corporation and British Commonwealth Ltd. had acquired equity positions of undisclosed sizes under agreements calling for joint product development.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There are no year-ago results because the trust was established in February 1985. Results for the latest year are actually for the period from Feb. 22, 1985 through December 1985.

title: ARLEDGE GIVES UP ABC SPORTS POST
description: Roone Arledge, the president of the sports and news divisions at ABC since 1977, will be giving up daily responsibility for sports operations in a management shuffle announced yesterday by Capital Cities-ABC Inc.

title: State of Union Talk To Be on TV Today
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress will be carried live at 9 P.M., Eastern standard time, on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN (the Spanish International Network) will be carrying the address, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast later in the evening.

title: JAPAN SEEN AS POISED TO LOWER INTEREST RATES
description: In a policy shift tied to the rising yen, Japan's monetary authorities appear ready to take the lead toward lower interest rates in the world by unilaterally reducing rates in Japan.

title: LaFontaine: No Fracture
description: Pat LaFontaine, the 20-year-old Islander center, had his injured shoulder examined yesterday by Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, the team physician, and the results were better than expected.

title: MINNESOTA DECIDES TO PLAY
description: The president of the University of Minnesota said today that, despite the arrest of three school basketball players on charges of sexual assault and the resignation of the head coach, the remaining members of the team would be allowed to play the games left on the schedule.

title: CYBERTEK COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1986
description: Companies

title: HARTFORD STEAM BOILER INPECTION & INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,334,000 for the quarter and $3,156,000 for the year. c-Including capital gains of $50,000 for the quarter and $8,756,000 for the year.

title: AARON RENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Early Breaking News
description: Because newspaper ink runs in George Frederick Evans's blood, it should have come as no surprise to his parents that he already has problems with deadlines.

title: Muse Acquisition
description: Eight-year-old Mingo-Jones Advertising, based in New York and billing some $30 million, has acquired more than half of J. Melvin Muse & Company of Santa Ana, Calif., which is only two years old and is billing $2.5 million. Both agencies specialize in advertising, marketing and public relations directed at the black community. The Muse operation will continue to operate under its old name and management.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $164 million for the quarter and the year for a proposed settlement of Department of Energy claims against the company regarding federal crude oil price controls mostly from 1970s and a net loss of $285,000,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-After net losses from discontinued operations of $40,000,000 for the quarter and $806,000,000 for the year. d-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: NIXON IS HOSPITALIZED
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon was admitted to the Miami Heart Institute today upon his return from a Bahamian golf holiday but his doctor said the 73-year-old former President's ailment appeared to be ''just the flu.'' Dr. Lewis Elias, Mr. Nixon's personal physician in the Miami area, said Mr. Nixon ''has some dehydration and a mild viral infection - we don't think it's anything serious. He has no cardiovascular disease whatsoever.'' The hospital listed Mr. Nixon's condition as satisfactory.

title: Liberal!
description: With new conservative organizations and candidates springing up daily and the Democratic Party easing perceptibly toward the center, the liberals who once dominated much of the political scene in Washington sometimes seem today like a minority group, ignored if not actually abused. But that doesn't daunt Michael Harrington, the longtime socialist, author and political science professor.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-For the year ago six months income the company neither reported neither a net income, nor a net loss.

title: A MAINSTAY OF MEAT AND POTATOES, IN JEOPARDY
description: When word leaked that the beloved Wedgwood Cafeteria was being closed, there was widespread disbelief and a general feeling of helplessness here. But the Town Council knew what to do.

title: Rudman to Seek Re-election
description: Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, who helped write the new budget-balancing law, said today that he would seek a second term. Mr. Rudman, 55 years old, said he felt an obligation to remain in Washington to help guide enforcement of the law he wrote with Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, providing for an end to deficit spending by 1991.

title: APPLIED COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTH JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $652,687 for the quarter and $615,869 for the year. c-Including a loss from discontinued operations of $7,294 for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $183,030.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1984 revenues have been restated.

title: People
description: * Murray Gaylord, Stuart Epstein and William Tucker, management representatives, promoted to executive vice presidents at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M. May Tie Offer to Intel
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it might offer this year $300 million in debt securities convertible into stock of the Intel Corporation. I.B.M. owns more than 22.5 million shares, or slightly less than 20 percent, of Intel stock outstanding.

title: STEFANKI ELIMINATED
description: Matt Anger fought back from an 0-3 deficit in the final set to defeat Larry Stefanki, 6-3, 6-7, 7-6, today in one of several close opening matches at the 25th United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

title: KOCH TO TIE CAB FARE RISE TO MORE MEDALLIONS
description: The Koch administration, which has long sought to put more cabs on city streets, intends to propose an increase in taxi medallions in exchange for a fare increase, according to city officials.

title: Computer Magazines Experience Shakeout
description: The expected shakeout in the previously booming business of publishing magazines for the computer field apparently began in 1985.

title: 6 Iraqis Reported Dead In an Air Raid by Iran
description: Iraq said that 6 civilians were killed today and 21 wounded in an Iranian air raid on the northern town of Siddiq, and that Iraq had retaliated with air strikes against military camps in Iranian Kurdistan.

title: Violence Extends Beyond the Court
description: The on-court violence that seems to be growing this season as a regular feature of both professional and college basketball is sometimes more than matched on the high school level by what occurs beyond the sidelines.

title: CASE TURNS ON RARELY USED LAW
description: A California state judge agreed today to postpone the entering of pleas by Representative Bobbi Fiedler and her chief aide, who are charged with attempting to pay off a rival candidate for nomination to the United States Senate.

title: SOME GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES TO THANK OTHERS FOR DEEDS
description: For some people, contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are a way of giving thanks to their fellow New Yorkers.

title: PARIS OPENINGS: SHORT SKIRTS AND POLO SHIRTS
description: Simplicity seems to be the catchword of the new couture season. With his polo shirts for day and night and his long sleek jackets, Marc Bohan of Christian Dior is a foremost advocate and his collection certainly works. But it must be kept in mind that what passes for toned-down styling in haute couture might look overwrought for anyone steeped in, say, American sportswear. When they are encrusted with intricate jewel embroidery, even Mr. Bohan's polo shirts do not seem understated.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Nomination For F.T.C. Post
description: The Reagan Administration yesterday nominated Andrew J. Strenio Jr., a Washington lawyer, to fill a vacancy on the Federal Trade Commission.

title: CHICAGO HAILS ITS CHAMPIONS
description: It was 6 degrees above zero with a wind-chill factor of minus 25, real Bears weather, and simply a perfect day for the new National Football League champions to come home.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $35 million provision for energy-related equipment and a charge of $43 million against the company's investment a steel company. c-Net income.

title: Diamond Trade Inquiry
description: The diamond trade in Antwerp, the world's biggest center for polished diamonds, came to a virtual halt today over a tax evasion investigation of a currency and brokerage firm that serves many of the city's merchants.

title: Patient With Artificial Heart Leaves Hospital for 2 Hours
description: With the help of a portable respirator, Murray P. Haydon left the hospital for the first time since receiving an artificial heart last Feb. 17, Humana Hospital Audubon disclosed today.

title: AMERITRUST FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $597,000 for the quarter and 6 months from a Federal Home Loan Bank Board dividend.

title: Politics; It's a Long Way, Denmark to Colorado
description: With Presidential politics in its off-Broadway phase, perhaps it is not realistic to expect any riveting political theater from a cast of Hamlets. But some of the 1988 Presidential hopefuls have already produced noteworthy performances raising questions about their own political character.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it had extended its consumer incentive programs to Feb. 28 from Jan. 31.

title: AGENTS REPORT LAX SECURITY AT LANDFILLS
description: Undercover agents investigating security at 34 landfills dumped cans and drums similar to those used for toxic wastes at 29 sites without being challenged by gatekeepers or other workers, the State Attorney General said today.

title: KATSUMORI YAMASHIRO
description: Katsumori Yamashiro, commander of the Japanese destroyer that sank the torpedo boat commanded by John F. Kennedy in the Pacific Ocean in World War II, has died of pneumonia, hospital officials said today.

title: OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOCH SAYS MANES COULD TAKE A LEAVE
description: Mayor Koch, who called repeatedly over the weekend for Donald R. Manes to resign as Queens Borough President, said yesterday that he would be satisfied if Mr. Manes took a leave of absence while charges that he solicited bribes are resolved.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
