description: b-After a writedown of assets and provision for closure costs of $36.000,000 for the quarter and year and including a gain of $9,400,000 on the sale of shares of Pine Point Mines LTD. for the year. c-Net income including a gain of $5,200,000.

title: THE DANCE: 'DUO-TRIO' AT EDENS
description: ''DUO-TRIO,'' the dance concert on Friday night at Edens Expressway, was a progam by three choreographers - Deborah Kayton, Amos Pinhasi and Deborah Reshotko -each of whom contributed two works. Most were tidily constructed. All were competently danced. If they shared a common fault, it was a tendency toward blandness.

title: ONE IN SIX GRADUATE WOMEN REPORT SEX WITH PROFESSORS
description: THE proportion of women in psychology who report having been sexually intimate with a professor during their graduate training is one in six, according to a survey of 464 women published in the current issue of the American Psychologist. An additional 30 percent of the women reported unwanted sexual advances from a professor while in graduate school.

title: RYAN A MUST FOR BEARS
description: If the Chicago Bears lose Buddy Ryan to either the Philadelphia Eagles or the St. Louis Cardinals as a head coach, will the Super Bowl XX champions repeat next season?

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Man to Look For
description: Mike Mitchell of the San Antonio Spurs, a gunner who makes no bones about it: ''I like to take all the shots in the tough situations. As a matter of fact, I like to take all the shots.''

title: PARKING BUREAU'S TROUBLES LEAVE BACKLOG OF UNPROCESSED TICKETS
description: The New York City Parking Violations Bureau is facing an unexpected side effect of the corruption scandal that has shaken the city government: a mountain of more than 315,000 unprocessed parking tickets.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALLEGHENY POWER INCALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: 'FOCUS!' AT JUILLIARD
description: FIVE of the six concerts being presented by the Juilliard School in its current ''Focus!'' festival deal with the years between 1918 and 1933, a time that appears to some historians today as excitingly fertile and to other observers as a period of musical decay. The second concert in the Juilliard series last night at the Juilliard Theater offered works that could provide ammunition for supporters of either view. Unfortunately, the overall result was an impression of patchiness and lack of - yes -''focus.''

title: LITTLE CONSOLATION FOR THE PATRIOTS
description: Tony Eason's father couldn't find him.

title: GUIDE ON AIDS URGES SURGEONS TO USE CAUTION
description: The Public Health Service has drafted new guidelines that urge surgeons, dentists and obstetricians to take even greater precautions to avert any transmission of the AIDS virus. It has also drafted recommendations designed to prevent the spread of AIDS in prisons.

title: HIGH COURT REVERSES RULING ON RELIGIOUS STUDIES
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the First Amendment does not necessarily bar use of state vocational rehabilitation money to finance religious studies by a partly blind student at a Christian college.

title: EUROPE AGREES TO BAN ARMS TO COUNTRIES BACKING TERROR
description: The European Common Market agreed today to ban arms sales to countries that were ''clearly implicated in supporting terrorism.''

title: Super Bowl Viewers Top Last Year's Contest
description: There was a drop in the numbers of viewers for the second half of the Super Bowl but as far as Robert Blackmore, senior vice president for advertising sales of NBC-TV, is concerned it was negligible and topped last year's contest in any event.

title: BELL ATLANTIC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Citicorp is offering $150 million of 10 1/2 percent subordinated debentures due 2016 at a price of 98 1/2 to yield 10.67 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $334,000 to operations which represented unamortized commitment fees as a result of a change in lenders and a writeoff of $190,000 related to installations in progress pertaining to a series of disputes with developers which arose prior to, or during 1983.

title: NO IDEOLOGICAL SHIFT IS DISCERNED
description: President Reagan continues to be extremely popular with the American public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, but there is no clear evidence that he has yet achieved the ideological realignment he has long sought.

title: Ausimont Compo
description: Ausimont Compo N.V. said it had agreed to acquire certain of Allied-Signal Inc.'s fluoropolymer business units for $55 million.

title: Ford Credit Sells $200 Million Issue
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.69 to yield 9.33 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Jan. 20 about a proposed garbage-to-energy plant in Rockland County misstated the plant's capacity. It would burn 2,250 tons per day, more than twice the county's estimated output.

title: Yugoslav Car
description: The manufacturer of the Yugo G.V. said that the car's American importers wanted to double yearly deliveries to fight competition in the growing American market for cheap cars. Rodoljub Micic, president of Zavodi Crvena Zastava, said the company wanted its United States partner, Yugo America Inc., to finance part of almost $400 million needed to expand production. Around 10,000 of the hatchbacks have been delivered since the car, which has a $3,990 list price, first appeared in the United States last August, and there is an order backlog.

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: ANNICK GOUTAL is a nose, as they say in the world of perfume. She is able to sniff floral essences, spices, fruits and such and blend them into perfumes with names like Passion, Heure Exquise, Camille, Eau de Ciel and Charlotte. She is also tall, slender, dark-haired and chic. The proprietor of two shops in Paris, as of this week she is ensconced in a bower of gilded flowers at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Venezuela's Debt Plan
description: Venezuela still plans to go ahead with a $21.2 billion debt rescheduling with its bank creditors, but the oil price slump has cast doubts on its ability to meet payments, bankers said today.

title: Courier-Journal Interests Gannett
description: The Gannett Company is interested in discussing the purchase of The Louisville Courier-Journal, Allen H. Neuharth, the chairman of Gannett, said at a news conference before an address to the Economic Club of Detroit.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAWYER CITES ERROR IN RULING ON U.P.I. SALE
description: The Financial News Network, frustrated thus far in its effort to acquire United Press International, could get another chance at U.P.I. because a September bankruptcy court order omitted what may prove to be critical language.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
BEARS ANSWER ALL QUESTIONS
description: ''I was getting a little bit bored. I was waiting for the clock to run out.'' That was Gary Fencik, the Chicago Bears' free safety.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring net charge of $88 million for the quarter and year for the cancellation of an oilfield development agreement. c-Net income. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $8.7 million for the quarter and $18.8 million for the year. million

title: AQUINO STIRS A CROWD
description: Tens of thousands of people took over the center of Manila's business district today in a wildly enthusiastic rally that demonstrated the wave of adulation that has built around the presidential campaign of Corazon C. Aquino.

title: COMMUNITY SHARES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Steel Quota Retaliation
description: Common Market foreign ministers decided today to take retaliatory measures against a United States decision to impose quotas on semifinished steel from the 12-nation trade bloc.

title: Drug Tied to Antibody Tried Against Cancer
description: Hoping to single out and kill individual cancer cells with a precision never before possible, doctors at the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation are conducting the world's first clinical trial of a special drug-antibody combination.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Hoffman-La Roche Inc., a health care company based in Nutley, N.J., has named Herbert J. Conrad senior vice president.

title: Filing by Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., a fast-growing vendor of computer work stations for engineers, has filed for an initial public stock offering and plans to offer four million shares at an expected price of $16 to $18 a share.

title: BERRY SAYS TEAM HAS DRUG PROBLEM
description: At least five New England Patriots have a serious drug problem, and five to seven more are suspected of having a problem, Coach Raymond Berry told a newspaper here.

title: Treasury Issues Up Modestly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, spurred by recent declines in American overnight interest rates and prospects for lower interest rates in Japan.

title: Fossil in Wyoming May Be A Distant Human Ancestor
description: The fossilized teeth and jawbones of one of the earliest known true primates has been found in Wyoming, and the squirrel-sized animal, which lived more than 50 million years ago, may be a distant ancestor of humans, a researcher said today.

title: Coca-Cola Plans Bottling Merger
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it planned to merge its bottling interests with those of the JTL Corporation, which operates Coca-Cola bottling companies in the West, to form the world's largest independent soft-drink bottler. Terms were not disclosed.

title: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL WARNS LIBYANS
description: A senior State Department official explicitly warned for the first time today that the Administration would consider military action against Libya if the nonmilitary sanctions already imposed by Washington fail to achieve results.

title: Steel Output Down The Associated Press
description: Steel production fell to 1.764 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of eight-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.779 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: NOBLE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OAKWOOD HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated retraactiely to give effect ot the 5-for-4 stock split declared Oct. 24, 1985.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Mulberry Wars in the Park
description: Though parks should, among other virtues, promote peaceful contemplation, New York's Central Park never ceases to stimulate warfare. Indeed, the latest call to arms is sounded by one of the park's most fervent boosters, M. M. ''Mickey'' Graff. She has forcefully declared in her maturity that the park fails in both its main functions - as a showplace of native American plants and trees and as an oasis of shade and meadow for urban refugees.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of $103.3 million for the quarter and $153.8 million for the year on communications equipment, net gains of $113.6 million for the quarter and $206.6 million for the year on antitrust settlements, an extraordinary net charge of $26.3 million for the quarter and year for losses on debt extinguishments and a gain of $18.2 million for the 6 months on the sale of land. c-After a writedown on equipment of $49.8 million.

title: James Martin Is Dead at 54; Ex-Philadelphia Police Aide
description: James Martin, the former Deputy Police Commissioner who was the highest-ranking officer convicted in a Federal investigation of police corruption here, died of cancer Saturday night. He was 54 years old.

title: PILOTS AT EASTERN TO CONDUCT VOTE ON CALLING A STRIKE IN FEBRUARY
description: The union for Eastern Airlines pilots, searching for a way out of a bargaining deadlock, announced today that it would conduct a referendum among its 4,300 members on whether to strike Feb. 25.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $9 million for the quarter and the year for the disposition of Hardwood Saw Mills.

title: Issue at Georgia
description: The student body at the University of Georgia had gone 0-for-the-1980's in terms of campus demonstrations. No issue seemed large enough - not apartheid, not the state's newly elevated drinking age, not anything - to bring a good old-fashioned protest.

title: TREVOR NUNN TO DIRECT 'CHESS'
description: Trevor Nunn, the Tony Award-winning director, will take over the direction of ''Chess,'' the expensive new Broadway-bound musical, the Shubert Organization announced yesterday. ''Chess'' was left without a director and choreographer last week, when Michael Bennett withdrew, reportedly because of health reasons.

title: Key-tronic Talks
description: The Key-tronic Corporation, the nation's largest independent manufacturer of computer keyboards, said it was discussing a manufacturing contract with the Minebea Company, a Japanese manufacturer of miniature ball bearings and electronic parts. Minebea and Key-tronic are considering a contract to produce Key-tronic's various keyboards and ancillary products at Minebea's plant in Thailand, a Key-tronic spokesman said. Key-tronic operates three plants in the Spokane area, as well as plants in Taiwan and Dundalk, Ireland.

title: BYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Nickolus Covello, Executive At The Times, Is Found Slain
description: Nickolus J. Covello, an executive in the advertising department of The New York Times, was found stabbed to death Sunday in East Ocean View, just east of Norfolk.

title: WHITE HOUSE DENIES REPORTS ON K.G.B. DEFECTOR
description: The White House today denied reports that a K.G.B. officer had fled to the West last year and was now living in the United States. Meanwhile, Congressional sources confirmed the reports of an officer's defection.

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREINER ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $143,000 for the quarter and year from the termination a unit's pension plan.

title: AT ALBANY EXHIBIT, MEMORIES OF A WARTIME REFUGEE CAMP
description: To this day, Simon Krauthamer carries in his wallet the pass he needed 42 years ago to leave the guarded refugee camp in Oswego, N.Y., each day and go to the local public school.

title: High Court Refuses Plea by Hauptmann
description: Anna Hauptmann, the widow of Bruno R. Hauptmann, who was executed 50 years ago for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son, lost a Supreme Court appeal today asserting her husband was not guilty.

title: CATALYST ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 6-for-5 stock split distributes this months.

title: Rose Sobell, Mother of Figure In Rosenberg Espionage Trial
description: Rose Sobell, who for many years fought to reverse the conviction of her son, Morton Sobell, the co-defendant of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, died Friday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in the Bronx. She was 91 years old and had lived at the home since 1977.

title: REAGAN SAID TO SHIFT IN FAVOR OF 16 CENT CIGARETTE TAX
description: Despite his earlier opposition, President Reagan will propose keeping the cigarette tax at 16 cents a pack in his 1987 budget, Administration officials said today.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Florida Freeze Threat Sends Orange Juice Up
description: A cold front swept across the United States and threatened Florida orange groves, prompting a sharp rise in prices for frozen orange juice futures today at the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: FRANK CAMP
description: Frank Camp, a former University of Louisville football coach, died Sunday at Methodist Evangelical Hospital.

title: Auction the Right to be an Immigrant
description: The debate over immigration tends to focus on a narrow range of tired options, excluding more radical ideas. One idea that has received no attention is sale of the right to immigrate.

title: Judge Dismisses a Suit Against Power Agency
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit against the Bonneville Power Administration charging that the Federal agency was negligent and misled buyers of bonds used to begin construction of two nuclear power plants.

title: VOYAGER DISCOVERS 'BOULDERS' IN RINGS
description: A new analysis of data from the Voyager 2 spacecraft has revealed that the rings of Uranus are composed primarily of blocky chunks of dark material at least three feet wide that orbit the distant planet about once every eight hours. This sets Uranian rings apart from the rings of bright fine-grained particles surrounding Saturn.

title: CASSETTES IMPERIL POST-OSCAR PROFITS
description: ''Prizzi's Honor'' and ''The Purple Rose of Cairo'' are considered among the front-runners for major Academy Award nominations this year. But no matter how many times they are nominated, neither movie is likely to make an extra dime at the box office. Even if one of them should win the Oscar as best picture - a prize that usually adds from $10 million to $25 million to a movie's revenues - few if any theaters will be willing to book it.

title: Algae Graze on Bacteria
description: Biologists studying microscopic life in a Canadian lake have discovered that algae, plants once thought to live almost entirely through photosynthesis, sometimes derive much of their energy by grazing on bacteria. Beneath the surface of Quebec's Lac Cromwell, four species of algae were found to be especially heavy feeders.

title: Olson Mark Reduced
description: Billy Olson's world-indoor pole-vault best that was achieved on Saturday was officially reduced by a quarter-inch yesterday. Olson cleared 19 feet 4 inches at the Albuquerque Invitational in New Mexico.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Analysts Differ Over Carbide
description: THE Union Carbide Corporation makes Prestone antifreeze, Glad plastic bags and a wide assortment of other products, but the Danbury, Conn., company also seems to have a knack for producing something else - controversy.

title: The Case For and Against Abducting Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: HALT IS ORDERED IN URBAN GIANTS
description: The Reagan Administration today ordered a halt to approximately $200 million in Congressionally approved spending for urban development.

title: A BUILDER FOR HONDURAS
description: He has a reputation among his countrymen as an unusually hardheaded politician who resigned from the Government three years ago rather than bend to the political dictates of the Honduran President. But today Jose Azcona

title: State of the State of the Union Talk
description: When President Reagan goes before Congress Tuesday to deliver his State of the Union Message, he will be maintaining a tradition as old as the nation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Timber!
description: Representative James Weaver of Oregon's timber-rich fourth Congressional District, a scrappy populist Democrat and scourge of corporate lumber interests, says he will have an announcement to make Friday. And no one doubts he will run for the Senate seat that has been held for three terms by Bob Packwood, a loyal but occasionally dissident Republican who has nettled the Reagan White House from time to time.

title: New Memory Boards Go Beyond the 640K Barrier
description: IT is sometimes helpful to think of a computer's internal memory as a post office. In the case of the I.B.M. PC and its compatibles, the post office is the Intel 8088 microprocessor chip, which has room for roughly one million post office boxes (one megabyte), each with its own address and each capable of holding one letter, or byte.

title: Top S.B.A. Official Leaving by April 1
description: James C. Sanders intends to resign as administrator of the Small Business Administration by April 1 after four years as head of the Federal agency.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 28, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 split of the company's common stock that was distributed Dec. 26, 1985, to stockholders of record on Dec. 13, 1985.

title: MEMPHIS STATE GOES 20-0
description: Baskerville Holmes scored 19 points tonight to lead undefeated Memphis State to an 83-61 Metro Conference basketball victory over Virginia Tech.

title: CUOMO WOULD BROADEN LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR JOB
description: Governor Cuomo wants his next lieutenant governor to double up, working in another top-level state job as well as being the Governor's designated successor.

title: Savin Account Goes to Korey
description: Korey, Kay & Partners has been named agency for the Savin Corporation, maker of office copiers.

title: SIMPLE WORD PROCESSOR FOR THE SOMETIME WRITER
description: AS a general-purpose machine the personal computer has been pretty much a flop in the home. Even the most optimistic industry pundits no longer expect the average person to spend his or her evenings in front of a computer monitor with programs like ''Managing Your Money'' or ''The Computer Cookbook'' rather than in front of the tube watching ''Dynasty.''

title: The Case For and Against Abducting Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY RECORDS SHATTER IMAGE OF INDIANS AS DUPES
description: TO buy Brooklyn from the Indians, the early Dutch settlers paid 200 times as much they did for Manhattan, a new analysis of 17th century records shows.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: THE DANCE: FAIRBANK AND BISSELL
description: COMPLEX are the uses of simplicity. That was demonstrated by Holly Fairbank and Bill Bissell, who shared a program Sunday night at Just Above Midtown. Most of their pieces utilized only a few steps. Yet in the best of them the movements were obviously chosen with care.

title: BELT TIGHTENING BY THE SAUDIS
description: After a decade of fairy-tale riches, Saudi Arabia saw its oil revenues dwindle in the last three years by more than two-thirds as it cut production in a vain attempt to mop up a world oil surplus and bolster prices set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: ROLLINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,434,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of property.

description: b-Including a net gain of $458,000 from discontinued operations and after a net loss of $9,000,000 from a provision for disposal of discontinued operations.

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,919,000 from the sale of the company's French and German subsidiaries.

title: Chic Boutique Wins Campfire
description: Chic Boutique, took the lead nearing the stretch and turned back Lord Ashdale's late challenge to score a three-quarter length victory in the $40,000 Campfire purse for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,469,000 from discontinued operations. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock-Exchange.

title: Padilla Enters Meet
description: Doug Padilla, ranked second in the world in the 5,000 meters last year, has entered the Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Feb. 3, and the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Feb. 14.

title: CITYFED FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,077,000 for the quarter and$4,153,000 for the year and a preferred stock dividend from the FHLMC of $2,612,000 for the quarter and year. c-After a charge of $787,000 resulting from penalties on prepayment of FHLB advances.

title: Pay Increases at a Low In Major Labor Pacts
description: Major collective-bargaining contracts reached in 1985 provided first-year pay increases averaging only 2.3 percent, the lowest ever recorded, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FLEET STREET BATTLE: MURDOCH TAKES ON THE UNIONS
description: For nearly two centuries, Fleet Street has been not only the London district where this nation's newspapers are printed, but also a bastion of union strength in resisting new printing technology.

title: North Stars Top Devils
description: Marc Habscheid, playing in his first game for Minnesota, scored twice in the first period tonight, as the North Stars coasted to a 6-2 victory over the Devils.

title: OFFSHORE DRILLER IN CHAPTER 11
description: Citing the sudden plunge in oil prices last week, Global Marine Inc. filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Israel's Choice: New 'Zionism' Or Historic Democracy
description: Meir Kahane, the Brooklyn-born rabbi who has created such a stir in Israeli politics, is in the United States this month seeking support and boasting about his prospects. The rabbi's predictions - that he will be Prime Minister within five years - could not be more farfetched, but that does not mean that we can ignore his views or their rising popularity among Israeli youth.

title: Southern Yemen's Rebels Said to Consolidate Hold
description: Hard-line rebels supported by Moscow were reportedly consolidating their hold on Southern Yemen today.

title: Surfeit of Honorifics
description: Normally the title Honorable is given to elected and appointed government officials. But in the program for a Conservative Party dinner last Thursday at the Sheraton Centre, the names of all the Honored Guests - politician and nonpolitician alike -were preceeded by Honorable.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of securities of $12,818,000 in the quarter and $37,073,000 in the year, and a gain from the sale of real estate of $3,417,000 in the quarter and $4,368,000 in the year; and after a loss from the sale of real estate in excess of current operating needs of $3,349,000 in the quarter and $10,673,000 in the year. c-After a loss on the sale of securities of $3,380,000 in the quarter and including a gain on the sale of securities of $814,000 in the year; and including a gain from the sale of real estate of $415,000 in the quarter and $3,858,000, and a gain on the sale of real estate in excess of current operating needs of $2,000 in the quarter and $2,972,000 in the year.

title: STAGE: 'RUM AND COKE,' BAY OF PIGS REVISITED
description: IN American history, as taught by the young playwright Keith Reddin, the cold war is to be found not only in the conflicts of nations and ideologies but also in the American values enshrined by hit pop songs, glossy Hollywood films and Life magazine photo spreads. ''Life and Limb,'' the Reddin play seen at Playwrights Horizons last year, offered a black comic vision of post-Korean War New Jersey in which the characters behaved like mutated conformists from Frank Capra movies and ''I Love Lucy.''

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $508 million for a provision for Montgomery Ward restructuring.

title: ALBERT B. GROSSMAN, INFLUENTIAL MANAGER IN POP-MUSIC FIELD
description: Albert B. Grossman, one of the most influential personal managers in the popular-music field, died of a heart attack Saturday on a flight to Europe to attend a music convention. He was 59 years old and lived in Bearsville, N.Y., in the Town of Woodstock.

title: Unmanned Spacecraft Are a Better Buy for Our Science Bucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsi Termed No. 1 Seller
description: Pepsi-Cola, moving into the gap between old Coke and new Coke, has become the nation's best-selling single soft drink, an industry publication says.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLD HELPS BOLSTER OIL PRICES
description: Crude oil and refined products firmed yesterday in the world oil markets, supported by forecasts of colder weather in Europe and the Eastern United States and by reports from the Middle East that Saudi Arabia and Libya would seek an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: AID UNIT DISPUTES ETHIOPIA'S POLICY
description: The Ethiopian Government and a private relief group are at odds over a report by the group that says more Ethiopians are dying as a result of the policies of their Government than as a result of famine.

title: Mobil Soars 49.6% in Quarter
description: Two of the nation's largest oil companies reported contrasting results in the fourth quarter, with the Mobil Corporation's net income soaring 49.6 percent while the Unocal Corporation reported a net loss of $134.7 million.

title: BLACK APPROVAL OF REAGAN IS RISING
description: Black Americans are much more likely to approve of how President Reagan is handling his job than they were three and four years ago, but they are far more critical than are whites, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: RANGERS GET TIE ON LATE GOAL
description: On one of the wildest nights of the year, on the night of his return, the puck wound up on the stick of Pierre Larouche just as he broke in alone toward the goal in the final seconds.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest first quarter reflect the reversal of a $400,000 charge recognized in 1983 and 1984 under a patent license agreement related to litigation by oneof the company's competitors.

title: Purchase Influence Research
description: ALL married people and those playing at being married, as well as each child in their households, know that everyone has some input into most buying decisions. The smart set in the world of marketing prefers to call them purchase influences and they never seem to tire of trying to evaluate them.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $84,100. Latest year results include the effects of the acquisition of certain assets and the business of the special products plant manufacturing division of Ozalid Corp., effective July 1, 1985. Year-ago results include the effects of reversing previously provided deferred income taxes of approximately $84,100, or 8 cents per share, relating to the company's Domestic International Sales Corporation.

title: INVESTIGATING GRAFT
description: It is a familiar scenario. A major scandal breaks. Law-enforcement officials - Federal, county and city -each maintaining they are merely following the law, conduct investigations simultaneously. At times they seem as intent on claiming jurisdiction as they are on amassing evidence.

title: OSHKOSH TRUCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
City Opera Announces Cast for 'Brigadoon'
description: The cast of ''Brigadoon,'' which will open the New York City Opera's first musical comedy season on Feb. 28, was announced yesterday.

description: b-Net income.

L.S.U. Resumes Play
description: Ten players on the Louisiana State basketball team, benched last week because of chicken pox, received medical clearance to play yesterday starting with Kentucky at midweek.

title: ROBINS, A H & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary charge of $3,320,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $14.4 million in the year. c-Net losses after a reserve of $489,067,000 in connection with costs associated with the disposition of pending and future compensatory claims and litigation expenses related to the Dalkon Shield.

title: THE DANCE: SUSAN MARSHALL
description: SUSAN MARSHALL is enough of a choreographic realist to know that people can be clumsy, or even oafish. Yet she is no pessimist. The characters in her dances are vulnerable, as well as arrogant, and even when bumptious they can be likable.

title: MURDER FOR HIRE CHARGED AT START OF JERSEY TRIAL
description: A prosecutor told jurors today that a prominent Toms River insurance salesman had his wife killed in 1984 in ''a case of murder for hire.''

title: Governor of Louisiana Calls Off Gambling Plan
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards conceded today that he did not have enough support among lawmakers to establish a statewide lottery or casino gambling in New Orleans, and called off his plans for a special legislative session on the issues that was to begin Feb. 3.

title: Major Repairs to Snag Traveling in Brooklyn
description: Two major repair projects starting this week will disrupt road and subway travel to and from Brooklyn.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a $63.8 million charge for the costs of plant closings and employment reductions.

title: Investment Bank Shift
description: Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., the leading underwriter of Eurobonds, said that Michael von Clemm, chairman and co-founder, had resigned for personal reasons. Mr. von Clemm, 50 years old, had been with the London-based international investment bank since 1971.

title: Profits at Merrill More Than Double
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that profits for both the fourth quarter and all of 1985 more than doubled from 1984 levels.

title: PROVISIONS TO REMOVE BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: A borough president may only be removed from office by the governor after formal charges and a hearing. But a borough president may turn his duties over to a deputy if he cannot carry them out himself.

title: HEREDITARY DISEASE: NEW THERAPIES ARE CLOSER
description: Human gene therapy, a long awaited way to cure some of the most terrible hereditary diseases, is coming ever closer to practical reality, but there are still important problems to be solved, a panel of experts said today.

title: I.R.S. ENDS COMPUTER CONTRACT
description: The Internal Revenue Service today canceled a multimillion-dollar contract to install the second phase of its troubled new computer system, in a move that seemed likely to delay further any reduction of the growing backlog of tax disputes.

title: SERGEANT TELLS JURY HE WAS NOT DRIVER IN FATAL ACCIDENT
description: A police sergeant charged in the hit-and-run death of a Manhattan psychologist testified yesterday that he was asleep in the passenger's seat when the accident occurred.

title: Lesotho King Swears In Cabinet in Shake-Up
description: King Moshoeshoe II swore in a new Cabinet today headed by the officer who overthrew the former Government a week ago.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks play their final home game of the month before taking off on a six-game western trip. This is Chicago's only trip this season to New York. Orlando Woolridge has taken over the scoring burden in the absence of Michael Jordan. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Nets vs. Golden State Warriors, at Oakland, Calif. For the final stop on their five-game road trip, the Nets pay a visit to Chris Mullin, a former St. John's player. He and the Warriors dropped an overtime decision in Madison Square Garden last Tuesday night to the Knicks. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 10:30 P.M.) Colleges: Syracuse at Boston College, 7 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7 P.M.); Wake Forest at Maryland, 9 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); New York Maritime at United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., 7:30 P.M.; Adelphi at Pace, 7:30 P.M.; Purchase at Pratt, 7:30 P.M.; Yeshiva at St. Joseph's (N.Y.), 7:30 P.M.; Dowling at Mercy, 7:30 P.M.; Yale at Manhattan, 8 P.M.; La Salle at Louisville, 8 P.M.; Baruch at York, 8 P.M. Hockey Islanders vs. Toronto Maple Leafs, at Uniondale, L.I., the Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. Pat Flatley, the Islanders right wing, almost did it all before his hometown fans when the Islanders beat the Leafs, 5-4, in Toronto on Nov. 6.

title: Board of Airbus Backs Jetliners
description: The board of the European Airbus Industrie consortium has approved further development work on the A330 and A340 long-range passenger jet projects and will decide whether to put them into production by early 1987 at the latest, an Airbus spokesman said.

title: CARTWRIGHT LIKELY TO BE LOST FOR SEASON
description: ''Cautious'' is perhaps the only way to describe the mood at the offices of the Knicks yesterday afternoon as the results of the latest X-rays of Bill Cartwright's fragile left foot were revealed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1986
description: International A report on Ethiopian resettlement has divided the Ethiopian Government and a private relief organization. A report by a Paris-based organization known as Doctors Without Borders says more Ethiopians are dying as a result of a resettlement program than as a result of famine. Ethiopia denied the charge, which appears in a report titled ''Mass Deportations in Ethiopia,'' a study of the Marxist Government's efforts to resettle 1.5 million famine victims. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dark Side of Student Loans to Needy
description: SHE is a sophomore at an Ivy League college, doing well academically but already in anguish over what will happen after graduation. Will there be a job? More terrifying, how will she be able to repay her student loans?

title: Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said that introduction of its Spectrum computer line was ''imminent.''

title: NATIONAL HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ST JOSEPH LIGHT & POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THATCHER DEFENDS INTEGRITY AND WINS VOTE OF SUPPORT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told Parliament today that her Government had mishandled aspects of the controversy over the future of a British helicopter company, but denied that there had been any wrongdoing.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE POET Walt Whitman, one of America's greatest poets, needs no particular point in time, such as a 100th anniversary of his birth or death, to inspire a celebration. And there are no people better equipped to celebrate him than his fellow poets. You may participate in this celebration by attending the preview of ''Walt Whitman,'' a 60-minute film, at 6 P.M. tonight at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street.

title: The Gold Standard
description: The old idea of tying the currency to a fixed price of gold is being pushed again by the hard right. The arguments are more sophisticated than during previous apparitions.

title: PLAN FOR BIG SUR SEVERELY RESTRICTS DEVELOPMENT
description: After more than a decade of debate, government officials and environmentalists have agreed on a sweeping zoning plan for California's Big Sur coast that they say will preserve its spectacular beauty.

title: Eastern Utilities Lifts Seabrook Bid
description: Eastern Utilities Associates, a Boston-based utility holding company, said yesterday it had increased by $30.9 million its offer to acquire an additional 11.3 percent interest in the nuclear project at Seabrook, N.H., from four utilities in Maine and Vermont. The purchase would bring Eastern's total participation to 14.2 percent.

title: Record Brazil Inflation
description: The country's inflation rate rose to 16.2 percent in January, the worst monthly figure on record, pushing the annual increase in prices to an unprecedented 237.3 percent, the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics said today. The January inflation rate, up from 13.36 percent in December, was principally attributed to rising food prices, including a large jump in coffee prices, brought on by a severe six-month drought.

title: MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in January 1986.

REFRIGERATOR HAS LITTLE TIME TO DEFROST
description: William Perry yawned, William Perry apologized.

description: * Monsanto Company to Muller Jordan Weiss for Landmaster Herbicide.

title: Chess: Two Leading 13-Year-Olds Contest Match With Vigor
description: Ilya Gurevich of Worcester, Mass., the World Under 14 Champion, and Michael Adams, the strongest 13-year-old in Britain, played to a 3-3 tie match at Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Textron to Sell Bostitch Unit
description: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Bostitch division to the Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., for about $193 million.

title: Judge Refuses Lawyers' Bid To Drop Charge Facing Goetz
description: The state judge who this month dismissed charges of attempted murder and assault against Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday denied a motion by Mr. Goetz's lawyers to dismiss a remaining charge.

title: On to Neptune
description: Voyager 2, eight years and two billion miles out from Earth, swung by the planet Uranus last weekend. The little spacecraft arrived 1 minute and 9 seconds early, but it sent back such startling evidence of Uranus's strange rings and planets that NASA can be forgiven the departure from schedule.

title: The Danger Is to All Species
description: When the last dodo bird died, around 1680, the number of species becoming extinct was matched by the number of new species evolving. Since then, mankind's destructiveness has far outpaced nature's adaptability. By the year 2000, a million species may have vanished.

title: CAPITAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings for all periods have been adjusted to reflect a three- for-two stock split declared in the second quarter of 1984.

title: MUSIC: BLITZSTEIN AT MEET THE MODERNS
description: FRIDAY'S Meet the Moderns concert by the Brooklyn Philharmonic at Cooper Union brought five new pieces to New York and then revived Marc Blitzstein's Piano Concerto, which has lain virtually unused for 50 years. The Blitzstein, with its acerbic distentions of tonality and gray earnestness, was at least a product of its own time. Most of the other pieces seemed to find no present, let alone a future, and fished casually around in the past.

title: IMRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: MARCOS MOUNTS ATTACK
description: Whatever the doubts about his war record, Ferdinand E. Marcos shows the boldness of the guerrilla fighter in his attacks from the political stump.

title: Bowery Picks Lawyer To Be a Vice Chairman
description: The Bowery Savings Bank, which was recapitalized and changed from a mutual institution to a privately held organization last October by a group led by Richard Ravitch, announced the appointment of Donald S. Rice, a lawyer, as a vice chairman.

title: Bridge: In Some Bidding Situations, Silence Is to Be Commended
description: The Bard of Avon did not think very highly of the virtue of silence. It ''is only commendable,'' said his character Gratiano in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' ''in a neat's tongue dried and a maid not vendible.''

title: COLUMBIA FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW POSTMASTER GENERAL REMOVES SEVERAL OF AGENCY'S TOP OFFICIALS
description: The new Postmaster General, Albert V. Casey, today took his first steps to reorganize the Postal Service headquarters here by ousting its top finance, operations and public relations officials, according to agency and industry officials.

title: 2 Experts Contend a Bomb Caused Fatal Air-India Crash
description: A leading Indian scientist and an investigator with the Boeing Company testified today that their own investigations had led them to conclude that a bomb had caused the crash of an Air-India jumbo jet last summer in which 329 people died.

title: Home Resales Jumped in '85
description: Sales of existing homes jumped 12.1 percent last year, hitting their highest level since 1979, a real estate trade group said today.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UGANDA REBELS TIGHTENING THEIR GRIP, SAID TO SEIZE NO.2 CITY
description: Ugandan rebel forces were reported today to have further consolidated their control of the country, seizing Uganda's second largest city.

title: 2 Are Killed in Beirut; Leaders Snub Gemayel
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen battled along the Green Line today after Moslem Cabinet members, including Prime Minister Rashid Karami, refused to meet President Amin Gemayel to debate a Syrian-brokered peace pact.

title: BRIBERY INQUIRY RAISING POLITICAL FUND QUESTIONS
description: The investigation of bribes and kickbacks in the city's Parking Violations Bureau generated questions yesterday about campaign contributions and party finances.

title: Gretzky Spree Halted at 39
description: Wayne Gretzky's 39-game point-scoring streak was halted tonight in a 4-3 victory by the Oilers over the Black Hawks.

title: LIBERTY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Soldier of Peace
description: Peacekeepers rarely match warmakers in renown, even at the United Nations. But one who has run an exceptionally strong race is Brian Urquhart, the Under Secretary General who managed 13 peacekeeping operations for the world organization and is now retiring. Fortunately, he'll be within easy reach a few blocks away, at the Ford Foundation.

title: STATE OF UNION PROMPTS DEBATE IN WHITE HOUSE
description: After a bitter debate within the White House staff, President Reagan has agreed to speak about family values as well as his domestic and foreign policy agenda in his State of the Union speech Tuesday, White House officials said today.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Breland Sets Own Pace
description: Mark Breland has his eyes on a professional welterweight championship to go with his 1984 Olympic gold medal. After nine professional fights, including a victory Saturday night over the previously unbeaten Troy Wortham, Breland is undefeated.

description: Federal and local prosecutors in Manhattan disclosed yesterday that they had begun separate criminal investigations into the awarding of a $22 million city contract to a company in which the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman, is a director and major stockholder.

title: 'FLASH' ESTIMATES TO BE DISCONTINUED
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today that his department would stop compiling its quarterly ''flash'' estmate of the country's rate of economic growth because the number ''necessarily is based on incomplete data and can be misleading.''

description: b-After a writeoff for a portion of the Zimmer Power plant of $141,934,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: China Aircraft Trade
description: China will increase exports of civilian and military aircraft over the next five years, but will have to import increasing numbers of long-haul passenger aircraft, the aviation minister, Mo Wenxiang, said. The China Daily quoted Mr. Mo as saying China is already exporting aircraft and can manufacture more than 20 types, including fighters, bombers, helicopters, transport and reconnaissance planes.

title: Appeal for Help for AIDS In Fashion Magazines
description: Thoroughly defying convention, an appeal for help in AIDS research - a stark black-and-white portrait of eight youngsters and nine young women - will appear in the March issues of major fashion magazines.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $972,000 due to a reversal of deferred DISC tax as permitted by the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: 24-HOUR DELAY CALLED FOR SHUTTLE FLIGHT AS WIND AND BALKY BOLT BAR LAUNCHING
description: High winds and a balky bolt on a spaceship door combined today to force yet another 24-hour postponement for the space shuttle Challenger. It was the third such delay in as many days, and the crew is scheduled to try again Tuesday morning.

title: PRINCIPALS IN THE EVOLVING CITY CORRUPTION INQUIRIES
description: The Investigations:

title: 3 HORMEL PLANTS DISMISS HUNDREDS
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Company discharged hundreds of union meatpackers today in Texas, Nebraska and Iowa for refusing to cross picket lines set up by workers who have been on strike against the company's plant here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOW TO BECOME RIDICULOUSLY WELL-READ IN ONE EVENING. A Collection of Literary Encapsulations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel optimistic from what I've seen that while this man may be pretty crazy, he's also crazy like a fox, and he will do what he needs to do to keep himself in power.'' - John C. Whitehead, Deputy Secretary of State, speaking of Muammar el-Qaddafi. [ A8:4. ]

title: BISHOP TUTU RETURNS HOME TO BARRAGE OF CRITICISM
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, returned home today after a visit to the United States to face a barrage of editorial and other criticism from whites angered by his reported comments about his country.

title: ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR COLLEGE TURNS AGAIN TO WAR
description: After many years of emphasizing politics, diplomacy and budgets, the Army War College has recently returned to its tradition of educating bright young colonels to be warriors competent in the operational art of battle.

title: GOODRICH-UNIROYAL TIRE LINK IS SEEN
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company and Uniroyal Inc., two major tire manufacturers, are planning to combine their tire operations in a partnership, industry sources said yesterday.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Procter & Gamble Income Up 20.4%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of the 1986 fiscal year climbed 20.4 percent on a 14.5 percent increase in sales.

It All Adds Up To Adding Things Up
description: Charles A. Bowsher has met the President only once, back in 1981, when he was invited over to the White House for a ceremonial photograph at the time of his appointment as Comptroller General of the United States.

title: ORRIN H. RILEY
description: Orrin H. Riley, an art conservator and restorer, died of pneumonia and respiratory complications Sunday at New York Hospital.

title: Thrift Institution In Mortgage Sale
description: Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan of Boston said that it had reached an agreement to sell up to $2 billion of new single-family home mortgages during the next year to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. In exchange, the thrift unit will receive from the federally chartered agency an equal amount of mortgage participation certificates, a kind of mortgage pass-through security.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Blue Cornmeal Blue cornmeal is nothing new. It goes back to pre-Columbian agriculture on this continent. Old as it is, however, it looks like the fashion food of 1986. Long a favorite in the Southwest, blue corn, with its dark purplish blue kernels, is a traditional food of the Rio Grande Pueblo Indians of New Mexico, according to Jane Butel, an authority on Southwestern cooking.

title: A.T.&T. Role in Golf Tourney Disputed
description: When Kathryn Crosby learned that A.T.&T. had agreed last January to pay a salary to the chairman of the group that conducted the Bing Crosby National Pro Am golf tournament before the company assumed sponsorship of the event, the entertainer's widow considered it improper and used it as a reason to remove her husband's name from the tournament, according to Ben Langella, a Crosby family spokesman.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $489,000 from early retirement of debt. c-Net loss.

title: PRESIDENT AS HEALER
description: A national disaster like the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger presents a leader with an especially difficult problem. He must identify with the ensuing national grief - lead the mourning, in a sense - but he must also confine it and direct it, lest it evolve into a sense of national despair and futility.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harry O'Donnell Memorial
description: A memorial service for Harry J. O'Donnell, who was a press aide for three New York governors and Mayor John V. Lindsay, will be held at noon tomorrow in the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, former Gov. Malcolm Wilson and Mr. Lindsay are among those scheduled to speak. Mr. O'Donnell died Oct. 27 at the age of 71.

title: IN TIRE MARKET, A NEW FORCE
description: Two leading tire companies are hoping that there is strength in unity.

title: NETS TRIUMPH; NETS 117, WARRIORS 113
description: The road trip ended in triumph tonight, but the Nets discovered that nothing comes easily. They gave back a 24-point lead in the second half before finally rallying to beat the Golden State Warriors, 117-113.

title: WAGE AND BENEFIT COSTS ROSE MORE SLOWLY IN '85
description: Employment costs, which account for a third to a half of the price of most products, rose in 1985 more slowly than at any time this decade, suggesting that inflation will continue to moderate, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CHEVRON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue figures include Gulf Corp. as of May 1, 1984.

title: COMMENT IS SOUGHT ON ALCOHOL LABELING
description: Attention all drinkers: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms is seeking your expertise on new labeling rules for the latest wave in hard liquor - low-alcohol distilled spirits.

title: Reds Pitcher Loses Star Role
description: Marge Schott was a Chevrolet dealer long before she bought the Cincinnati Reds. This is not news - except, apparently, to Tom Browning, who won 20 games as a rookie pitcher for the Reds last year.

title: 'THE CRADLE WILL ROCK,' BLITZSTEIN'S LABOR OPERA
description: MARC BLITZSTEIN'S controversial labor opera, ''The Cradle Will Rock,'' struck sparks when it was first produced on Broadway in 1937, under the auspices of the W.P.A. And in its 1983 Off Broadway revival at the American Place Theater, featuring alumni of the Acting Company, the satirical work emerged as a rugged period piece whose wit and allegorical force transcended heavy doses of dated, pro-union agitprop. Brought to television, as the second of three presentations in PBS's ''America's Musical Theater'' series, the show has lost none of its crude energy and satirical bite.

title: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER
description: Ronald E. McNair Dr. Ronald Erwin McNair, a physicist who became an astronaut in 1978, was the shuttle crew member who was to have launched a science platform to observe Halley's comet.

title: Readings by Black Poets
description: As part of the Academy of American Poets' celebration of Black History Month, four black poets will read from their work on Feb. 11 at 6 P.M. in the Donnell Library Center.

title: SOMMELIERS GET AS SCARCE AS '29 LAFITE
description: AT Le Cirque, captains in tuxedos proffer leather-bound wine lists and serve the wine. At Lavin's, which has a sophisticated wine selection and a state-of-the-art dispenser for wine by the glass, waiters and waitresses in white shirts and black bow ties explain the featured wines of the day. And at Le Bernardin, an elegantly appointed Parisian seafood restaurant opening on West 51st Street this week, the service of wine is being assigned to captains and waiters.

title: A SURPRISE SNOWSTORM LEADS TO TRAFFIC SNARLS
description: A light but quick snowstorm caught New York weather forecasters with their radar down yesterday, causing widespread rail, bus and traffic delays during the morning rush hour.

title: GUIDEBOOKS TO CHILD CARE IN THE CITIES
description: PLANNING for the birth of a baby does not often involve considering which hospital offers dinner for two by candlelight with champagne, a manicure for the new mother or an infant car seat.

description: United States and Soviet negotiators opened a new round of talks on chemical weapons here today and pledged to speed work toward a treaty banning the production, storage and use of the weapons by stepping up their discussions.

description: John T. Lupton started in the bottling business 38 years ago by learning the basics: He loaded a bottle-washing machine at the family-owned plant in Macon, Ga.

According to lawyers for the First City Bank of Richardson, Tex., Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys' running back, paid off a total of $121,000 in unpaid debts, satisfying a judgment the bank had won against him last month.

description: ALTHOUGH hundreds of ''new'' recipes are created yearly in professional and home kitchens around the world, each is likely based on an old precept. For instance, a cook may concoct an excellent salad, meat dish or such with an apparently unusual combination of elements and flavors, but the result will still be based on well-established theories.

description: The GTE Corporation, operator of one of the nation's largest telephone systems, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $1 billion after a $1.3 billion charge for restructuring.

title: 2D COMMERCIAL CHANNEL FOR FRANCE
description: The French Government awarded a franchise today for a second, fully commercial television channel, thus taking another step in its campaign to deregulate the country's once tightly controlled airwaves.

title: Chavez Is Running
description: Linda Chavez, who heads the White House Office of Public Liaison but has been pondering lately whether to make a run for Congress, has finally reached a decision. She will seek to fill the vacancy being left in Maryland this year by the retirement of Senator Charles McC.

title: LILLI PALMER, ACTRESS ON TV, STAGE AND SCREEN FOR 50 YEARS
description: Lilli Palmer, an actress on stage, screen and television for more than 50 years, died of cancer Monday in her Los Angeles home. She was 71 years old.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHEN THE DOCTOR IS IN, THE SHOW GOES ON
description: ''Yes, I was Marilyn Monroe's doctor,'' said Dr. Eugen Grabscheid, with a thick Viennese accent and a round mirror on his forehead. ''She was some girl. She had terrible problems, of course. Sinus problems.''

title: 10 Hours of Bach on WBAI
description: The radio personality known only as ''The Laughing Cavalier'' will present 10 hours of early Bach recordings tomorrow from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. on WBAI. Many of the recordings, which date back to the early years of the century and will include disks by Gerhard Husch, William Primrose, Kathleen Long and others, have never been transferred to long-playing format.

title: FIRES CALLED BLOW TO A PACT IN FISHERMAN'S STRIKE
description: The police investigated two fires and a bomb threat today that the authorities said might be linked to a month-old strike by fishermen against boat owners.

title: FAITH IN TECHNOLOGY IS JOLTED, BUT THERE IS NO GOING BACK
description: In almost three decades, American astronauts and those who had watched them soar so often into space had grown used to success.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: MARCY SCHWARTZ recently got out of a taxi in Manhattan and discovered that she had left behind a small notebook containing a year's worth of dreams; she had written them down for psychoanalysis. Since her name, she realized, was nowhere indicated in the book, Miss Schwartz assumed it was lost forever. She was wrong.

title: Collection Company Holds State Contract
description: Computrace, a collection agency linked to the City Parking Violations Bureau scandal, also holds a contract to collect overdue accounts for the State Insurance Department.

title: THEATER: 'UPTOWN' A MUSICAL
description: IF you stay only until intermission, you may leave the Lunt-Fontanne with some pleasant feelings about its energetic, often preposterous and finally loony new musical occupant, ''Uptown . . . It's Hot!'' A two-hour survey of the history of black American pop music from early jazz to rap, the evening is the theatrical equivalent of a telephone-booth-stuffing contest: Songs and proper names, from the Cotton Club to Prince, are shoveled indiscriminately into the show in logic-defying volume. The pace is predictably frantic. A viewer who pauses to glance at his watch may miss the entire rise and fall of doo-wop, the birth and death of the blues or, at one cryptic point, a literary roll call of the Harlem Renaissance. But until hysteria reigns completely in Act II - at which point the audience is no longer taking the A train, but is being mowed down by it - there are rewards to be had. These are attributable to some talented performers, giving their all to songs worthy of the effort.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TO REPAY LOAN EARLY
description: The financial condition of the Social Security System has improved so much that this week it plans to repay $10.6 billion it borrowed from the Medicare trust fund in 1982, Federal officials said today.

title: Ex-Police Official Tells Of Using Bomb on House
description: The city's former police commissioner testified today at the trial of a surviving member of the radical group Move that a bomb dropped on the headquarters of the group was intended to drive members out of the fortified house, not to kill people.

title: FOR NOVICES, USER-FRIENDLY MACHINE
description: AND then came Oskar, a little dynamo that has filled a gap left by the larger food-processing machines such as the Cuisinart and Robot-Coupe. As impressive as these big machines are for many kitchen tasks, they sometimes are unsuitable for the small jobs faced by the home cook.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Colleges: Villanova at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Television - USA, 8 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Utah at Notre Dame (Television - USA, 10 P.M.); Kentucky at Louisiana State (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., tape delay); Southern California at U.C.L.A. Hockey Devils vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. In their first two meetings this season, the Devils handled the Penguins nicely, winning both games. But when they met again, on Jan. 6, the Devils were unraveling. They built a 2-0 lead and then gave up three goals to the Penguins in a span of less than 8 minutes to lose, 4-3, at Pittsburgh.

title: Jordan, Ex-Carter Aide, Says His Cancer Is Cured
description: Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff under President Carter, said today that he has been cured of lymphoma, cancer of the lymph system, through an experimental program at the National Cancer Institute.

title: THE SEVEN WHO PERISHED IN THE EXPLOSION OF THE CHALLENGER
description: Ellison S. Onizuka Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force, an aerospace engineer, was a mission specialist on the shuttle. He was 39 years old.

title: FED OPPOSING CEILINGS ON CREDIT CARD RATES
description: The Federal Reserve Board today announced its opposition to bills pending in Congress that would set ceilings on the interest rates that may be charged by banks and other issuers of credit cards.

title: GLASGOW'S ARISING, ON ITS OWN, IT SAYS
description: If it was possible for her to do so, Margaret Thatcher might point to this formerly begrimed, now occasionally gleaming city as an example of an old industrial center that has responded to her calls for the need to adapt to the competitive demands of a post-industrial world.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Nolan, a former assistant coach at Oregon, Stanford, Rice and Vanderbilt, has been hired as linebacker coach by Louisiana State. The 26-year-old Nolan is a son of the Dallas Cowboys' assistant coach Dick Nolan. . . . Carl Lewis, who won four gold medals at the 1984 Summer Olympics, has entered the long jump at the United States Olympic Invitational track meet at the Meadowlands Arena on Feb. 8. . . . Nick Quartaro, former place-kicker for Iowa, will take over as head coach at Drake University when that school moves from Division I-AA to Division III for the 1987 season.

description: Encouraged by the modest success that steel companies are having in raising prices, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation said today that it would raise the price of its steel sheet piling by $30 a ton.

A little later the narrator sounds as if he were being initiated into the Eleusinian mysteries: ''We were to become more familiar every day with those who form his little solar system. Sensei is the center.''

title: BERRY ADMITS DRUG PROBLEM ON PATRIOTS
description: Raymond Berry, the coach of the New England Patriots, admitted yesterday that the team has been dealing with a drug problem for nearly a year. Yet the team's latest attempt to overcome the problem has been criticized by the players' union.

title: FILM: 'FOREVER YOUNG,' AN ARRAY OF FIRST LOVES
description: ''FOREVER YOUNG,'' the latest and best so far, by far, in the series of British-made movies on the theme of ''First Love'' now in progress at the Embassy 72d Street, has to do with several first loves, and some second loves as well. Its quality resides especially in the director David Drury's feel for a small Roman Catholic parish in England, where families still go to socials together.

title: What Happened To Republicanism?
description: Ronald Reagan's Cultural Revolution continues. His Red Guard comptrollers range through the Government sowing confusion in the name of changeable ideological purity. Certainty and safety are blown to pieces by automatic budget land mines sown by Capitol Hill and the White House alike. All of this is bewildering to me as an American. As a life-long Republican, it is pure devastation.

In the highly competitive food processor market, long dominated by Cuisinart and Hamilton Beach, Sunbeam's Oskar came up golden last year, carrying away a large share of holiday sales. So popular were the appliances that most stores' stocks were quickly depleted and the price skyrocketed from about $70 to as much as $90.

Ott of Beale Air Force Base in California, was arrested Wednesday after he contacted the Soviet consulate general in San Francisco and offered to provide Soviet agents with sensitive material involving national security.

title: AFTER THE SHOCK, A NEED TO SHARE GRIEF AND LOSS
description: The nation came together yesterday in a moment of disaster and loss. Wherever Americans were when they heard the news - at work, at school or at home - they shared their grief over the death of the seven astronauts, among them one who had captured their imaginations, Christa McAuliffe, the teacher from Concord, N.H., who was to have been the first ordinary citizen to go into space.

title: State of the Union?
description: The President's State of the Union address remains one of the majestic occasions of national and even world politics. It assembles together, before a vast television audience, the Chief Executive in the well of the House, addressing the representatives of the people in the presence of the members of his Cabinet, the Supreme Court and the diplomats of many nations.

title: WARNER LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MORE OIL-RIG DEBT PROBLEMS SEEN
description: The offshore drilling industry has been so battered by cuts in exploration budgets at major oil companies that other drilling companies are expected to take the same route as Global Marine Inc., which announced Monday that it would seek court protection from its creditors.

title: Hall of Fame's New Members
description: Willie Lanier Middle linebacker, Kansas City Chiefs, 11 seasons, 149 games. A ferocious tackler, he led an upset of Minnesota in Super Bowl IV.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GRAND ILLUSIONS They have made a big funhouse, in the name of science, of the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, 590 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street. The show that opens today is called ''Seeing the Light With the Exploratorium.'' It is about visual perception, and it has 83 exhibits, all of which you can get personally involved with - and maybe learn something from.

title: Doctor Says Nixon Is Tired, Alert and 'Reasonably Well'
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, hospitalized with a viral infection, was feeling tired but talkative today, discussing medical costs, the Super Bowl and Florida's cold snap, according to the doctor treating him.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ONE IS A WANDERER. Selected Stories. By Francis King. 315 pages. Little, Brown and Company. $16.95. IN his recent novel ''Act of Darkness'' (1983), the British author Francis King demonstrated a sure storytelling instinct, expertly using a murder mystery set in colonial India as the scaffolding for a precisely plotted moral tale about corruption and innocence betrayed. Those same gifts, when employed in the short story form, however, tend to point up Mr. King's limitations as a writer: Whereas the novel derived a kind of energy from the author's emphatic narrative drive, the stories seem to suffer from a surfeit of plot twists, melodramatic flourishes and authorial high jinks. Like old-fashioned works by O. Henry, the stories in this volume are continually jabbing the reader with an elbow, as though to say: ''Look at this! See how ironic this ending is. See how blind the characters are. See how superior you and I are for realizing what they will never know.''

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MICHIGAN GOVERNOR TO URGE COLLEGE TUITION GUARANTEE
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan said today that he would propose a program to guarantee college tuition to students whose parents had invested at least $2,400 in a tax-free account managed by the state.

title: India Charges Suspect With Spying for U.S.
description: An Indian businessman who was arrested on espionage charges last October was charged today with passing sensitive information to United States diplomats.

title: SEARCH BY AIR AND SEA YIELDS NO SIGN OF THE SHUTTLE CREW
description: As night fell along the Atlantic coast and debris began to wash up on the shore, the United States Coast Guard pulled back the 13 aircraft that had been searching today for the remains of the space shuttle Challenger and its crew of seven. They returned to base with no human effects found, and prepared to resume the search Wednesday.

title: A Tangible Tribute To Dr. King's Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYA MAKES OFFER TO STEM TERRORISM
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had offered to help halt Arab terrorist operations in Europe if the United States promised not to attack Libya.

title: Sri Lanka Imposes Curfew
description: A 15-hour curfew was imposed on nine tea-growing areas of central Sri Lanka today after Tamil tea plantation workers went on strike and looting erupted. The Defense Ministry said security forces fired on looters in the town of Talawakele, killing one and wounding another.

title: 'FACES IN A FAMINE,' ETHIOPIA DOCUMENTARY
description: THE drought and deaths in Ethiopia last year are explored once again in ''Faces in a Famine,'' a one-hour film tonight at 10 on WNET/Channel 13. The subject has been covered thoroughly in pictures and in print in the past; this program adds little to what is already known and misses an opportunity to explore the human, political and international-organization complexities of the tragedy in Ethiopia.

title: REFLECTING ON LOSS: WELLING OF TEARS, A DESIRE TO PRESS ON
description: The explosion yesterday of an American shuttle shortly after liftoff, with the death of its crew of seven people, stunned and deeply saddened much of the nation. Many of those who reflected on the disaster tell how it appeared from their perspective, as religious leaders, writers, students, psychiatrists, educators, scientists and test pilots. Daniel J. Boorstin

title: Pressure Increases On Gemayel to Resign
description: Pressure mounted today on Lebanon's Christian President to resign, and firing again broke out across the demarcation line that divides Beirut into Christian and Moslem sectors.

title: Another Dakota
description: It's no news that New York is No. 1 on Mayor Koch's list of favorite cities. But New York viewers of the ''Tonight Show'' didn't hear his choice of No. 2.

title: N.H.L. Experiment
description: The National Hockey League will use International Hockey League games at Indianapolis between the Checkers and Salt Lake City Golden Eagles Feb. 13 and 14 to experiment with the use of video replays to assist officials making decisions on disputed goals. ''The use of video has become a way of life in all sports,'' said David Poile, general manager of the Washington Capitals, who is examining video replay use for the N.H.L. ''It has helped to make the world more progressive, and we owe it to the players and our fans to see if there is a place for this in our game.''

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a credit of $4,715,000 from reversal of Disc tax.

title: BUSH FLIES TO SIDE OF CREW'S FAMILIES
description: Vice President Bush flew here this afternoon to try to comfort the families of the Challenger astronauts and, echoing President Reagan, urged the nation ''to press on'' in the face of a disaster.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $143,886,000 for the quarter and $146,705,000 for the year. c-Net loss. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $53,492,000, a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $78,108,000 and including an extraordinary gain of $11 million.

description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,510,000 for the quarter and $1,391,000 for the 6 months.

title: Blues Extend Contract
description: As a coach with more than two years left on his contract, Jacques Demers of the St. Louis Blues had more job security than most major sports coaches.

title: German Trade Surplus Rises to Record Level
description: West Germany recorded a trade surplus of $30.5 billion last year, its largest ever, according to preliminary statistics released today. The country's exports rose 10 percent in 1985, to $223.7 billion, while imports climbed 6.8 percent, to $193.2 billion.

description: The Reagan Administration today suggested for the first time publicly that it might be in the national interest for the Chevron Oil Corporation to terminate the $2 billion annual business in Angola done by its subsidiary, Gulf Oil.

description: b- Including gains from discontinued operations of $176,000 for the quarter and $607,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $388,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FREDERIKA FARLEY
description: Frederika Farley, for more than 30 years the director of the Home Nursing Service of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, died Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. She was 102 years old.
